column2: Greater use of dramatics and showmanship in food advertising was urged yesterday by J. Sidney Johnson, director of merchandising and advertising of the Independent Grocers Alliance, Chicago, at a luncheon in his honor given by McCall's Magazine at the Hotel Waldorf.
WORCESTER, Mass., May 20. -- Holy Cross crushed Amherst today in a free-hitting game, 26 to 4. The Crusaders registered 24 hits for a total of 41 bases.

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- Under the dual leadership of Representatives Buchanan, chairman of the Appropriations Committee, and Taber of New York, ranking Republican member, the House today sent back to the Senate the 1937 Interior Department Supply Bill, to which the Senate had added $62,757,427, chiefly for irrigation and reclamation projects.

A survey of the relief situation in Newark and Jersey City, the largest cities in New Jersey, since the State has thrown the administration of direct relief back on the municipalities, indicates that the authorities of these industrial centers are revising their entire psychology and methods in handling the relief problem.

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- The Interstate Commerce Commission took a hand today in the dispute over the Long Island Railroad passenger fares, rejecting the road's plan to charge a basic fare of 3 cents a mile in both coaches and Pullman cars.
BOSTON, May 20 (AP). -- After trailing for seven innings, the Reds staged a furious seven-run blast in the eighth and gained a 10-8 victory over the Bees today.
To begin with some actors:

ONE of the lesser events of the year 1882 was Oscar Wilde's visit to America. That was the year when Darwin, Emerson, Garibaldi and Longfellow died, when the assassin Guiteau was so spectacularly tried and executed, when John L. Sullivan beat Paddy Ryan in Mississippi City, and when "the dirty little coward who shot Mr. Howard laid Jesse James in his grave."

Forty-three awards to Manhattan College athletes, including eighteen major letters to members of the varsity basketball team, were announced yesterday by Brother Anselm, director of athletics. The quintet won seventeen of its nineteen regular games.

Greenpoint Properties, Inc., Henry D. Levy, attorney, has sold to I. D.S. Meister, Inc., an operating firm, the six-story automatic elevator apartment house at 2,101 Westbury Court, Brooklyn. The plot, about 121 by 112 feet, is a half block from Flatbush Avenue.

DETROIT, May 20. -- A home run by Marvin Owen on a drive that bounced off the rim of the scoreboard in distant left-center brought disaster to Charley (Red) Ruffing and the Yankees today in a ten-inning struggle at Navin Field that saw the Tigers gain their fifth straight victory and conquer the McCarthymen for the first time this season.

Athletic awards to 127 Columbia athletes and managerial candidates were announced yesterday by Graduate Manager Reynolds Benson. With three exceptions, the awards are for participation in the Winter sports program.

A migration of trading accounts of customers of New York Stock Exchange firms to foreign brokerage firms is going on to escape the rigid margin requirements of the Federal Reserve Board, a canvass of Stock Exchange firms revealed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- Federal aid for vocational training in retailing and other distributive trades was urged in a resolution adopted by the Retailers National Council, an organization made up of national retail trade associations, at a meeting here today at which other pending legislation was discussed and officers elected for the coming year.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., May 20. -- After inspecting areas which may figure in the development of the long-discussed Delaware water-supply system, Mayor La Guardia of New York and a party of officials arrived here tonight. The group planned to continue the tour tomorrow along the line of a proposed aqueduct to New York City.

Senator George R. Fearon of Syracuse, minority leader of the State Senate, who supported Governor Lehman's social security program at Albany, criticized it without reservation in a speech here yesterday.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., May 20. -- About 425 persons from many parts of Long Island and New York visited the gardens of Hill House, the estate of Paul D. Cravath in the Matinecock colony, this afternoon in a pilgrimage for the benefit of the Nassau County Girl Scouts.

Robert P. Stephenson, referee in bankruptcy, declined yesterday to order the disinterment of the body of Allan W. Harriman, only son of John W. Harriman, convicted banker, so that the burial plot in Locust, Valley Cemetery could be sold for the benefit of the J.A.M.A. Realty Corporation.

The Cunard White Star liner Aquitania, departing tonight for Channel ports, will take out among others George M. Cohan, actor and playwright; Sir Cecil Fitch, Sir Lawrence Halsey, Sir Mutchison Fletcher, Harrington Mann, Lado Hood, Marquis Amenda Mollner d'Incisa, Baroness Antonia Halvany, Mrs. Joyce Shonnard, Mr. and Mrs. F.W. Owen. Countess Buxton, Marchesa Mattei, Mrs. Sheila Cahill, Joseph Liddell, Mrs. Fortescue Pickard and Godfrey Herbert.

Union workmen in the Staten Island plant of the United Shipyard Corporation last night authorized their delegates to call a strike next Monday unless officials of the company accept their demands for improved wages and working conditions.
BUENOS AIRES, May 20. -- The fortnightly statement of the Central Bank of Argentina for May 15 shows the following changes, in paper pesos:

Young mothers, young women wage earners and male workers between the ages of 20 and 45, particularly those employed in the dusty trades, were described as "the last strongholds of tuberculosis'' at the annual conference of the State and Local Committee on Tuberculosis and Public Health of the State Charities Aid Association, at the Hotel Biltmore.

Nine former winners of the Metropolitan open crown and five former national open champions are in the field that will start in the three-day, 72-hole medal test for the district championship today on the Quaker Ridge course in Mamaroneck.

A bonus plan for the marketing divisions of the Continental Oil Company is explained in the company's annual report to the Securities and Exchange Commission. In a sliding-scale profit-sharing arrangement for marketing officials, credit is given for a net profit above a certain figure, and deductions are made for losses on certain types of products.

SCRANTON, Pa., May 20. -- Two hundred delegates attending the fourth annual convention of the Pennsylvania Retailers Association, which opened today in the Hotel Jermyn, heard William H. Hager, Lancaster, Pa., president of the association, declare "there has been a steady gain in business volume and a consequent return to profitable operation for industry and business as a whole," in the past year.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 20. -- Mrs. James Roosevelt, mother of President Roosevelt opened his estate to the delegates at the annual meeting of the Garden Club of America at Hyde Park House late this afternoon. Mrs. Roosevelt has been ill with an injured hip.

LONDON, May 20. -- Prices on the London Stock Exchange weakened slightly today owing to the almost complete absence of buyers. British Government stocks declined fractionally, while British rails also suffered from lack of support.

The influx of foreign gold was resumed yesterday, when $2,114,000 of the metal was reported engaged for shipment here -- $1,350,000 in France, $56,000 in Holland and $708,000 in India. These engagements brought the total since April 24, when the movement started, to $148,600,000, of which $126,400,000 was taken in France and $8,100,000 in Holland.

Police Commissioner Valentine stood on Eleventh Avenue nearly an hour yesterday morning observing the picketing of the Chelsea piers of the International Mercantile Marine Company by striking seamen and sympathizers as the United States liner Manhattan prepared to sail for Europe.

Demanding more relief for single men, forty persons, including two women, barricaded themselves in one of the rooms of the Emergency Relief Bureau on the second floor of 635 Fulton Street, between Rockwell Place and Hudson Avenue, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon and held the room until police broke down the door with axes half an hour later.
ALBANY, May 20. -- Here is Governor Lehman's formal statement, declining to seek re-election:

Net income of the Consolidated Oil Corporation in the first four months of this year approximated $4,500,000, H.F. Sinclair, chairman of the executive committee, told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday. For 1935, the company had reported net income of $11,306,904, or 74 cents a share on the 14,218,835 common shares outstanding, after preferred dividend requirements.

William T. Murnan, a bronzed and wiry man of 40, who is realizing the secret ambition of many less adventurous souls by sailing around the world in a fifty-three-foot boat, is in port with the good ship Seven Seas, which is moored to a crumbling pier in the East River at Twenty-sixth Street.

Harold W. Hastings, Assistant District Attorney in charge of the inquiry into an alleged extortion ring in this city, announced yesterday that on Monday he would present evidence before the New York County grand jury with a view to obtaining "several more indictments in new cases."

ROME, May 20. -- Speaking to the Chamber of Deputies on the national budget for the current and coming fiscal years, Count Paolo Thaon di Revel, Finance Minister, carefully avoided giving any figures apt to lift the veil of mystery surrounding Italian war finances.
TOKYO, May 20. -- As compensation for Britain's proposed increase in cruisers and destroyers the Japanese Navy contemplates asking the right to retain part of its excess submarine tonnage.

After a visit of only sixteen hours, the giant air liner Hindenburg saluted New York and provided a thrill for many thousands of spectators last midnight as she roared over the city on her return trip to Germany on the second of her ten scheduled trips to this country this year.

Paine, Webber Co. obtained representation among the executive officers of the Kansas City Southern Railroad for the first time by electing Kenneth D. Steere, a partner in the firm, chairman of the executive committee at the annual meeting yesterday.
Real estate activity in Manhattan and the Bronx yesterday was featured by sales of houses by banks to investors who plan to modernize the buildings.

JERUSALEM, May 20 (AP). -- A new Jewish-Arab incident threw Safed, ancient home of the Jewish mystics, into a panic tonight. The Palcor Agency reported a Jewish motorist knocked down an Arab with his car after the Arab had tried to attack him.

HAVANA, May 20. -- Dr. Miguel Mariano Gomez y Arias, elected last Jan. 10, was sworn in as Cuba's sixth constitutional President at noon today, which was celebrated as National Independence Day. His inauguration ended the series of provisional administrations that had ruled the island since the downfall of the Machado regime in August, 1933.

SOUTHPORT, England, May 20. -- The merry-eyed Miss Marion Miley of Lexington, Ky., last of the American squad, fell in the fourth round of the women's British open golf championship today before the determined onslaught of her older and more experienced English opponent, Miss Bridget Newell.

Industry must give more attention to "selling itself," with less emphasis on selling its products, Edward J. Mehren of Chicago, president of the Portland Cement Association, declared yesterday at the closing business session of the association's Spring meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
ALBANY, May 20. -- Governor Lehman announced with dramatic suddenness today that he would not be a candidate for a third term.
HAMILTON, N.Y., May 20. -- Cornell triumphed over Colgate, 8 -- 4, in a loosely played game today. Lozier, Cornell pitcher, held Colgate scoreless after the third inning.

A new sound has made its debut among the city's noises. It falls on the ear with startling effect. So a man might feel who has lived five years on a deserted island and one day there is a knock on the door of his hut.

PHILADELPHIA, May 20 (AP). -- Floyd Young's two home runs led a nine-hit attack today as the Pirates trampled the Phillies, 9 to 3. Zachary and the Pirates' Jim Weaver engaged in a pitching duel for four innings, but the veteran southpaw weakened and Euel Moore replaced him in the midst of a Pirate rally.

WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP). -- The office of Senator Dickinson (Republican, Iowa) today named Senator Reynolds and Representative Doughton, North Carolina Democrats, as the "powerful Washington figures" Mr. Dickinson accused earlier this week of putting politics into relief.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 20. -- Dr. and Mrs. Guy Hinsdale entertained with a tea today in their cottage for John Hays Hammond and his sister, Miss Elizabeth Hammond. The company included Major Gen. John L. Hines, U.S.A. (retired), and Mrs. Hines.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., May 20. -- For the first time since the inauguration of the series in 1922 two teams finished all even in the triangular matches of the Metropolitan Golf Association for the Stoddard Bowl as the Long Island and New Jersey aggregations posted like totals of 26 today.

Stocks recovered yesterday about half of the Tuesday losses, but the fact that trading was the slowest since last Wednesday when transactions were the fewest for a full day since April 4, 1935, detracted from the price showing. The market was almost wholly professional in character, drifting in uncertain fashion throughout the day and closing irregularly higher.

Restoration at the earliest possible opportunity of the old pay rates to the 135,000 New York City employes as a reward for their sacrifice in accepting the cuts when "the storm reached its height in 1933," was advocated yesterday by Controller Frank J. Taylor.

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- The Senate Finance Committee is expected to decide tomorrow on whether it will retain the principle of President Roosevelt's proposed tax on undistributed corporate profits in the pending Tax Bill, and if so in what form.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

ALBANY, May 20. -- Governor Lehman signed the bill of Senator Dunnigan, Democratic legislative leader, today, providing for the submission of a $30,000,000 unemployment relief bond issue to the voters at the Fall election.

CLEVELAND, May 20 (AP). -- The Senators beat the Indians, 7 to 6, today, in a contest marked by weak defensive play on each side. The Tribe was charged with three errors and the Senators four. It was the Indians' third successive defeat.

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- A modified Pure Food and Drug Bill was reported favorably by the House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee today. Efforts will be made to bring it to the floor for action before adjournment, although sponsors held little hope for passage at this session.

The annual commencement exercises of the College of Pharmacy of Columbia University will be held tonight in the McMillin Academic Theatre, 116th Street and Broadway. Degrees of Graduate in Pharmacy will be presented to sixty-six candidates by Dr. Edward Plaut, chairman of the board of trustees.

BALTIMORE, May 20 (AP). -- Steve Sundra, holding the Orioles scoreless for eight innings and keeping eight hits scattered, pitched Newark to a 9-to-2 victory in the opening game of the series here today. Sundra fanned seven and walked three.

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- New York State stood upon technical grounds today in resisting the effort of Elmer Rice, the playwright, to prevent retroactive taxation by the State on royalties from his plays.

PHILADELPHIA, May 20. -- Miss Katherine Elizabeth Wunder, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Wunder of Windy Top, Ardmore, will be introduced to Philadelphia society when her parents will give a tea on June 13.

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- The Senate staved off today an attempt to expand the omnibus Flood Control Bill, carrying $320,000,000, after Senator Copeland, chairman of the Committee on Commerce, had declared a proposed amendment, if adopted, would open the door to "pork barrel" additions.

Placing men in each event, the formidable High School of Commerce team easily captured the Manhattan Public Schools Athletic League track and field championship for the second successive year at wind-swept Baker Field yesterday.

CAMP NO. 3, Mount Everest, Tibet, May 20 (By Wireless via Calcutta) -- The 1936 British Mount Everest expedition, now encamped 7,500 feet below the summit of Mount Everest, is facing a desperate race with the monsoon.
WASHINGTON, May 20. -- The problem of Federal power production in the Tennessee Valley Authority experiment occupied President Roosevelt for a considerable time today, as he held three conferences.

HEAFFORD JUNCTION, Wis., May 20. -- A happy ending apparently neared tonight in a north-woods drama involving the aged widow of Eugene Field, beloved children's poet, who has been striving to save her home from sale under a foreclosure judgment.

The third program of the Dance Congress and Festival, which is in session this week at the Theresa L. Kaufmann Auditorium of the Y.M. H.A., was given last night before much the largest audience that has yet been present at any of the events.

JIBUTI, French Somaliland, May 20. -- Mr. Gerbal, French manager of the Franco-Ethiopian Railway, and a visiting Italian representative of the railway company left here for Addis Ababa today to discuss with the Italian high command the details of provisioning Italian forces from Jibuti.

The adoption of "a common peace program" by the Federal Government and the organization of the country against war by Congressional districts were among the proposals outlined yesterday by speakers at a panel discussion of the peace movement conducted under the auspices of the Federation of Jewish Women's Organizations at the Community House of Congregation Emanu-El, 1 East Sixty-fifth Street.

WASHLNGTON, May 20. -- The general level of retail food prices rose during the two weeks ended May 5, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. The index, based on the 1923-25 weekly average, now is 80.1, compared to 79.7 two weeks previously and 81.5 a year ago.

Dean Collins P. Bliss of the New York University College of Engineering announced yesterday that for the first time in the history of Iota Alpha, graduate honors society at the college, a husband and wife were among the forty students honored.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 20. -- Faulty fielding today caused Yale's downfall, 5 -- 1, in a light-hitting game in which the Brown's moundsmen, Ambie Murray and Bob Dye, pitched almost airtight ball.
Morris Cohon Co. have prepared a memorandum on the Climax Molybdenum Company.

The announcement yesterday by Governor Lehman that he would not be a candidate for re-election was a complete surprise to New York City politicians. The plans of the Democrats, and of the Republicans as well, had been based on the expectation that Mr. Lehman would yield to President Roosevelt's request and make the race again.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 20. -- Army broke a losing streak at baseball today by overpowering Wesleyan, 13 to 3. The cadets fell upon Coultas in the early innings and had enough runs to win when he left the game at the end of the third.

The first showers along the Atlantic Coast in several weeks had a depressing influence on new-crop deliveries on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and the list ended unchanged to 14 points lower. In addition to reselling by professional operators, houses with Japanese connections and spot interests distributed contracts which were believed to represent hedges against recent purchases of government cotton.

The destructive forces making for war may appear today to have conquered the forces working for world peace, but their victory can be only temporary, Oven D. Young said last night in accepting the gold medal of the Society of Arts and Sciences, at its fifty-fourth annual dinner, at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

BERLIN, May 20. -- Prices of stocks were weak on the Bourse today, but fixed-interest securities were again relatively strong. The sagging stocks did not result, however, in any very large turnover, the market generally being fairly quiet.

IT was in a gathering of baseball critics, scouts and camp followers that somebody asked Mr. James Isaminger of Philadelphia, the eminent collector of first editions, whether or not he knew one Bucky Walters.
The Mesta Machine Company has declared a quarterly dividend of 75 cents a share on the common stock. Previously, 50 cents quarterly was paid.

ADDIS ABABA, May 20 (Via Military Plane to Asmara, Eritrea) (AP). -- Marshal Pietro Badoglio, the viceroy, left the Ethiopian capital today for a triumphal return to Italy after handing over command of the Fascist troops in this country to Marshal Rodolfo Graziani.

The Eastern railroads will discontinue nearly all reduced fares now in effect on June 2, when a tariff of 2 cents a mile in coaches and 3 cents a mile in Pullmans, without surcharge, becomes universal, it was disclosed yesterday. Commutation and suburban fares generally will remain unaffected.

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- Forty-eight hours after the Supreme Court had invalidated the Guffey Coal Stabilization Act, a new regulatory measure from which the labor provisions had been "cut out with a knife" was before members of Congress today under plans for quick consideration.

The State of Virginia will be in the market with a new issue of $950,000 of general obligation bonds, award of which is scheduled to be made on June 4. The bonds will be dated July 1, 1936, and will mature on July 1, 1946. Bidders have been asked to name a rate of interest not exceeding 5 per cent.

Discussion in Washington of the situation created by the Supreme Court's decision on the Guffey act reveals one striking fact. There is practically no apparent demand in any quarter for the enactment of a new constitutional amendment authorizing Congress to do what the court declared it lacks power to do at present.

PARIS, May 20. -- The defeat of the top-seeded British pair, Miss Katherine Stammers and H.W. (Bunny) Austin, in the second round of mixed doubles provided the high spot of play in the French hard-court tennis championships today.

BUCHAREST, May 20. -- Payment by the government of its employes in counterfeit money, according to allegations in the newspaper Zorile, is the latest financial scandal in Rumania. It is alleged that large quantities of counterfeit 100-lei pieces were among those recently issued in sealed bags by the Ministry of Finance.

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- The Brooklyn Edison Company, in an amendment to its registration statement covering the issuance of $55,000,000 of consolidated mortgage 3 1/4 per cent bonds, series of 1936, announced the redemption provision and underwriters of the issue and the extent of their participation as follows:

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- Charging that the pending Robinson-Patman Anti-Chain Store Bill did not confine itself to the correction of existing abuses, but went far beyond into the field of legitimate business, six farm organizations filed a protest against the measure with Chairman O'Connor of the Rules Committee today.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., May 20. (AP). -- Michigan Democrats averted a factional fight at their pre-primary convention today by endorsing all comers for the major nominations which will be at stake in the primary September.

PHILADELPHIA, May 20. -- An improved bookkeeping system in American industries was blamed today by Charles F. Kettering, director of the General Motors Research Laboratories, for impeding the progress of industrial activities in recent years.

PARIS, May 20. -- Although he promised to give the matter twenty-four hours' reflection, it is definitely known tonight that Edouard Herriot refused yesterday Leon Blum's offer of the Foreign Affairs post in his Cabinet.

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- A denial of charges made yesterday before the Senate Appropriations Committee by George U. Harvey, Borough President of Queens, against the Works Progress Administration's operations in that borough, was contained in a letter sent tonight by Victor F. Ridder, WPA Administrator for New York City, to Senator Carter Glass, chairman of the committee.

LONDON, May 20. -- The American polo team caused a big sensation when it made its first London appearance at Hurlingham today and routed a strong club aggregation that included two United States players, Bobby Strawbridge and Elbridge Gerry, 20 to 4.

Several guns poked in his ribs convinced Peter Harris, according to his testimony yesterday, that it would be discreet to pay tribute to the vice industry alleged to have been organized by Charles (Lucky Luciano) Lucania.

DUBLIN, May 20. -- To illustrate the analogy between anglers and sweepstake subscribers, the Irish Hospitals Trust staged a display in the streets of Dublin today at the initial proceedings of the Derby sweepstakes draw.

BUENOS AIRES, May 20 (AP). -- Authoritative private advices from La Paz today said Colonel David Toro, absent head of the new Bolivian Government, had blackballed several members of the revolutionary junta by telegram from the Chaco, forcing its resignation.

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- The Townsend $200-per-month pension plan, if enacted into law, will call for the licensing for transaction tax collection purposes of every farmer in the United States, the license to cover everything from a dozen eggs to a bale of cotton, Dr. Francis E. Townsend, founder of the movement, admitted before the House investigating committee today.

BUENOS AIRES, May 20 (AP). -- Authoritative private advices from La Paz today said Colonel David Toro, absent head of the new Bolivian Government, had blackballed several members of the revolutionary junta by telegram from the Chaco, forcing its resignation.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 20. -- The twenty-fifth anniversary of the first intercollegiate rowing regatta to be held on Lake Carnegie was celebrated today by a special ceremony on the float of the Class of 1887 boathouse. Eighty Princeton oarsmen attended.
Today is Ascension Day and it will be widely observed by ritualistic churches. It is a holy day of obligation, when all Roman Catholics must attend mass.

Riding high and wide, though at times not exactly handsome, the Giants continued their impregnable defense of their home entrenchments yesterday by slashing down the Cardinals in the opening clash of a two-game series at the Polo Grounds.

Linking education with democracy, Charles A. Beard, noted historian, declared last night at a meeting of the American Association for Adult Education that the future of education was dependent upon the future of the democratic ideal.

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- President Roosevelt will leave here Friday night for a three-day visit to Hyde Bark, N.Y., where his mother is suffering from injuries received in a fall last Friday, the White House announced today.

VIENNA, May 20. -- Prince Ernst von Starhemberg arrived by airplane from Rome this morning at the Aspern airdrome, where he was welcomed by Edouard Baar-Baarenfels, the Heimwehr Vice Chancellor who succeeded him; Ludwig Draxler, the Heimwehr Finance Minister; former Foreign Minister Egon Berger-Waldenegg, who is another Heimwehr man, and many officers of the Vienna and Lower Austrian Heimwehr.

The unbeaten George Washington High nine strengthened its hold on first place in the Upper Manhattan Bronx division of the P.S.A.L. race yesterday by defeating James Monroe, 5--4, on the latter's diamond. Ampanis scampered home with the winning run on an error in the fifth.
The political career of Herbert H. Lehman has made him a key figure in major party and governmental developments of the past eight years.

NANKING, China, May 20 (AP). -- Drastic regulations designed to curb large-scale smuggling into North China, twice the subject of protests from the Chinese Government to Japan, were announced tonight.

It Is hard to understand the exultation of extreme conservatives over the Supreme Court's decision in the Guffey case, which is better news for Fourteenth Street than for Wall Street. The cumulative effect of the court's rulings in the various cases in which administration measures have come before it is this: In the next depression, the Federal Government cannot constitutionally do anything about it.

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- An attack upon the constitutionality of the New Deal's railroad retirement legislation by 430 railroads, two express companies and the Pullman Company was begun today in the District of Columbia Supreme Court. The suit challenges the validity of two acts passed by Congress in 1935 after Chief Justice Wheat of the District Supreme Court had held unconstitutional the Retirement Act of 1934.

For the second time within a five-day period, Manhattan College's baseball team could not solve southpaw pitching to any great degree, and Long Island University, behind Larry Burger's effective mound work, gained a 4-to-z victory yesterday at Dexter Park, thereby avenging an earlier setback received from Ray Volpi, Jasper righthander.

The depression-born changes in the attitude of both government and social agencies regarding relief were discussed last night by speakers at the eleventh annual meeting of the Welfare Council at the Hotel Pennsylvania. More than 500 persons attended the dinner. Charles C. Burlingham, president of the council, presided.

In response to a request from the National Student Federation that a student committee at City College get an interview with him to discuss a faculty matter, Dr. Frederick B. Robinson, president of the college, replied that peace and harmony would suffer if he attempted to confer with students on "every detail" of college administration.

SOUTHPORT, England, May 20. -- The last representative of America, Miss Marion Miley, went down to defeat with drums beating and flags flying in the fourth round of the women's British golf championship today.

The rate of steel output has increased 1 point 68 1/2 per cent of capacity as a result of unseasonably well sustained demand for heavy steel products, according to the weekly summary of Iron Age, issued yesterday. The rise, the magazine says, is significant in view of the curtailed buying by the automotive industry, and lighter takings by agricultural districts.

LANGLEY FIELD, Va., May 20. -- While Orville Wright, who, with his brother Wilbur, gave powered flight to man thirty-three years ago at a speed of thirty miles an hour, watched with absorbed interest, the new high-speed wind tunnel of the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics, capable of testing aircraft models at speeds above 500 miles an hour, was first demonstrated here today.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 20. -- Denunciation of legislation directed against business and banking and of the increase in the public debt marked the opening today of the forty-second annual convention of the Pennsylvania Bankers Association here in the Hotel Traymore.

The Regional Plan Association has looked over parking facilities in a number of representative communities scattered through the metropolitan region and found them lamentably inadequate. Millions of dollars have been spent on concrete highways and widened streets to help motorists go where they wish, but only a few thousand dollars on accommodations for their cars when they get there.

One great-grandmother, thirty grandmothers, eighty-three mothers and one father, representing thirty-six nationalities, formed the graduating class yesterday at the annual exercises in Carnegie Hall of the Day Classes for Adults in English and Citizenship of the Board of Education.

CHICAGO, May 20. -- The United States is "entering a period that is developing a new philosophy of government" with the masses "definitely in the saddle," according to Homer J. Buckley, a director of the Illinois Manufacturers Association.
SAN JUAN, P.R., May 20. -- Charges of political activities on the part of the Puerto Rican Reconstruction Administration are to be investigated, it became known today.

A decision on a novel question of real estate law was handed down yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Lloyd Church in a suit by Mrs. Leonora Speyer, poet and widow of James Speyer, banker, who died Feb. 10, 1932, leaving his wife the Speyer town house at 22 Washington Square North.

One great-grandmother, thirty grandmothers, eighty-three mothers and one father, representing thirty-six nationalities, formed the graduating class yesterday at the annual exercises in Carnegie Hall of the Day Classes for Adults in English and Citizenship of the Board of Education.

CHICAGO, May 20. -- The United States is "entering a period that is developing a new philosophy of government" with the masses "definitely in the saddle," according to Homer J. Buckley, a director of the Illinois Manufacturers Association.
SAN JUAN, P.R., May 20. -- Charges of political activities on the part of the Puerto Rican Reconstruction Administration are to be investigated, it became known today.

College authorities and not students are responsible for the radical trend and the feeling of dissatisfaction and insecurity on the college campuses and throughout the country declared the Very Rev. Aloysius J. Hogan, S.J., president of Fordham University, at the Ninth Annual Military Demonstration of the Fordham R.O.T.C. unit yesterday.

BERLIN, May 20. -- Dr. Rudolf Eicke, Reichsbank director, in addressing the bank's employes today, asserted Germany would reap no advantage in foreign trade by devaluation of the mark. He explained that devaluation would bring foreign trade increases in a free international economy but in the regulated economy prevalent in world markets new hindrances to the expansion of German trade could be expected which would completely nullify advantages obtained from devaluation.

TORONTO, May 20 (Canadian Press). -- Frederick Osborne, 72 years old, a former caretaker of the Grand Opera House here, testified today that a "certain man" offered him $20,000 to assist in the murder of Ambrose Small, millionaire theatre owner, who disappeared on Dec. 2, 1919.

Donizetti's "Lucia di Lammermoor," performed at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, was the fifth production of the Spring season. It was a creditable performance, and at times it achieved a dramatic impact that inheres in the score but is rarely brought into being.

Dr. Nielsen is quoted as saying; "No woman, whether intelligent or unintelligent, modern or old-fashioned, wants the birth of her baby a blank in her memory. * * * Child-bearing is such an essential experience for a woman that the thwarting of its normal course by the excessive use of analgesics may cause great damage to her personality."

Reports of jury-tampering in an extortion case which resulted in the acquittal of one defendant after another had pleaded guilty led District Attorney Geoghan of Brooklyn yesterday to begin a grand jury inquiry.

Mayor La Guardia, three other city officials and two legislators were elected to the board of directors of the New York World's Fair, 1939, Inc., at a meeting of the board yesterday afternoon in its new offices in the Empire State Building.

A decision on a novel question of real estate law was handed down yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Lloyd Church in a suit by Mrs. Leonora Speyer, poet and widow of James Speyer, banker, who died Feb. 10, 1932, leaving his wife the Speyer town house at 22 Washington Square North.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 21. -- Plans for a three-year advertising campaign were approved by executives of the nation's leading gas companies, meeting here today in the Hotel Traymore in the annual one-day conference of the executive committee of the American Gas Association.

MEXICO, D.F., May 21. -- President Lazaro Cardenas today instructed the Interior Department to rescind the ban it announced yesterday and allow the body of Archbishop Pascual Diaz Barreto to be transferred from his home to the cathedral tomorrow.

La Salle Academy lost both its tities as All Hallows captured senior honors and Mount St. Michael gained junior-midget laurels in the fifth annual track and field championships of the Manhattan-Bronx-Westchester division of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association at Manhattan Field yesterday.

New York State will begin an active campaign to detect and eradicate tuberculosis in its early stages by extending the services of sanatoria "into the home and life of every citizen of the district which they serve," it was announced yesterday.
LONDON, May 21 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

Aided by winds that helped her to reach a speed of 100 miles an hour, the giant Zeppelin Hindenburg was well over the Atlantic last night on a course far north of the shipping lanes on her return to Frankfort, Germany, from the second of her scheduled ten visits to the United States.

PITTSBURGH, May 21. -- There was almost no change in the level of business activity in the Pittsburgh district last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. The bureau's adjusted index stood at 87.5 per cent of normal in the week ended May 16. It was 65.2 in the corresponding week last year. Business in the district has held at about the same level for the last five weeks.
There is already talk of putting Governor LEHMAN under a draft law, to make him run for Governor in November, if he will not volunteer to do it. The thing has often been tried, seldom with success.

VIENNA, May 21. -- Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg completed his victory over Prince Ernst yon Starhemberg by constituting himself the sole dictator of Austria by a law promulgated this morning under the title of the "Fatherland Front Act."

CHICAGO, May 21. -- Colonel Frank Knox, candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, declared tonight that the party "would do well to adopt the principal economic planks of the Democratic platform of 1932," and add:
WASHINGTON, May. 21. -- The names of twelve directors of regional offices of the Social Security Board were announced today.

GENEVA, May 21. -- Efforts to find a non-habit-forming substitute for morphine have resulted in the drug desomorphine, which has "habit-forming properties even in excess of morphine or heroin," Stuart J. Fuller of the United States State Department told the League advisory opium committee today.

Treasury Financing Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau failed yesterday to shed much light on the nature of the government's financing next month, other than to state that details of the offering would be announced on June 1. Investors and government bond dealers, therefore, have another full week in which to speculate as to the amount and type of securities to be issued.

WASHINGTON, May 21. -- Senator Minton of Indiana succeeded in persuading the Senate today to remove from its omnibus Flood Control Bill a $2,540,000 project for drainage of the Kankakee River Basin. His action came while other members were clamoring to insert in the measure projects for the benefit of their individual districts.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 21. -- Julian Hart, 61, a retired San Francisco merchant, was swept to his death in the Klamath River last night while fishing near his Summer home at Walker in the Northern California Mountains. His body was recovered this morning.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:
ATLANTIC CITY, May 21. -- The responsibility for preparing the youth of the nation for the future was placed on the National Council of the Boy Scouts of America today by President Roosevelt.
TRENTON, May 21. -- State Auditor Walter R. Darby reported today that the fiscal condition of counties and municipalities improved during the three months' period ended March 31.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., May 21. -- Aided by a handicap of 25 strokes, Rube Goldberg, cartoonist, drew the attention of the members of the Artists and Writers Golf Association in the annual Spring tournament of the organization at the North Hempstead Country Club today.

Federal Judge Murray Hulbert, an appointee of President Roosevelt, handed down a decision yesterday that may pave the way for the recovery by taxpayers of more than $800,000,000 paid to the government under the Agricultural Adjustment Act, which the Supreme Court has held unconstitutional.

Present plans of the Triborough Bridge Authority contemplate the construction of a bridge between Old Ferry Point in the Bronx and Whitestone, Queens, to be completed in time for the opening of the World's Fair in 1939, Park Commissioner Robert Moses, who is secretary and chief executive officer of the Authority, disclosed yesterday.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., May 21 (AP). -- The Michigan State Democratic Convention adopted a resolution today instructing its delegation to the national convention in Philadelphia to cast the State's thirty-eight votes as a unit for President Roosevelt "from start to finish."

The city of Minneapolis, Minn., awarded yesterday a new issue of $545,365 of public relief and permanent improvement bonds to Phelps, Fenn Co. on a bid of 100.23 for 2s. The bonds will be dated June 1, 1936, and mature from 1937 to 1946.

Better coordination of clinical and hospital facilities to reduce the maternal death rate in this city was advocated yesterday by leaders in the medical profession and endorsed in a resolution by the Maternity Center Association at its annual Mother's Day luncheon at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

OTTAWA, May 21 (Canadian Press). -- Deposits with the Bank of Canada by the Dominion Government increased $580,238 and by chartered banks rose $3,098,485 in the week ended yesterday, the bank reported today. The-statement follows:
NEW ORLEANS, May 21. -- A Federal court jury awarded a $2,500 judgment, described as the first of its kind on record, to the parents of a lynched Negro today in a damage suit against a Sheriff.

WASHINGTON, May 21.--The United States has accepted a settlement of $3,000,000 from Canadian distillers in payment of customs duty on liquor allegedly smuggled into this country during prohibition, Secretary Morgenthau disclosed definitely today.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP). -- Plans for a coast-to-coast drive by 4,500 officers to tighten up the enforcement of liquor laws and the collection of alcohol taxes were revealed tonight by the Treasury.

PHILADELPHIA, May 21. -- A struggle for power between two groups of Philadelphia financiers was blamed today by counsel to the Sabath Congressional Committee for the wrecking of the Philadelphia Company for Guaranteeing Mortgages.

With most markets in Continental Europe closed yesterday in observance of Ascension Day, dealings in foreign exchange were quiet here and there were no fresh engagements of gold in Europe. Additional engagements abroad of $3,541,000 gold were reported to the Federal Reserve Bank, however, $2,198,000 of the metal having been taken in Mexico and $1,343,000 in India.

A week of intensive price warfare in the retail liquor industry was believed definitely ended last night when liquor stores in the downtown Manhattan area finally agreed to restore quotations on domestic liquors to previous levels. The restoration was made, according to liquor group spokesmen at 6 P.M. after a day in which retailers in other sections of the city repeatedly threatened to slash quotations unless downtown purveyors discontinued price cuts.
Mrs. Helen Wills Moody took time off from her exhibition of oil paintings at the Grand Central Galleries yesterday to get in three-quarters of an hour's practice on the tennis court.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 21. -- Mrs. Samuel Sloan entertained delegates of the Garden Club of America tonight at Lesburn Grange, her estate at Garrison. The annual meeting of the organization will end tomorrow after a luncheon at the Tuxedo Club and inspection of Gardens at Tuxedo Park.

CHICAGO, May 21. -- Hogs were in better demand because of the continued cool weather, light receipts and further strength in the market for fresh pork. Prices were steady to strong with some sales regarded as slightly higher than the close of Wednesday.

Diplomas were awarded last night to sixty-six graduates of the College of Pharmacy of Columbia University at commencement exercises in the McMillin Academic Theatre, 116th Street and Broadway. Dean Henry V. Arny introduced the candidates to Dr. Edward Plaut, chairman of the Board of trustees, who presented the degree of Graduate in Pharmacy.

CLEVELAND, May 21 (AP). -- Guy N. Thompson, trustee for the Missouri Pacific Railroad, filed suit today in Federal court against five residents of this city for $3,200,000, allegedly lost to the railroad through interlocking directorships of the Alleghany Corporation and Terminal Shares, Inc.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP). -- Representative Bacon, Republican, of New York, told newspaper men today he had heard that action had been taken in the Commerce Department to prohibit the use of government inspection boats for "political joyrides."

PAWTUCKET, R.I., May 21. -- The Silver Stock Farm's Mine Boy won the sixth race at Narragansett today to pay $353.60 for a $2 straight ticket, the largest straight price since pari-mutuel betting was legalized in New England.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 21. -- Academic prizes for the year were awarded to Vassar students this evening during the last chapel services of the semester.

MOSCOW, May 21. -- The dissatisfaction of Soviet citizens with the wretched quality of consumers' goods offered to them has reached the point where the government is adding its own official voice to the universal protest.

The appointment of seven architects and engineers to form a board of design to plan and supervise construction of the World's Fair to be held here in 1939 and 1940 was announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the World's Fair Corporation.
CLEVELAND, May 21 (AP). -- The Senators blasted thirteen hits, including two home runs, off two Cleveland pitchers today to trounce the Indians, 7 to 4.
JERUSALEM, Friday, May 22. -- A miniature battle has been going on since late yesterday evening between British troops and Arab peasants about twelve miles outside Jerusalem.

The WPA's Federal Theatre project once again offers the town's only theatrical opening this evening. It will be "Battle Hymn," a production of the Experimental Theatre which Virgil Geddes directs and which has headquarters at Daly's Sixty-third Street Theatre. Michael Blankfort and Michael Gold are the authors and the drama is of John Brown of Harpers Ferry fame.

ALL persons interested in literary history, even those who have no consuming love for Thomas De Quincey, or for the "Confessions of all English Opium Eater," or for early nineteenth-century English prose as a whole, owe it to themselves to look at Horace Ainsworth Eaton's "Thomas De Quincey" (Oxford, $5). It is a most impressive piece of work.
PARIS, May 21. -- Upsets continued to rule the play in the French hard courts tennis doubles championships today as three out of four Americans were eliminated.

The most elaborate and detailed canvass of the voters in recent years will be begun by the Republican State organization immediately after the national convention in Cleveland, it was indicated yesterday. It will be virtually a house-to-house round-up of the up-State voters, in an effort to get them to the polls this year to take New York out of the New Deal column and elect a Governor as well.
PHILADELPHIA, May 21 (AP). -- A six-run attack in the ninth, climaxed by Jensen's home run with two men on bases, gave Pittsburgh a 7-to-4 triumph over the Phillies today.

Samuel Fox and Harold Fox, who operated the unincorporated Fox Credit Clothing Company at 220 West Forty-second Street, were arrested yesterday and arraigned in Special Sessions on "informations" charging that they conspired to injure trade and commerce in what Assistant District Attorney James J. Wilson described as the "wage assignment" racket. They pleaded not guilty and were released in $1,000 bail each.

LONDON, May 21. -- Miss Helen Jacobs returned to London today, told reporters she was fully recovered from the illness that struck her in Vienna ten days ago and expressed regret that her tennis rival. Mrs. Helen Wills Moody, had not sailed with the rest of the American Wrightman Cup team.

Excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose $90,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to $2,860,000,000 according to the weekly Federal Reserve report, published yesterday. The gain, which lifted excess reserves to $550,000,000 above the low point of late March and early April, was attributed principally to gold imports.

The daily newspaper was called supreme as a broadcasting agency in the field of adult education, while the radio was regarded as a yet undeveloped instrument of educators at the closing sessions yesterday of the American Association for Adult Education in the Hotel Astor.

Whether there is "fair sailing ahead" for city finances, as Controller TAYLOR maintains, depends somewhat on the point of view. For mariners who have weathered the fiscal storms of the past four years the present ground swell must seem calm indeed. Debts have not increased.

Most commodity futures were slightly higher in light trading on the local markets yesterday. Sugar, hides and coffee declined. On the cash markets lard, hides, rye, butter, cocoa and wool tops advanced, while silk, eggs and corn declined.

One of two Bronx schoolboys who set out to spend a holiday afternoon rowing in the upper Harlem River drowned yesterday and the other was rescued. The boy who drowned had become frightened when they could not control the boat; he jumped out, capsizing the craft and throwing his companion into the water.

Miss Eunice Howard gave a reception with music yesterday afternoon at her home, 570 Park Avenue, for Mr. and Mrs. Henry Hadley. Compositions by Mr. Hadley were played by Miss Howard, pianist, and Miss Frances Blaisdell, flutist.
SOUTHPORT, England, May 21 (AP). -- Sharing interest with Miss Barton in today's golf final was the red-haired Miss Patty Berg of Minneapolis, the baby member of the American Curtis Cup team.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., May 21. -- Conclusive evidence that he is in fit condition for the forthcoming United States open championship at Baltusrol two weeks hence was furnished by stocky Gene Sarazen today.

In an atmosphere of gayety members of the recently organized Veterans of Future Wars met yesterday afternoon in the Gold Room of the Hotel Beekman, 575 Park Avenue, to open a series of meetings designed to win the support of older men and women for their organization.

BARTOW, Fla., May 21. -- Lawyers begau their final arguments today in the first of the Florida flogging trials, speaking all day on a charge of kidnapping E.F. Poulnot, made against five former Tampa, Fla., policemen.

WASHINGTON, May 21. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended May 20 as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks was $2,481,000,000, an increase of $6,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $5,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1935.

Persistent strength in the long-term obligations of United States Government again was the outstanding feature of bond trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The financial community, while awaiting some definite word from the Treasury Department as to its plans for the June financing, continued to pick up outstanding loans without reaching too far in the matter of price.

WASHINGTON, May 21. -- The first national agreement governing the disposition of employes affected by technological improvements and increased efficiency ever made in the United States was completed today by representatives of 85 per cent of the nation's railroad mileage and of the twenty standard railway unions.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 21. -- "The success of banking depends largely upon what the public thinks of banks," Preston E. Reed of Chicago today told members of the New Jersey Bankers Association, who are holding their thirty-third annual convention in the Hotel Ambassador here.
Applications for the listing of the following securities have been received by the New York Stock Exchange, it was announced yesterday:

IT was a fine morning and Farmer Frisch, unshaven, shirt collar wide open, was looking over his suburban garden plot and picking out the better sections for sweet corn, butter beans and tomato plants.

Higher prices for livestock, beef, wheat and corn sent The Annalist weekly index of wholesale prices 0.4 point higher in the week ended on Tuesday, the index rising to 120.0 from 119.6. Coffee, bananas, lemons, rubber, cotton and wool also contributed to the rise, although butter and eggs, potatoes oats, hides and zinc were lower.

Trading was casual in the share market yesterday. Stocks advanced fractionally at the start, then turned steady and dull, firming up slightly in the early afternoon, only to ease in the final half hour and finish irregularly lower. Trading dwindled to 668,000 shares from 686,000 the day before.

For ten years Cincinnati has been as a city set apart. She has enjoyed good government; and really good municipal government in this country is still sufficiently rare to be conspicuous. Other cities have envied her clean streets, efficient public services, low tax rates, high credit -- the highest in the land. They have wondered how she did it -- and kept on doing it.

WASHINGTON, May 21. -- A compromise tax program retaining only a vestige of President Roosevelt's proposed undistributed corporate profits tax, but at the same time putting the full burden of new permanent revenue of $620,000,000 or more a year on corporations and their stockholders, was agreed upon today by the Senate Finance Committee.
WASHINGTON, May 21. -- Replying to criticism by Chairman Farley of Governor Landon, Representative Lambertson, Republican Of Kansas, said today that "Jim Farley is scared before the race begins."

ROME, May 21. -- A triumphal reception is being prepared for Ethiopia's conqueror, Marshal Pietro Badoglio, who is now on his way home. It is said both King Victor Emmanuel and Premier Benito Mussolini will be waiting for him at Naples when he steps off the boat from Massaua, Eritrea.
BERLIN, May 21. -- The Italian whirlwind that has swept over Ethiopia has aroused hope for some good in at least one section of the German population, namely, the suppressed German Jews.

In the presentation of a medal to Mr. OWEN D. YOUNG by the Society of Arts and Sciences there might seem a somewhat unfortunate coincidence. The medal was conferred upon him mainly in recognition and honor of his achievements in promoting international good-will.

Testifying at the mail fraud trial of four former officers or directors of the Westchester Title and Trust Company, James J. O'Shaughnessy, a State bank examiner, declared yesterday that its president, J. Crawford Stevens, had told him in October, 1932, that the company had not invoked an eighteen-month non-payment clause.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, May 21. -- Elaborate ceremonies marked the arrival from England today, aboard the steamship Orbita, of Lieut. Gen. Sir Reginald Hildyard, Bermuda's new Governor, succeeding General Sir Thomas Astley Cubitt, who retired April 1.

SOUTHPORT, England, May 21. -- Miss Pam Barton, 19-year-old London golfer, after being in the final for the past two years, won the women's British golf championship today. The third time may be the lucky one, but it was more by good judgment than luck that she beat Miss Bridget Newell, barrister and magistrate, who is the champion of Derbyshire, by the resounding score of 7 and 5.

Despite a smaller turnover of checks in this city, bank clearings throughout the country for the week ended on Wednesday continued to go above those in the corresponding week of 1935. The total for the twenty-two principal cities of the nation, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc., was $5,275,135,000, against $5,084,202,000 a year ago.

PHILADELPHIA, May 21. -- The Philadelphia National League club announced today it had traded Curt Davis, a right-handed pitcher, and Ethan Allen, an outfielder, to the Cubs for Chuck Klein and Fabian Kowalik.

WASHINGTON, May 21. -- Transactions in equity securities by officers, directors and principal stockholders of corporations in March and earlier months, as made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission in a supplementary summary, showed that the selling trend predominated, as indicated in the earlier report covering the same period.
PARIS, May 21 (AP). -- The French Government tonight termed the expulsion of a French priest from Ethiopia by Italian forces "inacceptable" and a protest to Rome seemed likely.

The annual report of American Radiator and Standard Sanitary Corporation, filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, shows that Clarence M. Woolley, chairman and president, received compensation of $80,000 last year; Rolland J. Hamilton, vice president, secretary and treasurer, received $75,000; Henry S. Downe, European representative, $72,524; twelve directors, including officers, $327,100; five officers not directors, $80,603; twelve employes, each over $20,000, $482,171; and Arthur Young Co., auditors, $33,000.

TRENTON, May 21.--Having been in recess since Tuesday of last week, the Legislature reconvened tonight with the problem of financing emergency relief apparently as far from solution as it was when the 1936 session began in January.

The Chase National Bank is prepared to deliver definitive bonds in exchange for temporary Southern Natural Gas Company adjustment mortgage 6 per cent bonds due Jan. 1, 1960, and twenty-year 4 1/4 per cent debentures of Remington Rand, Inc., due March 1, 1956.

"There seems to be an epidemic of a suicide mood going through the ranks of the rafugees." This poignant statement comes to the American Christian Committee for German Refugees in a letter from the International Center of Paris, which is caring for German emigres, particularly those who are not Jews.

A healthy church is America's safeguard to democracy, the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, pastor of the Christ Methodist Episcopal Church, Manhattan, said last night at the closing meeting of a three-day conference of the New York Congregational Conference, held at Broadway Tabernacle Church.

LONDON, May 21. -- Trading was quiet and prices ended irregular today on the London Stock Exchange. The Chancellor of the Exchequer's somewhat discouraging remarks on the taxation outlook caused some selling of British funds.

The United States liner Presidedt Harding, arriving today from Hamburg, Havre, Southampton and Cobh, will bring Mr. and Mrs. William Philip Simms, Lieut. Commander R. S. Berkey, Edward A. Crowninshield, Robert Mendelsohn, 'cellist; R. A. Drysdale, Mrs. Stuart Cameron, Mgr. J. B. 0'Reilly, Horace A. Keith and Miss Elizabeth Newland.

CHICAGO, May 21. -- Prices of wheat fluctuated in an erratic manner on the Board of Trade today. An opening dip was followed by a strong rally which carried the May up 2 1/8 cents a bushel from the early low on free buying credited to Eastern shorts, but as soon as the urgent demand let up a reaction followed.

ALBANY, May 21. -- Pressure is being brought to bear on Governor Lehman in an effort to make him reconsider his decision not to become the Democratic candidate for Governor for a third time this year.

MOSCOW, May 21. -- After a long lull the Far Eastern situation came to the front again today with a strong protest by B.S. Stomonyakoff, Assistant Foreign Commissar, to Ambassador Tamekichi Ota of Japan against the arrests and trials of Japanese employes of the Soviet Embassy in Tokyo on charges of espionage and the continued campaign in the Japanese press against the Soviet Embassy and the Soviet Union.

HEWLETT HARBOR, L.I., May 21. -- One of the strongest Long Island golf teams in the history of the annual triangular intersectional tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association walked off with the Golf Illustrated Trophy after scoring 21 1/2 points to 12 for New Jersey and 11 1/2 for Westchester in the matches over the Seawane Golf Club course today.

Trading was moderately active in the wool goods markets this week, according to the report issued yesterday by the New York Wool Top Exchange Service. Indications are that machinery activity will be maintained at or slightly below current levels for the next eight to ten weeks, the report states.

A service commemorating the ninetieth anniversary of the consecration of Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway and Wall Street, was held yesterday morning. More than 2,000 persons, mostly workers in the financial district, visited the church for the service at 11 o'clock.

Although great strides have been made in selling advertising, there has been little progress in creating advertising, James T. Mangan, director of advertising and merchandising of the Mills Novelty Company, Chicago, told the Association of Advertising Men at a meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania last night.

The Citizens Family Welfare Committee could ask no higher commendation for its undertaking than that which was spoken by the late CHARLES W. ELIOT of Harvard University. He went so far as to say that "the security "and elevation of the family and "family life are the prime objects of "civilization and the ultimate ends of "all industry and trade."

WASHINGTON, May 21. -- In drawing up the administration's draft of the Philadelphia platform, which is not likely to be changed very much after the President has approved it, Senator Wagner will ask the assistance of men and women of differing political theory. It will be difficult to reconcile some of their views, and the conservative advisers will have the smaller part of the bag.

Borough President Joseph A. Palma of Richmond last night predicted substantial gains in American exports and in the use of American-made containers and labels as a result of the establishment of a free trade zone at Staten Island.

WASHINGTON, May 21. -- A group of coal operators opposed to reenactment of the price provisions of the Guffey Coal Act declared in a telegram today to Senator Wheeler, chairman of the Interstate Commerce Committee, and Representative Robert L. Doughton, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, that the new bill would increase the cost of coal.

Forty acres of land fronting on Smull and Park Avenues in West Caldwell, N.J., have been purchased by the James A. Whitman Construction Company, Essex County builders, for a housing development. The property, which fronts 1,100 feet on Smull Avenue and is fully improved, was sold by the Watchung Title and Mortgage Guaranty Company through the Simpson-Merritt Company.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 21. -- The honor of leading the largest qualifying field that over has taken part in the historic Garden City Golf Club invitation tourney was shared today by four players who posted 76s, four over par.

LONDON, May 21. -- The British Government "is taking and will take the most energetic steps" to clear up the whereabouts of a British Red Cross worker missing in Ethiopia, the House of Commons heard today. Viscount Cranborne, Parliamentary Under-Secretary for Foreign Affairs, gave this assurance in the case of L.J. Bonner, a nursing orderly.

General John J. Pershing sent a message of greeting and good wishes to the annual dinner of the New York unit of the Women's Overseas Service League held at Schrafft's, 220 West Fifty-seventh Street, last night.

Bill Holman's single to right field which scored Wexler from third base in the eighth inning broke up a stirring pitching duel between Ed Kleiner of Lincoln and Ed Dugan of Manual and enabled the former to win by 2 -- 1 at Lincoln Field yesterday.
The cellar shuttle service still is functioning for the Dodgers. Every time they arrive hopefully at seventh place somebody closes the doors before they can get out.
WASHINGTON, May 21. -- The agreement entered into by the railroads and their employes read as follows:
CHICAGO, May 21 (AP). -- Johnny Whitehead won a fourteen-inning pitching duel from Harry Kelley today to give the White Sex a 3-2 victory over the Athletics and a sweep of the two-game series.
The method suggested in THE TIMES for the regulation of the bituminous coal industry through interstate compacts raises several serious governmental and constitutional problems.

Creation of a citizens' committee of 500 to analyze and report on disturbing conditions in the American Merchant Marine, with particular attention to the part played by Communist agitators, was authorized yesterday afternoon at a meeting of the National Civic Federation held in the assembly room of the Merchants Association.

People of the world, engaged in a universal quest for economic justice, are seeking a better system for the exchange of goods and services among countries, Thomas L. Watson, president of the International Business Machines Corporation, said yesterday in an address before a luncheon meeting of the Advertising Club of New York.

BOSTON, May 21. -- High above Boston Harbor, a veteran pilot waged a successful battle in a wildly whirling plane late today to save the life of a young woman who attempted, he said, to plunge to death.
DETROIT, May 21. -- That old familiar cry, "Yeah, Goose!" echoed over Navin Field today and it was answered in the old familiar way.

The fourth session in the Dance Congress and Festival, now being held at the Y.M.H.A., served to fill the Theresa L. Kaufmann Auditorium virtually to capacity last night. The session was actually the first of the series which has belonged in the category of a congress event rather than a festival program, for it dealt almost entirely in demonstration of methods and various technical approaches, instead of merely presenting an aggregation of finished dance compositions.

National recovery would be greatly hastened if the Federal Government would discontinue both work and home relief and assist private industry to put the unemployed back to work by halting additional business taxes and permitting Federal funds to be borrowed "without security" by any going concern, Dr. Irving Fisher, Professor Emeritus of Economics at Yale University, declared last night.

WASHINGTON, May 21. -- The tariff rates on imports of bleached, printed, dyed and colored cotton cloths were increased by President Roosevelt today an average of 42 per cent, effective June 20, as the result of the collapse of negotiations with Japan looking to a "gentlemen's agreement" by which Japan would restrict to moderate amounts her exports of these goods to the United States.
Contracts for the leasing of dwellings, apartment houses and a gasoline station on Sixth Avenue made up the bulk of realty activity in Manhattan yesterday.

Borough President Samuel Levy of Manhattan was put forward as a possible Democratic nominee for Governor in place of Governor Lehman last night at a dinner of the West of Central Park Association, at which Mr. Levy was a speaker. The dinner was held at the Hotel Plaza.

ANDOVER, N.J., May 21. -- R. Elwyn Matteson, 36 years old, was dismissed tonight as principal of the Andover Grammar School because of "conduct unbecoming a teacher" with Carolyn McDavit, 15, a student at Newtown High School. The girl complained that Mr. Matteson hugged and kissed her as she was leaving his office March 11 after a conference.

Interest in the new class of racing yachts to replace the Long Island Sound Interclubs reached a point yesterday where the underwriting syndicate was faced with an oversubscription for the twenty sloops planned, and it was decided to raise the number to twenty-five.

Charles Evans Hughes Jr. was elected unanimously president of the New York County Lawyers Association last night at the annual meeting at the organization's headquarters, 14 Vesey Street. In this office he follows his father, the present Chief Justice of the Supreme Court, who was president of the association from 1919 to 1921.

WASHINGTON, May 21. -- Flood control was a major concern in Congress today, with the Senate passing the $320,000,000 omnibus bill and sending it to the House for consideration of an amendment to it, and the House debating the $272,000,000 Overton bill for projects in the lower Mississippi River Valley.
QUINCY, Mass., May 21 (AP) [The cruiser Vincennes, a 10,000-ton i vessel named after Vincennes, Ind., / was launched today at the Fore/ 'lver plant: of the Bethlehem hipI ]building Corporation.
The national executive committee of the American Legion has established a virtual censorship on all Legion publications through a resolution the sense of which was revealed here yesterday.

About 250 white and Negro followers of Father Divine, Harlem evangelist, caused an uproar in the Municipal Term of the magistrate's court yesterday afternoon and were threatened twice with ejection unless they stopped shouting.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 21 (AP). -- The Buffalo Bisons' winning string ended at fourteen games tonight as the Rochester Red Wings scored an 8-to-4 triumph before 8,500 fans. However, the Bisons continued in a tie for first place as Newark lost to Baltimore this afternoon.

Work being done by the recreation unit of the Works Progress Administration will be displayed at the Women's National Exposition of Arts and Industries, which will open tomorrow at Grand Central Palace.

Former Governor Smith feels thoroughly able now to "take a walk." He said so yesterday at the Biltmore at a meeting of committee heads of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee where it was announced that $1,006,434 had been raised thus far in the campaign.

MOSCOW, May 21. -- The result of the five matches in the sixth round of the international chess masters tournament, play in which was resumed today after a day's rest, brought about no change in the standing of the two leaders, M. Botwinnik of Russia and Jose R. Capablanca of Cuba.

GENEVA, May 21 (AP). -- A warning that a new war in Europe or Asia would wreck the hopes of any prosperity for the present generation was delivered today by Harold B. Butler, director of the International Labor Office, in his annual report to the International Labor Conference.

Edgar Schofield was re-elected president of the New York Singing Teachers Association yesterday at the final meeting of the organization at Aeolian Hall. Others elected were Hilda Grace Gelling, Walter Golde and Harry R. Spier, vice presidents; Fanny Gilbert Brines, recording secretary; Gertrude Blenko, corresponding secretary; Leon Carson, treasurer, and Melanie Guttman-Rice, registrar.

Public offering will be made today by a banking syndicate headed by Morgan Stanley Co., Inc., of a new issue of $22,727,000 of first and refunding mortgage 4 1/2 percent Series D bonds of the Chicago Western Indiana Railroad Company.

Wendell L. Willkie, in his annual report to stockholders of the Commonwealth Southern Corporation, issued yesterday, says the Federal power projects in the Tennessee Valley are not beyond the course of construction, so that no substantial amount of operating territory has been lost by operating companies of the group, nor has any material amount of power been sold by the government.

MARACAIBO, Venezuela, May 21 (AP). -- Shooting punctuated a demonstration of 20,000 residents of Caracas, unconfirmed reports said today, as labor unions here and in the capital began a forty-eight-hour general strike.
WASHINGTON, May 21. -- The rail carriers which have agreed to protect employes who may lose their work through railroad consolidations are as follows:

Roland Jones, in his dispatch from Omaha published in THE TIMES of May 3, declares that Terry Carpenter, Senatorial nominee of the Nebraska Democratic voters, "is regarded as uniting in one person Dr. Townsend, Father Coughlin, Upton Sinclair and the late Huey Long," and goes on: "Compared with him, Mr. Norris is being represented as a conservative."

WASHINGTON, May 21. -- Dr. Francis E. Townsend, founder of the Townsend Old-Age Pension Plan, defied the special House committee investigating his scheme today, stalked from the room and declared that he would not return "except under arrest."

Two representatives of Southwest golf, Jack Munger of the Brook Hollow Golf Club in Dallas, Texas, and Zell Eaton of the Twin Hills Golf and Country Club, Oklahoma City, will lead the procession in the opening eighteen-hole round of the fortieth United States open championship at Baltusrol on June 4, according to the pairings and starting times as released by the United States Golf Association yesterday.

High tide for the Townsend movement was reached last December when a supporter of the plan in Michigan was elected to Congress on the Republican ticket. But the plan's good fortune was its misfortune. As soon as it threatened to make serious progress it became worth while for the country to examine it critically and to look into its sponsorship.
With Ted Galligan allowing only five hits, the Boston College baseball team defeated St. John's University, 7 -- 2, for the second time this season at Dexter Park yesterday.

John Fiorenza's confession of the murder of Mrs. Nancy Evans Titterton, supported by police photographs taken as he re-enacted the crime, went into the record in General Sessions Court yesterday, the third day of the trial.
PHILADELPHIA, May 21. -- The annual Rittenhouse Flower Market today transformed an ancient square into a medley of vendors' cries, merry-go-round music and floral colors.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., May 21. -- Reports that 5,000 farm laborers, tenant farmers and share-croppers are on strike in Cross, Crittenden and St. Francis Counties in Arkansas were characterized today as false by residents of these counties.

Running in front for the entire seven furlongs of the Firenzi Handicap, Whitney Stone's unbeaten filly, Blue Sheen, qualified handsomely yesterday at Belmont Park for the Acorn Stakes and the Coaching Club American Oaks. It was the fourth race and the fourth victory for this daughter of Toro and Blue Eagle, and the margin was a length and a half.
WASHINGTON, May 21. -- President Roosevelt held a Cabinet meeting, signed the Rural Electrification Bill and nominated Morris L. Cooke of Pennsylvania to be REA Administrator for ten years.
The coming week-end promises to add further impetus to a saltwater fishing season that appears to have made a surprisingly early and auspicious start.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 21. -- Considerable political interest was aroused today by the news that Josef Beck, the Polish Foreign Minister, would arrive here either May 24 or May 28 for a two-day visit. The official statement that this will be a courtesy visit returning that paid to Warsaw three years ago by Dr. Voyislav Marinkovitch, then Premier, carries little conviction.

The magnificent Spring drive of the Giants which promised to blot out the entire Western section of the National League in its first parade of the year along the west bank of the Harlem without a single setback, was still moving along in a grand manner at the Polo Grounds yesterday as the clock atop the center field clubhouse recorded 4:50 P.M.

Mr. and Mrs. Bertrand L. Taylor, who returned recently from Hawaii gave a supper dance last night at their home, 455 East Fifty-seventh Street, for Mrs. Walter Dillingham of Honolulu, who will sail soon for Europe.
For the first time in his trial for compulsory prostitution, Charles (Lucky Luciano) Lucania was identified definitely yesterday as the leader of the vice ring.

WASHINGTON, May 21. -- Defending Governor Landon from assertions made by Chairman Farley before the Michigan Democrats yesterday, Representative Dewey Short of Missouri, in a speech before the House today, attacked Mr. Farley for serving as Postmaster General and also as the party's national chairman.

Senator AUSTIN of Vermont has shown remarkable knowledge, intellectual power and acuteness in debate. We have been accustomed to ascribe to him habitual moderation. Has he been bitten so early by the campaign bug? Speaking in this town at a luncheon of Westchester County Republican Women, he tried to make their flesh creep:
The renewal and extension of a mortgage on one property and the placing of a new loan on another marked realty activity in Brooklyn yesterday.

Miss Deborah Beirne, a writer, of 80 West Fortieth Street was the principal witness yesterday at the General Sessions trial of Walter C. Martin, 50 years old, formerly of Boston, on her charge that he defrauded her of $750 last year under pretense he had "influence" with high officials in Washington through whom he could obtain a $40,000 PWA loan for her.
LONDON, May 21. -- Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin delivered a pointed warning today to Italy or any other covetous power to keep its hands off Egypt and Palestine.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 21. -- Mrs. Lawrence C. Bostwick, assisted by Mrs. William J. Morris, was chairman of a contract bridge party this afternoon at the Casino. Prior to the party Mrs. Bostwick gave a luncheon for Mrs. Homer McGee, Mrs. I.B. Tigrett, Mrs. L.C. Bihler, Mrs. J.M. Breen and Mrs. W.W. Finley.

WASHINGTON, May 21. -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation will cooperate with banks which, in acting to retire preferred stock, capital notes or debentures aggregating about $1,000,000,000 held by the RFC, offer their stock to shareholders or the public generally, Jesse H. Jones, chairman, said today.
BALTIMORE, May 21 (AP). -- Cliff Melton had the better of a left-handed pitching duel with Kemp Wicker today and the Orioles evened the series by defeating Newark, 4 to 2.
Your correspondent's excellent account of the red spots before Senator McNaboe's eyes prompts me to ask a question that has long puzzled me. What is Americanism?

WASHINGTON, May 21. -- The WPA investigating staff has been reorganized and plans are being made to increase it substantially. Officials reported that the number of cases pending was swelling as charges of political activities continue to pour into Works Progress headquarters here.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 21. -- Expressing confidence in the future, Robert V. Fleming of Washington, president of the American Bankers Association, said tonight that with the cooperation of State and Federal authorities and the general public the most stable and serviceable banking system in our history will be established.
The renewal and extension of a mortgage on one property and the placing of a new loan on another marked realty activity in Brooklyn yesterday.

Miss Deborah Beirne, a writer, of 80 West Fortieth Street was the principal witness yesterday at the General Sessions trial of Walter C. Martin, 50 years old, formerly of Boston, on her charge that he defrauded her of $750 last year under pretense he had "influence" with high officials in Washington through whom he could obtain a $40,000 PWA loan for her.
LONDON, May 21. -- Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin delivered a pointed warning today to Italy or any other covetous power to keep its hands off Egypt and Palestine.
