WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 21. -- Mrs. Lawrence C. Bostwick, assisted by Mrs. William J. Morris, was chairman of a contract bridge party this afternoon at the Casino. Prior to the party Mrs. Bostwick gave a luncheon for Mrs. Homer McGee, Mrs. I.B. Tigrett, Mrs. L.C. Bihler, Mrs. J.M. Breen and Mrs. W.W. Finley.
LITTLE FALLS, Minn., May 21. -- The old Lindbergh homestead on the west side of the river is becoming spick and span.
City Magistrate Jonah J. Goldstein was named yesterday by Governor Lehman to fill the vacancy on the General Sessions Court bench caused by the recent death of Judge Otto A. Rosalsky.
Your correspondent's excellent account of the red spots before Senator McNaboe's eyes prompts me to ask a question that has long puzzled me. What is Americanism?

WASHINGTON, May 21. -- The WPA investigating staff has been reorganized and plans are being made to increase it substantially. Officials reported that the number of cases pending was swelling as charges of political activities continue to pour into Works Progress headquarters here.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 21. -- Expressing confidence in the future, Robert V. Fleming of Washington, president of the American Bankers Association, said tonight that with the cooperation of State and Federal authorities and the general public the most stable and serviceable banking system in our history will be established.

WASHINGTON, May 21.--The Southern Pacific Railroad, in seeking an extension until Nov. 1 of a $5,000,000 loan by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation which matures on June 1, is planning a refinancing operation of between $45,000,000 and $50,000,000 this Summer if market conditions are favorable, Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the RFC, said today.

HARTSDALE, N.Y., May 21. -- Miss Barbara Johnston of Knollwood, a comparative newcomer in the competitive ranks, today posted a 94 at the Scarsdale Golf Club to carry off the low gross honors in the third one-day tournament of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association.

WASHINGTON, May 21. -- Veterans of three wars were guests today of President and Mrs. Roosevelt at the garden party given annually for the convalescent patients of near-by soldiers' homes and hospitals. Nearly 1,000 attended.

ST. LOUIS, May 21 (AP). -- Wes Ferrell, who flunked against St. Louis yeserday, got a return assignment today and pitched the Red Sex to a 6-to-2 victory in the series closer, stopping the Browns' brief winning streak at three games.

The following film programs, which will he shown over the weekend, have been endorsed by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization of faculty members and parents of children in public and private schools:

SYRACUSE, May 21 (AP). -- The Remington Rand Company, manufacturer of typwriters and office equipment, today closed its Syracuse plant, employing 1,500, and announced a plan for consolidating work with its Ilion plant.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 21. -- Immediately on the arrival here today of James A. Farley, Democratic National Chairman, to deliver a speech at a party dinner tonight, State leaders began informal conferences in a movement to draft Governor Lehman as a candidate for re-election.

WASHINGTON, May 21. -- Wholesale prices moved generally downward again in the week ended on May 16, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The index, based on the 1926 weekly average as 100, fell to 78.1 from 78.6 the preceding week.

Arthur Williams, chairman for New York City and Westchester County of the Thomas Alva Edison Foundation Campaign, which seeks $5,000,000 nationally for a "living memorial" to the inventor, announced yesterday the personnel of the committee which will select 100 young men and women annually to receive Edison grants.

A dividend of 15 cents on the stock of the Transue Williams Steel Forging Corporation was declared yesterday, resuming the payment of dividends, the last having been 25 cents quarterly on July 15, 1931.

COPIAGUE, L.I., May 21. -- One of three Negroes surprised tonight by town constables at an unlicensed still in a shack in the woods north of this village was shot dead by the officers as he was trying to escape. The dead man was identified as A. Banks, 28 years old, of 68 West 134th Street, Manhattan.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

WASHINGTON, May 21. -- Strictly orthodox financing for the refunding of $686,616,400 of 1 1/8 per cent Treasury notes maturing on June 15, for $364,138,000 of 3 1/4 per cent notes maturing on Aug. 1 and probably for obtaining about $500,000,000 in "new money" at the June financing period was disclosed today by the Treasury.

Improvement of the financial position of the Shell Union Oil Corporation has been such as would justify the resumption of dividends on the preferred stock, J.C. Van Eck, chairman of the executive committee, informed stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., May 21. -- An unmanned "radio balloon" soared to an estimated height of thirteen miles today on a pioneering flight which scientists of the Bartol Research Foundation of the Franklin Institute hoped would herald a new era in cosmic ray investigation.
Two sets of delegates representing the Socialist left and right wings left this city yesterday for the party's national convention which will open in Cleveland tomorrow.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, May 21. -- Officials of the United States Steel Corporation, here today inspecting the new forty-three inch strip mill of the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation, said steel prices were headed upward. The party included Myron C. Taylor, chairman, and William A. Irwin, president of the corporation, and Benjamin F. Fairless, president of the Carnegie-Illinois Company.
BOSTON, May 21 (AP). -- Bill Urbanski poled a timely ninth-inning double today to provide the Bees with a 3-2 triumph over the Reds. John Lanning, a rookie from Knoxville, held the Reds to four hits.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, May 21. -- Officials of the United States Steel Corporation, here today inspecting the new forty-three inch strip mill of the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation, said steel prices were headed upward. The party included Myron C. Taylor, chairman, and William A. Irwin, president of the corporation, and Benjamin F. Fairless, president of the Carnegie-Illinois Company.
James P. Warburg, whose "Hell Bent for Election," published last Fall by Doubleday, Doran, has sold over 400,000 copies, has written a sequel, "Still Hell Bent," which will appear on June 5.

LONDON, May 21. -- Arms and munitions makers are the backbone of' the empire's defense and should not be subjected to "mud-slinging," Sir Maurice Hankey, secretary of the Committee for Imperial Defense, declared today before the Royal Arms Commission investigating munitions manufacture and traffic.
Metro's film version of Damon Runyon's "Three Wise Guys" will open today at the Capitol. Robert Young, Betty Furness and Raymond Walburn are its featured players.

Police Commissioner Valentine was a witness before the special grand jury investigating the Samuel Drukman murder case in Brooklyn yesterday. Shortly after he finished several of the jurors visited Mrs. Abraham Drukman, mother of the murdered man, at her home at 2,408 Beverly Road.
BOSTON, May 21 (AP). -- Bill Urbanski poled a timely ninth-inning double today to provide the Bees with a 3-2 triumph over the Reds. John Lanning, a rookie from Knoxville, held the Reds to four hits.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., May 22. -An ex-holder of the title, Paul Runyan, shied his hat into the ring and nominated himself as a candidate for re-election as metropolitan open golf champion at Quaker Ridge today.
PEORIA, May 22 (AP). -- The nomination of Colonel Frank Knox of Chicago for the Presidency was urged today by the Republican State Convention.

The Sharon Steel Corporation, formerly known as the Sharon Steel Hoop Company, and its wholly owned subsidiaries reported yesterday for the first quarter to March 31 a net profit of $212,616 after depreciation, interest, amortization, Federal and State income taxes and other charges.

ALBANY, May 22. -- Insisting there had been considerable misunderstanding of certain facts, Governor Lehman refused tonight to supersede District Attorney Martin W. Littleton Jr. of Nassau County and order a special grand jury investigation of the fatal shooting last month of Mrs. Marguerite Wiggen by two Nassau County detectives.

In his brief speech at Chicago on Thursday evening, Colonel KNOX scored neatly off Chairman FARLEY. The Postmaster General has set himself up as the chief expounder as well as defender of the New Deal. He also, in his flitting from one Democratic State Convention to another, has undertaken to interpret the mind and heart of President ROOSEVELT.

Walter Clemens Martin, 49 years old, of 740 Riverside Drive, the pseudo "fixer" who promised many men and women that his "influence" with high officials in Washington would obtain for them loans from the PWA, including one for $750,000, suddenly pleaded guilty to second-degree grand larceny at his trial in General Sessions yesterday.

Twenty-four of the fifty-two feature-length pictures to be produced in England next season by Gaumont-British will be released in the United States, it was announced here yesterday by Jeffrey Bernerd at the opening of the company's second annual sales convention in the Warwick Hotel.

This department is here to state this morning that a strong -- indeed, seemingly incontestable -- bid for top honors among the suburban entertainment resorts was flashed by Ben Marden's Riviera on Thursday evening and chances are altogether good that traffic on the George Washington Bridge will immediately show a rise.
BERLIN, May 22. -- Prices on the Boerse were firm today, stocks resuming an upward tendency, with fixed interest securities again listless.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- The Universal Corporation, a holding company controlling the Universal Pictures Company, Inc., and numerous subsidiaries and sub-subsidiaries, has filed three registration statements under the Securities Act of 1933, covering a series of securities, some of them now outstanding, which involve both a refinancing plan and the raising of a considerable amount of capital, the exact total of which is not estimated, for production of pictures, improvements, equipment and other corporate purposes.

The steady expansion of consumer buying this week, in spite of the cool weather in some sections, was accompanied by more evenness in the gain in retail sales for the various districts of the country, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

MOSCOW, May 22. -- The prevalence and growth of tipping in the Soviet Union, where theoretically it should not exist at all, is causing concern in the Communist party, some members of which see it destroying the dignity of the worker and fostering an incongruous master and servant psychology.

CHICAGO, May 22. -- The uncertainty that surrounds the May wheat situation has placed a damper on speculative interest in the wheat market as a whole, and most of the trade on the Board of Trade today was in the way of evening up the open interest in the current month.
SALT LAKE CITY, May 22 (AP). -- Amelia Earhart denied today that she plans a globe-girdling flight and said her ambition of the moment is to help develop planes safe for "papas and mamas."

A vested choir of nearly 1,600 girls and boys of the Sunday schools of the churches in the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York will march around the close of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine at 2 P.M. today and be reviewed by Bishop William T. Manning from the steps of Bishop's house.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., May 22. -With impressive pronouncements of chorale melodies by the Moravian Trombone Choir from the church tower, the Bach Festival at Bethlehem got under way late this afternoon. The weather favored the festival.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- The House committee investigating the Townsend plan, which last night voted to cite Dr. Francis E. Townsend for contempt because he defied the committee by walking out of a hearing, reversed itself today and adjourned a prolonged executive session without taking any action.

The Spring season of opera in the Metropolitan Opera House has presented some experiments. One of them, with Smetana's "Bartered Bride," sung in English, was a signal success. It has conferred a special value and distinction upon the early part of the season.

CHICAGO, May 22. -- Ten dollars a hundred pounds was paid for hogs today, the highest price since May 8, the market advancing 10 to 15 cents with most of the net gain made by hogs weighing under 250 pounds. Further strength in fresh pork was a factor.

CANBERRA, Australia, May 22. -In the House of Representatives today Sir Henry Gullett, Minister of Trade Treaties, announced increased duties and also a licensing system on a wide range of foreign goods by which 2,290,000 worth of imports will be diverted as follows: to Australian manufacturers, 845,000; to the United Kingdom, 1,310,000; to good customer nations, 135,000.

General Edward J. Higgins, who retired in 1934 because of his health as world head of the Salvation Army, made his first public appearance since that time here last evening. He conducted a devotional service for officers of the Salvation Army at Centennial Memorial Hall, 120 West Fourteenth Street.
John Fiorenza's mother, stepfather and aunt testified in General Sessions Court yesterday in an attempt to establish an alibi for him in his trial for the murder of Mrs. Nancy Evans Titterton.

DETROIT, May 22 (AP). -- Judge Patrick T. Stone imposed fines totaling $20,000 upon three former bankers convicted on charges of making false reports concerning the condition of banks thirteen months before the closing of two of Detroit's leading banking institutions.

PARIS, May 22. -- England's Davis Cup tennis team will have an intrasquad workout tomorrow in the semi-final round of the French hard courts doubles championships with the regular combination of George P. Hughes and Charles R.D. Tuckey opposing the singles stars, Fred Perry and H.W. (Bunny) Austin.

HAMILTON, N.Y., May 22. -- George Case, rookie southpaw, won his first start in a Colgate uniform when he triumphed over Rochester, 10 -- 8 today. He was reached for ten hits, but five errors by his mates figured in the scoring.

With a renewal of the liquor price war yesterday, strong-arm men attempted to prevent the delivery of three truck loads of liquor to the Nussbaum liquor store, 61 Cortlandt Street. A group of men in the crowd in front of the store, where liquor prices had been slashed, swarmed over the trucks and warned the drivers that "You can't deliver the liquor here."

The special exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art of "Franklin and His Circle" should be visited by every admirer of "Poor Richard." Rarely will there be presented another opportunity to see at one time such a fine collection of Frankliniana.
GENEVA, May 22 (AP). -- Italy charged anew today that the vanquished Ethiopians had used dumdum bullets supposedly made in Great Britain.

TOKYO, Saturday, May 23. -- Yesterday was an important date in Japan's commercial history. A few hours after the United States increased her tariffs on Japanese cotton textiles, Australia imposed higher duties on Japanese silks and cottons.

The collection and delivery of less-than-carload freight to be started by the Eastern railroads generally on Monday will provide a valuable service, Percy C. Magnus, president of the New York Board of Trade, said in a letter to the Interstate Commerce Commission made public yesterday.

YONKERS, N.Y., May 22. -- With an entry of sixteen, including several of the East's ranking stars, play in the Amackassin Club's invitation men's tennis singles tournament, an ancient fixture, started today, with one upset featuring the session.

PHILADELPHIA, May 22. -- Mrs. George Horace Lorimer is chairman of a committee from the Hannah Penn House group sponsoring the "Hollywood Revue" and annual benefit bridge which will take place on June 2.

An all-night session of the investigation by Assistant District Attorney Harold W. Hastings into the alleged extortion ring headed by Max D. Krone, private detective, was prevented last evening when Detective Hugo Harris reported by telephone from Buffalo that the airplane in which he was bringing an important woman witness had been forced down near there.
CHESTERFIELD, N.H., May 22 (AP). -- Discovery of the charred and broken body of a woman in a mountain thicket put a mystery before New Hampshire investigators tonight.

National Maritime Day was observed yesterday in the down town shipping district and along the waterfront. Flags were flown from the masts of the buildings occupied by ship lines, and ships in the harbor were bedecked.

The Long Island Railroad strenuously opposed yesterday the move of the State Transit Commission to restrain the railroad from charging more than 2 cents a mile in an action heard by Supreme Court Justice George H. Furman in Brooklyn.

WICHITA, Kan., May 22. -- Colonel Wint Smith, head of Governor Landon's State police force, was called the "Modern Carry Nation" today after he headed a score of highway patrolmen in a march through half a dozen night clubs last night in a fruitless search for liquor.

Plans for the new $5,500,000 hospital for chronic diseases on Welfare Island were made public yesterday by the Department of Hospitals. An appropriation for its construction is included in the 1936 capital outlay budget and work is expected to begin soon.

ALBANY, May 22. -- Governor Lehman today signed the Hollowell bill continuing the State's milk advertising program until April 1, 1937, with an appropriation of $250,000. Originally the measure called for an appropriation of $400,000, the same as last year, but the Republican Assembly leaders reduced it by $150,000.
An underrated City College nine scored a 13-2 decision over the powerful Long Island University team at Dexter Park yesterday.

When the writer of Monday's editorial speaks of the saving on paper containers that should be passed on to consumers he is actually reversing the situation. While it is true that the container is cheaper than the bottle at first cost, the fact is that a bottle makes thirty-three trips, while a container makes only one.

The member lines of the Atlantic Passenger Conference have written to Mayor La Guardia requesting a conference on the problem of taxicabs on city piers, but have received no reply. At a meeting of the conference yesterday it was decided to wait until Monday and, if no reply is then received, to repeat the request.

The contests of choruses, glee clubs and orchestras for public schools of Greater New York, sponsored by the Board of Education and the Music Education League, closed yesterday afternoon at the Town Hall, when eighteen choruses of the elementary public Schools competed in the finals.

SAN QUENTIN, Calif., May 22 (AP). -- Great Britain's repeated efforts to save the life of Alexander Mackay, subject of that government, condemned as a kidnapper, failed today as he dropped to his death through the trap of San Quentin prison's gallows.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 22. -Nine players out of a starting field of eighty-four survived the first day of play in the annual Princeton interscholastic tennis tournament, with one fourth round match still to be completed tomorrow morning.

The funeral of the Rev. Dr. Walter Laidlaw, nationally known authority on census and population studies, first secretary of the New York Federation of Churches and founder of the Clergy Association of New York and Neighborhood, took place yesterday noon in the chapel of the Riverside Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 22 (AP). -- Carl W. Fenninger of Philadelphia succeeded Frank F. Brooks of Pittsburgh as president of the Pennsylvania Bankers Association as the group closed its forty-second annual convention today.

HANOVER, N.H., May 22. -- Dartmouth's baseball team looked the part of champions today as Penn went down to a 9 to 2 defeat before the pitching of Ted Bruce, who started his first Eastern Intercollegiate League game.
JERUSALEM, May 22. -- Jewish-operated buses were again fired at today on the Jerusalem-Tel Aviv road, but there were no casualties.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 22. -T. Suffern (Tommy) Tailer of Piping Rock moved through the first two rounds of the Garden City Golf Club invitation tournament, but the three others who tied with him for the medal were on the sidelines at the end of today's play.

Because next Saturday is Memorial Day tomorrow there will be military and patriotic services with organizations attending in a body in many of the churches, and in many churches the pastors will preach sermons about war and peace. In some parishes tomorrow will be the annual Children's Day.

The National Labor Relations Board ruled yesterday that Morris Watson, vice president of the American Newspaper Guild, was discharged from the news staff of the New York office of The Asssociated Press last October because of his Guild activities, and ordered his immediate reinstatement.
CHICAGO, May 22 (AP). -- The Browns were unable to fathom the knuckle-ball pitching of Ted Lyons today and lost their fifth game of the season to the White Sox, 5 to 3.

Florence Brown, known as Cokey Flo, took the stand yesterday with plenty of opportunity to "put the finger" on Charles (Lucky) Lucania. She did a thoroughgoing job and enjoyed herself. Before she was done, Lucania had flung down his pencil in disgust and was glaring at her.

PITTSBURGH, May 22 (AP). -- The Cardinals, stopping en route home to play off a postponed game, strengthened their hold on first place in the National League today when they whipped the Pirates, 11 to 4.

When Assistant District Attorney David Dugan of Queens ran from the North Hills Country Club golf course last Thursday and phoned the police for an ambulance when he saw a practical joker "collapse" apparently in agony, he did not know that he was making a citywide matter out of what was intended as a joke on a fellow club member.

LONDON, May 22. -- For British diplomacy there now begins a period of unusual difficulty because it must proceed to liquidate the conflict with Italy without the assistance of public opinion and even, perhaps, against popular sentiment.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP). -President Roosevelt said today that his proclamation raising tariff walls against cotton cloth imports was not in conflict with his gen eral program of lowering trade barriers by reciprocal treaties.

CAMP 1, MOUNT EVEREST, Tibet, May 22 (By Wireless via Calcutta). -- After the most careful consideration of our position, I decided to bring all the members of the 1936 British Mount Everest Expedition down from Camp 3 for a short rest at Camp 1.

A grandmother will be among the 4,000 New York University students who will step up to the speakers platform Wednesday, June 10, at Ohio Field, University Heights, to receive their diplomas at the commencement exercises, it was learned yesterday.
The Equity Corporation and its affiliate, the American General Corporation, will issue today their statements for March 31, showing an increase in net assets compared with Dec. 31 last.

PHILADELPHIA, May 22. -- The Major Alfred Reginald Allen Memorial Fund of the School of Music, University of Pennsylvania, was the beneficiary of the performance of Gilbert and Sullivan's "Utopia Limited," given tonight at the Academy of Music by the Savoy Opera Company.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- Details of an agreement between the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and the long hostile Van Sweringen and Taplin interests of Cleveland, which would reorganize the capital structure of the Wheeling Lake Erie Railway to the financial betterment of all three parties, were announced today by the Federal agency.

Declaring that the city must not be "caught napping" in case pending negotiations for unification of rapid transit lines prove futile, Mayor La Guardia urged yesterday early action on the recapture of the B.M.T.'s Culver line to make possible the extension of he Independent Subway system to Coney Island.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 22. -Ten undergraduate prizes were awarded today by Tale University as follows:
City Magistrate Jonah J. Goldstein was sworn in as a General Sessions judge yesterday to succeed Judge Otto A. Rosalsky, who died recently.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals only $18,007,594, representing two States and fifty municipalities. The revised total for this week was $28,542,888. The weekly average of offerings for the year to date is $24,751,172.

What shall be the theme of the World's Fair to be held in this city in 1939, and what its design? Only a compelling theme will capture the imagination of the country, and the form it takes may well exert a considerable influence on American architecture for a generation to come.

LONDON, May 22. -- Colonial Secretary J.H. Thomas, former engine driver and labor leader, who became a Minister and friend of Kings, resigned from the Cabinet today in the face of the unprecedented scandal over the alleged leakage of budget secrets a month ago.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 22. -Mrs. M. Robert Guggenheim of Babylon, L.I., today captured the Gibraltar Challenge Platter with the fine-looking brown gelding Clifton's Beau in the Corinthian hunter class over an outside course, the main event of the second day of the Wilmington horse show.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- President Roosevelt revived plans today for a visit to the Southwest, setting a tentative date for the trip which would put his speeches on that trip in open competition for newspaper headlines with the Republican convention in Cleveland.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 22. -- J.F. T. O'Connor, Controller of the Currency, in an address today before the State Bankers Convention in Sacramento gave to the financial world the long awaited clarification of Federal regulations governing the securities that Federal Reserve member banks can purchase on their own account.

In a scene as fantastic as an episode from a slapstick comedy of the silent-film era, a Brooklyn policeman captured a robbery suspect yesterday afternoon and recovered a $780 payroll he is said to have snatched from an employe of the Queens Ribbon and Carbon Company at 360 Furman Street.
Increased automobile production aided the Pere Marquette Railway in April, according to its report for that period. The statement follows:
A fight within the American Legion on the subject of censorship appeared certain yesterday when a difference of opinion developed between Legion officers in the New York area.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- The possibility of entrusting the $1,425,000,000 work relief appropriation contained in the Second Deficiency Bill to President Roosevelt under terms similar to the $4,880,000,000 fund voted last year was discussed informally by some Senators today as a solution of the complications which might result from the provisions the House adopted before it sent the proposal to the Senate.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- The value of safety education for school children was stressed by President Roosevelt today in a brief address of welcome to the first National Conference of School Safety Patrols.
There will be four closings this evening and there may be another one or two before the week-end is done. So far, anyway, the list reads:

An initial dividend of 87 1/2 cents a share was declared yesterday on the new $3.50 cumulative convertible first preferred stock of the Radio Corporation of America, covering the period from April 1 to June 30 and payable on July 1 to holders of record of June 8.
PARIS, May 22 (AP). -- Leon Blum, prospective Premier of France, laid the groundwork tonight for a united mutual security front with five European nations.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 22. -- Bankers must prove to the country that they are conscious of their social responsibilities, Dean Christian Gauss of Princeton University told the New Jersey Bankers Association at their annual dinner here tonight.

MOSCOW, May 22. -- Jose R. Capablanca of Havana tonight defeated M. Botwinnik, the Soviet chess champion, in the seventh round of the international chess-masters' tournament amid scenes of the greatest excitement at the House of Unions, which was crowded to the doors.

FOR a smart, bright novel, quickened by wit, and with not even the slightest pretensions to that hazy quality called importance, try Lorine Pruette's "School For Love" (Doubleday, Doran, $2). This is a novel like a good dessert, light in substance but tangily flavored, easy to enjoy. The pace is fast, the style is fluent and the tone is amiable.

HARRISBURG, Pa., May 22. -Re-elected chairman of the Democratic State Committee at a reorganization meeting here today, David L. Lawrence sounded the keynote for the Presidential campaign in Pennsylvania by announcing his refusal to concede "a single county to the Republican machine."

Jerry Conway pitched the La Salle Academy baseball team to the Manhattan Division C.H.S.A.A. title yesterday, blanking Power Memorial Academy, 7 -- 0, at the Astoria Athletic Field. The victory was the fifth in a row for La Salle, which has one more game to play.

The purchase by St. John's University of a vacant plot at the northwest corner of Boerum Place and State Street adjoining its Borough Hall division in Brooklyn was announced yesterday. The property is 100 by 170 and will be used temporarily as tennis courts for students.

In the editorial "Milk Trouble" you say: "Nevertheless, some of his [Fee's] attempts to extricate himself and the industry from this torture are little short of ludicrous. The most recent instance is his effort to discourage the sale of milk in paper containers by fixing a price to consumers on milk so distributed 1 cent higher than on milk of exactly the same quality sold in glass bottles."

The agreement for the protection of employes displaced by railroad consolidations or coordinations that was reached on Thursday by representatives of the unions and the managements removed the obstacle that had halted many railroad economies in recent years, it was said yesterday in railroad circles.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 22. -- Up here in the city of Ithaca, house party crowds, banners and a miniature traffic jam indicated the start of Cornell's Spring Day festivities, with tonight's Navy Day ball, tomorrow's circus and the rest of the program discussed on all sides, but down by the lake there was quiet preparation under a hot sun.

Five members of a gang that defrauded hundreds of persons in the sale of memberships in the American Automobile Service League, Inc., at 38 Park Row, and the corporation itself were found guilty in Special Sessions yesterday of conspiracy and violation of the State insurance law.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP). -- The House approved the Overton $272,000,000 Lower Mississippi Flood Control Bill today, 162 to 156, and sent it back to the Senate with amendments which its proponents said "crucified the measure."

LOS ANGELES, May 22. -- A declaration that the nation was "at the cross roads" and must choose between free competition in industry or regulation and ultimate regimentation was made tonight by Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of General Motors Corporation, in a speech before the Los Angeles Chamber of Commerce at its annual dinner.

WATKINS GLEN, N.Y., May 22. -- In the beautiful setting of the Watkins Glen State Park, Miss Eleanor C. Sanford of Margaretsville, N.Y., was crowned Queen of May at the Elmira College fete this afternoon. Upward of 1,000 spectators witnessed the interpretive dances.

If an outsider may be permitted to butt into the controversy between those two eminent gentlemen, Lawson Robertson and Dan Ferris, as to the wisdom of holding the national track and field championships at Princeton on July 3 and 4, the week before the final Olympic tryouts, I'd like to take sides with Mr. Ferris. He's a smaller chap and probably needs some assistance anyway.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP). -- New objections to extension of emergency freight surcharges scheduled to expire on July 1 were raised today by shipping representatives at hearings before the Interstate Commerce Commission.
LONDON, May 22. -- Trading was quiet on the London Stock Exchange today, with prices ending irregular. British funds were weakened further by remarks on taxation by the Chancellor of the Exchequer.

Resumption of corporate financing an a moderate scale after a lapse of two weeks lifted new bond financing this week to $57,143,365. Last week the total was $26,386,000, all in tax-exempt issues. A year ago this week new bonds for $42,757,000 were marketed.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 22 (AP). -- Holy Cross and Rhode Island State, co-favorites in the fiftieth New England I.C.A.A.A.A. track and field championship meet, waged a keen battle for the opening honors in today's eleven trial events at Brown Field.
VIENNA, May 22. -- It is learned from usually well-informed circles that Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg is contemplating nationalization of the Austrian munitions industry.

Former Governor Smith received a present of six pairs of specially made shoes yesterday from Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx, but declared he did not know yet whether he would use any of them to "take a walk" at the Democratic National Convention.

Wilson College at Chambersburg, Pa., has a new president 33 years old. Wilson is a small college, but even then 33 is young for a man at the head of it. No record is involved, of course. That is still safe with ROBERT M. HUTCHINS, who became president of the University of Chicago at 30.
WASHINGTON, May 22. -- Business has been booming at the Supreme Court this term. Lawyers and sightseers already have established two all-time records for the highest tribunal.

BALTIMORE, May 22. -- Weary from his ordeal yesterday in Washington but as full of $200-a-month-pension enthusiasm as ever, Dr. Townsend, in blue-striped pajamas, talked as he rested in bed here today at the Baltimore headquarters of his movement.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- An unpromising picture of the redemption of $1,750,000,000 in railroad securities if the present railroad retirement legislation should stand was painted today in the District of Columbia Supreme Court by Edward J. Buckland, chairman of the board of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad and president of the Railroad Credit Corporation.

The engagement of $9,940,000 gold abroad for shipment here was announced yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Of the total $5,740,000 was taken in France, $1,799,000 in India, $1,331,000 in Canada, $681,000 in Holland and $389,000 in England.

The legal question whether American corporations may discharge their obligations to alien bondholders with the present United States dollar was argued yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Hofstadter by Nathan L. Miller, former Governor.

The Rev. Gerald L.K. Smith, national organizer of the late Huey Long's "Share-Our-Wealth" organization, came to New York yesterday to "see my friends," to champion Dr. Francis E. Townsend against the House "inquisition" and to proclaim that the followers of Dr. Townsend, the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin and himself were about to "congeal under a leadership with guts" to get rid of the "synthetic bath-tub gin" political leadership of James A. Farley.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers of America and chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization, announced to the steel workers union today that the nine unions in his group were prepared to spend $500,000 in a unionization drive in the steel industry in accordance with the resolution adopted last week by the steel union.

PORTSMOUTH, Ohio, May 22. -- About 5,500 employes of the Portsmouth plant of the Wheeling Steel Corporation left their jobs tonight, demanding 50 per cent increases in wages and recognition of the Amalgamated Association of Iron, Steel and Tin Workers as their sole bargaining agency.
I am particularly averse to letter writing, especially of the "vox pop" type, but there is something about tennis's Mighty Atom that makes persons think and do unusual things, Hence, this letter.

BERLIN, May 22. -- Germany has now taken steps to revise the last remaining provisions of the "dictated" Versailles treaty that still infringe her sovereignty, the provisions regarding internationalization of her principal waterways, which call for equal treatment on her main rivers for the nationals of all powers and their property.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:
CHICAGO, May 22. -- In one of the roughest stakes raced this season, Rushaway galloped to victory in the $12,000 added Illinois Derby at Aurora today.

Seven open boats returned to the dock at Montauk Thursday evening with an aggregate catch of 125 pollock, ranging in weight from twelve to thirty-two pounds. They were caught on the bottom with squid bait.

Faced with the alternative of dropping back into the National League cellar, the Dodgers summoned sufficient swatting strength to tie the Bees in the ninth inning at Ebbets Field yesterday and then managed to triumph with two down in the eleventh.

HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., May 22. -- The factory of the model homestead community being built near here will be leased to the garment-worker settlers for $500 for the first year and will be run cooperatively, it was announced today.

The share market made a little headway yesterday on the side of the recovery, but trading continued slow. Professionals are timorous about pursuing rallies far, and the "public" is virtually out of the market. The closing was steady and higher, with the main body of stocks showing fractional gains and a handful of issues moving up 1 to more than 4 points.

Pounding out eighteen hits off three pitchers, Boston College's baseball team overwhelmed New York University, 17 -- 2, at Ohio Field yesterday. It was the record triumph of their metropolitan tour for the Eagles, who defeated St. John's on Wednesday, and broke a four-game winning streak of the Violets.

ST. LOUIS, May 22. -- A report of the Christian Social Action Commission, made today to the Northern Baptist Convention here, declared the ultimate goal of Baptists should be abolition of the liquor traffic.

TRENTON, May 22. -- Dr. Charles H. Elliott, State Commissioner of Education, upheld today the Secaucus School Board in expelling two pupils, Alma and Vivian Hering, for refusal to salute the flag and pledge allegiance as required by a law enacted in 1932.

City College was divided into two camps yesterday afternoon. While the crack Reserve Officers Training Corps battalion of the institution held its annual military review in Lewisohn Stadium, antiwar students staged a "Jingo Day" protest meeting on the campus and took the Oxford Pledge not to support the government in any future war.

BALTIMORE, May 22 (AP). -- Newark unleashed a 21-hit attack on a quartet of Oriole pitchers to win today's game, 10 to 7. The Birds registered only eight hits off Spurgeon Chandler and Frank Makosky. Al Piechota pitched to one batter to wind up the game.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 22. -- The National Council of the Boy Scouts of America, in its twenty-sixth annual meeting here today, voted to fingerprint more than 1,000,000 Boy Scouts in the United States and its possessions. The boys were asked to send, through their local troops, to the Department of Justice for the necessary cards and return them for voluntary registration.

GENEVA, May 22. -- A report of the United States Government on babies born to narcotic addicts aroused lively discussion in the League of Nations opium advisory committee today.

TULSA, Okla., May 22 (AP). -- An electric motor which stands on its head at the bottom of a well and kicks oil to the surface with its "feet" was demonstrated to the International Petroleum Exposition here today.

Trading in the May delivery on the Cotton Exchange ceased at noon yesterday with a final quotation of 11.62 cents a pound, which was the closing figure of each day since Monday. Later months held within a narrow range, 3 points higher to 4 points lower. July ended 101 points over October.

PARIS, May 22 (AP). -- The outflow of gold from the Bank of France has been reduced greatly by the new restrictive measures, the bank's weekly statement showed today. In the week ended on May 15, gold withdrawals amounted to 514,000,000 francs ($34,094,678).

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- President Roosevelt discussed with Edward J. Flynn, Bronx Democratic leader, the situation created by the decision of Governor Lehman not to be a candidate for re-election; announced the schedule of a tentative trip to the Southwest in June, and left tonight for Hyde Park.

While the increase in the tariff on imported cotton goods was generally regarded as a "step in the right direction" by executives in the local market yesterday, they were practically unanimous in declaring that it did not solve the problem, as the Japanese could still undersell American mills.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

Decision on whom the friends of President Roosevelt will support for the Democratic nomination for Governor will not be made until next Fall, it was learned yesterday after the arrival of James A. Farley, State and national chairman.

The first meeting of Protestant laymen and clergy to discuss American participation in the World Conference for Life and Work in Oxford in July, 1937, and the World Conference on Faith and Order in Edinburgh, also in the Summer of 1937, was held yesterday at a luncheon at the Downtown Association.

Revenues from subsidiaries of the United Gas Corporation from crude oil operations in the first quarter of 1936 were fourfold those in the same part of 1935, or $1,144,162, against $278,099, the company's report shows. Revenues from natural gas were $8,677,454, against $7,213,418; from gasoline, $332,855, compared with $187,858; from sulphur, $374,861, against $206,217.

The Guffey Coal Act, which the Supreme Court has just invalidated in part, was enacted upon President Roosevelt's insistence that constitutional pangs of conscience should not make cowards of Congress. In so acting, the President followed the doctrines enunciated by Jackson, whom the Democrats have adopted, and Lincoln, who has been appropriated by His Excellency's Opposition.

GENEVA, N.Y., May 22 (AP). -While most of his Hobart classmates were dancing at the senior ball in the college gymnasium, Philip Tangier Smith Cooke, 24, son of a Springfield (Ohio) Episcopal minister, shot and killed himself early today in his room at the Sigma Phi fraternity house.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 22. -- The boy they all came to watch, Ohio State's Jesse Owens, whipped through four breezy but highly convincing trial efforts today as Michigan's defending champions set the pace in the qualifying for the thirty-sixth annual Western Conference track and field championships tomorrow.

LONDON, May 22 (Canadian Press). -- Victorious in its first four games, Kent today was beaten on the first innings by Gloucestershire in the first-class cricket match ended today. Leading the county championship, Kent now has 63 points, while Surrey holds the runner-up position with 40 points.

Three dollars' worth of ground coffee, sandpaper, cardboard and flowers were arranged so successfully by 11-year-old June Humble of Douglaston, Queens, that she won first prize yesterday afternoon in the city-wide child's garden competition sponsored by the Gardens of the Nations in Rockefeller Center.
Business and housing properties were included in the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.

On the polo field of Giralda Farms, the country estate of Mr. and Mrs. M. Hartley Dodge in Madison, N.J., today the Morris and Essex Kennel Club will hold its tenth annual exhibition, with a total of 3,751 dogs on the benches.

PARIS, May 22. -- Former Premier Edouard Herriot remained silent tonight at a meeting of the Radical Socialist party's executive committee, where it had been announced he would declare his decision on taking the Foreign portfolio in the Blum Cabinet. He resisted efforts to induce him to speak.

IT was in the paddock at Belmont Park, a pleasant place to be on a pleasant Spring day. The discussion on the Withers was going along nicely. The historian told the background of the race. It was first run at Jerome Park away back in 1874 and won by J. Donohue's Dublin. That was a year before they started running the Kentucky Derby at Churchill Downs.

Retail trade in the metropolitan area scored further gains during the week. Response to special promotions was reported excellent in many instances, with some department stores here going ahead by 30 per cent or more on one or two days of the week.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- With the administration's foreign trade policy already a campaign issue, the Department of Commerce disclosed today that this country's trade balance had been "unfavorable" in April for the third time in as many months. The value of imports exceeded exports by almost $9,000,000.

The Phils replaced the Cardinals as the Giants' foemen yesterday at the Polo Grounds, but to New York eyes they seemed to be that same Gas House Gang acting in boisterous fashion once more. For the Philadelphians, performing in a fashion quite out of keeping with their lowly estate in the league standings, routed Bill Terry's men, 15 to 0, and unceremoniously dumped them a game and a half out of first place.

DETROIT, May 22. -- Seven members of the Black Legion, a secret society of robed night-riders, faced murder charges tonight for the execution of Charles A. Poole, 32-year-old WPA worker, who was found shot to death beside a suburban road on May 13.

CLEVELAND, May 22. -- Seating plans for State delegations to the Republican National Convention June 9 give the States of Washington, Minnesota, Michigan and Maine front seats in the public auditorium.

Industry and art will be represented in exhibits showing the modern woman's interest in foods, household economy, polities, creative crafts, art and consumer problems, at the Fifteenth Annual Women's Exposition of Arts and Industries, which opens at noon today at the Grand Central Palace and will continue through next Friday.

The removal of District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan of Brooklyn on three general charges was demanded in the communication sent to Governor Lehman last Tuesday by the special grand jury investigating the Samuel Drukman murder case, it was revealed yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, May 22 (AP). -- The Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation announced tonight the long-expected increase in prices of steel. The new rates will be posted tomorrow with the opening of books for business of the third quarter of 1936.
WASHINGTON, May 22. -- President Roosevelt repeated the hope today that Governor Lehman would reconsider his decision to retire from politics, and become a candidate for re-election.

With the opening regetta this afternoon at the American Yacht Club, Rye, the championship season of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island will get under way, and thereafter on every Saturday, holiday and some Sundays through September the great fleet of sailing craft will spread wing in the waters between Execution Lighthouse, off New Rochelle, and Stamford.

CLEVELAND, May 22. -- Norman Thomas, leader of the Socialist party, said tonight in a speech over a nation-wide radio network that "we shall not hasten but delay a Farmer-Labor party by watering down our Socialist program or by uniting on a joint ticket with Communists.''

For almost two hours yesterday afternoon 4-year-old Wayne Lortz of 728 East Forty-fifth Street, Brooklyn, had the rare privilege of taking complete charge of Prospect Park Zoo by reason of being acclaimed the 2,000,000th visitor to the zoo since its opening last July.

In the editorial on milk containers you stated that if there is any saving in the use of paper containers for milk, it should be passed on to the consumer. The purpose of this letter is to dispel any doubts as to this "if."

ALBANY, May 22 (AP). -- Twenty-three black-hooded children representing those who died in Albany traffic accidents in 1935 lent a grim presence today to a safety pageant witnessed by thousands and depicting the trial, conviction and execution of "Old Man Carelessness."

Price movements of commodity futures were mixed in quiet trading in the markets here yesterday. Silk, which has been under steady selling pressure recently, eased further, but some strength was shown in rubber and sugar. In the cash markets, wheat, coffee, cocoa, rubber, eggs and printcloths were higher, while corn, rye, oats, cotton, silk, tin and wool tops were lower.

SUMMIT, N.J., May 22. -- An imported smooth foxterrier was crowned as king of them all today in the fifty-second specialty show of the American Fox Terrier Club on the lawns of The Brook. The victor in a large entry of smooths and wires was the lovely white and black bitch, Solus Joy, owned by E. Coe Kerr of Mill Neck, L.I., and handled by Percy Roberts.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

VIENNA, May 22. -- The principal aim in the reconstruction of the Austrian Cabinet was termination of the dualism in the leadership of the State, which, since the death of Chancellor Engelbert Dollfuss, has existed as a result of the historic development of the new Austria.

JERUSALEM, May 22. -- With this Holy City like an armed camp, British authorities called on additional troops today to stamp out the terrorism in which twenty-six Jews, sixteen Arabs and a Christian have been killed since April 19, when the Arab civil disobedience strike began.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP). -- Revised estimates of the 1935 cotton crop announced today by the Department of Agriculture gave production as 10,638,000 bales, each of 500 pounds gross weight, compared with 9,636,000 for 1934. Ginnings of 10,638,391 bales were reported by the Census Bureau, compared with 9,636,073 for 1934.
ALBANY, May 22. -- President Roosevelt's hope that Governor Lehman would decide to seek a third term brought from he Governor today only this comment:
Harper will publish on Monday Marquis W. Childs's pamphlet "They Hate Roosevelt," part of which appeared recently in Harper's Magazine.
HEAFFORD JUNCTION, Wis., May 22 (AP). -- Efforts of the widow of Eugene Field to save her 155-acre estate from a mortgage sale were hedged by uncertainty today.

BERLIN, May 22. -- Joseph Rosenstock, for a short period conductor of German opera at the Metropolitan Opera House in New York and later music director at the Mannheim Opera House, has accepted a call to Tokyo, where he will direct a new symphony orchestra.

ROME, May 22. -- Fulvio Suvich, Under-Secretary for Foreign Affairs, today received the French Ambassador, Count Charles de Chambrun, and informed him that the expulsion from Ethiopia of the 78-year-old French missionary, Mgr. Andre Jarousseau, had been suspended.

I recently have been informed that the Eastern Interscholastic golf tournament is not open to public schools this year. I believe that this action definitely makes the title misleading as, certainly, "Eastern Interscholastic" implies all Eastern schools, including high schools.

I have never heard a satisfactory argument advanced against the proposition that it is better to have the man who earns his money expend it under his own supervision and obtain full value in return for services rendered and materials purchased, than to have the government take an undue share of it from him in taxes to expend under the supervision of men who have no personal interest in its proper distribution.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- With all the delegates to the Republican National Convention selected except those of Texas and Indiana, the leaders of the respective candidates are now turning their attention to winning support from the States with uninstructed delegates.

BUFFALO, May 22. -- A prediction that the "few-cents-a-day plan" for hospital care would become popular in all the larger New York State cities was made today by Sherman D. Meech, managing director of the Rochester Hospital Service Corporation, and Frank Van Dyk, executive director of the Associated Hospital Service of New York, in addresses to the Hospital Association of the State of New York.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP). -- With some backers of the new Guffey Coal Control Bill predicting quick Congressional action on it, opponents demanded today an opportunity to express their views at a public hearing.

NICE, France, May 22. -- The newspaper Eclaireur de Nice today published an interview with Ernest Carl, a German wartime spy, who professes to have been responsible for the blowing up of the British cruiser Hampshire off the Orkney Islands and the death of Earl Kitchener, then War Secretary.

" The advertising profession is still where it was ten years ago with respect to its ability to forecast accurately what a given advertisement will do under a given set of circumstances," according to a study of 4,000,000 inquiries from magazine advertising prepared by H.J. Rudolph and to be published by the Columbia University Press. It is not uncommon, he said, for different ads to vary as much as 300 per cent in effectiveness.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 22 (AP). -- Western Conference coaches filled their 1938 football schedules today, each booking at least five Conference foes.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- The House Democratic caucus, compelled to meet tonight to discuss anti-lynching bills, ended without action after a session lasting an hour, in which Northern advocates of the legislation were unable to muster a quorum and the few Southerners present were unable to pass a motion to adjourn.

The average increase of 42 per cent in our tariff duties on bleached and colored cotton cloths is a regrettable backward step from the steady progress of Secretary HULL'S program to lower tariff barriers. The increase is mainly directed against Japanese imports, for attempts to deal with the question solely on the basis of "gentlemen's agreements" have not been successful.

Abraham J. Halprin, special counsel for the State Insurance Department in its suit against the directors of the defunct State Title and Mortgage Company for $5,000,000, charging waste of the company's assets, rested the department's case yesterday afternoon before Supreme Court Justice Hofstadter.

Apparently the fire alarm box at the southeast corner of 101st Street and Manhattan Avenue attracts horses. Or perhaps Queenie's nose itched. Then again, it may have been that Queenie is descended from an old-time fire horse.

The life of John Brown, he of the marching soul, is a constant temptation to the dramatist; the wonder is that more of them do not join the historians in trying to explain the origins of Harper's Ferry. A little over two years ago George Abbott, in a bushy beard, was the "Pottawatomie" Brown of a play by Ronald Gow.

LONDON, May 22. -- The eighth edition of the American newsreel, "The March of Time," on the international situation, which was heavily cut by the British censor, was privately shown today in the original and censored versions to Viscount Cecil of Chelwood and other representatives of the League of Nations Union.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 22. -- As delegates from all over the country were assembling here today for the national convention of the Socialist party, opening tomorrow, lines were being drawn for a battle for control on the floor of the convention between the warring left and right wings.

Construction contracts in the thirty-seven States east of the Rocky Mountains last month totaled $234,806,300, against $198,978,300 during March and $124,020,000 during April, 1935, the F.W. Dodge Corporation reported yesterday. Last month's figure was the highest, with the exception of last December, since October, 1931.

ALBANY, May 22. -- Governor Lehman announced tonight that he intended to defer action on the charges seeking the removal from office of District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan of Kings County until the special grand jury, which is investigating the Drukman murder case, has completed its duties and all prosecutions have ended.

The newly named board of design for the World's Fair to be held here in 1939 and 1940 held its organization meeting yesterday afternoon in the World's Fair Corporation offices in the Empire State Building and paved the way for the drafting of a master plan for the exposition.

Stockholders of Patino Mines and Enterprises Consolidated, Inc., were told at their annual meeting yesterday that the proposed consolidation with Sociedad Empresa de Estano de Araca had been canceled following the discovery of a mutual mistake as to the probable ore reserves of the latter.

Dr. J. Burns Amberson states that "the last strongholds of tuberculosis could be wiped out by early diagnosis." With due respect to Dr. Amberson, who is recognized as one of the great tuberculosis specialists, I must disagree, in part at least.

The strike of about 1,800 barbers in the Bronx was ended by a settlement yesterday, while the union went ahead with plans to extend the strike in Manhattan to the financial district and to call out union barbers on Long Island early next week.
PARIS, May 22. -- Colonel Francois de la Rocque declared today he intended to be "arbiter of France," as distinct from "dictator."

CHICAGO, May 22. -- Roger Adams, head of the department of chemistry at the University of Illinois and past president of the American Chemical Society, received the 1936 Willard Gibbs Medal of the society's Chicago section at a dinner tonight celebrating the twenty-fifth anniversary of the founding of the award by William A. Converse.
In The American Mercury Mr. NICHOLAS ROOSEVELT, a close and experienced watcher of public opinion, writes:

Dr. Darwin Hecht, 46 years old, leader of a fake accident insurance ring which had its headquarters in his so-called "clinic" in West Thirty-fifth Street, pleaded guilty in General Sessions yesterday to defrauding an insurance company of $135. He had rendered a bill for pretended medical services to one of his confederates, who had not been the victim of an accident.

With Brevity, Red Rain and Mr. Bones scheduled to meet seven others, the sixty-first Withers Stakes at Belmont Park today looms as one of the keenest renewals in the long history of this famous mile test, which dates back before the Civil War. Estimates range above 20,000 as to attendance, largely because the race is expected to have an important bearing on the 3-yearold championship.

CLEVELAND, May 22 (AP). --The Tigers and Indians hit the ball with everything except the flagpole today and when the dust had cleared away Detroit had given Cleveland its fifth straight defeat, 13 to 10.

A delegation of striking seamen conferred twice with Mayor La Guardia yesterday at City Hall on the rights of strikers to picket the municipal piers and on the methods of the police in handling pickets during two clashes on the waterfront.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- A possibility that the Senate Finance Committee may yet have to turn to other sources than corporations and their stockholders for new Federal revenue developed today with the publication of estimates showing that the compromise tax program agreed upon yesterday fell considerably short of the demands made by President Roosevelt in his message of March 3.
SAN LUIS OBISPO, Calif., May 22. -- A dip in a hot paraffin bath has awakened whole colonies of bacteria from a 100-year sleep, Dr. Ira B. Bartle, research bacteriologist, reported today.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- Increases in employment of more than 255,000 workers and of approximately $4,200,000 in weekly payrolls in April were anounced today by Secretary of Labor Perkins. The gains were reported general.

Edward W. Beatty, chairman and president of the Canadian Pacific Railway, and two vice presidents received an aggregate sum of $126,728, Canadian dollars, in salaries in 1934, according to a report by the company to the Securities and Exchange Commission made public yesterday.

Launched on a program of commercial cooperation with other nations, the United States must follow that course or push the world toward economic distress, political and governmental chaos and military adventure, Cordell Hull, Secretary of State, said here yesterday in defending the reciprocal trade and tariff policies of the Administration.
BALBOA, C.Z., May 22. -- The flagship Pennsylvania led eighty-six ships of the United States fleet to port here today after manoeuvers that took the entire force across the Equator.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., May 22. -- A dead heat in the third race at Narragansett Park today between C. W. Phelan's Be Just and Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs's Charmed Eyes resulted in a split in the daily double pool and two pay-offs, the first time this has happened in New England racing. It was the second dead heat for first place at this meeting.
The text of the address of Cordell Hull, Secretary of State, at the foreign trade luncheon at the Hotel Astor yesterday follows:
American Display Co., second floor, 24,000 sq. ft.. in 521 W. 43d St., where lessee has fifth floor, 30,000 sq. ft.; DuCret Co., brokers.

PHILADELPHIA, May 22. -- The Manhattan, Rutgers and Marietta College varsity crews and Pennsylvania's third varsity will compete in the third annual Harry (Dad) Vail Trophy regatta over the Henley course on the Schuylkill River tomorrow afternoon at 5 o'clock.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 22. -- Yale today held the Washington American Leaguers to a 1-1 count until the eighth inning, when five safeties, an error and a pass netted seven runs and gave the Senators an 8-1 victory.

The news late last night that the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation had announced an increase in prices of various classes of steel for the third quarter of this year fulfilled expectations. It had merely been a question which of the big companies would be first to make the announcement, with the smaller independent companies naturally waiting for the larger units to take the initiative.

AGUA CALIENTE, Lower California, May 22 (AP). -- Setting a new record for 125-horsepower planes, Peter Dana, 20, of Holderness, N.H., completed a Canada-to-Mexico flight down the Pacific Coast today in 12 hours 34 minutes elapsed time and 11 hours 6 minutes actual flying time.

THE speed traps which rural communities set up for the unwary motorist have long since vanished. At every turn of the road his way has been smoothed, both literally and figuratively. Yet the driver who sets out cross-country still has problems of wear-and-tear due to rough going -- even though the rough going may be for his temper rather than his machine.

THE devil, it is said, readily finds work for idle hands to do. This saying has been cited in India to explain the anti-government activities of university men, especially their connection with terrorism in Bengal. Since 1929 thousands in government and business offices have been thrown out of work, and young men on leaving school and college have found office-doors closed to them.

" Bury the Dead" is one of those plays which drop, like the bomb-shell this particular one denounces, into Spring's most placid theatre. A few months ago a cooperative group put it on for two performances: in the morning it was being acclaimed as one of the best anti-war pieces of the time.
A long-range program of flood control was sent to President Roosevelt and Governor Lehman yesterday by the State Society of Professional Engineers.

I RECENTLY spent fifteen days in Tripolitania and Cyrenaica. I made an airplane flight over the distant oases of the Sahara and I visited, together with Marshal Balbo, the troops stationed behind the Egyptian front. No journey could better reveal the creative and ardently mystical spirit that animates fascism, no trip could be more instructive for one who would know the mentality of the Italians who have in a few months conquered Ethiopia.

WASHINGTON, May 23. -- The "stop Landon" movement that once had the support of former President Hoover and his group has virtually disappeared with the decision of Mr. Hoover to cease his opposition and eliminate himself from the Presidential race.

HIGH POINT, N.C., May 23 (AP). -- The movement for unification of the major Branches of Methodism advanced another step today when the general conference of the Methodist Protestant Church formally approved the merger plan by a vote of 142 to 39.

MOST American gardeners long have realized the decorative possibilities of our native rhododendron for shady locations in shrubbery groupings, but only now are they beginning to take full advantage of the wealth of less well-known material of the same type which is available.

Announcement of the twentieth annual Summer session at City College, to open on Thursday, June 25, and continue for eight weeks until Wednesday, Aug. 19, was made yesterday by President Frederick B. Robinson. Dr. Charles Upson Clark, Professor of Languages, will be the director for the fifth consecutive year.

TORONTO, May 23 (AP). -- The Montreal Royals collected thirteen hits off Emmett Nelson, former Cincinnati hurler, as they defeated the Toronto Maple Leafs, 5 -- 1, in the final game of the series today.

Strong opposition to the placing of the control of advertising of foods, drugs and cosmetics in the hands of the Federal Trade Commission will be put forth by manufacturers on the ground that such action will result in great confusion in the enforcement of the proposed legislation now before Congress, it was indicated here yesterday.

THIS week's floral events begin with an iris and peony show at Horticultural Hall, Rockefeller Center. From Monday afternoon through Tuesday and Wednesday it will be open until 10 o'clock in the evening. In addition to cultural classes for irises and peonies, there are those for massed displays and for arrangements.

ALONG the thousands of miles of highway throughout Texas the State Highway Department has made available to motorists 500 roadside parks. Rapidly increasing motor travel in Texas following the improvement of highway surfaces convinced the State of the urgent need for such parks as a means of discouraging casual parking.

PARIS, May 23. -- Charles Maurras, Royalist editor, today for the second time within two months was convicted of inciting violence against Leon Blum, Premier-designate and head of the Socialist party.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 22. -Peace of a sort has settled over the waterfront as warring factions in the International Seamen's Union make progress toward resolving their differences, and as Harry Bridges, militant leader of the long-shoremen, gives evidence that he intends to accept the awards of the Federal arbitrator, M.C. Sloss.

THOSE who missed the Chinese exhibition at Burlington House may see the George Eumorfopoulus collection of Chinese art at the Victoria and Albert Museum. At present it is intended to prolong this exhibition to the end of the Summer.
CINCINNATI, May 23 (AP). -- The Hebrew Union College awarded an honorary degree of Doctor of Hebrew Law to James G. McDonald of New York, at the fifty-second graduation exercises today.

A GHOSTLY chill swept through the Times Square bar where we sat with Edward Halperin, specialist in spectral screen spectacles for certain necrophilous tastes about town. From far away the wall of what may have been merely a police siren sounded balefully like the howl of a werewolf, and along Broadway the lights on the theatre canopies seemed to dance a macabre rigadoon.

LATONIA, Ky., May 23. -- Rushaway, son of Haste and Roseway, made track history today by winning the $15,000 added Latonia Derby before a crowd of 18,000 spectators, twenty-four hours after capturing the $12,000 added Illinois Derby.

VIENNA, May 23. -- So far no fireworks have followed the return from Italy of Prince Ernst Ruediger von Starhemberg, the deposed Vice Chancellor. He has made no move to substantiate his statement on leaving Austria that on his return a real battle for fascism would begin.

Leaders of the teaching profession in New York paid tribute yesterday to Jacob Theobald, recentlyappointed Assistant Superintendent of Schools, at a testimonial luncheon in his honor at the Hotel Biltmore. The luncheon, attended by 400 teachers and representatives of the Board of Education, was tendered by his former associates at the Robert E. Simon Junior High School, where he formerly was principal.

The Philharmonic-Symphony Society has granted permission to Hans Lange, one of the staff conductors of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra for several seasons, to fill engagements as guest conductor of leading orchestras this Summer and next season.

THE flotilla of private motor-boats commuting to Manhattan is expanding again. In the boom days of 1929 it numbered about 100. By 1932 it had dwindled to 15 or so. Now so many are being launched that this Summer's flotilla will number forty or fifty -- a sign, yachtsmen figure, of better times.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP). -- The House old-age pension investigating committee was still deadlocked tonight over whether Dr. Francis E. Townsend should be tried for contempt before the bar of the House or in Federal court.

Presentation of awards of honor to outstanding poets of the nation and State will feature the initial program of national poetry week, scheduled for 7 o'clock this evening in the Rainbow Room at Rockefeller Center. Miss Anita Browne, founder and organizer of poetry week, will preside and make the announcements of the medal and emblem winners.
CAIRO, May 23. -- The Robert Mond expedition of the Egypt Exploration Society has just announced the results of the season's excavations at Erment in Upper Egypt.

LONDON, May 22. -- King Edward visited the Chelsea flower show this week and expressed keen interest. He has now become a first-rate amateur gardener in his country home, Fort Belvedere, where he spends most of his week-ends. Recently he has paid week-end visits to the Earl of Dudley at Himley and to the Duke and Duchess of Sutherland at Sutton Place.

Fordham University will confer about 1,000 degrees in course to students in its various schools, five honorary degrees and three Fordham Gold Jubilee medals at its commencement exercises to be held the week of June 7.

WASHINGTON, May 23. -- The machinery by which bonus bonds will be distributed to veterans next month through the Postoffice Department was described by the department today. It was also announced that Postmaster General Farley would describe the distribution system and "deliver a special message to veterans" over a national hook-up on June 13.

FRANCE once again moves in an atmosphere of crisis. She stands guard over an old civilization, yet her own future remains uncertain. Only one thing now appears relatively sure -- that in the months ahead the Third Republic will be guided by Leon Blum, leader of the Socialist party.

Beginning tomorrow morning the Bureau of Motor Vehicles will open ten additional branches in the city for the renewal of automobile driving licenses. This will make a total of fifteen offices at which the new permits may be obtained.

AN oddly old-fashioned atmosphere pervades this slim and uneven first novel, a tale recounting the cruel early vicissitudes suffered from the illegitimacy of his birth, in the Eighteen Eighties, by sensitive, idealistic Edmond, until, many years after, through his heroic efforts, he transcends the stigma and becomes a famous man.

THE New Friends of Music, Inc., an organization formed recently to devote itself to the presentation of cycles of chamber music and lieder, will give sixteen late Sunday afternoon concerts in the Town Hall next season, starting Nov. 8. There will be eight Beethoven programs and as many given over to works by Brahms.
AN exhibition of recent additions to the Print Collection of the New York Public Library has been installed in the Print Rooms of that institution to remain through October.

Franklin K. Lane High and New Utrecht High captured the Section 2 and 1 Brooklyn and Queens Division P.S.A.L. handball titles as competition in those groups came to a close at James Madison High School yesterday. Lane defeated Richmond Hill, 3 -- 2, for its sixth victory in as many starts, while Utrecht halted Brooklyn Tech, 5 -- 0, for its eighth consecutive success.

PORTSMOUTH, Ohio, May 23 (AP). -- The strike at the Portsmouth works of the Wheeling Steel Corporation, involving a possible test of the Wagner Labor Disputes Act, was facing tonight a Federal labor conciliator's inquiry.

IN a campaign designed to reduce the number of automobile fatalities along the country's highways, the American Red Cross has made noteworthy progress. Already there are 250 first-aid stations in operation. Sites have been selected and personnel is in training for 1,517 additional stations.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP). -- A Supreme Court test of the powers of Secretary Roper and his subordinates of the Department of Commerce to control steamship lines engaged in foreign commerce was forecast today in a suit filed by the Isbrandtsen-Moller Company.

READING, Pa., May 23. -- Arriving late at the dinner given in his honor tonight by the Berks County Young Republican organization, Governor Hoffman of New Jersey found that invitations to attend had been ignored by most of the major State officials of the party in Pennsylvania.

PITTSFIELD, Mass. -- Memorial Day programs of wide diversity have been arranged by the various Berkshire clubs. At Williamstown, Amherst and Williams Colleges will meet in a "crucial" baseball game. Of the 144 games played between these two colleges since 1859 each has won seventy-two.

A NEW floating room -- the only acoustically perfect room in the world, according to John Paul Livadary, chief sound technician for Columbia Pictures -- was used in the direct recording of the Fritz Kreisler music sung by Grace Moore in "The King Steps Out," which will follow "Show Boat" at the Music Hall.

OF the many slips that the garden beginner unwittingly makes, none is more frequent, nor more serious in its results, than that of neglecting to do "thinning out" on time. The grower of vegetables learns from experience that he must thin promptly and thoroughly if satisfactory results are to be expected.

CHICAGO, May 23. -- General liquidation in May wheat was under way today on the Board of Trade, with longs selling both outright and to close spread with July, while cash interests and those who were short May and long July did the reverse.

President ROOSEVELT made it clear last week that despite the situation created by another decision of the Supreme Court adverse to the New Deal there remain only two measures on which the Administration will insist that Congress act before adjournment. One of these is the Tax Bill and the other the Relief Bill.

Gratified at the recognition of their record implied in the invitation, twelve clubs functioning under the Nassau County Home Bureau are preparing one of the eight State exhibits that will be a part of the program of the triennial of the Country Women of the World at Washington next week.

Supreme Court Justice Burt J. Humphrey directed yesterday in Brooklyn, on the application of theTitle Guarantee and Trust Company, that a suit for $1,010,541 brought against the company byState Superintendent of Insurance Louis H. Pink as rehabilitator of the Bond and Mortgage Guarantee Company be stricken from the equity calendar.

SYDNEY. YOU may not choose your own milkman in Auckland, New Zealand. It's against the law! Only the Milk Council, which supervises all milk distribution, has the right to name your milkman, and if you have a complaint against him, or the milk he delivers, it is no use firing him.

HANOVER, N.H., May 23. -- Dartmouth pulled a sensation baseball game out of the fire today, shading Williams 11 -- 10 behind the superb relief pitching of Captain Ted Olson, who shut out the visitors with two hits in the last five innings.

WASHINGTON, May 23. -- Conferees of the Senate and House reached an agreement today on the $525,000,000 Naval Appropriation Bill, the largest expenditure for the naval establishment ever recorded in peace time.

WASHINGTON, May 23. -- In its adjudication of the constitutionality of the New Deal the Supreme Court of the United States again and again has emphasized the fundamental concept embodied in the Constitution of dual sovereignty -- the principle established by that document of the division of authority between the national and State governments.
ROME, May 22. -- The program of road construction in Ethiopia announced recently marks the beginning of Italy's effort to colonize her newest and most valuable foreign possession.

JERUSALEM, May 23. -- A huge demonstration of Arabs at Tulkarem was fired upon by troops today. One Arab was killed and several were wounded. The demonstrators smashed windows and doors of houses of British officials. Three arrests were made.

The July delivery was strong on the Cotton Exchange yesterday, advancing 5 points, compared with unchanged quotations for the January. Covering demand absorbed contracts and increased the July premium to 102 points above October, which delivery rose to a 7-point premium over January.

Although agreeing with cotton goods executives that the higher tariff imposed last week on imported cotton fabrics is not a solution of the problem, manufacturers in other lines of industry who have suffered from Japanese competition felt that some progress was made toward an alleviation of their troubles.

Plans for Senior Week at Manhattan College and the election of Vincent P. Reilly of Brooklyn as chairman of pre-commencement activities was announced yesterday by John J. Kean, president of the class of 1936.

GAINS in retail trade over a year ago were reported by most sections of the country for the week with the exception of the Pacific Coast. The increases ranged up to 25 per cent, which was reported for the Chicago area. Local stores found volume running about 15 per cent ahead, with some gains double that figure.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 23. -- Cornell's varsity crew put the signature today on a handsome marine painting that formed a highly successful Spring Day regatta. Rowing well and with beautifully controlled strength, the big varsity defeated Harvard by about two and a quarter lengths with Syracuse in third place a length and three-quarters back of the Crimson.

THOUGH review copies of the records have not reached us, it is impossible to let another week go by without noting the reappearance in the lists, after an interval of something in the neighborhood of seven years, of the name of Arturo Toscanini -- coupled with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra.

Apparently the sort of team which can do such things with amazing facility, the Giants staged another grand form upheaval at the Polo Grounds yesterday and forthwith put on a performance that was most delightful to a gathering of 14,000, though very upsetting to the Phillies.
