A telegram replying to an attack by Homer L. Chaillaux, head of the National Americanism Committee of the American Legion, was sent yesterday to Ray Murphy, national commander, by C. LeRoy Baldridge, who wrote the booklet on Americanism over which a censorship fight in the Legion has developed.

OMAHA, Neb., May 22. -- Monetary inflation schemes incubate easily in the farm States of the Middle West. Sometimes it has seemed as though the Missouri River must carry as much economic theory as it does silt in suspension, and this is a plenty.

CHICAGO, May 23 (AP). -- The White Sox beat the Browns, 8 to 3, today in the first game of a double header, but not only dropped the second game, 5 to 1, but lost the services of Outfielder Dixie Walker for at least a month.

DETROIT, May 23 (AP). -- Stand Pat, E.F. Seagram's big chestnut horse, galloped to an easy victory today in the $5,000 Wolverine Handicap, feature race of the opening-day program at the Fair Grounds track.

The United Shoe Machinery Corporation of New Jersey and the United Shoe Machinery Corporation of Maine reported yesterday for the year ended on Feb. 29 a net income of $10,267,642, after Federal taxes and other charges. Allowing for dividend requirements on the 6 per cent preferred stock, the income is equivalent to $4.28 each on 2,290,938 shares of $25-par common, excluding 38,651 shares held in the treasury.

PITTSBURGH, May 23. -- Declaring "officially and authoritatively" that the Supreme Court's decision in the Guffey Coal Act "has no effect whatever on the Wagner Labor Act," Chairman J. Warren Madden today foreshadowed the line of defense to be followed by the government in defending the Labor Relations Law.

IN the temporary galleries at 62 West Fifty-third Street the Municipal Art Committee opened last week its eighth group exhibition, which will continue until June 7. All of the work this time is confined to oil, except that in the rooms on the top floor, which represents various graphic media -- lithography, etching, drypoint and woodcut.

DURING the first big week-end exodus from the city on Memorial Day, accessories of raffia are almost sure to appear, for this material, is demonstrating its smartness and versatility this year. Now used to make bags, belts, visors and headbands, raffia began its 1936 career in comparative modesty at the Southern resorts during the Winter.

In the safety competition being conducted by the Police Department among the patrol, traffic and motorcycle precincts of the city, accident records play an important part. In the table, below, the April records of the three precincts in each borough, except Richmond, having the fewest and the most accidents are given. The standing of all the precincts in Richmond is included. The figures in parentheses following the April figures are those for March.

PITTSBURGH, May 22. -- Although there is considerable gloom in the soft coal fields of Western Pennsylvania over the invalidation of the Guffey-Snyder coal control plan, there is not the feverish anxiety which marked the interval between the ending of NRA in May of last year and the establishment last Fall of the modified substitute in the coal industry.

LORINE PRUETTE, who has written some serious books about psychologists, women workers and parents, displays a pleasingly facile touch in her first light novel. She writes in an amusing, knowing and sympathetic style.

WASHINGTON, May 23. -- Opposition to international agreements for currency stabilization was voiced tonight by Professor James Harvey Rogers of Yale University, former currency adviser to President Roosevelt, who contended in an address before the Academy of World Economics that instead, "continued intelligent management of the dollar on gold" was necessary.

MAJOR domestic airlines will have complete installation of de-icing equipment completed this Summer. The methods of breaking ice formations, which deform the shape of wings, tail surfaces and propellers and throttle the flow of fuel to the carburetors, find their chief usefulness, of course, in Winter, but, with altitude and certain conditions of humidity in the air, planes "ice-up" also when the weather on the ground is warm.

WHIMSICAL, pixy humor is often the avocation of serious-minded men engaged in the dryest and most ponderous of tasks. "Alice in Wonderland" was born in the brain of an Oxford professor of mathematics, and Stephen Leacock, also a teacher who writes about serious subjects -- economics and sociology -- finds time to cheer the lighter side of the world with his amusing frivolities.

Striking service employes of the Polyclinic Hospital, 345 West Fiftieth Street, resumed picketing yesterday afternoon with approximately 175 men and women, bearing placards and banners, in line.Two patrolmen at each entrance of the hospital dispersed a crowd of about 500 who were attracted by the pickets at 3 o'clock.

Reflecting a reversal in trend since the preceding week, the volume of announcements of bonds called for redemption before maturity increased last week. It was the first upturn in three weeks. The calls, however, were for small amounts of miscellaneous bonds for retirement in future months, no additions being made for May.

ONE of the world's most distinguished amateur asstronomers" is Dr. Harlow Shapley's high opinion of 32-year-old Leslie C. Peltier of Delphos, Ohio. Peltier is a draftsman (not a garage mechanic, as the newspapers had it) whose nights are spent in studying the sky with a small telescope.

For the first time since Yale broke through the circle of California supremacy in 1924, an Eastern college will win the championship of the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. when the sixtieth annual title games of the organization are staged on Friday and Saturday at Franklin Field in Philadelphia.

Leon Blum, wealthy leader of the Unified Socialists, who is due to become the Popular Front Premier of France when the new Parliament meets within a fortnight, makes it plain that the keystone of his foreign policy will be cooperation with Great Britain. That means he intends to continue the French policy of going along with London in the hope of building a solid Franco-British entente against any German effort at expansion.
STRASBOURG, France, May 28. -- The German-language newspaper Elsaesser said today 150,000 German workers were rushing two lines of fortifications to completion in the Rhineland.

Mayor La Guardia appointed yesterday a committee of sixty-five, with Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler as chairman and Samuel Seabury as vice chairman, to go down the bay and welcome the Queen Mary when the British liner arrives here June 1 on her maiden voyage.

That Mr. Pach has made a long and serious study of the art of Vin cent Van Gogh, this small though meaty volume is equipped to demonstrate. We have here a study of the artist and his work approached, as the subtitle states, "in relation to his times."

AMISCELLANY is apt to be more various than agreeable, especially when it covers the author's miscellanea from his twenty-fourth to his fifty-sixth year, but Mr. Forster's is all order and coherence. He has made a pleasant rearrangement of himself, not by chronology but by consistency of idea and feeling.

The prologue of this book tells of a murder in Ireland which is undetected, and several of the early chapters deal with events in England many years later. What happens later in a British colony in Africa is the direct consequence of all that has gone before.

PHILADELPHIA, May 22. -- The action of the Brotherhood of Transportation Workers a few days ago in suspending its militant leader, Frank P. McGlone, and ordering him on trial for "conduct unbecoming an officer and member of the union," has provoked wide interest in labor groups.

THIRTY truckloads of dirt and debris were removed last Fall by tree surgeons from the famous 800-year-old live oak in the Bellingrath Gardens, one of the recognized beauty spots of the South, twenty-odd miles from Mobile, Ala.

Lynn Riggs is one of the mystery men of the theatre. Some years ago his "Green Grow the Lilacs" created a considerable furor, while "Roadside" failed. His works since then have been seen mainly in the little theatres or their opposite home, the screen, while Mr. Riggs himself, has commuted between Hollywood and Santa Fe, N.M.
Reading The Reading Company reported an increase in net operating income in April. Its statement follows:

EIGHTY-ONE years ago during the Crimean War the British ship Black Prince floundered in the Black Sea near Sebastopol. For years a rumor persisted that she had carried a fortune in gold with her to Davy Jones's locker. Then in 1923 the Soviet Government, in desperate need of cash, attempted to raise the ship from its grave 240 feet below the waterline.

Dodie Smith can fashion an excellent, good-humored and sunny comedy. A few seasons ago it was "Autumn Crocus," and now it is "Call It a Day." Nothing much happens in the households which Miss Smith makes her own, it is not necessary that much should; for it is mainly on the stage that families are always turbulent and aroused.

Despite a triple triumph by Louis Black, weight man, his third in as many weeks, City College's varsity track and field team had its winning streak snapped by Fordham at Lewisohn Stadium yesterday, the Maroon gaining a 70-to-56 victory after a keenly contested dual meet.

The Guffey decision, following the NRA and AAA Supreme Court rulings, indicates that industry should attempt to solve the problem of unfair practices and competition by utilizing uniform State legislation, fortified by Congressional approval, Sol A. Herzog, counsel to several associations and a member of the Consumer Goods Industries Committee, said here yesterday.
GORHAM, N.H., May 23 (AP). -- Miss Grace M. Sturgess, 24, a librarian at Williams College, Williamstown, Mass., died today in an ice slide while skiing in Tuckerman's ravine on Mount Washington.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 23. -- Westchester society will attend on Monday the first charity garden fete of the season when the New Rochelle branch of the National Plant, Flower and Fruit Guild entertains at Grey-Dawn, the New Rochelle home of Mr. and Mrs. Oliver David Donaldson.
The specific acts of wrongdoing which the special grand jury charged against District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan as a basis for his removal were revealed yesterday.

THIS is a tale of collaborators. So many, in fact, that they were too numerous to list in the usual program credits, even if they wished to be listed. But their collective effort was so successful that it should not go unsung. "Graham Jones" may be a good pseudonym, but it covers too many persons.

A LONG the Gulf Coast of Mississippi with its pines and cypress swamps and high-growing palmettos, there lives a people whose ways are crude and shiftless. Descendants of a sturdlergeneration of pioneers, their stock has degenerated from fever and inbreeding, and the life which they lead is lazy and curiously isolated.

Foreclosures of residential properties in New York State this year will be practically 50 per cent less than the number recorded for 1935, declares Roy H. Bassett, vice president of the New York State League of Savings and Loan Associations.

HOLLYWOOD. INSTEAD of lamenting its sad plight, the theatre ought to awaken, read some Hollywood publicity, study a few studio press books and by the calcium light of the projection machine find its way back to prosperity.

THAT perennial question, "Have we an American art?" has been brought to the surface once more by the current exhibition being held at Rockefeller Center under the auspices of the Mayor of the City of New York and the Municipal Art Committee -- an exhibition to which the artists of every American State and possession have been invited to contribute.

MAILAMM, the American Palestine Music Association, is gathering works of Jewish nature and idiom, which will be sent to Palestine to be performed in concert and broadcast there. The works desired include chamber music, instrumental solos, and songs based on Hebrew texts.

LIBLAR, Germany, May 23. -- The Carl Schurz Society of Berlin observed its tenth anniversary today by making a pilgrimage to this Rhineland town, Schurz's birthplace, where a large group of government officials, representatives of the National Socialist party and members of the Cologne and Bonn University faculties participated in ceremonies commemorating the German-American statesman and political leader.

IT would seem that women are expected to take their sun baths in moderated doses this Summer. The designers have made provision for them to get under cover whenever they like. Coats accompany a big majority of the bathing suits, and beach hats are huge.
Several beach clubs will be opened the coming week-end, the inaugural festivities traditionally centering on Memorial Day. An active season of sports and entertaining is forecast.

PARIS, May 23 (AP). -- The play "Hitler," dramatized largely from a suppressed newspaper account of the German Chancellor's "love life," was banned tonight by the Minister of the Interior, acting "in accord with the Minister of Education."
With vacation time near, plans are being made for a greatly expanded program of school playgrounds, play schools and day camps in the parks for thousands of city-confined children.

Hordes of anglers from all parts of the East are descending on Maine these days. There are two reasons for the influx of sportsmen into the Pine Tree State in the Spring, namely, the landlocked salmon and the square-tailed trout.

While diplomats scurry around Europe to discuss limitations in armament, with special emphasis on military aviation, an intense international air struggle goes on almost unheeded. That struggle is the race for leadership on the new air trade routes of the world.
WORCESTER, Mass., May 23. -- I After winning thirteen straight games Holy Cross bowed to Providence College today, 3 -- 2, before a crowd of 4,000.

VIENNA, May 23. -- A group of twenty Nazis last night attempted to enter the Waxenberg Castle of Prince Ernst von Starhemberg, his Upper Austrian residence, in order to seize arms for their illegal organizations. Local gendarmerie were warned presumably by a Nazi traitor.

No one can envy the men who have to put together the platform of either the Republican or the Democratic party this year. The job will require carpentry almost to the point of high art. For both parties, in their declaration of principles, will have to put together opposites, and to assume a unity of ideals and purposes which does not exist.

MANILA. -- The question of Japanese penetration, brought sharply to a head by President Quezon's personal investigation of Japanese landholdings in the Province of Davao, now looms as the possibly deciding factor in the economic and political future of the Philippines.

The four Schechter brothers, poultry dealers, who successfully contested the validity of the National Industrial Recovery Act, will not celebrate on Wednesday the first anniversary of the Supreme Court decision in their favor.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 23. -- Woodfellow, a brown gelding from the stables of Miss Helen Bedford of Greenwich, Conn., was judged the champion hunter of the horse show which came to an end today on the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Norman P. Rood, six miles from Wilmington.

More than fifty real estate firms have been in business in Manhattan for forty-five years or more, and of these more than twenty have passed the sixty-year mark and six are eligible for the Century Club, an organization of business concerns 100 years old or more, according to William J. Brede of the Rieser-Brede Realty Relations Service.

After a slumbering, quiet Winter, alone, neglected and forgotten in its solitude, the most amazing and most popular of all the cruise rendezvous on New York's metropolitan waterways is now bestirring itself, taking a new lease on life and emerging in all its beauty, like a prim spinster tidying her cottage for Sunday afternoon callers.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., May 23. -- Almost 300 persons attended the garden party given this afternoon at Burrwood, the estate of Mrs. Walter Jennings, overlooking Cold Spring Harbor, for the benefit of the auxiliary to the Episcopal Church of Long Island.

CANBERRA, Australia, May 22. -- Since the World War there has been little evidence of military-mindedness in Australia. The peace establishment has fallen to 55,000 for the defense of the Continent of Australia. The Labor party's abolition of compulsory training several years ago is partly the cause of the condition, but lack of enthusiasm for the soldier's life is the main reason.

Petitions for an amendment to the sidewalk canopy ordinance to permit maintenance of such canopies in residence zones at all hours instead of only in inclement weather, as now specified, have been presented to Building Commissioner Samuel Fassler and to the Board of Aldermen by the First Avenue Association and the Washington Square Association.

A LITTLE more than a year ago the bodies of two unknown men were found on the black lava sands of an uninhabited island off the coast of Ecuador, and the long-drawn-out "mystery of Galapagos" became front-page news all over the world.

NOW that a Federal Court of Appeals has declared the Resettlement Administration unconstitutional, Hollywood may claim further justification for its refusal to assist in the distribution of the RA's three-reeler, "The Plow That Broke the Plains."

As WPA workers readied up the halls last week for the impending conventions (Republican: Cleveland, June 9; Democratic: Philadelphia, June 23), the nation's quadrennial concern about things political was quickened by various happenings.

THE entente, never cordial, between Fort Worth and Dallas, two of the loveliest villages of the Texas plains, has been all but dissipated by the decision of these civic duelists to hold simultaneous shindies to commemorate the hundredth anniversary of San Jacinto and the freedom wrenched from that dark and bloody fray.

Inspired by President Roosevelt's tax message of June 19, 1935, a tired Congress set itself to the task of preparing and enacting what proved to be the Revenue Act of 1935. In the main its provisions were made effective as to taxable periods beginning after Dec. 31, 1935.

The Fordham baseball forces went into a tailspin yesterday, turned in their saddest exhibition of the year before an enthusiastic alumni day crowd of 4,000 and bowed to Boston College, 12 to 2, for their second defeat of the year.

MOSCOW, May 23. -- Defeating A. Lilienthal of Hungary in an eight-round game lasting two sessions and fifty-four moves, Jose R. Capablanca of Cuba increased his lead in the international chess masters tournament tonight. The former world champion now is 1 1/2 points ahead of M. Botwinnik and V. Ragosin, two of the Soviet representatives, tied for second place.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 23. -- Those who disregard their political pledges after election were assailed today by Leslie G. McDouall of Newark, president of the New Jersey Bankers Association, as he called upon members of the association in convention here to take the lead in campaigning for reduction of taxes.

RIO DE JAINERO, May 23 (AP). -- Germany and Brazil have virtually agreed to exchange $46,000,000 worth of products manufactured or raised in the two nations, members of the Federal Council of Foreign Commerce said today.

An addition to the real estate study courses to be held this Summer, as in former years, under the auspices of the National Association of Real Estate Boards will be a course on property management. All of these courses will be conducted by the school of business of the University of Chicago in cooperation with various divisions of the national organization.

BUENOS AIRES, May 22. -- The recently terminated Chaco War is rapidly producing an aftermath of vast and radical social and political consequences. The establishment of a military dictatorship in Bolivia this week followed close upon an identical seizure of governing power by the Paraguayan Army three months ago.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., May 23. -- Alan C. Dodson of this city was elected secretary-treasurer of the Bach Choir this afternoon at the close of the first session of the annual festival. Mr. Dodson succeeds Dr. Francis J. Dever, who resigned some time ago.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., May 23. -- The Bach festival in Bethlehem was brought to a close with the twenty-ninth presentation of the Mass in B minor this afternoon. Packer Memorial Chapel of Lehigh University was filled to capacity for the performance of this mightiest of all choral works, which the Bach Choir first presented thirty-five years ago, under its late conductor, Dr. J. Fred Wolle.

From Rome last week came a few figures on what it costs to win a colonial war in the fourth decade of the twentieth century. The outlay for the war against Ethiopia, according to reports from the Italian capital, was $1,000,000,000. How it was paid or will be paid nobody knows.
CINCINNATI, May 23 (AP). -- Cy Blanton delivered one pitch today and lost a ball game.
WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP). -- The New Deal is bigger by thirteen Congressional directory pages than it was this time last year.

ST. LOUIS, May 28. -- The possibility of the proposed merger of the Disciples of Christ, known as the Christian Church, and the Northern Baptist Convention appeared remote today as the general council of the latter organization asked a committee to confer informally with the Rev. Dr. George A. Campbell, pastor of the Union Avenue Christian Church here, who made a plea for merger Thursday.

The return of home relief clients to private employment reached a high point for the year in April when 4,648 relief recipients left the ERB rolls for outside jobs, Miss Charlotte E. Carr, executive director of the bureau, reported yesterday.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, May 23. -- Heartened by the British sweep in the women's championship at Southport, John Bull expects his men to make equally short work of the overseas invaders in the men's national amateur tournament starting Monday.

The Dance Congress and Festival presented last night as the fifth program in its week's schedule at the Theresa L. Kaufmann Auditorium of the Y.M.H.A. an evening of modern dances. This was the second program devoted to this medium.

The United States Fleet -- 40,000 officers and men, 157 fighting ships, 450 planes -- is completing this weekend, in the tropical waters of the Eastern Pacific, the major phases of "Fleet Problem XVII."

IT is not often that a new dramatic form is introduced into America by a high school boy or via school graduation exercises. But a symphonic folk drama in free verse, which is to grace the class day of Ottawa Hills High School of Grand Rapids, Mich., on May 27, is believed to be the first offering by an American author to make use of choric speech.

Retail volume continued at a good pace last week, with satisfactory gains shown in apparel sales, according to a report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers. A large number of reorders were received for cotton dresses.

Due to the public interest aroused in its Better Housing Exposition, building permits showed a marked increase for April over previous months in Huntington, L.I., Mercer W. Sweeney, executive manager of the Huntington Better Housing Committee, told members of the Long Island Real Estate Board at a meeting in the Hotel Huntington last week.

Under the stimulus of favorable weather conditions, retail trade in the metropolitan area extended its gains last week. Leading department stores showed average sales increases over last year of 14 to 15 per cent, according to estimates by executives.

Seventy-one golfers, among them Mrs. Jonathan Thorne, the defending champion, will begin play tomorrow in the annual women's metropolitan title tournament at the Seawane Club. Play will continue until Saturday.

Flagging interest in cadet training for the Army Air Corps was indicated by the army authorities here yesterday. In the last class that entered the primary flying school on March 1 there were only sixy cadets, instead of the authorized 150.
ST. LOUIS, May 23. -- Outhit but not outtalked, Manager Frank Frisch and his league-leading Cardinals lost a 7-to-2 decision today to the Chicago Cubs and Umpire Babe Pinelli.

DETROIT, May 23. -- Night riders of the Black Legion, terroristic secret society, may have killed scores of persons opposed to their fanatical cult, officials here said tonight as Prosecutor Duncan C. McCrea continued to probe the murder of Charles A. Poole, 32-year-old WPA worker, whose body was found the night of May 13 on a lonely suburban road.

As program chairman of the College Women's Club of Montclair, Miss Anne Coe Mitchell will havecharge of the silver jubilee celebration planned for tomorrow as a garden fete at the home of Mrs. Frederick Pleasants of Upper Montclair. Mrs. Chauncey Hunter Marsh will direct a review incorporating music and dancing in costume by members of the club, depicting the events of the group's first quarter century of existence.
TOKYO, Sunday, May 24. -- The end of the three-week special session of the Diet, scheduled for today, has been delayed by opposition to the Seditious Documents Bill.

Propinquity is the faithful prop of writers of romances. But Ruby M. Ayres takes the opposite slant. In her new novel the man and the girl have been such good comrades and constant companions that it never occurred to them to fall in love.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., May 22. -- Dr. Ralph W. McDonald, 33-year-old college professor, believed by some to be the leading contender for the Democratic nomination for Governor of North Carolina, has thrown the biggest scare into the old-line Democrats that they have experienced since control of the State was wrested from the Republican party in 1898.

ROME, May 23 (AP). -- Pope Pius, who will observe his seventy-ninth birthday anniversary next Sunday, left the Vatican today to inaugurate the Church's new central government building in the Trastevere quarter of Rome.

S.N. Behrman is one of the most amiable of present-day American playwrights. His people are real, they are not simply chance acquaintances met casually at midnight parties. They are educated, frank and tolerant of the other opinion in any disputed matter.

HAIFA, Palestine, May 23. -- Haile Selassie sailed for England aboard the British cruiser Capetown tonight after he had spent a fortnight in Jerusalem recuperating from the mental and physical strain of his disastrous struggle against the Italian invaders of Ethiopia.
BARTOW, Fla., May 23. -- A jury of six men today convicted five former Tampa policemen of kidnapping Eugene F. Poulnot in Tampa Nov. 30.

MR. JOSEPH WARREN BEACH, Professor of English at the University of Minnesota, must have gone to infinite pains to produce a volume so comprehensive in its treatment of a single phase of poetical activity.
GLENS FALLS, N.Y., May 23. -- State Senator George R. Fearon of Onondaga declared today that he was "willing" to accept the Republican nomination for Governor if it were offered to him.

TRENTON, N.J., May 23. -- Although Governor Harold G. Hoffman was elected last Tuesday as adelegate at large to the Republican National Convention, the fact that he finished thousands of votes behind his three running-mate, is viewed by political observers as a defeat that seems likely to relegate him to a minor role in party affairs.

A two-room suite in the Waldorf-Astoria Towers, for which he paid $250 a month, was the headquarters from which Charles (Lucky Luciano) Lucania directed activities of the vice ring he allegedly organized, according to the situation portrayed yesterday by Thomas E. Dewey, Special Prosecutor.

A gift of $10,000 from Mr. and Mrs. George F. Baker headed a list of contributions to the Citizens Family Welfare Committee, made public yesterday by Laurence M. Marks, chairman of the committee in its effort to raise $1,500,000 for private welfare agencies here.

WASHINGTON, May 23. -- In its further quest for provisions to increase the capacity of its compromise tax program, the Senate Finance Committee indicated today that it might turn to estate and gift taxes for another $40,000,000 or $50,000,000 to meet President Roosevelt's revenue demands.

A survey of mortgage conditions today shows, points out Thomas G. Grace, New York State FHA director, that it has required little more than one year for the home mortgage lending business of the country to undergo some radical changes.

Twenty-three major Eastern railroads, banded together in resistance against passenger fare reductions, carried their fight before a United States statutory court yesterday, assailing as unconstitutional an Interstate Commerce Commission order reducing coach fares to 2 cents a mile and Pullman to 3 cents a mile without surcharges.

A special Brooklyn grand jury, investigating to determine why the April, 1935, grand jury failed to indict the killers of Samuel Drukman, garage bookkeeper, brought an indictment last week against eight persons for conspiring to protect the killers by bribery.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- Afloat and ashore, officers and men of the United States Navy will be well supplied this year with reading matter. In addition to the well-stocked libraries in the navy yards and shore stations, nearly every ship at sea, from the super-dreadnaughts to the small mine sweepers, gunboats and other auxiliaries, carries its quota of novels, biographies, and technical books of interest to seafaring men.

Reductions in some Pullman charges are to be made on June 1, D.A. Crawford, president of thePullman Company, announced yesterday. In compliance with an order by the Interstate CommerceCommission the railroads are to cut the rate for tickets good in coaches to 2 cents a mile and for tickets good in Pullmans to 3 cents and eliminate the surcharge on that date.

With a clean sweep in four of the fourteen events, New York University's track and field team brought to a close its dual season yesterday, defeating Rutgers, 74 to 52, at Ohio Field. The pole vault, javelin, broad jump and quarter-mile events were dominated by Violet athletes.

ART patrons and barflies will be familiar with Remington Schuyler's dainty exposition on canvas of "Custer's Last Stand." For many years, along with muscular rotos of the mighty John L., it represented the only intrusion of art into the prosy sanctuaries of whistle-wetting. "

1,000 TIMES: For the thousandth time last Monday night, Cyrano de Bergerac, as played by Walter Hampden, gasconaded across the stage, fenced to the cadence of his impromptu rhymes, challenged those who stared at his awesome nose, suffered for his love of Roxanne, and died gallantly, with his white plume unblemished.

BERLIN, May 23. -- In a world full of strife, distress and uncertainty, Germany is likely to appear to the casual tourist these days as a haven of peace, progress and prosperity. To all outward appearances the Germans are fairly bursting with new vigor and, according to National Socialist assurances, they are sitting on top of the world.

WASHINGTON, May 23. -- Too many high school and vocational students are studying shorthand typewriting and bookkeeping and too few are studying salesmanship and trades, according to conclusions drawn from studies being made by the division of vocational education of the Office of Education.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., May 23. -- The only one among the leaders able to put together two consistent rounds on the final 36-hole stretch in the metropolitan open championship, Byron Nelson, youthful playing-pro at the Ridgewood Club in New Jersey, today added that illustrious title to his list of links achievements.

If a prolonged period of dullness is to be regarded as a good augury for a resumption of the advance in stock prices, there is some solace to be gained from last week's market. Trading on the week was the slowest in almost a year, following as it did several weeks of inactivity.
Housing properties in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn proved attractive to purchasers in deals announced yesterday.

BROCKPORT, N.Y., May 23. -- Three kisses and a sparkling crown were bestowed by Consul General W.P. Montjin of the Netherlands on the blue-eyed queen of the Western New York apple blossom festival here today.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 23. -- The Republican party is the choice of seniors at New Jersey College for Women, the annual senior questionnaire revealed today. Last year the graduating class selected the Republican party first and the Socialist party second.

WASHINGTON, May 23. -- James W. Carter, president of the Carter Coal Company, and the company itself, two of the victors in the Supreme Court decision on the Guffey act, today asked the court to make Attorney General Cummings and other government officers who were the defendants pay the costs of thelawsuit.
WALLINGFORD, Conn., May 23. -- A graduating class of 127, parents and faculty members and the fifth form joined in the annual Prize Day and commencement exercises of The Choate School today.

THE growing importance of the Pacific Coast region to the automobile industry is emphasized by the present trek of a group of high General Motors officials headed by President Alfred P. Sloan Jr. to California and the Pacific Northwest, where they are inspecting the corporation's properties.

CARLSBAD Caverns National Park in New Mexico is expecting more visitors this Summer than it ever has had before. Officials of the park base their prediction on two facts: first, the Texas Centennial Exposition will bring many people West, and, second, travel in general is increasing.

With the news that the Italian armies are definitely in possession of Addis Ababa, which means Ethiopia, the signal has been given for the opening of a new controversy. The Italians say thatEthiopia no longer exists as a nation, while the English and French and certain of the pro-League nations maintain that, wherever the archives of the Ethiopian Foreign Office are located, there is the government.

Although there were indications of some weak spots, business in general was steady in almost all sections of the country last week, with retail sales continuing to show substantial gains over the figures for the corresponding period last year.

THIS week a new voice of Neptune will speak to the ends of the earth from the Atlantic. To the public she will be known as "the Queen Mary"; to the radio man, ashore and afloat, merely by the ethereal cognomen GBTT, for that is the wireless call of the new queen of the sea.

DUBLIN, May 23. -- A scathing denunciation of the methods of the government of North Island is embodied in a report just issued by a Commission of Inquiry appointed by the British National Council for Civil Liberties. The report follows an investigation carried out by the commission in a six-county area during the past year.

By the grace of their arch-rivals, the Giants, the Dodgers left the diamond at Ebbets Field yesterday still clinging to seventh place, although efforts on their own behalf were hardly responsible for keeping them out of the cellar.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 23 (AP). -- The Bisons handed the Rochester Red Wings another beating today, 10 -- 6, before a bargain-day throng of 16,608 fans, and were able to continue battling on even terms with the Newark Bears for first place.
WASHINGTON, May 23. -- The administration is preparing for a vigorous election campaign, in which brain trusters and others who have been political targets will take the stump.
NANTUCKET, Mass., May 23. -- A letter from Governor James M. Curley to Judge George M. Poland, questioning the jurist concerning his physical fitness, landed in Judge Poland's wastebasket.

RUSNYA, a kingdom somewhere in Europe. A revolutionary flare-up. All the royal family murdered except the 16-year-old heroine, Princess Tania; a young person of astonishing loveliness and still more astonishing ignorance, who is saved by a handsome peasant lad.

PITTSBURGH, May 23. -- Twenty-seven bankers, department store executives, public utility executives, architects and contractors were dropped from the Better Traffic Committee by Mayor McNair today. He prepared a list of candidates to replace them and put the complete overhauling up to Traffic Inspector Al Florig, who said:

The annual memorial service of the Police Department, by which those killed in line of duty andthose who died in the World War are honored, was held yesterday in the corridors of headquarters. For the first time since the services were started eleven years ago, they were attended by the Mayor.
CLEVELAND, May 23 (AP). -- The Indians broke a six-game losing streak and stopped the Tiger's consecutive victories at eight by taking the wind-up of the season's first double-header today, 4 -- 3.

The training of citizens interested in municipal reform and good government was held to be the responsibility of civics teachers in the high schools at meetings yesterday in the Hotel Pennsylvania of the Association of Civics Teachers and the Association of Social Studies Teachers.

CAMDEN, N.J., May 23. -- A tall, curly-haired, collegiate-looking Yale senior, Paul B. Sawyer Jr., who plans to stay on at New Haven for three years of law school and continue racing motor boats every chance he gets, today surpassed in watermanship and skill most of the leading professional drivers and many of the amateurs of the country to win the Delaware River marathon, sixty-five miles long.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 23. -- Never less than 2 up after the third hole, T. Suffern (Tommy) Tailer of Piping Rock today took the thirtieth edition of the Garden City Golf Club invitation tournament with a 4 and 2 final round triumph over Jimmy Bobbins of Mount Kisco, former captain of Princeton University's linksmen.

THE wings of fear have spread above Europe. In the past year, since Stanley Baldwin announced that the British frontier was on the Rhine, coming events have cast ever more somber shadows before them. The march of the Old World's history has been a steady procession from alarm to alarm.

The inquiry into the murder of Samuel Drukman in a Williamsburg garage is beginning to stretch far beyond the outline which was sketched for it when Governor Lehman appointed a special prosecutor and a special term of the Supreme Court to investigate the killing and the failure to find and punish those guilty of it.

Greater opportunities exist today for the export of American apparel to foreign countries than for many years past, according to research by organizations aimed at stimulating the export of such merchandise. A survey by the Chamber of Commerce of the Apparel Industry, Inc., of which M.D. Mosessohn is chairman, calls attention to the possibilities of exporting both women's and men's apparel to European countries, the British Colonial possessions, South America and the Near East.

The Public Service Commission of this State has authorized the Brooklyn Edison Company, Inc., to issue not more than $55,000,000 of consolidated-mortgage 3 1/4 per cent bonds dated May 15, 1936, and due on May 15, 1966, the commission announced yesterday.

A ruling recently made by Judge Lewis of the municipal court in this city in deciding against the claims of a submetering company in supplying electrical current to a tenant is of such importance to companies furnishing electricity to occupants of large buildings that it will probably be carried to the highest court for final decision, states Samuel R. Schneider of the New York Bar.

ALBANY, May 23. -- Two bills by Senator Buckley, New York Democrat, which would have exempted judges, justices and official referees from personal income taxes up to Jan. 1, 1936, were vetoed today by Governor Lehman.

PHILADELPHIA, May 23. -- The Yankees took two slapstick ball games from the Athletics in their first double-header of the season at Shibe Park today under conditions that just fell short of developing into a riot. The McCarthymen annexed the opener, 12 to 6, and came back in the nightcap to gallop home, 15 to 1.

RYE, N.Y., May 23. -- Thousands of feet of canvas were raised today in ringing up the curtain of the Long Island Sound yachting championships. The season's opening regatta at the American Yacht Club attracted fifty-five craft. The corresponding event last year drew forty-eight.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 23. -- The Naval Academy will graduate a class of 263 on June 4. Twenty-fiveof the graduates will be commissioned second lieutenants in the Marine Corps and 219 will be commissioned as ensigns of the line in the navy.

RADIO'S stock-in-trade is sound in any form. Wherever there is noise the microphone may go, whether it be to the woodlands of England to pick up the call of the nightingale; to Niagara to pick up the thunder of mighty water or to Italy to electrify the roar of Vesuvius.
STOCKHOLM, N.J., May 28. -- August Ober, 45 years old, of West Orange, was drowned near here today after he had saved the life of his 9-year-old son, Detrich.
BERLIN, May 23. -- The Boerse continued strong today, with stocks relatively active, while bonds remained quiescent.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., May 23. -- On Memorial Day three varsity and three freshman teams of Williams College will meet opponents on the last big day of Spring athletics. Five of these teams will close their seasons that day, only the varsity baseball team having further contests.

FROM now until Labor Day the list of bridge tournaments will read something like a catalogue of Summer resorts. When the hot weather comes, most people prefer their serious bridge to be accompanied by a morning swim and an opportunity to lounge all day in white trousers or beach pajamas.

WHILE all the world is watching with interest the transportation experiment being carried on this Summer over the North Atlantic by the Hindenburg a comparatively small but very important group is intensely interested in one factor of that experiment.

THERE is nothing pretentious about "A House in Vienna." In effect it is a simple story about the things that happened to some of the inhabitants of Papa Hodl's boarding house in the Luftbadgasse, a shabbily genteel back street that had seen better days, on the occasion of the landlord's golden wedding.

ST. LOUIS, May 23. -- The usual seasonal slowing down in many lines is reported in the Eighth Federal Reserve District, but the recessions are by no means pronounced and, in some instances, are hardly apparent.

City College Post of the American Legion last night conducted its second annual contest to select the champion fife, drum and bugle corps of the city before 1,000 persons at Lewisohn Stadium. Members of the post, students and faculty members, including President Frederick B. Robinson, attended the entertainment.

CHICAGO, May 22. -- Governor Horner's call for a fourth special session of the Illinois General Assembly was virtually a proclamation of Democratic factional war. The primary fight is to be continued on the floor of the Senate and House.

Reporters in the corridor outside the room in which the Senate Finance Committee met last Thursday heard voices raised in anger. Inside, the members of the committee were debating the Tax Bill, with which they had been struggling for three weeks to the detriment of their tempers.
LONDON, May 23. -- The resignation of J.H. Thomas yesterday as Colonial Secretary in unprecedented circumstances overshadowed all other subjects of discussion throughout Britain today.

CHICAGO, May 23. -- Making a distinction between slang and new words in the American language was one problem before the University of Chicago scholars who for ten years have been working, and still are, on the new "Dictionary of American English."

INDIANAPOLIS, May 23 (AP). -- Fear, not of the hazardous turns but of the gasoline their motors might consume, governed drivers in qualifying trials today for the 500-mile automobile race to be run next Saturday.

An effort by white-collar WPA workers employed at Ellis Island to have their six-hour work day include the time spent on Ellis Island ferryboats has been settled by discussion with Commissioner of Immigration Rudolph Reimer, it was announced yesterday.

ACCORDING to the busy wireless, His Excellency, Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels of Germany, has recently issued an order forbidding newspapers to publish criticism of new plays on the morning after the opening performance. Criticisms published so soon after the premiere Herr Goebbels considers "highly frivolous."

AT least six times in the course of a year the press reports the installation of some atom-smashing machine in a university laboratory. There are also tales of protons, positrons, alpha particles and neutrons -- all discovered as the result of atom-smashing. Nobel prizes are awarded to physicists whose interest in life is centered in the fragments of atoms that result from smashing.

ELSINORE, Denmark. WITH the restoration of the King's audience room, as well as the Queen's, in Kronborg Castle at Elsinore-on-the-Sound, this famous landmark immortalized by Shakespeare's "Hamlet" gains in vivid interest for the Summer traveler.

ALBANY, May 23 (AP). -- Ray Hofford, executive vice president of the Real Estate Association of New York State, said today that the 1936 Legislature passed twelve bills of State-wide interest to real estate. He added, however, that "most bills representing issues of major importance to real estate interests failed to pass."
PHILADELPHIA, May 23. -- Terraces and grounds of the Huntingdon Valley Country Club were festive tonight with Japanese lanterns, flowers and music when 200 guests danced at the June Fete Cabaret.

THE story of ocean flying has had a number of chapters. Many men of many nations and several types of aircraft have contributed. The Pacific is already crossed by flying boat schedules. So is the South Atlantic between Africa and South America, and Zeppelin service between Europe and the United States is started.

RECEPTION of American short-wave stations in Australia at this season is described as "excellent" by S.C. Rosier, radio editor of The West Australian, at Perth. He reports on the various stations as follows:

Before the World War it used to be said in China that the international competition took the form of diplomacy by banks and railways. To the media must now be added tariffs and currencies. These, too, have become weapons in the conflict for paramountcy in China, and as the conflict sharpens all weapons are being put to use.
LONDON, Sunday, May 24. -- May is England's most beautiful month in all the year and the coming week will be the most notable of all the four in it.
VIENNA, May 23. -- Restless guardsmen of Prince Ernst von Starhemberg's private army, the Heimwehr, gave Austria a taste of action -- and bullets -- today.

CHICAGO, May 23 (AP). -- Racing opened in Chicago today at the historic Hawthorne track and a Chicago-owned horse galloped off with the honors in the $5,000 Added Inaugural Handicap before 15,000 spectators.

BALTIMORE, May 23. -- Dr. Francis E. Townsend set out on a tour today of historic spots in Maryland and Pennsylvania, while his Baltimore headquarters, to which he returned after defying the Congressional investigation committee in Washington, was deluged with telegrams from enthusiastic supporters in New England, the West and South, urging him to "stand pat."

Carretinas, or rolling refreshment stands, which have been approved for use in the city parks this Summer, have been changed in such fashion that they will also dispense frankfurters, it was made known yesterday. Last Summer the rolling stands stocked only soft drinks, confections and cigarettes.

ANY one who has kept in touch with the general run of books during recent years will know by the title of this one what it is about, for there is only one "legion of hell" known to current literature. And about it there is no end to the making of books.

An increase of 631,608 passengers, or 0.90 per cent, for the subway division of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company in April, compared with the same month of 1935, was reported yesterday by Thomas E. Murray Jr., receiver, to the Federal Court here.

Nearly 200 girls from many parts of the country will be registered at the opening on Wednesday of Camp Edith Macy at Briarcliff, N.Y., the Girl Scout "university in the woods." The Summer will prove a banner season for Scout camp activities, according to Mrs. Paul Rittenhouse, director of the Girl Scouts, as there will be nearly 1,000 such centers in operation, each giving training courses for volunteer or professional leadership of girls.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 23. -- Led by Captain Milton Green, Norman Cahners, Bob Hall and Alex Northrop, Harvard scored one of its greatest track and field triumphs on Soldiers Field today, downing Yale by the record score of 91 to 44.

PARIS, May 21. -- The "Rallye Bacchus," or a progressive wine-tasting contest organized for the benefit of a children's charity by Princesse Achille Murat, was the pinnacle of the season. It was conducted like a treasure hunt, with relays at smart night clubs and houses of the couture, and ended with a ball at the famous Hotel de Rohan.

Behind the effective pitching of Joe Coppo, the St. John's University baseball team came back and evened its annual series with Long Island University by winning the second game, 7 to 4, at Dexter Park yesterday morning.

BERLIN, May 16. -- The male competitors in the coming Olympic Games at Berlin will live in truly splendid isolation. Throughout their period of residence here they will inhabit a made-to-order world -- a sort of Alice in Wonderland community twenty miles from the center of Berlin where their every wish will be instantly fulfilled.

OTTAWA, May 23 (Canadian Press). -- Lord Tweedsmuir, Governor General of Canada, disclosed last night his innate love of literature and for upward of an hour entertained a large audience here,attending a meeting of the Royal Society of Canada, with a lecture on Sir Walter Scott.
LONDON, May 22. -- There are nine openings next week, the material ranging from melodrama to farce and the schedule reading like this:

BOSTON, May 23. Reports from i all sections of New England indicate that retail trade is relatively very good. May so far has been an eminently satisfactory month for purveyors of nearly all classes of merchandise. Most wholesale lines l are active also, some of them doing [better than at this season in any year since 1930.

JAMES RUSSELL LOWELL said that reading Chaucer was like taking a walk in the morning air. "There is a pervading wholesomeness in the writings of this man, a vernal property that soothes and refreshes . . ."

A study course on housing, intended to emphasize the part pupils can play in improving livingconditions, has just been published by the housing section of the Welfare Council. It was prepared with the approval of the Board of Education, according to the council's housing committee, which hopes that the syllabus will find a place in high school social studies.

After a parade through East Side streets by representatives of several war veterans' posts, threetrees were dedicated yesterday afternoon in Union Square to soldiers of the Jewish, Protestant and Catholic faiths who died in action during the World War.

HAVANA, May 20. -- With the inauguration of President Miguel Mariano Gomez constitutional government is restored to Cuba, after nearly three years of provisional regimes, the problems before the new administration become greater than any that ever confronted an incoming Cuban Government.
Rallying to score four runs in the ninth inning, after two men had been retired, the New York Athletic Club defeated New York University, 7 -- 6, yesterday at Travers Island.

More than 1,000 school children and residents of Greenwich Village took part in the annual May Walk and Baby Parade yesterday afternoon in Washington Square Park, under the joint auspices of Greenwich House and the Greenwich Village Association.
WEST POINT, N.Y., May 23. -- Maryland had a merry-go-round today in batting three Army pitchers for nineteen hits to defeat the Cadets, 19 to 5.

ANY ONE who ever tried to curve a lawn bowl from a distance of a hundred feet, right up to where it will nestle softly beside a smaller white ball, knows that here is a real game. Thousands of new adherents are finding it out in the parks of the New York metropolitan area, in New Jersey and throughout the country.

TRENTON, May 23. -- State police from Michigan today took first place both in team and individual events in the eleventh annual interstate, intercollegiate pistol match held at the Wilburtha courts of the New Jersey State police this afternoon.

DURING the 1935-36 season of the National Symphony Orchestra, founded five years ago, Hans Kindler and his men played before more and larger audiences than ever before; the orchestra's personnel was expanded, and each player for the first time in the history of the orchestra was paid a weekly salary.

BERLIN, May 23. -- Premier Benito Mussolini's successful conclusion of Italy's war with Ethiopia provides the German press with an opportunity to proclaim anew the superiority of political over purely military leadership in peace and war.

VATICAN CITY, May 23. -- Pope Pius today made one of his rare appearances outside the Vatican, the first since his return from his Summer residence at Castel Gandolfo, to inaugurate a large building in the Trastevere section of Rome that will house five of the Vatican Congregations, corresponding to the Ministries or State Departments of civil governments.

The liquor-price war which began a little more than a week ago came to an end yesterday largely through the intervention of the distillers. While department stores began restoring the old prices of last Thursday, some of the smaller retailers continued to hold out until yesterdaymorning for lower prices.
DUBLIN, May 23. -- It only remains for Eamon de Valera, president of the Executive Council, to move the abolition motion in the Dail next week and the Free State's Senate will cease to exist.

PARIS. MANY couturiers have devoted more space than usual to the midseason collections, to clothes for the big Paris season and to dressy frocks for midsummer wear. They are using enormous quantities of linen in ensembles.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica. -- The difficult political situation in Honduras is attributed to the endeavors of President Tiburcio Carias to continue in office for a longer period than that for which he was elected, according to Dr. Venancio Callejas Nationalist party leader, who arrived here by airplane from Managua after he had been refused permission to remain in Nicaragua by President Juan B. Sacasa.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 23. -- The American penal system was condemned as "the last ward in social stupidity" today by Judge Joseph N. Ulman of the Supreme bench of Baltimore, chairman of the Prison Industries Reorganization Administration by appointment of President Roosevelt last year.

BOSTON, May 28 (AP). -- An eleven-inning game with the Senators brought defeat to the Red Sox and injury to the pitching hand of their star hurler, Lefty Grove, before a crowd of 25,000 today. Buddy Lewis aided by a single by Charley Myer and a double by Powell, came home with the winning run with two out in the eleventh to give Washington an 8-to-7 victory.

Making a vow to return to the Antarctic seems to the average mortal much like betting with thefates, but Paul Siple, Boy Scout member of the First Byrd Expedition, made this vow when he leftLittle America in 1930.

THE third annual New York piano playing tournament, sponsored by the National Guild of Piano Teachers, will be held June 4, 5 and 6, in Aeolian Hall. Children and adults throughout the metropolitan area, including Westchester, Long Island and New Jersey, are eligible as participants.

WASHINGTON, May 23. -- The Associates Investment Company of South Bend, Ind., filed today a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 60,000 shares of $100 par 5 per cent cumulative preferred stock, 63,750 shares of no par common stock and 60,000 warrants to purchase the common stock.

HAMILTON, Bermuda -- Bermuda's growing popularity as a year-round resort is being made evident in the purchase by wealthy Americans of home sites and famous old estates. More than half a million dollars' worth of real estate is reported to have been sold to Americans since the beginning of the year.

Everybody throws bouquets at youth, and everybody exploits youth. The young people are told that the future belongs to them, but the $200-a-month pensions are for persons over 65. Or do people mean that the future will belong to the young when they get to be 65?

NEW ORLEANS, May 23 (AP). -- Forest (Spec) Towns, University of Georgia star, bettered the listed world's record for the 110-meter hurdles for the third time in a week today at the Southern A.A.U. track meet.

Dean Herbert E. Hawkes of Columbia College, made public yesterday the results of a survey of members of the graduating class which showed that 236 of the 308 seniors will continue their studies in graduate or professional schools next year, while more than one-third of the remaining seventy-two already have obtained jobs.

BISMARCK, N.D. -- The influence of Mayan culture upon the primitive peoples of the Great Plainshas been further corroborated in North Dakota with the discovery of a stone "telescope" in a gravel pit north of Grand Forks in the Red River Valley.

CHICAGO, May 23. -- Aided by a special one-day sale event at retail and by a broad wholesale dry goods demand, merchandising totals ran far ahead of those in the period in 1935 in the week just ended.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., May 23. -- East Hampton's Summer colony will have many newcomers this season. Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Weicker and Miss Florence Weicker, who have spent the Summer at Southampton for several years, have taken Mrs. Ellery James's dune house, and Mrs. James has leased the Frederick Seymour house on Forest Lane for her own occupancy.

THE annual dinner of the Royal Literary Fund -- a fund, raised by voluntary subscriptions, which for nearly a century and a half has assisted authors who have fallen upon evil times -- is usually the occasion of notable utterances on literary matters.

MADRID, May 12, 1936. FAR the best native novelty heard in Madrid this season was Federico Elizalde's symphony with piano concertante, given here recently (first time anywhere) by the Orquesta Sinfonica under the composer's baton.
MEXICO, D.F., May 23. -- Forty thousand Mexicans today followed the body of Archbishop Pascual Diaz four miles through streets lined by 150,000 other mourners to the grave in Tepeyac Cemetery.

THE Cleveland Orchestra, next season, will give twenty pairs of Thursday and Saturday evening concerts in Severance Hall of its home city, and in addition two Thursday night opera performances and two Saturday night ones. Artur Rodzinski, before taking up his activities with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, will conduct the first thirteen programs in Cleveland and both of the operas to be given.

Commander John S. Baylis of the United States Coast Guard presented medals last night for life-saving and honorable service to several members of the United States Volunteer Life Saving Corps at the annual ball of the corps at the Hotel Plaza.

Under its new chief, William F. Carey, appointed a few days ago by Mayor La Guardia, the Department of Sanitation tomorrow enters upon another phase of its development. Complicated problems press for solution -- physical, economic and social.
DIREDAWA, Ethiopia, May 22 (Delayed). -- For the Italian army there is only one source of conversation today: When do we go home?

THE spinach crusade, promoted by every one from dietitians to funny-paper characters, has been in vain. The unassailable position that this vegetable has held heretofore is threatened by certain of its brethren in the vegetable kingdom.

MILWAUKEE, May 23 (AP). -- Milwaukee's "pre-divorce" court, where marital partnerships are patched up, passed its 4,000th case today with a record of mending 40 per cent of the squabbles that have come before it since its inception Jan. 1, 1935, according to Judge Richard J. Hennessey.

GLOBE-TROTTING records are just as likely to be a bore as the stories that begin with the introduction "Let me tell you about my operation." Yet both kinds of narratives can be amusing, and "Tickets, Please" is among the exceptions to the rule.

VALUED more highly than ever in home decoration are Chinese hand-painted panels and wallpaper which have come down from old dynastic periods, and the furniture, fabric and wallpaper design in the Chinese manner which were made in Europe in the eighteenth century.

To the booming of a cannon and the strains of the Star-Spangled Banner the yachting department of the New York A.C. formally opened what promises to be a highly active season at Travers Island yesterday.
When Annie May found the hidden door under the eaves in Gramma's house she hugged the discovery to herself as one of those delightful secrets which are a prime necessity in every child's life.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 23. -- Ohio State's spectacular Jesse Owens staged another one-man victory rampage today, but even his heroic efforts could not keep Don Lash and the other hustling Indiana Hoosiers from winning their first Western Conference track and field championship.

An astonishing situation has developed in the waterfront city of Hoboken since the State of New Jersey turned back the administration of direct relief to the municipalities a month ago and stopped its financial aid.

PARIS, May 22. -- In as plain language as courtesy toward an unsatisfied creditor would permit, Leon Blum, Premier-designate, sought last week in his American Club speech here to inform the American people that neither he nor any one else who might come to power in France could ever answer Washington's bi-annual reminder that a debt installment is due by making payments under the terms of the Mellon-Berenger agreement.

Although the Fall buying season for men's clothing has started off auspiciously, volume is only about 5 per cent ahead of a year ago, manufacturers said yesterday. In May, 1935, they pointed out, initial demand was excellent, principally because of a rising cloth market and extremely low retail stocks, two factors which are more or less lacking now.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., May 23. -- The new program at Union College for the study of State and local government has ended and today Dr. Patterson H. French, who established it last Fall, announced the thirteen students who had received "interneships" for study in State departments at Albany.

GENEVA, May 23. -- Italy's trade deficit in March previously reported as $4,000,000 old gold dollars rose to $5,200,000 in the League's latest sanction report published today. It gives the figures for twenty-eight countries in March instead of nineteen, the chief additions being Germany, France, Poland, Hungary, Canada and Yugoslavia and shows the continued strong application of sanctions.

THIS book is far more than a mere list of the possessions of India House, for Carl C. Cutler, who wrote "Greyhounds of the Sea," has spent years in research and has appended to the description of each picture the history of the ship, her size, builders, commanders and fate.
I read with a great deal of interest in THE TIMES the report of the committee of six physicians of the American Medical Association on the subject of birth control.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- Theatrical boarding-house sounds are coming through open windows of the government departments this Spring -- the rattle of kettle drums, the wha-wha of baby sax, the oom-pa of tuba -- jazz symphonette.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 23. -- The Harvard nine today won its seventh and eighth Eastern Intercollegiate League victories at the expense of the University of Pennsylvania, scoring by 10 to 4 and 5 to 1 and eliminating the Philadelphians as pennant contenders.

WASHINGTON, May 23. -- The Townsend Old Age Revolving Pension Plan has run into rough going. But so, it is the fairly unanimous opinion on Capitol Hill, has the House investigating committee of eight members whose zeal in performing its functions yesterday inspired Dr. Francis E. Townsend of California, the OARP founder and present unopposed official leader, to "take a walk" out of one of its most dramatic sessions.

IT was Margaret, daughter of Thomas De Quincey, who, in a letter to the Boston publisher James T. Fields, asked with affectionate pathos: "Have you ever had to deal with a very wise and very mad man?"

FEW amateurs of art, I think, can fully realize the immense scope of the general subject defined in three letters, art. The current exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum covers only fifty years, those curious years from 1450 to 1500 with America busy getting herself discovered by one and another, and the rest of the world greedy as now for gain.

Installation of Mrs. Samuel Sloan Duryee as president of the Women's City Club will be conducted by Mrs. H. Edward Dreier, retiring president, at the annual dinner tomorrow night at the clubhouse, 22 Park Avenue. Other officers to be inducted at the same time are Miss Juliett M. Bartlett, secretary, and Mrs. Percy Grier Hart, treasurer.

LITERARY prizes, particularly the more famous and coveted awards, have a way of departing after a time from the original intentions of their donors. Usually founded for the laudable purpose of encouraging young and struggling talent, they are apt to end by crowning the achievements of writers whose reputations are already firmly established.

Lee Pattison, city and State director of the WPA Federal Music Project, yesterday made known that the project would give a series of chamber operas, both modern and standard, at prices ranging from 25 to 75 cents.

When a famous English novelist rescues an international screen star from kidnappers and thenmodestly disclaims all credit, saying he would have done the same for any "decrepit old charwoman," he is in for trouble. Beautiful Gloria Drake took those words as a challenge.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 23. -- The local harbor was enlivened this week by the resumption of coastwise express-passenger service by lines which withdrew their ships from service at the height of the waterfront labor disturbances that several months ago practically prevented American-owned vessels from operating between the Canadian and Mexican borders on this coast.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 23. -- Skits satirizing the New Deal and the spending policies of President Roosevelt were presented here to night by the Garden City Republican Recruits.
CHUNGKING, China, May 23. -- Thirty million persons are facing starvation in Szechwan and HonanProvinces today, according to reports received here from famine investigators in the interior.

ONE gauge of the influence of the Italo-Ethiopian War upon world affairs has been the passenger volume on ships sailing the Mediterranean. During the weeks last Fall when British warships lay at Alexandria and the streets of Italian cities were crowded with soldiers ships sailing for Mediterranean ports were used almost exclusively by persons traveling on essential business.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 23. -- Rutgers snapped Dickinson's seven-game winning streak today when Steadman, Scarlet sophomore, held the Red Devils to seven hits and recorded a 4-3 triumph. Steadman fanned ten.

MADISON, N.J., May 23. -- Mr. Reynal's Monarch, a superb harrier owned by Amory L. Haskell of Red Bank, N.J., and handled by Albert Smith, received the P.A. Rockefeller Trophy today as best in show in the tenth annual Morris and Essex Kennel Club exhibition at Giralda Farms, the estate of Mr. and Mrs. M. Hartley Dodge.
WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP). -- Talking to a political study club, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt today gave some "new disciplines" that women should acquire in the political field.

THE winner of the Atlantic Monthly Prize of $10,000 offered by the Atlantic Monthly Press and Little. Brown Co. for the "most interesting and distinctive" novel submitted is Winifred Wayne Van Etten of Mount Vernon, Iowa.

HAMILTON, N.Y., May 23. -- Long-distance clouting gave Colgate a 17-to-1 triumph over Syracuse today. It was the first victory in the series for Colgate, which still finds Syracuse maintaining a 2-1 edge in games played.
PARIS, May 23 (AP). -- British and French Davis Cup players took a monopoly on the semi-final brackets today in the doubles competition of the French hard courts tennis championships.

LOOKING back over a century of politics it would appear that if there were but one golden maxim embossed upon the national velvet which papa politicians could safely show to baby politicians it would be, "My son, to get on in the political world, learn to compromise."

ROME, May 23. -- "There are two countries in Europe which are turning to the left, France and England," said former King Alfonso of Spain in an exclusive interview here. "English politics are the most sublimely confused' in the world.

MOSCOW, May 23. -- I.D. Simenchuk, petty tyrant of an icy island in the Artic Circle, was sentenced tonight to be shot for a reign of starvation, terror and death at Wrangel, polar station. The Supreme Court meted out a like sentence to Simenchuk's aide and co-defendant, S.P. Startseff.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 23. -Princeton University undergraduates are giving substantial financial help to fellow students through the maintenance of an emergency loan fund and of a library where used textbooks may be borrowed, according to figures announced today by Laurence Fenniger '09, director of the Student-Faculty Association.

GARDEN designers consider foliage plants a necessary part of the plan of every flower border, no matter how limited space may be. Such plants take the place of a variety of smaller flowering plants and thus obviate the crowding that is characteristic of the beginner's garden.

WASHINGTON, May 23. -- With certain qualifications, Charlton Ogburn, chief legal counsel for theAmerican Federation of Labor, predicted today that the Supreme Court would uphold the NationalLabor Relations Act.

Rare doings on a battleship of the United States Navy. First the Admiral of the Atlantic Fleet is murdered -- it is supposed to be suicide, but it isn't. Then Sheridan Doome of Naval Intelligence flies from Washington, accompanied by his trusty assistant. Rush Evans, to investigate what is not yet known to be a crime.

TO read these fascinating and rather terrifying books, one after the other, is to go far toward understanding why the German people submit to the Nazi regime. The effect of horror they produce is due less to the merciless portrait of Hitler than to the sullen background blacked in behind the central figure.

" Thunder Shower" has the appetizing flavor that can be given only by an author who has lived inhis own setting and liked it. It combines youthful romance, kid-brother pranks and small-town political wire-pulling in the up-State village of Simpson Falls.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 23. -- Religion wrought into citizenship was the theme of an address today by Governor Alfred M. Landon of Kansas at the opening of the twelfth annual convention of the National Federation of Men's Bible Classes in the Municipal Auditorium.

In connection with the eightieth birthday of Dr. Sigmund Freud an article by Kathryn R. Swift appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine which contained a derogatory reference to my publication regarding cocaine anesthesia together with a manifest misstatement.

AGAINST the gloomings of pessimists and non-believers, despite marked inequalities in the merits of the productions, the Spring season of opera in the Metropolitan Opera House has been, as a whole, extremely successful. Very seldom, in the Winter seasons, have audiences shown such enthusiasm and sheer enjoyment of the music and the show as was shown, for example, at the performances of "Carmen" and the performances in English of Smetana's "Bartered Bride."

LOS ANGELES, May 23 (AP). -- A middle-aged man who deposited more than $30,000 in Los Angeles banks and then disappeared was sought by Federal and private operatives today on the possibility that he may have met foul play.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa. -- Next Saturday will usher in the Summer season in the Poconos Mountains, and resorts throughout the area are preparing for capacity crowds. Golf courses and swimming pools are in order, and a number of other outdoor activities and dances are being arranged.

Smetana's comedy "The Bartered Bride," with its English version, was repeated for the third time yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan. The appeal of the opera has not diminished, as wasevidenced in the capacity audience, who roared approval at the antics of George Rasly as Wenzel and Louis D'Angelo as Kezal, the marriage broker.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 23. -Holy Cross gained its first New England collegiate track and field championship in fifty years today by piling up 35 3-11 points at Brown Field. This total gave the Crusaders a lead of nearly 11 points on Brown, which pulled into the runner-up position with a furious scoring burst in the field events.

THIS jovially overwritten book is the gaudy record of Wilde's year-long American tour -- and an informal panorama of the Republic in that time. All that happened to the dogged pilgrim of estheticism (and to America while it endured his visitation) is in this chronicle of imported (and domestic) bad manners.

The schedule for the women's combined national track and field championships and Olympic tryouts, to be held at the Brown University Field in Providence, R.I., on July 4, has just arrived from Ben Levias, chairman of the New England committee on women's athletics.

JACKSON, Mich., May 23. -- Ray Ernest, a guard at the Southern Michigan prison, was detained tonight and witnesses for a one-man grand jury were summoned hastily to investigate the reported flogging and death of Paul Every, 42.

Trim-lined hulls on craft of Manhattan registry cleaved through the water so cleanly yesterday afternoon that they annexed nearly all the events at the eighth semi-annual city-wide model sail and motor boat regatta conducted by Macy's and the Department of Parks on Conservatory Lake in Central Park.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., May 23. -- An eight-run rally in the fifth gave Penn State's baseball team a 10-2 triumph over Temple today. Johnny Waters hit a home run with the bases filled as twelve men went to bat in the inning.

THE cinema's dogdays, during which the industry poises waiting to leap into action when the year's announcements are made, were enlivened this week by the Warners' second important preview of the month, "The Green Pastures."

The outlook for real estate this year, and inferentially for real estate securities, is the brightest it has been in several years, according to a national survey just completed by the real estate securities committee of the Investment Bankers Association of America.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- Expecting a record-breaking Memorial Day crowd, Atlantic City is rapidly completing preparations for the entertainment of visitors. Special programs are being arranged by hotels, grills, night clubs, theatres and piers.

CHESTERFIELD, N.H., May 23. -- As the victim of the "torch murder" on Mount Wantasiquet was tentatively identified tonight as "Mrs. Grace Hurley of Boston," the authorities announced that they were tracing two suspects in Maine.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., May 23. -Mr. and Mrs. Norman H. Davis are spending their first week-end of the season at Oronoque, Stockbridge, which they are to open next week. Mr. Davis was at the Stockbridge Golf Club this afternoon.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., May 23. -"Let us conquer our frontiers" was the theme of Mrs. August Belmont of New York in an address made this morning at a special convocation of the Moravian Seminary andCollege for Women held in the Central Moravian Church.
ALBANY, May 23. -- Governor Lehman's announcement on Wednesday that he would not seek re-election has been the outstanding political event of a week otherwise quiet in State politics.

SUMMER visitors to Europe in search of new lands and new sights, will find land which is literally new not far from Amsterdam this year. A whole new province, so new that it drips with salt water, is slowly rising from the old Zuyder Zee.

THE author of "The Son of Marie Antoinette" has just published the first study in English of the remarkable Gascon adventurer of French Revolutionary times, the Baron Jean de Batz, akin to the elder Dumas's hero, who, all alone, like a small demigod of mythology contending fabulous monsters, attempted to undermine and destroy the whole Revolution, and in part succeeded.

The steady pressure of flight of capital kept the French franc at or below its gold-import point again yesterday and an additional $2,650,000 gold was engaged in Paris for shipment here. The franc was unchanged from the preceding day at 6.58 3/8 cents, but showed a net decline of 13-16 point on the week.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 23. -- The newly elected Parliament was formally inaugurated today with the customary pomp and ceremony except that the royal seat was vacant. Instead there were three gold chairs on the center of the platform occupied by the Regents, representing King Farouk.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., May 23. -- Six All-Smith blazers, highest award of the Smith College Athletic Association, were awarded tonight at the conclusion of Field Day and Float Night. The girls who received this honor for having played on three All-Smith teams were:

Don't let the title fool you. There are more than three murders in this book. The other victims did not happen to meet their fates beside the marble pool, but there are enough of them so that only a few of the original characters survive until the end of the story.
WASHINGTON, May 23. -- Pay day, an event important to most persons, gets scant personal attention from the justices of the Supreme Court.
BOSTON, May 22. -- Governor Curley's plan for the retirement of all Massachusetts judges over seventy years of age has "created" what he himself calls a "tempest."

A historical pageant, enlisting a group of full-blooded southwestern Indians, as well as several descendants of Texans prominent in the early history of that State, featured the Texas Centennial Blue Bonnet Ball held last night in the ballroom of the Biltmore.

Captain Hans Kieff, who is acting as staff captain of the Hapag Lloyd liner Reliance on her cruise around the world, will become her master when the ship arrives in port on Tuesday, replacing Commodore Fritz Kruse of the Hapag, who will return to his home in Germany.

AMSTERDAM, Netherlands, May 23. -- The Roman Catholic clergy, their previous opposition to National Socialism apparently unsuccessful, united tonight to crush the German movement by denying the sacraments of the church to its supporters.

INCREDIBLE though it may seem, the most important dance news from Europe has to do with the creation of another ballet company to add to the half dozen which are already touring there. In itself this would perhaps call for no more than passing mention, but in that it concerns itself largely with Michel Fokine, it assumes at once a certain significance.
