Most States suffer from too many layers of government. New York, after many years of urging, is now trying to get rid of some of them. New Jersey is about to make the same endeavor. In the first of a series of bulletins on its findings the Princeton Local Government Survey Committee asserts that she is the most "commission-ridden" State in the nation.

Central Park's East Green at Seventy-second Street was invaded yesterday by a crowd of children and parents estimated at 20,000 by the police and at 40,000 by the Fourteenth Assembly District Democratic Organization, sponsor of the gathering.

Retailers are faced with the necessity of making two clear-cut choices in their promotions designed for the veterans' bonus payment period, Paul Murphy, advertising manager of Frederick Loeser Co., said yesterday. The question is whether a store figures the veterans and their families are going to want bargains or whether good quality merchandise of seasonal appeal will be bought.
ROME, May 23 (AP). -- Italy will celebrate the twenty-first anniversary of her entrance into the World War tomorrow with a trinity of ceremonies.

WORTHY indeed and of real potential moment is the gesture that assembles for us art from the furthermost as from the nighest reaches of America. This nationwide survey, organized by the Mayor's Municipal Art Committee, and current (until July 1) at International Building, Rockefeller Center, represents an earnest wish to gauge the present status of our creative expression in painting and sculpture.

ALBANY, May 23. -- Mrs. Lila Papen, chief clerk of the State Motor Fuel Tax Refund Division, faced a charge of grand larceny, first degree, in Albany police court today, having been arrested last night in a New York City hotel, charged with appropriating to her own use a tax-refund check for $606, issued, it is alleged, on a claim of "J.L. Derusso," broker of Farmington, L.I.

THE most thickly settled parts of the United States will be hearing this week, and for two or three weeks after that, the ominous wailing of the dreaded seventeen-year "locust," or periodical cicada. From Long Island to Missouri, from Lake Ontario to Atlanta, the forests will sound like a wood-working shop with every lathe and chisel and saw and band roaring full tilt.

FEW Americans have any knowledge of the heroic struggle for universal education in the Southern States. Students of social movements, and especially of educational provisions in the South, will increasingly appreciate the remarkable service which Dr. Dabney has rendered through his compilation of biographical data concerning the able and devoted personalities who fought faithfully for a public school system.
WASHINGTON, May 23. -- The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated May 21:

THE boxing business is becoming brisk in a big way. The heavyweights have most of the floor. The fighter who has the bystanders guessing is Leroy Haynes, the Negro battler, who suddenly emerged from obscurity by reducing Primo Carnera to a rambling wreck in three rounds over in Philadelphia.

Prospective brides will study with interest a pamphlet entitled "The Married Woman and Her Job,"just issued by the National League of Women Voters. Its conclusions, drawn from several detailed surveys, emphasize the attitude of the organization that the security of the married woman in her job is in jeopardy.

HOW engineers may make automobile safer and more economical will be discussed at the annual Summer meeting of the Society of Automotive Engineers, to be held May 31 to June 5 at the Greenbrier, White Sulphur Springs, W. Va.
WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., May 23 (AP). -- The will of John N. Willys, automobile manufacturer, was admitted to probate today, apparently ending a long legal dispute over the $3,000,000 estate.

The weak underpinning which caused White Cockade to be kept out of the Kentucky Derby and Preakness Stakes was sound as knees of oak yesterday as the colt pounded through the Belmont Park stretch to win the sixty-first Withers Stakes at 15 to 1 to the surprise of most and to the consternation of those in the crowd of 20,000 who had made Brevity an odds-on favorite.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 23. -- The Greentree team, playing together as a unit for the first time this season, ushered in the 1936 polo campaign at the Meadow Brook Club today with a smashing 9-to-7 triumph over a White quartet led by the veteran internationalist, Devereux Milburn.

The report from Washington that the President is pursuing a study to the end that between 500,000 and 1,000,000 families may have homes costing not exceeding $2,500 each is just anotherdisclosure of the regimentation complex. Regimentation is the very opposite of economic sense.

HELENA, Mont., May 22. -- Conventions of both Montana political parties were held here Tuesday, Republicans deciding to send an uninstructed and unpledged delegation to the Cleveland convention, and the Democrats a delegation pledged to continue voting for Franklin D. Roosevelt until he is nominated.

ENGLEWOOD CLIFFS, N.J., May 23. -- Dominic L. O'Reilly, New York lawyer and a leader in the Bronx Democratic organization, died of a heart attack here late today just as a policeman was about to reprimand him for driving past a red traffic light.

WASHINGTON. LED by the flagship Shoshone, a Coast Guard squadron is heading north to establish the 1936 Bering Sea patrol. In the course of the annual patrol season, extending from May to October, Coast Guard vessels visit practically every settlement in the Bering Sea area and the Aleutian Islands, whose westernmost point is only a few hundred miles from Asia.

MONOTHEISTIC as we are (we knew the original Lawd, and doubt if we shall see his like again) we have to admit that Rex Ingram, "de Lawd" of Warner Brothers' version of "The Green Pastures," is a fine figure of a deity -- in sheer bulk, certainly, more impressive than the gentle, white-haired Richard B. Harrison of Marc Connelly's stage masterpiece.

NASSAU, Bahamas, May 21. -- Another design is being worked into the variegated and highly colorful patchwork of Bahamian history -- and this time the pattern is being deftly shaped by wealthy persons in the United States. They are seeking refuge from heavy taxation in their own country and, incidentally, security from its probable repercussions.

WASHINGTON, May 23. -- The local branch of the Young Democratic Clubs of America has decided to refuse a suggestion from Senator Metcalf, Republican, of Rhode Island, that it withdraw its invitation to him to speak over the radio in connection with "Kapital Kapers," a musical review to be presented by the organization here on June 1.

WASHINGTON, May 23. -- Pressing the administration drive to find jobs for the nation's unemployed in private industry, George L. Berry, President Roosevelt's industry coordinator, announced today the appointment of a committee to maintain a running inventory of unemployment.

THE Dionne quintuplets will be 2 years old next Thursday. Not a ripe age as ages go, but a record one for quintuplets, whose longevity hitherto has been measurable only in days or hours. A 2-year-old quintuplet has been as rare in the world's history as a 2-year-old unicorn.

WASHINGTON, May 23. -- The general leveling-off process noted in industrial activity in the first week of May continued until the middle of the month, the Department of Commerce reported today in its weekly summary of business activity. Few variations in the major weekly indices were recorded in the week ended on May 16.

MORE than one broadcast performer, especially the comedians, plan to "take a walk" from the microphone in June. But for every one who steps away from the air-cooled studios some one will step up; radio provides for no gaps in the show.

Through the centuries the bear has labored under what Miss Fyleman believes to be the undeservedcharacterization of crossness and treachery, and in this little volume she sets out to correct the slander. Whether naturalists and zoo-keepers will agree with her is an open question, but children from 8 to 12 will find here an interesting miscellany of fact and stories, which may serve as an introduction to Bruin's more likable qualities.

THE traveler passing through Oklahoma in Spring or early Summer -- or again in Autumn -- is fortunate in being able to see the prairie in bloom. He would do well to pause, for nowhere will he find flowers of more brilliant color or fragile beauty than the wild flowers that blossom on the plains of Oklahoma.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 23. -Peter Lauck today captured the Princeton interscholastic tennis honors left undefended by his Lawrenceville School team-mate, Frank Parker, when he defeated Charles Mattman of Trinity SchooI, 6 -- 3. [6 -- 3, in the final.

THE late Arnold Bennett (or Enoch Arnold Bennett as the intelligence tests remind us) was the youngest of Miss Rebecca West's famous avuncular trio and he was the first to die. Critics have expressed puzzlement because one gifted with so fine a talent as that manifested in "The Old Wives' Tale" and "Clay-hanger" should ever have stooped to such trivial journalese as "How to Live on Twenty-four Hours a Day."

Conflict contrary to the best economic interests of the legal profession, particularly of its younger members, has resulted from the free legal service offered by WPA, it was decided yesterday at a First Circuit conference of the Junior Bar Conference of the American Bar Association, held at the New York County Lawyers Association building, 14 Vesey Street.

A plan for rezoning 146 blocks on the West Side of Manhattan from Fourteenth Street to Fifty-ninth Street will be presented to Borough President Levy of Manhattan on Tuesday by the West Side Association of Commerce at a luncheon meeting in the Hotel Lincoln.

In this story of the murder of a book collector, Carolyn Wells has succeeded in maintaining suspense to the last chapter rather better than she did in most of the other Fleming Stone novels. Philip Balfour, the collector, is stabbed to death in the back room of a bookshop in circumstances that cause suspicion to fall on his librarian, Keith Ramsay.

HOT SPRINGS, Va. -- Resources of the Homestead Stables will be taxed to the uttermost next week to provide buckboards, buggies, surreys and runabouts enough for visitors who want to see nature's great show of mountain laurel and azalea.

A discussion by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, of the development of Manhattan Island from early Colonial days, with particular reference to the lands held by that institution, is contained as a foreword in a new volume published by the Columbia University Press, entitled Columbia University Officers and Alumni, 1754-1857.

ST. PAUL, May 22. -- Four years ago the Democratic party of Minnesota split into two bitter factions. Today the factional division is even sharper and more bitter than it was in 1932 and may play a decisive part in determining whether Minnesota goes Democratic or Republican next November.

The 118 suburban high schools entered in the Constitution contest for teachers being conducted by THE NEW YORK TIMES will hold their district elimination round June 20-25. The respective district chairmen announced last week that twenty-four judges will officiate during the trials.

ONCE again Mary Roberts Rinehart demonstrates her ability to hold the reader's attention through many closely printed pages. This time, moreover, she does it through the medium of what one may call a straight novel, serious, realistic, without mystery, murder or fantastic happenings of any kind.

WASHINGTON, May 23. -- Invalidation by the Supreme Court of the Bituminous Coal Conservation Act of 1935 (the Guffey law) carried with it implications that may profoundly affect American economic and industrial life and the relations of employer to employe in mining and manufacturing industries as well as in trade and commerce.

The agreement announced last week whereby the United States is to buy substantial amounts of silver from China is a step in the development of a modern monetary system by that country which will lead to a lessened dependence upon silver, according to C.H. Wang, who arrived here from Shanghai to take up his post as joint manager with H.D.R. Burgess of the New York agency of the Bank of China.

Of the 7,100 barbers in Manhattan and the Bronx who have been on strike, 3,600 returned to workunder settlements yesterday, and 3,500 remained on strike, it was announced by Anthony Merlino, vice president of the Journeymen Barbers International Union of America.

A survey by the management division of the Real Estate Board of the Bronx revealed a vacancy average of 6.42 per cent in suites renting for $10 per room or less. As a means of improving that situation in the borough, a committee has suggested that the houses in that class be resurveyed and divided into three groups: $5 per room and under, $5.01 to $7 per room and $7.01 to $10 per room.
WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., May 23. -- Two men were burned to death and a third was injured this afternoonwhen their plane crashed into the main street of Montoursville, four miles east of here.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 23. -- The Cornell nine rallied in the sixth inning of its Spring Day game with Yale today, scoring four runs to earn an 8-3 decision, its second of the Eastern Intercollegiate League season. The Ithacans outhit Yale. 14 -- 10.

TO Thomas Alva Edison, whose inventions transformed the workaday world and gave new pleasures to leisure time, there is to be a "living memorial." It is being established by a foundation of which Owen D. Young is national chairman, and will consist in awarding each year 100 Edison grants of money to educate particularly promising Americans who are 16 years or more old.

LOVERS of the woodland trail will find few areas more attractive at this season of the year than the Berkshires, where well-marked paths form a network over rugged mountains from Connecticut to Vermont. Already hikers with rucksacks on their backs may be found on these trails, tramping the forests, at lunch time sizzling steaks over live embers, and at night returning, tired by physical exertion, but at peace with the world.

Americans, who invested about half of the $10,000,000 paid in for tickets on the eighteenth annual Irish Hospital Sweepstakes on the English Derby to be run next Wednesday at Epsom Downs, were assured by the drawing in Dublin yesterday of receiving a large share of the $6,266,875 in prize money.

Once more Dr. CHARLES B. LIPMAN of the University of California, a bacteriologist of international authority and repute, comes forward with bacteria that seem to have defied senility and death. This time he finds them not, as in the past, in anthracite coal, pre-Cambian rocks and meteorites that flew into our atmosphere from outer space but in century old adobe bricks taken from an old mission in San Luis Obispo.

JOHN L. SPIVAK is a journalist of varied accomplishments. A note about him thoughtfully appended to this book explains that he served with The Sun, Journal and Graphic and as a special correspondent of the International News Service.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 23. -- After Harvard had tied today's polo game in the final minute of play on a spectacular goal by F.S. Von Stade, Peter Grace of Yale, with only seven seconds remaining, scored on a long shot from a difficult angle, giving Yale a 7-6 victory.

DALLAS, May 23. -- Summer weather has arrived in the Southwest, resulting in increased business throughout the Eleventh Federal District. Retail sales have risen rapidly in volume during the last two weeks. General rainfall over the area also encouraged all lines of business and brought increased activity.
BROKEN VOWS: In Salt Lake City thirty-five years ago fourteen young men formed a society of woman-haters. Ten of them attended a reunion last week. They were all married.
Dr. Robert Underwood Johnson, director of the Hall of Fame, announced yesterday that busts of William Penn and Simon Newcomb would be unveiled at New York University at 3:15 P.M. Thursday.

What otherwise might well have been a routine day in stocks was relieved yesterday by a brisk rally in the steel issues, responsive to the overnight news of an advance in steel prices for the third quarter of the year made by the largest producer in the industry.

MOORESTOWN, N.J., May 23. -- Concrete evidence that the United States Davis Cup team faces a formidable assignment when it engages the Australians at the Germantown Cricket Club next Saturday was furnished today as the antipodeans appeared in a series of exhibitions on the turf of the Moorestown Field Club.

ACROSS the Iowa countryside the transcontinental bus rolls rapidly. It will reach Chicago in the morning, but most of the passengers are not going so far. They are traveling from Omaha to Des Moines for the week-end. Salesmen are returning home from trips through Nebraska Schoolgirls on vacation are leaving the bus as it stops in the little towns.

LOVERS of the woodland trail will find few areas more attractive at this season of the year than the Berkshires, where well-marked paths form a network over rugged mountains from Connecticut to Vermont. Already hikers with rucksacks on their backs may be found on these trails, tramping the forests, at lunch time sizzling steaks over live embers, and at night returning, tired by physical exertion, but at peace with the world.

Americans, who invested about half of the $10,000,000 paid in for tickets on the eighteenth annual Irish Hospital Sweepstakes on the English Derby to be run next Wednesday at Epsom Downs, were assured by the drawing in Dublin yesterday of receiving a large share of the $6,266,875 in prize money.

This time he finds them not, as in the past, in anthracite coal, pre-Cambian rocks and meteorites that flew into our atmosphere from outer space but in century old adobe bricks taken from an old mission in San Luis Obispo.

JOHN L. SPIVAK is a journalist of varied accomplishments. A note about him thoughtfully appended to this book explains that he served with The Sun, Journal and Graphic and as a special correspondent of the International News Service.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 23. -- After Harvard had tied today's polo game in the final minute of play on a spectacular goal by F.S. Von Stade, Peter Grace of Yale, with only seven seconds remaining, scored on a long shot from a difficult angle, giving Yale a 7-6 victory.

DALLAS, May 23. -- Summer weather has arrived in the Southwest, resulting in increased business throughout the Eleventh Federal District. Retail sales have risen rapidly in volume during the last two weeks. General rainfall over the area also encouraged all lines of business and brought increased activity.
BROKEN VOWS: In Salt Lake City thirty-five years ago fourteen young men formed a society of woman-haters. Ten of them attended a reunion last week. They were all married.

WASHINGTON, May 23. -- The Interstate Commerce Commission issued today an order suspending free pick-up and delivery schedules of railroads for official territory east of Chicago and north of Virginia cities, which otherwise would have gone into effect on Monday.

LONG ISLAND will make a strong bid for visitors this Summer with a tercentenary celebrating the 300th anniversary of the first white settlement, by the Dutch, on its historic shores. Starting next Saturday and continuing all through the Summer, the island's four counties will vie in presenting colorful programs and pageants depicting three centuries of growth.

Coming through as anticipated, the strong array of Bishop Loughlin Memorial High School successfully defended its Athletic Association of Private Schools track and field championship at the nineteenth annual meet at Baker Field yesterday.

IDIOT'S DELIGHT" has provided the metropolitan dinner table with much of its Spring conversation. The sober can find, wrapped up in its three acts, an attack on the munitions makers, the Fascists and on war. The less worried are able to see Harry Van -- or Alfred Lunt, if you are talking about it over the coffee -- lugging half a dozen blond babes through the Italian Alps. "Idiot's

GENEVA, May 23. -- Reports that foreign correspondents are being expelled and Ethiopians shot in batches suggest how Italian law is being enforced in Ethiopia. But how is the League of Nations enforcing the sanctions against the Fascist government which it has decided to continue?

Terrestrial observers will have an opportunity during the next two months to see a "comet show," which may or may not be a good one, Dr. Harlow Shapley, director of the Harvard College Observatory, said last night at a dinner at the Hotel Colonial, Columbus Avenue and Eighty-first Street.

A program of education for the purchasing consumer will benefit business and labor as well as theconsumer, Mrs. Carl Schrader, chairman of the consumers' committee of the National Council of Women, said last night at a dinner at the fifteenth Women's Exposition of Arts and Industry in Grand Central Palace.

Many Long Island organizations of women have selected their leaders for the ensuing club year, insome instances retaining valuable leadership and in others electing successors to officials whose record will stand as a mark of achievement for the incoming presidents.

KENT, Conn., May 23. -- For the first time since 1875, when a Purple crew finished ninth among thirteen entries in an intercollegiate race at Lake Saratoga, an eight from Williams returned to competitive rowing today on the Upper Housatonic course in a race with the third Kent School boat.

LONDON (AP). -- London is changing. What amounts to a social and architectural revolution is challenging the famous chimney pots, the open coal fires, the old Georgian mansions and the quiet, sequestered squares.

NOT a single cowboy appears to break a broncho or ride herd in this modern Western story, but its account of a boy and his sister's plucky struggle to keep their land free of indebtedness gives the reader of high school age a vivid picture of present-day ranch life in a California valley.
PRINCETON, N.J., May 23. -- The Princeton nine played errorless ball today to score its first shut-out victory of the season, defeating the Navy on University Field, 5 -- 0.
Not only as the official biographer of the late Field Marshal Viscount Allenby but also as an Englishman may I thank you for your leading article in THE NEW YORK TIMES of May 15.

AT the bottom of this page is printed the monthly report of the Police Department listing the precincts in the city where the fewest and most accidents, fatalities and injuries occurred during April. Before submitting the figures this time, the department statisticians broke them down to show the causes of the accidents reported, and from these detailed records it is possible to introduce additional evidence in the case against the pedestrian.

SO fast are hobby clubs increasing in the United States that their growth is being traced and analyzed by the Federal Government. The beginnings of the movement were indicated in the survey of "Social Trends" started in the Hoover administration. Since then the hobby has come to be recognized as a definite factor in American life.

SHANGHAI, -- The legislative Yuan at Nanking, which has long been wrestling with the problem of devising simple election rules for the choice of delegates to the National People's Congress, has apparently succeeded only in creating a cumbersome procedure.

Having supervised the purchase during the last thirty-eight years of more than $1,000,000,000 worth of department-store goods during his career as head of the local buying office of the May Department Stores, E.M. Sostman, recognized as dean of the buying fraternity here, said yesterday that the vital lesson of these years has been the recognition of a "good source of supply as an asset that is as necessary to us as our customers are."

Brooklyn high school students virtually swept the field in the annual interscholastic mathematics contest conducted by the New York University Washington Square College, Dean Milton E. Loomie announced yesterday.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., May 23. -- Amherst defeated Wesleyan, 10 to 3, in a Little Three baseball game this afternoon. Amherst took a three-run lead in the opening frame when Kennedy's single brought in Warner and Balme, and Goodell scored on Turner's fly to O'Leary. Burton's homer in the ninth brought in Palumbo.

DETROIT, May 23 (AP). -- The low-wing monoplane Bremen, first to make a successful westward air crossing of the North Atlantic in 1928, will join other history-making aircraft soon in the museum of the Edison Institute at Greenfield Village, Dearborn, Mich.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., May 23. -- President Roosevelt returned here today for a three-day visit prompted principally by his desire to be with his mother, Mrs. Sara Delano Roosevelt, 82 years old, who is in bed as the result of a fall in which she injured her hip, painfully but not seriously.

The ghost of LYTTON STRACHEY was attacked the other day in Richmond by Dr. DOUGLAS S. FREEMAN, who wrote a four-volumed biography of ROBERT E. LEE that won the Pulitzer Prize in 1935. Conceding that STRACHEY possessed "ideal literary craftsmanship," Dr. FREEMAN contends that he "did not "examine all the evidence, or enough "of it, to sit in judgment on his char" "acters."

SHANGHAI, May 23. -- "The so-called smuggling in North China, for which the Japanese Army iserroneously held responsible, will not cease until China radically reduces her import tariffs," Major Gen. Seeichi Kita, the Japanese Military Attache, emphatically asserted here today.

THE telephone rang. Mr. Smithers picked up the receiver eagerly: his constituents evidently already were calling to promise to support his candidacy for the Constableship of Bear Valley A strident voice boomed through the instrument "Mr. Smithers?"

IN order that visitors to the Empire Exhibition at Johannesburg this year may see an African white rhinoceros, orders have been given to the game conservator at Umfolozi Reserve to shoot one of the few remaining specimens. Stuffed, it will be put on display.

AN oversupply of qualified applicants and increasingly high admission standards have turned New York City's teacher system, during the last few years, into what might be termed a closed community. Those within the gates enjoy a sense of security in their jobs hardly to be found among any other professional or industrial groups.

ROME, May 23. -- Finance Minister Count Paolo Thaon di Revel, speaking in the Senate today, dealt a blow to whatever hopes any one may entertain that the end of the East African campaign and the lifting of sanctions will mean abolition of the restrictions Italy has placed on her international trade.

Police Commissioner Valentine stood in Eleventh Avenue yesterday watching the picketing of the Chelsea piers by striking seamen as the Grace liner Santa Elena prepared to sail for the Panama Canal and the Pacific Coast.

Forty-seven students of Hunter College received awards for achievements in sports at the annual dinner of the athletic association of the college, held last night at the Maison Louis. Forty-one letters and nineteen sets of numerals were distributed.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP). -High school drill teams from Pennsylvania won the chief honors in the drill competition staged today in connection with the American Automobile Association's fifth annual parade of school safety patrols.

WASHINGTON, May 23. -- When the Resettlement Administration's housing program was declared to be based on unconstitutional foundations this week by the District of Columbia Court of Appeals, New Deal officials were shocked and Roosevelt foes were inclined to chortle with glee.

On the heels of the national observance of Foreign Trade Week, port cities of the United States moved yesterday to consolidate sentiment in support of international trade, to curb isolationist movements and to win backing for the trade agreements program of the government.

Leroy Haynes and Primo Carnera will open the major outdoor boxing season in this city when they clash in a ten-round bout at Ebbets Field on Wednesday night. The battle will be the second between the pair and is expected to attract a large crowd to the Brooklyn ball park.

KOPET ALTA" is a first novel, and, considered purely as a novel, it has little enough to recommend it. The romance which provides the essential framework of the narrative is trite in outline and depends heavily upon chance and coincidence for its development.

AUGUSTA, Ga., May 23 (AP). -- The Presbyterian Church in the United States endorsed a broad program of social reform at its session here today. The Southern churchmen adopted a report of the committee on morals and social welfare, but added this amendment:
MOSCOW, May 22. -- The naval conversations between the Soviet Union and Great Britain now being held in London have naturally directed attention once more to the Red navy.

Public office, home economics, accountancy and commercial art are cited as expanding fields for women by the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs in a statement issued yesterday as the result of compilation of material from surveys and reports.

The one-act play is as difficult as the good short story: Paul Green's "Hymn to the Rising Sun" can be taken as an excellent model. Beautifully written, it tells the story of a gang of Negro convicts, "rented out" by the Governor to a company building a railroad.

WITHIN the past three years the Stephens College library has almost quadrupled the number of books circulated among students. Where formerly students withdrew a yearly average of 10.28 books each, exclusive of overnight reserve book loans, they now draw 37.66 each.
PHILADELPHIA, May 23. -- With a brilliant closing sprint, the Rutgers varsity crew withstood a courageous challenge by the Marietta eight and won by a third of a length on the Schuylkill today.

WHEN old Luke Hamlin was murdered Fent Crocker, who had been foreman of the Hamlin ranch for fifteen years, thought he saw his way clear to ownership of the Hamlin spread -- for old Luke had no son, only a daughter, Fox.

NANKING. -- Public denunciation by General Chiang Kai-shek of the prevalence of "graft, squeeze and corruption" in the Nanking Government, and threats of drastic punishment if reprehensible practices are not quickly ended, have caused a furor here.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., May 23 (AP). -- Hal Price Headley's Apogee, winner of the Fashion Stakes at Belmont last Saturday, scored another sparkling victory before 42,000 fans at Narragansett Park today, taking the Old Colony Stakes at five furlongs.

In Kansas is found the model candidate. Strangely enough, it isn't Governor LANDON. It is an obscurer man who deserves to be illuminated. Mr. FRANK RYAN has been Secretary of State for term after term. This fact certifies to his competency. It implies extraordinary tact, skill, tenacity and power to please.

TIMES SQUARE hasn't seen much of Bartlett Cormack, and vice versa, since "The Racket" sizzled into town one night about nine years ago. Now there are signs of a renewed acquaintanceship. Give ear to Mr. Cormack, in militant mood at the other (or Beverly Hills) end of the wire:

Moderately higher prices ruled throughout the bond market yesterday in quiet trading on the New York Stock Exchange. The improvement, which was general in all of the major groups of domestic corporation issues, was, however, with only a few exceptions, confined to fractions.
BALTIMORE, May 23 (AP). -- Winning a free-hitting contest, 7 to 6, Newark made it three out of four in closing the series with the Orioles today.

The annual service for the presentation of the missionary offerings of the children of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York was attended by a capacity throng of more than 3,000 children and their parents at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine yesterday afternoon.

Comparing the Roosevelt New Dealers to a band of termites undermining the foundations of American institutions, Henry P. Fletcher, Republican National Chairman, appealed yesterday to the young men and young women of the nation to enroll in the Republican party to elect a Republican, President.

CHINWANGTAO, China, May 23. -- A two-day inspection of the activities of Korean and Japanese smugglers in Shanhaikwan and Chinwangtao reveals that the flow of contraband has increased to such an extent that smugglers are unable to clear the goods from beaches and other landing places on the coast north of Tientsin. There is a shortage of railway cars and trucks necessary for shipment to Tientsin.

BOSTON, Mass., May 23. -- The coming Presidential campaign "involves the very existence of our form of government and the welfare of future generations," Governor H. Styles Bridges of New Hampshire told the fifth conference of the New England Young Republicans in convention here tonight.

RECORDS show that the general health of the million and more Boy Scouts and their leaders is good. These records are based on the results of physical tests which most Scouts undergo before entering Summer camps. The organization seeks constantly to improve the health of its members through constructive programs for underdeveloped boys.

PHILADELPHIA, May 23. -- Cornered by a squad of heavily armed detectives, Edward (Trigger) Donnelly, paroled gunman, surrendered here today in an apartment house on Fifteenth Street, near Susquehanna Avenue.

TWO-WHEELED oxcarts make their slow and picturesque way along the roads of the Gaspe Peninsula, and the beauty of the countryside is unmarred by billboards or hot-dog stands. The French habitants speak the French language (not a patois, as is generally supposed), and place names, both French and Indian, offer pleasantness to the ear and a real descriptive quality when translated.

PHILADELPHIA, May 23. -- Former Senator Ralph H. Cameron of Arizona is being sought by Philadelphia detectives on charges brought by his former partner, William S. Graves, a Philadelphia mining engineer.

Expansion of interest in Pan-Americanism and closer contact with the students of Latin America were reported yesterday at the Tenth Semi-annual Convention of the Pan-American Student League of New York at the Capitol Hotel. The convention was attended by 400 delegates representing 10,000 students in sixty-five clubs throughout the United States and Latin America.

PHILADELPHIA, May 24. -- A crowd of 5,000, the greatest ever for tennis at the Merion Cricket Club, turned out today to witness the final exhibition matches by members of the United States Davis Cup squad.

A section of the Alcoholic Beverage Control Law that is seldom invoked in New York City, relating to selling liquor to intoxicated persons, was used yesterday with the arraignment of two bartenders before Magistrate Peter A. Abeles in Yorkville court.

MADRID, May 24. -- Ignoring the government's appeals to have patience and faith in its efforts to improve the standard of living for the workers, the Socialist trade unions threatened all hotels, restaurants and cafes of the capital today with a service strike such as took place recently in Barcelona.

CHICAGO, May 24. -- Ten dollars a hundredweight, paid here last week, was the highest price in two weeks. It meant an increase of 15 cents in two days and was for hogs weighing less than 250 pounds. It was 40 per cent above the close of the previous week.

Announcement by The St. Louis Post-Dispatch last week that it was abolishing all differentials between national and retail advertising rates caused considerable interest among advertisers and agencies here. The Post-Dispatch is about the third paper that has announced such a policy since the first of the year, but it is the most important.

The American people have reason to be gratified at the efficiency of the Department of Justice and the capture of so many of the country's worst criminals. But a good physician, chemist, electrician or engineer is not satisfied until he has gone to the root of any trouble to which his attention is directed, and such attention should now be given in a rational way to the cause of and cure for increasing crime.

Warning of an "inevitable tomorrow'' when the church might be rejected entirely by the people as a "mere burden," Dr. Shailer Mathews, dean emeritus of the University of Chicago School of Divinity, urged yesterday that organized religion accept the responsibility for helping persons to overcome their "feeling of futility" and "distrust of creative forces in the world."

Appointment of seven New York architects to the faculty of the Columbia University School of Architecture was announced yesterday. The staff was enlarged in accordance with the school's plan of relating the study of design to a "creative and living architecture," it was explained.

PHILADELPHIA, May 24. -- Tony Lazzeri hammered his way to baseball fame today with an exhibition of batting unparalleled in American League history as he set the pace in the Yankees' crushing 25-2 victory over the Athletics at Shibe Park.

The 1936 outlook for real estate, and inferentially for real estate securities, is the brightest it has been in several years, according to a national survey just completed by the real estate securities committee of the Investment Bankers Association of America.

There were 33,539,890 telephones in the world on Jan. 1, 1935, the latest date for which statistics are available, according to a report made public yesterday by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. A total of 16,868,955 telephones, or more than one-half the world's total, were in the United States, the survey showed.

PEIPING, China, May 24 (AP). -- Major Gen. Takayoshi Matsumuro, new leader of Japan's drive for expansion in North China, surprised foreign officials today by establishing military headquarters inside the legation quarter in a building rented from the Chinese maritime customs.

I was greatly impressed by the story in your issue for May 17, "City Pupils Read Few Good Books," which stated that a recent survey showed 71 per cent of the students in New York City high schools prefer light, trashy fiction to finer reading. What is the real reason or explanation for this?

Mrs. Hallie Flanagan, national director of the Federal Theatre Project, defended yesterday afternoon the work done under her direction by saying that the average salary paid an artist for creative work during from six to nine months was less than it cost "to blow a man to pieces in the trenches."

Memorial services for the 852 officers and men of the 165th Infantry (Old Sixty-ninth) who died in France in the World War and for the several hundred who have died since then were held yesterday by the Father Duffy Chapter, Rainbow Division Veterans, composed entirely of former members of the regiment, assisted by its women's auxiliary.

A short Republican platform, drafted by representatives of five Republican clubs for submission to the Republican National Convention at Cleveland, was made public yesterday by A. Perry Osborn, chairman of the drafting committee.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,956,724,200. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.
DETROIT, May 24 (AP). -- The only survivor of a sailing party of five men was found late today lashed to an overturned sailboat in Lake St. Clair, where he had drifted for nearly twenty-four hours.

LONDON, Monday, May 25. -- Earl Winterton, one of the most prominent anti-Baldwinites in the House of Commons, entertained a party composed chiefly of Conservative "rebels" at his country house at Chiddingfold, Surrey, over the week-end and the party may become famous.
ALBANY, May 24. -- Auto deaths in the State were reduced in April, the total being twenty-one under the figure for April last year.

A report of the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on March 31, including properties only from dates of acquisition shows electric revenue at $78,716,970, a gain of $12,557,962, or 19 per cent; gas revenue at $12,763,431, a gain of $1,256,275, or 10.9 per cent, and total operating revenues of $99,716,346, an increase of $14,832,331, or 17.5 per cent.

Passengers on the French liner Normandie, arriving today from Havre and Southampton, include Jules Romains, the French author; Eric Charrell, London producer; Laura La Plante, actress; Frederic R. Coudert, New York attorney; Joseph M. Schenck of Hollywood, Anna Sten, film actress; Jean Prouvost, French newspaper owner; Robert Marquis, French producer, and Ethel Leginska, pianist and composer.
W.C. Fields's next film for Paramount will be adapted from Julian Street's novelette, "Need of Change."

The Children's Village in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., will be the beneficiary of a luncheon, fashion show and bridge tournament June 3 at the Nassau Country Club in Glen Cove, L.I. Mrs. Eugene L. Maxwell heads the benefit committee.

Plans are going forward rapidly for the publication soon of an "Encyclopedia of the Negro," which will cover all important phases of Negro life and history in Africa, the United States and other parts of the world, according to an announcement made here yesterday on the authorization of Dr. Anson Phelps Stokes, canon of the Washington (D.C.) Cathedral and president of the Phelps-Stokes Fund.

Foreign exchanges showed more reserve in their movement and business last week than previously. The reduction in the "short" interest in the French franc which had been an influence in lifting that bill following Premier-Designate Blum's opposition to devaluation was a factor, coupled with the holiday on Thursday, in limiting business and fluctuations.

NEW HAVEN, May 23. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 80.5, which compares with 81 the week before, 81.6 two weeks before, 82.2 three weeks before and 82.5 four weeks before.

BOSTON, May 24 (AP). -- The Senators, with Jake Powell and their 19-year-old sensation, Buddy Lewis, playing star roles, whipped the Red Sox, 12 to 4, at Fenway Park today. The victory was Washington's second over Boston in two days.

YONKERS, N.Y., May 24. -- Alderman William Slater of Yonkers, this city's defender against the woman in shorts, announced today that he objected to the "class" of hikers who pass through Yonkers and would attempt to bring a court action to close Tibbetts Brook Park, which attracts many of the holiday hikers.

RYE, N.Y., May 24. -- Champion Cedar Pond Charmer, owned and handled by John Goudie of Great Neck, L.I., was adjudged best in the annual Summer specialty show of the Scottish Terrier Club of America, on the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Mark S. Matthews today.

NEW ORLEANS, May 24. -- Except for occasional bursts of activity, the cotton market here was somewhat quiet last week. There was little speculation, business in the contract market being confined to moderate trade buying and price-fixing, coupled with some long liquidation and short covering.
CINCINNATI, May 24 (AP). -- The Reds crushed the Pirates today, touching three pitchers for a 12-to-1 victory, before 11,500.

When Governor LEHMAN originally ordered an inquiry into the murder of SAMUEL DRUKMAN he declared that it would fall naturally into three phases: the arrest and conviction of the murderers, the investigation of charges of police bribery (and brutality) and the investigation of the charges lodged against members of the staff of the District Attorney of Kings County.

The sun, which always shines on the outdoor poetry show in Greenwich Village, shone true to form yesterday at the fourth annual renewal of the exhibition, held in connection with the opening of National Poetry Week last night.

The Dodgers suddenly came to life yesterday, slaughtered a trio of Boston pitchers for a total of fifteen hits, played errorless ball behind Van Lingle Mungo and romped off with an impressive 11.2 victory over the Bees, much to the satisfaction of a crowd of 8,000 at Ebbets Field.

TOKYO, Monday, May 25. -- The special session of the Diet has been extended until tonight by imperial order in the hope that the government will be able to push through the Seditious Documents and Mobilization Secret Bills.

Just because you know the Lord by name doesn't mean that you belong to Him, declared the Rev. Edward J. Kroencke, executive secretary of the Lutheran Inner Mission Society, in his sermon yesterday morning at St. Luke's Lutheran Church, 316 West Forty-sixth Street.

CHICAGO, May 24. -- Liquidation and hedging sales of lard for future delivery, combined with weakness in cotton seed oil prices and selling attributed to that interest, depressed prices of lard futures here last week, so that May was off 2 1/2 cents a hundredweight at the close of trading, while the July was down 5 cents and the September, 15 cents.

SANDS POINT, L.I., May 24. -- After clinging to an overturned canoe for more than an hour early tonight, three young men and a girl were rescued by a passing schooner near Execution Light in Long Island Sound.

Establishment of the C.I.T. Safety Foundation to promote street and highway safety was announced yesterday by Arthur O. Dietz, president of the C.I.T. Corporation, one of the subsidiaries of the Commercial Investment Trust, Inc., of New York.

An important feature of the proposed city charter -- the functions and authority of the Planning Commission -- seems to have received too little public discussion. The primary function of the commission is to make and preserve a master plan of the city. In order to encourage a harmonious development such authority seems necessary.

A new form of informative summary will be used by Halsey. Stuart Co., Inc., for the first time in connection with the forthcoming offering of $22,000,000 of first and refunding mortgage 4 per cent bonds, Series D, of the Peoples Gas Light and Coke Company.

MOSCOW, May 24. -- As the first half of the international chess masters tournament ended today with the matches of the ninth round,. Je R. Capablanca of Cuba was still leading the field of ten experts with a score of 6 1/2 -- 2 1/2.

There can be no true and permanent understanding between nations as long as minorities of the nations of the world are deprived of their liberties, President Roosevelt, speaking through Secretary of the Interior Ickes, declared last night. The President's view was expressed in a message to more than 1,000 Jewish communal leaders attending a dinner of the United Palestine Appeal at the Hotel Astor.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, May 24. -- Addressing the Scandinavian inter-parliamentary conference, which opened here yesterday, Foreign Minister Peter Munch of Denmark said:

Although beaten last week for the first time in circuit competition, Harvard virtually assured itself of the title in the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League with a pair of victories over Pennsylvania on Saturday. The two triumphs gave the Crimson a record of eight games won against one defeat and the pace-setters need only a single success in their three remaining games to win their first championship since 1885.

About 1,800 persons crowded into St. Anthony's Roman Catholic Church, 153 Sullivan Street, at 10:30 A.M. yesterday to attend a solemn pontifical mass celebrated by Archbishop Amleto Giovanni Cicognani, Apostolic Delegate to the United States.

BERLIN, May 23. -- Selling predominated on the Boerse in the first half of the week, but some public utility, potash and non-ferrous metal stocks continued to be bought. Favorable balance sheets for the Hamburg-American and North German Lloyd lines induced active buying of shipping securities that was maintained to the end of the week.

PARIS, May 23. -- The declarations concerning his financial policies made a week ago by Leon Blum, new Premier-designate, made a distinct impression on the Bourse. The tone then suddenly improved and a sharp recovery took place at the beginning of the week in rentes and other French securities, while foreign securities showed heaviness.

ROME, May 22. -- The Italian victory in Abyssinia not only raised the Fascist government to the pinnacle of its popularity but also reestablished complete confidence in the future possibilities of the nation which sees a solution to its problem of economic independence brought much closer by the conquest of the new territories.
CHATSWORTH, N.J., May 24. -- Nearly 1,000 men, including 400 CCC workers and firemen from many towns, battled a forest fire tonight which raged in three counties over a fifty-mile-square area.

The committee on admiralty of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York has been instructed by Clarence J. Shearn, president, to consider the need for revision of the American admiralty law in so far as the responsibility of ship operators is concerned. The committee will submit its findings at the monthly meeting of the association on June 29.

EATONTOWN, N.J., May 24. -- The Evergreen Farms poloists evened the score of their series with the Monmouth Country Club today by winning the fourth game, 7 to 6. Evergreen, trailing by 5 to 4 as the final chukker started, rallied to tally three goals.

The Rev. Dr. Wilbert Webster White, president of the Biblical Seminary in New York, delivered the baccalaureate sermon yesterday afternoon before twenty-seven members of the graduating class at the seminary building, 235 East Forty-ninth Street.

CHICAGO, May 24 (AP). -- A ninth-inning home run by Luke Sewell, his second of the season, settled a pitchers' duel between Babe Phelps and Al Thomas today and gave the White Sox a 7-to-5 victory over the Browns. It was Chicago's seventh victory in eight starts against the Browns this season.

LONDON, May 22. -- To the many factors working against the securities markets here and producing pronounced caution on the part of the investing public this week was added what many persons regarded as a discouraging statement by Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, on the outlook for taxation.

The Treasury Department will announce next week its program of June financing. There will be two parts to it. In the first place, money must be raised with which to meet two issues of notes maturing at an early date and amounting to about billion dollars.

BERLIN, May 22. -- The most important development that influenced the German securities market this week was the unsatisfactory trend reflected in the recent balance sheets of industrial corporations. These financial statements are regarded as eloquent guides to conditions.
Cotton futures fluctuated irregularly last week. At the close of trading on Saturday, the changes on the New York Cotton Exchange ranged from an advance of 8 points to a decline of 7 points.
PARIS, May 23. -- The French wholesale price index for April stood at 374, comparing with 379 for March and with 346 for April, 1935.

More than 500 members of the Salvation Army and their friends spent a "day with God" at the services yesterday morning at Centennial Memorial Hall, 120 West Fourteenth Street, headquarters of the Salvation Army General Edward J. Higgins, who retired in 1934 as head of the Salvation Army, conducted the services and was assisted by his wife.
ROME, May 24. -- Addressing a cheering crowd in the Venezia Square today on the twenty-first anniversary of Italy's entrance into the World War, Premier Mussolini demanded:

Hundreds of Italian women who had sent gold wedding rings to the Italian Red Cross to help finance the Italian expedition into Ethiopia renewed their marriage vows yesterday morning as iron rings from Premier Mussolini were placed on their fingers by their husbands at special services at Roman Catholic churches in the city and vicinity.

MADRID, May 24. -- Eleven Spanish bullfighters, including two star matadors, Corrochano and Valencia II, were arrested today because at the eleventh hour they refused to appear in the arena with the Mexican ace, Armillita. The gala spectacle, scheduled for this afternoon in the Plaza de Toros, had to be suspended.

An active demand for all types of cotton dresses featured trading activity in the women's wear division of the wholesale markets here last week. In some instances retailers experienced considerable difficulty in obtaining deliveries on time. There was a notable trend toward the sheer types and washable materials.

WASHINGTON, May 24. -- Charges that the WPA in Missouri reeks with politics were made today to Harry L. Hopkins, Administrator by Arthur M. Curtis, Republican National Committeeman for that State and assistant to Henry P. Fletcher, chairman of the Republican National Committee.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 24 (AP). -- Baltimore had two big first innings today and scored a double victory over the Chiefs, 7 to 5 and 10 to 5. The Orioles got four runs to start the first game, and staved off a late rally. In the second game they put together four hits, two errors and a walk for six runs and were never headed.

Commodity futures generally were lower last week, with the exception of wool tops, cocoa and coffee, with trading in about average volume for most of the staples. On the cash markets wheat, corn, rye, oats, pork. beef, dairy products, tin, silk and rubber declined, while cotton, hides, printcloths, wool tops, coffee, cocoa and lard were higher.

DUBLIN, May 24. -- Government leaders are taking cognizance of the report issued by the commission of the British Council for Civil Liberties on conditions in Northern Ireland. Premier Viscount Craigavon today said his Cabinet would give careful consideration to the report and would issue a statement during the week.

LONDON, May 22. -- In the week ended on Wednesday the Bank of England bought 1,085,878 of gold, while its note circulation declined 1,660,153. It is assumed in the City from the fall in circulation that the action taken by French banks to check the traffic in gold coin and foreign currency is having some effect, because Bank of England notes had been in particular demand for hoarding abroad.

Paced by Sambo Leslie, who unfolded a complete cycle of base hits in his grand-total of five wallops, the Giants gave the Phillies another going over at the Polo Grounds yesterday to bag the third game of the current series, 13 to 5.
PARIS, May 24 (AP). -- Socialists and Communists, marching behind red flags, sang the "Internationale" today as they paraded in celebration

Although this is the time of year when industrial activity usually slackens, on approach of Summer, no such movement was in evidence last week. THE TIMES index of production rose to the highest of the period, standing 23 3/8 per cent above the same week in 1935.

At 9 A.M. Saturday three young architects were locked into three separate cells on the third floor of the Beaux Arts Institute, 304 East Forty-fourth Street. They were told that they had to draw a plan for a Summer camp for 200 boys and had thirty-six hours in which to do it.

DETROIT, May 24. -- In order that the tariff issue may take its place as a non-partisan economic question, delegates to the Republican National Convention were requested today in a statement signed by Alvan Macauley, president of the Automobile Manufacturers Association, to write into the platform of that party a plank approving the principles of reciprocal trade agreements with foreign countries.

ALBANY, May 24 (AP). -- Smead Jolley's home run opening the eighth inning of the second game, which was to have been a seveninning contest, gave Albany a 3-2 triumph over Newark and an even break in today's double-header. Newark won the first game, 8 -- 1.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP). -- The Bureau of Mines recommended today a daily average crude oil production of 2,838,300 barrels for June to meet the estimated demand. This was 12,000 barrels higher than this month and 187,300 above June, 1935.

The twenty-fifth anniversary of the Truth-in-Advertising Movement was celebrated yesterday by the Advertising Federation of America in a one-hour broadcast over the WEAF network of the National Broadcasting Company.

Cotton manufacturing, both here and abroad, continues to run at a much higher level than a year ago, according to the New York Cotton Exchange Service. Mills in this country are operating on a basis 20 to 25 per cent higher than a year ago, French and German mills 25 to 30 per cent up and English mills about 15 per cent better.

Performing before one of the largest crowds ever to witness a horse show on Long Island, Ard Patrick, aged chestnut gelding belonging to Captain James M. Callicutt, captured the $250 champion jumping sweepstakes in the fourth annual Queens County fixture at Hillside Park, Flushing, yesterday.

BRUSSELS, May 24. -- Socialists were far ahead of other parties in returns late tonight in Belgium's parliamentary elections, and most political observers predicted the nation soon would be directed by a Socialist Premier.

The Gdynia America Line announced yesterday the official delegation coming to New York on the new liner Batory and the official reception committee in charge of welcoming ceremonies attending the liner's arrival on Wednesday. The new liner, a sister ship of the Pilsudski, which was placed in service last year, left Gdynia on May 18, and called at Copenhagne, the company's regular way port.

PARIS, May 24. -- The application of what may be called a policy of peacetime sanctions against nations that will not agree to reduction or limitation of armaments is suggested in an article by Paul Faure, secretary of the Socialist party and a close friend of Leon Blum, in the Populaire this morning.

With the temperature soaring under clear skies to a record heat for the date of 86.4 degrees at 4:40 P.M., more than 1,000,000 persons -- the figure is that of those expert crowd computors, resort officials -- had left the sweltering city yesterday afternoon to seek temporary relief at the beaches and resorts in the metropolitan area.

With Germany's new Zeppelin crossing the North Atlantic for the fourth time within a month, carrying passengers, mail and express, observers of this international race, for air supremacy are wondering which of the great air powers will be next to establish a transatlantic service.

A warning to be prepared for persecution of the Jews was voiced yesterday at the closing exercises of the Congregation Emanu-El Religious School held in Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 24. -- Two keenly contested high-goal polo matches were played in this vicinity today with F. Skiddy Von Stada Jr., the young Harvard ace, capturing the scoring honors with a total of five tallies.

" Foreign Trade Week" could not have been marked more auspiciously than by the speech of Secretary HULL to the Merchants Association of this city. It was comprehensive in grasp and tolerant in tone. The theories which it embodied were buttressed by concrete facts.

Harry Bleefeld, retired cotton goods broker, in whose home at 3,041 Voorhies Avenue, Sheepshead Bay, Paul Wendel, disbarred Trenton attorney, said he had been tortured into a fake confession of the Lindbergh kidnapping, died last night at Kings County Hospital of a complication of diseases.

DETROIT, May 24. -- A State-wide man hunt to arrest every ranking officer of the Black Legion, night-riding terror gang, was ordered at Lansing today by Captain Ira H. Marmon, head of the Michigan State Police.

The seventy-seventh annual art exhibition of the Cooper Union Art School will open tonight and continue until Friday evening. Included in the exhibits will be the work of the 131 students in the day and night divisions of the school, to whom prizes, medals and honorable mention were awarded.

WASHINGTON May 24. -- The Democratic leadership of the Senate will be put to the test this week to see if it can make good on the plan to complete all essential legislation and adjourn the present session of Congress by June 6, week from Saturday.
MONTREAL, May 24 (AP). -- The Toronto Maple Leafs and Montreal Royals divided a double-header today, each winning by the same score, 4 to 3.

With the sixty-first Withers history, the outlook for the sixty-eighth Belmont Stakes on June 6 is more brilliant than ever, and it is to be hoped that none of the formidable contenders for the 3-year-old championship will be laid low by injury.

Twenty-five hundred members of the Kings County American Legion paraded yesterday afternoon from the Grand Army Plaza through Prospect Park to the Todd Memorial Honor Roll, where special exercises were held. Twenty gold star mothers and nearly 6,000 residents of Brooklyn attended the services.
CLEVELAND, May 24 (AP). -- Lloyd Brown limited the Tigers to two singles today as the Indians blasted Schoolboy Rowe from the mound in two innings to win an easy 7-to-0 decision before 16,000 fans.

The special grand jury investigating the Drukman murder case will meet in Brooklyn this morning to consider among other matters the advisability of replying to Governor Lehman's letter of last Friday, in which he said he would defer action on the jury's request for the removal of District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan of Kings.

VIENNA, May 24 (AP). -- Prince Ernst von Starhemberg, leader of the Fascist Heimwehr, was alone in a secluded room of the Vienna Heimwehr headquarters today seeking a decision which may vitally affect the fate of Austria.
MANILA, May 24. -- Authorities said today they had learned a general strike would start Wednesday in Manila and the provinces.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., May 24. -- A bad start did not prevent Herc Atkin from sailing his Jubilee to a handy triumph over eight other members of the Western Long Island Sound fleet of the Star Class today in the first of a series of special Sunday races conducted by the Port Washington Yacht Club.
A continuance of the demand for flats and dwellings that has marked realty trading in the city in recent months was evident in deals announced over the week-end.

Decrying the charge of "militarism," Abraham J. Rosenblum, commander of the First American Legion District of New York, asserted yesterday that the Legion, although standing squarely for preparedness, was "the greatest pacifist organization in the United States."

MELBOURNE, Australia, May 24. -- Until executives have studied the new tariff changes opinions are withheld in many industries. Automobile manufacturers expect foreign car prices will rise and that there will be a scarcity of spare parts. They see disaster to assembling plants of American companies.

The announcement of State Senator George R. Fearon that he is "willing" to accept the Republican nomination for Governor gives Syracuse two aspirants for the nomination and has placed Clarence R. King, Onondaga County chairman, in a difficult position, according to opinions expressed by Republican leaders here yesterday.

As is their ancient springtime custom. The Players tonight administer a final fillip to the season. At the National, for the traditional single week, they will skip across the years and bring back George Ade's "The County Chairman," first acted here in 1903 at the old Wallack's.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 24. -- Rail down with all sail of her new rig, including a Genoa jib, set, Commodore Rudolph J. Schaefer's Edlu had a real tryout for the Bermuda race in the special regatta today of the Larchmont Yacht Club.

PARIS, May 23. -- The statement of the Bank of France for May 15 shows a decrease of 514,000,000 francs in the gold reserve, while bills discounted rose 471,000,000 francs, evidently by reason of the discounting of treasury bills. At the same time loans against securities and defense bonds decreased 200,000,000 francs.
John L. Lewis says "It is a sad commentary on our form of government when every decision of the Supreme Court seems designed to fatten capital and starve and destroy labor."

HACKENSACK, N.J., May 24. -- The epidemic of septic sore throat that has taken eight lives in Southwest Bergen County will form the basis of a campaign to ban raw milk in the city of Paterson, it was announced here today by Claude R. Newel, District Health Officer for Northern New Jersey.

The American I.G. Chemical Corporation reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended on March 31 a consolidated net income of $3,302,939 after taxes, interest and other charges. This was equal to $4.17 each on the 491,647 shares of A stock outstanding and 42 cents each on the 3,000,000 shares of B stock.

A trend toward wider giving by employe groups was noted yesterday by Laurence M. Marks, chairman of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee, as he studied early responses to group solicitation in support of the committee's effort to raise $1,500,000 for private welfare agencies in this city.

The Manhattan College baseball team defeated the New York Athletic Club nine, 3 to 1, yesterday at Travers Island for its second victory of the season over the Winged Foot and its twelfth triumph in fourteen starts this season. The game was witnessed by 5,000 persons, one of the largest crowds ever to see a game on the Winged Foot grounds.

PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., May 24. -- One of the features of the biennial meeting of the board of directors of the Hebrew Sheltering Guardian Society at the home at Pleasantville this afternoon was the birthday greeting extended to Adolph Lewisohn of New York, president of the institution, who will celebrate his eighty-seventh birthday Wednesday.

ELMONT, L.I., May 24. -- Five persons were injured slightly at 6 A.M. today when $5,000 worth of fireworks exploded here. The series of five blasts was heard for twenty miles. The explosions followed a fire in one of five small buildings of the Long Island Fireworks Company, at 499 Kirkham Avenue.

BOSTON, May 24 (AP). -- Young Republicans of New England called upon their party today to meet "the challenge to American ideals" and submitted a program as an expression of their opinion to the national convention.
Dr. Lawrence Kurzrok, seeking his fourth consecutive Long Island clay court tennis crown, defeated George Smith, 6 -- 3, 8 -- 6, in a first-round match at the Mammoth courts in Brooklyn yesterday.

The Citizens Budget Commission made public yesterday a thirty-one-page brief, addressed to Governor Lehman, asking him to veto a number of bills affecting city salaries that the commission estimated would cause a $37,075,000 increase in next year's city budget.

All employes of the World's Fair to be held in New York City in 1939 and 1940 to be hired at annual salaries of $3,000 or less will be selected on a merit basis from eligible lists prepared by the Municipal Civil Service Commission, Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair corporation, announced yesterday.

Seating arrangements for the State delegations at the Republican National Convention have been completed. The rival strategists can now proceed to make their plans accordingly. No responsible manager would dream of joining battle for his candidate without a thorough knowledge of the terrain.

PITTSBURGH, May 24. -- Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 70 per cent of capacity, unchanged from the preceding week and 2 points under the recent high rate, which was the highest since March, 1930.

Late in the performance of the "Elks Minstrels and Varieties of 1936," which was given before an enthusiastic benefit audience at St. James Theatre last night, the chief interlocutor who had played stooge haltingly throughout a long evening to two judges found himself in responding to a planned query, "Why don't you become an actor?"

Immediate abandonment by the administration in Washington of its silver-purchase policy as "wasteful and harmful" was recommended to Congress in a statement issued yesterday by the Economists National Committee on Monetary Policy from its headquarters at 70 Fifth Avenue.

PHILADELPHIA, May 24. -- Organized labor of Philadelphia today took steps toward direct participation in politics. Laying what was interpreted by some as the ground-work for an independent labor party, the Central Labor Union unanimously approved a resolution calling for the organization of union members by wards.

Since an Irishman is supposed to be handy with his fists, Paddy Boylan punched the bail into the net for the goal that gave the Cavan football team, champion of Ireland, a 9-9 tie with the very surprising all-New York selected fifteen that opposed it in the second and concluding game of the Gaelic football series at the Yankee Stadium yesterday before a crowd of 15,000.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., May 24. -- Special memorial services for soldiers were held in a number of churches in Westchester County today, one of the principal ceremonies being the massing of colors on the village green in front of historic St. Paul's Church at Eastchester, on the outskirts of this city.

CHICAGO, May 24. -- General rains are needed over a large part of the Spring wheat areas to give the new grain a good start. Special attention is being given to the territory between the Red River on the eastern boundary of Minnesota and the Dakotas and the Missouri River.

CINCINNATI, May 24 (AP). -- Pacing the finish field of twenty-five, Ernie Crosbie of the Detroit Track Club won the national A.A.U. 50,000-meter walk today in 5 hours 16 minutes 16 seconds, too slow to qualify for the Olympics. The 31 mile 125 yard race was to have been a means of selecting competitors for the Berlin games, provided the contestants finished within five hours.

Louis Hasselmans, conductor of the French repertoire at the Metropolitan Opera House for the last fourteen years, has resigned from his post, it was disclosed yesterday. An exchange of letters between Mr. Hasselmans and Edward Johnson, the general manager, brought the conductor's Metropolitan association to an end.

LONDON, May 22. -- There are no signs of any real reaction in British trade apart from the slowing down of exports. All current statistics point to the maintenance of the healthy position achieved during the last two years of steady progress.

WASHINGTON, May 24. -- An additional list of applications for registration as brokers and dealers in the over-the-counter markets, some of them supplementing previous application which had become effective was made public yesterday by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Coast Guardsmen transferred 102 persons from a fishing boat yesterday afternoon and during the day towed four other vessels to various ports on Long Island.
BUFFALO, N.Y., May 24 (AP). -- Staging an eight-run uprising in the third inning today, the Rochester Red Wings defeated the Bisons 14 to 11, to square the series.

ALBANY, May 24. -- Through the combined activities of the New York State Employment Service and the National Re-employment Service 33,428 persons were placed in jobs during April, Elmer F. Andrews, Industrial Commissioner, reported today.

DETROIT, May 24. -- The roundup of "night riders" of the hooded Black Legion spread today as officials directed their inquiry to reports that a membership totaling 135,000 in Michigan alone may be responsible for fifty deaths.

Another step in the refunding program of the Consolidated Edison of New York will be taken today with the offering to the public of a new issue of $55,000,000 of Brooklyn Edison Company, Inc., 3 1/4 per cent consolidated mortgage bonds by a banking group headed by Morgan Stanley Co., Inc.

Empire Day was observed yesterday afternoon with a service in St. Paul's Episcopal Chapel, Trinity Parish, Broadway and Fulton Street. Representatives of the British Great War Veterans of America and delegates of several other British societies were present.

Following the signing of an order approving the closing documents by Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson, the completion of the plan of reorganization of the Sherry-Netherland Hotel, at Fifth Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street, was announced yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 24. -- A great increase in governmental control over the social and economic life of the nation is inevitable, but it "must steer by the lodestar of the Constitution as a living thing," Mgr. Robert F. Keegan said at the auditorium here tonight in his presidential address to 7,000 delegates to the National Conference of Social Work.

Plans for taking 88,000 members of the Mormon Church off the public relief rolls and placing them under the care of the churches by Oct. 1 were outlined last night at the evening services at the Mormon Church, Broadway at Seventy-sixth Street, by J. Reuben Clark, a member of the First Presidency of the church.

WHITE RIVER JUNCTION, Vt., May 24 (AP). -- New Hampshire investigators sought an elderly, white-haired man tonight for questioning in the mountain-top slaying of a middle-aged woman known to them as "Mrs. Grace Hurley of Boston."

ST. LOUIS, May 24 (AP). -- Pitching flawless ball, Leroy Parmelee hurled the league-leading St. Louis Cardinals to a 7-to-1 victory today over the Chicago Cubs before 22,500 fans, the largest home crowd of the season.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, May 24. -- Leo Sack, United States Minister to Costa Rica, took Governor Harry W. Nice of Maryland to task for an interview attacking the Roosevelt administration, published here today in the newspaper Tribuna. Mr. Nice is on a tour of this region.

The new Parole Law in relation to making indeterminate all sentences to State prisons, commented on editorially in THE NEW YORK TIMES, has significance not yet fully appreciated. Consideration of its probable results makes it appear as a link of the greatest importance in the strengthening of law enforcement machinery in this State.

The difficulties that the Senate Finance Committee is having with the Tax Bill would not be a fraction as great as they are if the questions raised were solely fiscal and not political. The problem, in this election year, is to get more revenues into the Treasury without letting any but a negligible minority of the voters become aware that they are paying more taxes.

WASHINGTON, May 24. -- John J. Pelley, president of the Association of American Railroads, made public today a letter written by him to Senator Wheeler of Montana, chairman of the Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce, in which be asserts that if the long-and-short-haul clause in the Interstate Commerce Act were repealed the railroads would retrieve a large volume of freight now handled by other forms of transportation.

PARIS, May 24. -- Mrs. Dorothy Andrus of Stamford, Conn., leading American entry, withdrew from the women's singles of the French hard court tennis championships today when doctors at the American Hospital discovered she had broken a bone in her right arm.

CHICAGO, May 24. -- Advances in science are gradually shifting responsibility for evolution of life on earth from the "hands" of God to the "shoulders" of mankind, Professor Arthur H. Compton of the University of Chicago declared today.

LONDON, May 24. -- "Murder on Account," by Hayden Talbot and Kathlyn Hayden, is rated by The London Times as an ingenious play so far as marshaling of facts is concerned, but its interest is almost exclusively confined to the plot.

Another warning against a Red menace, the second within eight days, was sounded yesterday from the pulpit of St. Patrick's Cathedral when the Rev. Robert E. Woods, preaching at high mass, bade Catholics prepare themselves for an approaching onslaught by "the crystallized forces of evil, to which we may put the name communism.''

HYDE PARK, N.Y., May 24. -- With a pitching arm still in trim from throwing out the ball to open the Washington baseball season, President Roosevelt performed a like ceremony this afternoon for the Robin Hoods, his home-town team.

More than 2,000 truckmen and their employes yesterday abandoned plans for a general trucking strike they were prepared to call in opposition to the Eastern railroads' store-door delivery system. The strike plans were made before the Interstate Commerce Commission on Saturday suspended until Nov. 1 the store-door delivery tariffs that were to have become effective today.

BOSTON, May 24. -- Asserting that the National Chamber of Commerce merely assembled members' opinions instead of facts in its efforts to solve business problems, Edward A. Filene, Boston merchant and economist, announced his resignation from the organization tonight.

William B. Leeds, wealthy sportsman, whose marriage to former Princess Xenia of Russia ended in 1930, revealed yesterday in a cablegram to his secretary in New York that he had been married Saturday at sea to Miss Olive Hamilton, former telephone operator, whom he rescued from drowning about six years ago.
Writing on unemploymemt in THE TIMES of May 17, Louis Stark notes that government is to join with industry in a new survey of technological displacement of men by machines.

CHICAGO, May 24 (AP). -- Movie cameras were used by detectives today to produce a picturization of Thomas Starr's confession that he strangled and beat Mrs. Lillian Guild, 59, to death in her Y.W.C.A. Hotel room, May 9.

The need for some way of curbing perjury in the courts was emphasized by Magistrate Peter M. Daly at the annual communion breakfast of the Holy Name Society of the Fire Department of Brooklyn and Queens yesterday morning at the Columbus Club, 1 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn.
The text of the address of Secretary of the Interior Ickes at the dinner of the United Palestine Appeal at the Hotel Astor last night follows:

CLEVELAND, May 24. -- A rival Socialist party was organized here tonight after the convention of the Socialist party now in session here refused to seat the "Old Guard" delegation from New York and by this action put it out of the party.

ROME, May 24. -- Today, the anniversary of Italy's entry into the World War, which was celebrated throughout Italy with particular patriotic fervor created by the victory in East Africa, twice gave Premier Benito Mussolini occasion to reaffirm by implication his belief that a European war was inevitable.

WASHINGTON, May 24. -- Orders will be issued by the War Department tomorrow assigning Major Gen. Charles E. Kilbourne, now commanding the Second Division at San Antonio, Texas, to the command of the Sixth Corps Area with headquarters at Chicago.

A luncheon to mark the fifty-eighth anniversary of the founding of the New York Exchange for Woman's Work will be held June 2 at the Exchange Restaurant, 541 Madison Avenue. Mrs. Robert C. Ream is president of the organization, which was founded in May of 1878 by the late Mrs. William G. Choate to aid needy women in earning their own livelihood.

A united Methodist Church, with branches in every country, that will act as an international force for peace and good-will among nations was pictured by the Rev. Robert H. Dolliver, pastor of the John Street Methodist Church, 44 John Street, in his sermon yesterday morning.

ALBANY, May 24. -- Governor Lehman signed today the bill of Senator Burchill, New York Democrat, authorizing the Public Service Commission to fix gas and electric rates on a sliding scale providing for their automatic adjustment to changes in operating expenses.

The Declaration of Independence was nothing more than a political platform, former Governor Alfred E. Smith said last night at a dinner of the Catholic War Veterans, Inc., in the Hotel Commodore.
