More than 600 persons attended the dinner, at which medals of the Order of St. Sebastian were conferred on prominent churchmen and laymen, including Mr. Smith.

The Hebrew Technical Institute will hold its graduation exercises tonight at 8:30 o'clock at Cooper Union, Eighth Street and Third Avenue. Dr. Edgar S. Barney, principal, will present diplomas to the following 101 students:

ST. PAUL, May 24 (AP). -- Howard Y. Williams, national organizer for the Farmer-Labor party, said today that barring "something unusual," a Presidential candidate would not be considered at the national "third party" conference in Chicago May 30 and 31.

The Right Rev. William T. Manning, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of the diocese of New York, preached the sermon at opening services yesterday morning at St. Ambrose Negro Church, 130th Street, west of Fifth Avenue. About 1,500 worshipers crowded into the church building, filled the vestibule and overflowed into the street.
GARFIELD, N.J., May 24. -- Nearly fifty occupants of more than fifteen houses here were forced to flee from their homes today when a fire destroyed five of the houses and a lumber yard.

After nearly an hour of laborious effort, the huskies of Police Emergency Squad 1 succeeded yesterday afternoon in getting a big black and gray cat out of a Greenwich Village chimney, but not the way they intended.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, May 24. -- The mere fact that the British amateur golf championship starts over its famous public links tomorrow did not cause the St. Andrews town council to relax its dictum against Sunday play today.

THE big man wearing the brown suit, brown felt hat, sun-tanned complexion and eyeglasses was Racing Secretary John B. Campbell. He was seated in a clubhouse box at Belmont Park, slowly thumbing a program. Being of a mild and mellow disposition, he was just the man to give a casual visitor a little lesson in the A, B, C's of the turf.

JIBUTI, French Somaliland, May 24. -- Warrant Officer L.J. Bunner, pharmacist with a British ambulance unit in Ethiopia, whose arrest by Italians when he was leaving Diredawa to undergo treatment for rabies following the bite of a mad dog caused a stir in London, arrived here today.

The volume of passenger traffic and the value of foreign commerce moving through the port of New York last year showed increases over corresponding figures for 1934, according to a survey made by the Maritime Association.

PORTSMOUTH, Ohio, May 24 (AP). -- About 5,500 employes of the Portsmouth plant of the Wheeling Steel Corporation, idle because of a strike, await the outcome of a conference this week between Joseph K. Gaither, international vice president of the Amalgamated Association of Iron, Steel and Tin Workers, and R.M. Pilkington, United States labor conciliator, ordered here by Secretary Perkins.

A woman was burned so severely that physicians fear that she may die, two others were rescued, and fourteen firemen were injured in a fire early this morning in a restaurant and apartments in the four-story building at 371-73 Lexington Avenue, at the southeast corner of Forty-first Street.

Seth Bingham's American folk cantata, "Wilderness Stone," received its world premiere last night at the Manhattan Theatre in a performance sponsored by the Federal Music Project. It was performed by the New York Civic Orchestra and a mixed chorus of seventy voices, under the direction of Hugh Ross.
WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP). -- Benjamin Nathan Cardozo, the Supreme Court justice, was 66 years old today.

BERLIN, May 24 (AP). -- Efforts of German industrialists to put themselves in a position to share in the profits of Italy's program of expansion were seen today in an announcement that the Rheinmetall-Borsig Company had received a contract to build a 3,500,000-mark oil refinery for a corporation at Trieste.

CHICAGO, May 24. -- One of the most puzzling situations for wheat traders in recent years has recently developed with the turning of what was expected generally to be a bullish situation into one of the most bearish positions. Prices of all grains have declined and now are near the lowest levels of the season.
LONDON, May 24. -- The United States has become during the past year the most important country in the world for the promoters of the Irish Sweepstakes.

The founding 125 years ago of the Spring Street Presbyterian Church, 244 Spring Street, was celebrated yesterday with a special service at the church, which, when it was established, was the most northerly of all Presbyterian churches in the city and which today is the Presbyterian church furthest south.

A new issue of 200,000 Brandy-wine Shares will be offered today by Craigmyle. Marache Co. and Bond Goodwin, Inc., at approximately $24 a share, the price being determined by the cost of the underlying security. Each share will represent a one-hundredth interest in one share of common stock of the Christiana Securities Company, a holding company for du Pont interests.

SCARBOROUGH ON THE HUDSON, N.Y., May 24. -- More than 300 veterans and friends attended the annual memorial services this afternoon of the Veterans of the First Provisional Regiment of the New York Guard at the Memorial Boulder on the Broadway front of Sleepy Hollow Cemetery at Scarborough.

In a statement issued before he left for Chicago to attend meetings of the national executive board of the International Seamen's Union, Joseph Curran, chairman of the striking seamen's committee here, declared yesterday that he was "willing to go more than half way" to settle the strike, and would call off the walkout if union officials would agree to a referendum.
Connecticut's investigation of Niantic River striped bass, started less than a month ago, already is producing encouraging results.

Excessive rainfall in parts of Texas, with drought still unbroken in parts of the Eastern belt, brought an advance in prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday. With July holding in a range of 3 points, October rose to 10 1/2 cents a pound, and the list ended with gains of 1 to 4 points.

A study of the reactions of 3,345 New York City children, between the ages of 10 and 13, to radio programs was reported upon yesterday by Dr. Azriel L. Eisenberg of Teachers College, Columbia University.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- Paving the way for its Summer adjournment next Monday, the Supreme Court cleared its docket today of all except two cases ready for decision, namely, the test of the New York State Minimum Wage Law as it relates to women and a dispute between Wyoming and Colorado over water rights.
BOSTON, May 25 (AP). -- Fritz Ostermueller shut out the Washington Senators today, 6 to 0, allowing only four hits. The Red Sox collected four runs in the first inning.
CLEVELAND, May 25. -- Norman Thomas of New York, twice national standard-bearer of his party, was nominated again today for the Presidency of the United States by the National Socialist Convention.

Supervision of over 2,000 appraisals of real estate in all sections of New York State, for property totaling more than $250,000,000 in value, has indicated plainly that in Queens and on Long Island are excellent opportunities and probabilities of important real estate development in the very near future, according to Harry K. Keller head of the appraisal department of the State Mortgage Commission.

Investors in Series Q of defaulted guaranteed mortgage certificates sold by the New York Title and Mortgage Company will receive checks for $409,000 in interest and principal before July 1, and will have received a total of $614,398 within nine months.

The French liner Normandie, sailing tonight for England and France, will have among her passengers Dr. Alexis Carrel, American scientist and author; Frederick H. Prince, Boston financier, and Mrs. Prince; George Blumenthal, banker; William Gaxton, actor, and Mrs. Gaxton, and Tristan Bernard, French playwright and author.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., May 25. -- After three days of carefree rest spent at his mother's home here, President Roosevelt started back tonight to the capital where he will spend a fortnight before making his first political tour of the Summer.

DETROIT, May 25. -- Twelve members of the Black Legion, secret terrorist band, were held without bail today in Comon Pleas Court here on warrants charging them with murder and kidnapping in the vengeance slaying of Charles A. Poole, young WPA worker.

THOMAS PRYOR GORE is one of the bravest and wisest men in the Senate. His conscientious vote against the war cost him his seat, which he held for fourteen years after 1907. Re-elected in 1930, he is again a candidate. In his present term he gave another proof of his rare quality as a public man by voting against AAA on the ground of its unconstitutionality.

LONDON, May 25. -- A rush of betting support today hammered down the odds against William Woodward's Boswell and left the American-owned colt a strong fourth choice for the Derby at Epsom Downs on Wednesday.

Net income of the A.O. Smith Corporation for the twelve months ended on April 30 was $831,748 after depreciation, income taxes and other deductions, according to a report issued yesterday. After dividends paid on the 7 per cent preferred stock, now retired, the income was equal to $1.64 each on 498,575 shares of no-par common stock.

Edward V. Siedle has been elected president of the Rye-Harrison chapter of the Westchester County Realty Board for a term of one year. Gilbert J. Stevens was elected vice president; Edna M. Drummond, secretary, and E. Bird Kelly, treasurer.

Despite high pressure water towers, two fireboats and thirty-two pieces of fire fighting apparatus, the Abel grain elevator, a six-story grain-filled structure at the foot of Thirty-second Street on the East River, was damaged last night to the extent of $300,000, according to the estimate of the owners.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 25. -- The mysterious disappearance nearly a week ago of Captain Kenneth E. Kline of the United States Army, who is Associate Professor of Military Science at Rutgers University, was disclosed here today by the police.

The Federal Art Project Gallery at 7 East Thirty-eighth Street will open to the public today an exhibition of work carried out by the American Index of Design under the WPA. A preview was held yesterday afternoon, attended by members of the advisory committee, collectors, museum and historical society officials and WPA and Federal Art Project Administrators.

LONDON, May 25. -- Five plays or parts of plays, performed for the finals of the Community Theatre Festival of the British Drama League at Old Vic tonight, were chosen from the productions of more than 750 amateur dramatic societies in competition for a trophy given by Lord Howard De Walden.

Mail orders received in this market yesterday on Summer apparel and accessories were heavy. Chiffon and other types of sheer dresses up to the $10.75 wholesale price line were outstanding, continuing the improvement noted in the wholesale markets last week.

MADISON, N.J., May 25. -- John Hoctor, professional at Locust Grove, and Bobby Wilkinson, his amateur partner, clipped seven strokes from par today to win the New Jersey P.G.A. pro-amateur tournament at Braidburn with a 66.

The Spring season's fourth performance of "The Bartered Bride" in English took place at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. A large audience greeted the spirited interpretation with as much enthusiasm as at the preceding performances.

Commodity futures were moderately higher in quiet trading in the local markets yesterday. In the cash markets wheat, corn, rye, cocoa and silk were higher, while oats, cotton, butter, eggs, lard, tin and wool tops declined.

The United Drydocks Corporation refused yesterday to recognize the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America as sole representative of the 2,000 men employed at its Staten Island plant. The corporation offered, however, to arbitrate other demands for a new wage and working contract with the union, which has threatened to call a strike unless its demands, submitted last week, are granted.

Although George Ade's "The County Chairman" is no great shakes as drama it is a sociable piece of work. Being in a sociable frame of mind at the close of a busy season The Players revived it at the National last evening for a week of affable festivity.

Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, writing "as a taxpayer," has urged Governor Lehman to veto the nine pay restoration bills adopted by the Legislature, the Citizens Budget Commission, Inc., announced yesterday.
It must be discouraging for Secretary Hull to find the techniques of the writers for THE NEW YORK TIMES appearing somewhat inconsistent in their discussion of our foreign trade.
FITCHBURG, Mass., May 25. -- Gene Sarazen opened the defense of his Massachusetts open title, his last remaining golf crown, with a par 71 today on the long and windswept Oak Hill course.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- The House committee investigating the Townsend old-age pension plan will meet tomorrow to consider its course in contempt proceedings against Dr. Francis E. Townsend, founder and head of the movement. Dr. Townsend defied the committee last week and walked out of the hearing room announcing that he would not return except under arrest.
LONDON, May 25. -- In deference presumably to Anglo-Italian relations, there will be no official government welcome for Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia when he arrives in England incognito.

Jules Romains, the French playwright and novelist whose gigantic novel, "Men of Good Will," has already been presented to the world in ten volumes with more to come, arrived yesterday on the French liner Normandie to lecture at Mills College, in Oakland.

Last Sunday a Danish voice interpreted, with restrained hopefulness, the attitude of the smaller States toward the League of Nations, but at the same time sounded a significant warning to the Great Powers represented at Geneva. No countries have been stancher supporters of the League than the Scandinavian States.

By a vote of 70 to 57, the New York County Committee of the American Legion failed last night to endorse the booklet "Americanism -- What Is it?" prepared by its Americanism committee. Before adjourning the regular monthly meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania the county committee unanimously expressed its confidence in the motives if not the acts of its Americanism committee.

LONDON, May 25. -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden protested today in the House of Commons against anti-British propaganda radioed by Italy every week to the inhabitants of India and Palestine in their native tongues.
ST. LOUIS, May 25. -- A pinch single by Jim (Ripper) Collins with the bases loaded in the ninth gave Frankie Frisch's Cardinals a 2-to-1 victory in their series finale with the Cubs today.

HEWLETT HARBOR, L.I., May 25. -- Combatting a strong wind that swept across the links from Hewlett Bay and kicked up sand from the dunes and bunkers, Miss Ruth Adel of the Queens Valley Golf Club, Forest Hills, today fashioned a sparkling 84 to set the pace for a field of sixty-five starters at the Seawane Club in the thirty-sixth annual championship of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association.

A resumption of speculative interest in a few selected railroad and industrial loans was the feature of an otherwise dull and routine trading session in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The trend was toward moderately higher levels in all sections, except among United States Government issues, the latter easing off slightly in a mild corrective movement.

Primo Carnera and Leroy Haynes wound up training yesterday for their ten-round bout at Ebbets Field tomorrow night. Both boxers were reported in splendid shape by Andy Neiderreiter, who is staging the fight. Carnera expects to scale 260 pounds and at that figure will have a sixty-pound advantage over his Philadelphia rival.

EAST WILLISTON, L.I., May 25. -- Willie Klein and Charles Trunz, pro and amateur respectively, triumphed in the Long Island Golf Association's one-day combined tourney at Wheatley Hills today by putting together 32 and 35 for a 67.

LONDON, May 25 (Canadian Press). -- An amazing feat by Hedley Verity, Yorkshire's clever spin bowler, gave the champions victory by an innings and 153 runs over Kent in a county cricket match at Sheffield today. Verity bowled with deadly effect in the second innings, taking nine wickets for 12 runs.

Max Martin, 200, of Columbus, Ohio, defeated Leo Wallick, 200, of Germany, in the feature wrestling event at the New York Coliseum in the Bronx last night before 2,000 spectators. Referee Patsy Haley halted the bout in 20:41, disqualifying Wallick for improper use of the forearm.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., May 25. -- Mrs. Pauline V. Rogers, widow and third wife of Colonel Henry H. Rogers, asked Surrogate Pelletreau here today for a $1,000 monthly increase in her allowance from the estate of the oil man because she "cannot live on $5,000 a month."

DUBLIN, Irish Free State, May 25 (AP). -- Nine hundred and fifty-seven Americans were richer by a total of $1,324,080 tonight as the counterfoil drums of the eighteenth Irish Hospital Sweepstakes ceased to revolve. Four Americans won $26,687 each in residual prizes, while 521 won consolation cash prizes of approximately $500 each.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., May 25. -- Bill Goldbeck and Jim Rushin carried off the honors today in the second pro-amateur tournament of the Westchester County Golf Association on the rolling course of the Rockwood Hall Country Club.

Mrs. Florence van Courtlandt Field Parsons, widow of John E. Parsons, attorney, left an estate appraised yesterday at $1,402,864 gross and $1,243,239 net. She died in Pittsfield, Mass., on Oct. 15, 1922.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- A joint resolution creating a commission of seventeen members to study the question of Puerto Rican independence was introduced in the Senate today by Senator Millard E. Tydings, chairman of the Committee on Territories and Insular Affairs.

Senator Vandenberg of Michigan, who has definitely taken over the minority leadership in Congress, is quietly completing the most definite, yet liberal, anti-New Deal record of any Republican. By the time his party convention meets at Cleveland that record will be ready for campaign consideration by the delegates if anything happens to the Landon boom.
WASHINGTON, May 25. -- The opinion of the Supreme Court minority on the Municipal Bankruptcy Act of 1934 was as follows:

BRUSSELS, May 25. -- The new Belgian party of Rexists, whose political emblem is a cardboard broom symbolizing determination to "sweep banksters and politico-financiers out of office," recorded sensational successes in yesterday's general election.

Defense testimony that John Fiorenza, on trial in General Sessions for the murder of Mrs. Nancy Evans Titterton, was a dementia praecox case with a split mentality incapable of realizing the nature and quality of his acts, was bitterly attacked yesterday by District Attorney William C. Dodge.

A committee of eighty-two economists has recommended a policy which ought to be incorporated into a plank for both national platforms. This is repeal of the Silver Purchase Act of 1934. Experience has clearly demonstrated the harm done by this measure and its complete failure to accomplish what was predicted for it.

With gold coming to market at its present record-breaking pace and with the prospect of an increase in production in South Africa, Russia and other countries, the rise of commodity prices seems likely to continue "considerably further than the small beginning that it has already made," according to the quarterly review of J. Henry Schroder Co. of London, bankers, which was received here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- Senate consideration of the bill to provide more strict Federal regulation of the commodity exchanges of the country almost bogged down today in a quarrel between wheat and cotton interests. As a result, the measure had made little progress toward adoption when the Senate recessed this afternoon.

Public offering of a new issue of $2,000,000 first mortgage 3 3/4 per cent bonds of the Minnesota Transfer Railway Company will be made today by Lazard Freres Co., Inc., the Wells-Dickey Company and Kalman Co. The bonds, dated June 1, 1936, and maturing on June 1, 1956, will be priced at 105.80 and accrued interest, to yield about 3.35 per cent.

Eddington and Jeans, the Cambridge University fancy figure wizards, are due in this country shortly for a conference of higher mathematicians. Well, they can't come too soon. A grand problem already is awaiting them and Dr. Einstein can come to bat with his slide rule if he cares to join in the fun.
Enrico Venturi of Italy, holder of the lightweight boxing championship of Europe, defeated Al Roth, plucky Bronx warrior, in the feature bout of ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Palace last night.
LONDON, May 25. -- New York will see two famous English actors -- John Gielgud and Leslie Howard -- as Hamlet in the Autumn.

PARIS, May 25. -- Jean Borotra, still the Bounding Basque at 39, teamed with 19-year-old Marcel Bernard today to upset Great Britain's Davis Cup combination of George Patrick Hughes and Charles R.D. Tuckey in the final round of men's doubles in the French hard court tennis championships.
BERLIN, May 25. -- The German Foreign Office has embarked on its Whitsuntide holiday, so undertakings of a decisive nature are not expected during the next fortnight.

Duplicate contract bridge is not a gambling game, Justices Hackenburg, Kernochan and Brady decreed in Special Sessions yesterday. They acquitted Mildred Lovejoy, 34 years old, and Adelaide Neuwirth, 35, bridge instructors, who had been arrested April 28 by Detective Denis V. Clare of Commissioner Valentine's special squad in a raid on their bridge studio at 853 Seventh Avenue.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 25. -- Brazil will not embark on any trade expansion scheme that clashes with the commercial treaty with the United States, a member of the Federal Trade Council asserted today. He denied that accords with countries having conpensated currencies would change Brazil's commercial policies.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- The State Department is studying action by three countries, including Japan, that may have an adverse effect on United States trade, with a view to further diplomatic action, Secretary Cordell Hull revealed today.

Vibration on the new liner Normandie, which caused her officers and officials of the French Line several months of worry after she had been in operation last season, has been completely eliminated, they said yesterday when the liner docked from Havre and Southampton.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 25. -- -Gray-Dawn, the home of Mr. and Mrs. Oliver David Donaldson overlooking New Rochelle Harbor, was the setting this afternoon of a garden fete, in celebration of the fortieth anniversary of the founding of the New Rochelle branch of the National Plant, Flower and Fruit Guild.

DEVON, Pa., May 25. -- Ross Campbell Shaw's gray gelding Grayflex, won a jumping event for one of the biggest fields of open green hunters in years as the annual Devon Horse Show got under way today before a colorful crowd.

LIVINGSTON MANOR, N.Y., May 25. -- Up here in the greening valleys of the southern Catskills you expect to hear great tales of trout fishing in the waning days of May. For this is the land of the Willowemoc and the Beaverkill, fabled streams whose praises have been sung for generations by men who angle with a fly.

Gross earnings in April of the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway were higher than in the corresponding month in 1935, but expenses also increased, S.T. Bledsoe, president, reported yesterday. Passenger traffic began "a good seasonal movement" on May 15, when Summer rates went into effect, he added.

Highlights of the thirty-second annual convention of the Advertising Federation of America to be held in Boston June 28 to July 2, were announced yesterday. Bruce Barton, chairman of the board, Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn, Inc., will discuss "The Master Key in Business; Sensing What the People Want," at the luncheon on July 1.

A new variety of iris, as yet unnamed, was chosen yesterday at the opening of the iris exhibition in Horticultural Hall, Rockefeller Center, as the outstanding bloom in the show. It was developed by Howard R. Glutzbeck of Lynbrook, L.I., and is tagged simply Seedling 102-2.

VILLANOVA, Pa., May 25. -- Villanova closed its most successful baseball season in many years by defeating Long Island University today for the second time this season, 2 to 1. The Main Liners captured thirteen out of sixteen games.
ALBANY, May 25 (AP). -- Newark shut out Albany, 1 to 0, tonight to take the lead in the series, two games to one.

A former cotton broker who was indicted for mail fraud last August and was freed in bail of $3,500 was required to post additional bail for the same amount when he was arraigned yesterday before Garrett W. Cotter, United States Commissioner, on the charge of using the mails to mulct women of their savings.

At a special meeting of the members last night the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club officially changed its name back to its original form and henceforth will be known as the Crescent Athletic Club of Brooklyn. Resident and life class members voted upon the proposal, which was passed unanimously.

" Budget rooms" for the display of furniture and home decorations were termed a "terrible racket" by Richardson Wright, editor of House and Garden, in an address yesterday before 350 members of the Fashion Group at a luncheon at the Hotel Biltmore.
BOSTON, May 25. -- The Ford Motor Company has filed with Henry F. Long, Massachusetts Commissioner of Corporations and Taxation, its balance sheet as of Dec. 31, 1935.

SALEM, N.H., May 25. -- Trumpery, C.V. Whitney's strong-going son of Sir Galahad III, topped the field in the Speed Handicap in today's opening session of the season at Rockingham Park. A crowd of 5,000 witnessed the racing.

Elmer Davis's letter "Looking to a Grim Future" has the crisp and clear-cut character which one expects to find in his writings and it is, accordingly, likely to make a strong impression on readers generally. But whether that impression is justified by the facts may be very seriously questioned.
WASHINGTON, May 25. -- Two registration statements covering securities aggregating $46,250,000 were filed today by public utility companies under the Securities Act of 1933.

BERLIN, May 25. -- Dr. Guenther Gereke, former member of Chancellor Hitler's Cabinet, against whom the Black Corps, official organ of the secret State police, recently published a venomous attack because an election placard had been discovered pasted on his pig sty, has been placed in "protective custody."

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- Railway labor organizations are trying to work out private agreements with employers to keep employes on payrolls beyond the 65-year age limit for retirement prescribed by the railway retirement legislation of 1935, it was brought out today before Justice Jennings Bailey in the District of Columbia Supreme Court.

A proposal to settle for $1,500,000 suits against former directors of the International Match Corporation or their estates, aggregating $135,000,000 and a $15,000,000 claim asserted against Lee, Higginson Co., was filed before Oscar W. Ehrhorn, referee, at 3:45 P.M. yesterday by Rosenberg, Goldmark Colin, counsel for the Irving Trust Company, trustee in bankruptcy of International Match.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- By a five to four decision the Supreme Court struck down today the Municipal Bankruptcy Act under which Congress two years ago empowered municipalities and other political subdivisions of the States to readjust their indebtedness in the Federal courts.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 25. -- Unwillingness to forego his service bonus, amounting to more than $800, resulted today in the arrest in Los Angeles, Calif., of Donald J. Cirkot, 40-year-old ex-manager of the Grassy Sprain Golf Club, Yonkers, who was believed to have committed suicide in 1928. The bonus application revealed his suicide hoax.
Prospects for improved railroad earnings are distinctly brighter, according to a report issued yesterday by the railroad securities committee of the Investment Bankers Association.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., May 25. -- The printing plant, bindery and library of the House of Rudge, famous book manufactory on Bradford Road here, will be sold at foreclosure June 16, it became known here today. The Supreme Court at White Plains granted the foreclosure motion of Hunt T. Dickinson, a stockholder in the corporation and the holder of a mortgage on the real estate, last Friday.

Hope that the Republican national platform would not contain a plank urging a return to the gold standard was expressed yesterday by Kenneth F. Simpson, chairman of the New York County Republican Committee.

ARTHUR H. COMPTON, Professor of Physics in the University of Chicago and recipient of the Nobel Prize for his achievements in that field, brings highest and freshest scientific testimony to the view that in such attributes as clarity of reason, appreciation of beauty or consideration of our fellows, "our "remote descendants may be expected "to excel us as greatly as we are in "advance of the Java ape-man."

LIMA, Ohio, May 25. -- Virgil F. Effinger of Lima, alleged Western division head of the Black Legion, tacitly admitted tonight that he is an official of the society. He refused a direct answer, however, inquiring, "What if I am the leader?"

Two women of the vice ring of New York City swore on the stand yesterday to incidents of violence indicating that Charles (Lucky Luciano) Lucania headed an organization that burned women's feet with cigar butts and cut their tongues in reprisal for "squealing."

On the ground that the Congressional resolution deflating the dollar made no distinction as to gold payments of interest to foreign or domestic holders of bonds of American corporations, William D. Whitney, attorney for the Bethlehem Steel Company, a subsidiary of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, opposed before Supreme Court Justice Hofstadter yesterday an application by Dutch bondholders of the steel company to compel interest payments in Dutch guilders on bonds presented in Amsterdam.

LONDON, May 25. -- The political pot boiled merrily today at the approach of May 31, the date gossips picked several weeks ago for Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin's retirement and a thorough shake-up of the Cabinet.

BRUSSELS, May 25. -- Belgium, like France, will probably have a Socialist -- Emile Vandervelde -- as the head of her next government as a result of yesterday's elections. Despite the fact that the Socialists lost a few seats, they are still the largest single party in the Chamber of Deputies.

Unless ordinary signs are misleading, there appears to be a slow reawakening of the sponsorship that the share market has lacked these many weeks. The resistance points of many issues have been well tested recently. The fact that yesterday and on Saturday the steels and a few other groups received a little concentrated support without running into persistent liquidation, is worthy of note.

PARIS, May 25. -- The American women Curtis Cup golfers won ten out of twelve matches from France's leading players today in a series of exhibition matches which were witnessed by a large gallery, including American Ambassador Jesse Isidor Straus.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- E. Claude Babcock, president of the American Federation of Govern ment Employes, charged today in a pamphlet written for the Republican National Committee that "never before in the history of the nation has an administration, even before the passage of the Civil Service Act, handed out jobs to political cohorts in payment for political services on such a grand scale."

LONDON, May 25. -- The new liner Queen Mary, in the words of King Edward, who flew to Southampton today for a final inspection before she sails Wednesday on her first voyage to New York, is "a ship of which the empire may be proud; she is wonderful."

Large sums of money, including tribute paid by employers to Left Wing union leaders, collections for special defense funds and proceeds from sales of literature, are being made available for the financing of subversive activities of the Communist party in the United States, according to Archibald E. Stevenson, counsel to the National Civic Federation.

Anthony Cinquemanni, 22 years old, of 1,436 De Kalb Avenue, Brooklyn, who said he receives $11 food allowance every two weeks from the Home Relief Bureau, was charged yesterday with petit larceny in the theft of six loaves of bread. He appeared before Magistrate O'Dwyer in Bridge Plaza Court yesterday.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, May 25. -- Three of the six Americans entered in the British amateur golf championship were eliminated in the opening rounds today, among them being Dick Chapman of Greenwich, Conn., America's chief hope as a successor to Lawson Little, who recently turned pro.

ALBANY, May 25. -- Governor Lehman signed today the Republican bill, sponsored by Assemblyman Wadsworth, reducing the eligibility for old-age assistance from 70 to 65 years, but he condemned the Republican Assembly for refusing to enact the other seven points in his social security program.

Ambulance chasing by unscrupulous lawyers has grown so extensively since the close of the ambulance-chasing investigation before Supreme Court Justice Wasservogal seven years ago that the Appellate Division and the Bar Association have joined District Attorney William C. Dodge in a new campaign against the evil.

ROME, May 25 (AP). -- General Ruggiero Santini, commander of the Second Army Corps in East Africa, was named Governor of Italian Somaliland today. Vice Governor Guzzoni of Eritrea was made Governor of Eritrea.

Morton L. Schwartz's Bold Venture, winner of the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness Stakes, will not have a chance to test his mettle against Brevity and other 3-year-olds again this season. This son of St. Germans bowed a tendon while training at Belmont Park yesterday morning and, according to his trainer, Max Hirsch, will not race again this year.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- Beating off two attempts to insert import duties into its compromise tax plan, the Senate Finance Committee pushed forward today with revision of the revenue measure, hoping to increase its yield to meet the demands of President Roosevelt and report it to the Senate for action by Wednesday.
CINCINNATI, May 25 (AP). -- Behind Red Lucas's four-hit pitching the Pirates defeated Cincinnati, 9 to 2, today to forge ahead of the Reds in the National League standing.

TRENTON, N.J., May 25. -- The Legislature met for an hour tonight and adjourned until next Monday night, at which time a recess may be taken until after the Republican and Democratic National Conventions. Several bills were acted upon, but nothing was done toward solving the problem of financing emergency relief, the idea being, apparently, to wait until after the Republican and Democratic State Conventions have adopted platforms for the impending general election campaign.
Building plans filed yesterday included a $125,000 apartment house for the Bronx and a $200,000 multi-family unit for Long Island City, as follows:

Federal Judge William Bondy imposed a prison sentence of six months upon Andrew Anthanasiades, 29 years old, who pleaded guilty yesterday to having attempted to extort first $500, then $1,000, from Morris Sarnoff of 270 Madison Avenue, brother of David Sarnoff, president of the Radio Corporation of America.

An additional $3,333,000 of gold was engaged abroad yesterday for shipment here, this further reflecting the slow leakage of capital from the gold-bloc countries. Of the amount $2,210,000 was taken in Paris and $1,123,000 in Holland. Including these engagements the total taken since the movement began on April 24 is $168,000,000, of which $137,000,000 has been marked in France for shipment, and $9,900,000 in Holland.
MOSCOW, May 25. -- Dr. Emanuel Lasker of London today won his adjourned game with N. Rjumin, one of the five Russian competitors, in the ninth round of the international chess masters tournament.

Mrs. Giraud van Nest Foster gave a dinner last night in the roof garden of the Pierre for Dr. and Mrs. William Bradford Robbtns, Dr. and Mrs. F. Squier Dunn, G. Keller Burbridge and A. Ludlow Kramer Jr.

TRENTON, N.J., May 25. -- Preparations have been completed for the consecration of the Rev. Dr. Wallace J. Gardner, vicar of the Chapel of the Intercession, New York City, as Bishop Coadjutor of the Episcopal Diocese of New Jersey at Trinity Cathedral here on the morning of June 3.

PARIS, May 25. -- Mrs. Henry Symes Lehr, widow of the one-time New York society leader, and John Graham Hope De La Poer Beresford, Lord Decies of Ireland, were married here this morning by the Mayor of the Seventh District, the only persons present being the bridegroom's two daughters and their husbands.

Supreme Court Justice George H. Furman, in Brooklyn, reserved decision yesterday on the application of the State Transit Commission for an injunction restraining the Long Island Railroad from charging more than 2 cents a mile within New York City after June 1.

The board of design of seven architects and engineers which is to plan and supervise construction of the 1939 World's Fair will have as a workshop the greater part of the eightieth floor of the Empire State Building. The only other occupants of that floor, the top of the main building, are John J. Raskob and Pierre S. du Pont, who have the southern exposure.

Completely handcuffed by a 24-year-old rookie right hander, the Dodgers spent yesterday at Ebbets Field glumly watching rival runners rounding the base paths as the Bees belted three Brooklyn pitchers for fifteen hits and an 8-0 triumph.

Eleven charitable institutions will share equally 5 per cent of the estate of Judge Otto A. Rosalsky under his will, which was offered for probate yesterday. Relatives will share the remainder of the estate which was formally valued at "more than $10,000."

If a man walks the plank it may be news, but not exactly sensational, after several hundred years of pirate lore. But if a plank walks the man, so to speak, it is obviously a piquant item. That is why the Washington correspondents are now speculating about the men who will draft the new Democratic platform in Philadelphia next month.
Plans of four apartment houses for sites in Manhattan and the Bronx were announced yesterday by H.I. Feldman, architect.

The report that Leon Blum is planning to call an international monetary conference for currency stabilization when he becomes Premier of France was received in financial circles here yesterday with mild skepticism. The French would, of course, like to see an agreement reached between the British and the United States on currency matters which would help to clarify their own problem by definitely establishing the conditions with which they would have to compete abroad.

Consistent believers in borough autonomy should resent the present expansion of the Federal Government in local affairs, Thomas I. Parkinson, a member of the City Charter Commission, told the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce yesterday afternoon at the annual meeting in the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, May 25. -- The majority opinion of the Supreme Court, invalidating the Municipal Bankruptcy Act of 1934, was as follows:
LONDON, May 25. -- Foreign Secretary Antimony Eden was called upon to answer more than a half dozen questions in the House of Commons today on the growth of smuggling in North China.

TUCKERTON, N.J., Tuesday, May 26. -- Four youths were burned to death, ten or more seriously burned and a dozen were missing last night as fire swept nearly 100 square miles of fields and woodland in three counties in Southern New Jersey.

BERLIN, May 25. -- The result of the Belgian elections was greeted in Germany today with undisguised satisfaction, first, because of the rise of the Rex movement and, second, because of German solidarity in Eupen and Malmedy.

LONDON, May 25. -- The stock markets were irregular and generally lower today. British funds continued weak and the foreign market was quieter and uncertain. Domestic railway shares were dull as a result of the doubtful labor situation.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, May 25. -- After deliberations lasting sixty-five hours an Estonian court-martial today pronounced sentences on 148 Fascists charged with having participated in the attempt on Dec. 8, 1935, to overthrow the present political regime by an armed revolt intended to begin at Tallinn.

MOSCOW, May 25 (AP). -- An end of the easy divorce system in Russia and the creation of new, strict family responsibilities were foreshadowed in the project of a law issued tonight for public approval.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 25. -- A constitutional amendment to give Congress the power to regulate commerce, industry and agriculture as the basis for an economic readjustment of the nation was urged tonight by Mayor La Guardia of New York in an address before the National Conference of Social Work in the city Auditorium here.

CLEVELAND, May 25. -- On the ground that the right of workmen to organize will be determined largely in the November election, Sidney Hillman, president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, urged the biennial convention of the union today to endorse President Roosevelt.

The rift between playwrights and managers, which has disturbed the theatre since late February, was officially closed early last evening. After a long and occasionally acrimonious discussion, the membership of the Dramatists Guild accepted the proposed amendments to the contract they had previously offered the producers.

The Board of Education announced yesterday that it had asked Governor Lehman to veto a bill giving life tenure to members of the Board of Superintendents, the policy-making body for the city school system. All the members of the Board of Education -- five Fusionists and two Democrats-signed the appeal to the Governor.

TOKYO, May 25. -- While preparing to invoke against Australia Japan's trade protection law, Foreign Minister Hachiro Arita proposes only to "do his best" for the Japanese industrialists who are adversely affected by the new United States textile tariffs.
WASHINGTON, May 25. -- The Supreme Court today ordered its decision against the Guffey Coal Control Act into immediate effect.
An extra dividend of 25 cents in addition to the regular quarterly dividend of 50 cents was declared yesterday by directors of F.E. Myers Bro. Company.
CHICAGO, May 25. -- Grey Count, with Jockey Corbett up, won the $1,000 five furlongs feature race at Hawthorne today, defeating a fair band of five other 2-year-olds.

LONDON, May 25. -- Dr. William Tweddell of Stourbridge, who battled Lawson Little to the last hole in the final of the 1935 British amateur golf championship, today was appointed to captain Great Britain's team against the United States in the Walker Cup match at Pine Valley, N.J., Sept. 2 and 3.

Despite the fact that twenty-three railroads began suit last Saturday in the local Federal Court to enjoin the order of the Interstate Commerce Commission to put new fares into effect, railroad stations here yesterday were selling tickets for coach travel at 2 cents a mile and Pullman travel at 3 cents a mile without surcharge.

As might have been expected, the proposed charter is under attack from the flank as well as from the front. While the advocates of extreme borough autonomy are pouring their fire into those provisions of the draft which make for centralization, they and their political allies are also questioning the propriety of submitting the issue to the electorate next November.

Surrogate James A. Foley ruled yesterday that the Reno divorce obtained by the late Frank Hart, wealthy oil operator, was invalid and that his subsequent marriage to Muriel Constance Woodworth was void. The court held that Marion Alexander Hart was the widow.

PARIS, May 25 (AP). -- Mrs. Lehr became the second wife of Lord Decies, widower of Helen Vivien Gould Decies, in a short civil ceremony performed by Antonin Bartholemy, Mayor of the Seventh District, at his office. The couple then went to a small chapel at the bride's home, where a religious service was read.

Mayor Rolland B. Marvin of Syracuse, regarded as a leading aspirant for the Republican nomination for Governor, predicted last night that New York State would reject the Roosevelt New Deal at the November election.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 25. -- The Henry Clews estate, the Rocks, on Ocean Avenue, vacant last Summer, will be occupied this season by Mr. and Mrs. F. Griswold Flagg of Radnor, Pa., who for the last two Summers have occupied Shady Lawn, the estate of Mrs. Richard T. Wilson on Narragansett Avenue.

The Summer camp maintained at Upper Twin Lake, Central Valley, N.Y., by the Abbott E. Kittredge Club for Girls of 440 East Fifty-seventh Street, this city, has lengthened its season by a month, and will open on Memorial Day. The camp which was founded in 1920, will continue its activities until Labor Day.
More indictments were returned yesterday in the extortion investigation begun on the basis of charges brought by Alfred E. Smith Jr.

WARSAW, May 25. -- General Edward Rydz-Smigly, Inspector-General of the Army, has emerged from the annual convention of the Pilsudski Legionnaires as the recognized heir of the late Marshal Joseph Pilsudski and therefore as virtual dictator of Poland.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 25 (AP). -- A strong wind, making driving more hazardous than ever, failed to keep four racing daredevils from qualifying today for the 500-mile automobile race to be run here Saturday.

Brady Pleads for Unity in the Theatre, to Seize 'Opportunity of Century' on Road. In a singularly calm mood the Actors Equity Association held its annual meeting yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Astor, where ten council members were voted upon for terms of five years and four replacements were chosen for varying periods.
THE new novel by Mary Roberts Rinehart -- her fiftieth book counting three collaborations -- is a far more artful job than first readers apparently have realized.

Jamaica High pounded out twenty-six safeties to defeat Bryant High, 13 -- 6 and 11 -- 2, in a double-header at the Jamaica Stadium yesterday, thereby clinching the Queens P.S.A.L. baseball crown with a record of eleven triumphs and one setback.

LONDON, May 25. -- The original manuscripts of nearly all of the late Arnold Bennett's principal works attracted little interest in an auction at Sothebys today. The manuscript of "The Old Wives Tale," which first brought Bennett fame, was bid up to 1,250, but was not sold because it failed to reach the reserve price.

Sambo Leslie, whose hits seem to travel longer distances as the measurement of his ample waistline grows correspondingly shorter, had another fine clout in his bat at the Polo Grounds yesterday and it was well that he did.
I notice in Arnaldo Cortesi's cable correspondence the following remark:

PHILADELPHIA, May 25. -- The shoe was on the other foot today at Shibe Park as reaction set in against the battering Yankees. A baffling brand of pitching served by the Athletics' North Carolina rookie, Lee Ross, together with another poor performance by Lefty Gomez, frustrated their plans for a clean sweep of this series and the New Yorkers suffered a 10-7 setback.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- The constitutionality of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 was challenged today before the Securities and Exchange Commission by Charles C. Wright of Wright Sexton, a New York Stock Exchange firm, at the initial hearing in connection with allegations of manipulation of Kinner Airplane and Motor Corporation stock on the Los Angeles Stock Exchange.

A vacant plot, 300 by 100 feet, at the northwest corner of Perry Avenue and 205th Street, the Bronx, acquired by the city some time ago as part of the right of way for the Bronx Concourse line of the Independent Subway System, was sold for $67,600 at auction in the Hotel Commodore yesterday by John J. Reynolds, auctioneer, to the Ellbob Realty Corporation, Ely Maran, president, after eighteen bids. The upset price was $62,500.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- The cash income of farmers, from the sale of products plus government benefit payments, reached $2,079,000,000 during the first four months of 1936, a six-year high record. This compares with $1,970,000,000 a year ago, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics said.

The sixteen-month fight of Joseph (Joie) Rao and Joseph Parterre, Harlem gangsters, to prevent their serving a term of one to two years in Sing Sing for attacking a patrolman in Harlem in 1934 ended yesterday when General Sessions Judge Morris Koenig ordered them taken to the prison.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 25 (AP). -- A general strike in six plants of Remington Rand, Inc., was called tonight by leaders of the Remington Rand Joint Protective Board at a mass meeting of Syracuse employes. Workers have been on a "vacation" since Thursday.

J. Edward Jones, a dealer in oil royalties, yesterday filed a plea in the Federal Court here in abatement to the indictment found against him on May 8 charging use of the mails to defraud. He maintains through his counsel, Hyman I. Fischbach, that the grand jury which voted the bill had no competent evidence before it.
M. Antoni Zajaczek, better known as Marion A. Zioncheck, Washington State's fun-loving legislator, arrived here yesterday from the Virgin Islands on the steamship Scanpenn. His mood was utterly meek.

CHICAGO, May 25. -- A marked broadening in the Eastern demand for hogs, further strength in fresh pork and relatively light receipts advanced prices as much as 10 cents a hundred weight over Friday's level to the highest point in seventeen days. The top was lifted 5 cents to $10.05 while the day's average was 10 cents higher at $9.65.

The city of Tulsa, Okla., has invited bankers to submit on June 3 bids for a new issue of $1,700,000 of school district bonds, that will mature from 1939 to 1956. Bidders are to name the rate of interest.

TRENTON, N.J., May 25. -- Governor Harold G. Hoffman said here tonight that he intends to give "serious consideration" to a plea sent from Newark by a group of thirty-three ministers and civic leaders asking that he do what he can to save Jacob Ciemiengo, 16 years old, from the electric chair.

JACKSON, Mich., May 25. -- The oath of the Black Legion, which new members are said to have signed with their own blood after reciting the ritual at pistol point, was disclosed today by Owen Dudley, prosecutor of Jackson County.

SOUTHAMPTON, England, May 25 (AP). -- The British royal family bade "good voyage" to the liner Queen Mary tonight. Queen Mary was still in deep mourning for King George, but little Princess Elizabeth was in gray tweed and a mauve straw hat.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP). -- A representative of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation was accused before a Senate committee today of inspiring a proposal to sell and dismember the Minneapolis St. Louis Railway to protect the interests of Frederick H. Prince of Boston.

With "On Your Toes" going along as it is, which is to say very nicely, Richard Rodgers and Lorenz Hart are now planning another musical comedy for Dwight Deere Wiman. They have not actually gone to work on the book, lyrics or music, but the idea is set.

The special grand jury investigating the Drukman case informed Governor Lehman by letter yesterday that it "cannot agree" with the Governor's decision to defer action on its demand for the removal of District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan of Brooklyn.

HARRISON, N.Y., May 25. -- A gambling establishment catering to prominent and wealthy residents of New York and Westchester, on one of the county's most beautiful estates, was raided here today by the police.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

Mrs. Alice Gwynne Vanderbilt, widow of Cornelius Vanderbilt, left an estate appraised yesterday at $10,770,907 gross and $10,184,587 net. Mr. Vanderbilt died in 1899, and his wife died on April 22, 1934.

Both the old parties have worries enough, but the Socialist party has this year to take arms against a much greater sea of troubles. First of all is the sharp difference about its own organization. The long threatened split between the left wing and the so-called old guard became a reality at the Cleveland convention.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

Mrs. Alice Gwynne Vanderbilt, widow of Cornelius Vanderbilt, left an estate appraised yesterday at $10,770,907 gross and $10,184,587 net. Mr. Vanderbilt died in 1899, and his wife died on April 22, 1934.

Both the old parties have worries enough, but the Socialist party has this year to take arms against a much greater sea of troubles. First of all is the sharp difference about its own organization. The long threatened split between the left wing and the so-called old guard became a reality at the Cleveland convention.
United StateB Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices I in New York City;

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on May 20 shows a decrease for the week of $21,000,000 in total loans and investments, an increase of $110,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted and an increase of $86,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks.
MEMEL, Memel Territory, May 25 (AP) -- Spies and ballots stirred tiny, oft-troubled Memel today.

DALLAS, May 25. -- Plans for concerted action by landlords throughout the country to stabilize rentals and eliminate price-cutting as a means of attracting tenants were formulated by the National Association of Building Owners and Managers here today.

Fourteen men and one woman were arrested at about 8 o'clock last night as they were picketing the entrance to Polyclinic Hospital, 345 West Fiftieth Street, during the evening visiting hours. They were arraigned in Night Court on charges of disorderly conduct and released for a hearing Thursday in West Side Court.

Commencement exercises of the National Bible Institute and the Union Missionary Training Institute will be held tonight in the institute auditorium, 340 West Fifty-fifth Street. The Rev. Raymond Irving Lindquist, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church of Orange, N.J., will make the commencement address.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 25. -- More and better jobs can be provided for the nation's workers, not through a division of the work now available among a larger number of employes but by modernizing industry's productive facilities, Alfred P. Sloan said tonight in an address prepared for delivery before the San Francisco Chamber of Commerce and Chambers of Commerce of the Bay Area.

DEVON, Pa., May 26. -- Mrs. William du Pont rode her veteran campaigner, Quarryman, from the Fox-catcher Farms of Wilmington, to victory in the class for ladies' hunters under side saddle at the Devon Horse Show today before a big and enthusiastic crowd.

Primo Carnera will attempt to get back into the heavyweight picture tonight when he opposes LeRoy Haynes, the hard-hitting Negro from Philadelphia, in a ten-round bout at Ebbets Field. The former heavyweight champion of the world will be out for vengeance in the battle, which will be his first since he was knocked out by Haynes in the Quaker City two months ago.

BERLIN, May 26. -- The long series of trials of Catholic monks and nuns charged with violation of German foreign exchange regulations was succeeded by heavier artillery today when the government arraigned for mass trial in Coblenz no fewer than 276 monks of the Order of St. Francis and the Congregation of Merciful Brethren, all charged with immorality.

It seems incredible that serious persons should propose an 18 per cent tax on the income of corporations and a tax to common stockholders on their dividends in addition. If persons operated a business as a partnership their net income would be subject to the normal tax plus super-tax, and no more.

Preliminary estimates indicate that the Class I railroads earned a net operating income of about $42,000,000 in April, the largest for that month in any year since 1930. It compared with $35,205,514 in March last and $34,600,000 in April, 1935. This would bring the net income for the first four months of 1936 to about $146,000,000, against $121,000,000 in the same period in 1935.

Nine Manhattan properties were bought in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auction sales yesterday. A. scheduled offering of a fifteen-story apartment house at the south corner of Central Park West and Eighty-fourth Street was withdrawn. The results were as follows:

The Robinson-Patman Anti-Price Discrimination Bill, now pending in Congress, was bitterly attacked and strongly defended by speakers at the opening session yesterday of the first annual meeting of the Toilet Goods Association at the Hotel Biltmore.

LONDON, May 26. -- D.H. Lawrence's posthumous play, "My Son's My Son," revised and completed by Walter Greenwood, co-author of "Love on the Dole," was presented at the Playhouse tonight before a distinguished and appreciative audience.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- Opposition to the dominance of Charles D. Hilles of New York in Republican affairs, and especially in the designation of Representative B. H. Snell as permanent chairman of the Republican National Convention, was expressed today by Robert H. Lucas, former executive director of the Republican National Committee.

The climax of another season of college rowing came nearer yesterday with the draw for lanes in the Poughkeepsie regatta, which will take place on Monday, June 22. Made in the downtown offices of Maxwell Stevenson, chairman of the Board of Stewards of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association, the draw provided racing space, for eighteen crews; seven varsity, five junior varsity and six freshmen.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- President Roosevelt said today that his trip to Arkansas, Texas and Indiana, beginning June 8, which will coincide in time with the Republican National Convention, was not a political tour. The dates set for the trip were dictated solely by convenience, he explained, revealing that historical topics would be the subjects for the speeches he plans to deliver.

W.J. Parker, of W.J. Parker, Inc., trade association consultants, was yesterday elected president of the Trade Association Executives in New York, succeeding Harry R. Meixell, at the group's annual meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania. W.J. Donald, managing director of the National Electrical Manufacturers' Association was chosen vice present and James L. Fri, managing director of the Toy Manufacturers of the U.S.A., was named secretary treasurer.
Steamship operators reported yesterday that the number of available seamen had risen in the last week, indicating that men who have been on strike for a new contract are returning to work.

CARRYING curiosity as far afield as the Pompton Lakes training sector, this tourist discovered that there is nothing of the capering clown, the punching dummy or the physical freak about the dusky, husky Haynes gent who will be heading toward Ebbets Field this evening for his second meeting with Primo Camera.

DETROIT, May 26. -- Five more arrests of Black Legion members were made today on a warrant charging violence and prosecutors in all counties in the State were called upon by David H. Crowley, State Attorney General, to start inquiries.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- A substitute "paste pot and scissors" Guffey Coal Stabilization Act was approved by the House Ways and Means Committee by a vote of 18 to 6 late today, eight days after the Supreme Court invalidated the original measure.

BOSTON, May 26. -- Misfortune struck at Yankee pennant hopes today at Fenway Park. The New Yorkers lost the services of Bill Dickey, their chief run producer, for an indefinite period, perhaps for the remainder of the season.

SHANGHAI, May 26. -- Vehement protests against the Chinese Government's two recent orders detailing measures to check the movement southward from Tientsin of goods smuggled into North China were made last week to Nanking's Foreign Office by Japan.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- Charges of unfair practices in restraint of trade, which resulted in higher prices to the consumer, were made today by the Federal Trade Commission in a complaint issued against Millinery Quality Guild, Inc., and Uptown Creators Guild, both of New York, which design, manufacture and sell women's hats.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., May 26. -- Miss Kathleen Petry, Sewanhaka High School entrant, led the way into the semi-finals of the girls' division of the Long Island interscholastic tennis championship today as the first and quarter-final rounds were completed.

Yale and Harvard, two of the oldest rivals in college sport, will meet in the first game of the intercollegiate polo championship, due to start at Morris Memorial Field, Governors Island, on Saturday, June 13. Four teams have entered the tournament this year, the others being Princeton and Army.

One of the most disastrous brush fires in many years was reported under control last night after it had swept over ninety square miles of woodland in Southern New Jersey. Five of those who helped stamp it out were dead, and nine were in hospitals with severe burns.

LONDON, May 26. -- As a further development of the budget leak inquiry Leslie Thomas, stock broker son of J.H. Thomas, has resigned from Belisha Co. Mr. Thomas will remain a member of the London Stock Exchange, to which he was admitted in 1931.

LONDON, May 26. -- Poverty-stricken Poland, with only two destroyers and three submarines in her navy, has been invited to sign a naval limitation treaty with Great Britain. Negotiations will begin tomorrow with the object of bringing Poland into the system of qualitative restriction and exchange of building plans which the great naval powers accepted at the recent London conference.

The city of Boston, Mass., awarded yesterday a new issue of $4,000,000 of notes to Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and the Marine Trust Company of Buffalo on a 1.75 per cent interest basis, plus a premium of $15. The notes, dated May 28, 1936, and maturing on Feb. 24, 1937, were reoffered at prices to yield 1.10 per cent to maturity.

The "regular" or administration ticket of ten candidates and four replacements for the Equity council won a complete victory over an equal number of so-called independents, it was announced yesterday. The balloting took place on Monday at the annual meeting of the association.

DETROIT, May 26. -- Prosecutor McCrea announced today that the fire which destroyed the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin's original Shrine of the Little Flower March 17 was on the list of unexplained fires his investigators are checking for a possible connection with the Black Legion terrorism.
Dr. Gustav Eckstein is in New York from Cincinnati, bringing the manuscript of his new book, "Canary, the History of a Family," which Harper will publish this Fall.

The Board of Education was held responsible yesterday by members of the Teachers Retirement Board for the failure of the latter board to retire incompetent teachers when Dr. Alberto C. Bonaschi, chairman of that board and member of the Board of Education, reaffirmed his view that the Retirement Board must consider "emotional and pedagogical" fitness.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, May 26. -- As a result of the second day's play in the British amateur golf championship, only one American golfer survives, and his survival was not very glorious. Theodore Bassett of Rye, N.Y., reached the third round by means of a bye and a walkover.

ALBANY, May 26. -- The Court of Appeals affirmed today the conviction of Mrs. Frances Creighton and Everett C. Appelgate of Baldwin, Nassau County, who were found guilty of having killed Mrs. Ada Appelgate, wife of the convicted man, by arsenic poisoning.

Painting an optimistic picture of present financial and political conditions in Venezuela, Eugene Capucio, representative there for the Otis Elevator Company, assured the Export Managers Club of New York, Inc., yesterday that a good market for a wide range of American products is opening up in there at present.

Twenty-two G.A.R. men, fourteen of them more than 90 years old and the youngest 88, will ride in the vanguard of the Memorial Day parade of more than 20,000 soldiers and veterans on Riverside Drive Saturday. The city's tribute to the nation's soldiers of the past will include also a parade of 15,000 in the Bronx, according to the plans announced yesterday.

Too many of the current tax proposals in Washington contemplate the "actual destruction of the capital upon which our economic society depends," Professor Raymond Moley warned last night. He was popularly regarded as head of the "Brain Trust" in the early days of the Roosevelt administration.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP). -- Testimony that John W. Barriger 3d had appeared before an Interstate Commerce Commission examiner in Minneapolis as a personal "intervenor" in favor of dismemberment of the Minneapolis St. Louis Railroad, but at government expense, was heard today by a Senate Interstate Commerce subcommittee.

COBLENZ, Germany, May 26 (AP). -- Testimony that Franciscan monks accused of immorality had been advised to flee' from Germany was given today at the start of mass Franciscan trials by the order's general secretary, Father Erhard.

LONDON, May 26. -- Today is the birthday of England's beloved Queen Mary. Tomorrow will witness the sailing on her maiden voyage to New York of the Queen's marine namesake, the largest, proudest and best-equipped vessel that the British have ever put into commercial service.

No immediate European war is possible, because neither France nor Germany wishes to attack and because politicians elsewhere realize that there is no gain in hostilities, General Georges Pouderoux, a French division commander in the World War, said yesterday upon his arrival here.

Sir AUSTEN CHAMBERLAIN, WINSTON CHURCHILL and Sir ROBERT HORNE are the most distinguished Conservative malcontents who are determined that Mr. BALDWIN must "go." Unpersuaded of their superior wisdom, Mr. BALDWIN is resolved to stay until after the Coronation next Spring, anyway.
WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP). -- With Buddy Lewis and Cecil Travis leading a thirteen-hit barrage, the Senators defeated the Athletics, 8 to 2, today in the first of a three-game series.

Price movements were mixed on the local commodity futures markets yesterday, with trading very active in a few staples. Sugar, rubber and hides declined, while coffees, cocoa and cottonseed oil advanced. On the cash markets, cotton, tins and cocoa were firmer, while wheat, oats and lard sold at new low levels and corn, rye, flour and rubber eased.

An initial quarterly dividend of 12 1/2 cents on the new $10 par common stock of the National Lead Company was declared yesterday. This equaled the $5 annual rate paid on the old stock, which was recently split ten for one. The regular quarterly dividend of $1.50 on the Class B preferred stock also was declared.

The Chesapeake Corporation holds 47.7 per cent control of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway at the end of 1935, according to a statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission and made public yesterday. This is compared to a 51 per cent control held a few years ago, sales of stock and conversion of bonds meanwhile having reduced the ratio.

After four rebuttal witnesses had testified yesterday that John Fiorenza was sane when he attacked and strangled Mrs. Nancy Evans Titterton, both sides rested in Fiorenza's murder trial in General Sessions Court. Counsel will sum up this morning and the jury may get the case this afternoon or at the latest tomorrow morning.

ROSLYN, L.I., May 26. -- The Roslyn quartet of Gerard Smith, Ivor Balding, Earle A.S. Hopping and John Schiff topped J.H. (Jock) Whitney's Greentree poloists, 9 to 7, at Schiff Field today. Trailing for most of four periods, Roslyn tied the score late in the fifth and two goals by Hopping clinched the match.

More than 500 friends of Dr. Charles Pflug honored him at a testimonial dinner and dance last night at the Hotel Bossert, Brooklyn, to mark his completion of forty years of practice as a physician and surgeon in Brooklyn. Dr. Charles A. Gordon, attending surgeon at St. Catherine's Hospital in Brooklyn, presented a ship's clock to Dr. Pflug as a gift of his admirers.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP). -- Jean Trowbridge, a pretty blond Iowa girl of 13, struggled for three hours today through a series of multi-syllabled words of double spelling to become queen of the nation's juvenile spellers.

Challenging the appeal of such dishes as the "Chicken Symphony" and conquering even the erstwhile supreme broiled sirloin steak with mushrooms, a good old-fashioned main course of pot roast, string beans, egg noodles and escalloped tomatoes won first prize last night in the "cook-off" of the women's national menu recipe competition in Grand Central Palace.

JERUSALEM, May 26. -- "Disturbances" is no longer the word to describe the situation in Palestine -- it has now reached a state of actual rebellion directed mostly against the government, with Nablus, Gaza and Tulkarem as the chief hotbeds of trouble.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 26. -- Immediate freedom for Luis Carlos Prestes, alleged leader of last November's revolt, as well as for all political prisoners now in jail, was demanded in a telegram sent from Madrid by Spanish Leftist Deputies to President Getulio Vargas of Brazil.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 26 (AP). -- Newark defeated Albany, 5 to 2, tonight for its third victory in the series. The teams went into the eighth inning in a 1-to-1 deadlock. After walking two men, Matuzak was replaced by Benton, and doubles by McCarthy and Baker off the relief pitcher accounted for three Bear runs.
Housing and business structures were included in the Manhattan realty turnover reported yesterday.

Virtually all the bus lines in interstate service will reduce their fares to meet the competition caused by the 2-cents-a-mile base rate of rail transportation effective on June 1, a canvass revealed yesterday.

CLEVELAND, May 26. -- After adopting a platform of immediate demands, including revision of the Constitution to enable the government to cope with the economic problems without a check by the Supreme Court, the national convention of the Socialist party adjourned tonight in a bitter quarrel over the question of united action with the Communists.

PARIS, May 26.--Miss Billy Yorke of England and Marcel Bernard, 19-year-old French sensation, gathered in their second championships of the French hard-court tennis tournament today as they combined forces and annexed the mixed doubles title.

Harry Gumbert, who, despite an imposing record of four victories against no defeats, had not finished a game since April 15, learned the secret of success yesterday at the Polo Grounds as the Dodgers dropped in for a short visit and wound up dropping a few percentage points.
CLEVELAND, May 26. -- The text of the Socialist platform is as follows:

The annual meeting and Spring fashion show of the Brooklyn Heights Association was held last night in the ballroom of the Towers Hotel. More than 500 persons witnessed the pageant, which contrasted the feminine costumes of years ago with those of today.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 26 (AP). -- Conflicting accounts of a physical encounter at a Birmingham cafe came today from Representative George Huddleston and his Democratic primary opponent, Luther Patrick.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, said today that "the wave of strikes now in progress across the entire country" was "a manifestation of what was bound to follow the Supreme Court's decisions destroying such great principles as the NRA and the Guffey Acts established."

The engagement of $2,920,000 gold abroad for shipment here was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Of this, $1,700,000 was taken in England, $1,177,000 in Mexico and $43,000 in India. No engagements of gold in France or Holland were reported, but it was thought likely that some had been taken in those countries because their exchanges again sold below the gold-import points.

It should attract attention when any well-known Englishman openly questions the doctrine of conquest, but when one of the late Field Marshal Allenby's ability and distinction deliberately assails the "glory of conquest," a glory of which he has so strikingly partaken, it becomes impressive.

Daily average gross production of crude oil in the United States last week was 3,007,100 barrels, compared with 3,008,050 in the preceding week, the high record, a decline of 900, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. A gain of 10,000 barrels in the daily average output of Louisiana was offset for the most part by declines in California, Oklahoma and Kansas.
Remington Rand, Inc., with subsidiaries, showed the largest net income in the company's history with the exception of 1930, according to the preliminary statement for the year ended on March 31 last.

FITCHBURG; Mass., May 26. -- The last of the men's golf crowns Gene Sarazen has won during his spectacular international career appeared tonight to be in danger. He reached the halfway mark of the seventy-two-hole Massachusetts open tourney today five strokes behind the deadlocked leaders.

Dr. Howard D. Roelofs, dean of the McMickem College of Liberal Arts, University of Cincinnati, will deliver the address at the ll5th commencement of the General Theological Seminary of the Protestant Episcopal Church, 175 Ninth Avenue, at 11 o'clock this morning.

LONDON, May 26.--A mystery of the sea, involving the missing motor vessel Girl Pat and a tale of Captain William Kidd's piratical loot, darkened tonight when the twenty-five-ton will-o'-the-wisp bobbed up on the African West Coast, only to vanish just as suddenly.

The Municipal Bankruptcy Act, on which the Supreme Court has just handed down a decision, is a heritage of the panic stage of the depression. Strong pressure for its adoption appeared early in 1933, and one year later Congress completed action on the measure.

Depositions in a Chicago alienation suit for $100,000, for the loss of the affections of Charles MacArthur, playwright, were taken here yesterday in the offices of Stahl Updike, attorneys, 220 East Forty-second Street. By agreement between counsel, the proceedings were private and the depositions will not be made public before they are offered in court.

Borough President Samuel Levy of Manhattan told the members of the Charter Revision Commission last night that they had probably been "stampeded" into establishing a City Planning Commission by jobseekers and organizations with ulterior motives.

Traveling for the first time by airplane, Charles R. Gay, president of the Stock Exchange, arrived last night at Newark on a United Airliner from Denver to attend the regular meeting of the Exchange's board of governors today. On his return to the Exchange he will be greeted by complaints of many members that the high margin requirements of the Federal Reserve Board are strangling business.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- The Commercial Credit Corporation of Baltimore filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Securities Act of 1933, a conversion operation for the issuance of $25,000,000 of $100 par value cumulative convertible preferred stock and $4,600,000 of $10 par value common stock, and scrip certificates in lieu of fractional shares of the common stock.
PITTSBURGH, May 26 (AP). -- Clyde Beatty, trainer of wild beasts, was arrested at the circus grounds today on a complaint sworn out by the Humane Society charging him with cruelty to animals.

JERUSALEM, May 26. -- The government today for the first time mobilized Jewish colonists for self-defense as an open Arab revolt swept the country. Settlers at Rehoboth were armed and prepared to repel further assaults after two days' marauding had resulted in destruction of agricultural enterprises.

The gains both in prices and also in the volume in the share market yesterday were the best since May 14. Railway issues were leaders at the outset, with other groups later participating and utility stocks doing uncommonly well in the heavy buying that featured the final hour.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 26. -- A brilliant and colorful academic event will take place amid the elms of Harvard Yard on Sept. 18, with the bestowal of honorary degrees on sixty-six of the world's greatest scholars and scientists.

VIENNA, May 26. -- A council of Heimwehr leaders from all parts of Austria was held here today under Prince Ernst Ruediger von Starhemberg's presidency to decide the organization's policy in view of present conditions and learn the information that Prince Starhemberg, recently ousted as Vice Chancellor, brought back from Premier Benito Mussolini of Italy after his recent visit to Rome.

To give women a greater voice in the formulation of the party platform, Miss Mary W. Dawson, chairman of the Women's Division of the Democratic National Committee, announced yesterday a committee to suggest platform planks to the Democratic National Convention.

Additional heavy rains in the Southwest where not wanted and absence of relief in the Eastern States where moisture is urgently needed caused another upturn in prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday. October sold at 10.53 cents a pound, the best price since January, but the advance met some selling and the list ended 1 point higher to 4 points lower than on Monday.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP). -- An administration effort to revive the Florida ship canal and the Passamaquoddy tide-harnessing projects, upon which Congress once before turned thumbs down, today was brought before the Senate.

A new professorship in mathematics has been established at Columbia University in memory of Charles Davies, who taught at Columbia during the Civil War, it was announced yesterday. Awards of fifteen scholarships and fellowships, besides promotions and leaves of absence for members of the faculty, also were made public.

The National Labor Relations Board asked the United States Circuit Court of Appeals yesterday to require The Associated Press to comply with the board's order to reinstate Morris Watson, an editorial employe, alleged to have been discharged because of his activities on behalf of the Newspaper Guild.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- The drive to include in the commodity exchange control bill more drastic regulation of cotton trading than the Department of Agriculture thinks desirable again prevented the measure from reaching a final vote today.

Charles P. Taft in his recent book "You and I" says that if 4,000,000 voters would switch their votes they could elect a Republican President, but asks "Where will one find them?" I can tell him where a large proportion is, based on the following incident:

CHICAGO, May 26 (AP). -- The Cubs bounced back into the first division today as they came home from their losing trip, backed little Roy Henshaw's steady pitching with a seven-run splurge against Lee Stine in the third inning and defeated the Reds, 10 to 4.
