PARIS, May 26. -- For some reason not easily explained the Bourse today suddenly developed an optimistic mood. There was a quick spurt of business and the conviction seemed to have become general that the low level of prices of the last few weeks has been unjustified.

GENEVA, May 26. -- The Jewish Agency for Palestine will urge the League of Nations Mandates Commission, which meets here tomorrow for its twenty-ninth session, to hold the British Government strictly accountable for the restoration and maintenance of order in Palestine, one of its representatives said today.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 26. -- The dates for the tenth annual invitation golf tournament of the Newport Country Club have been set for July 30, 31 and Aug. 1 of this year. The tournament will open with a medal play qualifying round on the first day and match play follows on the next two days.

The infant death rate in the city showed an increase last week over the corresponding period a year ago for the first time since the week of March 28, the Department of Health reported yesterday. There were 115 deaths under 1 year, or 60.2 per 1,000 live births.

A banking group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., will offer today a new issue of $22,000,000 of first and refunding mortgage 4 per cent bonds, Series D, of the Peoples Gas Light and Coke Company at 97 1/2 and interest, to yield more than 4.15 per cent to maturity on June 1, 1961.
In his speech in New York on April 26 the President criticized the contention of an unnamed economist that recovery could be achieved by lower prices brought about by lowered costs of production:

Cash dividend payments by the companies of the Standard Oil group for the first half of 1936 will approximate $94,484,839, compared to $81,944,228 in the corresponding period of last year, according to a compilation by Carl H. Pforzheimer Co.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- The struggle between the craft unions, which have thus far controlled the American Federation of Labor, and the industrial union group headed by John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, moved toward a climax today with a revelation that an ultimatum has been sent to the Lewis group.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., May 26. -- A trio of golfers tied for low-scoring honors with 77's in the Long Island Golf Association's second one-day tourney of the season today at the Hempstead Golf Club.

The Very Rev. Coleman Nevils rector of St. Ignatius Loyola's Roman Catholic Church, Manhattan, and former superior of George-town University, will deliver the discourse at the commencement exercises of Notre Dame College, Grymes Hill, S.I., at 2 P.M. today.

ALBANY, May 26. -- Governor Lehman, in a new letter tonight to Horace N. Dougherty, foreman of the Drukman grand jury, again flatly refused to act on the charges demanding the removal of District Attorney Geoghan of Kings County until the grand jury had completed its investigations and prosecutions.

With 35,700 miles behind her, the world cruise liner Reliance of the Hamburg-American Line returned yesterday, 139 days after leaving New York for calls at thirty-nine ports. Captain Fritz Kruse, commodore of the line and a veteran world cruise master, said his ship had been favored with exceptionally good weather all the way, with only two days of rain out of the 139.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- Next Monday the Supreme Court will recess for four months, probably with its docket swept clean, to go more or less on trial in a Presidential campaign for the first time in years. This is the natural result of dissents to the court majority's invalidation of certain New Deal laws, dissents expressed more forcibly among the brethren themselves than by public or press.

EPSOM, England, May 26. -- The name of Boswell, William Woodward's Derby entry that has been trained by the Irishman Captain Cecil Boyd-Rochfort, at Newmarket, is on the lips of every gypsy tipster tonight as the possible winner of the most open classic ever to be run at historic Epsom Downs.
Increased activity in improved and vacant suburban properties was indicated by the Queens and Westchester sales reported yesterday.

JERUSALEM, May 26. -- British women and children were evacuated tonight from the troubled town of Nablus in an atmosphere made increasingly tense by bold Arab terrorists. Refuge was given them in the capital as a precautionary measure.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- Two national officials of the Townsend Old Age Pension movement who were subpoenaed to testify today before the special House committee, failed to appear. As a result the committee now has three contempt of the House problems before it instead of one.

ALBANY, May 26. -- A new trial for Mrs. Dorothy Sherwood, convicted of drowning her two-year-old son, was asked of the Court of Appeals today on the ground that the Orange County jury which found her guilty of first degree murder was misled by a statement by County Judge Wilson.

DETROIT, May 26 (AP). -- Detroit's Tigers divided a double bill with the Chicago White Sox today, pounding out a 12-9 victory in the first game, only to be checked by Merritt (Sugar) Cain, 9 -- 2, in the nightcap.

The number of visiting buyers reported in the market during the week ended yesterday was less than in the preceding week. However, the total was well above the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES. The arrivals for the week were 732 as against 809 in the previous week and 557 in the same period last year.

Four women and a man took the stand yesterday to inform Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook and a jury of the operations of the organized vice industry of this city. Their testimony, in large measure, was repetitious of evidence given by many other witnesses presented by Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey.

Both fascism and communism are utterly foreign to this country, the Right Rev. Michael J. Lavelle, rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral and Vicar General of the Archdiocese of New York, declared yesterday in an interview at the cathedral rectory, Madison Avenue and Fifty-first Street.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 26. -- Expressing his appreciation of the efforts of social workers to "make this country a more neighborly place in which to live," President Roosevelt declared in a message to the sixty-third annual meeting of the National Conference of Social Work that "we cannot be satisfied with any form of society in which human personality is submerged."

LONDON, May 26 (AP). -- King Edward drove in state today from Buckingham Palace to St. James's Palace to hold the second levee of his reign. He rode in the gold state coach drawn by four horses with an escort of Horse Guards.

Ali Baba successfully defended his world's heavyweight wrestling championship at Madison Square Garden last night. The Turkish grappler, giving away 135 pounds, pinned Big Chief Sanooke, huge Cherokee Indian, in 26 minutes and 29 seconds of a finish encounter.

Samuel H. Ordway Jr., a member of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, resigned his $6,500 position yesterday, explaining to Mayor La Guardia by letter that he wished to foster extension of civil service principles on a nation-wide scale.

SYRACUSE, May 26 (AP). -- Police stood guard over six Remington Rand factories tonight, deserted by an estimated 6,000 workers called out on a strike in protest over the company's announced plan to move its Syracuse plant to Ilion.

Mayor La Guardia, in a speech yesterday at the laying of the cornerstone for the new Williamsburg-Greenpoint Health Center Building in Brooklyn, answered critics of his alleged "carpet-bagger" policy in making appointments.

PHILADELPHIA, May 26. -- A deficit of $39,836 for the Philadelphia Orchestra's 1935-36 season was reported today at the annual meeting of the orchestra association. Benjamin H. Ludlow, the secretary, recalled that estimates before the start of the season had put the expected deficit in excess of $70,000.

Conde Nast Publications, Inc., has granted options at $5 a share on 6,000 shares of its common stock to Conde Nast, president, and on 4,000 shares to Mehemed F. Agha, the company disclosed in its annual report to the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday. Both options will expire on Dec. 31, 1938.

A wife is not to be considered "an almoner beseeching the bestowal of the crumbs from her master's table," Surrogate Wingate in Brooklyn ruled yesterday in awarding a Brooklyn widow one-third of her husband's $2,500,000 estate, in lieu of his bequest to her of a $500,000 trust fund and their town and country homes.
CLEVELAND, May 26 (AP). -- The lowly Browns jumped on three Indian pitchers for eleven hits and took the first of their three-game series today, 8 to 5.
BRUSSELS, May 26. -- Premier Paul van Zeeland tonight handed his resignation to the King and in all probability will be called on tomorrow to make an effort to form a new government.

ALBANY, May 26. -- Governor Lehman signed today the Byrne bill guaranteeing to employers that their contributions to the State Unemployment Insurance Fund will be returned to them without interest, if the law should be declared invalid by the Supreme Court.

LONDON, May 26. -- If it were the intention of the Italian Fascisti to goad British opinion into demanding a showdown in North Africa and the Mediterranean, the policy of pinpricking that is being pursued in those regions could not be better devised.

VATICAN CITY, May 26. -- Pope Pius received today the foreign correspondents of Rome who called on him to express their good wishes in advance of his seventy-ninth birthday, on Sunday. About 120 journalists representing seventeen countries and five religions participated.

CHICAGO, May 26 (AP).--The breach between the International Seamens Union and striking members of the Atlantic and Gulf District was widened tonight as each side rejected proposals to end the controversy.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 26. -- Ten members of the graduating class, "who have contributed, by their officer-like qualities and positive characters," to the development of naval spirit and loyalty within the regiment, will receive letters of commendation from Rear Admiral David F. Sellers, commandant of the Naval Academy.

Mike Belloise, newly designated world featherweight champion, fought a draw with Dave Crowley of England in a ten-round, non-title bout which featured the opening card of the new Queensboro Arena last night. Belloise weighed 127 1/4 and Crowley 127 3/4.

DUBLIN, May 26.--Sir Dawson Bates, Minister for Home Affairs in Northern Ireland, issued a statement tonight on behalf of the government replying to the report of a commission of the British Council for Civil Liberties, which recently charged that the government was dictatorial.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- Senate Finance Committee Democrats were told by President Roosevelt at a White House conference tonight that their compromise tax program was insufficient to meet the demands for new revenue. At the same time he urged a return to the sources outlined in his message of March 3, namely, a high tax on undistributed corporate profits, as a means for making up the deficiency.

ROUEN, France, May 26. -- New developments have taken place in the ecclesiastical conflict in the Rouen diocese which seem to indicate that the dismissal of Archbishop Andre du Bois de la Villerabel may prove to be only the beginning of a serious church conflict.

Representative industries throughout the country report employment nearing 1929 levels and voluntary maintenance by industry generally of improved wage and hour standards in a cross-section survey made by George A. Sloan, chairman of the Consumers Goods Industry Committee.

Business failures in all five trade groups in the week ended May 21 dropped below their average for the last twenty-one weeks, with the retail and commercial service divisions making the best showing, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced yesterday it had filed with the Federal Communications Commission reduced rates to become effective July 1 for telephone calls between the United States and most foreign countries.

A fifth indictment war voted by the grand jury yesterday against A. Henry Ross, Brooklyn lawyer, and Max D. Krone, a private detective, on another extortion charge growing out of a breach of promise suit. The indictment will be handed up to Judge Koenig in General Sessions today.
WASHINGTON, May 26. -- President Roosevelt vetoed today a bill to authorize the city of Newark to buy the old Port Newark Army Supply Base. He stated his reasons in a message to the House.

CLEVELAND, May 26. -- In response to the call of Assistant Secretary of Labor Edward F. McGrady to show where they stood with respect to President Roosevelt's "great effort to create a better life and a better day for the men, women and children of the nation," an overwhelming majority of the 450 delegates to the Amalgamated Clothing Workers' convention gave their approval today of the President's social and economic policies.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 26. -- In memory of Rear Admiral Willard Brownson, former superintendent of the Naval Academy, a mural painting of the engagement between the U.S.S. Constellation and the L'Insurgente in 1799, when both the British and French Governments were attacking American shipping was presented to the academy today, having been placed in Memorial Hall.

EPSOM, England, May 26 (Canadian Press). -- Twenty-two colts, comprising one of the largest Derby fields in years, were ready tonight for tomorrow's 153d running. To pick the winner blindfold with a pin appeared to be as good a way as any.

A code of ethics governing advertising by retail liquor stores is expected to be one of the first developments following in the wake of the intensive price war which enlivened local liquor merchandising in the last ten days. Retailers are said to be anxious to subscribe to some form of regulation which will prevent individual stores from starting another price battle, and work of drawing up rules will get under day this week.
WARSAW, Poland, May 26. -- An ardent believer in the importance of personal contacts in diplomacy, Foreign Minister Josef Beck left this morning for Belgrade, Yugoslavia, for a two-day stay.

The Marion A. Zionchecks were ready for visitors at the Hotel New Yorker at 10 A.M. yesterday, about four hours after they had said good-night. The Washington Representative was in a gay mood, forgetting entirely that one of his last acts of a hectic morning had been tossing a highball glass at another night club visitor in Harlem.

ST. LOUIS, May 26 (AP). -- Jim Winford of the Cardinals won his pitching spurs in a brilliant hurling battle today as St. Louis swept both ends of a double-header with the Pittsburgh Pirates by the same score, 6 to 2.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- Secretary Morgenthau announced tonight that he would include the refunding of $364,138,000 of 3 1/4 per cent notes due on Aug. 1 in his quarterly financing operations on June 15, thus in all probability raising the total sum to be borrowed considerably above $1,500,000,000.

Irving Anderson, leading rider at Narragansett Park, handled C.V. Whitney's Piccolo in the featured Harlem Claiming Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday and won by half a length in a hard drive. The impost of 100 pounds was too little for the regular contract riders, so that Anderson was assigned the mount and turned in an excellent performance.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., May 26 (AP). -- Scott M. Loftin, past president of the American Bar Association, will be Florida's junior Senator until a successor to the late Park Trammell is elected.

The "first milestone" in the rehabilitation of the West Side was reached yesterday when the West Side Association of Commerce presented to Borough President Levy petitions from 1,395 property owners approving the chamber's plan for rezoning 146 blocks between Fourteenth and Fifty-ninth Streets.

John Farrow of Bay Head, N.J., a member of the Beach Haven Tuna Club, landed a 527-pound tuna at Bimini the other day. It was the biggest trophy of the season, scaling only fifteen pounds under the record Bahaman blue-fin caught last year by Kip Farrington.

HEWLETT HARBOR, L.I., May 26. -- From the form Mrs. Jonathan Thorne of Innis Arden displayed in defeating Miss Rosalie Knapp, president of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association, 6 and 5, in the first round of the annual district championship today at the Seawane Club, she ranks as top-heavy favorite to retain the metropolitan title, which she won last year at Apawamis for the first time.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- The Farm Credit Administration has made loans of more than $3,704,000,000 since its establishment three years ago. William I. Myers, the governor, announced today that applications were received from more than half of the mortgaged farmers of the country, and 760,000 long-term advances were made through Federal Land Banks and the Land Bank Commissioner.

Europe will not see Mrs. Helen Wills Moody this year and the Wightman Cup team will not have the benefit of her trenchant racquet, but for the first time since 1933 the Californian will wage an American campaign.

TRENTON, May 26. -- Both the Republican and Democratic parties held the first sessions of their State conventions here today. Despite rumors of opposition, Governor Hoffman was elected chairman of the Republican convention.

MINEOLA, L.I., May 26. -- The Nassau County grand jury returned today four open and two secret indictments against six men in connection with the explosion of a mustard-gas bomb in a Mineola theatre on May 13. The four men named are members of the Nassau County Local of Theatrical Stage Employes International Association.

The American premiere of Richard Hageman's native opera, "Caponsacchi," which was scheduled for the current Spring season at the Metropolitan Opera House, has been postponed to the Winter season. Edward Johnson, general manager of the company, also announced at a press conference yesterday afternoon before his departure in the evening on the Norman- die for Europe, that the Spring season would end next week at the close of a run of four weeks.
TOKYO, May 26. -- In three weeks and two extra days the Diet has passed forty-five government bills and the largest budget in Japan's peace-time history.

SALEM, N.H., May 26 (AP). -- In a driving three-horse finish for which the judges called on the "camera eye" to determine the winner, C.V. Whitney's Roustabout scored his first victory of the 1936 season in the Advertiser Handicap, mile and a sixteenth feature of the card today at Rockingham Park.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 26. -- The development of the use of ether and chloroform in obstetrics was traced by Dr. Benjamin P. Watson, retiring president of the American Gynecological Society, at the sixty-first annual meeting of the society at the Seaview Golf Club, Absecon, near here, today.
BERLIN, May 26 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement for May 23 shows the following changes in reichsmark:

The lynch murder of which the Black Legion members stand accused is described by the Michigan judge as the most striking crime committed in the State in a quarter of a century. But the published ritual of this dread band reads as if it had been composed by Tom Sawyer to impress Huck Finn and Indian Joe.

James Rice, alias David Sherman, alias James Riegelman, of 28 Siegel Street, Brooklyn, an ex-convict and WPA worker employed as a Health Department investigator, was held on a charge of criminal assault for a further hearing on Friday by Magistrate Charles Solomon, sitting yesterday in the Pennsylvania Avenue Court.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 26. -- An index of the credit rating of patrons, from "N.G.," or no good, to "AAAA" for those with resources of millions, was kept by the proprietors of the gambling establishment raided at Harrison, N.Y., it was disclosed here today.

An increase of $2 a ton on virtually all finished and semi-finished steel products has been posted by the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, second largest steel producer of the United States, for the third-quarter deliveries. This announcement extends the range of the rise posted at the end of last week by the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation, operating subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation, on certain semi-finished and structural steel products.

Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard yesterday ordered the abandonment of trolley operation on all of the lines of the New York Railways system, the old Green Lines. Actual carrying of passengers on the lines for revenue purposes ended some time ago, when the system was motorized, but the company has maintained a skeleton service of one or two cars a day because of litigation.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- Whatever alterations a subcommittee of the Senate Appropriations Committee has made in the House draft of the Deficiency Bill, including the $1,425,000,000 work relief appropriation, were held secret today as the committee ended revision of the bill.

Commander Robert C. Lee, vice president of the American Scantic Steamship Line received the award of the Order of Polonia Restituta from the hands of Antoni Roman, Polish Minister of Industry and Commerce, yesterday in Warsaw, according to word received by the offices of the line, at 5 Broadway.

Members of the New York Stock Exchange discussed yesterday the advisability of petitioning Charles R. Gay, president of the Exchange, to send to the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Federal Reserve Board a vigorous protest against the restrictive effect of present margin requirements on security trading.

Patrolman William F. Murphy of the East Twenty-second Street Station was eliminated yesterday by Judge Morris Koenig of General Sessions as a defendant in a first-degree larceny indictment. Witnesses before the grand jury had failed to identify him as a participant in a $750 theft.

DALLAS, May 26. -- Methods of combating the growing threat of neighboring shopping districts to the prestige of "downtown" business centers of large cities were studied today at the annual convention of the National Association of Building Owners and Managers.

BERLIN, May 26. -- The Boerse opened today with a show of weakness and closed with a slight demonstration of strength. The turnover was limited. The impression prevails that the market has again become quiescent and entirely subservient to the customary officially guided influences.

In a very interesting letter in THE NEW YORK TIMES Joseph Lewis expressed deep regret that in the exhibition of Franklin and His Circle at the Metropolitan Museum of Art nothing on display was representative of Franklin's friend, confidant and companion, Thomas Paine.

It may be only a temporary flattering of her pride, but New York has suddenly become once more a "pivotal State" in a Presidential election. It all results from Governor LEHMAN'S refusal to run for another term in November. To most people this was only a surprise, but to politicians of both parties it was a shock.

The European struggle for and against dictatorship continues unabated. The most spectacular recent development in this political phase is the emergence in the Belgian parliamentary election last Sunday of a new authoritarian party, the Rexists, with a startling showing of support.
Mayor La Guardia repeated last night the warning he is sounding with increasing frequency lately, that the city is rapidly approaching a crisis in dealing with its transit problem.
PHILADELPHIA, May 26 (AP). -- Inspired by Chuck Klein's return after an absence of three years with the Cubs, the Phillies pounded the Bees to a 7-to-2 defeat in the series opener today.
Five physicians testified yesterday that the noise of children playing in Stuyvesant Square would seriously disturb their work and interfere with the treatment of patients in abutting hospitals.

A bunt by Abe Gerchick with three on in the last inning gave the Tilden High School its winning run over the Manual Training High School nine, 7 -- 6, at Erasmus Field yesterday. The victory allowed Tilden to hold its slim lead in the Brooklyn, Section B.P.S.A.L. race.

LIMA, Ohio, May 26. -- A night of terror under the guns of the Black Legion, the first case of violence by the organization to come to light outside of Michigan, was recounted tonight by William Smith, a farmer, of Waynesfield, near here.

Although trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange reached the largest volume in more than two months, little progress was made toward higher levels in the main body of issues. A few selected loans in the secondary railroad list were exceptions.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 26. -- Liberal and conservative delegates to the sixty-ninth annual convention of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island clashed verbally here today on the merits of Governor Lehman's eight-point social security program and the Wagner-Ellenbogen Slum Clearance Bill.

Because a passenger found at the last minute that she needed a supply of silk stockings, the American Export liner Exochorda was delayed for ten minutes yesterday afternoon at her Jersey City pier before sailing on a Mediterranean cruise.

Six alumni of New York University will be honored tonight by fellow-alumni at a dinner at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria as the recipients of the 1936 Alumni Meritorious Service Awards, Henry B. Fernald, '01, president of the Alumni Federation, announced yesterday.

It would appear to many fair-minded persons that there prevails much unjust criticism of Postmaster General Farley on the part of those who are playing politics at all times against the President. Is it possible that such criticism has been inspired by jealousy, envy or spite toward Mr. Farley because he is a masterful political strategist?

Edward S. Greenbaum, trustee in bankruptcy for the American estate of the Kreuger Toll Company, represented by Winthrop, Stimson, Putnam Roberts, attorneys, submitted yesterday a petition to Harold P. Coffin, referee, for a settlement of actions and claims brought by Kreuger Toll and other former Kreuger interests against various American banks. Mr. Coffin set 10 A.M. on June 11 for a hearing on the petition.

DETROIT, May 27. -- Declaring that he has received numerous complaints of Black Legion activities in more than fifteen States, including New York, as the result of his investigation into the secret terrorist society here, the Wayne County Prosecutor appealed today to Attorney General Cummings for Federal aid in uncovering the ramifications of the outlaw band.
In your editorial "Voting on the Charter" you discuss the objection which has been made by some opponents of the new charter to voting on it this year.

Primo Carnera weighed 265 pounds and LeRoy Haynes 200 1/2 for their scheduled ten-round fight at Ebbets Field last night. Arthur Donovan was the referee and the Judges were George Kelly and Amby McGarry.

As a result of disquieting reports from the South about wage cuts in cotton mills, which have caused hesitancy among buyers, a group of important mills yesterday gave assurance to distributers through their selling agents here that they were maintaining code wages on the basis of a minimum of 30 cents an hour.

Aroused by the presence of striking seamen picketing his home at 1,274 Fifth Avenue yesterday morning, Mayor La Guardia drove to the Chelsea piers of the International Mercantile Marine Company, accompanied by a spokesman of the pickets, and there watched about 100 placard men marching back and forth in front of Pier 60.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, May 27. -- Robert Sweeny, young American who has resided in London for years, emerged safely from the fourth round of the British amateur golf championship today with a stirring 1-up victory at the twentieth hole over Jack McLean, one of Scotland's hopes and probably the most consistent golfer in the country.

WASHINGTON, May 27. -- Formation of a third party by the Townsendites, with Senator Borah as its nominee for President, has been proposed to the Senator by Dr. Francis E. Townsend, author of the $200-a-month old-age pension plan. The offer was made a few days before Dr. Townsend walked out on the House committee investigating his activities.

ROME, May 27. -- Data on the excellent health conditions throughout the Ethiopian campaign among the Italian troops and workers were disclosed by Sir Aide Castellani, tropical disease specialist, who has been in charge of the medical service in East Africa and has just arrived at Addis Ababa.

Fordham's hitting lengthened with the shadows that overspread Ohio Field last evening as the Rams and N.Y.U. met in their first twilight game. Some long distance clouting in the final three innings broke up a tight 3-3 affair and gave the Maroon an 8-4 victory, its fifteenth of the year.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., May 27. -- Surrogate Robert S. Pelletreau of Suffolk Count signed an order today directing the executors of the will of Colonel Henry H. Rogers to continue the payment of $5,000 a month to Colonel Rogers's widow, Mrs. Pauline V. Rogers, for June and July.

With the producers pool holding July contracts calling for the delivery of 317,000 bales of spot cotton, the near month continued to increase its premium over distant deliveries on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and the list ended a point higher to 5 points lower than on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, May 27. -- Taking issue with the platform recently proposed by several New York Republican organizations, Senator Borah of Idaho said today he was not in favor of committing the party to a return to the gold standard.

Directors of the American Power and Light Company declared yesterday a dividend of 75 cents a share on the $6 preferred and 62 1/2 cents on the $5 preferred stocks. In previous quarters dividends of 37 1/2 cents on the $6 preferred and 31 1/4 cents on the $5 preferred were declared.

LONDON, May 27. -- British official circles, which have been counting upon making some progress at the forthcoming League gathering at Geneva next month toward a general understanding with Germany on the basis of her reply to the British questionnaire, are greatly disheartened by the latest reports from Berlin.

BALDWIN, L.I., May 27. -- The Democratic National Administration was charged with "slothful waste, bribery and incompetence" besides the "wild and demoniac dissipation of the nation's resources in man-power, moral force and physical materials" by Miss Melinda Alexander, who is seeking the Republican nomination for Representative in the Seventeenth Congressional District of Manhattan, in a speech here this afternoon.

Mrs. Helen M. Short, 33 years old, of 53 East Sixty-fifth Street, was indicted yesterday by the grand Jury on a forgery charge made by George M. Wallace, president of the Security First National Bank of Los Angeles. She is accused of raising a $150 check Mr. Wallace gave her as a loan in his office in Los Angeles last April 22 to $150,000.

WASHINGTON, May 27. -- President Roosevelt signed today an act of Congress amending the Securities Act to permit continued trading on Exchanges in unlisted securities, providing these fall within definite limitations imposed by the amending measure.

CONCORD, N.H., May 27. -- Former Senator George H. Moses, among the backers of Frank Knox for the Presidential nomination, predicted a Republican victory by a narrow electoral vote in an address today before the "North Country" Republican Women's Club at Littleton.

The unbeaten filly, Blue Sheen, owned by Whitney Stone, a comparative newcomer to racing, maintained her unblemished record at Belmont Park yesterday by the scantest of margins in the most courageous dash from behind ever seen in the Acorn Stakes. This $13,125-mile run for 3-year-old fillies saw the daughter of Toro Just get up to catch George D. Widener's High Fleet on the post.

There was a notable migration of birds from South to North in the Eastern part of the country this Spring, according to a statement by Ludlow Griscom, made public yesterday by the National Association of Audubon Societies Mr. Griscom, who is research curator of zoology at the Museum of Comparative Zoology, Cambridge. Mass., said that the migration was "one of the earliest and soonest concluded in a great many years."

WASHINGTON, May 27. -- The trouble with the Senate Finance Committee's revision of the President's new pet taxation plan was that it was 500 millions short of the amount needed over a three-year period to put the Federal budget in a defensible campaign position.

PHILADELPHIA, May 27. -- Disagreement among New Deal agencies as to what should be included in Federal housing legislation makes it unlikely that the Wagner Housing Bill or any similar measure will be passed at this session of Congress, the National Association of Heating.

BERLIN, May 27. -- Prices were strong and trading was lively on the Boerse today, with interest centering on stocks and foreign bonds. The share market showed buoyancy and the increased turnover recalled the boom times. Domestic fixed-interest securities also were buoyant, but the market for such issues remained narrow and therefore easy to control.

The extortion indictment vote by the New York County grand jury last Tuesday against A. Henry Ross, a Brooklyn lawyer, and Max D. Krone, a private detective, was handed up to Judge Koenig in General Sessions yesterday. They are expected to appear for pleading on the new charge tomorrow.

PARIS, May 27. -- Fred Perry and H.W. (Bunny) Austin, England's Davis Cup stars, moved into the quarter-finals of the French hard courts singles tennis championship today and Andrew Merlin completed his conquest of Heiner Henkel, brilliant young German internationalist.

WASHINGTON, May 27. -- Charging that the Michigan Black Legion had been supplied with radical literature by several un-American organizations, Representative Dickstein, chairman of the House Immigration and Naturalization Committee, introduced today a resolution authorizing an investigation of all such groups by a seven-member committee to be appointed by the Speaker.

The action of the stock market yesterday afforded additional proof that, despite the uncertainties attending an election year, there need not be general resignation to stagnant markets throughout the Summer. The volume on the Stock Exchange increased to 1,219,000 shares from 1,143,000 the day before, the first time in almost three weeks that million-share days have come in consecutive sessions.

COLUMBUS, May 27. -- A report of three official investigators connecting the Black Legion with acts of violence in Ohio and blaming the hooded order for threats to kidnap a daughter of Governor Davey was made public today by State Representative H.T. Phillips.
ABOARD THE S.S. QUEEN MARY, Thursday, May 28 (AP). -- The stately liner Queen Mary steamed westward this morning on her first voyage to the United States after touching at Cherbourg.

DETROIT, May 27 (UP). -- Tommy Bridges and Ted Lyons turned in six-hit pitching performances today, but the Tiger right-hander was more successful in scattering the blows and Detroit defeated Chicago, 3 to 2. The victory gave the Tigers a two-to-one edge in the current series and dropped the White Sox to fifth place.

Most commodity futures declined in the local commodity futures markets yesterday, although sugar and hides showed slight gains and cottonseed oil was strong. On the cash markets corn, rye, cotton, hides, butter and rubber advanced, while wheat, lard, standard tin and wool tops eased.

Verdi's "Aida" received its first presentation of the popular season at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. Although less resplendent in its pageantry than was the case at the performances of the opera during the Winter, on the whole the production was a creditable one.

LONDON, May 27. -- The trial match arranged for the American international polo team today at the Roehampton Club developed into a farce. Two chukkers were played, then the sides split up and almost everybody who happened to be around joined in.

MEXICO, D.F., May 27. -- A committee representing the Catholics of the State of Vera Cruz has appealed again for action by Silvano Barba Gonzalez, Minister of the Interior, for reopening for services thirteen churches in the State.

CLEVELAND, May 28. -- Plans for the Presidential campaign and measures designed to cope with the threatened extension of the party split were discussed today by the National Executive Committee of the Socialist party at its first meeting following adjournment of the party's national convention yesterday.

CLEVELAND, May 27. -- Increase in the public debt is nearing the point where resulting excessive taxation will actually diminish the aggregate wealth of the country, Allan M. Pope told the Ohio Bankers Association at its forty-sixth annual convention here today.

The Long Island Railroad will lose more than $1,700,000 annually if it is forced to charge a flat rate of 2 cents a mile to its interstate and intrastate passengers, Parker McCollester, special counsel for the railroad, told Public Service Commissioner George R. Lunn yesterday at an nvestigation into the "inconsistency" in the fares to be put into effect Monday.

PORTSMOUTH, England, May 27. -- T.O.M. Sopwith's Endeavour II will be launched at Gosport on June 8. The new yacht will be tuned up as quickly as possible so that she can start racing in the Falmouth regatta June 28 and 29. There she will meet the first Endeavour, Velsheda, and Astra, the only three old British Class J craft that have been brought out this year.

The Montgomery Advertiser urges the hundreds of young men and women who are being graduated from Southern colleges and universities to stay in the South, where they are more needed than in any other region. As it is, the South is bearing the expense of their training while other sections derive the benefit.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 27. -- International peace will never the permanently established until the nations of the world are willing "to merge their wealth and their resources, their unlimited sovereignties and their neutralities," Henry Wickam Steed, noted British journalist, declared today in an address broadcast from London to the National Conference of Social Workers at their sixty-third annual meeting here.

MANAHAWKIN, N.J., May 27. -About 170 of the 260 members of the CCC camp here, who were on almost continuous duty fighting the Cedar Run and Mayetta forest fires from Sunday night until 3 A.M., Tuesday, went on strike this morning when ordered into the woods to resume their regular forestry work.

Mr. and Mrs. George E. Dunscombe gave a dinner last night in the Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria for Mrs. Dunscombe's sister, Mrs. F. Warren Pearl, and her daughter, Miss Audrey Pearl, who will depart for London on June 5 on the Queen Mary.

NEW ORLEANS, May 27. -- C.A. Kelley of the Southern Sierras Power Company, Riverside, Calif., today warn elected president of the National Association of Purchasing Agents at the organization's twenty-first international convention at the Hotel Roosevelt. Mr. Kelley succeeds Fred J. Lucas of Purdy-Mansell, Ltd., Toronto, Can.

CLEVELAND, May 27. -- Major George L. Berry, chairman of labor's Non-Partisan League, whose slogan is "For Roosevelt in 1936," precipitated a noisy demonstration at the convention of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers today when he declared that the league would remain in existence "after the election and up to 1940."

NOW after a delay for which the British Foreign Office may or may not be responsible, E.M. Forster appears disconsolate as a young poet but with no inspired passion, wanting stability, comfort, a cure, but sure that he is unlikely to find them. He fears for the future -- when he tries to see it he sees a draggled mass of elderly people and barbed wire.

BOSTON, May 27. -- The Yankees downed the Red Sox despite a rainstorm which drenched Fenway Park today, but they required eleven innings and the good right arm of Monte Pearson to accomplish the feat.
ALBANY, May 27. -- Governor Lehman today announced the resignation of Lawrence B. Cummings as a member of the State Mortgage Commission.

WASHINGTON, May 27. -- With the farm issue coming more and more to the fore with the advent of the political conventions and campaign, Secretary Wallace moved swiftly today to deprive Republican strategists of another "cause" on which they might base an appeal for the farmers' votes.
Donald Culross Peattie's "Green Laurels: The Lives and Achievements of the Great Naturalists," will be published by Simon Schuster on July 15. It is the August selection of the Literary Guild.
WASHINGTON, May 27. -- President Roosevelt signed the bill to permit regulated trading in unlisted securities and discussed the pending Guffey-Vinson Coal Control Bill with John L. Lewis.

Fares to many points on railroads serving New York will be reduced on Monday in conformity with an order of the Interstate Commerce Commission which established a 2-cents-a-mile rate for coaches and a 3-cent rate for Pullmans, without surcharge, throughout the country.
Forty-six hours after they came down the gangplank of the steamship Scanpenn, the homeless Marion A. Zionchecks left New York at 3:30 P.M. yesterday via the Holland Tunnel.

WASHINGTON, May 27. -- Secretary Roper, in a letter to Representative Marcantonio today, declared that he had decided to drop a promised investigation of seamen's charges of lack of safety at sea, and to pass it on to a special committee appointed by Senator Copeland.

TRENTON, May 27. -- The "promiscuous distribution of State railroad passes on a large scale" by proposed legislation was denounced today by the Associated Railroads of New Jersey, the spokesman for all the important railroads in or that pass through New Jersey.

The I. Miller Sons Company, Inc., of Delaware, and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended on Feb. 29 a net income of $242,999 after depreciation, Federal income taxes, minority interest and other deductions. After allowing for annual dividend requirements on 22,445 shares of $50-par 8 per cent cumulative preferred stock, on which unpaid dividends have accumulated, the income equalled $1.39 a share on 109,996 shares of $5-par common stock.

I admire the temerity of my young friend Fabian Franklin in venturing to criticize that venerable sage and economist, Elmer Davis, who seems to believe that the only way out of our morass of industrial depression is through some form of Federal legislation.
Money market remained at a standstill in the matter of business and quotations. Demand was light, and rates unchanged.

GIBRALTAR, May 27. -- General Harrington, Governor of Gibraltar, today wirelessed an invitation to Emperor Haile Selassie, aboard the British cruiser Capetown, to lunch at Government House after his arrival, early Friday morning. Tonight the Emperor had not yet replied.

LONDON, May 27. -- The British Government let it be known today through an official spokesman that it had not swerved one inch from its policy of not paying the war debt to the United States at present.

Amid the blare of band music, the blast of boat whistles, the shrieks of sirens and the drone of airplanes overhead, listeners here eavesdropped on a vivid sound and word picture as the Queen Mary slipped from the dock yesterday at Southampton on her maiden voyage to New York.

SO far no lives have been lost but the American League pennant race is making baseball look like a bruising and bone-breaking game. The way the casualties shape up now, the stretch run of the contending clubs may be staged along some hospital corridor. Either that or the managers of the contending clubs will be unable to muster nine good men and true on a side.

The expanding life of the future was suggested as the basic theme for the World's Fair by the executive committee of the "Fair of the Future" last night at a dinner in the Ritz Tower grill room attended by members of the World's Fair board of design.
SYRACUSE, May 27 (AP). -- Leaders of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America met today to discuss church problems preparatory to opening the 148th general assembly.

ROME, May 27. -- The future may bring new troubles and the rest of the world may think differently, but Italy today abandons herself to the joy of a great success. This is the time to see the man who is the author of a national achievement.

WASHINGTON, May 27. -- The Treasury will offer to the public on June 15 $1,000,000,000 in "new money" and about the same amount of refinancing, Secretary Morgenthau announced today. This will constitute the largest peace-time financing operation in the history of the United States. The total offering will be about $2,050,000,000.

The WPA Federal Music Project yesterday announced plans for a series of fifteen "new talent" concerts which will be given by the New York Festival Orchestra, an eighty-five-piece symphonic unit, on Sunday afternoons during the Summer in the Sculpture Court of the Brooklyn Museum.

EPSOM DOWNS, England, May 27. -- A jocular North Country bookmaker, handing THE NEW YORK TIMES correspondent a ticket on Mahmoud, which had been selected in the time-honored Derby fashion by sticking a pin through the back of a race card, remarked: "The Aga Khan can't win with that one today -- he won't stay the course."

PARIS, May 27. -- Finding a Foreign Minister and perhaps also a foreign policy is one of the most difficult parts of Leon Blum's task in forming a Cabinet which should be ready at the end of next week, when the new Parliament has assembled and completed its organization.

SALEM, N.H., May 27 (AP). -- Faust, trim chestnut son of Diavolo, from the Canadian-owned stable of A.G. Tarn, gained an eyelash verdict in the New Hampshire Handicap, one-mile feature, before a crowd of 9,000 at Rockingham Park today. The horse paid $34.80 for $2 3to win the mutuels.

The Right Rev. James DeWolf Perry, presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church, presented diplomas yesterday to twenty-eight members of the graduating class of the General Theological Seminary at the 115th commencement of that institution at 175 Ninth Avenue.

ALBANY, May 27 (AP). -- Roy Schalk's home run with two men on the paths was the big blow in Newark's 7-to-5 victory over Albany tonight. Bob Loane also hit a home run with one one for the Senators, but struck out with the bases filled in the ninth inning.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 27 (AP). -Officials made plans to put a guard of eighty policemen tomorrow around the Remington Rand Company's plant, which is scheduled to open in the face of picketing by over 1,000 striking employes.

One year ago this morning the same newspapers that reported the invalidation of NRA by a unanimous Supreme Court also devoted many columns to comments on the probable consequences of that decision. Among these comments there were some of a highly pessimistic nature.

As an outgrowth of the controversy over American participation in the Olympic Games, Charles Ornstein, one of the leaders of the unsuccessful boycott movement, yesterday announced plans for a "world labor athletic carnival" in the city-owned Randalls Island Stadium Aug. 15-16.

On the first day of this month 212 Congressmen voted for a new Navy Bill. Twenty-one days later Sir Thomas Inskip, Minister of Coordination of Defense, announced Britain's vast rearmament program. A few days thereafter, on the twenty-first anniversary of Italy's entrance into the World War, Premier Mussolini informed his young Fascist warriors of an imminent and inevitable conflict.

Except for a few moments in the fifth inning, Lou Hall hurled shutout ball for City College at Manhattan Field yesterday, but during that brief lapse in his control Lou McKenna and Russ Kurtz smashed successive singles and George Kiefer lashed a homer over the centerfield fence to give Manhattan College a 3-to-2 victory.

WASHINGTON, May 27. -- Applications for Federal registration of $123,000,000 of bonds and debentures and 2,000,000 shares of no-par value common stock were filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the Texas Corporation, the Consolidated Oil Corporation of New York City and the Otis Steel Company of Cleveland.

WASHINGTON, May 27. -- President Roosevelt was described today by John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers of America, as favoring enactment at this session of Congress of the Guffey-Vinson bill, designed to salvage the price-fixing authorization for the coal industry which was lost with the old Guffey act when the Supreme Court invalidated that law because of unconstitutional clauses regulating labor.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., May 27. -- Dr. Harlow Shapley, director of the Harvard Observatory, tried this afternoon to explain the structure and function of the cosmos in "one-syllable words" to a group of students at Sarah Lawrence College for Women here.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 27. -- Recent statements that Chile's Minister of Finance made in London before departing for South America concerning a renewal of Chile's payments on her foreign debt have been taken up here in the columns of the Mercurio and other newspapers.

CHICAGO, May 27. -- The market for hogs was under pressure here today as the result of liberal supplies. Prices were shaded 10 to 15 cents a hundredweight to make sales, with some prices 20 cents under the best level on the previous day. So far this week local arrivals have been 20,000 head in excess of the corresponding period last week.
LONDON, May 27. -- If Great Britain is allowed to keep her excess destroyer tonnage that is due to be scrapped under the expiring 1930 treaty then Japan will feel entitled to do the same.

WASHINGTON, May 27. -- Dr. Francis E. Townsend, founder of the $200-per-month old-age pension plan, and two of his chief aides will be cited for contempt by the House of Representatives if that body accepts the recommendation made today by the special House committee which is investigating the movement.
ALBANY, May 27. -- Governor Lehman signed today the bill of Senator Baldwin of New York vesting broad powers in the New York City Commissioner of Markets.

LONDON, May 27. -- A rally in British funds on the London Stock Exchange today accompanied a brighter tone in most sections of the market, where the upward movement was assisted to some extent by yesterday's recovery in Wall Street.
CLEVELAND, May 27. -- A truce has been declared between the Van Sweringen-Nickel Plate interests and the Taplin forces in their ten-year battle for control of the Wheeling Lake Erie Railway.

TORONTO, May 27. -- Ontario's metallic production for the first three months of 1936 was valued at $37,635,296, compared with $29, 517,953 in the same period a year ago, an increase of approximately 27.5 per cent, according to a report issued by the Ontario Department of Mines today.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP). -- The industrial unionism dispute which for two years has threatened to split the American Federation of Labor approached a showdown today as John L. Lewis treated with sarcasm an inquiry on policy from William Green.

PHILADELPHIA, May 27 (AP). -- A pinch-hit double by Manager Jimmy Wilson with the Bases loaded in the eighth broke a 2-2 tie with the Boston Bees today and gave the Phils a 5-to-2 victory and a sweep of the two-game series.

Captain Kenneth E. Kline, U.S.A., who disappeared more than a week ago from Rutgers University, New Brunswick, N.J., where he had served since 1930 as Associate Professor of Military Science, was identified yesterday at the Fort Jay Hospital at Governors Island, military authorities announced.

Bernard DeVoto, novelist and critic, has been appointed editor-in-chief of The Saturday Review of Literature and will assume his new post in September, it was announced yesterday. Mr. DeVoto will succeed Henry Seidel Canby, founder of the publication and its editor since its establishment in 1924. who will continue active association with the editorial staff and also as a contributor.

In the platform adopted by the Socialist party one plank calls for sweeping amendments of the Constitution. This will furnish an added reason why the Democratic party will not call for anything of the kind. Let it be left as the sole property of the Socialists. They are quite within their rights in pressing for an amendment which would permit them to carry out their policies.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 27. -- Mrs. J.B. Scott entertained with luncheon today at the Casino Terrace for Mrs. R.J. Bowman. Mr. and Mrs. S.D. Stonebraker were luncheon hosts before departing today for New York, as were Mr. and Mrs. A.W. Stewart and Mr. and Mrs. Walter H. Eckert.

Election of officers for the academic year 1936-37 in twelve fraternities of Columbia College was announced yesterday by Dean Herbert E. Hawkes, chairman of the Pamphratria Council, the association of fraternities.
Sparse Gray Hackle contributes an interesting analysis of the current trout fishing on the Beaverkill River in the Catskills, a stream with which he is thoroughly familiar.

According to the files of the Federal Bureau of Investigation some 10,000 dangerous criminals are always at large. Most of these birds of ill omen have been caged before, so that they have won a place in the police "Who's Who." To recognize them after they are arrested for the tenth or twentieth time is easy enough.

TRENTON, N.J., May 27. -- The use of sound motion pictures in bringing about the identification of criminals was demonstrated here this afternoon by members of the New Jersey State police before a gathering of more than 400 police officials from this country, Canada and England.

Aside from the belated speculative interest in secondary railroad issues, trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange was of a routine nature and devoid of unusual features. High grade corporate loans maintained a firm undertone, interest in those issues, however, switching to the public offering of two new issues, both of which were met with a broad investment demand.

WASHINGTON, May 27. -- Attorney General Cummings, former chairman of the Democratic National Committee, joined Chairman Farley today in attacking the century-old rule under which a two-thirds majority is required for a Presidential nomination in a Democratic convention.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP). -- Senator Rush D. Holt, Democrat of West Virginia, declared today he has been stripped of Federal patronage because of his repeated allegation that the Works Progress Administration is influenced by political consideration, but added that "there will be no retreat."
Here are a few things which puzzle me:

WASHINGTON, May 27. -- With charges still pending against Michael J. Meehan for irregular transactions in stocks of the Bellanca Aircraft Corporation, the Securities and Exchange Commission has withdrawn its stop-order proceedings against the company's registration statement and has permitted the application and amendments to become effective as of April 8, 1936.

O. Howard Wolfe, cashier of the Philadelphia National Bank, will be the speaker tonight at the graduation exercises of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Banking, to be held in the Brick Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street. Mr. Wolfe will tell the graduates "What Banking Expects of You."

WASHINGTON, May 27. -- Counsel for more than 400 railroad enterprises attacking the constitutionality of the railroad retirement legislation of 1935 closed their case in the District of Columbia Supreme Court today and the government began its defense.

MOSCOW, May 27. -- Amid the greatest stir the Soviet Union has known since the abolition of bread cards, the population settled down today to the discussion that the government invited on the projected law for prohibiting abortions and tightening divorce and alimony regulations.

Seattle's Congressman goes on adding to the gayety of the nation, if you can call it gayety. It must be confessed, however, that in his most recent efforts there is a forced note. The first fine frenzy which thrilled a continent has spent itself.

The recently announced increases in steel prices for the third quarter of 1936 should result in heavy shipments during June, which may make the month the best of the year for the steel industry, according to the weekly summary issued yesterday by the magazine Iron Age.

ROCHESTER, May 27. -- "Save New York from the New Deal" was the substance of the appeal of four political and industrial leaders today before Associated Industries, Inc., gathered here for its annual convention.

To nineteen residents of New York and near-by suburbs yesterday the finish line at Epsom Downs as the rainbow's end a little stub of pasteboard was the mythical pot of gold. They were the big winners in the Irish Hospital Sweepstakes on the English Derby, which paid an aggregate of $3,304,780 to American ticketholders, netting the United States Treasury an estimated $784,000 in taxes.
CHICAGO. May 27 (AP). -- The Reds came back in the ninth inning today, after being held scoreless by Southpaw Larry French, to score all their runs in a 5-to-3 victory over the Cubs.
By way of demonstrating that a grand master should never be forced to recognize an exception in his calling, Carl Hubbell made his first start of the year against the Dodgers at the Polo Grounds.
A plot on the Mount of Olives in the Holy Land was passed off like any ordinary vacant lot to a creditor in bankruptcy court yesterday to prevent foreclosure by a German bank in Jerusalem.
AGAWAM, Mass., May 27 (AP). -- Wise Anne, owned by Mrs. W.C. Weant and trained by her husband, captured the Agawam Handicap, feature race on the inaugural card at Agawam Park today.

PHILADELPHIA, May 27. -- A miniature Rue de la Paix will cross the lawns of the Philadelphia Country Club to the Polo Field when the Philadelphia annual horse show takes place, from June 11 to 14. Frocks and furbelows, refreshments and diversions will fill small booths in charge of members of the show's junior committee, of which Mrs. W. W. Richardson Jr. is chairman.

Salaries of the principal officials of the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey and subsidiaries reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission for 1935, as detailed in statements filed yesterday with the New York Stock Exchange, show Thomas N. McCarter, president, received $144,167, of which $69,167 was paid by the corporation and the balance by five subsidiaries.

The New York County grand jury yesterday handed up to Judge Koenig in General Sessions a first-degree murder indictment against Miss Gussie Freedman, 45 years old, an inmate of the State Hospital for the Insane at Creedmore, L.I., in the kidnapping and drowning of 10-month-old Jacob Horowitz last Jan. 5.
WEST POINT, N.Y., May 27. -- Army, in its pre-Navy baseball contest, won today from Bucknell by a score of 12 to 7. It was a free-hitting contest with the cadets doin the more damage.

Manufacturers of cosmetics, perfumes and allied lines launched a movement yesterday, at an executive session of the annual convention of the Toilet Goods Association at the Hotel Biltmore, to establish a bureau of standards in the industry.

Curly Mills of Los Angeles, driving with splendid finesse and utter abandon, roared home the winner of the feature four-mile event last night as the series of midget auto races at the Madison Square Garden Bowl began in Long Island City. A crowd of 17,400 persons was on hand.
SHANGHAI, May 27. -- A baby boy, selected by mystical methods, was reported today to have been chosen to become the spiritual and temporal ruler of remote Tibet.

The direct effect of motion picture opposition to the terms of the new Dramatists Guild contract was revealed yesterday with the announcement by J. Robert Rubin, vice president and general counsel of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, that his company was withdrawing its financial backing for stage productions next season from Sam H. Harris and Max Gordon, two of Broadway's most important theatrical producers, because of their acceptance of the new agreement.

Increasingly frequent intimations of attempts to influence witnesses against testifying for the State at the trial of Charles (Lucky Luciano) Lucania and nine others on charges of compulsory prostitution reached a climax yesterday when it was revealed that Samuel Kornbluth, a lawyer, of 313 Montgomery Street, Brooklyn, had been arrested on a charge of "attempted subornation of perjury" and that two other men and a woman had been held as material witnesses.

WASHINGTON, May 27. -- Plans for early June adjournment of Congress were in jeopardy tonight as the Senate Finance Committee became involved in a new tangle over President Roosevelt's renewed demand for a tax measure that would re-establish the integrity of the budget which he presented to Congress on Jan. 6 and conform to the revenue message he submitted on March 3.

SHANGHAI, May 27. -Optimistic expectations that Japan would be satisfied with improving her position in Hopei and Chahar Provinces and had abandoned plans for an autonomous regime in all five of the North China provinces were contradicted in a frank announcement today by a Japanese spokesman that the five-province plan is still a live issue.

Testifying in the Supreme Court yesterday before Justice William T. Collins in defense of the suit by Beth Israel Hospital and other institutions fronting on Stuyvesant Square to restrain him from completing playgrounds in the square, Park Commissioner Robert S. Moses said he has learned that parks without playgrounds are unsuccessful.

ROME, May 27. -- Augur's interview today with Premier Benito Mussolini affords a convenient starting point for a brief review of Italian policy in the principal sectors affected by the Italo-Ethiopian dispute and by European reactions to which it has given rise.
ST. LOUIS, May 27 (AP). -- Pittsburgh's Buccaneers gained sweet revenge today for the double defeat of yesterday, slashing out fifteen hits for an 11-to-2 victory over the Cardinals.
MILWAUKEE, May 27 (AP). -- Lieut. Gov. Thomas J. O'Malley stepped into his first public office in 1932 after a career of forty-four years as a railroad man.

MADISON, N.J., May 27. -- Three golfers, two of them prominent in metropolitan tournament circles, tied for the qualifying medal today in the New Jersey State amateur championship. The trio-John E. Parker Jr. of Essex County, holder of the metropolitan amateur title; Charles Whitehead of Forsgate and Frank Giessen of Branch Brook -- shaved a stroke from the Braidburn Country Club par of 73.

Cotton Goods Sales Improve A substantial volume of "quiet" buying has taken place in the primary cotton goods market this week and has served to lift prices a degree from their previously very low levels, selling agents reported yesterday. With the low stocks that are reported in the hands of distributors, the movement of goods this week may gather momentum shortly, it was felt, and strengthen the market considerably.

In spite of the constant rage of "liberal" Republicans against the Old Guard, it is not too easy to find anywhere more than a skeleton regiment of those ancient warriors. Fortunately, Indiana, where politics begins at birth, still abounds in such heroes. JIM WATSON and former Governor GOODRICH are fighting not the foe but each other, as they have been doing for years that transcend memory.

Directors of the Retail Merchants Association of New Jersey voted unanimously yesterday to apply for affiliation with the American Retail Federation at a luncheon meeting held at L. Bamberger Co., Newark. William J. Wells, president of Bamberger's was host to the directors of the association and to other leading merchants of the State who attended.
Mayor La Guardia reaffirmed yesterday his injunction to the Police Department to rid the city of criminals and gangsters, however great their political influence.

Still deadlocked more than eleven hours after retiring to consider the evidence in the trial of John Fiorenza for the murder of Mrs. Nancy Evans Titterton, the jury was locked up in the jury room at 2:15 o'clock this morning with instructions to remain there until 10 A.M. today.

A consolidated net income of $3,164,214 was reported yesterday by the Electric Power and Light Corporation and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on March 31. This was equivalent to $4.11 each on 770,556 combined shares of preferred stock and compared with a deficit of $83,679 for the preceding twelve months.

TRENTON, N.J., May 27. -- Since the State of New Jersey turned the administration of direct relief back to the municipalities six weeks ago the city of Trenton has reduced its relief roll from 3,682 to 1,602 cases and the costs of relief from more than $100,000 to about $30,000 a month.

The proposal to tax corporate surpluses has been so fiercely debated that no one seems to have noticed that the solution of the whole problem, from the standpoint of revenue as distinguished from the social point of view, can be found in the decision of the United States Supreme Court in Koshland v. Helvering, May 18, 1936.

The stewards of the Jockey Club during a meeting at Belmont Park yesterday reached a decision on starting devices which is expected to have a far-reaching effect on the sport in this country and to make the method of starting uniform with that prevailing in most of the countries having thoroughbred racing.
Gold of the value of $4,100,000 was engaged in Paris yesterday for shipment here, making since April 24, $175,000,000 engaged abroad, and $141,100,000 taken in France.
NANKING, China, May 27 (AP). -China refused tonight to accept Japan's explanation of why she poured thousands of additional troops into North China.

More than 90,000 renewed driving permits, it was estimated, were issued yesterday to motorists who applied at the offices of the Bureau of Motor Vehicles in the five boroughs. At the bureau's headquarters, 155 Worth Street, Commissioner Charles A. Harnett ordered additional rooms opened to accommodate the applicants.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

PITTSBURGH, May 27. -- C.W. Bennett, president of the American Sheet and Tin Plate Company, retired today from that position, as plans were completed to merge that subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation with another subsidiary, the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation. The merger will become effective on June 1.

WASHINGTON, May 27. -- The only way Great Britain can retain excess cruiser and destroyer tonnage over the limits of the London treaty of 1930 is by resort to the escalator clause of that pact, Admiral William H. Standley, Acting Secretary of the Navy, said today after a study of the project had been completed by the Navy Department.

PHILADELPHIA, May 27. -- Thirteen students of the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts today received William Emlen Cresson Memorial Traveling Scholarships of $900 each, plus $200 for tuition for the coming year at the academy.
JERUSALEM, May 27. -- Arab demonstrators uprooted trees and attempted to burn Jewish crops today and continued aimless shooting at Jewish colonists.

Two of eighteen suits for triple damages brought under the Sherman and Clayton anti-trust laws against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the Western Electric Company and Electric Research Products, Inc., have been dismissed by Federal Judge Knox, it was revealed yesterday.

DEVON, Pa., May 27. -- Knight Bachelor, owned by Miss Judy King of Atlanta, enjoyed a successful day at the Devon Horse Show today, climaxing the afternoon by winning a leg on the Goodman Challenge Trophy for the best harness horse.

The legislative committee of the New York Cotton Exchange, of which Perry E. Moore is chairman, sent yesterday a telegram to Senator David I. Walsh of Massachusetts, asking him not to support legislation proposed by Senator E. D. Smith of South Carolina and now before Congress designed to further restrict trading on the Cotton Exchanges of the country.

PHILADELPHIA, May 27 (AP). -- The whole complexion of the I.C. A.A.A.A. meet at Franklin Field Friday and Saturday was drastically changed tonight with the announcement from the favorite, Harvard, that its star, Captain Milton Green, may not compete.

The North German Lloyd liner Bremen will arrive today from Bremen and Channel ports. Her passengers include Alanson B. Houghton, former United States Ambassador to Great Britain; Frank O. Lowden, former Governor of Illinois, with Mrs. Lowden; Guthrie McClintic, producer; the Countess of Warwick; Antonio Moreno, former film actor, and John Keith, inspector for the Federal Bureau of Investigation in Washington.

The possibility that WPA projects in the city parks would have to be shut down because of a shortage of materials was averted yesterday when a WPA check for $234,000 was sent to Park Commissioner Robert Moses for the purchase of new supplies.

BELGRADE, May 27. -- Colonel Josef Beck, Polish Foreign Minister, arrived here today as official Yugoslav circles insisted that his visit was merely of a courtesy character. He was received at the railway station by Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch and the Polish Minister to Yugoslavia.

GENEVA, May 27. -- Signs reaching the Secretariat of the League of Nations point increasingly toward the continuation of sanctions till Autumn at least through the adjournment of all decision on the Ethiopian question until the September Assembly.
CLEVELAND, May 27 (AP). -- The Indians climbed back into fourth place today by defeating the Browns, 12 to 2, while Chicago was losing to Detroit.

We are in the midst of the great annual festival when every animate thing bursts forth in brilliant color and a new song; the tremendous urge of a new life opens before us. Windows, too, are opening to the gladsome season, and from many of these come strange and terrible sounds.

HEWLETT HARBOR, L.I., May 27. -- Miss Ruth Adel, 1934 Long Island titleholder, led the way into the quarter-final round of the women's metropolitan golf championship at the Seawane Club today by defeating the New York State champion, Mrs. Sylva Annenberg, 3 and 2.

BERLIN, May 27. -- The first sentences in the mass trial of Catholic monks at Coblenz on charges of immorality were passed today when Bernhard Steinhoff, called Brother Leovigill, a priest of the Order of St. Francis, was sentenced to eight years at penal servitude and to ten years' loss of civil rights.

Failure of a company manufacturing a year-round product to advertise during the Summer month, requires that greater pressure be applied when advertising is resumed during the Fall, according to one agency executive yesterday. If a company keeps its product in the public eye during the Summer, even though sales may slump, less effort in "getting up steam" is necessary in the Fall months, he said.

WASHINGTON, May 27. -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ended May 16 totaled 315,481,000 barrels, according to data compiled by the Bureau of Mines for Secretary Ickes. Compared with figures of the previous week, this total represents an increase of 582,000 barrels, comprising an increase of 658,000 barrels in stocks of domes- tic crude oil, but a decrease of 76,000 barrels in stocks of foreign crude.

TOKYO. May 27. -- Eiji Amau, the Foreign Office spokesman, who on May 15 said the smuggling in North China was a result of China's high tariffs and official slackness, chose new ground today, but made it even clearer than be fore that Japan did not intend to intervene.

HARRISON, N.J., May 27. -- James Casey Jr., nine-year-old son of a factory worker, was drowned this afternoon in the Passaic River while trying to teach himself to swim. His sister, Geraldine, 7, made futile efforts to save him and had to be rescued herself from the water.
The current term in the public schools will close on June 26 instead of June 30 as originally scheduled, according to a resolution adopted yesterday at a meeting of the Board of Education.

As indicated in these columns yesterday, Katharine Hepburn will return to the stage next season in Helen Jerome's dramatization of "Jane Lyre." Miss Hepburn has signed a contract, and the play will have its New York premiere about Jan. 1, the Theatre Guild said yesterday.
Problems affecting the steel industry will be discussed today by steel leaders at the forty-fifth general meeting of the American Iron and Steel Institute in the Waldorf-Astoria.

LONDON, May 27. -- Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh and Mrs. Lindbergh were King Edward's guests this evening at a royal dinner in St. James's Palace, where a notable party was assembled, including Prime Minister and Mrs. Stanley Baldwin.

The new motor-liner Batory, the second addition to Poland's merchant marine in the last nine months, arrived in the harbor yesterday amid an enthusiastic welcome led by hundreds of happy Polish-Americans who had journeyed here from all parts of the country to pay her tribute.

The 100th session of the special grand jury investigating the Samuel Drukman murder case was held yesterday with the hearing of testimony by Deputy Police Commissioner John J. Sullivan and other high police officials.

WASHINGTON, May 27. -- President Roosevelt is made administrator of the $1,425,000,000 relief appropriation for the next fiscal year under the terms of the Deficiency Bill reported today by the Senate Appropriations Committee.

Three outmoded buildings that were landmarks in the heyday of German singing societies in this city will make way for a structure that will contain the latest in modern broadcasting facilities, it was revealed yesterday, when the Columbia Broadcasting System announced that it had purchased the southeast corner of Park Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street and adjoining property.

Six hundred leaders of the shipping industry attended a luncheon yesterday at the Hotel Commodore in honor of Emmet J. McCormack, treasurer of Moore McCormack, ship operators, who recently retired as president of the Maritime Association after having served four years.

The first accurate mapping of a great gorge through which the Hudson River flowed in prehistoric times, at a point that is now 7,200 feet below the sea, was reported yesterday, when the United States Coast and Geodetic Survey ship Oceanographer returned from a hydrographic survey.

Applause of staid theatre-goers greeted a score of juvenile actors and actresses yesterday in the John Golden Theatre at the twenty-second annual commencement exercises of the Professional Children's School.

PHILADELPHIA, May 27. -- Frank H. Davis, vice president of the Penn Mutual Life Insurance Company, was found dead of carbon monoxide gas poisoning today in the garage of his home in Merion. The doors were closed and the body, discovered by Hammit Brideforth, a houseman, was slumped on the floor.
LeRoy Haynes beat Primo Carnera at Ebbets Field last night, beat him so badly that he induced a state of temporary paralysis in the former heavyweight champion's left leg.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP). -Nine rural resettlement projects have been "financially unsuccessful," Rexford G. Tugwell, Resettlement Administrator, stated in testimony at hearings, made public tonight, on the Relief Bill.

WASHTINGTON, May 27. -- Five hours of debate on the Chain Store Bill designed to prevent price discrimination by manufacturers was concluded in the House late today, putting the measure in the amending stage. Leaders hoped to obtain a vote before adjournment tomorrow.
CAMP NO. 3, MOUNT EVEREST, Tibet, May 27 (By Wireless Via Calcutta). -- For the better part of a week weather conditions have been extremely baffling.

Morris E. Leeds, president of the Leeds Northrup Company, Philadelphia, will be awarded the Henry Laurence Gantt gold medal for "distinguished achievement in industrial management as a service to the community," it was announced yesterday by Alvin E. Dodd, executive vice president of the American Management Association.

The board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange approved yesterday the listing of securities of nine issuers, including shares of the Dixie-Vortex Company heretofore traded on the Chicago Stock Exchange. The governors also received from the committee on stock list the applications of five other companies already approved by the latter group.

Father Charles E. Coughlin, head of the National Union for Social Justice, said last night in a telephone interview with THE NEW YORK TIMES, from his homo in Royal Oak, Mich., that he would not support Governor Alf M. Landon of Kansas if the latter was the Republican nominee for President.

Two men were arrested in Boston last night in connection with the strangling and robbing on May 14 of Edgar L. Eckert, 54 years old, of 3,307 Bainbridge Avenue, the Bronx, assistant treasurer and director of the Rogers Peet Company, in the Forty-second Street Station of the Independent Subway.
FITCHBURG, Mass., May 27 (AP). -- Harold (Jug) McSpaden, former Kansas City professional, won the Massachusetts open golf title with a 71, 75 finish today at Oak Hill.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

JACKSON, Mich., May 27 (AP). -- Harley Smith, who told a grand jury that he was forced to join the Black Legion and was flogged Nov. 5 for refusing to attend another meeting, disclosed today how he was lashed by the legion members.

BELGRADE, May 28. -- Foreign Minister Joseph Beck of Poland left Belgrade tonight after a long conversation with Premier Stoyadinovitch. His departure was followed by the issuance of a communique that said the meeting of the two statesmen had resulted in a complete understanding concerning the foreign policies of Poland and Yugoslavia.

LONDON, May 28.--"Grievous disappointment" that "no Christian voice was heard in Italy to remonstrate against the use of barbarous poison gas" against the Ethiopians was voiced yesterday by the Most Rev. Cosmo G. Lang, Archbishop of Canterbury.

PARIS, May 28. -- The swiftly growing forces of the striking employes in France accepted a proposal today to meet with factory owners tomorrow afternoon to formulate a "specific accord." Preliminary conferences between strikers and their representatives are to be held tomorrow morning, when union officials will give reports to the workers.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- Five corporations filed applications today under the Securities Act of 1933 for the issuance of securities. The largest registration covered $12,000,000 of fifteen-year 3 1/2 per cent sinking fund debentures due June 1, 1951, by the Crane Company of Chicago.

The excessive rainfall in Texas has offset the relief from drought in certain areas west of the Mississippi River as a market influence and prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday gained 2 to 8 points. While the demand for July contracts continued to hold the near month a cent or more over new crop deliveries, less selling pressure appeared in the market generally and most months closed at the top.
JERUSALEM, May 28. -- The official list of fatalities since the beginning of the Palestine disturbances in April totaled forty-eight yesterday, but it was increased by fresh clashes today.
