I attended a motion-picture theatre the other evening at which an appeal for funds for the Will Rogers Memorial Hospital was made. Pictures of Mr. Rogers were shown and Lowell Thomas spoke. The presentation of the appeal was most moving and resulted in generous contributions.
BERLIN, May 28. -- The Boerse was mixed in prices today, with signs of firmness, although the turnover remained relatively limited.

Alfred P. Sloan Jr. refers to "the philosophy of scarcity" as opposed, one assumes, to the philosophy of plenty and expansion. But does not our national economy rest, not upon scarcity or plenty as such, but rather upon profitable operation as such? To omit so simple a fact threatens us with the spell of nice-sounding phrases, to which business itself pays scant heed.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 28 (AP). -- The fastest field in history will start the 500-mile automobile race Saturday. This was assured today with completion of qualifying trials when the thirty-third position in the classic was won by Emil Andres of Chicago at an average speed of 111.455 miles per hour.

SENECA FALLS, N. Y., May 28. -- Amelia Bloomer, pioneer feminist, who devised and publicized the "daring" article of feminine attire which became famous under her name, was recalled by elderly residents of this village today on the 117th anniversary of her birth.

DALLAS, May 28.--Mounting governmental expenditures and administration polices thought likely to restrict private enterprise or retard realty recovery were criticized in resolutions adopted at closing sessions of the annual convention of the National Association of Building Owners and Managers today.

Vigorously opposing the manufacturers' 10 per cent excise levy on cosmetics, members of the Toilet Goods Association, at the closing session yesterday of their annual convention at the Hotel Biltmore, adopted a resolution calling upon the two major political parties to include in their platforms planks demanding the repeal of all "nuisance taxes."

BERLIN, May 28. -- The Reichsbank appears to be getting seriously short of foreign exchange. To date it has been possible for German citizens to send abroad ten marks every month. A ruling issued today suppressed this privilege.

Representatives of several branches of the women's apparel industry testified yesterday in behalf of the program of the Fashion Originators Guild of America to prevent "style piracy" which they termed one of the factors undermining that industry.

John Fiorenza, upholsterer's apprentice who strangled Mrs. Nancy Evans Titterton in her home at 22 Beekman Place on the morning of Good Friday, was found guilty in General Sessions Court yesterday of first-degree murder. The death sentence will be pronounced a week from today by Judge Charles C. Nott Jr.

Led by a gain in shoe turnover, chain store sales in this district in April rose 5.3 per cent over the same month of 1935, a larger percentage increase than in March, according to figures issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
LONDON, l@fay 28 (TPl. -- The weekly statement of the Bank of Eng- land shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

Harris, Upham Co., member of the Stock Exchange; Harris, Winthrop Co., its predecessor firm, and twenty-one defendants, formerly partners or agents of the latter company, were named defendants yesterday in a suit for $250,000 brought in Federal court by Frederick J. Ward of Detroit.

Ruddy-cheeked and completely recovered from his illness of recent months, Charles M. Schwab, chairman of the board of Bethlehem Steel, returned from Bad Nauheim yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen. Optimistic as always, the steel magnate said on the liner that his six-week rest in the German watering place and talks with European industrialists had given him an even rosier outlook than usual.

MADISON, N.J., May 28. -- Upsets marked the first two rounds of match play in the New Jersey State amateur golf championship at the Braidburn Country Club today. John E. Parker Jr., metropolitan amateur titleholder, and Frank Giessen of Branch Brook, two of the three who tied for the qualifying medal yesterday with sub-par 72s, first-round victims.

Any ill-advised action affecting the steel industry would work an injury not only to the 457,000 workers in this $5,000,000,000 industry but would hurt the 552,000 thrifty stockholders and their dependents whose savings are involved, was the warning sounded by Myron C. Taylor, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, last night.

The following film programs, which will be shown over the weekend, have been endorsed by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization of faculty members and parents of children in public and private schools:

Superintendent S. Meredith Strong Jr. of the Queens Highway Bureau has notified John S. Laughlin, borough engineer of the Works Progress Administration in charge of Queens, that the paving job nearly finished by the WPA on Jamaica Avenue, between 168th and 225th Streets, Queens, at a cost of more than $500,000 is so poor that the city cannot accept the improvement as a paved thoroughfare, it was learned yesterday.

The Democratic campaign headquarters in the drive for the reelection of President Roosevelt will be in New York City and not in Washington, it became known yesterday. The set-up that is planned is almost identical with the one that functioned so well and with such absence of friction in 1932 party leaders said.

The Twentieth Century Sporting Club, of which Mike Jacobs is the guiding genius and Joe Louis is the star attraction, yesterday acquired a permanent home. Jacobs announced that he had taken a lease on the Hippodrome, which he will convert into an indoor arena, where he plans to promote amateur and professional sports attractions.

A tendency toward reduction of management fees will be the subject of discussion at a meeting to be called soon by the owners division of the Real Estate Board of New York. The division will consider whether the rates which the board now recommends are proper rates, and if these recommended rates should be established as official rates.

DUBLIN, May 28. -- Speaking in the Dail Eireann for the first time since his return from Switzerland, Eamon de Valera, President of the Executive Council, rose this evening to pronounce a sentence of death upon the Senate when he moved the passage of the Abolition Bill. His motion carried, 74 to 52.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 28. -- Polo's most famous field, the big international enclosure on which some of the greatest stars of the world have ridden, today was opened for play during the regular Thursday evening program at the Meadowbrook Club with a practice match among players preparing for the opening of the Meadowbrook's twenty-goal tournaments which start the week-end of June 6.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- Denying charges attributed to Philip J. Roosevelt of New York that the Reconstruction Finance Corporation had closed its doors against any plan for reorganization of the Minneapolis St. Louis Railroad except that offered by the Associated Railroads Company.

Officers of the steel companies attending the forty-fifth general meeting of the American Iron and Steel Institute in the Waldorf-Astoria reported yesterday that the outlook for the industry was better than at any previous time in six years.
LONDON, May 28. -- The coronation of King Edward VIII in Westminster Abbey Wednesday, May 12, 1937, was announced in tonight's London Gazette.

PARIS, May 28. -- Four Frenchmen, a German and a Swiss marched into the quarter-final round of the French hard court tennis championships today, catching up with Great Britain's Davis Cup aces, Fred Perry and H.W. (Bunny) Austin, who had been a step ahead of the field.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 28. -- Firm opposition to new taxes unless they assure the lightening of the burden on real estate was expressed today by the New Jersey Building and Loan League at its twenty-eighth annual convention in Chalfonte-Haddon Hall, here.

The Citizens Budget Commission urged Governor Lehman yesterday to veto bills which would add $37, 075,000 to the city's annual expenditures. The Teachers Union at the same time asked Mayor La Guardia to request the Governor to sign the Feld-Crews bill restoring city pay to the 1932 levels.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- Senator Borah warned the Republican party in a radio address tonight that it must not permit the Hilles-Roraback group and powerful corporate and financial interests to control the convention, select the Presidential nominee and shape the party platform.

NOROTON, Conn., May 28. -- In memory of the late John Golden, Ryder Cup player and Connecticut open champion, members of the National and Metropolitan Professional Golfers Associations staged a tourney today over the Wee Burn links, at which club Golden had served as professional.

PITTSBURGH, May 28. -- Further strength of business activity in the Pittsburgh district was shown by the reports for last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. The general index of business activity adjusted for seasonal variation and for trend stood at 89.3.

"By the way, where are the Colonies?" a famous English statesman is said to have asked at a meeting of the Cabinet. The anecdote may be apocryphal, but a hundred years ago there was scanty interest in the Colonies in Great Britain. It was even proposed that they should be given up.
DETROIT, May 28. -- A routine police investigation of a supposed gang slaying unmasked the hooded and robed Black Legion whose night riding terrorism brought official scrutiny in several States.

While trading in the wool goods markets was fairly active this week, deliveries continued to run ahead of new business, which is a normal condition for this time of year, according to the report issued yesterday by the New York Wool Top Exchange Service.
ABOARD THE QUEEN MARY, May 28. -- Passengers on the Queen Mary, still uninformed as to whether a speed trial was in progress, reported vibrations of metal furniture in the aft sections tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- The House voted, 271 to 41, today to cite Dr. Francis E. Townsend and two of his aides, the Rev. Dr. Clinton L. Wunder of New York and John B. Kiefer of Chicago, for contempt because of their defiance of the special House committee investigating the Townsend old-age pension plan.

New reduced rates for telephone calls from all parts of the United States to Hawaii, the Philippines, Colombia and the Dominican Republic will become effective July 1, according to a schedule filed yesterday with the Federal Communications Commission.

LONDON, May 28. -- The friendly and pacific attitude assumed by Premier Benito Mussolini in the interview he has granted to British journalists in Rome during the past few days carried even further officially today. For the first time since the Italians' entry into Addis Ababa, Ambassador Dino Grandi made a formal call at the Foreign Office and had a talk with Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden.

TIENTSIN, China, May 28 (AP). -- Officers of Japan's enlarged military garrison quickly demanded tonight that Chinese authorities stamp out a strike by thousands of students, who called upon China to "rise against the Japanese invasion."

SYRACUSE, May 28. -- C.N. Wonocott of New York City, treasurer of the Presbyterian Board of National Missions, told the church General Assembly today that "the New Deal dangers to the earnings of our invested funds have begun to reflect themselves in reduced income."

An automobile accident at Lenox Avenue and 133d Street that resulted in the death of a 63-year-old Negro threatened for a few minutes last night to result in a riot as more than 500 Negroes attempted to seize the driver of the car, a white man.

Mrs. Mildred Balitzer took the stand yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook and a jury to testify to conversations she had with Charles (Lucky Luciano) Lucania about vice ring operations he is alleged to have directed.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- A desire of several Latin-American governments to await the outcome of the Presidential election in this country before entering the Inter-American Conference at Buenos Aires for considering means of consolidating peace in the Western Hemisphere has been a controlling reason for postponement of the conference until at least December.

CHICAGO, May 28. -- Measured by the improvement shown by companies whose shares are listed on the Chicago Stock Exchange, business in the Middle West is making definite progress toward recovery, Michael J. O'Brien, president of the Exchange, said tonight in his annual report.
MADRID, May 28. -- An uproar took place in a Madrid court today during the trial of Jose Primo de Rivera, leader of the Fascist party, who was sentenced to five more months' imprisonment.

TROY, N.Y., May 28 (AP). -- Mrs. William D. Thomas of Hoosick Falls announced today that she would be a candidate for the Republican nomination to succeed her late husband, Representative Thomas of the Twenty-ninth Congressional District who died last week in Washington.

In her letter to THE TIMES Miss Mann arises to the defense of Mr. Farley against what she deems the prevailing unjust criticism of him, but I think she misses entirely the true significance and basis of that criticism.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., May 28. -- Several thousand men and women whose lives have been "changed to God-control," or who approach the possibility of such change, are assembling here and at Lenox and Great Barrington for the opening tomorrow of a national assembly of the Oxford Group, otherwise known as the First Century Christian Fellowship, under the leadership of its founder, Dr. Frank N.D. Buchman.

With its June borrowing the Treasury Department will undertake the largest peacetime financing operation in the country's history. A total of $2,050,000,000 will be offered in new securities. About half of the amount thus raised will be used to refund two issues of outstanding notes maturing on June 15 and Aug. 1.

JERUSALEM, May 28. -- At least five deaths marked renewed clashes in Palestine today. The government was seriously considering imposing martial law in the most troublesome centers and was planning an aerial bombardment of villages in the Nablus mountains unless disorders there subsided.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- Senator Borah's final important pre-convention utterance -- his radio speech tonight -- turned out to be a sort of military bridge. He can advance over it to new political ground and burn it behind him. He can use it for a safe retreat to the bridgehead where he entered. He can sit in the middle of it and refuse to have anything to do with the forces on either bank.

A lot of misery from an unexpected quarter descended on the Giants at the Polo Grounds yesterday when, in an unguarded moment, Bill McKechnie was permitted to turn his Bees of Boston loose in the arena for the season's first double-header on the Harlem.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

Legal action was taken yesterday to protect the old established law firm of Choate, Larocque and Mitchell, 41 Broad Street, against complications growing out of the allegedly unauthorized issuance of notes against the firm's credit.
NEW HOPE, Pa., May 28. -- An airplane chartered by two students at the Solebury School for Boys, near here, crashed from a low altitude today, seriously injuring both occupants.

Robert Comin, principal of Junior High School 149, Brooklyn, was elected president of the Joint Committee of Teachers Organizations, succeeding Arthur Bowie, at a meeting yesterday in the headquarters, 130 West Forty-second Street. The group also voted to abolish its old method of organization and adopt proportional representation.

The Hamburg-American liner Hamburg, arriving today from Hamburg and the channel ports, has on board thirty Christian Scientists who are en route to Boston to visit the home of the Mother Church. The ship's list includes:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 28 -- Trustees of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad insisted today in the Federal court in a hearing before Judge Carroll C. Hincks that they were unwilling that the trustees of the New York, Westchester Boston Railway Company should continue to use their property, alleging that its use under present conditions was an injustice to the holders of securities of the New Haven system.

Graduation exercises of the Horace Mann School for Girls will be held tonight at 8:30 o'clock in the school auditorium, 120th Street and Broadway. Dean William F. Russell of Teachers College, Columbia University, will preside, and Dr. Rollo G. Reynolds, principal of the school, will present diplomas to thirty-six students.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- By a standing vote of 290 to 16, the House today passed the Robinson-Patman anti-chain-store bill and sent it back to the Senate for a conference on the disagreements. An early agreement is expected.

PARIS, May 28. -- Strikes that began two days ago in suburban motor factories spread today to an extent that gives the movement considerable importance. The factories involved are mostly automobile or aviation plants, but since most of them also manufacture armaments particular concern is being shown in government circles.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., May 28 (AP). -- Package, a 3-year-old bay gelding, owned by Aaron Kayfetz and trained by N.L. Byer, won the feature race today at Agawam Park.

Declaring that the dire prophecies so frequently heard during the last three years never became actualities. C.L. London, vice president of J.M. Mathes, Inc., advertising agency, yesterday told members of the Rotary Club at their weekly luncheon at the Hotel Commodore that the future of this country is "extravagantly fine."

Details of the plan of the Manufacturers Trust Company for retiring its $50,000,000 of capital notes held by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, through an offering of preferred stock to common shareholders will provide that only holders of 333 shares or fewer of the common stock may avail themselves of the offer of the RFC to finance them in the installment purchase of preferred shares, it was learned yesterday.

Parker McCollester, special counsel for the Long Island Railroad, said yesterday the railroad would demand a court order before it would reduce its intrastate fares from 3 to 2 cents a mile. The Public Service Commission began an investigation into the railroad's within-the-State rates on Wednesday.

CHICAGO, May 28. -- Hogs met with a broad demand here today despite fairly liberal supplies. Prices were steady to 10 cents a hundredweight higher, the best level being paid early. The top price was 10 cents higher than yesterday at $10.10, while the day's average was 5 cents higher at $9.65.

MOSCOW, May 28. -- Drawing his eleventh-round game with Salo Flohr of Czechoslovakia in 24 moves, Jose R. Capablanca of Cuba remained undefeated in the international chess masters tournament at the House of Unions today and remained in the lead with a total score of 8 -- 3 to his credit.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 28. -- The action of the Republican Assembly in New York State in defeating the Social Security Act was a piece of political folly that insures the election of a Democratic Governor next Fall, Mgr. Robert F. Keegan, president of the National Conference of Social Work, said here tonight.

CAMDEN, N.J., May 28. -- John Bonitatibus, railroad crossing watchman, arrived at his modest two-story red brick row house after work this evening to find himself' the hero of the 200 neighborhood children who play on the vacant lot next door.
Macmillan will publish John Masefield's new book "A Letter from Pontus, and Other Verse" on June 16.

TRENTON, May 28. -- Tentative drafts of the Republican and Democratic platforms, made public today subject to ratification by the State conventions next Tuesday, put the former party on record for "replacement" taxes to aid municipalities in financing emergency relief, and the latter for no "new" taxes.
At midnight last night, New York time, the Radiomarine Corporation reported that it had been in contact with the Queen Mary but that her exact position and her speed at that time were not known.

The Utilities Power and Light Corporation reported yesterday a consolidated net loss of $1,889,844 in 1935, against a net loss of $2,230,577 in 1934. The income statement for 1935 excludes the operations of two minor subsidiaries in the United States, but includes a dividend paid by one of them.

SYRACUSE, May 28. -- The Rev. Dr. Henry Buck Master of Philadelphia, general secretary of the Presbyterian Board of Pensions, was elected this afternoon Moderator of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- Industry re-employed 726,000 laborers during April and the number of unemployed in the nation declined from 12,183,000 in March to 11,506,000 in April, William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, reported today.

PEIPING, China, May 28. -- Mystery surrounds the identity of the attacker of a Japanese soldier named Kisaku Sasaki, who died today as a result of embroilment in a fight Tuesday night in one of Peiping's main streets.
BOSTON, May 28. -- The Yanks headed for home two and one-half games in front in the American League pennant scramble thanks to a complete collapse of the Red Sox at Fenway Park today.

It has visibly been springing in the Republican breast. An unmistakable quickening of Republican courage has been under way for the past few weeks. A good deal has been done to overcome the defeatist attitude into which the party had seemed to have fallen. This has not gone so far as to predict that Mr. ROOSEVELT will be beaten. But there are now confident assertions that he can be beaten.

CLEVELAND, May 28 (AP). -- The reconstructed hall in which the Republican National Convention will be held, beginning June 9, holds about 15,000 persons, but Ralph Williams of Oregon, vice chairman of the party's national committee, said today that already 100,000 applications for seats had been received.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- A method by which the small corporation may devote its earnings to company expansion and still escape the proposed high taxes on undistributed profits was commented upon today at the Treasury Department.
CALLANDER, Ont., May 27. -- A. fortune of $250,000 spot cash for a movie contract was dumped into the laps of the five little Sisters Dionne today when they achieved the age of two.

CLEVELAND, May 28. -- By unanimous vote, 500 shouting delegates to the biennial convention of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers today rejected the American Federation of Labor's ultimatum to disband the Committee for Industrial Organization, formed in November by eight unions to further the industrial form of organization in the mass-production industries.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP). -- Certain provisions of the Senate-approved bill to strengthen the Federal Trade Commission's powers in regulating business practices were scored today before the House Interstate Commerce Committee by spokesmen of newspaper publishers and manufacturers.

HEWLETT HARBOR, L.I., May 28. -- Misjudgment of her clubs on the last few holes induced by fear of the wind blowing across the Seawane Club course plus the courageous play of her opponent today cost Mrs. Jonathan Thorne her chance to retain the metropolitan golf title.

A piece of cake, it was disclosed yesterday, led to the arrest of three men in connection with the slaying of Edgar L. Eckert, 54-year-old assistant treasurer and director of the Rogers Peet Company, retail clothiers. He was strangled in the Eighth Avenue subway station at Forty-second Street on May 14.
The excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose $40,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to $2,900,000,000, according to the weekly report of the Reserve published yesterday.

OSSINING, N. Y., May 28. -- Four young men, convicted of a murder during a hold-up in a Brooklyn saloon two years ago, were put to death tonight in the electric chair at Sing Sing prison. It was the third time in sixteen years that the sentence of death has been executed on as many as four men at a time in this State.

The Equitable Office Building Corporation declared yesterday a dividend of 10 cents a share, the first since July 2, 1934. Le Roy W. Baldwin, chairman, said that in the opinion of the board the payment was justified by the current position of the company.

In a shift to strengthen Manhattan's varsity crew for its race with Rollins College of Winter Park, Fla., on the Harlem River Sunday afternoon, Coach Allen Walz yesterday drafted two freshman oarsmen for service. Robert McManus, erstwhile stroke of the cub eight, and James Kelly were moved into the bow and No. 2 positions, respectively, and functioned well in these places during a long workout.

Faced by the task of distributing bonus money to nearly a quarter of a million veterans of the World War on June 15, Postmaster Albert Goldman of New York and sixty-four other postmasters in the metropolitan area met yesterday at the General Postoffice, Eighth Avenue and Thirty-third Street, to expedite the work.

Races for the intercollegiate yachting championship will be held by the Pleon Yacht Club of Marblehead, Mass., on June 10 and 11. The dates were set yesterday. The Pleon Club is a leading junior racing organization, and observes its fiftieth anniversary this Summer.
ALBANY, May 28. -- Paper containers for milk were put on a parity with glass bottles in the metropolitan area today by Agriculture Commissioner Peter G. Ten Eyck.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, May 28. -- Robert Sweeny, sole surviving American, was eliminated from the British amateur golf championship today in a 21-hole sixth-round match with the Australian champion, James Ferrier.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- Wholesale prices advanced slightly in the week ended on May 23, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The index rose to 78.2, based on 1926 as 100, compared with 78.1 the preceding week and 80.3 the year before.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- The "chaotic" condition of the coal industry was cited today by the House Ways and Means Committee in making a favorable report on the new Guffey Coal Bill, substantially re-enacting the bill invalidated by the Supreme Court except for the overruled labor provisions.

The Charter Revision Commission, it became known yesterday, is giving serious consideration to a change in the voting strength of the boroughs in the Board of Estimate to give greater recognition to the increases in population in Queens and the Bronx.

A season of open-air grand opera will be presented by Fortune Gallo at Jones Beach this Summer by arrangement with the Long Island State Park Commission, it was announced yesterday. The season will begin on June 27 with a performance of "Carmen."
LONDON, May 28. -- Renewed apprehensions that British financiers are lending money to Germany that is being used for German rearmament found expression at question time in the House of Commons today.

GENEVA, May 28. -- In a letter accompanying its annual memorandum, the Jewish Agency for Palestine appeals to the British Government to make the Jewish national home immune from further attack by actively encouraging Jewish settlement.

Announcement by the Securities and Exchange Commission of the creation of a new division whose duty it will be to weed out of the unlisted departments of the stock exchanges, securities which, because of inactivity or other reasons, might better be traded exclusively over the counter, aroused considerable interest in brokerage houses yesterday.

Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts, filed with the Board of Aldermen yesterday a report saying that the prominent architectural firm of Sloan Robertson, 420 Lexington Avenue, had made excessive profits due to political patronage.
PARIS, May 28 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

A complete investigation by Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts, of the financial accounts and the activties of every plainclothes patrolman assigned to duty at police headquarters was asked yesterday by Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine.

GIBRALTAR, May 28. -- The British naval authorities and the Military Governor of Gibraltar, General Sir C.H. Harrington, will receive Haile Selassie I of Ethiopia as an honored guest but not as an Emperor when he arrives here early tomorrow morning aboard the British cruiser Capetown.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended May 27, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,474,000,000, a decrease of $7,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $1,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1935.

The approach of Memorial Day, which will be celebrated tomorrow throughout the city with parades and other ceremonies honoring the military dead, was reflected yesterday in increased activities at the city's terminals of transportation by land, water and air.

The gold-bloc currencies weakened further yesterday under an increased pressure of flight of capital and the discount on future contracts in these exchanges widened. Additional gold engagements of $10,929,000 abroad were announced by the Federal Reserve Bank here, $8,680,000 of the amount being taken in Paris and $2,249,000 in Mexico.

BERLIN, May 28. -- In a speech before the German Domestic Shipping Congress, being held in Duisburg, Baron von Reubenach, Transportation Minister, expressed great satisfaction with the recent revision of the Versailles provisions on government Rhine shipping.
CHUNGKING, Szechwan Province, China, May 28 (AP). -- Dispatches from the Tibetan border reported today 500 Buddhist priests had been slain by Communist troops invading Hsikang Province.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- Senator Byrd told the Senate today that the Federal Government would spend $600,000,000 more for ordinary expenses and relief during the coming fiscal year, than will be spent this year. His statement came during consideration of the Deficiency Appropriation Bill containing $1,425,000,000 for continuation of work relief.

The old fellows of the Forest Park Pinochle Club who have been dealing hands in a shaded glen of Forest Park, Queens, for the last ten years, received assurance yesterday that in future park officials would recognize the recreational desires of age as well as of youth.
CHICAGO, May 28 (AP). -- In a game spiced by a free-for-all brawl at home plate that resulted in four players and coaches being banished from the field, the Cubs defeated the Reds, 11 to 5, today.

Establishment of a permanent committee to promote advertising standards and to judge advertising every week in their field was suggested yesterday by Edgar Kobak, vice president of Lord Thomas and chairman of the Advertising Federation of America, to members of the Toilet Goods Association in convention at the Hotel Biltmore.

Retail package deliveries in the metropolitan and suburban areas rose 22 per cent for the week ended May 23, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. The increase is the largest for any weekly period this year, with the exception of Easter week when a gain of 28 per cent in packages handled was reported.

GENEVA, May 28. -- Japan's "laxity" toward narcotic traffickers in China was denounced as "an unfriendly act toward the nations of the North American Continent" today by Stuart J. Fuller of the State Department before the League of Nations Opium Advisory Commission.

The dissolution of three firms holding membership in the New York Stock Exchange and the formation of two new ones were announced yesterday by the Exchange. Partnerships which are being dissolved are Barry Hughes, Frank Doyle Co. and C.H. Murphey Co.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 28 (AP). -- State Senator John Davis of Cleveland, fighting vainly for a searching legislative inquiry of the Black Legion, charged today that four thugs had intimidated a woman State employe possessing important information concerning the organization's activities.

The most conspicuous price changes in bond trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange were toward lower levels. Without any widespread selling pressure, both the gilt-edge and secondary corporate loans found it easier to drift slightly lower on a moderate turnover.

J.A. Brown, president of the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday that earnings this year have been about $7,000,000 better than in the corresponding period of 1935. For all of 1935 the company had reported net income of $22,525,892 after charges, taxes and reserves, or 72 cents a share on the 31,151,075 capital shares.
WASHINGTON, May 28. -- The text of the radio address made by Senator Borah here tonight was as follows:

SYRACUSE, May 28 (AP). -- Several hundred strikers quietly picketed the Remington-Rand Company's Syracuse plant tonight, refusing to return to work when the plant was reopened after a shutdown caused by labor difficulties.

With the approach of the holidays here and abroad, the share market quieted yesterday. The closing was fractionally lower, with a handful of issues off a point or more. Trading on the Stock Exchange amounted to but 762,000 shares, against 1,219,000 the day before.

The American Federation of Labor estimates that 726,000 men and women went back to work in the single month of April. If this estimate is correct, it is one of the three greatest monthly decreases in unemployment of the whole recovery period. The other two, according to the federation's estimates, occurred in June and August of 1933.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- In a desperate attempt to save their plan for adjournment of Congress by June 6, Democratic leaders decided today to rush the Finance Committee's compromise revenue bill to the Senate floor, despite the objections of President Roosevelt to its failure to meet demands for revenue and corporate tax reform outlined by him in his message of March 3.
LENOX, Mass., May 28. -- Mrs. Charles Lewis Slattery of Boston gave a luncheon today for the Oxford house party at Curtis Hotel, Lenox, where she is staying.

Settlements through the banks tend lower but continue above the 1935 aggregate, according to figures covering the twenty-two leading cities throughout the country for the week ended on Wednesday. Dun Bradstreet, Inc., set the total of clearings at $4,725,152,000, against $4,689,790,000 for the corresponding week last year.

ABOARD THE QUEEN MARY, En Route to New York, May 28. -- At noon today the Queen Mary had completed 326 miles of her course in fair weather and a moderate sea at an average speed of 28.73 knots. She had left Cherbourg at 12:32 this morning, ship's time.

Directors of Commercial Credit Corporation, a financing company, increased the regular dividend rate on the common stock yesterday, declared a 20 per cent stock dividend and voted a 5 per cent bonus to employes.

TOKYO, Friday, May 29. -- The Tariff Commission Secretariat has prepared plans to limit exports from Australia by licensing wheat and wool and putting high tariffs on Australian beef, butter and hides. The new system is expected to start June 10.

PHILADELPHIA, May 28. -- In cold, windy weather today the Davis Cup teams of Australia and the United States went through their last intensive practice before their meeting on Saturday, Sunday and Monday at the Germantown Cricket Club.
Apartment rentals reported in the city yesterday included leases of several large suites in houses on Park Avenue. The renting also extended to properties on Fifth Avenue and flats on the West Side.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- Betti C. Goldwasser of New York and Louise W. Holborn of Hamden, Conn., graduate students at Radcliffe College, are among fourteen to whom fellowships have been granted by the Brookings Institution for advanced study in the social sciences during the coming year.
The formal business of clinching its new minimum basic agreement with the Dramatists Guild was completed yesterday by the League of New York Theatres.

John Henry Lewis, light-heavyweight champion of the world, will square off against Bob Godwin, Southern heavyweight, tonight in a scheduled ten-round bout that tops an interesting card at Madison Square Garden. It is a non-title fight and Lewis is strong favorite.

BARNEGAT, N.J., May 28. -- A man and his wife were killed instantly, the man's mother was critically injured and three other persons also were hurt when an automobile and a crowded school bus were in collision on Route 4 a mile south of here about 4:30 o'clock this afternoon.

PHILADELPHIA, May 28. -- While fewer than 1,000 shivering fans viewed the proceedings with considerable amazement but no admiration the Dodgers and Phillies played ball for 2 hours and 48 minutes today.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 28. -- Cornell University graduated fifty-one from its law school today, as the class, receiving Bachelor of Law degrees from President Livingston Farrand, was adjured to "harden your hearts with hope."

Arthur G. Homeyer, a former examiner in the United States Appraisers Stores, was convicted yesterday by a jury in Federal court of a customs fraud which was alleged to have deprived the government of more than $1,000,000 import duties between 1927 and 1934.

The steel industry vigorously protested yesterday against political bureaucratic control of the country's economic life and excessive taxation which its spokesmen declared must be borne eventually by the workers and consumers.
ST. LOUIS, May 28 (AP). -- Big Jim Weaver held the Cardinals to four hits today and the Pirates tied the series by making it two straight over the league leaders, 7 to 2.

Higher prices for livestock and meats were responsible for a further moderate rise in The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices to 120.6 on Tuesday from 120.0 the Tuesday previous. The index is, however, 4.1 points below the level of a year ago, due primarily to lower quotations for farm and food products.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 28. -- With the completion today of the competitive infantry drill, which occupied the first four days of the week, the fifth company of the regiment of midshipmen, commanded by John P. Preston of Los Angeles, was declared winner of the contest among the eight companies.

Edwin F. Jaeckle, Erie County leader, sent a telegram from Buffalo last night to State Chairman Melvin C. Eaton protesting against the holding of a secret meeting of Republican leaders here today which he contended would pave the way for the re-election at the national convention of Charles D. Hilles as national committeeman for New York State.
A 400-room housing operation will be started in the Bronx as the result of the sale yesterday of a large plot on Bronx Park East, about 261 feet south of Pelham Parkway South, to builders.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings and the ratio of reserve for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date.
DETROIT, May 28 (AP). -- The White Sox drove Vic Sorrell from the box in the ninth inning today and then pounded two other Detroit pitchers to score a 6-5 victory over the Tigers.
Variety marked the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday, the properties including both residential and commercial parcels.

NATURE may be wonderful, but the effect of environment should not be overlooked. If they staged Ibsen's "Ghosts" at Ebbets Field it probably would appear in Flatbush trimmings as a delightful comedy that would send the audience rolling in the aisles. The Brooklyn ball players have been inhabiting the place for so many years that the native hilarious atmosphere is contagious and infectious.

Busts of William Penn and Simon Newcomb, two great Americans of foreign origin, were unveiled yesterday at the Hall of Fame on the University Heights campus of New York University. The exercises were preceded by an academic procession from the Elmer Ellsworth Brown House for English Studies to the auditorium of the Gould Memorial Library, where Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, chancellor of the university, presided at ceremonies before the unveiling.
PRAGUE, May 28. -- Foreign Minister Kamil Krofta told Parliament's Foreign Affairs Commission today:
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 28. -- Twenty-two appointments to the Harvard University faculty for the next academic year are announced. They are:

Indefinite continuance of the Federal Home Owners Loan Corporation will have a disastrous effect upon both lenders and borrowers in the field of building finance, Le-Grand W. Pellett, president of the United States Building and Loan League, said last night at a dinner of the Metropolitan League of Savings and Loans in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- President Roosevelt devoted the day to routine business, including the nomination of Lloyd J. Porter to be examiner-in-chief of the United States Patent Office and Henry Van Arsdale to be Assistant Commissioner of Patents.

Commencement exercises of the Institute of Musical Art of the Juilliard School of Music will be held at 8:30 o'clock this evening in the concert hall of the school, 130 Claremont Avenue. Roy Dickinson Welch, Professor of Music at Princeton University, will be the principal speaker.

Prices of commodity futures were generally higher yesterday in slightly heavier trading. In the cash market, wheat, rye, cocoa, cotton, butter and eggs were higher, while corn, silk, tin and wool tops were lower.

LONDON, May 28. -- The London Stock Exchange retained today the brighter tone shown yesterday, although business did not show any expansion owing to the holiday atmosphere. British funds recovered further on the belief that a halt would be called to State and municipal borrowing.
ATLANTA, May 28. -- The Tennessee Valley Authority's right to sell and distribute electric power in Georgia was upheld today by Judge Samuel H. Sibley of the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals.

PHILADELPHIA, May 28. -- Athletes from Eastern universities, with Michigan State as the only Western team representative, start the trials in the sixtieth annual Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. track and field championships on Franklin Field tomorrow afternoon at 1 o'clock.

DEVON, Pa., May 28. -- Iron Man, 9-year-old chestnut gelding, captured the Clarence H. Geist Challenge Trophy for corinthian class hunters at the Devon horse show today, giving the Sifton Stables of Toronto permanent possession of the prize.

In Nazi Germany it is difficult to distinguish between judicial procedure and political propaganda. The opening in Coblenz last Tuesday of the trial of 276 monks and lay associates on a charge of immorality suggests that once more the German courts are being used for National Socialist purposes -- this time to further the party's persistent attacks on the Catholic Church.

CLEVELAND, May 28 (AP). -- The Cleveland Indians vaulted into third place today by a 6-to-5 victory over St. Louis as the Chicago White Sox defeated the Tigers by the same score at Detroit. Two days ago the Indians were fifth.

Massing all their seven hits in their three scoring innings, Fordham University's baseball forces recorded their second success in as many days, turning back Columbia, 9 to 6, in the face of a strong, cool northwest wind at Fordham Field yesterday.
"I have yet to wet a line this year. Where can I find a bit of fresh-water fishing not too far from New York?" asks Arthur Martin of Manhattan.

OTTAWA, May 28 (Canadian Press)-- Deposits with the Bank of Canada by the Dominion Government rose $451,480, and by chartered banks fell $2,822,974 in the week ended yesterday. The weekly statement follows:
NEWARK, May 28.--The Newark Bears lost first place in the International League today when they were defeated, 9 to 2, by Baltimore, while the Buffalo Bisons were kept idle by cold weather.

The National Steel Corporation has sold $10,000,000 of its first collateral mortgage sinking fund bonds, 3 3/4 per cent series, to Kuhn, Loeb Co. and associates, who have placed the entire issue privately. The bonds are dated June 1, 1936, and will be due on June 1, 1965.

ALBANY, May 28. -- Nearly 300 New York City transit employes went to the Executive Chamber today, the majority to urge Governor Lehman to approve the bill of Assemblyman Fitzgerald, Queens Democrat, which is designed to protect them in their jobs in the event of unification of the subways.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., May 28. -- A resolution denouncing the sale of liquor for profit and the profit system in general was adopted today at the opening of the eighty-eighth session of the New York East Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church in the First Methodist Church here.

Jockey Ira Hanford's first triple since his victory in the Kentucky Derby was scored at Belmont Park yesterday when he was home first with Crop, Drawbridge and Masked Gal, the first two in the colors of the Wheatley Stable. The day's feature was the Potomac Handicap, which attracted a field of only three. J.B. Partridge's Prince Abbot was the winner.

DETROIT, May 28. -- Evidence on which Duncan C. McCrea, Wayne County Prosecutor, bases his belief that Federal laws have been violated in the activities of the Black Legion will be submitted to the Department of Justice in his effort to obtain a Federal investigation of complaints of terrorism by members of the secret society in fifteen States.

BERLIN, Nay 28. -- The mass trial at Coblenz of 276 Franciscan monks charged with crimes against young persons committed to their charge has been adjourned until after the Whitsun holidays. It is apparently to be kept before the public for several weeks.

BALTIMORE, May 28. -- Sheridan Downey of California, attorney for Dr. Francis E. Townsend, said today he thought the contempt citation voted by the House would not be tried until after the November elections.

The aggregate net operating income of the first fifty-eight railroads to report for April, including almost all the large Class 1 companies, showed an increase of 21.5 per cent from April, 1935. The following table shows the April results of this group compared with 1935 and 1934, the last three ciphers being omitted from totals:

LONDON, May 28.--William George Arthur Ormsby-Gore, one of the Conservative party's outstanding experts on colonial affairs, was appointed tonight Secretary of State for the Colonies, in succession to J.H. Thomas, who resigned last week over the budget leakage scandal.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

A plea of not guilty to a forgery indictment was entered in General Sessions yesterday by Mrs. Hazel M. Short, 38 years old, a widow, of 53 East Sixty-fifth Street. The indictment was handed up by the grand jury on Wednesday on the complaint of George M. Wallace, a California banker.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 28. -- Twelve annual prize awards were announced today by Yale University as follows:

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, May 28. -- A rebellion led by the National Guard is under way in Nicaragua, Thus far bloodless, the conflict is between President Juan B. Sacasa and General Anastasio Somosa, commander of the National Guard, who is said to have ambitions for the Presidency.

The names of student council and class officers elected for the Fall term were announced yesterday at City College. With the exception of Bernard Shifrin, who was named vice president of the class of '39, undergraduates running on the American Student Union ticket was elected.

There has been so much loose discussion of the little booklet called "Americanism -- What Is It?" issued by the Americanism Committee of New York County, American Legion, that a word as to the reason for its rejection by the American Legion County Committee last night is in order.

TOKYO, May 28. -- Charges of a "sinister press campaign" against Japan in the United States are circulated by the Domei News Agency. It declares that official quarters, which have been paying serious attention to "deliberate misrepresentations of fact" in the British press, are disturbed by similar happenings in the United States.

Emilio J. di Rienzo of Mount Vernon was re-elected president of the alumni association of the School of Architecture of Columbia University at the annual meeting last night in the Men's Faculty Club of the university, 117th Street and Morningside Drive.

An agent of the Department of Justice, testifying at the mail fraud trial of four former officers of the defunct Westchester Title and Trust Company, told a jury and Federal Judge Patterson yesterday that $55,000,000 in whole mortgages issued by the company were in default in taxes, assessments or interest to the extent of $13,000,000.

CHICAGO, May 28. -- Arthur W. Cutten, described by the Department of Justice lawyers as the greatest speculator in the country's history, will probably never operate in the market again because of ill health.

Chester C. Davis, Agricultural Adjustment Administrator, returned yesterday on the liner Washington from a two-month survey of agricultural and marketing conditions in eleven European countries, convinced that the United States Government must continue its aid to the farmer in the solution of his problems.

PARIS, May 28. -- Although final details of the assumption of power by the new government have not yet been officially settled, it seems probable that Leon Blum's Cabinet will not be installed before June 9.

When Borough President LEVY attacks the proposed City Planning Commission he sinks his knife in the heart of the new charter. To this agency the framers of that document look to guide the future development of the city, avoiding the evils of haphazard expansion and contraction which have characterized its growth in the past.

A plea for budgetary appropriations to extend medical service in the public schools was made yesterday by education and health officials at a luncheon in the City Club to mark the tenth anniversary of the health demonstration in the West Side Continuation School.
The real estate market turnover in Manhattan yesterday consisted principally of sales of dwellings and flats in the East and West Side sections. Buyers of some of the houses plan to alter them.

TRENTON, May 28. -- Colonel William H. Kelly, internal revenue collector for North Jersey, appears to be chairman of the Democratic State Committee, "ex officio," "without portfolio" or something. This is because of the Treasury Department's edict against its employes taking an active part in politics.

The new rates to be announced Monday by the Greyhound Lines will be the lowest in the history of motor bus travel and in some cases will drop below 1 1/4 cents a mile, L.H. Ristow, general traffic manager, announced yesterday in Cleveland.

The volume of bankers' acceptances outstanding fell $15,310,000 in April to $343,694,299 as of the end of that month, according to the monthly survey of the American Acceptance Council, published yesterday. This total was $69,678,472 under the volume a year ago and $1,400,000,000 below the record high of Dec. 31, 1929.

NEWARK, N. J., May 28. -- Mrs. Rosa Franks, 26 years old, and her son, Matteo, 3, lost their lives this afternoon in a fire that destroyed their apartment on the top floor of a three-story, six-family, frame building at 457 Broadway here. Another son, Nicholas, 5, escaped.

Miss Hildegarde Graham gave a luncheon yesterday in the Japanese Garden of the Ritz-Carlton for the Misses Elizabeth B. Glover, Anna Butler, Eileen Gillespie, Alice Andre, Jeanie Van Norden, Jane R. Murdoch, Elena L. Villa, Audrey K. Anderton and Abbey Kissel.

ALBANY, May 28. -- Governor Lehman signed today the bill by Assemblyman Pack, Democrat, of the Bronx, continuing the prohibition against the sale of guaranteed mortgage certificates until July 1, 1937.

It is about time that, instead of saying "The administration agrees to spend another billion for this" and "Congress votes another appropriation of a hundred million for that," we consider that it is our own hard-earned money, mulcted in high taxes, which the administration and Congress are blithely. voting away.

Industrial activity advanced sharply in April, although it was still below the high point for the recover period reached in December 1935, according to the monthly survey issued yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board.

Some one in the metropolitan area suggested the other day that the Rockefeller interests want people to rivet their gaze on the nebula in Andromeda so they won't notice the price of gasoline in the United States.

A bid of $3,400,000 was made yesterday by the City Bank Farmers Trust Company in taking over at auction the twelve-story Belnord Apartments on the upper West z Side. The property occupies the block bounded by Broadway, Amsterdam Avenue, Eighty-sixth and Eighty-seventh Streets.

LONDON, May 28. -- The British Navy was severely criticized in the House of Commons today by Admiral Sir Roger Keyes, retired, who returned recently from a visit to the Mediterranean Fleet. What he saw there, he said, convinced him that the United States naval air Force was twice as efficient as the British.

The Federal Government allocated more than $1,000,000 for planning projects in the metropolitan area in the last year as a result of its efforts, the Regional Plan Association's annual report disclosed yesterday. The report was presented by George McAneny, president, at the annual meeting at its offices, 400 Madison Avenue.

Mrs. Madeleine S. Stern, widow of Benjamin Stern, former president of Stern Brothers, left an estate appraised yesterday at $4,505,549 gross and $3,773,515 net, of which she received $2,941,769 under the will of her husband, who died in March, 1933. Mrs. Stern died Sept. 22 of that year.

Publication of forty-nine State editions of the "Retailers Manual of Taxes and Regulations" covering the State and municipal laws affecting retailers was announced yesterday by the Limited Price Variety Stores Association.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- Federal interest in the Detroit Black Legion revelations deepened today as Senator Benson introduced a resolution in the Senate calling for an investigation of that organization and other secret societies by a joint Congressional committee, and Attorney General Cummings asked for further information to establish whether violations of Federal statutes were suspected.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP). -- The Athletics, who had lost all of the five games previously played with the Senators, today won a ten-inning first game of a doubleheader, 4 -- 3, but were shut out in the final engagement, 5 -- 0.

The United States Distributing Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the first quarter of 1936, a consolidated net profit of $35,087 after depreciation, depletion, amortization, interest, Federal taxes and other charges. It equals 35 cents a share on 99,915 shares of $100-par, 7 per cent cumulative preferred stock, excluding 26,384 shares held in the treasury.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 29. -- George G. Ortlip, Overseer of the Poor, said today that a new record had been set in the Atlantic City relief roll.

Winning six of the eleven events and placing men in all, Evander Childs swept to an overwhelming victory in the fourth annual Bronx Public Schools Athletic League track championships at Ohio Field yesterday. The Orange and Black rolled up 79 points to defend the laurels it captured for the first time last year.

In last Saturday's TIMES there was a letter from a reader who commented on Terry McGovern's victories over such fighters as George Dixon and Joe Gans and his defeat by a little streak of lightning, Young Corbett. Do you really think that Terry could have conquered Dixon or Gans when they were in their prime?

Trading in futures on the local commodity markets yesterday was dull, with the tendency slightly easier. Cocoa futures advanced sharply in heavy trading. In the cash markets, wheat, rye, oats, flour and cotton advanced, while cocoa set a new high, and corn, lard, silk and tins declined.

New bond financing this week amounted to $119,748,000, with a resumption of corporate refunding operations on a substantial scale. Last week new bond issues for $57,143,365 were placed on the market, while a year ago this week new offerings amounted to $73,509,500.
The United States Steel Corporation announced yesterday that J. Carlisle MacDonald had become an assistant to Myron C. Taylor, chairman of the board, in respect to public relations.

NEWARK, N.J., May 29. -- Kemp Wicker, Newark southpaw, weakened in the eighth inning of a pitching duel with Frank Pearce, Baltimore right-hander, and the Orioles took the second game of the series today, 6 to 2.

PARIS, May 29. -- Some reaction from the pessimism of the last two days was evident on the Bourse today and prices recovered. The shift was all the more remarkable because the strikes in the Paris district are not over and the Bourse this evening closed for three days, Monday being a holiday.

The first "Pagliacci" in the Spring repertoire of the Metropolitan Popular Season was given last night. The feature of the evening was the Metropolitan debut of Arthur Carron, English dramatic tennor, in the role of Canio.

The Franciscan fathers of the New York Province wish to express their gratitude to THE NEW YORK TIMES, and our admiration for your fair-minded presentation of news, for the excellent manner in which your paper has treated the news of the charges brought against the Franciscan brothers of Waldbreitbach by the Nazi government.

LONDON, May 29. -- The red brick walls of St. James's palace, which for centuries have seen English history in the making, gray Charing Cross, where pigeons circle the whole day long, Temple Bar, where the city gate once was, and the steps of the Royal Exchange, the center of British commercial life, again today were the backgrounds of another of those ceremonies so characteristically British.

After an exceedingly bitter controversy, the American Association of Railroads has ratified the cooperative magazine advertising campaign, proposed by its board of directors. The Western roads, however, through the Western Association of Railway Executives, are not entirely satisfied with the magazine plan and, accordingly, have agreed to assess themselves an amount equal to that which they are contributing to the national drive, for a campaign in newspapers.

On the deep-turfed courts of the Germantown Cricket Club, where the United States lost possession in 1927 of the Davis Cup, which it had held for seven consecutive years, interzone play begins this afternoon between our team and that of Australia for the famous trophy.

CHICAGO, May 29. -- The grain markets on the Board of Trade fluctuated in an erratic manner today with evening up for the double holiday offsetting to a considerable extent the dry and hot weather talk from the Spring wheat area. The price of Spring wheat moved up around 1 cent a bushel in the early trading, but the upturn was lost later, following the passage by the Senate of the Commodity Exchange Control Bill.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- Senate approval of the Deficiency Appropriation Bill carrying the $1,425,000,000 fund for work relief in the next fiscal year was blocked today by a protracted wrangle over the Florida ship canal and Passamaquoddy tide-harnessing projects, revived under a new administrative move.
Every year when Kentucky Derby time rolls around New York newspaper men write of "the Blue Grass State" and speak of the "Darby."

The State rested its case at 6:40 o'clock last evening in the trial of Charles (Lucky Luciano) Lucania and nine other men before Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook and a jury on charges of compulsory prostitution.
Money market closed the week quietly, business being small and quotations unchanged for all classifications.
WASHINGTON, May 29. -- With flags and flowers the nation will honor its soldier dead tomorrow, along with continuing care of more than half a million disabled veterans of its wars.
ST. LOUIS, May 29 (AP). -- The Pirates walked the plank which they had greased for the Cardinals up to the fifth inning today. St. Louis won, 9 to 7.

JERUSALEM, May 29. -- The situation in Palestine remains grave, although the only incidents today were the stabbing of a Jewish policeman, the usual explosion of homemade bombs, rifle shots, the burning of Jews' crops and the usual Friday demonstrations after Arabs left their mosques.
GENEVA, May 29. -- The League of Nations Opium Advisory Committee adopted today at China's request a resolution aimed to bring pressure on Japan to end laxity toward narcotics traffickers in China.

YONKERS, N.Y., May 29. -Just in case the sight of women in shorts might be too dazzling for one policeman over the coming holiday week-end, the Yonkers Police Department is assigning ten men to duty to enforce the city's "anti-shorts" ordinance.

Fifteen prize winners shared in four awards of prizes and scholarships announced last night at the annual commencement exercises of the Institute of Musical Art of the Juilliard School of Music. The exercises took place in the concert hall of the school, 130 Claremont Avenue.

MOSCOW, May 29. -- While Jose R. Capablanca of Cuba added still another point to his score and increased his lead in the international chess masters' tournament at the House of Unions tonight, M. Botwinnik, the Soviet champion, and the Cuban's nearest rival, again figured in an adjourned match in the twelfth round.

AK-BULAK, U.S.S.R., May 29. -- The solar eclipse expedition of Harvard University and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology is comfortably installed near this Central Asian town and has already made appreciable headway in setting up its instruments to observe the total eclipse on June 19.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- Under pressure of a renewed drive for adjournment of Congress before the beginning of the Republican convention in Cleveland on June 9, the Senate Finance Committee today turned to a small increase in the low-bracket surtaxes to improve the revenue yield of its compromise tax plan, and then ordered this last "must" bill to be reported to the Senate for action as soon as it could be drafted.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- The Oklahoma Natural Gas Company has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 22,200 shares of 6 per cent convertible prior preference stock, $100 par, and 133,200 shares of common stock, $15 par.

CHICAGO, May 29. -- The entire Chicago street-car system, comprising 1,111 miles of track, 3,920 passenger street cars and buses and other equipment, was sold today for $33,100,000 by Thomas J. Peden, special master, to representatives of the security holders of the four companies making up the Chicago surface lines.

THOMAS CARLYLE'S home in Chelsea, London, is now a national museum. In the house at 24 Cheyne Row -- it was 5 Cheyne Row in his lifetime -- CARLYLE lived, worked and preached over a period of forty-seven years.

ROME, May 29. -- Yesterday's meeting in London of the Italian Ambassador, Dino Grandi, and the British Foreign Secretary, Anthony Eden -- the first since Marshal Pietro Badoglio entered Addis Ababa -- is regarded in Rome as the first positive symptom of improvement in the relations between Rome and London.

CLEVELAND, May 29 (AP). -- Casual spectators at the Republican National Convention will constitute a small minority, Ralph Williams of Oregon, national committeeman in charge of arrangements, said today in disclosing ticket reservations for the political "big show."

DEVON, Pa., May 29. -- Royal Irish, 8-year-old chestnut mare owned by Dixiana of Lexington, Ky., was judged the winner of the ladies' saddle horse class before another big turnout at the Devon Horse Show today. The Belbrook Stables of San Diego, Calif., furnished most of the opposition with the 5-year-old chestnut.

DEXTER FELLOWS differs from Santa Claus in that he appears in the Spring and is friendly to newspaper men. For forty-three years he has been roaming the country with circuses and giving away passes. Now he has a definite place in American mythology. More fantasies have been created in his name than in the name of Cinderella.

Several of the experimental "platforms" adopted recently by different groups of Young Republicans (and older ones) have emphasized the importance of reviving foreign trade. It will be interesting to see what the Cleveland convention has to say on that question.

The Board of Governors of the New York Stock Exchange requested member firms yesterday to supply not later than June 15 comparative data on margin accounts as of March 31, April 30 and May 29 which, it is believed, will be used by the Exchange to demonstrate to the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System that its margin requirements are too stringent.

Just why should Fabian Franklin in your issue of May 26 and Whidden Graham in today's TIMES become unduly concerned over Elmer Davis's defeatist attitude concerning recent decisions of the Supreme Court nullifying certain New Deal legislation?

Trowels and shovels, deftly handled by the four New York City school children who won prizes in the child's garden design competition under auspices of the Gardens of the Nations, flew rapidly yesterday afternoon as the youngsters began work on their full-size garden in Rockefeller Center.

ALBACETE, Spain, May 29. -- A soldier who took part in a clash with peasants at Yeste declared the fighting grew out of the desire of the peasants to cut trees on the richly forested mountain region in the southern part of Albacete Province in order to convert the land to agricultural purposes.

The Chamber of Commerce, the Merchant Association, the City Club and a score of other local civic organizations have joined with the Citizens Budget Commission in an appeal to Governor LEHMAN to veto nine bills restoring salaries of teachers and other city employes to levels established before the emergency arose, and imposing other personal service charges on the city budget, bringing the total so mandated to $37,000,000.

The sudden drop in the temperature retarded consumer buying in many sections of the country this week, with most of the cities in the affected areas reporting only moderate gains over the figures for the previous week, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Charles A. Monroe and William P. Philips, as voting trustees for common stock of the Columbia Oil and Gasoline Corporation, have notified holders of voting trust certificates that the voting trust agreement dated June 30, 1930, has been terminated and that par value of common shares was changed from no-par value to $1-par value on Thursday.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- More convinced than ever that production control alone could avert "another tail-spin in American agriculture," Chester C. Davis, AAA. Administrator, was back at his desk today after a tour of eleven Western European countries, where he found "a greater degree of complexity of controls than any one in this country ever dreamed of."

Increased payments by several of the country's largest industrial corporations swelled the total of dividends declared in May to the highest figure for that month since 1931. The amount was also the biggest for any month since June, 1931. Dividend declarations aggregated $412,340,784 for 866 corporations in May, compared with $172,636,197 for 737 companies the month before and $328,858,312 by 776 corporations in May, 1935.

On the Harcourt, Brace Fall list are Virginia Woolf's new novel, "The Years"; "The Big Money," a novel by John Dos Passos; "Essays Ancient and Modern," by T.S. Eliot, and works by Kay Boyle, Carl Sandburg, Lincoln Steffens, Mabel Dodge Luhan, John O'Hara, Logan Pearsall Smith and T.A. Daly.

SYRACUSE, May 29. -- Chairmen of various committees of the Assembly of the Presbyterian Church, announced today by the newly elected Moderator, the Rev. Henry Buck Master of Philadelphia, are as follows:

Accepting a challenge by Jesse Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, Philip J. Roosevelt, chairman of the reorganization committee for the Minneapolis St. Louis Railroad, announced yesterday that he soon would submit to Mr. Jones a plan of reorganization for the company to be financed with a $5,000,000 loan from the RFC and $1,000,000 to be raised privately.

MINEOLA, L.I., May 29. -- An estate unofficially estimated at more than $1,000,000 is disposed of in the will filed for probate here today with Surrogate Howell of Mrs. Helen Hastings, widow of Thomas Hastings, New York City architect.
Free dancing on the Central Park Mall, inaugurated three years ago by the Department of Parks, will be resumed on June 9. The WPA orchestra will play two dance sessions a week.
Ten days or more ago I heard an address given at the Law Building of Yale University by Mr. Saito, Ambassador of Japan to the United States.

BERLIN, May 29. -- The second sentencing in the Coblenz secret mass trial of Catholic friars charged with immorality was imposed today when Matthias Wansart, known as Brother Oswald of the St. Francis Society, was sentenced to four years' penal servitude and five years' loss of civil rights.

Dr. Clarence A. Barbour, president of Brown University, spoke yesterday at the commencement exercises of the Lincoln School of Columbia University. He urged the graduates to remember that they could influence other persons in two ways, purposely and unconsciously.

EPSOM DOWNS, England, May 29 (AP). -- Stepping to the front in the final furlong, Sir Abe Bailey's Lovely Rosa, a 33-to-1 shot in a field of seventeen, today won the 158th running of the Oaks, one and one-half mile test for 3-year old fillies.

Bequests totaling $150,000 and three additions to the staff were announced yesterday by Dr. Claude A. Burrett, dean of the New York Medical College and director of the Flower Hospital. Commencement exercises will be held Tuesday night at the Plaza Hotel, where diplomas will be presented to seventy-seven doctors and thirty-eight nurses.

MERCERSBURG, Pa., May 29. -- Mercersburg Academy commencement festivities, including this year a preliminary celebration of its centennial, were marked by the Musical Club's concert today and a formal dance tonight, while tomorrow a pageant will be a leading feature of the week-end program.
The twenty-three G.A.R. veterans who will march in the Manhattan parade are:

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

GIBRALTAR, May 29. -- British authorities today made every effort to emphasize the unofficial nature of the Gibraltar stopover of Emperor Haile Selassie and his party, who arrived aboard the cruiser Capetown at 9:30 A.M. today.

HEWLETT HARBOR, L.I., May 29. -- Mrs. Henry Dietrich of Briar Hills and Mrs. William R. Kirkland Jr. of Women's National today reached the final of the women's metropolitan golf championship. They will meet tomorrow for the title in a thirty-six-hole match over the Seawane Club course.

PHILADELPHIA, May 29. -- Harvard's crippled captain, Milton Green. performed magnificently today, but his sounder-bodied teammates failed to follow his sterling example. And so Cornell, rather than the Crimson, was heading toward the team championship of the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. tonight as the preliminary round of the sixtieth annual title meet was completed at Franklin Field.

ALBANY, May 29. -- Governor Lehman signed today the bill of Senator Kleinfeld, Brooklyn Democrat, authorizing the Board of Commissioners of the Land Office to grant to the Federal Government certain lands now or formerly under the waters of Jamaica Bay for the establishment of a Coast Guard aviation station.

At the recent Kansas City meeting of the American Medical Association the issue of pain relief in childbirth was raised once more. Since 90 per cent of the leading and competent obstetricians of America relieve pain in labor safely and effectively in a large proportion of their cases, may I clarify a confused matter, and this because I am one of the small group of women who have studied analgesia for twenty-three years?

Many pastors will preach Memorial Day sermons tomorrow. A number of military and patriotic societies will attend special services. Tomorrow is the Feast of Pentecost or of the descent of the Holy Ghost, which is considered one of the three greatest festivals of the Christian year, the others being Christmas and Easter.
John Henry Lewis, world's light-heavyweight champion, enjoyed a breeze at the expense of Bob Godwin, Daytona Beach (Fla.) veteran, at Madison Square Garden last night.

More than 6,000 cross-country racing enthusiasts are expected to gather at the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club, Rye, N.Y., for the second annual meeting of the Fairfield and Westchester Hounds today. This promises to be one of the best of the hunts meets in the East, having had a very successful inaugural last year.

National savings, as represented by deposits or assets of savings institutions, have recovered more than half their depression loss and now amount to $53,500,000,000, against the record of $56,000,000,000 made in 1930, according to The Index, publication of the New York Trust Company.

Yesterday Governor LANDON formally announced, what was well known before, that JOHN HAMILTON will make the nominating speech for him at Cleveland. It is right that Mr. HAMILTON, who has displayed such zeal and collected so many delegates, should have due honor.

CHICAGO, May 29 (AP). -- The Senate's adoption of the Commodity Exchange Bill today was followed by a late setback in the prices of wheat futures here, but market officials and traders generally were reluctant about commenting pending examination of the contents of the bill as it was passed.

Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral and Vicar General of the Archdiocese of New York, will observe his eightieth birthday today by offering a pontifical mass of thanksgiving at 10:30 o'clock this morning in the cathedral, where he has served forty-nine years as rector.
SHANGHAI, May 29 (AP). -- On the heels of a strike of Chinese students in Tientsin against Japan's program, 3,000 fresh Japanese troops marched into North China garrisons today.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:
The sailing vessel is coming back, at least pictorially, it seemed yesterday when the ninth outdoor art exhibition was opened in the streets around Washington Square.

Ahead all the way, the St. John's University baseball team, behind Frank McGuire's capable pitching, topped one of its borough rivals, Brooklyn College, to the tune of 8 to 6, at Manhattan Beach yesterday, thereby repeating an early season success.

TOPEKA, Kan., May 29. -- Governor Landon announced today the selection of John D.M. Hamilton, manager of his pre-convention delegate campaign, as the man from Kansas who will put his name in nomination at the Republican convention.

The nation should keep faith in its youth and refrain from pitying them during "these trying times," Dr. John L. Elliott, senior leader of the New York Society for Ethical Culture, declared yesterday afternoon at the annual commencement address of the Fieldston School, high school unit of the society.

CAMDEN, N.J., May 29. -- There has been a "purge" of the relief rolls and a drive against "chiselers" in Camden since the State of New Jersey threw the administration of direct relief back upon the municipalities last month.

Developments in the foreign exchange market yesterday gave evidence of increasing strain on the gold-bloc currencies as the time approached for France's new Leftist government to take control next week. The engagement of $18,661,000 additional gold abroad for shipment here was announced at the Federal Reserve Bank.

The men of the city whose memories remain focused upon the events of Shiloh, the siege at Vicksburg and the confusion of Antietam will be the central feature today of parades and celebrations marking New York's commemoration of Memorial Day.

Further testimony on the detrimental effect of "style piracy" upon the retail branch of the women's apparel industry was given yesterday by Edwin Goodman, head of Bergdorf-Goodman Company, at a special hearing in the Bar Building, 36 West Forty-fourth Street, in the suit of William Filene Sons Company of Boston against the Fashion Originators Guild of America.

The following table gives the amount of the dealings in the stocks from which the averages are computed, as well as the total dealings in the rails and industrials, and the combined trading in both classes of issues and the number of the latter appearing in the daily and weekly transactions:

Victor F. Ridder, local WPA Administrator, yesterday ordered 7,300 WPA workers on fifty highway construction jobs in Queens shifted to other boroughs on Monday morning because George U. Harvey, Queens Borough President, rejected the WPA repaying job on Jamaica Avenue which was described by S. Meredith Strong Jr., superintendent of the Queens Highway Bureau, as "a disgrace."

PHILADELPHIA. May 29. -- A turbulent opening session of the State Senate's investigation of WPA activities in Pennsylvania was climaxed today by the issuance of warrants for the arrest of six persons for contempt of the inquiry committee.
MANAGUA, Nicaragua, May 29. -General Anastasio Somosa, commander of the National Guard, issued the following declaration today to the local and foreign press:

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- Suspension by the Executive Council of the American Federation of Labor of all nine major unions that have demanded a single union for each new industry organized was predicted by a spokesman for the dissident unions today after the United Mine Workers had rejected an ultimatum by the A.F. of L. demanding dissolution of the committee for industrial organization by June 3.

DETROIT, Mich., May 29. -- The Federal law violations indicated in the complaints and evidence resulting from his investigation of the Black Legion were disclosed today by Duncan C. McCrea, Wayne County prosecutor.

DETROIT, May 29 (AP). -- Clarence (Red) Phillips, big rookie right-handler from Oklahoma, making his first start of the season, pitched the Tigers back into third place today with a 4-to-3 ten-inning victory over the White Sox. It was the only game scheduled in the American League.

The strike of Atlantic Coast seamen, directed for the last ten weeks by a rank-and-file committee of the International Seamen's Union without official sanction of the union, was brought to a close yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, May 29. -- Unconfirmed reports reaching here late today said revolutionaries had risen in arms against the Praguayan Government of President Rafael Franco and were marching toward Asuncion, the nation's capital.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals $23,308,077, representing one State and sixty-three municipalities. The revised amount for this week was $21,407,594. The weekly average this year stands now at $24,599,192.
