The American Newspaper Guild, in its third annual convention, which opened yesterday at the Hotel Astor, is expected to vote overwhelmingly today for affiliation with the American Federation of Labor.

On the application of distributors of milk in paper containers Supreme Court Justice Carew signed yesterday a temporary injunction restraining the New York State Division of Milk Control from putting into effect on Monday a new price schedule for the metropolitan area which will increase the cost of milk sold through stores in paper containers 1 cent a quart.

PARIS, May 29. -- Government mediation failed today to obtain a general settlement of the strike of metal workers in the Paris suburbs. Instead the strike spread to another score of factories, which were occupied by the workers, who will remain possession night and day.
ABOARD THE QUEEN MARY, en Route to New York, May 29. -The Queen Mary will break all records for a day's steaming at noon tomorrow. She is doing thirty knots in clear weather and a smooth sea.
St. ANDREWS, Scotland, May 29. -- Unless all prophets are hopelessly mistaken there is going to be a great final in the British amateur golf championship at St. Andrews tomorrow.

PHILADELPHIA, May 29. -- Donald Budge of Oakland, Calif., and Wilmer Allison of Austin, Texas, were named today as the American singles standard bearers against Jack Crawford and Adrian Quist of Australia in the Davis Cup tie starting at 2:30 tomorrow afternoon at the Germantown Cricket Club.

NEWARK N.J., May 29. -- "Corrupt election practices" in "various parts of New Jersey, particularly Hudson County," were charged today by Franklin W. Fort, who was defeated May 19 by Governor Hoffman for election as delegate at large to the Republican National Convention.

MANILA, May 29. -- Plans to make the Philippine Islands "invasion proof" with a fleet of tiny, high-speed fighting craft and a relatively large but fast-moving army reserve were revealed tonight by Major Gen. Douglas MacArthur.

The Cunard White Star liner Britannic will sail today for Cobb, Southampton, Havre and London. Her passengers include forty-three Canadian young women en route to London to participate in a demonstration for the Women's League of Health and Beauty.

CHICAGO, May 29. -- Hogs were in fairly active demand again today, with prices steady to 10 cents a hundredweight higher. Hogs weighing less than 210 pounds showed the most strength. Light receipts and reports of a fairly good movement of fresh pork were the strengthening influences.

Although Bill Dickey is no hero of mine, the injury which he sustained while trying to block another player from reaching home plate moves me to remark that it is too bad that any one must suffer because of a foolish practice which is illegal, according to a strict interpretation of baseball rules and which John Kieran has tried to encourage in some of his columns.

At the time of the opening of the Moscow subway your correspondent gave a masterly description of its beauties. I shall not attempt at giving further details about a subway that is particularly captivating to us New Yorkers who have to suffer the Seventh and Lexington Avenue subways.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP). -A controversy over the barring of four Negro athletes from competition in the District of Columbia Olympic track and field trials tomorrow was smoothed over today when the boys were promised an opportunity to qualify later.

By a vote of 4 to 1 the Appellate Division upheld yesterday the constitutionality of the law passed last year barring suits for alienation of affections, seduction and breach of promise. Presiding Justice Francis Martin cast the dissenting vote. The opinion, written by Justice Irwin Untermyer, was concurred in by Justices McAvoy and O'Malley, while Justice Dore concurred in the result.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 29. -Demands for minimum wages and maximum hours and a constitutional amendment to permit Congress to pass laws to safeguard the economic welfare of workers were unanimously approved in resolutions today by the biennial convention of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America.

Persistently unfavorable weather for the new crop, along with a decided improvement in wholesale cotton goods conditions, lifted prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday 2 to 9 points. Trading was the most active in several months.

" Their Adopted Home," two-reel melodrama detailing the adventures of Giovanni Pasquale and his family, who "recently arrived" in this city as immigrants, received its world premiere yesterday at the Horace Mann School for Girls, 120th Street and Broadway. A private performance for students and members of the faculty was given the day before.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 29. -The great problem of the day for the United States is the adaptation of tried and true democratic principles to an environment that has been greatly changed by large-scale industrialism, Dr. Harold Willis Dodds, president of Princeton University, told the National Conference of Social Work here tonight.
LONDON, May 29. -- Peter Fleming sends the following from aboard the S.S. Queen Mary:

Despite the holiday influences, the share market regained yesterday most of the fractional losses of the day before under the leadership of the steel, gold-mining and various other industrial groups. The closing was firm and higher. Trading remained quiet as is usual when a long week-end lies ahead; the volume on the Stock Exchange was 740,000 shares, against 762,000 on Thursday.
Entries in the second contest of the National Conference on Legalizing Lotteries, Inc., of which Mrs. Oliver Harriman is president, will be closed today.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 29. -- Brunswick School of Greenwich held its annual commencement today and the following were graduated: Paul D. Benton and Charles E. Wentworth, Rye, N.Y.; Raymond M. Grossman, Old Greenwich; Theodore K. Quinn Jr., Darien, honor student; Robert E. Clift Jr., class president and honor student; Dickson G. Glass, James B. Kennedy and John J. Sinnett Jr., all of Greenwich, and William R. Van Loan of Noroton.

HAVANA, May 29. -- Dr. Joaquin Martinez Saenz, head of the ABC revolutionary organization and former Secretary of the Treasury, returned this morning by plane from Miami, where he has been living in exile. He is the first prominent exile to return following the inauguration of President Miguel Mariano Gomez.

Gains ranging up to 20 per cent featured department store trade in the metropolitan area during the week. Most departments shared in the increased volume, although the cooler weather slowed down the demand for some of the strictly hot-weather goods.

Two weeks before Mgr. LAVELLE was ordained as a priest St. Patrick's Cathedral was dedicated, and as he was at once assigned as an assistant on the staff of the new cathedral, his priestly career may be said to be coincident with its life to this day, which is the eightieth anniversary of his own birth.

Any doubt of the re-election of Charles D. Hilles as member of the Republican National Committee from New York that may have existed seemed to have been dispelled yesterday when he was assured of the support of the party leaders of the metropolitan district.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

With twelve named for the golden anniversary running of the Suburban Handicap and the same number entered for the historic Juvenile Stakes, which is ten years older, Belmont Park today seems assured of one of the greatest crowds in its history.

GENEVA, May 29. -- The Argentine Government orally informed the League of Nations today that it desired a special Assembly session late in June to decide on League policy regarding Italy and Ethiopia.

SALEM, N.H., May 29. -- Speed to Spare, one of the minor members of Albert Gwynne Vanderbilt's handicap string, turned a smashing effort in the Roseben Handicap, five-furlong sprint feature today at Rockingham Park, before 9,000 persons, and paid $33.40 for $2 in the mutuels.
MADISON, N.J., May 29. -Charles Whitehead, powerful young Forsgate linksman, and J. Walcott Brown, twice a winner of the title, reached the final of the New Jersey State amateur championship today.
WASHINGTON, May 29. -- Congressional advocates of the TVA declared today that the suits filed in Birmingham and Knoxville represented dilatory tactics on the part of the power companies.

A suggestion that women's organizations concentrate on projects aimed at the prevention of juvenile delinquency, both as a matter of salvaging youth already susceptible to criminal elements and as a means of reducing the tax burden, was made yesterday by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt in a radio address.

I should like to offer the following suggestion which I believe would be of constructive benefit for the promotion of prizefights: Instead of collecting the decisions of the judges and the referee at the end of a bout, collect them at the end of each round and announce the result on a large scoreboard.

For two hours yesterday the regular and additional New York County grand juries sat in joint session awaiting the appearance of Mayor La Guardia to discuss their advocacy of an appropriation for a new Criminal Court Building, but the Mayor failed to arrive.

PEIPING, May 29. -- Should the student movement in Peiping and Tientsin develop dangerous anti-Japanese tendencies, the newly augmented garrisons of Japanese troops in North China "are prepared to do their duty and protect Japanese lives and property," declared a Japanese military spokesman today.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., May 29. -- The ministers and laymen of the Methodist Episcopal church of the New York East Conference at their eighty-eighth annual session here this afternoon went on record opposing a provision for exclusion of Negroes from the jurisdictional conferences of white churchmen in the Northern States.

BERLIN, May 29. -- The Boerse showed strength today on the last day before the Whitsuntide holiday. Heavy industrial shares opened strong, Mannesmann gaining 3/4 point, Rheinstahl 1 1/4 points and Mansfeld 2 points. Potash shares were stagnant.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 29. -- Midshipman August F. Weinel of Columbia, Ill., has attained the highest average in scholastic work for the course at the Naval Academy and will be graduated with highest honors this year.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 29. -- More than 2,000 persons tonight attended the commencement concert given in Woolsey Hall by students of the Yale School of Music. The students were assisted by the New Haven Symphony Orchestra, with Dean David Stanley Smith conducting.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- President Roosevelt announced at his press conference that he would attend Memorial Day ceremonies at Arlington tomorrow and spend the week-end aboard his yacht at Annapolis. The White House announced plans for his trip to the Southwest starting June 8.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 29. -- The Court of Appeals has affirmed a decision of Robert McCurdy Marsh, referee, awarding to Fowler McCormick and the two daughters of Mrs. Edith Rockefeller McCormick a trust fund valued at $12,000,000 to $14,000,000.
PHILADELPHIA, May 29. -- More than 100 college and club oarsmen churned the Schuylkill waters today in a final tune-up for the thirty-second annual American Henley, which opens tomorrow morning.

BERKELEY, Calif., May 29 (AP). -Five meet records were broken and two tied today in qualifying trials of the Pacific Coast Conference track and field championships as the University of California led the field by putting fourteen men in tomorrow's finals.
KIEL, Germany, May 29 (AP). -Chancellor Adolf Hitler reviewed a reborn German Navy today in a sea spectacle unrivaled here since manoeuvres preliminary to the Battle of Jutland.

PHILADELPHIA, May 29. -- Possibly finding it difficult to breathe freely in the rarefied atmosphere of seventh place, the Dodgers displayed slight resistance today as the Phillies jostled them rudely back into the National League cellar, from which position they will be peering distractedly at the Giants in tomorrow's double-header at home.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- Former President Hoover, as the titular head of the Republican party, has been invited and has agreed to address the national convention in Cleveland, June 10. An invitation to attend also was sent to Charles G. Dawes and Republican Governors and Senators by Chairman Fletcher.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., May 29. -- The spiritual benefit of telling one's sins in public "with absolute honesty" was explained tonight in the Town Hall by a British lord, the Protestant Episcopal Bishop of Arizona, a wholesale Canadian baker, a retail New York butcher, a Communist leader, a French baroness and others.

Mixed price trends characterized trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. In general, however, the undertone was firm, with small advances outnumbering the declines throughout the main body of domestic corporation loans on a slightly heavier turnover than the day before.

CAMDEN, N.J., May 29. -- William Fox, former movie executive, whose financial operations have been the subject Of much litigation in recent years, has filed a voluntary petition in bankruptcy in the Federal District Court here.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- The Senate passed the Commodity Exchange Control bill today by a vote of 62 to 16 after Senator Smith had withdrawn his controversial cotton amendments which had delayed passage for several days. Senator Smith acted at the request of Secretary of Agriculture Wallace.

Trading in most of the world's security and commodities markets will come to a virtual standstill today. With a few exceptions in the South, where the New Orleans cotton ring will remain open, primary markets throughout the United States will be closed in observance of Memorial Day.
The week-end will see three plays depart from the dwindling list of the theatre's current offerings. They are:

Fifty-three delegates to the third triennial conference of the Associated Country Women of the World were guests of the American Women's Association at a luncheon yesterday at the American Woman's Club, 353 West Fifty-seventh Street.

CHICAGO, May 29 (AP). -- The Cubs mixed eight passes with seven hits against Gene Schott today for an 8-to-1 triumph over the Reds, making Curt Davis's home debut successful. The victory sent Chicago into third place, ahead of the Pirates.

At noon yesterday the Queen Mary was approximately 1,070 miles out of Cherbourg Breakwater. She had broken no speed records, although her time for the day's run from Thursday noon to yesterday noon came close to the Normandie's record time. She steamed 747 miles at an average speed of 29.88 knots.

The City of New York won yesterday the test suit brought by the Standard Gas Light Company, subsidiary of the Consolidated Edison, which in effect would have forced the city to refund $30,000,000 of utility taxes collected and used for emergency relief purposes.

BALTIMORE, May 29. -- With the intention of drawing closer the link between college and university and enabling undergraduates to come into contact with men on the faculty who have given the university an international reputation, Dr. Isaiah Bowman, president of Johns Hopkins University, today announced that a new curriculum program was being planned by the president and members of the faculty.
LONDON, May 29. -- Prices on the London Stock Exchange were fairly firm today, although little business was done on the eve of the Whitsuntide holiday.

ALBANY, May 29. -- The State's Old-Age Assistance Law is constitutional and is now in effect, Attorney General Bennett Jr. certified today to the Federal Social Security Board at Washington. He also certified that the orders, rules and regulations of the State Board of Social Welfare governing the administration of old-age assistance are valid and consistent with Article XIV-A of the State Public Welfare Law and accord with the State Constitution.
The paragraph headed "Arnold Bennett MSS. Sold at Low Prices" in THE TIMES gives a different and more pessimistic summary of this sale than I think the facts warrant.

Salaries of the officers of thirteen corporations whose issues are listed on the New York Stock Exchange were disclosed yesterday in annual financial reports filed under rules of the Securities and Exchange Commission. The Packard Motor Car Company omitted salaries from its statement, filing them confidentially under Rule UB-2.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange in May was the slowest of any month since March, 1935. Sales for the month, as compiled by THE NEW YORK TIMES, totaled 20,614,690 shares, compared with 39,616,438 shares in April and 30,438,423 shares in May a year ago.

Although he has spent years studying marine life, Dr. William Beebe recently caught a large fish for the first time in his life. The deep-sea explorer returned to New York yesterday after a two-month scientific cruise in and about the Gulf of California, where he caught a 207-pound swordfish, aboard the schooner Zaca, owned by Templeton Crocker of San Francisco.

PRAGUE, May 29. -- The Sudeten German party apparently is undergoing one of those purges that have become popular among Fascist parties, but without the bloodshed associated with the German purge or the sensation associated with Austria's.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 29. -Nineteen public utility companies opened a joint attack on the constitutionality of the Tennessee Valley Authority today, filing an action in the Federal District Court for Northern Alabama here and a similar suit simultaneously in the Chancery Court of Tennessee at Knoxville.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- Colonel Joseph I. McMullen, who for two years has been the object of charges of official misconduct as a member of the Judge Advocate General's office of the War Department, was dropped from the army on May 8, it was announced today in routine army orders.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., May 29. -Mrs. Carl H. Donner of Baltusrol, holder of the New Jersey closed championship, won her third Women's New Jersey Golf Association one-day tournament today at the Montclair Golf Club with an 85.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- Definite indications that President Roosevelt planned to make a Western campaign trip were given today with the announcement by Governor Davey of Ohio, after a White House call, that Mr. Roosevelt probably would make a speech in Ohio in August.

Many things could be said about Senator BORAH'S long-awaited radio speech. It did not live up to the advance notices. It was not the thunderbolt which it was predicted it would be, shattering various Presidential candidacies and leaving the Republican managers pallid and palsied.

Lack of oxen has brought the Coney Island tercentenary celebration parade, scheduled for Friday and Saturday, to a standstill, it was disclosed yesterday. Wolphert Gerritse Van Couwenhoven and others of the original 1636 land grant burghers, have bequeathed an imposing array of descendants, costume designs, faded maps, fragments of Dutch furniture and seventeenth century vehicles but, alas, few oxen.

Increasing governmental aid to disabled World War veterans was reported yesterday in New York and other parts of the country, as plans were completed for exercises today in many veterans' hospitals in commemoration of Memorial Day.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- A renewed plea for transfer of the hearings on the complaint charging Charles C. Wright, specialist on the New York Stock Exchange, with manipulating the market in the stock of Kinner Airplane and Motor Corporation to New York City so that the proceedings might be expedited was made today to the Securities and Exchange Commission by counsel for Mr. Wright and others named in the complaint.
Swift and decisive were the punitive measures which the Giants imposed on the Bees at the Polo Grounds yesterday for the double stinging the latter inflicted on the Terrymen on Thursday.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP). -- The House Commerce Committee reported favorably today a bill providing for the creation of a commission to determine the proper height for a rapid transit bridge across the Hudson River between Fifty-seventh Street, New York City, and the New Jersey shore.

Irving Ben Cooper, special counsel to Paul Blanchard, Commissioner of Accounts, was formally requested yesterday by Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine to investigate the finances and activities of plainclothes men assigned to police headquarters.

PARIS, May 29. -- Fred Perry and Christian Boussus moved into the semi-finals of the French hard court tennis championships today, but it was 20-year-old Boris Maneff, Bulgar-Swiss, who caught the crowd's eye.

The dividend declaration of 25 cents a share by the United States Industrial Alcohol Company, payable on July 1 to common stockholders of record of June 15, was, through error, published yesterday as being that of the United States Distributing Corporation.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission granted today an application by the Narragansett Electric Company, a subsidiary of the New England Power Association, a registered holding company, for exemption from filing a declaration in connection with the issuance of $34,000,000 of three-year 3 per cent notes to be used as collateral for bank loans preliminary to refinancing the retirement of outstanding obligations.

DETROIT, May 29. -- The Black Legion was reported on the run today before the campaign of extermination set in motion a week ago. Definite information that frightened members were burning the hoods and robes was reported by Prosecutor Owen Dudley of Jackson County, where five men are held on charges of beating a fellow-member.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 29. -- The nerveless men who make their living in the death challenging game of automobile racing are ready again for the big event of their vocation -- the annual 500-mile classic to be run tomorrow before an expected crowd of 150,000.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

QUEBEC, May 29. -- Ann Harding apparently took a long lead tonight in the race from her pursuing former husband, Harry Bannister, reputedly seeking to prevent the screen actress from sailing for England with their 7-year-old daughter.

HALEDON, N.J., May 29. -Choking and half-blinded by thick clouds of tear and fog gas, four bandits fled from the Haledon National Bank this morning, empty-handed except for the pistols and sawed-off shotguns they had carried into the building with them.
Shipping men found support for their earlier prophecies of new Summer travel records yesterday as they studied the figures of the more important ships that left the port this week.

SYRACUSE, May 29. -- A twelve-year battle between Presbyterian Modernists and Fundamentalists was decided in favor of the former today as the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States voted to sustain rulings of various Synods and Presbyteries to enforce the mandate against membership in the Independent Board for Foreign Missions.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- With his position as Coordinator of Transportation scheduled for expiration in two weeks, Joseph B. Eastman struck out again today against what be considered wasteful railroad practices and for each proposed a remedy.
Mr. and Mrs. Anthony J. Drexel Biddle gave a dinner last night at Trouville for Mr. and Mrs. T. Markoe Robertson, Mrs. Boyce Thompson, Angier Duke and Anthony Duke.

Almost every one, I suppose, has at one time or another either heard or has himself expressed various opinions on the general subject of relief administration. I have not in mind the question of the need for relief, nor whether it is wisely and efficiently handled. I am concerned only with the moot question of whether or not it is handled honestly.

Dean Harold E.B. Speight of Swarthmore College was the guest of honor last night at commencement exercises of the Kew-Forest School in the Forest Hills Community House. Dr. Speight spoke on the theme of education for life after three students, Beryl Lorraine Moses, Hugh Mullen and Phyllis Gordon, had delivered opinion on the problems of youth:

Paramount Pictures, Inc., reported yesterday a net income of $718,921 for the quarter ended on March 31. Of the excess costs of certain pictures for which a reserve was provided out of earnings in 1935, about $800,000 was charged to operations for the quarter and a similar amount of the reserve was credited to operations.
The Bangor Aroostook Railroad bought $2,695,000 par value of its own or its subsidiaries' bonds for $2,706,161 in 1935, the company's report to the Interstate Commerce Commission disclosed yesterday.

The Whitney Museum of American Art will put into effect its Summer schedule, beginning today. It not only will be closed for the holiday, but until Tuesday. This schedule will be observed through June and July, when the museum will be closed Saturdays, Sundays and Mondays, and will be open Tuesdays, Wednesdays, Thursdays and Fridays from 1 to 5 P.M.

What with the long Decoration Day recess, the gala arrival of the Queen Mary on Monday with a shipload of bon vivants and the unqualified advent of the Summer season, the facilities as well as the ingenuity of practically every available night club, hotel roof and rustic pavilion will be taxed to capacity this week-end.

The arrival of one ship from a cruise around the world and the departure of two on Memorial Day Cruises, combined with the regular transatlantic services, raised the volume of tonnage handled at the Hapag Lloyd Line piers last week to 127,432 tons.

The application of scientific methods to lowering of production costs and to the molding of commodities and services to satisfy most fully the wants of consumers will, if retained and encouraged under private enterprise, be the source of creating full employment at increasing real wages, Warren M. Persons, consulting economist, declared yesterday.

Governor Lehman, in signing the bill bringing the State's old-age assistance system in line for contributions from the Federal Government under the Social Security Law, issued postmortem regrets last week for other phases of social security for which he had battled but which the Republican-controlled Assembly had killed.

GIBRALTAR, May 30. -- Although the British authorities here have been at pains to stress the informal nature of the visit of Haile Selassie, fugitive Emperor of Ethiopia, officers of the navy today extended themselves to make their guest's brief stay enjoyable.

PHILADELPHIA, May 30 (AP). -- The Athletics and Boston Red Sox divided a double-header before Shibe Park's record crowd of the season, 28,450 paid, today. The Mackmen won the first game, 6 to 4, and the Red Sox the second, 6 to 2.

THE NEW YORK TIMES described the recent ceremony when the painting of the discovery of America by Leif Ericsson was presented to the Congress by Dr. Alf Bjercke on behalf of the people of Norway. On this occasion the Norwegian Minister, Wilhelm Morgenstjerne, pointed out that "the real incentive behind this presentation undoubtedly is, first, love of historic truth."

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 30. -- Moses Brown School of Providence won the thirty-second annual Brown interscholastic track and field meet today with a total of 30 points. Mount Pleasant of Schenectady, N.Y., was second with 23.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., May 30. -- Eighteen Williams College juniors, including four from New York and vicinity, were tapped today for Gargoyle, the senior honorary society. They were:

ST. LOUIS, May 30. -- The contraseasonal industrial activity is regarded as a highly encouraging feature in the Eighth Federal Reserve District. Reports are constant of small plants either making additions or increasing output. Heavy plants are receiving good commitments from railroads for much needed track material, as well as for cars.

Max Phillips's goal on a short poke in two minutes of the sudden death period enabled the Governors Island poloists to defeat Ramapo of Rockland County, 5 -- 4, at Morris Memorial Field, Governors Island, yesterday.

WINNIPEG, May 30 (Canadian Press). -- Failure of rain to fall on Western Canada's parched wheat ands lifted prices of that grain today on the Winnipeg Grain Exchange. The close was 5/8 to 3/4 cent a bushel higher than yesterday.
LONDON, May 29. -- The openings next week are these:
IDA GROVE, Iowa, May 30 (AP) -- Ray Murphy, National Commander of the American Legion, pledged the organization today to preservation of the "sacred spirit" of Memorial Day.

COOLER weather in the week cut down retail trade in Summer goods in some sections of the country, but reports continued to be highly cheerful. Special promotions to herald the vacation season, with special emphasis upon travel needs, registered excellent consumer response.
WORCESTER, Mass., May 30. -- The second annual championship regatta of the Schoolboy Rowing Association of America was held on Lake Quinsigamond today under blue skies but over rather choppy waters.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, May 29. -- New Zealand has completed plans for moving industry on to a forty-hour-week basis, with the upper chamber of the Legislature having approved the Laborite proposals. The shorter week will go into effect Sept. 1, and the Industrial Commission is instructed to see that all industries adopt it unless it can be proved that they are unable to stand the economic strain.

Nearly thirty thousand thoroughbred dogs were registered in the United States during the first third of 1936, it was announced yesterday by the American Kennel Club. Their estimated value, figuring each specimen at the minimum price of $50, was nearly a million and a half dollars.
TORONTO, Ont., May 29. -- Capital for the development of Ontario's gold mines is being furnished in ever increasing amounts, according to a report from the Ontario Department of Mines.

I first met Glazunoff in Berlin in 1923, where he had come from Soviet Russia to take the cure at a health resort. He had been ailing for several years. He gave two concerts of his own compositions in the German capital. At that time I had already invited him to come to the United States.

WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP). -- One of three young women who battled for their lives in the icy waters of the "bottomless" Chasm Falls in Estes Park, Col., may receive $5,000 damages from the Federal Government.
With a gathering of 2,500 spectators filling every available place about the pool, Mrs. Eleanor Holm Jarrett yesterday lowered another record in her long career as a premier back-stroke ace.
PANAMA. -- The government of Ecuador has established censorship of foreign correspondence like that of Fascist Italy, Soviet Russia and Nazi Germany.

BERKELEY, Calif., May 30. -- Southern California's powerful track and field team won the Pacific Coast Conference championship today but the cheers of the crowd went to two athletes who stamped themselves as outstanding contenders for the American Olympic team.
Because of the great acclaim received by the Queen Mary, shipbuilders believe a second liner will be constructed to run as a sister ship. The liner cost about $25,000,000.

PARIS, May 30 (AP). -- The government announced tonight that 60,000 strikers who had been occupying French factories had evacuated them after independent agreements had been reached with their employers.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 30. -- The twenty-ninth annual commencement of the College of New Rochelle will take place on the campus on Wednesday at 4 P.M. It will be the last of the commencement exercises this year, being preceded instead of followed as usual by the traditional turning of the tassels of the student body.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 30. -- Colgate closed its baseball season today with a 7-to-4 victory over Syracuse in an abbreviated seven-inning game before a crowd of 2,000, which included many alumni back for commencement activities.

Senior week activities at Hunter College will begin on Wednesday, June 17, after final examinations, and close on Wednesday, June 24, with commencement exercises, it was announced yesterday by Miss Harriet Seliger, president of the outgoing senior class, who is in charge of arrangements.

That America and Europe will soon be linked by air routes across the Arctic wastes is the prediction of Sigismund Levanevsky, well-known Russian airman, who was balked last year in the attempt to fly non-stop from Moscow to San Francisco, but hopes to make the flight this Summer.

THE authors of this helpful manual have had extensive training and a wide experience upon which to base their advice. For to fifteen years of study and of teaching and counseling must be added the opportunities these have given them for that practical observation manifest in this and previous books.

While Gregory Margin, the national indoor champion and defending titleholder, was idle because of a first-round bye, favorites emerged victorious yesterday as the nineteenth annual Brooklyn open singles tennis championship got under way at the Terrace Club of Flatbush.
WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP). -- A contention that the TVA has helped private utilities has been put forward by David E. Lilienthal, director of the Tennessee Valley Authority.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., May 30. -- Bunching hits in the first inning for three runs and tallying in the late innings on a pair of homers, Manhattan College defeated Saton Hall in the annual Memorial Day game at Setonia Field today, 7 to 0.
OTTAWA, May 29. -- National government for Canada was thrown into the arena of public discussion this week by William D. Herridge, former Canadian Minister in Washington.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 30. -- American democracy cannot endure if the "agony and misery of the-last six years" are to be regarded as regularly recurring features of the business cycle, Dr. Solomon Lowenstein declared today at the closing session of the sixty-third annual meeting of the National Conference of Social Workers.

There is little likelihood that expectant mothers in New York City will have quintuplets or even quad ruplets, according to statistics made public yesterday by Dr. John L. Rice, Commissioner of Health. In the recent history of the Health Department there have been only two sets of quadruplets.

DETROIT, Mich., May 30. -- In the exposure of the Black Legion the Midwest has come face to face with a native mass movement with roots in various parts of the country which in the name of the Constitution and "true Americanism" would deny to large elements of the population the equal rights guaranteed to them and would concentrate political power in its own leadership allegedly by terror and violence.

The national convention of the Socialist party in Cleveland last week, which nominated Norman Thomas for the third time as its candidate for President, brought to a head the intra-party conflict which first manifested itself at the Milwaukee convention in 1932 and assumed acute form since the Detroit convention of 1934.

RADIO shows such promise of expanding in the future that the Federal Communications Commission has scheduled "a sweeping inquiry" to begin June 15 in Washington to consider the outlook. The hearing, it is explained, will be broad in scope, and "neither individual applications nor individual assignments within the service bands will be considered."

INTEREST ran high in an experiment of the Metropolitan Spring season of popular-priced opera which was not mentioned in these columns last Sunday. That was the production of Gluck's "Orfeo," with dancers of the American Ballet miming on the stage while the music was sung and played by executants stationed in the orchestra pit:

ECHOES of the recent radio popularity poll conducted by the Women's National Radio Committee are being studied by the group, according to Luella S. Laudin, director, who reports both bouquets and brickbats have been thrown in the direction of the committee of awards.

Inspired by a suggestion from Mrs. Carrie Chapman Cart, a committee of fifteen women selected from all parts of the country will be named to make a study of "What Constitutes National Defense?" it was announced yesterday by Miss Josephine Schain, chairman of the National committee on the Cause and Cure of War.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 30. -- Army, displaying a powerful, speedy attack and a stout defense, defeated Navy, 10 to 4, today in their annual lacrosse game. Fast dodging and clever stick work marked the play of the West Pointers from the outset.

HOLLYWOOD. THERE is little left of Poverty Row. The B films from the major lots which were calculated to do away with independent competition have, to some extent, accomplished their purpose. But if the lads with short money and long hopes have fallen by the wayside, the more substantial of the independents have prospered and have turned the second-grade films from the big studios into ammunition for their own cause.

LONDON, May 30. -- Professor William Rappard, Swiss sociologist and statesman, in delivering the Richard Cobden lecture before the Royal Society of Arts this week, dealt with "The Common Menace of Economic and Military Armaments."

C01NTRASTING the work of Giorgione especially with that of Titian, Duncan Phillips contributes to the May issue of the American Iagazine of Art the first of three papers on "The Leadership of Giorgione." Mr. Phillips discusses the various approaches to Giorgione and ne "Giorglone. legend."

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- More than half a million acres of land unsuited for farming are being bought and developed for public recreational facilities by the Resettlement Administration, it was disclosed today in a summary of the activities of RA under its "land-use" program.
The New York Athletic Club's baseball team defeated Brooklyn College, 13-9, in a free-hitting contest yesterday at Travers Island.

Upon reading Anne O'Hare McCormick's article "The New Italy," certain pertinent questions arise in the mind of a close observer of European affairs. The answers to these, if attempted now, will be only speculative.

PHILADELPHIA, May 30. -- Riding along on the crest of the inspirational lift that had headed it in the direction of the team championship of the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. after yesterday's trials, Cornell captured the title today, slamming the door in Harvard's face at the ninth event and nailing it fast from there on.

With the funds owing foreign traders by the government now estimated to have reached a total in excess of $5,000,000, the National Foreign Trade Association stepped into the situation yesterday with a demand that some means of making payments be devised at once.

The largest of the Works Progress Administration art projects in New York -- the mural decoration in the dome of the New York County Court House -- will be completed by July 1, according to a report made to Victor F. Ridder, Works Progress Administrator for New York City.

PARIS, May 29. -- It will not be until about the end of next week that Leon Blum will constitute his Cabinet, and for the present the future Premier is keeping his plans and policy strictly to himself. No one, not even his closest friend, has been willing to hazard a guess as to what kind of Premier he will make.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 30. -- The Brown University baseball team gained a 2-1 victory over Harvard today in their annual Memoroal Day tilt. The play was even throughout and was featured by the fine hurling of the three pitchers. Both teams scored once in the first inning and Brown won the game in the sixth.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 20 (AP). -- Champion of all Speedway champions, Louis Meyer, 32 years old and the only three-time winner in the history of the 500-mile Indianapolis marathon, said today as he sat in the winner's enclosure:

It is not surprising that from time to time admirers of Gilbert and Sullivan are tempted into retelling for children the stories of the operettas. It would obviously be a pity for boys and girls not to be given the freedom of that remarkable world peopled by pirates, fairies, Japanese nobles, sailors and gondoliers, where Lord High Chancellors and shepherdesses, baronets and village maidens mingle on equal and highly entertaining terms.

In her attempt to dominate China Japan has used various weapons. The most successful has been her army. Japanese troops and machines of war have rumbled across the mainland of Asia; they have sliced off large portions of territory from China and have put them under the indirect control of Tokyo.
With a little thoughtfulness and some intelligent advance planning the voyage up the Hudson for the Poughkeepsie regatta on Monday, June 22, can and should be one of the best cruises of the season.

Senator Steiwer, the Republican National Convention keynoter, will have to choose his keynoting words pretty carefully, we noted recently, in view of his voting record. His oratorical form may be somewhat cramped if he remembers the ballots he cast for the NRA, AAA and TVA, the Thomas inflationary amendments and the Wagner Labor Relations Bill.

Probability of stronger support than had been expected for Governor Alf M. Landon of Kansas among the New York delegates to the Republican National Convention was indicated yesterday by the results of surveys made by party leaders in the metropolitan district.

THE TIMES editorial on the decision of the Supreme Court on the validity of the Guffey act contains a suggestion that its objects and purposes might well be achieved through interstate compact under Congressional consent.

When Cass Kneeland offers his godson, Rex Hall, a secretarial job with no definite duties except to spend the Summer at Kneeland's Long Island "camp," Hall suspects that he is being made an object of charity, but he soon learns that whatever salary he receives will be well earned.

EITHER the baseball managers are talking through their hats or something remarkable cropped up in big-league life. They moan about their pitchers who can't win or their outfielders who fail to hit or the injuries that Rave hampered the progress of their clubs. But mention first base and almost every major-league manager dons a smile a mile wide and says he has the best first baseman in the business, bar none.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 30. -- The Indian Harbor Yacht Club of Greenwich held its opening dinner dance of the season tonight, with 200 in attendance for dinner and 100 in addition, who came later for dancing.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 30. -- Establishment of a Bureau of Biological Research at Rutgers University to facilitate cooperative research in "borderland fields" of biological science was announced here today by Dr. Robert C. Clothier, president of the institution.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- About one in every two persons in New England and in a large section of the Middle West will live long enough to be entitled to old age assistance under the social security plan. Only about one in three in the Southern States will live that long.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, May 23. -- Dr. Hernandez Somoza, one of the most popular and best-liked judges of Managua, has become a victim of a systematic persecution by a band of petty thieves and criminals, many of whom he has either fined or imprisoned.

After a recent visit to England, I was very much amused to read in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine of May 17: "But they're modern, and they draw luxurious trains at eighty miles an hour as an everyday performance. But don't wonder, for everything is so different," and so on and so on.

Under a cooperative arrangement which, among other things, will enable them to pool purchases and effect savings, the three trustees of each of the three largest group certificate issues of the New York Title and Mortgage Company purpose to realize larger returns for certificate holders.

THE clerks at the Marriage License Bureau expect to be busier than ever this June. Like all the rest of us, they say, Cupid suffered during the depression, but things are brightening now and orders for his tingling arrows flock in. Nearly 30,000 weddings gave Manhattan a boom year in 1935, and 1936 is already ahead of its predecessor.

LONDON, May 29. -- Flushed with his victory over Ethiopia and over British diplomacy, Premier Benito Mussolini seems determined to follow up his advantage by further undermining British prestige in the eastern Mediterranean as far as this can be done with propaganda.
WASHINGTON, May 30. -- Memorial Day, 1936, finds a great group of the veterans of the armies of the past on the rolls of the army of the present -- the Veterans Administration.

SOUTH AMERICA is the setting for the greater part of Victoria Ferguson's novel. To the little town of Banca comes a young American consul, Edward Ralston. He has an affair with a native woman, Mercedes, his laundress, but leaves her when he discovers that she is carrying on an intrigue with one of her fellow-countrymen.

TOPEKA, Kan., May 29. -- Despite the fact that Kansas backers of Governor Landon believe his nomination for President at Cleveland is so certain that the balloting will be little more than a formality, some of the Governor's friends fear that continued drives by drys in this State are threatening smooth sailing, if not at the convention then in the campaign afterward.

PARIS MIDSEASON collections are in many ways more instructive than the big Summer and Winter openings. They show the mode pruned, as it were, of the plethora of sensational, but superficial detail, used in introducing any new fashion.

George Eastment's brilliant band of athletes from Bishop Loughlin Memorial High of Brooklyn added the City Catholic High Schools Athletic Association senior and junior-midget crowns to its imposing list of track and field accomplishments this year at the teeth annual games held at Fordham Field yesterday.

LAKE SEBAGO, N.Y., May 30. -- Ernie Riedel of the Pendleton Canoe Club of New York, holder of the international double-blade title for the past thirteen years, gave a convincing demonstration of his paddling prowess in the inaugural preliminary Olympic divisional canoeing trials today.

Truly enough, it is quite often the case that "the longest way 'round is the nearest way home." A most conspicuous recent instance is, of course, that of our Minister to Addis Ababa, who, in his pressing need to get word to the British Legation, only four miles away, found it necessary to radio and cable across the world.

ALTHOUGH a most thoroughly scholarly piece of work, documented at every turn, "The Enchanted Glass," by Hardin Craig, is, nevertheless, so lively an exploration of the Elizabethan mind as crystallized in the literature of the age as to offer uncommonly good reading for those who would like further knowledge of the intellectual interests of Shakespeare's day.

IN the Spring the average citizen wonders what is wrong with him. If the year is an ordinary year, he concludes that nothing much is the matter, except that he has that tired feeling and needs a good long vacation. "Spring fever," he says, and lets it go at that.
PHIDELPHIA, May 30. -- The thirty-second American Henley Regatta on the Schuylkill today belonged, so far as the chief honors were concerned, to Pennsylvania.

The millions of schoolboys throughout the land who look forward impatiently to the coming vacation season are suffering no more these interminable days than are the 531 members of the United States Congress. Our Congressmen, too, hanker to go fishing without further delay -- fishing for votes instead of bass.

HARRY W. LAIDLER is well known as one of the most active members of the Socialist party in the United States. He was recently made its chairman for New York State and is executive director of the League for Industrial Democracy and author of nearly a score of books dealing with socialism in one way or another.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- The Democratic platform will be written in Washington and New York, and if any changes are made in Philadelphia they are not likely to be many or important. But the Republican platform, especially since Herbert Hoover, William E. Borah and Arthur H. Vandenberg all plan to be present, will be written in Cleveland.

CLEVELAND, May 30 (AP). -- Cleveland took both ends of a double-header with the Chicago White Sox today, winning the first game, 4 to 3, and the second, 11 to 3, before a holiday crowd of 22,000 persons.

A HUMOROUS angle on the frivolity and ennui of the very idle rich is the outstanding feature of Richard Connell's latest light novel. His playboy is Million-a-Year Mike, heir to the Van Dyke millions, which were amassed by his grandfather through a nation-wide hookup of Two-Bit stores.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 30. -- Army field and track men won from the Navy today by 64 2-3 to 61 1-3, in the closest, and by all odds, the most thrilling match in which the service teams in that sport have ever contested.

THE bough full of angels which William Blake saw as he walked through the fields could not have resembled the ordinary mortals on S.M. Steward's branch. Not even the most prophetic and mystic eye could render celestial the spinsterish Purfles, the fleshly Geasler, the cheap-scented Mary Nowell of this book.

KIEL, Germany, May 30. -- In the presence of Chancellor Adolf Hitler as commander in chief of the German defense forces and a distinguished assemblage of government and National Socialist party leaders, navy staff officers, naval veterans of the World War and members of the Navy League, the massive war naval memorial at Laboe, five miles from Kiel, was dedicated today with simple but impressive ceremonies.

Your appreciative readers would like to take for granted the uniform excellence of your Book Review section. In general they are not disappointed despite the tendency among newspapers to lower both standards of writing and of criticism. One difficulty, however, seems perennial with your staff.

DEVON, Pa., May 30. -- Before more than 12,000 persons, King Vulture, heavyweight hunter from the Dilwyne Stables of R.R.M. Carpenter, Montchanin, Del., was judged the champion hunter of the Devon Horse Show as it came to a successful close today.

WEST LONG BRANCH, N.J., May 30. -- Chester A. Bowman, member of the American Olympic team at Paris in 1924 and widely known as a champion sprinter and as a former University of Syracuse football star, was found dead in his automobile shortly after 7 o'clock tonight.

RYE, N.Y., May 30. -- Many country and beach clubs in Westchester held dinner dances tonight in celebration of Memorial Day. One of the largest was at the Westchester Country Club here and was attended by more than 400 members and their guests.

Mail orders for many types of goods were heavier last week, but there were fewer buyers in the market, according to a report prepared especially for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buyers. Outstanding in the demand were Summer dresses, furs, men's Summer suits, luggage, hosiery and porch items.

On the outgo side of the national ledger the relief item is the most important single factor in determining how far the budget falls short of balancing. Any Congressional debate on relief, therefore, invariably brings in the budget question. Last week the Senate debated relief -- and heard about the budget.

In Sunday's edition of THE TIMES, under the caption "Reviving an Old Tonsorial Custom," a most amusing article informs the reader of the coming of the screen picture of "The Last of the Mohicans." My attention was particularly called, however, to the writer's interesting detailed description (furnished, as I inferred, by Mr. Lambert) of the process of scalping.

The baccalaureate address to the graduates of Marymount College, Tarrytown, will be delivered by the Very Rev. Mgr. Francis Gonne, president of St. Bede's College, Manchester, England, today when the class-day and commencement eve exercises are held on the college campus.

" Those Who Dared" is frankly a supplementary reader, but its abundant illustrations in black and white, with many details such as children enjoy, its large type, uncrowded page and its end papers showing a map of the world Columbus knew before his first voyage, make it an unusually attractive schoolbook.

(]AN COUNT: Confronted with the necessity of giving up either his job as Mayor of Gulfport, Fla., or his job as assistant foreman on a WPA project, Andrew E. Potter retired from City Hall. He got $10 a month as Mayor; the WPA job pays $75.

Sally Keating came from a family of near-geniuses. Her father was an unappreciated artist. Her grandmother lived in the long-gone days when she had been a pretty comedienne. Sally's mother, a sweetly ordinary person, had broken her heart over her husband's failure to win recognition.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 29. -- The WPA and State relief rolls in California have declined 46.8 per cent since May 23 one year ago, with business recovery and the beginning of the harvest season reabsorbing the unemployed in private industry.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 30 (AP). -- Syracuse and Albany divided in their International League double-header today. Albany came from behind in the closing innings of the first game to defeat Ray Starr, 6 to 4, but Leo Mangum brought the Chiefs to victory in the second, 5 to 0, allowing only three safeties.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- As new obstacles in the way of quick action on the $702,000,000 Tax Bill developed today and the Senate spent another day on the $1,425,000,000 relief appropriation without reaching a final vote, adjournment of Congress by June 6 or 8 was believed to be hardly more than a possibility.

The Ordinance of 1787 for the Northwest Territorial Government contains within itself the provision that the resolutions of April 23, 1784, are repealed. That reference is understood to be to the ordinance drawn by Thomas Jefferson, now said by the eminent authority on our organic laws, Charles S. Lobingier, to have been rejected by the Continental Congress.

Miss Vera McCrea, elected State president of the Federation of Business and Professional Women at the recent convention at Jamestown, announced yesterday that a representative will be sent to the regional meeting at White Sulphur Springs, W.Va., in June and another to Chicago in July for the board meeting of the National Federation.

A returning traveler reports that recently the fencing series of Paris have been in a great state of excitement because Miss Helene Mayer, German Olympic champion of 1928 and the American titleholder of 1924 and 1935, arrived for several weeks of concentrated practice and instruction with the Parisian professional fencers.

THIS is a fragment of American regional story telling; a minor chronicle of a Midwestern family of thirty or forty years ago; one of those fictionized histories that young novelists so frequently construct out of their own family background; a first novel (apparently) that, although lacking in both depth and deftness, offers an honest, grave and simple little story.
In city, State and nation men marched, drums rolled and bugles sounded yesterday as Memorial Day, the annual anniversary of commemoration, was celebrated.

READERS of The Literary Digest will hardly need to be told the origin of this book. For in each issue of that publication Mr. Funk presides over a short boxed article bearing the same title and containing a few names of current importance with concise information, derived from the owner of each name, as to its proper pronunciation.

MR. MURRY is a familiar figure in the background of the English literary scene. He has been associated with the old Athenaeum. The Times Literary Supplement, and the old Westminster Gazette under Spender.

With virtually no controversy on the main issue, the American Newspaper Guild, at its annual convention in the Hotel Astor yesterday, voted, 84 to 5, for affiliation with the American Federation of Labor.

OF the many impressive demonstrations arranged by Dr. George W. Lewis and his staff of research engineers at the recent engineering conference of the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics at Langley Field, Va., few were more striking than that concerned with the behavior of the tapered wing at the stall.

AT his press conference on the eve of his departure for Europe last week, Mr. Johnson spoke optimistically of several of the young singers who had been introduced to the Metropolitan stage through the good offices of the Spring season.

THE Schools Motion Picture Committee, inaugurated with the object of aiding parents in selecting entire film programs suitable for young people, has ended its first season with thirty-four theatres, including the Radio City Music Hall and the Roxy, cooperating in its program.
BALTIMORE, May 30. -- Out-of-town drivers made a clean sweep of the power boat races today in the Maryland Yacht Club regatta.

ONE is at first persuaded, so well does his book start off, that Gerald Warner Brace has produced the best of the Maine novels. He has a style of real distinction; his atmosphere is superb; the tone he adopts is definitely less nostalgic than that of the Carroll-Coffin school.

FREDONIA, Kan., May 30 (AP). -- Hopefulness that the United States would continue at peace with the world was coupled today by Harry H. Woodring, Assistant Secretary of War, with a plea for adequate national defense.

QUEBEC, May 30 (AP). -- After using an airplane, a warrant and a ship's searching party in a vain attempt to find Ann Harding, his former wife, Harry Bannister reluctantly recessed the international chase tonight.

MINEOLA, L.I., May 30. -- After investigation Nassau County detectives here today decided that the fatal injury received early this morning by Mrs. Pauline Hood at Mitchel Field, when she jumped out of her husband's automobile, was due to her own act.

ROME, May 29. -- The East African campaign was brought to a close more than three weeks ago, but there is as yet no evidence, at least on the surface, of any very considerable lessening of European tension.

LONDON, May 29. -- Once again international events of the week have not tended toward peace. It is true that public attention has been diverted momentarily from that gathering black cloud across the North Sea, whose contemplation is calculated to chill the spine and fill the heart with foreboding over what may come, hut attention has been diverted only by what seems to be a nearer peril.

MADISON, N.J., May 30. -- Charles Whitehead, 23-year-old inks star from Forsgate, today won the New Jersey State amateur golf championship at the Braidburn Country Club, defeating J. Wolcott Brown of Manasquan River, 5 and 3, in the 36-hole final.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 30. -- Army and Navy batsmen engaged in a heavy hitting contest today, but the Navy lads wielded the willow just a little more effectively, and won by 11-to-10.
MANAGUA, Nicaragua, May 30. -- A spokesman for the National Guard made the following declaration today in connection with recent developments:
' A DOLF HITLER is Germany and Germany is Adolf Hitler," say the Nazi propagandists, and have therewith hit on the most effective slogan possible for them today.

WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP). -- After several rulings vitally affecting the New Deal and its major legislation, the Supreme Court will conclude on Monday one of its most important terms in the nation's history.

MOSCOW, May 30. -- Bureaucracy -- an ancient incubus on old Russia's life and a constant plague of new Russia, where nearly every human activity is under official supervision -- was denounced by the Soviet Control Committee today as responsible for varied injustices against workers.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., May 30. -- Accomplishing what no other driver has done, Louis Meyer of Huntington Park, Calif., roared to his third victory in the 500-mile automobile race over the Indianapolis Motor Speedway today in record-breaking time and with a record-smashing crowd cheering him wildly.

Governor Lehman's action on the pending bill providing for continuation of the employment of workers on privately operated rapid transit lines, in the event of unification, will have an important bearing on the city's plans for operation of unified lines under a Board of Transit Control, it was indicated yesterday.

About once a year there appear articles about an inventor who has a new machine for making ordinary books available to the blind. Some use sound and some use the sense of touch. Most make their appearance once and then are never heard of again.

ONE of the earliest collectors in Massachusetts was the Rev. Thomas Prince, who bequeathed his library to the Old South Church in Boston. Ten years after his retirement from the Presidency, John Adams, a great admirer of these books, wrote: "I mounted up to the balcony of Dr. Sewall's church where was assembled a collection which Mr. Prince had devoted himself to make in the twentieth year of his age.

PHILADELPHIA, May 29. -- Persons who smiled at suggestions that the present special legislative session would find Pennsylvania Democrats and Republicans reaching a quick agreement on relief insist, after watching this week's proceedings at Harrisburg, that they had good ground for their skepticism.

NEARLY one million persons are expected to use house trailers for touring this year, according to estimates prepared by the American Automobile Association. It is not surprising then, to discover that the trailer manufacturing industry is doing a flourishing business.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., May 30. -- Memorial Day entertainments were held in most of the Berkshire resort towns. The Pittsfield Country Club had a high-bicycle parade from Memorial Park to the clubhouse, with costumes reminiscent of the "Gay Nineties." Kite-flying, potato and three-legged races followed the luncheon for members and their guests.

WITH so much to be done in the garden at this time of year, it is comforting to know that the house plants, once they are shifted outdoors, will need very little care until Autumn. Wise gardeners no longer expect them to do duty all Summer, after blooming indoors all Winter.

RYE, N.Y., May 30. -- Mrs. Verner Z. Reed's Sir Gareth, a 6-year-old son of Sir Gallahad III and winner of the Billy Barton Chase in Maryland, scored another fine victory today by winning the Greenwich Cup at about three miles in the second annual meeting of the Fairfield and Westchester Hounds at the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- A proposal for a survey looking to continuance of the Passamaquoddy tidal power generation project was rejected by the Senate today after the Maine Senators had voted against a similar survey of the Florida ship canal.

I ask for nothing more than an expression of gratitude from all New Deal Congressmen. I bring to them the suggestion for another tax. I found it in Noah Webster's epitome of knowledge, otherwise known as his dictionary. He defines: "Moneyage -- A tax paid to the first two Norman kings of England to prevent them from debasing the coin."

THE fourth and final week of the Metropolitan popular season will be marked by the debuts of Anna Leskaya and Ruby Mercer, and the first performance of "Madama Butterfly." The week will consist of five evening performances beginning Tuesday instead of Monday night, and the Saturday matinee will be omitted.

Just about a year ago at this time, the golf world got the surprise of its life when Sam Parks Jr., virtually unknown outside of his own home district, Pittsburgh, won the United States open championship at Oakmont, a course he knew like a book.

A success story with interlardings of romance, "Love's a Career" is chiefly interesting for its sidelights on the internal workings of a big New York department store. Carol Morris of Morristown -- pretty, talented and inexperienced -- came to New York determined to make a success.

NEW radios for 1936-37 are beginning to appear on the market, a few weeks earlier than usual in an effort to capitalize on the urge to buy modern receivers for the national political conventions, Joe Louis-Max Schmeling fight and other special events scheduled for Summer.

SAN JUAN, P.R., May 30. -- The Liberal Senator, Luis Munoz Marin, from Washington today proposed as Resident Commissioner for Puerto Rico the Rev. Jose Rivera, an ardent nationalist known throughout the island as "the Puerto Rican Father Coughlin."

EIGHTEEN distinguished persons, among them England's poet laureate. John Mase-field, have contributed to this garland for presentation to England's distinguished scholar, Gilbert Murray, on his retirement, at the age of 70, from the Chair of Greek at Oxford.

Robert White, 19 years old, of 254th Street and Palisade Avenue, was rescued from the Hudson River shortly before 6 o'clock last evening by a sister, who had seen his plight from the lawn of their Riverdale home, and two friends after his sail-rigged canoe had capsized in the swell of two passing boats about a quarter of a mile off shore.

ANDRE MALRAUX'S observable development along certain well defined lines led us to predict, in commenting on "The Royal Way," that he would soon produce a far better book. This prediction has, in fact, been fulfilled by "Days of Wrath."

BARCELONA has recently been the center of European musical activity, as both the third congress of the International Society for Musical Research and the fourteenth festival of the International Society for Contemporary Music were held there late in April.

SYRACUSE, May 30. -- War would disappear if the monarchs and legislators who voted for it were put in the front line trenches, President Lewis of Lafayette College said in an address tonight at the men's annual fellowship dinner, held in connection with the Presbyterian General Assembly in the United States. of America.
WASHINGTON, May 30. -- Plans for an airplane attack on savage packs of Alaskan wolves were worked out today by three Federal agencies.

IN "The Marceau Case," published a few months ago, Mr. Keeler gave us one solution of the mystery surrounding the death of Andre Marceau. In that story an American newspaper man proves, by what seems to be irrefutable logic, that Marceau was slain by a wire-walking midget.

IN his introduction to "King Jasper," Robinson's last book of poetry, Robert Frost says: "But for me I don't like grievances. I find I gently let them alone whenever published. What I like is griefs --." This remark, made as preface to a statement about Robinson's own work, is a key to Frost's latest poems.

LONDON, May 30. -- The United States polo players were given a good workout in their trial match at the Ranelagh Club today and although they won by 15 -- 10 after giving their opponents six goals at the start, they had to ride good and hard to do it.

OCEAN CITY, N.J., May 30. -- With national and city colors flying the length of the boardwalk and on the main crosstown streets, Memorial Day found Ocean City in complete readiness to receive the thousands of visitors taking advantage of the two-day holiday for a trip to the seashore.

ROME. THE Roman Catholic world will be present in spirit at the imposing ceremonies that will be held in the Vatican today as Pope Plus XI enters upon his eightieth year. Hundreds of thousands will kneel in the vast and stately Piazza San Pietro to receive the blessing that the Pope, on this birthday, will personally impart from the basilica built over the tomb of the Apostle Peter.
RUSHVILLE, N.Y., May 30 (AP). -- A twenty-five mile long all-day celebration will be New York State's part in the national observance of the Whitman-Spaulding Oregon Trail Centennial Thursday.

AMONG the interesting recent acquisitions in the Print Department of the Brooklyn Museum is one of Giovanni Battista Tiepolo's rare etchings. It represents that lively and highly individual artist on his most personal side, the side that makes magic, caprice and imaginary experiences nourishing food for his buoyant mind.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., May 30. -- In memory of Dr. Edwin A. Alderman, friend of Woodrow Wilson and late president of the University of Virginia, the alumni association of the institution founded by Thomas Jefferson has started a campaign for a fund with which to carry on in his name special university projects and activities.

Agitation over political topics, preliminary to the impending conventions at Cleveland and Philadelphia, has extended to organizations of women as divergent in their objectives as the planks they are planning to submit to the major parties in both cities.
PEIPING, China, Sunday, May 31. -- A section of track on the railway line from Tangku to Tientsin was blown up yesterday following the bombing of a bridge on the line last night.

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- An intensive engineering study of public utility operations in the New England area is being conducted by the Securities and Exchange Commission to establish a background for the shaping of police contemplated for the administration of Section 11 of the holding company provisions of the Public Utility Act of 1935.

Through successive seasons programs of the Chautauqua Woman's Club at Lake Chautauqua, N.Y., have attracted thousands of women from many sections of the country. An undiminished popularity is predicted for the series this Summer, from the time the season opens on July 6 with the first of an imposing list of men and women speakers on varying topics.
ATLANTIC BEACH, L.I., May 30. -- The opening of the season at the Atlantic Beach Club took place tonight with a dinner dance attended by nearly 400 persons. The clubhouse was elaborately decorated.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- According to a tabulation released today by John H. Hamilton, campaign manager for Governor Landon, the Kansas candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination already has 179 delegates to the national convention instructed for him.

The insistence of the special Brooklyn grand jury in the Drukman case that Governor Lehman take some action against District Attorney Geoghan has again centered public interest on that powerful office of law enforcement and raised the question as to just how far a District Attorney should go as an investigating officer.

ST. LOUIS, May 29. -- Several months ago Arthur M. Curtis, Republican National Committeeman from Missouri, declared in an open letter to Harry L. Hopkins, Emergency Relief Administrator, that the WPA in this State was ridden by politics and that all of its activities were subservient to Thomas J. Pendergast, boss of the Democratic machine in Kansas City.
WASHINGTON, May 30. -- In the last twelve months we have been confronted with a paradoxical situation, which, in the manner of paradoxes, was at once the cause of gratification and of stave concern.

Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral and Vicar General of the Archdiocese of New York, observed his eightieth birthday yesterday. Thousands of friends in the United States and overseas joined in felicitations to him. He has been a priest of the cathedral for the fifty-seven years of his priesthood, the last forty-nine of which he has been rector.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 30. -- Century-old traditions of the Deep South will be actualized again in the observance of Old White week at the Greenbrier in White Sulphur Springs beginning Aug. 16. Customs associated especially with Old White (the name by which the Greenbrier hostelry, with its famous springs, is referred to even today by Southerners) will be revived.

ASHEVILLE, N.C. -- Four Southern States have designated beautiful girls to attend the Rhododendron Festival here from June 15 to 19, to represent their respective commonwealths. Six other States, completing a list of ten Southern States, will name their representatives within the next few days.

DR. SHELDON has struck a new note in modern psychology by emphasizing the close correlation which exists between this field of science and religion. He is not a clergyman nor layman, but an able clinical psychologist and doctor of medicine.

The Queen Mary is manned by a crew of approximately 1,100 veteran officers and seamen rigorously trained in the maritime traditions of the British Empire. Most of them are members of the Royal Navy Reserve.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., May 30. -- About 5,000 men and women assembled under the trees in front of the Stockbridge Town Hall here this afternoon, on benches normally used for the Summer symphony season in the Berkshires, to listen to an appeal to "surrender absolutely to God's guidance."
ASUNCION, Paraguay, May 30 (AP). -- Officials revealed today that an attempted counter-revolutionary plot was thwarted last night with the arrest of several politicians.

Employment opportunities for commercial travelers have been increased by the cut in railroad passenger rates effective tomorrow, manufacturers here said yesterday. A number of producers, particularly those in the apparel industries, said that the economies in rail fare possible under the new 2 cents a mile for coach fares and 3.2 cents for Pullman and railroad rates would enable them to send salesmen to communities which are now neglected.

With a full realization of changed conditions in the world, the Republican National Convention should adopt a brief, definite, constructive and forward-facing platform, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, declares in the current issue of The Young Republican, the national magazine for young Republicans, published in Chicago.

THE late First Marshal of Poland. Joseph Pilsudski, is as closely identified with Poland as ex-President Thomas Garrigue Masaryk is with Czechoslovakia. The lives of these two men would make excellent material for a modern Plutarch.

The National Conference Social Work is indeed an expression of the social conscience of America. Its members have consecrated their lives to the bringing about of a better social order wherein men and women shall have greater opportunity to enjoy the blessings of life.
LONDON, May 30. -- Two topics of absorbing interest excluded all others this week in London, Derby day and the sailing of the Queen Mary.

ALTHOUGH great abbeys, churchyards and museums attract their share of tourists, analysis of the more popular itineraries show that generally the traveler favors scenes of conflict. In London he will spend more time at the Tower than at Westminster; and while he may tire of the cathedrals and the galleries, he will always be ready to study the dungeons and moats of the early castles or follow Napoleon to his victories.

ANTIQUES which have been in the family for generations are prized by their possessors more highly than even greater rarities. Such heirlooms of furniture, china and silver, mainly found in long-settled communities, year by year gain in sentimental and historical value as their number is decreased by the break-up of homes and the dispersal of furnishings.

LONDON, May 30. -- Great Britain and the United States cannot depend upon ties of common blood to prevent war between them, declared the Rev. Dr. Bernard Iddings Bell of Providence, R.I., at the American Memorial Day services at St. Margaret's Church here today.
OYSTER BAY, L.I., May 30. -- The New York Yacht Club 32-footers made their first start as a class today in the opening race of a two-day series conducted by the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club.
SOME women who follow a conservative taste in shoes during three seasons of the year, in Summer like to take a flier in open-shank-and-toe slippers for street and country wear.

Probably the most important characteristic of last week, market-wise, was that Wall Street sentiment improved far more than did prices. As it was, THE NEW YORK TIMES average of fifty stocks moved up 1.62 points on the week to make the net gain for the month 5.42 points, virtually making up the April loss of 5.45 points.

This little volume is an appropriate commemoration of the Hans Christian Andersen Centenary. It contains the first four tales that Andersen wrote, "The Tinder Box," "Little Claus and Big Claus," "The Princess and the Pea," and "Little Ida's Flowers," in not only new but particularly pleasing versions, for Mr. Keigwin's translation retains the colloquial and dramatic quality of the originals.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- Congressional leaders are facing a drastic test in their efforts to adjourn the present session of Congress by the week-end of June 6. Whether they will succeed is yet a matter of sheerest conjecture.

" THE impish Aldo Palazzeschi, who had it gravely appear that his cat had published his first book of verse, began as a futurist, that most solemn of literary rebels, and here appears as a biting and intelligible satirist, in what amounts to an Italian version of "Gulliver" standing on its head.

Gold medal winners of the current season's contests for junior soloists were announced yesterday by the Music Education League. Final sessions have been conducted at Steinway Hall for two weeks. Contestants with an 85 plus percentage were entered, striving for a standard of 90 per cent.
ABOARD THE QUEEN MARY, May 30. -- Thick fog late today Continued on Page Thir

In the year since the National Industrial Recovery Act was voided by the Supreme Court, a number of advertising practices which were either restricted or outlawed by the various codes have come back into existence with renewed vigor, according to comments here yesterday.

IS "progressive education" changing its tune? Thirty schools in different parts of the country are cooperating in a kind of self-survey to try to determine how their present-day aims differ from those of a decade ago. If the findings reveal enough unity of purpose, they will be published in a new handbook which will reinterpret progressive education.

OUT of a party of twenty being sent under Harvard University and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology to the little Russian village of Ak-Bulak, in the southern Ural Mountains, to observe the total eclipse of the Sun of June 19, no fewer than eight will be women.

With Clinton H. Crane, her designer, at the helm, Van S. Merle-Smith's international 12-meter sloop Seven Seas swept across the finish line yesterday a decisive winner over the other large sloops in the Harlem Yacht Club's Long Island Sound championship regatta and its fifty-fourth annual event.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- Though the State Department in its Foreign Service employs more foreign than American clerks -- 919 against 714 -- Americans fill the bulk of the better-paying clerkships. Of the 659 Foreign Service clerks drawing salaries of $1,000 a year or better only twenty-eight are of foreign nationality.

Always Sir PERCY BATES, chairman of the Cunard White Star Company, protested that the Queen Mary was to be not a record breaker but a ship to meet changing economic exigencies. Similar deprecations came from the directors of the German, French and Italian companies when the Bremen and Europa, the Normandie, and the Rex and Conte di Savoia were proposed.

PARIS, May 30. -- Memorial Day was celebrated in France and the graves of soldiers who lie here were decorated in all cemeteries, the French taking part with the Americans in the tributes. During the morning religious services were held in St. Joseph's Catholic Church and in the American Pro-Cathedral, the Church of the Holy Trinity.

LONDON, May 15. THE battle over the censoring of Elsie Schauffler's "Parnell" still continues. It is a strange fight, for one of the antagonists is prevented by the traditions of his office from publicly replying to criticism.
