REQUIRING, as they generally do, two albums to contain them, complete operatic recordings represent a not inconsiderable investment to both producing company and purchaser. So it is not surprising that, whereas, about five years ago, Italy and France between them produced fifteen of them over a period of twelve months, the only item of the sort we can remember having come from either country since then is the third version of "Pagliacci."

CHICAGO, May 30 (AP). -- Chanceview, a big son of Chance Shot, gave nine other thoroughbreds a good view of his flying heels today as he sped to a surprise victory in Hawthorne's $5,000 added Decoration Day Handicap before a throng of 25,000, the biggest attendance in the history of Chicago's oldest track.

PARIS, May 30. -- Many different interpretations are being placed in Paris on the action of the Argentine Government in asking the summoning of the Assembly of the League of Nations for next month to deal with the questions of sanctions against Italy, non-recognition of a situation created by force and reform of the League.
BY early Summer one of the most important series of highway improvements in the West, that of rebuilding the major roads in the Columbia Basin, will be completed and ready for the traveler.

DURING his three years as our Ambassador to Spain Claude G. Bowers has written a sequel to his "Jefferson and Hamilton," dealing with Jefferson's eight years as President. The title of the book, which Houghton Mifflin will publish in the Fall, is "Jefferson in Power."

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 30. -- Challenging the nation's bankers to "keep up with the times," Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, in an address before the District of Columbia Bankers Association in the Hotel Greenbrier here, today urged the members to adopt a more tolerant attitude toward reforms sponsored by the present administration.

JUST plain, everyday racketeering is, apparently, in the size of its earnings, one of the biggest of big businesses in this country. By one method or another, most of it by schemes that are within the law, smooth racketeers relieve unsuspicious citizens of billions of dollars every year.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- The Federal Government now has more than 250 different sources of income, according to Treasury Department compilations. Most of the income is derived from internal revenue, but sizable sums are obtained from customs and "miscellaneous revenues" from a variety of sales and services, rents and royalties, fines, forfeitures and fees.

Memories of the past mingled with hopes of the future yesterday, as Brooklyn paid honor to its dead and began an eight-day celebration of Long Island's tercentenary with the borough's largest parade in many years.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., May 30. -- Pitching six-hit ball and making the longest home run ever hit at Weston Field, Walter (Shanty) Fuchs led the Williams College baseball team to a smashing 10-to-3 victory over Amherst today. The victory gave the Purple undisputed leadership in the Little Three race.

THE modern movement -- which for convenience is generally described as beginning with Cezanne -- has been, and no doubt will for a long time continue to be, surveyed from many points of approach. Its multiple strands have been studied severally and collectively; in deep seriousness, in lighter vein and, as could not but be expected, with scoffing and scorn.

BERLIN, May 29. -- The coming Olympic Games have now assumed in Germany an almost fantastic importance. Incongruous as it may seem, the key to German national policy at the moment is simply a determination to make the Berlin Olympiad a striking success.

More than 4,000 New York University seniors will participate in senior class activities that start this week at the various, colleges and schools of the university, Harold O. Voorhis, university secretary, announced yesterday.

For the first time in years the Dodgers won a double header from the Giants at Ebbets Field yesterday and 38,000 fans, jamming the stands beyond seating capacity, were well-nigh overcome by the spectacle. So was Colonel Bill Terry, who saw his infield crack up in each game to let in important runs.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- With $100,000 in State Department funds earmarked for transportation costs, a vacation at home is now assured in the fiscal year beginning July 1 to many foreign service officers assigned to posts in Asia, South Africa, Australia and in South America.

An argument over the parking of an automobile in front of 127 West Fifty-second Street last night resulted in the death of Anthony Scarpilla, 37 years old, of 1,330 Sixth Avenue, proprietor of a used car establishment. He died at 8 o'clock in Polyclinic Hospital, half an hour after he was stabbed, according to the police, by Daniel Lynch, 60, of 400 West Fifty-seventh Street.

VATICAN CITY, May 30. -- Ten thousand pilgrims came to Rome tonight for tomorrow's celebration of the seventy-ninth birthday of Pope Pius. Among these pilgrims were 100 from the United States. Cardinals called upon the Pontiff, bearing felicitations.
GREENWICH, Conn., May 30. -- Mr. and Mrs. Glen Wiggins. of Greenwich gave a party at their home this afternoon.
GRANADA, Col., May 30 (AP). -- Flood waters swirled over portions of the Southwest dust bowl tonight, leaving two persons dead, five missing and several towns inundated.

SYRACUSE, May 30. -- Construction will begin within six weeks on a building to house the Maxwell School of Citizenship and Public Affairs at Syracuse University, Chancellor Charles W. Flint announced this evening at the annual Alumni Association dinner.

Two alleged robbers were shot, one fatally, and three others escaped early yesterday after three detectives, hiding in a near-by doorway, had watched them remove a quantity of men's ties from the Armel Neckwear Company at 317 Chester Street, in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn.

Despite the sharp increase in home furnishings sales last year, which showed a gain more than twice that for the store as a whole, these departments on the average operated at a loss and wiped out about 20 per cent of the profits made by other departments.

ORANGE, Conn., May 30 (AP). -- A crash involving two automobiles and a large bus resulted today in the death of Charles Kane, 36, of 31 West 124th Street, New York, and injuries to five other persons.

THE power age has come to one of the last frontiers of the United States. Three thousand miles from Washington -- almost as far from the hub of the American Government as are the British Isles -- workmen and engineers are weaving two giant dams across the surging waters of the Columbia River.

DETROIT, May 30 (AP). -- The Browns administered a double beating to the champion Tigers before a crowd of 39,500 at Navin Field today. The Browns captured the first game, in which they drove Schoolboy Rowe from the mound, 5 to 3, and proceeded to rout Detroit, 5 to 0, in the second.

William J. O'Hara of the class of '37 was elected head of the Athletic Association in the Fordham College elections, completed last week. Thirty-four campus organizations, including the three under-classes, chose officers for the school season beginning in September.

BOSTON, May 30 (AP). -- After coming from behind to capture the opener by a 5-4 margin in 10 innings, the Phillies blasted two of the three Boston pitchers in the second game for a 9-6 triumph that swept the holiday twin bill today before a paid crowd of 24,430.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., May 30. -- A theatre in which will be presented at least six productions in Williamstown this Summer has been established by a number of William's and Bennington undergraduates. They have obtained a playhouse, the Peter Payne Dean Barn, on the Pittsfield-Williamstown highway, and will have it completely equipped.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- The century-old two-thirds rule for the nomination of Democratic Presidents and Vice Presidents will be abrogated by the Philadelphia convention in June, with the approval of President Roosevelt, according to those advocating its repeal and the adoption of a majority rule.

The first of the four Naumburg Memorial Concerts was given last night on the Mall in Central Park. The concerts were donated to the city by George W. and Walter W. Naumburg in memory of their father, Elkan N. Naumburg, who several years ago donated the bandstand on the Mall.

IT is not only the gardens and truck farms which produce Spring crops for the New York markets. From the sea come foods associated by tradition with the season -- soft-shell crabs, lobsters and shrimps. The three are crowding the sea-food counters.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- In the marble amphitheatre at Arlington National Cemetery, overlooking 44,000 graves of America's soldier dead, President Roosevelt today led the nation in Memorial Day ceremonies.
NOTRE DAME, Ind., May 30. -- Bachelor degrees will be conferred on 398 at the University of Notre Dame on June 1. In addition thirty students will receive law degrees.

During the coming month the Presidential campaign will be set actually in motion. The national conventions of both major parties will have met and completed their plans for the great appeal, every four years, to the voters of the United States. It will be a period of turmoil and shouting.

Support of the government and maintenance of order out of respect for tradition was the theme of the addresses delivered yesterday at the annual memorial exercises at Soldiers and Sailors Monument on Riverside Drive, which traditionally follows the Memorial Day parade on the Drive.

BURLINGTON, Vt., May 30. -- Dartmouth defeated the University of Vermont, 14 to 13, today. Bill Hart, Indian right fielder, singled with two out and two on to give Dartmouth its margin in the ninth inning.

Income tax law with regard to stock dividends continues to crystallize. It would new appear that the process of clarification of this branch of tax law has been considerably retarded by early regulations and legislation not wholly consistent with the basic principle of tax-free stock dividends as laid down in the leading case of Eisner v. Macomber (252 U.S. 189).

CONTINUING the highway development program inaugurated in 1929, Quebec this Summer is adding 2,000 miles of roadways to its system, it is reported. This will give the Province a network of more than 18,000 mites of improved roads.
EXETER, N.H., May 30. -- Andover won its dual track meet with Exeter today by a score of 80 to 46.

ANOTHER theatrical season ended last night. To all intents and purposes it was over a month or more ago, but historians of the stage, like other professional men, must keep a fiscal year: and this one runs through May.

HOT SPHINGS, Va. -- The Decoration Day program at Hot Springs includes a skeet marathon for men and women on the Homestead Skeet Field and a blind bogey golf tournament on the Homestead and Cascades course. The majority of the homes, forming an important part of the Hot Springs colony, are now open for the season.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 30. -- Fordham three times came from behind Yale today and finally, with an eight-inning rally, sent two runs across the plate for a 7-to-6 victory. The Elis outhit the Rams, 12 -- 7, but failed to make the most of them.

While business conditions were spotty in some sections of the country last week, trade as a whole was satisfactory, retail distribution in most of the Federal Reserve Districts continuing to show substantial gains over the volume of sales registered in the corresponding period last year.

This book Contains a well chosen collection of really fine photographs showing characteristic views of New York City from Chinatown to the Bronx Park Zoo. The text, which is an account of a visit made to New York by two children who were the winners of a national radio contest, is so dull that it is unlikely that any child will either enjoy hearing it read aloud or reading it for himself.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., May 30 (AP). -- Construction within four years of air transports with a cruising radius of 10,000 miles was predicted today by George Strompl, factory superintendent of the Douglas Aircraft Company here.

OMAHA, May 29. -- Corn planting has been finished; that is, all but replanting in the bare spots where the seed failed to germinate. There is a good deal of that this year because last year's crop, raised under semi-drought conditions, was pretty poor.

The May panel of the Kings County grand jury, in a presentment to filed tomorrow, praises District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan of Brooklyn as having "established an enviable and salutary record of criminal prosecution."

DALLAS, May 30. -- Generous rains fell over the Eleventh Federal Reserve District early this week and fair weather prevailed at the end of the week. Business generally was retarded by the continued rainy weather, building operations feeling most heavily this slackening influence.

Memorial Day and the absence of his adversary brought no armistice yesterday in the dispute which Borough President Harvey of Queens is waging with Victor F. Ridder, Works Progress Administrator, over the Queens executive's rejection of the repaving job done by WPA workers on Jamaica Avenue.

SYRACUSE, May 30. -- The Fundamentalist faction was defeated again today, as over its protest the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States adopted a basic budget of $8,000,000 for 1936-37.

Diplomas and certificates will be awarded to 274 graduates of Cooper Union Institute of Technology, Day Art School, Night School of Engineering and Night School of Art at the Seventy-seventh annual commencement exercises on Thursday night in the Great Hall, Fourth Avenue and Eighth Street, it was announced yesterday by Gano Dunn, president of the board of trustees.

STROUDSBURG, Pa. -- Crowds flocked into the Poconos, the playgrounds of Pennsylvania, within the past week. The resort area appears at its best -- Spring blossoms throughout the woods, and golf courses in most excellent condition.

What is described as the largest single purchase of electrical refrig- ] ertor eve made w nnnounced' yesterday by officials of the Hearn Department Store. The deal involves a $1,000,000 cash purchase of Williams Iee-o-Matie electrical refrigerators from the Bloomington (Ill.) plant, of which (. U. Williams is president.

SEATTLE, May 29. -- The Hon. Marion Anthony Zioncheck, Representative in Congress from the First Washington District, is as complete an enigma to his constituents as he is to the rest of the country. They are baffled and bewildered by the multitude of unorthodox escapades that have kept their congressman in the headlines of every newspaper in America.

A WOMAN who answers her own doorbells and telephones, pours the tea for everybody and passes around the cakes herself before any one can rise to intercept her, simply because she is too much alive to sit still and be waited upon, Anna Sten, the blonde Russian actress, is in New York again after an absence of nine months in the British studios.

Exports and imports from and into the United States by classified groups in April have been announced by the Department of Commerce, and they are compared with those of the preceding month and with April, 1935. Exports, as given in the tables that follow, cover only domestic exports, not foreign goods re-exported.

NOW we have it on good authority that duplicate bridge is a game of skill and that it is no crime to run a bridge club, even if cash prizes are given at duplicate games. Three judges of the New York City Court so ruled when the proprietresses of the Lovejoy Studios came to trial last week.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 30 (AP). -- A dazzling display by Si Johnson of Toronto Maple Leafs blotted out a fresh Buffalo winning streak of five straight in the second game of the holiday double header today. Despite unseasonably cold weather, a throng of approximately 11,000 spectators saw Johnson allow four hits and blank the Bisons, 4 to 0, after the home forces cantered off with the opener, 9 to 1.

THE saccharine cycle which loomed so formidably following the success of the early sweetness-and-light films, but which abated for a time again, has come to the fore. By placing Ginger Rogers in the leading role, RKO hopes to make of "Mother Cary's Chickens" one of the season's important financial offerings.

More bonds were called for payment in May before their maturity dates than in any month since December. The large increase in retirements was caused principally by refunding in the public utility and railroad fields. In the latter the calls were the largest for any month in more than ten years.

The attention of the public, especially that of individuals and organizations interested in the health of children, was drawn last week to the need for an adequate citywide program of free medical service in the schools.

In stressing the importance of preparedness, particularly as regards the maintenance of an adequate naval force, Governor George H. Earle of Pennsylvania last night urged also the improvement and development of a larger merchant marine.

WITH the publication of her second novel -- her first, "Once Again in Chicago," was a simple and rather homely little love story laid against the background of the World's Fair -- Minnie Hite Moody reveals herself not only as a gifted new writer but as an uncommonly versatile one.

FOLLOWING the general trend of development of radial air-cooled engines, which has made such rapid progress during the past year, the Gnome Rhone Company has just presented a new twin row eighteen-cylinder supercharged geared engine, which marks another forward step in the development of this type of aviation motors.

For practical purposes Nebraska has followed an old maxim of thrift. It pays as it goes. For years it needed a State Capitol. The old one presented a real hazard to life and limb. So, a quarter-mill levy was imposed and faithfully collected. Twelve years were required to obtain enough money to pay for the building -- but it's paid for and there are no interest charges on its $10,000,000 cost.

TO the distinction of being one of the busiest authors in two hemispheres Helen Jerome will soon add another. For, according to Sir Barry Jackson, she will be the first feminine playwright ever to have a work presented at his Malvern Festival.

Plans for the coordination of color in home furnishings lines are being given consideration and preliminary steps to put them into effect are scheduled for the Fall season, it was announced yesterday by Margaret Hayden Rorke, managing director of the Textile Color Card Association.

IT was 2 P.M. in the afternoon watch, May 31, 1916, twenty years ago today. A rusty tramp -- the N.J. Fjord -- with the flag of Denmark painted large upon her sides and splotches of red lead showing on her weather-beaten plates steamed slowly across the North Sea.

Sustained activity featured both retail and wholesale trade in the metropolitan areas during the week. While the cool weather slowed down the demand for some items of Summer apparel, department store trade on the whole was good and an average sales increase of 19 to 20 per cent for the week over last year was estimated.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- The words to be put into the mouth of the mechanical man who will be sent along to do the talking for the Labor Department's delegation to the Texas Centennial Exposition were set down today in black and white.

ST. LOUIS, May 30. -- The statement that young men seeking employment now hold a more serious attitude toward their work than those who sought jobs in the 1920-1930 era was made today by John A. Zellers, vice president of Remington Rand, Inc., of Syracuse, N.Y., in an address before the Na tional Federation of Sales Executives.

Memorial Day sermons were preached in synagogues throughout the city yesterday. In one, the Black Legion was attacked as a betrayal of those who fought to preserve democracy, and in another a proposal was made for a day of remembrance of those martyrs who died to advance science and progress.

UELTY fO LXONS: Surgeons, plastic and others, have had to perform their art many times on the features and lh-nbs of Clyde tty, lion and tiger tamer. Four years ago he almost died after an African lion bit and clawed him during rehearsal for the circus at Peru, Ind.
In a copyrighted statement in THE NEW YORK TIMES the Austrian Chancellor, Dr. Kurt Schuschnigg, attempts to make Austro-fascism palatable to the American public.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- First Congressional action on the proposed Equal Rights Amendment sponsored by the National Woman's Party has been taken in a subcommittee report to the House Judiciary Committee favoring a joint resolution.

PARIS, May 30. -- France is passing through the difficult trials of an interregnum. It is not surprising that ferment should develop within at a moment when the government in power has lost its authority and the government to come has not yet assumed responsibility.

HEWLETT HARBOR, L.I., May 30. -- By the power of her putter, Mrs. Henry H. Dietrich defeated Mrs. William R. Kirkland Jr., 1 up, on the thirty-sixth hole at Seawane today and became the 1936 women's metropolitan golf champion. Runner-up to Mrs. Jonathan Thorne last year, when she was Miss Betty Pietsch, Mrs. Dietrich acquired the title after a match filled with much spotty play but many dramatic moments.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 30 (AP). -- Rochester and Montreal divided a Memorial Day twin bill today, the Wings winning the first, 8 -- 7, and the Royals the second, 14 -- 2.

A ten-year program to bring cheap power to American farms is provided for in the Norris-Rayburn Rural Electrification Act, under which the Rural Electrification Administration has just been made a permanent agency, with Morris L. Cooke of Philadelphia remaining at its head.

A plan of reorganization for the Cosden Oil Corporation (Maine) was presented in the Northern District Federal Court of Texas on Thursday by J.J. Kann, Henry Offerman and A.B. Ulman, a bondholders' reorganization committee for general lien 6 per cent bonds due in 1938, under Section 77b of the National Bankruptcy Act.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, May 30. -- "Wine by the Hour" is the slogan a Bucharest wineshop proprietor has discovered to lead to wealth and local fame.

MADRLD, May 30. -- The disquieting situation is growing in Spain. The events of the last twenty-four hours in Madrid and outside have included terrorism, rioting and bloodshed. The country is becoming steeped in social and political conflict.

In discussing the relative slowness of industrial recovery, since the recent movement of reaction culminated, stress was always laid on the absence of new industries as compared with other similar periods, and on the lack of fortunate circumstances surrounding older industries.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, May 30. -- The German-Brazilian commercial agreement will be signed next week. An official said today the one-year agreement prohibits Germany to resell to other nations products bought from Brazil to prevent a flooding of the market.

CHIGAGO, May 30. -- The combination of special sales and ideal shopping weather brought gains little short of sensational to the larger Chicago department stores during May. By comparison with May, 1935, when these special sales events wore lacking, increases for the month averaged nearly 30 per cent.

BAY SHORE, L.I., May 30. -- Members of the Babylon Yacht Club won three of the six races that marked the opening invitation regatta of the season of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association, held today under the auspices of the Bay Shore Yacht Club.

FOLLOWING the established custom of who's who publications, the Richard Blank Publishing Company now offers the second volume of their "America's Young Men." the first having appeared two years ago. It carries the brief and compact biographies of 6,010 American men not more than 45 years of age, an increase of over 1,800 names.

LAKELAND, Fla., May 29. -- Developments of the past few days here and in Washington offer strong evidence that Florida's $146,000,000 cross-State ship canal-project is anything but a dead issue. Its advocates assert that its prospects are brighter than they have been since the fight for more funds began.

ROOSEVELT FIELD, L.I., May 30. -- l=r. rry B~n-t~ter, former husband of Ann tIardlng, arrived here in his plane tonight from Quebec. With ~tm was his attorney, Stanley J. Harte. Referring to his attempt to prevent Miss tEardlng and their daughter from sailing for England, Mr. B~nnt~ter said:

ROME, May 10, 1936. THE sudden death of Ottorino Respighi has given a distinct shock to the music lovers of Italy and the many other countries where the compositions of the Bolognese maestro were known and appreciated.

NEWARK, N.J., May 30. -- The Newark Bears virtually tied the Buffalo Bisons for first place in the International League by defeating Baltimore in both ends of a double-header before 10,000 today. The scores were 10 -- 5 and 9 -- 5.

The reviewer of Claire Warner Churchill's "South of the Sunset" accepts without question the author's spelling and interpretation of the name of the Indian woman who accompanied the Lewis and Clark expedition. It is curious that this error should persist; more curious yet that it should thrive.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, May 30. -- Foreign Minister Nicolas Titulescu's sudden secret departure last night for Belgrade caused much interest in the Rumanian capital today. It was the first time he had traveled by airplane which indicated his hasty departure.

THERE are jests about the English week-end but its results have to be included in history. Among the privileges of the leisured class has been longevity, and as a grand old man of the nineteenth century, always healthy, always in harness, Lord Palmerston was a popular favorite.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., May 30 (AP). -- Governor Paul V. McNutt of Indiana said today on this battlefield shrine of the Civil War that Americans were pledged to keep the nation a land of equality, opportunity, hope and orderly liberty.

The seniors of Barnard College held their annual ball, their last social event on the campus, in Barnard Hall last evening. Among the guests were Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve, Miss Mabel Foote Weeks and Mr. and Mrs. Robert Herr.

TEXAS moved this week into the final and Summer-long phase of the celebration of its first hundred years of independence. The historic dates have passed, duly commemorated with solemn ceremonials at the Alamo, at Goliad and at other shrines of the memorable struggle with Mexico in 1836.

Charles W. Kellogg, chairman of the Engineers Public Service Company, selected recently by a nominating committee of trustees of the Edison Electric Institute as their candidate for the next president of the institute at the election this week, has devoted much time in recent months to the problem of government competition with private utilities.

The First Memorial Day service ever to be held in Times Square caused its busy stream of holiday traffic to pause several times yesterday afternoon, when a program of music, addresses and prayers was, delivered from an improvised stand in the Forty-seventh Street triangle.

LONDON, May 30. -- William Woodward's Omaha, racing two miles for the first time in his gallant career, defeated Lord Derby's Bobsleigh in as thrilling a finish as likely will be seen in England his or any other Summer as he won the Queens Plate at Kempton Park today for his second straight victory on foreign soil.

FOR Sea Scouts the boating season is now in full swing. As Winter merges into Spring they overhaul their craft, working after school and over week-ends; during May they embark on preliminary cruises, trying out their sea legs after months ashore; and with June and vacation time 29,000 boys and their leaders cast off for long voyages upon the coastal waters and the inland lakes and rivers of the country.

The elimination round for high school teachers of upper New York State and Connecticut who are entered in the Constitution contest for teaching plans and articles being conducted by THE NEW YORK TIMES will extend from June 2 through June 25 and will be divided into eight districts.

ROME, May 30. -- The end of war finances is foreshadowed by an official announcement today that subscriptions to the loan floated last September to provide funds for the East African enterprise will close definitely July 31 and by today's Cabinet decision to authorize the Italian Credit Consortium for Public Works to found an autonomous section to finance public works in Ethiopia.
When the Colonial Line steamer Cambridge docked at the foot of Rector Street at 10 A.M. yesterday, it became known that a 24-year-old passenger had been lost overboard at 1:40 o'clock in the morning.
MINEOLA, L.I., May 30. -- The new police emergency truck equipped with a two-mile searchlight and two 1,000-watt floodlights has been placed in operation by the Nassau County Police Department.

THIS isn't quite the book to stick in one's coat pocket before starting out to do the cathedrals of France in ten days. It isn't quite a "new 'Golden Bough' of architecture," though Mr. Hamlin's description of it in those words is understandable.

BRUSSELS, May 29. -- As a result of the Parliamentary elections in Belgium, confusion has been added to an already confused situation. The success of the newly born Fascists and extremists is one fact that stands out. "Fascism is here to stay," a member of the long-suffering middle class put it.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., May 30. -- The Riding Club of East Hampton opened its clubhouse today. William C. Morgan, president, and several committees are planning for various activities, which include a one-day horse show in August, weekly junior riding and jumping contests, gymkhanas and hunt meetings.

CONTRARY to the advance notices, this novel is not "a study of the struggle between communism and Catholicism for a young man's soul," but is rather a loosely told story of a young, impoverished writer's life in contemporary Greenwich Village, with the main stress on an unhappy love affair and the fakery and poignancy of a bohemian existence.
GENEVA, May 30. -- The League of Nations advisory committee on opium and other narcotics paused for a few humorous moments today over whether to include among these "narcotics" tea and coffee.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 30. -- The fourth annual faculty-alumni forum on current questions will mark the 189th commencement week at Princeton University, according to the program announced here today by Dr. Wilson Farrand, '86, chairman of the commencement committee and clerk of the board of trustees.

WHEN the fighting was over and done with Brother Pascual, that gigantic friar, called "Senor El Keed" to him. "When you come south," said the friar, "there is trouble. * * * Consider this. * * * A peon is flogged, and that was too bad.

Recently an article appeared, entitled, "Many Radio Features Disliked by Children." Of course, it was the report of a committee of mothers and teachers from one small school. It did not seem representative of the likes of children I know.

Trailing by two points with four events to go, Curtis High School drew on its strength in the field events and took the mile relay to triumph handily yesterday in Wagner College's first annual invitation Interscholastic track and field meet at Wagner field, Grymes Hill, S.I.

ASBURY PARK, N.J. -- With the Decoration Day week-end officially opening the bathing season and a full schedule of sports activities well under way here, municipal officials are shaping final plans for the reopening of the Hall of Nations Museum in the beachfront Convention Hall.

The Roosevelt Administration's proposal to raise additional revenue by taxing the undistributed profits of corporations was criticized last week by Senator James Couzens of Michigan as the "most carelessly drawn and undeveloped" proposal he ever had seen and as unwise at this time.

THE Queen Mary, which has been "talking" her way across the ocean with an ultra-modern radio equipment, will be the center of broadcasting activities tomorrow afternoon. A giant hook-up, with the English network wired into the international all-wave circuit, will handle what the broadcasters describe as "one of the most colorful and complex broadcasts ever staged."

PHILADELPHIA, May 30. -- In the most thrilling Davis Cup match played in this country since 1927, Donald Budge came back from the jaws of defeat today to save an apparently lost cause for the American tennis team at the Germantown Cricket Club.

THIS English version of the standard German biography of Friedrich Engels was produced at the instigation of that tireless disseminator of Marxian doctrine, G.D.H. Cole; and in a brief introduction Mr. Cole states his motive as follows:

When the programs of important organizations of women in New Jersey are resumed in the Fall leadership of the outstanding groups will be in the hands of the women whose photographs are reproduced herewith. Most of them were installed following their election prior to the disbanding of their clubs for the Summer.

DURING the years when Whitman was revising and issuing successive editions of his "Leaves of Grass" he was also engaged in extensive journalistic activities. Numerous articles were poured from his pen into the pages of the journal known as Life Illustrated; articles which, for the most part, he did not regard as of permanent interest, and which in many cases he did not even dignify with his signature.

CHICAGO, May 30. -- Late inning rallies of five runs in each game paved the way for Pittsburgh's Pirates to take both ends of the holiday double-header from the Cubs, 7 to 5, and 11 to 7, before an overflow crowd of 43,332 today.

In 1897 Lord Chancellor HALSBURY, who lived to be 98, appointed to the King's Bench Division of the High Court of Justice the eminent judge and "character" who is just dead at 86. In popular estimation the judge may have been overcrowed by the "character.''

RECENTLY an amusing story was published about the small boy who inveigled his father, a college president, into signing his name on bits of paper every evening until an inquiry revealed that he was bartering the autographs among playmates for marbles, knives, tops and such-like treasure.

In the nation's capital at noon tomorrow, a convocation of the most surprising aspects will be formally opened in the United States Government Auditorium. Where hundreds of delegates had been expected for the triennial conference of the Associated Country Women of the World, thousands have registered for this first American assembly.

In the case decided by the Supreme Court last February the utilities sought desperately, but in vain, to make the Tennessee Valley Authority and its power program the issue. The Administration's lawyers insisted that the only question before the court was whether the Federal Government might dispose of the surplus power generated at Muscle Shoals, and for that purpose acquire from the Alabama Power Company certain transmission lines leading to neighboring markets.

The St. Peter's College baseball team was overwhelmed yesterday at Lincoln Park, Jersey City, by the Montclair State Teachers College nine by a score of 17 to 1. The Indians hammered three St. Peter's pitchers for sixteen hits. Zinn, the Montclair left fielder, led the assault with two home runs and two singles.
DES MOINES, Iowa, May 30 (AP). -- Iowa will vote Monday in a primary having at stake the immediate political future of the State's Republican Presidential possibility, Senator Lester Jesse Dickinson.

Although the speeding Queen Mary marked up a new record yesterday in the total number of miles covered in a day, she he yet to equal the average speed set by the Normandie on her best but slightly shorter day.

JERUSALEM, May 30. -- The Palestine Government today warned all mukhtars (village chieftains) that there would be collective punitive measures unless the cutting of telephone wires, bomb explosions, attempts to demolish railway lines and other acts of brigandage ceased.

IN new gardens in suburban areas poison ivy is often a serious pest. Even where it does not actually come inside the garden wall, if it lurks near by it will cause trouble. Visitors to the country, ignorant of this innocent-looking enemy, too late discover that they have been subjected to its annoying infection.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 30 (AP). -- Two hundred and seventy-seven cadets, fourteen of whom are from New York State, will receive diplomas at graduation exercises of the United States Military Academy June 12. The exercises will take place at the base of Battle Monument on historic Trophy Point.

HAVANA, May 30. -- A mass meeting demanding the amplest amnesty law was held last night in the building of the Spanish regional society Centro Isturianos under the auspices of the Committee for Political and Social Amnesty.

WITH Spring, even to city dwellers, comes the mental picture of a garden, though it be but a dream garden -- a garden which they yearn for, but scarcely expect to own. Cooped up in the city, except for brief Summer vacations, they recall those few priceless weeks in the country and wish for a garden to roam in from April to November.

With another public offering scheduled for next month in Baltimore, the government is making slow but steady progress in disposing of the nearly 2,000,000 drought hides and skins, which it held at the beginning of the year, according to comment by tanners here yesterday.

ABOUT 500 persons, most of them police dignitaries, gathered in the War Memorial Building in Trenton, N.J., last week to behold the latest method of running criminals to earth. It is an advance for which Colonel H. Norman Schwarzkopf, superintendent of New Jersey's State Police, receives credit.

The biggest baseball crowd of the year yesterday welcomed the Yankees back to the Stadium and saw a typical exhibition of Yankee hitting strength together with the best pitching performance the club has had as the McCarthymen downed the Senators in both ends of a double-header.

ERNEST SCHELLING, as conductor of the municipally maintained Baltimore Symphony Orchestra, gave eleven compositions their first Baltimore hearing in the course of the ten concerts of the recently terminated season.

LAWRENCEVILLE N.J., May 30. -- Bringing the track and field season to a close, the Lawrenceville School team captured the trophy for Group 4 in the New Jersey, State prep school championship today. Totaling 92 points, the home squad led its nearest competitor St. Benedict's, by 39.

TO the "nine old men in black robes" of popular objurgation, Professor Fred Rodell has now added the fifty-five youngish men in knee breeches who wrote the Constitution of the United States, and his complaint is much the same, that what they intended was a let and a hindrance to "pure democracy."

SELINSGROVE, Pa., May 30. -- Dr. Edward Drew, surgeon of Philadelphia, will present as a gift to Susquehanna University at the closing dinner of the 78th session on Monday, a portrait of Susquehanna's president, painted by Elmer Snyder ou Philadelphia.

IN reference to the First National Exhibition of American Art at International Building, Rockefeller Center, the following letter has been received from Nicholas Haz, artist, author, lecturer and teacher:

THE case of Stalin is somewhat different from that of Hitler or Mussolini, because he is not the "founder" of the power he wields but its inheritor -- and something more. In the Fall of 1929, after interviewing Stalin, I wrote that he was "the inheritor of Lenin's mantle."

Applications for the position of assistant superintendent in the school system to fill a vacancy which will occur with the retirement of Frank Hankinson, in charge of Districts 53 and 54, Richmond, on Sept. 1, must be filed not later than tomorrow in the office of the associate superintendent in charge of personnel at 500 Park Avenue.

LEAVING the fleshpots of Hollywood, with which he dallied none too successfully in some of his more recent novels, Ernest Haycox has now returned to the more congenial field of his earlier successes and produced a first-class fighting tale of the gun-governed West of the Eighteen Eighties.

OF the first national Dance Congress and Festival, which came to a close on Monday after an eight-day session of performances and conferences, it is incumbent to speak a few polite but sorrowful words. Conditioned from the start by having been hastily organized, it offered a series of almost completely futile exhibitions, and in the last two or three days, when the conferences began, quite literally talked itself to death.

More than seventy-five witnesses will be called by Special Prosecutor Hiram C. Todd to testify against the six men accused of conspiracy in the Drukman murder case, it was said yesterday. The trial starts tomorrow before Supreme Court Justice Erskine C. Rogers in an extraordinary term of the court in Brooklyn.

A baccalaureate service today at 4 P.M. in St. Paul's Chapel on the campus will mark the opening of Columbia University's 182d commencement, which will continue until Tuesday evening, when, at outdoor exercises in front of the Low Memorial Library, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, will confer degrees and certificates and diplomas.

TO see The Players revival of George Ade's "The County Chairman" the other evening was to realize how completely our attitude has changed toward the small rural town. We are critical of it now. In 1903, writing of some generalized Mississippi Valley community, Mr. Ade was humorous and appreciative.

' TWAS ever thus in the career of Allyn Joslyn, one of the more somber of the new comedians. Tossed from the schools of New York to the Hedgerow Theatre, and from the Theatre Guild to the gilded radio studios,' this young man of 31 has had little time to think of being funny, much less to think up jokes.

Economic sanctions are "hostile acts short of assault," that probably Would bring war, it is argued by Bernard M. Batch, President Wilson's chairman of the War Industries Board, who points the way to neutrality in an article on that subject in the June issue of current History.
RADIO'S showmen usually look to June as the month that inspires program themes allied with roses, bugs, brides and graduates. This year it will be different.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 30. -- Many high-ranking polo players preparing for the start of the annual Meadow Brook Club 20-goal tournaments next Saturday engaged in practice contests today, with Greentree's 7-to-6 triumph over the Gulf Stream quartet featuring the activity.

OVER a period of a good many years little girls from 9 to 12 have continued to enjoy Mrs. Rankin's "Dandelion Cottage," that pleasant story of four girls who kept house in a tiny cottage. For in truth the castle in Spain of many a little girl is a playhouse sufficiently practical to admit of real, though small scale, housekeeping.
BOSTON, May 30 (AP). -- An army plane zoomed out of a loop and nose-dived into Boston Harbor late today, carrying one mechanic to his death and causing "probable fatal" injuries to another.

Completely surprised by the move of officials in Washington to have the proposed Federal Pure Food and Drugs Act provide for grade labeling of food products, using the s-called "A-B-C' method, representatives of cnning, wholesaling and large chain-store interests gathered their forces together last week to renew their fight for descriptive labeling.

FLOWER shows continue to be the order of the day in garden-club activities. On Wednesday, the joint show of the Great Neck Garden Club and the Great Neck Woman's Club at the Great Neck Community House will open at 3 o'clock in the afternoon.

Incorporation of the World Center for Women's Archives, for which preliminary organization meetings were held last Fall, was announced yesterday, with Mrs. Inez Haynes Irwin as chairman of the board of directors. Temporary headquarters for the institution, which is intended to assemble and classify documents relating to feminine contributions to the progress of the race, have been established at 40 East Forty-second Street.

Contending that the United States through its trade agreement vith tranee will be drawn into the tariff jockeying and bickering which has characterized European trade and tariff relations for years, Dr. Walter R. Peabody, sorQtary of th Ameulcan Tariff League, yesterday predicted that the agreement will be subject to constant modifications and changes throughout its life.

NO kind of catalogue is in greater need of annotation than a list of new auto-biographies and volumes of reminiscences. Biographies do not, as a rule, require such a supplement. When a new life in announced, it is ordinarily concerned with a celebrity so well known that we can anticipate whether its main interest will be literary, or political, or religious, or what not.

WHAT is believed to have been the first airplane towed glider flight in the naval service was most successfully completed at Pensacola by Lieut. Commander Ralph S. Barnaby recently. The flight was made from the station field using an NY training landplane for the towing ship.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, May 30. -- The British amateur golf championship relinquished by Lawson Little today went to 22-year-old Hector Thomson, first home-bred Scot to capture the crown in eleven years.

Closing with a rush that electrified 25,000 persons, Firethorn was up in the last stride at Belmont Park yesterday to nip Granville on the post and win by a nose in one of the most thrilling finishes the famous Suburban Handicap has known in all its fifty runnings.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- In a few weeks the first national agreement covering protection of railroad workers displaced by mergers or consolidations will go into effect. Written by spokesmen for 85 per cent of the nation's rail mileage and chiefs of twenty standard railway unions, this voluntary compact guarantees for five years payment of specific sums to employes who may be affected by consolidations.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- The Smithsonian Institution has recently placed on view the firefighting methods used in America. Exhibits range from bucket brigades of Colonial times to the magnificent mechanized apparatus used by metropolitan cities today.
ALBANY, May 30. -- Governor Lehman today vetoed the bill of Assemblyman Swartz, Buffalo Republican, to lower the transfer tax on stock selling for less than $20 a share.

SALEM, N.H., May 30. -- Elwood Sachsenmaier's Roman Soldier, burdened with the top impost of 126 pounds, rushed out of the stretch today to account for the $3,500 added Decoration Day Handicap before a crowd of 45,000, the largest in Rockingham Park's running horse history.

BOSTON, May 29. -- New England is busy with regional plans for flood relief under the Copeland bill now pending in Congress. The calamity of this year may not be repeated for a century, and it may happen again next year. The money damages, estimated at the time at $200,000,000, are now set at about half that sum.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, May 30. -- The Soviet Legation here has sheltered since yesterday a Russian citizen, Feodor Matvejev, a cooperative store manager of East Karelia. He cannot leave the legation without risk of being arrested by the Finnish police.

MOSCOW, May 29. -- Soviet Russia, already glorying in a rapidly rising birth rate while births in capitalistic countries are declining, is framing a complex program for further increasing the population which is certain to have momentous consequences.

MR. BACON is a man of catholic distastes. If you begin by noting that to him capitalism and communism are "two sides of one abysm," you can then go on to see with what little idolatry he writes verses about the Democrat, the Republican, the Stock Exchange, President Roosevelt, the Mellons and the Morgans, Karl Marx, the Townsend Plan, the Communist, Hearst, Hitler, Father Coughlin, the Southern lynchers, the Supreme Court and Herbert Hoover.

Interest rates for call and time loans were raised one-quarter of 1 per cent in May, the first change since Oct. 20, 1935. The quotation of three-quarters of 1 per cent for call loans on the New York Stock Exchange, carried forward from April, was raised to a flat 1 per cent on May 11, and continued so to the month-end.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- Senator Vandenberg in leading the attack on the Florida and Maine relief projects today asserted that the amendments were designed to make Congress "share the responsibility with President Roosevelt" for starting them.

Driving Irving Prince from the mound in the seventh inning during a five-run rally the Savage School baseball team turned back St. John's University, 6 to 4, in the final game of the season for both teams at Carey Field in Brooklyn yesterday.

A steadily increasing percentage of cases of typhoid fever contracted out of the city by vacationists and brought back with them, caused Health Commissioner John L. Rice to issue a Summer warning yesterday to those leaving for the country.
In THE TIMES recently I read an article under the caption: "Confining the Missouri." I desire to point out the following errors in the article.

ST. LOUIS, May 30 (AP). -- Turning the tables with a barrage of home runs the Cardinals defeated Cincinnati, 7 to 4, today in the nightcap of a double-header after the Reds, with a powerful eighteen-hit attack, had taken the first game, 10 to 1.

Memorial Day ceremonies were held in all towns throughout Staten Island yesterday, with the main affair being held at Hero Park, Tompkinsville, under the joint auspices of the American Legion, the Veterans of Foreign Wars and the United Spanish-American War Veterans.

While the rest of the nation was commemorating Memorial Day, 5,000 members of the American Youth Congress and affiliated organizations celebrated United Youth Day yesterday by parading from Madison Square to Houston and Wooster Streets, where in a mass meeting they demanded jobs for youth, attacked individual capitalists and shouted for the end of war and fascism.

THE list of important and interesting paintings being assembled for the Texas Centennial Art Exhibition at Dallas this Summer is steadily lengthening. Dr. Robert Harshe and Daniel Catton Rich, who are in charge of the preparations, have already reported a number of pictures obtained that would by themselves make the event notable.

THE list of important and interesting paintings being assembled for the Texas Centennial Art Exhibition at Dallas this Summer is steadily lengthening. Dr. Robert Harshe and Daniel Catton Rich, who are in charge of the preparations, have already reported a number of pictures obtained that would by themselves make the event notable.

ABOARD THE QUEEN MARY, En Route to New York, May 30. -- From noon yesterday until noon today, a twenty-five-hour run on the westward course, the Queen Mary steamed 766 miles at an average speed of 30.64 knots, breaking the Normandie's record of 754 nautical miles for a day's run.

ANNAPOLIS, May 30. -- June week, the commencement period at the Naval Academy, opened officially today with the Army and Navy meeting in track and baseball rivalry -- and a water carnival, an entirely new feature introduced by Rear Admiral Sellers, the superintendent, in which historic annals of the navy and one of its traditional customs were portrayed.

PARIS, May 30. -- Great Britain's hopes for a successful defense of the Davis Cup teetered today as H.W. (Bunny) Austin pulled a ligament in his right leg and defaulted to Marcel Bernard of France in the quarter-final round of the French hard court tennis champion ships.

Where To, the sturdy bay mare owned by Fagan Surgeon, won the championship stake for hunters or jumpers at the Fourth Annual Staten Island Horse Show, held on the grounds of the Headquarters Troop Fifty-first Cavalry Brigade Grounds, West Brighton, yesterday.

IN addition to proving what folks have thought all along, that the double-feature system of cinema exhibition is almost universally unpopular, the Warner Brothers' poll of opinion on the question has been a source of considerable innocent merriment to those privileged to peep at the replies that have come in thus far.
WASHINGTON, May 30. -- Business activity is being maintained at a level substantially higher than a year ago, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly review.

LONDON, May 30. -- In keeping Memorial Day here Ray Atherton, Counselor of the United States Embassy, placed a wreath on the grave of the Unknown Warrior in Westminster Abbey. Uniformed attaches of the embassy and a group of Americans stood in a driving rain in Whitehall when the American Legion commander, Gilbert Carr, placed a wreath at the Cenotaph.
MOSCOW, May 30. -- Jose R. Capablanca of Cuba and M. Botwinnik, the Soviet champion, drew their games today in the thirteenth round of the international chess masters tournament.

ALBANY, May 30 (AP). -- Cooperation of the Greater New York Police Department has increased the State Labor Department's intervention in labor disputes almost fourfold, A.J. Portenar, director of the Division of Industrial Relations, reports in the May issue of the department's industrial bulletin.

ONCE again, and for the first time in sixteen years, much is being heard, as the national conventions draw near, of the "Old Guard." Since 1920 that little group of Republicans -- political giants, would-be giants and retainers -- whose chief desire is to keep the nation quiet and conservative, has excited but small attention.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., May 30. -- One man was killed and fourteen persons were injured, four seriously, last night and this morning in two automobile collisions in Northern Westchester County, one on Bedford Road, near Chappaqua, and the other on Route 22 above Armonk.

IT was several years ago that Mussolini declared that one of the problems to which he was dedicating most care and attention was that of creating a political and economic machine capable of carrying on the theory and practice of fascism even when he will no longer be here to make its most important decisions and steer it round the most dangerous corners.

MOSCOW, May 30 (AP). -- A Soviet luxury train started on an experimental run today. The least of its appointments is a barber shop. It also carries a nursery car with toys, complete bath compartments, individual radios, and a train crew dressed in the manner of Broadway doormen.
TO understand what has happened in France one must recall the traditional political alignment and how it had been transformed before the recent national election.

On the theory that most women need consistent education on matters of finance, Women Investors of America, which is headed by Miss Cathrine Curtis of New York, will sponsor the First Finance Congress for Women Wednesday and Thursday at the Palmer House in Chicago.
PARIS, May 28. -- The success of the Gardenia Club's Gainsborough ball is forecast to foster quantities of large felt hats, trimmed with ostrich plumes, at the races this June.

LATONIA, Ky., May 30 (AP). -- Myrtlewood, queen of the Western sprinters, gave another brilliant display of her speed today when she easily accounted for the twenty-third running of the Quickstep Handicap before a large Memorial Day crowd.

Repots can the needs of inhabitants of Southern mountain and other regions and on welfare work being carried on were given Friday at a meeting of the directors of the Save the Children Fund, the American branch of the International Save the Children Fund of Geneva.

ATTENTION of college administrators throughout the country has been focused on the fraternity question by the recommendations contained in the recent report of the committee for the survey of social life in Dartmouth College.
More than 600,000 spectators were attracted to major sports events throughout the United States yesterday.

CLEVELAND, May 29. -- The Cleveland Democratic organization broke sharply with Senator Robert J. Bulkley at its biennial county convention this week, and will go into the Fall campaign in this industrial Roosevelt stronghold with a permanent schism.

DESPITE the fact that there is, on the average, one filling station or garage for every mile and a half of surfaced highway, more than 1,000,000 drivers ran out of gasoline last year, the American Automobile Association reports.

SOME millenniums ago a glacier, lumbering down from the Arctic, with plenty of time at its disposal, scooped a quantity of sand, gravel and assorted rock off Southern New England, carried it a short distance out to sea and laid it down in the form of a good-sized fish-shaped island.

WHEN the Queen Mary steams up New York Harbor she will mark another step in the shipbuilding rivalry between nations which has resulted in turning out in recent years a group of the largest and fastest ships yet constructed.

The berthing of the liner Queen Mary at her new North River pier will provide as great a thrill to some persons as will the majesty of her appearance to others as she proceeds up the bay and into the river on the last leg of her maiden voyage.

W.G. Gottlieb of New York has been elected vice commodore of the Sands Point Y.C. at Port Washington to succeed Hugo Klein, who resigned because of a long stay in Europe on business. N.H. Vanderwall, commodore for the past two seasons, has been installed as "commodore emeritus," a newly created rank.

" On the afternoon of May 28, 1936," wrote the Chinese historian Hi-Ho-Hum, "radio listeners in the Eastern United States were the recipients of a rare treat. It was a broadcast from the new superliner Queen Mary, then somewhere off the west coast of Ireland, on her maiden voyage from Southampton to New York.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- Representative Marion A. Zioncheck of Washington State renewed his frequent contact with the police tonight when he capped a tumultuous twenty-four-hour round by ending up in a local police station charged with disorderly conduct.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 30. -- With parades, speeches, volleys by firing squads and the sounding of "taps," every community in Westchester County honored its soldier dead today and paid tribute to the veterans of four wars. Each city, town and village had its own ceremonies.

During the coming week wo new outboard hydroplane motors of the Class X variety, all but unknown on this side of the Atlantic, will be tested secretly on the Hackensack River to provide some advance indications whether a pair of young Americans can expect to triumph on July 4 at Paris for the richest prizes known to the sport of motor boating.

THE third annual Reading music festival will be held in Albright College Stadium, Reading, Pa., tomorrow and Tuesday nights. A chorus of 1,000 voices, under the direction of Willy Richter and Ralph Fisher Smith -- the latter director of music in the public schools of Reading -- will be heard in numerous selections, accompanied by a symphony orchestra of 125 pieces.

DETROIT, May 30. -- The Black Legion was described today by investigators as a group of loosely federated night-riding bands operating in several States without central discipline or common purpose beyond the enforcement by lash and pistol of individual leaders' notions of "Americanism."

The roof of the Hotel Commodore has been transformed into a camp for city children, with trees, a lake and stream stocked with live fish, as an exhibit by the Children's Welfare Federation for the Boys Exposition, which will open tomorrow at the hotel and continue for three days.
The annual Long Island women's golf championship opens at the Wheatley Hills Golf Club in East Williston tomorrow, with Mrs. Marion Turpie Lake defending her title against a strong field.

IN the ancient phrase of the prize ring, the movies emerge from the vigorous trial to which they have been subjected in this book "somewhat disfigured and a bit groggy, but still going strong." Apparently, a goodly proportion of the contributors were glad of the chance to give them a good, sound thwack.

Verdi's "La Traviata" was accorded its first presentation of the popular season at the Metropolitan Opera House last night before a large holiday audience. Judging from the liberal applause which followed every number, this particular opera was wisely chosen by the management for the special occasion.

CHARLES WILLIAM JANSON was an intelligent, knowledgeable Englishman, who succumbed to the romantic lure of the New World and, wishing to make his fortune, came to America in 1793. He spent thirteen years in the United States and was admitted to practice at the American bar, but his search for lucrative employment was unavailing, so he returned to England.

DETROIT, May 30. -- Michigan's investigation of terrorism by the Knights of the Black Legion, an investigation in which all agencies of the State from the Governor down, county authorities in six localities and several city forces are cooperating, was halted at State lines today as the decision of the Federal Government on whether its agencies would intervene was held in abeyance.

The berthing of the liner Queen Mary will be the assignment of twelve tugs with a combined pulling power of 9,000 horsepower in commend of Captain Herbert Miller. Docking operations will be started at 3:30 P.M. tomorrow when the tides will be quiet, the line announced yesterday.

FOLLOWING June commencement exercises approximately 150,000 young men and women will leave the cloistered halls of American colleges and universities. Doctors, masters, bachelors -- diploma in hand -- they face the future expectantly, ambitiously, confidently, critically.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- William T. McMahon, who has been knocking on the door to marathon championships for four years, finally hammered his way inside today with a record-breaking National A.A.U. victory that likely earned him a post on America's Olympic team.

OF all musical hobbies none is more absorbing to its devotees than playing and collecting mouth organs, otherwise known as harmonicas. Monarchs and millionaires, schoolboys and dignified grown-ups, professional musicians and the veriest tyros delight in the strains of these lowly instruments of music.

A plan of "voluntary volume allocation" will be instituted by at least two of the groups into which the membership of the Industrial Council of Coat, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc., has been divided for stabilization purposes, it was announced yesterday by Samuel Klein, executive director.
PRINCETON, N.J., May 30. -- Scoring eleven runs on twelve hits, the Princeton baseball team today defeated Columbia, 11 -- 1, and moved into fifth place in the Eastern Intercollegiate League.
TOMORROW in Macon, Ga., Wesleyan College, oldest chartered college in the world exclusively for women, holds its centennial.

CHICAGO, May 30. -- Objection to a third-party Presidential ticket this Fall was voiced today by Governor Floyd B. Olson of Minnesota, who declared in a letter read here that this might defeat "our liberal President" and elect a "Fascist Republican."

THE San Carlo Opera Company will be brought to Jones Beach this Summer for a season of outdoor opera and ballet performances, which will open June 27 with a production of "Carmen." This will be followed the next night by "Aida."

Although the beaches within the metropolitan area and those adjacent to it were swept by a rather chilly west wind, along with a threatening or overcast sky, the Memorial Day crowds patronized them freely yesterday. In some resorts record crowds were reported.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 30. -- For five months last Fall and Winter the police of seven counties in Western Ireland went over the countryside giving a friendly warning to the people that a woman was coming to see them on an unusual errand.

While the giant liner Queen Mary sped through calm seas toward New York yesterday, officials of welcoming committees and Anglo-American societies, as well as the official welcoming parties representing the city, State and nation, completed last-minute details for a reception comparable in dimensions to the liner herself.

The Smetana Festival at the National Theatre in Prague, which began May 10, came to a close last week with a performance of that composer's opera "The Devil's Wall," under the direction of J. Charvat. The festival cycle of Smetana's compositions started the afternoon of May 10, with the playing of the six symphonic poems forming the set "My Country" (Ma Vlast).

BEACH HAVEN, N.J., May 30. -- Fifteen hundred men, women and children took part here today in a memorial service honoring the seventy-six officers and men of the dirigible Akron and the blimp J-3, which searched for the Akron, who lost their lives when the two craft fell into the sea within fifteen hours of each other in April, 1933.

OTTAWA, May 30 (Canadian Press). -- Sinister influences in Europe which seek to promote atheism and materialism and to undermine and destroy things formerly held sacred must not be allowed to gain a foothold in Canada, Prime Minister Mackenzie King declared in a speech here last night.

RYE, N.Y., May 30. -- The race meet held this afternoon at the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club here under the auspices of the Fairfield and Westchester hounds was attended by a large gathering of members of society.
WASHINGTON, May 30. -- The Navy Department estimates that the cost to the German dirigible Hindenburg for the use of the facilities at Lakehurst, N.J., on each trip is between $3,000 and $5,000.

NEWARK, N.J., May 30. -- Hollyrood Perry, bay trotter owned by Eugene Carpenter, and Elizabeth N.J., 2-year-old bay filly pacer from the Newbrook Stables, annexed the feature events of the holiday matinee sponsored By the Road Horse Association of New Jersey at Weequahic Park today.

AMID predictions ranging in tone from dire to highly optimistic, railroads of the East, bowing to the Interstate Commerce Commission's order of Feb. 28, will reduce their passenger fares tomorrow to 2 cents a mile in coaches and 3 cents a mile in Pullman cars.

TELEVISION promises a place for women announcers, because good looks as well as a pleasant voice are the qualifications, according to London impresarios who have selected Jasmine Bligh, age 22, and Elizabeth Cowell, age 23, as the first announcers of the BBC television service.

Senator BRYD of Virginia asked a question last week which interests a great many people. He wanted to know why the Government's expenditures are steadily increasing, in the face of a steady improvement of business. During the fiscal year 1932-33, which covered the worst stage of the depression, including the period of the bank panic, the Government spent a total of $5,100,000,000.

THE quips outnumber the tips in this little book of gay and refreshing verse from an English garden. Indeed, there is a charming flippancy scattered here and there throughout these pages; there are some good-humoredly stabbing rhymes, and garden pests show a tendency to predominate in the pictures.

THE town libraries in which Dreiser is still suspect will be rather certain to have a full shelf of seductive confectionery by Miss Sawyer. She has the recipe and the technique by which the best literary meringues take shape and a sweet-toothed audience has a way of finding the jam pot.

DUBLIN, May 29. -- While the findings of the British commission investigating conditions in Northern Ireland, particularly as they affect the Catholic minority, have been much discussed in the Free State, members of the government have studiously refrained from making any comment.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- The Summer season opened for Atlantic City this week-end with some 100,000 of the annual influx already in the hotels or opening their cottages. The Atlantic City Beach Patrol is on duty to protect the bathers and seek to preserve its last year's record of no drownings on this beach.

IT is just a hundred years since Texas won its independence, and here is an exceedingly interesting book to celebrate the centenary. This collection of photographs not only shows the progress and modern prosperity of Texas but especially its wide variety in scene, in agriculture and industry and in social and historic background.

WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP). -- Leaving the Federal District Attorney to worry over the contempt proceedings against Dr. Francis E. Townsend, a House investigating committee arranged today to make a further study next week of his old-age pension plan.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 30. -- Complaint that present rates for cargoes between Pacific Coast ports are unduly low have been laid before the Railroad Commission by H.C. Cantelow, manager of the Pacific Coastwise Conference. The complaint has resulted in the commission's beginning an investigation.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- The White House informed the two major broadcasting chains today that President Roosevelt desires to avoid being placed in the position of "competing or conflicting" with the Republican National Convention in Cleveland.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 30. -- The return of direct relief administration to the municipalities last month has produced a reduction to 1,700 cases at a cost of $40,000 a month from 3,105 cases costing about $80, 000 a month under the State Emergency Relief Administration.
The competition for supremacy on the International Air Trade routes will be decided finally by personnel.

PARIS. THE fundamental incapacity of the French mind really to sympathize with a work which is not logical or precise is illustrated by the tendency of the Parisian dramatic critic to classify any play which ventures into the borderland of the unreal as "une feerie," a fairy story.

JERUSALEM, May 29. -- The present disturbances in Palestine indicate, first, that nothing but force and iron-handed methods can put Eastern hotheads in their place, and secondly, that Moslem religious fanaticism is a fire that once kindled is difficult to extinguish.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., May 30. -- Residents of this resort are celebrating the fiftieth anniversary of the founding of Tuxedo Park with a two-day program of sports and social events. It was on June 1, 1886, that the late Pierre Lorillard presided at the official opening of the Tuxedo Club.
TROY, N.Y., May 30. -- Class reunions and the annual alumnae meeting and luncheon comprised commencement activities at Russell Sage College today.

More than half of the 12,661 families aided by private family welfare agencies in this city last month suffered from problems unrelated to unemployment, Laurence M. Marks, chairman of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee, said yesterday.

OPERATION of the United States Army Air Corps is a great deal more than the tactical flying of airplanes in the pursuit, bombardment and attack categories. At the huge plant of the Materiel Division at Wright Field, Dayton, under command, as division chief, of Brig. Gen. A.W. Robins, the whole technical functions are centered.

Franciszek Dolezal, Under-Secretary of Commerce and Industry in Poland, who is on his first visit here, predicted an increase in trade between Poland and the United States based upon the rise of cotton imports recently recorded by his bureau of the government.

It was an excellent idea to put together an omnibus volume of the tales which originally appeared in "Rootabaga Stories" and in '"Rootabaga Pigeons." In this well made, well printed book, the reader is sure of finding his favorite story whether it is the lovely "White Horse Girl and Blue Wind Boy" from "Rootabaga Stories" or "Deep Red Roses" from "Rootabaga Pigeons."
ADDIS ABABA, May 30 (AP). -- Export of silver thalers and precious metals from Ethiopia was forbidden today by the Italian administration.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- The legislation that extends unlisted trading on national securities Exchanges beyond tomorrow will not result in any rapid-fire change in the existing situation, inasmuch as the principal immediate result will be to permit continuation of the unlisted trading provision in such securities as had that status before March 1, 1934.

Declaring "we are paying the price today in the State of New York," as a result of an influx of "several hundred thousand men and women who are largely un-American, whose alien vote controls the vote in the City of New York," the Rev. Dr. J. Stanley Durkee, pastor of the Plymouth Congregational Church of the Pilgrims, Orange and Hicks Streets, Brooklyn, advocated yesterday that we "destroy the alien vote."
Several month-end changes have been announced by financial organizations.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 31 (UP). -- A gun battle in which five men were wounded following a walk-out of iron-ore miners in the Birmingham area tonight brought a complete shut-down of the workings supplying this city's giant steel mills.

MERCERSBURG, Pa., May 31. -- Dr. Boyd Edwards, headmaster of Mercersburg Academy, urged on the graduating class of 101 today that they cooperate with those who seek the same objectives as theirs, although language and modes of thought be different.
The following table gives the high and low prices for 1936, as well as last price, for all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange that were not traded in last week:

KEY WEST, Fla., May 31. -- All the churches of this city held thanksgiving services today for President Roosevelt's approval of a $4,300,000 Public Works loan to rebuild the "oversea highway" to the mainland. The loan will restore communication with the mainland, give eighteen months' work to hundreds of unemployed and assure a share in Florida's rich tourist traffic.

BANGKOK, Siam, May 31. -- Reports of increasing intimacy between Siam and Japan have been discredited by the Siamese Foreign Minister, Luang Pradit Manudharm, in an important statement he made through The Bangkok Times.
PARIS, May 31 (AP). -- Armies of strikers holding metal factories in the Paris region dwindled today, but the government was disturbed by the prospect of a new wave of strikes Tuesday.

CHICAGO, May 31. -- Twelve passengers and the crew of three members on a huge air liner of the Transcontinental Western Air Lines had an almost miraculous escape from death tonight when the ship struck a tree and a house on South Kilbourne Avenue and then settled with a dull thud in a vacant lot.
The letters in your issue of May 23 in regard to milk in paper or glass containers serve to emphasize the folly of the action of the State in attempting to regulate prices in a competitive industry.

FARMINGDALE, L.I., May 31. -- Another field was thrown open to polo with appropriate ceremonies today when the new playing surface and stands of the Bethpage Polo and Riding Club were the scene of their first game before a crowd of 5,000, some of whom also sat in parked automobiles along the side boards and across the end.
MAINE, N.Y., May 31. -- A 200-year-old tree has been saved for possibly another 150 years because C.V. McGregor, its owner, refuses to believe that "progress" demands the destruction of beauty.

ORANGE, N.J., May 31. -- Firemen rescued William T. Smith, New York banker, his wife and two daughters from the front porch roof of their home here early today when flames wrecked the two-story frame residence at 462 Berkeley Avenue. Mr. Smith is president of the Harriman Industrial Corporation and a director of numerous corporations.

AMSTERDAM, May 29. -- Prospects of the gold bloc are becoming gradually gloomier. Although Dutch financial circles hesitate to make a definite forecast, the common opinion is that the situation never has been so critical as now.

NEWARK, N.J., May 31. -- The Newark Bears divided a doubleheader with Syracuse before 9,300 fans today. The Chiefs won the first game, 4 -- 3, when Dib Williams hit a home run in the ninth inning. The Bears captured the nightcap, 5 -- 2, on circuit blows by Bill Baker and Ernie Koy in the sixth.

TOKYO, Monday, June 1. -- From today Japanese newspaper readers will see the outside world through the window of a single Japanese news agency closely connected with the government. At midnight Domei Tsushinsha absorbed its only rival, Dentsu, and became the sole agency importing and distributing foreign news in Japan.

Queens civic leaders began considering an appeal to relief authorities in Washington last night as the impasse between Borough President Harvey and Victor F. Ridder, Works Progress Administrator, over the quality of the work done by WPA pavers on Jamaica Avenue remained unbroken.

NEW ORLEANS, May 31. -- There was little change in the cotton market here last week, although there were several spurts of activity in futures contracts. Traders were still waiting for final action by Congress on the Smith bill.

Despite Governor Lehman's announcement that he will not be a candidate for re-election, efforts to get him to reconsider his decision have been continued, it was learned yesterday, and influential Democrats, supporters of President Roosevelt, believe they may be able to draft him.

Many persons of prominence in society here and in London, including leaders of the British colony in this city, will attend the Queen Mary supper dance and fashion show to be held Thursday night in the Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria in connection with the welcoming ceremonial to the liner Queen Mary on her maiden voyage.

ON BOARD THE S.S. DUCHESS OF ATHOLL, May 31 (AP). -- Ann Harding, screen actress who is en route to England with her 7-year-old daughter Jane, refused today to take seriously the news that her former husband, Harry Bannister, had obtained a warrant at Quebec charging her with abduction.

CHICAGO, May 31 (AP). -- The Cubs, defeated in both ends of their double-header by the Pirates yesterday, managed to salvage the final game of the series, 8 to 7, today, but were forced into an extra inning to do it.
LONDON, Ky., May 31 (AP). -- Robbers murdered former Magistrate Reed Taylor and his wife at their store in Keavy, Ky., ten miles from here, last night, while their baby slept in their home near by.

GIBRALTAR, May 31. -- Bound for London to open his personal campaign "to obtain justice," meaning the recovery of his throne and the world's recognition of the wrongs against his country, Haile Selassie, self-exiled Emperor of Ethiopia, left Gibraltar late this afternoon on the liner Orford.

LONDON, May 29. -- There are many indications here that British trade is continuing in a healthy state of activity. Retail sales expanded further in April, the value of such business being 5 per cent more than that of the same month of 1935, compared with an increase of 7.9 per cent in March over a year before.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 31. -- Harlan J. Swift, '37, of Buffalo, has been elected captain of next Spring's Princeton crew, it was announced today by Gordon Keppel, '36, of New York, captain for the past two years. Swift rowed No. 4 in the varsity beat a year ago and No. 6 in the jayvee eight this past season.
Fordham's powerful nine continued to perform in impressive style during the past week as most , of the metropolitan college baseball teams completed their schedules.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- A defense of democracy was delivered by Chancellor Joseph M.M. Gray in his baccalaureate address today at American University in which he declared that it was to be judged not by "our unachieved ideal but by the alternatives which are available."
