HAVANA, May 31. -- The possibility of a consolidation of all Cuba's indebtedness and of a new loan of at least $80,000,000 was presented as a front-page feature this morning by El Mundo, an important morning paper. The information was purported as emanating from Congressional sources.

The New York camping season is officially open. There are now no less than twenty-nine public camp sites in the Adirondacks and the Catskills, all under the supervision of the Conservation Department.

LAUREL SPRINGS, N.J., May 31. -- Mayor Frederick von Nieda of Camden told more than 100 admirers of Walt Whitman today that a gibe from a fellow councilman caused him to lead a movement to make a shrine of Whitman's Mickle Street house in Camden.

PARIS, May 29. -- Gold losses caused by capital exports must have been larger two weeks ago than was shown by the Bank of France's report, but these apparently were neutralized, in part, by an influx of the metal from Switzerland.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., May 31. -- An education which does not point the way to the proper development of man's senses, intellect and will is narrow, provincial and unworthy of the nobility in man, the Very Rev. Mgr. Francis Gonne, president of St. Bede's College, Manchester, England, declared this afternoon in a baccalaureate address to the graduating class of Marymount College.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- More than 1,700 of the 6,000 Associated Country Women of the World arriving here for their Third Triennial Conference, which will open here tomorrow, attended a special vesper service held for them in the Washington Cathedral this afternoon.

CHICAGO, May 31. -- Speculative holders and packers of lard here were credited last week with being liberal sellers of futures in expectation that a good increase in stocks this month would be shown tomorrow. Shipping trade in lard and meats was only moderate.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 31. -- "Steam wisely, moor safely," was the advice given to the 263 members of the graduating class at the Naval Academy today by Commander William M. Thomas, academy chaplain.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., May 31. -- In honor of the first great Sunday meeting at this first annual assembly held in the United States by the Oxford Group, its founder, Dr. Frank N.D. Buchman, who usually leaves public speaking to the leaders he has trained, addressed an outdoor audience of 3,000 here this afternoon in front of the town hall.

Police throughout the nation are searching for William Webster Theile, 15 years old, son of William Theile, financier, and a direct descendant of Daniel Webster, who disappeared twenty-seven days ago, it was learned yesterday.

The Bank of the Manhattan Company, as trustee, has notified holders of bonds of the Prudence Corporation, fifth series, guaranteed by the Prudence Company, Inc., that they will receive 3 per cent of the principal amount in cash upon presentation of the bonds at its corporate trust department, 40 Wall Street.
WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP). -- Representative Zioncheck of Washington State returned to his apartment tonight from what he said was a day of search for his wife.

WARSAW, May 31. -- Forty-two Polish peasants and fourteen young Jews will be tried Tuesday in the District Court at Radom, in Central Poland, for manslaughter during the rioting in the town of Przytyk on March 9, when one Gentile and two Jews were killed.

CLEVELAND, May 31. -- A cigarette can be lighted in a jet of steam made by a new type of electric light bulb invented in the lamp development department of the Nela Park laboratory of the General Electric Company in East Cleveland.

A schedule for 1936-37 providing for the release of sixty-nine feature-length motion picture productions by the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation was announced yesterday by John D. Clark, general manager of distribution, following the annual convention of the company in Chicago.

Reflecting the rise in consumer purchase of all types of Summer apparel, particularly in the dress and sportswear departments, manufacturers in the wholesale markets here experienced an active demand for merchandise last week. While the cool weather in many sections retarded the buying of cotton dresses, orders received by manufacturers were so heavy that many were unable to make shipments to retailers on time.

New York State is doing a good job of caring for the folks who like to pack a tent on the auto rack and pass a week-end or even a full vacation period camping out on the shore of a lake or beside a flowing stream.

JERUSALEM. May 31. -- Today marks the end of the sixth week of rioting, murder and acts of brigandage by Arabs in Palestine. The situation is unchanged, and there is no sign of abeyance in the terrorism.

Some weeks ago Congress plucked up courage to refuse to vote further appropriations for two public works already authorized and begun. One of them is the Florida ship canal. The other is the Quoddy power project. Both were opposed as ill-advised, needless, full of wasted public funds, and also full of politics.

Fair Business in the Field of Merchandise, the publication of the Better Business Bureau of New York City, Inc., of which Trowbridge Callaway is president and H.J. Kenner is general manager, features in the issue just published a four-month report on truth in advertising in this city.

Employe groups have contributed $160,000 of the $1,151,614 raised to date by the Citizens Family Welfare Committee, Laurence M. Marks, its chairman, announced yesterday. The group is seeking a minimum of $1,500,000 to aid family welfare agencies in this city.

GRANADA, Col., May 31 (AP). -- Six persons were known to be dead and another had apparently perished before high waters of the Memorial Day floods receded slowly today in the dust bowl areas of Southeastern Colorado End Western Kansas.

Looking forward to a day when the church will have an even stronger position in civilization than it now holds, the Rev. Dr. Irving Husted Berg, retiring minister of the Fort Washington Collegiate Reformed Church, Fort Washington and 181st Street, preached his farewell sermon there yesterday morning.

ABOARD THE QUEEN MARY, May 31. -- As this voyage draws to a close, the question of a trans-atlantic record increasingly dominates conversation. Long division has rivaled in popularity the less arduous shipboard recreations, from shuffleboard to squash, as passengers with furrowed brows try to compute the Queen Mary's average speed and compare it with the Normandie's.

SYRACUSE, May 31. -- The Reserve Officers Training Corps was defended by Chancellor Charles Wesley Flint in the Syracuse University baccalaureate today as a means of obtaining a degree of preparedness without militarization.

DETROIT, May 31 (AP). -- Rogers Hornsby, St. Louis Browns' manager, made his first appearance of the season today as a pinch hitter in the ninth inning and came through with a sharp single to right field, scoring Rollie Hemsley from second base with the winning run in an 11-to-10 slugfest victory over Detroit.

Detective Charles H. Tracy of the Brooklyn racket squad, while driving home at 2 A.M. yesterday, surprised two Negroes robbing a white woman at Fort Greene Place and Fulton Street, a lonely and deserted neighborhood at that hour.

DETROIT, May 31. -- Ontario authorities were asked today by David H. Crowley, Attorney General, to aid in investigating the death of a Michigan factory worker on an island in Canadian territory the day after Charles A. Poole, young WPA worker, was killed by members of the Black Legion.
Another banner holiday crowd, a gathering of 41,781 by official announcement, left the Yankee Stadium yesterday singing the praises of Joe DiMaggio.

A rise in the pound sterling to the highest since early February, weakness in the French franc and the gold bloc as a result of which engagements of gold abroad aggregated $39,943,000, and an advance in the Dutch Bank rate represented the budget of interesting events in the foreign exchange market last week.

PHILADELPHIA, May 31 (AP). -- Pete Appleton's five-hit pitching through the last six innings stopped the Athletics today, Washington taking a 6-to-4 decision. Appleton came in at the start of the fourth inning. The former Indian held the Mackmen scoreless the rest of the way while fanning six.

The Dallas Gas Company has notified holders of its first-mortgage 6 per cent bonds due in 1941 that $22,500 of the bonds has been drawn for payment on July 1. Of this amount, $3,000 will be redeemed at 103 1/2 and $19,500 at 103, with accrued interest, at the Bank of the Manhattan Company.

SYRACUSE, May 31. -- A church program embodying the social impulse for human betterment was urged this afternoon at a meeting under the auspices of the Boards of National Missions and Christian Education of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church of the United States of America.

BERLIN, May 31. -- The vigor with which the government has gone to work to suppress every outward sign of disharmony within the Third Reich until after the Olympics threatens to involve it again in an open clash with the independent Protestant clergy of the Confessional Synods.
A contest for the presidency of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, the first in the twenty-two years that Joseph T. Moran has held that office, was revealed at police headquarters yesterday.

PEEKSKILL N.Y., May 31. -- The Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, pastor of Christ Church, Methodist Episcopal, Manhattan, delivered the baccalaureate sermon in the Ford Auditorium here today for the 103d commencement exercises of the Peekskill Military Academy before more than 1,300 persons, including 310 members of the student body.

VIENNA, May 31. -- Prince Ernst yon Starhemberg, leader of the Fascist Heimwehr, gave this evening an indication that he was prepared to bury his animosity toward Nazi Germany by publicly inviting Germany's official representative in Vienna to a flight in his airplane.

The standard of examinations for licenses as master or mate of American commercial ships has been raised in the last year to a point that compares favorably with that of any nation in the world, according to Captain Norman E. Merrill.

The first comprehensive effort in this State to "add up" and compare the results of education in city and country schools will be undertaken this week by the Regents' "Inquiry Into the Character and Cost of Public Education," Dr. Luther Gulick, director of the inquiry, announced yesterday.

Commodity futures were fairly active in last week's trading of four days, with gains in cocoa, coffees and hides as rubber and metal eased. In the cash markets, cotton, hides, butter, oats and cocoa were firmer, while wheat, corn, rye, lard, wool tops, rubber and tins declined.

SAN JUAN, P.R., May 31. -- Puerto Rico's inherent conservatism is believed to be responsible for a noticeable swing in the last week away from the independence demands vociferously proclaimed immediately following the presentation of the administration-sponsored Tydings bill for a plebiscite.

Edgar Chambless, 60 years old, was found dead in bed in his room at 117 West Forty-ninth Street at 3:20 o'clock yesterday afternoon. A tube leading to a gas heater was in his mouth. The police listed the case as a suicide.

ALBANY, May 31. -- Governor Lehman signed today the bill of Senator Dunnigan authorizing the merger of domestic gas and electric corporations where there is 95 per cent stock ownership. Under the present law 100 per cent stock ownership is required.

Once again the Giants found ways and means to outfumble the Dodgers yesterday. While a farewell crowd of 12,000 hooted its derision at Ebbets Field the New Yorkers gave back the game in the last of the ninth inning after their hosts had tried hard to present it to them in the first half.
The Board of Education is about to throw out of the school system several thousand teachers who have served from six to eight years. I cite my case as typical.
WASHINGTON, May 31. -- The Chamber of Commerce of the United States and the National Association of Manufacturers in statements today attacked the new Guffey-Vinson Coal Bill.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- The people of the United States were invited today by Secretary Morgenthau, in announcing the June 15 financing plans of the Treasury, to subscribe more than $2,000,000,000 to the public funds at interest rates which, in one category, set a new low record.

Cardinal Hayes presided in the sanctuary of St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday as the Most Rev. Stephen J. Donahue, Auxiliary Bishop of New York, celebrated pontifical mass. It was the Feast of Pentecost, commemorating the descent of the Holy Ghost upon the Apostles.

CHICAGO, May 31. -- The heaviest receipts of hogs here for any week since February were readily taken by packers last week and prices advanced 10 cents a hundredweight on Friday, the last day of trading in May, the stock yards being closed yesterday, Memorial Day.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 31. -- Practice, matches for poloists preparing for the coming Meadow Brook Club tourneys were staged on two fields today with three teams participating in a round-robin on Hitchcock Field here and another pair meeting on Schiff Field in Roslyn.

Continued cool weather curtailed the holiday activities of many New Yorkers yesterday, but did not prevent thousands from visiting the beaches or from joining in the post-Decoration Day rush of travel in the afternoon and last night.
MENDENHALL, Miss., May 31 (AP). -- Extra guards protected Frank Bruce, charged with critically wounding Circuit Judge Edgar M. Lane, at the Simpson County jail today.
Sales of housing properties in Manhattan and Queens by Louis H. Pink, as liquidator of title companies, featured deals reported in the city over the week-end.

Dispatches to THE TIMES have summarized the experience of several New Jersey cities since the responsibility of providing direct relief of unemployment in that State was thrown back upon the municipalities. In Trenton the relief roll has been reduced from 3,682 to 1,602 cases, and the cost of relief has declined from more than $100,000 to about $30,000 a month.

The forthcoming Presidential election in Nicaragua is at the root of yesterday's outbreak. Two factions, one headed by President Juan B. Sacasa and the other by General Anastasio Somoza, chief of the National Guard, accuse each other of designs to gain control of the Presidency by unconstitutional methods.

Two seeded players in the nineteenth annual Brooklyn tennis championship fell by the wayside yesterday at the Terrace Club as William Lurie, metropolitan public parks titleholder, and David Geller of N.Y.U. were victims of upsets.
URBANA, Ill., May 31 (AP). -- A six months' study of newspapers in Europe has convinced Professor R.R. Barlow that international discord is the product of a muzzled press.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, May 31. -- A machine-gun battle broke out this morning between the National Guard and the Guardia de Honor garrisoned in the Presidential palace on a hill called La Loma behind Managua. The battle continued for half an hour, after which both forces ceased firing.

PANAMA, May 31 (AP). -- Gabry Rivas, director of the Managua newspaper Nueva Prensa, said in a dispatch tonight to The Panama Star and Herald that "it is unconfirmedly reported" President Juan B. Sacasa of Nicaragua has resigned.

The American Newspaper Guild, holding its annual convention at the Hotel Astor, was informed yesterday that William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, had predicted that the guild would receive its A.F. of L. charter in July and that its delegates would be seated at the federation's national convention in November.

With the body of a 16-year-old girl who had been strangled hidden in a closet near his bed, Oley Thompson, 41 years old, an unemployed seaman, was found a suicide by gas yesterday in his furnished room at 411 West Twenty-first Street.

Evensong of Pentecost (Whitsunday) was sung at Trinity Church yesterday afternoon by more than 100 boys and men in a choir augmented by members of the Trinity Choir Alumni Association at its fourteenth annual service.

LONDON, May 29. -- The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood on May 27 at 69.8, compared with 70.5 two weeks before, 70.9 a month before, and with 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- Charging that the public utility, corporations, especially the holding companies, are quietly at work in an effort to control the nomination and election of candidates for the Presidency and the Congress, the National Popular Government League issued today a thirty-six-page pamphlet compiled by Judson King, its national director, which purports to give the utility records of all the leading candidates for the Presidential.

HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., May 31. -- Commencement exercises of the Peddie School opened this morning at the 11 o'clock services in the First Baptist Church when Headmaster Wilbour Eddy Saunders delivered the baccalaureate sermon to the sixty-three graduating students.

SHANGHAI, Monday, June 1. -- Cables from Tokyo freshly emphasizing the Japanese Army's unalterable stand concerning its insistence for an immediate settlement of all pending Chino-Japanese issues serves only to confirm the conviction, long established in Chinese Government inner circles, that this Summer will witness the ultimate crisis in Chino-Japanese relations.

PARIS, May 29. -- Varied and often conflicting reports are circulating here with respect to the future policy of Leon Blum, the incoming Premier. But the fact is, however, that nothing is known positively about his projects, and it is by no means certain that any have been determined as yet.

LYNCHBURG, Va., May 31. -- Modern freedom was the subject of both praise and a warning today by Bishop Paul B. Kern of Greensboro, N.C., in his baccalaureate sermon to the 115 graduates of Randolph-Macon Woman's College.
TROY, N.Y., May 31. -- "Living is giving," the Rev. Dr. William Herman Hopkins of Albany declared today in his baccalaureate sermon to the graduating class of Russell Sage College.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- A call for decisive leadership and a platform by the Republican party which will "deserve the confidence of the American people," was made by Senator Vandenberg in a radio interview tonight in terms which were construed by political observers as signifying that the Michigan Senator was prepared to assume that leadership, if the nomination is offered to him at the Cleveland convention.

HARRISBURG, Pa., May 31. -- Governor Earle suggested tonight a possible means of breaking the legislative deadlock over relief by asking that $70,991,000, which he had estimated as needed for relief until Feb. l, be made available for an indefinite period.

Cotton futures advanced moderately last week, chiefly because of unfavorable crop reports and high mill activity and consumption in this country and abroad. Prices on the New York Cotton Exchange ended the week at gains of 9 to 17 points.

PHILADELPHIA, May 31. -- One of the most inexplicable collapses of tennis form in memory dealt America's Davis Cup hopes a staggering blow today as Donald Budge and Gene Mako let victory escape their grasp and Australia won the doubles to gain a 2-1 advantage in the tie at the Germantown Cricket Club.

At the Martin Beck Theatre, where it played 178 performances earlier in the season, Maxwell Anderson's "Winterset" pays another visit tonight. It comes back sporting the Drama Critics Circle prize, which garland was hung upon it during its tour; it comes back also with star billing for Burgess Meredith, and with a cast which includes Margo (for a few performances), Myron McCormick, Lee Baker, Ruth Hammond, Harold Johnsrud, Morton L. Stevens.
The sale of the official Book of the Democratic National Convention of 1936 is being pushed in letters sent out to party workers by W. Forbes Morgan, secretary of the Democratic National Committee.

BALTIMORE, May 31. -- Speaking on "The Radiant Life," the Rev. Dr. Clarence A. Barbour, president of Brown University, asserted today in the baccalaureate sermon at Goucher College that "we practical, hustling Western people" had lost the "art of calmness and peace."
When the mighty turbines of the Queen Mary slow down and come to a stop this morning off the entrance to Ambrose Channel the liner will signal to a dwarfed pilot boat waiting there.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- The possibility of Congress adjourning by Saturday night or Monday at the latest, fulfilling the leaders' original plan, was believed tonight to rest largely with President Roosevelt and his decision, yet to be made, on whether to insist further on his "reform" tax program.

LONDON, May 29. -- It is impossible to estimate with any degree of accuracy the extent to which purchase of sterling by foreigners endeavoring to escape possible devaluation of their own currencies has been carried. It is probably true, to say the least, that there has been an increase of 20,000,000 in British note circulation owing to this factor.

A revival of historical studies, bringing with it a new understanding between peoples, was forecast yesterday by Dr. William Foxwell Albright, Professor of Semitic Languages at Johns Hopkins University, in an address at the eleventh annual commencement exercises of the Jewish Institute of Religion.

Today an instructive experiment goes into effect. The Eastern railroads, responding reluctantly to the order of the Interstate Commerce Commission, reduce their fares from 3.6 to 2 cents a mile. The theory behind this reduction is that it will so stimulate passenger travel that the net revenues of the roads will actually increase.

Charging that repeal of the prohibition amendment had created a situation worse than that which prevailed before the revolt against alcoholism led to the outlawing of liquor, the Rev. Harry Emerson Fosdick yesterday predicted a new upheaval.
PITTSFIELD, Mass., May 31. -- Mrs. Reginald Nicholson of London was the honor guest at a tea given this afternoon by her sister-in-law, Mrs. Frederick A. Pearson at Estamos, Great Barrington.

An old-fashioned bucket chain, including a 16-year-old volunteer, and a modern fireboat cooperated yesterday in quenching a creeping rubbish fire from which smoke annoyed hundreds of worshipers leaving the Riverside Church at 122d rim were spreading over the Grant's Street and Riverside Drive.

The Purchase Department spent $17,512,000 last year in buying city supplies and material, as against $14,245,000 in 1934, Russell Forbes, Purchase Commissioner, said yesterday in his annual report to Mayor La Guardia on the department's activities.
ST. LOUIS, May 31. -- Overcoming an early lead, Frank Frisch's Cardinals won a twelve-inning slugfest from the Cincinnati Reds in their series finale today, 8 to 7, before 9,500 fans.
THE exhibit this morning is a strange one, in that the most significant of three books is the least successful, and the least significant the most successful.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., May 31. -- Although Ralph P. Manny's new 32-footer Swell failed to win today's competition for the latest one-design class of the New York Yacht Club in the concluding portion of the two-day regatta of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club, she captured the handsome trophy offered by Vice Commodore E. Townsend Irvin.

The expert testimony offered in the Fiorenza case and some time ago at the Hauptmann trial should awaken the public to the importance of divorcing from the realm of partisanship the testimony of experts in criminal cases.

CLEVELAND, May 31 (AP). -- The magazine Steel said today that its price index for finished steel, effective on July 1, would be $53.40 a ton, based on price adjustments made within the industry in recent weeks.
WASHINGTON, May 31. -- The Foreign Policy Association said in a report today that "a growing Nazi terror" existed in the Free City of Danzig.
Bunting blossomed on Twelfth Avenue and pictures of the Queen Mary appeared in cafe and store windows yesterday as the West Side prepared to welcome the Cunard White Star liner today.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., May 31. -- The homes of two well-to-do families of South Orange have been bombed by explosives attached to electric wiring and set off when the residents themselves threw on light switches, the police disclosed tonight.
CHICAGO, May 31 (AP). -- A movement for immediate formation of a third national political party collapsed today just before the close of a conference of third party advocates from over the nation.
Governor Alf M. Landon of Kansas, leading candidate for the Republican nomination for President, was asked yesterday by Amos R.E. Pinchot to say how he stood on a return to the gold standard.

A special meeting of holders of preferred and common stock of the Certain-teed Products Corporation has been called for June 24 in Baltimore to consider a plan of recapitalization proposed by the directors. The purposes of the plan are to eliminate the present consolidated deficit, to fund accumulated dividend arrears on the preferred stock and to eliminate accumulated arrears in the sinking-fund payments for the preferred stock and future requirements for the fund.

BERLIN, May 29. -- Political interest this week was diverted to developments in Central and Southeastern Europe, where local observers professed to see loosening of the French system of alliances. This, they consider, is likely to lead to political and commercial advantages to Germany.

Calling upon Catholic college graduates to wage an unrelenting battle for truth, the Rev. Henry M. Hald, Assistant Superintendent of Brooklyn diocesan schools, declared yesterday at the sixty-sixth annual baccalaureate services of St. John's University that "today Catholic scholarship must be genuine, reflective and productive if it is to fulfill its purpose."
CAMP NO. 1, Mount Everest, Tibet, May 31 (by Wireless via Calcutta). -- The British Mount Everest expedition again has evacuated Camp No. 3 and has returned to Camp No. 1.

Alan Sutherland, proofreader and editor, was found dead at about 6 A.M. yesterday on a bench in Madison Square Park. He was 73 years old and had been living for the last four years at the Hotel Broztell, 5 East Twenty-seventh Street.

Awards to sixteen winners of the national poster contest conducted by the Propeller Club of the United States to encourage interest in the American merchant marine were announced yesterday by C.H.C. Pearsall, president of the Colombian Steamship Line and national president of the club.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., May 31. -- Seven Seas, Van S. Merle-Smith's international twelve-meter yacht, again showed her heels to competition in the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's Long Island Sound championship regatta today. She defeated Bayard S. Litchfield's Cantitoe by 5 minutes and 40 seconds over 16 4-5 miles.

PITTSBURGH, May 31. -- Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 69 per cent of capacity, down 1 point from the two preceding weeks and 3 points from the recent high rate, when output was the heaviest since March, 1930.

LONDON, May 31. -- Perhaps the most striking aspect of current European diplomacy is the emergence of Russia. The new Russians are playing the game of realpolitik with a skill that the Czars and their Foreign Ministers might have envied.

PARIS, May 31. -- Fred Perry, England's world-famed tennis star, had to muster all his cunning and tennis art today to defeat Christian Boussus, first ranking French player, in the semi-finals of the French hard courts singles championship.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, May 31. In gigantic country-wide demonstrations 520,000 farmers of the Rumanian Peasant party protested today against the influence of Mrs. Magda Lupescu in the government and urged official prosecution of Nazi organizations.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $5,006,834,200. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

PARIS, May 31. -- On the eve of the opening of the new French Legislature Leon Blum, Premier-designate, who before the end of the week will be called upon by the President of the Republic to form a new government, addressing a congress of his Socialist followers this evening, declared that his government would be new not only in name but in character, in action and in the manner of that action.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP). -- A new-administration attack on the housing problem, involving development of "garden homes" outside of large cities, was outlined today by Stewart McDonald, Federal Housing Administrator. Reporting that President Roosevelt "is enthusiastic" over the plan, Mr. McDonald said it was aimed at a gradual movement of industrial workers and similar classes from urban and suburban areas to small homes situated on one to two acre plots several miles from city limits.
WASHINGTON, May 31. -- Senate leaders said today that they were ready to work day and night toward an adjournment before the Republican convention opens a week from Tuesday.

A. group of women prominent in civic affairs assailed yesterday the equal rights amendment approved by a subcommittee of the House Judiciary Committee and expressed hope that it would not be passed by Congress. Heading the protesting group was Mrs. Carrie Chapman Cart.

Favored by almost perfect Spring weather, nearly 1,000 Columbia University seniors marched slowly across the campus from their respective colleges and converged upon St. Paul's Chapel yesterday afternoon for the baccalaureate service that opened the 182d commencement exercises of the university.

The near approach of the nominating conventions, the formal beginning of the political campaign, has as yet found no visible reflection either in the course of trade or in financial markets. This may mean only suspended judgment. But it is more probable that results in the two conventions have come to be pretty much taken for granted.

Ogden L. Mills, former Secretary of the Treasury; Representative James W. Wadsworth, former United States Senator, and Park Commissioner Robert Moses, nominee for Governor in 1934, have been suggested for the New York member of the important committee on resolutions of the Republican National Convention, it was learned, yesterday.

TIENTSIN, China, May 31 (AP). -- Japanese newspapers warned China today that it would be "disastrous" to oppose the Japanese Army in North China following the blowing up of a bridge and a part of the track on a railway line.

A SKEPTIC was encountered one day. He suspected the illicit manufacture of quotations in this corner. "Do people really come around and say the queer things you say they say?" he remarked. "I don't believe it." Believe it or not (by special permission of Bob. Ripley), they do. Like the man who came around yesterday and began talking of the approaching sixty-eighth running of the Belmont, for 3-year-olds and upward, $25,000 added.

BRUNSWICK, Me., May 31. -- A three-month scientific research expedition to the Bay of Fundy under the auspices of Bowdoin College will sail from Lubec, Me., on June 15, for its base at the Bowdoin Scientific Station on Kent's Island, New Brunswick, Canada. A preliminary announcement of the expedition was made here today by William A.O. Gross of Bowdoin, field director.

ABOARD THE QUEEN MARY, en route to New York, May 31. -- At noon today the Queen Mary had covered 2,517 miles of her course from the Cherbourg Breakwater at an average speed of 29.15 knots, and was 641 miles from Ambrose Light.
HUNTINGTON, L.I., May 31. -- A committee which will attempt to have the birthplace of Walt Whitman preserved as a national park was formed here today.

MOSCOW, May 31. -- Jose R. Capablanca of Havana, former chess champion of the world, was still in the lead by 1 1/2 points at the close of today's session in the international chess masters tournament.

LONDON, May 29. -- Business and the security markets are at the lowest ebb for many months. Pending the break-up of the existing stagnation of the European political situation, and the development of clearer ideas concerning the future of the gold-bloc currencies, the markets are prone to consider at length matters which, under more active conditions, would not attract their attention.

Pope Pius XI was acclaimed on his seventy-ninth birthday yesterday as "God's special gift to the church and the world, during these critical times," in an address by Patrick Cardinal Hayes which was broadcast over a nation-wide network of the National Broadcasting Company and also transmitted by short-wave radio to other nations.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., May 31. -- An alleged burglar was shot four times and seriously wounded here tonight by a policeman after he had once escaped from the officer following the burglary of two Bronxville homes.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- Identical planks pledging a balanced budget and rigid economy will be urged upon the Republican and Democratic National Conventions by the Economy League for incorporation in the party platforms.

Securities offerings to the public here in Nay were the smallest in volume in three months. Offerings amounted to $261,982,000, of which $249,316,000 represented forty-five bond issues and $12,666,000 eight stock issues, compared with $926,771,000 in April, when $886,087,000 accounted for in sixty-three bond issues and $40,684,000 in seventeen stock issues.

BERLIN, May 29. -- The Boerse was less active this week as investors showed growing caution, due to the aggravation of the foreign exchange position, as signalized by the new ordinances which drastically restrict the present meager right of transfer.

NEW HAVEN, May 30. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 81.2, which compares with 80.5 the week before, 81 two weeks before, 81.6 three weeks before and 82.2 four weeks before.

Nazi officials were attacked for their "frame-up" of 275 Catholic clergy now on trial in Germany yesterday morning by the Rev. Peter B. Duffee in a sermon at the 10 o'clock mass of St. Francis Assisi Roman Catholic Church, 135 West Thirty-first Street.

The 1935 national Theodore N. Vail awards for "noteworthy public service" by telephone company employes have been made to a telephone operator in Wisconsin, to another in Mississippi and to the entire personnel of the office at Helena, Mont., it was announced yesterday by the New York Telephone Company.

ON BOARD THE QUEEN MARY, en route to New York, May 31 (Canadian Press). -- The Queen Mary's passenger's are dancing to music broadcast from New York while the ship's radio receives and sends a constant flood of messages.

Having completed its series of public hearings on the draft charter, the Thacher commission is now about to consider in executive session the criticisms and suggestions offered. The most vigorous opposition has come from those confirmed advocates of borough autonomy who think even the reasonable measures of centralization proposed go too far.

Retailing in this city "may well congratulate itself upon the increase in the accurate and confidence-building qualities of its newspaper advertising," according to Fair Practice in the Field of Merchandise, publication of the Better Business Bureau of New York City, Inc.

The Rev. Dr. Millard L. Robinson, general secretary of the New York Bible Society, spoke yesterday at St. Paul's Methodist Episcopal Church, West End Avenue at Eighty-sixth Street, on "The Standard Measurement of Christian Attainments.'

On May 18 the American Federation of Labor released a survey of business in which we showed by comparing the progress of business and employment since March, 1933, that business today is not re-employing workers fast enough to give jobs to all who want them by the time "normal" activity is again achieved.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- Fighting in Managua and Leon in the latest Nicaraguan revolution, the first since 1926-27, was reported in dispatches to the State Department today from Boaz W. Long, the United States Minister.
CLEVELAND, May 31 (AP). -- The Indians solved their old nemesis, Vernon Kennedy, for base hits in every inning today to win, 7 to 5, and sweep a three-game series with the White Sox.

LAKE SEBAGO, N.Y., May 31. -- Ernie Riedel of the Pendleton Canoe Club, New York, scored a double victory in the second day of the Atlantic division, American Canoe Association's divisional Olympic tryouts over the 1,000-meter course today.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- There was a sharp decline in activity on national securities Exchanges in April according to a summary made available today by the Securities and Exchange Commission. The dollar value of sales amounted to $2,188,264,102, a decrease of 20.9 per cent compared with March, but an increase of 83.1 per cent compared with the figures for April a year ago.

The International Steel Cartel is sending its representatives here aboard the Queen Mary to lay before leaders of the American steel industry tonight a proposal that they join foreign manufacturers in a pooling of resources, experience and technical skill to develop world markets for their common advantage.

At Mayor La Guardia's suggestion, the Board of Transportation is working on a plan to round out and extend the city's Independent System of rapid transit lines so that it can operate at full competitive efficiency should pending negotiations for transit unification fail.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, May 31. -- Suspension of the constitutional form of government is demanded in a proclamation issued this afternoon by the Rightist parties supporting President Agustin P. Justo's government. The proclamation announces the formation of a National Front of conservative parties to oppose the Popular Front formed by the Leftists.

We need today a renewal of Whitsunday's spirit which shall convince the world of the active presence of God, enlightening life, purifying and making its purpose single, the Very Rev. George Paull T. Sargent declared in his sermon yesterday in St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church.

As a result of profitable exchange operations occasioned by the recurrent weakness in the French franc, imports of gold here in May were in the largest volume for any month since December and exceeded the combined total of gold received in the preceding four months.

CHICAGO, May 31. -- Passage of the Commodity Exchange Bill by the Senate in Washington last week has bewildered the cash interests and traders on the Chicago Board of Trade. They profess to lack a satisfactory explanation as to what can or cannot be done by the grain exchanges and handlers of commodities.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 31. -- Almost lost in the millions of words uttered here last week at the National Conference on Social Work in behalf of the "forgotten man" were the Spanish accents of five young women, arguing the cause of a whole island of forgotten people.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 31. -- Announcement of new officers and new members of the three leading student honorary organizations at Brown University marked today the close of undergraduate activities for 1935-36. The calendar for the rest of the year includes semester examinations and commencement.

Perhaps no one expects consistency from Senator Pittman, the silver-tongued silver Senator from Nevada, but there are some interesting instances of inconsistency in his recent speech, headed "Silver and the Monetary Policy," as published in the Congressional Record of May 25.
MANAGUA, May 31. -- In a Nicaraguan Army revolt today rebels made an unsuccessful attack upon the Presidential palace here.
BOSTON, May 31 (AP). -- Defeated twice yesterday, the Bees turned the tables on the Phillies today with a 6-to-5 victory in eleven innings. A crowd of 10,000 looked on.

A powerful, smooth-stroking crew from Rollins College of Winter Park. Fla., fought off a game closing challenge by Manhattan's varsity eight to triumph by half a length in a match race over the Henley course of one mile and five- sixteenths on the Harlem River yesterday.
NEWPORT, R.I., May 31. -- Miss Augusta McCagg entertained a number of guests at luncheon at her home here today.

A head-on collision last night on the Arthur Kill Road, Staten Island, resulted in the death of one woman and serious injury to five other persons, including her husband and daughter. Two of the injured are in critical condition.

Of interest in connection with money market prospects is the heavy volume of Treasury financing scheduled for June 15 and subsequent payment of the soldiers' bonus, according to the June monthly letter of the National City Bank of New York.

VATICAN CITY, May 31. -- More than 40,000 Catholics, including 10,000 pilgrims from all parts of Christendom and scores of ecclesiastical and lay notables, cheered Pope Pius XI this morning as he entered St. Peter's for a special mass celebrating his seventy-ninth birthday.

The aggregate net income of thirty major oil companies in 1935 was $258,542,320 after charges, taxes and reserves, compared to $158,282,145 in 1934, according to a compilation by Carl H. Pforzheimer Co. The gross operating income of the group was $3,754,036,619, compared to $3,521,692,015.

The first of the June 1 index numbers of average commodity prices, that of Dun's Review, indicates a decline of seven-eighths of 1 per cent during May. The June 1 average is the lowest since Sept. 1 of last year. The decline from the same date a year ago is 1 1/4 per cent, as compared with the same date in 1934 the advance has been 4 7/8 per cent.

A good retail establishment and a university have much in common, for both "are concerned with the insatiable wants and vagaries of humankind," Harold O. Voorhis, secretary of New York University, declared at the annual dinner of the School of Retailing of New York University last night.
WASHINGTON, June 1. -- The text of the majority opinion of the Supreme Court outlawing the New York Minimum Wage Law was as follows:

ROME, June 1. -- The Cabinet, meeting this morning under Premier Benito Mussolini's chairmanship, approved a law, effective immediately without waiting for parliamentary sanction, laying down the main lines of organization of Italy's East African empire.

As the Queen Mary came up the harbor her 1,849 passengers talked of many subjects, from the skyline and the price of cocktails to politics, economic conditions and international trade, but all turned their conversation inevitably back to the topic uppermost in their minds -- the crossing of Great Britain's new challenger for supremacy on the commercial seas.

Five Manhattan properties and a Bronx parcel were bought in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auction sales yesterday. The largest holding was a sixteen-story loft building at 693-97 Broadway, southwest corner of Fourth Street. The property was taken over on a $1,000 bid by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company, plaintiff in an action against the Protective Security Corporation for $589,514 due, with taxes, , totaling about $34,513.

The members of the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday elected John C. Botts president and Alpheus C. Beane vice president. Mr. Botts, who has been vice president two years, succeeds John H. McFadden Jr. Clayton B. Jones was re-elected treasurer.

MOSCOW, June 1. -- Reorganization of the Soviet judicial system so as to protect the civil rights and personal dignity of citizens will be provided for in the new Constitution of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. This was announced today by Andrei Vyshinsky, the Soviet's chief prosecutor, who is a member of the commission headed by Joseph Stalin that has framed the Constitution.

Making his first appearance since the competition got under way, Gregory Mangin, the national indoor titleholder, reached the quarter-finals in the nineteenth annual Brooklyn tennis championship yesterday at the Terrace Club of Fiatbush.

Rear Admiral Richard Evelyn Byrd will announce his future plans, which were said by friends yesterday to involve "activities of world-wide significance and interest" at a testimonial dinner to be given in his honor at the Waldorf-Astoria on Friday evening.

There is just a chance that, when Jed Harris gets around to presenting Philip Barry's newest play, Owen Davis Jr. and Mary Rogers will be the leading people in it. On behalf of "Spring Dance," which is the entertainment's name, the Harris scouts have extended offers to both of them.
WASHINGTON, June 1. -- The dissenting opinion in the New York minimum wage case, written by Chief Justice Hughes and concurred in by Justices Brandeis, Cardozo and Stone, follows:

The Department of Labor rejected yesterday the petition of Otto Richter, 21-year-old German citizen, to go to Canada to obtain legal reentry into the United States, and ordered him to report to Ellis Island for deportation on June 23. He will be sent to Germany on the President Harding on June 24, it was said at the office of the American Committee for Protection of Foreign Born, 100 Fifth Avenue, which has handled the case.

LONDON, June 1. -- New Yorkers have surprised and delighted the British with the warmth of their welcome to the Queen Mary. The thunderous applause that came through countless radio receivers as a background to vivid word pictures of scenes in New York Harbor told that even the demonstrations at her departure from Southampton had been outdone.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- Warnings of a bitter fight ahead over the Tax Bill, supported by the filing in the Senate of a minority report against the Finance Committee compromise, failed to deter administration leaders today in their drive to end the present session of Congress by Saturday or Monday.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation called for bids today to be received until noon on June 18 at its offices here on forty-five issues of securities of States, municipalities, counties and school districts aggregating $4,254,300, and on one issue of Great Northern Railway Company secured serial bonds of $4,935,000, making a combined total of $9,189,300.

A lease calling for payment to the city of the first $2,000,000 net receipts from the world's fair to be held in the Flushing Meadows in 1939 was approved yesterday by the executive committee of the World's Fair Corporation.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

Gallant Prince, a 4-year-old son of Gallant Fox owned by William Woodward, chairman of the Jockey Club, came back with one of his best efforts yet and captured the Peter Pan Handicap at a mile and a sixteenth, feature of the racing at Belmont Park yesterday.

The Twenty-third Street Association will hole its third annual golf tournament and outing today at the Green Meadow Golf Club, Harrison. The group will leave in the morning from the George Washington Hotel, 23d St. and Lexington Av.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., June 1. -- Miss Janet Douglas of the Rumson Country Club shot an 86 to take a two-stroke lead in the first round of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association fifty-four-hole medal play championship today at the Crestmont Golf Club.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 1. -- A resolution inviting former United States Senator James A. Reed, Democrat, of Missouri, to address the Republican National Convention will be placed before the committee on convention arrangements tomorrow.

Mr. RALPH ADAMS CRAM, so generally and justly admired as an architect and a medievalist, will "probably" vote for Mr. ROOSEVELT. His enthusiasm is not extreme. He "sharply dissents "from at least half the present govern-"mental program," yet half a loaf satisfies him. "One-half a policy" he calls it.

Degrees will be conferred upon 108 graduates of the College of Mount Saint Vincent at the commencement exercises this afternoon in the auditorium of the college. Cardinal Hayes will award the degrees.

Discussion of the advisability of nominating a Democrat for Vice President, centering on former Governor Joseph M. Ely of Massachusetts and Lewis W. Douglas, former Director of the Budget, has been resumed by Republican leaders, it was learned yesterday.

General satisfaction was expressed and complete success assured for the two-billion-dollar government financial operation, details of which were announced yesterday. Banks and government bond dealers reported a widespread demand for both the 2 3/4 per cent 15-18-year bonds and the 1 3/8 per cent five-year notes.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., June 1. -- Except for Walter Hagen, who seldom gets to the scene of a national open championship until the last minute, and silver-haired Tommy Armour, practically all of golf's "who's who" were on the Baltusrol Golf Club course today tuning up for the Untied States open, which starts here on Thursday and continues through Saturday.

The Securities and Exchange Commission, which was criticized recently by the United States Supreme Court for using allegedly unfair tactics in its investigation of the activities of J. Edward Jones, dealer in oil royalties, won two victories and suffered one defeat yesterday in the Federal courts here.
DES MOINES, Iowa, June 1 (AP). -- Returns tonight from the Republican primary gave Senator Lester J. Dickinson a 2-to-1 lead over his nearest rival for the Senatorial nomination.
WASHINGTON, June 1. -- A summary of the main provisions of the revised Tax Bill as reported for the Senate Finance Committee today by Acting Crairman King follows:

The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary arrived at the Ambrose Channel Lightship at 9:03 A.M., yesterday, making the voyage of 3,158 miles from Cherbourg breakwater in 4 days, 12 hours, 24 minutes, which was forty-two minutes longer than the maiden voyage of the Normandie last year.
WASHINGTON, June 1. -- The separate dissenting opinion of Justice Stone in the New York minimum wage case, in which Justices Brandeis and Cardozo concurred, follows:
JERUSALEM, June 1. -- Arab youth leaders who have been conducting a strike in Palestine for forty-two days are concentrating now on efforts to collect funds to keep up the strike.

The nation's first major effort to provide economic stability for its aged and jobless citizens was started in this State yesterday with the opening of regional offices of the Federal Social Security Board at 45 Broadway.

In addressing the June grand jury that he swore in yesterday, Judge Peter J. Brancato, in the Kings County Court, warned its members they were not to indict persons on "flimsy grounds" and warned against attempts to influence their judgment.

A possible solution to the "3X" murders that terrorized nocturnal couples in sparsely settled sections of Queens in 1930 was provided yesterday by the arrest of a man in Elizabethtown, N.Y., who, the police declared, confessed to the crimes.

A taxi rank nearly six blocks long lined up on the west side of Twelfth Avenue yesterday afternoon to serve the passengers debarking from the Queen Mary. It was open to both independents and fleet cabs, but so many of both appeared that it was placed under strict police supervision and was not opened for formation until 1:30 o'clock.
WORCESTER, Mass., June 1. -- The Boston Bees, en route to the West, dropped off here today to play an exhibition game with Holy Cross and were on the short end of a 12-3 score.
Two jurors were chosen and one defendant pleaded guilty yesterday at the opening of the Drukman conspiracy trial before Supreme Court Justice Erskine C. Rogers in Brooklyn.

Application for listing on the New York Stock Exchange of 236,235 shares of no-par common stock of the American Seating Company has been approved by the committee on stock list of the Exchange. Of these shares 33,360 are reserved for conversion of the company's ten-year 6 per cent convertible gold notes.

TRENTON, N.J., June 1. -- Fortified with an opinion by Attorney General David T. Wilentz that about $15,000,000 due New Jersey from the estate of the late Dr. John T. Dorrance may be considered as anticipated revenue for the State's coming fiscal year, beginning July 1, the joint appropriations committee of the Legislature completed tonight work on the annual Appropriations Bill and the separate budget for the Highway Department.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- Indicating a heavy oversubscription of the Treasury's offering of $600,000,000 of 2 3/4 per cent bonds and $400,000,000 of 1 3/8 per cent notes, Secretary Morgenthau announced that the books on the cash offerings for these securities would be closed this midnight.

Most commodity futures were lower in quiet trading on the local markets yesterday. Gains were made by sugar, cocoa and cottonseed oil. On the cash markets cotton was higher, and declines appeared in wheat, corn, rye, oats, butter, tins and silk.

An old Brooklyn holding of the Van Wyck family passed to new control when heirs of one of the earliest Dutch settlers here sold the business building at 77 to 81 De Kalb Avenue, it was announced yesterday.
Vincent Norman, 5 years old, of 27-24 Twenty-first Street, Astoria, was rescued from the swift cross currents of Hell Gate in the East River yesterday afternoon by the master of a fishing schooner.

One wonders how many of those Americans who are shocked at the revelations of the lynchings and other crimes attributed to the Black Legion realize how this movement stems directly from the unchecked and almost unrebuked lynchings of Negroes which have occurred in America for the last fifty years.
WASHINGTON, June 1. -- Leaving a record of nearly 1,000 cases handled at this term, the Supreme Court adjourned today until Oct. 5, after one of the most historic sessions in its lifetime.

Walter Frank in today's issue discussed the Koshland Supreme Court decision in terms of income tax problems. Obviously a share of common stock is a fraction of the worth of the corporation; the value cannot be increased by splitting it into pieces; a dollar note changed into halves does not mean income.

Dr. ARTUR RODZINSKI, one of the New York Philharmonic's conductors next season, had a short letter on this page yesterday about touring in Italy. It made one think of the author of Proverbs, who, it will be recalled, found four things beyond his comprehension.
PARIS, June 1. -- France's new legislature began its four-year term this afternoon with an exemplarily quiet session.

Dr. Milton Charles Winternitz, Anthony Professor of Pathology at Yale University, will give the commencement address tonight at the annual exercises of the Long Island College of Medicine, to be held at the Brooklyn Academy of Medicine.

ALBANY, June 1. -- Governor Lehman signed today the bill urged by the State Conference of Mayors which is designed to place cities and villages on a more sound financial basis and possibly lighten the tax load borne by real estate.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- One more item of industrial reform legislation was nullified by the Supreme Court today when the justices, in a 5-to-4 decision, declared the New York State Minimum Wage Law for Women and Children unconstitutional as violating the due process clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, June 1. -- The coming November elections will be the determining factor in independence for Puerto Rico, Antonio R. Barcelo, head of the Liberal party, asserted on his return from Washington today.

ROME, June 1. -- Interest and speculation have been aroused in political and diplomatic circles in Rome by the arrival of the Earl of Mansfield, A.R. Wise and Mr. de Courcy, members of the imperial policies group of the British Conservative party.

Clearing weather improved conditions west of the Mississippi River yesterday, but prices on the Cotton Exchange advanced again as a result of increasing anxiety over the crop in Georgia and the Carolinas, where the rainfall last month was the smallest for a May in many years.

The Republican National Convention is urged to nominate a Democrat of "national reputation" for the Vice Presidency on the Republican ticket in a front-page editorial in today's editions of The New York Herald Tribune.

The engagement of $39,277,000 gold abroad for shipment here on last Saturday was reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The operations included $18,913,000 of the metal taken in Paris; $18,978,000, Holland; $1,189,000, Mexico, and $197,000, India.

The possibility of a change in the "deceptive appearance" clause in the pending Copeland Food and Drug Bill, dealing with adulteration, was reported yesterday at the opening session of the annual convention of the Flavoring Extract Manufacturers Association of the United States at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

With a little more than three days to be spent in port here before she puts to sea again, the Queen Mary will become today a veritable sightseer's paradise. But of the million or more persons who would like to tread her decks, only a few thousand will have the opportunity on this trip.

MOUNT VERNON, N.J., June 1. -- A report vigorously denouncing Fascist tendencies in government and industry and committing the church to a progressive program of social action was adopted this afternoon by the New York East Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church at the close of its eighty-eighth annual session here today.

PINE BEACH, N.J., June 1. -- The annual presentation of awards was made at the Admiral Farragut Naval Academy here this afternoon and followed by the last parade. Governor Hoffman, who was scheduled to make the presentations, was kept in Trenton by a Board of Pardons meeting and the awards were presented by Admiral S.S. Robison, superintendent.

Stockholders of the Great Northern Railway bought about $94,000,000 of the $99,422,400 of general mortgage 4 per cent convertible bonds, due in 1946, that were offered to them by the company for subscription last March, it was announced yesterday at the office of the First National Bank.

GENEVA, June 1. -- The British Government regards the establishment of order in Palestine as of first importance and will not be deflected from its policy by riotsor threats, H.H. Trusted, speaking for the mandatory power, assured the League of Nations permanent mandates commission this afternoon.

The city of Buffalo, N.Y., will consider tenders on June 9 for a new issue of $2,700,000 of tax-anticipation certificates, to be dated June 15, 1936, and to mature Dec. 15, 1936. Bidders are asked to name a rate of interest not exceeding 6 per cent.

Mail orders received in the wholesale markets here yesterday were again substantial, reflecting continued active trade last week in most sections of the country. Sheer and cotton dresses were in active demand. Pastel and white coats were still somewhat slow, but the peak of the retail call for this merchandise is expected this week and next.

The Earl of Dudley, head of the British Iron and Steel Federation, invited leaders of the steel industry in the United States last night to pool their resources, experience and skill with the International Steel Cartel for the development of world markets for their common good.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, speaking yesterday afternoon at the class day ceremonies of Columbia College seniors, praised American colleges for developing in their students high standards of thought, honesty of character and good manners.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on May 27 shows increases for the week of $15,000,000 in total loans and investments, $67,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks and $172,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, and decreases of $15,000,000 in time deposits and $26,000,000 in deposit balances standing to the credit of domestic banks.

The seventy-sixth commencement exercises of the New York Homeopathic Medical College and Flower Hospital will be held tonight at the Plaza Hotel, with the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, pastor of Christ Church, as the commencement speaker. Seventy-seven graduates will receive the degree of Doctor of Medicine, and thirty-eight will be graduated as nurses.

With interest and investment circles centered on the Treasury's security offering, the bond market on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday was a dull affair. Trading was of routine character, with prices, even among the pivotal and more speculative issues, fluctuating irregularly within narrow limits. Total transactions amounted to $8,017,600, compared with $9,766,000 on last Friday.

Governor LEHMAN has signed a bill authorizing the Public Service Commission to experiment with sliding-scale rates, on the Washington model. Under an agreement between the Potomac Electric Light and Power Company and the District Commission, reached in 1924 after prolonged controversy, a value was put on the

Another group of men and women investors testified for the State yesterday in the General Sessions trial of William F. Baeck, a vice president of the defunct Lawyers Title and Mortgage Company. Baeck is being tried on an indictment he violated Section 662 of the Penal Law in issuing one of the title company's mortgage certificates in 1932, on property owned by another corporation, in excess of the limit set by the section.

The defense in the compulsory prostitution trial before Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook and a jury opened yesterday with a plea of guilty by one of the ten men at the bar and with charges by another that members of Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey's staff had tried to coerce him into perjury.

The distance by rail from Jamaica, Queens, to the Pennsylvania Station is roughly eleven miles. While thousands of commuters ride daily between these two points, probably none, with a single exception, has thought of the distance in any other terms but a necessary evil that separates them from their work in the morning and their homes at night.

OKLAHOMA CITY, June 1 (AP). -- Mrs. Dan Chandler of Dallas, with a sub-par 79, won medalist honors in the women's Southern golf championship today. Mrs. Chandler's score, one under par, bettered by four strokes that of her nearest rival, Miss Betty Jameson of Austin, who carded 42, 41 -- 83.

TARRYTOWN. N.Y., June 1. -- Twenty-two girls were graduated this morning from Marymount College here, receiving their diplomas from Cardinal Hayes, Archbishop of New York. Judge Martin T. Manton of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals delivered the commencement address, urging the girls to follow the principles of justice and liberty learned in college.

Charging the Federal courts with "greedy seizure of dictatorial powers over the State and Federal governments during the past year" that creates an "alarming threat to newspaper workers and to labor," the American Newspaper Guild in convention at the Hotel Astor yesterday adopted a report calling for a constitutional amendment to protect the rights of labor.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- The Standard Products Company of Cleveland has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 101,000 shares of $1-par value common stock.

OTTAWA, June 1 (Canadian Press). -- Books will be opened on Wednesday for a new issue of Dominion of Canada bonds, of approximately $207,871,200. Par of the money will be used next Fall to convert three issues amounting to $187,871,200.
Many parties will be held in connection with the supper dance on the Belvedere Roof of the Astor on Thursday for the benefit of the Community Music Schools.

If Henry A. Wise Wood will consult the official reports on commercial vice made to the Municipal Council of Paris in the years since the war, he will discover that State supervision of prostitution has not succeeded in checking venereal disease in Paris. Nor has it succeeded in checking brutal treatment of the prostitute and her economic exploitation by male parasites.

Marking the end of Class Day activities at Columbia College yesterday, the annual promenade of the senior class was held in John Jay Hall. More than 200 couples attended the dance, which was the last social event at the college this semester.
WASHINGTON, June 1. -- The minority report on the Senate Tax Bill, filed today by Senator Black in behalf of himself and Senator La Follette, follows:

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., June 1. -- Asserting that the movement for the safe use of motor vehicles is sweeping the country, with the most influential public agencies and private organizations striving to reduce highway accidents, J.M. Orr, general manager of the Equitable Auto Company of Pittsburgh, outlined a six-point program today before the Society of Automotive Engineers.

Following the example of Governor LANDON, Senator VANDENBERG has answered the questions of a reporter and thus given his opinions to the country over a wide radio hook-up. He states his views not as a candidate for the Presidency but as a Senator who desires to continue to work for the Republican party in the office which he now holds.

The Zenith Radio Corporation reported yesterday for the year ended on April 30 a net profit of $1,212,752 after the deduction of Federal taxes, depreciation and other charges. The earnings were equal to $2.46 each on 492,464 shares of no-par capital stock.

Railroad stations throughout the city were crowded yesterday as twenty-three Eastern railroads, in accordance with the recent ruling of the Interstate Commerce Commission, reduced their travel rates to the lowest levels since the beginning of the century.

Victor F. Ridder, Works Progress Administrator, threatened yesterday to withdraw all of the 31,313 WPA workers on projects in Queens unless the citizens of the borough made it clear to Borough President Harvey and other officials that they wanted the relief work to continue.
The City Bank Farmers Trust Company has been appointed trustee for $30,000,000 of twenty-year debentures due Feb. 1, 1956, of the Columbia Oil and Gasoline Corporation.

Floyd L. Carlisle, chairman of the Consolidated Edison Company, announced yesterday his gratification at the signing by Governor Lehman of a bill permitting the merger of public utility companies in New York State when not less than 95 per cent of the voting stock is owned.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., June 1. -- The "sins of respectability" were pointed out today to an audience of about 1,500 men and women by Loudon Hamilton, generally regarded in the loose organization of the Oxford Groups as second only to Dr. Frank N.D. Buchman, who gave the Oxford movement its present form fifteen years ago.

With most of the European markets closed yesterday in observance of Whitmonday, the stock market here was relatively quiet but maintained a firm undertone throughout the day. Trade reports since the closing on Friday were reassuring, and the terms of the mid-June Treasury financing, as announced yesterday, were orthodox, assuring complete success of the undertaking.

Three honorary degrees, in addition to forty-five degrees in course, will be awarded tonight at the commencement exercises of St. Francis College in the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The Most Rev. Raymond E. Kearney, Auxiliary Bishop of Brooklyn, will preside.
A college boy, tempted by the mild weather to go for a swim although the season was still too young to make bathing comfortable, was drowned yesterday afternoon in the ocean off Coney Island.

Continuing its program of coordinating and unifying its personnel, the United States Steel Corporation issued yesterday the first edition of US Steel News, a monthly magazine to be distributed among its 210,000 employes. This is the first periodical to be issued by the corporation for its employes, although several of its subsidiaries have issued such publications.

The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary met all expectations during her maiden voyage to the United States, and will make a try on some later trip for a new transatlantic speed record, Commodore Sir Edgar T. Britten, master of the ship, said yesterday in a radio address.
WASHINGTON, June 1. -- Miss Valerie Prochnik, daughter of the Austrian Minister and Mme. Prochnik, was married today to Jean Raymond de Sibour, son of Viscount and Viscountess J. Henri de Sibour.

The value of scientific analysis of markets for the purposes of judging probable sales and also for guidance in planning advertising campaigns in various sections, was outlined to the Sales Executives Club of New York, Inc., yesterday by Dr. L.D.H. Weld, director of research for McCann-Erickson, Inc.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- The House today passed a bill authorizing lump-sum payments by the Federal Government in lieu of taxes on Federally owned housing projects and also authorizing the fixing of rents on low-cost housing projects at a figure below that representing a "fair return" on the projects, most of which are under the PWA.
Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday the reappointment to office of two of his original supporters in the Fusion movement, James E. Finegan and Frederic Kernochan.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- Reports of transactions in securities by officers and directors of corporations and beneficial owners of their stocks, as reported for April to the Securities and Exchange Commission, again showed sales of considerable volume, according to a summary made public today by the commission.

The Supreme Court has been swatting the big fellows of the New Deal legislation, the NRA, the AAA and the Guffey Coal Act -- the leaders, if you please. But down in the ranks there have been some jobs extremely well done by less spectacular and up to now uncontested New Deal measures.
ANNAPOLIS, June 1. -- A typical June week program was presented at the Naval Academy today, as visitors from all parts of the nation poured in on Annapolis.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- Welcomed by President and Mrs. Roosevelt, and addressed also by Secretary Hull and Secretary Wallace before going to the White House for a garden party unique in its history, more than 6,000 country women of the world, including delegates from every State in the Union and twenty-two foreign countries, opened here today their third triennial conference, the first ever held in this country.

GIBRALTAR, June 1. -- Whatever hope the government's Tourist Bureau may have had of encouraging American vacationists to travel in Spain this Summer has already been virtually dissipated by political strife. Unrest promoted by Marxists and labor unions makes it impossible to guarantee train service, interurban bus services or even hotel and restaurant accommodations in the principal cities.

VIENNA, June 1. -- With the secrecy that usually surrounds the frequent trips of Austrian statesmen to Italy, Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg left Vienna tonight for Venice. It is believed that Venice is not his ultimate destination, but that when he arrives there he will be informed where the political conference for which he is going to Italy can he held.

The Gdynia America liner Batory, the latest addition to Poland's merchant fleet, sailed last night from Hoboken on her first eastbound trip with 662 passengers. About 1,000 persons visited the ship in the evening, many of them having come a distance to view the liner.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French frano on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

TRENTON, N. J., June 1. -- Governor Harold G. Hoffman sent to the Senate for confirmation tonight the appointment of Colonel Mark O. Kimberling, warden of the State penitentiary, as superintendent of the New Jersey State Police to succeed Colonel H. Norman Schwarzkopf.

The United States Treasury undertook yesterday the largest peacetime financing operation in the country's history and met with a highly favorable response. Two issues of new securities were offered. One consisted of eighteen-year bonds bearing interest at 2 3/4 per cent and the other of five-year notes with interest at 1 3/8 per cent.
MANAGUA, Nicaragua, June 1. -- This capital was tense under an armed truce today after yesterday's hostilities in which the National Guard fought with troops guarding the Presidential palace.

A group of officials of the United States Lines, competitors of the Cunard White Star Line in the North Atlantic trade, witnessed the arrival of the Queen Mary in their own tug. They had attended the annual meeting of stockholders of the parent International Mercantile Marine Company in Hoboken, and as soon as business was ended boarded the tug and went down the bay, docking later at the Battery.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- Representative Zioncheck's erratic career came to a temporary halt, at least, when the police put him in a ward at Gallinger Municipal Hospital today for observation as to his sanity.

It was Father and Son Day up at the 300-acre woodland retreat of the Campfire Club last Saturday. By some miracle of self-sacrifice the fathers actually got out of the way and let the youngsters have the run of the place, which made the event unique for a Father and Son program.

LONDON, June 1 (by Wireless). -- Brig. Gen. E.F. Norton, leader of the 1924 Mount Everest expedition, holds the view that Hugh Ruttledge's party still has a chance to reach the summit of Mount Everest.
A novel exhibition made up entirely of art by New York newspaper men and women is being held at Contemporary Arts, 41 West Fifty-fourth Street. It opened yesterday and will continue until June 20.

CHICAGO, June 1. -- Outside and professional interest in the wheat market on the Board of Trade today was at a low ebb and while there were reports indicating that rain was needed to prevent deterioration of the crop in parts of the Dakotas and in the southern sections of the Prairie Provinces in Canada, the forecast indicated lower temperatures and scattered showers.
Great throngs from New York and New Jersey turned out yesterday to welcome the Queen Mary.

Final details of the completion of the refunding operation of Chicago Park District were announced yesterday by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., refunding agent and depositary. Approximately 98 per cent of all bonds of the park districts superseded by Chicago Park District have, it is stated, been deposited under the refunding offer of Chicago Park District, which offer was declared effective on April 21.

Excursion steamers listed uncomfortably, speed boats cut frothy swaths in the olive-drab bay and a score of planes etched invisible trajectories on a cloudless sky yesterday as the Queen Mary moved into New York Harbor.

HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., June 1. -- The annual commencement exercises of Peddle School ended today with an address by Headmaster Allen V. Heely of the Lawrenceville School. Mr. Heely said the sixty-three graduating students were passing through their most crucial period of life and urged them to seek truth with a scientific approach and without fear or favor.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith expressed the opinion yesterday that business conditions in the consumer's goods field had decidedly improved, whereas the heavy industries, such as building, were lagging due to high taxation, which disrupts the flow of capital.

BUENOS AIRES, June 1. -- Robert B. Delano, 22 years old, a second cousin of President Roosevelt, killed himself today at Barranqueras, a small port on the Parana River in Argentine territory of the Chaco. He came here several months ago, saying he was interested in developing cotton in Argentine Chaco.

ALBANY, June 1. -- Governor Lehman, on being informed that the Supreme Court had set aside the New York Minimum Wage Law for women in industry, and Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner, both deplored the court's action.

Since the organization of the Fashion Originators Guild of America there has been greater security in the dress business with resulting advantages to retailers, the public and labor, it was testified yesterday in a Federal court action by William Filene's Sons Company against the guild.

LONDON, June 1. -- A large holiday crowd saw the American international polo team batter its way through opposition as strong as itself on goals at the Hurlingham Club today to score a 20-to-5 victory.

Lambert Fairchild in an attack on me and my associates in the Americanism Committee of New York County American Legion for the publication of "Americanism; What Is It?" speaks of "much loose discussion" concerning the booklet. Right!

The public ceremonies of the Columbia College chapter of Phi Beta Kappa were held in the Harkness Academic Theatre of the university yesterday afternoon after the class day exercises. The election of twenty-seven seniors to membership in the society was announced.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- Men who until a few days ago were high in the councils of the Townsend old age pension movement, two of them as members of the directorate of Old Age Revolving Pensions, Ltd., told the House investigating committee today that in their opinion the movement, as now organized, cannot long survive.

ROSLYN, L.I., June 1. -- Charles Hopkins offered tonight as the opening play of the Summer Robert E. Sherwood's comedy, "The Queen's Husband," to an audience of North Shore society members in the Theatre of the Four Seasons.

The five-to-four decision of the Supreme Court declaring the New York Minimum Wage Law for women and children unconstitutional is unfortunate in more than one respect. It was reached by a majority of only one, as was the four-to-three decision of the New York Court of Appeals against the act.

ALBANY, June 1. -- Representatives of civic, church and reform organizations today joined hands in urging Governor Lehman, in the interest of law and order, to veto the bill of Assemblyman Hall, Nassau Republican, which would legalize dog racing at county fairs in Nassau, Monroe and Erie Counties.

Two hours before the new British liner Queen Mary started up the bay to her North River pier on her maiden transatlantic crossing yesterday afternoon the annual meeting of the stockholders of the International Mercantile Marine Company was convened at 51 Newark Street, Hoboken.

CHICAGO, June 1. -- Offerings of hogs here today were again heavy but met with a good demand. Prices generally were 5 cents a hundred-weight higher, although some extreme sales were regarded as 10 cents above the level on Friday. Hogs weighing less than 225 pounds showed the most strength early, with business in the final rounds mainly steady.

PHILADELPHIA, June 1. -- Weather clear; wind brisk. In this corner, Jack Crawford, the sharp-featured court veteran from Australia. In that corner, Wilmer Allison, the blond terror from Texas, also a veteran of the tennis wars. Crawford is the taller and also carries a trifle in the way of extra weight. Rufe Davis, another veteran, in the chair.

As Mayor La Guardia stood by Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine swore in 180 probationary patrolmen yesterday and promoted twenty of their elders in the service to higher rank. The posts include promotions to deputy inspector, captain, seven lieutenants and eleven sergeants.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- The Senate passed late today, by a vote of 62 to 14, the Deficiency Appropriation Bill containing $1,425,000,000 for work relief and $300,000,000 for grants and loans on public works to be expended during the coming fiscal year.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- In a sharply worded telegram today to Louis Leonard, secretary of the Amalgamated Association of Iron, Steel and Tin Workers, John L.
