Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers of America, demanded that the steel union's executive officers decide whether they will "cooperate or obstruct" in his efforts to organize the steel industry.

Miss Mabelle Lane gave a farewell dinner last night in the Viennese Roof Garden of the St. Regis for Arthur Bliss Lane, United States Minister to Nicaragua, and Mrs. Lane, who are sailing tomorrow. The other guests were Mr. and Mrs. Acosta Nichols, Mr. and Mrs. Lane Lovell, Miss Margaret B. Lane, Wallace Tobin and Philip Baldwin.
The Queen Mary -- latest queen of the western ocean -- stood into port yesterday and all hands agreed that "the liner is a lady."

Holders of city of Porto Alegre (Brazil) forty-year 8 per cent bonds of 1921 have been notified by Ladenburg, Thalmann Co., special agents, that funds have been deposited to pay 22 1/2 per cent of the June 1 coupons, amounting to $9 for each $40 coupon and $4.50 for each $20 coupon.

A tower duplex apartment of fourteen rooms and seven baths in the San Remo, Seventy-fourth to Seventy-fifth Street, Central Park West, was rented to Theodore C. Wiehe, vice president of Schenley Products Company, it was reported yesterday by the Real Estate Bureau of the New York State Banking Department, which is in control of the building.

One of the largest recent deals in Harlem was reported yesterday, involving a change in ownership for a large Third Avenue corner plot. Several properties of varied types in the Bronx also figured in the day's realty transactions.

LONDON, June 1. -- A secret representative body of German trade unionists has been set up "to overthrow Hitler," according to J.C. Little, president, addressing the annual conference of the national committee of the Amalgamated Engineering Union at Morecambe today.

EAST WILLISTON, L.I., June 1. -- With her chip shots as her chief asset, Mrs. Edward G. Peterson of North Hempstead put together 42 and 40 for the medal-winning 82 today as the annual women's Long Island championship began at the Wheatley Hills Golf Club.
Among the celebrities aboard the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary to reach here yesterday were the eight members of the women's United States golf team, back from their invasion of British links.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- Democratic politicians, after getting the gist of the Supreme Court decision today in the New York minimum wage case, were less certain that the forces which will seek in the Philadelphia platform a plank advocating a constitutional amendment can be held in committee and off the floor. It had been rather generally expected that no minority report on this proposal would be made.

OSSINING, N.Y., June 1. -- A life-term convict was struck on the head and fatally injured in Sing Sing late today by other prisoners. The dead man was a musician in the prisoners' band and officials expressed the belief that other members of the band might have considered him responsible for a recent cut in their small salary.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 1. -- Yale University tonight announced the award of 161 athletic insignia. Eight managerial appointments were made and officers elected.

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 1. -- The Yanks came here today for their annual exhibition baseball game with the Army nine and won rather easily, 6 to 2. Five thousand spectators crowded the Army's stands on the plains diamond, many of whom were small boys dismissed from near-by schools to get a glimpse of the big leaguers in action.

LIMA, Peru, June 1. -- Minister of Marine Hector Mercado gave a reception Friday at the country club for Admiral Charles P. Snyder and other officers of the visiting United States fleet. A party of 300 men traveled by the central highway to Rio Blanco.

Several German societies have withdrawn from the Long Island Tercentenary celebration, it was revealed yesterday, because the Tercentenary committee has refused to invite the German Ambassador to its dinner, to be held next Saturday night at the Hotel St. George.

In a technical manner of speaking, a new theatrical season starts each June 1. This morning is the time for leniency, however, and, waiving technicalities, to decline to clutter up a fresh page in the ledger with "To My Husband." That, then, belonged to last season, and since there are no openings for a considerable stretch, the Broadway drama may now wander amiably to the country.

PHILADELPHIA, June 1. -- On the same turf tennis courts where the Davis Cup was lost to France in 1927, the United States today suffered its first defeat in the American zone in the intervening nine years.
Columbia University, holding its 182d annual commencement exercises today, will confer 4,500 degrees in courses upon students and post-graduates and will award 273 diplomas and certificates.

"Maxwell Anderson's 'Winterset,'" said the marquee of the Martin Beck Theatre last evening with simple dignity, and therewith an event of the passing season came back to become an event once more. There have been some changes since the night it was born last September, an untried candidate for Broadway favor.

PARIS, June 1. -- Firing a devastating attack that observing critics pronounced as almost perfect, Baron Gottfried yon Cramm gave Germany a clean sweep of singles titles in the French hard court tennis championships today by toppling England's great Fred Perry, 6 -- 0, 2 -- 6, 6 -- 2, 2 -- 6, 6 -- 0.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- Astonishment, indignation and disappointment greeted the Supreme Court's decision in the New York minimum wage case from the ranks of labor, Congress and women advocates of such laws. The National Woman's Party, ardent supporter of equal rights for women, hailed the decision with delight on the ground that laws seeming to "protect" women really exploited them.

A collection of thirty imported models, together with supplemental fashion sketches, is being shown to a selected list of local garment manufacturers by the Associated Merchandising Corporation, it was stated yesterday by Colonel P.J. Reilly, executive director.

SALEM, N.H., June 1 (AP). -- Bay Bubble, sprightly daughter of Bubbling Over, held off the challenge of Black Mistress and won the Tomlin Handicap, six-furlong main event at Rockingham Park today. First by a neck, Bay Bubble paid $7.60.
WASHINGTON, June 1. -- The President and Mrs. Roosevelt, Secretaries Hull and Wallace, welcomed the Associated Country Women of the World at the third triennial convention of the organization.

SYRACUSE, June 1. -- The 148th General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America late this afternoon affirmed the sentences of lower judicatories suspending from the ministry the Rev. Dr. J. Gresham Machen of Philadelphia and six Fundamentalist associates for refusing to resign from the independent board of foreign missions.
The disappearance on March 6 of Dr. Arthur F. Cody, president of the Woodlawn Sanitarium in the Bronx, was solved yesterday with the finding of his body in the Hudson River off 125th Street.

The current gold shipments from Paris to New York reflect largely a means by which the transfer of French capital to London is being effected, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York says in its monthly review, published yesterday. There has been no evidence, the bank says, of an increase in French balances in New York corresponding to the gold imported.

Cheered by thousands ashore and afloat, Great Britain's new 80,000-ton challenger for supremacy among the merchant vessels of the world, the 1,018-foot Queen Mary, completed her maiden voyage to the United States yesterday afternoon, sliding into her berth at West Fiftieth Street as smoothly and easily as a yacht.

Taking a hand in the competitive situation existing between manufacturers of glass and tin beer containers, the United States Brewers Association yesterday announced it has obtained pledges from producers to delete controversial advertising of an unethical nature in the future.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 2. -- With several of the teams entered engaging in practice matches on the grounds today, the Meadow Brook Club announced the entry and the draw for its June tournaments, which start this week-end with games on Saturday and Sunday.

While business failures declined in the manufacturing and wholesale divisions in the week ended May 28 as compared with the figures for the previous week, there was an increase in insolvencies in the retail branch, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

MEXICO, D.F., June 2. -- Half a million members of the Confederation of Mexican Workers will quit work June 18 for half an hour in the morning and for half an hour in the afternoon according to a resolution adopted this evening at the confederation's convention here.

Awards to the number of 105 have been granted to Brooklyn College athletes for participation in sports during the Spring term, it was announced yesterday by Louis R. Oshins, college manager of athletics.

With sales this year 300 per cent ahead of the corresponding period of 1933 and still climbing, producers gathered at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday to attend the annual meeting of the National Piano Manufacturers Association unanimously predicted new volume records for the industry in the next two years.

SYRACUSE, June 2. -- The General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America unanimously adopted today a resolution of protest against the persecution of religious and racial minorities in Germany.

Increasing nervousness over the absence of relief in the drought areas in the Atlantic States started the broadest buying movement of the year on the Cotton Exchange yesterday. Under an active demand from both foreign and domestic trade interests, particularly Southern mills in the heart of the dry region, prices moved steadily upward from the opening and closed at the top with gains of 4 to 31 points.

WASHINGTON, June 2. -- A picture of a past that linked him with bootlegging and illicit narcotics today was painted around Edward J. Margett, Townsend leader in California, in affidavits, documents from the files of the Department of Justice and the testimony placed before the House committee which is investigating the Townsend old-age pension plan.

Marie Nielson, 22 years old, a former show girl, who, as Miss America, won a beauty contest at Atlantic City in 1931, was committed to the House of Detention for Women in default of $10,000 bail by Judge James G. Wallace in General Sessions yesterday.

The 185 employes of the General Motors Corporation now earning more than $20,000 a year each, received in 1935 an aggregate of $7,031,983, compared with $3,170,215 in 1934, the annual report of the corporation to the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed yesterday.

SHANGHAI, Wednesday, June 3. -- The South China government of Canton, Japanese officials said today, has issued a manifesto demanding a national war against Japan. The Japanese declared South China had pledged full aid to Nanking in a war against "Japan's aggression" in North China.

Abraham Luckman, a brother of the Meyer Luckman who was convicted as one of the murderers of Samuel Drukman, was found by the police yesterday afternoon in a dazed condition in the gas-filled kitchen of his three-room apartment at 45 Cook Street, Brooklyn.

LONDON, June 2. -- Great Britain called on five veterans and a 22-year-old newcomer today to halt America's string of five successive victories when the Wightman Cup tennis matches are played at Wimbledon June 12-13.

Nullification by the Supreme Court of the New York Minimum Wage Law "has brought joy to the hearts of those who believe in a labor market unhampered by standards of decency," declared George Meany, president of the State Federation of Labor, in an address last night over Station WEVD.

WASHINGTON, June 2. -- Republican leaders were interested but skeptical today in commenting on the proposal for a coalition of Republicans and conservative Democrats with one of the latter as the Republican Vice Presidential candidate, as set forth in an editorial in this morning's New York Herald Tribune.
CLEVELAND, June 2. -- Former President Hoover alone will be invited by the committee on arrangements to address the Republican National Convention here on June 10.

Efforts to bring about an open and formal coalition between Republicans and Democrats this year are strongly advocated in some quarters. One plan is to invite distinguished Democrats who are against the President to address the Republican National Convention at Cleveland.

Conflicting provisions in the city's code of traffic ordinances would be eliminated under a revision of the regulations introduced yesterday in the Board of Aldermen by Aldermen Alexander A. Falk and Michael E. Pellegrino of Manhattan.

RIVERHEAD, L.I, June 2. -- Past Long Island's towns and maples, her lakes and pastures, her golf courses and her quail farm, Governor Lehman sped here today with a motor caravan of ninety-four cars in connection with the tercentenary of what is now Kings, Queens, Nassau and Suffolk Counties.

Tony Marino of Pittsburgh gave Lou Salica of Brooklyn a setback in his attempt to regain the bantamweight title when he outpointed the former champion in ten rounds at the Queensboro Arena last night. Marino won the unanimous decision of referee and judges in a hard fought battle before a crowd of 2,000.

Murray W. Stand, majority leader of the Board of Aldermen, introduced a local law yesterday providing for the admission of unaccompanied minor children to theatres under strict supervision of the License Commissioner.

DETROIT, June 2. -- The prosecution, in its effort to bring fifteen members of the Black Legion to trial for the murder of Charles A. Poole, traced the background of the crime in a preliminary court examination today and offered evidence of the terror by which the organization bound its own members to it.

Directors of the Reynolds Spring Company declared yesterday a stock dividend of 100 per cent in addition to the regular dividend of 25 cents a share on the common stock now outstanding, which amounts to about 145,000 shares. Both dividends are payable on June 29 to holders of record of June 15.
Various residential properties in Nassau County were reported sold yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 2. -- Working under the direction of Representative O'Connor of New York, chairman of the Rules Committee, the House today approved without a record vote the Senate bill authorizing two additional Federal judges for the Southern District of New York, and sent the measure to the White House for approval of President Roosevelt.

CHICAGO, June 2 (AP). -- The Inland Daily Press Association adopted a resolution today accusing the Black Senatorial committee of "persecution and harassment against newspapers" and urging "victims of the illegal acts to seek civil damages from agents of the committee."

A bandit, fleeing in an automobile after a $50,000 hold-up, was stopped yesterday morning by a motorcycle policeman, who gave him a ticket for making an improper turn. The driver tried feebly to "square" the summons, then drove off. Half a minute later the policeman learned of the hold-up.

Because of the holiday the number of visiting buyers recorded in the market during the week ended yesterday was the smallest for any week this year. However, the total was above the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES.

Twelfth Avenue, near Fiftieth Street, assumed yesterday the appearance of Main Street on circus day as thousands flocked to view the Queen Mary. Great Britain's giant liner lay at her pier, while crowds walked or drove past or congregated on the east side of the avenue to study her lines and marvel at her size.

ALBANY, June 2. -- More than $2,000,000 of Federal money is to be expended in New York State under the Social Security Act, including the amount that will be turned over to the Social Welfare Department for old-age relief.

More gold was received here yesterday, and more was contracted for abroad. The Federal Reserve Bank reported the receipt of $6,578,300 of the metal, of which $2,429,800 came from France, $2,249,200 from Mexico, $1,680,000 from England and $219,300 from India. The Mexican shipment, presumably, went into the stock of gold held under earmark here for foreign account so that the sum may not be actually added to the imports at this time.

It is the conviction of the signers of this letter that the course of national policy followed by this administration and by its Republican predecessors in the whole post-war period is profoundly reactionary, however much its sponsors may imagine it to be enlightened and progressive, that it is jeopardizing the highest interests of the American people, that it has marked a departure from the enduring principles of American society.
Apartment houses and dwellings were included in the Manhattan realty turnover reported yesterday.

The Rev. Dr. Ralph V. Sockman, pastor of Christ Church, made the address to the seventy-seven doctors and thirty-eight nurses who received degrees and diplomas at the seventy-sixth commencement exercises of the New York Homeopathic Medical College and Flower Hospital held last night at the Plaza Hotel.

PARIS, June 2. -- While the dollar remained firm at the gold point in respect to the franc in the foreign exchange trading today, sterling again moved upward to 85.96 francs to the pound. Forward rates for both currencies, however, were easier.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., June 2. -- Adding a steady 85 to her first-day score of 89 for a thirty-six hole total of 174, Mrs. T.W. Hawes of the Canoe Brook Country Club today took a one-stroke lead in the medal play championship of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association at the Crestmont Golf Club.

LONDON, June 2. -- The self-exiled Ethiopian Emperor will arrive in England tomorrow morning on the liner Orford. He comes incognito, unquestionably at the suggestion of his hosts, whom he will, naturally, seek not to embarrass.

ST. LOUIS, Juno 2. -- Casey Stengel's Dodgers achieved a moral victory today by scoring against the Gas House Gang at Sportsman's Park for the first time this season and knocking out two pitchers in a ninth-inning rally, but they lost the game, 5 -- 4, to make their usual inauspicious Western start.

WASHINGTON, June 2. -- The Niagara Falls Power Company of Buffalo has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering the issuance of $32,493,000 of first and refunding mortgage bonds, 3 1/2 per cent series, due March 1, 1966, the proceeds from the sale of which would be used to reimburse the company for funds used in the redemption of a similar amount of outstanding obligations.

PHILADELPHIA, June 2. -- Reversing a lower court decision, the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals ruled today that war veterans, their wives or widows are not entitled to preferential treatment in the award of jobs on the Federal business census project.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 2 (AP). -- Jaako Joakin Mikkola, a 50-year-old Finlander, today was named head coach of the Harvard varsity track and field team.

After more than an hour of debate yesterday the Aldermanic branch of the Municipal Assembly voted to continue the city's $67,000,000 emergency relief tax program until July 1, 1937, under authority granted by the last Legislature.

Smetana's "The Bartered Bride" was given its fifth and final performance last night at the Metropolitan Opera House. The opera, with its hilarious English version has been performed more times than any other opera in the current popular season at the Broadway house, and each performance has been attended by near-capacity or capacity audiences.

BERLIN, June 2. -- The success of the Washington government in concluding one reciprocal trade treaty after another has aroused considerable apprehension in German official and financial circles regarding the further development of what remains of German-American trade and it has also set many minds thinking of ways and means of preserving and improving this trade.

BERLIN, June 2. -- The Boerse reopened today after its holiday idleness with a continuation of the upward movement that has already sent the stock index 16 per cent above that at the beginning of the year, but the strength was confined entirely to shares and foreign bonds.

Retirement to some men may mean a long vacation for recreation and rest, but to Dr. Walter Damrosch, who in 1928 gave up most of his concert activities after forty-three years as a distinguished conductor, it means an opportunity to devote his talents to creative music, it became known yesterday.

The Public Service Corporation of New Jersey has addressed a letter to the protective committee for holders of National Public Service Corporation 5 per cent debentures expressing a willingness to submit a bid of $5,000,000 for 68 per cent of the common stock of the Jersey Central Power and Light Company, the only important collateral securing the debentures, in the event that the committee decides to offer it at auction.
The address of Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler delivered at the 182d Commencement of Columbia University follows:

Nothing could better expose the weakness of the proposed tax on undistributed profits than the argument that Senators BLACK and LA FOLLETTE put forward in favor of such a tax in their minority report. The chief contention of the two Senators is that the flat corporation tax falls unfairly on the small stockholder and enables the big stockholder to avoid his proper taxes.

ANNAPOLIS, June 2. -- The June Week program at the Naval Academy reached its mid-point today, and the largest crowd of the period was drawn to Worden Field when Miss Julia Bishop of Poland, Ohio, presented the colors to Midshipman John P. Preston of Imperial, Calif., commander of the Fifth Company.

The second dead heat of the meeting and the first of the New York season in which the photographic finish has figured occurred yesterday at Belmont Park when Corundum and Isolater crossed the line as a team in the Ballot Purse. Neither the judges nor an examination of the picture could separate them.

Donations amounting to $3,000 from the United Mine Workers of America to the American Newspaper Guild were confirmed yesterday by Jonathan Eddy, national executive secretary of the Guild. A donation from the union to help the Guild strikers in Newark in the Spring of 1935 was for $1,000.

A variety of properties, stores, apartments, building sites and farm acreage figured in deals reported in Westchester yesterday. Among properties sold were a number of company assets of title and mortgage guarantee concerns in liquidation or rehabilitation under supervision of the Insurance Department.

GENEVA, June 2. -- The United States Government threw its support today in the International Labor Organization's governing body to a proposal by the Japanese workers' delegate that it consider the question of assuring the freedom of association for workers.

OSSINING, N.Y., June 2. -- Edward Farrell, a Sing Sing prison keeper, was suspended here today as a result yesterday of the fatal attack upon Frank Lopez, 44-year-old life-term convict, by other prisoners.

TRENTON, June 2. -- The State's annual Appropriations Bill, carrying a total of $42,691,746, and the Highway Department's Appropriation Bill of $30,017,581 were introduced in the Legislature today before both houses recessed until after the Republican National Convention.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 2. -- Former Senator Hiram Bingham, who will be Connecticut's member of the resolutions committee at Cleveland and who is engaged in preparing a platform draft, rejected the Republican coalition idea today, saying that the platform rather than political affiliation should be used to attract Democrats.

As a result of the termination of the voting trust for common shares of the Columbia Oil and Gasoline Corporation, of which 2,340,655 are being issued to holders of the voting trust certificates, owners of the securities must for the present rely on over-the-counter trading for sale or purchase of shares.

DURHAM, N.C., June 2 (AP). -- Ogden L. Mills, former Secretary of the Treasury, urged today that the people of the United States "firmly resolve to resist to the last all onslaughts on constitutional government, the Bill of Rights and the authority of an independent judiciary."

St. John's University will award 143 degrees and two honorary degrees this afternoon at its sixty-sixth annual commencement exercises at the Brooklyn Academy of Music when three departments of the university, St. John's College, the Teachers College and the Graduate School will present candidates for their awards.
Careful preparations by a liquor-store manager for the possibility of a hold-up resulted last night in the wounding critically of one of three men who held up the store and took $100.

Revocation of the Mayor's order barring taxicabs from the city piers is recommended in a report drafted by the committee on harbor and shipping of the State Chamber of Commerce, it was announced last night. The report will be submitted tomorrow to the monthly meeting of the chamber.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., June 2. -- Mrs. Henry Ford, wife of the automobile manufacturer, arrived here today in her husband's private railway car and spent the day hearing the Oxford Group at its first annual "life changing" assembly here.
NEWARK, N.J., June 2. -- The Newark Bears regained first place in the International League tonight when they defeated Syracuse, 13 to 7, while their rivals, the Buffalo Bisons, remained idle.

The Hupp Motor Car Company reduced its loss in the quarter ended on March 31, according to the report made public yesterday. The net loss, amounting to $265,965 after taxes, depreciation, idle plant expense and other charges, is compared to one of $688,253 in the March quarter a year ago.

Columbia University conferred degrees in course upon 4,498 men and women, awarded 273 diplomas and certificates and bestowed honorary degrees upon seven men and two women of distinguished achievement as its 182d annual commencement exercises last evening.

PARIS, June 2. -- The visit of Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg of Austria to Italy is being watched here with the strongest suspicions and the French press tonight gives vent to rumors of a Hapsburg restoration.

MOSCOW, June 2. -- While Jose R. Capablanca was held to a draw by G. Loewenfisch of Leningrad in the fourteenth round of the international chess masters tournament today, M. Botwinnik, the Soviet champion, defeated his countryman, I. Kan, and gained half a point on the Cuban in the exciting race for the first prize.

Surrounded by motor-cycle policemen, a mile-long fleet of automobiles and buses started from Prospect Park, Brooklyn, for Coney Island yesterday morning. It conveyed 5,400 orphans from sixteen institutions in Brooklyn and Queens. They were the guests for the day of the Long Island Automobile Club on the seventeenth annual orphans' picnic arranged by the club.
PITTSBURGH, June 2 (AP). -- An eighth-inning rally netted two runs and a 5-to-4 victory for the Pirates in their engagement with the Bees today.
Counsel for Charles (Lucky Luciano) Lucania called to the stand yesterday a succession of bookmakers and other gamblers to support the contention that his source of livelihood lay in games of chance.

LONDON, Wednesday, June 3. -- There was a note of sympathy in most newspaper editorials tonight for the man who rose from the job of engine wiper to become a friend of kings, only to pass from public life within six weeks of having let slip a State secret.

The Samuel J. Tilden High baseball team captured the Brooklyn Section 2 title in the P.S.A.L. yesterday by defeating James Madison, 9 to 7, at Erasmus Field. Trailing, 4 to 1, in the fifth, the victors tied the score with a three-run rally which was featured by Henry Ferrioli's triple, accounting for two runs.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP). -- President Roosevelt today proposed that a check-rein be placed on the size of Federal benefit payments to large corporate farming enterprises, some of which received huge sums during the regime of the old AAA.

Preparing for what promises to be one of the most active seasons since 1929, manufacturers in the market here opened the curtains last night on the new fur styles in women's apparel for the Fall and Winter season at a fashion show at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

GENEVA, June 2. -- Argentina formally requested the League of Nations tonight to convoke the Assembly on or about June 16 for "examination of the situation brought about by the annexation of Ethiopia and of the situation in regard to the sanctions enacted by that body."

All fire and allied lines of insurance under control of the Mortgage Commission of the State of New York will be written by a group of companies under a pooling agreement, Wendell P. Barker, chairman, announced yesterday. The plan was agreed upon to avoid discrimination against any class of company doing business in the State.

BOSTON, June 2 (AP). -- The Red Sox ended the Indians' five-game winning streak with a 14-to-6 triumph today in the first clash of their series. As a result, Boston increased its lead over Cleveland for second place to a game and a half.

The Earl of Dudley, an intimate friend of King Edward VIII, who came here with associates to make overtures on behalf of the British Iron and Steel Federation to steel makers in this country to join the International Steel Cartel, was guest at a luncheon yesterday of the directors of the United States Steel Corporation, including J.P. Morgan. Myron C. Taylor presided at the luncheon in the offices of the corporation at 71 Broadway.

The nation's educators "should apologize for their inadequacy," Dr. William E. Grady, Associate Superintendent of Schools, declared yesterday. To prevent maladjustment that leads to juvenile delinquency and crime, he said the pattern of education would have to be changed to increase vocational training and restore the dignity of labor.

' lne New York Exchange for Woman's Work celebrated the fiftyeighth anniversary of its founding at a large luncheon yesterday in the Exchange Restaurant at 541 Madison Avenue. Members of the board of directors and many friends of the organization attended.

TRENTON, June 2. -- The Republican and Democratic parties of New Jersey adopted platforms today at the final sessions of their State conventions. The Democrats came out strongly against new taxes and the Republican party, in a platform considered a defeat for Governor Hoffman, suggested new taxes only "if necessary."

Recommendations for changes in some sections of the Wagner-Ellenbogen housing bill, now before Congress, are embodied in resolutions which have been approved by the executive committee of the Federal Grand Jury Association for the Southern District of New York.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 2. -- A special medal was sent to Governor Harold G. Hoffman today by twelve Princeton undergraduates to commemorate his "fisticuffs" with a newspaper reporter in a New York restaurant two weeks ago.

WASHINGTON, June 2. -- Predicting that the restoration of the gold standard will become before long an important question of policy in many countries, the Brookings Institution, in a study made public today, contended that no existing or prospective deficiency in the supply stood in the way of this development whenever other conditions made such a step advantageous.

Formal offering will be made today of a new issue of $1,400,000 of city of Kansas City, Mo., 3, 2 1/2 and 2 3/4 per cent bonds due on June 1, 1938 to 1975, by a banking syndicate headed by Brown Harriman Co., Inc., and including Eldredge Co., Inc., Stranahan, Harris Co., Inc., City National Bank and Trust Company of Kansas City, the Illinois Company and Crouse Co. of Detroit.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., June 2 (AP). -- Taunton, big bay 5-year-old, captured the feature at Agawam Park today. Taunton won the only mile event on the eight-race program, holding off the late rush of Tack. Jockey Tucker, on Taunton, gained first money by half a length.

Cardinal Hayes conferred degrees upon 108 graduates of the College of Mount Saint Vincent at the commencement exercises yesterday afternoon in the Cardinal Hayes Auditorium of the college. Dr. Joseph J. Reilly of Hunter College gave the address to the graduates.

WASHINGTON, June 2. -- The Wisconsin Power and Light Company was exempted today by the Securities and Exchange Commission from the necessity of making a declaration in connection with its issuance of $1,100,000 of first lien 5 per cent refunding mortgage bonds to be used as collateral for bank loans in a refunding operation, upon the condition of compliance with provisions in a certificate of authority issued by the Public Service Commission of Wisconsin.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., June 2. -- With the arrival of the sometimes late Walter Hagen, everything seems to be complete so far as the United States open golf championship is concerned. It will start Thursday morning and continue through Saturday unless there is a tie at the end of the seventy-two-hole grind over the upper course of the Baltusrol Golf Club.

ROBERT FROST was 38 years old in 1913 when his first book of poems, hardly more than a pamphlet, was published in England at one shilling sixpence. Today his latest book, "A Further Range," is out in a limited edition, a trade edition (Holt, $2.50) and an edition for the Book of the Month Club -- in all, well over 50,000 copies. Success and dilution of talent, you might think, learning of the total.

Angling potpourri: From a reliable source comes word that several fair catches of weakfish have been made in Jamaica Bay in the past week. . . . One fisherman, using shrimp for chum and sandworm bait, boated a nice mess that included a six-pounder. . .

In the dispatch relating to the opening of the Oxford Group's national assembly at Stockbridge, your headline writer gave a wrong slant to a fine story. No group leader has ever "urged" or even tolerated public confessions, in the sense that the average man uses the term.

THE esteemed J.J. Dykes, manager of the White Sox, hove into sight wearing a green suit with hat to match. It was taken for granted that he bought the suit himself, but the hat might have been the reluctant gift of G. Stanley Cochrane.

HAVANA, June 2. -- Dr. Jorge Manach, former Secretary of Education and a leader of the ABC revolutionary organization, was detained this morning when he arrived by steamer from the United States. He was taken before a specially convened urgency court, where he was tried and immediately acquitted. He had been in exile for several months.

Trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange was of routine character and devoid of outstanding developments. The main body of domestic corporation loans reflected a lack of speculative interest and a disposition on the part of traders to "mark time" until final allotments on the new Treasury offering are announced tomorrow.

Approval of the plans for refinancing $38,000,000 of bonds and notes of the city of Asheville and Buncombe County, N.C., including obligations of the Board of Education of the county, was announced yesterday by the bond and note holders' committee.
BIRMINGHAM, June 2 (AP). -Three company deputies fell wounded today in an ambuscade marking the third outbreak of gunplay in Alabama's strike-locked iron-mining district.
WASHINGTON, June 2. -- The Senate Finance Committee's formal report on the tax bill, made public today, contained the following explanation of the revised version it recommended to the Senate:

EAST WILLISTON, L.I., June 2. -- While Mrs. Robert C. Lake, defending titleholder, and Mrs. Edward G. Peterson, yesterday's medalist, were advancing easily through the first round of the women's Long Island golf championship at Wheatley Hills today.

The Art Students League is celebrating this year its sixtieth anniversary and has arranged a large exhibition to signalize the event. It opened with a preview reception last night in the galleries of the American Fine Arts Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street, where -- beginning today, and for one month -- the work may be viewed by the public.
HAVANA, June 2. -- The Supreme Court this afternoon declared public works bonds that have been in default since 1933 constitutional and legal and affirmed that the obligation should be paid.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 2. -- Fifteen men, including six members of police departments and five traffic experts from various parts of the United States and from England, have won fellowships of $1,200 each for study during the next academic year at Harvard University's Bureau for Street Traffic Research.

Primo Carnera, former heavyweight champion of the world, and Isadore Gastanaga, Spanish boxer, will not be permitted to fight again in New York State, according to an edict handed down yesterday by the State Athletic Commission.

NEWARK, N.J., June 2. -- Fifty-nine members of the senior class of the New Jersey College of Pharmacy of Rutgers University will receive the degree of Bachelor of Science in Pharmacy at the school's forty-third annual commencement in the auditorium of the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company here tomorrow evening.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, June 2. -- One of the two government strong-holds in Nicaragua ran up the white flag today and negotiations through the diplomatic corps were expected to bring the surrender of the other to the insurgent National Guard.

Sales of several large apartment houses were among the Bronx deals reported by brokers yesterday. The six-story elevator apartment house on a plot, 125 by 100 feet, at 3,467 De Kalb Avenue, was sold for the Kalbed Realty Corporation to an investing client by Jacob and Emil Leither, Inc.

Arthur Bliss Lane, United States Minister to Latvia, with Mrs. Lane; George Wadsworth, United States Consul General at Jerusalem, with Mrs. Wadsworth, and Charles S. Reed, Consul at Belgrade, accompanied by Mrs. Reed, are among the passengers sailing today for the Channel ports on the Washington of the United States Lines.

The theatre under construction on the site of the old Criterion on Broadway between Forty-fourth and Forty-fifth Streets will open as a first-run motion picture house on Aug. 15, probably as the New Criterion, it was announced yesterday by B.S. Moss, president of the Macon Amusement Corporation, which will operate the house.

KATOWICE, Poland, June 2. -- The trial of 119 young German members of the illegal German National Socialist Workers Movement, accused of conspiring to separate Upper Silesia from Poland and join it with Germany, will begin in the district court here tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, June 2. -- An extensive modification of the army's 1933 wartime mobilization plan to provide more effective control of industry in the event of war has been prepared by the War Department, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP). -- The Washington jinx still held sway over St. Louis today as the Browns, although, outhitting the Senators, lost 15 to 11. It was the Browns' fifth straight loss against Washington this year. They have yet to score a triumph over the locals.

WASHINGTON, June 2. -- Coalition, as symbolized by the nomination at Cleveland for Vice President of a regular Democrat of national reputation, has long been under discussion in Washington. But recently Democratic critics of the New Deal have been making public announcements of their regularity, and the topic has waned.

Sixty years ago today Frederick E. Bertine, then 19, trudged from his father's, home at 253 West Twenty-fourth Street to the Fifth Avenue Bank at the corner of Forty-fourth Street, to begin work as a bank runner.

BERLIN, June 2. -- Five hundred Italians, including Countess Ciano, Premier Mussolini's daughter, have arrived in Berlin on a semi-official visit, which has furnished both sides an occasion to emphasize the friendly relations existing between the two countries.

A capacity attendance filled the new Belvedere Roof Garden of the Astor last night for its formal Sumi mer opening. The double-terraced rendezvous was decorated with i spruce trees, plants, shrubbery and !statuary to resemble a garden on the Italian Riviera.

With the success of the huge Treasury financing assured, officials of the Federal Land Bank System began active preparations yesterday to carry out their plans for the refunding of the $83,000,000 of 4 1/4 per cent bonds which are callable on July 1.

William Webster Theile, 15 years old, descendant of Daniel Webster and son of William Theile, financier, returned to his parents by plane from Chicago yesterday after a month's try at making his own way in the world.

WASHINGTON, June 2. -- Recent decisions by the Supreme Court, including the one yesterday holding unconstitutional New York State's Minimum Wage Law, were described by President Roosevelt today as seeming to create a "No Man's Land" where neither States nor the Federal Government had the right to legislate.

What is believed to be the first skyscraper scaresparrow (it would have been a scarecrow but for the fact that no crows have been in the midtown area since the farms disappeared) was placed in a vegetable garden yesterday afternoon on the eleventh floor of Rockefeller Center.

George Macy, director of the Limited Editions Club, has returned from a two-month visit in Europe with the news that he has acquired for the Limited Editions Club a controlling interest in The None-such Press of London, which was established in 1922.

AMSTERDAM, June 2. -- Firm conviction of the ultimate ability of the gold standard to lead the Netherlands out of the depression is expressed by Dr. L.J.A. Trip, president of the Bank of the Netherlands, in the bank's annual report, published today.

ALBANY, June 2. -- Governor Lehman has signed three bills designed to protect the jobs, pension and sick benefit rights of transit employes in New York City in the event of unification, it was announced today. Two of the measures were sponsored by Assemblyman Fitzgerald, Democrat, of Queens, and the other by Assemblyman Brownell, Republican, of New York.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 2. -- Yale's poloists, preparing for the intercollegiates, which they open at Governors Island with a game against Harvard, rode through a practice match on No. 2 field at the Meadow Brook Club today and triumphed, 16 to 6. Bradley Martin, L.E. Stoddard Jr., Dr. J.D. Richards and Gerald Dempsey played for the losers.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., June 2. -- Bud Schildkrecht of Kansas City, who lost a close decision to Joe Louis in the national amateur boxing championships in St. Louis two years ago, joined the Brown Bomber's troupe today and was greeted with a terrific right to the chin.

WASHINGTON, June 2. -- The Senate Finance Committee's Tax Bill would raise more additional revenue over a period of five years than the measure passed by the House, Senator King told the Senate today as he brought the bill to the floor. Consideration proceeded at a rapid pace and leaders planned to dispose of it tomorrow, even if a night session is necessary.

WASHINGTON, June 2. -- Heavy oversubscription to the Treasury's offering of $600,000,000 in 2 3/4 per cent fifteen-eighteen-year Treasury bonds and $400,000,000 in five-year notes bearing 1 3/8 per cent coupons was announced tonight by Secretary Morgenthau.

WASHINGTON, June 2. -- A letter from Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh praising the work of Colonel H. Norman Schwarzkopf and the New Jersey police during the Lindbergh baby kidnapping was made public today by Senator A. Harry Moore, who was Governor of New Jersey during the kidnapping.

Among the housing and business property sales in Brooklyn reported yesterday was the conveyance by the Brooklyn Trust Company, as trustee, of a six-story apartment house at 1,641 Ocean Avenue, 210 by 115 feet to an investor.

CHICAGO, June 2. -- Drought reports from the Northwest, with the weekly summary of several Minneapolis line elevator companies indicating the new Spring wheat crop had already been irreparably damaged in parts of the Dakotas and Montana, reversed the early, action of the wheat market on the Board of Trade today and brought about a rally of 2 cents a bushel from the low point.

After one Broadway production -- this season's successful "Parnell" -- Robinson Smith and Frederick W. Ayer have formally dissolved their partnership, and each will hereafter pursue a separate theatrical career. Mr. Smith will go to London late this month to negotiate for the American rights to two plays, one a current offering over there.

The dress industry was urged yesterday to "cease buying" from manufacturers who hold to the "unethical" practice of copying and selling garments originated by others. Jesse Woolf, a former manufacturer, suggested this at a hearing in a Federal court action by William Filene's Sons Company against the Fashion Originators Guild of America.

The medal which will be presented Friday evening at the dinner for Admiral Richard E. Byrd, sponsored by the American Industrial and associated groups, is shown above. The face of the medallion depicts the admiral in his hut at his advance weather station in the Antarctic.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 2. -- Copies of the contract offered to the Japanese Land Colonization Corporation, involving land grants in the State of Amazonas for fifty years amounting to 1,000,000 hectares, were distributed today among members of the Senate for perusal.

WASHINGTON, June 2. -- Revised adjournment plans, agreed upon today among leaders of both parties and in both the House and Senate, were believed by them to give definite assurances that Congress would not be in session during either the Republican or Democratic convention, and, furthermore, that no other important legislation was to be added to the calendar other than that already on its way through the legislative mill.

The suggestion of the nomination of a coalition ticket at the Republican National Convention in Cleveland by naming an anti-New Deal Democrat for Vice President was received yesterday with favor by local Republicans.

How odd it would be if Soviet Russia were to pick up the democratic standard as it slipped from the faltering hand of the free nations of the West! Yesterday our Paris correspondent was speaking of the new Chamber of Deputies.
BALTIMORE, June 2. -- Settlement of claims in connection with Continental Shares, Inc., an investment trust in receivership in Maryland and Ohio, was approved here today by Judge Robert Stanton.
BOSTON, June 2. -- Hammering five Northeastern University pitchers for fourteen safeties, the Long Island University baseball team scored a 15-to-6 victory at Huntington Field this afternoon.

BUFFALO, June 2 (AP). -- Edwin F. Jaeckle, Erie County Republican leader, accused State Chairman Melvin C. Eaton today of trying to "rig" the New York delegation to the Republican National Convention to insure the re-election of Charles D. Hilles as national committeeman.

CINCINNATI, June 2 (AP) . -- Forced to start their half of the ninth inning after the Phillies tied the score with a six-run rally, the Reds eked out a 9-to-8 victory in the first major league floodlight game of the season tonight as Ival Goodman, first man up, sent the ball into the right field bleachers for a home run. A crowd of 19,173 saw the game.

DES MOINES, June 2 (AP). -- Senator Lester J. Dickinson, Republican critic of the New Deal, and Governor Clyde L. Herring, its Democratic supporter, were chosen as their parties' nominees for the Senate in Monday's primary, returns late today showed.

Both branches of Congress have now passed the Administration's relief bill, and such differences as exist between the House and Senate versions of the measure can probably be reconciled without much trouble. The essential principle is the same in both cases. At least for another year the Government will continue the "work relief" program on which it embarked in 1935.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotalons for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

WASHINGTON, June 2. -- Official, social and civic Washington dropped the keys to the city today into the laps of delegates to the triennial convention of the Associated Country Women of the World. As a result the dozens who came to vote transacted the business at the afternoon session and the thousands who came to visit had all the fun.

Back in 1890 Congress granted a charter to the North River Bridge Company to construct a private toll bridge across the Hudson opposite Fifty-seventh Street. The late GUSTAV LINDENTHAL, one of the most eminent of our American bridge engineers, fought, bled and died for this project, never relaxing his efforts until the end.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,943,950 barrels, compared to 3,007,150 in the previous week, a decline of 63,200, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Declines of 31,700 barrels in Texas and of 27,100 in Oklahoma were the important changes.
ROME, June 2 (AP). -- A grim story of how thirty Italian soldiers described their own massacre by Ethiopians in frantic radio messages was disclosed tonight by military authorities.

CLEVELAND, June 2. -- Governor Landon's path to the Republican nomination for President was made easier today by the announcement of J. Henry Roraback, Connecticut Republican leader, that his State would cast its nineteen votes for the Kansan on the first ballot.

The recent bill signed by Governor Lehman, making the penalty for driving an automobile in a reckless or culpably negligent manner, whereby a human being is killed, punishable by imprisonment not to exceed five years or a fine of not more than $1,000, or both, is undoubtedly a step in the right direction.

Through the generosity of Mr. LUCIUS N. LITTAUER there has been privately printed a brochure, by Dr. CHARLES FREDERICK BOLDUAN, containing brief sketches of the "Illustrious Contributors to Public Health" whose names are carved on the new building to house the Departments of Health, Hospitals and Sanitation and the office of the Chief Medical Examiner.

MELBOURNE, Australia, June 2. -- The United States is the third country to manifest apprehension over Australia's new tariff policy, under which a licensing system is applied to certain goods. The other countries are Belgium and Japan, but none of the three has yet lodged a formal protest.

Price movements were mixed on the local commodity futures markets yesterday, with sugar, coffee, silk and wool tops depressed, while cocoa, cottonseed oil and hides advanced. On the cash markets, cotton, wheat, rye, butter, print-cloths and cocoa advanced and corn, quicksilver and tins declined.

A decision yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin upheld a contention by the City of New York that under the Dongan charter of 1686 it is the owner of land now being used for the East River Drive. The court had heard claims for more than $500,000 by former occupants of riverfront sites between 82d and 122d Streets on the ground that the old grants made them the owners of the property.

The overemphasis which has been given social-economic problems has produced a legislative jam that could easily clog the wheels of industrial progress, Frank A. Blair, president of The Proprietary Association, declared yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

TOKYO, June 2. -- Allegations that the extensive North China smuggling is being fostered by the Japanese Army's rules and regulations under the 1933 Tangku truce are an insult to the army, said Lieut. Gen. Hayao Tada, former commander of Japan's North China garrisons, in an interview published in the newspaper Asahi today.

OKLAHOMA CITY, June 2. -- Led by the medalist, Mrs. Dan Chandler of Dallas, leading favorites came through unscathed as good weather brought better golf in the first round of match play in the women's Southern tournament today.

ELIZABETHTOWN, N.Y., June 2 (AP). -- District Attorney Charles P. Sullivan of Queens County, said tonight he would return Frank Engel, 30 years old, who claims to have committed the "3X" murders which terrorized the Long Island area in 1930, to New York tomorrow for further questioning. He added that he thought Engel was "a mental case."

LONDON, June 2. -- In one of the most plainspoken judgments that have ever come from a judicial body in Britain, J.H. Thomas, who recently resigned as Colonial Secretary, was branded today as the man who betrayed the secrets of the budget in April and inflicted losses of almost 100,000 on London underwriters.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

Joseph Downing, penthouse in 339 E. 58th St.; Dr. L. W. Myers, suite in 521 Park Av.: IVilkie Bushby, in 1,192 Park Av.; through Duff Conger; Miss Elizabeth M. Hughes, in 205 E. 78th St.; Carlos O'Brlen, in 41 W. 4,6th St.; Pease gillman, Inc., brokers.

Seven apartment houses and five dwellings were bought in by plaintiffs at Manhattan foreclosure auction sales yesterday. One scheduled sale was adjourned. The largest structure was a twelve-story apartment house at the north corner of Central Park West and Seventy-fifth Street.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 2. -- Emmett Steele, 16-year-old Scarborough School star, who lives in Madison, S.D., scored the first major upset of the Essex County junior tennis championship tournament today at the Montclair Athletic Club when he routed Jack Totten of Paterson, seeded No. 3, in the first round. Steele won at 6 -- 4, 6 -- 2.

Joseph Bulova, president of the Bulova Watch Company, who died last Nov. 18, left an estate appraised yesterday at $174,577 gross and $138,195 net. He held 700 shares of preferred stock in the watch company, worth $36,837, and New York City bonds worth $44,670.
The Yanks showed a crowd of 10,000 at the Stadium yesterday just how they can lose ball games with the maximum of inefficiency.
When Mrs. Margaret Hunt told her 15-year-old son, William, not to go swimming yesterday afternoon with other boys in the Brooklyn neighborhood where they live, William meant to obey.

TRENTON, N.J., June 2. -- The Senate adjourned today until June 15 without acting upon Governor Hoffman's nomination of Colonel Mark O. Kimberling, principal keeper of the New Jersey State prison, to succeed Colonel H. Norman Schwarzkopf as Superintendent of the State Police Department.

The net earnings of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey in the first four months of this year approximated those of the corresponding period of 1935, Walter C. Teagle, president, told stockholders yesterday at the annual meeting in Newark, N.J.

Medical economics and the needs of patients both require the young doctor to give up the idea of specialization and devote himself to general practice, Dr. Milton C. Winternitz of Yale University declared last night in an address to 104 graduates of the Long Island College of Medicine in the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

Chairman MCGRATH of the Massachusetts Democratic State Committee has uttered frankly his generous and humane view of the conditions of relief in Massachusetts. A brother committee-man had previously confessed that he had told a seeker for work on a sidewalk which the State is building to enroll himself as a Democratic voter.

CHICAGO, June 2. -- Less favorable reports on the movement of fresh pork caused buyers to go a little slow in taking hogs in the early trading here today and some sales were regarded as 5 to 10 cents a hundredweight lower. The demand broadened, however, on the decline and most sales later were largely at steady prices.

The great danger to the world at present lies not in dictatorships but in the conditions which permit dictators to seize power, particularly the failure of intelligent, educated groups to exercise their proper leadership in public affairs, Dr. William Mather Lewis, president of Lafayette College, declared yesterday at the annual Columbia University Alumni luncheon in John Jay Hall.

Frank Bowden, second seeded star, led the field into the semi-finals of the nineteenth annual men's Brooklyn tennis singles championship yesterday by eliminating George Stevens, Yale captain, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 1, in a quarter-final struggle.

WASHINGTON, June 2. -- President Roosevelt today gave assurance of his "earnest consideration" of a proposed farm-tenant betterment plank submitted to him by six Iowa members of Congress with the suggestion that it be included in the Democratic platform.

WASHINGTON, June 2. -- A composite farm relief plank, embracing most of the plans thus far proposed as substitute for government control of production as under the original AAA programs, has been drafted by a group of Midwestern Republican leaders for submission to the resolutions committee of the Cleveland convention.

PARIS, June 2. -- There will be at least one woman and perhaps two women in the Cabinet Leon Blum is expected to announce Friday. Although women cannot vote and cannot be elected to Parliament, nothing in the French Constitution prevents their holding Ministerial offices, so the new government will seek to gain their support by naming one or more as Under-Secretaries of State.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 2. -- There are "tides" in the head as there are in the sea and headaches suffered by many persons come at these "high and low tides," it was said here today by Dr. Temple Fay, Professor of Neurology and Neural Surgery at Temple University.

The Western Pacific Railroad Corporation, a holding company which controls the Western Pacific Railroad Company, reported yesterday a net loss of $409,471 in 1935, against a reported net income of $598,793 in 1934. The holding company holds all capital stock and $11,416,553 first-mortgage bonds of the railroad, which entered bankruptcy last August.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 2. -- Hungarian police followed recent arrests of 770 persons by filing a blanket complaint charging high treason. The police said the participants planned to come to Budapest on excursion trains to start a Nazi uprising

A city-wide drive on stores, taverns and other places displaying coin-operated amusement or vending machines of the crane, claw and digger type was started by the police last night as the result of a decision by the Court of Appeals at Albany that the machines are gambling devices.

LOS ANGELES, June 2 (AP). -- A shouting, jeering mob, about 100 men and women, severely beat William Haines, former motion picture star, and Jimmy Shields, a companion, near Manhattan Beach and drove them and nineteen friends out of town, a Sheriff's report said today.

VIENNA, June 2. -- Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg's hurried departure last night for a secret destination in Italy, this correspondent learns, was brought about by several internal and external problems and is likely to have important results, among them an early Cabinet change.

Graduation exercises of the Teacher Training Department of the Ethical Culture Schools, the last in the series of commencements in the various units of the schools, will be held at 3 P.M. today at the meeting house of the New York Society for Ethical Culture, Sixty-fourth Street and Central Park West.

PHILADELPHIA, June 2 (AP). -- The Tigers opened their second tour of the East by taking a 5-to-4 decision from the Athletics today. Harry Kelley, issuing a pass to Mickey Cochrane with three on in the eighth inning, forced in the winning run.

VIENNA, June 2. -- Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg's hurried departure last night for a secret destination in Italy, this correspondent learns, was brought about by several internal and external problems and is likely to have important results, among them an early Cabinet change.

Graduation exercises of the Teacher Training Department of the Ethical Culture Schools, the last in the series of commencements in the various units of the schools, will be held at 3 P.M. today at the meeting house of the New York Society for Ethical Culture, Sixty-fourth Street and Central Park West.

PHILADELPHIA, June 2 (AP). -- The Tigers opened their second tour of the East by taking a 5-to-4 decision from the Athletics today. Harry Kelley, issuing a pass to Mickey Cochrane with three on in the eighth inning, forced in the winning run.

A total of $875,000 was distributed yesterday by officials of the United Hospital Fund for the maintenance of service in seventy-nine hospitals through the city at a luncheon in the Hotel Biltmore which was attended by persons engaged in this field.

Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo reserved decision yesterday on a plea by milk consumers and by dealers who sell Grade B milk in paper containers to continue an injunction restraining the State Department of Markets from putting into effect an order increasing the price of milk sold in paper containers 1 cent a quart.

Prizes totaling more than $2,000 were awarded in the twelfth annual soap sculpture exhibition that was opened yesterday morning in the mezzanine gallery of the R.C.A Building In Rockefeller Center. The prize-winning carvings were selected from 4,500 entries from various parts of the country.

The share market displayed a subdued tone yesterday. Stocks sold off rather sharply in the initial hour of trading, some of the leaders losing 1 to 4 points; but as the selling pressure was not continued, the list steadied in slow dealings, subsequently regaining part of the early losses.

A comprehensive Federal inquiry into living and working conditions for seamen on American merchant ships was proposed yesterday by Secretary of Labor Perkins after she had inspected the crew quarters of the Queen Mary and pronounced them the best she had ever seen.

In a move that was carried out with lightning swiftness, Ellis H. Parker Sr., chief of detectives of Burlington County, N.J., was arrested about 8:30 o'clock last night in Mount Holly. The arrest came three hours after the Kings County grand jury had handed up a secret indictment charging him, his son, Ellis Jr., at present a fugitive, and three other men with the kidnapping of Paul H. Wendel Jr.

United States Senator Francis T. Maloney of Connecticut urged graduating students of St. John's University yesterday at commencement exercises to stand firm for the preservation of the Constitution, but warned that it is a "meaningless" document if it is "without the Ten Commandments."
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

The total market value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange rose $2,224,330,033 last month, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange. Average price a share of all listed stocks on June I was $37.35, compared with $35.74 at the beginning of May.
It is regrettable that Governor Herbert Lehman cannot see his way clear to accept renomination for Governor this Fall.

Following several months of negotiation between representatives of insurance companies holding bonds of the Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad and the management of the road without an agreement on its reorganization, it was announced yesterday that the fiduciary institutions' representation had been reorganized and enlarged under the chairmanship of George S. Van Schaick, vice president of the New York Life Insurance Company.

SYRACUSE, June 3. -- Recommendations of a special committee that the constitution of the church be amended to permit Presbyterians the legal and spiritual right to be conscientious objectors to war and military service was adopted this afternoon at the closing session of the 148th General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America.

CHICAGO, June 3. -- Estimates of the wheat crop in this country, given to the trade today by local statisticians, were about in line with the expectations. Recent rains and favorable weather for filling resulted in considerable improvement in the Winter-sown crop in May, and the average of five returns showed an estimated yield of 501,000,000 bushels.

New York's greeting to the Queen Mary, in the opinion of the chairman of the Cunard White Star Company, means "a further strengthening of the bond that unites our two peoples." Sir PERCY BATES has ample justification for his belief.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., June 3. -- Golf fans who plan to be here tomorrow for the first round of the United States open golf championship will have an opportunity to see some of the game's celebrities in action from early morning to late afternoon.

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- Eager to avoid possible conference entanglements which might endanger passage of the Senate-approved Commodity Exchange Control Bill, and thus kill chances of its passage at this session, the House, without a record vote, today accepted the measure as it was passed by the Senate and sent it to the White House for the signature of President Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- With the adjournment of Congress at least remotely possible within the next few days, President Roosevelt today ordered his secretarial staff to cancel all personal engagements tomorrow and Friday so that he might be free for legislative conferences and to handle routine work.
NANKING, June 3. -- The Foreign Office denied tonight the Japanese report that Canton had declared war on the Central Government.

ROCHESTER, June 3. -- The General Synod of the Reformed Church, in convention here, prepared today to start a vigorous campaign on liquor conditions, which, according to the synod's social welfare committee, are "more demoralizing under repeal than under prohibition."

The Schulte Retail Stores Corporation and three subsidiaries, operators of cigar and liquor stores and real estate, and the related Huyler's corporations of Delaware and New York, operators of candy stores and restaurants, filed petitions in Federal court yesterday to reorganize under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act.

Proposals to launch a $250,000 to $500,000 one-year national campaign to revive interest on the part of American women and girls in the art of home sewing were voiced yesterday before a meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania of more than 100 department store merchandising executives, representatives of sewing machine companies and spokesmen for the cotton, wool, silk, rayon, linen, thread and similar industries.

EAST WILLISTON, L.I., June 3. -- Mrs. Robert C. Lake advanced to the semi-final stage in the defense of her women's Long Island golf championship at Wheatley Hills today by virtue of a 3-and-2 victory over Miss Rosalie Knapp.
WASHINGTON, Thursday, June 4. -- Speaker Joseph W. Byrns died suddenly of a cerebral hemorrhage at his apartment in the Hotel Mayflower at 12:15 o'clock this morning after a brief illness.

ALBANY, June 3. -- Governor Lehman has signed the Fearon bill providing five optional plans of county government, but he is convinced that it will fall far short of what is necessary to bring about any effective reorganization and a consequent reduction in the cost of local governments, it was declared today at the executive chamber.

ALBANY, June 3 (AP). -- A considerable portion of the $375,000 appropriation made available by Governor Lehman's signature for expansion of the State Police will be used to build up the Bureau of Investigation or "Scotland Yard" branch, Major John A. Warner, Superintendent of State Police, said today.

Prepared and published under the auspices of the Phelps-Stokes Fund, a study entitled "Slums and Housing, With Special Reference to New York City," By James Ford, with the collaboration of Katherine Morrow and George N. Thompson, and an appendix by I.N. Phelps Stokes, will be brought out this month by Harvard University Press.
SHANGHAI, Thursday, June 4 (AP). -- A huge Cantonese army was reported by Japanese sources today to have struck at North China cities, opening civil war.

The silver trophy awarded annually by the American Jersey Cattle Club for outstanding butter fat production by a Jersey cow was presented yesterday to Owen Moon Jr., newspaper publisher of Winston-Salem, N.C., as owner of Stockwell's April Pogis of High Pastures, Woodstock, Vt.

The letter printed on this page yesterday and signed by NEWTON D. BAKER, L.W. DOUGLAS and LEO WOLMAN is a valuable contribution to political thought. In its analysis of conditions which have prevailed in this country since the war it is penetrating. Its explanation of what has happened, and why it has happened, is persuasive.

CLEVELAND, June 3. -- Herbert Hoover's acceptance of the invitation to address the Republican National Convention next week, in his capacity as titular leader of the party, was announced today by Henry P. Fletcher, chairman, to the Republican National Committee.

Sam H. Harris yesterday bought a play and put it on his Fall schedule: "Man on the Dock," by Henry Ephrom and Sam Rosenberg, a comedy with an American locale. Mr. Ephrom previously was known to the Harris office as assistant stage manager of "Merrily We Roll Along." Mr. Rosenberg, new to the theatre, comes from Cleveland and is a painter.

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- Sharp criticism of past and present procedure in connection with defaults on real estate bonds, reorganization committees and voting and liquidating trusts was made today by the Securities and Exchange Commission in a report to Congress in which it said that steps for regulation, to be effective, must be so shaped as to cover the existing trusts as well as future readjustment plans of all types.

Through a battering four-hour cross-examination as the gambler he professed himself to be, Charles (Lucky Luciano) Lucania clung steadfast, at his trial in the Supreme Court yesterday, to his denial that he was the leader of the city's $12,000,000-a-year vice ring.

NEWARK, N.J., June 3. -- The Newark Bears tightened their grip on first place in the International League today with a 6-to-0 victory mover Syracuse, to make it three out of four in the series with the Chiefs.

CLEVELAND, June 3. -- In preparation for making up the temporary roll of the Republican National Convention which will open Tuesday, the Republican National Committee began today its usual series of hearings on contests. Seats of fifty-seven delegates, including some entire delegations, are included.

BERLIN, June 3. -- The Boerse showed a firm tendency today, and the upward movement that set in yesterday after the post-holiday recess was steadily maintained in the early trading period. The advanced quotations yielded slightly to realization sales, but they recovered near the close.

TRENTON, June 3. -- Governor Harold G. Hoffman expressed calm indignation today over the presentation to him yesterday by a group of Princeton undergraduates of a silver-plated medal in "recognition" of his recent fistic encounter in New York with a newspaper man.

The Canadian-American Hockey League yesterday adopted a resolution calling for the playing of an interlocking schedule of games with teams in the International League during the 1936-37 season, The Associated Press announced.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, June 3. -- Adrianus J. van Hengel, well-known Netherland financial expert, was killed tonight when a plane he was piloting crashed at the airfield here. Captain Burlowski, an Austrian flying instructor, a passenger in the plane, also was killed.

LONDON, June 3. -- Reports of imaginary revolts in widely scattered parts of the British Empire, with hundreds killed and the authorities taking desperate measures to restore order, were broadcast recently in Arabic from the Italian radio station at Bari, it was learned today.

More than 500 members of the American Woman's Association were guests last night of Mrs. W.K. Vanderbilt at a Spring party given in the Tudor Lounge of the clubhouse, 353 West Fifty-seventh Street. The old "nickelodeon" of thirty or more years ago was the feature of the program.

Mayor La Guardia characterized the Merchants Association, the Chamber of Commerce and the Citizens Budget Commission yesterday as chronic whiners and complainers about municipal ferry operation and criticized their failure to submit bids for private operation of the city ferry between the Battery and Thirty-ninth Street, Brooklyn.
INDIANAPOLIS, June 3 (AP). -- The Indiana State Republican Convention went on record today as favoring the nomination of Governor Landon of Kansas for President.

Nearly 1,000 Socialists of the Old Guard, now no longer affiliated with the Socialist party as a result of action of the national convention in Cleveland last week in approving suspension of the New York organization's charter, met last night at Beethoven Hall, 210 East Fifth Street, and voted unanimously to affiliate with the newly formed Social Democratic Federation.

Despite his continued insistence that he was the man responsible for the "3-X" murders in Queens six years ago, Frank Engel, 29-year-old lifeguard and taxi driver, was virtually cleared of suspicion last night when two witnesses to the fatal shootings failed to connect him with the crimes.
PARIS, June 3. -- A raging strike fever stayed the hands of 350,000 French workers tonight and alarmed a changing government with the menace of Paris food, water and gas shortages.

In one of the largest exchange realty deals negotiated in this city in some time the eighteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 450 West End Avenue was purchased yesterday by an investor who gave in part payment twenty-four properties scattered throughout Manhattan and the Bronx.
The committee for the first annual World Labor Athletic Carnival, which will be held at Randalls Island on Aug. 15 and 16, was announced yesterday by Charles L. Ornstein, the chairman.

The State's case against a Brooklyn Assistant District Attorney and the four other persons indicted for conspiracy in the Samuel Drukman murder case was shown yesterday, in a two-hour description to the jury, to extend further than had been suspected.

Mr. J. HENRY RORABACK'S announcement that the delegation of his State will vote for Governor LANDON on the first ballot is cheering, if expected, news to Landonians. Mr. BORAH'S notion that the selection of uninstructed delegates hid some sinister design of Eastern Republican leaders was characteristically whimsical.

TORONTO, June 3 (AP). -- Bill Harris, Buffalo right-hander, turned in a perfect pitching performance in the seven-inning second game of today's double-header against Toronto to give the Bisons an even break. The Leafs won the first game by 5 to 3 and the Bisons took the nightcap, 2 to 0.

CHICAGO, June 3. -- Newspaper publishers were urged today to stay on the offensive and keep up their fight for an unfettered press in the face of a "national administration policy which is far less concerned with the value of the freedom of the press than an American government should be."

For the second successive time standard bearers from the Williamsburg Vocational High School carried off the team prize at the annual city P.S.A.L. vocational high and continuation school track championship held under a twilight setting at Wingate Field, Brooklyn, yesterday.

Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens turned from road rejection to court action yesterday. in his dispute with Victor F. Ridder, local Works Progress Administrator. Attorneys for the borough executive filed a short form complaint in the County Clerk's office at Jamaica, naming Mr. Ridder as defendant in a $250,000 suit for slander.
HONGKONG, June 3. -- The position of Canton in relation to the Central Government at Nanking remains partly speculative because of the refusal of Cantonese leaders to state a definite policy.

A denial that the Fashion Originators Guild of America sought to monopolize the dress industry or to drive any one out of business was made yesterday during the hearing in a Federal court action by William Filene's Sons Company of Boston against the guild.

JACKSONVILLE, June 3 (AP). -- Judge W. Raleigh Petteway of Tampa, Fred P. Cone of Lake City, William C. Hodges of Tallahassee and B.F. Paty of West Palm Beach ran one, two, three, four tonight in Florida's fourteen-candidate race for the Democratic nomination for Governor.

TRENTON, June 3. -- The Rev. Dr. Wallace John Gardner, former vicar of the Chapel of the Intercession, New York, was consecrated in Trinity Cathedral here this morning as Bishop Coadjutor of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New Jersey.

The New England Gas and Electric Association, controlled by affiliates of the Associated Gas and Electric Company, lost $800,000 in 1935 in the sale of companies in Nova Scotia, said the annual report yesterday. Proceeds from the Nova Scotia sale were used to buy stocks of the New Bedford Gas and Edison Light Company, controlled by the association.

CHICAGO, June 3. -- Decreasing supplies of hogs more than offset the effect of lower prices for fresh pork here today and hogs advanced 10 to 15 cents a hundred weight to the best level since May 7. Hogs weighing more than 250 pounds showed the most strength.

The directors of the Fifth Avenue Bank declared yesterday the regular quarterly dividend of $6 and extra dividend of $10, both payable able on July 1 to stockholders of record of the same date. At this time last year the company declared an extra dividend of $10.
WASHINGTON, Thursday, June 4. -- All legislative plans looking to final adjournment of Congress were thrown somewhat into confusion early today by the death of Speaker Byrns.
Pratt Institute will award 561 diplomas and certificates to its graduating class at the annual exercises at 2:30 P.M. today in the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

Grover Whalen will be the commencement speaker this afternoon at the annual graduation exercises of the Webb Institute of Naval Architecture, Webb and Sedgwick Avenues, the Bronx. Seventeen students will receive the degree of Bachelor of Science in Naval Architecture and Marine Engineering.
Awards to seven students in the Departments of English and Romance Languages at Hunter College were announced yesterday.

The administration of relief in New Jersey has been turned back to the overseers of the poor of the various communities. While it is true that this has resulted in apparent savings, it has also been reported that the selection of recipients of aid has been capricious in many places and that many worthy families have not been able to bring themselves to apply for relief under the poor laws.

Twenty-nine students will be graduated by the Harriette Melissa Mills Training School for Kindergarten and Primary Teachers at its twenty-seventh annual commencement exercises this morning at the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street. The school is at 66 Fifth Avenue.

GENEVA, June 3. -- The Mandates Commission of the League of Nations decided today after a two-day discussion to deal with the present unrest in Palestine at this session, in connection with the 1935 report of Great Britain as the mandatory, in so far as is now possible and not to defer discussion of the report to its Autumn session.

Showing an ability to go a route which many did not suspect, George D. Widener's Jack High filly, High Fleet, yesterday captured the $13,175 Coaching Club American Oaks, championship test of the early season for 3-year-old fillies, at Belmont Park.

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- In the third call to Democrats to rally with their contributions round the party standard, Postmaster General Farley, acting in his role of chairman of the Democratic National Committee, today formed the Roosevelt Nominators.
