Social standards and juristic norms as now enunciated by the Supreme Court make it difficult for one to speak of progress in terms of constitutional law, and law in terms of legal precedents.

ST. LOUIS, June 3. -- Tarzan Parmelee, who had beaten only two clubs, the Giants and Cubs, this year, today added the Dodgers to his list as the Gas House Gang overpowered George Earnshaw for a 7-3 victory to retain their three-game lead in the National League.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 3. -The three remaining seeded players, Marvin Kantrowitz, Joseph Fishback and Donald Buffington, gained semi-final brackets in the annual Essex County junior singles tennis championship today at the Montclair Athletic Club.

CLEVELAND, June 3. -- Nomination of Governor Landon on the first ballot as the Republican candidate for President was predicted tonight by well-informed political leaders, who based their conclusion on the recent accessions to the Kansas Governor.

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- With hopes of its passage dismal if Congress adjourns at this week-end, but heightened if the session should extend into the Summer, the Wagner-Ellenbogen Housing Bill was reported to the Senate by the Committee on Education and Labor today.

Twenty-five years ago Phillipe De Clamecey's personal charm won for him the friendship of justices of the Supreme Court of Massachusetts, the keys to the city of Boston and large amounts of money from prominent business men. He was a top-flight confidence man.

The Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad Company obtained yesterday a record low interest cost on a new issue of $3,950,000 of 2 1/2 per cent equipment trust certificates, awarding them to the Harris Trust and Savings Bank of Chicago on its bid of 102.72933, giving an interest cost to the carrier of approximately 1.95 per cent.

Supreme Court Justice Charles C. Lockwood, sitting in Queens, denied yesterday a taxpayer's application for an order restraining Controller Frank J. Taylor from paying inspectors and supervisors on unfranchised bus lines operating in that borough under special permits from the Department of Plant and Structures.

As it celebrates the three hundredth anniversary of its settlement, Long Island looks back over a past rich in historic figures and events. GEORGE WASHINGTON, NATHAN HALE, JOHN HOWARD PAYNE, RUFUS KING, WALT WHITMAN, SETH LOW are the names of but a few of the illustrious men with which its history is associated.

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- All responsibility for the defeat of the Passamaquoddy project in the Senate rests upon the shoulders of the two Republican Senators from Maine, Governor Brann of that State charged in a statement today.

Resolutions urging a Federal appropriations of $26,000,000 to assure the continued payment of ocean mail contracts to American ship lines "unless President Roosevelt is sure that some new shipping legislation will be passed that will guarantee the operation of American flag vessels in foreign trade" were adopted yesterday at the annual meeting of the United Licensed Officers Association.

PARIS, June 3. -- In a situation that is fast becoming gravely threatening both industrially and financially the Sarraut Cabinet will resign tomorrow afternoon, and President Albert Lebrun will summon Leon Blum to form the first Socialist Ministry in France.

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 3. -After three gruelling jump-offs over the testing Course M. Captain John W. Wofford of West Point this afternoon emerged the victor in the individual military championship of the eighteenth annual West Point Horse Show, which opened this morning in the picturesque ring of the United States Military Academy.
Degrees, diplomas and certificates will be presented to 274 seniors and eleven alumni of Cooper Union at the seventy-seventh annual commencement in the great hall of the Union at 8 o'clock tonight.

MOSCOW, June 3. -- Jose R. Capablanca of Havana and Dr. Emanuel Lasker of London, both former world champions, whose match fifteen years ago gave the Cuban supremacy, met again today in the international chess masters tournament before a record crowd.

The Senate Finance Committee was at first inclined to be friendly to the Administration's proposal for a corporation tax solely on undistributed profits. As it began to study the House measure with its highly complicated embodiment of that principle, and to listen to criticisms of it, its attitude cooled until it finally abandoned the proposal, except in the form of a moderate supplementary tax.

The criticisms so far noted concerning the opinion of the Supreme Court in the New York Minimum Wage Law omit, in my judgment, to take note that this situation has developed from our erroneous approach by legislation designed to effect governmental control of business operations.

Professor Georg Bernhard, German journalist, statesman and economist, who was editor-in-chief of the Ullstein Press for thirty years and editor of the Vossische Zeitung for seventeen years, arrived yesterday from France on the liner Paris of the French Line as the guest of the American Jewish Congress.

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- President Roosevelt canceled all engagements for tomorrow and Friday to be ready for conferences with Congress leaders on pending legislation. He reappointed George Henry Payne as a member of the Federal Communications Commission.

BALTIMORE, June 3. -- Captain Johnny Allen is more than 70 years old. For fifty-four years of his life, since he was a boy of 16 in Maine with the hankering for voyaging in his blood, he has sailed the sea in steam and in sail.

HARRISBURG, Pa., June 3. -- The Federal Government, through a court order, succeeded today in blocking, at least temporarily, the investigation of WPA activities in Pennsylvania by a State Senate committee.
W_a.IwlNGTOIq, Thursday, June 4. -- Dr. George W. Calver, Capitol physician, announced the death of the Speaker in the following bulletin:

The Thompson-Starrett Company, Inc., and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended on April 23 a net income of $31,287, compared with a net loss of $200,976 in the preceding year. The net income equals 49 cents a share on 63,896 no-par shares of $3.50 preference stock, on which accrued dividends on April 1 amounted to $1,006,362.

William C. Bullitt, United States Ambassador to Russia, will arrive today from Europe on the North German Lloyd liner Europa. Others on the list are John Norman Stuart Buchan, brother of Lord Tweedsmuir and Assistant District Commissioner of the Uganda Protectorate; Mr. and Mrs. Frederic R. Coudert Jr., Sir Ralph Gore and Lady Montague.

Engineering awards in the United States last month fell below the rate for the first four months of this year, but showed a 15 per cent increase over last May. The Engineering News-Record reported yesterday.

TRENTON, June 3. -- Rebuffed yesterday in their efforts to confirm Colonel Mark O. Kimberling as Superintendent of the State Police, the Republican Senate leaders are hoping that something may be done to change the attitude of the Democrats before the Legislature meets again on June 15.

ANNAPOLIS, June 3. -- The Naval Academy completed today the special events which made up its June week program and the commencement period will end tomorrow with the graduation ceremonies, at which Admiral William H. Standley, head of the Bureau of Navigation and Acting Secretary of the Navy, will address the graduates and deliver diplomas.

The forty-second commencement exercises of the School of Nursing of the Presbyterian Hospital will be held this afternoon at 4 o'clock, with Dr. George E. Vincent, former president of the Rockefeller Foundation, as the speaker. Seventy-eight nurses will be graduated.
ITHACA, N.Y., June 3. -- Joe Mangan, one of America's best milers, announced tonight he had retired from competition for the year and would not be a candidate for the Olympic team.

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- It can be said of the letter from L.W. Douglas, Newton D. Baker and Leo Wolman in THE NEW YORK TIMES today that it was widely noticed in Washington but not warmly received by any group. The reasons are many.

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- Attorney General Cummings assigned Sam Whittaker, special assistant to the Attorney General, today to investigate charges of Federal law violations in connection with the strike of cotton choppers and tenant farmers in Arkansas.

John Wolfe Ambrose, whose persistent struggle for Congressional appropriations to improve New York Harbor almost forty years ago resulted in the creation of the deep-sea channel named for him, was praised for his vision and courage by Mayor La Guardia yesterday afternoon at exercises in Battery Park in which a bronze bust of the former civic leader was unveiled.

Although steel operations are unchanged at 68 per cent of capacity this week, the trend appears to be upward. The Iron Age says in its weekly summary, issued yesterday. Buying of steel in anticipation of the increase in prices for delivery in the third quarter of the year is expected to force the rate of output above 70 per cent this month, the magazine adds.

ROME, June 3. -- A few hours before Emperor Haile Selassie was enthusiastically received on British soil Italy was giving triumphal honors today to the man whose strategy crushed the Ethiopian empire.

Despite the protests of small groups of passengers, voiced on its trains and at its ticket windows, the Long Island Railroad continued yesterday to enforce its 3-cents-a-mile rates for intrastate business.

A banking syndicate headed by the First Boston Corporation will offer to the public today an issue of $25,000,000 of Wisconsin Public Service Corporation first-mortgage 4 per cent bonds, due in 1961, at a price of 99 1/2 and accrued interest. This financing is the final step in the corporation's plan to consolidate certain properties in Wisconsin, simplify the corporate structure and reduce interest charges.

The Guaranty Trust Company of New York, as corporate trustee under the first terminal and unifying mortgage bonds of the St. Louis Southwestern (Cotton Belt) Railway Company announced yesterday its intention of filing on behalf of all bondholders in the reorganization proceedings a claim for payment in Netherlands guilders, amounting to 2,490 guilders, or the equivalent of nearly $1,700 for each $1,000 bond.

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- As the first step in the development of uniformity in accounting in a field where quite diverse practices have prevailed, the Securities and Exchange Commission made public today a uniform system of accounts for mutual service companies and subsidiary companies of holding company systems registered under the Public Utility Act of 1935 and effective on Aug. 1.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 3. -Wednesday racing instead of the Friday series was started today by the Interclub sloops at the Larchmont Yacht Club, and Emil Mosbacher's Susan, sailed by Lou Pearson, showed the way home over a five-mile leeward and windward course.

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- Department of Justice officials today were studying a report made by President William Green of the American Federation of Labor, who asked that Attorney General Cummings investigate charges that the Black Legion had terrorized union automobile workers.

LONDON, June 3 (AP). -- America's international polo forces suffered their first casualty today when Bobby Strawbridge, chairman of the United States Polo Association and manager of the invading team, was ordered to bed to hasten the cure for an infection of the leg.

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- The post-depression campaign of the Scripps-Howard newspapers for lower telephone rates was characterized as a "purely mercenary" policy designed to attract attention and increase circulation without reference to the facts of the situation, in testimony at today's hearing before the Federal Communications Commission which is conducting an inquiry into the affairs of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

The city-wide drive by the police on stores and other places possessing slot machines, following word from Albany Tuesday night the Court of Appeals had ruled they are gambling devices, was criticized yesterday by Magistrate August Dreyer in the Tombs Court.

Three patrolmen, a detective and an employe of the Bonded Sales and Service Company, an automobile sales and repair concern at 184-01 Hillside Avenue, Hollis, Queens, were overcome yesterday by carbon monoxide gas in a futile attempt to save the life of one of the owners of the company, Frank Koehl, 54 years old, of 250 Stuyvesant Street, Brooklyn.

Abandonment of the trolley lines of the New York Railways Corporation and their replacement by buses became a fact yesterday after more than a year of litigation when Federal Judge Goddard signed final orders for the reorganization of the company as the New York City Omnibus Corporation.

PARIS, May 3. -- While the dollar remained fixed at the gold export point of 15.19 francs, sterling rose today to 76.25 francs to the pound, the highest point reached for a long time. Forward rates were quoted nominally at 76.125 francs for sterling, but dealing in forward francs was virtually suspended.

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- The plan proposed by Philip J. Roosevelt of New York for financial reorganization of the Minneapolis St. Louis Railroad was rejected today in its entirety by Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, who described the proposal as a "delusion" which would make the road "a pawn subject to abuses and manipulations that should not be tolerated."
Apartment houses and dwellings were included in the Brooklyn realty turnover reported yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, June 3 (AP). -- Bob Reis, relief pitcher for the Bees, defeated the Pirates, 4 to 3, today. He went on the mound in the eighth, succeeding Danny MacFayden, who had been removed for a pinch hitter, and in the eleventh knocked out a single to pave the way to victory.

Members of the Stock Exchange displayed little enthusiasm yesterday over dispatches from Washington indicating that the Federal Reserve Board might permit itself to be persuaded that brokers should be able to borrow from banks more than the current limit of 60 per cent of market value of securities.

Seven Fordham seniors received their final degrees as A.B. (Able Batsmen) yesterday as the Rams concluded their most successful baseball season in a decade. The Maroon finished its campaign with an anti-climax game against Montclair State Teachers College at Fordham Field, winning, 7 to 1, for its eighteenth victory in twenty starts.
CHICAGO, June 3. -- Curt Davis, the Philadelphia refugee who recently enlisted himself under the Wrigley banner, was a victim of mistaken identity today.
GENEVA, June 3. -- The Italian delegation to the twentieth session of the International Labor Conference, opening tomorrow, received instructions from Rome today not to attend.

Long Island University will graduate 113 students tonight at the annual commencement exercises in the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The speaker will be John T. Flynn, economist and author and member of the Board of Higher Education.

Ralph T. Friedmann, vice president of the Cavendish Trading Corporation, in a report to the executive committee of the buying agency following his return from Europe on the Queen Mary, said exports from European countries off the gold standard to American stores are up from 20 to 35 per cent over last year, Paul Lundgren, managing director, announced yesterday.
BOSTON, June 3 (AP). -- Wes Ferrell added a timely single to his effective "nothin' ball" delivery today to provide the Red Sox with a 6-2 triumph over the Indians.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 3. -- Presentation of an original pageant, "The Atonement," by Miss Jane Paul of Montclair, featured the annual garden party of the Woman's Club of Upper Montclair today at the home of Mrs. Frederick Pleasants.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 3. -- A report demanding repeal of the anti-birth-control laws and urging the American Medical Association to seek that reform, was adopted today at the sixty-second annual meeting of the American Neurological Association in the Hotel Ambassador here.

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- As shadows lengthened across the lawn at Mount Vernon, ending a day of brilliant sunshine, a gay parade of buses carrying delegates to the triennial of the Associated Country Women of the World bowled away from downtown hotels late this afternoon.
CLEVELAND, June 3. -- Some of the Eastern party leaders arriving almost a week in advance of the Republican convention said today they did not see how the early Landon sweep was to be stopped.

With the 1936 campaign a closed book after their 3 -- 2 defeat by Australia at Germantown, the members of the American Davis Cup team sailed for England yesterday, bent on redeeming themselves in the British tennis championships at Wimbledon.

The city of Cincinnati, Ohio, yesterday made the award of two new issues of bonds, aggregating $8,128,000, to a banking syndicate headed by The National City Bank. The financing consisted of $7,810,000 of Cincinnati Southern Railway construction refunding bonds, due in 1952, and $318,000 of city waterworks refunding bonds, due serially from 1937 to 1945.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 3. -- The 142 graduates of the College of New Rochelle, largest Catholic women's college in the United States, were advised this afternoon against following "the patrioteers of profit" who defend the Constitution and decry social justice as communism.

LONDON, May 3. -- Trading on the London Stock Exchange was restricted today, and prices were generally irregular. British funds were lower because of the unsettled Continental currency situation. Far Eastern issues were uncertain in the foreign department and the German list was irregular.

FASHINGTON, June 3. -- The Broad River Power Company of Columbia, S.C., has filed under the Securities Act of 1933 for the issuance of $10,000,000 of first mortgage bonds, due 1966, to be used in the redemption or retirement of outstanding bonds.

The domestic news bearing on the stock market yesterday was encouraging, but foreign developments made for uneasiness. The net result was that stocks moved narrowly in the slowest trading since May 13, and the closing was irregularly lower.

An analysis of the 398 answers to questionnaires sent by the Securities and Exchange Commission to investment trusts of the general-management type showed that 193 had assets of $500,000 or more each on Dec. 31, last, and 205 had less than $500,000 each in assets, the SEC announced yesterday at its local office.

Standing on the balcony of a new 70-foot tower rising above a 90-foot ash heap in the Flushing Meadows, the directors of the World's Fair Corporation looked out through a drizzling rain last night over the 1,000-acre site of the World's Fair of 1939.

Unable to discharge their comeback powers against Charley Ruffing after his team-mates had obtained a four-run lead in the first frame, the White Sox received an 11-to-1 drubbing at the Stadium yesterday as the McCarthymen fattened their batting averages.

WEYBRIDGE, England, June 3. -- Two members of America's Wightman Cup team passed out of the picture in the St. George's Hill tennis tournament today as the third, Mrs. Sarah Palfrey Fabyan of Brookline, Mass., gained the fourth round.

Production of pig iron in May, according to The Iron Age, rose to 84,837 tons daily, a gain of 5.9 per cent over April's rate of 80,123 tons, establishing a new six-year record. Total output was 2,629,957 tons, compared with 2,403,683 tons in April.

Prices of bonds rose generally yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. While most of the improvement was in fractions, all groups, including the high-grade investment as well as the secondary loans, participated in the upward trend. The trading pace was stepped up moderately as a result of special activity in Cuban bonds, and sales amounted to $11,350,500, compared to $10,456,700 on Tuesday.
PHILADELPHIA, June 3 (AP). -- The Athletics evened the series with the Tigers by capturing the second game today, 11 to 7.

A total of $19,092 was presented by the Barnard College alumnae to Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve for the college last night at the annual commencement reunion. Of this amount $8,595 represented individual contributions and $3,480 class gifts.

DRESDEN, Germany, June 3 (AP). -- Lieut. Gen. Walter Wever, 49 years old, chief of staff of the German Air Force, was killed in an airplane crash today at Dresden Airport. The only other occupant of the plane, Mechanic Sergeant Krauss, also was killed.

Commodity futures prices were generally stronger yesterday in spite of restricted trading. Tin futures, however, continued under pressure and Straits contracts lost 125 to 195 points on transactions of only twenty tons. In the cash market wheat, corn, rye, oats, raw sugar, butter, lard and rubber were higher, while cocoa and tin were lower, the latter touching new low levels for the current movement.

Early participation in the International Steel Cartel by producers of steel in the United States is unlikely, officials of steel companies here said yesterday. At the same time they feel that the cartel offers advantages which should be studied with a view to obtaining an agreement satisfactory to all interests.
BERLIN, June 3 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of May 30 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

ALTHOUGH Dr. James T. Shotwell uses "On the Rim of the Abyss" (Macmillan, $3) as the title for his new book on world affairs, he is, in general, hopeful. The League of Nations is still a power in the world, he believes, and if the United States will uproot prejudice to make room for a little straight thinking, that power may be greatly increased and civilization saved from the devil of war in the abyss.

MUNICH, June 3. -- The secret marriage of Miss Abigail Beveridge, daughter of the late United States Senator Albert J. Beveridge of Indiana, to Franz Baum, German artist, more than six months ago was disclosed here today.

Nearly 10,000 visitors boarded the Queen Mary yesterday, and of these 5,858 paid $1 each. The ship was opened to the general public for the first time at 9 A.M. and from that time until noon 2,570 persons passed through the public rooms and a selected group of staterooms.

The general municipal law throws a number of safeguards around the right of cities to contract debts. For example, the debt must be for a specific object, expressly stated in the ordinance or resolution proposing it, and that ordinance or resolution must either be passed by a two-thirds vote in council or submitted to a popular referendum.

Freshening winds followed by rain about 9 P.M. brought relief to the New York area. last night after a day in which the thermometer averaged thirteen degrees above the normal figure for this time of year. One death and two prostrations were attributed to the heat.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 3. -- A wild throw to first base in the last half of the ninth inning gave Providence College a 2-1 victory over Long Island University at Hendricken Field today. Charlie Gallagher scored the winning tally from third base as Jules Bender, L.I.U. shortstop, hurled high over Abe Abramowitz's head.

DETROIT, June 3. -- The granting of vacation with pay to employes on hourly wage bases was announced today by Alvan MacCauley, president of the Packard Motor Car Company, as one of several features of a new labor policy just adopted. It is estimated that 7,000 employes will benefit.

OKLAHOMA CITY, June 3. -- The shadow of defeat played fitfully over the field of favorites in the second round of the women's Southern golf tournament today and finally settled on the medalist, Mrs. Dan Chandler of Dallas.

DETROIT, June 3. -- Dayton Dean, Black Legion gunman, in a surprise move almost without precedent, took the witness stand voluntarily over his counsel's protest today at the preliminary court examination of himself and twelve other members of the organization whom the prosecution is seeking to bring to trial for the murder of Charles A. Poole.

SHANGHAI, Thursday, June 4. -The reports of civil strife between the southwest and the Central Government, asserted to be marked by a sweeping advance of the southwestern armies, still lack confirmation here and come from no source except the Japanese Domei Agency.

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- Ruffled Senatorial sensibilities, stirred by the revival on the floor of a feud growing out of consideration by the Senate Finance Committee of the House Tax Bill's schedules on undistributed profits of corporations, forced leaders to arrange a recess late today instead of sitting until the bill was passed, as planned.

Mr. and Mrs. John Calvin Thorne gave a dinner last night in the Summer Garden of the Ambassador for Mr. and Mrs. James A. Thomas, Dr. and Mrs. Davenport West, Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin F. Few, Mr. and Mrs. Edward H. Little and Mrs. Frederick Townsend.

SALEM, N.H., June 3. -- Before a crowd of 10,000 Felix Spatola's Wise Prince, an 8-1 shot, today captured the New England States Handicap, feature at Rockingham Park. Wise Prince won by a neck from Ed McMann's Spixi, and was clocked for the six furlongs in 1:11 2-5.

LONDON, June 3. -- Haile Selassie, exiled Emperor of Ethiopia, arrived in London this evening and a great crowd of British sympathizers cheered him as he drove away from Waterloo Station to a private residence in Princes Gate, Kensington, placed at his disposal by Sir Elly Kadoorie, wealthy Oriental merchant who is now in China.

JERUSALEM, June 3. -- Armed with the endorsement of Jerusalem's Grand Mufti and a letter of recommendation from the Palestine Government, an Arab delegation today proceeded to London as the unofficial representatives of the Arab nation, marking the first attempt of Arab leaders to break the impasse resulting from their opposition to the government.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., June 3. -- Baltusrol, where Willie Anderson won the second of his four United States open crowns early in the century; where H. Chandler Egan beat Freddie Herreshoff in the 1905 amateur; where Jerome Travers snatched victory away from Tommy McNamara in the 1915 national open, and where George Von Elm broke Bobby Jones's string of conquests a decade ago, is ready to add one more championship to its illustrious string.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., June 3. -- Detraining quietly at a little-used crossing to elude reporters and photographers for the second successive year on his annual Spring trip north, John D. Rockefeller Sr. arrived at his Summer estate, Golf House, here this afternoon.
JERUSALEM, June 3. -- Instead of abating, Arab brigandage seems to be on the increase and the rebels are becoming bolder daily.

LONDON, June 3. -- Far from being ashamed over the budget leak scandal, the British people were able to pride themselves today over the efficiency and courage with which the whole squalid business was brought to light.

The Shippers Conference of Greater New York, at a special meeting yesterday, reaffirmed its position in favor of the railroads' proposal to install free pick-up and store-door delivery of freight, and delegated two of its members to support the proposal before the Interstate Commerce Commission at a hearing June 16 in Washington.

Lou Calder, Westchester sportsman, is going to plant several acres of his estate with a Winter food mixture this week. Up at the Campfire Club the other day he showed us a circular containing instructions and a list of desirable seeds that had been sent to him by the New York Conservation Department.

The flight of capital from European gold-bloc countries spurted yesterday as the spread of strikes increased anxiety over the financial and political situation in France. An additional $12,088,000 gold was engaged in Paris for shipment here, but in spite of this the franc fell below the gold point and closed at 6.58 5/16 cents, off 1/16 point.

Radio waves are not always the speedy messengers of constant velocity that most scientists have believed them to be, but sometimes "doddle along in second gear" at about half their normal rate as they skip from place to place over the earth, according to Dr. Harlan T. Stetson of the Institute of Geographical Exploration, Harvard University.
Walter R. Miller has been elected an assistant secretary of the Manufacturers Trust Company.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 3. -Yale turned back Holy Cross, 4 to 2, today before 3,000 spectators, largely through the airtight pitching of the veteran Ted Horton, who was switched from the outfield to the box. He allowed the visitors seven safeties and kept them scattered.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French frano on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

For the first and only time during the popular season at the Metropolitan Opera House an opera of Puccini came to performance with last night's presentation of "Madama Butterfly." Perhaps it was the unabated drawing power of the music of this composer that was largely responsible for the size of the audience, which was an exceedingly large one, in spite of the heat.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., June 3. -- Finishing with a brilliant 79, one under women's par, Mrs. William Hockenjos of the home club today coasted home the winner in the 54-hole medal play championship of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association at the Crestmont Golf Club.

LONDON, June 3. -- Joachim von Ribbentrop, German Ambassador at Large, continued his unofficial conversations with influential Britons today, but if those with whom he talked read current news dispatches his task of convincing them of the permanence of Germany's pacific intentions must have been an uneasy one.

NAPANOCH, N.Y., June 3. -- No matter what may be the outcome of his fight with Joe Louis June 18, Max Schmeling continues to get the approval of visiting experts and boxing luminaries. Latest to put the stamp of approval on the Uhlan is James J. Braddock, world champion, who made his first visit to Max's training camp today and watched the German go through six rounds of fast boxing.

LONDON, June 3. -- Joachim von Ribbentrop, German Ambassador at Large, continued his unofficial conversations with influential Britons today, but if those with whom he talked read current news dispatches his task of convincing them of the permanence of Germany's pacific intentions must have been an uneasy one.

NAPANOCH, N.Y., June 3. -- No matter what may be the outcome of his fight with Joe Louis June 18, Max Schmeling continues to get the approval of visiting experts and boxing luminaries. Latest to put the stamp of approval on the Uhlan is James J. Braddock, world champion, who made his first visit to Max's training camp today and watched the German go through six rounds of fast boxing.
Wilhelm Schult has sold a six-family house at 76 Columbia Avenue, Jersey City, to Alma Murtha. J.I. Kislak, Inc., the broker, arranged a first mortgage for the buyer.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, June 3. -- General Anastasio Somoza, chief of the insurgent National Guard, returned with 2,500 soldiers tonight from Leon, where his forces captured a fortress yesterday. Managua was decorated and the general received an enthusiastic welcome.

A PUSHING, tiptoeing mob crowded the after-portion of the Berengaria's promenade deck one evening last July. Coming upon the scene, I pushed and tiptoed with the rest for a few moments, but soon turned away without learning who or what was the center of attraction. Down on D deck I found my friend's cabin; there we talked until the all-ashore whistle blew and it was time to go.

A delay of a week or ten days in seeking extradition of Ellis H. Parker Sr., Burlington County, N.J., detective under indictment in Brooklyn for the kidnapping of Paul H. Wendel, was decided upon yesterday by District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan.

ALBANY, June 4. -- Governor Lehman signed today the bill of Assemblyman Holley of New York, designed to help remove the stigma of illegitimacy from children born out of wedlock by providing that birth certificates need not disclose the marital name or status of the mother.

The veil shrouding the economic workings of Father Divine's "Kingdom" was lifted briefly in the municipal term of the magistrates' court yesterday -- long enough to permit a glimpse of how the Peace Mission Garages on West 144th Street are operated.

One test the city sales tax, now renewed for another year, meets triumphantly. It works. It raises the revenue needed. It enables Mayor LA GUARDIA, once its bitterest foe, to sleep more soundly at night, because he knows that in the morning the money will be there to take care of the unemployed.

Fly-fishing for black bass in Maine became legal last Monday. Angling for the bronzebacks is restricted to the use of flies until June 20, when the regular season opens. Until then bait and plugs are barred. The creel limit during the special fly-fishing period is three per day.

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 4. -- Tupelo, veteran chestnut gelding owned by Mrs. Julius Bliss of Bronxville, N.Y., and ridden in all his classes by Miss Ann Kenyon of Providence, captured the hunter championship of the eighteenth annual West Point horse show, which was concluded today on the show grounds of the United States Military Academy.

ATLANTA, June 4 (AP). -- Crop losses due to the southeastern drought passed the $100,000,000 mark today. A $50,000,000 estimate for North Carolina topped the seven-State list. Consumer interest mounted with rising vegetable prices.

PARIS, June 4. -- At a moment when all authority seems to have disappeared in France and order is being kept only because the hundreds of thousands of striking workmen are themselves quiet and orderly, Albert Sarraut's government has resigned and Leon Blum's Cabinet has been formed.

Establishment of an East River ferry at the foot of Forty-second Street, to serve visitors to the World's Fair in Flushing, was listed as an objective of the Forty-second Street Property Owners and Merchants Association, Inc., at its annual meeting yesterday in the Hotel Commodore.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- Rejecting arguments of George H. Dern, Secretary of War; Claude A. Swanson, Secretary of the Navy, and Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior, against construction of the proposed $175,000,000 Fifty-seventh Street bridge and terminal connecting Manhattan with Weehawken, N.J., the House Interstate Commerce Committee in a formal report today urged early action on a bill to authorize beginning of Construction.

MELBOURNE, Australia June 4. -- The Japanese Consul General, Kuramatsu Murai, has arrived from Sydney for a conference with the Trade Treaties Minister Sir Henry Gullett. It is believed he has asked for revision of the new duties.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- A new record in the gross value of securities registered under the Securities Act of 1933 released for sale in a single month was made in April, when the aggregate proceeds were estimated at $751,012,738. The previous record was in March, with $583,391,363.
TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., June 4. -- Horse lovers will gather here tomorrow and Saturday for the annual Tuxedo horse show. There are more entries than in recent years.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 4. -- With the Hudson River in an ideal mood for rowing, one more crew today joined the little colony that will swell to eighteen shells by the time the intercollegiate regatta is held on June 22.

Twenty-five diplomas will be awarded tonight at the commencement exercises concluding the twenty-ninth year of the Riverdale Country School. The exercises will be on the campus, weather permitting, or in the gymnasium in the event of rain.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., June 4. -- Where par was broken by only one player in the opening round of the United States open championship last year at Oakmont, fourteen registered sub-par scores in the initial chapter of the fortieth annual classic at the Baltusrol Golf Club today.

NEWARK, N.J., June 4. -- Newark registered its fourth straight victory today, defeating Rochester, 4 to 3. Marvin Duke blanked the Red Wings until the eighth when a homer by Rothrock and doubles by Weintraub and Mills sent him to the showers.

The stoopnocrats, as members of the philanthropically conceived Society of Stoopnocracy call themselves, embarked last night on a "Crazy Cruise" up a goodly length of the Hudson River and return for a festive evening in the interest of charity.

TRENTON, June 4. -- Governor Hoffman hailed today the official returns of the Republican primary, in which he was elected delegate at large to the national convention by 54,217 votes over his opponent, former Representative Franklin W. Fort, as a genuine victory and not a "repudiation" of him by the voters.

Although there were only five business days in the week ended on Wednesday, bank clearings showed a substantial gain, after declining to the lowest point in fifteen weeks. First-of-the-month payments were included in the reports for both this year and last.

The Scudder School will graduate eighty-five young women at its forty-first annual commencement this morning at 11 o'clock in the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Twelfth Street. The Rev. Edgar F. Romig, pastor of the West End Collegiate Church, will address the graduates.

May volume of advertising was highly encouraging to the field, with practically all types of media broadening their gains over the corresponding month of last year, according to comments by executives here yesterday. The seasonal Spring peak was reached in April but because of improved conditions and greater consciousness of the need for holding up Summer advertising, increases over 1935 are expected to be maintained and even widened.

The Queen Mary sails for England today with a list of 1,855 passengers. Among the prominent persons sailing are Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, with Mrs. Butler; Jules S. Bache, banker; Lucius Boomer, president of the Waldorf-Astoria, with his wife; Nancy Hoyt, author, and Clara E. Laughlin, traveler and lecturer.

A charge of negligence by Captain William B. Perry, master of the Bull Line freighter Angelina, for the collision between his ship and the fishing boat MJR 3d, which occurred May 3 off Ambrose lightship, was filed yesterday by examiners of the United States Steamboat Inspection Service.

Quentin Apa.rtments, Inc., (Soko]or Brothers), have sold the sixstory apartment house at 2,626 Zings Highway, Brooklyn, to Elias Iaplan and [Ray Iaplan, his wife, for investment. The buyers paidI cash over a first mortgage of $105,000 and a second mortgage of $20,000.

Sales of Montgomery Ward Co. for May are expected to show a better rate of increase ever 1935 than the 18.9 percent gain registered in April. May sales last year totaled $22,914,580. For the first quarter of its fiscal year, the three months to April 30, last, sales were 10.3 per cent over the corresponding period last year.

BOSTON, June 4 (AP). -- Bob (Lefty) Grove gained his eighth victory, against one defeat, today when the Red Sox came from behind and turned back the Indians, 4 to 3, sweeping the three-game series. The southpaw gave nine hits, passed four and hit a batsman, but managed to hold Cleveland scoreless until the seventh.

In the fastest mile and an eighth turned in at Belmont Park in several years, J.B. Partridge's Prince Abbot yesterday won the featured Fair Play Handicap in 1:491-5. This is only three-fifths of a second behind Hot Toddy's track record, which once stood as the world's mark.

Efforts of a group of shipping and trade organizations in the metropolitan district to force the longshoremen's and truckmen's unions to service their trucks on piers in this port whether or not their drivers are members of the union have been thwarted by the Supreme Court of the United States, it was learned yesterday.
LONDON, June 4 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

Rudy Vallee heard himself described in the Supreme Court yesterday as a contract breaker when he appeared to defend a suit for $170,000 damages brought by the Ruvall Orchestra Corporation, which conducted the Villa Vallee at 10 East Sixtieth Street and which also asks $300,000 from the National Broadcasting Company for interfering with Vallee's contract.

TRENTON, June 4. -- The payment of $15,620,793.45 as inheritance tax and interest on the estate of Dr. John D. Dorrance, head of the Campbell Soup Company of Camden, more than wiped out today New Jersey's anticipated deficit of $13,000,000 for this year.

Athletic insignia have been awarded to a total of 106 participants in Spring sports at Manhattan College, it was announced yesterday by Brother Anselm, director of athletics. The awards include sixty varsity letters and forty-six freshman class numerals.

BERLIN, June 4. -- Dr. Hjalmar Schacht's round trip to the capitals of Southeastern Europe, which has been discussed abroad for more than a week, was finally announced in Germany today. The official announcement says that he will start out next week and will visit Belgrade, Athens, Sofia and Budapest.
The memoirs of Count von Bernstorff, German Ambassador to the United States during the first year of the war, will appear under the Random House imprint in October.
In outdoor cleanliness and in efficiency of its public services New York "compares favorably" with London and the large capitals of Europe, in the opinion of R.J. Hall, Lord Mayor of Liverpool.

MOSCOW, June 4. -- By playing a draw in the critical match with M. Botwinnik, the Soviet champion, in the sixteenth round today, Jose R. Capablanca of Cuba held his lead in the international chess masters tournament.

VIENNA, June 4. -- "During the past two years the Austrian Government has reiterated the solemn declaration that it considers a Hapsburg restoration a matter of no immediate concern," the head of the official press bureau reminded foreign correspondents today when asked about the object of Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg's visit to Italy.

CHICAGO, June 4. -- Rules for the elimination of trade abuses and evils in the rubber tire industry were adopted today by a trade practice conference attended by representatives of the rubber tire and allied industries and presided over by Robert E. Freer, a member of the Federal Trade Commission.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 4. -- Harvard's batsmen, packed a heavy punch today against Larry Burger and Harry Grant, Long Island University pitchers, and beat the New York nine, 13 to 4.

ROME, June 4. -- Yesterday's meeting between the British Foreign Secretary, Anthony Eden, and the Italian Ambassador, Dino Grandi, in London is considered particularly significant in Rome, owing to the evidence of a desire on the part of the British and Italian Governments to reach an understanding.

WARSAW, June 4. -- Premier Felicien Slawoj-Skladkowski emphatically declared in his speech at the convocation of an extraordinary Sejm session today that the government would use all means available to protect the Jewish population and to halt anti-Semitic rioting.

OTTAWA, June 4 (Canadian Press). -- Deposits with the Bank of Canada by the Dominion Government declined $2,884,553 and by chartered banks rose $1,338,464 in the week ended yesterday, the bank reported today. The statement follows:

The first shipment of thousands of bonus bonds will be sent to the General Postoffice today from the Federal Bond Issuance Department of the Federal Reserve Bank. The bonds will continue to go out from the bank daily beginning with this shipment until a few days before June 15, when the postoffice will start their distribution to the veterans themselves.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- How can America get its unemployed back to work and also find its way out of "this business of relief" so as to get rid of the present relief establishment and its burden of billions of dollars annually?

DETROIT, June 4. -- Fifteen more members of the Black Legion were charged with kidnapping in a warrant sworn out today by Duncan C. McCrea, Wayne County prosecutor. The accusations were in connection with the flogging of another member for failure to attend meetings.

Supreme Court Justice George H. Furman granted a temporary injunction yesterday to the State Transit Commission restraining the Long Island Railroad from charging more than two cents a mile within the City of New York, but confusion over the rates is likely to continue for some time.
PARIS, June 4 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:
MADRID, June 4 (AP). -- Signs of a growing split in the Leftist front, which dominates the Spanish Government, accentuated the gravity tonight of a series of growing strikes.
In the twenty years he has been a member of the House of Representatives Mr. Bankhead has acquired a reputation for skill and energy which made him one of the leading members of his party.

Three girls received superior ratings of more than 95 per cent at the third annual three-day New York piano-playing tournament which opened yesterday at Aeolian Hall, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fourth Street.

VILLANOVA, Pa., June 4. -- Dr. Ross J. Swartz Hoffman, Professor of History at New York University, told members of the graduating class of Villanova College at commencement exercises today that religion was the only true basis of human freedom.
LONDON, June 4. -- Trading on the London Stock Exchange was dominated today by the unsettled foreign conditions, particularly the French crisis, and operations were generally dull and restricted.

Large-scale production of what is claimed to be the first commercially practicable artificial wool will be started in this country by the Lanatin Corporation, a newly formed organization, within the next few months, it was made known here Wednesday.

EAST WILLISTON, L.I, June 4. -- A three-foot putt that rimmed the cup instead of dropping in gave Mrs. William R. Kirkland Jr. a 6 on the eighteenth hole and gave her opponent, Mrs. Robert C. Lake, the right to play in the final of the women's Long Island golf championship at Wheatley Hills tomorrow.

CHICAGO, June 4. -- The Giants' promising gay dash through the West was pulled up short today as the Cubs unfurled a bristling attack that set the Terrymen back on their heels and finally upended them by the score of 8 to 5.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP). -- A substitute proposal was advanced today by Senator Shipstead of Minneapolis for the bondholders' plan to reorganize the Minneapolis St. Louis Railroad, which latter he said had "some serious defects."

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- State administration of relief by nonpartisan boards is proposed in a relief plank to be submitted to the Republican convention next week. The committee drafting the plank was composed of most of the Republican leaders here who have been directly interested in the relief problem.

A cross-section of nation-wide Republican viewpoint was presented last night in an hour's symposium in which persons engaged in a variety of pursuits from coast to coast lashed out at New Deal policies and gave their suggestions for the party's platform to be adopted in Cleveland.

Twenty-five small tobacconists who make their own cigarettes in little shops on the lower East Side, Brooklyn and the Bronx were busy during the last three months turning out their fanciest bootleg products for a group of new and apparently prosperous customers.

LONDON, June 4. -- There are indications here of a serious effort to lead British public opinion out of the labyrinth of good intentions ending in futility, in which it is now wandering, into the more direct path of a foreign policy that leads somewhere.

Congressional leaders now say that owing to the recess caused by the sudden death of Speaker BYRNS, adjournment seems likely to go over until the week after the Republican convention. This is a decision that was probably inevitable in any case. In view of the status of the Tax Bill alone, talk of adjournment by June 6 or 9 seemed unrealistic from the beginning.

The West Side Association of Commerce announced yesterday that unless the city withdraws its order barring taxicabs from city-owned piers it will invite the steamship companies to join in a court action testing the city's power to make the regulation.

Aroused by a large number of taxicab accidents in comparison with the city's total motor accidents, Police Commissioner Valentine ordered the police yesterday to be more rigorous in enforcing regulations designed to permit only safe taxicabs and taxicab drivers on the streets.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- Fifteen hundred strong, farm women from remote sections of this and foreign countries rose tonight at a dinner to acclaim Mrs. Carrie Chapman Cart, who voiced an ardent plea for their aid in the abolition of war. Secretary Wallace was the other featured speaker at the event, an important adjunct to the triennial meeting of the Associated Country Women of the World, closing tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- Wholesale prices advanced slightly in the week ended on May 30, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 weekly average as 100, rose to 78.4, compared with 78.2 the preceding week and 80.2 the year before.

CLEVELAND, June 4. -- A sectional struggle over the drafting of the Republican platform is developing here with the leaders from the East demanding that the sound money and tariff views of that region be embodied in the party's declarations if the West is permitted to have its way on the farm and social security planks.

After a four-year survey of professional economic conditions, a special committee of the New York County Lawyers Association reported its findings last night in a comprehensive fifty-four-page dossier which contained the conclusion that the local bar "is so overcrowded as to create a serious community problem."
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, June 4. -- The outbreak of strikes in Yugoslavia has reached Croatia, causing the authorities concern. Not only workmen but clerks and shop employes are affected. No responsible persons believe these strikes have a political background.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 4. -- Owing to its precarious financial condition, the New York, Westchester Boston Railroad is unable to pay taxes due to this city, C.L. Bardo, trustee of the railroad, informed the city in a letter today. The taxes for the first half of this year amount to $19,235.
LONDON, June 4. -- Haile Selassie, exiled Ethiopian Emperor, spent most of today conferring with advisers as to what he could do, now that he is here, to serve the cause that brought him to London.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., June 4. -- Fearing failure to graduate with his class at Lehigh University, Wesley L. Clow, 23 years old, today shot and fatally wounded his English instructor, C. Wesley Phy. The student then turned a pistol on himself and died an hour and a half later from a wound in the temple.

PHILADELPHIA, June 4 (AP). -- Scoring ten runs in the third inning and six in the fifth, Detroit walloped the Athletics, 18 to 9, today and took the series, two games to one. Fourteen Tigers batted in the third, and excepting Jack Burns all scored a run or more.

Reflecting the activities of dealers in government securities, preparatory to the government financing announced on Monday, the total of brokers' loans, as reported by member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City, rose $208,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to the highest mark for more than a year at $1,176,000,000.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- The Federal Communications Commission issued a ruling today denying the application of the Mackay Radio and Telegraph Company to establish a commercial radio circuit between New York and Oslo, Norway, in competition with RCA Communications.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 4. -- Emil Bayer of 116-34 199th Street, St. Albans, Queens, who told District Attorney Littleton he was unemployed but out to "make fame and fortune" by his 15-year-old daughter's parachute jumps, was arrested today for allowing a minor to endanger her life.

PARIS, June 4. -- With the constitution of the Blum Cabinet, France is in the novel position of having three new Ministers who cannot vote. They are three women Under-Secretaries of State who, according to the laws of France, if they are obliged to sign bank checks must have them countersigned by their husbands.

JERUSALEM, June 4. -- Since the shooting of two Jews near Rishon Legion and the wounding of several Jews by a bomb thrown at an autobus in Haifa yesterday, no further incidents have been reported for twenty-four hours except the usual nightly rifle shots and bomb explosions, all harmless.

SANDS POINT, L.I., June 4. -- Nine planes left about 3 P.M. today from the Sands Point Bath Club beach here on the sixth annual seaplane cruise from Port Washington, L.I., to Chesapeake Bay. The fliers, who left after lunch in the clubhouse, headed for the Gibson Island Club in Chesapeake Bay, where a reunion dinner was to be held.

Morris E. Leeds, president of the Leeds Northrup Company, Philadelphia, received the Henry Laurence Gantt gold medal of the Institute of Management last night "for distinguished achievement in industrial management as a service to the community."

CLEVELAND, June 4. -- With supporters of Governor Landon more insistent than ever that he will receive the Republican nomination for President on the first or second ballot at the Republican National Convention, which will begin here on Tuesday, a stir was noticed in the camps of other aspirant as preparations for a "stop-Landon" drive got under way today.
LOS ANGELES, June 4 (AP). -- Attorneys for principals in the Freddie Bartholomew custody controversy reached an agreement tonight.

The State Division of Licenses yesterday found the American Confidential Bureau, 605 Fifth Avenue, an agency which supplied guards and strikebreakers during the building strike last March, guilty of violating the law governing the licensing of private detective bureaus.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- The publicity campaign of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, including the use of fifty-six motion pictures, was further described today before the Federal Communications Commission. These pictures, produced in ten years at an original cost of $261,958, were distributed to associated companies, which paid $170,417 for 2,492 prints furnished at actual cost of production, according to James M. Hamilton, vice president and motion-picture director of the A.T. T.

An expression of hope that the United States and Great Britain "may in some way be joined together to prevent the horrors of war" aroused an audience of 1,000 persons yesterday as Lord Essendon, British shipping leader, spoke the thanks of his government for the reception accorded the new Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary on her first visit to New York.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- After long hesitation, officers of the Amalgamated Association of Iron, Steel and Tin Workers decided tonight to affiliate with the Committee for Industrial Organization headed by John L. Lewis in order that a drive to organize the 500,000 workers in the nation's steel plants may be started soon by the cooperation of the two organizations.

The stock market was as confused yesterday as were the interpretations placed on the financial (and political) news, domestic and foreign. French labor disturbances increased in intensity, as did the nervousness over the fate of the franc and its gold-bloc allies, Italy's difficulties growing out of her Ethiopian adventure were again in the news, and the trouble in the Far East remained serious.

The round of ceremonies and entertainments attendant on the stay of the liner Queen Mary here after arriving on her maiden voyage culminated last night in a supper dance and fashion show in the Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria.

CLEVELAND, June 4. -- Frank L. Smith, National Committeeman from Illinois, denied today that he had conceded Governor Landon's nomination on the first ballot. He was quoted to this effect in a dispatch from here. He said:

ST. LOUIS, June 4. -- Professor Stengel made the surprising discovery today that the Gashouse Gang not only can be beaten on its own lot but that the feat can be performed by coming from behind. Two Dodger runs, scored in the eighth, overcame a local lead attained in the seventh and gave Brooklyn a 4-3 triumph.

In THE TIMES of May 31 there are several articles concerning Palestine. It is strange that not a single account considers the rights of the Arabs. Palestine is a Moslem country. True, it is a mandate of Great Britain, but is it ethical to ask the protector to give away a nation, the homeland of a race which has lived there for centuries?

PRINCETON, N.J., June 4. -- The tenth annual commencement weekend of the Westminster Choir School of Princeton opened here this morning with graduation exercises in the school chapel. The program will continue through Saturday afternoon when the annual Talbott musical festival will be held on the campus of the school.

The first of two benefit supper dances for the Community Music Schools of New York was held last night in the Belvedere Roof Garden of the Hotel Astor under the auspices of a committee headed by Mrs. Lawrence Tibbett and Mrs. Alexander H. McLanahan. The parties are supplementary to the campaign conducted recently for the music schools.

Former Supreme Court Justice Daniel F. Cohalan urged last night that all persons on relief and all Federal employes except civil service workers should be barred from voting in the coming Presidential elections. He advocated legislation that would prevent President Roosevelt himself from casting a ballot.
An attempt by two Welfare Island workhouse prisoners to escape by swimming the East River to the Queens shore yesterday afternoon resulted in success for one and recapture for the other.

In the June 1 issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES there appear two illustrations showing the decorations at the entrance of Pier 90 incident to the welcome of the Queen Mary. In the upper illustration both the British and American flags are draped, the former about the red cross of St. George, and the latter about the American shield.

" I do not respect the 'New Deal' in the churches, schools and political life of the United States, where material advantages are placed above a man's service to humanity," Dr. Clarence Cook Little, former president of the University of Maine and the University of Michigan, now head of the Roscoe B. Jackson Memorial Laboratory at Bar Harbor, Me., said yesterday afternoon in the commencement address to Pratt Institute's 561 graduates.
Most commodity futures were lower yesterday in quiet trading. In the cash markets wheat, corn, rye, flour, butter, lard, tin and silk were higher, while cotton, rubber and antimony were lower.

This Summer's college graduates face a more cheerful world than in the last half dozen years. Testimony from a number of sources declares that the field of opportunity is opening up. Business firms are once more interested in young men and women leaving college.

The resignation of William L. Nolan, technical adviser of the Securities and Exchange Commission since its organization in October, 1934, was announced yesterday at the regional office of the commission, 120 Broadway. Mr. Nolan expects to re-enter the banking and brokerage business in Wall Street after a brief vacation.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- Disbursements by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in May aggregated $130,306,184, bringing the grand total since its establishment on Feb. 2, 1932, to $8,772,463,161, the RFC reported today. The principal outlay in May was $97,000,000 for the purchase of stock of the Commodity Credit Corporation.

A large audience last night attended the fourth and final presentation of Bizet's "Carmen" at the Metropolitan Opera House. Like Smetana's "The Bartered Bride," the Bizet production has been a strong box-office attraction in the popular season at the Broadway house.

The possibility of a strike on many buildings now under construction in this city developed yesterday with the announcement that sixteen unions in the building trades had promised their support to the Structural Iron Workers Union, Local 40, which called a walkout yesterday on a building being erected at 40 West Fortieth Street. The union is fighting for recognition.

Holders of defaulted mortgage certificates will collect more interest than their certificates call for under a decision yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler involving all mortgages from which title companies received 6 per cent and guaranteed only 5 1/2 per cent to the purchasers of the certificates.

For some time bills have been pending in Congress to create additional Federal judges. Need for them was argued on the basis of the crowded calendars with consequent delays in the administration of justice. Reports of the Attorney General had shown that even after the multitudinous prohibition cases which so long cluttered up the calendar had been swept away, there is too much congestion in the lower Federal courts.

GENEVA, June 4. -- The League of Nations announced today that the president of its Assembly, Eduard Benes, had definitely decided to summon an Assembly meeting as Argentina requested and would very soon fix the date.
Three boys who "hitched" a ride on a produce truck bound for Hempstead encountered unexpected opposition from the Jamaica police yesterday when they were mistaken for fleeing bandits.
HONGKONG, June 4 (AP). -- Provincial armies of Southern China tonight demanded to be sent to fight the Japanese.

In a letter bristling with criticism of the city's bidding standards and procedure, Park Commissioner Robert Moses notified the Board of Estimate yesterday that he had rejected as unsatisfactory the two lowest bids submitted for grading the Flushing Meadows site for the 1939 World's Fair but had accepted the third lowest bid.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., June 4. -- What "God control" has done for Canada in three years since the movement reached there was told here today by Canadian participants in the first assembly of the Oxford group in the United States.

The State of Virginia yesterday awarded a new issue of $960,000 of general obligation bonds to a banking group headed by Edward B. Smith Co., and including the First Boston Corporation, G.M.-P. Murphy Co. and Alexander Brown Sons, on a bid of 101.7699 for 1 3/4s.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- The letter written by former Secretary Newton D. Baker, Lewis W. Douglas, Director of the Budget in the early days of the Roosevelt administration, and Leo Wolman, which was published in THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday, is occasioning much comment in Congress.

Estimates of the percentage of allotments of the new Treasury 2 3/4 per cent bonds and 1 3/8 per cent notes offered for cash have necessarily been altered materially since the preliminary figures on the oversubscription on the $1,000,000,000 cash offering were announced in Washington.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- An increase of approximately $765,000,000 in 1935 in the investments by residents of foreign countries in stock and bonds of corporations in this country and in other so-called "long-term" holdings, bringing the aggregate to about $5,035,000,000, was estimated today in a study by Amos E. Taylor, assistant chief of the finance division of the Department of Commerce.

A break in the bloc of New York City leaders on the question of remaining unpledged until the State Republican delegation arrives in Cleveland came last night when Warren B. Ashmead, Queens County leader, announced that he was emphatically for the nomination of Governor Landon.
May I call your attention to an omission in your editorial "Rising Employment" of May 29? It deals with the reference to The Sun's survey of employment, with which the writer is connected.

Twenty-three scholarships and thirty prizes were awarded to graduates of Cooper Union last night at the seventy-seventh annual commencement exercises, held in the Great Hall of the Union. Gano Dunn, president of the board of trustees, made the awards.

HORACE'S bimillennium would have been short of its adequate observance if it had not evoked an essay by ANDREW F. WEST, formerly dean of the Graduate School of Princeton University -- a "short paper," as he called it, "addressed to all who love true poetry." It appears in a recent number of The American Scholar under the title "The Genius of Horace."
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings, the reserve note circulation and the ratio of reserve to be at the highest of the year to date.

Fifty students were inducted into the Hunter College chapter of Phi Beta Kappa, national honor fraternity, at the annual meeting last evening in the college auditorium, Sixty-eighth Street and Lexington Avenue.

The controversy between Victor F. Ridder, Works Progress Administrator, and George U. Harvey, Borough President of Queens, which resulted in the suspension of all WPA work in that borough, was settled yesterday after intervention by Mayor La Guardia and an exchange of letters between the two officials.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., June 4. -- Making her first start since capturing the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship last week, Mrs. Henry M. Dietrich of Lawrence Farms today captured the low gross prize in a one-day tournament of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf-Association.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- Reflecting what Secretary Morgenthau said he considered a feeling of public confidence that there would be no inflation of currency, conversions of Treasury notes maturing on June 15 and on Aug. 1 amounting to $1,050,754,000 were more than 90 per cent, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- The Crown Cork and Seal Company, Inc., has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 for the issuance of 225,000 shares of $2.25 cumulative, no-par, preferred stock with warrants for the purchase of common stock, and 56,250 shares of no-par common, this last to be reserved for the exercise of the warrants.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- With his head bowed to hide tears and his raised hand shaking with emotion, William B. Bankhead of Alabama took the oath of office at 11:06 o'clock this morning to become the forty-eighth Speaker of the House of Representatives. He succeeds Joseph W. Byrns of Tennessee, who died suddenly in his hotel apartment less than twelve hours previously.

ROCHESTER, June 4. -- The church must turn to "case work evangelism" and "soul clinics" to save itself from dissolution, Dr. Jesse M. Bader of New York told the General Synod of the Reformed Church today.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- In less than twelve hours after the sudden death of Speaker Joseph W. Byrns, the House today fell in line behind a new commander, Representative William B. Bankhead of Alabama, and prepared to join the Senate in carrying out a revised program to enact all pressing legislation and to end the present session of Congress by mid-June, if possible.

NAPANOCH, N.Y., June 4. -- Convinced now that he has a very good chance to beat Joe Louis in their fight at the Yankee Stadium, June 18, Max Schmeling today capitulated to the persistent efforts of Mike Jacobs and signed a contract to fight James J. Braddock for the world heavyweight title in the event that he triumphs over the Brown Bomber.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., June 4. -- Three golfers posted better scores than he did today, but there was no one in the national open golf field of 164 who was any happier tonight than Tommy Kerrigan of Siwanoy.

Governor Landon of Kansas has a wide lead as the choice of Republicans for President in a special Literary Digest poll of Binghamton, N.Y., which is included in the current publication. President Roosevelt has practically all the Democratic votes, but his total of 1,287 compares with 2,208 Republican votes for the city.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- The anti-bounty clause of the 1930 Tariff Act was invoked by the government today on account of discriminatory practices by Germany against a number of articles imported from that country and countervailing duties were ordered imposed, effective July 11.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -Conscientious performance of his duties, which gradually wore down his strength, and of late years a tendency to worry about his health were cited by friends and long associates of Speaker Byrns today as reasons for his sudden death.

W.T. Holliday, president of the Standard Oil Company of Ohio, received in 1935 a salary of $81,000 while J.I. Mange, president and chairman of the Associated Gas and Electric Company, was paid $58,755, it is disclosed in annual reports of the companies to the Securities and Exchange Commission filed in duplicate with the New York Curb Exchange.

Apprehension over the fate of the French franc deepened yesterday as strikes and disorders were reported spreading in France and the new government of Leon Blum prepared to take office today. The engagement of $1S,455,000 gold in Paris for shipment here was announced at the Federal Reserve Bank, bringing to $212,300,000 the amount taken in France for United States account since April 24.

CHICAGO, June 4. -- An apparent realization that the outcome of the Spring wheat crop on both sides of the international line was hanging in the balance as the result of continued dry weather swept the world's leading wheat markets up sharply today.

CHICAGO, June 4. -- Prices for packing sows suffered the severest break of the season here today, sales showing a decline of around 25 cents a hundredweight from yesterday's level, with extreme weights off 50 cents in the past two days.

Recognition by the United States of Italy's claims to annexation of Ethiopia was urged yesterday upon President Roosevelt in an open letter from New York State Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo.

Shopping in the Piccadilly bazaars, J.J. Shubert has taken the American rights on "Whiteoaks," Mazo de la Roche's dramatization of her own novel. It has been playing along in London since mid-April.... Lee Shubert is delaying his annual London jaunt and doubtless further English purchases, until late Summer.

The Eastern railroads recovered promptly in April from losses incurred in March as a result of floods in Pennsylvania and New England, according to a report issued yesterday by the Association of American Railroads. The report, which covers the entire country, was based on returns by 140 Class I companies operating 237,085 miles of line.

Governor HOFFMAN is a cheerful soul. He positively revels in the figures of the recent primary; and not merely on his own account. More votes were cast by the Republicans than by the Democrats, not so stimulated. The Democratic vote was 4,714 less than in the primary of 1934.

BERLIN, June 4. -- The upward movement on the Boerse, which has raised the stock index 18.2 per cent above that of Jan. 1, gave way to a reaction today, affecting both shares and foreign bonds, especially those that had risen the most. Losses of 1 or 2 points were frequent, and some were even larger.

PHILADELPHIA, June 4. -- Despite official denials from Washington, regional officers of the WPA here said today that a survey soon would be made to see "what is happening to the relief family in New Jersey" now that the State has turned the relief administration back to municipalities.

ANNAPOLIS, June 4. -- With an impressive ceremony lasting less than an hour, 261 midshipmen who had completed the course at the Naval Academy received the diplomas which marked the completion of their academic work and the degree of Bachelor of Science.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 4. -- The thirty-one seniors at Good Counsel College were graduated this afternoon at commencement exercises at which Dr. Frank P. Graves, president of the University of the State of New York, was the speaker.
Plaintiffs bought in nine properties in Manhattan at auction sales yesterday. A hotel and apartment and business buildings were among the improvements sold under the hammer.

A goldfish named "Tootsie" that is said to jump from her bowl to answer the telephone for Detective Charles S. Corbett, and his pet canary that goes on errands for him to the grocery store, were described in the Drukman conspiracy trial yesterday in an attempt by the defense to discredit Corbett as a witness.
The president of the American Federation of Labor, in a letter to THE TIMES on business and employment, closes with this paragraph:

Yankee pitching went into a violent tailspin yesterday at the Stadium as four twirlers of assorted degrees of ineptitude strove to avert a White Sox field day. They couldn't do it. The Chicagoans hammered away with gay abandon and collected sixteen hits to gain a 16-3 verdict over the New Yorkers.

The annual deficit from operation of the municipal ferry system was cut last year by $427,885, or 43 per cent, to $549,092 as against a 1934 deficit of $976,977, F.J. Kracke, sioner of Plant and Structures, Commissioner of Plant and Structures, reported yesterday.

A schedule of forty motion picture features for the six months beginning in August was announced yesterday for Paramount Pictures, Inc., by Neil F. Agnew, vice president in charge of sales, coincident with the opening of the company's annual sales convention in Chicago.

Terming the First National Exhibition of American Art now being held in the International Building, Rockefeller Center, as "an honest representation of the work being done by artists in this country," John Sloan, the artist, sharply denounced New York art critics yesterday for their "snooty" attitude toward the show.

The United States Lines announced yesterday that it has chartered the California of the Panama Pacific Line for a special voyage to Plymouth, Havre and London, leaving New York on July 1. The ship was obtained to meet the demand for space which the regular ships have been unable to supply, according to A.J. McCarthy, vice president of the International Mercantile Marine Company.

GENEVA, June 4. -- Walter Riddell of Canada, president of the governing body of the International Labor Office, opened the twentieth session of its conference today. He stressed that "moral and military ideals are totally incompatible, and higher ethical and cultural ideals can only be developed by the social and economic progress to which war is an insuperable barrier"

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- President Roosevelt, Vice President Garner, members of the Cabinet and members of Congress from both political parties joined today in paying tribute to the life and character of Speaker Byrns.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., June 4. -- Victor Ghezzi, one of the low scorers today, will be in the first pair that sets off tomorrow morning at 8:15 to start the second round of the national open golf championship. Ghezzi will have Stanley Kertes of Santa Monica, Calif., as his partner again.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the three months ended on March 31 last a consolidated net income of $1,608,750, which was equal to 25 cents a share on the 6,399,002 capital stock outstanding.

SALEM, N.H., June 4. -- In a thrilling race from start to finish, Ladfield, owned by Mrs. C. Crane, came from behind to score by a neck over Joseph Bartell's Bubblesome in the Canobie Lake Claiming Handicap today.

The present patent law is inadequate for the protection of style adaptation in wearing apparel, according to Henry D. Williams, patent attorney, who testified yesterday at the hearing in a Federal court action by William Filene's Sons Company against the Fashion Originators Guild of America.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- The policy of the United States Government of not interfering in the domestic affairs of American nations was reaffirmed by Secretary of State Cordell Hull tonight in a statement prompted by representations from Chile and Peru against the possibility of intervention by the United States in Nicaragua as a result of the revolution there.

Directors of the Allis Chalmers Manufacturing Company declared yesterday a quarterly dividend of 25 cents on the common stock. This places the stock on an annual rate of $1 and marks the resumption of dividends on the issue, the last previous payment having been 12 1/2 cents quarterly on May 16, 1936.

EASTON, Pa., June 4. -- Departing from custom Lafayette College will award an honorary degree in absentia to Secretary Hull at the 101st commencement exercises tomorrow. Three other honorary degrees of Doctor of Laws will be bestowed, with 163 degrees in course, two master degrees and eleven fifty-year certificates.
MANAGUA, Nicaragua, June 4. -- Diplomatic representatives had conferences today with President Sacasa and his Ministers at the Presidential palace and also with the rebellious National Guard leaders.
CINCINNATI, June 4 (AP). -- The Reds moved back into fifth place today by defeating Philadelphia, 5 to 3, to sweep the two-game series.
The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday the retirement of Rene Leon from Munds, Winslow Potter and cessation of the interest of the estate of James W. McPartlin in Tailer Robinson.

PITTSBURGH, June 4 (AP). -- The Bees shelled Cy Blanton from the mound for the tenth time this season, but the Pirates' 1935 star rookie won his second game when Paul Waner quelled a Boston uprising in the eighth with a leaping catch off the wall of Hal Lee's liner with two men on the bases. The score was 7 -- 5.
WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP). -- The Browns today snapped a string of six straight losses to the Senators this season by turning in a 6-to-2 victory.

PITTSBURGH, June 4. -- Urging active support and adoption of the interstate oil compact by oil-producing States, Axtell J. Byles of New York, president of the American Petroleum Institute, today maintained that such agreements will do much to lessen taxation and promote conservation in the oil industry.

SHANGHAI, June 4. -- The Kwangsi provincial military, which already was reported to have started 100,000 regular army and provincial militiamen northward into Hunan Province, announced tonight the enlistment of 60,000 additional militiamen, according to Japanese reports from the Kwangsi capital.
A variety of realty, including vacant lots, flats ana taxpayers, changed hands in deals in the Bronx reported yesterday.

VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., June 4. -- The Furness liner Fort Amherst, which went aground off Oak Bluffs late last night with twenty-six passengers aboard, was anchored in Vineyard Haven harbor tonight awaiting repairs after her passengers had been taken off earlier in the day by the Coast Guard.

The sixteenth annual field day of the Bond Club of New York will draw a large number of bankers and bond men from Wall Street to the Sleepy Hollow Country Club today. The club's membership exceeds 600 and W. Harman Brown Jr., chairman of the attendance committee, said yesterday that an unusually large proportion of the members had indicated their intention of spending the day at Sleepy Hollow.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- Charges that the Republican National Committee lent funds subscribed by the public for the national campaign to the Ohio State Republican Committee to obtain the election of delegates pledged against Senator Borah were made here today by the Senator.
