Commencement activities at the College of the Sacred Heart, Convent Avenue and 133d Street, will end this afternoon with the graduation exercises, at which Cardinal Hayes will present the degrees to fifty-three girls. The address to the graduates will be given by Professor Ross J. S. Hoffman of New York University.

The compulsory prostitution trial before Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook and a jury moved toward its close when both sides rested at 3:45 P.M. yesterday. Thereafter, attorneys for Thomas Pennochio, David Betillo and Benny Spiller summed up.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 4. -- Four matches, involving a host of poloists who will participate in the coming Meadow Brook Club's 20-goal tournaments, were staged in this sector today with Old Westbury's 9-to-7 victory over Greentree on Hitchcock Field as one of the highlights.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended June 3, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,476,000,000, an increase of $2,000,000 compared with the preceding week and with the corresponding week in 1935.
CLEVELAND, June 4. -- Former President Hoover will not enter into a rough and tumble attack on the record of Governor Landon, it is asserted by his advisers.

We are entering an era "that requires more than international-mindedness, whereby the greatest possible exchange of goods, information, ideals and experience must be the dominant aim," Dr. John H. Finley said last night. Dr. Finley delivered the commencement address of the New York Stock Exchange Institute, held at the Stock Exchange.

TORONTO, June 4 (AP). -- An alleged confession by the now dead wife of Ambrose J. Small, Toronto millionaire whose disappearance has never been solved, that he was dismembered in 1919 was read in court today.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- Secretary Ickes said today that attempts to "liberalize" the Republican party were "in vain," characterized William Allen White as the last liberal in the party, and belittled the suggestion of a coalition between the Republicans and an element of the Democratic party.

The percentage of gain in retail package deliveries in the metropolitan and suburban areas continued at a high level during the week ended May 30, the increase of 22 per cent being unchanged from the previous week, the United Parcel Service reported yesterday.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 4. -- Construction of strong fortifications along the German border was approved today by the Supreme Defense Council, presided over by President Eduard Benes.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- Who would have thought, up to last Monday, that the problem of what to do about the fundamentalist majority on the Supreme Court would arise to plague the delegates of Cleveland as well as those of Philadelphia? A few people, to whom this culmination of the court's session seemed obvious, expected it.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., June 4. -- They may have to call the Fire Departments of the neighboring New Jersey towns to keep this open golf championship under control. The players have been burning up the course right from the very start. It's all right as long as they stick to the fairways, but if they start slicing under the trees they will soon have the woods aflame.

For fourteen consecutive terms JOSEPH W. BYRNS represented the Fifth District of Tennessee in Congress. That is a record of continuous service matched only in the case of two other members of the present House of Representatives. It was in 1909 that Mr. BYRNS came into a House then in revolt against the iron rule of Speaker CANNON.

By a vote of 1,399 to 84 the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America won the right in a referendum today to represent 2,000 employes of United Dry Docks, Inc., Mariners Harbor, S.I., as their collective bargaining agency.

A concerted effort to prevent the outbreak of international conflict was demanded last night by Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President; Earl Browder, general secretary of the Communist party, and other speakers at an anti-war symposium at St. Nicholas Palace, Sixty-sixth Street, near Columbus Avenue.
WASHINGTON, June 5. -- Subscriptions for the Treasury's offering of $1,000,000,000 in securities to raise new money amounted to $7,054,000,000, Secretary Morgenthau announced today.
PARIS, June 5. -- Notwithstanding the extension of the French strike today to great department stores and leading supply shops, trading on the Bourse was surprisingly and exceptionally satisfactory.

Unless the Transit Commission of New York and the Public Service Commission rule to the contrary before July 1 a 20 per cent increase in monthly commutation fares on the New York, Westchester and Boston Railway will be effective the first of next month, C.L. Bardo, trustee of the railroad, said yesterday at his office, 481 Morris Park Avenue.

Another standard opera made its final appearance in the Metropolitan's popular season last night when Verdi's "Aida" was given for the third time. The cast included the same artists who appeared in the previous presentations. As at the first two performances, a large audience was present and responsively applauded the principals.

J.P. Morgan Co. have notified holders of Imperial Chinese Government 5 per cent Hukuang Railways loan of 1911 bonds that funds have been received for the payment on and after June 15 of the coupon due June 15, 1930, on all bonds of the American, British and French series and the coupon due Dec. 15, 1929, on the bonds of the German series.

Since about only 10 per cent of the odd 2,500 daily newspapers in the country have any identity as far as advertising agencies are concerned, Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn, Inc., have instituted an "exploratory" survey of the smaller papers to find out what can be done to develop them as advertising outlets or to increase their value to advertisers.

Team-work in their own circles and interest in their country were emphasized yesterday for students graduating from the Todhunter School by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, who spoke at the graduation and closing-day exercises in the grand hall of the New York Junior League, 221 East Seventy-first Street.

Salary increases approximating 100 per cent through profit-sharing agreements of principal executives of the McGraw-Hill Publishing Company were disclosed yesterday in the annual report of the company to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

EAST NORWICH, L.I., June 5. -- Raffles of Earlsmoor, an English-bred dog owned by Dr. and Mrs. Samuel Milbank of New York City and shown in the ring by the former, was awarded the highest honors today at the fourth annual specialty show of the Labrador Retriever Club of America, held in an orchard on the estate of Benjamin Moore.
VIENNA, June 5 (AP). -- Archduke Otto, claimant to the defunct Austrian throne, issued a new and urgent appeal today to the Austrian people to make him Emperor.

Philip J. Roosevelt, chairman of the reorganization committee for the Minneapolis St. Louis Railroad, said yesterday that his committee was prepared to accept the plan of Senator Shipstead of Minneapolis for refinancing the line. Senator Shipstead, who is chairman of a Senate interstate commerce subcommittee inquiring into the situation of the company, proposed that it be reorganized with the aid of a $6,000,000 loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.
PARIS, June 5. -- The text of Premier Leon Blum's radio speech to the nation today follows:

The Tariff Act of 1930 contained a section providing that if any country subsidized exports to the United States, directly or indirectly, the Secretary of the Treasury should impose additional duties on those articles equal to the net amount of the subsidy. Under this provision we have imposed countervailing duties on Danish butter, rye from Poland, pork from Ireland, and certain whiskies and artificial silk products from Great Britain.

First National Stores, Inc., the New England groceries and meat markets chain, reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended on March 28 a net profit of $3,163,329 after interest, depreciation, Federal taxes, loss on disposition of capital assets and other charges. After allowing for dividend requirements on the 7 per cent preferred stock the profit was equal to $3.65 each on 816,579 shares of no-par common stock, excluding 11,055 shares held as an investment.

The Bowling Green Midday Club, a new downtown business men's group, was organized yesterday with D.M. Cooper as president and Walter F. Campbell as vice president. Both are with Tobey Co. Mr. Cooper is a member of the New York Stock Exchange.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- Informal conversations concerning commercial relations between the United States and Japan will be conducted with State Department officials during the next few days by Saburo Kurusu, newly appointed Japanese Ambassador to Belgium, who arrived here today en route to his post.

TUXEDO PARK, June 5. -- The annual Tuxedo horse show opened today with a large number of spectators. Nearly every box was occupied at the afternoon session. The feature of the show was the well-filled classes that resulted in close competition. Several military classes for West Point cadets added color to the show.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers.

Parker McCollester, special counsel for the Long Island Railroad, tried unsuccessfully at a hearing yesterday before Public Service Commissioner George R. Lunn to show it was not discriminatory on the part of the railroad to charge interstate passengers 2 cents a mile and intrastate passengers 3 cents.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- In the presence of President Roosevelt, members of his Cabinet, the diplomatic corps and the Senate, the House of Representatives today paid tribute to Speaker Joseph W. Byrns, who died suddenly yesterday morning.

Retail trade in the metropolitan area continued to maintain an excellent pace of activity during the week. Weather conditions were uniformly favorable during the period, against two days of the week last year when rain cut sales volume. On several days of the week individual stores here bettered their figures of last year by 20 to 22 per cent, while the average for the week ranged around 15 per cent.

Health officers from three States New York, Connecticut and New Jersey, met yesterday at the Health Department offices here and organized the Metropolitan Health Officers Conference. Its aim is to bring to the metropolitan area greater uniformity in administrative procedure in public health, closer cooperation in health problems and closer personal relationships.
WEST POINT, N.Y., June 5. -- Lieutenant Charles Leonard led the army contestants in the modern pentathlon Olympic trials after the first day's competition today.

Almost any newspaper one picks up these days tells of a record being broken in some sport, but it is seldom that one hears of a rowing mark being smashed. Is this because the records are too good to be beaten or because rowers have shut their eyes to what is being done in other lines of athletics?

CHICAGO, June 5. -- Offerings of hogs in the open market here today were small, a good share of the receipts going direct to packers, and prices advanced 10 to 15 cents a hundredweight. The top price was 10 cents higher than yesterday at $10.25, equaling the best price of the week, while the day's average was $9.90, also up 10 cents.

Harold P. Coffin, referee in bankruptcy for the American estate of the Kreuger Toll Co., signed yesterday an order approving the inter-company agreements winding up claims and counter-claims between former Kreuger interests and adjourned to the special meeting of creditors on June 11 the proposed settlement of a Federal tax claim against the estate, which has not yet been completed.

ST. LOUIS, June 5. -- Pitching no harder than he had to, but hard enough when occasion demanded it, the indomitable Dizzy Dean became the first major league pitcher to win ten games this season before a Ladies' Day gathering of 15,000 today.

DETROIT, June 5. -- An attempt by the Black Legion to enforce its political demands with a bomb plot against the life of a suburban village president was charged to the hooded terrorists today, as rumors of two other death conspiracies met prompt denials.
WASHINTON, June 5. -- Secretary Harold L. Ickes in an interview today urged greater cooperation between government and business to solve the problems of unemployment and relief on a permanent basis.

Just another fan on the rampage about the absolute powers entrusted to an umpire. The writer always has been taught that no man is infallible, but it seems that that is all wrong, for he has learned that an umpire never makes a mistake.

The Board of Estimate advanced development of additional sources of water supply from the Delaware River watershed yesterday by authorizing an appropriation of $17,500,000 in corporate stock to be used by the Board of Water Supply.

EAST WILLISTON, L.I., June 5. -- It took Mrs. Sylva Annenberg twenty-five holes of the scheduled 36-hole final in the women's Long Island golf championship at Wheatley Hills today before she could get all her shots under control, but in the meantime Mrs. Robert C. Lake had piled up a lead that gave her the title for the second successive year. The score was 5 and 4.

When Dr. Charles Franklin Kittering, director of the General Motors research laboratories, accepting the Franklin Medal from the Franklin Institute of Philadelphia, spoke of the vast area of totality which science has not penetrated, he admonished his audience to adopt a proper attitude of "mental humility."

CHICAGO, June 5. -- A few minutes before 3 o'clock today a group of fans from Ray Berres's home town of Kenosha, Wis., gathered at the Wrigley Field home plate to present a basket of flowers and a watch to the Brooklyn catcher. Less than an hour later Van Lingle Mungo and the Dodgers presented the game to the Cubs when seven Bruins scored in the fifth inning.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- The Phoenix Brass Fitting Corporation of Irvington, N.J., filed today, under the Securities Act of 1933, a registration statement for the issuance of $700,000 of first-mortgage 5 1/2 per cent convertible sinking fund bonds, due on June 1, 1951.

The dissatisfaction with which many members of the Stock Exchange view the current volume of business was typified yesterday by Jules S. Bache, head of J.S. Bache Co., as he sailed on the Queen Mary for a vacation in England. Fifty per cent of the margin accounts are restricted and the other half is largely trading in London, he said.

John R. Crews, Brooklyn Republican leader, formally announced yesterday that as a delegate at large to the Republican national convention in Cleveland next week he was for the Presidential nomination of Governor Alf M. Landon of Kansas.
As a bruised veteran of the bumpy roads of Queens, I would like to say a word in the Harvey-Ridder controversy over the quality of WPA paving projects.

Pending the return of some 6,000 VPA workers shifted to other boroughs early this week by Victor F. Ridder, local WPA Administrator, Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens put his Highway Bureau employes to work on repaving jobs yesterday.
ROME, June 5 (AP). -- The return to the British Cabinet of Sir Samuel Hoare was generally regarded favorably tonight in unofficial Fascist circles.

Ending her triumphant visit here as Britain's greatest and fastest superliner, the Queen Mary sailed yesterday for her first eastward crossing. She carried nearly 1,900 passengers as she backed into the stream off her West Fiftieth Street pier and started seaward under auspicious weather conditions that favor her chances of taking the eastbound speed record from the Normandie.

ROME, June 5. -- Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg of Austria was entertained at luncheon today by Premier Benito Mussolini at the latter's country estate at Rocca della Caminate. Later the two had a cordial two-hour political conversation.

ALBANY, June 5. -- Governor Lehman vetoed today the Hall bill, which would have legalized open betting on dog races at fair grounds in Nassau, Monroe and Erie Counties. He said the measure was unsound in that it failed to provide for any system of regulation of such races.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., June 5. -- The Oxford Group offered itself at today's session of its first national assembly in America as a substitute for socialism, communism and fascism. The theme was developed by speakers at an outdoor meeting attended by 1,500 men and women, in the presence of Dr. Frank N.D. Buchman, founder of the movement.

EASTON, Pa., June 5. -- An appeal was made to the 163 members of the graduating class of Lafayette College to apply their college spirit to their affairs in life by Dr. Tyler Dennett, president of Williams, speaking at the commencement exercises today.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- The text of the opinion rendered today by Chief Justice Wheat of the District of Columbia Supreme Court, on the constitutionality of the Public Works Administration's power program, was as follows:

Thirty-six young men who have just finished the course at St. Joseph's Seminary, at Dunwoodie, will be ordained to the priesthood by Cardinal Hayes at 8 A.M. today in St. Patrick's Cathedral. The Cardinal will be assisted in the ceremony by members of the faculty.

Class day exercises will be held at Manhattan College today, with more than 1,500 persons expected to attend. The ceremonies, opening senior week, will be held in Smith Auditorium on the campus, 242d Street and Spuyten Duyvil Parkway, Riverdale, starting at 2:30 P.M.
SHANGHAI, June 5 (AP). -- Southern Chinese armies drove north today, the Domei (Japanese) News Agency reported, and occupied four towns in Hunan Province.

Veterans on home relief who receive substantial bonuses in the distribution on June 15 will be dropped from relief rolls, according to a "clarifying statement" issued yesterday at TERA headquarters, 79 Madison Avenue. Victor F. Ridder, WPA Administrator, said he had received as yet no instructions from Washington as to the status of bonus recipients employed on Federal relief projects.

There is no doubt that the new Belvedere Roof of the Hotel Astor and the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria will be two of the most popular dancing spots in the city during the warm Summer evenings ahead. The former resort, which opened on Tuesday night, offers a large, airy and refreshing room decorated in a coral, green and white color scheme, not to mention the music of Rudy Vallee and his Connecticut Yankee troupe.

The vanguard of the croaker schools, running up to four pounds, that have been affording fishermen in the Chesapeake splendid sport during the last two weeks, has arrived in Barnegat Bay with a sprinkling of the first fluke, according to reports yesterday from Forked River.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 5. -- Committee reports presented at the opening session of the thirty-eighth annual convention of the New Jersey Bar Association, at the Hotel Marlborough-Blenheim here today, stressed the need for additional legal aid societies and for reform in the present system of expert evidence.

Republican leaders have drafted a tentative plank dealing with the difficult question of relief of unemployment. In place of the Administration's present plan of meeting the entire cost of caring for a fixed number of the unemployed through an ambitious "work relief" program, these Republicans would substitute a flat allocation of funds to the States by the Federal Government.

One form of employment in which the supply of workers cannot meet the demand is that of domestic servants, Victor F. Ridder, Works Progress Administrator for New York City, declared yesterday afternoon at ceremonies opening the seventh WPA model house for the training of household employes.

Bill Bonthron will return to the foot-racing wars today, when the holder of the world's 1,500-meter record makes the first start of a campaign that he hopes will lead him to Berlin and an Olympic championship. The three-quarter-mile special at the 136th track and field games of the New York A.C. at Travers Island will serve as the vehicle for Bonny's 1936 debut.

When last year's import of gold from abroad was reported by the Commerce Department at $1,740,979,000 -- exceeding the highest previous annual import by $550,000,000 -- its occurrence in a year when the "visible balance" of other trade transactions, for the first time since pre-war days, had run heavily against this country excited comment.

Carle Bigelow of the Forstmann Woolen Mills, was yesterday elected president of the Institute of Management, the research organization of the American Management Association, at the close of a two-day session at the Hotel Astor. Dr. Lillian M. Gilbreth, president of Gilbreth, Inc., and Dr. C.S. Yoakum, of the University of Michigan, were chosen vice presidents.

LONDON, June 5. -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden officially visited Emperor Haile Selassie at the Ethiopian legation in Prince's Gate this afternoon, remaining in conversation with him nearly an hour.

LITTLE FERRY, N.J., June 5. -- Summoned by Prosecutor John J. Breslin Jr. of Bergen County an hour after bandits had looted the Little Ferry National Bank of $15,000 here this morning, about 200 municipal police chiefs and patrolmen, county and State police mobilized in Hackensack today for an intensive search for the bandits here and in surrounding communities.

A further advance in prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday carried October contracts to within 3 points of the 11-cent level, the highest record since early last December, and left the list with gains of 3 to 13 points. From a discount of more than 1 cent a pound recently, October gained steadily on the July until the two months changed hands in final dealings at a spread of only 70 points.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today broadened its rule JB4 for incorporation of information by reference in reports made under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 to cover data filed by a corporation under the Public Utility Act as well as under the Securities Act of 1933.

Unless they agree to obey the school rules as individuals, nine seniors at the Seward Park High School who walked out of classes to take part in the anti-war demonstration on April 22 may not receive diplomas when the 600 members of their class are graduated this June, Robert B. Brodie, the principal, said yesterday morning at a noisy three-hour session in his office with the students and their parents.

John Fiorenza, 24 years old, convicted slayer of Mrs. Nancy Evans Titterton, was sentenced by Judge Nott in General Sessions yesterday to die in the electric chair in the week beginning July 13. Fiorenza, neatly attired in a blue suit, blue shirt and a dotted white tie, received the sentence calmly.

For ten hours yesterday in the court presided over by Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook, oratory and cajolings resounded, all intended to induce a jury to liberate nine men accused of operating a wide-flung vice ring.

HELSINGFORS, June 5. -- Anglo-Russian naval conversations are attracting keen attention in all Baltic States, which feel considerable anxiety over the reported recent expansion of Soviet naval resources which was made possible by increased armament grants.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., June 5. -- Governor Curley was endorsed by acclamation at the Democratic convention tonight as the party's choice for United States Senator.

PHILADELPHIA, June 5. -- Playing on the turf courts where the Davis Cup matches were held, the New York representatives of the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association defeated the Middle-Atlantic team today as the annual inter-sectional competition for the Sears Cup started at the Germantown Cricket Club.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- The National Steel Corporation has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering $10,000,000 of first collateral mortgage sinking fund 3 3/4 per cent bonds, due on June 1, 1965, which Kuhn, Loeb Co. and associates, the statement said, disposed of on June 1 to a single purchaser by private sale at an aggregate price of $10,088,000.

The "ruthless" defeat of his social security program in the 1986 Legislature, followed by the decision of the United States Supreme Court invalidating the Minimum Wage Law for women and children, was characterized by Governor Lehman last night as heavy blows to the State's efforts to aid in the solution of the problem of marriage and the home.
SHANGHAI, Saturday, June 6. -- Evidences of a rapidly worsening situation were received here last night from the south and the north.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, who on Thursday urged the Republican party to awaken to new national problems born of war and depression, sailed yesterday on the Queen Mary declaring flatly that the Republican hopes in the coming election were marked for disaster if the convention nominated Governor Alf M. Landon of Kansas as the standard-bearer.

LONDON, June 5. -- Lloyd's underwriting agents, who, with equal nonchalance, will take a risk on a charity garden party being ruined by rain or the safety of a vessel like the Queen Mary, were warned today by their executive committee to refuse purely speculative contingency risks until they were satisfied that the assured has legitimate interests.

Warner Brothers announced yesterday that, like Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, it will finance no plays under the recently arrived at contract between the Dramatists Guild and the League of New York Theatres. In making the announcement, Jacob Wilk, the head of the story department at Warners, said that the decision would not affect the commitments already undertaken with regard to next season.

SHANGHAI, June 5. -- Although the reported penetration of Southern armies into Hunan Province is still denied, it becomes evident that military movements of prime importance and inspired by calculations based on the likelihood of conflict are being made by the Southerners.

Over the objections of Mayor La Guardia and Borough President Raymond V. Ingersoll of Brooklyn, the Board of Estimate went on record yesterday as disapproving submission of the proposed new city charter to the voters at the next general election.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP). -- Hopes of administration chieftains to avoid a wide-open fight this session over the selection of a new House floor leader to succeed Speaker Bankhead were blasted tonight when Representative Rankin of Mississippi said there would be a "spirited contest" and that he himself would be a candidate.

Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd will consecrate the rest of his days, with the exception of two years he set aside for further exploration, in work for international amity and in fostering the ideal of building "a fairer and better life for human beings," he revealed last night at a testimonial dinner at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria given in his honor by representatives of American industrial, professional, scientific, educational and cultural groups.

Prices of commodity futures were barely steady in yesterday's markets, where trading was fairly quiet. Gains were made by rubber and cocoa and heaviness was confined mostly to cottonseed oil and hides. In the cash markets cotton, lard, oats, butter, eggs, rubber and tins were stronger, while wheat, corn, rye, coffees and silk declined.

DETROIT, June 5. -- The Black Legion has raised a substantial defense fund for the legal protection of those of its members who are now facing prosecution on various charges, including murder, kidnapping and felonious assault, it was disclosed today.

SCARBOROUGH, N.Y., June 5. -- With customary good weather and a record-breaking attendance, those at the sixteenth annual field day of the Bond Club of New York saw the New York golf team win from the Philadelphia Bond Club team in the Morgan Cup match by a score of 5 to 4 at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club today.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 5. -- Another day of almost perfect rowing weather greeted the oarsmen in training for the intercollegiate regatta on June 22. A spotless sky with a hot sun smiled down on the broad stretches of the Hudson today along the famous course that wanders under the two bridges at the city and a mild breeze left the surface as undisturbed as a sheltered inland lake.

MILWAUKEE, June 5 (AP). -- Paced once more by Don Lash, who won the mile and two-mile runs, Indiana completed its conquest of midwestern track and field rivals tonight by rolling up 45 points to win the Central Intercollegiate Conference championships.

MOSCOW, June 5. -- Mr. Botwinnik, Soviet chess champion, defeated his countryman, V. Ragosin, in the seventeenth and semi-final round today, slightly reducing the lead of Jose R. Capablanca of Cuba in the international chess masters' tournament.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP). -- Warrants for the arrest of Representative Marion A. Zioncheck of Washington State and his bride, the former Miss Rubye Nix, were handed police today to be served as soon as he leaves Gallinger Hospital, where he is undergoing mental tests.

Exposure of fraudulent accident claims was expedited yesterday when the Board of Estimate voted a $50,000 appropriation to District attorney William C. Dodge for an investigation of these eases in New York County.

LONDON, June 5. -- Although trading on the London Stock Exchange was inactive again today the tendency of prices was generally much steadier. Comparatively little selling marked the operations, despite the last day account, but fresh buying was lacking pending Continental developments.
PARIS, June 5. -- American visitors at the Majestic Hotel and others where the employes are on strike are all anxious to report home that they are well and not uncomfortable.

The editorial page of THE TIMES makes frequent reference to the 100,000 protesting Democratic votes cast in recent primaries for Colonel Breckinridge. Would it not be in keeping with the spirit of fair play for which THE TIMES is justly famed to play up with equal prominence the millions of protesting Republican votes cast in recent primaries for Senator Borah?

Newton D. Baker, L.W. Douglas and Leo Wolman, in their letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES of June 2, reveal themselves as our Mahatma Gandhis. Whereas the Hindu sage would return from the machine to the spinning wheel, so these gentlemen would abandon mass production and large-scale enterprise to return to small competitive units.

I am sure THE TIMES shares my gratification that the unfortunate strike that could well have paralyzed the Port of New York has, at least temporarily, been settled. I think there are two lessons to be learned from what has occurred.

HAVERFORD, Pa., June 5. -- Robert M. Hutchinson of Narberth, a member of the graduating class of Haverford College, was announced tonight as winner of the Clementine Cope fellowship for graduate study at another institution.

A degree of Bachelor of Arts was awarded summa cum laude for the first time in the history of the College of the Sacred Heart, Manhattanville, yesterday afternoon, when Cardinal Hayes presided at the school's commencement exercises.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- Charges that a large number of the Navajo Indian tribe are in danger of "extermination" because "a dozen livestock barons" and Senator Chavez of New Mexico are holding up Senate action on the Navajo Boundary Bill, which would give the Navajos exclusive right to an additional 2,000,000 acres of New Mexico grazing land, were made today by John Collier, Indian Commissioner.

ROCHESTER, June 5. -- At the late afternoon conference session here today of the General Synod of the Reformed Church in America, a one-man stand "turned the tide" and was credited with saving North Western Academy and Junior College for that denomination, which founded it.
PARIS, June 5. -- France has probably never before faced a strike in which the issues have appeared as confused to the general public as in the one that tonight is approaching a general tie-up.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- Former President Wilson was praised in high terms today by the Senate Munitions Committee, whose chairman, Senator Nye, asserted in January that Mr. Wilson and Secretary Lansing had "falsified" in denying advance notice of secret treaties to distribute German territory after the World War.

The New York Towboat Exchange sought an investigation by army engineers yesterday of the navigation problems expected to develop from the proposed extension of Governors Island and the establishment there of a flying field.

TITO SCHIPA has been subjected to cruel and unusual punishment in Mexico. Arriving in that country for a concert tour, the distinguished Italian tenor has been put on the grill by the radical union of moving picture workers.

CLEVELAND, June 5. -- Governor Landon is continuing his apparently triumphal progress toward the Republican nomination for President, according to his managers, who asserted tonight that if assurances of shifts from uninstructed delegations are fulfilled he will be chosen on the first ballot. They estimated his strength at 520 on the opening vote.

Because tomorrow is Trinity Sunday, pastors will preach sermons on the theme, "The Three Persons in the Godhead: Father, Son and Holy Ghost." Today and tomorrow there will be ordinations of young men to the ministry. In denominational as well as in ritualistic churches there will be celebrations of the holy communion.

Over the protests of Mrs. W.K. Vanderbilt, Miss Anne Morgan and other property owners along the line of the East River Drive, the Board of Estimate voted yesterday to complete the drive between Fourteenth and Thirty-second Streets and from Forty-ninth to Fifty-fourth Street with a 20 per cent local assessment.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- An appointment today to membership on the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System was President Roosevelt's reward to Chester C. Davis for his long service as chief pilot of the Administration's Agricultural Adjustment program.

With Mayor LA GUARDIA acting the part of peacemaker, GEORGE HARVEY and VICTOR RIDDER have patched up their official differences, even though some personal differences apparently remain. They are both inclined to be explosive in their utterances, and that inevitably causes friction.

Only $13,346,373 of new municipal issues, representing fifty-nine communities, will come up for award next week through competitive bidding, compared with this week's revised total of $25,018,077. The weekly average for the year thus far is $24,617,404.
LONDON, June 5. -- Experiments here with the new drug commonly called prontosil, a German aniline compound, in cases of childbed fever have given exceptional results.

LONDON, June 5 (AP). -- America's Wightman Cup tennis team, which will meet the English for the international team trophy next Friday and Saturday, was completed today when Mrs. Dorothy Andrus of New York and Stamford, Conn., was chosen as the fifth member.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., June 5. -- The seventy-six remaining players in the national open golf championship are slated to play two rounds tomorrow. The first pair, Willie Hunter and Albert Huske are scheduled to start the third round at 8 A.M.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 5. -- Many hospitals in the United States are failing to meet the needs of all classes of persons, it was said here today by Dr. Francis Brown, Associate Professor of Sociology at New York University.

Plans for a vehicular tunnel from the Battery to Brooklyn, recently prepared by the Board of Transportation, were approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate and were sent to the New York City Tunnel Authority with a request for immediate construction.

Aggregate market value of bonds listed on the New York Stock Exchange declined in May from $41,524,856,027 to $39,648,252,468, due to the removal from the list of twenty-two issues of foreign governments for failure to register under the Securities Exchange Act.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- While John L. Lewis, chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization, was conferring with associates today on plans for an organization drive in the nation's principal steel centers within a month, William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, accused the C.I.O. of having "thwarted" plans prepared by the executive council of the federation for the unification of the entire labor movement behind the council's organization plan.
New bond financing this week amounted to $58,693,000, against $119,748,000 last week and $76.614,000 a year ago.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., June 5. -- Picking the winner of the fortieth national open golf championship in advance is a job for which it is difficult to qualify. But a good percentage of the 6,000 spectators who formed the galleries over sundrenched Baltusrol today took part in a little guessing game entitled, "Who will win tomorrow?"

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 5 (AP). -- The 489 members of the second, or junior, class were left at the Naval Academy tonight as the battleships Arkansas, Wyoming and Oklahoma, with 1,115 aboard, steamed down the Chesapeake Bay, headed for Europe.
I read with a great deal of interest your editorial "Levy on the Charter," and I agree with you that I sank my knife in the heart of the new charter and I believe the operation will be successful.
WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP). -- The Senators climbed back into the first division today by banging out thirteen hits for a 6-to-2 triumph over Detroit.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses and Grover A. Whalen, chairman of the World's Fair committee, received a setback in their plans for the Fair yesterday when Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx blocked the Board of Estimate's approval of a grading contract in Flushing Meadows, the Fair site.

A Murray Hill property that had been held in one ownership for forty years changed hands yesterday when Joseph L. Ennis Co., operators, purchased the four-story dwelling at 115 East Thirty-sixth Street, near Park Avenue. The property was sold by Brooks, Harvey Co., brokers, for Lawrence Turnure and Elizabeth Turnure Livermore, executors of the estate of George E. Turnure.

LEON BLUM'S Socialist and Radical Cabinet assumes power at a critical moment for France. Unless the epidemic of "siege" strikes -- intended primarily perhaps as a warning from the Left that the Premier would better not be too moderate -- soon spends itself, it may wreck the new Government before that has had a chance to develop its program.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- In a ceremony intimate as a neighborly call, yet fraught with pride of country, symbolized by massed banners of their homelands, country women from the four corners of the earth took formal farewell of each other at sundown today, after five crowded days of activity.
CHICAGO, June 5. -- Professional and public interest in the wheat market continues apathetic despite the pessimistic character of the crop comments from the American and Canadian Northwest.
Resales by operators of apartment houses in the Bronx to investors formed the bulk of realty deals in the borough yesterday.

GENEVA, June 5. -- Russia informed the international labor organization today that she is sending a worker-delegate to the annual conference which began here yesterday. Hitherto she has limited her delegation to one government delegate, Boris Markus.

Coney Island's contribution to the Long Island Tercentenary celebration was a parade on Surf Avenue last night depicting Brooklyn of the past, present and future. More than 400,000 persons watched the spectacle.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- The Senate passed late tonight its version of the proposed 1936 Revenue Act, designed to make up to the Treasury budget deficiencies caused by the payment this year, instead of in 1945, of the adjusted service compensation to veterans and by the invalidation of the Agricultural Adjustment Act and its processing taxes. The vote was 38 to 24.

The exchange off checks at the principal clearing houses of the country in May amounted to $24,701,993,365, a decline of 8.4 per cent from the preceding month and of 1 per cent from the turnover in May last year.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., June 5. -- Keeping to the early pace, the fun was fast and furious in the second round of the open golf championship over the Baltusrol course today. Vic Ghezzi was up with the lark, brushing with hasty steps the dew away to snare the birdies on the upland lawns. The big fellow, who looks like Max Adelbert Baer, had only one minor difficulty on his early whirl over the course.

MOSCOW, June 5. -- A special session of the All Union Congress of Soviets will be called to pass on the new Soviet Constitution, the Central Committee of the Communist party has decided. This will be the first special session ever called of the Congress, which technically is the supreme governing power of Soviet Russia and which normally meets every two years, following the nation-wide elections.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- Edward C. Johnson, trial examiner for the Securities and Exchange Commission in its hearing of charges that C.C. Wright of New York manipulated operations in stock of the Kinner Airplane and Motor Corporation, today clarified his ruling of yesterday as to testimony taken in preliminary inquiries by the commission's agents.

France continued to lose gold heavily yesterday as the Socialist Government of Premier Leon Blum took office amid a growing general strike movement. An additional $23,845,000 gold was engaged for shipment to this country, the largest single day's engagement for the movement thus far, while the pressure of the flight of capital from France to London continued to force up the price of the pound sterling.
WASHINGTON, June 5. -- Members of this year's graduating class at the Naval Academy were assigned to duty by the Navy Department today, with orders to report on or about June 28. The assignments are:

Seventeen girls and three men employed in the F. and W. Grand 5-10-and-25-cent store at 26 East Fourteenth Street, between Fifth Avenue and University Place, collapsed at their posts about 5:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon when they were overcome by sulphur dioxide fumes escaping from an ice cream cooling plant in the basement.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., June 5. -- Ch. Nix of Flenmar, a fine looking 5-year-old dog from ch. Utz V Haus Schutting-ch. Jessica of Hoheluft, owned by William Mengel of Mount Kisco, won the best of breed award in the specialty show held today by the Shepherd Dog Club of New England at Lawridge, the estate of Mrs. Robert Law.

A field of ten colts, including Brevity, beaten favorite in the Kentucky Derby and Withers, has been named for the $45,000 Belmont Stakes to he run this afternoon at Belmont Park before an expected crowd of 25,000 persons. The traditional mile-and-a-half test, which goes back to 1867, will be the high spot of the closing-day program, which is made up of seven races including three stake events.

SYRACUSE, June 5 (AP). -- The Remington-Rand Company announced tonight that the company's strike-closed plant here would "reopen on Monday" and that the company had "positions open for only 800 workers instead of the 1,800 workers formerly employed."

BOSTON, June 5 (AP). -- Boston humbled Chicago for the seventh consecutive time today, by an 8-6 margin, when the Sox of different hues opened a three-game series before a ladies' day crowd of 13,000 at Fenway Park.

BERLIN, June 5. -- The reaction on the Boerse was continued at the opening today, but gave way to some recovery near the close of the market. Losses of two to three points were frequent at the start, but final changes were small and some issues were able to register gains.
BERLIN, June 5. -- The National Socialist regime's drive against Catholic clergymen, friars and laymen accused of immorality produced several more severe sentences today.

The May grand jury was dismissed unexpectedly yesterday by Judge Franklin Taylor in the Kings County Court for disobeying the court's instructions and taking testimony from potential defendants in the investigation of a case of alleged police brutality.

PARIS, June 5 (AP). -- A single labor union of 1,250,000 men and women, united after a fourteen-year split, dealt tonight with the new Leftist government of strike-torn France. Fear of the spread of fascism and growing opposition to former Premier Pierre Laval's decree laws, cutting wages and pensions, labor chiefs said, brought the conservative General Federation of Labor and the radical United General Confederation of Labor to end their differences and unite.
TRENTON, N.J., June 5. -- Twenty-five auditors were hurriedly assigned today under orders from Governor Harold G. Hoffman to examine the books of the New Jersey State police.
CHESHIRE, Conn., June 5. -- Graduation exercises of the Roxbury School were held this afternoon in historic St. Peter's Church, scene of important events in American church history.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- A list of fifteen corporations to which the Securities and Exchange Commission has granted confidential treatment of certain data filed under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 in registering their securities on the Exchanges was made public today by the commission.

TUXEDO PARIS, N.Y., June 5. -- With sparkling performances by Woodfellow, capable timber topper owned by the Wynfromere Farm of Green's Farms, Conn., and shown by Miss Helen Bedford, leading the way to an array of talented hunters, the annual Tuxedo horse show opened in the spacious ring at Tuxedo Park today.

VIENIA, June 5. -- "We are ready to cooperate with all Austrians, regardless of their political past, in the work of building up a free independent nation on the sole condition that their eyes shall turn neither to Berlin nor to Moscow, but shall remain fixed on Vienna," declared Vice Chancellor Edouard Baar-Baarenfels at an Anglo-American Press Association luncheon today.
SPRINGFIELD, N.J., June 5. -- The end came today for Sam Parks Jr., who surprised the golf world a year ago when he emerged from oblivion to win the United States open championship at Oakmont.

CLEVELAND, June 5 (AP). -- William B. Woods, special master, submitted to the Federal Court today a plan for reorganization under Section 77b of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, of the Van Sweringen Company. This concern developed Shaker Heights, an exclusive local residential suburb.

ALBANY, June 5. -- Governor Lehman signed today the bill of Senator Nunan, Queens Democrat, creating a temporary State commission of eighteen members to cooperate with New York City in establishing the 1939 World's Fair.

PHILADELPHIA, June 5. -- Predicting that the Democratic National Convention, starting here June 23, would attract the largest crowd in the history of American political conventions, W. Forbes Morgan, secretary of the Democratic National Committee, arrived today to take personal charge of arrangements.

CLEVELAND, June 5. -- Herbert Hoover will appear on Wednesday evening before the Republican National Convention, which will hold its opening session here on Tuesday. The titular leader of his party will discuss issues of the coming campaign to the exclusion of any discussion of candidates.

Political reporters already swarming at Cleveland speak of the "drive to stop LANDON." On examination it would seem that rather unruly horses are to be hitched together for that drive. Others refer to the hope of some delegates and Republican leaders that a deadlock may be brought about in the national convention.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -The power program of the Public Works Administration with its policy of lending and granting funds to municipalities for the construction of municipally owned lighting plants, was upheld by Chief Justice Alfred A. Wheat in District of Columbia Supreme Court today.

Stocks moved indecisively yesterday as the news of the day, although abundant, answered none of the questions that are perplexing followers of the markets. With Congress to recess for one week, the matter of Federal taxation that is causing so much uncertainty, marketwise, must wait.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 5. -- Playing over her home links in the annual invitation tournament of the Westchester Hills Golf Club, Mrs. Emmet F. Whalen today scored a brilliant 85 to capture the low-gross prize in a field of 101 starters.

LONDON, June 5. -- Sir Samuel Hoare is back in the British Cabinet. It was announced tonight that "the King has been pleased to appoint" the former Foreign Secretary to be First Lord of the Admiralty in place of Viscount Mon-sell of Evesham, who resigned.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals reserved decision yesterday on an appeal taken against a lower court ruling that German corporations must meet their bond obligations here, despite Reich monetary moratorium legislation. The litigation will affect $886,945,810 German bonds held by Americans, almost all of which are in default.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 5. -- New Jersey College for Women will confer degrees on 226 seniors tomorrow morning at the college's fifteenth annual commencement. Candidates will be presented by Dean Margaret T. Corwin, and Dr. Robert C. Clothier, president of Rutgers University, will confer the degrees.
Lou Gehrig celebrated his 1,700th consecutive game in a matchless career yesterday at the Stadium as the Yankees opened a three-game series against the Indians.

Up the gangplank of the new Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary, well in advance of sailing time, strode members of the Kent School crew yesterday morning, bound for Henley-on-Thames, England, where they will seek the Thames Challenge Cup during the first few days of July.

The 150th anniversary of the New York Luthern Ministerium, which seven years ago merged with two other Lutheran bodies covering the same territory into a new organization -- the United Lutheran Synod of New York -- will be formally ob- served next week.

PITTSBURGH, June 5. -- Reports on developments in the technical fields of the oil and gas industries, committee reports and election of officers closed today the annual two-day meeting of the eastern district of the division of production, American Petroleum Institute, in the William Penn Hotel here.

Here to lecture on liberation and restoration of world trade, Wilfred Hill, a vice president of the Comite International des Eschanges of Paris, an organization of Europeans interested in perfecting a means of international exchange, yesterday urged that close thought be given in this country to the Milhaud plan of international purchase checks, devised by Professor Milhaud, political economist of Geneva University.

Here to lecture on liberation and restoration of world trade, Wilfred Hill, a vice president of the Comite International des Eschanges of Paris, an organization of Europeans interested in perfecting a means of international exchange, yesterday urged that close thought be given in this country to the Milhaud plan of international purchase checks, devised by Professor Milhaud, political economist of Geneva University.

PARIS, Saturday, June 6. -- With nearly 1,000,000 workers on strike, half of them in the Paris district, Premier Leon Blum and his government, backed by the leaders of the French Labor Confederation, continued early today to try to get in front of the strike and lead it instead of being dragged along in its wake.

Scribners have just acquired the original manuscript of Mozart's Haffner symphony, an oblong folio of sixty pages that was one of the more valuable items in the library of King Ludwig II of Bavaria. This symphony was written by Mozart at the request of his father and the superscription is in Leopold Mozart's hand.

Evidence was laid before the New York County grand jury yesterday of an alleged racket through which eight concerns in this city profited in the last three years to the extent of several million dollars in a country-wide sale of spurious automobile parts.

MADRID, June 5 (AP). -- Strikes, fighting and rumors of a monarchist revolt shook a harassed Leftist government tonight in Spain. Despite the government's outlawing of strikes as a labor weapon, industry in many parts of the country remained paralyzed.

Business in the bond market yesterday was dull and the price swings were narrow, a condition that might have been accounted for, in park, by most of the bondmen of the community being at the annual outing of the Bond Club. Transactions on the Stock Exchange amounted to $8,045,800, compared with $10,818,500 on Thursday, the dealings in United States Government issues being limited to $271,800, against $1,369,500 the preceding day.
Lou Gehrig celebrated his 1,700th consecutive game in a matchless career yesterday at the Stadium as the Yankees opened a three-game series against the Indians.

ETHEL BOILEAU is a graceful romancer, as many readers have already learned to their pleasure. She has given us in the past a number of excellent tales -- some of them, like this one, agreeably filled with the swing of kilts and the skirl of bagpipes, with peat smoke and heather, grouse shooting and deer stalking, with snatches of rich Gaelic speech and the stirring ballads of the Highlands.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- Confronted by the Supreme Court's decision in the New York State Minimum Wage Law for women and children, organized labor finds itself in a quandary. To be for a constitutional amendment or not to be for one -- that seems to be the question.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., June 6. -- The only way to get a real look at the golfing parade was to perch under a noble maple tree and watch the pursuers of the open championship pass a given point. The observation post commanded a view of the fourth fairway and green and the tee and green of the short fifteenth hole beyond. From this point an onlooker could catch the players coming and going.

Developments of great import appear to be impending in the Far East. Chinese public opinion is growing more insistent in its demand for resistance to Japanese encroachments in the North. Canton's manifesto of last Wednesday, conveniently interpreted by the Japanese as a threat of civil war, was a call to Nanking for united action against Japan.

A NEW horizon of elegance has been opened to the modern male with the advent of the 1936 Summer evening wear. For a moderate sum it is possible for a man to be turned out after 6 o'clock correctly, romantically and smartly. The new white dinner jackets may be had in tropical-weight worsteds and in linens and Palm Beaches.

THE little known Mormon War of 1857 and the Mountain Meadows Massacre form the background of this newest tale from the indefatigable pen of Colonel Rodney. Dr. Charles Blake, having amassed a fortune of $100,000 in California, sends the gold East to St. Louis, and shortly thereafter starts eastward himself on the Overland Stage.

VIRGINIA'S newest playground, about 3,000 acres of beautiful, rugged beachland, embracing areas of shifting dunes and dense forests, as well as a mile and a half of beachfront on the Atlantic Ocean near Cape Henry, will be formally opened on June 15.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 6. -- James Simpson's chestnut gelding, Gifted, ridden beautifully by Earl Jensen, won the principal event today at the seventh annual race meeting of the Farmington Valley Polo Association.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., June 6. -- Bishop William T. Manning advised members of the Young Peoples Fellowship of the Episcopal Archdeaconry of Westchester today to participate in all sorts of church activities because they are the proper foundation for the leadership in church affairs which will be theirs when older people relinquish their duties.

A good crop of "green" manure turned under the soil supplies humus equivalent to a heavy dressing of stable manure. This method of soil enrichment has been practiced by farmers for centuries, but home gardeners seldom utilize it.
WASHINGTON, June 6. -- Senator Borah spoke strongly today against adoption by the convention of a plank calling for return to the gold standard.
PARIS, June 6. -- Following is the text of the Ministerial declaration read by Premier Leon Blum to the Chamber of Deputies and by Vice Premier Edouard Daladier to the Senate:

IN spite of John Heywood, who sang "A happy man's without a shirt," the Spring and Summer landscape will be filled with happy men whose gayety will be enhanced rather than diminished by the gay colorings of their shirts. And these shirts will rest lightly on the shoulders of their wearers.

HAS American literature had a square deal in Great Britain? This hackneyed question has been discussed afresh by Professor Edwin Mims in a critical but friendly address delivered to the English-Speaking Union and published in its monthly organ, The Landmark.

George Emmons, president, and Paul C. Gaylord, vice president of the Raritan Bay Yacht Racing Association, are proceeding with plans to hold a race for power cruisers around Staten Island, probably on July 26. They recently discussed details with Wilbur F. Crook, chairman of the A.P.B.A. board of directors for this region, and with his son, Melvin Crook, whose Betty V was the fastest single-motored speed boat in America last season.

The drinking, as distinguished from the drunken, driver was characterized as "a major traffic menace" in a statement issued yesterday by Alfred Reeves, vice president and general manager of the Automobile Manufacturers Association.

THIS is a kind of literary scrapbook, with the faults and virtues of any scrapbook. It presents materials, organized in some sort of fashion, not to be found in book form; at any rate, not in any one book. They belong to the genre known as "literary curiosities"; they are brief and scrappy, they tantalize, they whet the appetite, but they do not satisfy.

THE Canadian West, popular for years with the American tourist, has an unusually large number of attractions for the visitor this year. Recently John Murray Gibbon, secretary of the Trail Riders of the Canadian Rockies, announced that the annual five-day ride on sure-footed mountain horses would start at Mount Edith Pass, near Banff, July 31, ending at Hillsdale Aug. 4.

The trend of crude oil production in the United States, which for the first the is more than 3,000,000 barrels daily, or about 350,000 more a day than a year ago, does not inspire confidence in the maintenance of the price of crude oil, according to executives of leading companies.

THIS little book is the life story of an Irishwoman whose parents died of starvation during the famine of the Forties, and who came to America in the steerage of a sailing ship at the age of 15. Catherine Loftus (Katteen called her) was born to the desperate hardship and hunger of the Irish village life of a century ago, and she was 90 when she died.

The popular season at the Metropolitan terminated last night with the presentation of a triple bill consisting of "Cavalleria Rusticana," "Pagliacci" and the ballet, "The Bat." This triad of offerings was so alluring to the patrons, that the house was sold out, long before the rise of the first curtain.

The last of three actions of the Federal Government directed against the Norwegian freighter Reidun, which was seized in this port on March 17 as a supply ship for rum runners, has been dismissed by United States District Judge Marcus B. Campbell, it was announced yesterday.

Bonds moved within a narrow trading range yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange in a typically dull week-end session. With the market generally lacking any signs of leadership, prices in most of the major groups drifted to slightly lower levels.

A woman was killed and five persons, including two firemen, were injured in a fire that started at 1 o'clock this morning in two three-story wooden frame houses at 1,131 and 1,138 Tinton Avenue, the Bronx.

THERE is no stately temple in Washington dedicated to the men who made the United States Navy. Nevertheless, the navy has its hall of fame -- a windy Valhalla, arching the seven seas. Wherever one of our destroyers pokes its sharp nose into a pink and azure Mediterranean port or pushes up the yellow flood of a Chinese river it proclaims the name of some American naval hero.

EASTPORT, Me., June 5. -- Despite the adverse 39 to 28 vote of the Senate on Saturday, in turning down the $36,000,000 Federal tide-harnessing development of Passamaquoddy Bay, Maine proponents of the work-relief project are still looking to the heavens for a Presidential manna to finance further construction.
PARIS, June 6 (AP). -- Bitter opposition is in store for the 40-hour work week which Premier Leon Blum's Leftist government would give the workers of France.

MANILA. -- The ultimate disposition of the famous Culion leper colony bids fair to become a major political issue. Manuel Quezon, President of the Philippine Commonwealth, has said: "As far as I am concerned, Culion is ended. It should be closed."

BOSTON, June 6. -- The homerun slugging of Zeke Bonura and Tony Piet availed the White Sox little today when they dropped their eighth straight game to the Red Sox, 10 -- 6, before a crowd of 16,000. It was the Boston's fifth victory in a row.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- A slight decline in business activity in the week ended on May 30 was attributed today by the Department of Commerce to seasonal influences, particularly the Memorial Day holiday.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 6. -- The annual shooting of the rifle and pistol matches of the New York State National Guard and Naval Militia began here at Camp Smith today with the running off of three pistol matches.

OGDEN, Utah, June 6. -- A vigorous declaration that the States should receive authority, by constitutional amendment if necessary, to regulate both the hours and wages of women workers was voiced by former President Herbert Hoover as he paused here between trains tonight en route to the Republican National Convention at Cleveland.

The first two chapters of this book record three sudden deaths, one of which is obviously a murder. Dan Hurley, editor of the local newspaper, believes that all three deaths are connected and that all three are murders. Working together with Inspector Osgood of the Elmhurst Police Department, he sets out to discover the motive and the person responsible for the killings.

Giving effect to recent large-scale refinancing, the volume of bonds called last week for redemption before maturity increased sharply. The calls included a wide selection of issues, with those for public utility companies predominating.

IT has been the custom for a number of years to present here at this time an itemized record of the season's activities in order that the growth of interest in the dance and the directions of its various developments might be made apparent on a basis of comparison with the specific records of other seasons.

The use of dinitrophenol, a drug used to bring about reduction in weight, and the inhalation of napthalene given off by ordinary moth balls, were described to the American Eugenics Association yesterday as causing congenital deformities.

RIO DE JANEIRO. -- The Pan-American peace conference soon to meet in Buenos Aires, on the initiative of President Roosevelt, may settle for Latin Americans the old dispute about the Monroe Doctrine. Interpreted in many different ways, the doctrine enunciated by President Monroe in 1823 has often served in the past as the target for attacks on so-called Yankee imperialism.

Here, there and everywhere the growing public demand for municipal or State-owned yacht basins has brought about some unique developments of all sorts, shapes, sizes and varied conveniences. But for a good many boating seasons to come the extraordinary anchorage at Zachs Bay will continue to hold fascinations, if not world's records.

ROBBED: While District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan of Brooklyn was presenting evidence last week before the grand jury, a thief entered the yard of his Flatbush home and took from the clothes line three business suits and a suit of evening clothes. The District Attorney, who imports his fabrics from Ireland, estimated the loss at $500.

STROUDSBURG, Pa. -- The next two weeks will be filled with interesting events in the Pocono Mountain playgrounds of Pennsylvania. The Shawnee open golf tournament will be revived tomorrow and Tuesday, after a lapse of five years, and many of the nation's leading golfers, including Lawson Little, Willie MacFarlane, Johnny Farrell and Harry Cooper, will compete.

On April 26 and May 3 France went to the polls. When the votes had been counted the Popular Front, made up of Communists, Socialists and Radical Socialists, had won a great victory. Leon Blum's Socialist party had become the strongest single group in the French Chamber.

THERE was a day when the showmen of radio thought they had to surrender the Summer microphone to dance bands, because they believed the listeners favored "music of a lighter vein." But that theory has changed. The radio people have discovered that warm weather does not necessarily mean the public has put the love for good music away with the furs and overcoats.

CLEVELAND, June 6. -- All the facilities at its command are being mustered by the National League of Women Voters for its appeal to the platform committee of the Republican party for a plank pledging enforcement of the merit system in civil service Headquarters will be opened here tomorrow, where a special rally luncheon on the topic is set for Monday.

CHICAGO, June 6 (AP). -- Dogaway, 2-year-old colt by Bull Dog -- Runaway Lass, galloped to an easy victory in the tenth running of the $5,000 Hawthorne Juvenile Handicap before 18,000 spectators today.

A department in the State government to deal with marriage and domestic relations was proposed yesterday at the closing session of the first New York State Conference on Marriage and the Family in the Hotel Roosevelt.

NASHVILLE, June 6. -- The body of Speaker Joseph W. Byrns, who died suddenly in Washington Thursday morning, was laid in a vault in Mount Olivet Cemetery this afternoon while President Roosevelt, Postmaster General Farley, Secretary of State Hull and about ninety members of Congress stood uncovered in front of the small stone structure.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., June 6. -- Racing from behind to set a new world's record for a major seventy-two-hole title tournament, Tony Manero, slightly built former Westchester caddie, today won the United States open championship in a manner that gave one of the largest galleries of all time a thrill such as few golfing crowds have experienced in the forty-year history of the event.

Popeye the Sailor, an Indian in full regalia; Little Miss Muffet, the King of Hearts and assorted fairy princesses and cupids strutted proudly before the judges' stand in Fort Tryon playground at Broadway and 200th Street yesterday morning.

A race-track handyman who served on three Kings County grand juries during periods of unemployment furnished the jury in the Drukman conspiracy trial yesterday with such tangled, yet revealing, accounts of his jury experiences that he was committed to jail in $10,000 bail.

i EAST HAMPTON. L. I., June 6. I -- One of the events of the early sea!son here will be the annual Iris !and Peony Show, being held by the Garden Club of East Hampton at historic Clinton Academy on June 16. Mrs. Ellery S. James is president of the Garden Club, Mrs. Elwood Hendrick the vice president, Mrs. James A. Edwards secretary and Mrs. Juan Terry Trippe the treasurer.

Although this book was written especially for the boys and girls of Detroit, the history of a city whose streets have known such colorful and dissimilar figures as La Salle, the Sieur de Cadillac. Daniel Boone, Chief Pontiac, John Brown and Thomas Edison is bound to hold the attention of the young reader who is interested in the American epic.

FROM most sections of the country trade reports continued last week to be most cheerful. The Pacific Coast described a slower movement and in some parts of the South drought has reduced activities. In other areas the gains ran up to 30 per cent.

HAVERFORD, Pa., June 6. -- An appeal for this country "to get morality back where it belongs as the first essential of education" was made by Dr. William W. Comfort, president of Haverford College, at the institution's commencement exercises today.
OKLAHOMA CITY, June 6. -- Twisters, floods, lightning, hail and torrential rains left nine persons dead in Oklahoma and Kansas today and caused widespread property damage and suffering.

THIS book, by the distinguished surgeon and scientist, George Lindsay Johnson, although likely to be scoffed at by some, is certain to bring comfort and support to many more. Throughout the ages the problem of immortality has occupied the mind of man.

A HEROIC chapter in the history of the Ohio Valley will be commemorated here next week-end, with President Roosevelt as the expected guest of honor, when the memorial to George Rogers Clark and the frontiersmen who marched with him to save the old Northwest from British domination will be officially dedicated.
OREGON, Ill., June 6. -- Frank O. Lowden, "the sage of Sinnissippi," was a silent and unknown quantity tonight in the Republican pre-convention deliberations over Presidential candidates.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., June 6. -- Scooting along at times and lying breathless at others, ninety-six craft competed today in the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club's sixty-fourth annual regatta, which was the fourth championship event of the Yacht Racing Association this season.

LONDON. -- After a succession of blunders and bad luck which would have shaken most Prime Ministers out of office, Mr. Baldwin is secure in his position once more. The change in his fortunes has worked wonders in him since the time, not many weeks ago, when he had the manner of a harassed and beaten man.

WITH frames or specially prepared seed-beds emptied of seedling plants that have been transferred to garden beds and borders, there is now an opportunity to start a batch of perennials. Some of the new varieties, not yet generally available or still rather high in price, are desirable subjects, as packet of seed will yield a generous number of plants.

TRENTON, N.J., June 5. -- With the Legislature not due to meet until June 15, the hullabaloo surrounding the naming of Colonel Mark O. Kimberling to replace Colonel H. Norman Schwarzkopf as Superintendent of State Police, is fast subsiding. Interest now centers on the possibilities of Republican leaders gathering two or more Democratic Senators' votes to insure confirmation.
Education, which has been one of the dead spots of past international expositions, will be a dramatic, living exhibit at the World's Fair here in 1939 if currently suggested plans are approved.
NEWARK, N.J., June 6. -- The Newark Bears dropped the first series of their home stay today when Rochester captured the third and deciding game, 8 to 3.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 6. -- Flashing high-calibre team-work throughout the match, the Aknusti quartet won the opener of the Third Westbury Challenge Cup polo tournament at the Meadow Brook Club today, conquering Old Westbury to the tune of 6 to 4.
The weather during the national conventions is likely to be merciless to both parties, according to a long-range prediction by Henry Helm Clayton, meteorologist, which was made public today.

PARIS, June 5. -- Few legislatures and few governments, even in France, have, in recent times at least, come into office in the midst of such difficulties as beset Premier Leon Blum and his colleagues.

SINCE the passage of the Social Security Act in August, 1935, at least three good books have appeared discussing its implications. One of these is the short, simple volume by Eveline M. Burns, "Toward Social Security," reviewed in these columns not many weeks ago.

ANEW lightship, No. 112, will take up its station about July 1 off the Nantucket Shoals, south of Cape Cod, where, on May 15, 1934, its predecessor was rammed and sent to the bottom by the liner Olympic. This station, on the main route to Europe, is rated the most important lightship station in the world, and certainly none is better known to travelers.

Long Island concluded its official eight-day tercentenary program last night with a dinner at the Hotel St. George in Brooklyn that was attended by more than 1,500 persons, including Governor Herbert H. Lehman, Governor Theodore F. Green of Rhode Island, leaders of the bench and bar and persons prominent in civic and national life.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., June 6. -- Standing out strikingly in his immaculate white coat against the greensward of the polo field of the estate of Mrs. Robert Law, Champion Nunsoe Duc de la Terrace of Blakeen this evening was paraded by his owner, Mrs. Sherman R. Hoyt of Katonah, N.Y., to capture the highest honors of the seventh annual Greenwich Kennel Club all-breed show.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., June 6. -- Degrees of Bachelor of Physical Education were conferred on thirty-seven candidates at the nineteenth annual commencement exercises at Panzer College here this morning. Miss Frances Kimball of Nutley received the Tucker Jones Medal, denoting the highest professional excellence of the class.

BY assembling another volume of his thoughts and observations W.B. Yeats reminds his readers that there are giants walking the earth this day. Not very many, perhaps, for there have never been many at any one time, but Mr. Yeats ranks with those who have had integrity and genius.

Retail business continued at a good level last week, although activity in the wholesale markets here slowed down, due to ample store stocks, according to a report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers.

PERHAPS never has safety been the subject of engineering discussion as much as it was at the annual Summer meeting of the Society of Automotive Engineers, which ended here Friday. The 400 members who attended from all parts of the country centered their attention upon the reduction of the highway accident toll, and particularly upon ways and means whereby they, as designers and developers of automobiles, can aid in the campaign.

Representatives of several architectural societies and welfare agencies announced yesterday that they would oppose some of the recommendations made by the Charter Revision Commission concerning the handling of housing and construction work in the city.

PARIS, June 6. -- By the enormous majority of 384 to 210 the new Chamber of Deputies this evening voted confidence in Premier Leon Blum's Cabinet to carry through the program of reforms for which the country voted when it returned the Popular Front to power a month ago.
PARIS, June 6. -- Paris continues to look and behave astonishingly normally, despite the fact that more than half of its working population is on strike and the strike fever is mounting everywhere.

THE seventh Writers Conference in the Rocky Mountains will be held at the University of Colorado, Boulder, Col., during the three weeks beginning July 27, under the direction of Edward Davison, poet and critic.

VAUGHAN Williams's first operetta, "The Poisoned Kiss," with libretto by Evelyn Sharp, was enthusiastically hailed by the London press upon its recent premiere at the Arts Theatre, Cambridge, England. Williams has not been any too critical in his choice of a book, according to the reviewers.
ROME, June 6 (AP). -- Duce and Emperor tomorrow will welcome their African conqueror and picked thousands of his veterans in a victory celebration recalling the glories of ancient Rome.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) -- In a final report on the Federal Emergency Relief Administration, Harry L. Hopkins said today that relief activities cost the Federal Government nearly $300,000,000 more in 1935 than in 1934.

The development of the city's uptown marine terminal, centered about the three 1,100-foot piers of the Hapag Lloyd, French and Italian Lines and limited roughly by Forty-second and Fifty-fifth Streets, has created a commercial neighborhood of its own.

The vise-like grip that New Utrecht High School has held on the city P.S.A.L. senior outdoor track and field championship for the past twelve years was broken yesterday at the General George W. Wingate Field in Brooklyn, where the Green and White could do no better than finish fifth in the thirty-third annual meet.

CLEVELAND, June 6. -- Now that the Republican National Committee, after three days of hearing and deciding contests for seats in the Republican National Convention, has completed its work of making up the temporary roll for next week's big meeting, party men throughout the country are awaiting the reaction among Negroes in the North from decisions affecting Negro delegations from the South.

Dr. Charles Gordon Heyd, acting president of the American Medical Association, gave the commencement address to the seventy-seven graduates of the First Institute of Podiatry at the exercises last night at Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street. Dr. Heyd praised the members of the faculty and stressed the importance of podiatry in the field of medicine.

WEST POINT, June 6. -- The modern pentathlon Olympic tryouts continued today and Lieutenant Charles Leonard took a firm grip on first place by placing second in the 4,000-meter cross-country run and third in the 25-meter pistol shooting contest.

SCOTCH PLAINS, N.J., June 6. -- The bruised body of Elise Arnold, 5-year-old daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clayton Arnold, was found here early this morning hidden under a haymow in the barn of Raymond Somelock, her father's employer. The police believed that the child had been run down and killed by a truck and that the driver then hid the body.

President BENJAMIN HARRISON gently remonstrated with a civil service commissioner named THEODORE ROOSEVELT for wanting to bring on a political millennium overnight. Blessings or miracles of that kind in our public life cannot be hastened. They have to be worked for and waited for during many years.

BEATRICE WHITE'S standing as a scholarly historian of the Tudor period was established by her biography "Mary Tudor," a work in which the character portraits, built up from accumulated evidence, were integrated by intuition and an individual viewpoint. In this presentation of another Mary Tudor, sister of Henry VIII, she has thrown off the shackles forced on conscientious historians by adherence solely to certified fact and has allowed her imagination the scope granted by fiction.
BALTIMORE, June 6 (AP). -- Montreal closed its series with Baltimore today by winning, 12 to 9, for its only victory.
THE TIMES editorial "Progress and Jobs" is almost a crown upon the storm of abuse called forth by Mr. Roosevelt's speech of April 26.

MUCH careful and quiet study is being given these days to the question of catapulting aircraft as a regular take-off practice. Engine manufacturers, transport operators and those interested in the safety of operations on the airways are especially interested in this development.

LONDON, June 5. -- The Ascot race meeting will open on June 16. For four days the loveliest gowns of the Summer season will be seen in the royal enclosure and on the green lawns. In the absence of King Edward and Queen Mary, the picturesque semi-state procession along the course will be abandoned.

Mr. JOHN R. TUNIS gives in Scribner's the results of his patient study of the biographies of 500 members of the Harvard class of 1911, written for its twenty-fifth anniversary.
