As in similar records of most colleges, the majority have gone into business. The present-day college might almost be called a preparatory school for business.

A REPORT that cannibalism has broken out in the Fiji Islands causes the authorities to send a hurry call to Bertram Lynch, sleuth extraordinary. Lynch, in turn, sends for his faithful stooge, Robert Deane, a teacher of medieval history, who is constitutionally unable to resist the lure of a man hunt.

PHILADELPHIA, June 6. -- Lindenhurst, the estate of Mrs. Henry W. Breyer near Jenkintown, reverted today to scenes of 225 years ago for the June fete given annually for the benefit of the Abington Memorial Hospital.

During the first quarter of this year, 3,874 German Jews were helped to migrate from their homes by service agencies supported by the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, according to statistics made public yesterday by Joseph C. Hyman, secretary of the organization.

PERFECTLY imitating -- though perhaps unintentionally -- an early Beadle Novel issue, this quaint tale recounts the adventures which befall an Ohio pioneer family after they have started westward in the first half of the nineteenth century.

PARIS. WHEN Paris couturiers want to change a style boundary they begin paving the way seasons ahead, long before the new silhouette bursts into the fashion headlines. A few transitional models appear in each successive collection, gradually accustoming our eyes to the novel line.

WINSTON CHURCHILL may prove to have been right in saying recently that within the life of the present British Parliament -- that is, within about four years -- Europe would either find a new equilibrium or explode in another war. The almost universal pessimism among informed people was well expressed by Professor Arnold J. Toynbee, who has commented upon the Italian use of poison gas in Ethiopia by saying:

LARCHMONT, N. Y., June 6. -- Representatives of the New York, Westchester Boston Railway Company and officials of Westchester communities served by the line are preparing to confer soon on plans to prevent abandonment of the service, it was disclosed today.

BUCHAREST, June 6. -- President Eduard Benes of Czechoslovakia and Prince Paul, Chief Regent of Yugoslavia, arrived here this morning to take part in tomorrow's political conference, the first meeting of the heads of the Little Entente States ever held.

The drain of gold from France continued unabated yesterday as the new Socialist Premier, Leon Blum, announced his program and began putting into effect financial reforms by removing Jean Tannery from the governorship of the Bank of France and installing Emile Labeyre in his place.

Stated baldly, the stock market drifted lower during the week just completed, in the slowest trading since the week ended on April 6, 1935. But when it is considered that the immediate outlook is fraught with so many uncertainties, foreign and domestic, bearing on the markets, the view may be taken that stock prices have remained reassuringly firm.

PLANS recently completed in Washington for Federal buildings, big and little, all over the country, represent a new deal in public architecture which may mean much. The Treasury Department is architect-in-chief of the whole lot, instead of merely overseer and paymaster of many jobs scattered among private architects.

Experimentation is the very essence of science. Even the astrophysicists whose lifework it is to tell us how remote stars are constituted cannot dispense with it. They create in terrestrial laboratories the conditions that probably prevail in the sun and on the planets, and make the necessary inferences.

All last week crowds of New Yorkers converged at the west end of Fiftieth Street, where the liner Queen Mary, after her first transatlantic trip, was berthed at the 1,100-foot pier built especially for her and Completed just in time for her arrival on Monday.

PITTSBURGH, June 6 (AP). -- The Phillies drove Big Jim Weaver from the mound today with a four-run assault in the first inning and scored a 5-1 victory over Pittsburgh behind Orville Jorgens's four-hit pitching.

A special committee of five or more members of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York will be appointed by Winthrop W. Aldrich, president, to study and recommend plans to speed up the settlement of certiorari proceedings in tax-assessment cases and relieve what is termed the "appalling congestion" of these suits in the courts.

Anticipating the resumption of extra-curricular activities in the Fall term, the Student Council of Hunter College and its affiliated organizations have elected officers to serve during the coming academic year.

BRINGING together all of Thomas Mann's shorter fiction in one volume is an event of some importance. In this age of so many omni buses, it might well have been done earlier. At any rate, here is more than a sound tribute to one of the most distinguished of living writers; here also is our first opportunity to encounter in English a half dozen of Mann's fictional writings.

THE spas perennially attract many travelers to Europe. With their medicinal waters, gay casinos and other Continental features, they offer an amusing interlude to any journey. The fun-lover as well as the rheumatic is found at the well-known health springs of Germany, Hungary, Czechoslovakia and the Balkan States.

Banking on the belief that the Robinson-Patman anti-price discrimination bill will be lost in the final rush for adjournment of Congress, food and drug interests here, however, were prepared to strongly contest by court action the constitutionality of the measure if it should be adopted at this session.

LONDON, June 6. -- The American polo team had to produce everything it knew at Roehampton today to win the last trial game before the Westchester Cup series, eventually beating three fellow countrymen, Elbridge T. Gerry, James P. Mills and Cecil Smith, and the Australian, Bob Ashton, 9 to 6, after being held in check for four periods.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 6. -- The first week's training on the scene of action for the intercollegiate regatta of 1936, which will see a flotilla of eighteen crews race down the Hudson in the three contests, ended tonight.

NAPANOCH, N.Y., June 6. -- Max Schmeling never looked more impressive in training than in his thirteenth workout today in preparation for the Joe Louis encounter. A crowd of 500 saw the German in action.

Industry by its own actions is encouraging the development of NRA practices it assailed when the Recovery Act was in force, George A. Renard, secretary-treasurer of the National Association of Purchasing Agents, said yesterday in attacking the recent growth of reciprocal buying among industrial establishments.

With some 186,000 veterans' bonus bonds, representing a value of about $110,000,000, on hand from the Federal Reserve Bank, Postmaster Albert Goldman outlined yesterday afternoon details of the active part the local postoffice will play in the distribution of checks to the ex-soldiers.

THE TIMES Manila dispatch contained an interview with General MacArthur, President Quezon's military adviser, that gives interesting details of the defense plans calculated, the General says, to make the Philippine Islands "invasion proof" at the end of ten years.

CLEVELAND, June 6. -- Upon the eve of the convening of the Republican National Convention it is evident that the Landon candidacy has gathered what seems to be irresistible momentum in an atmosphere of grave doubt as to the party's chances in the Fall and of realization that the Republicans now face a turning point in their history.
CHARLOTTE, N.C., June 6 (AP). -- Clyde R. Hoey strengthened his hold on first place in the four-way Governor's race as returns were compiled tonight from today's Democratic primary.

THIS is an era of great ships. Surely there is in all the world no marvel so intriguing as a modern steamship, crystallizing in one great achievement, as does the new Queen Mary, the widest knowledge and the deepest wisdom of a nation's marine experts and engineers.
OMAHA, June 5. -- Before the State primary this week, Iowans were expecting that it might furnish a pretty important test of the standing of the New Deal.

CLEVELAND, June 6. -- It may or may not have been an omen of their future role in the Republican convention picture, but the fact remains that more women than men answered roll-call this morning at the meeting of the preliminary platform committee.

FOLKWAYS, those racial customs that survive time and migrations, are held to tenaciously in rural neighborhoods. The natives of Smithtown, L.I., still give newlywed couples a mock serenade to mark their introduction into the community as man and wife.

PARIS, June 6. -- The first move to break the grip that the Popular Front has charged has been maintained on French economic life by the Bank of France was made by the Blum Cabinet in council today. Jean Tannery, the governor general of the bank, was "promoted" to an honorary position and Emile Labeyrie, a partisan of the Popular Front, was appointed to succeed Mr. Tannery as acting governor general.

THE big event of the week in metropolitan garden circles is the four-day Westchester County Flower Show, to he held in the County Center at White Plains, opening Wednesday afternoon. This show is the fifth annual exhibition of the Westchester County Horticultural and Agricultural Association.

Private reports of showers in the heart of the drought-stricken region of the Carolinas caused a sharp break of a dollar a bale in prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday. The finish was at losses of 2 to 15 points.

PASSENGER traffic over eastern railway and motor-bus lines showed a definite upward trend during the past week -- the first week of the new low fares established by the Interstate Commerce Commission. But whether the travel increase was directly traceable to those lowered fares, travel experts were, for the most part, reluctant to say.

DETROIT, June 5. -- The inland industrial States know now, after a fortnight of investigation of the Black Legion by State, county and city law enforcement agencies in Michigan, that however fantastic the activities of the secret terrorist society may have been, however ridiculous its weird rites and practices may have appeared in the light of day, the organization would have shortly become a serious menace to democratic processes had it not been exposed.

ONE of the latest recruits to join the municipal safety parade is South Bend, Ind. It is reported from this city of gridiron glory that the local government is out to make its accidents as few as its touchdowns are numerous. An official campaign, supported by the local chapter of the National Safety Council, is soon to be launched with the object of making South Bend "the safest city in the United States."

THE interest of Mr. Jessup in life in the open and in all manner of outdoor sports, games, means and methods of enjoyment is well known to others similarly interested, as are also his comprehensive knowledge concerning them and the authority with which he can speak about them.

In a recent editorial you hopefully ask whether the Republican party will recognize that foreign trade is a two-way process. Unfortunately the titular head of the party, Mr. Hoover, fails to do so. At Philadelphia, he said: "By wise use of tariffs protect our farmers from the flood of imports.

CONSIDERING that it is a light, not to say trifling, novel, "Wind Which Moved a Ship" has a plot of formidable complexity. Omitting, however, its divagations and finer points, it relates the tempestuous history of one Charlotte Elizabeth, who surprised and annoyed her conservative English kin by developing into a musical genius.

With shouts of "China wants peace! Japan wants war!" seventy-five Chinese-Americans picketed the offices of Japan's Consul General at 500 Fifth Avenue yesterday in an orderly demonstration by the American Friends of the Chinese People. The group, which began parading at noon, sent a letter to the Consul General protesting the "ominous arrival of additional Japanese troops in North China."

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- Benefits under the Social Security Act are now shared, under one or more of its provisions, by all the forty-eight States as well as Hawaii and Alaska, according to a survey made today at the office of the Social Security Board.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., June 6. -- The first serious forest fire to strike this section swept over 500 acres of a pine belt in Monmouth County along a five-mile front today and threatened more than two-score homes and farms in the Reevytown section about ten miles west of this city.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- A new administrative policy is being put into effect by James M. Landis, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, to promote greater efficiency and prevent delays due to unnecessary red tape.
ROME, June 6. -- Marshal Pietro Badoglio, on the eve of the celebration of his victory in Ethiopia, revealed himself in an interview tonight as a convinced lover of peace.

WHEN a motion picture is about to be offered to the public, the publicity men seldom fail to assure potential audiences that it contains all the glory, all the thrills, all the humor, all the beauty that the spectator can stand without physically dying with delight.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 6. -- Climaxing a three-days commencement program at the Westminster Choir School, the annual Talbott choral festival, participated in by forty choirs numbering 3,500 voices, was held here this evening at 6 o'clock on the front campus.

WASHINGTON. A SCHOOL for Federal housing managers, established here with Rockefeller funds, recently graduated its first class, numbering approximately sixty men and women. Intended to provide trained real estate managers for Federal service, the school, with the cooperation of the Public Works and Rural Resettlement Administrations, has been carried on under the direction of Donald Slesinger, Professor of Public Law at the University of Chicago.

THE "Silver Greyhound" was the insignia of the officers of the courier service upon which the American members of the Peace Commission in Paris after the armistice depended for communication with the small missions they maintained, scattered over Europe and in Asia, to furnish necessary information concerning the various countries and their peoples.

RICCARDO PICK - MANGIAGALLI'S latest opera, "Notturno Romantico," in one act and two scenes, by Arturo Rossato, scored a decisive success on its baptism at the Royal Opera recently as the second novelty of the local season.
PARIS, June 6. -- Curiosities of the French strike: Workers occupying one of the largest department stores in Paris danced through the night to the tunes of accordions.
WASHINGTON, June 6. -- Only a European war can prevent restoration of economic prosperity in this country and throughout the world in the opinion of Secretary Wallace.

BERLIN, June 5. -- The swastika cross has conquered all things in Germany except one -- the Christian cross. Despite the totalitarian effort to put all issues on ice for the present in order to present to a troubled world generally, and Olympic visitors particularly, a picture of a strong, united and happy Germany, the conflict between the National Socialist State and the churches continues to disturb the apparent tranquillity.

J.H. McNash, president of the Hazel-Atlas Glass Company, received in 1935 compensation of $50,000 and George A. Hill Jr., head of the Houston Oil Company of Texas, was paid $45,360, it was disclosed yesterday in annual reports of the companies to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

ONLY the lightest, airiest gloves will keep the hands cool though covered during hot days. Gloves that fall into this category are made of raffia, soft and flexible, in an open-mesh crochet that lets the air in. They are to be worn with linen or boucle, or any Summer sports fabrics.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 6. -- A signal of one gun from the flagship Edlu, Commodore Rudolph J. Schaefer's yacht, at 1 o'clock and the raising of the flag at the Larchmont Yacht Club here opened the club's fifty-sixth season today. Hugh Kilmer is fleet captain of the club; W.G. McCullough, first vice commodore; Harry Conover, rear commodore; Robert E. Carrick, secretary, and Thomas L. Burton, treasurer.

The jury received the case of Charles (Lucky Luciano) Lucania and eight other men accused of compulsory prostitution at 9:31 o'clock last night. Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook, however, directed that the jurors be taken out to dinner before beginning their deliberations.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers of America, and William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, exchanged communications today that widened the rift between opposing forces on the craft-industrial union issue and, in the opinion of labor observers, apparently insured a disastrous split in the labor movement.
TOURISTS returning from the tropics bring home the impression that New Yorkers would be more comfortable in Summer if, like people further South, they used more spices and condiments.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., June 6. -- Roswell Gray Ham, Associate Professor of English Literature in Yale University and executive fellow of Jonathan Edwards College at Yale, has been selected to succeed Miss Mary E. Woolley as president of Mount Holyoke College.

Although thousands of craft still are cradled in the shipyards awaiting their turn to slide down the railways into the water for another season afloat and although many city folks with children defer until schools close the opening of their seaside cottages and Summer camps, the first week of June generally is regarded as marking the official start of the yachting year.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 6. -- Breaking fifteen standards in the thirty-nine-event program, New Jersey schoolboy track and field athletes turned in the greatest record-breaking performances in the eighteen-year history of the New Jersey State Interscholastic Athletic Association today at Essex Field.

RECENTLY at a "benefit party" at Walter Reed Hospital in Washington, General Pershing had his photograph taken. From the smile on his face, one might imagine he had in mind the coming celebration in June of the fiftieth anniversary of his graduation from the United States Military Academy.

MOSCOW, June 6. -- Winning his adjourned game from the fifteenth round with Salo Flohr of Czechoslovakia. M. Botwinnik, Soviet chess champion, today made a further gain on Jose R. Capablanca of Cuba, leader in the international chess masters tournament, with one more round to be played.

VIENNA, June 5. -- The rivalry between the Heimwehr and Chancellor Schuschnigg's Clericals and the Chancellor's mysterious journey to Italy this week have revived the importance of the Nazi movement in Austria. Dr. Schuschnigg, confronted with the necessity of finding new backing, can do so only by compromising with the Socialists or with the Nazis or by trying the desperate venture of a Hapsburg restoration.

DALLAS, June 6. -- With the words, "Texas sends greetings to all the peoples of the world on the occasion of the celebration of her 100th anniversary." Secretary Roper opened the Texas Centennial Central Exposition here at noon today.

DURING the month of June something like 150,000 young Americans of both sexes will step forward as their names are called and receive from the hands of a college or university president, or his deputy, a document signifying that they have been admitted to the society of learned men and women.

WHEN roaring guns rescued golden-haired heroines from the clutches of mustache-twirling villains, and Biograph was a rising new film company, Harry Carey was winning his spurs in the motion picture field. "Trail of '98," "Slide, Kelly, Slide," and "Satan Town" are among the silent dramas that saw Harry Carey as a star.
GEORGE BORROW reinforced the value of his writings with the picturesque flavor of his personality. He was at heart an invincible romantic and a confirmed knight of the road.

Cruising in perfect formation on the calm Hudson, the fleet of sleek cruisers participating in the seventh annual Richardson Sailaway Cruise pulled up at Duffy's Landing, Seventy-ninth Street and Riverside Park, yesterday and was greeted by an assemblage of prominent yachtsmen and city officials.

The new Staten Island Zoo will double as a zoological college under plans made public yesterday. The zoo, housed in a T-shaped building of red brick and limestone, will be opened at 4 P.M. on Wednesday.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 5 -- After twenty-five years of congratulating itself that graft had disappeared from its Police Department along with the late Abe Ruef and Eugene Schmitz, San Francisco is shocked today by revelations pointing toward the existence of an organized payoff system alleged to involve some of the highest officers of the department.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., June 6. -- The Lehigh University Alumni Association voted at its annual meeting today to provide money from the alumni fund for an addition to the university's chemical laboratory.

TIMES change, and man changes with them. National prohibition comes and goes in the United States. Women get the vote, and, being still teminine, instantly demand the right to equal penalties with equal privileges under the law. Italy revenges upon Haile Selassie in 1936 the defeat by Menelik at Adowa in 1896.

NORTH CHINA presents today an amazing spectacle of mass smuggling. For volume that smuggling probably has been equaled only once before in history -- by the torrent of liquor that flowed into the United States in the prohibition era. For spectacular effrontery it stands alone.

ALBANY, June 6 (AP). -- Albany made it two out of three games from Buffalo today, winning 12 to 9, as Bob Loane, Senators' center fielder, drive in six runs on two home runs and two out. Buffalo used five pitchers and Albany three, the Senators making fifteen hits and the Bisons twelve.

AT intervals since 1929 William Harris Jr. must have remembered fondly the Martin Flavin play called "The Criminal Code," and if he did, you couldn't blame him. That was the season Mr. Flavin had three plays at once on Broadway; and of the trio "The Criminal Code" was the champion. . . .

ANEW course in Eastern art, to include rugs, pottery and miniatures, was opened at the Metropolitan Museum June 1 by the New York School of Industrial Art, under the auspices of the Board of Education and the Works Progress Administration. Field trips to museums and art centers will be a part of the course.

A marked increase of popular interest in opera is indicated by the advance subscriptions already received for the 1936-37 regular season of the Metropolitan Opera, it was disclosed yesterday by Earle R. Lewis, box-office treasurer of the opera house.

CLEVELAND, June 6. -- The monetary plank in the tentative draft of the Republican platform, brought here by William Allen White, declares for improvement of the gold standard in cooperation with the rest of the world and repeal of the acts devaluing the dollar and authorizing the purchase of silver.

SAN JUAN, P.R., June 6 -- Orlando Colon, policeman, was killed as he entered his home near Rio Piedras last night. Colonel Enrique Orbeta, new Police Chief, said after an all-night investigation that Colon's death was probably the result of a Nationalist vendetta.

There is widespread misconception concerning the speed at which birds normally fly, declares Frederick C. Lincoln, biologist of the United States Bureau of Biological Survey, in a pamphlet on the migration of North American birds published recently by the Department of Agriculture.

Fifty years ago on a field at Newport, R.I., polo teams representing the United States and Great Britain started a series for the Westchester Cup which reaches its golden anniversary this week when, on Wednesday, teams representing the two countries ride out once more, this time on the historic turf of the Hurlingham Club in London, to renew the series.

THE libraries of some 600 city and State philanthropic and correctional institutions have been enriched by donors in the city's first Book Sharing' campaign. About 200,000 volumes ranging from encyclopedias and standard reference works to current best-sellers, were contributed; sponsors of the drive, as a result, have been able to supply institutions on their list with most or all of the books requested.

TO the long list of American cultural exports there must now be added a new item -- women's fashions. "American women are the best dressed women in the world," a big London dry-goods store has discovered. And not only discovered but proclaimed in a full-page advertisement in one of the biggest of London's newspapers.

AS an essay in retrospective regionalism, the show called "Yesterday in Chester County Art" (current at the Art Center, West Chester, Pa., until June 14) appears to have been assembled with imagination, skill and no halting sense of the dramatic.

PHILADELPHIA, June 6. -- Rozia Singletary of St. Augustine College, Raleigh, N.C., loomed tonight as a new rival to Jesse Owens of Ohio State and Eulace Peacock of Temple for a place on the United States Olympic track and field team.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 6. -- The 103d commencement exercises of The Peekskill Military Academy were held today in Ford Auditorium. Diplomas were awarded to a class of fifty-six. The Right Rev. David Lincoln Ferris, Protestant Episcopal bishop of Rochester, member of the class of '82 and of the board of trustees of the academy, gave the address.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended June 3, which included five business days in most of the reporting cities, aggregated $9,139,000,000, or 23 per cent above the total reported for the preceding week and 26 per cent above the total for the corresponding week of last year, which also included five business days in lost of the reporting cities.

CLEVELAND, June 6. -- Here in this big industrial city on the shores of Lake Erie delegates from all parts of the country began arriving today to build the Republican party's platform for 1936 and select a man to stand upon it. Their talk was of national issues and affairs, but their thoughts also were upon the more intimate problems, such as the election of Sheriffs and county officers in their own bailiwicks.

EVER since Chaucer -- and, no doubt, before English language has taken on instant limpid beauty of word and rhythm whenever English writers have touched the subject of the English land. The Englishman's devotion to the English country finds voice in the deep and lovely expressiveness of the English tongue, and gives simple prose the quality of poetry.

ROME, June 5. -- The most notable feature of the administrative organization announced Monday for Italy's East African possessions is the rigidity with which the Fascist principle of authority will be applied.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- Such acts as "the unofficial negotiations of Colonel House by which this private person sought to bring the United States into the war on the Allied side" make it necessary for Congress to maintain and strengthen existing neutrality legislation, the Senate Munitions Committee reported today in filing Part 6 of its findings.

BERLIN, June 6. -- The Boerse, which had suffered sinking spells twice yesterday, reversed itself completely today and made a strong recovery in prices both of shares and of foreign bonds. Gains of one to two points were frequent and some upturns were even higher.

INTERNATIONAL relationships will be strongly accented in the clothing worn by the well-dressed man this Summer. In making up the featherweight ensemble, the purveyors of fashion have found motifs among the high reaches of the Andes, the shifting sands of the desert and along the sparkling waters of the Mediterranean.

Valance Bynoe, 7-year-old Negro, of 167 West 126th Street, was accidentally shot and fatally wounded and Preston Best, 43, of 147 West 126th Street was slightly wounded about 10:45 o'clock last night by a Negro patrolman, who intended the bullets for three Negro thugs who were about to rob a white man. The thugs escaped unharmed.

THERE are 50,000 miles of highways in the United States that need lighting to "decrease the rising tide of night accidents," D.M. Diggs, General Electric engineer, told the Western New York Safety Congress in Buffalo recently.

Unless the girl who is planning to attend a co-educational college is blessed with a prom-trotter for an older sister, a friend who is a dean of women, and that sixth sense which enables some few to anticipate any crisis this book should be on her list of required reading before she packs her trunk.

Weather is the realm of perpetual change, of eternal motion, of infinite mystery. It is the influence of six million tons of air surging about our earth. What do we know about its cause and its effect? What must we know in order to take full advantage of its enormous power?

JOLIET, Ill., June 6 (AP). -- James Day, 21-year-old convict acquitted Thursday of murdering Richard Loeb, will be punished in Statesville Penitentiary for the killing. Warden Joseph Ragen demoted Day from Grade A convict, the highest, to Grade E, the lowest, and decreed twenty-one days in solitary confinement, with only one prison meal every five days.

THIS latest of the Fu Manchu chronicles also threatens to be the last. But there is no putting your trust in the apparently inevitable doom looming up in the path of a serial detective or villain. The new tale is laid in the United States, over which, believe it or not, the Chinese superman, Dr. Fu Manchu, is coolly planning to establish a dictatorship.
HONGKONG, June 6 (AP) -- South China's patriots, apparently feeling they had dared Japan far enough, tonight disclaimed desires to wage a lone war upon the Japanese.
An itinerant horticultural exhibit will tour the city playgrounds this Summer, providing children in congested areas with a living picture of how flowers and plants grow and are cultivated.

BENNINGTON, Vt., June 6. -- The fifty-three members of Bennington College's first graduating class received Bachelor of Arts degrees today in the first commencement at the institution, which is now finishing its fourth year. The event marked the end of a phase in an experiment in progressive education which has been watched with great interest by educators.

TRENTON, N.J., June 6 (AP). -- Governor Hoffman, delegate at large to the Republican National Convention, voiced opposition tonight to a suggestion that the republicans nominate a Democrat for Vice President. He declared that for the party to follow such a procedure would be to "admit that he did not have a proper candidate within its own ranks.

CLEVELAND, June 6. -- A platform pledging the Republican party to progressive social and economic action within the traditional Democratic party principle of States' rights is being whipped into shape here by supporters of Governor Landon.

The use of the name Protestant by the Black Legion is assailed by the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America. This designation for the terroristic Michigan organization is characterized as "unjustifiable and shameful."
Any curtailment of private family welfare work will "in all probability bring an increase in the future number of public charges," the heads of four of the city's largest welfare agencies warn.

Two announcements in the last week, one by a ship line and the other by an organization of ships' officers, reflected improved condition of the shipping industry. The United Licensed Officers Association in its annual report said 480 members had been added to its roll in the year and the United States Lines announced that it had chartered the California of the Panama Pacific Line for a transatlantic sailing July 1.
THE $50,000 home which the late Dr. Charles Proteus Steinmetz built in Schenectady and then did not know what to do with, soon may become a State-owned memorial to the electrical wizard.

HOLLYWOOD. THE technical expert occupies an odd place in the concoction of screen entertainment. He is necessary to many productions; studios wouldn't think of embarking upon a tale of some complicated or specific phase of life without him; yet his advice generally is accepted with reservations, directors preferring to risk inaccuracies and anachronisms rather than jeopardize their conception of dramatic structure by adhering with too great fidelity to what did or could happen.

HERETOFORE having published at least two other tall tales concerning certain thrilling exploits performed by young Jim Green o' Texas, otherwise (and more widely) known as Sudden the Outlaw, Oliver Strange now goes back to an earlier day in his hero's life and tells how he assumed the name Green and how the other appellation came to be thrust upon the youth who was not an outlaw at heart.

WHEN I think of women painters in general I am apt to descend rapidly to the particular and let myself dwell less on Mary Cassatt than on Marie Laurencin. I suppose, of course, the reason is merely that I think not exclusively of a woman but of a feminine woman, and that, most of us would agree, Marie Laurencin is.

CLEVELAND, June 6. -- For the first time, the soldiers of the World War are in the key places at the Republican National Convention. Four years ago they dominated the delegates' seats; eight years ago they were just coming in; twelve years ago, here in Cleveland when Coolidge was nominated, the World War veterans were tip-toeing into the third line from G.H.Q.

FRANZ BORNSCHEIN'S setting of the poem "Freedman's Song," by Gough D. MacDaniels, will receive its first performance, under the municipal auspices of the city of Baltimore, June 25 at the Douglas High School auditorium, Baltimore, Md.

PITTSBURGH, June 6. -- The big guns of labor's militant drive will be turned full upon the United States Steel Corporation in its first major offensive to organize the nation's 500,000 steel workers into one big union, it was learned authoritatively today.

DETROIT, June 6. -- Duncan C. McCrea, Wayne County Prosecutor, who has taken a leading part in the exposure of the Black Legion, suspended a member of his staff today on evidence that he was a member of the secret society.

NO matter how many books there may be about some great person or momentous event or important period of the past, every now and then the world needs a new one. New facts may have been disclosed that demand revision of the story, the developments of time may be changing the world's viewpoint of the subject, or a writer may come along with a fresh, original or revolutionary conception of the theme.

EUGENICS is likely to fall into disrepute if social reformers persist in using it to justify ancestor worship and race prejudice and to obstruct anthropological, and even social, progress. Unless the geneticists take it in hand and curb the 100-percenters who see no good in any one who is not white, Protestant and "Nordic," we might as well abandon it altogether as a guide in improving the social quality of humanity.

In one respect at least the problem of the Republican platform-builders has been simplified by comparison with 1932. Prohibition will not lift its head at Cleveland. It may be difficult now to recall the fact, but in 1932 the Eighteenth Amendment was the most troublesome question with which the Republicans were confronted.

CHICAGO, June 6. -- When President Roosevelt signs the Commodity Exchange Bill, which he is scheduled to do next week, a new experiment in Federal regulation of commodity markets will be started. The measure this week received approval of the Senate, which had debated and delayed its passage for more than a year.
PHILADELPHIA, June 6. -- For the third successive year the New York women's team of the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association won the Sears Cup today on the turf courts of the Germantown Cricket Club.

PARIS, June 6. -- Newspaper pickets fought with Republican Guards, students clashed with the police and Leon Blum, Socialist Premier, walked out on a tumultuous Chamber of Deputies attack in strike-locked France tonight.

PROFESSOR Langer continues here the masterly survey of European diplomatic history, of which "The Franco-Russian Alliance," published in 1929, and "European Alliances and Alignments, 1871-1890," published in 1931, are earlier parts.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., June 6. -- Announcement of the completion of plans for a new biology laboratory and endowment was made today by President Frank Aydelotte at the annual commencement luncheon of the college alumni. The new building is to be constructed out of funds provided in a $900,000 gift to the college by Fred M. Kirby of Wilkes-Barre, Pa.

When the United Lutheran Synod of New York celebrates its 150th anniversary Tuesday in Albany it will mark only half the span of Lutheran influence in New York State, the Rev. Dr. Samuel Trexler, for many years president of the synod, said in an official history written for the celebration and made public yesterday.

In a nose-and-nose drive that lifted 30,000 persons to their toes, William Woodward's Granville yesterday won the sixty-eighth Belmont Stakes from J.H. Whitney's Mr. Bones, in a finish that will not soon be forgotten, even in a season which has abounded with tight decisions.

HOW can we arrange for the use of park tennis courts for our children? Whom should we see about improving the lunch service at our school? What museum will help our children with their stamp collections?

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Jane 6. -- Favored with the finest weather that has prevailed at any of its fixtures in recent years, the thirty-eighth annual Tuxedo Park Horse Show came to a successful close today with entries of Miss Helen Bedford's Wynfromere Farm of Green's Farm, Conn., capturing championship rosettes in two classes.

All of the important families in a little Pennsylvania town on Lake Erie lived on Benefit Street. Jane Abbott succeeds in making the street a real and rather unpleasant place. Its inhabitants prided themselves on their o neighborliness, which expressed itself in church work, gifts of goodies to the sick and the poor, but chiefly in an excessive interest in each other's private lives.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, June 6. -- Detailed reports received here seem to confirm rumors that the Soviet Government in recent weeks has deported on an unprecedented scale members of the Finnish-speaking population in the districts between Leningrad and Finland.

ST. LOUIS, June 6. -- The Cardinals, without their lean and towering Dizzy Dean on the firing line, became birds of a different feather today as the Giants turned violently on their tormentors and yanked both ends of a double-header away from the astonished Frischmen, while a crowd of 27,000 looked on in something akin to a trance.

PARIS. THE highbrow theatre need not be ashamed of its success in Paris just now. Louis Jouvet has passed the 200th performance with Jean Giraudoux's play about the Trojan war, which is the most highbrow of philosophically poetic denunciations of the mad obsession which drives nations fight each other.

Negro spirituals and other songs were chanted on the Mall in Central Park yesterday morning by 5,000 children and grown-ups from various community centers throughout the city who assembled to demonstrate the results of the Experimental Community Centers project, the aim of which is to cut down juvenile deliquency by providing programs of occupation.

NOT least among the victors of peace was William Cobbett, who battled unceasingly during the first third of the nineteenth century in behalf of the underprivileged of England. Marjorie Bowen calls her "Peter Porcupine" mainly a picture of the man himself against his background.

The railroads bought more locomotives and freight and passenger cars in the first five months of this year than they did in all of 1935, according to a compilation by Railway Age. The magazine stated that orders for rail in the five months were 92 per cent of the 1935 figure.

WITH a certain fine condescension Mr. Francis Toye of The London Morning Post discovered Mme. Kirsten Flagstad to be a singer of exceptional attainments. This is more than interesting; it is reassuring.

WHILE the exhibition for which it was prepared has come and departed, the Museum of Modern Art's catalogue of "Cubism and Abstract Art" represents a work of permanent value within its field, especially as a volume for source reference.

THE title, "In Tract of Time," with its suggestion of spaciousness and serenity, prepares the reader for the deep mood of the exceptional poetry of Helen Cornelius. The book contains but threescore pieces, the sixty poems which this talented young woman, shortly before her death, in 1933, selected to live after her.

WHEN the new Polish liner Batory arrived in New York on its maiden voyage a fortnight ago it gave impetus to a hobby that has been steadily growing in the United States in recent years -- the collecting of costume dolls. In the Batory's hold were 1,000 dolls, meticulously dressed in the costumes of Poland, destined for distribution as a means of bringing the people of Poland closer to those of America.

A FORCE of nature rather than a mere man, is the impression one gets from this account of the life of Charles Goodnight, famous in the Southwestern border country for half a century. Such vast reservoirs of dynamic energy as were constantly pouring their forces through him seem to have their equal only in the inexhaustible stores of nature.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- To the tune of political charges that echoed throughout the nation and to the cracking of political whips, the Senate this week approved the second huge work-relief appropriation requested by President Roosevelt and already endorsed by the House.

Somewhat worried by the possibility of widespread wage-cutting in industry following the Supreme Court decisions on the Guffey Coal Act and the New York State-Minimum Wage Laws, industrial and merchandise buyers were assured by representative organizations last week that they need not fear any such development.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP). -- With a study of legislative interests of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company completed, Federal Communications Commission investigators mapped plans today for an intensive study of the company's large-scale financial transactions.

BY taking advantage of the fictional method, Mr. Bogoslovsky has been able to present his ideas concerning present-day and future educational ways and means and aims with more color, vivacity and personalized interest than would be otherwise possible.

MR. M.P. SHIEL, who is Irish and a Civil List Pensioner in literature, has been praised by such queer critical bedfellows as Hugh Walpole and Rebecca West. Others have credited him with an imagination "more vigorous than Stevenson's," and "a genius drunk with the hottest juices of our language."

THE broadcasters are wondering what it will cost them to electrify the national political conventions. Such broadcasts are unsponsored "shows," which means the radio organizations must foot the bill, and when regular commercial programs are sidetracked for a non-revenue political "act" the cost is further lifted.

YONKERS, N.Y., June 6. -- Sweeping through his two matches with the loss of only two games, Paul Haber of the Bronx went into the third round as the metropolitan clay court tennis championship got under way today at the South Yonkers Tennis Club.

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 6. -- Considerable anxiety was caused in political circles today as a result of charges by the president of the Radical party that many prominent supporters of former President Carlos Ibanez, in exile in Argentina, had begun new efforts to overthrow the government and set up a new dictatorship.

These stories, gathered directly from the Indian tribes of Texas or their close associates of many years, have the simplicity and directness which characterizes genuine folklore. They are largely legends concerning the origins of the familiar things of the Indian's world, and they reflect his habits of life and thought.
" THE eyes of Texas are upon you," runs the State University song which has come by now to be accepted as a kind of unofficial State anthem for greeting eminent visitors to Texas.

New York University will formally open its 104th commencement program this afternoon with baccalaureate services in the chapel of the Gould Memorial Library at University Heights and will be culminated on Wednesday morning when Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase will confer degrees upon approximately 4,000 candidates at the commencement exercises on Ohio Field, which 15,000 people are expected to attend.

Due to a lack of transportation facilities, only seven youngsters appeared at the Center Drive in Central Park yesterday afternoon for the final races in the pushmobile contest which was staged by the recreation division of the New York City Parks Department.

People are prone to forget that by far the greater part of the world's population is actively engaged in agriculture or is directly dependent on the results of agriculture. This means that you ladies have a great responsibility for today and for the future; it means that you can raise not only the standards of agricultural life but the standards of all life as well.

THIS book, one of the kind known as provocative, is the last of three -- a trilogy, Mr. Gray calls them -- giving an account of the art of music in the present and the past, and now undertaking to set forth the future. The extent of this, he acknowledges, must be exceedingly limited.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- To forestall critics who are expected to charge in the coming political campaign that the Roosevelt administration has wrecked the civil service, administration leaders today put themselves behind a bill, introduced this week by Senators O'Mahoney and La Follette, designed to put all regular government employes under permanent civil service.

WESTBURY, N.Y., June 6. -- Although able to produce only one individual champion, Henry Weseloh in the 220-yard low hurdles, Hempstead placed in nine out of eleven events to win the team championship in the Nassau County interscholastic meet with 25 1/2 points today.

Stating that present boom conditions in England are not founded on a healthy basis, Wilfred Hill, vice president of the National Union of Manufacturers of England, predicted yesterday that the abnormal prosperity there will begin to "peter out" by the end of this year.

ALTHOUGH Arizona has more than its share of natural wonders, it has lacked a suitable cave to exploit. This deficiency has now been met and a cave about twenty-five miles from Tucson -- "measureless to man," according to the current descriptions -- is now being explored and properly dressed up as an attraction added to the canyons, painted deserts, petrified forests, and so forth, that Arizona has long boasted.

Additional special patrolmen for the city subway system will be appointed from existing police eligible lists, Mayor La Guardia said yesterday. The Board of Estimate on Friday authorized Chairman John H. Delaney of the Board of Transportation to increase the special police force from the present ninety men to 136 and to increase it later on if necessary.

BERLIN, June 6. -- The Washington Government's action in imposing countervailing duties ranging from about 22 to 56 per cent on numerous German goods imported by the United States came as a shock to the German Government.

The attack of the German Government on the Roman Catholic clergy of that country in which charges of immorality have been made against a large number was protested in a statement made public yesterday by a group of forty-eight Jewish and Protestant clergymen.

The share market yesterday plodded through its dullest half-day session since June 29, 1935. Business on the Stock Exchange was only 253,000 shares, compared with 438,000 the Saturday before. The market maintained a firm under-tone throughout, closing higher, on the average, but with most of the gains confined to fractions of a point.

PARIS, June 4. -- Pinet's retrospective exposition of their outstanding shoe models, from 1870 to 1910, will undoubtedly influence coming foot fashions. It is forecast that high-laced, colored stain boots, embroidered with a petit point flower design, will be worn with dressy short afternoon or dinner frocks.

ONCE more the nasturtium is returning to favor. It is coming back with a host of new forms and in numerous new colors. All those reds, oranges, yellows, salmons, and creamy whites signal its renascence. Although the nasturtiums have been in cultivation since 1684, distinct new "types," as well as new varieties, are still being developed.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 6. -- Professor Robert Seneca Smith of the Yale Divinity School will preach the anniversary sermon to the graduating class tomorrow.

A GREAT deal of attention has been paid in recent months to the hazards of commercial airline flying. Those most vitally concerned with air transport -- the passengers who use the airlines -- hope that this interest will continue to the point where flying ranks with rail travel in the matter of safety.

In Topeka, Kan., last week Alf M. Landon, who appears to be the Republican man of the hour, went about his work undisturbed. "Of course I'm tremendously interested in the convention," he chuckled, "but it's really nothing to get excited about."

Governor Lehman's announcement of his decision not to run again has stimulated aspirants for the Republican Gubernatorial nomination despite the fact that many persons believe he may reconsider. The announcement has been followed by the launching of at least half a dozen booms.

In a ruling of interest to owners of mortgaged real estate the Court of Appeals has granted leave to appeal to Jacob Heiman in his action for a deficiency judgment against Henry Bishop and others from the ruling of the Appellate Division denying the judgment.

A new low typhoid mortality rate was reached in New York State in 1935, Dr. E.L. Stebbins, District State Health Officer of the New York State Department of Health, disclosed yesterday. Speaking at a symposium on the typhoid-carrier problem at the New York Post-Graduate Medical School and Hospital, he declared that for twenty-five years New York State had been a leader in the general decline in typhoid mortality and morbidity.
College Humor and five other magazines have been "blacklisted" by the newly formed Cartoonists Guild of America, Adolph Schus, secretary of the organization, announced last night.

THIS week radio goes to its fourth national political convention, and, incidentally, returns to Cleveland, the scene where the microphone first triumphed in handling one of these quadrennial lessons in civics. But there were less than twenty stations in the hook-up that broadcast the nomination of Coolidge; this year there will be a nation-wide string of more than 200 transmitters from Portland, Me., to Honolulu.

Governor Hoffman of New Jersey, revealing last night what he described as a "striking parallel" of the Wendel kidnapping case, criticized the New Jersey State Police for showing no interest in the case.

THOUSANDS of American women are now planning their Summer trip to Europe. Those who have not been abroad before and are puzzled as to what wardrobe to take along turn to the experience of the seasoned traveler, who chooses clothes that are smart and inconspicuous.

RESUMPTION of travel to Europe on a pre-depression scale, noted with complete satisfaction in some quarters, has prompted scowling and shaking of heads in others. Certain viewers-with-alarm are saying that America may be in for another deluge of novels and plays about Babbitts abroad; musical comedy quips about French telephones and English tea drinking; cartoons of disgruntled husbands trailing determined wives through the Louvre; jokes about Iowa farmers and the Venus de Milo.

A SUMMER tournament which will comprise three events spread over four or more days has been announced by the United States Bridge Association. The dates are July 22-25, inclusive, with possible play-offs on July 26 and 27.

HATS may be of braided straw, panama weave, coco-fiber or felt, but two qualities all hats share in common this Summer -- coolness and lightness. Many are ventilated. There may have been a time when it was more comfortable to go bareheaded and risk sunstroke than to bind the brow and heavily cover the cranium, but that day is gone.

THE Law, as Kipling used to put it, is that the assistant keep mum and work harder than the bloke he's assisting. City editors and chief engineers of tank boats, we have noticed, are usually placid; it's the fellows about them who are in a lather.

Hubert Fauntleroy Julian, onetime colonel in the army of the Ethiopian Emperor, sailed for the Mediterranean yesterday on the Italian liner Vulcania. As usual faultlessly attired in black fedora, ascot tie, wing collar and morning coat, Colonel Julian said he looked forward to a Mediterranean voyage under "my own national flag."

AUTOMOTIVE manufacturing and motor trucking interests were disturbed last week by two governmental moves which seemed to them to give the railroads undue "aid and comfort" in the growing struggle for the freight business of the United States.

ONE of the features of the Rhode Island Tercentenary program will be the retrospective exhibition which is being arranged through the cooperation of the Art Association of Newport and the Newport County Committee of the Rhode Island Tercentenary.
ANTWERP, Belgium, June 6 (AP). -- Belgian strikers were warned by the Cabinet today to avoid any impassive occupation of harbor works and factories.

OWNERS of gardens large or small who for one reason or another did not make a garden by sowing flower seeds this Spring may still enjoy many brilliant, attractive garden flowers by planting the bulbs known as "Summer-flowering."

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- Governor Landon of Kansas may be nominated on an early ballot of the Republican National Convention next week at Cleveland, and the platform may be a wordy compromise of highly controversial views which will be adopted without floor warfare. But there is just enough chance of an upset in both particulars to make the prospect one of the most interesting in many years.

Two Negroes whose knowledge of Hoyle did not match well with their story of winnings in a poker game were held for the grand jury yesterday by United States Commissioner Garrett W. Cotter charged with attempting to pass a counterfeit ten-dollar note.

BOXING enthusiasts should not miss this stirring tale of a young heavyweight's struggle, for the story, in itself first-rate ring fiction, gives a most thorough and startling lowdown on those crooked inside practices of the industry which have long made pugilism an object of suspicion to the cannier.

THE environment and the features of everyday life briskly described in Andre Billy's novel "Quel Homme Es Tu?" (Flammarion, 12 francs), even apart from the other constituents of the work, are worth the perusal.

Emphasis on hard-hitting, timely promotions, tempered by the belief that it would not be altogether wise to encourage the veterans to go on an immediate spending spree, are outstanding features of retail plans dealing with merchandising to follow the veterans' bonus payments after June 15, it was indicated here yesterday.

LADY ASTOR has a new parliamentary dignity. For seventeen years she has been famous as the first woman in history to cross the threshold of the House of Commons -- and she was born a Virginian at that. She now has the added distinction of heading the largest "family party" in the House.

JAMES WHALE came to this country with R.C. Sherriff in 1929 to preserve an authentic Eton and Harrow restraint in that series of glimpses of British gentlemen at war that was known as "Journey's End." That he remained to direct such incongruities as "Frankenstein" and "The Invisible Man" for the American screen is one of the more amusing vagaries of Hollywood.

Taking five of the six singles matches, junior representatives of the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association regained the Stephen Tilton Bowl by conquering the Middle home team, under the direction of Arthur E. Woods, last won in 1933.

WITH the Metropolitan's Spring season still fresh in memory -- it departed last night after a term of four weeks -- the opening bulletin this morning will deal with the production that was the pride and joy of said season. The opera in question was, of course. "The Bartered Bride." Done in English, the gay

MANILA. -- A long step forward in the development of the island of Mindanao will have been taken by the middle of July when an interprovincial road is opened to traffic from the Province of Lanao to the Province of Cotabato.

MOSCOW, June 5. -- The liberalized criminal code that will be part of the new Soviet Constitution is the latest of several developments showing the dawning of a regard for Soviet citizens as individuals, not merely as components of a proletarian mass.
WATERTOWN, Conn., June 6. -- President J. Edgar Park of Wheaton College will give the address to the graduating class of the Taft School on Friday.

NEW YORK CITY thinks of having a new charter. Her present one is almost forty years old, covered with patches and beginning to give at the seams. It has never quite fitted her, anyway. She will be debating the cut of the new one till November next.

CEDARHURST, L.I., June 6. -- Tennis officialdom went down to defeat in the first day's play of the annual Rockaway Hunting Club's invitation doubles tournament today as Julian S. Myrick, chairman of the Wightman Cup committee, teamed with O.H. Gruner Jr. and lost to Watson Washburn and A.W. MacPherson, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 2.

Both retail and manufacturing trade developments in the metropolitan area last week continued favorable. Leading department stores reported expanding trade, with volume on some days of the week running 20 to 22 per cent ahead of last year.

The ninety-first commencement of Fordham University will begin this morning at 11 o'clock with the baccalaureate services in the university church. About 400 members of the graduating classes in the Bronx and Manhattan divisions of the College of Arts and Sciences will attend in academic caps and gowns.

WITH school vacations in sight the Boy Scouts are on the verge of their Summer camping season. Since 1910, scouting has made the camp the backbone of its program in the out-of-doors; and authorities are not lacking to credit the movement with a large part in making America camp-conscious.

CHICAGO, June 6. -- Suits attacking the validity of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 were entered today before the United States Circuit Court of Appeals by two large companies which seek to enjoin the Securities and Exchange Commission from making public certain information filed in connection with their applications for registrations under the act.

SHANGHAI, June 6. -- Canton advices carried by the Domei (Japanese) News Agency continued to bring details of an alleged invasion of Hunan Province today by Canton government troops, but Chinese termed the reports untrue.

PITTSFIELD, Mass. -- In another week the mountain laurel and other wild flowers of the Berkshire Hills will be in bloom. The Mount Everett Reservation in Southern Berkshire, with Guilder Pond, highest natural body of water in the State, surrounded by the pink and white blossoms, makes a singularly attractive garden.

CLEVELAND, June 6. -- Among early arrivals for the Republican National Convention is Godfrey G. Gloom, an old-fashioned Jeffersonian Democrat from Amity, Ind., whom a TIMES reporter discovered this afternoon in the act of furtively removing a Landon sunflower from his lapel.

HOT SPRINGS, Va. -- An exhibition of antique and modern laces opens at the Homestead tomorrow. Exhibits fall into two main categories -- bobbin-made and needlepoint. Among the needlepoints is a sixteenth century specimen of Reticelli.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- A registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 was filed today by the Western Massachusetts Companies of Boston, covering $11,000,000 of 3 1/4 per cent coupon notes due on June 15, 1946. The net proceeds from the sale of the notes would be used as follows:
THIS month hundreds of thousands of young men and women will leave their classrooms, all ready to go to work. Many of them will get jobs, either in the professional world or in industry.

The degree of Doctor of Hebrew Literature in course will be conferred upon Rabbi Solomon Goldman of Congregation Ansche Emeth, Chicago, at the commencement exercises of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, Broadway and 122d Street, to be held this afternoon at the seminary quadrangle.
WASHINGTON, June 6 )(AP). -Yielding only seven hits, Schoolboy Rowe held the Senators in check today and the Tigers registered a 10-to-4 victory.

AS the armies of Badoglio drew near Addis Ababa there was a rumor in Rome that Il Duce would fly to Ethiopia and take part in the triumph that followed the occupation of the capital. Had the rumor become an actuality Il Duce could have covered the 2,500 miles, with a possible stop in Libya Italiana, by piloting the plane that bore him.

IN November, 1890, Parnell stood at the summit of one of the great political careers of the nineteenth century. When he had entered Parliament in 1875, the Irish National party under the leadership of Isaac Butt was ineffectually endeavoring to win Home Rule for Ireland by a policy of courtesy and conciliation.

THERE is a fascination in the re-creation of the beginnings of a great city, and in this story Elizabeth Gale recalls a picture of Manhattan when New Amsterdam was only a cluster of cottages and a stockade, when wolves howled in the forests of which Central park is now a memory, and wildcats padded through the streets on cold nights.

NONAGENARIAIN'S ARRIVAL: At a lonely crossing near Lakewood, N.J., last Wednesday, John D. Rockefeller Sr. stepped from his private train, up from Florida on the annual Spring trip north, and sped by auto to his estate Golf House.

WHILE the radio engineering corps has been moving truck loads of electrical paraphernalia into the Cleveland Auditorium to eavesdrop on the Republican convention, the broadcasters have assembled a "teaching" staff to interpret the bedlam and action, which listeners never see from their seats at home. The ethereal word-picture "painters" follow.

ROCHESTER, June 6. -- A unanimous vote to condemn the "alarming increase in Congressional military and naval appropriations" was registered at a session of the General Synod of the Reformed Church today.

THE Pribilof Islands, near the center of Bering Sea, are preparing receive their Summer visitors. Here during the months of June and July the great North American fur seal herd comes ashore to its only terrestrial home. Feverish activity prevails.
STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., June 6. -- The Oxford Group undertook today at a meeting of its first annual assembly in America to tell youth how it works.

The Port of New York Authority reports that a new traffic record for May was established on its interstate tunnel and bridge facilities. All bridges and the Holland Tunnel shared in the increased traffic. The gain was nearly 13 per cent over May, 1932, the previous peak, and 14 per cent over May, 1935.

A new record for attendance at the mid-year conference of the National Retail Dry Goods Association is expected to be set this week when Chicago will be host to several thousand retailers and store executives from department, dry goods and specialty stores in every section of the country.

ALBANY, June 6. -- Four bills which would have compelled New York City to restore the salaries of policemen, firemen and teachers and other employes in the school system to the 1933 levels at a cost of $18,500,000 were vetoed today by Governor Lehman.

The United States Army military pageant to be given at 2 o'clock this afternoon at the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club in Port Chester, N.Y., should be the most colorful and spectacular of the equestrian events of the Summer. A program of eleven events is expected to attract a huge gathering of miliary officials, horse-show enthusiasts, hunting folk and others who enjoy exciting competition over the stiffest of international courses.

ANDOVER, Mass., June 6. -- Only twenty-nine Exeter men faced Ted Harrison as he pitched Andover to a 6-1 victory today. In seven out of the nine innings Exeter, making only three hits, went out in order. The Andover southpaw fanned four and did not issue a pass.

FREEDOM of speech has always been a highly prized privilege of the British citizen; so has the sanctity of the home, and with this in mind the British Broadcasting Corporation reports in its official journal, The Radio-Times, that it has been trying, through a long series of experiments, how best to reconcile the two.

In their effort to assist families to regain financial independence, private family welfare agencies in this city last year spent $335,000 for "opportunity relief," Laurence M. Marks, chairman of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee, announced yesterday.

PANAMA, Panama, June 6. -- President Harmodio Arias pleads for orderly and fair elections when Panama voters elect a new President and National Assembly tomorrow after one of the bitterest campaigns in the history of the republic.
BABYLON, L.I., June 6 -- Horace (Bud) Havemeyer Jr., sailing his father's Vim, won the International Star Class contest in the opening invitation regatta of the Babylon Yacht Club today.

New York City's slot machine industry, which reportedly has been collecting 1,000,000,000 nickels a year from a gullible public, has now been outlawed so far as its gambling elements are concerned. A terse decision last week by the highest State court, the Court of Appeals, all but closed the door on the industry's last hope -- the crane, claw and digger machines.

REGARDLESS of the feelings and the rulings of the censors, the shirt has been largely eliminated from the American bathing ensemble for males. Yet that does not mean that it is fashionable to be dressed at a minimum on the beach -- quite the contrary.

The Park Department will request that positions be established in the 1937 city budget to keep all monuments in first-class condition, it was announced yesterday. Among the employes the department would like to have for this work are a curator, a stone artisan, a stone setter and a metal artisan.

The Baltimore City College lacrosse team, recognized national scholastic champion, concluded its campaign with eight victories in as many starts as the result of a 12-7 triumph over a Brooklyn-Long Island scholastic combination at Erasmus Field, Brooklyn, yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, June 5. -- Two points are evident in the State Senate's investigation of the Works Progress Administration in Pennsylvania, which was blocked this week by Federal Court order. In the first place the Republicans, insisting that the WPA is drenched in Democratic politics, have determined that there shall be a public "expos" of conditions.

Although New York is a "swell town" and Coney Island "better than the circus" in the opinion of fifty-four newsboys of The Worcester, Mass., Telegram and Gazette, the youngsters, who arrived in the city yesterday morning on a trip won in the newspaper's circulation contest, liked the boat ride down from Providence best of all.

SEATTLE, June 5. -- The issue of production for use has created a schism in the Democratic party in Washington which may drive the conservative wing into the bailiwick of the Republicans. Such a coalition has been widely rumored.

In your review of the life of the late Lord Allenby you justly emphasized the crowning glory of his military career, which was the historical feat of his conquest of Palestine. However, in your account of the campaign in the Jordan Valley, while giving duly deserved credit to the Anzac Mounted Division, you failed to mention the active participation of the Jewish Legion, namely the Thirty-eighth, Thirty-ninth, Fortieth and Forty-second Battalions, Royal Fusiliers.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 6 (AP). -Syracuse spotted Toronto to four runs in the second inning and one more in the third, came from behind twice to tie the score and then slugged its way to an 11-to-7 victory today. The Chiefs scored in each of the last five innings, clinching the verdict in the eighth with a four-run splurge.

YOU can't appreciate how little New York matters in the scheme of things -- what a back-number the old town is, really -- until you meet some up-and-coming juvenile like Robert Taylor who has been known in motion pictures for a couple of years now in spite of having set foot on Broadway last week for the first time in his young life.
St. Patrick's Cathedral was crowded yesterday morning when Cardinal Hayes ordained thirty-seven young men to the priesthood.

CINCINNATI, June 8 (AP). -- The Bees beat back the Reds' bid for fifth place in the National League today by scoring two runs in the tenth inning to win the second game of a double-header, 10 -- 8, after the Reds had taken the first, 4 -- 1, behind five-hit pitching by southpaw Al Hollingsworth.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 6. -- Roy Bruninghaus allowed Harvard only five scattered hits and Holy Cross won its second game of the year from the Crimson today. The tally was 7 -- 1.

Securities with a minimum value of $104,949 mysteriously disappeared yesterday morning from the offices of Shields Co., brokers, on the twentieth floor of the Bank of America Building at 44 Wall Street.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- The decision last Monday of the Supreme Court of the United States holding unconstitutional New York's Minimum Wage Law, in its application to adult women, has given rise to fears that other social legislation may eventually meet the same fate at the hands of the present court.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 6. -- Alumnae reunions and class day exercises began commencement exercises at Vassar College today. A fair June day and the famous pines of the Vassar campus provided the background for the parade of alumnae this morning.
The Yanks will testify this morning that when misfortune strikes the squad it deals an overdose. Dame fortune did not smile on the McCarthymen yesterday at the Stadium and here is what happened:

Forty-nine of the 252 students who will receive diplomas at the eighty-third commencement exercises of Manhattan College Tuesday afternoon have been cited for scholastic excellence according to an announcement by the president's office.
PRINCETON, N.J., June 6. -- Alumni reunions here next week-end will be the largest ever held at Princeton University, Donald W. Griffin, '23, secretary of the Graduate Council, predicted today.

THERE is a growing movement in England for schools to "adopt" ships of the merchant marine. Adoption means an exchange of letters between seamen and school children, in which the children are told of the ship's cargo, route and port of call, the sights and customs of the lands visited, and the life of the sailors.

VIENNA, June 6. -- The Italian guard on Brenner Pass, which was considerably reduced at the beginning of this year as a result of the African war, is being restored, according to reports from the Austrian border.

MOSCOW time is eight hours faster than Eastern standard time and three hours ahead of Greenwich Mean Time, according to an official announcement from Radio Center, Moscow. There has been some confusion among listeners in this country regarding whether the Russian capital is two or three hours away from London.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., June 6. -- The eighth annual commencement exercises of Sarah Lawrence College were held here today, at which twelve Bachelor of Arts degrees and ninty-one diplomas signifying the satisfactory completion of two years of college work were conferred.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- The Potomac Electric Power Company of this city, a member of the North American Company system, has filed under the Securities Act of 1933 for the issuance of $15,000,000 of first mortgage 3 1/4 per cent bonds due on July 1, 1966.

THE Baireuth performances this Summer will open Sunday, July 19, with "Lohengrin" and will close with the sixth presentation of that opera Monday, Aug. 31. "Parsifal," which is to be given five times, will receive its first performance Monday, July 20.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va. -- Entries in the national contest sponsored by the Old White art colony for original paintings of the historic Old White Hotel have been hung in the gallery of the Greenbrier (Old White's modern successor) pending the decision of the judges on June 21.

CHICAGO, June 6. -- Wholesale and retail trade maintained a profitably active pace this week. While the gain over last year was much narrower than in the week preceding, this was due to the absence of several special sales held in the first week of June, 1935.

EVELYN BURRAGE is left alone at the age of 37 to rebuild her own life following the sudden marriages of her father and her daughter. From the sheltered, gracious life at Morning Glory, her father's home, Evelyn steps into unexpected difficulties and romantic complications when she accepts a portion as housekeeper and companion.
SYOSSET, L.I., June 6. -- A B-10 Martin bomber from Mitchel Field, L.I. -- one of the most recent types of army bombers -- went into a flat spin, crashed and burned near here this morning.

EASTON, Pa., June 6. -- Dick (Lefty) Baldwin, Lafayette mound ace, starred in a relief role today as the Maroon nine halted Rutgers before a large Alumni Day crowd on Fisher Field. The score was 6 to 4.

PHILADELPHIA, June 6 (AP). -The Athletics and Browns divided a double-header today, the Mackmen taking the first game, 6 to 5, and the Missourians the second by a score of 5 to 3. The Athletics triumphed with a six-run rally in the seventh inning.

The complete curricula of the Board of Education and the WPA adult education project will be continued this Summer, according to an announcement by Gustav A. Stumpf, administrator. The present session will close June 26 and the Summer session will begin July 6 and end Aug. 14.

Any tax imposed upon undistributed corporate earnings is in effect a deterrent to expansion of business enterprise; and any bar to expansion essentially leads to contraction. The school of thought which fosters contraction of industry by taxation is destructive not only of the growth of industry but of the flow of government revenue from this source as well.
BOSTON, June 5. -- The decision of the Supreme Court in the New York minimum wage case hits New England hard.

AN increasing number of canoeists will paddle off this Summer on trips that will take them into wild country, where fish and game abound, and where the hardy may live close to nature. The guide books of New York, New England and Canada list many such trips, which may be covered by the experienced canoeist in two weeks to a month -- but the inexperienced are not advised to attempt them without a guide.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 6. -- Women are "a sex lost to history" under the domination of the thought of men, it was said here today by Mrs. Mary Ritter Beard, feminist and historian.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- Determined efforts by Senator Wagner to pass or at least to obtain preferred status for the administration-sponsored housing bill in the Senate were balked just before that body adjourned today until Monday, when it will meet and then cease work for a week pending the close of the Republican National Convention.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., June 6. -- Union College alumni back for class reunions heard Frank Bailey, '85, of New York City, make his annual treasurer's report, showing that the college had for the thirty-third consecutive year operated without a deficit.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., June 6. -- Joe Louis went back to work today. The brown bomber, who went over to Baltusrol to watch the golfers go through their paces yesterday, resumed his training for his bout with Max Schmeling, whom he will meet in a fifteen-round contest at the Yankee Stadium a week from Thursday.

CLEVELAND, June 6. -- With Governor Landon continuing to gain in the race for the Republican nomination for President, supporters of other aspirants today based their hope of stopping him on expectation of an attack on him by Senator Borah, when he arrives tomorrow, and on a rather belated effort to build up "favorite son" candidates to prevent a Landon nomination on the first ballot.

MODERN transport -- the automobile in particular -- has brought grave problems to many Old World communities. Brighton, the popular English Channel-resort, is a case in point. Its original builders planned haphazardly and provided only narrow streets.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 6. -- The movement of tonnage through the Golden Gate in May showed a rise of 47,413 tons over the same period last year, according to the Marine Department of the Chamber of Commerce.

CHICAGO, June 6. -- Frenchy Bordagaray did two extraordinary things today. In the first inning he hit a home run over the right-field corner exit gate and laughed his way around the bases. In the sixth inning he fell flat on his back as he was about to catch Frank Demaree's fly to short center and the 8,000 fans burst into raucous laughter.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, June 6. -- Escorted by members of the diplomatic corps and his personal friends, President Juan B. Sacasa left Managua at 11:30 this morning for Corinto where he boarded the Grace liner Cuzco. The ship sailed at 3 P.M.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- Reports that some New York contractors were shying away from PWA housing projects on the ground that "too much red tape" is involved, and that payment is delayed, brought a statement from PWA officials today that no payments will be made when construction does not meet specifications.

THIS novel of the Far East is a garish concoction of Oriental color, murderous hates, sudden and violent lovemaking and those cryptic sayings which Occidental minds associate with Chinese wisdom. It aims to make your fresh creep at exotic horrors, and in a flashy and superficial way it succeeds.

HITHERTO no systematic presentation has been made of the field of Colonial and early republic decorative design in furniture, fabrics, metal-work and pottery. To supply this important aid to anti-quarians and designers an "Index of American Design" is being prepared as a WPA project.

QUIETLY, a remarkable transformation is taking place in the design of street cars, which may ultimately have a profound effect on trains and automobiles as well. Utilizing rubber in a new way for springs and wheels, a vehicle has been developed which operates with almost no noise or vibration.

YONKERS, June 6. -- Samuel Untermyer, lawyer, observing his seventy-eighth birthday today at his country estate, Greystone, in Yonkers, discussed several timely topics. He predicted President Franklin D. Roosevelt would be re-elected easily and said he believed the President then would become more conservative.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 6. -- The New Jersey State Bar Association, in its thirty-eighth annual convention at the Hotel Marlborough-Blenheim here today, charged Governor Harold G. Hoffman had failed to keep campaign promises regarding judicial appointments.
