LONDON, June 6. -- A reception to the diplomatic corps given by Haile Selassie this evening was chiefly interesting as indicating the new standing of the Ethiopian Emperor in the world at large.

Consumer buying reached high levels throughout the country last week, as the demand for all types of Summer merchandise lines continued to broaden under the influence of ideal weather conditions. Industrial operations, particularly in the consumer goods division, moved along favorably in all sections, with reports from some centers indicating gains in employment and a shortage of skilled workers.

Returning from Mexico, whither he has gone to forget that he is a newspaper man and to write a novel, Steve Moffatt comes back to the "glittering isle" of Manhattan and dives head first into a murder mystery. Steve is completely hard-boiled and hopelessly disillusioned, but he has unbounded confidence ill his own a ability to get at the truth.

YOU delightfully picturesque Norteamericanos who are looking for a place to spend your Summer vacaciones should leave for a while this great country with its vivid landscapes and spirited racketeers and visit an older civilization. Mejico, as the Senor Jackson and his Senora did for a month last Fall, driving their own automovil down the new Pan-American Highway from Texas to the capital of Mejico, and beyond.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- Foreign trade in April increased with every geographical grand division compared with April, 1935, the Department of Commerce announced today. Exports totaled $192,692,000, compared with $164,151,000 a year ago. Imports amounted to $202,789,000, compared with $170,500,000.

IT is the Colosseum, majestic in its crumbling skyline. On its outer wall maps show the far-flung frontiers of the old Roman Empire. Mussolini enters, the Dictator whose bust, carved in marble, recalls the head and shoulders of Julius Caesar. Legions of exultant Fascists raise their right arms in the old Roman salute.

CHICAGO, June 6. -- The spell of dry weather in the Spring wheat belt was partly broken by the showers in the more easternly section of the Dakotas and the southern part of the prairie Provinces in Canada, taking the edge today off the bull movement that has shown evidence of developing and closing trades were around the bottom.

THE COLOPHON has been doing some interesting surface scratching in a brand-new field of collecting activity. In the show room at 229 West Forty-third Street, New York, the results are on display through the month of June in the form of some eighty magazines.

UTICA, June 6. -- The State convention of the Young Democratic Clubs and the Intercollegiate Democratic League adopted a resolution tonight advocating a Federal amendment giving the States the right to pass laws dealing with

The drab lives of poor working girls have no place in Maysie Greig's scheme of things. She is fond of shop-girl heroines, and every one of them is distractingly pretty, young, spirited and the center of a whirlpool of exciting romance and intrigue.

To one who has practiced medicine in both the metropolitan area and the country, the contrast between the abundance of medical care supplied to the cities and its absolute dearth in the country is striking. The facilities in the big centers are so well known it seems hardly necessary to enumerate them.

Continental "pensions," or residences, will lead color to the Columbia University campus during the thirty-seventh Summer session which starts July 7. Students of French, German and Italian may live in residence houses in which customs of the country whose culture is being studied will be simulated.

CONFLICT, ever more entertaining than tranquillity, continues to engross the town with strained player-producer relationships contributing most substantially to the hubbub. James Cagney has suffered a salary loss of $130,000 since he took his affairs to court and is causing some speculation.

Tomorrow Miss Charlotte Glutting, provided an injured hand she brought back from the Curtis Cup matches in England does not give her too much trouble, will tee off at the Winchester Country Club in quest of the Women's Eastern Golf Association title which Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare won in Philadelphia last year.

TRENTON, N.J., June 6. -- As State auditors rushed the audit of the records of the State Police Department in order to present their report to Governor Harold G. Hoffman before he leaves tomorrow night to attend the Republican Convention at Cleveland, Colonel H. Norman Schwarzkopf, retiring Superintendent of Police, spent the day in removing his personal belongings from the office.

Opening a prospect of new loads and ranges for aircraft, as well as improvement in the safety factor through availability of emergency power, a new fuel for aviation engines was described yesterday by W.S. Farish, chairman of the board of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, and F.A. Howard, president of the Standard Oil Development Company, at the company's offices in Rockefeller Center.

SUMMIT, N.J., June 6. -- Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Schiffer's Kilkare Farm of Elberon accumulated six blue ribbons in both saddle horse and jumping events during the initial sessions of the tenth annual horse show of the Watchung Riding and Driving Club in the Watchung reservation today.
WASHINGTON, June 6. -- Harry L. Hopkins, WPA Administrator, opened an attack today on political and business critics of the Federal relief program.

THERE is some uncertainty as to whom the Republicans will nominate for President in Cleveland this week, but when the Socialists met in that city the week before last, although there was a rift in the party, there was as little doubt as to who would be its standard bearer as there is as to what the Democrats will do the latter part of this month in Philadelphia.

MR. DE LA MARE'S delicate dream-world remains as evocative and still as evanescent as ever. It is the least pretentious of fine poetry, attempting nothing that it cannot do: a shadowy landscape, a gossamer continuity of reality, a throng of half-ghostly creatures, a legend vaguely told and mysteriously suggestive, a music that lingers in the memory -- words may be added to words, and still its special quality recedes to its personal sensibility.

In a recent radio address Sir Charles Morgan-Webb made a strong plea for a system of managed currencies. He clearly inferred that British well-being was due to divorcement from gold and advised emulating England's example.

LONDON. THERE have been two occasions of interest during the past week -- the first performance in England of Eugene O'Neill's "Ah, Wilderness!" and a new play, "Bees on the Boatdeck," by J.B. Priestley.

Discussions between representafives of the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation and United Gas Improvement subsidiaries for the sale of natural gas to companies serving a wide area adjoining the city of Philadelphia are nearing a conclusive stage, almost four years after the matter first was considered.

PHILADELPHIA, June 6. -- Abraham Lincoln's first draft of the Emancipation Proclamation, never before exhibited publicly, is among a large group of original documents relating to the Republican party which are on view at the Free Library of Philadelphia today to celebrate the Republican National Convention opening in Cleveland next week.

MURIEL HINE has undoubtedly mastered the technique of light novel-making. She is never dull and her work is invariably easy to read. In her latest novel the characterization, within its somewhat restricted class-range, is excellent.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., June 6. -- The commencement program at Skidmore College was marked today by the ceremonies of Class Day and Alumnae Day, with a large number of visitors and alumnae in attendance.

Agriculture, real estate and the government's monetary policies will be the principal topics discussed at the four sessions of the annual convention of the New York State Bankers Association in the Sagamore Hotel, Bolton-Landing-on-Lake-George, on June 20 to 22, according to the program announced here yesterday by S. Sloan Colt, president of the association and of the Bankers Trust Company.

Bill Bonthron's first foot race in a year was an artistic success yesterday, but not a victorious one. The triumph went to Chuck Hornbostel on the wings of a blazing sprint in the last 100 yards as the Indiana graduate whirled up from fourth place to first in the three-quarter-mile feature at the 136th track and field games of the New York Athletic Club.

The third of the race meetings of the New York season, that of the Queens County Club at Aqueduct, will get under way tomorrow with brighter prospects than at any time since John E. Cowdin assumed the presidency. Nine stake events stud the program, which will extend for twenty-two racing days, and Mr. Cowdin recently announced that the program of alteration and improvement of the course had been completed.

LEEK WOOTTON, Warwickshire, England, June 6 (AP). -- Great Britain is ready to enter a non-aggression mutual assistance agreement in Western Europe, Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden declared in an address tonight.

ABOARD PRESIDENTIAL SPECIAL TRAIN, CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., June 6. -- President Roosevelt was engaged tonight in the preparation of several speeches which he will make during the next week, when he will visit Southwestern States on what is to be the first "real" campaign tour.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 6. -- Brown conquered the Long Island University nine by 7 to 1 today, providing a total of four defeats and one victory for the visitors on their New England trip.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., June 6. -- The new national open golf champion, Tony Manero of Greensboro, N.C., not only set a record score of 282 to win, but he also survived an ordeal on the last hole, that might have wrecked a less courageous golfer.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- Changes in administration of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 in dealing with over-the-counter markets, incidental to the recent legislation enacted by Congress in amending Section 15, are expected by the Securities and Exchange Commission to have important results in making its task more practical and in clearing Up confusion concerning brokers and dealers who are subject to registration.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 6. -- Princeton today replaced Yale in fourth position in the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League and eliminated the Elis from the title race by winning the opening game of their annual series, 8 -- 3. Nearly 3,000 spectators witnessed the battle.

The Fire Department announces that the largest display of apparatus in its history will be held in City Hall Park at noon on June 16. Comprised of obsolete and modern equipment, the exhibition will precede the annual graduation exercises of the Fire College, in East Sixty-eighth Street.

THE first big thrill of Dexter Fellows's life as a boy in Fitchburg, Mass., came when for a few never-to-be-forgotten moments he was permitted to hold the horse of Buck Taylor, king of the cowboys with Buffalo Bill's Wild West Show.

SOME idea of America's growing interest in its pre-historic past may be gleaned from the number of travelers who visit Mesa Verde National Park in Colorado. Last year more than 22,000 persons surveyed the ancient Pueblo Indian cliff dwellings in the canyon-seamed reservation, and early indications are that a new record will be established for 1936.

CONTINUING the policy of putting on exhibitions in which the work of contemporaries is displayed along with paintings by artists a generation or two removed, the Babcock Galleries have opened a Summer group show which invites the visitor to make some observations and comparisons for himself.

BY no means for the first time, Columbia is to he congratulated and thanked for taking us on an excursion off the beaten track. In Masterworks Album No. 258 (three twelve-inch and two ten-inch records) are to be found twenty-four of the songs of the practically forgotten Robert Franz, sung by Ernst Wolff, baritone, to his own piano accompaniment.
When Congress recessed on Wednesday night it was in the midst of a legislative spurt, which suggested that adjournment was but a few days off. Then death intervened.

Departing from his rule not to discuss his cases publicly, former Governor Nathan L. Miller, counsel in the Brooklyn laundry owner's test case against the State Minimum Wage Law, has issued a 1,000-word statement in praise of the United States Supreme Court decision invalidating that act.

Three weeks ago today this column was given over to some random thoughts about the speed of mail correspondence through the ages. The occasion was a letter which went from Germany to Honolulu in five and a half days via the Hindenburg, the transcontinental air mail and the China Clipper.

IN the early Eighties of the last century One-Shot Brady and his gang of outlaws made a business of robbing the stages by means of which the Wells Fargo Express was serving cattlemen and miners along the route between Deming and Lordsburg, in high New Mexico.

While attempting to scale a seventy-foot cliff in Highbridge Park at 184th Street, overlooking the Harlem River Speedway, Elmer Borheim, 16 years old, of 63 Post Avenue, became stranded half way up yesterday and had to be rescued by an emergency squad from the West 152d Street station, under the command of Sergeant John Casey.

ATLANTIC BEACH, L.I., June 7. -- The Long Beach Coast Guard station here, ready for wrecks, drowning men and cast-up whales at any instant, had to cope with its first squirrel today. It didn't do so well.

SUMMIT, N.J., June 7. -- Victory in the saddle horse sweepstakes gave Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Schiffer's Kilkare Farm of Elberon, N.J., its eighth blue ribbon during the two days of the tenth annual horse show of the Watchung Riding and Driving Club, which came to a close before a record crowd in the Watchung Reservation today.

The selection of Dr. HAM as president of Mount Holyoke College brings about as close a balance as can obtain between the men and women presidents of the leading colleges for women. Of the seven colleges, which are usually put in a class apart, there are, since the new elections (of Miss MCAFEE for Wellesley and Dr. HAM for Mount Holyoke), four women presidents and three men.

CLEVELAND, June 7. -- The new version of Stephen Foster's catchy song "Oh, Susanna," adapted as the theme song of the Landon campaign, appeared in the streets of Cleveland tonight. It is printed on the inner fold of a two-leaf yellow pamphlet, whose front is decorated with pictures of a train of covered wagons, a bearded pioneer strumming his banjo and a boy singing.

ALBANY, June 7. -- New York State's birth rate for April was 13.4 per 1,000 population, the lowest ever recorded for that month, Dr. J. V. DePorte, director of the Division of Vital Statistics, reported today. The death rate for April was 12.4 per 1,000 population.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., June 7. -- Departing from the traditional type of baccalaureate sermon "to think more specifically in the concepts of the day," the Rev. Dr. Henry H. Crane, pastor of Elm Park Methodist Episcopal Church at Scranton, told 4,000 persons assembled at Pennsylvania State College this morning that they should mold their lives on the principle of the thermostat instead of the thermometer.
PITTSBURGH, June 7 (AP). -- Bill Swift held the Phillies to seven hits today while the Pirates walloped a trio of Philadelphia hurlers for eighteen safeties and Pittsburgh won, 6 -- 2.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 7 (AP). -- Seven persons died and eighteen were injured today in a fire that swept rapidly through a four-story frame hotel in the South-of-Market-Street rooming-house district.

COLLINGSWOOD, N.J., June 7. -- The Rev. Carl McIntire, pastor of the Collingswood Presbyterian Church, whose suspension from the ministry was upheld last week by the Presbyterian General Assembly, declared in a sermon tonight that the assembly had "enthroned tyranny" and that "an outward visible organization has dethroned Jesus Christ."

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Monday, June 8. -- Settlers in the isolated community of Porangahau report having seen rocket signals, believed to have been sent up by the full-rigged ship Joseph Conrad. The signals were seen on May. 28. Three hatchcovers bearing iron grips have now come ashore on a dangerous part of the coast.

DOYLESTOWN, Pa., June 7. -- Three thousand persons from Philadelphia, New York and adjacent communities attended the annual founder's day exercises at the National Farm School today and heard John B. Kelly, Secretary of Revenue of Pennsylvania, deliver the principal address.

PHILADELPHIA, June 7. -- Present-day problems will be solved neither by legislation nor the sword but rather by a Christian spirit in human relationships, the Rev. Dr. James H. Franklin, president of Crozer Theological Seminary, told the Temple University graduating class in a baccalaureate address today.

OTTAWA, Ont., June 7. -- Canada is expected to produce and export this year almost twice as much nickel as in the boom year 1929. The nickel industry, of which the Dominion has a virtual world monopoly, is flourishing as it never before has flourished, but for reasons that, whatever they may mean for Canada in dollars and cents, seem to bode no good for the world's peace.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $5,057,173,200. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 7. -- The Rev. Dr. Henry H. Tweedy of Yale Divinity School, delivering the baccalaureate sermon to the graduating class of the men's college of Rutgers University in Kirkpatrick Chapel, Queen's Campus, this morning, discussed life as a challenge to the individual, a challenge which should be met successfully only by "intelligent, courageous good-will toward the purposes of the Creative Spirit in the universe and toward all one's fellows."
PHILADELPHIA, June 7. -- The Rev. Dr. Daniel A. Poling of New York accepted a call today to the pastorate of Baptist Temple, founded by the Rev. Dr. Russell H. Conwell.

Yale's defeat by Princeton on Saturday left Dartmouth as the only team with a chance to overtake Harvard in the Eastern Inter-collegiate Baseball League race. The Elis could have tied Harvard by sweeping their annual series if they had conquered the Tigers.

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 7. -- An appeal to "probe beneath the surface of life" to gain a clearer understanding of the modern world was made to the graduating class of the United States Military Academy today by the Rev. R.T. Foust, chaplain.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., June 7. -- There are too many "play-boys" writing and thinking today, the Rev. Dr. Alexander Purdy of Hartford Theological Seminary declared at the Swarthmore College baccalaureate service this morning, but in spite of this concern with trivialities, he predicted that civilization would advance because of its spiritual achievements.

Warning members of the graduating class at New York University they are entering a confused world, the Rev. Dr. Irving H. Berg, university chaplain and dean- elect of the college of Arts and Pure Science, in the baccalaureate address yesterday urged them to cling to religion and the "fundamental principles which have marked the progress of true civilization."

ALBANY, June 7. -- Governor Lehman signed the Supplemental Appropriation Bill today after cutting the total to $1,929,124. As passed by the Legislature during the closing hours of the session the bill called for appropriations of $2,094,724, but the Governor vetoed items totaling $165,600.

CHICAGO, June 7. -- Furthering their drive for increased business, the Western railroads will spend $300,000 this year in an advertising campaign, utilizing every newspaper in the Western area, both daily and Sunday, according to an announcement today by Harry G. Taylor, chairman of the Western Association of Railway Executives.

After pondering the possible effects of the Public Utility Act of 1935 on the public financing of holding companies which are contesting the act or which have failed to register under its provisions, and the financing of operating companies which are subsidiaries of non-registering holding companies, investment bankers have decided to go ahead as usual within the terms of the Securities Act of 1933, as amended in 1934.

ATLANTA, June 7 (AP). -- Prayers for rain were followed by generous showers in parts of the Southeast drought area today. Scattered thunder showers, accompanied in some localities by damaging winds, fell from coastal Louisiana inland to central Virginia.

CLEVELAND, June 7. -- Under the leadership of Senator Joseph R. Grundy and Joseph N. Pew Jr., an effort will be made to influence Pennsylvania's seventy-five delegates to vote solidly for Governor Landon on the first ballot.

Governor LEHMAN'S veto of bills restoring the pay-cuts in this city is based on impregnable reasons. In the first place, the passage of such mandatory bills by the Legislature is a gross and unwarranted interference with municipal home rule. The State of New York has undertaken by its Constitution and laws to place the control of city finances wholly within the hands of the local authorities.

WESTPORT, Conn., June 7. -- Showing in marvelous condition, the orange-sable pomeranian Champion Little Sahib this evening was awarded the highest honors of the fourth annual show of the Long Shore Kennel Club held on the polo field of the Fairfield Country Hunt Club.

NEW ORLEANS, June 7. -- Trading in futures contracts in the cotton market here picked up considerably last week and prices held in a higher range. The increased activity was due in the first place to the dropping from the Commodity Exchange Bill in Congress the proposed amendment prohibiting the carrying of contracts for more than 600,000 bales by any one interest in a single year.

CLEVELAND, June 7. -- The hubbub is growing stronger in the lobbies and corridors of the hotels near the square in Cleveland. Here, every hour since Sunday morning, the crowd has been thickening and, curiously, with the swelling crowd has come a distinct defining of issues.

For the past twenty-five years responsible citizens, grand juries and criminal court judges have advocated the construction of a new building to house the criminal courts and the District Attorney's office in the Borough of Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, June 7. -- A demand that the Republican National Convention adopt a plank in its platform for severence by the United States of diplomatic relations with Russia was made in a statement today by Representative Tinkham of Massachusetts as the National Lumber Manufacturers Association asked that when the one-year trade agreement between the two countries is renewed next month the interests of the lumber industry be safeguarded.

CHICAGO, June 7. -- Young Tom Baker pitched eight fine innings against the champion Cubs today, but in the ninth he served up a fourth ball to Ken O'Dea, with the bases filled, to force Woody English home with the winning run, giving the Bruins a 4-3 victory and a sweep of the series.

Dancers from Switzerland and Italy joined yesterday with those of Finland, Germany, Poland, Sweden, Estonia and Ukraine in the annual June frolic sponsored by the Folk Festival Council on the Mall of Central Park. Nearly 10,000 spectators circled the group of 200 dancers gayly decked out in their national costumes.

CHICAGO, June 7. -- Interest in the grain markets developd last week. Cutting of wheat in the Southwest is under way. Reports from Texas indicate good yields of soft Winter wheat, which is passing into the markets there. The situation in the Texas Panhandle and extreme Western Oklahoma has not improved, and reports from Kansas are irregular.
Despite a fairly cool day, more than 1,000,000 persons left the city yesterday to spend the day at the beaches and resorts in the metropolitan area.

Miguel A. de Capriles of the University Fencers Club, former national three-weapon title-holder, captured the national outdoor epee championship yesterday on the strips of the New York A.C. at Travers Island. His victory kept the title in the family after his younger brother, Jose R. de Capriles, faltered in the defense of the crown when he passed from the tourney in the semi-final bracket.

In its efforts to further national recovery the cotton textile industry increased its hourly rate of wages and decreased the hours of its work week relatively more than any important industry. In both respects it had previously been out of line with other domestic industries -- but not so with other cotton textile-producing countries.

Attacks by some European governments against the Roman Catholic religion were assailed in the several addresses yesterday morning at the annual communion breakfast of the ladies' auxiliary of the Vera Cruz Council of the Knights of Columbus, held at the Commodore Hotel.

WASHINGTON, June 7. -- In an attack on the Republican party tonight, Secretary Ickes asserted that attempts to unite liberals and conservatives within its ranks on a constructive platform are futile and assailed leading candidates for the Republican Presidential nomination, including Governor Landon of Kansas.

Characterized as a living description of religious experience rather than an arbitrary theological esotericism, the doctrine of the Trinity was the subject of the name-day sermon preached yesterday at Trinity Church, Broadway and Wall Street, by the Rev. John V. Butler Jr., rector of St. Peter's Church, Springfield, A@ass., and formerly of[ the Trinity parish clergy at the! Chapel of the Intercession.

LONDON, June 7. -- Viscount Cecil of Chelwood, president of the League of Nations Union, which organized the British peace ballot, issued tonight "the most serious, most urgent communication" he had ever addressed to the members in reminding them that the obligation of the League to preserve Ethiopian independence still remains.

Expansion of the Federal savings and loan system in this State involves "considerable potential danger" and is a matter of growing concern, the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York says in its last weekly news letter.

MELBOURNE, Australia, June 7. -- The Commonwealth Government's answer to Japan's representations seeking a revision of Australia's latest tariff schedule was sent to Sydney yesterday to the Japanese consul general, Kuramatsu Murai. This action followed a special Cabinet meeting; with which Prime Minister Joseph A. Lyons, who is in Tasmania, maintained telephone contact.

TRENTON, N.J., June 7. -- On orders from Governor Harold G. Hoffman, Captain William G. Carter, commander of Troop A of Hammonton, will take command of the New Jersey State Police at midnight tonight when the term of Colonel H. Norman Schwarzkopf expires, along with that of Major Charles H. Schoeffel, his deputy.

Faith must be dynamic and not static, and the problem of keeping faith through changing opinion entails a personal allegiance to Jesus Christ, who is a "spiritual flame that kindles souls with fire and sets them burning, each in his own time and in his own way," the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, pastor of the Riverside Church, said in his sermon there yesterday morning.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 7. -- Harvard's varsity crew, after its strenuous four-mile row upstream on the Thames River last night, had a respite from rowing today and enjoyed a long sail on Long Island Sound aboard John Cutler's trim yacht Helianthus.
JIBUTI, French Somaliland, June 6 (AP). -- Ethiopian troops, despite the flight of their Emperor, are still under arms and at least 11,500 of them are within fifty miles of Addis Ababa.

More than 500 members of the Ukrainian Orthodox Church who reject the jurisdiction of the Russian Greek Orthodox Church and of the Soviet Government over their own native church and customs attended special services and a solemn high mass yesterday at St. Vladimir's Ukrainian Church, 334 East Fourteenth Street.

ST. LOUIS, June 7. -- Conceding, perhaps, the point that the Cardinals, without Dizzy Dean on the firing line, are never quite the same as when their famed righthander is "fogging them through," the St. Louisans whipped right back with their matchless flinger against the Giants today and forthwith conceded nothing.

CLEVELAND, June 7. -- Backers of Colonel Frank Knox in the pre-convention race for the Republican nomination for President denied tonight that they were attempting to organize a coalition against Governor Landon of Kansas, admittedly the outstanding contender for the honor at this stage.

CHICAGO, June 7 (AP). -- Competing only in the broad jump, Jesse Owens of Ohio State easily won the event today at the thirty-fifth annual Central A.A.U. track and field championships and Olympic tryout at Stagg Field. He leaped 25 feet 3 inches in his first effort.

WASHINGTON, June 7. -- Guy T. helvering, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, announced today that 4,201,859 individual income tax returns were filed for the calendar year 1934, compared with 3,900,004 for the preceding year. The returns were filed in the year subsequent to that during which the income accrued.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP). -- Roxie Lawson, relieving Joe Sullivan with the tying run on base and none out in the ninth, quelled a Washington rally today that had already netted three runs, and gave Detroit a 10-8 victory.

The national champion New York Athletic Club crew, vengeance-bent for a return battle with the Penn A.C. eight, met the Manhattan College varsity lightweights instead on the Harlem yesterday and won the feature race of the annual New York Rowing Association regatta pretty much as it pleased.

Price trends for commodity futures were mixed in the markets here last week, with gains in cottonseed oil, cocoa, rubber and hides, as sugar, coffees, wool tops, silk and metals went lower. In the cash markets, wheat, corn, raw sugar, lard, cotton print cloths and rubber gained and oats, coffees, antimony, tins and quicksilver declined.

CLEVELAND, June 7. -- Senator Vandenberg of Michigan, first of the "Big Three" Presidential nomination possibilities to reach the convention city, sounded a note of warning soon after his arrival this morning.

Viking Press reports that although Lionel Wiggam's "Landscape With Figures," is a first book of lyrics by a 20-year-old poet, more than 2,000 copies were sold in advance of publication, an unusually large sale for a book of poems.

OAKDALE, L.I., June 7. -- Company B, commanded by Cadet Captain Howard J. Felchlin, was winner of the company competitive drill at the annual Summer review of the cadet battalion of La Salle Military Academy here this afternoon.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 7. -- Shot under the supervision of Brig. Gen. Fred M. Waterbury, executive officer, the annual small-bore matches of the New York State Rifle Association were concluded here at Camp Smith today with the running of thirteen events, with members of the Valley Stream Rifle and Revolver Club winning the most awards.

CLEVELAND, June 7. -- W. Kingsland Macy, Suffolk County chairman, who was Republican chairman in New York State during the successful campaign of F.H. La Guardia for Mayor of New York, sent to the Mayor tonight the following telegram:

SHAWNEE-ON-DELAWARE, Pa., June 7. -- Making his first appearance in a tournament since scoring his sensational victory in the United States open golf championship at Baltusrol, Tony Manero, former Westchester caddie, today discovered that a champion's bed is not one of roses.

WELLESLEY, Mass., June 7. -- Girls who hope to see women assume leadership in business, civic life and the professions can get their best training in the woman's college rather than in the coeducational institution, where they must compete with men.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 7. -- Sunday in the rowing camps along the Hudson is largely a day of rest. Pennsylvania does no rowing at all and any by the other crews is short.

Two tax collectors arrived at Washington Square at 5:45 P.M. yesterday just as the ninth annual outdoor art exhibition and sale was drawing to a close. The sale opened Friday, May 29, and until yesterday many of the artists thought they wouldn't have to pay any city sales tax.

If the interview printed Sunday is an example of the way in which Mr. HOPKINS intends to answer the criticisms of relief, it does not promise a dispassionate or very illuminating discussion of the problem, nor any serious investigation of charges made against the relief system.
Senator Wagner of New York defended the philosophy of the program of the Roosevelt Administration in a radio address broadcast yesterday afternoon over WHN.

CARLSTADT, N.J., June 7. -- Although the national intercollegiate outboard regatta at Richmond, Va., is not to start until June 27, the majority of the outstanding college pilots invaded the seventh annual North Jersey outboard championships today and carried off four of the five events in which they were eligible.

BISMARCK, N.D., June 7. -- Showers fell on drought-parched North Dakota fields today as citizens of the State knelt en masse to pray for rain. Answering the supplications in advance, the heavens dropped moisture before the Sabbath dawn.

CLEVELAND, June 7. -- After almost abandoning hope of blocking the nomination of Governor Landon for President, supporters of rival candidates became active today and started a campaign to canvass arriving delegates with a view to preventing his being chosen on the first ballot.

SHAWNEE-ON-DELAWARE, Pa., June 7. -- Every United States open golf championship has its aftermath. After the 1935 classic at Oakmont, when Sam Parks Jr. unknown Pittsburgher won, the general opinion was that the course had been made too severe by cutting the greens too close, by putting the pins in too tricky spots and by furrowing the bunkers.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., June 7. -- Daniel Frohman, the only survivor of the 248 founders of the Actors Fund of America, greeted the permanent guests of the Actors Fund Home here today in the annual June luncheon and entertainment.

CEDARHURST, L.I., June 7. -- A young team from Princeton, playing as smart and sound a game of doubles as has been developed in the college ranks in recent years, won the invitation tennis tournament at the Rockaway Hunting Club today.

PARIS, June 7 (AP). -- Harold L. Smith, retiring commander of the American Legion in France, protested today against a bill prepared for presentation to Parliament that asks the French Government to pay the debts of Pershing Hall, headquarters of the Paris post of the Legion.
LAKEWOOD, N.J., June 7. -- There was no rest for Joe Louis today. He went through the hardest workout of his entire training campaign before a crowd of almost 4,000 boxing enthusiasts.
Two plane crashes marred the Sunday flying activities of the airports about New York yesterday, wrecking three planes and injuring three persons slightly.

YONKERS, N.Y., June 7. -- Seeded stars came up to expectations today as the thirty-ninth tournament for the Metropolitan clay court tennis championship went into its second day at the South Yonkers Tennis Club.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 7. -- Failure to integrate their lives through a belief in God has brought chaos into the lives of millions, the Rev. Dr. Albert G. Butzer, pastor of the Westminster Church, Buffalo, told Vassar College seniors today in a baccalaurate sermon.

CHICAGO, June 7. -- The condition of the oat crop is said to have been improved by the recent rains over much of the Central West and parts of the Northwest. This brought selling of sufficient volume on the Board of Trade last week to carry prices lower.

Mrs. Sophie S. Stevens, author and mother of a 6-year-old son, who lives at 21-74 Bathgate Avenue, the Bronx, explained yesterday that her academic work at Hunter College, from which she will be graduated this term, has been a "rejuvenation."

It is not possible to kill in war without murdering Jesus, nor is it possible to do a kindness to any one without doing a kindness to Christ, for He is identified with humanity, the Rev. Dr. George Arthur Buttrick, minister of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-third Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning.

The College of Pharmacy of Fordham University will hold its graduation exercises tonight at 8 o'clock in the university gymnasium. Dr. James H. Kidder, dean of the college, will confer degrees on thirty- seven candidates. Dr. Harold Brown Keyes of the staff of French Hospital is to make the commencement address.

CLEVELAND, June 7. -- The chances of James W. Wadsworth becoming the Republican Vice Presidential nominee dimmed considerably today when strong opposition to his selection for that post developed within the New York State delegation on their way here.

BALTIMORE, June 7. -- In his final report submitted yesterday to Judge O'Dunne on the affairs of the Baltimore Trust Company, now in receivership, Simon Sobeloff, special investigator, referring to the activities of William A. Read of London and Australia, in a chapter entitled "Horses from Europe," said:

NEW HAVEN, June 6. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 81.2, which compares with 81.2 the week before, 80.5 two weeks before, 81.0 three weeks before and 81.6 four weeks before.

An "Evening Under the Stars" has been arranged under the auspices of Rockefeller Center, Inc., for the night of June 17 as a benefit jointly for the Judson Health Center and Greenwich House, to mark the opening of the outdoor Promenade Cafe in Rockefeller Center.

PARIS, June 6. -- The statement of condition of the Bank of France dated May 29 shows further increase of 1,452,000,000 francs in bills discounted. Besides this, advances on securities and bonds increased about 100,000,000 francs and the note circulation 1,367,000,000.

CLEVELAND, June 7. -- Dr. Francis E. Townsend, author of the Townsend plan, arrived here tonight, but told reporters that he was not interested in the Republican convention and would have no suggestions to make concerning candidates or the platform.

DETROIT, June 7. -- William W. Voisine, Mayor of Ecorse, in the area where the Black Legion had its only fully recruited "regiment" in Michigan, was threatened with death and went into hiding early today as his investigation of the secret terrorist society showed it to be a hybrid of Molly Maguire and Ku Klux Klan characteristics.

The antipathies of opposed Jewish groups and their widely differing aims were denounced by Dr. Simon Greenberg, rabbi of the Congregation of Har Zion of Philadelphia yesterday when he made the principal address at the commencement exercises of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, Broadway and 122d Street.

I Nine young men were ordained deacons and nine deacons were advanced to the priesthood yesterday morning at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue and 112th Street, in the Trinity Ordination for 1936 of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., June 7. -- The Rev. and Mrs. George Gardner Monks have as guests for the Lenox School graduation Mrs. William F. Knowles, Mrs. George Howard Monks and Miss Olga Monks of Boston. Mrs. Monks gave a tea and supper tonight at Clipston Grange after a glee club concert.

PARIS, June 7 (By Cable). -- Former Premier Albert Sarraut expressed the opinion today that the demands of workmen who have paralyzed France's industrial life in a series of strikes were largely justified.
PARIS, Monday, June 8. -- A settlement of the main issues in dispute behind the strike of more than 1,000,000 workers in France has been concluded.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., June 7. -- The Rev. Dr. Rufus M. Jones, president of the board of trustees and directors of Bryn Mawr College, in a baccalaureate sermon tonight told members of the graduating class that a "cosmic elevator" seemed to carry forward the process of evolution to a certain point.

If American democracy is to be kept safe, the military must be not only well trained and highly subsidized but it must also be composed of "God-fearing, God-loving Christian men," the Rev. George G. Murdock declared yesterday at high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral,
Jacob C. Klinck, Grand Master of Masons in the State of New York, announced yesterday the annual list of appointments to offices and committees in the Grand Lodge.

WASHINGTON, June 7. -- Political systems which seek to make education conform to their beliefs were attacked as threatening ruin to the university system by the Very Rev. Patrick J. Healy, Professor of Church History, at the annual baccalaureate mass in the National Shrine of the Immaculate Conception at Catholic University of America here today.

PRAGUE, June 7. -- The Sudeten German party, headed by Konrad Henlein, is faced with a great internal crisis, which is being compared by many with the purge by the German Nazis of June 30, 1934, although the Czechoslovak Nazi party's purge is absolutely bloodless.

Anxiety over the financial and political situation in France was the dominating influence in the foreign exchange market last week. The erratic movement of the foreign currencies followed the spread of strikes in Paris, and the assumption of power by the Leon Blum government.

LONDON, June 5. -- Once again financial London is being heavily overshadowed by the industrial and financial storm sweeping over France. Although the franc shows comparatively little depreciation in value in relation to sterling, a big effort on the part of British and French authorities has been called for to avert a panic on the decline.

Before leaving for Cleveland, Senator VANDENBERG waved away the suggestion that he be the Republican candidate for Vice President. Politely assuming that the Republican ticket is sure to win, he was sure he could be "of greater service in active labors on "the Senate floor than on its silent "rostrum."

JERUSALEM, June 7. -- Five Arabs were killed and many were wounded this afternoon in a clash with British troops and policemen after an attack on several Jewish-owned buses outside Jerusalem. A British soldier and a British police corporal were seriously wounded.

BORDENTOWN, June 7. -- The fifty-first commencement of the Bordentown Military Institute will be brought to a close Tuesday afternoon when fifty-five seniors and post-graduate students will receive their diplomas, certificates and military awards, to be presented by David Styer, principal.

TORONTO, Ont., June 7. -- The Provinces of Quebec, Manitoba, Saskatchewan, British Columbia, Nova Scotia and Ontario, besides the Yukon Territory, produced more gold in 1935 than in 1934, a survey shows.

An exchange of verbal thrusts between Nathan Straus and Representative Emanuel Celler as to the blame for the uprisings against the Jews in Palestine disquieted the early part of the speaking program at a dinner tendered by the United Palestine Appeal to Harold Jacobi, president of the Schenley Corporation, and New York co-chairman of the-appeal, at the Hotel Astor last night.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., June 7. -- Bachelor of Arts degrees will be awarded to seventy graduates of Upsala College at commencement exercises here at 2:30 o'clock tomorrow afternoon on the campus. Dr. Fraser Metzger, Dean of Rutgers University, will deliver the address.

PITTSBURGH, June 7. -- Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 70 per cent of capacity, up 1 point from the preceding week, although 2 points lower than the recent high rate.

With retailers holding adequate stocks of Summer merchandise to meet their immediate needs, evidence of a slight cessation of activity was noted last week in the local wholesale apparel markets. However, manufacturers of Summer wear, particularly dresses and sportswear, were kept busy accommodating repeat requests for popular styles.

HUNTSVILLE, N.J., June 7. -- More than 200 men, women and children spectators as well as an "army" were routed here today by tear gas during a sham battle which proved a victory for chemical warfare and resulted in the "capture" of the community of Tranquility.
The dancing beams of Aurora Borealis, or Northern Lights, were first shown at the Hayden Planetarium yesterday in the course of lectures to visitors.

Last Friday's meeting of the Board of Estimate was a somewhat historic occasion for New York City. At that time the board authorized an appropriation of $17,500,000 in city bonds to enable the Board of Water Supply to start construction of the long-delayed Delaware system, which may ultimately cost the city the good round sum of $275,000,000.

The gold and emerald crown of Our Lady of the Andes, which was wrought by Spanish goldsmiths more than three centuries ago, has been bought from the Roman Catholic Church of Popayan, Colombia, by "a very small group" of men from Chicago, headed by Warren Piper, gem specialist.

CLEVELAND, June 7. -- A rainy Sunday kept most of the delegates to the twenty-first quadrennial convention of the Republican party indoors today, and thanks to repeal and a State law providing a weekly prohibition Sabbath, they remained drier than the average representative of the people at party pow-wows during the prohibition era.

Last week's financial markets continued to rest on their oars. Prices did not resume an upward movement on the Stock Exchange; but, on the other hand, they did not lose ground noticeably, their very limited movement merely repeating alternate forward and backward swings, within a few points of the season's highest.

WASHINGTON, June 7. -- Woman's Party leaders, in a statement issued here tonight, declared that the Supreme Court had "exposed the fallacy and forever disposed of the strange theory that imposition upon women of wage rates not applicable to men would be an act of social justice" and had left to be decided on its merits the question of minimum pay regulation for all workers.

BERLIN, June 5. -- Uncertainty over the prospects for the new Blum Cabinet in France and the continued crisis in the gold currencies of Europe dominated the securities markets here this week and, although German stocks had a tone that was fundamentally firm, there were sharp temporary reactions.

As the site for a new one-story taxpayer the property at the northeast corner of Gedney Way and Pleasant Avenue, White Plains, has been purchased by a syndicate headed by Nathan Wilson and William H. Jeffers, operators. The plot has a frontage of sixty-five feet and is near the Gedney Way railroad station.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., June 7. -- Dean Robert Russell Wicks of the Princeton University Chapel, delivering the baccalaureate sermon at Mount Holyoke College here today, called upon his listeners in Mary Lyon Chapel to unite with the rest of the world for the promotion of a real league of common security.

A survey of 121 educators throughout the State indicated that 70 per cent of them were dissatisfied with the standards of teaching civics, it was announced yesterday by the National Self Government Committee.

With the greatest volume of trading in many months, prices of new crop cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange last week recorded net gains of 25 to 35 points. The old crop July contract, which was subjected to liquidation by the producers' pool, advanced only 6 points.

CHICAGO, June 7. -- Speculative interest in the wheat market was kept on edge last week, resulting in a reduction in outside business and a disposition by traders to sell the market short on all sharp bulges. The volume of outside business on the Board of Trade was so limited that the trade was disposed to take small profits and work in and out of the market.
Steps to cope with the pollution of Flushing Bay -- characterized as a menace to the 1939 World's Fair -- have been taken by the Merchants Association of New York, it was announced yesterday.

The names of 1,421 youths who have been picked by the army to attend the Citizens Military Training Camp at Plattsburg Barracks, N.Y., were made public yesterday by Major General Frank R. McCoy, commander of the Second Corps Area, with headquarters at Governors Island.
CLEVELAND, June 7. -- Godfrey G. Gloom, the veteran Hoosier Democrat, was discovered by a Times reporter this afternoon painfully easing his aged frame into an easy chair in a hotel lobby.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 7. -- A crowd estimated at 250,000, including President Vargas and other notables, found vantage points on the famous Gavea Circuit today to witness the annual international automobile race, in which the Argentine drivers, Cappoli and Caru, finished first and second respectively.

BOSTON, June 7. -- Young and trained college graduates must go into politics to replace professional politicians if the country is successfully to meet changing conditions, the Rev. Dr. Russell Henry Stafford, pastor of the Old South Church, told the class of 1936 of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in his baccalaureate sermon today.

The former silk mill at 166-186 West Fifty-second Street, Bayonne, N.J., has been sold by Benjamin Silverman to the Fifty-second Street Company, which in turn leased the plant to Ershler Krukin, Inc., manufacturers of stainless steel kitchen and restaurant equipment, who plan to move from North Bergen in an expansion of their manufacturing facilities.

PHILADELPHIA, June 7 (AP). -- St. Louis made it two of three from the Athletics today by taking advantage of Gordon Rhodes's wildness, putting eight hits together with nine passes and three errors for a 9-5 victory.
Forty weeks of lost New York history have come to light in a file of the city's first newspaper just presented to the New York Public Library by George F. Baker, a trustee.

CLEVELAND, June 7. -- Caucuses and electioneering ran a poor second today in the Republican convention city to the competition provided by the garden party at the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Chester Bolton at Lindhurst. Intermittent showers descended alike on the prominent and the obscure among the 700 assembled, scattering the guests twice within an hour, but long before the notables had departed the rain had stopped.

Two mortgages held by the Emigrant Bank from the Almor Operating Corp., ,forr/s Solomon, president, have been consolidated as a single first lien for $29,813 on 416 E. 15th St. and extended to May 31, 1941, at 4 per cent.

WASHINGTON, June 7. -- A proposal for industry, labor and other economic units to contribute to the solution of social and related problems was made tonight by the Rev. Edmund A. Walsh, vice president of Georgetown University, in a commencement address to the graduates.

NEWARK, N.J., June 7. -- The Newark Bears tightened their grip on first place in the International League today with a double victory over the Montreal Royals before 9,000. The scores were 5 -- 4 and 4 -- 3.

With King Saxon slated to run in the featured Queens County Handicap, the Summer meeting at Aqueduct will begin today to run for twenty-two racing days. Seven events are on the opeing program, which in addition to a fine field in the main event finds Goldey F. named in a five-furlong dash for fillies.

At Cleveland, ex-Senator MOSES as champion of the Knox candidacy is in a state of disgust. He never saw anything like it. The London managers have the effrontery to claim that they have a majority of the delegates already in hand, that they can name all the committees and write the platform.

ST. PETER, Minn., June 7 (AP). -- Sixteen inmates of the criminal ward of the St. Peter State Insane Asylum, led by a former Barker-Karpis gangster, escaped tonight after slugging five guards. Five hours later fourteen of them still were at large.

Chief Fire Marshal Thomas P. Brophy, his aides and more than 100 detectives seemed baffled yesterday by two series of early morning fires -- four blazes in Harlem and four in the Bronx -- in old-law tenements crowded with families on relief.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 7. --Harry L. Maxwell's twelve-meter one-design sloop Iris came into her own today in the Larchmont Yacht Club's first special Sunday regatta of the season. Both she and H.T. Von Frankenburg's Zio, dragging the propellers of their auxiliary motors, defeated W. Roy Manny's Night Wind with their handicaps.

Bishop William T. Manning visited Welfare Island yesterday afternoon to serve the spiritual needs of the city's wards and patients. On his sixteenth annual Trinity Sunday pilgrimage to the island, he confirmed twenty-seven inmates of institutions there and one woman who journeyed from New Rochelle, N.Y., for the service.

The first World Jewish Congress will make history, honor the Jewish race and promote understanding among the families of the world, Dr. Stephen S. Wise, president of the American Jewish Congress, declared yesterday at a conference of Jewish organizations at the Hotel New Yorker, where 1,000 delegates endorsed the world congress and elected a delegation to represent Manhattan in the national conference in Washington on June 13 and 14.
SHANGHAI, Monday, June 8. -- It was admitted by the Nanking Government today that the Southern situation had become extremely serious. The chances of averting civil war were considered slight.
ROME, June 7 (AP). -- King Victor Emmanuel, newly declared Emperor of Ethiopia, reviewed today thousands of bronzed troops who won him that title in an empire celebration of victory.

ALBANY, June 7. -- Up to June 1 8,303 new stock corporations had been formed in the State this year, the division of corporations of the Department of State revealed today. This total is practically identical with that of a year ago. The total for May was 1,604. It was twenty-four ahead of April and equaled that of May, 1935.

Failure of the War Department Failure to order the removal of a group of old ramparts from the new site of the New York State Merchant Marine Academy at Fort Schuyler has caused the Bronx Board of Trade to invite Mayor La Guardia and a group of civic leaders to visit the site with a view to making formal protest.
CLEVELAND, June 7. -- Young Republicans are preparing for a united front in their party's convention which may cause a clash with the Republican national leadership.
Resales of houses that figured in l a recent upper West Side trade deal featured realty activity in this city over the week-end.

LONDON, June 5. -- The feeling of tension in the foreign-exchange market here has found reflection in abnormally quiet and dull security markets and a rising tendency in money rates. The monetary situation, indeed, is being influenced appreciably by the foreign-currency crisis.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 7. -- To climax as close and as thrilling a contest as has been seen in Long Island polo circles this year. Billy Reynolds scored after five extra minutes of play today on the Meadow Brook Club's Cochrane Field, thereby giving the Hurricanes a 7-to-6 triumph over East Williston.

Success in life cannot be complete unless the ideals of Catholic training are followed, Manhattan College's graduating class was told yesterday by the Rev. Dennis P. Coleman at baccalaureate services in De La Salle Chapel on the campus.

Instructions relating to the cashing of the bonds that are to be issued in payment of the veterans' bonus were contained in regulations of the Treasury Department received here yesterday. Bonds transmitted to the United States Treasurer for payment must be signed in the presence of one of an authorized list of persons, the regulations stated, and must be certified by this authorized person.

The report of the City College administrative committee of the Board of Higher Education on its four-month inquiry into the fitness of Dr. Frederick B. Robinson to continue as president of the college became a center of controversy last night, forty-eight hours before formal submission of the report to the board.

LEWISBURG, Pa., June 7. -- "The Christian Church is the greatest agency in American life," Arnaud C. Marts, acting president of Bucknell University, told the graduating class in his baccalaureate sermon today.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 7. -- Mr. and Mrs. Francis Taylor, who had Mr. and Mrs. Sigourney Thayer, Miss Fernanda de Mohrenschildt, Miss Virginia Cowles, Julian M. Gerard Jr. and Bertram de N. Cruger as their guests over the week-end, entertained at their home today.

ALBANY, June 7. -- New Yorkers who buy liquor at Cuba, Nassau, Bermuda and other West Indian islands will hereafter be informed of the fact that liquor from other States or foreign countries is subject to a $1 a gallon State tax. Mark Graves, Commissioner of Taxation and Finance, said tonight that two Federal departments have joined with this State to protect tourists from "misleading literature and statements" of liquor dealers.

RYE, N.Y., June 7. -- With a crowd of more than 8,000 in attendance, one of the largest assemblages ever to witness an outdoor horse show in the East, a colorful program of exhibitions by the United States Olympic equestrian team and a military pageant were staged on the spacious Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club grounds today.

It is against the best interests of England to injure the Jewish position in Palestine, Professor Albert Einstein said in a message read last night at a dinner celebrating the eighteenth anniversary of the Jewish Teachers Seminary and the first anniversary of the charter granted the Jewish People's University.

There is not a semblance of Catholic thought in the business or professional world despite the fact that one-sixth of the country's population is Catholic, the Rev. Francis X. Fitzgibbon, '25, told 400 members of the graduating class of Fordham College at the baccalaureate services of Fordham University held yesterday morning in the university church.

The month of June signalizes the appearance of the first surface-feeding species of salt-water game fish in our near-by waters. Within the next few weeks we can look for reports of swordfish being sighted by commercial harpooners off Montauk or Block Island.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 7. -- John Hay (Jock) Whitney's Greentree riders overpowered the Roslyn quartet, 15 -- 5, today as high-goal polo was ushered in on the field of the Sands Point Club. The contest, which was a first-round affair in the third Westbury Challenge Cup competition, was staged for the benefit of the Hospital for Ruptured and Crippled Children.

The big task at Cleveland, it is said, will not be choosing the candidate but writing the platform. And the two most difficult planks in the platform, it is said, will be the farm plank and the recovery plank. How would it do, then, to combine the two problems in one by writing a plank denouncing the American farmers as the real money-changers of the country?

BOSTON, June 7 (AP). -- Mike Kreevich's home run with the bases full in the sixth broke up the game with the Red Sox today before 26,500 and gave the White Sox their first victory in nine starts this season against Boston, 13-5. The defeat snapped a Boston winning streak at five games.
LIMA, Peru, June 7. -- The Constituent Assembly recessed early today to clear the field for the electoral campaign. It will meet in a brief session July 28 in accordance with the Constitution.

Charles (Lucky Luciano) Lucania and eight co-defendants who undertook to organize vice in this city on a racket basis were found guilty of compulsory prostitution in a verdict returned at 5:25 o'clock yesterday morning.

A tribute to Denmark, citing the long-standing amity between that country and the United States, was made yesterday by Stanley H. Howe, executive secretary to Mayor La Guardia, in an international broadcast.

CLEVELAND, June 7. -- The pre-convention drive of Landon supporters for a liberal Republican party platform endorsing the necessity of social and economic reforms under control of the States was developing into a landslide movement today following Herbert Hoover's proposal for a constitutional amendment, if that was necessary, to give the States control over wages, hours and working conditions.

AURORA, N.Y., June 7. -- Dr. Kerr Duncan Macmillan, president of Wells College, in his baccalaureate sermon to the forty-two young women in the institution's graduating class here today, questioned the Christianity of American colleges and universities and whether they measured up to the standard set by Jesus.

In the name of fair play and impartiality, why does THE NEW YORK TIMES persist in assailing the President's proposed high tax on undistributed corporate profits, without also fairly stating the claimed benefits of the new tax and admitting its deep-seated social significance?

TRENTON, N.J., June 7 (AP). -- The prospect that Walter Evans Edge, former Ambassador to France, might be considered for the Vice Presidential nomination occupied attention today of the New Jersey delegation to the Republican National Convention at Cleveland.

SCHENECTADY, June 7. -- Dr. Dixon Ryan Fox, president of Union College, uttering "a kind word for the Puritan" today in his baccalaureate address, urged the 147 students who will be graduated tomorrow to emulate the Puritans in integrity, courage and "high purpose."

George Selkirk strode to the plate at the Stadium yesterday and with one lusty blow into the right-field bleachers brought to an end a thrilling sixteen-inning duel between Charley (Red) Ruffing and Oral Hildebrand, the Yankees defeating the Indians, 5 to 4.

The 35,000 school teachers of the city are being enlisted in support of the campaign of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee for $1,500,000 to help recognized family welfare agencies. The teachers have been asked to contribute through the municipal employes' committee, headed by the Rev. Father Joseph McCaffrey, police chaplain.

Only one play -- "Ghosts" -- had been scheduled to close last Saturday night, but when the time came three others decided to wander away, too -- "May Wine," "One Good Year'' and "A Private Affair.'' Their respective opening dates were Dec. 5, Nov. 27 and May 13. . . .

CHICAGO, June 7. -- Prices of hogs moved up sharply here last week, sales on Friday at $10.25 a hundred-weight for the best light weights being the highest in four weeks. Packing sows declined 35 to 50 cents, due to heavy marketing. Light and medium weight sows, 275 to 350 pounds, sold at $8.75 to $9.10.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., June 7. -- "Only those populations capable of adult life will continue to captain their own souls," said President Henry T. Moore in his baccalaureate address to the senior class at Skidmore College here this afternoon.
NORTHPORT, L.I., June 7. -- Twelve men and women clinging to a grounded sailboat were rescued here today by Coast Guardsmen who rowed nearly a mile in a choppy sea to save them.

WASHINGTON, June 7. -- President Roosevelt returned to the capital at 1:05 o'clock this afternoon from the funeral of Speaker Byrns at Nashville yesterday afternoon. He went at once to the White House, where he planned to put the finishing touches on the speeches that he will make during the tour of the Southwest, which he will start at midnight tomorrow.
Frank Cist, writing to THE NEW YORK TIMES on technological shifts, neglects two main points regarding technological displacement and non-absorption of labor:

CLEVELAND, June 7. -- On the general charge that mere political expediency has animated the bandwagon rush toward Governor Landon of Kansas and most of the platform proposals which have come from his spokesmen, the opposition to his nomination began work in earnest today to prevent his nomination.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., June 7. -- The first national assembly of the Oxford Group closed a ten-day session here today and announced the opening of a country-wide campaign to convince America that this group contains "the only sane people in an insane world."
The Encyclopaedia Britannica announced with some breathlessness yesterday that the Dionne quintuplets had "made" the new printing of the fourteenth edition of the work.
Frank Cist, writing to THE NEW YORK TIMES on technological shifts, neglects two main points regarding technological displacement and non-absorption of labor:

A total of 462 degrees and five certificates will be awarded to graduates of St. John's University School of Law at the commencement exercises tomorrow morning at 10 o'clock at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

PARIS, June 8. -- Without devaluation of the franc Premier Leon Blum's program for industrial recovery and social reform is not possible, in the opinion of most of the manufacturers who will be hit by the 7 to 15 per cent wage increases agreed to last night when the basis of a settlement of France's widespread strikes was reached.

MOSCOW, June 8. -- Jose R. Capablanca's victory in the international chess tournament was achieved without the loss of a game. His closest call was in the seventh round against Mikhail M. Botwinnik. The Cuban won the match but might easily have lost if his opponent had not been under the pressure of the time limit.

CLEVELAND, June 8. -- In their own fashion and their own haunts, feminine politics were seething in Cleveland tonight. Several longtime careers in the arena dwindled to oblivion as new ambitions and new personalities bobbed up in the race for the coveted positions on important committees and the offices of National Committeewoman.

Harlem's accomplishments under WPA auspices were put on display last night at the opening of a six-day festival and exhibit in St. Mark's Methodist Episcopal Church, 137th Street and St. Nicholas Avenue.

CLEVELAND, June 8. -- Purchase of the Canton Tin Plate Corporation of Canton, Ohio, as of July 1, for an unnamed cash consideration, was announced today by the Republic Steel Corporation. The transaction is subject to corporate approval.

As an aftermath of the compulsory prostitution trial in which Charles (Lucky Luciano) Lucania and eight other racketeers were convicted Sunday morning, Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey last night sent to the City Bar Association the names of two lawyers for disciplinary action.

CHICAGO, June 8 (AP). -- Knocked out in each of his last six starts, Lefty French finally righted himself today and shut out the Phillies with eight hits to give the Cubs the opening game of the series, 3 to 0. It was the fifth straight victory for the reviving National League champions.

LONDON, June 8. -- The financial editor of The Times found indications in the London money market late tonight that Premier Leon Blum's policy had not restored confidence in the future of the franc, although he thinks it may check the flight of capital from Paris temporarily.

POUGHKEEPSIE, June 8. -- Education and social freedom for women have made the goal of life only more accessible and have not guaranteed its attainment, Vassar College graduates were told today by Dr. Alan Valentine, president of the University of Rochester and the commencement speaker.

There is one principle of modern highway construction that cannot be emphasized too strongly. It is this: that if the highway is designed to be ornamental as well as useful, the landscape architect must be called in at the beginning, and must work hand-in-hand with the engineer.

The graduating class of the Fordham College of Pharmacy was urged to take a firm stand against the use of harmful drugs and unethical practices by Dr. Harold Brown Keyes of French Hospital in his address at the twenty-second commencement exercises of the college last night in Fordham University gymnasium.

The Board of Higher Education will be asked tonight by two of its Fusion members to order continuation of the investigation by the board's City College administrative committee into the fitness of Dr. Frederick B. Robinson, president of the college.

TRENTON, N.J., June 8. -- Major Charles H. Schoeffel, deputy superintendent of the New Jersey State Police, took an "indefinite" leave of absence today after officials conferred to determine if his tenure expired with that of Colonel H. Norman Schwarzkopf.

WASHINGTON, Tuesday, June 9. -- President Roosevelt, after a busy day at the White House, left Washington a few minutes after midnight on a 4,000-mile tour into the Southwest which he has insisted is not political.
Another fishing superstition went into the discard when Francis G. Geer, 20-year-old Yale oarsman, landed a 380-pounci broadbill swordfish, first of the season, off Manasquan, N.J., last Saturday.
SALEM, N.H., June 8. -- A thrilling stretch drive gave Donald Christmas's sprinter Accolade victory in the Panzaretta Handicap, six-furlong feature event at Rockingham Park today.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., June 8. -- A suggestion that world peace would come nearer reality "if statesmen would face war as physicians face disease" was offered at the Bryn Mawr College commencement exercises by Dr. Alice Hamilton, special consultant of the Department of Labor and the Public Health Service.

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on June 3 shows an increase for the week of $334,000,000 in total loans and investments and a decline of $96,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks and an increase of $135,000, 000 in deposit balances standing to the credit of domestic banks.

With the price of potatoes at least twice as high as it has been in the past ten years, there was no dispute yesterday among government market experts and dealers that a real scarcity exists all over the country as well as in New York. There was a divided opinion on how long the condition will continue.

TOPEKA, In., June 8. -- Governor Landon, before motoring the J twenty-eight miles to the UniversityI of Ifansas to speak tonight, wentj calmly about the business of being J "the Governor of a typical prairie J State," seemingly unaware of the. convention in Cleveland.
BOSTON, June 8 (AP). -- Mrs. Elizabeth Cadwell Tomlinson of Boston became president today of the Christian Science Mother Church.

CLEVELAND, June 8. -- The Republican National Convention is to assemble in the auditorium by Lake Erie at 11 o'clock tomorrow morning and the preliminary manoeuvres ended tonight with only three factors standing in the path of the nomination of Governor Alfred M. Landon for President on the first ballot.

CLEVELAND, June 8. -- Godfrey G. Gloom, the veteran Democrat from Amity, Ind., ran into a TIMES reporter this afternoon in the crowd that was swarming down a narrow corridor after the Borah press conference.

WITH PENNSYLVANIA REPUBLICAN DELEGATION, EN ROUTE TO CLEVELAND, June 8. -- A drive to capture the Republican Vice Presidential nomination for Justice George W. Maxey of the Pennsylvania Supreme Court got under way today as the State's delegation to the party's national convention started for Cleveland.
Value of Dollar in Exchange The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

PARIS, June 8. -- Yugoslavia, a comparative newcomer to international team tennis, landed in the semi-final round of the European Zone Davis Cup competition for the first time today as Ferenc Puncec scored a major victory over Christian Boussus and sent France tumbling to a 3-2 defeat.
BLAIRSTOWN, N.J., June 8. -- Commencement exercises of Blair Academy were held here today. Fifty-seven graduates received diplomas from Dr. Charles H. Breed, the headmaster.

One hundred and six contributors from fourteen States had material in the 1936 edition of The Bawl Street Journal, just issued. About half of the contributors are associated with Wall Street firms or publications, while eleven are members of the Bond Club of New York, whose annual field day held last Friday in Scarborough, is the occasion for the publication.

Mr. WILLIAM ALLEN WHITE is a man of impulsive benevolence. He was disappointed and even shocked, as were millions of other Americans, at the decision of the Supreme Court invalidating the New York law guaranteeing minimum wages for women workers. Mr. WHITE at once wrote in his Emporia newspaper that the Constitution should be so amended as to permit the freest scope, in both State and nation, for "social welfare."
UNION CITY, N.J., June 8. -- Six firemen were overcome by smoke here tonight when a spectacular fire wrecked seven stores and a factory and damaged an equal number of buildings.

TRENTON, N.J., June 8. -- Factory employment and payrolls in New Jersey continued to show increases during April, John J. Toohey, State Labor Commissioner, reported today. The gain in employment was eight-tenths of 1 per cent, sending the number of workers in 753 plants to 226.301, an increase of 1,723, and advancing the weekly payroll to $5,288,075, an improvement of $79,194.

La Salle Academy will graduate 107 boys tonight at the annual exercises to be held in the Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street. The speaker will be John F.X. McGohey, Assistant State Attorney General. Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral, will preside.

John Henry Lewis, with his world light-heavyweight crown not at stake, easily outpointed John Anderson of Sweden in a ten-round bout last night at Dexter Park, Woodhaven, before a crowd of 3,000. Lewis weighed 180 pounds and Anderson 176 3/4.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 8. -- In spite of one of the hottest days yet encountered by the crews training for the intercollegiate regatta on June 22 all hands put in two good workouts again today and at least one eight rowed against the watch.

IF it's the last thing he does before going off the reservation, Captain Pat Echols of West Point is determined to make clear to all and sundry that the modern pentathlon in Olympic competition is the greatest all-around event on any athletic calendar.

MOSCOW, June 8. -- Jose R. Capablanca of Cuba, former chess champion of the world, staged a great comeback tonight by winning the international masters tournament here against nine outstanding experts.

WORCESTER, Mass., June 8. -- Ninety per cent of the people are "functionally illiterate" and their taste in reading does not extend beyond "cheap drugstore magazine literature," said Dr. Irving Maurer, president of Beloit College, in addressing 113 graduates of Worcester Academy, parents and friends at the 102d commencement exercises this morning.

Exercising his rarely used prerogative as chief magistrate of the city, Mayor La Guardia issued a summons yesterday charging criminal libel against Robert E. Edmondson, who sends out anti-Jewish literature from a printing shop at 80 Washington Street where he has desk room.

Samples of a natural poison so powerful that a few drops under the skin will cause instant death, used by Indians in British Guiana, South America, for poisoning arrows, were brought to New York in large quantities yesterday by Dr. William Hall Holden, surgeon. Dr. Holden returned from a two months' expedition to study native medicines for the American Museum of Natural History.

PITTSBURGH, June 8. -- Liberalization of the educational program in technology so as to assure to engineers a thorough understanding of the social implications of their work was set today as his major objective by Robert Ernest Doherty, recently elected president of the Carnegie Institute of Technology. He spoke at the commencement exercises.

A Summer trip to her birthplace in Sweden and later a new home here, and a baby, have suddenly been planned by Mrs. Clementina Anderson, a housemaid, and her husband, Ivar, a chauffeur. It all came about because Mrs. Anderson received a check for $37,500 yesterday morning as first-prize winner in the Third Grand National Treasure Hunt contest.

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- E. Claude Babcock, president of the American Federation of Government Employes, suffered a heart attack today at a meeting of the executive council of his union after his council had decided to begin proceedings preliminary to recalling him from office.

One Sunday morning in June fifty years ago the belfry of St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church in the Village of Flushing, Queens, sent forth ringing notes of unusual insistence. Charles Carrol Wilson, 17-year-old youth who served as assistant sexton to the parish, was hauling on the bell rope for the first time and enjoying the experience.

CLEVELAND, June 8. -- Nomination of Governor Landon of Kansas on an early ballot, probably the first, was indicated by an independent poll made by THE NEW YORK TIMES today of the fifty-three State and Territorial delegations.

Formation of a committee of lawyers to cooperate with labor and other organizations in redrafting the Minimum Wage Law, declared unconstitutional by the Supreme Court, was urged yesterday by Professor Herman A. Gray, chairman of the New York Unemployment Insurance State Advisory Council and an authority on social legislation.

NEWARK, N.J., June 8. -- Marvin Duke, pitching his first complete game in five weeks, hurled Newark to a 3-to-1 victory over Montreal today to make it three in a row for the Bears in the current series.
DETROIT, June 8. -- Dayton Dean and twelve others were bound over today for trial on murder and kidnapping charges in the Black Legion slaying of Charles A. Poole.

CLEVELAND, June 8. -- Today the crowds are here, a cross-section of American men and women, moving like herded cattle, milling around in the hotel lobbies, drifting aimlessly through the corridors, peeking into the newspaper workrooms on the upper floors of the hotel, mistaking them for smoke-filled rooms of plotting statesmen.

CLEVELAND, June 8. -- The National League of Women Voters, at a luncheon today, acclaimed one victory and predicted another in opening their battle for a plank committing the Republican party to support of a system of trained personnel in civil service.

CLINTON, N.J., June 8. -- Prosecutor Anthony M. Hauck of Hunterdon County today turned over to a representative of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh the $14,665 of ransom money which ever since the arrest of Bruno Richard Hauptmann has been held as evidence by the State of New Jersey.

Despite the designation of last week as Safety Week by Governor Lehman, motor accidents, deaths and injuries rose here during that time for the first time in many weeks, compared to those of the corresponding period of last year. The official figures of the New York Police Department showed increases in all tables except that of the deaths occurring over the weekend.

PITTSBURGH, June 8. -- For the second successive day Professor Casey Stengel had to watch his Dodgers lose a game in the ninth inning. Yesterday in Chicago the winning run was forced in by a pass. Today Woody Jensen carried it across on a fumble by Junior Frey, one more misplay to add to his imposing total.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP). -- Secretary Dern issued a sharp reprimand today to Lieut. Col. Edward L. Hoffman of the Army Air Corps for "concealing" from his superior officers an alleged connection with Safe Aircraft, Inc., and the Triangle Parachute Company of Cincinnati.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., June 8. -- Declaring that "the unscrupulous politician can be beaten or circumvented only by constantly watchful opinion, expressed at the correct time and in the strategic quarter," Governor Wilbur L. Cross stressed the necessity for active interest in politics in an address to the graduating class of Swarthmore College at commencement exercises today.
