DETROIT, June 8. -- In today's issue of his publication, "Social Justice," the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin tells why he "cannot support the New Deal."

CAMP NO. 1, Mt. Everest, Tibet, June 8. -- After two avalanches almost cost the lives of two members of our expedition, it was decided today that any attempt on Mt. Everest's unscaled summit by the only known route must be abandoned this year.

Mrs. Ethel S. Cohen, Zionist leader and the mother of a 9-year-old son, will be graduated from New York University tomorrow summa cum laude, the highest ranking woman student of Washington Square College. Three other mothers, one a grandmother, also are members of the class.

CLEVELAND, June 8. -- The hand-shakers and the whisperers had their last fling today as the delegates to the Republican National Convention pinned on their badges and prepared to meet in public sessions, in which their leaders say there is the gravest crisis in the nation's history since Abraham Lincoln was nominated by the famous Wigwam convention at Chicago in 1860.

Two of the city's few remaining milestones that were set up early in the nineteenth century to give directions and distances to the seat of constitutional authority will be presented in formal ceremonies today by the city to the Museum of the City of New York.

ALBANY, June 8. -- Banks and trust companies are authorized to establish personal loan departments under the provisions of the Stephens bill which Governor Lehman signed tonight. The act fixes interest rates at not to exceed 12 per cent per annum.
Veterans who wish to cash their bonus bonds next week will not be required to bring any witnesses with them, Postmaster Albert Goldman announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 8. -- President Roosevelt today appointed Vincent L. Leibell, a New York attorney, to a vacant judgeship on the Federal bench for the Southern District of New York.

LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., June 8. -- Edward S. Harkness, New York philanthropist and financier, has given funds to Lawrenceville School to permit the introduction of a new system of small-group instruction, it was announced here today by Allan V. Heely, head master of the school, at the opening of its 126tlx annual commencement week.
RENO, June 8. -- Malvina C. Hoffman Grimson, a sculptress of New York and Chicago, obtained a divorce here from Samuel B. today Grimson on charges of desertion.

Trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange was routine in character with speculative interest at a minimum as the trading pace slackened to one of the quietest days in several weeks. The undertone, however, held firm with fractional advances outnumbering the declines at the end of the day.

Eight young men, the largest number ever licensed to preach by the Presbytery of New York at one time, were accepted at a meeting of that body yesterday afternoon in the parish house of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street.

Plans for expansion of several of its units in Manhattan have been announced by Restaurants Longchamps. The company reported yesterday that it had taken a long lease on the store and basement in the Chanin Building, at the southwest corner of Lexington Avenue and Forty-second Street, which has been occupied by Broadstreet's.
Headed by Mrs. H. Walter Blumenthal, the former Baroness Levi, a field of forty players started out yesterday in the women's New York State championship at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club, Queens.

Statistics issued by the automobile and steel industries yesterday indicated that the normal seasonal decline in sales and production has been of less than the usual proportions. Steel operations actually are increasing this week, whereas normally June is a month of steadily contracting output.

From Washington come reports of a sudden show of interest on the part of Democratic leaders in a bill designed to put all regular Government employes under civil service. It would affect not only the higher classes of postmaster-ships, which are now exempt from civil service regulations, but also positions in all other governmental agencies with the exception of those which expire on fixed dates and those which were set up by Executive order.

" I come from a State." * * * "The peerless orator, patriot and statesman." Already there is a taste of honey in the mouth. Flowers of speech faintly perfume the air. Nominators and seconders at Cleveland will soon go through the ancient ritual. At least one hopes so. It is too good to lose.

MONTREAL, June 8 (Canadian Press). -- Dividends of $14,985,000 were drawn to date by twelve members of an original syndicate which in 1905 invested $500,000 in common stock of the Dominion Textile Company, Ltd., it was disclosed today by Sir Herbert Holt, who had been called to give evidence to the Turgeon Commission investigating the industry.

SEATTLE, Wash., June 8. -- Fifteen hundred delegates to the four-day annual convention of the American Institute of Banking arrived here today on six special trains and by airplane, automobile and ship from all parts of the United States.

PARIS, June 8. -- In order to get first-hand information regarding the situation and opinion in each of the principal European countries, Premier Leon Blum and Foreign Minister Yvon Delbos have begun a series of conferences with France's Ambassadors.

No solution of the nation's slum problem can be expected "until the primacy of public interests over private interests in property is recognized." it is asserted in a study of model housing in the United States prepared by Professor James Ford of Harvard University and being issued today in two volumes by the Harvard University Press.

The twenty-ninth annual commencement exercises of the Fordham University School of Law will be held at 11 o'clock this morning on the terrace of Keating Hall at Fordham. The degree of Bachelor of Laws will he conferred upon 257 men and women members of the graduating class.

CLEVELAND, June 8. -- Expressing special interest in the Republican platform planks on foreign affairs, monopoly and currency, Senator Borah declared today that if his planks were accepted and the party's Presidential nominee fitted the platform, he would support him.

CHICAGO, June 8. -- Charges that the Roosevelt administration is aiming again at regimentation and price fixing, such as was embodied in the NRA, were made here today by Professor Malcolm P. McNair, director of research of the Harvard University Graduate School of Business Administration.
NANKING, China, June 8 (AP). -- The most powerful man in China, Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, virtual dictator of the Nanking National Government, sharply opposed tonight a war against Japan.
MADISON, N.J., June 8. -- More than 350 men took part in the annual alumni day exercises at Drew University here today. The alumni association also met and elected officers.

PAULSBORO, N.J., June 8. -- A 70-year-old watchman risked his life early this morning and was beaten unconscious by thieves when he worked loose his bonds and blew a factory siren. His efforts were futile. The police failed to hear the alarm and the thieves escaped with $10,000 worth of machinery and dresses.

NORTHFIELD, Vt., June 8. -- A warning against "befuddled dreamers" and "preachers of despair" was sounded by William P. MacCracken Jr. of Chicago, former Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Aeronautics, in an address to the graduating class of Norwich University today.

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- Senator James Hamilton Lewis of Illinois predicted today that the French, British and Italian Governments soon would make new proposals for settlement of their war debts to the United States. Senator Lewis has long been a bitter critic of defaulting nations.

The question of whether the two-cents-a-mile rate will become effective immediately on the Long Island Railroad within this city will be decided today before Supreme Court Justice George H. Furman in Brooklyn.

With moisture in the areas in the Eastern cotton belt for the first time in several weeks, prices on the Cotton Exchange were set back in early trading yesterday, but selling pressure was so light that a steady recovery the balance of the session left the list unchanged to 8 points higher than on Saturday.

BELLMORE, L.I., June 8. -- A man and wife were killed here today by escaping illuminating gas which exploded and wrecked their home at 15 Smith Court. Although gas jets on a stove were open, the police listed the deaths and explosion as accidental.

SHAWNEE-ON-DELAWARE, Pa., June 8. -- Tony Manero, the new national open golf champion, began to recover his batting eye today when he clipped four strokes off the score he made in the initial round of the nineteenth Shawnee open tourney.

Broadcasting from the Republican National Convention at Cleveland is scheduled to begin today at 11:30 A.M., Eastern daylight saving time, over a record-breaking hook-up of more than 200 transmitters. The New York outlets will be WEAF, WOR, WJZ and WABC.
Housing properties made up the bulk of the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.
The Oxford Group brought its first national assembly in America to the Metropolitan Opera House last night in a farewell session for the movement's "international soul-changing team."

CLEVELAND, June 8. -- With the Landon band wagon rolling on apparently almost unimpeded to victory, aspirants for second place on the ticket are filing their petitions and pushing their availability with the managers of the Landon pre-convention campaign.

The news bearing on the stock market yesterday, and over the week-end, was preponderantly favorable, and share prices responded with the best gains since May 26. Many leading issues rose 1 to 3 points on the day, with the steel and farm-equipment groups particularly favored.

Quincy Porter's Third String Quartet and LeRoy J. Robertson's Piano Quintet in A Minor have been chosen for publication this year by the Society for the Publication of American Music, it was announced yesterday. A. Walter Kramer is president of the society.

Sales of cars manufactured by the General Motors Corporation established new high records for May, according to figures covering the month and issued yesterday by the corporation. With the exception of the totals for April, 1936, sales of General Motors cars to consumers and to dealers in the United States were the largest for any month in the corporation's history.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 8. -- Professor Millar Burrows of the faculty of the Yale Divinity School gave the address today to members of the graduating class at the anniversary exercises.

CINCINNATI, June 8. -- The affairs of our Giants in the West, which have been sort of hanging in the balance the past week, took a sharp turn for the worse today as the Terrymen opened a three-game series with the Reds and immediately dropped the first one as though it were a curling iron somebody forgot to switch off.

Dr. John Lovejoy Elliott, senior leader of the New York Society for Ethical Culture and headworker of the Hudson Guild, will preside and make the commencement address tonight at the annual exercises of the School for Printers Apprentices.

GOSPORT, England, June 8. -- T.O.M. Sopwith's 30,000 prospective challenger for the America's Cup in 1937, the Endeavour II, was launched at Camper Nicholson's yard today as Mrs. Sopwith broke a bottle of champagne over the bow.
LONDON, June 8. -- Two occurrences today may have an important bearing on the future of the British Empire, which in turn implies the future of the whole world.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., June 8. -- An alumna back on campus for her fiftieth reunion and a judge of the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals received special recognition at the ninety-ninth commencement exercises of Mount Holyoke College today when President Woolley conferred honorary degrees on Miss Harriet B. Prescott of New York City and Judge Florence Ellinwood Allen of Cleveland.

Emerging from a batting slump that had begun to worry his admirers, Joe DiMaggio set the pace for his Yankee team-mates yesterday at the Stadium as the McCarthymen downed Rogers Hornsby's Browns, 12 -- 3, and the Bronx returned to normalcy.

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- Weather forecasts two or more weeks in advance are in prospect, and the possibility will be the subject of tests by the Smithsonian Institution as soon as an appropriation of $200,000 for seven new solar radiation stations is made available by Congress.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 8. -- Turning in a fine 67, Maurice Walsh, professional at the Sunning-dale Golf Club, and Paul Adler of the same club, took first honors in the pro-amateur tournament today at the Quaker Ridge Golf Club. The event was held under the joint auspices of the Westchester County Golf Association and the Westchester division of the P.G.A.
PHILADELPHIA, June 8 (AP). -- The Athletics beat the White Sox in the initial clash of a three-game series, 5 -- 4, in ten innings today.

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- In a move to smooth over the differences between the Senate and House concerning the 1936 Revenue Bill, President Roosevelt invited to the White House today the Democratic members of the conference committee.

Police and fire officials were frankly balked yesterday in their search for the pyromaniac or pyromaniacs who have set fire to eighteen homes in the Bronx and in Harlem since mid-April, eight of them last Sunday morning.

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- The first of the now routine notices by debtor nations that payments would not be made to the United States when due on June 15 arrived at the State Department today. It was delivered by Sir Ronald Lindsay, the British Ambassador, on behalf of his government.

Twenty-eight years ago John McGovern, who was born on a farm that is now a part of Brooklyn, started work as a street cleaner in a suburban development at the southwest edge of Prospect Park. Last night he stood, bald-headed and slightly stooped, on the platform in the auditorium of Public School 154, at Eleventh Avenue and Windsor Place, and received a gold watch in recognition of his services.

CLEVELAND, June 8. -- Governor Landon favors sound money and will stand on the monetary plank adopted by the Republican National Convention if he is the Presidential nominee, John D.M. Hamilton, his manager, declared tonight in reply to Senator Borah's demand that the Governor state whether he favors returning to the gold standard.

LONDON, June 8. -- A sharp recovery of the gold currencies today brightened the stock markets, and the latter were generally firmer. Wall Street's action on Saturday and improvement in the Continental situation also were favorable factors. British funds met renewed demand.

CLEVELAND, June 8. -- That Landon bandwagon almost turned into a juggernaut tonight for pretty Peggy Ann, who got pulled, pushed, yelled at, photographed and interviewed all within half an hour of her arrival in the Republican convention bailiwick. She took it not only like a soldier but like a lady.

After a moderate slackening of operations in April, construction work in New York City resumed its upward trend during May, according to Dow, Jones Co. The value of permits for the four boroughs of Manhattan, the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens was up 35.5 per cent last month over the same month in 1935, bringing the gain for the year thus far to 41 per cent.

About 1,500 passengers on the municipal ferryboat Manhattan, making a trip between Staten Island and the Battery shortly after 5 o'clock last night, were thrown into excitement as the result of a brawl in which one person was seriously stabbed.

As one of the State-wide committee which, in 1916-17, pushed to its happy conclusion New York's movement for the creation of a State police force, may I have a word today? It is to protest against the tragedy now enacting in New Jersey.

Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's silks again were in front when the Queens County Jockey Club began its Summer meeting at Aqueduct yesterday, as the filly Good Gamble led from end to end of the mile feature and was clearly best by two lengths. She was one of three to carry the cerise and white diamonds, and her stablemate, Good Harvest, was just nosed out of the place by the Western speed star Clang.

PARIS, June 8. -- Although the spread of strikes has been halted and settlements have been reached in the big industries, which removed all threat of danger, the Bourse today was disappointing. The contrast with Friday's market was very marked, and it was evident that the rise on that day in rentes and French industrial values was due in some measure to an expectation that the government would declare for monetary devaluation.

CLEVELAND, June 8. -- The New York delegation to the Republican National Convention rejected tonight the candidacy of former Secretary Ogden L. Mills for member of the resolutions committee from New York and elected in his stead John Taber, veteran Representative in Congress from Auburn.

TOPEKA; Kan., June 8 (AP). -- Stroking brilliantly over the wind-whipped Topeka Country Club course to a sparkling 71, six strokes under women's par, Mrs. Opal S. Hill of Kansas City, defending champion, won medal honors in the eighth annual women's Western open golf tournament today.

ALBANY, June 8. -- Clerical and lay delegates numbering 400 from churches of the United Luthern Synod of New York, which embraces New York, Northern New Jersey and the New England States, gathered for the opening session of the synod's convention tonight.

TOKYO, June 8. -- Informal Anglo-Japanese conversations began today when Sir Frederick Leith-Ross, chief economic adviser to the British Government, saw Lieut. Gen. Rensuke Isogai, Vice Chief of the General Staff.

DES MOINES, June 8 (AP). -- Declaring that college youth are facing a new frontier of living, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt told 190 Drake University graduates and a commencement audience today that to change one's criterion of success from a material standard to one of service was the most successful way of meeting and solving changing world conditions.
Prices of commodity futures were generally higher yesterday. In the cash markets, corn, rye, cocoa, silk and hides were higher, while wheat, oats, butter, eggs and tin were lower.
Monday, June 8, 1936 The money market was uneventful so far as business and rate changes were concerned. The demand for funds was light at prevailing quotations.

When Governor LEHMAN, nearly a year ago, ordered the inquiry which Mr. DEWEY is now directing, he commanded the grand jurors to investigate "racketeering and vice," organized crime, and any connections which might exist between criminals and officers of the law. Justice MCCOOK defined racketeering as "extortion, by "intimidation or otherwise, from a le-"gitimate or illegitimate business."

Sales of the J.C. Penney Company for May and five-month periods constitute a new high record for the corresponding periods in the company's history. May sales amounted to $20,639,830, compared with $16,976,709 in May last year, an increase of 21.6 per cent.

Leo Luckman, a pudgy young man of 27, whose fugitive father is said to have been active in raising the alleged Drukman "slush fund," admitted yesterday that he withdrew $3,000 from his bank account after the murder and gave $2,000 of it to his uncle, Meyer Luckman, without asking any questions or getting any explanations as to why the uncle wanted it.

PHILADELPHIA, June 8. -- Eleven ministers in this area, leaders of the militant Fundamentalists, resigned today by letter from the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America. Three lay members took similar action and two other ministers announced that their resignations would follow.

CANTON, N.Y., June 8. -- Deploring the trend toward "teachers' loyalty oaths," as well as the "exaggeration of the jurisdiction of government," Dr. William Alfred Eddy, president-elect of Hobart College, made a plea at the St. Lawrence University commencement here today for "sharp boundaries to our thinking to distinguish the respective sovereignty of self, society and science."

Lord Duveen of Milbank, international art expert and president of Duveen Bros., Inc., has been sued, with others, for $2,000,000 by Carl W. Hamilton, art collector and dealer, it was disclosed yesterday by a complaint filed in the County Clerk's office.

With the heavy short-interest in the franc in Europe forced to cover yesterday, that currency rose sharply against the pound and the dollar, closing here at the day's high of 6.60 1/2 cents, up 2 1/8 points from Saturday's final quotation. This rate was the highest since May 14.

The plot of "Pinafore" is coming to life at Cleveland. Who does not remember Little Buttercup? Toward the end of the play she reveals her secret and it turns out that the humble sailor Ralph Rackstraw is really the captain of the Pinafore, and Captain Corcoran is really a plain sailor.

CARLISLE, Pa., June 8. -- The annual commencement exercises at Dickinson College were held here today following an academic procession through Dickinson's campus. In the absence of President Fred P. Corson, Dean Ernest A. Vuilleumier presented diplomas to 116 young men and women.

Several specimens of the banting, the wild ox of Indo-China which looks much like the Jersey bull, but with much larger horns and a more vivid coloration of the body, were obtained by the Flieschmann-Clark Expedition of the American Museum of Natural History, it became known yesterday from Dr. James L. Clark on his return to New York.

Your notice of the murals now being painted at the New York County Court House gives no idea of the grandiose conception this dome decoration depicts. Nor does it go into the consummate artistry with which it is wrought.

Net profit of Remington-Rand, Inc., for the fiscal year ended on March 31 was $3,010,288 after depreciation, interest, amortization of discount on debentures and Federal taxes, according to the pamphlet report made public yesterday. After allowing for a full year's dividend requirements on preferred stock outstanding on March 31 and to be issued as of April 1, the profit was equivalent to $1.24 each on 1,380,284 shares of S1-par common stock outstanding.

WINCHESTER, Mass., June 8. -- Mrs. Edward Stevens of Greenwich, Conn., led the contingent of ten metropolitan players through the first round of the fifty-four-hole-medal play Women's Eastern Golf Association championship at the Winchester Country Club today, but her steady 85 wasn't quite good enough to put her up with the Massachusetts and Philadelphia leaders.

Only light realty trading in Manhattan was reported yesterday, the greater activity being in the auction rooms, where five parcels offered in foreclosure were bought in by the mortgagees. Industrial and housing deals were arranged in Brooklyn.

American ships have won back much of the foreign trade which was lost in the years preceding the World War but they can maintain their position only with the aid of government subsidy, according to Charles H.C. Pearsall, president of the Colombian Steamship Company.

LEWISBURG, Pa., June 8. -- Bucknell University today conferred honorary degrees upon Roger Williams Straus of New York and Newton D. Baker of Cleveland, co-chairman of the national conference of Jews and Christians, for their promotion of religious liberty.

Manhattan College will confer 254 degrees in course at its eighty-third commencement exercises today. Patrick Cardinal Hayes, '88, will preside at the ceremonies, which will be held on the campus quadrangle, 242d Street and Spuyten Duyvil Parkway, Riverdale, starting at 3:30 P.M.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 8. -- Government regulation of the four main branches of transportation -- rail, water, highway and air -- was urged today by leaders in those fields at a national transportation conference which was a feature of the annual observance of alumni day at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

Growth of the foreign demand for American scrap iron and steel has led the scrap industry in this country to plan the formation of an association to operate under the Webb-Pomerene Export Trade Act. Papers showing the aims of the association are being prepared and will be presented soon to the Federal Trade Commission, which is in charge of all associations formed under the act.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 8. -- Shozo Wakahara, Waseda University pitcher, retired Yale today without a hit or run and fanned twelve batsmen while his teammates collected ten blows to win by 6 -- 0. The Elis have been blanked before this season, but today's was the first no-hit game pitched on Yale Field since 1933.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 8. -- Harvard's four crews were held up by examinations this morning and the coaches were not able to put the shells overboard until noon. Charley Whiteside had the two varsity eights and the freshmen in charge while Bert Haines had the combination boat to look after.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., June 8. -- Dr. Dixon Ryan Fox, president of Union College, presented honorary degrees to ten leaders in education, government, industry, journalism, literature and the theatre at the commencement exercises today.

Hundreds of commuters as well as long-distance travelers deserted the bustling waiting room in the Pennsylvania Station yesterday afternoon to visit the second annual Spring Flower Show of employes of the Pennsylvania and Long Island railroads in the auditorium of the Young Men's Christian Association on the fourth floor of the terminal.

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission moved today to bring under stricter control the marketing of oil and gas royalty interests in issues of not more than $100,000 by amending its rules so as to provide for the issuance of "suspension orders" to halt the sale where such action is deemed necessary in the public interest.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 8. -- With more than 300 riflemen of the New York State National Guard and Naval Militia taking part, five events were run off here today on the Camp Smith range, with Lieut. Col. Henry E. Sauvet, executive officer, supervising.

CLEVELAND, June 8. -- Further liberalization of the Republican platform to include a strong "anti-monopoly" plank and a fuller acceptance of the views of George N. Peek on farm relief, tariff and currency stabilization were indicated today as those engaged in drafting the principles worked amid controversy.

WEST POINT, June 8. -- The standings of the 276 cadets of the 1936 class of the Military Academy who will be graduated here Friday were announced today, the No. 1 position in the general merit roll going to Cadet O.G. Haywood Jr. He was appointed from the New Jersey National Guard.

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission moved today to bring under stricter control the marketing of oil and gas royalty interests in issues of not more than $100,000 by amending its rules so as to provide for the issuance of "suspension orders" to halt the sale where such action is deemed necessary in the public interest.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 8. -- With more than 300 riflemen of the New York State National Guard and Naval Militia taking part, five events were run off here today on the Camp Smith range, with Lieut. Col. Henry E. Sauvet, executive officer, supervising.

CLEVELAND, June 8. -- Further liberalization of the Republican platform to include a strong "anti-monopoly" plank and a fuller acceptance of the views of George N. Peek on farm relief, tariff and currency stabilization were indicated today as those engaged in drafting the principles worked amid controversy.

WEST POINT, June 8. -- The standings of the 276 cadets of the 1936 class of the Military Academy who will be graduated here Friday were announced today, the No. 1 position in the general merit roll going to Cadet O.G. Haywood Jr. He was appointed from the New Jersey National Guard.
SHANGHAI, Tuesday, June 9.-It is now officially admitted that Southwest China troops are slowly advancing into Southern I-Iunan Province, which is under the Central Government's control.

Two new exhibitions at the Museum of Modern Art will open with private views today and to the public tomorrow. The first, which has been installed on the ground floor, consists of enlarged photographs and plans of modern exposition architecture -- assembled by the museum as a timely contribution to the current interest in plans for a World's Fair in New York in 1939.

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- While some Republican leaders at the Cleveland convention were discussing possible action toward a constitutional amendment for minimum wage laws, an administration lieutenant introduced in the Senate today a proposal vastly broader in scope.

In THE TIMES editorial comment upon Messrs. Baker, Douglas and Wolman's letter you say: "It is very near the truth to say that if we had never had a high protective tariff under the Republicans we should not have got the AAA under the Democrats."

ROCKVILLE, CENTRE, L.I., June 8. -- Scoring an eagle and five birdies on the last twelve holes, R. J. Zipse, Wheatley Hills amateur, and Al (Red) Brosch, Bethpage pro, produced a 66, six below par, to win an amateur-pro tournament of the Long Island Golf Association today.

PITTSBURGH, June 8. -- Sixty-three Bachelor of Arts degrees were conferred at the commencement exercises of Pennsylvania College for Women today. The Rev. Dr. George A. Buttrick of New York City made the commencement address. Dr. Herbert L. Spencer, president, presented degrees.

Now that the fate of the country is to be given into the hands of the political conventions, Katharine Dayton and George S. Kaufman are stepping out. Their "First Lady," which opened away back in November, leaves the Music Box a week from Saturday, carrying with it the season's chief saga of Washington political life.

BASLE, Switzerland, June 8. -- A drift into depreciation of the French franc is foreseen, and feared as worse than deliberate devaluation or deflation, by central bankers, who were here today for the monthly board meeting of the Bank for International Settlement.

BOSTON, June 8 (AP). -- Lefty Grove scored his ninth victory of the season by a 6-3 margin before 23,500 fans today and the Red Sox then collapsed behind Fritz Ostermueller and tossed the second half of the double-header to the Tigers, 12 -- 7.

Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson began hearings yesterday on the application of attorneys and creditors' committees for final fees and allowances, which, if granted, would bring the total to $2,170,000 in the reorganization of the McCrory Stores Corporation.

With the railroads starting both their institutional campaign and promotion of the fare cut to 2 cents a mile, major bus companies are increasing advertising appropriations to publicize their fare reductions, also effective this month. The Greyhound Lines have almost doubled their appropriation for June and are launching a drive, featuring rate reductions in the area east of the Mississippi and north of the Ohio.

RICHMOND, June 8. -- The policy of employing labor upon a yearly basis will be adopted in the next quarter-century in many industries, resulting in removing much of the uncertainty of employment, Henry H. Heimann, executive manager of the National Association of Credit Men, said at the opening of the association's annual convention today.

A banking group headed by Lazard Freres Co., Inc., obtained yesterday the award of a new issue of $1,500,000 of sewer-disposal bonds of the city of Denver, Col., on its bid of 101.085 for 2 1/4s. The bonds, which mature from 1947 to 1956, were reoffered to yield from 1.95 to 2.15 per cent, according to maturity.

ALBANY, June 8. -- New York City residents will have an opportunity to vote in November on the question of a three-Platoon system for members and officers of the Fire Department under the terms of a bill introduced by Senator Jeremiah F. Twomey, of Brooklyn, which was signed tonight.

Part of the peculiar genius of the politician is the discovery of the well known. As a result of the minimum wage decision President Roosevelt has discovered a "no-man's land" in the field of so-called social legislation.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, June 8. -- Twenty persons were killed and more than 700 injured at the gates of the royal palace here today as a grand stand collapsed in view of King Carol and distinguished foreign guests. They were attending a national celebration marking the sixth anniversary of Carol's return to the throne.

LONDON, June 8. -- Great Britain will be forced to take the field for the first game of the international polo series against the United States Wednesday without the services of the eight-goal Indian ace Rao Rajah Hanut Singh, it was announced definitely today.

Mail reorders on women's Summer apparel and accessories received here yesterday were fairly numerous, but volume continued to be held down by the desire of retailers to spur turnover of present stocks before placing additional commitments, Interest in sheer dresses and the "linen-silk" styles of material resembling shantung, was sustained.

The Pennsylvania Electric Company, which is controlled by the Associated Gas and Electric Company, spent $121,000 in fighting enactment of the Public Utility Law of 1935, the report for last year issued yesterday discloses.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 8 (AP). -- J. Gilbert Hall of Orange, N.J., seeded No. 1, and Hobey Hyde of Hartford, defending champion, seeded No. 2, advanced to the third round today at the conclusion of the first day's play in the fiftieth New England tennis tournament.

ABOARD THE LINER QUEEN MARY, En Route to Southampton, England, June 8. -- In the twenty-three hours ending at noon today the Queen Mary covered 670 miles at an average speed of 29.14 knots. The liner's officers expect her to arrive at Southampton at 3 o'clock Wednesday afternoon.
Pedro Montanez scored the most important triumph of his campaign in this country by defeating Frankie Klick, San Francisco boxer, in the feature bout of ten rounds at Dyckman Oval last night.

VIENNA, June 9. -- Sixty thousand members of the Fatherland Front attending today a rally of the organization heard Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg emphasize Austria's desire to maintain friendship with every State, including Germany, on condition that the nation's independence be respected.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 9. -- Coach Hubert Glendon shuffled his oarsmen about several times this evening and when he had finished an entirely new combination had been tossed together in the Columbia varsity shell. Liggitt, in the waist of the boat, was the only man to retain his seat.
The Bronx Department of Buildings took on the appearance of "boom" days yesterday with the filing of plans for six large apartment houses and other structures for that borough.

WASHINGTON, June 9. -- Final subscriptions on the Treasury's June 15 offering of 2 3/4 per cent bonds of 1951-54 and 1 3/8 per cent notes of series 1941 showed a total of $8,079,443,100, of which $2,130,896,350 was allotted, Secretary Morgenthau announced today.
Additional purchases by the Port of New York Authority for a tube to Manhattan and a factory conveyance were included in the New Jersey transactions reported yesterday.

Charley Gomer of Baltimore gave Petey Caracciola of Bensonhurst his first professional defeat in twenty starts by taking the verdict in the feature six-round bout at the Broadway Arena last night. The victor scaled 138 3/4 to 141 for Caracciola.

RICHMOND, Va., June 9. -- Increased employment and stability for wage earners will result from reciprocal trade agreements made by the Roosevelt administration, Representative Clifton A. Woodrum of Roanoke declared here today in an address in which he said that "the fallacy that high tariffs protect the American wage earner" had been disproved in recent years.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 9. -- The award of three prizes to students in the School of Public and International Affairs at Princeton University was announced today by Professor De Witt Clinton Poole, director of the school.

Six thousand feet scraped rhythmically over the 58,333 hexagonal asphalt blocks that make up the remodeled outdoor floor at the Mall in Central Park last night as the City opened its third successive season of "social dancing."

Mrs. E. Singer Proctor gave a luncheon yesterday in the Japanese Garden of the Ritz-Carlton for Mrs. Ansel Phelps, Mrs. Burgess Gurnee, Mrs. Julian S. H. Humphrys, Mrs. Duncan Sterling and Mrs. Willard S. Brown. Another luncheon there was given by Mrs. Hoppin Pool for Mrs. George Legg, Mrs. William Adams Kissam and Mrs, Pierre C. Cartier.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP). -- Some of the biggest names in the nation's industrial and social lists appear in the Republican National Committee's quarterly financial statement, filed with the House clerk today, showing pre-convention war chest of $220,856.

The five-story apartment house at 147-9 West Tremont Avenue, northeast corner of University Avenue, in the Bronx, has been purchased by an investing client of Samuel Sprung, lawyer, from I. D.S. Meister.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., June 9. -There was a strong possibility tonight that there will be no heavyweight title fight between James J. Braddock and Joe Louis this year, even if the Brown Bomber succeeds in beating Max Schmeling in New York June 18.

WASHINGTON, June 9. -- The Department of Labor and the National Labor Relations Board assigned agents today to investigate the story of an assault on President Sherman Dalrymple of the United Rubber Workers of America at Gadsden, Ala., on Saturday night, after a meeting arranged for employes of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company.
OTTAWA, June 9 (Canadian Press). -- The Dominion Bureau of Statistics today issued its third crop report for the prairie provinces and a report for all of Canada's field crops. The summary said:

Six members of the Charter Revision Commission, speaking last night at the annual meeting of the Citizens Union, made an aggressive defense of the proposed new city charter. It was their first comprehensive reply to critics of the charter since the draft was made public April 26.

A petition seeking the removal of former Supreme Court Justice Stephen Callaghan and former Assistant United States Attorney William T. Cowin, as trustees in reorganization proceedings of the Prudence Company, Inc., was filed yesterday in the Federal court in Brooklyn.

BOSTON, June 9. -- The world champion Tigers sliced another game of the Red Sox second-place advantage today, piling up seven runs in the second inning and whipping the Fenway Millionaires, 8 to 4, before 4,500. Detroit, in third place, now trails Boston by three games and the league-leading Yankees by six.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 9(AP). -- The police guard at Remington Rand Company's Syracuse plant was Increased tonight with the announcement by company officials that they planned to "import 500 strikebreakers" to step into jobs left vacant by employes.

PITTSBURGH, June 9. -- After shuttling back and fourth for weeks between seventh and eighth place the Dodgers today crashed right through to the National League cellar when they dropped a doubleheader to the Pirates and ran their losing streak to six games.

CLEVELAND, June 9. -- The Republican National Convention came near to displacing Colonel Lafayette B. Gleason as its secretary tonight. His name was not on the list of convention officers prepared by the committee on permanent organization, despite the fact that he had been serving in the afternoon as temporary secretary.

Despite the seasonal exodus to the countryside and seashore, a large increase in city apartment rentals was indicated by reports from brokers yesterday. Penthouse and terrace apartment leases were numerous. Many of the tenancies were listed to begin next Fall.

CLEVELAND, June 9 (AP). -- New Jersey convention delegates concentrated today on aligning support in other delegations for Walter E. Edge, former Ambassador to France, for Vice President, and reported "the Edge boom was rolling along."

A class of thirty-five students was graduated by Adelphi Academy in Brooklyn at the commencement exercises held in the auditorium of the school at 282 Lafayette Avenue, Brooklyn, on Monday night. The commencement speaker was Dr. Tertius van Dyke of Washington, Conn., son of Henry van Dyke.

Turning its attention to chamber opera, the WPA Federal Music Project produced two amusing works at the Biltmore Theatre last night. The first was Weber's 125-year old score, "Abu Hassan," and the second was the American premiere of Ernst Toch's "The Princess on the Pea," written about a decade ago.
Pete De Ruzza, 139 1/2, Mamaroneck, N.Y., outboxed Willie Pal, 138 3/4, Albany, in the six-round feature bout at the New York Coliseum last night before 3,000 spectators.

CLEVELAND, June 9. -- When the gavel fell this morning in the huge auditorium for the opening of the Republican convention, one of the most fascinated spectators in the galleries was Miss Peggy Ann Landon, 19-year-old daughter of the Governor of Kansas, who was witnessing her first national political show.

An action to recover $50,000 damages from the State for the death of her brother, who was stabbed by a fellow prisoner in Great Meadows Prison on April 14, 1935, will be brought in Court of Claims this morning by Miss Florence Cronin of 610 Ninth Avenue.
Apartment structures on the upper West Side, houses on the East Side and various commercial buildings were included in the Manhattan realty turnover reported yesterday.

CLEVELAND, June 9. -- The sweetest smelling delegates ever gathered at a Republican national convention met this morning in the Republican Auditorium here with the "Song of Love" from "Blossom Time" as their theme song. Naturally enough the Democratic administration cracked down this afternoon on the ticket scalpers and demanded that they pay the "amusement tax" on the tickets sold for the big show.

PUBLIC AUDITORIUM, CLEVELAND, June 9. -- Before a cheering throng of 12,000 gathered here tonight and over the radio to all citizens of the United States Senator Frederick Steiwer of Oregon sounded the keynote for the coming Republican campaign -- an invitation for all voters to join in a movement "to restore America to the American people."

A suit to recover preferential payments made by Bertrand Coles Neidecker to his wife, Sybil, in 1935, when he and his brother, George, who operated the Travelers Bank in Paris, were insolvent, was filed here yesterday by trustees in bankruptcy for the brothers.

MELBOURNE, June 9. -- The Council of Scientific and Industrial Research, after investigation of the denudation of pastoral country by rabbits, principally in South Australia, concludes that it is impossible to exterminate the rabbit, although more effectual methods of control may be evolved.

Three explosions, occurring at 3:47, 3:50 and 3:52 P.M. yesterday in Broad Street, half a block south of the Stock Exchange, caused considerable excitement in the financial district for a few minutes.

For a few hours yesterday afternoon it seemed as if the single-ticket riders on the Long Island Railroad would be charged only 2 cents a mile for trips within the city. Just after noon Supreme Court Justice George H. Furman in Brooklyn signed a temporary injunction order restraining the railroad from charging the three-cents-a-mile rate.

Two women will receive the highest honors at the thirty-fourth annual commencement exercises of Brooklyn Law School tomorrow morning in the Albee Theatre, 1 Albee Square, Brooklyn. This is the second time in the history of the college and the second consecutive year that women have won the first and second awards.

CHICAGO, June 9. -- Dry goods merchants attending the mid-year conference of the National Retail Dry Goods Association discussed today the social security program, employe relations and the need for safe and economical traffic.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., June 9. -- Thirteen students from New York State were among the more than 600 persons who received degrees today at the sixty-second annual commencement exercises at Purdue University. The entire class numbered about 750, including those who completed their courses last August and in January.
SAN JUAN, P.R., June 9. -- Carlos Marchand Paz, 20 years old, reputedly a Nationalist, was arrested today charged with the murder of Policeman Orlando Colon last Friday.

A drink of furniture polish taken mistakenly for milk, cost the life yesterday of Staten Island's oldest woman resident, Mrs. Mary Curtis, who celebrated her 100th birthday Saturday at the home of her son Patrick Curtis, with whom she lived at 89 Gregg Place, West New Brighton.

PHILADELPHIA, June 9. -- Academic achievements of students at the University of Pennsylvania received recognition in a list of awards announced tonight on the eve of commencement exercises at which degrees in course will be presented to 1,524 persons.

LONDON, June 9. -- The eve of the tenth renewal of the fifty-year-old international polo series between America and England tonight found prospects for a capacity crowd of 10,000, possibly including King Edward, and a sweep by the invaders, who hold the Westchester Cup.

ELMIRA, N.Y., June 9. -- Dr. Carl O. Lange, director of the seventh national soaring contests which open here June 20, said today that the first radio robot meteorological station in the country will be established here in connection with the meet

A mother of ten children will get her law diploma in Providence, R.I., today. The husband and nine of the the children will be present. The youngest will stay at home, being only 6 months old. He could hardly be expected to follow the commencement orator's argument.

For the twenty-third consecutive year Joseph P. Moran was elected yesterday as president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association at the annual meeting at Germania Hall, 160 Third Avenue, near Sixteenth Street. He defeated his only opponent, Patrolman Patrick Harnedy, almost six to one.

CHICAGO, June 9. -- The United States Circuit Court of Appeals entered today an order setting aside the ruling of the Federal Grain Futures Commission which barred Thomas M. Howell, grain speculator, from trading on the country's grain Exchanges for two years.

BALTIMORE, June 9. -- Four hundred and eight seniors of the Johns Hopkins University were warned at their commencement exercises today not to let the fact that they were university graduates become a "menace" to their development. The warning was given by Dr. Isaiah Bowman, the president.

May I be permitted to add my tribute to the many and well-deserved tributes which you and many others have paid to Mgr. Lavelle on the occasion of his eightieth birthday? The cathedral and the monsignor have been synonymous for years beyond numbering.

WASHINGTON, June 9. -- Through their far-flung business and other affiliations, officers and directors of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company have "had some voice in the conduct of companies having total assets of about $34,000,000,000," according to evidence presented to the Federal Communications Commission today at its inquiry into A.T. and T. affairs.

ROME, June 9. -- Premier Benito Mussolini today relinquished three of the seven Cabinet posts he has held for several years, appointing new Ministers in his place. He still retains the portfolios of Internal Affairs, War, Navy and Air and has abandoned those of Foreign Affairs, Colonies and Corporations.

IT should be the Navy's turn today, but the fleet didn't get in. Instead it was a brisk, chunky chap who turned up to discuss matters military and the gentle art of self-defense, not to mention certain methods of counter-attack. It was Lieutenant John Lovell, C.A.C., from away off in Hawaii, pausing here on his way to Berlin, where he will be military adviser to the United States boxing committee at the Olympic Games.

Angelo Rizzo, whose ambition long has been to give to his children the education he lacked, was the happiest man in New York yesterday. He said so himself in words that emanated from the heart but words which would have netted him something less than an A in a grammar class.
CLEVELAND, June 9. -- After all, Republican leaders gave a share in important convention activities to the women today just when they had resigned themselves to isolation on the side-lines.

ALBANY, June 9. -- After a spirited debate on demands for a larger representation of younger members of the Lutheran faith in the annual conclaves of the United Lutheran Church in America, the convention today adopted a recommendation barring clerical delegates from being designated for two successive years.

It seems that a new Republican party is being born at Cleveland, not without the customary pangs. For old stagers not too "sot" in their ways this event is made more tolerable by the presence on the platform of the perpetual and perennial Colonel LAFE GLEASON.

WELLESLEY, Mass., June 9. -- Opening the twenty-fifth and last commencement season of Ellen Fitz Pendleton as President of Wellesley College, her fellow-alumnae will do her special honor on Saturday with a jubilee pageant depicting the growth of the college since its founding in 1870.

WASINGTON, June 9. -- Conversations between Japanese and American diplomats and commercial representatives were held in friendly fashion over a luncheon table today when Acting Secretary of State William Phillips entertained Japanese officials, including Hirosi Saito, Ambassador to the United States, and Saburo Kurusu, new Ambassador to Belgium.
LONDON, May 9. -- Operations on the London Stock Exchange today were again cheerful, although quieter than yesterday.

The heavy fog which came down over the entrance to the harbor at 1 A.M. yesterday stopped the incoming and outgoing shipping for several hours and delayed more than 1,000 passengers from reaching their destinations until afternoon.

SHANGHAI, June 9. -- Four divisions of Kwangsi Province (South China) troops have proceeded twenty-five miles beyond Yengchow and more than forty miles north of the border of Hunan Province without meeting resistance from Central Government armies.

CINCINNATI, June 9. -- After getting himself unhorsed in seven successive starts, Clydell Castleman, the Giants' sensational freshman pitcher of 1935, finally got off his goal line today to pitch his first complete game of the season.

CLEVELAND, June 9. -- A serious revolt by county leaders and delegates favoring the nomination of Governor Landon broke out today in the New York delegation, as a result of the decision of the leaders and the delegation last night to postpone a poll until tomorrow afternoon or later.

The creation of leaders is the most important goal of education, Dr. Frank P. Graves, president of the University of the State of New York and Commissioner of Higher Education in New York State, told the graduating class at Manhattan College in his address at the eighty-third commencement, held on the college quadrangle yesterday.

New York City and the surrounding countryside are being parched by the most serious drought in years. Only partly broken in spots by light, localized showers, the dry spell is playing havoc with truck farms, flower gardens, lawns and golf courses, it was revealed yesterday by reports from the surrounding sections.

The undefeated baseball teams of the Police and Fire Departments marched from the Battery to City Hall yesterday in playing uniforms to be received in City Hall Plaza by Mayor La Guardia, Police Commissioner Valentine and Fire Commissioner McElligott.
ST. LOUIS, June 9 (AP). -- The Cardinals added a game to their first place lead, defeating the Bees, 7 to 5, in the first contest of a short series.

Of 103 participants in the New York Piano Playing Tournament held last week at Aeolian Hall, seven won gold seal certificates with a superior rating -- the highest honors given in the tournament -- it was announced yesterday by Irl Allison, president of the National Guild of Piano Teachers, sponsors of the tournament.
RUMSON, N.J., June 9. -- Edward O'Brien Jr., soloist at the fashionable St. George's-By-The River Protestant Episcopal Church here, shot and killed himself in his home today.

ABOARD THE LINER QUEEN MARY, en route to Cherbourg, France, June 9. -- The Queen Mary has shown remarkably consistent speed on this trip, today's run being 679 miles for the twenty-three hours ending at noon, or the same distance as that covered on the second day of the voyage, for an average speed of 29.52 knots.

MADRID, June 9 (AP). -- The Leftist Spanish Government, determined to end the terrorism that has been sweeping the country since the Feb. 16 elections, announced tonight that it was rushing a draft of a law making the possession of arms and explosives one of the most serious offenses in the penal code.

The board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange is expected this afternoon to select a successor to Ashbel Green, secretary of the Exchange, whose intention of retiring on July 1, was announced a year ago. Robert L. Fisher, an assistant secretary of the Exchange since August, 1933, is understood to have been recommended by the committee on management and personnel to fill the vacancy.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 9. -- A demand that the Board of Supervisors have a new county charter prepared by July 15 or give citizens of the county an explanation for failing to offer a method of reform for county government was made tonight at the annual meeting of the Westchester County Taxpayers Association.

SHAWNEE-ON-DELAWARE, Pa., June 9. -- With 70s on his last two rounds, strapping Ed Dudley, pro at the Philadelphia Country Club and Augusta National, today repeated his 1930 triumph in the Shawnee open golf tournament.

The United American Bosch Corporation reported yesterday for the twelve months ended on March 31 a profit of $188,998 after ordinary taxes, depreciation and other charges, but before Federal taxes. For the preceding twelve months the profit amounted to $55,079.

WASHINGTON, June 9. -- The report of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for April, sent to Congress today, showed that repayments made in that month by various borrowers aggregated $36, 360,333, while new loans actually disbursed in the same period were $21,493,339.

PUBLIC AUDITORIUM, Cleveland, June 9. -- The West took over the Republican National Convention and the party machinery when the delegates assembled for their first session today, and the claim was staked in the name of Alfred M. Landon, Governor of Kansas.

HELSINGFORS, June 9. -- Finland's hopes to be permitted to arrange for the 1940 Olympic Games were further increased when Count Henri de Baillet-Latour, president of the International Olympic Committee, completed his inspection of the country's fitness to organize the games today.

MADISON, N.J., June 9. -- Churches might be better off if instead of always having a message for the world they listened for a while to what is going on in the world, it was said here today by Bishop Francis J. McConnell of the New York area of the Methodist Episcopal Church.

Before yesterday's headlines (about bribery in the vice ring trials) were smudge-proof, the Warner Brothers announced their intention of filming "The Man Behind the Story," about lawyers in league with the lawless. The picture will continue the topical cycle that already includes "The Cave In" (formerly "Draegerman's Courage"), which was inspired by the Canadian mine disaster; "Mountain Justice," suggested by the Maxwell case; "China Clipper" and "Black Legion."
Class day exercises were held at two divisions of New York University yesterday preparatory to the 104th commencement exercises on Ohio Field today.

G. Gordon Gale, president of the Canadian Hydroelectric Corporation, sent yesterday a statement to stockholders of the company in which he said that henceforth its earnings would be affected by a reduction of about $2,000,000 annually in receipts as a result of an adjustment in a contract with the Ontario Hydroelectric Power Commission.

PLANDOME, L.I., June 9. -- Charles H. Mayo Jr. of Lido, who will start the defense of his Long Island amateur golf championship at Seawane on Thursday, led forty contestants today at the Plandome Club with a 76 in a one-day amateur fixture.

As a visitor to the United States, I greatly appreciate the courtesy of the comments of Rene Leon on my recent radio address, which appeared in yesterday's issue of your paper. One or two of his statements, however, seem to ask for a reply. He states:

World production of rayon yarn and staple fiber for 1935 passed the billion-pound mark for the first time in the history of the industry, according to figures compiled and released today by The Rayon Organon, published by the Textile Economics Bureau, Inc.
Two thugs, one of them armed, held up a messenger yesterday in an elevator at 477 Broadway, near Grand Street, and escaped with a $1,900 payroll.

RYE, N.Y., June 9. -- Mark J. Stuart of the home club and Henry N. Robertson of Milbrook tied for the William Henry Beers Memorial Golf Trophy today, posting identical low net scores of 72 in the seventh annual tournament over the west course of the Westshester Country Club.

CHICAGO, June 9. -- Grain traders were more interested in evening up their market commitments on the Board of Trade today, preparatory to the government report, which is due tomorrow than in taking new positions. Prices were confined to narrow limits and at the close wheat futures were 1/4 to 1/2 cent a bushel higher.

British diplomats seem to be busily engaged in preparing for the removal of the chief obstacle to the rebuilding -- perhaps the extension -- of the Stresa front. That alignment, achieved a year ago last April as a new basis for European peace and stability, was the response of Great Britain, France and Italy to one of the most fundamental factors in European international relations -- fear of Germany.

SEATTLE, Wash., June 9. -- Delegates to the thirty-fourth annual convention of the American Institute of Banking had their own keynote speech here today. It was delivered by Lyman E. Wakefield of Minneapolis. It called for a withdrawal of government from business and from interference with the rights of citizens and said that danger was inherent in the worldwide Leftist trend.

It seems that Representatives Sirovich and Kramer, who propose the annexation of Canada and Lower California to the United States, believe that the Black Legion, unemployment and the CCC should extend both North and South. Canada has declined politely to become a member of the American States, and it is hoped that the answer from Mexico will indicate at least a sense of humor.

CLEVELAND, June 9. -- The prayer of invocation as delivered by the Rev. Dr. Albert Joseph McCartney, pastor of the Church (Presbyterian) of the Covenant, Washington, D.C., at the opening of the Republican convention follows:

TOPEKA, Kan., June 9 (AP). -- Upsets and extra-hole matches marked the first round in the women's eighth annual Western open golf tournament today, but still marching along in the favorite's role was the medalist and defending champion, Mrs. Opal S. Hill of Kansas City.

As the result of a dispute between Count Ludwig Salm of Vienna and his former wife, now Millicent Rogers Balcom, over the payment of the tax on the trusts of their son, Peter, under the will of his grandfather, Colonel Henry H. Rogers, Count Salm applied in the Supreme Court yesterday to have her removed as one of the two guardians of the boy and for the appointment of a new guardian.

WASHINGTON, June 9. -- After the House conferees on the Tax Bill notified their Senate colleagues today that they were ready to proceed with consideration of the differing versions of the proposed Revenue Act of 1936, arrangements were made to bring the two groups together tomorrow for the first time.

CLEVELAND, June 9. -- Godfrey G. Gloom, the old-fashioned Jeffersonian Democrat or new-fashioned Jeffersonian Republican, as the case may turn out to be, was discovered today by a TIMES reporter on a curbstone, from which he was contemplating the covered wagon drawn by four oxen that is going about the streets advertising the Landon candidacy.

Miss Norma Taubele, runner-up for the title last year, gained the quarter-final round of the women's New York State championship at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club yesterday with a 6 -- 3, 9 -- 7 victory over Mrs. Paul Haber.

DETROIT, June 9. -- Under plans to carry forward aggressively the Pennsylvania investigation into the Black Legion and similar organizations, N.L. Wymard, Chief Deputy Attorney General of Pennsylvania, and a staff of investigators, including detectives of the Pennsylvania State police, arrived here today to receive from Duncan C. McCrea, Wayne County prosecutor, evidence pertaining to their State. The force was sent by Charles J. Margiotti, Pennsylvania Attorney General.

SWEET BRIAR, Va., June 9. -- "A message from millions of women, now mostly past and gone," was delivered to the graduating class of Sweet Briar College by Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt at the commencement exercises held today.

In quest of the famous Gold Cup of international yachting, Herman F. Whiton sailed yesterday on the liner Bergensfjord for Norway. His 6-meter yacht Indian Scout was lashed on the forward deck. The contest for the prize will he held off Hanko on June 30 and Indian Scout will represent the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club of Oyster Bay, L.I., and the North American Yacht Racing Union.

The Upper Harlem Taxpayers Association, at a meeting at the Hotel Theresa, Seventh Avenue and 125th Street, decided last night to call upon all its members for concerted action to catch the pyromaniac who has set many fires in upper Harlem and the Bronx.
CLEVELAND, June 9. -- Frank F. Taggart, a Massillon banker, today displaced former Postmaster General Walter F. Brown of Toledo as Republican National Committeeman from Ohio.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:
CLEVELAND, June 9. -- Senator Borah is Landon's problem child. All day the Landon forces have been trying to find some way to make peace with Borah.

Fined plans for the transformation of Rockefeller Center's sunken plaza into an open-air restaurant for its opening night, June 17, to be called "Evening Under the Stars," were formulated yesterday at a meeting in the R.-C.-A. Building.

PURCHASE, N.Y., June 9. -- A virtual newcomer to tournament golf, Miss Katherine Sylvester of Green Meadow, today annexed the low-gross prize at the Century Country Club in a one-day tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association.

Registration of visiting buyers in the market during the week ended yesterday showed a gain over the preceding week and the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES. For the past week 711 buyers were reported, as against 506 in the previous week and 618 in the same period last year.

Samuel Deutsch's Play Chance, a 15-to-1 shot, came back yesterday to the fine form he displayed in Florida last Winter and sprang a surprise by capturing the Exile Handicap at a mile and a sixteenth, feature of the racing at Aqueduct.
CLEVELAND, June 9. -- The text of Senator Frederick Steiwer's keynote address before the Republican National Convention tonight was as follows:

LONDON, June 9. -- Sir Samuel Hoare made his first speech as First Lord of the Admiralty tonight when, before the Cambridge Union, he upheld the tradition, experience and spirit of the British Commonwealth as an example the word might take into account when discussing the future of the League of Nations.
CLEVELAND, June 9. -- Colonel Frank Knox, the Illinois candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, arrived in Cleveland this afternoon because, as he said, he "just got curious."

Announcing the completion of arrangements for cashing bonus bonds next week, Postmaster Albert Goldman said yesterday his clerks at armories, district stations and other places in Manhattan and the Bronx would be able to handle applications for pavement at the rate of 20,000 a day.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, June 9. -- Dr. Carlos Brenes Jarquin, member of the Chamber of Deputies from Masaya, was sworn in as President of Nicaragua this morning. A joint session of Congress named him as the first designate who automatically becomes President in the absence of the President and Vice President.

An increase of at least 50 per cent in the volume of passenger traffic from Europe to American ports is expected this year, according to ship lines and travel agents. The movement is due partly to the lower railroad rates on American lines but chiefly to the ability of visitors to obtain more for their money in this country than in previous years.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 9. -- Lawrence Kibbler Desmond, 34 years old, a native of Corry, Pa., who was employed in Oakville, Ont., by a leather company, was killed and eleven other persons were injured this morning when a Swedish four-engined Fokker airliner crashed near Malmoe, Sweden. It was the first fatal accident in the Swedish Aerotransport Company's twelve years of existence.

GENEVA, June 9. -- France will not lower her trade barriers except for countries with high standards of working conditions, Leon Jouhaux, French labor leader, declared before the International Labor Conference today.

ALBANY, June 9. -- Two bills sponsored by Senator Fearon of Syracuse, minority leader of the Senate, were vetoed today by Governor Lehman. One provided for the transfer to the Department of Public Works of duties performed by the Public Service Commission in railroad crossing elimination.

Two young Americans in a series of secret tests on the Hackensack River at Carlstadt yesterday succeeded in coaxing two new experimental Class X outboard hydroplanes to speeds of approximately eighty miles an hour and declared themselves ready for the invasion of France for the 150,000-franc Spreckels race on July 4.

Don H. Taylor, executive vice president of the New York Employing Printers Association, will present diplomas and Regent's certificates to forty-one pre-apprentices tonight at the commencement exercises of the New York School of Printing, operated under the direction of the Board of Education.

If there is anything in prophecy, a leading event took shape yesterday in the Summer schedule with the news that Jimmy Savo will play the title role of Moliere's "The Would-Be Gentleman" on Aug. 3 at the Country Playhouse, Westport. It will be his first appearance in a dramatic part after a career spent chiefly in vaudeville, with occasional visits to the musical show stage.

The Attorney General's Bureau of Securities received a complaint early yesterday afternoon from two New Hampshire attorneys charging that an oil royalty salesman had taken $51,400 in securities on June 3 from a woman living in Raymond, N.H.

George A. Sloan, a leader in the cotton manufacturing industry, in a letter to THE TIMES recounts the troubles of the industry -- high wages followed by loss of business and idleness. "With the increased labor costs of recent years," he says, "it was not surprising to find a shrinkage of 60 per cent in our export business."
BERLIN, June 9. -- The National Socialist regime boasts another victory with the Labor Office's announcement that the number off registered jobless dropped to 1,491,201 at the end of May.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, June 9. -- The official casualty list for yesterday's collapse of a grandstand at the celebration marking the sixth anniversary of King Carol's return to the throne has not yet been published, but the number of dead is now estimated at between forty and sixty.

The Temporary Galleries of the Municipal Art Committee open a new exhibition today, with some thirty painters in four groups represented. As before, the groups are composed of artists who organize outside the gallery for the purpose of exhibiting.

TOPEKA, Kan., June 9 (AP). -- After listening tonight to a broadcast of Senator Steiwer's keynote address before the Republican National Convention at Cleveland, Governor Landon said to newspaper men:

ALBANY, June 9. -- Three bills designed to protect workingmen in industries affected by silicosis or other dust diseases were signed, although Governor Lehman in a memorandum stated that "certain provisions of this legislation are not at all to my liking" and that they "run counter to what I have believed to be sound principles of workmen's compensation laws."

Daily average gross production of crude oil in the United States last week was 2,935,450 barrels, compared with 2,943,950 in the preceding week, a decline of 8,500, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. A decrease of 20,150 barrels in Kansas and gains of 15,850 and of 12,300, respectively, in Oklahoma and California were the important changes.
Oscar Fuss, secretary of the City Projects Council, an organization of white-collar workers on WPA projects, was ordered dropped from the WPA rolls yesterday by" Administrator Victor F. Ridder.

One of the largest graduating classes in the history of New York University will participate in the 104th annual commencement exercises today at Ohio Field, University Heights, when Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase will confer 4,206 degrees and certificates in course.

While District Attorney William C. Dodge made ready yesterday to press a charge of criminal libel against him, Robert Edward Edmondson, publisher of anti-Semitic leaflets that have been widely distributed, lashed back at Mayor La Guardia for having instigated the proceedings against him.

CLEVELAND, June 9. -- A boom for the nomination of Governor H. Styles Bridges of New Hampshire for Vice President as a representative of the younger members of the Republican party was started today by Walter J. Mahoney of Buffalo, president of the New York State Association of Young Republican Clubs.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 9. -- The University of Maryland placed four men on the first All-America team of the Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association, Harry J. Rockafeller, president of the association, announced today. St. John's of Annapolis gained two places, and Johns Hopkins, Army, Navy and Hobart one each.

PORTSMOUTH, England, June 9. -- The Repulse, 32,000-ton British battle cruiser, one of three big ones in the British Navy, left Portsmouth yesterday following her reconstruction. She is to join the Mediterranean Squadron permanently.

PHILADELPHIA, June 9. -- The Central North Broad Street Presbyterian Church today became a pivotal point in the modernist-fundamentalist controversy as plans were made by officials of the Presbytery of Philadelphia for declaring the pastorate vacant at next Sunday's service.

SYRACUSE, June 9. -- With the colors flying from flagstaffs, homes and business buildings, Syracuse today welcomed a handful of nonagenarians to what may be the last encampment of the New York State Department, Grand Army of the Republic.

WINCHESTER, Mass., June 9. -- Two Philadelphia district players, Miss Edith Quier and Mrs. Norman Lack, ended the second day of the women's Eastern Golf Association championship tied for the lead with 36-hole scores of 164. With only one more round of the 54-hole medal play tournament left for tomorrow, it seems fairly certain that the title will go to one of these two players, since they have a four-stroke margin and are consistent golfers.

SAN SALVADOR, El Salvador, June 9. -- Dr. Juan B. Sacasa, exiled President of Nicaragua, who arrived here last night, charged today that General Anastasio Somoza, commander of the National Guard and leader of the rebels, had betrayed his confidence.

The French franc has survived so many "crises" in the last few years that it would be hazardous to predict that it will not survive the present one. Yet pressure on the franc has been steadily increasing from several directions. The recent loss of confidence is reflected in the withdrawal from the Bank of France of 438,000,000 francs in the last week and of 8,679,000,000 francs in the last ten weeks.

Two of New York's genuine old landmarks -- almost the last of the century-old Manhattan milestones still standing-disappeared from the city's streets yesterday. The fourmile stone at Fifty-seventh Street and Third Avenue, marking the distance from City Hall, and the two-mile stone, directly South at Seventeenth Street, were removed from the spots, where 114 years ago they first directed rural travelers, and placed in the Museum of the City of New York for safe keeping.

May one who agrees 100 per cent in principle with Mr. Baker, Mr. Douglas and Mr. Wolman, ask whether they have in mind any means by which monopoly may be effectively prevented? Judge Edgar H. Farrar of New Orleans, speaking as president of the American Bar Association, in 1911, said:

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company is to receive about $3,000,000 as a result of a dividend of 50 cents a share on common stock declared by the Western Electric Company, Inc., its manufacturing subsidiary, it was announced yesterday.

Ceremonies under the joint auspices of the Park Department and the Staten Island Zoological Society will formally open the Barrett Park Zoo this afternoon at. 4:30 o'clock. Speakers will include Mayor La Guardia, former Governor Alfred iE. Smith, Park Commissioner Robert Moses. and Borough President Joseph Palma.

Jean Cocteau. the French poet and dramatist, now emulating Jules Verne's character who voyaged "around the world in eighty days," sat in his suite at the Hotel Ambassador yesterday and paused to consider the seventy-three days behind him.

ALBANY, June 9. -- Eight bills carrying into effect recommendations of Governor Lehman for the greater control of crime became law tonight with the signature of the Governor. They relate to exemptions from jury duty, qualification for bail, extradition, return of stolen property, arrest of persons fleeing from other States, arson, disorderly conduct and procedure for the prosecution of offenses against the income tax law.

BASLE, Switzerland, June 9. -- A libel action against the editor of The Iron Broom, organ of the anti-Semitic National Front, arising from the trial in which the so-called "Protocols of the Elders of Zion" were proved spurious, was settled today.

While business failures declined in the construction and wholesale divisions in the five-day week ended June 4, as compared with the previous week, there was an increase in insolvencies in the retail and manufacturing branches, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

CHICAGO, June 9 (AP). -- Given a four-run working margin in the first two innings, Roy Henshaw, diminutive Cub southpaw, defeated Philadelphia, 6 to 3, today to extend Chicago's longest winning streak of the season to six games.
PUBLIC AUDITORIUM CLEVELAND, June 9. -- The twenty-first Republican National Convention opened today at 11:41, Eastern standard time, when Henry P. Fletcher, national chairman, called it to order.

PARIS, June 9. -- Bills providing for a forty-hour week without reduction of present wages, for vacations with pay and for collective working contracts were introduced in Parliament this afternoon by Premier Leon Blum. In this way he kept his promise to the strikers to recognize their principal demands.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Wednesday, June 10. -- Governor Landon approved the tentative draft of the platform prepared by William Allen White and former Governor Henry J. Allen, which was presented to the subcommittee of the Resolutions Committee early this morning.

A Brooklyn politician, at present "unemployed," told in the Drukman conspiracy trial yesterday how he tried to earn $50 in a jury-tampering deal which he testified was suggested by Henry G. Singer, former Chief Assistant United States Attorney, who was acting in behalf of murderers of Samuel Drukman.

Dr. George S. Cattanach, neurologist, defending a suit for separation by Mrs. Elizabeth L. Cattanach on charges of cruelty and desertion, testified yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Rosenman that while his wife was in a nervous condition she embarrassed him at a time when she was seeking to join the Riverside Church.
The Commonwealth of Massachusetts will be in the market on June 23 with a new issue of $3,000,000 of public works bonds, maturing on June 15, 1937 to 1941. Bidders are to name the rate of interest.

BERLIN, June 9. -- The upward movement on the Boerse continued today. Financial commentators attributed the upturn to favorable business reports, a reduction in unemployment to below the 1,500,000 level and declarations of improved dividends, but it was noticeable that foreign bonds were again lively and strong, while domestic fixed-interest securities continued dull.

Five minutes before an important State witness was to take the stand in the recent compulsory prostitution trial Thomas E. Dewey, Special Prosecutor, discovered that the man had been bribed to tell a story that would damage the State's case, it became known yesterday.

The New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad reported yesterday a profit and loss surplus of $25,804,316 as of March 31, against $19,824,603 a year previously. Total assets were $288, 141,240 against $288,907,991.

Revived interest in secondary railroad and a few selected industrial loans featured a rising trend in bond trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The trading pace reflected a wider speculative interest as sales expanded to $10,754,500, as compared to $7,374,200 on Monday.

ROCHESTER, June 9 (AP). -- A proposse to admit women as members of consistory, the governing body of individual churches, was voted down today in the concluding session of the General Synod of the Reformed Church in America. The synod completed its business.

HAMILTON, Ohio, June 9. -- Johnny Black, 45, song writer who made thousands of dollars on his song hit "Dardanella," died today of a skull fracture suffered in an argument over 25 cents at a cafe he operated near here.

WASHINGTON, June 9. -- A plan designed to insure an American-controlled system of world communications is being developed by officials of the Federal Communications Commission, it was learned today, and is scheduled to be submitted soon to the State, War and Navy Departments for approval.

PUBLIC AUDITORIUM, CLEVELAND, Wednesday, June 10. -- Early this morning the credentials committee of the Republican National Convention, acting upon appeals, upheld decisions reached by the National Committee last week in contests involving twelve delegates from Florida and one from the Fifth Congressional District in Georgia.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 9. -- Stephen (Laddie) Sanford's Hurricanes galloped into the final round of the polo competition for the Third Westbury Challenge Cup today on Cochran Field at Meadow Brook, easily subduing the Aiken Knights, headed by G.H. (Pete) Bostwick, 13 -- 6.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 9. -It became evident tonight that Coach Ed Leader of Yale still faces a problem in fashioning a varsity crew for the resumption of the ancient rivalry with Harvard on the Thames June 19. In almost complete darkness, with running lights on the following coaching launches, Yale's junior varsity finished a four-mile upstream time row almost three lengths ahead of the varsity.
