The Hugo Stinnes Corporation and its wholly owned subsidiary, Hugo Stinnes Industries, Inc., which have paid 4 per cent interest on their notes and debentures since 1933, deferring the balance of 3 per cent to the maturity of the two issues, have notified holders of these securities of their intention to continue payments in dollars of 4 per cent interest on both issues.

Most of the men who attended the opening of the forty-first annual convention of the Southern New York Volunteer Firemen's Association in Carnarsie yesterday were veterans of a day when hand-pulled fire-fighting apparatus bumped uncertainly along muddy roads and cobbled streets.

When JOHN HAYS HAMMOND was making an expedition to Guatemala many years ago the little craft in which he was traveling encountered a storm in the Gulf of Mexico of such violence that the captain gave slight hope of its surviving. Mr. HAMMOND wrote a short will and a farewell letter to his family, put them in a bottle ready to be thrown overboard, then settled down to read Prescott's "Conquest of Mexico."

The Republican National Committee has employed the promotional technique and methods developed by radio advertisers and merchandising experts to dramatize its radio activities in connection with the current convention. "How to advertise and merchandise effectively Republican broadcasts in your community'' is the title of one promotional piece which suggests penny postcards containing listening data, window streamers and dodgers to be distributed by political workers.

ON BOARD PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT'S SPECIAL TRAIN, June 9. -- While riding westward today and this evening, President Roosevelt spent his time revising a series of speeches which from tomorrow onward will mark an extraordinarily active tour of the South and Southwest.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses was referred to as a "speed demon" yesterday by Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx, who tried unsuccessfully to block the Board of Estimate's approval of a World's Fair grading contract to the third lowest bidder in a list of seven.

The Southern Pacific Company will eliminate its indebtedness to banks and to the United States Government as a result of the public offering to be made today by Kuhn, Loeb Co. of a new issue of $60,000,000 of the road's ten-year 3 3/4 per cent secured bonds, maturing on July 1, 1946.

ALBANY, June 9. -- The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, and Dairy Sealed, Inc., have been directed by the Division of Milk Control to show cause why their milk licenses in the metropolitan district should not be revoked because the Stores bought milk at prices lower than the minimum established.

Some irregularity developed yesterday in price movement of commodity futures. Trading was quiet. In the cash markets, wheat, corn, rye, cocoa, cotton, silk, wool tops and butter were higher, while tin established a new low level for the move.
NEWARK, N.J., June 9. -- Newark made a clean sweep of the Montreal series tonight when Al Piechota shut out the Royals, 8 to 0, for his ninth victory of the season.

Graduation exercises of the Lexington School for the Deaf will be held tonight at Julia Richman High School Auditorium, with Dr. Rowena K. Keyes, chairman of the Department of English of the Julia Richman High School, as the principal speaker. President Sol E. Rains of the board of trustees will distribute prizes and certificates.

CLEVELAND, June 9. -- One of the minor commotions of the convention has been caused by rumors that Mrs. George Simmons of Marshall, Mo., the farm wife who bolted the Democratic ranks at the time of the "Grass Roots" convention at Springfield, Ill., may repudiate the Republicans also.

The keynote sounded last night at Cleveland by Senator STEIWER necessarily differed from other keynotes in recent years at other Republican conventions. In 1924, in 1928 and again in 1932, the Republicans met at a time when they were in control of affairs at Washington.

A four-run rally in the third frame enabled the Samuel J. Tilden High School nine, Brooklyn title winner, to defeat Jamaica, Queens champion, 7 to 3, yesterday in a semi-final encounter in the Public Schools Athletic League tournament.
Necessity drove the aging Rogers Hornsby into starting his first game of the season yesterday at the Stadium with results that were at once positive.

Postal authorities shifted the quarterly auction of unclaimed articles yesterday from the lobby of the main building at Eighth Avenue and Thirty-third Street to a special room on the fourth floor of the new annex at Ninth Avenue and disposed of 441 lots of merchandise for $3,561.50.

WASHINGTON, June 9. -- The Otter Tail Power Company of Minnesota has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Securities Act of 1933 a statement covering $3,000,000 of 4 per cent first mortgage bonds, due 1961, and $600,000 of 3 per cent secured notes, due 1941.

You wade waist-deep in clear pale green water on a rock and gravel bottom. In front, in back all around you, swim schools of fish -- narrow, streamlined, colored dark gray on top, silvery on the sides.

Following its brief rally on Monday, which was due to short-covering, the French franc yesterday relapsed to the gold-import point and the flow of gold to this country from Paris was resumed. The currency fell to 6.58 5-16 cents and closed at 6.58 3/8 cents, off 2 1/8 points from the previous day.
CLEVELAND, June 9. -- Some of the phrases coined by Chairman Steiwer in his speech were:
MANILA, June 9. -- A dispute over a successor of the childless Sultan of Sulu threatened tonight to embroil 500,000 Moros in a civil war.

Stocks continued higher yesterday, this time under the leadership of the communications and merchandising issues. The trading volume on the Stock Exchange went from 694,000 shares on Monday to 876,000 yesterday, or to the heaviest day's business since May 27.

The Dorr Company, Inc., consulting engineers, have leased 20,000 square feet, almost two floors, in the General Electric Building, 570 Lexington Avenue, at Fifty-first Street, it is reported by Cushman Wakefield, Inc., agent of the building and broker in the transaction.
BOSTON, June 9. -- Newton D. Baker urged the members of the graduating class of Massachusetts Institute of Technology here today to "carry science into politics."
BERLIN, June 9 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of June 6 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

Evidence to indicate that the Westchester Title and Trust Company issued a misleading financial statement in 1931 was introduced yesterday at the mail fraud trial of four former officers or directors of the company, which failed with about $81,000,000 in mortgage securities outstanding in March, 1933.
Fordham University will confer approximately 600 degrees and certificates upon graduates at the ninety-first annual commencement exercises, to be held this morning at 11 o'clock on the campus.

PURCHASE, N.Y., June 9. -- The Simon F. Rothschild Memorial Trophy went to James Twiname of B. Altman Co., as forty-four members and guests took part in the sixteenth annual Retail Dry Goods Association golf tourney at the Century Country Club today.

The Board of Higher Education last night accepted the conclusions of its City College administrative committee upholding the fitness of Dr. Frederick B. Robinson to continue as president of City College by a vote of fourteen to seven at a lengthy meeting in the School of Business and Civic Administration, Twenty-third Street and Lexington Avenue.

WASHINGTON, June 9. -- The Texas Corporation has filed an amendment to its registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 for issuance of $60,000,000 of 3 1/2 per cent debentures, due in 1951, naming forty-eight underwriters and the allotments taken by each as follows:

WASHINGTON, June 9. -- The large June financing program of the Treasury having been completed. Governor W.I. Myers of the Farm Credit Administration announced today that about $83,125,000 of 4 1/4 per cent individual bonds of the Federal Land Banks would be called for redemption tomorrow and that a new issue of $83,000,000 of consolidated bonds of the Federal Land Banks would be offered to the public on Thursday.

Evidence to indicate that the Westchester Title and Trust Company issued a misleading financial statement in 1931 was introduced yesterday at the mail fraud trial of four former officers or directors of the company, which failed with about $81,000,000 in mortgage securities outstanding in March, 1933.
Fordham University will confer approximately 600 degrees and certificates upon graduates at the ninety-first annual commencement exercises, to be held this morning at 11 o'clock on the campus.

Sixteen athletes for each track event and twenty for each field event have been decided upon by the American Olympic track committee for the final tryouts at Randalls Island on July 11 and 12, Chairman William J. Bingham announced yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, June 9 (AP). -- The Chicago White Sox turned the tables on the Athletics today, tying the score in the ninth inning and winning in the tenth, 5 to 2.
ALBANY, June 10. -- Fourteen bills designed to reduce the total of automobile deaths and injuries have been signed by Governor Lehman, it was announced today.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 10. -- R. Perry Elrod, a senior closing his intercollegiate athletic career, hit a home run with one on in the tenth inning to give Brown a 5-to-3 verdict over Yale on Aldrich Field today. The triumph gave Brown a sweep in the home-and-home series with Yale and ended the most successful Bruin baseball season in more than a decade with twelve victories in seventeen starts.

WASHINGTON, June 10. -- The American Cities Power and Light Corporation of Jersey City, N.J., an investment trust, filed today under the Securities Act of 1933 a statement covering 150,000 shares of $25-par value Class A stock, optional dividend series of 1936, with attached warrants for purchase of common stock of the North American Company.

A shortage of potatoes, brought about mainly by drought, has caused their price to soar to a level twice as high as it has been in the past ten years. The fact is a sardonic commentary on the Potato Control Law, which was quietly repealed by Congress when the Supreme Court declared AAA unconstitutional.

CLEVELAND, June 10. -- Pennsylvania's delegation agreed in caucus today to cast fifty of its seventy-five votes for Governor Landon on the first ballot. This unexpected action, John M. Hamilton, Governor Landon's manager, said clinched the nomination of the Kansan on the first ballot.

LONDON, June 10 (AP). -- Battle lines for the fourteenth Wightman Cup international tennis series between American and British women were drawn today and immediately experts decided Britain's chances of ending America's five-year supremacy were unusually bright.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 10. -- Color and orderly garden patterns filled the County Center today at the opening of the fifth annual exhibition of the Westchester County Horticultural and Agricultural Association. The show will be continued through Saturday.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP). -- A crop of 482,000,000 bushels of Winter wheat, considerably above last year's production but far below the 1928-32 average, was forecast today by the Department of Agriculture in warning of a threat of widespread damage to the crop by drought. The production in 1935 was 433,000,000 bushels. The 1928-32 average was 618,000,000.

Patrolman George Heidt, who testified for the defense at the trial of Charles (Lucky Luciano) Lucania and eight co-defendants last week, was examined at length yesterday by Irving Ben Cooper, special counsel to Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts.

Henry G. Singer, former Chief Assistant United States Attorney and hitherto one of the most silent of the five defendants in the Drukman conspiracy trial, rose unexpectedly in court yesterday to defend his name against the accusations of a man he convicted of bail-bond frauds four years ago.

The programs for the first week of concerts by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at the Lewisohn Stadium were announced yesterday. Jose Iturbi, who will conduct on the opening night, Wednesday, June 24, as well as five of the Stadium's eight weeks, left Buenos Aires yesterday and will arrive at the Newark Airport next Wednesday.

The thirteenth annual presentation of awards by the Music Education League was held last night at the Town Hall before an audience which filled the auditorium. A concert was given by the winners of the league's contests during the past season.

The single-trip riders on the Long Island Railroad will continue to pay 3 cents a mile within the City of New York until next Monday at least, according to a decision handed down late yesterday by the Appellate Division for the Second Department.

CHICAGO, June 10 (AP). -- A single by Catcher Ken O'Dea, with the bases loaded and two out, in the ninth drove across the two runs that gave the Cubs a 4-to-3 victory over Philadelphia today. The triumph gave the champions a clean sweep of the three-game series and extended their victory streak to seven games.

CLEVELAND, June 10. -- New York State will cast a minimum of eighty-five votes for Governor Landon on the first ballot, it was disclosed today at an open poll of the delegation. With eighty-nine of the ninety delegates present or represented by alternates, there was one vote for Hoover, two for Frank E. Gannett and one for Alfred P. Sloan Jr.
CLEVELAND, June 10 (AP). -- Perched in the very last seat under the dark towering balconies of the Republican National Convention hall was Carey F. Clark of Cincinnati.

WASHINGTON, June 10. -- Reports that restrictions placed upon trading on American Exchanges by the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Federal Reserve Board were resulting in a considerable volume of such business being transferred to London and other foreign cities were sharply challenged today by Duncan U. Fletcher, chairman of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee, and James M. Landis, chairman of the SEC.

To provide additional working capital and to reduce borrowing requirements in the company's peak season, an offering of 8,391 shares of common stock of the New York Merchandise Company, Inc., at $50 a share will be made today by a banking group composed of Burr Co., Inc.; King, Crandall Latham, Inc., and Chandler Co., Inc.

CLEVELAND, June 10. -- The refrain "Three Long Years" bids fair to become a Republican campaign slogan. Verses inspired by it are appearing in multiplying versions and, set to music, are being sung by delegate groups and played by convention bands. One set of verses has been accepted by the National Committee as an official tune.

ILION, N.Y., June 10 (AP). -- James H. Rand Jr., president of Remington Rand, Inc., told more than 900 employes tonight that both of the company's plants would remain in Ilion and predicted that "this is the beginning of the end of the strike." He spoke at a mass meeting of workers who returned to their jobs today.

James J. Noll, alias James Walker, a former New York patrolman, was arrested last night on a charge of assault and robbery after he had been identified as one of four men who held up a fur firm at 288 Seventh Avenue. His three alleged companions escaped with skins valued at $3,000 and $20 in cash which they took from Nathan Horowitz, a brother of the proprietor.

SHANGHAI, June 10. -- Canton's plans to obtain military support from North China seem to have failed. Dispatches from Peiping today said General Sung Cheh-yuan, chairman of the Hopei-Chahar Council, had rejected an invitation telegraphed from Canton asking him to assume command of a second "anti-Japanese National Salvation Army," like the one in South China.

President ROOSEVELT in his very felicitous address yesterday at Little Rock allowed the claim of Arkansas to the name which was given to her by the Legislature -- "The Wonder State." And he might have added that she is still true to her motto, "Regnat Populus."

GENEVA, June l0. -- The delegates of the French Government, employers and workers to the International Labor Conference here, quarreled today over the meaning of the agreement in Paris Sunday that was designed to end the present French strike movement.

Consolidated net income of the Texas Corporation and its subsidiaries for the three months ended on March 31 was $5,842,897, after all charges, provision for taxes and other charges, according to an amended prospectus filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with the company's $60,000,000 3 1/2 per cent debentures to be offered soon to the public.

Article III, Section 1 of the Constitution of the United States of America provides that "The judicial power of the United States shall be vested in one Supreme Court and such inferior courts as the Congress may from time to time ordain and establish."

PUBLIC AUDITORIUM, CLEVELAND, June 10. -- The prayer by Dr. Ernest Lynn Waldorf, Resident Bishop of the Chicago area of the Methodist Episcopal Church, made at the opening session of the Republican National Convention at 11 A.M. today, follows:

Politicians of the leading parties will commit a grave mistake if they attempt to give the nation a theoretical solution of the monetary problem. The foremost monetary experts of the world have tried their wits in the field, with the only result that after six years they present us a picture of the greatest confusion that ever existed in monetary matters.

TUCSON, Ariz., June 10. -- Wings which spread from 27 to 29 feet, tip to tip, and a rapier-like bone-armored beak were part of the equipment of a Jurassic pterosaur, fossil remains of which have been uncovered by Dr. T.A. Stoyanow, Professor of Geology at the University of Arizona.

Another nose finish, with the camera deciding the result, occurred in the $6,925 Shevlin Stakes yesterday, at Aqueduct, with the number of the Brookmeade Stable's Gean Canach being posted first. He was a 20-to-1 shot and got up in the last stride to edge Gleeman into second position by the narrowest of margins.
ANDOVER, Mass., June 10. -- Awards of numerous prizes and scholarships were anounced at Phillips Academy today. The list was as follows:

A domestic wheat crop of almost 700,000,000 bushels is indicated this year by the report of the Department of Agriculture, released yesterday. The government placed the indicated Winter wheat yield at 482,000,000 bushels as of June 1, compared with 463,708,000 on May 1, and an actual yield last year of 433,447,000.

SALEM, N.H., June 10. -- Pegotty Ann, smashing bay daughter of the imported Pharamond II, bearing the colors of John D. Spreckels 3d, led all the way today to capture the five-furlong Juvenile Handicap, feature of the Rockingham Park card, before 8,000 persons.

Speaking at the ninety-first annual commencement exercises of Fordham University yesterday, the Very Rev. Aloysius J. Hogan, the president, charged that American colleges and universities, in their support of secular education, betrayed American ideals and ideas.

PARIS, June 10. -- A general strike of hotel, cafe and restaurant employes in the Paris region was voted tonight, as a possible cleavage in the government's Leftist majority over the forty-hour-week bill was seen. The union announced the strike had been called "in view of the obstinacy of the proprietors."

VIENNA, June 10. -- Austrian official circles received with regret the news of the removal of Fulvio Suvich as Italian Under-Secretary for Foreign Affairs. The official Wiener Zeitung described Mr. Suvich as a brilliant expert on Central European affairs who had rendered great service both to Italy and Austria when the Rome protocols were drafted.

PHILADELPHIA, June 10, -- A tribute to "the sustained good-will and understanding" between this country and Canada as contrasted with "the destructive and blighting influence of a heritage of conflict, distrust, fear and often hatred" among European nations was paid today by Sir Joseph Flavelle, Toronto banker, in a commencement address at Beaver College.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 10. -- A new Yale varsity rowed from Gales Ferry today following last night's upset of the then top crew. With two exceptions, it was composed of the eight men who scored by three lengths in the dramatic time trial that was finished in almost pitch blackness in Bartlett's Cove.

RICHMOND, Va., June 10. -- Adoption of a resolution commending the sales and collection survey by the United States Department of Commerce in the fields of wholesaling and manufacturing was announced today as delegates to the forty-first annual convention of the National Association of Credit Men interrupted their business sessions to spend the day sightseeing in historic Williamsburg.
LONG BEACH, L.I., June 10. -This city will not charge visitors or residents for using the public beach this Summer, it was announced here today by Mayor Charles Gold.

Justice George Sutherland of the United States Supreme Court and his wife will sail for Europe today on the French liner Ile de France. Others include Mrs. W.K. Vanderbilt, Astor Knight, portrait painter, with Mrs. Knight, and Colonel Sosthenes Behn, president of the International Telephone and Telegraph Company.

FORT WILLIAM, Ont., June 10 (Canadian Press). -- Canada's wheat carry-over at the end of this crop year, July 31, should be not more than 125,000,000 bushels if the present rate of exports is maintained, says the monthly report of the Board of Grain Commissioners issued here today.

BOSTON, June 10. -- Damage from the waters of the Merrimac River in the plants of the Amoskeag Manufacturing Company during the recent flood cost that textile company $2,500,000 and washed out its new reorganization plan, it was revealed today when John L. Hall of Choate, Hall Stewart, counsel for the company, told the master in the Federal court that the flood-repair bill made it necessary for the company to withdraw the plan.

Nicholas Opolonick, 46 years old, a Russian chemist, was put under $2,000 bond by United States Commissioner Garrett W. Cotter yesterday, pending investigation by the Federal Grand Jury of charges that he sent threatening letters through the mails.

A definite stiffening in the prices of finished cotton goods, reflecting the current advances in gray cloth, was reported yesterday in the local trade. Solid color shirtings, for instance, have been moved up somewhat in the last week, percales have shown a firmer price tone and other fabrics are also stronger.

The gold-export movement from this country in February -- presumably resulting from sales by Europe of some of the American securities bought last year -- was welcomed rather than deprecated in the markets. But it did not continue; the abnormal flow of foreign gold to America has been resumed.
NEWARK, N.J., June 10. -- Newark ran its winning streak to five straight today with a 5-to-1 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs in the first game of a series.

JERUSALEM, June 10. -- Five Arabs were seriously wounded today in part of a round of disorders such as have become typical of the Arab anti-Jewish campaign in Palestine. The usual clashes, bomb-throwing and rifle-firing also characterized the day's events.

CHICAGO, June 10. -- Conditions in the grain trade are not such as to invite large speculative operations and most of the business was confined to the Board of Trade here in professionals and in spreading operations between near and distant futures here and in Kansas City, Minneapolis and Winnipeg.

AGAWAM, Mass., June 10 (AP). -- Reliant, with Jimmy Lynch up, which won the first race at Agawam Park today, was disqualified. The stewards ruled the horse had moved over in a stretch drive, forced Bess Tam to the rail and shut off the rest of the field of maiden 2-year-olds.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., June 10. -- The intercollegiate sailing championship regatta got off to a grand start today in spite of the threatening weather that had been coming in and out of Marblehead all day. Following races in two classes, Princeton took the lead with 16 1/4 points, with Yale scoring 16.

Bernard Rogers's orchestral work, "Once Upon a Time," has been selected for publication by the Juilliard School of Music. The work was chosen through a competition, sponsored by the school, in which nearly seventy orchestral compositions were entered by composers from twenty States.

CHICAGO, June 10. -- J.L. Keeshin, president of Keeshin Transcontinental Freight Lines, Inc., of this city, took advantage today of one of the conferences of the joint midyear gathering of the National Retail Dry Goods Association to present his view of "coordinating rails and highways to improve transportation service for the retailers."
ALFRED, N.Y., June 10. -- The largest class in its history was graduated today by Alfred University. Those receiving degrees were:

The first twenty-five chain-store systems to report for May had aggregate sales of $225,605,035, an increase of 16.4 per cent over the same month a year ago, according to the monthly compilation issued yesterday by Hammons Co., Inc., and Childs, Jeffries Thorndike, Inc.
Your editorial of June 6 entitled "Subsidized Exports" contains an unfortunate contradiction which apparently resulted from your failure to carry your own splendid argument to its logical conclusion.

LONDON, June 10. -- In spite of general disappointment over the Queen Mary's not breaking the transatlantic record either way, the liner was enthusiastically welcomed at the end of her first round trip at Southampton this afternoon.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 10. -- Following is the text of President Roosevelt's speech at the Arkansas centennial celebration today:

CLEVELAND, June 10. -- Dr. Frank N.D. Buchman, founder of the Oxford Group, arrived in Cleveland this morning with fifty-five group members, who will hold a mass gathering tomorrow night, besides meeting Ohio adherents of the movement at a number of luncheon parties this week.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 10. -- The observance of the tenth anniversary of the founding of the Portsmouth Priory School began yesterday. This evening the first of three plays by the dramatic society of the school, a German play, "Der Hauptmann von Koepenick," was presented.

Representatives of banking interests, real estate groups and business associations were told yesterday by John H. Delaney, chairman of the Board of Transportation, that higher fares on the rapid transit lines were distinctly a future possibility, regardless of the outcome of pending negotiations for rapid transit unification.

GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, June 10 (AP). -- The British ship Girl Pat, whose mysterious course has puzzled African and European ports, was reported today to have been sighted off the coast of South America, flying a distress signal.

ALBANY, June 10. -- Decision was reserved today by Kenneth F. Fee, director of the Division of Milk Control in the case of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, accused of receiving discounts on milk sold by Dairy Sealed, Inc.

A kindly man of 80, wearing a red-sashed black cassock with a crimson feriola and a red-tufted black biretta, stepped to a microphone before almost 2,500 persons at the Hotel Astor last night and entertained them thoroughly with simple Irish stories, with tales of Mrs. Flanagan and Mrs. Murphy and of Clancy and his "mither."

TOPEKA, June 10 (AP). -- Miss Mildred (Babe) Didrikson, the tournament's only professional, went out of the eighth annual women's Western open golf tournament today as the defending champion led the parade into the quarter-finals.

Rising tendencies continued in bond trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Secondary railroad liens, many of which were bid up briskly in fairly active operations, led the rise 20.05 points on the day in the combined price average for domestic corporation bonds.

CLEVELAND, June 10. -- Colonel Frank Knox, the Chicago publisher whose hat still lies in the ring for the Republican nomination for President, began to figure today conspicuously in the busy talk about a running-mate for Governor Landon of Kansas.

WASHINGTON, June 10. -- Tentative agreement on compromises of some of the relatively unimportant differences between the Senate and House Tax Bills was reached today at the first meeting of the conferees.

CLEVELAND, June 10. -- The enterprising business men of Cleveland who paid $150,000 to play host to the Republican National Convention will not lose on their investment but may even get a dividend, James L. Jappe of the convention committee disclosed today.

PUBLIC AUDITORIUM, Cleveland, June 10. -- Joseph W. ("Tieless Joe") Tolbert with his "black and tan" delegation of ten from South Carolina was seated by the Republican National Convention today on the recommendation of the committee on credentials, overruling a decision reached last week by the Republican National Committee, which placed a "lily white" delegation on the temporary roll of the convention.

The retirement of James French as chief surveyor of Lloyd's Register of Shipping in the United States and Canada was announced yesterday. Mr. French will be succeeded by William Bennett, senior ship surveyor in Lloyd's Philadelphia office.

Lawyers are easygoing persons, as a group, without regard to the consequences of their work on society, and the profession needs legal hospitals equipped as medical hospitals to take care of the cases not properly handled today, Professor Zachariah Chafee Jr. of the Harvard University Law School declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 10. -- The fifteen planks of the American Federation of Labor, proposed to the Republican convention's platform committee yesterday, will also be submitted to the Democratic convention's platform committee, it was stated today.

WINCHESTER, Mass., June 10. -- In a dramatic finish Miss Edith Quier wrested the Women's Eastern Golf Association championship away from Mrs. Norman Lack of Newcastle, Del., at the Winchester Country Club today.
CLEVELAND June 10. -- State Senator Frederick H. Bontecou of Poughkeepsie, alternate from New York, was robbed of $400 early this morning.

DETROIT, June 10 (AP). -- A roving Black Legion "torch squad" which was directed by code messages from high officers of the terrorist society to hunt out and burn homes of suspected Communists was disclosed today, Prosecutor Duncan C. McCrea declared, by the statements of four men.

From Hollywood comes the word that "The Rivals," which Warners have been secretly contemplating for some time, has been placed on immediate schedule with Hugh Herbert assigned the role of Bob Acres. Louise Fazenda has been tentatively cast as Mrs. Malaprop, but before the final decision is made exhaustive tests will be made of Alice Brady, Ruth Donnelly and Mary Boland.
UTICA, June 10 (AP). -- The labor difficulties at six of the Remington Rand plants have been settled definitely, James H. Rand Jr., president of the company, said in a statement tonight.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., June 10. -- Mrs. W.R. Kirkland Jr. of the home club shot a sparkling 40, 38 -- 78, one stroke over women's par, to capture low gross laurels in a field of forty in the Women's Long Island Golf Association one-day tournament at the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club today.

Gloria Laura Morgan Vanderbilt, 11-year-old daughter of the late Reginald C. Vanderbilt, will need $4,250 for vacation expenses during July, which she will spend with her mother, Gloria Morgan Vanderbilt. This was learned yesterday when Surrogate James A. Foley signed an additional allowance for her maintenance and support.

Forestalling bank robberies raises some interesting thoughts. In a letter published this morning your reader suggests that the presence of a car parked at the curb outside the bank with a man sitting at the wheel should be taken as a signal that mischief is afoot.
LONDON, June 10. -- The detailed description of the opening match in the Westchester Cup polo series played at Hurlingham today follows:
CLEVELAND, June 10. -- The most significant feature of this convention is the quiet, calm, unanimous determination to defeat the President.

In a letter addressed to all banks and distributed through the Federal Reserve System, President Roosevelt yesterday urged bankers to cooperate with the government in cashing bonus checks promptly and in full. Copies of the letter sent out by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York yesterday read as follows:

Thomas A. Dempsey, who has been chief clerk of the New York City Magistrates' Court for eight years, was appointed general clerk of the Brooklyn Supreme Court yesterday. The appointment was made by the board of justices from Kings County and was announced by Supreme Court Justice Peter P. Smith.

Only light and occasional showers along the Eastern seaboard were predicted for today by the Weather Bureau last night. The showers, it was said, will probably not be sufficient to bring much relief to drought conditions which are seriously affecting potato, grain, vegetable and berry crops.

Prices in the commodities futures markets were generally firm yesterday. The trading was quiet. Sugar advanced as volume increased, while rubber was lower. In the cash markets wheat, rye, oats, flour, cocoa, butter, eggs and silk were higher, while corn, rubber and tin were lower.

The directors of the Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association of San Francisco declared yesterday a special dividend of $1,000,000, or 50 cents a share on the 2,000,000 shares of capital stock outstanding. In addition they declared two quarterly dividends totaling $3,000,000.

LONDON, June 10. -- The London Stock Exchange was again cheerful today, more business following the Wall Street recovery and the better feeling regarding the situation on the Continent. Fluctuations in foreign exchange quotations continued to be keenly watched, but less anxiety was shown concerning the gold currencies.

Losing control, Ernie Gesell, of Hollis, L.I., was thrown clear of his car as it crashed through the rail on the fifteenth lap to end the scheduled twenty-lap Metropolitan Sweepstakes on the midget auto racing program at the Madison Square Garden Bowl in Long Island City last night. A crowd of 10,000 saw the race.
WILDWOOD, N.J., June 10. -- Two men were killed and five persons were seriously injured in a collision of automobiles at Routes 4 and S-49 four miles west of here, today.

PHILADELPHIA, June 10. -- Distribution of 5,000 City of Philadelphia courtesy cards, prepared for Democratic National Convention participants, was foreshadowed yesterday at a ceremony in Mayor S. Davis Wilson's reception room.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., June 10. -- Dr. Tyler W. Dennett, president of Williams College, and Mrs. Dennett are to have as house guests over the 142d commencement, starting Friday, Dr. and Mrs. Gilbert Horrax and family of Brookline. They are holding a reception Saturday afternoon for trustees, alumni, faculty and members of the graduating class.

Senior Week activities at Fordham College will be brought to a conclusion tonight with the presentation of the annual senior ball in the Grand Ballroom of the Hotel New Yorker. Heading the reception committee for the affair are Daniel J. O'Connor, chairman of Senior Week, and Harry P. Cronin, dance chairman.

OTTAWA, June 10. -- A few hours after the Conservative leader of the Senate had declared today he would "prefer to see the Senate abolished for having done its duty to seeing it despised for having failed to do so," that body, Conservative in politics, defeated an amendment to Canada's Constitution proposed by the Liberal House of Commons and reattached to a Railroad Bill an amendment which the House of Commons had already refused.

WASHINGTON, June 10. -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull was requested by the American Manganese Producers Association today to conclude no new agreement with Russia that provides any reduction in duties on manganese ores and alloys.

Eighty-five insignia and seventy-one medals for intra-mural activities are included in the second list of athletic awards announced yesterday through the athletic office of St. John's University. In addition eighteen honor sweater awards were made to students who have been outstanding on various varsity athletic teams during the past season.

The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey may liquidate its $76, 000,000 Standard Oil Export Corporation, W.S. Farish, chairman of the parent company, said yesterday. Like moves have been undertaken by other large corporations since income taxes on consolidated returns were revised.

A re-examination of all of the 203,384 cases on the city home relief rolls was ordered yesterday by Miss Charlotte E. Carr, executive director of the Emergency Relief Bureau. This "social audit" will have the double purpose of lopping from the lists cases which do not belong there and of standardizing the administration of relief in the bureau's forty-four district offices.

Gross operating earnings of banks in New York State outside New York City reached in 1935 the lowest point since the depression started, but net operating earnings were more than 10 per cent larger than in 1934, showing the first upturn since the depression began.

Our neighbor The Sun printed yesterday some remarks made by former Governor ELY of Massachusetts, whose opposition to some of Mr. ROOSEVELT'S policies has been sincere and steadfast. NRA and AAA have been his special aversions. He goes so far as to say that:

BOLTON LANDING, N.Y., June 10. -- An acre of fir wooded land will be turned over to this village Saturday afternoon as a memorial to Carl Schurz and Dr. Abraham Jacobi, leaders among men. The dedication will be the closing feature of the convention of the American Pediatric Society, which began its sessions today.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP). -- The Indians, batting hard behind the effective pitching of George Blaeholder, repulsed the Senators today in the final game of an abbreviated series, 10 to 2.

CONVENT STATION, N.J., June 10. -- The Most Rev. Thomas J. Walsh, Bishop of Newark Diocese of the Roman Catholic Church, will confer degrees upon seventy-one students at the commencement exercises of the College of Saint Elizabeth here tomorrow afternoon. The graduation will be held on the campus near Santa Maria Hall.

PUBLIC AUDITORIUM, CLEVELAND, June 10. -- An invitation to "constitutional Democrats" to join the Republicans in the campaign against the "unconstitutional dictatorship" and "arrogant individualism" of President Roosevelt was issued today by Representative Bertrand H. Snell in his speech on assuming the permanent chairmanship of the Republican National Convention.

WASHINGTON, June 10. -- Graduates of today should entertain no fear for the fate of the United States, Senator Lonergan assured 516 students of the Catholic University of America upon whom academic degrees were conferred at commencement exercises today.

Thirty-one men employed by the Pennsylvania Railroad system, all of whom had known the guest of honor for twenty-five years or more, attended a surprise luncheon yesterday in honor of Loren S. Wells, who has completed fifty years of service with the railroad.

CLEVELAND, June 10. -- Former President Hoover arrived here today to become the center of a series of rousing demonstrations leading up to his speech tonight before the Republican convention. As a result his political stock again was put on a rising market.
CONVENTION HALL, CLEVELAND, June 10. -- The Republican delegates found in their convention seats tonight a new campaign song, "Three Long Years," which is sung to the tune of "Three Blind Mice."

MINEOLA, L.I., June 1O. -- Supreme Court Justice Paul Bonynge reserved decision here today after hearing arguments in an action brought by Percy Reed, proprietor of the Nassau Kennel Club at Mineola, for a declaratory judgment to permit the kennel club to hold greyhound races at the Mineola Fairgrounds.

Aldous Huxley's new novel, "Eyeless in Gaza," which was earlier announced for publication this Spring, has now been put in the first position on the Harper Fall list. The novel is said to mark a change in Huxley's philosophy.

LONDON, June 10. -- After one of the grimmest battles ever seen on any polo field, the United States beat England in the first match of the two-out-of-three game series for the Westchester Cup at Hurlingham today by 10 goals to 9. The crowd of 10,000 persons, the largest that ever has witnessed a polo game here, included the Duke and Duchess of Gloucester and hundreds of Americans.
After developing a slightly easier tone yesterday morning, prices on the Cotton Exchange steadied under persistent trade demand and ended unchanged to 4 points lower than on Tuesday.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., June 10. -- Progress in all phases of college life, the opening of several new buildings, added activity in many branches and an improved financial condition were shown by President McConaughy of Wesleyan University in his annual report to the trustees, made public today.

PHILADELPHIA, June 10. -- Militant fundamentalists, who will meet tomorrow for the announced purpose of forming a new church organization, accused officials of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America today of exerting "last minute pressure" to deprive them of a meeting place.

CENTENNIAL STADIUM, LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 10. -- In a speech which constituted a virtual challenge to the Republican National Convention, President Roosevelt tonight opened a totally unexpected campaign for broadening interpretation of the Constitution to embrace all legislation necessary to safeguard human welfare under modern conditions.

R.H. Macy Co. omitted from their report for 1935 to the Securities and Exchange Commission, which was given out yesterday, the salaries of its principal executives, stating that "the registrant finds it impractical to furnish such material prior to May 31, 1936, the date on which this annual report is required to be filed."

CHICAGO, June 10. -- Lucius J.M. Malmin, one of two Chicago lawyers accused of having used unethical methods in trying to gain a political appointment from Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes, was disbarred today by the Illinois Supreme Court.

Mr. and Mrs. J. Cheever Cowdin gave a dinner last night in the Viennese Roof Garden of the St. Regis for Lord and Lady Milford Haven. The other guests were Mr. and Mrs. Ottavio Prochet, Mr. and Mrs. Russell Forgan, Mrs. Julien St. C. Chaqueneau, Mrs. Jorge R. Andre, Miss Corinne Griffith, Prince Serge Obolensky, William K. Dick and M. Dorland Doyle.

A total of 398 degrees will be conferred by Brooklyn Law School of St. Lawrence University at its thirty-fourth annual commencement this morning at the RKO Albee Theatre, 1 Albee Square, Brooklyn, In addition to 324 Bachelor of Laws degrees, 58 will be Master of Laws and 16 will be Doctor of Juridical Science.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 10. -- The amounts of German purchases from Brazil for one year under the new trade agreement were revealed today. Germany will buy more of a number of commodities than in the past year. She will take 1,600, 000 bags of coffee compared with 871,000; 10,000 tons of frozen meat against 50, 200,000 cases of oranges against 16,180 and 4,000 tons of bananas against 100.

The "irritating and needless word 'obey'" will be omitted from the marriage ceremony by ministers of the Congregational and Christian churches if a recommendation to be made at the biennial meeting of the National Council of those united denominations is adopted.

Warden Lewis E Lawes of Sing Sing testified for the State of New York yesterday before Judge Emanuel Greenberg of the Court of Claims in the $50,000 suit brought by Mrs. Florence Cronin against the State on the ground that her son Bartley Cronin, who was stabbed by a fellow convict in the Great Meadow prison, on April 14, 1935, was killed through negligence of the keepers.

WASHINGTON, June 10. -- An assertion that the keynote speech of Senator Steiwer at the Republican convention "hardly squares" with his own voting record and contained a "great vacuum" with regard "to what happened during the last four years of Republican rule in the United States" was made today by James A. Farley, Democratic National Chairman.

Dr. Frederick B. Robinson, president of City College, will not be the sole target of the investigation of college affairs ordered by the Board of Higher Education, it was learned yesterday. The actions of deans, department heads and other ranking members of the institution's faculty will be sifted by the board's inquiry committee in its effort to fix responsibility for the frequency of student and staff difficulties.

Alfred E. Smith became curator of the new Staten Island Zoo yesterday at dedicatory ceremonies at Clarence T. Barrett Park, West New Brighton. The honorary night custodian of the Central Park animals, who is also renting agent for the Brooklyn menagerie, responded in tones vibrant with satisfaction.

CHICAGO, June 10. -- Lighter receipts of hogs here today, only 13,000 head, which was the second smallest run for a Wednesday in six weeks, made for a steady market and an advance of 5 to 10 cents a hundredweight over Tuesday's close.

As an aftermath of the investigation of the brokerage firm of Walter P. McCaffray Co. and the suspension of the firm from the New York Stock Exchange, the governing committee of the Exchange amended its rules yesterday to require all members carrying margin accounts to notify the business-conduct committee of the Exchange of the character of their business.

MADRID, June 10 (AP). -- Five men, including four officials of American and British banking institutions, were held incommunicado tonight while the government investigated what it called a large conspiracy to smuggle currency from the country.

Two weeks from today the bombardment of America will start. In fact, in a small way, the first faint shots are now echoing across the country, but inside of two weeks they will have gained such proportions that they can no longer be denied or ignored by any one.

The city of Newark, N.J., will be in the market on June 23 with a new issue of $1,000,000 of airport and water bonds which will be dated June 1, 1936, and mature from June 1, 1937 to 1976. Bidders are to specify a rate of interest not exceeding 4 per cent.

Regarding your attitude in the matter of water supply as expressed in yesterday's editorial, I wish to point out what seems to be a one-sided way of dealing with a great public question. You have in your possession certain data which if carefully studied would tend to discredit your conclusion that a danger point has been reached in the margin of safety required to avert a famine of water in this city.

Norman Thomas dispatched a telegram to President Roosevelt in Arkansas yesterday, calling upon him to take action to prevent further violence against striking sharecroppers in that State. In his telegram Mr. Thomas, the Socialist candidate for President, said:

The United States will be represented at Berlin by the largest Olympic team in its history, it became known yesterday when Frederick W. Rubien, secretary of the American Olympic Committee, forwarded to the German Organizing Committee the national entry forms for the various international events.

LONDON, June 10. -- Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, gave a further indication tonight of the line the British Government may take in reform of the League of Nations. He suggested to the members of the 1900 Club that regional arrangements or guarantees might be concluded to localize world danger spots.
The purchase of new equipment for research work and salaries for research workers are among the items provided for in $39,402 gifts to Columbia University, it was announced yesterday.

VIENNA, June 10. -- Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, German Minister of Economics and president of the Reichs-bank, arrived by air from Berlin this evening on his tour of Southeastern Europe. Franz von Papen, the German Minister, greeted him at the airfield, from where he was driven to the legation.

In a letter to THE TIMES Charles H. Ingersoll included Professor Irving Fisher's suggestion of government lending to manufacturers among the queer nostrums for reducing the unemployment, which Mr. Ingersoll must admit is still our greatest problem, despite all the government has already done to create a consumer spending power.

Governor LEHMAN'S reasons for signing the Twomey bill calling for a referendum in this city next November on the question of establishing the three-platoon system in the Fire Department are not convincing. He insists that this measure does not violate the home rule principle.

SEATTLE, Wash., June 10. -- Delegates to the thirty-fourth annual convention of the American Institute of Banking voyaged today to Victoria, B.C., aboard the Canadian Pacific liner Princess Marguerite after a brief session this morning. A dance band accompanied them.

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 10. -- For proficiency in Spring sports, 124 athletes of the United States Military Academy received awards at the athletic review this morning. Members of the baseball, lacrosse, track, golf, polo and tennis squads were honored.

CLEVELAND, June 10. -- Miss Mildred Reeves of the District of Columbia, who came into prominence yesterday as the first woman in history to help draft a Republican national platform, was definitely among those present in committee and convention last night and today.

WEST POINT, June 10. -- While hundreds of graduates and a crowd of visitors assembled here for the "June Week" program lined the wide parade field this evening, Major Gen. William D. Connor, superintendent of the Military Academy, presented "stars" and other awards to cadets distinguished in scholarship and other achievements.

Mrs. H. Walter Blumenthal, the former Baroness Levi, advanced to the quarter-finals of the women's New York State championship yesterday as the brackets in this round were completed at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club, Queens.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 10. -- For eleven crowded hours today President Roosevelt participated in the celebration of the centenary of statehood for Arkansas, attending public demonstrations in both Hot Springs and this city, as well as an old-fashioned camp meeting at a rural Methodist church erected in 1836.

On a field bordered with violet and white, New York University conferred degrees, certificates and awards upon 4,206 graduates and other honored recipients yesterday at its 104th annual commencement exercises on University Heights.

NEWARK, N.J., June 10. -- Dean Christian Gauss of Princeton University will be the principal speaker at the first commencement exercises at the merged University of Newark tomorrow night at the Mosque Theatre. Dr. Frank Kingdon will confer degrees on 192 students.

MELBOURNE, Australia, June 10. -- The extraordinary circumstances surrounding the shooting of Superintendent Brophy, head of the criminal investigation department, in Royal Park on the night of May 22 were the subject of an investigation today.

The first-degree murder trial of Miss Elizabeth Voloshin, 22 years old, in the poisoning of Stephen Shubunka, 33, last Feb. 22 in an apartment at 315 West 106th Street, where she was employed, had to be halted temporarily in General Sessions yesterday when the defendant and a woman witness broke down.

TOKYO, June 10. -- Sir Frederick Leith-Ross, chief economic adviser to the British Government, has now exchanged views with Foreign Minister Hachiro Arita, Finance Minister Eiichi Baba and Lieut. Gen. Rensuke Isogai, Vice Chief of the Army General Staff.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP). -- Joseph B. Eastman, Federal Coordinator of Transportation, today made public the conclusion reached from a two-year study which approved "collective bargaining" methods in fixing wages for railroad employes.

PUBLIC AUDITORIUM, CLEVELAND, June 10. -- Speaking before nearly fifteen thousand persons in the Republican National Convention tonight, Herbert Hoover, former President of the United States, compared the New Deal with the "march of socialism and dictatorships" in Europe and called upon the American people to enter upon a "holy crusade for freedom."

It is a coincidence that payments from European nations on their war debts to the United States have fallen due at a time when the Republican party is holding a national convention, but the coincidence could be used to point a moral in a field of public policy in which both Republicans and Democrats are interested.

Twenty-five out of thirty-five "upstairs" divisions of local department stores showed advertising increases during May, according to the "breakdown" issued yesterday by Media Records, Inc. Total linage for the month was 3,395,722, against 3,061,759 for May, 1935

Dr. Henry C. Turner, president of the Board of Education, will deliver the commencement address of the Flatbush School, 1,615 Newkirk Avenue, Brooklyn, at exercises at the Flatbush Congregational Church tonight. Dwight R. Little, principal of the private school, will officiate.

Coincident with the notification ceremonies at the Democratic National Convention in Philadelphia on June 27, rallies of members of the Roosevelt Nominators will be held throughout the State to listen to the President's address accepting renomination.

Plans to reorganize the Brooklyn Academy of Music, which filed a petition under Section 77b of the Federal Bankruptcy Law on April 22, 1935, were submitted in Federal court in Brooklyn yesterday by Adrian Van Sinderen, president of the corporation.

It turns out to be Lee Ephraim who, in association with Dwight Deere Wiman, will offer the English production of "On Your Toes." London-bound tonight on the Aquitania, Mr. Ephraim plans an Autumn showing over there for Mr. Wiman's current musical success.

NAPANOCH, N.Y., June 10. -- Whatever else may be said of Max Schmeling and his chances against Joe Louis when they meet at the Yankee Stadium June 18, none can deny that the German is possessed of supreme confidence.
PITTSBURGH, June 10. -- Van Lingle Mungo, 25-year-old star of the Dodger pitching staff, today deserted the club and returned to Brooklyn.

PHILADELPHIA, June 10. -- A warning against "excess faith in ideas" was voiced by Professor James Grafton Rogers of Yale University in a commencement address at the University of Pennsylvania today. He appealed to American universities "to think in longer time periods, welcome every theory to their doors and indoctrinate none," and urged the graduates to avoid becoming "dated."

Formal offering will be made today of a new issue of $83,000,000 of Federal Land Banks 3 per cent consolidated Federal farm loan bonds due on Jan. 1, 1956, and redeemable after Jan. 1, 1946. The bonds will be priced at 100 1/4 and interest, to yield about 2.97 per cent.

PARIS, June 10. -- As the French strike epidemic dragged on today with less progress toward a general settlement than had been expected, the new Blum government faced a growing sentiment among certain elements for forcing private industry into bankruptcy.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 10. -- Dr. Robert C. Clothier, president of Rutgers University, will confer 231 degrees at the annual commencement of the School of Education of the university in the college gymnasium tomorrow afternoon.

TOKYO, Thursday, June 11. -- The Japanese-Netherlands shipping war has ended in a heavy defeat for Japan out the Netherlands side, anticipating early resumption of the general trade conference, has conceded terms that grant Japanese shippers virtually the position they occupied before the war began.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 10. -- The University of California rowing squad arrived here this morning to begin a campaign aimed at the intercollegiate championship on June 22 and the Olympic trials later.

HERBERT HOOVER went before the Republican convention last night not as a candidate for his party's nomination, not as a partisan of any one who aspires to the nomination and not as a spokesman of any group or faction, but as the titular leader of his party, seeking unity for the Republicans and a vindication for himself.

CLEVELAND, Thursday, June 11. -- Platform declarations which would commit the Republican party to a "sound and stable currency" to be attained by a balanced budget, repeal of the Presidential power to fix the value of the dollar and avoidance of foreign alliances through the League of Nations or the World Court were among planks laid before the full resolutions committee late last night for final ratification.

PUBLIC AUDITORIUM, CLEVELAND, June 10. -- The Republicans of the East capitulated to the Republicans of the Mississippi River basin today, having received certain assurances on the platform, and, unless William E. Borah can prevent the nomination of the Governor of Kansas -- a slight possibility indeed -- he will be chosen on the first or second ballot.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 10. -- A single by Toshiatsu Tsuruzaki in the ninth inning, sending Saburo Nagata across the plate, gave the Waseda nine from Tokyo a 5 -- 4 victory over Princeton today on University Field.

BERLIN, June 10. -- Chaplain Mierzwa, a Catholic priest from Ratibor, was sentenced by a local court to fifteen months' penal servitude today on a charge of immorality involving a 15-year-old girl whose confessor he had been. The announcement of the sentence gave no details, merely saying that the evidence had revealed numerous cases showing the moral inferiority of the accused.
TOPEKA, June 10 (AP). -- Governor Landon said today that he hoped there would be "harmonious agreement on a platform" by the Republican National Convention.

PARIS, June 10. -- More resistance developed on the Bourse today, but little business was done. Although the main issues of the wide strike have been settled, so many small strikes are continuing and breaking out every hour that the position is very uncertain.

CLEVELAND, June 10. -- Godfrey G. Gloom, the veteran Jeffersonian from Amity, Ind., was discerned in the convention hall this morning, imperfectly disguised by the gilt badge of an honorary assistant sergeant-at-arms and a pair of amber sun glasses.

The importance of consumers as the final court determining the life of an economic method or service was stressed yesterday at the distribution conference of the National Confectioners Association in annual convection at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 10. -- The Governor's Cup, for which marksmen of the New York National Guard and New York Naval Militia have competed annually since it was offered in 1893 by Governor Roswell P. Flower, has been won twice heretofore with perfect scores.

A BLACKGUARD, mischievous set of memoirs, which once started all fashionable London chattering and drove the ready pens of the writing gossips at full speed, while such critics as Sir Walter Scott and Lord Canning express grinning appreciation, provides the basis for Angela Thirkell's "Tribute to Harriette: The Surprising Career of Harriette Wilson" (Random House, $2.50).

WASHINGTON, June 10. -- Charges and counter-charges today marked the last hearing to be held for several weeks in the Federal Communications Commission's inquiry into the affairs of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.
CLEVELAND, June 10. -- Former President Hoover's address to the Republican convention tonight was as follows:

The engagement of $4,540,000 gold in France for shipment here was reported yesterday at the Federal Reserve Bank, bringing to $339,300,000 the total of gold engaged abroad since April 24. Of this, $270,600,000 has been taken in France.

EL PASO, Texas, June 10. -- Ruling today that the National Labor Relations Act was unconstitutional in its entirety, Federal Judge Charles A. Boynton of the West Texas District granted an application of the El Paso Electric Company, a Stone-Webster subsidiary, for a permanent injunction against the members of the National Labor Relations Board at Washington.

LONDON, June 10 (AP). -- England's gallant four horsemen today came thrillingly close to springing the biggest polo upset since the war in their defeat in the opening match of the international cup series.
LONDON, June 10. -- Increasing impatience and annoyance are evident in official quarters here because Germany has not yet replied to the British questionnaire of May 6.

Making public the results of a survey just completed into the costs of Federal, State and local governments, the National Industrial Conference Board announced yesterday that expenditures of all governments in the United States rose from $12,232,000,000 in the fiscal year 1933 to $14,449,000,000 in 1934.

Robert Edward Edmondson, anti-Semitic publisher, failed to appear in the Tombs Court yesterday morning to answer the summons issued by Mayor La Guardia Monday charging him with criminal libel. After Magistrate Mogilesky had threatened to have a warrant issued for him, John S. Wise Jr., a lawyer, of 135 West Sixteenth Street, appeared for him.

PHILADELPHIA, June 10. -- Flowers from private gardens of near-by estates formed a setting for the dinner dance and cabaret held at the Philadelphia Country Club tonight as a prelude to the opening tomorrow of the Philadelphia Annual Horse Show at the polo grounds of the club in Bala.

ALBANY, June 10. -- A report from the Committee on Moral and Social Welfare was rejected today by the United Lutheran Synod after delegates had assailed it as an "alarmist" view of the state of society. Placed before the convention this afternoon, the report made no recommendations, but offered observations.

PHILADELPHIA, June 10. -- Officers of the graduating classes of Temple University took part today in traditional ivy-planting ceremonies outside Mitten Hall as part of their program of pre-commencement activities.

Wherever one turns he sees things going by contraries. Soviet Russia is getting ready to introduce the secret ballot and other free institutions, but in New York City south of Fifty-ninth Street a great many American intellectuals have lost faith in voting and other liberalist practices and doctrines.

THE first time that Rogers Hornsby ambled to the plate this season with bat in hand he beat the Tigers out of a close ball game in Detroit. The first full day he worked in uniform he led and helped his St. Louis Browns to a victory over the league-leading Yankees in their own ball park. The old gentleman certainly picked his spots.

BOSTON, June 10 (AP). -- Former Governor Joseph B. Ely, administration critic, said today he would cast his lot with the Republican party if the Democratic party's 1936 platform attempted to revive New Deal policies declared unconstitutional.

An intermediate accounting in the estate of John Whalen, banker and lawyer, who died on Dec. 31, 1926, filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday, disclosed that his bequest of one-half of his residuary estate to Cardinal Hayes was worth $1,346,252.

CHICAGO, June 10. -- America's biggest bank, the Chase National of New York, is perfecting plans for retiring its $50,000,000 of outstanding preferred stock, $46,222,160 of which is held by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, The Chicago Tribune says.
CLEVELAND, June 10. -- The text of the address made today by Representative Bertrand H. Snell of New York as permanent chairman of the Republican national convention was as follows:

With current market influences continuing to be on the side of advancing prices, stocks moved higher again yesterday, although irregularly so, and trading was heavier. The day's grist of trade news, corporate reports and dividend announcements was reassuring.

BOSTON, June 10 (AP). -- The Red Sox used every one of their five hits today to finish on top of the Detroit Tigers, 4 to 3, in a thrilling pitching duel between Wes Ferrell and Rookie Clarence Phillips.
PRINCETON, N.J., June 10. -Reunion activities of the 189th commencement week at Princeton University will begin tomorrow evening with the first session of the third annual faculty-alumni forum.

Quick action by Irving Wolf, superintendent of the new Rialto Theatre building at Forty-second Street and Seventh Avenue, in extinguishing a small fire, averted what might have developed into a serious situation in the recently opened arcade of the Times Square subway entrance at 3:30 P.M. yesterday.

The Harriman Memorial Gold Medal for Safety, the most coveted prize in the field of railroad safety, was awarded yesterday to the Union Pacific Railroad, at a luncheon at the Hotel Commodore given by Arthur Williams, president of the American Museum of Safety.

LONDON, June 10. -- J.H. Thomas, former Colonial Secretary, will announce his resignation from Parliament tomorrow at the start of the debate over the recent leakage of budget secrets. He will not, however, have to face a criminal trial.

The Royal Dutch Company, a holding organization for oil companies, reported yesterday for 1935 a net income of 54,279,189 florins, equivalent to $36,692,732 after expenses, taxes, interest and other charges. This after dividends on its 4 per cent preferred stock equaled 10.76 per cent on 503,624,000 florins of ordinary stock.
Permission was granted yesterday by the committee of the whole of the Board of Estimate for the Sanitation Department to purchase $8,000,000 of new equipment consisting chiefly of snow apparatus.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 10. -- Contrary to the usual changes in factory employment and payrolls which showed decreases, Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews reported today that in the period from April to May there were increases of 0.2 per cent in employment and 0.7 per cent in payrolls.

WASHINGTON, June 10. -- The California Water Service Company has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an amendment to its registration statement for the issuance of $10,000,000 of first-mortgage 4 per cent bonds due on May 1, 1961, and $550,000 of serial notes that will mature serially from May 1, 1937, to May 1, 1946, giving the offering date as June 12, this Friday.

James A. O'Leary, Representative from Richmond County, is expected to take the witness stand in Federal court, today to deny a story given yesterday at the trial of a former inspector of the Home Owners Loan Corporation that he "got so liquored" about a year ago in Washington "that he almost swallowed his false teeth."

Commenting on a report from Chicago that the Chase National Bank here was planning to retire its $50,000,000 of preferred stock, Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the bank, said yesterday that although the matter had been under consideration for some time, no conclusion had been reached.

CLEVELAND, June 11. -- The Plain-Dealer says Senator Borah appeared "stunned" when informed at Akron tonight that Governor Landon had declared for a gold-backed currency and a constitutional amendment, if necessary, to permit State regulation of wages and hours.

The absence of editorial comment by THE NEW YORK TIMES, which has always been alert on conservation matters, on the enactment by the 1936 Legislature of two bills making possible the construction of a summit shelter and an elevator shaft on Whiteface Mountain, seems to me surprising.

PUBLIC AUDITORIUM, CLEVELAND, June 11. -- Nature and art were combined in bringing Governor Landon before the national public with a skill which was never shown by the Old Guard. To build up William McKinley to the status of 1896 (Mark Hanna's feat) was not a comparable performance.

WASHINGTON, June 11. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended June 10, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,476,000,000, unchanged from the preceding week and the corresponding week in 1935.

BOONTON, N.J., June 11. -- George Voigt of Winged Foot, Walker Cup team nominee, set a course record of 69 today at Knoll, but the fine performance enabled him to get nothing better than a tie for first place in the first annual Women's New Jersey Golf Association's four-ball mixed foursomes.

ST. LOUIS, June 11 (AP). -- Coming to life with four runs in each of the eighth and ninth innings, the Phillies scored their first victory of the season over the Cardinals, 12 -- 4, today. Each team got thirteen hits, the collection including seven doubles, three triples and a home run.

As I watched in convention hall and listened to the typical convention noises with the eyes and ears of one who has no party prejudices and has never aligned herself with one party or another. I had a feeling that the circus around me was a screen that all but obscured the basic reasons for this great gathering.

Prices of commodity futures were generally higher yesterday in more active trading. Raw silk futures scored heavy gains in the largest turnover since Feb. 26. In the cash market all staples, including wheat, corn, rye, butter, tin, printcloths silk, rubber and cocoa were higher.

WARSAW, June 11. -- The Polish Government has reacted to the change in French Government by sending as Ambassador the young radical, Julius Lukaszewsicz, to replace Dr. Alfred Chlapowski, who has represented Poland in Paris for twelve years in the old, traditional diplomatic manner.

CLEVELAND, June 11. -- The Landon bandwagon made its final rounds this morning and, before it had proceeded further than from Alabama to Arkansas, it was necessary to hitch on a string of trailers because of the great crush of delegates crowding, pushing, fighting to get aboard.

ON BOARD PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT'S SPECIAL TRAIN, June 11. -- Coming to Texas to participate in the Lone Star State's celebration of the centennial of its independence from Mexico, President Roosevelt received a welcome as warm as the sun that beat down today on the prairies at stops in Houston, San Antonio and Austin.

LONDON, June 11. -- James Henry Thomas, forced out of the Cabinet because he was accused of having revealed budget secrets, stepped out of public life today in a scene filled with emotion such as Parliament has seldom witnessed.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., June 11. -- Guy the Tramp, owned by W.C. Crummer of Pinehurst, N.C., won the 2:14 trot at the opening session of the Penn-Jersey circuit meeting on the Flemington Fair Grounds today.

Retail package deliveries in the metropolitan and suburban areas showed an increase of 14 per cent for the week ended June 6, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. The figure compares with a rise of 22 per cent for the previous week.

The "irritating arid needless word 'obey'" will be omitted from the marriage ceremony by ministers of the Congregational and Christian churches if a recommendation to be made at the biennial meeting of the National Council of those united denominations is adopted.

Continuing in a week of unusual activity, building plan filings in the Bronx yesterday called for three six-story apartment houses to cost a total of $420,000. Last Tuesday plans for six houses to cost $1,100,000 were submitted.

Earnings for the typical department store in 1935 enjoyed further recovery from the low levels of the depression both from the standpoint of dollars and percentage of net sales, the showing being the best for any year since 1929, according to the annual survey issued yesterday by the Bureau of Business Research at the Harvard Business School and presented at the mid-year conference of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at Chicago.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

WINCHESTER, Mass., June 11. -- By the same score that they lost to Philadelphia on the final day of the intersectional Griscom Cup team matches in Philadelphia last year, the New York players turned the tables at the Winchester Country Club today, defeating the defending champions, 9 to 6.

Field, Glore Co. and F.S. Moseley Co. will offer today to the public 60,000 shares of 5 per cent cumulative $100 par value preferred stock of the Associates Investment Company with common stock purchase warrants attached. The price will be $103 a share.

Recent decisions of the United States Supreme Court on economic and social legislation will enlist many supporters to the ambitions of organized labor to urge both of the major political parties to include in their platforms recommendations for the support of an amendment to the Constitution to require two-thirds vote of the Supreme Court to declare legislation unconstitutional.
CLEVELAND, June 11. -- Herbert Hoover's demand for a "gold standard" plank was contained in a telegram to Chester Rowell, chairman of the California delegation, which read as follows:
BOSTON, June 11 (AP). -- Rick Ferrell's bat bludgeoned the Browns into defeat today as the Red Sox won the series opener, 7 to 5.
PARIS, June 11 (AP). -- A British plan for the abolition of sanctions against Italy has been presented to the French Government for its agreement, it became known tonight.

Included in a large volume of business rentals reported yesterday was a contract for space in the RCA Building, Rockefeller Center, signed with the National Fuel Gas Company, which is quitting downtown Manhattan after maintaining offices in 26 Broadway for thirty-four years. The organization, which controls fuel gas companies operating in Western New York and Pennsylvania, will occupy its new quarters immediately.

SYRACUSE, June 11 (AP). -- Police guarding the Remington Rand Company factory here, center of a three-week old strike, was ordered today to "stop using kid gloves on these strikers and swing your clubs."

PUBLIC AUDITORIUM, CLEVELAND, June 11. -- The opening prayer at tonight's session of the Republican National Convention was offered by Bishop James W. Brown, minister of New Mother African Methodist Episcopal Zion Church, the largest Negro church in Harlem.

CLEVELAND, June 11. -- The Landon forces have not yet abandoned the hope of persuading Senator Vandenberg to accept the nomination for Vice President, despite reiteration of his announcement of last week that his decision to remain in the Senate was "final."

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 11. -- Several new varieties of roses and lilies and an exhibition of a rare tropical flower featured the second day of the fifth annual Westchester Flower Show at the County Center here today.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 11. -- An unbossed Republican National Convention, yet working like a machine, at 11:41 o'clock tonight unanimously nominated Alfred M. Landon of Kansas for President, adopted unanimously a platform embracing certain social welfare ideas of the New Deal (which otherwise is excoriated) and seated party control in a group of young Kansas politicians and editors who entered the national political field less than two years ago.
PARIS, June 11. -- During the absence of the editor, Georg Bernhard, in the United States, his newspaper, the Pariser Tageblatt, has been taken from his control and he has been dismissed.

That the railroads will substantially increase their newspaper advertising appropriations this year over the $3,500,000 spent in 1935 was indicated by a statement yesterday by the Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association.

Homer Saint-Gaudens director of fine arts at the Carnegie Institute, Pittsburgh, returned yesterday on the United States liner Manhattan from Europe, where he has been assembling pictures since March for the 1936 Carnegie international exhibition of painting, which will open in Pittsburgh on Oct. 15 and continue through Dec. 6.
CLEVELAND, June 11. -- Following is the text of the party platform as adopted by the Republican National Convention tonight:

With trading the heaviest of the year, prices on the Cotton Exchange moved upward sharply yesterday into new high territory and ended with gains of 5 to 24 points and all positions above 11 cents a pound for the first time since Dec. 9.

NAPANOCH, N.Y., June 11. -- Seven rounds of boxing constituted the major part of Max Schmeling's training today. With one of the largest week-day crowds of the campaign looking on, the German heavyweight, who fights Joe Louis at the Yankee Stadium a week from tonight, engaged four spar-mates and his performance, to say the least, failed to impress the gathering, which was predominantly German.

The danger of heavy loss to farmers from the current drought which came near ruining crops in Long Island, New Jersey and Pennsylvania was alleviated to some extent in certain sections last night when heavy rains fell within a wide radius of New York.

The trial of a suit of the city against its former chamberlain, now Representative Charles A. Buckley, for $25,800 for making an allegedly improper investment, began yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Hammer. The city also names two bonding companies which supplied the $300,000 bond for Mr. Buckley when he became chamberlain on Jan. 3, 1929.
CLEVELAND, June 11. -- Following is the vote by States for Governor Landon when roll was called on the nomination for President:
Karl Freund has opened an exhibition of new sculpture by Vally Wieselthier at his galleries, 50 East Fifty-seventh Street.

Next week's solitary visitor, "Kick Back," has found a home and a date -- the Ritz Theatre on Wednesday evening. This is the Edwin Harvey Blum play christened "Backwash" when the WPA tested it recently in Brooklyn, and among those in its Broadway cast will be Maurice Burke, Walter Scott Weeks, Diane Tempest, Mary Hutchinson and Robert Harrison.

United States Government bonds turned soft yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange on a slightly heavier turnover. Trading in other sections of the market, however, reflected the predominance of constructive influences with speculative interests carrying prices among the secondary issues up fractions to several points.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., June 11. -- Joe Louis sent 800 spectators away from his training camp today thoroughly convinced that there is nothing wrong with the Brown Bomber, despite rumors to the contrary. He thrilled the crowd through eight rounds of boxing against five sparring partners in the best workout he has had since he began preparations for his fight with Max Schmeling.
The Alabama Great Southern Railroad Company declared yesterday a dividend of $1.50 a share on its common stock. The previous payment was $2, on Dec. 31, 1934.

OTTAWA, June 11 (Canadian Press). -- Deposits by the Dominion Government with the Bank of Canada were increased $5,788,957 in the week ended yesterday, the bank's weekly statement showed today. Deposits of chartered banks declined $3,937,379.

The origin and fruition of the candidacy of Governor LANDON will long be ranked among the surprises, one might say the curiosities, of American politics. Unexpected nominations for the Presidency have often been made. Military heroes like General TAYLOR have been chosen, of whose selection by the Whigs DANIEL WEBSTER said that after that no man could feel safe from being nominated for the Presidency.

The fourth annual commencement of the School of Dental Hygienists of the Murry and Leonie Guggenheim Dental Clinic of New York was held last night in the Julia Richman High School Auditorium. Nine members of the class of January, 1936, and twenty-one in the June class received diplomas.

NEWARK, N.J., June 11. -- The Newark Bears registered their sixth consecutive victory with an 8-to-0 triumph over the Toronto Maple Leafs in the second game of their series today. A downpour limited the contest to six innings.
