WASHINGTON, June 11. -- Nine billion dollars would be required by the government annually to carry out a work relief program calculated "to take care of the unemployed on a decent scale," Aubrey Williams, Assistant WPA Administrator, asserted here today.

The labor unions joined yesterday in the fight of the coat and suit manufacturers and wholesalers against the Pope amendment placing a 3 per cent tax on furs and on articles of which fur is the component material of chief value. David Dubinsky, president of the Interiational Ladies Garment Workers Union, in a telegram to Senator Pope, author of the amendment, said:

PARIS, June 11. -- Viscount Cecil of Chelwood, speaking at the American Club here today on whether it was possible to end war, declared that it was wholly a question of organizing an international force.

IF they didn't furnish fun, they wouldn't be the Dodgers. The Great Mungo Rebellion has added to the hilarity of the baseball campaign. Van of the Flatbush Flock was showing the peak of Mungo form in his parting gesture in Pittsburgh, plenty of speed but no control. He was the second wildest pitcher in the league last year.
CHICAGO, June 11. -- American carelessness in 1935 footed up to a loss of 100,000 lives and a cost of $3,450,000,000, the National Safety Council reported today.

An application by the trustees of Series B-K of defaulted New York Title and Mortgage Company certificates, to compel the State Mortgage Commission to turn over $68,710 alleged to belong to the certificate holders, was dropped yesterday in the Supreme Court and an order to show cause granted by Justice Alfred Frankenthaler was withdrawn when the commission agreed to make payment.

Victor F. Ridder, Works Progress Administrator, denied yesterday appeals for the reinstatement in his WPA job of Oscar R. Fuss, executive secretary of the City Projects Council. Efforts by the council to obtain the reinstatement of Mr. Fuss and an appeal by Dr. James E. Mendenhall, sponsor of the "building America project" that Mr. Fuss be returned to his post, proved unavailing.

The establishment of a known sales policy as a basic principle of mechandising was urged yesterday by Seymour Soule, sales manager of the confections division, Kraft-Phoenix Cheese Corporation, at the final session of the annual convention of the National Confectioners Association at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, June 11. -- General American Transportation Company of Chicago filed today a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering $19,250,000 of serial notes maturing serially from July 1, 1937, to July 1, 1946.
MARBLEHEAD, Mass., June 11. -- For the fifth time in the nine years of the McMillan Cup series, the intercollegiate yacht racing championship was won today by Princeton.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 11. -- After the drastic shake-up in Yale's first and second crews yesterday, Coach Ed Leader was busy today shifting his charges and making an eleventh hour attempt to form two eights that might lower Harvard's colors next Thursday.

After hearing testimony for three hours in a case involving the failure of one of Father Divine's enterprises to carry workmen's compensation insurance, Magistrate Nathan D. Perlman in municipal term court yesterday reserved decision and announced that he would call a conference of State officials to decide "what to do about this and similar cases."

Fresh from his big reception at the Republican National Convention at Cleveland, former President Herbert Hoover arrived in New York City yesterday afternoon, to be hailed by several thousand persons at Grand Central Terminal.
WASHINGTON, June 11. -- Instead of the usual decline in department store sales from April to May, an increase was shown this year, according to the announcement of the Federal Reserve Board today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 11. -- Louis H. Johns of this city announced tonight a statement that the Adley Company of this city, the Bay State Carloading Company of Massachusetts and the John J. McCarthy Company of Taunton, Mass., were to be merged to operate a motor trucking business in New England, New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania.

CHICAGO, June 11. -- Grain traders had several surprises today. The first was the failure of wheat prices to decline sharply on a fairly bearish interpretation put on the government crop report which was issued after the close of business yesterday. Sufficient selling developed in the morning to carry prices off sharply.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 11. -- The New York Central Railroad has been experimenting in the last few days on its Harlem Division with a steam locomotive whistle said to be more mellow in tone than those that have allegedly annoyed residents along the right of way.
ROME, June 11. -- To Marshal Pietro Badoglio, 64-year-old conqueror of Ethiopia, was entrusted today another big task -- reorganizing Italy's Army, Navy and air force.

A recommendation to Mayor La Guardia that the case of Thomas P. Sharkey, former fireman, who allegedly accepted $600 for which he promised to obtain a patrolman's job for the brother of the man who paid, be referred to District Attorney Charles P. Sullivan of Queens, was revealed yesterday by Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings and the ratio of reserve to be at the highest of the year to date.

DETROIT, June 11 (AP). -- Two attempts by the Black Legion to assassinate William W. Voisine, Mayor of the suburb of Ecorse, first by bombing his home and then by sending out a "death squad" of picked gunmen, were described today by Dayton Dean, "trigger man" in the organization's execution of Charles A. Poole.

The Summer edition of the New York Telephone Directory (copyright 1936, corrected to May 13) came out yesterday, a bit more gay that the 1935 Winter number put out last December. The chief change lies in the cover design, made up of two rate maps.
MOSCOW, June 11. -- The proposed new Soviet Constitution, which will be published tomorrow, is strikingly different from the earlier Constitution, which became law July 6, 1923.

The second of two supper dances for the benefit of the Community Music Schools was held last night in the Moonlit Terrace of the Biltmore. It was a pre-opening celebration, as the redecorated rendezvous will have its formal Summer opening tonight.

LONDON, June 11. -- The report current in Paris tonight that the British have presented to the French a definite plan for the abolition of sanctions against Italy and for reform of the League of Nations lacks official confirmation, both there and here, and in all probability exceeds the literal facts.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 11. -- A new series of severe sentences imposed on Austrian Socialists, not published in the Vienna press, were reported in this week's Arbeiterzeitung, the official organ of the illegal Austrian Socialist movement.

CLEVELAND, June 11. -- Through the stentorian tones of Nominator John M. Hamilton conveying his sentiments on the merit system in civil service and protective legislation for women and children, Governor Landon tonight undoubtedly has won the good-will, if not the votes, of a large section of the electorate, according to women leaders at the convention.

The Yankees took the first game of their series with the Tigers at the Stadium yesterday -- took at the hard way. Through ten innings and nearly three hours of warfare the McCarthymen had the ball game lost, won, tied and apparently lost again until Robert The Red Rolfe assumed the role of hero.

CLEVELAND, June 11. -- Governor Landon, while approving most sections of the platform, sent the following message which was read to the convention before he was placed in nomination by John M. Hamilton:

Mr. and Mrs. John E. Connelly Jr. gave a dinner last night in the Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria for Miss Muriel Koch and Thomas F. Scholl, who will be married on June 18. The other guests were Mr. and Mrs. Reginald V. Hiscoe, Mr. and Mrs. Albert Connelly, Mr. and Mrs. Leo Kissam and Mr. and Mrs. H. Davies Roulston.

LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., June 11. -- The 126th Annual commencement exercises at the Lawrenceville School will be held tomorrow, with Ivy and Class Day ceremonies in the morning and the awarding of diplomas to a class of 111 in the afternoon at 3:30. No commencement address will be given.

ALBANY, June 11. -- The United Lutheran Synod in its final session today rejected the question of merging Hartwick and Wagner Colleges on Staten Island. This was accomplished only after a debate in which impassioned speeches were made on both sides.

Austria's hopes of setting its house in order continue to be frustrated by its neighbors. Chancellor SCHUSCHNIGG, in his speech last Tuesday after his return from conferences with MUSSOLINI, energetically but vainly strove to show that he is establishing domestic harmony and national security.

Governor LEHMAN designated last week as Safety Week. Thereupon the perversity of things brought a sharp rise in automobile accidents in the city as compared with last year and after a gratifying decline extending over many weeks.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 11. -- Prize day, the forty-sixth commencement of the Rosemary Hall School, took place today in ideal weather at the school in Rock Ridge. Of the thirty-one members of the senior class, twenty-nine received diplomas and two accessit certificates.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday the transfer of the membership of the late Albert E. Goodhart to James N. Slee and the proposed sale of the seat of Charles J. Gallic to Gaines Gwathmey, who, if elected, will become a partner of Elder Co.
ALBANY, June 11 (AP). -- Governor Lehman's signature on twenty-five bills officially ended the 1936 legislative session today, bringing to 944 the number of laws enacted.

WASHINGTON, June 11. -- A cash balance of $299,074.49 as of May 31 was reported to the clerk of the House today by the Democratic National Committee. There was $227,300 on hand when the last quarterly report was made.

BELGRADE, June 11. -- Dr. Hjalmar Schacht began his important Balkan tour when he landed at the Belgrade airfield this morning. Because he is traveling as president of the Reichsbank and not as the German Minister of Economics, he was not officially received, only the governor of the Yugoslav National Bank and members of the German Legation's staff being present.

Those who heard Mr. Ickes's forecast of the Republican convention and platform on the radio last night must, if they had memories four years long, have thought him ungrateful in casting aspersions on the Republican convention because of his claim that Mr. Hearst would dominate it.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 11. -- Mrs. Russell Holman of the Innis Arden Golf Club of Greenwich, Conn., today scored a brilliant 84 over the trick links of the Bonnie Briar Country Club to win the low gross prize in a one-day tournament of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association.

WASHINGTON, June 11. -- Charles Rudy of 240 East Twentieth Street, New York City, and Henry Kreis of Essex, Conn., have received commissions of $7,500 each to execute two sculptures for the facade of the Bronx Postoffice on the Grand Concourse.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 11. -- Miss Adele Thibault, daughter of Mrs. Walter Fortnum Jones of Princeton, was formally presented to society this afternoon at a tea given for her by Mr. and Mrs. Jones at their home.

Cardinal Hayes presided last night at the commencement exercises of Cathedral College, preparatory department of St. Joseph's Seminary and College, in the Cathedral High School auditorium on Fiftieth Street near Lexington Avenue. Diplomas were awarded to thirty-nine graduates, and the degree of Bachelor of Arts was conferred upon thirty-two other young men.

CLEVELAND, June 11. -- Herbert Hoover's place in the Republican party was still a matter of doubt today following the reaction to his fighting speech at the national convention last night, but the opinion was wide that he had put a premium on his services in the coming campaign.

PARIS, June 11. -- This strangely well-behaved strike proved today that Americans, especially the women, are good sports. They were actually enjoying it. The case of one American may be cited as typical, although by request she must be nameless.

CINCINNATI, June 11. -- With a crowd of nearly 17,000 making noise enough for double their number the hapless Dodgers played their first night game of the year tonight and ran their losing streak to eight straight -- their longest in years.

CHICAGO, June 11. -- Stockholders of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company are expected to approve tomorrow plans for retirement of $5,000,000 of the $50,000,000 of the bank's preferred stock owned by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation. The retirement will be effected, it is expected, along with the distribution of a 20 per cent stock dividend on the $25,000,000 of common stock now outstanding.

LENOX, Mass., June 11. -- Miss Marion H. Blodgett, who was graduated yesterday from Miss Mira Hall's school in Pittsfield, was the honored guest at a luncheon given today by her father, Delos A. Blodgett 2d of New York, at Curtis Hotel, Lenox.

WASHINGTON, June 11. -- Rejecting the ultimatum of the Executive Council of the American Federation of Labor, the International Ladies' Garment Workers Union has refused to dissolve the Committee for Industrial Organization, or withdraw from it, according to formal action by the union's executive board.

Alfred Mossman Landon, Governor of Kansas, business man, lawyer and independent oil producer, was swiftly projected to the foreground of the national political picture through establishment of a record as a budget balancer and an economizer at a time when big spending was the rule of the day.

The Northern States Power Company, a subsidiary of the Standard Gas and Electric Company, is to make refunds of about $200,000 to consumers of electricity or steam in Minot, Fargo and Grand Forks, N.D., as a result of orders in April by the Minnesota Board of Railroad Commissioners, according to an announcement yesterday.

LONDON, June 11 (AP). -- Whether the United States can stretch its string of triumphs to six in the Wightman Cup international women's tennis series, to be renewed tomorrow for the thirteenth time, appeared tonight to depend on Miss Helen Jacobs, four times American champion.

CLEAVELAND, June 11. -- For the first time in recent political history a Republican National Convention finds itself in the position of having its activities and its plans for the coming campaign vitally affected by a Democratic tenant of the White House whom it is the party's objective to eject.

PHILADELPHIA, June 11. -- Breaking away from the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America on the ground that it has become apostate, a group of militant Fundamentalists organized late today a denomination to be known as the Presbyterian Church of America.

FONTHILL, Ont., June 11. -- Unhampered by soggy footing and slow greens, Craig Wood of New York and the unheralded Santa Rosa (Calif.) player, Rod Munday, tied for the lead in the first round of the $4,100 General Brock open tournament today as Tony Manero, the new United States open champion and the defending titleholder, trailed five strokes off the pace.

Miss Rose Monastero, 27 years old, of 1,049 East 232d Street, the Bronx, is in Fordham Hospital in serious condition suffering from stab wounds received in a family quarrel last night, in which her two brothers, a sister and her father also were slashed.
PHILADELPHIA, June 11 (AP). -- Bob Johnson hit two homers and a double today to drive in four runs as the Athletics defeated the Cleveland Indians, 5 to 2, in the opener of the current series.

RICHMOND, Va., June 11. -- America has had a "jolly boondoggling drunk, but the bottle is empty and the nation economically must sober up," Royall E. Cabell of Richmond, United States Commissioner of Internal Revenue under the Taft administration, said today before the bankers' section of the National Association of Credit Men here.

The fact that the share market completed yesterday its sixth successive session of rising prices, when a decline through profit-taking could scarcely have been thought unnatural, was heartening to the market's following. There was particular gratification that the industrial shares made a new high mark for the current movement, and also that the trading pace increased, even if little.
JERUSALEM, June 11 (AP). -- Jerusalem was again cut off from the rest of Palestine and the world generally when vandals last night severed telephone and telegraph lines.
BERLIN, June 11. -- Official orders kept public buildings barren of their customary flags and floral decorations today as Catholic sections of the Reich celebrated the Festival of Corpus Christi.

A new chamber of suspended animation, in which adult tissue can be kept alive and functioning without either growing or dying, is described in the current issue of Science, out today, by Dr. Raymond C. Parker of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research.

A number of Long Island clubs publish salt-water fishing guides. These booklets are a real help to anglers seeking information regarding places to fish, species to be caught, boating facilities, hotel accommodations at various centers and other details.

A nation-wide banking syndicate headed by Stone Webster and Blodget, Inc., will offer to the public today a new issue of $30,000,000 of Oklahoma Natural Gas Company bonds and convertible debentures, the proceeds of which will be used to retire all of the outstanding debt and bank loans of the company and its subsidiaries.

SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., June 11. -- A round of sub-par golf brought the medallist honors in the Westchester amateur championship to Willie Turnesa, Holy Cross undergraduate and former titleholder, at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club today.

Any attempt by the government to prescribe by law what proportion of a corporation's profits it is desirable to distribute among stockholders would affect adversely the growth of American business, Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of the General Motors Corporation, says in a letter to its shareholders accompanying the regular quarterly dividend of 50 cents a share and the extra dividend of 75 cents a share, payable today.

Brokers' loans declined $61,000,000 to $1,115,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, according to the condition report of member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City, issued yesterday. The reduction reflected the repayment of some of the borrowings of government security dealers, which had been responsible for a rise of $208,000,000 last week.
SAN ANTONIO, Texas, June 11. -- Following are the texts of the three addresses made today in Texas by President Roosevelt:

Samuel S. Leibowitz remains chief defense counsel for the nine Scottsboro Negro youths accused of criminal assault despite the formation of an Alabama Scottsboro Committee, according to announcement yesterday by the Rev. Allan Knight Chalmers, chairman of the Scottsboro Defense Committee.
CLEVELAND, June 11. -- A list of the new Republican National Committee follows:

SHANGHAI, June 11. -- South China's leaders have decided that since Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, head of the Central Government, seems to prefer "dilatory" tactics, negotiations and offers of money, their best plan is to push forward rapidly and force a beginning of hostilities between the Nanking and Canton (Southern) Governments.

PUBLIC AUDITORIUM, CLEVELAND, June 11. -- More than sixteen thousand persons at tonight's session of the Republican National Convention cheered the nomination of Governor Alfred Mossman Landon of Kansas for President and witnessed the unanimous adoption of the party platform.
CLEVELAND, June 11. -- Senator Borah expressed himself this afternoon as well pleased with the platform sent to the national convention by the committee on resolutions.

WEST POINT, June 11. -- Addressing the Military Academy's Association of Graduates today following Alumni Day exercises at the Thayer Monument, Major Gen. J.G. Harbord expressed "a sense of uneasiness for the future."
CLEVELAND, June 11. -- All day long the Kansas friends of Governor Landon have been struggling to picture him as he really is: a Kansas liberal who is for sound money.

" Cleveland Democrat" presents the question of the method of destroying monopolies in today's TIMES. The question implies that the destruction would be beneficial, and limits discussion to technical means of accomplishment.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 11. -Three new highs in team match records were made here at Camp Smith today in the firing of the New York National Guard and the New York Naval Militia rifle matches. The 102d Engineers of Manhattan set one new record and the New York Naval Militia teams two.

In an article in these columns on May 29 THE TIMES commented upon the discrepancy between the estimate of 11,506,000 unemployed published by the American Federation of Labor and the estimate of only 3,000,000 to 3,500,000 unemployed published by The New York Sun.

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 11. -- Local life insurance underwriters entertained today the State insurance commissioners who are here attending the national meeting of the Association of Insurance Commissioners. Almost 100 commissioners and others were guests at a luncheon in the St. Paul Athletic Club where Louis H. Pink, Superintendent of Insurance for New York, was the principal speaker.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 11. -- The seventeen-year locust has appeared on Long Island, it was reported today by the Nassau County Farm Bureau here. Officials said they had been informed the cicada had been found first in Carmen Avenue, Farmingdale, which is in mid-island just on the Nassau-Suffolk boundary.

NINE years ago Henry Williamson wrote "Tarka the Otter," a story that won the Hawthornden Prize. "Salar the Salmon" (Little, Brown, $2.50) is the successor. "I wanted to write about salmon," Mr. Williamson reports from his cottage in Devonshire, "and put all I knew -- not much -- into it. Sometimes I worked all night and all day; wish I hadn't; now at 39 my hair is white.

Two hundred and fifty children, some of whom have never seen a cow or a farm, spent two hours yesterday afternoon "harvesting" a crop they had planted and cultivated themselves. Each went home proudly with a bag or box filled with radishes or scallions they had grown.

PHILADELPHIA, June 11. -- Use of the "power of dreaming" as a "spur" rather than an "opiate" was recommended to the graduating class of Temple University today by the Rev. Dr. S. Parkes Cadman of Brooklyn.
LONDON, June 11 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:
CLEVELAND, June 11. -- In a dither of excitement, but in almost complete obscurity in the throng, Peggy Landon saw (or rather heard) her father nominated.

A silver-haired "G-woman" unobtrusively sitting among the spectators in Federal court yesterday detected an attempt to coach Major Gen. John F. O'Ryan just as he was about to resume the witness stand as a character witness at the mail fraud trial of four former officers or directors of the defunct Westchester Title and Trust Company.

Ira Hanford, rider of the Kentucky Derby winner, Bold Venture, scored a triple yesterday at Aqueduct in one of the most exciting midweek afternoons the metropolitan turf has seen this season. The young apprentice's winners were Shot and Shell, Jesting and Exhibit.

PUBLIC AUDITORIUM, CLEVELAND, June 11. -- Election of members of the national committee for the next four years was the only business accomplished at the brief afternoon session of the Republican National Convention here today.
PARIS, June 11 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

I have attended conventions at various seasons of the year, which have resulted in both pleasure and profit. But nothing surpasses the summertime comfort of taking my Turkish bath, while fully clothed, in a conference room or convention hall.

The General Postoffice, at Thirty-third Street and Eighth Avenue, sent to stations in Manhattan and the Bronx yesterday for delivery to veterans Monday the first of the bonds in payment of adjusted service certificates. About 450 pouches containing more than 75,000 bonds and checks of the 406,000 to be delivered in this district were sent to the various postal stations of the two boroughs.
Assemblyman Edward S. Moran Jr., Democrat, of Brooklyn, charged yesterday that a ten-cent fare on all rapid transit lines was the real goal of pending negotiations for transit unification.

Officials of the New York Stock Exchange, who for a week have been gathering informally from member firms data on foreign trading securities, admitted yesterday that they had no facts or figures with which to reply to the inferential denial of James M. Landis, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, that Federal restrictions were diverting brokerage business from New York to London and other foreign markets.
The Park Department will open today four new and three reconstructed playgrounds in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens. The openings will be without ceremonies.

PHILADELPHIA, June 11. -- The Democratic Presidential and Vice Presidential nominees will make their acceptance speeches at the same ceremony on Franklin Field the night of June 27. This will be a political precedent, according to W. Forbes Morgan, secretary of the Democratic National Committee.

LONDON, June 11 (Canadian Press). -- Derbyshire gained a decisive ten-wicket victory over Gloucestershire in their English county cricket championship match at Derby today. Gloucestershire mustered only 95 and 194 runs against the Peak Country's 200 and 91 for no wickets.

AGAWAM, Mass., June 11 (AP). -- The Menden Purse, feature on the Agawam Park card today, went to the heavily played favorite, Uppercut, 6-year-old chestnut gelding owned by Mrs. M. Colford. Apprentice Arthur Cooper, leading rider of the meeting, kept him slightly off the pace to the far turn and then opened up.

CHICAGO, June 11. -- Return of E.L. Cord to the head of the farflung Cord Corporation, a post which he relinquished in 1934, was disclosed in a brief announcement today by L.B. Manning, whom Mr. Cord replaces as president. Mr. Manning will succeed Mr. Cord as chairman of the Aviation Corporation.

Employes of the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company in April paid subscriptions for 10,000 shares of common stock of the company, which also disposed of 3,687 shares through conversion of its bonds. This, along with many other changes by companies, was disclosed yesterday in the reports to the New York Stock Exchange of stock reacquired by listed corporations.
Governor Landon of Kansas, Republican nominee for the Presidency, is a member of the Methodist Episcopal Church.

ROME, June 11. -- Marshal Pietro Badoglio has resigned as Viceroy of Ethiopia in order to be free to exercise exclusively his duties as chief of staff of all Italy's armed forces. Marshal Rodolfo Graziani has been appointed Viceroy.

Among the passengers due today on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen are Gonzalo Santos, Mexican Minister to Denmark, and his son, Gaston Santos; the Misses Elizabeth and Ann Kilpatrick, Dr. and Mrs. Hubert Overbeck, Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Mercer Walker, Mrs. Clement S. Houghton and Lupe Velez, actress.

The annual report of the magistrates' courts of the city for 1935, released yesterday by Chief Magistrate Jacob Gould Schurman Jr., showed that the number of arraignments in the five boroughs increased more than 33 per cent over the preceding year.

QUEBEC, June 11. -- Premier Taschereau, the oldest Canadian statesman in active service, tendered his resignation, together with that of his Liberal Cabinet, to Lieut. Gov. Patenaude today, and asked for dissolution of the Legislature.

CLEVELAND, June 11. -- After the great Republican disaster in November, 1932, there were the customary speculations as to the future of the party, if any. Only persons with very short memories predicted that the party was going to disappear, but there was a pretty general agreement that it needed new leadership; and countless were the speculations as to where that leadership might come from.

LONDON, June 11. -- Prices on the London Stock Exchange continued firm today, but trading was quiet because of settlement day. After opening higher, British funds eased. Far Eastern issues strengthened in the foreign department.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 11. -- The champion of the Hudson -- California -- today shared the interest among the crews training here for the regatta of June 22 with an Eastern contender which has been granted only an outside chance.

Supreme Court Justice Valente reserved decision yesterday on a plea by Isidor J. Kresel, counsel for Carl W. Hamilton, art collector and dealer, to take testimony immediately of Miss Hannah Counihan, formerly an agent for the Anderson Galleries, on the ground that she is a material witness in Mr. Hamilton's $2,000,0000 suit against Lord Duveen and Duveen Brothers.
WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP). -- Holding the White Sox to a single scratch hit in the fifth inning and double in the seventh, Jimmy De Shong today pitched a 2-0 victory for the Senators.

The complete program for the opening day of the final Olympic tryouts at Randalls Island Stadium on July 11 was announced yesterday by William J. Bingham, chairman of the track and field committee, and Frederick W Rubien, secretary of the American Olympic committee and manager of the meet.

Each State has electoral votes in the Electoral College equal to its number in the House of Representatives, plus two United States Senators. The State of New York, for example, has forty-seven electoral votes, made up as follows: Forty-three members of the House of Representatives elected in the various Congressional districts, two members of the House of Representatives elected at large by the voters of the entire State, and the two Senators.

PARIS, June 11. -- In a seven-hour session, the Chamber of Deputies tonight hurriedly voted laws giving workers paid vacations, exempting war veterans from certain taxes, restoring pay cuts of government employes and providing for collective labor contracts.

CLEVELAND, June 11. -- After laboring for three days and nights to draft a declaration of political principles that would come near to satisfying the expected Presidential candidate and placate potential party bolters, the resolutions committee of the Republican National Convention brought forth tonight a platform on which it hopes the party can carry the national elections in November.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 11. -- Splendidly mounted and coordinating in virtually flawless fashion, the young Aknusti riders swept into the final of the third Westbury Challenge Cup tourney today with a brilliant 14-to-6 triumph over Greentree on the Meadow Brook Club's famous International Field.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., June 11. -- Father Nieuwland attended commencement exercises at Notre Dame Tuesday. Later he left for Washington, apparently in good health.

A new slender gas-filled tube, emitting invisible rays which promise to save billions of dollars in the annual meat and bread bill of the American people by eliminating the large waste now caused by bacteria and spores, was demonstrated for the first time in public last night at a meeting of the American Institute of the City of New York at Town Hall.

HEWLETT, L.I. June 11. -- Alick Gerard Jr., Peddle star and son of the well-known professional at the National Links of America, and Celestin Durand shared honors in the qualifying round of the annual Long Island amateur golf championship which got under way at the Seawane Club today.
CLEVELAND, June 11. -- The text of the speech by John Hamilton, national committeeman from Kansas, nominating Governor Landon for the Republican nomination for President, was as follows:

Members of the Stock Exchange who are disturbed by the trend of security trading from New York to London and other markets regreeted yesterday that Chairman Landis of the Securities and Exchange Commission could offer no factual evidence that their fears were not well grounded.

CHICAGO, June 11 (AP). -- The Cubs spotted Boston an early four-run lead today and then persistently sniped at Ray Benge to defeat the Bees, 6 to 4, in the opening game of their series. The victory extended the National League champions' winning streak to eight games and put them in second place, supplanting the Pirates, who were idle.

CARACAS, Venezuela, June 11 (AP) -- The new Venezuelan government, moving swiftly against a general strike started today by workers, threw the strike committee, at Maracaibo into jail and there was shooting on streets here.

Indictments charging malicious criminal libels on Dean Virginia Gildersleeve of Barnard College, Miss Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, and the Jewish religion speedily were voted yesterday by the New York County grand jury against Robert Edward Edmondson, elderly pamphleteer.

Official Referee Oscar W. Ehrhorn heard arguments yesterday on three phases of the tangled affairs of the International Match Company and its Swedish affiliates, the Kreuger Toll Company and the Swedish Match Company. He reserved decision in each instance.

TOPEKA, Kan., June 11. -- With thousands of his neighbors and other citizens of Topeka gathered around the yellow brick Executive Mansion at Eighth and Buchanan Streets, Governor Alfred M. Landon delivered to them tonight a simple message of his appreciation of their loyalty and affection was they gathered to celebrate his nomination as the Republican candidate for President.

Arthur W. Page, vice president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, replied yesterday to a statement made before the Federal Communications Commission that 5 per cent of the stockholders held one-half the company's stock by reasserting the company's contention that it was owned by many persons, none of whom has control.

NEWARK, N.J., June 11. -- An "extreme form of money madness" is the most serious threat to civilization today, Dean Christian Gauss of Princeton University told the graduating class of the University of Newark at commencement exercises in the Mosque Theatre tonight.

Bank clearings for the week ended on Wednesday were the highest in five weeks. The total for twenty-two leading cities in the United States, as reported to Dun Bradstreet, Inc., was $5,651,302,000, compared with $4,776,778,000 in the same week last year, an increase of 18.3 per cent.

Although dealings in foreign exchange continued quiet yesterday, the flow of gold from France to this country was maintained. Engagement of the metal in Paris to the value of $6,125,000 for shipment here was reported at the Federal Reserve Bank.

The platform adopted last night at Cleveland accurately represents the point of view of the new group which has taken command of the Republican party after its four years in exile. These men are not the natural allies of large industrial and financial interests in the East.

Although Robert Nathan's new novel, "The Enchanted Voyage," will not be brought out in book form until August, the picture rights have already been sold to Twentieth Century-Fox Films. Alfred A. Knopf will publish the book.

WASHINGTON, June 11. -- An assertion that former President Herbert Hoover by his speech last night to the Republican convention in Cleveland "has clinched for all time the undisputed championship as the prophet of collapse, despair and panic for the American people" was made today by Speaker Bankhead.

Mr. Steiwer's reference to "flaming youth" and sovietism suggested an argument he seemed to miss. The youth of today and their children must pay not only for their own relief but for that of their parents and grandparents. Any farmer can help his neighbors and live high himself by placing a second mortgage on the farm.

Mr. Steiwer's reference to "flaming youth" and sovietism suggested an argument he seemed to miss. The youth of today and their children must pay not only for their own relief but for that of their parents and grandparents. Any farmer can help his neighbors and live high himself by placing a second mortgage on the farm.

Van Lingle Mungo, star hurler of the Dodgers, who deserted Manager Casey Stengel's club in Pittsburgh Wednesday and came to Brooklyn to make a plea at the home office of the club that he be traded, was met with a $200 fine by President Stephen McKeever yesterday and the notification that he will not be sent to the Giants, Cardinals, Cubs or any other National League club.

WASHINGTON, June 11. -- The Graham-Paige Motors Corporation filed today a statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 612,866 shares of common stock and warrants evidencing the right to subscribe for it. The statement said the shares would be offered at $3 to present holders of common stock on the basis of one share from each four now held.

LEXINGTON, Va., June 11. -- Attorney General Cummings told the students and faculty of Washington and Lee University today that the pioneer spirit had not perished and that education offered new frontiers to cross. He spoke at the dedication of Tucker Hall, the Law School building erected in honor of John Randolph Tucker of Virginia.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 11. -- The spoils system, "always characteristic of our political methods," has never been more "widespread, more flourishing or more costly than at present," Dr. Harley L. Lutz, Professor of Public Finance at Princeton, told several hundred alumni here tonight at the first of the annual reunion events.

WASHINGTON, June 11. -- Wholesale prices, on the average, were unchanged in the week ended on June 6, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The index, based on the 1926 average as 100, remained at 78.4, compared with 79.9 a year ago.

James A. O'Leary, Representative from Richmond County, admitted yesterday in Federal Court that he had just one false tooth, but he denied that he had ever been in danger of swallowing it because he had drunk too much liquor.

MOSCOW, June 11. -- The Presidium of the All-Union Central Executive Committee approved today the text of a proposed new Constitution for the U.S.S.R. and convoked a session of the All-Union Congress of Soviets for Nov. 25 to pass on the Constitution.

PHILADELPHIA, June 11. -- Miss Deborah G. Rood of Wilmington, Del., furnished the thrills at the opening of the twenty-fourth Philadelphia horse show on the sun-parched field at the Country Club, Bala, today.

TOPEKA, Kan., June 11 (AP). -- Governor and Mrs. Landon tonight sat down to dinner alone -- "the first dinner we have had alone for a long time" -- while a throng of townspeople strained against ropes outside the Executive Mansion waiting to celebate their townsman's nomination for the Presidency.
CLEVELAND, June 11. -- The prayer at the morning session of the Republican National Convention by the Most Rev. Joseph Schrembs, Catholic Bishop of Cleveland, was as follows:

CLEVELAND, June 11. -- Godfrey G. Gloom, the veteran Jeffersonian, was discovered this afternoon by a TIMES reporter, shivering on a corner of Superior Street. Mr. Gloom was tastefully costumed in a black overcoat over a Palm Beach suit.

Charles S. Corbett, the enigmatic Brooklyn police detective, emerged from the obscure background of the Drukman murder case yesterday to testify concerning his charge that a $100,000 bribe was offered and an Assistant District Attorney had interceded with him in behalf of the killers of Samuel Drukman.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., June 11. -The Hilberts, who have been struggling for a month in the red-tape bonds of New Jersey relief, have finally found food and lodging. Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Hilbert, their daughters, Roberta, 6 years old, and Mary Lou, 1, were in cells in the Morris County jail here today beginning a sixty-day sentence for disorderly conduct.
Mrs. H. Walter Blumenthal and Miss Norma Taubele, finalists last year, took their places in the semi-finals of the women's New York State championship yesterday at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club.

Nineteen high school students were announced yesterday as winners of the annual essay contest conducted by the Propeller Club of the United States, in which several thousand entrants submitted essays on "The Relationship of the American Merchant Marine to Manufacturing, Agriculture and Labor."

Opening a new path through the "wilderness" spectrum of radio on the 3-meter wave, a New York-Philadelphia facsimile circuit was demonstrated yesterday by the Radio Corporation of America. The system, which is completely secret, is designed for transmission and reception of pictures, maps, handwriting and other visual matter.

SEATTLE, Wash., June 11. -- Fears that banks of the United States will plunge into reckless credit inflation are not justified by facts, delegates to the thirty-fourth annual convention of the American Institute of Banking were told today by Carl S. Dakan of the College of Economics and Business at the University of Washington.

Our Hollywood operative reports that the Shakespearean cloud, yesterday no bigger than a man's hand on the cinematic horizon, has now achieved storm-warning proportions. Hard on the heels of a David O. Selznick announcement of the filming of "Julius Caesar" comes Samuel Goldwyn with a half promise to bring "Othello" to the screen, with Walter Huston, following the play's run on Broadway this Fall, if we are all good children.

The Celotex Corporation reported yesterday for the six months ended on April 30 a net profit of $232,480 after interest, depreciation and other charges, but exclusive of Federal taxes, against which the company had statutory provisions eliminating the requirement for any provision.
CLEVELAND, June 11 (AP). -- Away out in quiet Wade Park Manor, far from the Republican convention, two newspaper men's wives heard good news today.

PARIS, June 11. -- As Paris succumbed today to the French strike fever that has been raging for two weeks, Premier Leon Blum pushed through the Chamber of Deputies his first batch of measures designed to placate the workers.

BERLIN, June 11. -- The Boerse turned weak today at the opening and remained so most of the day, although the losses barely exceeded a point. The reaction was attributed to persistent rumors of a new government loan and also to the report from the Business Research Institute characterizing the present stock level as high, with some issues overvalued.

BERLIN, June 11. -- The Boerse turned weak today at the opening and remained so most of the day, although the losses barely exceeded a point. The reaction was attributed to persistent rumors of a new government loan and also to the report from the Business Research Institute characterizing the present stock level as high, with some issues overvalued.

UPPERVILLE, Va., June 11. -- Ray S. Shoemaker brought with his string of horses from Harrisburg, Pa., Our Way, a fine bay gelding, which captured the largest number of prizes at the opening of the Upperville Horse Show at Grafton Farm today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 11. -- Harvard's nine today failed to come through with the hoped-for victory against Dartmouth -- one that would have carried with it the Eastern intercollegiate title for the year. The Indians won their second game from the Crimson by 4 to 2, with Ted Olson again the winning pitcher.

A Shipping Board investigation of the complaint by the Black Diamond Steamship Line that competitors in the transatlantic trade have violated the terms of their operating agreement will be opened this morning at the Federal building, 45 Broadway.

NEWARK, N.J., June 11. -- The Newark College of Engineering will confer 120 baccalaureate and five professional degrees at commencement exercises tomorrow at 8:30 P.M. in the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company Auditorium at 300 Broadway here.

MADRID, June 11. -- Although not booked on any charges, Benjamin Fulgenzi, American assistant manager of the International Banking Corporation, which is the Madrid branch of the National City Bank of New York, is still held incomunicado in the model prison pending questioning by an examining magistrate as to what he may know concerning the "Black Bourse," or bootleg money exchange.

MADRID, June 11. -- Although not booked on any charges, Benjamin Fulgenzi, American assistant manager of the International Banking Corporation, which is the Madrid branch of the National City Bank of New York, is still held incomunicado in the model prison pending questioning by an examining magistrate as to what he may know concerning the "Black Bourse," or bootleg money exchange.

PEIPING, June 12. -- The warlike declaration of Southern leaders and the advance northward of their armies, ostensibly for an anti-Japanese crusade, are arousing extreme speculation and suspicion in Northern China.

The names of 2,244 young men from New York, New Jersey and Delaware who will go to the Citizens Military Training Camp at Camp Dix, N.J., on July 13 were announced yesterday by Major Gen. Frank R. McCoy, commanding the Army's Second Corps Area.

SYRACUSE, June 12 (AP). -- Workers in one of the three strike-harassed Remington Rand plants in up-State New York received a new ultimatum today -- return to work tomorrow or watch their factory be moved to Marietta, Ohio.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals $16,113,898, represented by State and 107 municipalities. The revised total for this week was $13,046,373 and the weekly average for this year $24,135,778.

By agreement, the annual model boat race between P.S. 209, Sheepshead Bay, and P.S. 29, Brooklyn Heights, on the lake in Prospect Park is a free-for-all. Yesterday the fifth annual renewal set 256 boats afloat, but in the end proved nothing, as the schools came out all square.

FORT WORTH, Texas, June 12. -- President Roosevelt this afternoon received the acclaim of nearly 200,000 persons who lined flag-draped streets here and gathered in the rain at Marine Park to hear him.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 12. -- A rose exhibited at the fifth annual Westchester Flower Show at the County Center here was named today the Peggy Ann Landon Rose in honor of the daughter of the Republican candidate for President.
CHICAGO, June 12. -- The Chicago Tribune, Independent-Republican, commenting editorially on the results of the convention, says:

Plans for two new Roman Catholic parishes in the Diocese of Brooklyn were announced yesterday by Bishop Thomas E. Molloy in connection with the appointment of five to new pastorates, two of which are in the new parishes. Two pastors were transferred and three assistants promoted to the rank of pastor.
PITTSBURGH, June 12. -- With Bandmaster Carl Hubbell conducting a seemingly fine masterpiece today, somebody blew a sour keynote for the Giants that just about wrecked everything.

Architects filed plans yesterday for four apartment houses in the Dyckman section of Manhattan. The proposed buildings will be erected at a total cost of approximately $925,000, three of them to go up on sites at Broadway and Dongan Place, near Fort Tryon Park, and the fourth in Academy Street.

Corporations in the United States cannot discharge their obligations to foreign bondholders with the current devalued United States dollar, according to ruling handed down yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Samuel H. Hofstadter in a suit entered by Netherlands corporations against two subsidiaries of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the Bethlehem Steel Company and the Lackawanna Steel Company.

CLEVELAND, June 12. -- Resisting importunities from Governor Landon to be his running mate, Senator Vandenberg today clung to his earlier decision to continue his attacks on the New Deal in the Senate and not be lured into the national campaign as a candidate for Vice President.

The inevitable reaction to the choice of a man for the presidency of Mount Holyoke is the question "Why?" This is true whether the one who voices the question approves or disapproves of this departure from the tradition of 100 years in this pioneer institution for the higher education of women.

LONDON, June 12. -- Certain bankers and brokers here are beginning to notice an increased volume of trading in American stocks which apparently are being bought in New York and sold here at a profit. This process, it is believed, is a form of tax evasion and it is assumed that the motive behind the operations is a desire to avoid the taking of profits in the United States.

There is a possibility that Eddie Cantor will not make "Pony Boy" for Samuel Goldwyn. The comedian has not been enthusiastic about the story, and yesterday Mr. Goldwyn ordered Henry Johnson to prepare a new treatment of William Collier's "Never Say Die," which the Goldwyn studio has owned for some time.

Acting Lieutenant Albert E. Jenner and Detectives William Walsh and John E. Moran, all of the Bath Beach police station, were named in an indictment returned yesterday by the Kings County grand jury charging assault in the second degree.

The name of District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan of Brooklyn was brought into the Drukman conspiracy trial by his own accused assistant yesterday in an attempt to establish the identity of the "white-haired Willie" said to have been mentioned by Leo P. Byk in an attempt to "fix" the murder case.
NEW LONDON, Conn., June 12. -- Both the Yale and Harvard varsity crews had four-mile time trials this evening, the Cambridge crew rowing unpaced.

WASHINGTON, June 12. -- Coincident with the completion of the Republican ticket and platform, James A. Farley, Postmaster General and Democratic National Chairman, to day moved to solve intra-Democratic fights in twelve States in an effort to present a united administration front against Republican attacks.

Mrs. Concetta Toscarrelli, 45 years old, of 161 Tompkins Avenue, Stapleton, S.I., was shot and killed yesterday by her estranged husband, Basillo Toscarrelli, 46, a tailor, who then turned the pistol on himself, inflicting a serious wound.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP). -- The "Loans Here" signs in 286 offices of the Home Owners Loan Corporation throughout the country were ordered taken down at midnight tonight to make room for "Pay Here" notices to more than 1,000,000 home owners.

The nomination of Colonel KNOX for Vice President will strengthen the belief that the Western Republicans determined to have their way to the end. After having got into the saddle and ridden the Easterners off the track on the questions of the platform and the Presidency, they rudely maintained their ascendency.

In a further step in the readjustment of the funded debt of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., the New York Edison Company, Inc., filed yesterday with the Public Service Commission of New York an application for permission to issue $30,000,000 of 3 1/4 per cent, Series E, first and refunding mortgage bonds, due in 1966.

GROTON, Mass., June 12. -- The time for vocational education to start is when college graduates begin their life's work, Robert M. Hutchins, president of the University of Chicago, declared in the principal address at the annual award day exercises of Groton School here today.

The loss of $4,500 worth of radium somewhere between Switzerland and New York was reported to the police in Queens yesterday by Dr. Ludwig Heine, Professor of Radium Treatment, of Berlin, Germany, upon his arrival at the Kew Gardens Inn, Queens Boulevard and Union Turnpike, Kew Gardens, Queens.

An amendment to the registration filed by the G.C. Murphy Company with the Securities and Exchange Commission shows that J.S. Mack, president, will receive a bonus for 1936 of 2 1/2 per cent of the profit of the company's store operations; W.C. Shaw, vice president, 1 1/2 per cent; E.M. Mack, vice president and treasurer, 1 per cent; B.E. McSheehy, secretary, and J.A. Krut, assistant treasurer, 3/4 of 1 per cent.

While his mates were engaged in pounding two Detroit pitchers for sixteen hits, Charley (Red) Ruffing overcame a shaky start, sagged a bit in the middle, but managed to outlast the opposition as the Yankees took the measure of the Tigers, 9 -- 6, before 12,000 fans at the Stadium yesterday.

Robert Edward Edmondson, elderly publisher, furnished $2,500 cash bail in General Sessions yesterday on his indictment last Thursday on charges of criminally libeling Dean Virginia Gildersleeve of Barnard College, Miss Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, and the Jewish religion.

Miss Elizabeth Voloshin, 23-year-old cook, was acquitted by a jury in General Sessions at 9:20 o'clock last night of murdering Stephen Shubunka, 33, by giving him an overdose of a sedative in the apartment where she was employed at 315 West 106th Street last Feb. 22.

SHANGHAI, June 12. -- Evidently deciding that South China has been met more than half way with patience and forbearance, the Central Government forces today halted their gradual withdrawal northward in Hunan Province.

Princeton will act as host to some 52,000 track followers in Palmer Stadium today when it stages its third annual invitation meet under novel circumstances. No admission is being charged and, at the last count, 47,000 had applied for tickets, leaving a scant 5,000 to be taken care of in order of arrival today.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 12 -- Two hundred and sixty-two baccalaureate degrees and forty-three advanced degrees will be conferred by Dr. Robert C. Clothier, president of Rutgers University, at the 170th commencement in the college gymnasium tomorrow morning.

WATERTOWN, Conn., June 12. -- Dr. J. Edgar Park, president of Wheaten College, told the ninety graduates of Taft School today that "the greatest obstacle in the way of success in life is the difficulty of getting yourself to do the things you don't feel like doing."

PRINCETON, N.J., June 12. -- Four-fifths of all revenue raised by State and local taxes in New Jersey is expended by the local governments, the Princeton Local Government Survey Committee reported today in the second of its series of bulletins.

WEST POINT, June 12. -- The Class President and First Captain of the Class of 1886 of the United States Military Academy stood before West Point's Class of 1936 at graduation exercises at the Battle Monument this morning, asked for courageous leadership in all walks of life and warned that "good citizens cannot shut their eyes to the possibility of war."

The letter in last Saturday's TIMES from William S. Chandler in which he recommended the application of the principles of mechanics in order to step up the records in crew racing opens the doors to lengthy controversies with little or no promise of the desired result.

TOPEKA, Kan., June 12. -- The parlor of the Executive Mansion here was the scene this morning of the real entrance into public life of Mrs. Alfred M. Landon. She held her first press conference there and acquitted herself in a manner to win the instant admiration of the assembled press.

While no one wishes to detract from the fine playing of Tony Manero in the recent national open, it must be apparent to every one that, as matters stood, Baltusrol was not a real test of championship golf.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., June 12. -- Competition in the forty-third annual two-day Westchester County Horse Show, one of the oldest fixtures of its kind in the country, started today in the spacious ring of the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club with events for hunters featuring a highly interesting program.

The Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo, recently installed as pastor of the Collegiate Church of St. Nicholas, has leased an apartment in 1,010 Fifth Avenue from the Fred F. French Company, Mrs. Edward Stout, Inc., the broker, reported yesterday. Other lessees included the following:

The New York Railways Corporation, which is controlled by the Fifth Avenue Coach Company, has reported to the Securities and Ex-charge Commission a net income of $147,095 for 1935 before interest on 6 per cent income bonds, against $212,686 in 1934.

Prices on the commodity futures markets were reasonably steady yesterday, although some heaviness was noticeable in cocoa and silk. In the cash markets, corn, cotton, wool tops, silk, rubber, butter and eggs were higher, while wheat, rye, cocoa and tin were lower.
CLEVELAND, June 12. -- Peggy Anne Landon's departure this morning from the convention city was as unobtrusive as her arrival had been tumultuous.
HONKONG, June 12. -- The first fighting between Central Government troops and the advancing South China armies occurred today.

The second trial of William R. Hayward, suspended principal of the Theodore Roosevelt High School, was closed yesterday before the Board of Education, which will give its decision at its next meeting, June 24.

RICHMOND, Va., June 12. -- Protests against the undistributed profits tax, the unbalanced budget and what was considered proposed monetary inflation were voiced and the public career of Senator Carter Glass was praised at the closing session here today of the forty-first annual convention of the National Association of Credit Men.
PARIS, June 12. -- Paris returned to its normal appearance and life today with the reopening of cafes, restaurants and hotels where strikes had occurred.
CLEVELAND, June 12. -- The prayer offered by Rabbi Louis Wolsey of Philadelphia at the final session of the Republican National Convention today was as follows:

Declaring that the vital problems of the retail trade industry, affecting the interests of more than 5,000,000 directly, are closely linked with political events, Grover A. Whalen, president of the World's Fair, urged retailers yesterday to study the platforms and personalities of the two major parties to determine "which holds out hope for you."
WASHINGTON, June 12. -- Three members of the Republican party's liberal wing today expressed variant reactions to the nomination of Governor Landon for the Presidency.

LONDON, June 12. -- Sir Eric Drummond, the British Ambassador in Rome, has addressed an insistent warning to London that Premier Benito Mussolini's decision to leave the League of Nations unless economic sanctions are removed must be taken seriously.

CHICAGO, June 12. -- There was a wide range in hog prices today with the extreme top at $10.25 a hundredweight, unchanged from the previous day's high and the average price at $9.80, a decline of 10 cents. Most sales were made at $9.50 to $10.15, the latter figure paid by local packers for the best light butchers.

Topped by the Bowman Steeplechase Handicap, a card of six races will constitute the United Hunts Racing Association's annual Spring meeting to be held this afternoon on the estate of Charles V. Hickok in Roslyn, L.I. The opening event will start at 2:45 o'clock.

NAPANOCH, N.Y., June 12. -- Doc Casey, veteran handler, who was behind Jack Delaney in most of the former light-heavyweight champion's important battles, will be in Max Schmeling's corner on Thursday night when the German boxer meets Joe Louis in their fifteen-round bout at the Yankee Stadium.
WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP). -- Buck Newsom gave the White Sox only five hits today and shut them out, 6 to 0, to score his seventh pitching triumph of the season for Washington.

TOPEKA, June 12. -- Eager for "an immediate move on the enemy," Governor Landon laid plans today in his first busy hours as the Republican Presidential nominee for a meeting of his general staff on Monday to study campaign strategy.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 12. -- A strong, downstream wind prevailed all day over the course of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association regatta and gave the crews of the four colleges already here their first taste of really rough rowing today.
NORTHAMPTON, Mass., June 12. -- President Neilson announced at the last chapel exercises of Smith College today that a total of $492,000 had been received in gifts during the year.

Farm agents in New York and New Jersey took stock yesterday and found that the rains of Thursday evening had, on the whole, brought about benefits to the farmers who were facing loss of crops from drought.

PHILADELPHIA, June 12. -- Dixie Belle, 6-year-old black mare owned by Ward Sullivan, won the Olympia course jumping test at the Philadelphia Horse Show on The Country Club's oval at Bala today before an enthusiastic crowd.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., June 12. -- Lefty Tom Bryant bested Dee Coultas of Wesleyan in a pitchers' duel on Weston Field today and Williams triumphed, 3 -- 1, to bring the Purple one step nearer the Little Three championship. An Alumni Day crowd of 3,000 watched Bryant tighten in the pinches and keep eight Cardinal hits well scattered, while his mates were bunching six blows for three runs and victory.

The trial of William F. Baeck, vice president of the defunct Lawyers Title and Guaranty Company, on an indictment charging fraudulent sale of a $1,000 mortgage certificate in February, 1932, ended at 1 o'clock this morning when the jury in General Sessions Court sent word to Judge James Garrett Wallace that it was hopelessly deadlocked.

ST. LOUIS, June 12 (AP). -- The league-leading Cardinals evened the series with the Phillies today by winning, 3 to 2, when Ripper Collins drove his sixth home run of the season to end a pitching duel in the eleventh inning.

CLEVELAND, June 12. -- Colonel Frank Knox of Chicago appealed to the delegates to the Republican National Convention as the strongest possible nominee for Vice President, after Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg of Michigan formally notified them today that he would not accept the second place on the ticket headed by Governor Alfred M. Landon of Kansas.

ANDOVER, Mass., June 12. -- Addressing a graduating class of 194 at Phillips Academy at Andover this morning, President MacCracken of Vassar College based his remarks on the scene in Shakespeare's "Hamlet" where Polonius bids farewell to Laertes with cynical advice.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 12. -- Roger William Straus of New York City, co-chairman of the National Conference of Jews and Christians, will receive the class of 1913 loving cup from his classmates at Princeton University tomorrow for his work in fostering better understanding between Christians and Jews in America.

CHICAGO, June 12 (AP). -- The Cubs, in the midst of a streak reminiscent of their pennant rush of last September, posted their ninth straight victory today, running up their biggest score of the season in a 17-1 rout of the Bees. Tex Carleton limited Boston to eight hits for his seventh triumph of the season.

A commencement address on the "Call of Youth to Catholic Action," by Helen Imelda O'Brien, an honored member of the class of 275 graduates, marked the graduation exercises of Cathedral High School at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday.

By authorizing an extension for six months of the emergency freight surcharges from June 30, when they were due to expire, the Interstate Commerce Commission was seen yesterday as effecting a compromise. Some reductions are ordered in the decision, but the railroads are left with a substantial number of the higher rates which they vigorously demanded.

ROOSEVELT FIELD, L.I., June 12. -- Roosevelt Field No. 1, the upper field, from which Lindbergh, Chamberlin, Byrd, Post, Kingsford-Smith and a host of other well-known fliers have taken off, was dedicated today to a new use, that of the Roosevelt Raceway, a four-mile track for automobile road-racing.

There is just one closing this evening, Mr. Anderson's "Winterset," which is to leave the Martin Beck after a return engagement of two weeks. The play is, of course, the holder of the Drama Critics' first annual prize, and during its various runs it managed to provoke more than its fair share of discussion.

BERLIN, June 12. -- The reaction in prices on the Boerse continued today. Professional traders took profits following the semi-official hint from the Business Research Institute that the price level was !too hih, but the public i appari ently sitting tight because of inflation fears. Losses ranged between 1 and 2 points.

THE free-for-all in the Palmer Stadium at Princeton today should produce some good running debates. Jack Lovelock of New Zealand will not be on hand -- or on foot -- to meet Glenn Cunningham, Gene Venzke and Bill Bonthron in the mile race, but the Cunningham-Venzke-Bonthron rivalry is enough to stir a lot of autos into chugging toward Tigertown this afternoon.

PARIS, June 12. -- With the resumption of work in a goodly number of trades and the re-establishment of the normal appearance of Paris by the reopening of hotels, cafes and restaurants, the Bourse picked up courage today and prices became firmer. Rentes regained a fraction of yesterday's losses and French industrial securities were stronger.

CLEVELAND, June 12. -- Half a dozen of the leading Republican women will join the trek toward the Gubernatorial Mansion at Topeka Tuesday, as members of the committee to notify Governor Landon of his nomination.

A wide divergence of views, but mostly favorable, on the results of the Republican National Convention, are contained in editorial comment in newspapers through the country. Excerpts from editorials follow:

LONDON, June 12. -- A cheerful tone prevailed again today on the London Stock Exchange. British funds strenghened under the lead of war loans. Far Eastern issues were uncertain in the foreign department as Brazilians weakened.

Disruption of the shipping trade between New York and the ports of Antwerp and Rotterdam was threatened yesterday at a hearing of the Shipping Board on an application of the Black Diamond Steamship Line for rejection of a proposed modification of the conference agreement binding ship lines in the North Atlantic Continental trade.

The financial community examined minutely the various planks in the Republican party's platform, and was cheered by those parts regarded as unequivocally stated and remained hopeful about those sections that must await clarification. But the net result was that the markets were undemonstrative.

CLEVELAND, June 12. -- No longer the babes in the Republican woods that they once were, the Young Republicans in the nation made it known at a meeting of their national council this afternoon that the fight of Governor Landon for the Presidency was their fight, and that they were rarin' to go.
It's a long time now since the last All-America football team was selected, so I feel that I won't be ruled out-of-bounds if I pick for you an American Olympic track team.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 12 (AP). -- The No. 2 American doubles team made a glorious comeback today to triumph in the Wightman Cup competition. Miss Babcock and Mrs. Van Ryn downed Miss Dearman and Miss Lyle after trailing at 0 -- 3 in the final set.

Grimes Rayburn Waller, an amateur radio operator well known in this area, was killed by a shock early yesterday in his room in the Hotel Victoria, Seventh Avenue at Fifty-first Street. He apparently had dozed while attempting to communicate by short wave with friends in Texas.

WASHINGTON, June 12. -- The Interstate Commerce Commission, through Oliver E. Sweet, director of its finance division, has called on the Wheeling Lake Erie Railroad for a further explanation of the proposed changes in its capital stock structure as outlined in an application filed a few days ago seeking authority to put the changes into effect, if ratified by stockholders at a meeting on June 29.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers.

The country's speed champion, Sation, will attempt to shoulder top weight of 132 pounds and win the Carter Handicap at Aqueduct this afternoon, in a field of half a dozen entered for the Queen's County Jockey Club's week-end feature.

Vandals broke into the five-story building of the Uptown Talmud Torah (Harlem Hebrew Institute), at 132 East 111th Street, west of Lexington Avenue, between 10:30 P.M. Thursday and 6 A.M. yesterday and wrecked many of the interior furnishings, including sacred books and scrolls.

DALLAS, Texas, June 12. -- President Roosevelt received today as a surprise gift the renewed support of the State Democratic organization in Louisiana, which went to extreme pains in an unexpected ceremony here to mend the breach created by former Senator Huey P. Long's opposition to the administration.

A Christian Youth Conference will be held in Lakeside, Ohio, June 23-28. Some 1,800 delegates have been appointed. They will meet in discussion groups under eighty nationally known religious leaders. The gathering will be under the auspices of the joint committee on the United Youth Movement.

WASHINGTON, June 12. -- In an order granting authority to the Minneapolis, St. Paul Sault Ste. Marie Railway Company to extend for a period ending not later than July 1, 1938, a $5,000,000 loan obtained from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation which will mature on Aug. 1, 1936, the Interstate Commerce Commission found today that the railway was not in need of financial reorganization in the public interest at this time.

SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, June 12. -- Willie Turnesa of Fairview reached the semi-final round of the Westchester amateur golf championship at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club today but had to win an extra-hole match to do so.

Former President Hoover declared yesterday that the Republican Presidential ticket of Governor Landon and Colonel Knox "suits me perfectly," and that he would leave it to Governor Landon and the Republican National Committee to decide what part he should take in the campaign.
MORRISTOWN, N.J., June 12. -- Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Hilbert and their two young children were released from the Morris County jail here today and a house, food and job were obtained for Mr. Hilbert.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP). -- Joseph B. Eastman, Federal Coordinator of Transportation, today recommended sweeping changes by railroads in the passenger field to recapture the business lost in recent years, chiefly to automobiles.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 12. -- America's tennis invasion of Europe got off to a discouraging start today when Great Britain's Wightman Cup team won two of the day's three matches on the center court at Wimbledon.

Because tomorrow is Flag Day, clergymen will preach sermons on the Stars and Stripes. With the Republican National Convention this week and the Democratic Convention in the near future, politics will come in for comment. Annual Children's Day will be observed in many churches.

PHILADELPHIA, June 12. -- The General Assembly of the newly organized Presbyterian Church of America voted into regular standing in the new denomination today those ministers and others who were disciplined by the Presbyterian Church of the United States of America for refusing to resign from the Independent Board for Presbyterian Foreign Missions.

The earmarking of $11,906,300 gold, believed to be for China in exchange for silver under the agreement announced on May 18, was reported yesterday at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The Reserve Bank, following its custom, gave no indication of the foreign central bank for which the gold had been set aside, but inferences pointed to China.

CLEVELAND, June 12. -- Only rarely has the New York delegation to a Republican National Convention been so much in the limelight and received so much attention as have the spokesmen for the New York Republicans to this convention, which went to the West for both its candidates and its impulses.

A rare armorial Brussels tapestry of the late seventeenth century, one of a set of eight hangings made for William and Mary, British sovereigns (1689-1702), has been acquired by the Metropolitan Museum of Art and will be placed on display this morning in the room of recent accessions.

Colonel Frank Knox, publisher of The Chicago Daily News and once a lieutenant in former President Theodore Roosevelt's "Bull Moose" movement, has had a long and active career in journalism and politics to fit him for his role as Republican candidate for Vice President.
ITHACA, N.Y., June 12. -- Dartmouth still retained a mathematical chance of tying Harvard for first place in the Eastern Intercollegiate League race by virtue of an 8-to-4 victory over Cornell today.

The teamsters' and longshoremen's unions will renew next week their drive to organize the waterfront completely, after being halted two years ago by an injunction issued by Supreme Court Justice Burt J. Humphrey. They will refuse to move to and from piers any freight handled by non-union truck drivers and checkers.

Prominent educators joined with authors and school children yesterday in honoring the memory of James Fenimore Cooper, whose name has been perpetuated through romantic novels of the sea and Indian life. Exercises at which a memorial tablet was unveiled were held in the auditorium of the James Fenimore Cooper Junior High School, 116th Street between Fifth and Lenox Avenues.

With the exception of 1929, Remington Rand, Inc., reported yesterday the best first month of a fiscal year in its history. Net income for April amounted to $277,330 after taxes and other charges, and compared with $193,030 earned in April, 1935.

Trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange lapsed into the doldrums, with the only speculative interest of the day being centered in a few selected rail liens. This alone enlivened an otherwise extremely dull and routine market.

CLEVELAND, June 12. -- Some doubt was expressed today by Eastern Republicans, including some in the New York delegation, as to the ability of the party's platform, in view of the eleventh-hour telegram from Governor Landon, to win over the industrial Atlantic seaboard sections and at the same time win the farmers away from the present agricultural program.
Industrial deals featured the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.
Mrs. H. Walter Blumenthal and Mrs. Philip B. Hawk reached the final round of the New York State doubles championship yesterday at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., June 12. -- A scintillating card of 67 by T. Suffern (Tommy) Tailer Jr. over his home links today set a new competitive record for the Piping Rock Club's 6,161-yard course and enabled the former metropolitan amateur champion and his partner, J.S. Frelinghuysen, to capture the gold medals in the qualifying round of the annual invitation best-ball tournament.

New York City children have a long idle Summer before them, with no outlet except what they find for themselves on the street. In the upper East Side a plan is afoot to organize an active and extensive program of recreation -- to create a substitute for Summer camp -- for the thousands of children who are not among the fortunate few who get away to the country.

PUBLIC AUDITORIUM, CLEVELAND, June 12. -- Delegates and alternates to the Republican National Convention entered the final session today eager to hasten the nomination of a candidate for Vice President so that they might leave during the afternoon or early evening for their homes.

T.O.M. Sopwith is to have a veritable blue streak for his second attempt to capture the America's Cup. His new Endeavour II, prospective challenger which is now in the water at the yard of Camper Nicholson in Gosport, England, is to be a long, narrow yacht, the largest built for the cup in thirty-three years.

A group of 160 chemical engineers sailed yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Samaria for Liverpool to attend the International Chemical Engineering Congress in London June 22 to June 27. The World Power Conference will be held at the same time.

Archbishop Amleto Giovanni Cicognani, Apostolic Delegate at Washington, and Mr. and Mrs. Simon Guggenheim are among the passengers sailing today for Italy on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia. Others leaving on the ship include Robert Goelet Jr., Baroness Nikola Korff, Dr. and Mrs. Angelo Lauria, Countess Irene di Robilant, Mr. and Mrs. Giuseppe Sturani, Mrs. E.R. Thomas.

WASHINGTON, June 12. -- By a seven-to-three decision, in which the three dissenters sharply criticized the desirability or the wisdom of the action taken, the Interstate Commerce Commission today granted, with certain modifications, an extension for six months of the emergency freight surcharge rates which otherwise would have expired on June 30.

NEWARK, N.J., June 12. -- The Newark Bears' winning streak was snapped tonight by the Toronto Maple Leafs, who triumphed, 10 to 4, after the league leaders had won six straight. About 10,000 saw the game.

Judge Grover M. Moscowitz in the United States District Court in Brooklyn dismissed yesterday a petition filed by Joseph and Louis Sandel, acting as a committee of Benjamin Sandel, a disabled war veteran, seeking the removal of Stephen Callaghan and William T. Cowin as trustees in the reorganization proceedings of the Prudence Company, Inc.

DALLAS, June 12. -- President Roosevelt struck out forcefully in a speech here today against monopolistic tendencies in business which he said must be eliminated to save from extinction "the yeomanry of business and industry and agriculture."
I noticed a statement in THE TIMES of June 11 that Gordon Dunn's discus throw of 171 feet 5 1/4 inches is the best in the world this year.

Speaking yesterday at Dallas, President ROOSEVELT again raised the question of a proper balance between national and State authority. Texas, he said, managed to solve many of its problems locally, but found that some of the worst of them "merely jumped "over the boundary into some other "State."

THE variety of American life is nowhere more apparent than in the novels published from day to day. There are stories of New England, the Middle West, the Northwest, the South; of mountaineers, plainsmen, city folk, farmers; of doctors, teachers, actors, merchants; of rebels and stand-patters; of the very rich and the very poor.

BRUSSELS, June 12. -- Former Premier Paul van Zeeland was summoned to the palace this evening and had a long conference with King Leopold. On leaving, he said that he would do all in his power to form another Ministry without delay and would try to complete it by tomorrow night.

Retail trade in the metropolitan area continued active during the week, although increases in dollar volume were not as marked as in recent weeks. Estimates indicated an increase over the comparative period a year ago of about 10 per cent, with several of the leading department stores here running ahead of that figure.

Columbia University Press reports that the publisher of a "Life of John Wesley" received the following note from a minister who had just bought a copy of the book: "Gentlemen: I have before me a volume which, according to the title on the binding, purports to be the life of a great religious leader, John Wesley, but I am sure he would not have approved the contents.

A further advance yesterday, which carried the price of October deliveries up to 11.20 cents a pound, or 5 points net higher, was followed by moderate reactions in the futures market on the Cotton Exchange here. There was some hedging, as well as considerable realizing, while the more urgent demand appeared to have been pretty well supplied on the early advance.
