CLEVELAND, June 12. -- Following is Governor Landon's telegram to the convention after reiceiving congratulations on his nomimation:

The international situation today is "frightfully dangerous," the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president of Union Theological Seminary, told the graduating class of Stevens Institute of Technology yesterday at the baccalaureate vespers in Trinity Church, Hoboken.

Green and white awnings, tall mint drinks, flowered evening gowns and linen jackets have taken possession of the entire night club front these evenings, and the informal town-and-country atmosphere is soothing after a hectic Winter.

Who started the baseless slander that members of the Old Guard are bald and paunchy? The generosity which spares a conquered foe should not be denied even to an Old Guard. Its behavior at Cleveland was exemplary.

A passenger elevator in the Wurlitzer Building, 120 West Forty-second Street, crashed eight stories to the basement last night, shattering itself on the springed base and causing injuries to the fifteen passengers, of whom nine were women. Four victims were taken to hospitals.
TOKYO, June 12. -- Sir Frederick Leith-Ross, chief economic adviser to the British Government, tonight concluded his exchange of opinions with Japanese officials.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 12. -- The shooting of perfect scores and breaking of records have become virtually daily occurrences at Camp Smith here in the New York State National Guard and New York naval militia matches.

WASHINGTON, June 12. -- Details concerning the offering of $14,500,000 of first leasehold and general mortgage bonds, 4 1/4 per cent series due in 1946, of the Southern Kraft Corporation, Mobile, Ala., which has been registered under the Securities Act of 1933, were made available at the Securities and Exchange Commission today.

The Soviet regime is the earliest of post-war dictatorships in Europe and has served as the model and inspiration for many imitators in the heart of the Continent. Today, when the democratic-bourgeois cause is on the defensive, even in Western Europe, the proposed new Soviet Constitution brings it unexpected aid and comfort.

Interest has been heightened in the series of matches for the Westchester Cup between the high-goal polo teams of the United States and the British Empire by the grim battle at Hurlingham on Wednesday, when, for all its hard hitting and coordinated team play, America was hard pressed to win the first game by 10 to 9.
QUEBEC, Que., June 12. -- Adelard Godbout, Quebec's new Premier, is confronted with a problem in selection of a Cabinet with which to go to the people on Aug. 15.

The Pennsylvania Exchange Bank declared yesterday its first dividend since 1921, one of 20 cents a share to stockholders of record June 20, Milton Collier, president, announced. There are 33,000 $10 par shares outstanding.
Sales in Queens and Nassau Counties were reported yesterday by the title and mortgage rehabilitation and liquidation bureau of the State Insurance Department.

DALLAS, June 12. -- Jesse Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, and three other passengers here were saved from death today by two daring pilots who raced a flaming monoplane to earth while fire raged in their compartment.

CLEVELAND, June 12. -- The conquest of the Republican party by youth and liberalism was completed here this afternoon when a rejuvenated national committee named John D.M. Hamilton of Kansas as its chairman and, as a consequence, the party's generalissimo for the coming election campaign.

Samuel Goldfarb, 30 years old, of 302 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, was killed yesterday morning by hold-up men, who took $5,000 in jewelry and scraps from Goldfarb Frieberg, jewelry manufacturers, on the seventh floor of 338 Canal Street.

WINCHESTER, Mass., June 12. -- The Boston women's Griscom Cup golf team soundly defeated the defending Philadelphia players on the Winchester Country Club links today, 11 to 4, and that means that means that New York will have a strong assignment on its hands to defeat Boston tomorrow and take the cup.

CHICAGO, June 12. -- Advanced prices for wheat in foreign markets failed today to have any important influence on the markets in the United States, all of which closed lower, with a distrustful feeling. Price movements on the Board of Trade here were within a narrow range, and there was little disposition on the part of traders, either here or on any other big market, to take hold.

With many of the streams in their State reduced to mere trickles by the protracted dry spell, New Jersey anglers await with more than customary eagerness the opening of the black bass season next Monday.

With both buses and railroads reducing fares and publicizing the cuts widely, automobile manufacturers, gasoline and oil companies and others may be forced to put on a little extra pressure in their advertising to meet the competition, according to comment yesterday among agencies.

LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., June 12. -- Waldron P. Belknap of New York, president of the board of trustees. awarded diplomas to a graduating class of 111 today at the 126th annual commencement exercises of the Lawrenceville School.

CHICAGO, June 12. -- Directors of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company declared today a 20 per cent common stock dividend and authorized the retirement from earnings of $5,000,000 of the $50,000,000 of preferred stock held by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

FORT WORTH, Texas, June 12. -- After reviewing two Texas Centennial Expositions in one day and being greeted by some 750,000 citizens, a large part of whom waited for him here despite a driving rain, President Roosevelt tonight enjoyed his first rest since Monday at the home of Elliott Roosevelt, his second son.

The first-railroad to report for May, the Alton, a .subsidiary of the Baltimore ' Ohio Railroad, re[ported yesterday, increased gross revenues and a decrease net loss for the month. Its statement loll lows:

GENEVA, June 12. -- The principle of the forty-hour week received strong support at the International Labor Organization conference today from Marion B. Folsom, representing the United States employers. It made a deep impression because the American employer delegation is the only employer group here that favors this principle and it can speak from practical experience.

LONDON, June 12. -- Reinforced by new ponies, Great Britain's hard-riding poloists will take the field tomorrow confident they can square the international series with the United States and force the issue into a third and decisive contest.

Jerome A. Jacobs, a lawyer with an office at 1,450 Broadway, was indicted yesterday by the New York County grand jury in an investigation of an alleged extortion ring, resulting from the complaint of Alfred E. Smith Jr.

Continuing testimony in his own behalf at the mail fraud trial of four former officers or directors of the Westchester Title and Trust Company, Reginald P. Ray, a vice president, said yesterday he cashed some of his own mortgage certificates five months before his company failed because he needed the money, but not because he had lost faith in their soundness.

CHICAGO, June 12. -- Colonel Frank Knox, who had left the Republican Convention in Cleveland feeling his "participation all over," only to learn on the way home that he had become the party's Vice Presidential nominee by a unanimous vote, returned to his office tonight declaring that he was "honored" to have been chosen.
CLEVELAND, June 12. -- It is "Alf" Landon now to his friends. Once it was "Fox," a nickname given to him by chums in his student days at the University of Kansas.

Postmaster Albert Goldman of Manhattan and the Bronx and Postmaster Frank J. Sinnott of Brooklyn announced yesterday that preparations had been completed for the prompt delivery on Monday of veterans' bonus bonds.
CLEVELAND, June 12. -- Godfrey G. Gloom, the aged political observer, was encountered by a reporter today in the crowd drifting away from the auditorium.

The marketing of $83,000,000 of Federal Land Banks consolidated 3 per cent bonds and a resumption of corporate refunding lifted the total of new bond financing for this week to $204,466,600. This is the largest volume of any week since that ended on May 1, when new issues for $237,315,000 were placed, including $110,000,000 for the Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit Corporation.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 12. -- Finding that it was not suited for his needs, John Jacob Astor 3d is offering for sale his yatch Placidia, an old steam craft which he purchased in New York a couple of years ago and refitted at considerable expense.

DETROIT, June 12 (AP). -- Warrants charging twenty-seven men with Black Legion conspiracies to murder a newspaper editor and a suburban Mayor, who stood in the path of the terrorists' drive for political dominance, were issued today.
HEWLETT, L.I., June 12. -- After the first two rounds of the annual Long Island golf championship the two co-medalists as well as the defending champion are still in the ring.

With the residential mortgage emergency apparently a problem of the past, the Home Owners Loan Corporation officially ceased its lending operations yesterday and Vincent Dailey, State manager, issued a report showing that in the last three years the Federal agency had saved 82,000 homes in New York from foreclosure.

A test case, affecting about $375, 000,000 in mortgage certificates, to decide whether damages may be collected in behalf of certificate holders from title companies or their parent organizations for permitting the substitution of unsalable mortgages for first-class mortgages securing mortgage certificates, was argued yesterday before the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court.

PULASKI, N.Y., June 12 (AP). -- A County Court jury of farmers and tradesmen freed Mrs. Charlotte Wood Dobson, 30, of Constantia, of a charge of murder today arising out of the stabbing of her husband, Rufus, because he "squandered" their money at penny ante.

No man living knows more about subways and the transit problem than JOHN H. DELANEY, chairman of the Board of Transportation. Whatever he has to say on the subject is always worth listening to, and when the subject of his discourse is the five-cent fare, politicians and students alike will prick up their ears.
DALLAS, Texas, June 12. -- Following is the text of President Roosevelt's speech at the Texas Centennial Exposition here today:

FONTHILL, Ont., June 12. -- Tony Manero of Greensboro, N.C., who has been playing a very ordinary brand of golf since he won the United States open title last week, made a sudden about face today to tie for the lead at the end of 36 holes in the General Brock open tournament.

WASHINGTON, June 12. -- Permission to withdraw a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering an issue of $650,000 of 6 per cent income notes and stock, some of which had been sold after the statement became effective, was asked today by counsel for the National Boston Montana Mines Corporation of Montana.

Radio policemen captured two men, shooting one, at about 10 o'clock last night in pursuing four men fleeing from a stolen automobile at Coney Island Avenue and Glenwood Road, Brooklyn. The injured man is Daniel G. Considine, 23 years old, of 2,063 Mill Avenue, Brooklyn. With a bullet in his back, he was taken to Kings County Hospital. He was accused of robbery.
It is conceded, I believe, that no method of starting thoroughbred races has proved to be entirely satisfactory.

TULSA, Okla., June 12. -- Declaring that repeal of national prohibition had "brought an understanding of the real danger of alcohol," Mrs. Ida B. Wise Smith of Evanston, Ill., national president of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union, opened the annual convention of that organization here tonight with an assertion that there was "a resurgence of sentiment for complete abolition of liquor."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 12. -- Waseda University, behind the four-hit twirling of Wakahara, the right-hander who hurled a no-hitter against Yale last week, blanked Harvard on Soldiers Field today, 5 to 0.

ROME, June 12. -- The death blow delivered to sanctions by Great Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, Neville Chamberlain, in a speech two days ago, in Italian opinion, permits Italy to look definitely ahead to the day when, abandoning her aloofness from the League of Nations and from European problems, she will resume her collaboration with Geneva and with other powers.

" Radio wants its share of the tele-"graph traffic, but it looks also at the "much bulkier mailbags," remarked DAVID SARNOFF when the Radio Corporation of America experimentally sent and received pictures and handwriting through the ether between New York and Philadelphia.

WASHINGTON, June 12. -- The Hoberg Paper Mills, Inc., of Green Bay, Wis., has filed under the Securities Act of 1933 for $900,000 of first mortgage 5 per cent convertible sinking-fund bonds, due on July 1, 1946, and 18,000 shares of no-par common stock, to be reserved for conversion.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., June 12. -- A nation, like a man, recovers from depression by confident effort and not by hopeless surrender, said Owen D. Young, chairman of the board of directors of the General Electric Company, in addressing executives and managers attending the jubilee dinner tonight celebrating the fiftieth anniversary of the founding of the company by Thomas A. Edison.
Ceremonies marked by parades and meetings in parks and other places will be held tomorrow throughout the city in celebration of Flag Day.

GOSHEN, N.Y., June 12. -- Champion Halcyon Play Boy closed his show career this afternoon in a blaze of glory. Now more than six years old, this grand terrier was adjudged best in show at the specialty exhibition of the Welsh Terrier Club of America, held on the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Edward T. Clark.

David H. Knott, owner of the Hotel Van Rennsselaer, protected the hotel property yesterday by purchasing the adjoining four-story dwelling at 21 East Eleventh Street from the estate of Mrs. Caldwalader Jones. The house occupies a lot 27 by 103 feet and was sold through Malcolm E. Smith, Inc.
The rolls of the Emergency Relief Bureau have declined for three successive weeks, it was announced yesterday by Miss Charlotte E. Carr, executive director.

THE nineteenth season of Goldman Band concerts, the gift of the Daniel and Florence Guggenheim Foundation, will open Wednesday evening on the Mall in Central Park. Concerts will be given in Central Park on Monday, Wednesday, Friday and Sunday evenings, and in Prospect Park, Brooklyn, on Tuesday, Thursday and Saturday evenings.

Old Guard leaders at Albany, as at Washington, sometimes complain of "Executive domination," They maintain that the Governor's job is to execute the laws, and that when he goes beyond that and he takes a hand in lawmaking he is "usurping a legislative function."
FONTHILL, Ont., June 13. -- A record-smashing 68 on the final round enabled Craig Wood of New York to come from behind and win the $1,000 first prize in the General Brock open golf tournament today.

FOR four days beginning tomorrow, Cornell graduates, sitting under some of their old professors on their own campus, will consider "The Arts in an Industrial Democracy" in a second annual Alumni Institute.

HAVANA, June 13. -- A petition asking reconsideration of the decision of the Supreme Court on June 1 upholding the legality of public works bonds issued by the late Machado government and now in default has been presented by Dr. Rafael Ramos Grau.

With sixty-eight candidates scheduled to tee off, the annual women's Westchester-Fairfield golf championship will start tomorrow at the Wee Burn Club in Noroton, Conn. Mrs. Jonathan Thorne of Greenwich, defending champion, will be among the contestants.

Ever since Prometheus stole it for us from the gods, the process of rapid oxidation known as fire has had tremendous fascination, incalculable utility, and equally incalculable destructiveness. Some men, fascinated by fire, have learned the secrets of its control and built the fuel engines which give power to our civilization.

JOE LOUIS avoids meeting people, hates conversation (even fight talk) and says less than any man in sports history including Dummy Taylor, the Giant pitcher, who was a mute. Dr. William Walker, who examined Louis before the Carnera fight a year ago, was amazed at the man's silence.

IN "Maria Paluna" Mrs. Niles wrote the first of a series of novels intended to re-create in the form of historical romance the ancient civilization of Latin America. Her story of sixteenth-century Guatemala in the throes of the Spanish conquest achieved a vivid beauty and an authentic atmosphere which made it a memorable venture in its field.
PALO ALTO, Calif., June 13. -- Two West Coast foot racers today made formidable challenges for American Olympic berths.

SCARBOROUGH, N.Y., June 13. -- Willie Turnesa of Fairview came back into possession of the Westchester amateur golf championship today by defeating A.C. Giles of Briar Hills, 1 up, at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club. Turnesa, a junior at Holy Cross College, previously won the title in 1933 and replaces Tommy Goodwin as monarch of the county's amateurs.

Threatened by bankruptcy through litigation and inability to meet its obligations, the Consolidated American Royalty Corporation, a holding company of which J. Edward Jones is president and a director, petitioned the Federal court yesterday for permission to reorganize under the Bankruptcy Act.
LONDON, June 13 (AP). -- Rain forced postponement of the second match of the international polo series and gave England new hope of regaining the Westchester Cup, lost to America in 1921.

THE American girl shines best in the Summer time. She loves sports and is good at them; she puts on sports togs and looks well in them. There's an honesty about play togs that, whether worn in the field or on the side lines, harmonizes with her own outspokeness.
PHILIP THORNTON is an English musician specially interested in Oriental music, which, he says, has fascinated him ever since he was a child.

THE Brinleys start out to Cape Breton Island, as they did to the Gaspe Peninsula, in a whirl of laughter and gay talk; and with light-hearted chatter and neighborly merriment they continue an their way. It is the greater mark of their joint ability, therefore, that they have again produced a travel book which is neither trivial nor self-centered.

BERLIN, June 13. -- The reactionary trend on the Boerse continued today, although much more steadiness than that shown recently was displayed near the close. The day's losses were substantial, many exceeding 2 points.

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- A sense of discouragement is a mild term to use in describing the feeling that pervaded the American Federation of Labor headquarters when officials picked up their newspapers and read the text of the Republican party platform.

BALBOA, C.Z., June 13. -- Kelvin Arthur Rogers, 3 years old, who is traveling half way around the world to have a nail removed from his lung, arrived here last night from Melbourne, Australia, aboard the American Pioneer Line motorship Jeff Davis.

ATLANTA, June 13. -- Angelo Herndon, Negro Communist, lost another move today in his fight to escape a chain-gang sentence imposed under an Insurrection Law enacted in reconstruction days. The Georgia Supreme Court ruled unanimously that the statute, passed in 1871, did not violate either the State or Federal Constitutions.

EIGHT million dollars can't be wrong. That cinematic truism hangs over Fritz Lang every time he conceives a scene or, on the set, calls "Camera." Splendid and faithful as is "Fury," in every argument the director had with his producers that phrase beat against his ears with the same relentlessness as the marching feet that drove Spencer Tracy through the night.

Twenty years ago today, Louis D. Brandeis assumed his seat on the Supreme Court. The bitter five-month fight which took seven past presidents of the American Bar Association to Washington to testify against him had ended at last in failure. That there could have been such a battle seems unbelievable after two decades.

SOME years ago James Bryce stated that the chief difficulty of running a government by public opinion was the difficulty of ascertaining public opinion. Today the measurement of public opinion -- "that great compound of folly, weakness, prejudice, wrong feeling, right feeling, obstinacy and newspaper paragraphs" -- has become both a business and a profession.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP). -- Federal Prison Industries, Inc., the government's $4,000,000 corporation for turning criminal hands to useful labors, is adding to its plant a clothing factory on Alcatraz Island, a homespun woolen industry at the El Reno (Okla.) reformatory and a chair factory at Chillicothe, Ohio.

I don't know how the producers of the picture "The Story of Louis Pasteur" look on this fine and valuable offering of theirs in the financial way, but the following report might be of interest to the American public.

CARACAS, Venezuela, June 13 (AP). -- Elbano Mibelli, Governor of the Federal District, announced over the radio tonight that Venezuela's general strike was ended. He said that some services had already been resumed, and urged everybody to return to work Monday.
MIAMI, June 13 (AP). -- A potential hurricane, first disturbance of the season, swirled over the treacher-oils waters to the south today.

SALEM, N.H., June 13. -- Muddy going and a light burden were so much to the liking of Gallant Gay, an 11-1 shot, owned by Weston Adams of Boston, that he registered a surprising victory over a crack field in the $10,000 added Rockingham Park Handicap today.

CLEVELAND, June 13 (AP). -- A "breathing spell" to delay for several weeks Senator Borah's answer to whether he will attack, support or be indifferent to the Presidential candidacy of Governor Landon was predicted today by mutual friends.

YEAR by year the dude ranch looms larger in the American vacation picture. This season more than 15,000 Easterners -- including, presumably, some of the radio baritones who have been yearning very audibly for "boots and saddles" all Winter long -- are eagerly pressing westward along the trail once traveled so unwillingly by the immortal Ruggles.

PROFESSORS THRALL and Hibbard of the University of North Carolina and of the Northwestern University, respectively, have collaborated to produce an excellent handbook for the student taking college courses in English. They modestly preface their book with a motto from Dr. Johnson: "Dictionaries are like watches; the worst is better than none, and the best cannot be expected to go quite true."

PARIS, June 3. -- Society here is now characterized by a period of comparative calm which is a prelude to the intense activity that will soon mark the month of June and the beginning of the grand season.

DALLAS, Texas, June 12. -- The Texas Centennial Central Exposition, which opened here on June 6, has drawn thousands of visitors from other States and stimulated business not only here, but throughout the State. The visit of President Roosevelt to Texas also has brought additional trippers and has further stimulated sales in this territory.

The boom which last week brought Alf M. Landon the Republican Presidential nomination is unique in American political history. When, a year and a half ago, the Landon supporters began to plot the capture of the nomination, their man was unknown.

NOTWITHSTANDING the fact that the military as well as the political side of the American Revolution has been treated extensively and minutely by innumerable historians, the failure of the British regulars to crush the revolt of a comparatively small force of untrained American farmers has never been satisfactorily explained.

THE complete title of V. Sackville West's forthcoming biography of the Maid of Orleans will be "Saint Joan of Arc; Born January 6, 1412; Burned as a Heretic, May 30, 1431; Canonized as a Saint, May 16, 1920." The book is a study of the human being behind the legend and the relation of that human being to the world of her time.

With a total of approximately $134,500,000 to be distributed, beginning tomorrow, as bonus payments to veterans in the metropolitan area, increasing competition between retailers here for their share of the bonus funds became evident last week.

AS Bernardino Molinari rode to an ovation and recharged on his favorite war horse, "The Ride of the Valkyries," the Augusteo closed its door to music for good last night. It was not without sentiment that the local devotees bid farewell to Italy's high temple of symphony, which is to be restored to its original use as the tomb of Augustus, founder of the Roman Empire, for the Augustan celebrations next year.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP). -- A warning from the United Mine Workers that they intend to "shut down" the giant soft coal industry if the Guffey-Vinson Coal Control Bill fails to pass at this session and wage cutting ensues today brought Senate hearings on the measure to a close.

BEHIND his expansive smile and jovial manner, Edward G. Robinson seems vaguely disturbed, like a man who can't remember whether or not he mailed his wife's letters last week. We thought perhaps he was unhappy at heart because of his relatively unsuccessful efforts to be graduated from the gangster and big-shot department at Warner Brothers, but Mr. Robinson denied this.

DETROIT, June 13. -- Hollyrood returned today to the form that made him a $64,745 winner as a 2-year-old and raced in record time across the finish line a half length in front of his filly stablemate, Sparta, to give Hal Price Headley a sweep of first and second places in the third running of the $25,000 added Detroit Derby.

Postmaster General James A. Farley charged yesterday that critics of the New Deal were trying "to create a bugaboo to frighten the American voters." Deriding the "howls and moans" of these critics, he put forth fifteen questions concerning policies and undertakings of the Roosevelt administration and challenged its opponents to answer them "specifically and unequivocally."

ON BOARD PRESIDENT'S SPECIAL TRAIN ENROUTE TO VINCENNES, Ind., June 13. -- After five days of intensive touring during which he defined two major campaign issues while participating in historical celebrations in Texas and Arkansas, President Roosevelt headed eastward tonight to devote tomorrow to public appearances in Indiana, Ohio and Kentucky.

AMERICA is on the move again. Along the roads, the rivers and the coasts hundreds of thousands of people are wandering, rediscovering their country, finding in it beauties which they did not know existed, settling down at times for the contemplation of places which rest the mind and give opportunity for exercise and sport.

ROME, June 12. -- Every time that relations between Italy on the one side and Britain and France on the other side enter a particularly delicate or, at least, interesting phase, the rumor of an Italo-German understanding crops up again.

CANADA'S dwindling Indian population has taken an upward turn as the result of a welfare program initiated by the Department of Indian Affairs, it is shown in figures released recently at Ottawa. The total Indian population for 1934 was given as 112,510, compared with 104,894 in 1924.

No problem exists today between industry and labor that cannot be solved by frank and open discussion from an economic viewpoint, Charles D. Jaffee, head of Jaffee, Cohen Lang, and last week elected president of the New York Clothing Manufacturers Exchange for the thirteenth consecutive year, said yesterday.

THE annual opera season presented at the Zoo Opera Pavilion in Cincinnati by the Cincinnati Summer Opera Association will open tonight with a performance of Meyerbeer's "L'Africaine," and will continue for ten weeks. Three works by contemporary composers have been included in the repertoire.

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- Is the American Federation of Labor headed for a split, the craft unions remaining in one group and the unions advocating the industrial form of organization in the other group?

STATISTICS reveal that more than 50 per cent of all boys of Scout age in the United States live in communities of less than 2,500 population -- that is, in what the Census Bureau terms rural areas. Boys of these communities have special problems and interests, and to meet their needs scouting has developed what may be described as a rural program.

To American tourists the French breakfast of coffee and rolls has often seemed unnecessarily frugal. But in Paris last week there were days when not even coffee, much less rolls, could be obtained in the hotels and restaurants which Americans frequented. Not only were meals unobtainable, but beds went unmade, shoes unpolished.

CANTON, June 13. -- One of the most gigantic parades and mass meetings in the history of this ancient city was held here today. It was designed by Southwestern leaders to give spirit to the entire Chinese people and to arouse other cities to hold similar demonstrations against the Japanese.

NOW that Italy has conquered Ethiopia, what is she going to do about it? Even here, in the capital of the new Fascist empire, every one is wondering. Viceroy Marshal Pietro Badoglio remarked to the writer the other day that Italy's real task is just beginning, and one must not forget Premier Mussolini's statement, well before hostilities started last Autumn, that it would take some fifty years to make the most of a possible victory.

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- Secretary Hull has sent congratulations to Bolivia and Paraguay in messages to their Foreign Ministers on the first anniversary of the signing of the protocol which brought about a termination of hostilities in the Chaco.

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- The manufacturing industry as a whole has not contributed to the support of the consuming market in proportion to the increase in production, according to George L. Berry, Industry Coordinator, who made public today an analysis of production, wages and employment in all manufacturing industries.

Fanciers of the Eastern section will welcome the reappearance of the Queensboro Kennel Club as a show-giving organization. Following a hiatus of a number of years there has been a revival of the spirit which sponsored many popular exhibitions at the Aqueduct race track.

NYACK, N.Y., June 13. -- Mrs. Evelyn Word Leigh returned here yesterday after a winter in Florida to find her glass house wrecked by vandals and her personal belongings ransacked, Mrs. Leigh, it is said, intends to ask the aid of President Roosevelt, but so far has ignored the Nyack Police Department.

PITTSBURGH, June 13 (AP). -- William N. McNair, Mayor of Pittsburgh, was arrested today and held for the grand jury on charges of halting the machinery of the law and preventing magistrates from sending prisoners to jail.

IN city and suburban gardens, shade or semi-shade frequently presents a vital problem for the gardener to solve. The general run of flowering plants and shrubs will not thrive without plenty of sunlight. Yet many times shade is unavoidable.

HANOVER, N.H., June 13. -- Dartmouth's baseball team set a unique record today unparalleled in green history. When Ted Bruce, junior right-hander, set Cornell down 8 -- 4, it marked the third successive day that the Indians had defeated an Eastern Intercollegiate League rival and also marked the third different pitcher to go the route in that time.
CONSIDERABLE controversy is raging, at the moment, over the First National Exhibition of American Art, current, until July 1, in the mezzanine galleries of International Building, Rockefeller Center.

LONDON, June 13. -- While the opinion of the British press is that President Roosevelt's re-election is a foregone conclusion, nomination of Governor Landon and the Republican platform brought a new personality and new problems to British readers.

Although aimed primarily to offset Japanese competition, the reduction in cut rayon staple prices by leading mills last week is expected to spur the sales of spun rayon fabrics for Fall, according to comment in the local market last week.

MEDFORD, Mass., June 13. -- The Harvard nine gained an 8-to-4 victory over Tufts College on the latter's rain-soaked diamond today in a loosely played game, held as part of the annual field day exercises of the Jumbos.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 13. -- The Summer training season of the New York State National Guard units will begin tomorrow at the two major reservations, here at Camp Smith and at Pine Camp, where all commands will receive two weeks of instruction.

NO Sunday article this morning. If it had not been for an unexpected domestic crisis a well-bred article could have been written in the course of the day and delivered to the printers as usual. A suitable subject had been quarried out of nothing -- which is the usual June custom.
May I offer these few thoughts respecting "Macaulay's Prophecy," noted in THE TIMES.

There is no murder in this story. Perhaps if Edgar Wallace had lived to finish it there might have been one or more, although it is difficult to see just where it would have fitted in. There are persons in it who would have no scruples about killing, and one of them actually attempts to murder the heroine, but nothing comes of it except the discomfiture of the villain.
PARIS, June 13. -- Contented strikers evacuated the besieged factories of France today.

THERE have been innumerable studies of municipal political parties. Dr. Peel has written the first book confined to the lowest rung in the party ladder -- the Political Club. He treats the rather tawdry atmosphere of municipal politics with the philosophic detachment of an anthropologist describing the quaint folkways and fetishes of some primitive tribe.

LONDON, June 13. -- A great British expert on foreign affairs turned the palms of his hands to the fire in the old-fashioned grate. "Unusual this cold spell in June," he said. Then he looked up: "What do you say? As unusual as the present complicated situation in Europe?

MR. ELIOT has become a classic in his own time without having been very well understood or much read. The quality of his poetry had been obvious since 1917, when "Prufrock and Other Observations" was issued from Bloomsbury Street.

THE work of a very distinguished archaeologist of Tulane University, this book gives a vivid and detailed account both of the Spanish Conquest of Yucatan and of the great civilization of the Mayas which that conquest brought to a final collapse so complete that elements of its surviving into our own day are either in the form of archaeological materials or else are furtively held possessions among Indians in remote regions of the peninsula.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 12. -- A definite increase was shown in the volume of retail sales in this Federal Reserve district with vacation items such as sports clothing and equipment outstanding. In wholesale reports electrical goods, hardware and shoes showed most activity.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., June 13. -Seventeen-year-old Miss Betty Bell of Montclair, N.J., took no less than seven of the classes at the second annual Rock Spring Horse Show today. Through her excellent horsemanship and finely conformed saddle and hack entries, the youthful Montclair exhibitor sparkled in the all-day fixture on the Rock Spring Riding Club's grounds.

ISTANBUL. -- Class distinction, which has been abolished by law among living Turks, is to be restored to them once they are dead -- or so it is to be concluded from the draft of a by-law relating to the burial of the dead now being considered by the municipality.

THE once famous Baghdad Railway is to be completed at last, opening up the promise of through trains from Europe to ancient Nineveh, Babylon and the Garden of Eden. The last-named may be a bit difficult to find nowadays, but Nineveh and Babylon need puzzle nobody, for their sites are well known.

CANTON (By Courier to Hongkong), June 13. -- In statements clear and unreserved, General Chen Chia-tang, dictator of the Kwangtung independent government and most powerful figure in Southwestern China, outlined today the policies and aims of the Southwestern anti-Japanese movement.

ST. LOUIS, June 12. -- Large commitments due to soldier bonus expectations are reported in the Eighth Federal Reserve District, giving a sharp advance in furniture, household utensils and automobile sales.

PHOENIX, Ariz., June 12. -- In this year of political turmoil on all fronts, when officeseekers are defending the Constitution, deriding the New Deal, tinkering with the tariff, yowling about States' rights, and dragging from their graves all sorts of old tenets of discarded political theorems, it is refreshing to find a State that has found an entirely new issue -- the abolition of the slot machine.

ABOVE all things, Summer styles lay stress on the silhouette. Avoirdupois has no place in the stream-lined bathing suits, culottes, slacks or shirtwaist dresses that every one wants to wear. Nor will it have when we all get back to town and face the new outlines, for there is every indication that the accent will be on the young figure, meaning slimness of waist and hips.

An investigation into the death of Edward Herlich Jr., 16 years old, of 71-68 Seventieth Street, Glendale Queens, was begun yesterday by the office of the Kings County District Attorney and detectives. The boy died on May 3 at Wyckoff Heights Hospital, Brooklyn, of what was believed to have been pneumonia.

ST. LOUIS, June 13 (AP). -Bunching six of their eight hits in the first two innings and taking advantage of a breakdown in the enemy defense, the Cardinals defeated Philadelphia, 7 to 1, today to maintain their first place lead of three and a half games in the National League.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 13. -- California once more captured the chief interest among the crews in training for the rowing regatta of June 22. This morning, with almost ideal conditions on the course, the Bears came down the four miles, unpaced for the first two miles and picked up by the freshmen at the two-mile mark, in 19:21, according to Coach Ky Ebright.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 13. -- The firing of the New York State Rifle Association and New York State National Guard and Naval Militia rifle matches which started last Saturday and were completed at Camp Smith today was marked throughout by the frequent breaking of previous records, the number of perfect scores shot and the record number of marksmen who took part in the events.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP). -- Senator Borah disclosed today that he had drawn on the anti-trust platform of the Democratic party in 1912 in arguing at the Cleveland Republican convention for a strong anti-monopoly declaration.

A blond, blue-eyed woman sat in Felony Court yesterday afternoon and heard Magistrate George B. DeLuca commit her to the Women's House of Detention in default of $1,500 bail on a charge of grand larceny, pending a further hearing Tuesday.

LOVERS of roses and sweet peas in the metropolitan area will have a double-barreled treat this week, with two full-fledged rose and sweet pea shows being staged in New York. The first, held in Horticultural Hall, Rockefeller Center, will open at 2:30 tomorrow afternoon.

CHICAGO, June 12. -- Colonel Frank Knox, who calls himself the first mate eager to carry out the orders of his captain, Alfred M. Landon, was one of the first men to launch a vigorous and persistent attack against the New Deal.

DETROIT, June 13 (AP). -- Fifteen men were ordered held today under bonds of $25,000 each on charges of plotting to kill two political enemies of the Black Legion. This brings to forty-two the number charged with terroristic acts since the bullet-pierced body of Charles A. Poole was found in z. roadside ditch a month ago.

SINGAPORE. -- Newcomers to Singapore find that the sight of a British warship in the harbor or a naval uniform in the street is as rare as a Winter fur in this equatorial city. Yet Britain recently has completed eight years of work on a naval base on Singapore Island -- a base that cost approximately $38,500,000 and is accounted one of the engineering romances of this era.

DEVELOPMENT of the conference method of instruction has been one of the distinctive contributions to educational procedure by Princeton University's School of Public and International Affairs. After five experimental years the school is now to be made permanent.

LONDON. OF the two plays, one about Byron, the other about Parnell, of which I have previously reported that they were refused the censor's license, the former has now been passed; "Parnell" is still in chains.

AMERICAN farms stabled 2,000,000 fewer horses in 1935 than in 1930, according to figures recently compiled by the Census Bureau. The mule, too, is running a losing race against trucks, tractors and motor cars, having suffered a net loss of more than 535,000 in the last five years.
WINDSOR, Conn., June 13. -- The winners of eleven prizes at the Loomis School were announced at the commencement exercises today.

SYDNEY. ON the Queensland sugar cane plantations another beetling season has recently been completed. Millions of beetles were caught and paid for by the mills at about 20 cents a pound, a pound of beetles containing some 200 insects.

The lines of conflict converge in China. The customary lull is over. On Japan's side there are the usual premonitory signs of another advance to be set in motion. But this time a new force has been injected. There are indications, now more than rhetorical outbursts, that China will resist, almost in spite of itself and certainly in spite of its government.

LONDON, June 13 (AP). -- A compromise between Great Britain and Soviet Russia, in which Russia's Far Eastern naval problem as it concerns Japan is tentatively worked out, was disclosed authoritatively today.
CHICAGO, June 13 (AP). -- The world's record-breaking racing mare, Myrtlewood, galloped to an impressive victory in the $5,000 added Hawthorne sprint handicap today.

NEW York promises a bumper crop of new and modern swimming holes for its inhabitants this Summer. Although the city's numerous creeks have been smothered under pavements -- and those that still insist on bubbling as they did in rural New York are considered intruders in cellars and sub-basements -- there are now facilities to take the place of these natural swimming places.

RIDING THE RAILS: A David-Goliath struggle took place on a chilly day last week along Canadian National rails north of Toronto. Caterpillars, two and three inches deep, snuggled to the rails to keep warm. A passenger train plowed into them and was delayed for almost two hours.

Notes covering $17,750,000 due large American exporters and tied up in Brazil by exchange restrictions will be sent here by air mall this week, completing the arrangement under which $20,000,000 in American funds has been liberated by the "unfreezing" agreement worked out by the National Foreign Trade Council with Brazilian authorities.

TROY, June 13. -- Two hundred and fifty-two young men received degrees this afternoon at the 111th commencement of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute. The class was representative of twenty-three States and three foreign countries.

"Little Englanders" used to be a term of reproach applied to those who had small concern for the British colonies and who did not realize the vast importance of British commercial and political interests across the Channel and beyond the seas. Their narrow views and limited vision appear to have been transferred to those who wrote the Republican platform at Cleveland.

LONDON is in the same emotional state that Hollywood was in fifteen years ago but within a few years British production will be either as important as American or very close to it. Easy money has lured into production men with no knowledge of or fitness for it.

SYDNEY. PEARLS are the cause of increasing tension between Australia and Japan, and the incessant irritation which is being set up by Japanese acts is likely to find release in some cable-searing incident.

BRUSSELS, June 13. -- Belgium's prolonged Cabinet crisis ended tonight when a new van Zeeland government was formed. It was the fourth time he had made the attempt. The Socialist leader Emile van der Velde also had tried unsuccessfully.

TOPEKA, June 13. -- It was just six years ago that Alf M. Landon was defeated for precinct committeeman in his home precinct of Independence, Kan. Just six years ago that he was not able to get even his neighbors to vote for him for the lowest office in the organization of his political party.

Additional bond redemptions announced last week for June consisted of several small municipal and miscellaneous issues. The total for the month to date is $304,088,000, compared with $371,061,000 last month and $206,276,000 for June, 1935, in corresponding weeks.
I have just read the letter of Robert E. Naumberg under the heading "For Blind Readers." His comments are correct. However, there are a few other matters worthy of consideration.

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- Immediate collective action to Protect the Jews from progressive deterioration of their rights was demanded at the opening session tonight at a conference called by the American Jewish Congress. More than 100 delegates are participating in a two-day session.

Mail requisitions eased off somewhat last week in the wholesale markets as retailers reported ample Summer stocks, according to a survey prepared especially for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buyers. Visiting buyers were interested chiefly in Fall merchandise for early presentation.

OUT in the West the railway coach passenger is beginning to get more attention. For years many railroads thought primarily in terms of Pullman passengers, giving less heed to the comfort of coach riders. Then the automobile and the bus came along, and the coach travelers took to the highway.

DR. CUNNINGTON knows fashions. No Paris or New York stylist can be so authoritative as he on women's clothes of the nineteenth century, and he probably knows just as much about the modes of the twentieth, if he were indiscreet enough to tell.

With variety store sales in May showing the best monthly percentage increase in three years and with these chains giving evidence that they are now joining other types of retail distributors in marked sales gains after a long period of lagging behind, increased attention is being given to the "experiment'' of the F.W. Woolworth Company in extending its merchandise prices up to $1.
HANOVER, N.H., June 13. -- While fourteen classes of alumni, attired in colorful costumes, were celebrating reunions today, the seniors of Dartmouth College held their class day.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 13. -- The Westchester estates' version of the humble vegetable today competed at the Westchester County center in the agricultural classes of the fifth annual Westchester Flower Show. Mrs. H. Edward Manville of Pleasantville led the lists of prize winners, her estate taking eight firsts.

WHILE the memory of the Spring season is still fragrant, a few final notes should be appended about the audience. On the closing night, with "Cavalleria Rusticana," "Pagliacci" and "The Bat," as the bill, a huge throng turned out.

THE experience of the Chicago Social Club which recently scraped a collection of supposedly worthless securities off its walls, where they were serving as wallpaper, and sold them for a good round sum, illustrates the thrill that comes every so often to the collector of financial "cats and dogs."

An auspicious beginning of the stadium concerts is indicated with the announcement that the reserved space -- sixty tables -- has been sold out for the opening concert Wednesday night. Jose Iturbi, pianist and conductor, will direct the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in a program of Beethoven's works on the first night at the Lewisohn Stadium.

The International Seamen's Union has undertaken a campaign to extend its membership to all American seamen and strengthen its position for the fight that is expected in September when the Pacific Coast wage agreement expires, it was learned yesterday.
PARIS, June 10. -- The Duchess of Kent's semi-mourning wardrobe includes Schiaparelli's black and white mushroom print ensemble, having a cape edged with a fluted white linen frill.

WITH steadily increasing appreciation of its possibilities, American business is shipping its goods by air. Due largely to the unified air and air-rail express service in which twenty of the country's air lines joined with the Railway Express Agency to start a nation-wide business and an international goods transport service through Pan American Airways, the air lines are now carrying more goods in a month than they carried five years ago in a whole year.

STRANGE islands line the Irish coast and one of the strangest of them all is Tory Island -- the ancient stronghold of the Formoriens, a legendary race of gigantic pirates whose chieftain (1200 B.C.) was the one-eyed Balor of the Mighty Blows.

PHILADELPHIA, June 13. -- Mr. and Mrs. Harrison K. Caner Jr. of Philadelphia and Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Dickson Irwin of Winter Quarters Farm gave a dance tonight at the Merion Golf Club for Miss Uytendale Emily Wayne Caner and Miss Jeanne Lawson, daughter of Mrs. Irwin.
WASHINGTON, June 13. -- The Federal Housing Administration, in a statement today, urged veterans to "hold your bonds, if you can," but suggested that "if you cash them, think of your home first."

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., June 13. -- The Williams College administration informed visiting alumni today that $252,000 had been contributed this year, the highest figure in annual gifts since 1930. At the same time the election of Hubert D. Bennett, '17, of Toledo, to succeed Damon E. Hall of Boston as alumni trustee, was announced.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 13. -- America's women tennis players won enough glory for a whole year on Wimbledon's famous center court this afternoon when they captured three matches out of four from the British team and took the Wightman Cup for the sixth successive year.

SHEFFIELD, England, June 13. -- British medical circles today heard the story of Miss Mary Devonport's seven-minute interlude of "death" in a dental chair, how she lost two dozen teeth and how she went back to work in a steel factory.

FAIRFIELD, N.J., June 13. -- Despite a heavy downpour that hampered attempts for high scores, Paul Halloway of Canoe Brook, N.J., retained his New Jersey Trap Shooting Association doubles championship today, shooting over the North Jersey Gun Club traps.

A 2,000-mile exploratory, expedition through Alaska in search of fossil vertebrates of the upper Cretaceous period will be made this Summer by a group headed by Dr. Erich Maren Schlaikjer, instructor in geology and paleontology at Brooklyn College, and including Louis Irving Jr. of New York, David Bradley Cheek of Harvard Medical School and John Wolback of Boston.

ONE'S correspondence often increases during the Summer, with friends away on vacation, week-end invitations to be sent out and so many bread-and-butter letters to be written to hostesses. New colors and papers in writing materials are intended to make the business of penning notes more interesting.

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- Overruling Victor Ridder, New York City WPA Administrator, Aubrey Williams, assistant chief of the Works Progress Administration, today recognized the Workers Alliance of America as representing New York WPA workers in collective bargaining.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., June 13. -- An unusually distinguished field that includes Sidney B. Wood Jr. and Gregory Mangin gathered here today for the annual invitation doubles tennis tournament at the Piping Rock Club.

THE autobiography of Igor Stravinsky ("Chronicle of My Life") which, in the original French edition, has more than once been referred to in these columns, is now translated to workmanlike English, and issued by Victor Gollancz of London.

NORTON, Mass., June 13. -- Class and alumnae day events began at Wheaton this morning with senior hoop rolling, followed by the senior-father baseball game. The traditional ivy was planted this afternoon, with Miss Audrey Witherell of Swampscott, as the speaker.

Charles Newmark, builder, real estate owner and operator, of 235 West 102d Street, filed a plea in bankruptcy yesterday in the United States District Court. He said his liabilities aggregated $2,224,816 and that he had no assets.
LONDON, June 12. -- Britain obviously is on the eve of a change in foreign policy and of a new naval strategy in consequence.

CINCINNATI, June 13. -- Van Lingle Mungo, back again, penitent and once more effective with his fireball after his brief one-man strike, stepped on the mound along about sunset today and helped hold a slender margin that enabled the desperate Dodgers to snap their losing streak at nine straight.

Although the political news from Cleveland tended to obscure the very favorable trade and industrial reports last week, the effect of politics on the share market was more sentimental than real. As it was, however, trading on the Stock Exchange was the heaviest in five weeks, and THE NEW YORK TIMES average of fifty stocks showed the best gain since the week ended April 1.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., June 13. -There is no longer even a lingering doubt but that Joe Louis is right at the top of his form and ready to step into the ring against Max Schmeling Thursday night as finely conditioned as he has ever been for any fight.

ATHENS. A LARGE sanctuary from Greek and Roman times has been excavated about a mile west of Kurion in Southwest Cyprus by George H. MacFadden of the expedition of the University of Pennsylvania Museum.

THE modern June bride has been called "canny and practical" by any number of authorities on brides, but the fact remains that she is the same sentimental creature that her grandmother was. "Something old, something new, something borrowed, something blue," still guides the wedding.
Our present political leaders might well gain some economic wisdom if they were to consult the writings of Thomas Paine.

GENEVA, June 13. -- The chests of gold Emperor Haile Selassie has been taking with him on his travels contain the gold reserves of the Bank of Ethiopia, according to an Italian source in a position to know and worthy of belief.
CHICAGO, June 13 (AP). -- Seven California stars won their first matches in impressive style today as the national clay courts tennis championship opened at the River Forest Tennis Club.

ROSLYN, L.I., June 13. -- Through a driving rainstorm, Frank M. Gould's What Have You scampered home in a sea of mud twenty lengths ahead of Richard K. Melton's The Stag II to win the R. Penn Smith Jr. Steeplechase, the feature of the United Hunts Spring race meeting.
STOCKHOLM, June 13. -- Sweden's Socialist government was overthrown when both legislative chambers rejected a government bill to increase old-age pensions where the cost of living had risen.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 13. -- The Atlantic County Board of Taxation has announced a decrease of nearly $3,000,000 in assessed valuations in the county. The 1936 schedule of tax rates was made public yesterday.

This is the week when yacht masters and deck hands work their hardest. Muscles will be sore shining brass, polishing chromium and washing down the white top-sides. No self-respecting yachtsman out of New York or Boston cares to miss the annual June cruise to New London even if two or three cylinders are missing.

The maintenance of the fleet at treaty strength and the replacement of obsolete auxiliary vessels with 15 to 20 knot ships are two of the outstanding needs of the navy, Rear Admiral Harris Laning, the new commandant of the Third Naval District and of the navy yard in Brooklyn, said yesterday in an interview.

The proceedings of three regional conferences on banking problems held by the American Bankers Association early this year have been published by the association in a 500-page volume titled, "Present Day Banking -- Public Relations, Earnings, Management."

CHICAGO, June 13. -- With Curt Davis pitching air-tight ball after Baxter Jordan made a two-run homer in the first inning, the Cubs defeated the Bees again, 7 to 2, before 9,300 today to extend their winning streak to ten straight games.

AT a gathering last Tuesday of Old Timers and New Timers connected with the automobile industry, the vehicular Old Timer pictured above was among those present. It is one of the side-cranking, chain-driven, "one-lung" Cadillacs famous early in the century.

Landon and Knox as the Republican candidates confirm the belief of the Communist party that the Republican banner serves to rally all the most reactionary forces in America, Earl Browder, general secretary of the Communist party in this country, said in a press interview yesterday at the party headquarters, 35 East Twelfth Street.

THE great vacation caravan which winds its way out of New York this Summer will encounter a procession almost as great -- and full of the same holiday spirit -- trekking toward the city. Summer has always been "tourist time" in New York, and this Summer promises to be the biggest tourist season since the depression.

NEW American and international records for motorless aircraft, for both distance and altitude, will be the goal of the seventh annual national soaring contest, which will open on Saturday, at Elmira under the auspices of the Soaring Society of America.

IN the final busy days of planting in the garden, the question of material for suitable edgings is apt to be slighted in favor of the more showy sorts. Actually a great many edging plants may be chosen from among annual, perennial or shrub groups.

ONE always waits with interest and misgiving for a second book from the pen of a writer who has an unusually fine first novel to his credit. Welbourn Kelley, the gifted young Southerner who gave us several seasons ago a splendid story of the Negro sharecroppers, "Inchin' Along," presents here a second novel widely different in kind, but no leas encouraging in its augury for his future as a novelist.

Thirty-two chatty letters written by one of the Drukman murderers to his wife while he was in jail and while, apparently, he was anticipating his early freedom, were vested with a sinister significance as they were read to the jury by the prosecution in the Drukman conspiracy trial yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP). -- Democratic chieftains checked things over today and said that they were just about ready for their party's national convention at Philadelphia, which opens June 23 to renominate President Roosevelt.

All political circumstances considered, the particularly noteworthy incident of the Republican convention's platform-making was not the" currency plank" itself, but Governor LANDON'S interpretation of it. The platform as adopted had declared for "a sound currency, to be preserved at all hazards."

With the conviction of fourteen defendants in the recent prostitution cases, the special prosecutor, Thomas E. Dewey, has his indictment slate clean. What he intends to do next he won't say, largely because he always has declined to indicate what his next move will be, and partly because he says he doesn't know.
In his march toward the world's heavyweight championship, Joe Louis, famed Brown Bomber of the ring, will face his third ex-champion Thursday night.

MEXICO, D.F., June 13. -- Dr. Isaias Balanzario Rosas, Department of Health delegate in Motozintla, Chiapas, radioed to The Associated Press today that he had successfully substituted the needle for the knife in treating the dread, blindness-producing disease, onchocercosis.

Alida Schuyler is a young American whose father has been born and brought up in Holland. During her "year of promise" described in Miss De Leeuw's story, she visits Dutch relatives in Haarlem while her mother is ill in Vienna.

The hero of this exciting tale is Archie Lumsden, a young Englishman who has a veritable genius for getting into trouble and for getting out of it. He takes on a rather shady job and runs into something a great deal shadier before he is through, but he emerges unscathed except for a heart wound which yields readily to treatment by the beautiful girl who inflicted it.

DETROIT, June 13. -- What sort of man is he who, after a fatiguing day's work, will motor to a "meeting" in a shadowy field out in the country? Don a black robe and a hood emblazoned with skull and crossbones? Thrill to a ritual as weird and blood-thirsty as Mark Twain's small-boy classic?

The Midtown Community Music Center, 93 Park Avenue, a WPA Federal Music Project unit, will be "at home" to the musical public starting tomorrow night and lasting through the week, it was announced yesterday.

Clad in the picturesque costumes of other lands, 200 young dancers gathered on the Central Park Mall yesterday afternoon for the finals in the Park Department's city-wide children's folk-dance contest, and so eager were they to compete for prizes that they performed their terpsichorean antics for an hour and a half in a driving rain before the event was called off.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 13. -- Over a cinderpath that lay soggy beneath a dank blanket of rain, Donald R. Lash, unheralded 22-year-old Indiana University junior, broke the immortal Paavo Nurmi's world two-mile record today as a crowd of 30,000 at the Princeton invitation meet gazed on in amazement.

Week-end realizing and scattered selling in adjustment of the technical position were absorbed on declines of about 2 to 10 points at the opening yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange, with some rallies following on trade buying and covering.
PHILADELPHIA, June 13. -- Twelve grants of funds with which to start or continue scientific research of cultural projects were announced today by the American Philosophical society.

NEW LONDON, June 13. -- A gift of about $1,200 for the Department of Music was presented by the graduating class of Connecticut College to President Katharine Blunt at the Class Day exercises this afternoon. The presentation was made by Gertrude Allen of Trenton, N.J.

TWO unique events were announced last week. The first is a victory tournament to be held on Tuesday, at the Hotel Pennsylvania, to celebrate the acquittal of Miss Mildred Lovejoy and Mrs. Adelaide Neuwirth on a charge of running a gambling house at their bridge club.

LOURENCO MARQUES, framed in the wild beauty of the subtropical African coast and spiced with a suggestion of Oriental mystery, and famed the world over for its magnificent gaming casino, is a city of astonishing contrasts.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 13. -- A rush movement of vast quantities of aviation gasoline to inland Siberian storage points, via the port of Vladivostok, is under way at California oil ports.

PITTSBURG, Kan., June 13 (AP). -- Governor Landon stated tonight "to me the fight is on" in the "greatest struggle for retaining a constitutional government since the birth of the Republican party." In a message sent here to those celebrating his nomination, he said:

THIS broadly based study of a complex and widely ramifying subject is so remarkably comprehensive in its treatment as to be as satisfactory as the present state of knowledge concerning its theme makes possible. Its authors realize how desirable it is to know a great deal more about many of its aspects, but they recognize the present limitations and do the best they can within them, with interesting and useful results.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 13 (AP). -- Accolades were heaped on Miss Jacobs and Mrs. Fabyan for registering the clinching victory in the Wightman Cup matches today, but the silent heroine was Miss Babcock. Her brilliant play in yesterday's doubles saved the United States from a shut-out and today her victory over Miss Hardwick, a

A group of crusaders from Kansas marched into Cleveland last week and captured the Republican party. When they left for home at the end of the week they had made Kansas, the almost exact geographical center of the United States, also the center of the G.O.P.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., June 13. -- Twenty-one members of the class of 1886, Wesleyan University, gathered tonight at its reunion in the Downey House, the new student union, with Judge John C. Clark of New York City acting as secretary. Edward L. Blaine traveled across the continent from Seattle to be at the reunion.
PORTLAND, Me., June 13 (AP). -- Maine's primary election campaign tapered off tonight with Dr. Francis E. Townsend and the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin holding prominent places in closing activities.

THE thousands of motorists from every State coming here for the Texas Centennial Exposition, which opened on June 6, have no difficulty in finding quarters for their automobiles, for, in addition to an abundance of garages, there are numerous parking places all around the exposition grounds.

NAPANOCH, N.Y., June 13. -A complete reversal of form was shown by Max Schmeling today. In his ring work on Thursday the German was unimpressive, but today he appeared to excellent advantage, so much so that there was a general return of confidence among his followers regarding his chances against Joe Louis on Thursday night.

LONDON. AMERICANS who rent Scottish grouse moors will be interested in a recent judgment of the Edinburgh courts, which awarded 950 damages to a Scottish sportsman because he did not get as many grouse as he expected.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., June 13. -- After a long and trying campaign in the rain-soaked ring of the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club, Firenze Red Tape, noted timber-topper of Mrs. M. Robert Guggenheim's string, was named the champion hunter today to bring to a close the forty-third annual Westchester County Horse Show.

IN the Matanuska Valley, in Southern Alaska, forty-five miles inland from the Cook Inlet port of Anchorage. Uncle Sam's first government- planned experiment in pioneering is entering its second year in a mood of enthusiasm quite different from the doubt, confusion and downright discouragement of a year ago.

IN spite of its flamboyant title, "Men Are So Ardent" is an enticing, heady draft for the reader who demands body as well as bubbles in his light fiction. Mr. Kersh is lavish with juicy adjectives, shrewd characterizations, humorous comment, lifelike conversation.

WINCHESTER, Mass., June 13. -- After a morning of close and interesting matches, fifteen Boston golfers today won a clear right to the possession of the Griscom Cup, large silver trophy emblematic of the Women's Eastern Intersectional team championship.

PHILADELPHIA, June 13. -- The appointment of Saul Caston as associate conductor of the Philadelphia Symphony Orchestra for next seasen was announced today. A member of the orchestra since 1918 and first trumpet player since 1923, Mr. Caston was one of the guest conductors during the recent transcontinental tour.

IT is a tribute to the author of this Australian novel to say that "Return to Coolami" succeeds almost in spite of itself. There is no drearier trick in modern fiction than the scheme of a journey (usually long enough to permit a flashback), begun by two characters with mingled or desperate emotions, and ending in a tinsel Arcadia of manufactured bliss.

THE sixth annual American Folksong Festival will be presented today at Traipsin' Woman cabin on the Mayo Trail near Ashland, Boyd County, Ky., under the auspices of the American Folksong Society, with the cooperation of the WPA Federal Music Project.

FOUR of the characters who played important parts in "The Rose Petal Murders" appear again in this book, and again they cooperate in solving a murder mystery, this time on a Southern plantation completely surrounded by the raging waters of the Mississippi in flood.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 13. -- A sculptured head of Hadad, the Thunderer, known to ancient Romans as the Greatest Zeus, has been discovered in one of the oldest temples in the ancient city of Dura, Syria, it was announced today by the Yale University and French Academy of Inscriptions and Letters Expedition, in progress nine years under the supervision of Professor Michael I. Rostovtzeff of Yale.

BERLIN, June 13. -- The Voelkischer Beobachter, the official National Socialist party organ, is beginning to reply to the "innumerable" but naturally anonymous letters sent to it by disillusioned workers and others pointing out the rising industrial profits and declining real wages and mocking the Socialist pretensions of the Nazi regime.

The city police force has contributed $9,225.40 toward the $1,500,000 goal of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee, Laurence M. Marks, chairman of the committee, announced yesterday. City employes in the service of the Department of Hospitals have given $1,682.18.

HAMILTON, N.Y., June 13. -- A new $250,000 student union building will be started at Colgate University during the Summer or early Fall, William M. Parke of New York, president of the board of trustees, announced today to hundreds of alumni here for commencement.

CAMPINA, Rumania, June 13. -- In his special train returning to Czechoslovakia after a conference of Little Entente statesmen at Bucharest President Eduard Benes declared "we have accomplished infinitely more in the last conference than in all the preceding meetings between the Ministers of our three States."

Public Works Administrator Harold L. Ickes and Mayor La Guardia will take part in ceremonies next Saturday morning to mark the completion of the foundations and the laying of the first bricks on Harlem River Houses, at 153d Street and the Harlem River.

BOSTON, June 13. -- Next Tuesday the eighth annual girls' intercollegiate tennis tournament starts at the Longwood Cricket Club. Inaugurated in 1929 by Mrs. George W. Wightman and won that year by a Californian, Miss Marjorie Gladman, who now as Mrs. John Van Ryn is competing in England in the Wightman Cup matches, the tournament always has had a good entry and more than once a Californian has come on to win the title.

THE broadcasters are trying to re-establish their regular program schedules after a week's bombardment of politics from the Republican National Convention. Well-planned and rehearsed shows suddenly found themselves sidetracked as the actors and musicians, many of them stars of the air, were nonchalantly brushed aside when the announcer suddenly exclaimed, "we now take you to Cleveland."
Four years of change and controversy, giving birth to new issues, are reflected in the platform adopted by the Republican National Convention last week in Cleveland.

ALBANY, June 13 (AP). -- Heat and echoes, proverbial accompaniments of legislative oratory, both may be controlled through extensive alterations being made in the Assembly Chamber during the "off" season.
The appointment of eighteen new faculty members has been announced for the 1936-37 academic year at Sarah Lawrence College, Bronxville. The new members and their respective departments follow:

MILTON, Mass., June 13. -- Jerome D. Greene delivered the commencement address today at Milton Academy, where forty-three boys received diplomas from Roger Pierce, president of the board of trustees. The valedictory was given by Frederick Holdsworth Jr.

PHILADELPHIA, June 13 (AP). -Playing a double-header despite a steady drizzle of rain, the Athletics and Indians split the verdict today. The Mackmen won the first game, 7 to 3, and the Indians the second, called at the end of eight innings, 19 runs to 1.

BEFORE anybody could learn anything much about it, a musical comedy has almost been born hereabouts to the name of "But It's My Town." And that is fairly unorthodox, because while a straight play can be hatched anywhere, a musical is a more heavily populated venture and some one usually talks.

Students from many parts of the world will discuss world problems and hear outstanding speakers on political, cultural and economic subjects at an international student institute beginning tomorrow at International House, Riverside Drive at 124th Street.

LONDON, June 13. -- Summer has suddenly come to England at the right moment for a great carnival of sports, which commenced with the Westchester Polo Cup matches between Great Britain and the United States at Hurlingham this week.

AMHERST, Mass., June 13. -Before a commencement crowd of 4,000 Amherst alumni, the Amherst baseball team scored a 3-2 victory over Williams today. The triumph gives the Lord Jeffs a tie with Williams for the Little Three title.
Senior week activities will begin at Hunter College Wednesday with a tea to be given by the Associate Alumnae for the graduating class at the Bronx buildings.

NORWALK, Conn., June 13. -- Eleven boats answered the starting gun off the Norwalk Yacht Club this morning for the annual Duck Island-Norwalk race, which, with good weather conditions, will be brought to a conclusion late tomorrow afternoon.

Surrogate James A. Delehanty granted yesterday additional expenditures of $3,000 for medical expenses from the trust allowance of Lucetta Cotton Thomas, 11-year-old daughter of Mrs. Lucy Cotton Thomas Magraw, whose former husband, Edward Russell Thomas, left an estate of close to $2,000,000 in trust for the child.

A NATIONAL showing of paintings, water-colors and designs for murals done under the Federal Art Project of the WPA will be held at the Phillips Memorial Gallery from June 16 to July 5. About 100 works have been selected for this display by Duncan Phillips, Marjorie Phillips and C. Law Watkins.
PRINCETON, N.J., June 13. -- The Yale baseball team downed the Princeton nine, 13 -- 6, on University Field today before an Alumni Day crowd of about 5,000 spectators.

CHICAGO, June 13 (AP). -- Edward A. O'Neal, president of the American Farm Bureau Federation, said today that while he believed the Republican platform adopted at Cleveland was "a real attempt in the direction of liberality," he was disappointed that "some of the most important things he wanted to see included in it, were left out."

The press reported recently a petition from citizens of the United States to Stanley Baldwin urging Great Britain to greater efforts in settling distressed Jews in Palestine. The petition assumes to voice the "consensus of enlightened Christian American opinion"; it comes from the Pro-Palestine Federation of New York.

PARIS, June 12. -- It is not yet certain whether what is happening in France is reform or revolution. Premier Leon Blum's Popular Front government has been in office for a week, and during that week there has been that turmoil and uncertainty which are always incident to quick growth. But what the eventual crop will be is still an unanswered question.

A foreign central banker's appraisal of the economic prospects in this country is provided by the annual report of the governor of the National Bank of Greece, John A. Drossopoulos, delivered before the annual meeting of the bank in March, which has just been received here.

ITHACA, June 13. -- Reunion activities at Cornell, a prelude to the university's commencement exercises Monday, reached a climax today with class dinners, the annual reunion rally and meetings of the alumni organizations. The baccalaureate sermon will be heard tomorrow.

THE latest of the excellent series of publications of the Museum of Modern Art is "Modern Painters and Sculptors as Illustrators." Monroe Wheeler assembled the material for the current exhibition and has supplied a preface for the catalogue in which he outlines the development of book illustration during the last thirty-five years.

LEOPOLD STOKOWSKI and the Philadelphia Orchestra have gone to the country and have found in all sections an intense eagerness to hear great and inspired music. Back from a transcontinental tour at the head of his brilliant virtuoso band, the dynamic, silver-haired conductor tells stirringly of what he has seen, heard and sensed.

ALTHOUGH automotive engineers may agree that the car of the future will be fully streamlined and will have the engine mounted in the rear, automobile manufacturers have too much at stake to gamble on radical changes.

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- Brig. Gen. Aaron S. Daggett, retired, the oldest officer of the army, was honored by the War Department today on his ninety-ninth birthday at his home in West Roxbury, Mass., by the presentation of the decorations of the Silver Star and the Purple Heart by a representative of Major Gen. Fox Conner, commander of the First Corps Area.

SIX concerts, devoted to the chamber works, Lieder and piano works of Brahms, will be given on consecutive Monday nights, starting June 29, at Greenwich House Music School, 46 Barrow Street, under the sponsorship of the Federal Music Project.

Rain curtailed play in the women's New York State championships at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club yesterday, but not until it had subsided long enough to allow Miss Norma Taubele, runner-up in last year's competition, to make her way into the final round of the singles division.

The Manhattan, Brooklyn and Westchester delegates to the Republican National Convention in Cleveland came home yesterday, brimming with confidence in the party's slate. Their leaders foresaw a decisive victory for the Landon-Knox ticket next Fall. They wenti further and predicted that it would not only carry this State, but would also sweep with it the party's I Gubernatorial and legislative slate.

One hundred years ago Arkansas became a State, just in time to cast its three electoral votes for Van Buren, Democrat. In 1836, also, Texas declared its independence from Mexico. Both States are now celebrating their centennials. Last week, while Republican ideas radiated copiously by wire and ether out of Cleveland, the two celebrations gave President Roosevelt occasion to travel in Democratic territory and speak some Democratic thoughts.
WASHINGTON, June 13. -- France defaulted on her war debt installment today in a note to the State Department, but with the expression of a hope for future settlement.

TO endow it with the pathos and sentiment that increase by distance, Paramount has striven hopefully to find out if the carnival is not dead. It would have liked to hill W.C. Fields in "The Vanished (or Vanishing) Carnival" and to let the curtain down with a bang on an era, as has been done with Roman history, Ziegfeld and other phenomena of the past.

PROVIDENCE, June 13. -- Continuation and expansion of advanced study will overcome many of today's evils arising from prejudice and ignorance, Dean Roscoe Pound of the Harvard Law School declared in an address at the annual Graduate School convocation of Brown University in Sayles Hall this afternoon.

THE National Youth Administration is looking forward this Summer to continuing its program of educational camps for young unemployed women. Last year's program brought 3,009 girls and young women from the tenements of industrial cities, from poor farm homes and bleak mountain shacks to six weeks of rest, rehabilitation and study amid healthful surroundings.

TRENTON, N.J., June 13. -- General John J. Pershing Unveiled here today a plaque honoring the late Judge James g. Kerney, director of the American Committee on Public Information in France during the World War.
TOPEKA, June 13. -- Governor Alf M. Landon today pledged the Republican party to a hard but fair fight in the coming Presidential campaign.
