ALBANY, June 13. -- On the application of District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan of Brooklyn, Acting Governor M. William Bray issued today a request to Governor Harold G. Hoffman of New Jersey for the extradition of Ellis Parker St., chief of detectives of Burlington County, N.J.

The stock market retrieved part of Friday's setback, closing irregularly higher for yesterday's half-day trading period. The volume on the Stock Exchange was 375,000 shares, compared with 253,000 the Saturday before. Bonds were firm, the Treasury issues in the slowest dealings since Dec. 21.

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- Since there has already been uttered sufficient public and private criticism of the course of Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg to indicate that he has been cast in certain influential Republican quarters as the villain of the Cleveland drama, a review of the steps leading up to choice of Colonel Frank Knox for Vice President seems in order.

THE Delphic Oracle had a system. When a trusting visitor asked him -- her or it? -- an embarrassing or otherwise difficult question, the answer was usually so shrewdly ambiguous that, whatever happened, the Oracle's priestly interpreter could say, "I told you so."

KINGSTON, R.I., June 13. -- The usual six-week Summer school period in the Department of English of Rhode Island State College will be reduced to three weeks this year by doubling the daily lecture hours.

OFF the coast of Maine is an archipelago of islands which Uncle Sam has rechristened Acadia. At the northern end is Mount Desert, the "largest rock-built island on the Atlantic Coast." Until recently only the wealthy could afford Acadia; now it can be enjoyed by any purse.

Impressed by the manner in which the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., have defeated fraudulent consumer claims for damages against its members, four other national groups joined them last week in a determined move to stamp out a racket which has taken hundreds of thousands of dollars annually from industry.

JIM COOK, at one time in his life generally known also as Jim Lane, which explains the parenthetic surname, is another of the dwindling number of frontiersmen whose stories deserve to be preserved. He is still living, hale and vigorous and youthful, although nearing his eightieth year, and looks back - with reminiscent pleasure upon a life whose activities span the creation of all our vast Southwest out of virgin prairie and desert sands.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 13. -With an easterly blow, rain and a flood tide, a combination that billowed Long Island Sound into long, rolling swells reminiscent of those off Newport, H.C. Taylor's 50-foot sloop Barbara, Bayard S. Litchfield's international 12-meter Cantitoe and Commodore R.J. Schaefer's yawl Edlu swept through to victories today in the Larchmont Yacht Club's fifty-second Spring regatta, the fifth one of the Yacht Racing Association's season.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., June 13. -- Suits filed by an insurance company in Superior Court today against the beneficiaries of a poison victim's insurance policy lent fresh impetus tonight to the State's investigation into a half-hundred deaths in near-by milltown communities.

A postcard ballot is being taken among the Riverside Y.C. members on the proposal to permit women to use the club's new bar and grill room. The men, however, have expressly excepted, in case the vote is in the affirmative, the evenings of the annual overnight race, stag dinners and other robust affairs.

There are one or two less important movie transgressions that I wish might be eliminated. One is the frightful, embryonic-gangster speech of some -- most -- of the small children who are supposed to be the sons and daughters of our best people.

Anticipating their most active Fall season since 1929 and encouraged by the sharp improvement in the primary markets in the last week, dry goods wholesalers will start this week to buy large quantities of Fall merchandise, purchasing of which has been deferred for a number of reasons.

Less work and more pay will be the lot of 2,800 milk drivers under a contract made public yesterday by Max Liebler, secretary-treasurer of the Milk Drivers Union, Local 584, of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters. The contract, signed by 108 independent milk dealers, provides an average increase of $2 a week for inside men, route men and helpers and runs for two years, Mr. Liebler said.

THE present administration, easily the most "stamp-minded" in our history and headed by a philatelist President, has added thirty issues to the United States postage album since March, 1933. This does not include the imperforates, which do not represent new stamps.

Last week the first number of the Harvard University Tercentenary Gazette appeared, with an initial article on the meaning of the tercentenary. The celebration will be an occasion for reviewing the pageant of the past of this first of American institutions of higher learning, for looking into the future and for advancing the bounds of knowledge to the common good of humanity.

PITTSBURGH, June 13. -- Even the magical name of Al Smith failed New York very dismally today, and a great cause received another staggering blow as Pie Traynor's Pirates bowled over our latest prize left-hander to wallop the Giants for the second successive day before 14,000 thoroughly pleased spectators.

ALBANY, June 13 (AP). -- Estimates that the State's new Unemployment Insurance Law would yield about $30,000,000 during its first year of operation are borne out, Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews said today, by collection of $8,254,970.41 for four months.

EDMUND WILSON has put some of his best work into this book, and his best, in its sensitiveness, its observance of significant details and a style which is certainly carefully studied but usually does not seem to be so, is good indeed.

Controversy rages about the new autobiography of JOHN MIDDLETON MURRY. Out of the dust of battle a pair of old maxims emerge, recognizable if somewhat mussed up. It makes a difference whose ox is debunked.

About $50,000,000 of revenue will be provided for the railroads by applying the emergency freight surcharges in the last half of this year in accordance with an order issued by the Interstate Commerce Commission on Friday, it was estimated yesterday.
NEW radios for the 1936-37 season continue to reach the market places, with the designs offering further evidence that long-distance reception from lands across the sea is no mere fad or fancy.
The board of directors of the National Symphony Orchestra Association has re-engaged Hans Kindler as conductor of the National Symphony Orchestra of Washington and C.C. Cappel as business manager.

GUIDED by concert programs, it might be excusable to class Antonin Dvorak with Cesar Franck as a one symphony composer. Conductors are satisfied to confine themselves to one of his full-length works, and that, having been labeled as "From the New World," is seldom identified, popularly, by his number.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., June 13 (AP). -- Dancing Cloud, owned by Phillip Schwartz of Suffield, Conn., captured the feature race on the Agawam Park program in a driving finish with Golden Words today before a crowd of 12,000.

NANKING, June 13 (AP). -- American and British missionaries, traveling by airplane, by pony-cart and on foot, tonight were reported pushing back into China's remote Northwest, despite diplomatic warnings of Communist and bandit perils.

IN the six short poems which Charles W. Kennedy calls "Elegies" the reader to whom Anglo-Saxon has been a closed book will glimpse startling and unexpected beauties. That these poems are not "elegies" as that term was employed Professor Kennedy makes clear in his scholarly but unpedantic introduction.

ROSLYN, L.I., June 13. -- In spite of drenching rain and spongy fields, many North Shore colonists and New Yorkers crowded the rolling hillsides of the Charles V. Hickox estate to see the curtailed races of the Spring meeting of the United Hunts Association this afternoon.
BALTIMORE, June 13 (AP). -- Libby Holman Reynolds had the $7,000,000 estate of her 3-year-old son, Christopher, placed under a guardianship today.

MOSCOW, June 13 (AP). -- An official interpretation of the new Russian Constitution declared today that Soviet working people would have guarantees of greater freedom of speech, press and public manifestation than any other workers in the world.

PRODUCTION of aircraft in the United States for the first quarter of 1936 increased more than 33 per cent over that for the 1935 period, according to the Bureau of Air Commerce. The comparative totals were 456 and 349. There was a notable increase in the category of light planes for the private owner.

Rain and wet grounds caused the postponement of many major athletic contests yesterday. In this city the annual charity baseball encounter between the police and firemen at the Polo Grounds was called at the end of two-and-a-half scoreless innings.
DANZIG, June 13 (AP). -- Danzig's Nazis, stung by the killing of a storm trooper at a meeting-house brawl, moved tonight to answer their foes en masse.

OTTAWA, Ill., June 13. -- Hope for the full recovery of Joseph Lengan Jr., 30-year-old cement worker, who has been asleep for 440 days, was expressed today as he continued to show indications of reviving from what many believed was the "sleep of death."

PHILADELPHIA, June 13. -- The group of Fundamentalists who seceded from the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America and fo1Tned the Presbyterian Church of America, voted today to establish the first two of its Presbyteries.

WITH the New York World's Fair ahead of us, the Museum of Modern Art has undertaken a preliminary service to the undertaking by putting on an exhibition of modern exposition architecture. Chiefly consisting of enlarged photographs of buildings and plans of sites, the show is interesting for the comparisons it permits and the partial perspective afforded over architectural developments in such enterprises during the last twenty years.

CHICAGO, June 13. -- Strength in the Northwestern markets was the dominating factor again today in trading in wheat, anxiety increasing in regard to the Spring wheat conditions, especially in North Dakota. At the start prices on the Board of Trade here were slightly lower, but there was an absence of pressure and the market began to harden almost immediately and worked up gradually above yesterday's final quotations.
WASHINGTON, June 13. -- No large changes in business activity have been observed recently, after due allowance for seasonal trends, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly survey.

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- Announcing a partial list of labor union veterans who will head the Steel Workers' committee in its campaign to organize the iron and steel industry, the Committee for Industrial Organization completed its program today for the first meeting of the new committee in Pittsburgh next Wednesday.

About 900 needy Catholic children from 6 to 14 years old will be moved from congested areas of Manhattan to eight "fresh air homes" in New York and North Jersey from July 3 to 5, the New York Catholic Charities announces.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP). -- A new plan of reorganization for the Minneapolis St. Louis Railroad, offered by Philip J. Roosevelt of New York, chairman of a bondholders' committee, was reported here tonight by Senator Shipstead of Minnesota.
CHAPEL HILL, N.C., June 13. -- An institute on Southern regional development and the social sciences will open at the University of North Carolina here next Tuesday and continue through the month.
CLEVELAND, June 13. -- Plans for a militant and whirlwind opening of the Republican campaign, possibly within the next ten days, were tonight mapped here by members of the party's high command.

CLEVELAND, June 12. -- The Republican convention was a strange convocation of the quick and the dead. Of every convention this is true in some degree. Seldom so strikingly as here, however, have ghosts walked in company with living men.

In today's issue of THE TIMES I read the account of Senator Ashurst's introduction of his resolution to the Senate for a basic law change involving the transferring of power over industry, labor, agriculture and commerce to Congress.

BIRTHDAY: On Thursday the man who is conceded to be the greatest German master of the opera since Wagner celebrated his seventy-second birthday. Also, he marked his sixty-sixth year of composition, for Richard Strauss first wrote music as the age of 6.

MR. WIGGAM writes agreeable poetry with skill and ease and sensibility. His book -- it is his first; he was born in 1915 -- has the almost anonymous quality of maturity that springs from the use of familiar themes and cadences: landscapes sensitively recorded, notations on the heart -- and an extraordinarily narrow selection of material from the events of his own life as his publishers present it.

GENEVA, June 13. -- The proposed forty-hour week convention for the textile industry cleared the first hurdle at the International Labor Organization conference when the committee dealing with it voted today to finish discussion at this session instead of delaying it until next year.
This week brings the last stages of what has been an interesting season of college crew racing.

THE airplane and radio will be given a bigger assignment than ever before in the 1936 campaign against forest fires. New ground equipment and new methods will add greatly to the efficiency of the airplane as a fire-fighter. The Forest Service will try dropping waters or chemicals direct on small fires to hold them in check until ground crews can reach the danger zone.

In "Wings Over Holland" (Macmillan), Anne Merriman Peck and Enid Johnson have written vividly and sympathetically for American boys and girls about the life and customs of a European country, and Miss Peck's "Story Book Europe" and "Roundabout Europe" (Harper), are among the best travel books for 12 to 14 year olds that we have.
NEW LONDON, Conn., June 13. -The I-tarvard and Yale oarsmen had comparatively easy workouts today.

While gains in consumer buying last week were not as marked as in recent weeks, retail trade in most sections of the country continued brisk. Distribution of bonus payments to veterans beginning tomorrow is expected to result in sharp gains in volume, for which both retailers and manufacturers have prepared.

George A. Sloan, chairman of the Consumers' Goods Industries Committee, made public yesterday reports from leaders in twelve diversified industries to the effect that industry is "maintaining improved wage and hour standards, and employment is approaching and in some cases exceeding 1929 levels."

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- Since the registration features of the Securities Act of 1933 went into operation in July, 1933, securities of various types for an aggregate of slightly more than $6,000,000,000 have become effective, thus being eligible for distribution by issuers or their underwriters and agents.

To clear up misapprehensions about the distribution of the veterans' bonus bonds, which begins tomorrow morning, Postmaster General James A. Farley outlined last evening the governing regulations in a radio address here over an NBC national hook-up.
An enrollment of 7,000 students, 800 more than last year, for New York University's Summer session, which starts tomorrow, was predicted yesterday by Henry G. Arnsdorf, registrar.

PHILADELPHIA, June 13. -- Between showers, Huntley Glen, 7-year-old brown mare, owned by Miss Josephine Deubler of Newtown, Pa., won the open jumping event at the Philadelphia horse show on the Country Club oval at Bala today.

THIS charming volume suggests the children's books an earlier day. The editor and translator, who is the granddaughter of Sir Edward Burne-Jones, dedicates her book "To the memory of the Brothers Grimm, Hans Christian Andersen, Berthold Auerbach and their translators, known and unknown:" she has, however, left the beaten track to find the stories which she includes.

SHORT-WAVE radio conditions are generally rated excellent when Bombay, India, is mistaken for GSC, the powerful English transmitter at Daventry; on the dial they are only a hairbreadth from each other, but are usually on the air at different hours.

MANILA, June 13. -- The heir apparent to the Sultanate of Sulu was reported tonight ready to wage war for the throne left vacant last Sunday by the death of the aged, childless Sultan Jamalu'l Kiram. The new Sultan will be chosen tomorrow.

OTTAWA -- Royal Canadian Mounted police and Indian agents are busy this month taking a census of those who live in the far northern regions of Canada's Saskatchewan and Alberta. Into remote districts where trappers, prospectors and Indians live, pack-horses and canoes are carrying the census officials.

FORTY years ago a novelist called Grant Allen wrote a best-seller entitled "The Woman Who Did." In these pages the woman who did appears as the woman who was. Harriette Wilson -- by birth Dabuchot -- was the most illustrious courtesan of her day.

DO colonies pay? is the question asked by (Drover Clark. His answer is an emphatic "No" -- too emphatic, one is inclined to think, in a matter so vast and complicated, and open to doubt on various grounds.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 13. -- Miss Virginia Bradley of Maplewood will head a delegation of college students who will represent the New Jersey College for Women at the annual intercollegiate Silver Bay conference which convenes next Wednesday at Silver Bay, Lake George, N.Y.

This volume contains eight stories taken from "The First and Second Jungle Books" and a ninth, "In the Rukhy," from "Many Inventions." Kurt Wiese has made nine spirited drawings, a frontispiece in color, chapter headings and decorations.

INSTEAD of taking a final examination in "American Civilization" sophomores at Horace Mann School for Girls recently were permitted to produce a movie. Similar experiments in other progressive schools are convincing many educators of the advantages of student cinematography.

PROBABLY there is no phase of gardening to which the moral of the old adage about locking the stable after the horse is stolen applies, more definitely than to providing support for plants likely to need it. One bad storm, or even a few moments of high wind accompanying a sudden thunder shower, may do irreparable damage to valued plants that might, if properly supported, have gone unscathed.

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- An intensive drive for adjournment of Congress not later than June 20 was organized by leaders today as Republicans drifted in from their convention and Democrats looked forward to their own convention in Philadelphia June 23.

SEVERAL months after the death of Edwin Arlington Robinson the last poem he wrote, "King Jasper," was published with a penetrating and sympathetic introduction by that other New England poet, Robert Frost. Mr. Frost may want to reject the flattering unction contained in the "New England" title.

THE actor who played John Wilkes Booth with such a picturesque, old-school flourish in "Birth of a Nation" was Raoul Walsh, who passed through town a few days ago on his way to direct Kipling's "Soldiers Three" and one other he-man production as yet unnamed, for Gaumont-British.

GENEVA, June 13. -- Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, definitely announced to the League of Nations that the Council would meet June 26, instead of June 16, and that there would be four points on the Agenda. These are the Ethiopian question, the Locarno problem, the slavery committee's report and the settlement of Assyrians in Iraq.

THE commercial theatre, notoriously different as a means of livelihood from all other pursuits, is strangely like the others in one essential detail -- its terrifying prejudice against the newcomer. It insists that he be experienced before being allowed to work and, since it is fairly obvious that work is the only means of obtaining experience, a very neat and vicious circle surrounds the beginner.

BOSTON, June 12. -- Business in New England continues to hold the gains of the earlier months of the year. In general, factory operations are the best since 1930. The recent shoe shows in Boston resulted in heavy orders for Fall delivery, the amount of new business booked running more than double a year ago.

The Western speed star, Clang, holder of the world six-furlong record and co-holder of the universal seven-furlong mark, proved his speed before 12,000 persons at Aqueduct yesterday when he raced through sloppy going to victory in the $8,950 Carter Handicap.
PHILADELPHIA, June 13 (AP). -- Philadelphia is sprouting the gala garb of an "old home week" and a dozen entertainment units are in rehearsal for the opening of the Democratic convention on June 23.
JONES BEACH, L.I., June 13. -New Jersey schools took premier honors in the Eastern interscholastic outdoor swimming championships today at Jones Beach State Park.

HAMILTON, N.Y., June 13. -- The strange story of Harry C. Kinne Jr. of Watertown, N.Y., and Harry C. Kinne Jr. of Wilmette, Ill., will reach a climax Monday when the two walk on the platform at Colgate University and receive their Bachelor of Arts degrees.
The New York Conservation Department yesterday issued a summary of Conservtaion Law changes enacted by the 1936 Legislature. Among the bills were a number affecting the interests of sportsmen.

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- A recently completed survey of the farm and grazing lands of the country by the United States Soil Conservation Service reveals a tragic picture of erosion conditions affecting every part of the nation except New England and certain widely separated areas in other parts of the country.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 13. -- Nearly 4,000 alumni, the largest number ever to return for a Princeton reunion, braved a threatening storm that became a steady rain before the afternoon was well under way to participate in the annual alumni parade from Nassau Hall to University Field here today.

Rising sales abroad of American-made machinery and machine tools, supplemented by the steadily increasing demand in this country, may soon make it difficult for buyers to obtain deliveries of such equipment in less than two or three months, according to Charles J. Stilwell, vice president of the Warner Swasey Company of Cleveland, builders of machine tools and precision instruments.

MOTORISTS visiting the Yosemite area of the Sierra this year will not be able to travel over the roads leading toward Mono Lake and Reno until some time in July. Park officials explain that the reason is that last Winter's snowfall in the higher ranges was one of the heaviest of recent years.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 13. -- Selecting a crew from among its class members on hand to witness the Alumni Day exercises, the Princeton class of '31 surprised by showing the way to the Tiger varsity by half a length in the annual Downhill regatta on Lake Carnegie this morning.
JERUSALEM, June 13. -- Bethlehem today played a leading role in the ever-shifting scenes of the tragic drama of the Palestine disturbances, now in their eighth week.

Industry has a way of ignoring the shadows cast by coming events. The railroads could not believe that the automobile and the motor truck would deprive them of both passenger and freight; the phonograph companies dismissed radio broadcasting as of no consequence; the owners of Chilean nitrate mines saw no threat to their monopoly when synthetic ammonia was first introduced.

A HOT June sun has begun to drop behind the western horizon at the close of another day, but has left enough of itself behind to raise shimmering heat waves from the surface of the river. Ordinarily placid and never particularly crowded, this river today bears a company which comes to it only once a year, when the annual races that form the final chapter of college rowing are held.

The task of budget-making is again under way at the Board of Education, with pleas for reduction of class sizes and extension of services for evening students and handicapped children demanding first consideration.

THESE ten brilliantly written biographical sketches by Dr. Gumpert, a noted German scientist who is said to be preparing to become an American citizen, were first published a year ago in Berlin under the title "Das Leben fuer die Idee."

THE Somerville by-pass on New Jersey Route 31 was scheduled last week to be opened to motor traffic yesterday. The new alignment, which has a length of one and eight-tenths miles, leaves the traffic circle where Routes 28 and 29 meet, and continues to the Raritan River, just north of the Duke estate, where it joins the present highway.

THERE will come shortly from Hutchinson's what is likely to be the most important political biography of the year -- the life of Lord Balfour by his niece, Blanche E.C. Dugdale. This book has developed from an autobiography that was long contemplated but never written.

THE myriad resorts that lie between the Appalachians and the Atlantic, with their varied attractions of sunshine, sea breeze and scenery, are ready for their biggest seasonal influx since 1929. In the next two or three weeks the perennial mass migration from city to country will be at its peak.

The emergency fund American seamen's welfare age benefited to the extent of $3,222.80 because of the visit of the new Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary to this port. Kermit Roosevelt, treasurer of the fund, in his weekly report yesterday, said $8,154 had been collected from visitors to the new liner, and expenses were $38.80, leaving $8,115.20.

PHILADELPHIA, June 13. -- A 10 per cent tax on the retail prices of liquor, voted this week by the Legislature, was significant not only because it increased the cost of drinks to Pennsylvania consumers, but also because it was the only one of the tax measures sponsored by Governor George H. Earle to be passed by both houses during the first six weeks of the special legislative session.

Degrees were awarded to six honorary recipients, seventy-eight seniors and nine graduate students yesterday at the sixty-fourth annual commencement of Stevens Institute of Technology in Hoboken. One of the honorary recipients, Thomas J. Watson, president of the International Business Machines Corporation, delivered the address.

JERUSALEM, June 13. -- A factor in the current Palestine disorders that is little known to the general public is a long-standing political feud between the two leading Arab families, for which the Jews happen to be convenient scapegoats.

A reply to the criticism of the Federal Savings and Loan System that was issued a week ago by the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York was made yesterday by C. Harry Minners, president of the New York State League of Savings and Loan Associations, in a letter addressed to Harold Stone, president of the savings banks organization.

Development of a new instrument to simplify navigati0nJ by air, at sea and for operations on the ground, was disclosed yesterday by Sherman M. Fairchild, president of the Fairchild Aviation Corporation. Known as the Hegner position finder, the device was invented by Fred C. Hegner of San Antonio, Texas, on the basis of personal experience in navigation while cruising for pleasure in the Gulf of Mexico.
WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP). -The White Sox avenged two successive scoreless drubbings by battering a pair of Washington pitchers today for sixteen hits to take the third game of the series, 15 -- 2.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 13. -- America's oldest annual academic ceremony, dating back to 1642, with a history marked by colorful pageantry and interrupted by wars and pestilence, will be observed again next week as Harvard celebrates commencement.

PHILADELPHIA, June 12. -- Business gains continued in this district this week, although trade was spotted in some lines. Volume of retail turnover is estimated at about 12 1/2 per cent above that at this time last year, being especially active in such household articles as electric refrigerators and felt-base floor coverings, sales of which are running 20 per cent or more above last year's amount.

BERLIN, June 13. -- Persons arrested as drunken drivers in Germany are subjected to a blood test revealing not only whether they have been drinking but how much alcohol remains in their systems when they are arrested.

"HAVE you androsace sarmentosum?" More than one nurseryman the past year or so has been startled with a purchaser crisply asks such a question. The truth is, that the garden clubs with their lectures, along with articles appearing in newspapers and magazines, have added zest to the horticultural world in a manner almost unbelievable.

THE diversified nature of Benjamin Franklin's life and work has caused no end of wonderment in every corner of the world. Biographers have for the most part, however, neglected his brief but important career as a military man.

The right of the State Industrial Commissioner to set up a list of physicians authorized to practice in workmen's compensation cases was upheld by Supreme Court Justice Bernard L. Shientag in a decision made public yesterday.

HEWLETT, L.I., June. 13. -- For a while today it appeared as if two chips off the old golfing blocks, Charley Mayo Jr., son of the Lido pro, and Alick Gerard Jr., whose father holds a similar position at the National Links of America, would be the finalists in the fifteenth annual Long Island amateur championship at the Seawane Club.

THE Orquesta Sinfonica de Mexico, under the direction of Carlos Chavez, opens its season of eight Friday concerts, July 17, in Mexico, D.F. In addition to these subscription concerts to be given in the Palace of Fine Arts there will be six popular concerts, four concerts for children and six concerts for workmen.

A busy week has been arranged for the record graduating class of more than 2,100 men and women at City College who will receive degrees, diplomas and commissions at the ninetieth commencement exercises in Lewisohn Stadium Wednesday night.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 12. -- The government's June estimate of a 130,450,000-bushel wheat crop for Kansas, the largest since the record of 251,766,000 bushels made in 1931, furnished a general stimulant to trade in the Kansas City territory this week.

Thirty-two families living in four adjoining tenement buildings on Tompkins Avenue near DeKalb Avenue, Brooklyn, were forced to flee from their home shortly after 1 o'clock this morning when fire swept the four-story building at 221 Tompkins Avenue from the basement to the roof.

THE berry season is in full swing. The cream jug on the breakfast table beckons to every hand. The shortcake spreads its enticements and the jam makers are busy. Though the berries are fine, they are not arriving in as large a volume as usual at this time.

Pointing out that the consumer of one package of cigarettes a day pays into the Federal Treasury $21.90 a year in cigarette taxes, the Retail Tobacco Dealers of America, at their annual convention in the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday, declared strongly against the imposition and extension of State taxes on tobacco products.

FROM its title, "Village Chronicle," one might suppose this to be a novel in the Phil Strong or neo-bucolic manner. Actually it is no such thing. With skill and nerve, and a good deal of real penetration, Mr. McConnaughey has drawn a composite picture of a North Carolina university town which can be pretty transparently identified as Chapel Hill.

HOLDING former gains fairly well, retail trade through the country ran from 5 to 15 per cent ahead of a year ago last week and is now entering the period when distribution of the veterans' bonus is expected to push these increases higher.

With distribution of bonus bonds starting tomorrow and with the expected buying of gifts for Father's Day, which will be next Sunday, men's wear retailers yesterday predicted a brisk upturn in sales volume. Last year the promotion of Father's Day alone was credited with jumping sales volume on an average of about 35 per cent over the preceding week.

GRAY as a background color is one of the recent discoveries of the interior decorator. Gray walls are far from somber; they give a pleasant air of coolness in Summer and are surprisingly adaptable, harmonizing with every color of wood or fabric.

The American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers yesterday made known that it had extended the final date of the New York City song contest until Aug. 1 to permit more contestants to enter. The society also disclosed that many entries have already been received.
WASHINGTON, June 13. -- Four university fellowships and fifteen tuition scholarships at American University were announced by Dr. Ernest S. Griffith, dean of the Graduate School.

A concerted and country-wide effort to provide pleasure yachtsmen with additional public boat basins has not only been launched this month but, according to Ira Hand, secretary of the N.A.E.B.M., which conducts the National Motor Boat Show in New York each January, there is fast-growing municipal recogntion of the requirements of skippers residing in large cities.

EAST HAMPTON L.I., June 13. -- Mrs. William R. Maloney, president of the Ladies' Village Improvement Society, has called a meeting for Monday afternoon, June 15, at her Jones Road Summer home, for chairmen of the various attractions at the annual Village Fair, to take place on July 31.

It seems to me that Messrs. Baker, Wolman and Douglas are in error in assuming that monopolistic practices and organizations in this country are due either to purposely granted "immunities and privileges" or to the tariff.

LONG ISLANDERS are campaigning for a public college of their own. The three-year success of the Nassau Collegiate Center, a junior college operated with the aid of WPA funds and makeshift equipment in an old airplane plant at Garden City, has proved, they think, the need.

CANADA'S special radio committee has recommended to Parliament that broadcasting in the Dominion be nationalized and patterned after the non-commercial British system rather than the American sell-time-on-the-air plan.

AFTER twenty-five hectic years of vicissitudinous fortune the Cambridge Medieval History has been completed, only two months after the tentative completion of the Cambridge Modern History. The editors have signed their initials for the last time, "not without a sigh of relief."

HALIFAX, N.S., June 13 (Canadian Press). -- Captain James Gosling and his crew of twenty-four Newfoundland fishermen landed today to tell how their 100-ton schooner, the Beatrice Vivian, was cut in two by the 17,000-ton Anchor liner California, twenty-five miles off Cape Race Thursday, without the loss of a member of the crew or injury to a man.

VINCENNES, Ind., June 13. -- This Southwestern Indiana city completed preparations today to accommodate 125,000 persons at the dedication tomorrow of the $2,500,000 memorial to the Northwest Territory conqueror, General George Rogers Clark.

The Women's City Club, after a study of probationary schools under the Board of Education, finds no definite policy in their administration and a lack of objective consideration of the problems confronting truant children.

WELLESLEY COLLEGE this week-end has been celebrating the achievements of a woman which many a man in business or government would have been glad to emulate. Miss Ellen Fitz Pendleton is ending her quarter century as Wellesley's president.

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- Postmaster General Farley declared in a statement issued here today that Governor Landon, Republican Presidential nominee, was a "synthetic candidate" running on a "counterfeit New Deal platform."

TONAWANDA, N.Y., June 13 (AP). -- The three Remington Rand factories hardest hit by a month-old strike, in Syracuse, N.Y., Norwood, Ohio, and Middletown, Conn., are being dismantled and will be closed permanently, the company announced here today.
THE number of women police attached to the metropolitan force is to be increased from the present strength of 67 to 142, in accordance with the recent statement of the Home Secretary.
MOSCOW, June 13 (AP). -- A learned front of scientists was forming in thirty-six expeditions across Soviet Russia tonight, awaiting Friday's total eclipse of the sun.

ZION NATIONAL PARK in Utah is rapidly overtaking the Grand Canyon as an attraction for tourists. Last year it drew 96,000 visitors, as compared with 108,000 for the South Rim of the Grand Canyon and 31,000 for the North Rim.

PEOPLE who travel to Europe and South America and take languorous cruises to the South Seas still think that the African big game hunter is invading the stronghold of the most savage beasts in the world, and that he must walk warily in imminent danger of destruction.

FOR the first time, really, in three-quarters of a century, the American public is to be treated this year to a Presidential campaign in which a genuine, clear-cut issue divides the electorate, in which the issue, in fact, overshadows party allegiance. It may well be a critical year in our political history, a year in which, as in 1860, the break-up of a party alignment which has lasted for generations becomes a visible fact.

VINCENNES, Ind., June 13. -- This Southwestern Indiana city completed preparations today to accommodate 125,000 persons at the dedication tomorrow of the $2,500,000 memorial to the Northwest Territory conqueror, General George Rogers Clark.

The Women's City Club, after a study of probationary schools under the Board of Education, finds no definite policy in their administration and a lack of objective consideration of the problems confronting truant children.

WELLESLEY COLLEGE this week-end has been celebrating the achievements of a woman which many a man in business or government would have been glad to emulate. Miss Ellen Fitz Pendleton is ending her quarter century as Wellesley's president.

Enos Mills, like John Muir, is associated with the western mountains of the United States and with the preservation of forests and natural life of all kinds. It was well worth while for Hildegarde Hawthorne and Mrs. Mills to put into book form the story of Enos Mill's life, beginning when, at 14, he set forth from the family home in Kansas for the Rockies, a goal he had long dreamed of reaching.

The number of deaths in New York City due to alcoholism has decreased steadily since the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, Chairman Henry E. Bruckman of the State Liquor Authority announced yesterday.

VIENNA, June 13. -- For the first time in almost a year Nazis openly became, active in Vienna tonight when the performances at the State Opera and at the Burg Theatre were disrupted by stench bombs. Many were forced to leave the theatres.

PARIS, June 13. -- With flags flying as a sign of victory and in some cases riding in flower-decked lorries, workers in automobile and metal work factories today evacuated the works where they have been installed for more than two weeks.

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- Postmaster General Farley declared in a statement issued here today that Governor Landon, Republican Presidential nominee, was a "synthetic candidate" running on a "counterfeit New Deal platform."

TONAWANDA, N.Y., June 13 (AP). -- The three Remington Rand factories hardest hit by a month-old strike, in Syracuse, N.Y., Norwood, Ohio, and Middletown, Conn., are being dismantled and will be closed permanently, the company announced here today.
THE number of women police attached to the metropolitan force is to be increased from the present strength of 67 to 142, in accordance with the recent statement of the Home Secretary.
MOSCOW, June 13 (AP). -- A learned front of scientists was forming in thirty-six expeditions across Soviet Russia tonight, awaiting Friday's total eclipse of the sun.

Two days to see the high spots of Paris is a prescription to promote pandemonium. Miss Antoin ette Davies, other-wise Tony, was out to torpedo the town before she sailed back to America to join her fiance. After seeing him off at the Gate St. Lazare, pretty Tony was promptly picked up by a playboy of Paris, Joe Harrisson.

More than 20,000 Italians and Italian-Americans filled Madison Square Garden to its capacity last night to demonstrate their satisfaction with, and enthusiasm for, the victorious campaign which annexed Ethiopia to the Italian kingdom, and to pay tribute to Benito Mussolini.

MAX ROTH, the German baritone, is now known in his native land as "the flying Siegfried." For two hours after his arrival at the Croydon Airport, whither he had flown from Stuttgart, he sang the role of the Wanderer in "Siegfried" at Covent Garden, London.

TULSA, June 13 (AP). -- The Women's Christian Temperance Union backed up its campaign against liquor with a drive for a million-dollar "war chest" tonight. The drive, which it is hoped to complete by 1939, was decided upon at the organization's national convention today, to finance a youth educational campaign.

VIENNA, June 13. -- For the first time in almost a year Nazis openly became, active in Vienna tonight when the performances at the State Opera and at the Burg Theatre were disrupted by stench bombs. Many were forced to leave the theatres.

PARIS, June 13. -- With flags flying as a sign of victory and in some cases riding in flower-decked lorries, workers in automobile and metal work factories today evacuated the works where they have been installed for more than two weeks.

Under the watchful eye of fifty patrolmen and eight mounted men, 100 persons staged an anti-Olympic demonstration for one hour last night in front of the Yorkville Casino, 210 East Eighty-sixth Street, where inside were gathered 1,000 persons at an Olympic fund-raising rally conducted by the German American Bund.
BOSTON, June 12. -- The Democratic convention just held at Springfield for the endorsement of candidates for State-wide offices produced one big surprise and an aftermath of intense bitterness.

MOUNT HERNION, Mass., June 13. -- Dr. Robert E. Speer of New York, who was present at the second memorable meeting in 1887 of the Northfield Student Conference, called tonight for volunteers to the cause of Christ as he spoke to the students here at the service commemorative of the founding fifty years ago of the Northfield Conference.

ELMTRA, N.Y., June 13. -- Soaring will be possible practically every day of the Seventh Annual National Soaring Contest, opening here next Saturday, according to Dr. Karl O. Lange, contest committee chairman, who said that new arrangements have been made to offset weather handicaps.

WELLESLEY, Mass., June 13. -- A steady downpour spoiled the new ensembles of Wellesley alumnae and the elaborate plans made to honor President Pendleton today, but it failed to curb the enthusiasm of over 1,200 graduates who returned to the campus today for reunions and the jubilee celebration of Miss Pendleton's fifty years as Wellesley graduate and twenty-five as president.

BRUSSELS, June 13. -- An outstanding fact in the recent national elections, again confirmed in the provincial balloting, is the unexpectedly strong vote for the new Rexist party, which is ready to furnish a dictator in its leader, Leon Degrelle.

An old hand at stirring up plotty tales of romance and intrigue, the Baroness yon Hutten has contrived a novel situation for her new book. Two men from different stations in life meet at the Jerningham Arms in an obscure English seaside resort and are immediately drawn together by a common bond.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 13. -- Brazil will carry out the four-year plan for payment of her foreign debt, which plan was arranged in 1934 by Dr. Oswaldo Aranha, Ambassador to the United States, and which will mature in March, 1938, it was stated today by Arthur de Souza Costa, Minister of Finance.

BOSTON, June 13 (AP). -- The 1936 award of $1,000 literary fellowships to Clelie Huggins, 20 years old, of Brooklyn, N.Y., and Robert Penn Warren, a Baton Rouge editor, was announced tonight by Robert N. Linscott, an official of the Houghton-Mifflin Publishing Company.
PHILADELPHIA, June 13. -- Pennsylvania delegates to the Cleveland convention returned home today with praise for the ticket and predictions of victory in November.

NOTHING is much pleasanter now that Summer heat approaches than to find yourself in a gallery furnished for coolness, surrounded by paintings, prints and drawings that are neither puzzling nor commonplace, but gently stimulating. The only thing against your satisfaction is your own sense of futility in finding anything to say that will convey the special quality of this selection of work from the permanent collection of the Whitney Museum.

The French franc rallied strongly above the gold-import point yesterday as bears purchased to cover future contracts falling due next week. After having sold as low as 6.58 3/8 cents, the effective gold point, the franc advanced to 6.58 3/4 cents and finally, in late trading, was lifted to 6.59 5/8 cents by a fairly substantial order which came into the market.

MADRID, June 13. -- Admitting no charges had been brought against him but without offering any apology, the Spanish authorities tonight unconditionally released Benjamin Fulgenzi, American assistant manager of the International Banking Corporation, the Madrid branch of the National City Bank of New York.
WASHINGTON, June 13. -- Governor Landon's campaign managers are planning to shift their headquarters from Washington to Chicago, with Eastern headquarters, as already announced, in New York.

A "million-dollar" rain was what produce farmers of Long Island and Southern New Jersey termed yesterday's penetrating downpour, ending a six to eight weeks' drought that had threatened with destruction potato, berry and fruit crops, as well as lawns, shrubbery and golf courses.

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- Monday the bonus bonds start moving out, more than 30,000,000 of them going to more than 3,000,000 veterans. To the veterans the bonds and the accompanying checks are a $1,600,000,000 gift from the government at whose behest they went to war twenty years ago.

In THE TIMES of May 31 there appeared a letter by P.W. Hayward in which he criticizes the equipment, appurtenances and meals on the Cunard special boat train that runs from Waterloo to Southampton, or vice versa.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 13. -- More than 3,500 relatives and friends of members of Rutgers University's class of '36 and 1,000 alumni thronged the college campuses today to witness the 170th anniversary commencement in the gymnasium this morning.

FOR sheer penetrating power there is nothing on earth like the neutron. It pierces ordinary matter far more easily than do the X-rays. In fact, so readily does it slip through matter that it has to be slowed down by layers of paraffin wax or water if it is to be effectively captured and held by an atom.

CHICAGO, June 13. -- Colonel Frank Knox, Republican nominee for Vice President, was described as smiling with anticipatory pleasure today when the employes of his Chicago newspaper called his attention to a dispatch in which the head of the ticket, Governor Landon, told of the fighting campaign to be waged against the Democrats.

In an interesting letter from Iceland, printed in THE TIMES, the claim is made that Leif Ericsson, the early discoverer of Vinland, was not a Norwegian but an Icelander. This is much the same as saying that Calvin Coolidge was not an American but a Vermonter.

Retail trade in the metropolitan area maintained an active pace last week, but some seasonal slowing down was noted in major manufacturing lines here. Department store trade was estimated as showing about a 10 per cent increase against the comparative period of 1935.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 13. -- The Century Country Club here will be the scene on Tuesday of an all-day fete sponsored by the Westchester Chapter of the Women's Division of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies of New York.
OMAHA, Neb., June 12. -- The "Draft Norris Movement," a potentiality ever since it became obvious that the Senator would not voluntarily seek re-election, has now become kinetic.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June l3. -- Two goals in the last quarter the All-America lacrosse team a 7-to-7 tie with Rutgers today in the all-stars' first game preliminary to the international Lally Cup series with Canada later in the month.

The Central States Electric Corporation and the Utilities Shares Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary, reported holdings of 580,489 shares of North American Company common stock on May 15 to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 13. -- Two world records were equaled as Ohio State and Southern California battled through a track meet today, finishing in a deadlock at 7 1/2 to 7 1/2. The events were run off on a "winner-take-all" basis, with credit for first places only. A crowd of 5,600 attended.
Gifts and bequests totaling $86,587.60 have been received by New York University in the last two months, it was announced yesterday by Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase.

MEXICO, D.F., June 13. -- The Nacional, organ of the National Revolutionary party, in an editorial this morning suggested that foreign correspondents accept it as the source of news from Mexico. This editorial is accepted as indicating the views of the Cardenas government.

IT was Magellan who called the southernmest tip of South America Patagonia ("big shoe"), for to the Portuguese navigator that land seemed to resemble nothing so much as a huge boot. Why he should have called the islands which hove up to larboard as he beat his way through the strait that bears his name Tierra del Fuego ("Land of Fire"), is made clear in this book, the saga of a last frontier.

A VAST migration of joyous boys and girls from a thousand cities and larger towns of the United States is under way. This mighty host of young folks, expected to reach a total of between two and three millions before the Summer has ended, is on the march for forest and mountain and lake and seashore.

By the margin of one-half point Kearny High School captured the Hudson County Class A track and field championship for the second consecutive year at Pershing Field, Jersey City, yesterday with a total of 47 points. Dickinson was second with 46 1/2 points and Lincoln finished third with 40 1/2.

With 500 librarians from all parts of the country enrolled, Columbia University will establish this Summer a new type of professional school which "aims to develop the public library as the cultural and intellectual center of American community life," according to an announcement yesterday.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 13. -- A score of unique Arabic manuscripts which have been discovered during the last year are on display in the treasure room of the Princeton library as one of the feature exhibits arranged for alumni and commencement visitors this week-end.

FACSIMILE radio, called the gateway to television, swung open on its scientific hinges during the past week when a three-meter circuit was demonstrated between New York and Philadelphia by the Radio Corporation of America.
LISBON. -- Portugal is indignant over suggestions made in other European capitals that the new Germany's hunger for colonies might be appeased by carving up the Portuguese empire.

LONDON, June 13. -- The great Socialist experiment in France and the conditions which have hastened its headlong inauguration are being watched here with anxious eyes, for what Premier Leon Blum is doing there is fast becoming vital to a larger area than is comprised in the French Republic.

AGAIN we have reached that optimistic time of year when the film-makers of Hollywood and Denham, tossing modesty to the lions, announce their product for the new season. Their dossiers are gift-edged and multi-colored, with display references to super-specials, box-office winners, blue ribbon extras, epics and smashes.

IN his usual whimsical vein, Johannes V. Jensen once again roams favorite emigrant trails, which in the past have carried him alike into dewy tropical jungles or over prehistoric Arctic glaciers, and in "Dr. Renault's Temptations" he now reverts to fiction technique for the first time in thirty industrious literary years.

TORONTO, June 12. -- An examination of the annual reports of 153 companies, covering the last fiscal year, discloses that the returns from mines represented 42.17 per cent of the total net earnings of companies in Canada. Higher profits of several of the larger base-metal mines, new gold mines coming into production and a marked upward trend in earnings of established companies were responsible for the leading position attained by mines.

The Consolidated Mining and Smelting Company of Canada declared yesterday a dividend of 50 cents on the new capital stock for the half year ended on June 30. This was double the regular rate on a proportionate basis paid on the old stock, which was split five-for-one recently.

MOSCOW, June 13. -- The Soviet public was informed of Alf M. Landon's nomination today by the Pravda, which gave its readers a brief description of the Kansas Governor that may sound surprising to American ears. The news arrived too late for publication yesterday, which was the weekly holiday, and Pravda is the only newspaper published in Moscow the day after a holiday.

Ten scholarships for a year's study at the Art Students' League of New York will be awarded Tuesday to ten high school graduates on this year's high school competition. Forest Grant, director of art in the public schools, will make the awards after the judges have selected the winners.
BELGRADE, June 13. -- The efforts of Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, German Minister of Economics and President of the Reichsbank, to increase German trade with Yugoslavia seems to be making good progress.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., June 13. -- Undaunted by a driving rain that swept over the picturesque links of the Piping Rock Club, favorites advanced to the semi-final round of the annual invitation best-ball golf tournament today. In addition to the rain, a strong wind made conditions almost impossible for play.

PARIS. IF one wishes to forecast fashions for the remote future it is generally safe to choose the silhouette that is the exact opposite of the one outstanding at the moment, for the style pendulum swings pretty regularly from one extreme to the other, and the perpetual miracle of Paris couture is that creators are always able to do the familiar things in a different way.

BERLIN, June 12. -- A characteristic feature of all strong dictatorships is that they are ambitious. Their ambition is part of their strength because good ambition, properly presented, is apt to rally people behind them much more effectively than could bayonets.

John A. McKillop, 33 years old, of 781 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn, a patrolman attached to the Telegraph Bureau at the Brooklyn police headquarters, was suspended by Inspector Edward M. Butler, head of the North Queens uniformed division, early yesterday morning after he had been examined by a police surgeon.

THE "five foreigners" of whom Dr. Gowen writes are one Portuguese, one Spaniard. one Englishman and two Americans who, from the middle of the sixteenth century to the middle of the nineteenth, made as many links in a chain connecting Japan with the Occident and exercising upon the destiny of that country a notable influence.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., June 13.-- Champion Nunsoe Duc le la Terrace of Blakeen, the superior white poodle owned by the Blakeen Kennels of Mrs. Sherman R. Hoyt of Katonah. N.Y., tonight gained his eighth best-in-show victory. He topped 770 other thoroughbreds at the annual exhibition of the North Westchester Kennel Club held on the Lawrence Farms.
DALLAS, June 13 (AP). -- Eugene Schacher of Houston, co-pilot of the plane which crashed with Jesse Jones, RFC chairman, and four others yesterday, died of his injuries today.

CHICAGO, June 12. -- A Democratic State Senator from Cook County in a speech on the Senate floor asserted that the passage of the permanent registration and honest elections bill would deprive the Democratic organization of 250,000 votes in the Chicago metropolitan district.

OUR oldest university, seated in the vicinity of Boston, is celebrating next Thursday the commencement which marks her 300th anniversary and which perpetuates a ceremony more than twice as old -- the Inceptio, or initiation of neophyte scholars into the Guild of Masters of Arts.

NEW exhibitions in the galleries, if few in number, were varied and rewarding in the week just ended, and most of them will continue long enough to afford plenty of time for even the most indolent of Summer visitors to get around to some of them before they close.
NORTHAMPTON, Mass., June 13. -- Ivy Day was observed at Smith College today, beginning with the alumnae parade of 1,800 persons from Chapin House.

The bond market did little more than mark time during the two-hour trading session yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Speculative interest was at a minimum, while trading in the higher grade investments was almost in negligible measure.

ST. JOHN'S, Nfld. NEWFOUNDLAND'S government has completed a bridge across Robinson's River as a link in a system of automobile roads that will unite the west of the island with the east. Much of the route will be through agricultural lands and will penetrate little-known territory that is majestic in scenery and abounds with opportunities for fishing and shooting.

Members of the House and Senate conference groups on the Revenue Bill are asked to "give business a fair chance" in a letter by Louis K. Comstock, president of the Merchants Association of New York, the association announced yesterday.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 14. -- One hundred and forty-five girls are scheduled to attend the annual Princeton senior promenade, the final social event for the class of 1936, which will be held in the university gymnasium tomorrow evening, concluding a day of class activities.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., June 14. -- The need for the "critical process" as a weapon against dogmatism and the propaganda of demagogues was emphasized by President Tyler Dennett in his baccalaureate address at Williams College today.

PARIS, June 13. -- Exports of capital continued this week, but on a smaller scale than they have been recently. The next statement of the Bank of France probably will show a smaller loss of gold because of the increasing difficulties for speculators in forward purchases of foreign exchange, and probably also because Premier Leon Blum again declared himself as opposed to devaluation in his address yesterday in the Chamber of Deputies.

NAPANOCH, N.Y., June 14. -- Max Schmeling passed his preliminary physical examination today with flying colors. He submitted to a thorough going-over by Dr. William Walker of the State Athletic Commission before engaging in his regular ring workout, and the report was excellent.

The executive committee of the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America approved yesterday progress made by Joseph I. Breen in connection with the Motion Picture Production Code administration, but declared "much of the output of the studios" was "still distinctly low grade."

WASHINGTON, June 14. -- Vigorous condemnation of the Clark amendment and the proposed substitute for the amendment permitting private industrial pension plans to be excluded from the Federal Social Security Act is contained in a report made to the Social Science Research Council by Rainard B. Robbins, secretary and actuary for annuities of the Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association, founded by the Carnegie Foundation.
TIENTSIN, China, June 14. -- Japanese dealers here handling smuggled goods formed an organization today to combat anti-smuggling measures taken by the Nanking Government.

WASHINGTON, June 14. -- President Roosevelt's candidacy for reelection has been endorsed, unofficially, by the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, whose membership of 200,000 makes it the third largest union in the American Federation of Labor.

WASHINGTON, June 14. -- The biggest pay day in the government's history will take place tomorrow when postal carriers throughout the land will deliver to World War veterans 28,094,875 baby bonds in denominations of $50, together with checks ranging from one cent to $49.99 in full payment of the soldier bonus.

It is pleasant to see a candidate for a nomination for Vice President take not reluctantly but joyously the consolation prize. In his cordial telegram to Governor LANDON accepting an invitation to be in Topeka today, in justice to himself Mr. KNOX did not forget the heroic services of both budding statesmen in 1912.

SHANGHAI, China, June 14. -- The Canton Government appealed to the national government at Nanking today to take a stronger attitude toward Japanese activities in China. This message, telegraphed by Chen Chia-tang, said Cantonese forces were withdrawing from Hunan Province "for the present."
VATICAN CITY, June 14 (AP). -- Pope Pius, despite his seventy-nine years, worked today on the allocution he will deliver at a consistory tomorrow, in which he may refer to the Italo-Ethiopian war.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., June 14. -- In the best condition she has attained through a long and highly successful career, Southball Moonstone of Halcyon was named best in the Orange Kennel Club's third annual exhibition at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club today.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 14. -- The Summer training of more than 21,000 State guard members under the direction of Major Gen. William N. Haskell, commander of the New York State National Guard, began today with the arrival here at Camp Smith and at Pine Camp of 2,500 men, who will receive two weeks instruction.

ABOARD PRESIDENT'S SPECIAL TRAIN, en route to Washington, June 14. -- As the last act of a notable tour covering almost 4,000 miles, President Roosevelt today went into Kentucky to pay a reverent visit to the Memorial Building at Hodgenville which houses the small log cabin in which Abraham Lincoln was born.
Dartmouth retained its chance of tying Harvard for the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League lead with three victories on successive days last week.

A GENERAL custom when writing about slums is to attack the surface fiercely. It is usual to point out that slums cost a community a great deal of money and do no one any good. Over and over again it has been discovered that slum dwellers take up more than their share of the Police Department's time and energy, lift Health Department costs, fill free clinics and hospital beds and hog relief funds.

James J. Halleran, Public Works Commissioner of Queens, has sent a letter to the Appellate Division in Brooklyn, complaining that he and other property owners are unable to obtain lair awards in condemnation proceedings before Justice Charles C. Lockwood.

The custom of calling many biblical happenings miracles was declared to be false by the Rev. Dr. J. Stanley Durkee of the Plymouth Congregational Church of the Pilgrims, Orange and Hicks Streets, Brooklyn, in the baccalaureate sermon to the 1936 graduating class of the Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 14. -- Declaring that the last few years in this country had seen a trend toward the rise of a totalitarian state, President James Rowland Angell warned the Yale graduating class in his baccalaureate address today that the nation in the period between now and the November election would "be measurably deciding what in the immediate future Americanism is to be and to mean."

Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins has accepted the chairmanship of a chain letter-chain dinner campaign for the re-election of President Roosevelt, according to an announcement made yesterday from the headquarters of the National Women's Pro-Roosevelt League at 789 Park Avenue.

This is the day set for distribution of the soldiers' "bonus bonds," authorized by Congress over a Presidential veto. There can be no satisfaction in the event for thoughtful people who are now about to witness the final phase of a demonstration of the power of a well-organized minority to have its way in Washington.
LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., June 14. -- Gregory S. Mangin of Newark and James H. Van Alen of Newport won the invitation doubles tennis tournament at the Piping Rock Club today.

Foreign exchanges milled about last week very much in the fashion which marked other periods. Business was never unusually active, but it was evident that a nervous undertone persisted with respect to the future of the French franc which brought in its wake fresh engagements of gold in Paris for this country.

NEW ORLEANS, June 14. -- Trading in the cotton market here last week was rather good, although there were periods of comparative quiet. In the second half of the week business was fairly active, with buying of contracts by mills, trade purchasing and some revival of speculation.

Recalling its recent successful fight to prevent the introduction of motion-picture theatres on Madison Avenue, the Fifth Avenue Association yesterday issued a statement in which it urged the rezoning of the upper part of Madison Avenue to stave off the invasion of manufacturing interests.

LAKE SEBAGO, N.Y., June 14. -- Two solo triumphs and one tandem victory enabled Ernie Riedel of the Pendleton Canoe Club of New York to take premier double-blade honors in the final divisional Olympic canoeing tryouts today. Riedel led off with a victory at 10,000 meters in the morning, duplicated it at 1,000 meters in the afternoon, and took the tandem double-blade 1,000-meter test with Burr Folks.

A 21-year-old South African Negro has won the fifth essay contest to be sponsored by the New History Society, it was announced last night at the home of the society's founders, Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Stuyvesant Chanler, 132 East Sixty-fifth Street.

An appeal to the citizens of this city to supplement government relief activities by extending, through private welfare agencies, "the helping hand that will serve to maintain morale" was issued yesterday by Governor Lehman in behalf of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee.

WELLESLEY, Mass., June 14. -- "We must honor the individual, whether man or group or nation, and yet live together in the bond of unity," the Rev. Dr. George A. Buttrick, minister of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York City, told the 308 members of the Wellesley graduating class today in the baccalaureate service.
BERLIN, June 14. -- Official Germany continues to view with a show of disinterestedness the convulsions outside her frontier.
INDIANAPOLIS, June 14 (AP). -- Ray Murphy, American Legion National Commander, said today on the eve of distribution of the bonus bonds:

SAN FRANCISCO, June 14. -- A total of 28,994 San Francisco World War veterans will be richer by $19,000,000 tomorrow when they receive their share of the cargo of bonus "baby" bonds from the Federal Reserve Bank here.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., June 14 (AP). -- Many beach residents at resorts on the Florida central and lower west coast left their homes tonight and moved into cities as a moderate tropical disturbance approached.
VINCENNES, Ind., June 14. -- Following is the text of President Roosevelt's speech here today dedicating the George Rogers Clark Memorial:

SHANGHAI, China, June 14. -- Nanking is puzzled by South China's tactics. It believes the halt of the northward march of Southern troops probably was due to the fact that the rest of the country condemns moves that threaten civil war.
VIENNA, June 14. -- Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, whose public utterances are rare, has revealed some part of his economic schemes in Greek newspapers and has caused some astonishment thereby.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 14. -- Fifteen years after the baccalaureate message to his class, President Alan Valentine of the University of Rochester, in the baccalaureate here today, told the Rochester graduates of this year that their college studies had been more "realistic" than his and better designed to give them "sales resistance" to propaganda they would meet in the outside world.

NEW HAVEN, June 13. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 82.3, which compares with 81.2 the week before, 81.2 two weeks before, 80.5 three weeks before and 81.0 four weeks before.

Is there no way -- has the Democratic Administration no way -- of making Chairman FARLEY attend strictly to his own knitting? He is always talking. He rushes in unbidden to speak for his party on all occasions. Scarcely had the Republican convention finished its work at Cleveland, when he issued a long statement attacking and ridiculing every detail of its work, including its choice of a Presidential candidate.

JERUSALEM, June 14. -- In attacks near Jerusalem today Arabs wounded five Jewish chauffeurs and laborers, two of whom are in a serious condition. Only recently, in the same vicinities, Jewish travelers were killed in similar attacks.

Prices of commodities for future delivery were mixed last week in quiet trading here. Changes either way mostly were small. In the cash market, wheat, corn, rye, oats, flour, cocoa, cotton, printcloths, silk, wool tops and hides were higher, while rubber and tin were lower.

DETROIT, June 14 (AP). -- William J. Cameron, speaking for the Ford Motor Company, said tonight that "in thirty-three years this company has exchanged 24,500,000 cars and other products for $12,951,338,028 and paid out $12,109,321,884 for materials, labor and wages."
CANTON, China, June 14 (AP). -- Prospects of immediate hostilities between Canton troops and forces of the Nanking government in Hunan Province appeared lessened today.

A new record for newspaper advertising of radio receiving sets will be established by the new Philco campaign, plans for which were announced yesterday by E.B. Loveman, advertising manager of Philco Radio and Television Corporation.

WASHINGTON, June 14. -- As the cargo of bonus bonds worth nearly $1,650,000,000 was trundled from reserve bank centers at midnight, tagged for delivery to veterans, the government threw around the system of distribution all possible checks against fraud.

The population of New York City is estimated at 7,363,624 by the Health Department's Bureau of Records, it is disclosed in the department's quarterly bulletin, made public yesterday by Dr. John L. Rice, Commissioner of Health.

PITTSBURGH, June 14. -- Like the fabled old horse that always came thundering down those last hundred yards to the home stall and oat bag at breakneck speed, the Giants concluded another ill-starred tour of the West today with an eye-dazzling performance.

TOKYO, June 14. -- The creation of a demilitarized zone of fifty kilometers [about thirty-one miles] on each side of the Soviet-Manchukuoan frontier is about to be proposed by Japan, according to articles, evidently enjoying a common source of inspiration, that appear in all the morning newspapers.

LONDON, June 14. -- The conversations with Oswald Pirow, Defense Minister of South Africa, now in progress at the Dominions Office regarding the future lines of the imperial defense policy, are taking a turn that is certain to produce important developments.

Val Jean Monk, writing from St. Petersburg, forwards a reminder that the tarpon are heading for trouble in Southern waters. Hundreds of anglers from all parts of the country are converging on the west and east coasts of Florida to do battle with the acrobatic silver kings.

Revision of the international yacht-racing right-of-way rules has been suggested by Harold S. Vanderbilt in collaboration with Henry H. Anderson, Philip J. Roosevelt and Van S. Merle-Smith. Their ideas were placed yesterday before yachting organizations in this country and abroad, and standing out with their recommendations was their representation in yachting.

Now that the business men on its board of trustees, in the name of the humanities, have so nobly saved Mount Holyoke College from itself -- that is to say, from the vice of over-feminization -- the time would appear ripe to save another venerable Massachusetts institution -- namely, Harvard College -- from a similar vice -- namely, that of over-masculinization.
BAY SHORE, L.I., June 14. -- Four men and a woman, clinging to an overturned boat in Great South Bay, were rescued by a fishing boat today after they had been in the water for more than a half hour.

BERLIN, June 13. -- The problem of clearing international exchanges has been brought to a head here by Germany's denunciation of her agreement with Switzerland, the ostensible cause of which is that the former heavy surplus of German exports has disappeared.

Colonel Sir Charles William Wright, chairman of Baldwin's, Ltd., of London, former British Minister of Munitions of War, and Lieut. Col. J.B. Nelison, deputy chairman of Vickers Armstrong, Ltd., of London, are among the passengers arriving today from Europe on the Normandie of the French Line.

The Fire Department is ready for the biggest display of apparatus in its history, Commissioner John J. McElligott announced yesterday. The demonstration will begin at noon tomorrow in City Hall Plaza.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 14. -- The colleges and their graduates are the country's real and only defense against the "pernicious propaganda" with which national learning is being saturated, the Rev. Norman E. Richardson of the Presbyterian Theological Seminary of Chicago told the graduating class of Connecticut College in his baccalaureate sermon at St. James's Church tonight.

In spite of more favorable reports of the condition of the cotton crop, the new crop deliveries on the New York Cotton Exchange last week registered gains of 29 to 34 points following advances of 25 to 35 points in the previous week. The old crop July delivery advanced 7 points following a gain of 6 points the week before.

Flag Day celebrations throughout the city yesterday, scheduled to be the most colorful since the day was set aside twenty years ago by President Wilson, were either curtailed or postponed because of the weather. A few braved the rain for the annual pilgrimage to Bedloe's Island for the joint celebration of Flag Day and a brief ceremony to mark the fiftieth anniversary of the Statue of Liberty.
CHICAGO, June 14 (AP). -- Five seeded stars scored straight-set victories today as the national clay courts tennis championships continued at the River Forest Club.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 14. -- Debate on social and political problems must be unlimited in a healthy national scheme, Dr. James B. Conant told Harvard seniors in his baccalaureate address here today.

HANOVER, N.H., June 14. -- Dr. Ernest Martin Hopkins, president of Dartmouth College, in the annual baccalaureate sermon this morning challenged the graduating class to "endure hardness" and to strive to overcome the economic obstacles of the times.
Non-sectarian Summer camps for children were denounced as irreligious and hostile to Catholics by the Rev. Thomas L. Graham, preaching yesterday at high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.
CHICAGO, June 14. -- Delivery of bonus bonds and checks to World War veterans in the Chicago area will begin tomorrow morning.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., June 14. -- Mrs. E. Parmalee Prentice gave the first of a series of weekly musicales yesterday afternoon at Mount Hope Farm, Williamstown. Lucius Metz, tenor, sang three groups of songs and Archer Gibson was organist. A company of 100 heard the program, which was followed by tea served on the lawn.

NEWARK, N.J., June 14. -- A State appropriation of $5,000,000 from the recently acquired Dorrance tax fund to aid municipalities administer emergency relief will be urged by State Senator Lester H. Clee, it was learned here today.

SEA GIRT, N.J., June 14. -- Major Melvin L. Krulewitch of New York, in command of a provisional regiment of Marine Corps Reserve troops, opened a fortnight of field training here at Camp Hoffman today. He announced tonight that two regimental reviews would feature the encampment period.

WASHINGTON, June 14. -- Endorsement of the movement to create a permanent central and democratic representation for the Jewish people for the defense of their rights and the improvement of their status through a world Jewish congress was voted here tonight at the conclusion of a two-day conference by more than 1,000 delegates representing the majority of American Jewry.

Now that the West has taken charge of the Republican party it would be extremely interesting to take a peek over the shoulders of the young Western Republicans as they sit down to make their first tentative draft of the electoral vote in November.

CLEVELAND, June 14 (AP). -- The magazine Steel said today that strong demand for immediate con sumption, combined with an increasing amount of speculative buying against the higher prices announced for orders deliverable in the third quarter of this year, raised operations of steel mills last week 1 point to 68 per cent of capacity.

After an ownership of two months, the five-story building containing thirty apartments at 1,525 Nelson Avenue, between 172d Street and Featherbed Lane, the Bronx, was resold by Joseph L. Ennis Co., operators, to Isidor Lorber, operator. Samuel Rubin and Irving Mason were the brokers.

The lesser lights of the track world received a taste yesterday of the wretched weather conditions that had confronted their more illustrious mates at Princeton the day before as the Metropolitan A.A.U. junior championships were conducted at the Castle Hill Athletic Field in a driving downpour that washed out the field events completely but could not halt the foot races.

PARIS, June 14. -- In nearly every town and village in France today political organizations of the Leftist Popular Front celebrated with processions and meetings, and in some cases picnics, their victory at the recent elections and the advent of Leon Blum's Popular Front government.

LONDON, June 14. -- Gilbert K. Chesterton, for more than a generation the most exuberant personality in English literature, died today at his home in Beaconsfield after a brief illness. He was 62 years old.
If this morning's principal bulletin concerns Broadway only indirectly, it is nevertheless quite a bulletin. In substance it follows:

WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP). -- Success during the past year in the use of a new drug for the treatment of burns, chronic ulcers and other non-healing wounds was announced today from the Department of Agriculture.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 14. -- Rainbow's End, owned by Miss Jeanne Nehrbas of Huntington, captured the saddle horse championship of the annual Sands Point show on the Luckenbach estate today. While Miss Nehrbas was unable to ride because of an injured knee, her handsome chestnut mare was shown adequately by James Thompson.

PARIS, June 13. -- The statement of condition of the Bank of France for June 5 shows a further decline of 1,500,000,000 francs in its holdings of gold, although the end-of-the-month (May) requirements over bills discounted increased 52,000,000 francs and advances on securities and bonds rose 250,000,000 francs.

NEWARK, N.J., June 14. -- A plain Newark alley cat made a stand yesterday for the things her instincts told her were right. She held an automobile against all comers, snarled and scratched at all opposition, including the police, and only human trickery defeated her.
