Rupert S. and Viola Austin purchased the dwelling at 463 Upper Boulevard, Ridgewood, N.J., through the Realty Exchange of Ridgewood. The house was built under contract for the purchasers by Model Home Builders, Inc., owners and developers of Colonial Gardens, Ridgewood.

Assemblyman Saul S. Streit, chairman of the joint legislative committee to investigate the actions of bondholders' committees, trustees and others in the mortgage-bond field, said yesterday that it was advisable for bondholders, bondholders' committees, trustees, trust companies, fiduciaries, executors, administrators, lawyers, management companies and the public generally to become familiar with the laws recently enacted by the State Legislature for the protection of bond and mortgage investors.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 14. -- The rumor around this town is that Ky Ebright is here to tie the old Cornell record of four straight in the Poughkeepsie Regatta with his sea-going Golden Bears from California. The sweepswingers from the Oakland Estuary have three straight victories behind them -- and one just ahead if the current rumor in this river town is well founded.

James T. Berney, 49 years old, a salesman, fired a bullet into his right temple and fatally wounded himself yesterday noon after he shot his 42-year-old wife, Dorothy, in the right thigh at their home at 91-56 ll2th Street, Richmond Hill, Queens. He died at 10:45 last night in Jamaica Hospital, where Mrs. Berney was also taken.
The importance of the minimum wage decision and its consequences justify a statement of certain legal considerations which have not thus far been brought to public attention.
The 9,769 veterans on the city home relief rolls who will receive bonuses today will continue to receive relief payments in full until July 1, it was indicated last night.
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., June 14. -- The 104th commencement exercises of Wesleyan University were held outdoors this afternoon on the Denison Terrace with about 1,000 guests present.
WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP). -- Vernon Kennedy, pitching steadily in the pinches, enabled the White Sox to defeat the Senators, 6 to 4, today and even a four-game series.
PARIS, June 13. -- The general wholesale price index at the end of May was 377, compared with 374 at the end of April and 353 at the end of May, 1935.

ST. LOUIS, June 14 (AP). -- The Cardinals and Phillies stood toe to toe in a free-hitting demonstration today, with the Red Birds finally coming out on the long end of a 12-10 count after the score had been tied at 9-all in the eighth.

Experienced steamship agents in the North Atlantic trade believe the number of passengers leaving the Port of New York this year will total above 100,000, a figure near that of 1929. Previously 1913 was a big year, due to heavy third-class bookings.

LONDON, June 12. -- The securities markets here in the last few days have exhibited greater confidence than they have for some time. Whatever may happen to the French franc, official devaluation as an act in a deliberate policy now is apparently definitely ruled out and the foreign-exchange situation is exerting considerably less influence on the British securities markets.

SOMERS, N.Y., June 14. -- Before the largest congregation ever gathered in the edifice, Bishop William T. Manning preached a special sermon this morning during the 100th anniversary celebration of the founding of St. Luke's Episcopal Church at Somers, in the northern section of Westchester County.

ST. LOUIS, June 14. -- About 135,000 war veterans in the Eighth Federal Reserve District, of which this city is headquarters, will receive a total of $67,572,500 in bonds and checks after the distribution of the bonus is completed.

VINCENNES, Ind., June 14. -- A plea for public support for the economic and social program of the administration was made by President Roosevelt here today as he extolled the work of George Rogers Clark, whose victory at Vincennes in 1779 made secure for settlers the territory west of the Alleghanies and north of the Ohio River.

SINGAPORE. Straits Settlements, June 14 (AP). -- Special "anti-spy" police squads patrol approaches to the world's mightiest naval base here, Great Britain's chief citadel in the East. British naval engineers and Admiralty experts are now putting the final touches on the base.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., June 14. -- Disregarding a driving rain during a dank afternoon, Jess W. Sweetser of Siwanoy and Juan T. Trippe of the home club today vanquished T. Suffern Tailer Jr. and Joseph S. Frelinghuysen, 3 and 1, in the final round of eighteen holes in the annual invitation best-ball golf tournament at the Piping Rock Club.

BERLIN, June 13. -- The Boerse, after initial advances this week, reacted sharply later. In the opinion of the financial community the principal influences were the Supreme Court's decision on dollar bonds and the drive of the Ministry of Economics against agreements for clearing international exchanges.

PHILADELPHIA, June 14. -- After displaying brilliant form for four days, Bond Street, from the Sunwood Farm of F. Woodson Hancock, Valley Forge, Pa., was adjudged champion hunter as the Philadelphia Horse Show ended at the Country Club, Bala, tonight. The reserve ribbon went to Sanamor, owned by Miss Nancy Marie Shaw of Chester Springs, Pa.

HEWLETT, L.I., June 14. -- Charley Mayo, featherweight golfer, whose fragile physique makes one wonder where his power comes from, retained the Long Island amateur title today when he defeated robust Ray Torgerson, 8 and 6, in the final thirty-six-hole round of the fifteenth annual championship at the Seawane Club.

NORWALK, Conn., June 14. -- W.F. Gillespie's Fishers Island sloop, Lady Babby, from Stamford, won the annual Norwalk-Duck Island auxiliary race sponsored by the Norwalk Yacht Club, crossing the finish line at 2:13.24 this afternoon.

TOPEKA, June 14. -- The first Landon campaign tour will probably be an invasion of the East, with speeches in New York, Boston Philadelphia, Chicago and other important centers. This is a purely tentative program, but one that represents the present inclination of the Republican candidate for President.

Mrs. Meta Herlich, 37 years old, a widow living at 71-68 Seventieth Street, Glendale, Queens, left the Glendale police station at 5:30 P.M. yesterday after failing to help authorities solve the death of her son, Edward Herlich Jr., 16 years old, on May 3, in Wyckoff Heights Hospital in Brooklyn.

To a tiny stage two flights up in the Princess Theatre Building a new group last night brought a generally satirical revue entitled "Pins and Needles," launching therewith a series of weekly studio performances. The Contemporary Theatre Company, the group is called, its sponsor being the recently formed Labor Stage and its goal a regular run.

Spotty activity featured the wholesale markets here last week. Reorders on women's Summer apparel fell off as retailers sought turnover of their present stocks. Unfavorable weather conditions continued to retard sales of Summer dresses generally, although new dark "silk-linen" types were in active demand during the week.

PHILADELPHIA, June 14. -- Militant Presbyterian Fundamentalist ministers were prevented from conducting services today in three churches here under the jurisdiction of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America, and members of the three congregations joined them in a walkout.
Housing properties in Manhattan and the Bronx that were foreclosed recently by lending institutions were resold in deals announced over the week-end.

FAIRFIELD, N.J., June 14. -- John Rowland of the Court Club of New Brunswick won the New Jersey trapshooting championship with a score of 198 out of 209 targets in the final event of the tournament at the North Jersey Gun Club today.

Final arguments against the pending bill to authorize construction of a railroad bridge across the Hudson River at Fifty-seventh Street will be submitted to members of the House of Representatives today, the Port Authority announced yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, June 14. -- Nearly all of fifty-eight cities reporting collections and credit sale trends to the National Retail Credit Association here told of increases in May over the same month a year ago and gave as the reason "general improvement in business conditions," the association reported today.
ASHLAND, Ky., June 14 (AP). -- The songs that the mountain folk sing were repeated here today before an audience of several thousand.

In his first sermon since his ordination a week ago, the Rev. Luther Tucker preached at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street, said yesterday that the political campaign now beginning called for recognition of the fact that all Christians had a political responsibility.

In the fickle literary world, G.K. CHESTERTON, in the last decade, had become somewhat unfashionable, but the reason was not that his powers had declined, but that they hadn't. He continued to pour out his paradoxes so lavishly that they got in each other's way. He produced a surfeit of them.
WASHINGTON, June 14. -- What has happened in two months to change the Southwest's "dust bowl" into a mud puddle and the Southeast into a brick kiln?
RIO DE JANEIRO, June 14 (AP). -- Estimates by officials today were that Brazil may export this year 800,000 bales of cotton, compared with 610,000 bales shipped last year.

Members of the Milk Drivers Union, Local 129, and employes of the New York Eskimo Pie Corporation, 110 Bridge Street, Brooklyn, against whom the union has been conducting a strike for the last week, clashed twice yesterday in Brooklyn.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., June 14. -- Joe Louis's final hard workout in preparation for his fifteen-round battle against Max Schmeling Thursday night was curtailed two rounds today out of necessity, but carried conviction in every frame of the six he sparred.

A few of the millions who had listened in night after night at the Republican proceedings in Cleveland mechanically turned their radios on again Friday evening after the whole thing was ended. All that they heard was the weary patter of announcers and commentators snapping up a few stale and unprofitable trifles.

HONGKONG, June 14. -- Anti-Japanese sentiment is increasing in Canton but there is strong opposition to civil war between the Canton and Nanking Governments. It is now obvious that Kwangtung Province desires peace with Nanking and is making every effort to reach an understanding.

CINCINNATI, June 14. -- Holding the Dodgers to four hits, one of which was Danny Taylor's second home run of the year and two of which came in the ninth, Lee Stine pitched the Reds to a 5-1 triumph today and sent the visitors homeward with one of their worst Western trip records in several years.

WASHINGTON, June 14. -- The Democratic platform, now being drafted, will declare in favor of public works "planning" and also will contain a pledge for a long-range public housing program, according to information obtained today. Thus the Democrats will go the Republican platform, which declared simply in favor of independent public works, one better.
Were it not for the fact that the money question is so vital everywhere at this time, I would hesitate to request publication of this rejoinder to Sir Charles Morgan-Webb's letter.

MOSCOW, June 14. -- The most important thing that has happened in the Soviet Union in the past eighteen months is not the new Soviet Constitution -- although every Soviet citizen would today declare it was -- but something that few of them think of because it is put beneath their noses every morning and its action is gradual rather than sensational.

So far as maintenance of sufficient commodities for normal demands is concerned, both "the old deal" and the New Deal were at fault, the Rev. L. Bradford Young said yesterday in his morning sermon at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity, Clinton and Montague Streets, Brooklyn, of which he is associate minister.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 14. -- Brown University's graduating class was advising to apply wisdom and insight to the working knowledge obtained in college, to try to solve the problems of the world, in a baccalaureate address today by the Rev. Dr. Charles N. Arbuckle, pastor of the First Church of Newton Center, Mass.

SEATTLE, June 14. -- Adolph Spreckels, wealthy sportsman, was injured seriously today when he lost control of an outboard motorboat which raced up the beach of Green Lake, hurtled through a crowd of spectators and crashed on top of a sound truck.

HAMILTON, N.Y., June 14. -- Three American characteristics, independence, thrift and initiative, were analyzed by President George Barton Cutten of Colgate University today in his baccalaureate address to 210 seniors.

DOBBS FERRY, N.Y., June 14. -- Seeing a danger, he says, that both parties may fail to take an unequivocal stand on whether the Constitution should or should not be changed, Messmore Kendall, president general of the Sons of the American Revolution, wrote today to the platform committee of the Democratic National Convention, urging it "to perform a great service to the nation by bringing the constitutional issue completely into the open."

CLEVELAND, June 14. -- Cleveland merchants, hotel men and others who cash in on conventions looked over their records and figured today that probably a round million dollars was left in Cleveland by delegates and onlookers at the Republican National Convention.

CHICAGO, June 14. -- Weather and crop reports, combined with limited outside business, are the main features in the speculative grain trade. In the Northwest many sections of the Spring wheat country are short of moisture, and observers there say that unless this condition is remedied soon there will be a short crop on both sides of the international line.
CHICAGO, June 14. -- John D.M. Hamilton, new chairman of the Republican National Committee, fired back today at James A. Farley, Democratic national chairman.
PITTSBURGH, June 14. -- Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 71 per cent of capacity, up 1 point in a week and 2 points in a fortnight.

Ben Chapman, fleet outfielder for the Yankees for the last five seasons, was traded for Alvin Powell, centerfielder of the Senators, late yesterday afternoon, the announcement being made after the Yankees' game with the Tigers had been called off and the American League leaders were preparing for their second invasion of the West, which opens at Cleveland tomorrow.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., June 14. -- President William Allan Neilson delivered the baccalaureate address in Sage Hall to the members of the Smith College senior class this morning. Custom was followed in this, the only event in the commencement activities to which guests are not invited, and no visitors were present in the hall.

Award of six fellowships by the John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation to Latin-American scholars, who will come to this country to work on problems of paramount interest in their homelands in collaboration with scholars here, was announced yesterday. The winners are from Argentina, Chile, Cuba and Mexico.

The C.I.T. Safety Foundation, formation of which was announced recently by the C.I.T. Corporation of 1 Park Avenue, yesterday made public a plan to select the automobile driver with the best safety record in each State and the Distinct of Columbia, and bring the forty-nine winners here for a two-day safety clinic, beginning Aug. 31.

The national outdoor saber championship was moved indoors yesterday with the result that the national indoor titleholder, defender of the outdoor crown, was deprived of his laurels. Norman C. Armitage of the Fencers Club lost his title to John R. Huffman of the New York A.C., holder of that honor in 1934, on the strips of the Salle Santelli.
PHILADELPHIA, June 14 (AP). -- The Athletics closed their home stand today by taking the third game in four from the Indians, 8 to 6. Home runs played a major part in the scoring.

CHICAGO, June 14. -- The range of prices for hogs was widened sharply on Friday. Lard hogs lost the most, those weighing more than 250 pounds declining 10 to 25 cents a hundredweight. The top for hogs for the week was $10.25, the same as in the preceding week.

BOSTON, June 14. -- Delivering the baccalaureate sermon before 1,142 graduating students of Boston University today, President Daniel L. Marsh declared that the crying need in life was for more religion in its broadest meaning in the minds and hearts of the people.

LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., June 14. -- Attributing many of the ills of the depression to a lack of "moral responsibility" and "essential honesty" on the part of world leaders, Allan V. Heely, headmaster of Lawrenceville School, in his baccalaureate address today in the Edith Memorial Chapel, called upon the youth of the nation to translate "your opinions into attitudes, your beliefs into convictions, your ideals into habits."

PARIS, June 14 (AP). -- The Berlin correspondent of the newspaper Paris-Soir said in a dispatch tonight that a secret organization of the followers of Captain Ernest Roehm, brown-shirt leader slain in the Nazi "blood purge" of June, 1934, is waging a terrorist campaign of murder and threats against Nazi officials.

WASHINGTON, June 14. -- How strikingly the Republican party has departed from precedent in nominating Governor Landon is shown by a survey giving the geographical distribution of the twenty-nine candidates for the Presidency since 1860.
PARIS, June 14. -- Maurice Thorez, leader of the Communist party, told his celebrating followers today that France's factories would soon become the property of the workers.

GRAYVILLE, Ill., June 14 (AP). -- This little Wabash River town of 1,954, feeling itself one of the most important places on the map, and dressed in its Sunday best, was hostess today to the First Lady.

WASHINGTON, June 14. -- Asserting that steps taken by the administration toward "socialization" of the electric power industry "bear witness to what may be imminent in other industries if present policies are continued," the American Liberty League said in a statement today that support of the policy "came from those who would abandon our institutions in favor of some form of collectivism."

A heavy rainfall which was considered "worth a million dollars" to vegetable farmers and fruit growers of Long Island and New Jersey continued yesterday in a steady drizzle. It threatened, however, to bring too much moisture to crops that had been suffering from drought.

President ROOSEVELT in his Vincennes address has assisted history in making known to added millions the story of the expedition of GEORGE ROGERS CLARK and its incomparable consequence in giving the new nation, fighting for its independence, a valid claim to the great Northwest.

BOSTON, June 14. -- Five o'clock tomorrow night was the "zero hour" set tonight when 1,300 letter carriers will march out of ninety-one stations in the Boston Postal District to deliver bonus bonds to 87,000 Greater Boston veterans. In Massachusetts 137,113 veterans are entitled to get $83,147,977.57, but many have not yet made application.

WASHINGTON, June 14. -- Secretary Ickes, reporting progress under PWA on the eve of its third birthday, asserted today that nearly 2,000,000 jobs had been supplied each year, directly and indirectly, on "useful" and "socially desirable" public works.

NANUET, N.Y., June 14. -- More than 10,000 persons journeyed here today in spite of heavy showers to take part in the annual pilgrimage at the Shrine of St. Anthony in St. Anthony's Roman Catholic Church. Ten masses were arranged for the visitors and an all-day program lasted until late this evening.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 14. -- Old-fashioned liberalism, on trial as an "outmoded and sterile" philosophy, was defended by Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, in his baccalaureate address this morning in the university chapel before a capacity audience of 2,000 seniors, parents, alumni and faculty.

WASHINGTON, June 14. -- A charge that those who control the destinies of the Republican party will employ money received from special interests to buy the electorate in the Presidential election was made in a nationally broadcast radio speech tonight by Senator Norris, Nebraska Progressive, who forsook the Republican party to support President Roosevelt in 1932.

LONDON, June 14. -- It will not be long now before the British Cabinet finally makes up its mind to abandon sanctions and bring Italy back as one of the protectors of the status quo in Europe. The decision may be taken at the next regular meeting, Wednesday, for there is not much time left before the League Council assembles at Geneva.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 14. -- The crews of Washington and Navy today joined the others in training here for the regatta of June 22, and now only one more delegation is needed to make the field complete.

WASHINGTON, June 14. -- Formation of a nation-wide agency, or of agencies, to transport freight in portable containers with resultant savings in costs of transfer and damage is recommended in a report issued today by Joseph B. Eastman, Federal Coordinator of Transportation.
MASHPEE, Mass., June 14. -- Sixteen polite little Indians received gold pieces this morning in the old Indian Church at Mashpee on Cape Cod, in recognition of their polished manners and kind actions.

The Big Brother Movement seeks to enlist interest in its endeavor to give under-privileged boys from Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx a two-week stay in the country this Summer. Heat-ridden streets, crowded tenements and noisome alleys are no places for boys.

WASHINGTON, June 14. -- Hopeful, yet somewhat dubious that Congress can finish its tasks by next Saturday night, leaders on both sides of the Capitol planned tonight to exert every influence toward an early agreement on the two most serious obstacles to swift adjournment: taxes and relief.

In a pamphlet entitled "Sixteen Million Books," published by the New York Public Library, it is stated that Andrew Carnegie originally wrote Dr. John S. Billings on March 12, 1901, offering $5,200,000 for building the circulating branch libraries, the first one of which to be opened was the Harlem.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., June 14. -- Citing the Black Legion, the Townsend Plan and "misguided nationalism" as examples, President Paul D. Moody warned the graduating class of Middlebury College today that the "lunatic fringe" was steadily widening.

The grace of God can impart the nature of Christ to men just as the leaven in bread imparts its own nature and quality to the dough in which it is placed, the Rev. Dr. Albert J. McCartney, minister of the Covenant-First Presbyterian Church of Washington, D.C., declared in his sermon yesterday morning at the Collegiate Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue at Forty-eighth Street.

The diplomas of two participants in the student peace strike at James Monroe High School will not be signed by Dr. Henry E. Hein, principal of the Bronx school, unless they demonstrate that they have learned the "lesson of citizenship" by recognizing their obligation to observe established rules, Dr. Hein said yesterday.

More than $175,000 has been subscribed to a memorial fund in memory of Judge Otto A. Rosalsky of General Sessions, who died May 11, it was announced yesterday by the memorial committee, which has opened offices at 122 East Forty-second Street.
Extra periods were needed to decide the national soccer final between the Brooklyn German Sports Club and the Castle Shannon Soccer Club of Pittsburgh at Grand Stadium in Brooklyn yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 14 (AP). -- A pair of homers by Frank Demaree cashed in on airtight pitching by Lon Warneke today and the Cubs continued their way toward the top of National League affairs by beating Boston again, 3 -- 1, for their eleventh straight victory.

The great parade of bonus bonds into the hands of World War veterans will begin this morning throughout the United States. In New York and other large cities the major delivery of the registered mail will get under way at 5:30 P.M. and continue for hours.

PHILADELPHIA, June 14. -- World War veterans in this district, comprising the thirty-nine eastern counties of Pennsylvania, the State of Delaware and South Jersey, will begin tomorrow receiving their bonus bonds and Treasury Department checks totaling $65,592,400.

ITHACA, N.Y., June 14. -- From the words of Tagore and Paul of Tarsus, Dr. Thomas W. Graham, dean of the Graduate School of Theology at Oberlin College, drew his text for Cornell's baccalaureate sermon today.

The fleet Miss Erna Kompa smashed three American long-course records in winning the invitation 300-meter back-stroke event, one of the features of the highly interesting Metropolitan A.A.U. senior swimming meet yesterday.

The efforts of the Welfare Council to stabilize the direction of private and public welfare activities, in the face of unprecedented need and governmental confusion, are summarized by Robert P. Lane, executive director of the council, in his annual report, made public yesterday.

In some respects -- especially in regard to the candidate selected and the absence of factional dissension -- the Republican convention fulfilled financial expectation. There were, however, some surprises, and one of them certainly was the candidate's public interpretation of the Cleveland platform's money plank.

"Sin is considered too archaic to enter into any serious discussion of our social, economic, or political difficulties today," the Rev Dr. A. Edwin Keigwin, pastor of the West End Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and 105th Street, said yesterday morning in his sermon, "Whitewash as a Defense Against Hailstones."
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 14. -- The Black Legion description of the New Deal as a "Jew Deal" was assailed here today at the thirty-first annual meeting of the Independent Order of B'rith Sholom.

"The American people need to learn to think," the Rev. Dr. Samuel Trexler declared yesterday morning in a sermon at St. James Lutheran Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-third Street. He deplored the fact that most of the world lives on what he called "borrowed thought."

The City of New York applied yesterday to Supreme Court Justice Cotillo to compel Gustave Halpern of 110 Riverside Drive to return between $100,000 and $150,000 of a condemnation award on the ground that he has solved the problem of "eating his cake and still having it." The court reserved decision.

Appeals in newspaper copy by retailers, manufacturers, service companies and others to veterans yesterday were very restricted, a check-up showed. Apparently, few companies wanted to be placed in the position of urging the veterans to spend their money and this attitude was reflected in the cautious tone of the ads.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- Two $1,000 bills, a $500 bill and four $100 bills, representing "conscience money," have been mailed to Secretary Morgenthau from Mount Airy, Wilmington, Del., Treasury officials stated today.

Roses of varieties several centuries old were mingled with popular varieties of recent years at a special exhibit of roses and sweet peas grown outdoors which opened yesterday in Horticultural Hall at Rockefeller Center. Cash prizes were awarded to commercial growers, private exhibitors and garden clubs in thirteen classes.

Sitting with two other members of the Court of Special Sessions in Brooklyn, yesterday, Justice Frederick L. Hackenburg criticized the administration of justice under District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan. He demanded to know why the prosecutor failed to proceed with a case resulting from the strike last Winter in May's Department Store, instead of asking for another adjournment.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- President Roosevelt returned to Washington soon after noon today from his trip to the Southwest, where, in speeches made against historical backgrounds, he went deeply into a discussion of political doctrines.

CHICAGO, June 15. -- Hogs sold today at $10.25 a hundredweight, that price being paid for selected stock averaging from 190 to 218 pounds. The market for the most part was steady. The average price for the day was $9.80, a drop of 10 cents from last week.

Several dwellings and multi-family houses figured in real estate transactions in Manhattan and the Bronx reported yesterday. Eight Manhattan properties and two Bronx parcels were bid in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auction sales. A Sheriff's sale to settle an estate also was listed.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 15 (AP). -- Wild Bill Mehlhorn, Louisville (Ky.) pro, carded a scorching 68 over the rolling Drumlins course today to go 4 under par and take the lead in the fifty-four-hole Central New York open golf championship.

More than $2,000,000,000 will be required to pay the taxes on and to service the 300,000,000 gallons of whisky in bond in this country under existing tax regulations, representatives of the National Wholesale Liquor Dealers Association will argue in Washington tomorrow before a conference committee of the Senate and House.

The Republican national campaign in New York will be opened by John D.M. Hamilton, the new national chairman, at a dinner for him at the Hotel Astor next Monday. The dinner, which will be given by the Republican National Finance Committee, the Republican State Committee and the New York County Committee, is designed also to aid the drive for campaign funds.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- Officials of the SEC in explaining today the new procedure in security underwriting, pointed out that under conditions of rising markets such as have obtained recently, the practice of having underwriters make their commitment before they had arranged for subunderwriting had worked all right.

Wherever a gambling machine is found the Police Department will continue to arrest the owners or operators "regardless of any and all criticism," it was made known last night by Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine in a letter to Magistrate Frank Oliver.

Continuing at the high level reached last week, Bronx housing plans filed yesterday called for twelve six-story apartment structures, to cost a total of $1,970,000. Last week the Bronx projects included elevent multi-family buildings, at an estimated cost aggregate of $2,020,000.

BOSTON, June 15. -- B.N. Kane's overlooked Go Quick, a 4-year-old filly, splashed out of the mud along the rail in the home stretch and registered a two-length victory over another outsider, Mrs. A. Phillips's Jair, in the six-furlong Pilgrim Handicap, main event of the Suffolk Downs opening program today.

Members of the American Acceptance Council, at a special meeting yesterday, voted full dissolution of the organization, as of July 1 confirming the recommendation of the council's executive committee at its meeting on May 13. In a formal statement, the council states that "the statistical research activities will be taken over on July 1 by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York."

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- The Mutual Management Company, a Delaware Corporation, filed today under the Securities Act of 1933 for the registration of 250,000 trust certificates of The Mutual Investment Fund in an amount of $3,847,500. The trustee is the Commercial Trust Company of New Jersey, Jersey City.
NEW LONDON, Conn., June 15. -- Long-distance time trials for the Yale and Harvard crews ended tonight when the Eli varsity eight paddled upstream, unpaced, over the Thames River four-mile course.

ITHACA, N.Y., June 15. -- A warning that even America was not safe from attacks against the principles and rights of mankind was sounded before Cornell's graduating class today by Dr. Livingston Farrand, president of the university.
CLINTON, N.Y., June 15. -- Hamilton College conferred degrees on 104 undergraduates today and conferred five honorary degrees as follows:

RIVER VALE, N.J., June 15. -- Playing over a rain-drenched course, Willie Walker and Fred Habian of the Englewood Golf Club with a card of 68 won the pro-amateur best-ball event sponsored by the New Jersey P.G.A. at the River Vale Country Club today in a field of nineteen teams.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission expects soon to send to Congress, probably even on Wednesday, a report of its protective committee study treating with its findings as to trustees under the indentures.

An army of postmen all over the United States carried thousands of brown manila envelopes yesterday to the army of 1917-18, as the government -- in the greatest payday in its history -- distributed more than $1,500,000,000 in bonus bonds to 3,000,000 war veterans.

VIENNA, June 15. -- Rumors persist that the government is negotiating for the cooperation of the so-called emphatic nationalists. Even the arrival of the former Italian Undersecretary for Foreign Affairs, Fulvio Suvich, with his wife, for a sojourn at Semmering outside Vienna, was immediately linked with these rumors.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- The Gar Wood Industries of Michigan has filed under the Securities Act of 1933 a registration statement providing for the sale of 320,000 shares of $3 par value common stock held by its president, Garfield A. Wood, the motorboat racer.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., June 15 (AP). -- Say Do, bay gelded son of St. Brideaux and Do Say, proved best in the mud in the fifth and feature race at Agawam Park today, and won handily after taking the lead from the barrier.

Former Mayor James J. Walker and Mrs. Walker will sail on the Normandie of the French Line tomorrow evening bound for England, where Mr. Walker expects to spend several weeks on business affairs. The former Mayor said last night that his visit abroad would last about two weeks, or three at the most.

DETROIT, June 15 (AP). -- Dayton Dean testified today that N. Ray Markland, former Mayor of near-by Highland Park, complained repeatedly that he would be ruined politically unless Dean and other Black Legion gunmen succeeded in their persistent efforts to kill the fighting editor of the community newspaper.

More than 36,000,000 man hours of employment have been provided on Public Works Administration projects in this State. Arthur S. Tuttle, State PWA director, announced yesterday, on the eve of the third anniversary of the legislation which enabled President Roosevelt to plan the first emergency public works program on a national scale.

A motion picture to illustrate projects of the New York City Housing Authority and to further slum clearance was shown in the Chanin Building auditorium yesterday in the presence of Tenement House Commissioner Langdon W. Post and a number of civic workers and housing experts.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- The Democratic administration plans to pass the revised Guffey bill before the Philadelphia convention meets, and among other effects of that action, it will be the first answer to the Cleveland platform of the Republican party. That oil-and-water document, prepared on the formula of opposing only those New Deal measures which had been invalidated by the Supreme Court, and in part adopting the rest, did not endorse the Guffey act.

CLEVELAND, June 15. -- Colonel Leonard P. Ayres, economist, said today in his monthly business bulletin that "business activity and the security markets will be moving in advancing trends during the second half of this year if they follow the courses marked by their averages in the election years of the past century."

Jacob Abelson, the Jamaica textile salesman and commuter who has stanchly contended that the Long Island Railroad should abide by the 2-cents-a-mile fare rate ordered for other railroads by the Interstate Commerce Commission, went through the formality of arrest yesterday after he had been ejected twice from a train to Far Rockaway.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP). -- A session-end fight over hour and wage regulation shaped up today as the House Rules Committee considered giving right-of-way on the floor to the much amended Walsh-Healey Government Contracts Bill.

AMSTERDAM, June 12. -- Netherlands financial circles still regard the French situation as a cause for gloom. Although from the theoretical viewpoint, Premier Blum's policies may raise the purchasing power and State revenue in France there is the greatest doubt here whether the promised new deal of the Leftist Cabinet, in practice, will be a panacea for the almost hopeless financial situation which, it is felt, the nation faces.

ASCOT, England, June 15 (Canadian Press). -- The Ascot race meeting, which starts tomorrow, will be held without the presence of the King and members of the royal family. They will be absent owing to court mourning, but England's most fashionable meeting nevertheless promises to be as popular and crowded as ever.

The refusal of Governor Landon of Kansas, Republican nominee for President, to deliver a political speech over the radio on Sunday night a few weeks ago was "warmly commended" yesterday by the board of managers of the Lord's Day Alliance of the United States at their semi-annual meeting in the Presbyterian Building, 156 Fifth Avenue.

A move designed to afford to underwriting houses a greater latitude in determining the time of the public offering of new issues and, at the same time, to minimize the importance of the actual effective date of those issues in registration with the Securities and Exchange Commisssion will be undertaken in connection with the forthcoming financing by the New York Edison Company, Inc., involving the issuance of $30,000,000 of 3 1/4 per cent bonds.

HAVANA, June 15. -- Four were drowned and there was tremendous loss of property and destruction of crops over the island as a result of heavy rains for five days which caused small streams and rivers to overflow, swept away bridges and flooded towns. Communications were interrupted.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., June 15. -- One hundred and thirty-seven seniors were graduated at the commencement exercises of Middlebury College this morning. Ten received their masters degrees. President Paul D. Moody conferred the degree of Doctor of Laws on Karl Taylor Compton, president of Massachusetts Institute of Technology, who gave the commencement address in the Congregational Church, where the Middlebury exercises have been held for over 126 years.

CANTON, China, June 15. -- The tension among foreign officials in South China has not lessened, despite the fact that the Southern army has withdrawn from Hunan Province and that there is no indication of resumption of the march northward.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, June 15. -- General Anastasio Somoza, commander of the National Guard, was nominated for the Presidency today by the convention of the National Liberal party at Leon. General Somoza will go to Leon tomorrow to accept the nomination and proclaim the platform of the party.

BERLIN, June 15. -- The Boerse opened this week with a resumption of the upward trend interrupted in the latter part of last week. Strength was pronounced in the share market and in foreign bonds, while domestic fixed-interest securities continued dull and rather weaker.

E. Phillips Oppenheim, whose first novel was published fifty-nine years ago, will have his 100th novel published next month. The title is "The Magnificent Hoax," and Little, Brown will be the publishers. The publication date is July 17.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- The Douglas Aircraft Corporation of Santa Monica, Calif., has filed under the Securities Act of 1933 a registration statement providing for 93,480 shares of no-par value capital stock in the amount of $4,206,600. The stock will be offered to present shareholders at the ratio of one new share for each five shares held and any of the shares not taken subsequently will be underwritten.

PHILADELPHIA, June 15. -- Closing a ten-month study of the Philadelphia magistrate system, a special grand jury made an official presentment today to Judge Harry S. McDevitt, charging misconduct and improprieties against a group of the minor "judges."

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 15. -Academic freedom that will keep professors out of politics and government control out of universities was urged today by Walter Lippmann, columnist, as commencement speaker at the University of Rochester.

GENEVA, June 15. -- Reports that Rome planned to send Fulvio Suvich to Washington as Ambassador and Augusto Rosso to Moscow aroused special interest here today as test cases involving recognition of Italy's annexation of Ethiopia.
AMOY, China, June 15 (AP). -- An American doctor and nurse were in a seaside hospital that was attacked by a pirate band tonight and were saved by a machine-gun defense in which five were slain.

Trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange failed to lift the market out of its recent lethargy and speculative interest remained at a minimum. Prices fluctuated without exception in a narrow range. Total transactions amounted to only $8,238,500, compared with $9,140,700 on last Friday.

SYRACUSE, June 15 (AP). -- The strike involving the Remington Rand Company neared the end of its fourth week today, marked by a refusal of workers here to return to their jobs and an announcement by a strike leader that he would file formal charges against the company with the National Labor Relations Board.
AMHERST, Mass., June 15. -- Bachelor of Arts degrees were conferred upon 172 members of the graduating class of Amherst College at the annual commencement held today in College Hall.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 15. -- Princeton University will confer baccalaureate and advanced degrees upon 570 candidates at its 189th annual commencement exercises tomorrow morning at 11 o'clock. Dr. Harold Willis Dodds, president of the university, will preside at the exercises, which will be held on the lawn in front of Nassau Hall, if the weather permits.
HAMILTON, N.Y., June 15 (AP). -- Thomas J. Watson, New York industrialist, told 210 graduates of Colgate University today that "we need cooperation in international affairs more than ever before."

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- A promise that airplane passengers and air mail would reach midtown New York within fifteen minutes after their arrival on Governors Island should an airport be built there was made by Mayor La Guardia today to the Senate Military Affairs Committee in urging a favorable report on the Peyser bill which already has passed the House.

GENEVA, June 15. -- Frieda Miller asked the International Labor Office Conference today to continue its studies of the nutrition problem and to "prepare a balance sheet of food supplies against food needs throughout the world."

IT begins to appear that Shufflin' Joe Louis picked the proper spot when he went to train at Lakewood. The sovereign State of New Jersey must have a remarkable climate. It was the Jersey air that built up Jim Braddock to heavyweight championship requirements. It must have been the air. That was about all Jim had to live on when he started along the come-back trail.

PARIS, June 15. -- All over France the return to work was general today and although a good many special strikes continue the great movement has passed and the normal situation has been completely restored.
WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP). -- Startling developments in the field of radio and television in the near future were forecast today at a Federal Communications Commission fact-finding investigation.

WATERVILLE, Me., June 15. -- Deploring any attempt of politicians to gain control over public education, Professor Kirtley F. Mather of Harvard University, addressed the commencement exercises of Colby College this morning on "Education for Freedom."

Ex-Marine George M. Porter received $750 in bonus bonds and a United States Treasury check for $18 at his office in the Chrysier Building yesterday morning at 10 o'clock. Four hours later he parted with $2.60 to become the 100,000th person to subscribe to New York's 3-cent-a-day plan for hospital care. Mr. Porter declared that he would not spend another cent of the money until 1945, when the bonds mature.

A mid-June opening without postponement or other difficulty lies outside the great tradition. Write down "The Kick Back" as no exception to a general rule. Instead of opening at the Ritz this Wednesday evening, it will arrive there next Monday.

A vagrant rumor that has a good sound ring insists that Maurice Silverstone, United Artists' chief in England and Continental Europe, will be the new president of the United Artists Corporation. He is in Hollywood at the moment, conferring with Douglas Fairbanks, Charlie Chaplin and Mary Pickford, who has been acting president since the resignation last year of Al Lichtman.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- The Senate Military Affairs Committee today decided to call additional witnesses on the Governors Island Landing Field Bill, one of whom will be Brig. Gen. James A. Woodruff. With other army officers he surveyed the Governors Island situation in 1927.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 15. -- An address by Dean Christian Gauss of Princeton was read to the graduating class of Connecticut College at the commencement exercises this morning. It said that acceptance of material wealth as the measure of human excellence is the greatest single error of our time.

Poor Mr. HOOVER! He is simply out of luck with Senator NORRIS. Even if Mr. HOOVER was very good, Mr. NORRIS wouldn't like him, and would be confirmed in his very worst suspicions of him. For instance, there is the ovation accorded by the Cleveland convention to Mr. HOOVER.

The report of Joseph P. Kennedy to the directors of the Paramount Pictures, Inc., with respect to the company's affairs praises the efficiency of its theatre properties and finds fault with its motion picture producing activities, it became known yesterday.
Distribution of the bonus bonds to veterans was reported as follows in the metropolitan area:

A preliminary condensed annual report of the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation for 1935 shows consolidated gross revenues, including new properties only from their date of acquisition, amounting to $93,215,717, compared to $83,973,089 for 1934. Operating income after expenses, taxes and reserves was $27,033,265, against $25,183,469 in 1934.
HAVANA, June 15. -- President Miguel Mariano Gomez today asked Congress to authorize the issue of 12,000,000 to 20,000,000 silver pesos and an equal amount in silver certificates.

LONDON, June 15. -- Abandonment of sanctions was finally decided upon this evening by the Foreign Affairs Committee of the Cabinet, meeting for the last time before the decisive meeting of the full Cabinet on Wednesday. Among those who approved the new policy was Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden, who will announce it to the House of Commons on Thursday.

Baron Giorgio Suriani di Castelnuovo plucked at the knees of his perfectly creased gray trousers in his new office at the St. Moritz yesterday afternoon, relaxed in a swivel chair, lit a cigarette and explained the Noblemen's Club, which he had just organized.

Thirty students, the largest class in the history of the institution, will be graduated today at the fifth, annual commencement of Yeshiva College, to be held at 4 P.M. in the auditorium of the college at Amsterdam Avenue and 186th Street.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., June 15. -- Warnings against regimentation and a defense of the Supreme Court came from former Senator George Wharton Pepper of Pennsylvania in his commencement address at Williams College today. In the student orations Edward Hoyt of New York City assailed the Republican relief platform and Pierce Wood of Dayton, Ohio, criticized the cry of "Back to the Constitution.''

PORTLAND, Me., June 15. -- Lewis O. Barrows, Secretary of State, received the Republican Gubernatorial nomination in today's Maine primary, defeating Blin W. Page, Skowhegan banker, who had the endorsement of the Townsend old-age-pension group.

NORTON, Mass., June 15. -- Christopher Morley told the Wheaton College graduating class today that he believed "prearranged, predigested, precocious discourses are the dark shadows which have brooded over commencement for 100 years," and then talked to his audience spontaneously and informally.

Declaring that advertising should be considered primarily by industry and trade as an investment, Kenneth Collins, vice president of Gimbel Brothers, yesterday told members of the Newark Advertising Club at a luncheon at the Newark Athletic Club that when a store's advertising meets the essential requirements for investment, "there is almost no limit to the extent of its use."

INDIANAPOLIS, June 15 (AP). -- Charges of attempted coercion of WPA workers in connection with the nomination tomorrow of a Democratic candidate for Governor enlivened the final hours tonight of one of the most bitter political contests in Indiana.

ROSLYN, L.I., June 15. -- George T. Dunlap Jr. of the Garden City Country Club, former national amateur champion, paired with Henry Ciuci, Fresh Meadow professional, to tie with Jim Barnes, veteran Crescent A.C. pro, and Charles H. Mayo Jr. of Lido for top honors in the weekly amateur-pro golf tournament today at the Shelter Rock Country Club.

NEW ORLEANS, June 15. -- The United States Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals ruled today that the National Labor Relations Board had no power to regulate the relations of employer and employe in manufacturing. Its decision was unanimous.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- A drive for Senate action on the revised Copeland-Guffey-Gibson Ship Subsidy Bill was made by its sponsors today in agreeing to incorporation in the bill of several new amendments.

Permission for removal of the ashes of her son, Edward Herlich, 16 years old, who died of arsenic poisoning on May 3 in Wyckoff Heights Hospital in Brooklyn, was granted to investigating authorities yesterday by Mrs. Meta Herlich of 71-68 Seventieth Street, Glendale, Queens, the boy's mother.

Five hundred persons, representing more than thirty patriotic and historic societies, braved yesterday afternoon's rain to march up lower Broadway to City Hall Park in the nineteenth annual Flag Day celebration of the Sons of the Revolution in the State of New York.

CHICAGO, June 15 (AP). -- Frankie Parker of Milwaukee and Lawrenceville, N.J., top-seeded star, breezed through his first and sec-one-round matches today in the national clay courts tennis championships at the River Forest Club.
WASHINGTON, June 15. -- President Roosevelt today sent to the Senate the names of John W. Clancy and Samuel Mendelbaum to fill vacancies in the Federal bench for the Southern District of New York.
ST. PAUL, June 15 (AP). -- Governor Floyd B. Olson and Representative Theodore Christianson appeared to have been nominated by the Farmer-Labor and Republican

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on June 10 shows increases for the week of $15,000,000 in total loans and investments, $150,000,000 in Reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks, $97,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, $49,000,000 in deposit balances standing to the credit of domestic banks and $52,000,000 in deposit balances standing to the credit of foreign banks.
WASHINGTON, June 15. -- Disappointment over the New Orleans steel case decision was voiced by spokesmen for organized labor and the National Labor Relations Board.

Clerical forces of the Stock Exchange began yesterday the task of tabulating returns from the Exchange's questionnaire of May 30 asking of member firms the ratio of customers' collateral to their debit balances and the number of accounts restricted through failure to maintain a 55 per cent margin.
The city, the State and the Long Island Railroad fought two battles yesterday, but there was no decision in either case.
Royal S. Copeland, senior United States Senator from New York, announced last night that he was "not going" to the Democratic National Convention in Philadelphia next week.

CHICAGO, June 15. -- Wheat prices forged ahead sharply on the Chicago Board of Trade today in the broadest trade witnessed in several weeks. Closing quotations were nearly 3 cents a bushel above Saturday's finish. The upturn was inspired entirely by pessimistic crop reports from the Spring wheat belt of the Northwest, where temperatures over the week-end were extremely high.
VATICAN CITY, June 15 (AP). -- Pope Pius XI, creating two new Cardinals, spoke thoughtfully today of his duties, "as long as life lasts."
WASHINGTON, June 15. -- President Roosevelt returned from his Southwestern trip and conferred with Secretary Morgenthau, Postmaster General Farley and Attorney General Cummings.

The foreign exchange market hinged on the abrupt decline in the franc yesterday. As the franc dropped 15-16 points to 6.58 5-16 cents on the day, thereby wiping out all of the sudden gain made on Saturday, the other gold currencies declined.

CHICAGO, June 15. -- An unusual scholastic feat will have been accomplished at the University of Chicago's convocation exercises tomorrow when Donald MacMurray, 21-year-old New Yorker, receives the degree of Bachelor of Arts.
WASHINGTON, June 15. -- Organized labor was busy today preparing to advance its policies on the industrial, political and legal "fronts" in view of important events pending.

Without fanfare or ceremony the first actual work on the grading of the site in Queens of the 1939 World's Fair, a $50,000,000 project, started yesterday. A steam shovel puffed furiously, dug the claws of its bucket into the ground and started a procession of dump trucks that will continue for a long time.

ROME, June 15. -- It is believed that changes in the Italian foreign service, of which there has been talk for some time past, are about to be announced. The reshuffling will be one of the largest in Italian diplomacy, about thirty-five persons being involved.

Henry Root Stern, former treasurer of the Republican State Committee, telegraphed yesterday to Senator George W. Norris of Nebraska, charging the latter with unfairness in his radio speech of Sunday evening. Mr. Stern challenged the Nebraska Senator to name the men he alleged dominated the Republican National Convention at Cleveland and made "puppets of the delegates."

Don't you think a reading, even a casual scanning, of that document whose title has so recently seeped into millions of human consciences, but where, up until a few months ago, it was a total stranger -- the United States Constitution -- would be enlightening to many who publicly discuss it pro and con?

Awards of medals, scholarships, honors and prizes to fifty-five graduates and students of the College of the City of New York were announced yesterday by President Frederick B. Robinson. The awards are to be made at the commencement exercises in Lewisohn Stadium tomorrow evening.

In a talk on the danger of "socialistic doctrines" to this country, Howard E. Coffin, chairman of Southeastern Cottons, Inc., told a meeting of the Sales Executives Club yesterday that the most important job of industry was "reselling America to Americans."
NORTHAMPTON, Mass., June 15. -- Five honorary degrees were conferred at the Smith College commencement exercises this morning by President Neilson.

A series of four outdoor symphony concerts in the City Schools Stadium will open in Newark tonight. The Newark Symphony, under the direction of Erno Rapee, will perform, with Lily Pons, Metropolitan Opera soprano, as soloist.

For the last two years a wizened little man with thinning gray hair -- a dealer in antique objects -- sought an interview with J.P. Morgan, the banker, hoping that the financier would purchase what he believed to be an original statue by Michelangelo.

PHILADELPHIA, June l5. -- Two hundred and sixty students in the Schools of Engineering, Business Administration, Home Economics and Library Science of Drexel Institute of Technology received degrees and diplomas today at the forty-third annual commencement, the first under the new name of the West Philadelphia College.

American ship lines operating in foreign trade are feeling the effect of a lack of governmental policy toward the merchant marine, according to Commander Robert C. Lee, vice president of Moore McCormack, ship operators.

Price movements on the local commodity futures markets were mixed yesterday, but gains predominated. Coffee, wool tops, hides and tin futures were lower. On the cash markets wheat, corn, rye, oats, flour and rubber advanced, cocoa making a new high since 1930.

NOROTON, Conn., June 15. -- Striking the first blow in defense of the laurels she gained last year, Mrs. Jonathan Thorne of Innis Arden led a field of sixty-two in the qualifying round of the fourteenth annual women's Westchester-Fairfield golf championship at the Wee Burn Club today.
NEWARK, June 15. -- The Newark Bears increased their league lead to four games tonight with a 6-1 triumph over their nearest rivals, the Buffalo Bisons.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- Applications for two series of Treasury bills to be dated June 17, 1936, which were offered on June 12, amounted to $250,055,000, the Treasury announced today, and of this amount $100,030,000 was accepted.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., June 15 (AP). -- Three Coast Guard fliers on storm patrol duty lost their lives today in a tropical disturbance which isolated several South Florida communities by floods.
WILDWOOD, N.J., June 15. -- The Rev. Leonard S. Pitcher, 30 years old, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church of Wildwood, has tendered his resignation, he announced today.

A total of 12,500 automobiles, 50 per cent of them used cars and the rest new models, will be bought by veterans in the next few weeks, it was estimated yesterday by the Automobile Merchants Association of New York, Inc. The new business, accruing to local auto dealers as a result of the bonus, the organization figured, should amount to $8,000,000.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

Leo P. Byk, Brooklyn slot machine operator, who is said to have acted as an intermediary in an attempt to "fix" the Drukman murder case, deposited $14,800 in cash in the three months immediately following the murder. The sum was only $1,000 less than his total cash deposits for the year.

Charging that nationally known meat packers are violating terms of a consent decree they signed in 1920 and are attempting to establish a monopoly in the East, Charles Marks, attorney for the New York State Association of Retail Meat Dealers, Inc., yesterday announced plans to picket the plants of the most persistent violator.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- Refreshed by a week's recess, both houses of Congress turned today to clearing up legislative odds and ends in the hope of adjourning by the end of the week. Leaders expressed varying degrees of optimism as to the possibility of completing the Seventh-fourth Congress's business by next Saturday.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., June 15. -- Though they haven't as yet issued an "official" pro-battle announcement of what they expect Joe Louis to do to Max Schmeling Thursday night, it is an open secret that the Bomber's handlers are pointing for a victory that may establish a new record for brevity in major heavyweight competition.
PHILADELPHIA, June 15 (AP). -- Democrats took possession of Philadelphia's Municipal Auditorium and doubled their field office force today in a surge of preparations for the convention next week.

Murray T. Quigg's defense of the minimum wage decision in THE TIMES of June 9 starts with a glaring historical inaccuracy and concludes with a most unfair reflection on the intellectual integrity of a really great judge. Between these two extremities stands a typical example of the use of pious talk about liberty as a cloak for ruthless human exploitation.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 15. -- Denouncing war as an "unmistakable symbol of bankrupt statesmanship" and declaring that the "predatory instinct of national aggrandizement is again rampant," Secretary of State Cordell Hull called upon alumni of Brown University today to assist in raising again the standards of international morality, so that war would not be possible.

Dry goods jobbers indicated yesterday that the volume of business to be placed this week would probably be the largest in several months. The strengthening in prices has reached a point where it is advisable to cover their Fall needs liberally, they said, in addition to which very little time is left to operate on some lines, if deliveries are to be obtained.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- The fate of the Republican "brain trust," created by the Republican National Committee during the chairmanship of Henry P. Fletcher, will be settled by the new regime late this week. John D.M. Hamilton, the new chairman, has scheduled a conference late this week in New York City with Dr. Olin Glenn Saxon, chief of the Republican professors.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- A parade of members, some of whom were said to believe there was no possible chance for action at this session, marched to the well of the House late today to sign a petition to discharge the Judiciary Committee from further consideration of the Gavagan Anti-Lynching Bill.

LONDON, June 15 (AP). -- Donald Budge of Oakland, Calif., and Gene Mako of Los Angeles today advanced to the second round of singles in the Queens Club tennis tournament. Budge defeated W.H.B. Michelmore, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 2, while Mako downed W.W. Robertson, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 0.

LONDON, June 15. -- The Cabinet Foreign Affairs Committee's agreement in principle tonight to the lifting of sanctions against Italy, it was understood, was based on the failure of sanctions to stop Italy's conquest of Ethiopia, and on the necessity of Italian representation at conferences dealing with the Turkish request for refortification of the Dardanelles.

CHICAGO, June 15. -- A quarrel over army discharge papers and today's bonus payment ended today with the death of Joseph W. Bolton, 40 years old, an insurance broker. Police held his estranged wife, Mildred, who said her husband was shot while she struggled with him in his office for possession of an automatic pistol. He was shot three times.
Once again rain intervened yesterday to postpone the finals of the women's New York State championship at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club.
A four-year search for William F. Ellison ended yesterday when he was seized by detectives attached to the Attorney General's office in front of 15 Broad Street.

Alderman Joseph E. Kinsley of the Bronx moved yesterday to clear up the status of bonus recipients on home relief, while the Emergency Relief Bureau took no steps to clarify the position of the veterans.

CAMP NO. 1, MOUNT EVEREST, Tibet, June 15. -- With Mount Everest buried under deep snow, further effort this year to reach its un-scaled summit must be abandoned. As a result our expedition must now depart, as further effort would be useless.
Value of Dollar in Exchange The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- A report that "starvation and disease" are to be found in many homes in New Jersey as a result of failure by the State to provide relief for "unemployables" was made today by Harry L. Hopkins, WPA Administrator.

Henry L. Stimson, former Secretary of State, has been elected chairman of the board of trustees of International House, 500 River- side Drive, it was announced yesterday by John L. Mort, director ef the house and a member of the board.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- The present government of Cuba has not yet filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an application for the permanent registration on the New York Stock Exchange of the $40,000,000 of public works 5 1/2 per cent bonds issued by the Machado government under an agreement dated Feb. 26, 1930.
WASHINGTON, June 15. -- Uncle Sam "paid off" and settled his account today with millions of veterans of the World War.

TRENTON, N.J., June 15. -- With aid from the Democratic minority, Governor Hoffman tonight obtained Senate confirmation of his nomination of Colonel Mark O. Kimberling to succeed Colonel H. Norman Schwarzkopf as superintendent of the State Police Department.
NAPANOCH, N.Y., June 15. -- Only one more day of boxing and Max Schmeling will be ready for his Thursday night's engagement with Joe Louis.

CHICAGO, June 15. -- Colonel Frank Knox, nominee for the Vice Presidency, and several members of a subcommittee of Republican party leaders departed for Topeka tonight to confer on campaign strategy and organization with Governor Alf M. Landon.

CARDIFF, Wales, June 15. -- A strong plea for putting teeth in the sanctions machinery of the League of Nations was made today by Ramsay MacDonald in a speech to the thirty-first International Peace Congress. The Lord President of the Council assumed the leadership of Cabinet opposition to the stand taken by Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer.
CANTON, China, June 15. -- The anti-Japanese professions of Kwangsi Province were upheld as to sincerity today by General Li Tsung-jen.

Corporation Counsel Paul Windels and John J. Halleran, Queens Public Works Commissioner, clashed yeterday over the latter's charge that the Corporation Counsel's office was largely responsible for low condemnation awards to Queens property owners.

DURHAM, N.H., June 15. -- Basing the text of his address, "Intellectual Independence," on the reflective writings on democracy of the late President Edward M. Lewis, Dr. Kenneth C.M. Sills, president of Bowdoin College, characterized today as "a nation prone to jump at conclusions, to go off intellectually half-cocked and to be impatient with processes that require the slowly developing power that comes from the use of reason."

In one of his early fighting speeches at Chicago last month Senator BORAH said that nobody had asked him to run for the Presidential nomination. He had flung himself into the campaign on his own motion. He added that "I will stay in it until I'm thrown out." The Senator was not thrown out.

LONDON, June 15. -- Sir Auckland Geddes, former British Ambassador to the United States and now director of many financial houses here, appealed today for a diminution of the restrictions in the United States which make it difficult for the British to invest in American securities which he said was necessary and in the interests of this country.

The first hearing in this district on applications by the National Labor Relations Board to enforce orders against employers held by the board to have been guilty of unfair labor practices was conducted yesterday by the United States Circuit Court of Appeals.

OMAHA, Neb., June 15. -- Officers of the National Retail Credit Association and the National Consumer Credit Reporting Corporation on the eve of their conventions said today that retail collections were better than at any time in their memory.

When the starting gun for the biennial ocean race to Bermuda sounds off Newport next Monday, a record number of yachts for the event will cross the line, thanks to the presence of a large representation from foreign waters.

GRAYVILLE, Ill., June 15. -- With appreciation in her voice, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt faced a crowd of thousands of sweltering farm folk standing in hot sunshine, hazy with dust, today, and thanked them for a huge picnic given in her honor.

The northeast blow and intermittent downpours spoiled the fishing on the local deep-sea grounds over the week-end. It was a disappointing climax to the best week of sea bass fishing at Seabright so far this season.
MADRID, June 15 (AP). -- Incessant rains added crop worries to Spain's strike woes tonight.

PARIS, June 15. -- A drive in two directions against "enemies of the regime" was begun tonight by the new Leftist French Government, determined not to allow the ebbing strike movement to get out of hand.

TRENTON, N.Y., June 15. -- Dr. Henry B. Kummel, director of the State Department of Conservation and Development, received today a copy of resolutions sent to Governor Hoffman by cranberry growers and sportsmen's organizations in South Jersey, demanding that Colonel Leonidas Coyle, State Fire Warden, be forced to resign.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- The Treasury's cash and paper turnover, including pledges under the soldiers' bonus and income-tax returns, was close to $6,000,000,000 today, the largest in peace-time history for any quarterly financing period.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 15. -- The three most urgent needs of Princeton University are a new library, a satisfactory center for the social life of the campus and modification of the preceptorial system, William A. Carlile of Columbus, Ohio, president of the graduating class, declared today at the seniors' annual cannon exercises.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- The House Rules Committee today reported out a resolution providing for a commission to investigate the political, economic and social situation in Puerto Rico. The committee amended the resolution as it passed the Senate by cutting out all reference to the possibility of Puerto Rican independence.

Nathan Burkan, attorney and Tammany Hall leader, who died on June 6, left his estate in trust to his widow and son, it was disclosed yesterday when his will was filed for probate in Surrogate's Court. It was reported that the estate would exceed $1,000,000.

COLLINGSWOOD, N.J., June 15. -- The Collingswood Presbyterian Church with a membership oil 1,100 persons, whose pastor, the Rev. Carl McIntire, has been associated with the militant fundamentalist wing of the Presbyterian denomination, voted tonight to withdraw from the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America.

NEW HAVEN, June 15. -- Nearly 2,000 Yale alumni were pelted with rain as they began their commencement reunion festivities today. The undergraduate seniors held their class day exercises, although the Sheffield Scientific School class was driven indoors.

HANOVER, N.H., June 15. -- For the first time in several years rain forced the Dartmouth commencement exercises indoors as President Ernest Martin Hopkins conferred 490 degrees on a record graduating class.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 15. -- The tall banks of the highlands that border the Hudson River looked down tonight on the complete cast of actors for the intercollegiate regatta next Monday. Cornell, the last of the competitors, arrived this morning and the eighteen crews entered in the three races, as well as several fours and makeshift eights of substitutes, gave the pilots of the ferry boats something of a traffic problem in the early evening.

Opposition to a World Jewish Congress in Geneva in August is expressed in a statement issued yesterday by a group of leading American Jews. It came from the office of James N. Rosenberg, lawyer, 165 Broadway, and resulted from action taken in Washington last Saturday and Sunday, where delegates of ninety-nine Jewish communities in thirty-two States expressed themselves in favor of the congress.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 15. -- The Westchester Board of Supervisors gave its consent this afternoon to plans for ending the long boundary controversy between the cities of New York and Mount Vernon, paving the way for a referendum June 23.

About 2,000 members of the staff of the Emergency Relief Bureau attended a meeting last night called by the American Federation of Government Employes to protest against a proposal for civil service examinations in the relief bureau. The meeting, held in the Rockland Palace, 155th Street and Eighth Avenue, adopted a resolution contending that the proposal would mean the dismissal of 10,000 ERB employes.

MEDFORD, Mass., June 15. -- A world "speeding aimlessly" down a complex highway to "a dark destiny," which can be forestalled by professional education, was pictured today to 455 Tufts seniors and the college alumni by Dr. Robert E. Doherty, president-elect of the Carnegie Institute of Technology, speaker at the commencement.

For the quarter ended on April 30, Distillers Corporation-Seagrams, Ltd., and subsidiaries reported yesterday a net profit of $1,619,680 in Canadian currency, after deducting interest, depreciation, provision for income and profits taxes and other charges.

Supreme Court Justice Ernest Hammer reserved decision yesterday in the suit by the City of New York against Charles A. Buckley, former City Chamberlain, and the Aetna Casualty and Surety Company, the Hartford Accident and Indemnity Company and the Glens Falls Indemnity Company, which went on his bond for $300,000 when he took office.

An injunction protecting the consuming public from being compelled to pay 1 cent a quart more for milk purchased in paper containers than in glass bottles was granted by Supreme Court Justice Salvatore Cotillo yesterday in a suit by Dairy Sealed, Inc., a subsidiary of the Borden company against the New York State Division of Milk Control.

An attempt to eliminate the antagonism between the various veterans' organizations and the Communist party was evidenced last night when the New York State delegates of the party, assembled at the final session of a four-day convention, adopted a resolution supporting the veterans in their demand that no ex-service man be cut off the relief or unemployment-relief rolls because of receipt of the bonus.

The town of Stamford, Conn., will be in the market on Friday with a new issue of $650,000 of emergency and trade school addition bonds. The bonds will be dated July 1, 1936, and will mature on July 1, 1938 to 1948.

LONDON, June 15. -- Members of the European committee of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace unanimously agreed today that there should be no changes in the covenant of the League of Nations.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 15. -- The trial opened today at Bekes of 113 members of the Sickle and Cross organization, who are charged with participation in the recent fantastic march on Budapest for the purpose of overthrowing the government.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 15. -- Dave Tuttle and Richard Skinner opened their seventh season of Westchester's Summer drama tonight at the Ridgeway Theatre with Barbara Brown and George Blackwood in Lawrence Riley's "Personal Appearance."

TOPEKA, June 15. -- Governor Alf M. Landon's plan of campaign became more definite tonight, after a five-hour conference with his campaign manager, John D.M. Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Committee.

WELLESLEY, Mass., June 15. -"There is no problem of the present time more acute than that which concerns the relations of the individual with the group, the problem of the conflict between freedom and authority," Dr. Charles Seymour, provost of Yale University, told the 308 members of the graduating class of Wellesley College this morning.

A correspondent implies that Whiteface Mountain has been profaned by the construction of the highway which now makes its summit accessible to thousands, where formerly none but the hardy mountaineer could reach it.

President ANGELL was addressing the young baccalaureates of Yale last Sunday, but the subject and scope of the address and the authority with which this eminent citizen speaks made it a word of warning to the people -- to the nation at the "critical crossroads" of its development, at the threshold of another "great chapter" in our national history.
New York State Mayors are about equally divided on the question, "Has drinking decreased since repeal?" according to replies to a questionnaire sent out by the State Liquor Authority.

The Universal Leaf Tobacco Company has declared an extra dividend of $1.75 on the common stock, and a quarterly dividend of 75 cents on the common. The quarterly dividend puts the stock on a $3 annual basis, against $2 previously. A year ago, an extra of $2 was paid in addition to the quarterly dividend of 50 cents.

Homer Rodeheaver, for twenty years musical director and choir leader on the evangelical programs of the late Billy Sunday, returned yesterday on the French liner Normandie from a trip which included a flight from Brussels to Marseilles and then to the Belgian Congo and covering 16,000 miles.

Sir Alfred Zimmern, Professor of International Relations at Oxford University, will arrive today from England on the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria. Others aboard include Commander Gade, United States Naval Attache at Brussels, and Mrs. Gade; Lady Fitzherbert, Mr. and Mrs. William Dana Orcutt, Mr. and Mrs. T.E. Murchison, Mrs. A.G. Chubb, Mrs. J.H. Halsey and Dr. Gray Carter.

LONDON, June 15 (AP). -- Following are the Board of Trade figures of British foreign trade for the month of May: Total imports, 69,170,000; exports of British products, 36,390,000; re-exports 5,630,000; total exports 42,020,000; excess of imports 27,150,000.

The Metropolitan A.A.U. senior track and field championships which point in two directions -- the national tide meet at Princeton on July 3 and 4 and the final Olympic tryouts at Randalls Island on July 11 and 12 -- will be staged at Glen Park, Yonkers, on Saturday with 307 athletes entered.

LOUIS ALEXANDRE TASCHEREAU had been a member of the Quebec Legislature for thirty-six years and Prime Minister of the Province for sixteen, when he resigned last week. He is a Grand Seigneur. The first Canadian member of his family, distinguished in France, came to Canada more than 200 years ago.

The United States Treasury undertook yesterday the largest peacetime financial operations in the country's history. In the first place, it issued $1,025,000,000 in new bonds and notes, which were given in exchange for one series of notes that matured yesterday and one that will mature on Aug. 1.

SHANGHAI, Tuesday, June 16. -- While the domestic prestige of the Central Government has undoubtedly been enhanced by South China's hesitation to face Nanking's readiness to block the northward advance with strong armies, the net result is profoundly disquieting.

It is trite to say that surpluses and reserves are as essential to a business as is invested capital. Moreover, properly handled they can be used as a most effective remedy for the cure of our sick capitalism. Today, on the contrary, they constitute capitalism's supreme handicap.

Running through the rain and over a muddy track, the Crack Brigade gelding, Bill Farnsworth, captured the featured Helmet Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday in 1:17 3-5, only a fifth of a second slower than the six and one-half furlong track record.

TRENTON, N.J., June 15. -- While the Assembly discussed tonight the controversial question of emergency relief financing without taking action, the Senate passed the Municipal Budget Bill intended to place municipal governments on a cash basis by 1945. The vote was 19 to 0.

Running through the rain and over a muddy track, the Crack Brigade gelding, Bill Farnsworth, captured the featured Helmet Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday in 1:17 3-5, only a fifth of a second slower than the six and one-half furlong track record.

TRENTON, N.J., June 15. -- While the Assembly discussed tonight the controversial question of emergency relief financing without taking action, the Senate passed the Municipal Budget Bill intended to place municipal governments on a cash basis by 1945. The vote was 19 to 0.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., June 15. -- The distinguished career of Daniel McFarlan Moore, whose electrical researches and inventions brought the cooperation and applause of Thomas A. Edison, Sir William Ramsay and other eminent scientists, came to an abrupt and tragic end here early this morning at the hand of an unknown assassin.
