MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 15. -- Paul Runyan, former National P.G.A. champion, had a field day in a one-day tournament of the Westehester P.G.A. over the east course of the Winged Foot Golf Club today.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP). -- Legislation to continue Joseph B. Eastman as Federal Coordinator of Transportation for one year, but without the regulatory powers which the office exercised for the last three years, was put in position today for a vote on it by the Senate.

More than 1,000 persons attended commencement exercises for 114 boys at Brooklyn Preparatory School in the Brooklyn Academy of Music last night. The diplomas were presented by the Rev. George E. Kelly, president of the school board of trustees.

A double-header, pitting Yale against Harvard at 3:30 P.M. and Princeton against Army at 5:30, will open the annual intercollegiate outdoor polo championship tourney this afternoon at Morris Memorial Field on Governors Island.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., June 16. -- Mrs. Robert Bacon, who has recently returned from a stay in Europe, was hostess this afternoon at Old Acres, her home in this village, at a garden tea in aid of the English Speaking Union of America.

NOROTON, Conn., June 16. -- Mrs. Henry Dietrich of Briar Hills, the new metropolitan champion, provided the only surprise in the first round of the fourteenth annual Westchester-Fairfield golf championship at the Wee Burn Club today.

TRENTON, June 16. -- When Colonel Mark O. Kimberling takes office tomorrow as superintendent of the State Police Department, the appointment of his successor as principal keeper of the State Prison here will rest with Governor Hoffman.

BUCHAREST, June 16. -- A conference of the chiefs of the general staffs of the Little Entente States is now being held here and will last until the week-end. Only problems common to all three armies are under discussion, including military cooperation as a counterstroke to a Hapsburg restoration in Austria or Hungary.
VIENNA, June 16. -- For the second time in a fortnight a Vienna court has imposed nominal sentences on Nazis charged with high treason for participation in the reconstructed Austrian Brown Army.

AS a rule the fighters would prefer to say nothing and let Nature take its course. But kind friends, chance acquaintances and total strangers press around them in public or secluded spots, all asking the same stock question, to wit:

Somewhat subdued following their disastrous road trip, the Giants returned to the Polo Grounds yesterday to launch what they hope will be a profitable home stand, and although they managed to defeat the Reds, 5-2, there was a woeful lack of finesse.

While the Bronx, with five apartment house projects totaling $895,000 again led the city in building plans yesterday, multi-family construction for Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens sites also was listed.
Taxation relief for real estate and the business community was urged yesterday by Charles F. Noyes, head of the realty brokerage company bearing his name, in its annual statement to stockholders.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- President Roosevelt and Vice President Garner will be nominated by unanimous vote at the Democratic National Convention, officials of the national committee, who have been advised of conditions in the State delegations, predicted today.

A total of seventy-three infant deaths was reported in the city last week, according to the Department of Health. The infant death rate per 1,000 live births was 38.5, compared to 40 the week before and 56.9 a year ago. For the year to date the rate is 50.4, or 8 per cent under last year's, that established a new low.

Business failures in the retail division in the week ended June 11 fell below their average for the first twenty-four weeks of this year, while in the wholesale division the figures were on a par with the average for the current period, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

PARIS, June 16. -- France is about to relinquish her mandate over Syria. According to a projected treaty examined today by high government officials at the Quai d'Orsay, independence would be granted to the Syrian territory and it would be recognized as two separate republics, Syria and Lebanon.
BERLIN, June 16. -- The Boerse opened strong today, but turned weak later. Net losses of 1 to 2 points and some of more were frequent at the finish.

ASCOT, England, June 16. -- Major J.B. Walker's Bouldnor today won the 2,000 added Ascot Stakes by two lengths from Sir Percy Lorain's Coup de Roi. A head away in third place was Sir Ernest Tate's Blue Girl.
LAKEWOOD, N.J., June 16. -Trained to the minute and ready for action, Joe Louis brought his long conditioning grind to a close today.

Maine is rich in true believers in Dr. TOWNSEND'S gospel; and that congregation of the faithful seems largely composed of Republicans. There were two active Republican candidates for Governor, Secretary of State BARROWS and Mr. BLIN PAGE, banker. Mr. BARROWS is all for liberty and the Constitution.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- Approval by President Roosevelt of the Jones bill to extend the same character of regulation to commodity exchanges as is exercised over securities exchanges was announced by the White House today.

SHANGHAI, Wednesday, June 17. -- High officials of the Central Government and Kwangsi Province are discussing peace proposals at the town of Nanyui, south of Hengchow, but it is understood that Kwangsi's demands are such that the government cannot entertain them.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., June 16. -- The printing house of William Edwin Rudge, which was founded in 1873 and later became one of this country's finest book printers and binders, was sold at auction today to satisfy a $200,000 mortgage.

The numbers of visiting buyers recorded in the market during the week ended yesterday was less than in the preceding week. However, the total was well above the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.
ROME, June 16. -- Italy, from sources close to Premier Benito Mussolini, sounded a strong note of friendship for Germany today.

TOPEKA, June 16. -- The Republican leaders who came to Topeka today for a conference with Governor Alf M. Landon coupled a general discussion of campaign strategy with the business of organizing the national committee for the next four years, and in so doing followed a middle-of-the-road course.
ASCOT, England, June 16 (AP). -- Ascot Week, the mannequin-parade-race meeting that highlights the London season, came in today in a profusion of women's fashions and bright shirts for the men.

John K. Conant of the General Printing Ink Corporation was elected president of the Purchasing Agents Association of New York last night at a dinner meeting in the Cafe Savarin. Besides the election of officers, the meeting also signalized opening of the new offices of the organization at 120 Broadway.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- The proposed plan to modify provisions of its prior lien and preferred stock, as submitted to the Interstate Commerce Commission by the Wheeling Lake Erie Railway, will, it is hoped, settle a controversy among stockholders which has been going on for nine years, according to a letter received by Oliver E. Sweet, director of the finance division of the I.C.C., from Andrew P. Martin of counsel for the company.

Few choices before this country are more fundamental than the question whether the United States is to move forward toward political and economic cooperation in world affairs or to withdraw toward isolation. On the eve of its national convention the Democratic party has been given an unusual opportunity to appeal for the support of Americans who favor cooperation rather than isolation.

Mayor La Guardia sent a telegram yesterday to Representative Thomas L. Cullen in Washington urging that the New York members of the House join in an effort to block passage of a Senate bill authorizing a Hudson River bridge at Fifty-seventh Street.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- President Roosevelt declined at a press conference today to discuss the Republican platform or his own tour of the Southwest, saying only that he recommended a trip to Texas for the benefit of the figure. He lost five pounds.

RKO-Radio Pictures plans to release fifty-four feature-length motion picture productions in the 1936-37 season, it was announced yesterday by Ned E. Depinet at the second session of the annual sales convention of the company at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

One of the largest deals of the season in the upper Inwood-Dyckman section of Manhattan has been closed in the sale of the six-story apartment house at 1-9 Seaman Avenue, northeast corner of Dyckman Street, to an investing syndicate by the Ivor Realty Corporation.

A $150,000 slander suit, based on an alleged $100,000 bribe offer to the Police in the Drukman case, was filed in the Supreme Court yes terday by Abraham Rosenblum against Abraham J. Weinstein. Both are produce men, Rosenblum having an office at 304 Washington Street and Weinstein at 320 Washington Street.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,971,400 barrels, compared to 2,935,450 in the previous week, an increase of 35,950, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Gains of 19,800 barrels in Oklahoma and of 17,150 in Kansas were the important changes.
Registering her first victory over Mrs. H. Walter Blumenthal in four years, Miss Norma Taubele won the New York State championship yesterday at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club.

PHILADELPHIA, June 16. -- Legal action in the Presbyterian Modernist-Fundamentalist controversy was foreshadowed today, when the West Jersey Presbytery, meeting at Daretown, N.J., dissolved the pastoral relations of two congregations and their ministers and prepared to go to court, if necessary, to "protect the legal rights" of the Presbytery and of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- The Wagner Slum Clearance and Low-Cost Housing Bill, regarded by the administration as an important feature of the recovery program and an asset in a campaign year, was passed in the Senate, 42 to 24, today and sent to the House Banking and Currency Committee, which is considering a similar measure.

The price movements in the commodity futures markets were quite mixed yesterday, with coffee, sugar, wool tops, silk and cocoa easier. On the cash markets, cocoa was lower, while wheat, corn, rye, oats, flour, lard, standard tin, silk, rubber and cotton advanced.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals heard argument yesterday and reserved decision on the application of the National Labor Relations Board for an order enforcing its ruling against The Associated Press. The board has ordered the association to cease interference with the right of its employes to organize, and to reinstate Morris Watson, an editorial worker, who, the board has held, was dismissed for his activity in the American Newspaper Guild.

CHICAGO, June 16. -- More encouraging reports from the dressed meat trade made an active market for hogs here today as prices declined 5 to 15 cents a hundred-weight. The extreme top was $10.20 for choice light weights, which were scarce, while the average run sold at $9.70, a drop of 10 cents from Monday.

TRENTON, June 16. -- Caucusing tonight on the annual appropriations bill providing $42,691,746 for operation of the State government, exclusive of the Highway Department, during the fiscal year beginning July 1, the Republican majority in the Assembly voted to reject it as passed this afternoon by the Senate and to assist on revisions to reduce the total about $2,000,000.
PHILADELPHIA, June 16 (AP). -The Cubs added timely hitting to steady pitching today to win their twelfth consecutive victory by subduing the Phillies, 4 to 1.

PARIS, June 16. -- Expressing great misgivings, the French Senate began discussion today of the first batch of bills that Premier Leon Blum's Leftist government has introduced for the establishment of the forty-hour week, collective contracts, paid holidays and revision of deflation laws.

OTTAWA, June 16. -- Canadian uneasiness, not only regarding the course of events in Europe, but about Britain's policy toward the League of Nations, will find expression in Parliament next Thursday, when a debate on foreign affairs has been arranged.

The reappointment of Morris Schappes, a tutor in English at City College and the center of a controversy over free speech, was voted last night at a meeting of the Board of Higher Education on the recommendation of the City College Administrative Committee.

GLEN RIDGE, N.J., June l6. -Mrs. B.C. Rosenberg of Lakeville today won the low gross award in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association one-day tournament when she carded an 85 over the rugged Glen Ridge Country Club course. Out in 41, the Long Island star seemed headed for a brilliant score until she ran into difficulties on the incoming holes, getting two 7s and a 6.

JERUSALEM, June 16. -- Jacob Gerson, 21 years old, died in the Hadassah Hospital in Jerusalem this morning, the thirty-first Jewish victim since the Palestine disturbances began April 19. He had been shot three days ago by Arabs from the hills near Jerusalem while driving a truck.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- The experiment of voluntary code organization in its field has been found satisfactory in establishing an effective medium of stabilization and curbing of substandard conditions, the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board maintained today as it met in the first of its two-day sessions here.

CHICAGO, June 16. -- Sentiment in the world's wheat markets is in the main bullish, especially here and in Minneapolis and Kansas City. Traders say that unless the Dakotas, Minnesota and Montana get good rains within a few days, they will look for higher prices.

Family background held the attention yesterday of authorities investigating the mysterious death from arsenic poisoning of Edward Herlich Jr., 16-year-old Glendale schoolboy. Particular attenion was focused on four wills.
HARRISBURG, Pa., June 16. -- Governor Earle of Pennsylvania was slightly injured this evening when landing in his autogiro at the United States Army depot at Middletown.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- Secretary Ickes set a precedent today by announcing that a contract for 1,438,560 pounds of steel piling for the Imperial Dam in Arizona, involving $40,086, would be withheld from the Jones Laughlin Company because the company had been found guilty by the National Labor Relations Board of unfair labor practices.

PEIPING, China, Wednesday, June 17. -- Policemen, gendarmes and firemen blocked two attempts by Tientsin students to demonstrate against Japan yesterday and finally herded them back to their universities.

INDIANAPOLIS, June 16 (AP). -- In a fiery convention marked by a, bitter contest for ballots and one fist fight, M. Clifford Townsend of Marion, the Lieutenant Governor, who had the support of Governor Paul V. McNutt, was nominated by Indiana Democrats today as their candidate for Governor in November.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith declared yesterday that he had not made up his mind whether he would go to the Democratic National Convention at Philadelphia. He was equally uncertain whether, if he did go, he would "take a walk."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 16. -Pitcher Ted Horton of Yale today won his own game as he singled in the tenth inning to send across the run that beat Harvard, 8 -- 7, before a commencement day crowd of nearly 7,000. The battle, an Eastern Intercollegiate League affair, was the first in the annual series between the Blue and Crimson.

The Board of Aldermen voted approval yesterday of the local law introduced by Majority Leader Murray W. Stand to permit unaccompanied minors to attend theatres at certain hours under specified conditions.

National and international political events are influencing women's styles to a greater extent than ever before and manufacturers of style merchandise have a splendid opportunity this year to link their merchandise to timely developments, stylists addressing a special luncheon meeting of the National Notion Association at the Advertising Club said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- Charges that fourth-class postmasters were being "mobilized as a campaign machine in behalf of the New Deal" were made today by Representative Charles A. Halleck of Indiana, a Republican member of the Committee on Civil Service.

Thomas J. McGee, a Brooklyn Democratic district leader, was appointed deputy chief clerk of the New York City Magistrates Courts yesterday afternoon. A few hours later he was sworn in by George A. Wingate. Kings County Surrogate.

The turnover in the money market in the last two days is estimated to have been about $650,000,000, of which about $500,000,000 was on Monday and $150,000,000 yesterday. This involved payment of income taxes, disbursement of interest by the government, cash subscriptions to the Treasury's offering and cash redemption, if any, of maturing government obligations.

ITHACA, N.Y., June 16. -- Cornell was enriched by $111,000 today. President Farrand announced an anonymous gift, without restriction, of $110,000, and $1,000 from the Procter Gamble Co. of Cincinnati for a chemistry fellowship.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- By a standing vote of 161 to 90, the House passed and sent to the Senate today the "Scissors Substitute" Guffey Coal Stabilization Bill, from which the labor provisions of the original measure invalidated by the Supreme Court last month were deleted.
The golden stream of the bonus began to trickle into the channels of trade yesterday as a few veterans who had their bonds certified early Monday received the government's checks in the day's mail.

A prisoner who escaped from police headquarters, apparently by the simple procedure of walking out of the front entrance, was the object of a city-wide hunt last night when an alarm to all precincts was sent over the police teletype system at 6 P.M.

LONDON, June 16 (AP). -- Gene Mako of Los Angeles, a member of the unsuccessful United States Davis Cup team, was eliminated today in the second round of the Queens Club tennis tournament by G.R.B. Meredith, a Leicester County player. 6 -- 4. 5 -- 7, 6 -- 4.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- A protective committee for holders of bonds of Wesleyan College, Macon, Ga., old educational institution under the control of the Southern Methodist Church, has filed under the Securities Act of 1933 for the deposit of $1,000,000 of first and closed mortgage 5 1/2 per cent serial gold bonds, of which $998,000 is outstanding.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- Even a cursory examination of the Industrial-Agrarian-Borah compromise which is the Republican platform produces the strong impression that no President elected upon it, even as publicly amended by Governor Landon, can discharge its final requirement that candidates shall be true to the outlined program "as a matter of private honor and public faith." The contradictions are too many.

It is painful to have to record that the President has again treated important appointments to the Federal courts as if they were ordinary partisan spoils. He has nominated two men for the two new Federal judgeships recently created in this district who may be well known as politicians but are certainly little known as lawyers.

Andre Jessurun, 148, Bronx welterweight, defeated Sonny Jones, 142 1/2, Canadian, in the main ten-round bout at the new Queensboro Arena, Long Island City, last night before 3,000 persons. The card was sponsored by the printing, publishing, paper and allied trades, part of the proceeds going to the joint distribution committee.

One of the most interesting phases of the investigation of the lower Hudson watershed by the Biological Survey of the New York Conservation Department is the study of sturgeon. Once so numerous as to gain the appellation "Albany beef," the sea sturgeon as a fisheries resource has dwindled to the vanishing point.

President Frederick B. Robinson's name was booed and hissed last night at the traditional "Numeral Lights" festivities on the City College campus, where 3,000 graduates and their friends gathered for the open-air celebration which marked the beginning of commencement week.

BOSTON, June 16. -- Leading the field from flagfall to finish, Breckenridge Long's Legume, chestnut son of Epinard, today entered the winner's circle in the mile and a sixteenth handicap, feature of the second day of the Suffolk Downs meeting.

HAVERFORD, Pa., June 16 (AP). -- Miss Helen Pedersen of Stamford, Conn., the defending champion, won three matches today in the annual Pennsylvania and Eastern States women's tennis tourney and gained the fourth round.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 16. -- The estate of John Bishop, an attorney, of this city, who died March 2, has been valued at $1,300,969.70, according to an inventory placed on record today at the office of Surrogate Frank A. Connolly.

John J. Halleran, Queens Public Works Commissioner, who is protesting an award made to him for land taken through condemnation for the World's Fair site, received $147,260 in 1929 through condemnation for six and a half acres which cost him $258 an acre.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- The farm population of the United States as of Jan. 1, 1935, was 31,800,907, the Bureau of the Census announced today, and was the largest ever recorded, exceeding the farm population as of April 1, 1930, by 1,356,557 persons.

A protest against the provisions of the Healy bill, fixing maximum hours and minimum wages for labor on government contracts, has been filed with the Judiciary Committee of the House of Representatives by Walter S. Tower, executive secretary of the American Iron and Steel Institute.

A reduction in the gross bonded debt of 283 cities in the United States and Canada and a corresponding lowering of the weighted average per capita gross debt in those cities in 1935, were shown in the annual review of municipal indebtedness prepared by C.E. Rightor of Dun Bradstreet, Inc., for the National Municipal Review, published by the National Municipal League.
Forty-five women and twenty-eight men will receive diplomas tonight at the commencement of the Savage School for Physical Education at Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street.

Thirty-seven large laundry concerns of New York, whose gross business per year amounts to between $30,000,000 and $35,000,000, announced yesterday that they had agreed to pay their employes at the rate of 31 cents an hour for a forty-hour week, the terms specified by the invalidated New York State Minimum Wage Law for Women and Children.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 16. -- The fourth Westchester all-day fete, sponsored by the Westchester Chapter of the women's division of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies of New York, attracted more than 2,500 persons at the Century Country Club here today.

An active market, especially in the renting of stores, was reported by brokers yesterday. Numerous leases were reported in the Garment Center area, although other sections were also well represented. Chain store organizations were prominent among the lessees and large space was contracted for in some instances.

Stockholders of Paramount Pictures, Inc., yesterday elected five new directors, but failed to re-elect as a director John E. Otterson, president, who went to the company last year soon after its financial reorganization.

CHICAGO, June 16. -- The defeat of the No. 2 seeded star, J. Gilbert Hall of South Orange, N.J., and the steady advance of the tournament favorite, Frankie Parker of Milwaukee and Lawrenceville, N.J., featured today's play in the national clay court championship at the River Forest Tennis Club.
PARIS, June 16. -- Premier Leon Blum warned an excited and critical Senate tonight that forced devaluation might be the answer to failure of his "spending" remedy or France.
How much longer must we submit to conditions that make the once-despised subway a blessed retreat from discomfort, impertinence, probably bodily injury and lack of ventilation?

PORTLAND, Me., June 16 (AP). -Two candidates in Maine's primary elections endorsed either by the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin's organization or that of Dr. F.E. Townsend won nominations on the basis of unofficial tabulations nearing completion today, while four others so endorsed had been rejected by the voters.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., June 16. -- High-goal poloists, kept idle by rain and wet fields the past several days, participated in two round-robin events sponsored by the Meadow Brook Club today at the J.S. Phipps estate.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

DETROIT, June 16 (AP). -- The Tigers lost their fourth consecutive game today when pinch-batter Carl Reynolds blasted a tenth-inning home run with two mates on the bases to give the Senators a 9-to-8 victory.

The great day is at hand. This morning W.C. Fields returns to his colony of admirers in "Poppy," at the Paramount. The picture is based on the play of the same name, in which W.C. achieved his first stage success years ago. Others in the cast are Rochelle Hudson, Lynn Overman, Catherine Doucet and Rosalind Keith.

President ROOSEVELT at Vincennes told again the thrilling story of how GEORGE ROGERS CLARK won the Northwest Territory for the infant American nation. Mr. ROOSEVELT then went on to deplore the prodigal manner in which the American people have administered this magnificent heritage.

The business of A. Iselin Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange and one of the oldest of Wall Street firms, is to be merged about July 22 with Dominick Dominick, also members of the Exchange, it was announced yesterday.

The Himation hurdle race, second event on yesterday's program at Aqueduct, saw the 7-5 favorite, Jungle Dawn, fall when in front at the final fence and suffer a broken neck; another jumper, Funny Bone, fall, break a leg and be destroyed; two horses leave the course and the event end in a dead heat.

Grave news reached us recently from Palestine, where a veritable reign of terror was caused by Arabs in their attacks upon Jews. The British authorities, until recently, were unable or unwilling to adopt the proper stringent measures to protect the several Jewish colonies.

The board of directors of the Association of National Advertisers, acting upon the recommendations of the government relations committee of the organization, has gone on record as being opposed to any State bill which would have mandatory State registration of trademarks for revenue only, upon penalty of the loss of common-law rights therein.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 16. -- Three of the leading contenders for intercollegiate rowing honors swept downstream over the Hudson today. The Navy and Cornell varsities went the four-mile distance for the first time since they pitched camp here.

The names of a number of persons widely known in Brooklyn political circles or notorious in the underworld were mentioned in the Drukman conspiracy trial yesterday when a wire-tapping police detective repeated conversations he said he overheard between two of the accused conspirators.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- Representatives of the Army Engineers, the Army Air Corps and the Department of Commerce, testifying before the Senate Committee on Military Affairs today, contended that Governors Island is not suitable for an airport and that the plan advocated by Mayor La Guardia would produce a marine hazard.

FRESH from the success of "Personal History," Vincent Sheean has turned to non-personal history, to a novel of Bourbon Naples in 1799 entitled "Sanfelice" (Doubleday, Doran, $2.50). It is the Book Union selection for July.

Robert E. Gross, president and treasurer of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, told stockholders yesterday in connection with the issuance of the balance sheet of April 30 that orders on hand on June 12, amounting to $630,000, would keep the present plant operating at capacity for some time.

Because of governmental red tape and too rigid architectural specifications for low-cost housing, building contractors of this city have informed the Public Works Administration that few bids would be made for the widely heralded $12,333,000 Williamsburg slum clearance project.

Frederic A. Ley, son of Fred T. Ley, skyscraper builder, has purchased forty-two lots on the northeast corner of Bayside Avenue and Union Street, Flushing, from the Bel Building Corporation, for developing with six and seven room houses and garages, it was announced yesterday.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, June 16. -The strike situation is serious at Liege and Mons, according to reports received here tonight. Although demonstrations and street gatherings are forbidden, there were attempts at Liege to organize processions.

HONOLULU, June 16. -- Twenty-five thousand troops of the Hawaiian Department marched into field positions today as the annual June manoeuvres started under the direction of Major General Hugh A. Drum. Orders that sent the first units on the way to the positions they will occupy to repulse a hypothetical enemy were issued by General Drum from department headquarters at 2 o'clock this morning.

Village elections in Suffolk County yesterday were marked by a contest in Ocean Beach. In East Hampton a last minute write-in vote gave a number of votes to candidates of the Home Town party who officially withdrew from the campaign last week.

An extraordinary series of coincidences attending the murder Monday morning in East Orange, N.J., of Daniel McFarlan Moore, eminent engineer, and the suicide yesterday of Jean Philip Gebhardt at New Monmouth, N.J., has caused the authorities to center the murder investigation on the suicide.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- An application for authority to sell $15,300,000 serial notes, dated July 15, 1936, and maturing serially, $1,530,000 annually, from July 15, 1937, to July 15, 1946, was filed today by the Chesapeake Ohio Railway Company with the Interstate Commerce Commission.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 16. -More than 4,000 Harvard alumni, about 600 graduating seniors and 5,000 guests will participate tomorrow afternoon in the colorful class day exercises which will close the social activities of Harvard University's 300th year.

On the heels of a declaration here yesterday by the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin that by Friday night there might be a third-party candidate for the Presidency, announcement was made at the Chicago headquarters of the Townsend plan of a "united front" of the supporters of Representative William Lemke of North Dakota, the Detroit priest's National Union for Social Justice, the Townsendites and the share-the-wealth movement.
Villages in Nassau County held elections for Mayor, trustees and other town offices yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, June 16 (AP). -- The Browns opened a long home stay in defeat today, bowing to the Athletics, 9 to 4. St. Louis got away to a 4-0 lead, but Jack Knott was unable to hold it and his successors, Hogsett, Andrews and Mahaffey, also were touched briskly.

MOSCOW, June 16. -- The Soviet Government has just taken the unusual step of paying by Oct. 1 the sum of $10,000,000 (at present Swedish exchange values) to the great Swedish electric firm Asea, although by the terms of the agreement the final payment was not due until 1948.

Republican leaders in New York are awaiting the arrival of John D.M. Hamilton, national chairman, to straighten out a tangle which has developed over direction of the New York State drive for the Landon-Knox ticket.
TOPEKA, June 16 (AP). -- So much company came to the buff-brick executive residence of Governor Landon for luncheon today that Mrs. Landon was forced to press three card tables into service.

CHICAGO, June 16 (AP). -- Two long home runs by Jimmy Foxx, his fifteenth and sixteenth of the season, were not enough against the White Sox today as Chicago pounded Bob Grove from the mound and beat Boston, 4 to 2.
Books by President Roosevelt already have become collectors items, according to an article by Frederick B. Adams Jr. in the Spring number of The Colophon, a Quarterly for Booklovers, published today.

In driving about New York I have been seriously perplexed as to the location of traffic signals. When they are placed at the curb line they are lost in the glare from advertising signs. On busy streets such as Eighth Avenue the driver should be able to glance up at any time and spot the traffic signal without diverting his attention from the car and jay-walkers about him.

CHICAGO, June 16. -- Coincident with Father Coughlin's disclosure in New York today of his plans to support a third party Presidential nominee, announcement was made here of a "united front" of the Detroit priest's National Union of Social Justice, the Townsendites, the share-the-wealth movement and the supporters of Congressman William Lemke of North Dakota.
MANILA, June 16. -- A woman ruled the warlike Moros today after stepping temporarily into the position left vacant by the death of Sultan Jamalu'l Kiram and blocking the selection of a new Sultan.
PHILADELPHIA, June 16. -- Police put up their barriers today against unwelcome visitors during the Democratic National Convention next week.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- Dis play Products, Inc., of Detroit filed today under the Securities Exchange Act for 50,000 shares of Class A non-voting common stock, par value $5. The issuer manufactures advertising display signs and devices.

Passengers aboard the Lake Cities Express of the Erie Railroad, bound from Jersey City to Cleveland, were shaken but uninjured last night when the engine and first cars of the train jumped the track about 9:15 o'clock at Paterson, N.J.

ROCHESTER, June 16. -- A new "birth certificate" for the earth, which fixes the time of its "creation" from the bowels of the flaming sun at a period dating back 2,500,000,000 years, was described here today at the Summer meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, by Drs. T.R. Wilkins and W.M. Rayton of the University of Rochester.

PHILADELPHIA, June 16. -- A change in plans which will result in the nomination of President Roosevelt on Friday evening, June 26, instead of a day earlier, was announced today by W. Forbes Morgan, secretary of the Democratic National Committee, as he made public the program of the national convention.
PARIS, June 16. -- A historic emerald collection has been sold by Ganna Walska, opera singer, to Countess Barbara Hutton Haugwitz-Reventlow for $1,200,000, the newspaper Paris-Midi said tonight.
TOKYO, June 16. -- Interviewed by the press before he left for China today, Ambassador Shigeru Kawagoe advocated Japanese economic assistance to China, but limited it to the North.

Oscar W. Ehrhorn, referee in bankruptcy for the International Match Corporation, approved yesterday the sale of European assets of International Match and its subsidiary, Continental Investment A.G., to the Swedish Match Company for $8,500,000.

A record total of 2,147 degrees, diplomas and commissions will be conferred tonight at the ninetieth City College commencement exercises in Lewisohn Stadium, 137th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. More than 17,000 parents and friends of the graduates are expected to witness the open-air ceremonies, which will begin at 8 o'clock with an academic procession along the campus.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- The court fight of 434 railroad enterprises against the railroad retirement legislation of 1936 approached its close today in the District of Columbia Supreme Court as final arguments of counsel were begun before Justice Jennings Bailey.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- The New York Edison Company, Inc., wholly-owned subsidiary of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, in filing under the Securities Act of 1933 today for the registration of $30,000,000 first lien and refunding mortgage 3 1/4 per cent bonds, Series E, due April 1, 1966, stated that it would file a post-effective amendment.

Mrs. Harry Payne Whitney will be the sculptor of the statue of Peter Stuyvesant that is to be placed in Stuyvesant Square, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. A. Barton Hepburn, chairman of a committee of women that is cooperating with the Netherland-American Foundation in the project.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP). -Representatives of the radio industry were told today that television would not be ready for the public for several years and the home sets, when perfected, would cost about as much as the popular automobile.

After a demonstration yesterday at City Hall, thirty-two new pieces of fire apparatus costing almost $500,000 were accepted and put into service by Mayor La Guardia and Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 16. -The forty-fourth annual New Jersey men's singles tennis championship and the ninth annual women's Eastern clay court championship got under way today at the Montclair Athletic Club courts after being delayed by rain.

Moderate improvement in prices spread over a wide area in the bond market yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The trading pace, at the same time, was stepped up considerably with total transactions reaching $10,814,300, compared to $8,238,500 on Monday.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- Representatives of twelve States having minimum wage laws for women decided today at a conference called by Secretary Perkins that efforts should be continued to protect the health and well-being of women workers in their States under their minimum wage laws.

MADRID, June 16. -- Thirty-six Catholic churches were burned and thirty-four others were seriously damaged by fire set by rioters and terrorists in the last forty-eight hours, according to charges by Jose Maria Gil Robles, leader of the Catholic Popular Action party, in the Cortes tonight.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 16. -Bachelor of Arts degrees will be conferred on eighty-nine members of the graduating class of Adelphi College and one Master of Arts degree will be awarded at the fortieth annual commencement of the school tomorrow morning at 10:30 o'clock in the recreation building.

By their very nature, facts about unemployment cannot be established through a census. This archaic method of counting noses is so cumbersome and slow that before the figures are compiled and made available the situation may be radically changed. What then becomes necessary is to use the census figures as a "base" on top of which must be piled mathematical equations and percentages in order to guess the changed situation.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- The drive to adjourn Congress by the end of this week gained force today when conferees reached agreement on the work-relief appropriation and a compromise on the Tax Bill came into sight.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- As one of his last official acts as Federal Coordinator of Transportation, Joseph B. Eastman, a member of the Interstate Commerce Commission, has sent to Senator Wheeler, chairman of the Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce, a list of seven additional railroad systems whose affairs he felt the committee should include in the inquiry that it is now conducting under a Senate resolution.

A study of Women's Court procedure led a committee of the Welfare Council to conclude yesterday that "sympathetic social treatment" would prove more effective than criminal prosecution in meeting the problem of prostitution.
ST. PAUL, June 16 (AP). -- Republicans rejoiced in their biggest primary vote since 1930 with tabulations of yesterday's primary contest, which sped Governor Olson's hope to enter the Senate.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., June 16 (AP). -- State investigators sought today from foreign-born residents of near-by mill communities information which they hoped would help them solve several suspected slayings for insurance.

Two plots containing about 12,000 square feet at Riverside Drive and Seventy-third Street have been sold by the Booth Estates, which held the property for thirty-five years, to a syndicate headed by Aaron Simon.

BERLIN, June 16. -- Danzig's National Socialist Government, which rules the Free City under a democratic constitution guaranteed by the League of Nations has decreed a State funeral tomorrow for Guenther Deskowski, a Storm Trooper who was killed during an attack on opponents of the National Socialist party.
Value of Dollar in Exchange { The dollar on the local foreigna exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on theI dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- A contract for seventy-seven single-seater pursuit airplanes and for parts equivalent to eight planes was awarded by the War Department today to the Seversky Aircraft Corporation of Farmingdale, L.I., at a cost of $1,636,250. The award was made after extensive tests in competition with other planes at Wright Field, Ohio.

The upward movement in prices on the Cotton Exchange made further headway yesterday, and at the close showed an improvement of 6 to 11 points. The rise brought the list into new high ground, with October selling at 11.29 Cents a pound, or within a point of 1 1/2 cents above the low records of the last few months.

BUCHAREST, June 16. -- "If other countries knew their aims and intentions as fully as we, Europe could be quiet," King Carol said in an interview here today in speaking of his conference with Dr. Eduard Benes, President of Czechoslovakia, and Prince Paul, First Regent of Yugoslavia.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP). -- A Democratic chant of "Twelve Long, Weary, Tragic Years" under Republican rule was heard in the Senate today as an echo to the Republican convention theme song of "Three Long Years" under the New Deal.

The newly reorganized Universal Pictures Corporation will produce forty-two feature films during the 1936-37 season, it was announced yesterday at the Hotel Astor, where the company is holding its first annual sales convention since Carl Laemmle sold to interests headed by R.H. Cochrane and J. Cheever Cowdin.

Marked increases in the carrying of motor cars for passengers traveling to foreign ports have been noted on practically all ship lines this year. New records have been established due to improvements in the international agreements which govern motoring abroad and in the ability of the ship lines to handle automobiles.
ALBANY, June 16 (AP). -- The State Department of Education granted today a limited stay, restraining the New York City Board of Education from filling sixty-three vacancies for teachers.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 16. -With traditional pomp and ceremony the graduating exercises of Yale College, the Sheffield Scientific School and the School of Engineering of Yale University were held this morning in Woolsey Hall. Seven hundred students ended their undergraduate days and received their diplomas.

ALBANY, June 16 (AP). -- A movement to draft Governor Lehman for a third term took definite shape tonight under the direction of John E. Mack of Poughkeepsie, former Supreme Court justice, and Morris P. Davidson of New York.

NAPANOCH, N.Y., June 16. -With an outburst of savage fighting fury Max Schmeling today ended six weeks of preparation for his scheduled fifteen-round bout with Joe Louis at the Yankee Stadium Thursday night.
BOSTON, June 16 (AP). -- Tiny Jim Chaplin, the Bees' elongated pitcher, beat the Cardinals, 10 to 4, to open a seventeen-game home stay today.

GRAYVILLE, Ill., June 16. -- With the assurance of past experiences, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt went down today into another coal mine -- the New Orient at West Frankfort, world's largest bituminous colliery, which holds the hoisting record of 15,318 tons in an eight-hour day.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- Senator Borah indicated today that he would seek re-election to the Senate from Idaho although he declined to announce his political plans or reveal whether he would support the Republican national ticket.
PITTSBURGH, June 16. -- The steel industry is preparing to announce a 10 per cent wage increase affecting its 500,000 employes, it was reported in steel circles today.

The second attempt within a week to terrorize electrical workers employed on the Triborough Bridge occurred yesterday with the kidnapping and subsequent release of William Nielsen, 41 years old, of 196-27 Foothill Terrace, Hollis, Queens.
ROME, June 16. -- The news that the British Cabinet decided to reverse its policy on sanctions was received here with satisfaction but without enthusiasm.
LONDON, June 16 (Canadian Press). -- Defeating Somerset by six wickets for the second time this season, Kent pulled away from its chief rivals for the county cricket championship today.
LONDON, June 16. -- Sir Samuel Hoare's accession as First Lord of the Admiralty has been quickly followed by reports of an extension of Great Britain's battleship building program.

BOSTON, June 16. -- The revelation was made here today that some 50,000 "Roosevelt nominator" tickets had been dumped into the Federal Building, with all employes being urged to sell the tickets at $1 each.

Forced upward by the flight of capital from Continental Europe to London, the pound sterling yesterday rose to $5.04 1/4, the highest price since Aug. 29, 1934, and closed at $5.03 15-16, up 1/8 cent from the previous day. The advance here was largely a reflection of movements taking place abroad.
NEWARK, N.J., June 16. -- The Bears completed a long home stay tonight by dividing a double-header with the Buffalo Bisons, their closest rivals in the International League race.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- The White House announced that President Roosevelt had signed forty-one bills, including the Commodity Exchange Control Bill and the Overton Flood Control Bill. The President nominated Robert E. Healy for reappointment to the Securities and Exchange Commission, conferred with Postmaster General Farley and held his regular press conference.

James J. Walker, former Mayor of New York, with Mrs. Walker; Rabbi and Mrs. Stephen S. Wise, Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve of Barnard College and Ely Culbertson, bridge expert, are among the persons sailing this morning for Europe on the French liner Normandie.

In his speech at Dallas the President declared that "if labor is to be a com"modity in the United States * * * it "means that we shall become a nation "of boarding houses instead of a na"tion of homes." The statement that labor is not or should not be a commodity has been familiar for many years.

LONDON, June 16. -- Earl Stanhope, Parliamentary Under Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, figured in two government announcements tonight. One was his appointment as First Commissioner of Works, with Cabinet rank, succeeding William Ormsby-Gore, who replaced J.H. Thomas as Colonial Secretary.
MEMPHIS, June 16 (AP). -- Authorities received reports today of three floggings in the Eastern Arkansas area where cotton workers are on strike.

Fewer than 3,500 fans gave the Dodgers a mixed welcome at Ebbets Field yesterday as they faced the Pirates to start their long home stand, but before the afternoon's sport had ended the cheers were completely drowned out by jeers as the Bucs came from behind to win, 9 -- 2.

NORFOLK, Va., June 16 (AP). -- Virginia Democrats, in an enthusiastic convention, today instructed the State's twenty-two votes for the renomination of President Roosevelt, and commended both national and State administrations.
By unanimous vote the Board of Aldermen branch of the Municipal Assembly decided yesterday to grant eight-hour working days to employes in city hospitals.

BUENOS AIRES, June 16. -- Well informed sources close to the Foreign Office expect Argentina to take the leadership in the League of Nations Assembly in refusing to recognize the annexation of Ethiopia by Italy.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., June 16. -- More than 1,500 delegates, augmented by missionaries who came to deliver their messages from all parts of the world, gathered at Mount Holyoke College today for the opening of the eight-day session of the General Council of Congregational and Christian Churches of the United States.

DETROIT, June 16 (AP). -- A drive to purge public payrolls of all members of the Black Legion was begun today in three communities, including Highland Park, where an official described the situation as "the most serious in the city's history."

Representatives of educational institutions who expect to join in the celebration of the 550th anniversary of the University of Heidelberg in Germany were criticized yesterday at the fifth annual commencement exercises of Yeshiva College for condoning Germany's "dying academic freedom" through their participation.

LONDON, June 16. -- Trading on the London Stock Exchange was generally quiet today, with prices irregular at the finish. British funds weakened further. Foreign bonds were less firm, although Far Easterns were well maintained.

Although it is a volume of poetry and was published only two days ago, the first and second editions of Stephen Vincent Benet's "Burning City," have been exhausted and the third printing is now on the press, Farrar Rinehart report.

CLEVELAND, June 16. -- A number of notable events came to pass today that should have sent the front-running Yankees off to a gaudy start on their second swing around the western half of the American League.

Mrs. Vincent Astor, acting president of the Musicians Emergency Fund, yesterday reported that 137 musicians were receiving assistance weekly from her organization and that 2,674 other artists were recipients of intermittent aid. Mrs. Astor made her announcement at the annual meeting of the board of directors of the organization at the Steinway Building, 113 West Fiftyseventh Street.
The Erie P. Railroad reported yesterday for May and the first five months of the year increases in gross and net operating income over a year before. Its statement follows:

PARIS, June 16. -- The action to be taken by Great Britain's Cabinet tomorrow is awaited here with concern, not so much because there is any strong opposition in France against the removal of sanctions against Italy, but because of the effect this may have on the future European situation.
URBANA, Ill., June 16 (AP). -Joseph B. Eastman, Federal Coordinator of Transportation, today expressed the view that government regulation eventually would extend to all forms of transportation.

A banking group headed by Lehman Brothers obtained the award yesterday of a new issue of $5,010,000 of the City of Camden, N.J., refunding bonds at a price of 92 for 4s, affording an interest cost to the city of 4.307 per cent. The sale of these bonds represents the completion of the first phase of the city's plan to convert its floating debt into long-term serial form.

Bondholders yesterday took over, at an upset price of $717,500, the Lewis Morris apartment house in the Bronx. The structure is thirteen stories high at the northwest corner of Grand Concourse and Clifford Place and extends back to a height of seventeen stories on Walton Avenue.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 16. -Forty-eight Harvard seniors who will be graduated Thursday with high honors were elected members of Phi Beta Kappa today. They were:

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 16. -- Sixty-eight members of the New York Athletic Club took part in the club's second golf tourney of the season at the North Hempstead Country Club today. William V. (Bill) McCarthy, baseball coach at New York University, led the way in the nine-hole qualifying round this morning with a 41.

ALBANY, June 16 (AP). -- A representative of Dairy Sealed, Inc., distributor of milk in paper containers, admitted at public hearing today that the company had paid 2 per cent discounts for cash to various chain stores.

To ease the minds of those officials of film companies who have hesitated to back stage productions under the terms of the new basic agreement between managers and playwrights, the joint advisory committee of the two groups met on Monday and decided that the instructions to the negotiator covering the sale of film rights to a filmbacked play shall be those in effect at the time such backing is disclosed to the negotiator.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 16. -- In a setting of green flecked with silvery sunlight, Princeton University held its 189th annual commencement exercises on the lawn in front of historic Nassau Hall this morning. In striking contrast with the rainy weather that had prevailed at the two prior commencements a perfect June day heightened the colorful pageantry dictated by academic tradition.

In a brief filed yesterday with the Public Service Commission and the Transit Commission, as a climax to hearings over an application for an increase in commutation fares on the Long Island Railroad, the Association of Long Island Commuters accuses the Pennsylvania Railroad, owner of the Long Island, of using its subsidiary "for selfish purposes."

Successful completion of the initial distribution of the $65,000,000 of Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit Corporation rapid transit collateral trust 4 1/2 per cent bonds due on May 1, 1966, was announced last night by Hayden, Stone Co., Brown Harriman Co., Inc., and Lazard Freres Co., Inc., managers of the banking group that offered the issue.

WARSAW, June 16. -- Alarming reports of a new wave of terrorism in Danzig stronger than ever before reached Warsaw today. Not only members of the opposition to the Nazi regime but also Polish-speaking persons have been among Storm Troopers' victims.

Sixty-four graduates of Cornell University Medical College will receive their degrees this afternoon at the thirty-eighth commencement exercises at the college, 1,300 York Avenue. The exercises will begin at 4 o'clock.

TRENTON, N.J., June 16. -- Carl K. Withers, State Banking Commissioner, announced today a net saving of 34.8 per cent in general administration expenses in connection with liquidation of insurance companies taken over by the State. Credit for the saving was given to the Division of Conservation of the department, in which administration of the liquidating work has been centralized.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 16. -- The method under which Percy C. Reed, proprietor of the Nassau Kennel Club, conducts dog races on the track at the Mineola Fair Grounds was upheld in a decision filed here today by Supreme Court Justice Paul Bonynge.

The world economic situation brightened somewhat during April, according to the monthly review of foreign conditions in The Annalist of June 19. Industrial activity expanded generally, international trade rose in response, and surplus commodity stocks tended to decline further.

The Nassau County Horticultural Society's annual Sweet Pea and Rose Show opened at 2 P.M. yesterday at the Horticultural Society of New York, 598 Madison Avenue. Among the hundreds of varieties of all types of flowers were two Golden Orb lilies, said to be the only ones in America, and a native Baghdad plant brought to the United States by J.P. Morgan.

LONG BEACH, L.I., June 17. -- With a flash of form reminiscent of the days when he reigned as United States amateur champion, George T. Dunlap Jr. of Pomonok raced home in 34 at the Lido Country Club today to gain the qualifying medal in the thirty-sixth metropolitan amateur golf championship.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- Management and labor in the cloak and suit industry agreed to cooperate in a program designed to stimulate the market for the industry's product, with consequent increased production and broader distribution, at the closing session today of a two-day meeting of the National Cloak and Suit Industry Recovery Board.

NASSAU, Bahamas. June 17. -- The trawler Girl Pat, which is believed to have been wrecked on a cay northwest of Silver Bank, left Grimsby, England, April 2, presumably bound for the North Sea fishing banks but fled southward. The owners filed charges of barratry and underwriters' agents in many ports were ordered to watch for her.

Ruth Weston, John Williams and Louis Hector will have the leading roles in "Eastward Ho!" which will be tried out at the Greenwich (Conn.) Playhouse on July 7. . . . Henry Hull will appear next week in the production of "Springtime for Henry" at the Theatre of the Four Seasons in Roslyn, L.I. . . .

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP). -- Abandonment of efforts to broadcast to the United States the story of the sun's eclipse from Kustanai, Russia, tomorrow night was announced today by the National Geographic Society.

The Four Aces, one of the foremost contract bridge teams in the country, are now only three. The captain of the team, Michael T. Gottlieb, has been deposed for "unsound bidding theories contrary to the Four Aces system,'' according to a statement yesterday by the remaining three members, David Burnstine, Oswald Jacoby and Howard Schenken.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 17. -- Miss Josephine Roche, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, emphasizing the fresh equipment for leadership and the young idealism of college graduates, today appealed to them to join the older persons who are striving to break down barriers in order to build "a new order of the ages," as conceived by Thomas Jefferson, Benjamin Franklin and John Adams.

CHICAGO, June 17 -- Frankie Parker, first seeded star from Milwaukee and Lawrenceville, N.J., gave a sample of his best form today as he trounced Thane Halsted of Chicago to lead the way into the quarter-finals of the national clay court tennis championship. Parker won at 6 -- 0, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 1.

With Police Commissioner Valentine as their first witness, the five men on trial in Brooklyn began yesterday, through counsel, the task of refuting or explaining the testimony of the 103 persons called by the State in its attempt to convict them of conspiring to corrupt justice in the Samuel Drukman murder case.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- The question of what, if anything, shall be said in the Democratic platform about government control of agricultural production is causing concern among managers of the New Deal farm program. While some officials think it would be politically unwise to mention the subject, in view of the Supreme Court's condemnation of the policy, others feel that to follow such a course would amount to repudiation of what has been done.

BOSTON, June 17 (AP). -- The Cards came to life in the second game of a double-header today and whipped the Bees, 10 to 2, after losing the first two games of the series. The Bees took this afternoon's opener, 9 to 6.

CLEVELAND, June 17. -- It is quite possible you could have knocked the Indians over with a feather today. So one can readily imagine what suffering a fine midweek crowd of 22,000 Clevelanders endured as the Yanks swung from their heels and inflicted two terrific thrashings upon Steve O'Neill's hapless Tribe, all for the price of a single admission.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- Postmaster General Farley denied today that he had written, or had anything to do with, a form letter alleged to have been sent to postmasters over his signature asking them to contribute to Democratic campaign funds.

NAPANOCH, N.Y., June 17. -- Max Schmeling enjoyed complete ease today. Secluded in the deep woods, four miles from his training center, the German ex-heavyweight champion passed the time idly in the company of his trainer, Max Machon, and his close friend, Otto Petri.

Senator Borah's sudden and dramatic revival of the monopoly issue may, of course, end with the campaign as it has in the past, notably in 1912. To Senator Borah it may be said that there are times when it is vastly more important to be right than to be President.
The preamble to the Republican platform reads: "The integrity and authority of the Supreme Court have been flaunted."

Professor Casey Stengel saw little to make him glad on the recent Western tour, but nothing he witnessed on that disastrous invasion was comparable to the defeat administered to his Dodgers by the Pirates at Ebbets Field yesterday.

" The tuna are in!" was the exciting message broadcast by skippers along the Jersey coast yesterday. Here is news for which thousands of salt water anglers have been waiting. For, with the possible exception of the bluefish, there is no species more popular with the offshore fishing devotees of this area than the school tuna.

After little debate worthy of the name, the House at the end of April passed one of the worst revenue bills in its history. The corporation tax embodied in that bill was so badly drawn, so ludicrously complicated, that it did not find a single supporter in the Senate. Even those who favored the principle of a corporation tax solely on undistributed profits could not stomach it in that form.

Eight witnesses, including Joseph Paresi, delegate of Local 27 of the Paper Box Drivers, Chauffeurs and Helpers Union, appeared yesterday' in response to subpoenas, when a special Federal grand jury began an investigation of alleged racketeering in the paper box manufacturing industry.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., June 17. -- Adoption of pension and retirement provisions constituted the important business today of the biennial session of the General Council of Congregational and Christian Churches of the United States at Mount Holyoke College.
The French liner Normandie sailed thirty minutes late yesterday after waiting for several passengers who were delayed by late trains and heavy traffic in the city.

Arrangements for the sale to a large institutional investor of $10,000,000 of 3 per cent ten-year debentures at par by the International Business Machines Corporation was announced yesterday by Thomas J. Watson, president of the Corporation.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP). -- tation in the New York City area The Armstrong system of radio transmission and reception, which apparently eliminated all static and outside interference, was demonstrated today before several hundred representatives of the radio industry.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- The deadlock among Senate and House conferees on the Tax Bill was broken at a night session tonight, and a tentative agreement was reached. Details of the agreement were withheld, but Representative Doughton, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, announced that the bill would be "turned over to the drafters tomorrow."

The city of Manchester, N.H., has invited tenders for a new issue of $500,000 of short-term notes, award of which will be made on June 25. The notes will be dated June 25 and will become payable on Feb. 18 and March 18, 1937.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 17. -- The names of thirty members of the New York State National Guard chosen as the Governor's honor men, a rating established by Governor Lehman in 1933, were announced today by Lieut. Col. Henry E. Sauvet, Camp Smith executive officer.

In the July issue of Foreign Affairs, published today, Mr. HAROLD NICOLSON asks the question, "Has Britain a Policy?" The very terms of his title imply the period of uncertainty and bewilderment following the complete defeat of British foreign policy by MUSSOLINI. This Mr. NICOLSON admits in unqualified language.

GLEN COVE, L.I., June 17. -- President Harold W. Dodds of Princeton University will be among the guests at the first annual outing and dinner of the Princeton Club of Nassau County, which will be held here Friday at the Nassau Country Club.
PARIS, June 17 (AP). -- France may send a semi-official envoy to Washington to discuss currency stabilization and war debts, reports circulated in the Chamber of Deputies said today.

A fake charity ring using high pressure methods to garner at least $600 a day for months is under investigation. The police, the District Attorneys of Brooklyn and Manhattan, and Public Welfare and postal officials are cooperating in an effort to this drain from stop legitimate charities.

The 1936 fund-raising campaign of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee ended officially yesterday, with contributions totaling $1,363,812 reported. The goal of $1,500,000 was not reached, but Laurence M. Marks, chairman, announced at a final report luncheon at the Hotel Biltmore that active solicitation would continue for several weeks.
Discovery and Airflame won for Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt at Aqueduct yesterday to give him a double which carried with it far more satisfaction than was represented by the value of the purses.
ASCOT, England, June 17. -- William Woodward's Omaha, great-hearted son of Gallant Fox, tomorrow will bid for the Ascot Gold Cup, a turf will-o'-the-wisp no American-owned thoroughbred ever has won.

The waters of New York Harbor show a worse state of pollution when inspected at first hand than was expected from studies, in the opinion of the sanitation committee and other members of the New York State Chamber of Commerce who toured the harbor and East River yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, June 17 (AP). -- The rampaging Cubs made it thirteen straight by defeating the Phillies, 5 -- 3, today.

LONDON, June 17. -- The British Cabinet held today its most decisive meeting since that golden Summer day last August when it decided to impose economic sanctions against Italy and rush the home fleet into the Mediterranean.
Approval of the lease conveying the Flushing Meadows site for the 1939 World's Fair from the city to the World's Fair Corporation was voted yesterday by the Sinking Fund Commission.
Police Commissioner Lewis S. Valentine last night announced six auto routes to the Yankee Stadium , which are deemed practical in di[recting traffic to the arena from !various parts of the city.
BERLIN, June 17 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of June 15 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

At a hearing before Federal Judge Murray Hulbert yesterday attorneys informed the court of a tentative agreement for the reorganization of the Warner-Quinlan Company, maker of petroleum products, under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act.

SHANGHAI, Thursday, June 18. -It is believed the danger of a civil war has been averted until after the conclusion of the plenary session of the Kuomintang (National People's party), called for Nanking on July 10.

Surrogate James A. Foley signed an order yesterday directing the executors of the estate of Irving I. Bloomingdale to pay unpaid legacies to his first wife, Mrs. Rosalie Bloomingdale, amounting to $40,000; to the merchant's widow, Jeanne Hughes Bloomingdale, $47,000, and income amounting to $10,800 to Donald Bloomingdale, a son by his first marriage.
CHICAGO, June 17. -- Wheat prices were uncertain today, moving within a range of 1 1/2 cents a bushel and closing unchanged to 5/8 cent lower. The volume of trading was moderate.
ASCOT, England, June 17 (Canadian Press). -- Lady Nuttall's 5-year-old chestnut colt, Guinea Gap, 28 to 1, today won the Royal Hunt Cup, second in importance of Royal Ascot's feature races.
WASHINGTON, June 17. -- A request was forwarded today to President Roosevelt by the American Civil Liberties Union asking that the government intervene to investigate the Black Legion.

In direct violation of one of baseball's unwritten laws, Ernie Lombardi, lumbering Cincinnati catcher, cut at the "cripple" -- a three-and-nothing ball -- and the result was disastrous for the Giants yesterday. With two on, Lombardi blasted the pitch into the right-field stands at the Polo Grounds and the Reds had enough runs to carry them to victory.

LONDON, June 17. -- Operations were again quiet today on the London Stock Exchange, although the undertone of prices was firm. British funds were mostly higher under the lead of the war loan. Numerous foreign bonds bettered their positions, Far Easterns recovering further.

PHILADELPHIA, June 17. -- Postmaster General James A. Farley surveyed arrangements for the Democratic National Convention during a six-hour stay in Philadelphia today, approved them enthusiastically and announced that he would return here on Friday to take charge of the national committee's headquarters.

NASSAU, Bahamas, June 17. -- The missing British trawler Girl Pat, which was taken from Grimsby, England, by six fishermen on April 2, is believed to have been wrecked a few days ago on the extreme eastern cay of the Samana group, 300 miles southeast of Nassau, with the loss of all on board.

TRENTON, June 17. -- Bolting a majority caucus decision to pass an election measure, seven Passaic and Union County Republicans friendly to Governor Hoffman joined with the Democratic minority in the Assembly tonight and defeated, 27 to 25, a bill designed to insure "honest elections."

Speakers representing the alumnae and administrative bodies of Hunter College urged the graduating class at a tea yesterday in the Bronx buildings of the college to help the campaign for a new building by joining the Associate Alumnae.

Continuing testimony in his own behalf for the fifth day yesterday, Reginald P. Ray, a vice president of the defunct Westchester Title and Trust Company, denied he had intended to coach or warn Major Gen. John F. O'Ryan, to whom he passed a note last Thursday in Federal Court.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 17. -Yale University concluded its 235th commencement today with the granting of diplomas and certificates to 498 candidates from the graduate and professional schools and the bestowal of eleven honorary degrees.

TOPEKA, June 17. -- The conference here yesterday, in which Governor Alf M. Landon, Colonel Frank Knox and John D.M. Hamilton talked with the officers and executive committee of the Republican National Committee, agreed, it was learned today, that Colonel Knox should do the barnstorming for the ticket and that Governor Landon's formal speeches will be much more limited in number.

A change in the date of a proposed lightweight title bout between Tony Canzoneri, champion, and Lew Ambers, Herkimer, was approved yesterday at the meeting of the State Athletic Commission. The contest, originally scheduled for July 16, now is listed for July 30.

PHILADELPHIA, June 17. -- The Presbyterian Church of America, formed here last week by a group of militant fundamentalist ministers who seceded from the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America, received into membership tonight the Knox Presbyterian Church, the first congregation to affiliate with it.
CHICAGO, June 17 (AP). -- Started off by Jimmy Foxx's seventeenth home run of the season with two men on in the first inning, the Red Sex squared the series today by defeating Chicago, 9 to 4.

Dr. Livingston Farrand, president of Cornell University, conferred degrees on sixty-four graduates at the annual commencement exercises of the Cornell University Medical College, 1,300 York Avenue, yesterday afternoon. He also administered the oath of Hippocrates and announced the winners of eleven prizes.

The directors of the Chase National Bank authorized yesterday the retirement of the bank's entire issue of $50,000,000 of preferred stock, Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the board, announced. The retirement, which had been contemplated some time, will be made entirely out of recoveries realized on assets previously written down.

A benefit outdoor dinner dance and entertainment last night marked the formal opening of the new Promenade Cafe in the lower plaza of Rockefeller Center. Entitled "An Evening Under the Stars," the fete had been arranged for the benefit jointly of the Judson Health Center and Greenwich House.

CHICAGO, June 17. -- Lighter receipts of hogs here today reversed the trend of the market and prices were steady to 10 cents a hundredweight higher. The extreme top, $10.25, was paid for selected light and light butchers, against $10.20 on Tuesday. The average price was $9.75, a gain of 5 cents.
PARIS, June 17. -- Street fighting between Nationalists and Leftists in Marseilles and violence in Algeria darkened the French strike picture today.

ITHACA, N.Y., June, 17. -- The modern structure of bridges, trains, turbines and airplanes "reflect the times in which we are living and the psychology of our day -- romance, speed, activity and accomplishment,'' S.C. Hollister, director of the School of Civil Engineering at Cornell University, told the Alumni Institute today.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., June 17. -- For the second week in succession, Mrs. William R. Kirkland Jr. of Women's National carried off low gross honors in a Women's Long Island Golf Association one-day event, posting a brilliant 89 -- 39 -- 78 to lead a field of forty-eight at the Piping Rock Club today.
ROME, June 17. -- A distinctly more Conciliatory attitude toward the sanctions problem and the League of Nations is discernible in Italian circles today.

Fifteen prominent business men, bankers, clergymen and lawyers met at the Metropolitan Club last night and accepted the invitation of George Gordon Battle to launch the American League for Religious Liberty, an organization of Catholics, Protestants and Jews, with Mr. Battle as president.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., June 17 (AP). -- Chester Davis, retiring farm administrator, attacked today two proposals in the farm plank of the Republican platform.

DETROIT, June 17 (AP). -- Proclamations posted at various points in Detroit's confident Harlem, which is positive of another Joe Louis triumph, today drew the Negro Belt's attention to "victory parties." Approximately 500 Detroit Negroes, departing in motor-car caravans from a drug store headquarters, are expected to see the fight.

Walter Clemens Martin, 49 years old, a former resident of Boston, was sentenced to five years in Sing Sing by Judge Cornelius F. Collins in General Sessions yesterday. Martin, who had a previous record of arrests in Washington and New Hampshire, is wanted in Florida and North Carolina on forgery charges.

LADY HESTER STANHOPE'S search through Europe and the East during the first decades of the nineteenth century for the way of life and the spirit of the century into which she was born, has brought her down through history as the Queen of the Eccentrics. But when all circumstances are considered, as they are in Joan Haslip's "Lady Hester Stanhope" (Stokes, $3), her conduct hardly seems unduly odd.

For the first time since the improvement in prices on the Cotton Exchange began over a month ago, July led the rise yesterday and advanced a dollar a bale to within 5 points of the 12-cent level. Trading was the heaviest for a day, so far this season, with sales of July by the pool estimated as high as 75,000 bales, making nearly 150,000 bales liquidated since Monday morning.

LONDON, June 17 (AP). -- Gerald Stratford of San Francisco reached the quarter-final round of the Queens Club tennis tournament today at the expense of Enrique Maier, Spain's No. 1 ranking player. The score was 6 -- 4, 4 -- 6, 7 -- 5.

Charles (Lucky Luciano) Lucania, the eight men convicted with him and four other figures in the vice ring who pleaded guilty will appear before Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook this morning for sentences on charges of compulsory prostitution.

Whether former Governor Alfred E. Smith will be at the Democratic National Convention as a delegate remained in doubt yesterday. Mr. Smith conferred at his office in the Empire State Building with some of the leaders in the Liberty League.

Arrangement of training facilities and allotment of space and time for practice of the various units of the Olympic team aboard the United States liner Manhattan, on which the American athletes will sail July 15 for the games at Berlin, were settled yesterday.

Prices in the commodity futures markets continued mixed yesterday, The volume of trading increased. Cocoa and September sugar contracts touched new seasonal high levels. In the cash markets all the grains, cocoa and dairy products were higher, while tin and rubber were lower.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., June 17. -- The First Institute on Regional Development, through which it is designed to translate into effective action the scientific research work of years into the resources and special needs of the Southeastern States opened here this morning and will continue in session for two weeks at the University of North Carolina.

FREE CITY OF DANZIG, June 17. -- A State funeral decreed by the National Socialist Government of this city for Guenther Deskowski, the Storm Trooper who was killed last Sunday in a clash with anti-Nazis, resolved itself into an impressive party demonstration today.

Speculative interest was increased in secondary railroad and selected utility issues as trading in bonds became more active yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Sales reached $12,081,600, compared with $10,814,300 on Tuesday. The underlying trend was again toward higher levels led by the lower-priced domestic bonds and by pivotal European government obligations.

Convinced almost beyond the shadow of a doubt that Jean Philip Gebhardt, an electrician, who committed suicide at New Monmouth, N.J., Tuesday, was the slayer of Daniel McFarlan Moore, inventor and electrical engineer, the New Jersey investigating authorities turned their attention yesterday toward discovering Gebhardt's motive, but without much success.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, June 17. -- Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, German Economics Minister and president of the Reichsbank, received an enthusiastic send-off when he left this capita this morning for Budapest. It is not known whether he concluded definite agreements here, but it is known he was largely concerned with the financial side of Bulgarian rearmament.

PARIS, June 17. -- Despite the denial by the Ministry of Finance of the report published in some of this morning's newspapers that the forced conversion of rentes to 2 1/2 per cent was being planned, the Bourse continued Weak and rentes fell again, the 4 per cents of 1925 dropping as much as two francs.

The Sharon Steel Corporation declared yesterday an initial dividend of $1.43 a share on the $5 convertible preferred stock. This includes 18 cents for the period from March 19 to March 31, the unexpired part of the first quarter during which the stock was in existence, and $1.25 for the quarter ended on June 30.
ST. LOUIS, June 17 (AP). -- Lyn Lary's single enabled the Browns to beat the Athletics today, 14 to 13.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 17. -- Fresh from her triumph in the New York State championship, Miss Norma Taubele, top-seeded star, starting a day late, chalked up three victories with ease today at the Montclair Athletic Club to advance into the semi-final round of the ninth annual women's Eastern clay court tennis tournament.

LONDON, June 17. -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler, instead of remaining at his desk studying the German reply to the British questionnaire, has preferred to attend manoeuvres organized for him by his admirals. They are intent on proving that the resurrected navy, despite the nominal restrictions of the Anglo-German treaty, will a few years hence be able to give the swastika flag absolute predominance not only in the Baltic but also in the North Sea.

GENEVA, June 17. -- Italy lost thrice more gold in April than in the corresponding month of 1935. In February, the latest month for fairly complete figures, her trade deficit was, for the first time since sanctions began, greater than in the year previous, although only slightly greater.

A banking group headed by Morgan Stanley Co., Inc., will offer today to the public a new issue of $12,000,000 of fifteen-year 3 1/2 per cent debentures, due June 1, 1951, of the Crane Company of Illinois, at 98 1/2 and accrued interest, to yield about 3.63 per cent.

PARIS, June 17. -- While in Paris the number of strikes is gradually declining the situation in the provinces remains far from a solution. In Lyon tonight the transport strike is causing grave disruption in the distribution of food supplies and there is an important strike among steel workers in the Saint Chamond mills.
