Scoring nineteen points in the field events postponed from Sunday on account of rain, the New York Athletic Club went on to retain its junior metropolitan A.A.U. team championship last evening at Castle Hill Park in the Bronx. Nine events were contested.

MOSCOW, June 17. -- Although war clouds still hang over the eastern and western frontiers of the Soviet Union and the vigiiance of the Red Army has not relaxed, there is a lessening of tension in the Russian Far East, combined with a feeling that, whatever Germany's ultimate intentions, that country is unlikely to strike in the comparatively near future.

Declaring that the aggregate per capita Federal, State and local debt amounted to $376.24 as of June 30. 1935, Dr. Joseph Klein warned last night that a time must come when the steadily mounting deferred burden can no longer be ignored, "unless there be repudiation."

BERLIN, June 17. -- The long struggle among some of the principal National Socialist leaders for control of the all-important police power in the Third Reich was temporarily settled by a compromise today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 17. -- More than 200 delegates, including many from twenty foreign countries, will attend a first International Conference on Soil Mechanics and Foundation Engineering at the Harvard Graduate School of Engineering from next Monday through next Friday.

BRUSSELS, June 17. -- Strikes in Belgium spread tonight with the threat of becoming general in the industrial part of the country tomorrow. In two provinces, Brabant and Hainaut, martial law has been declared and the situation at Liege, where armed forces are taking repressive action, remained serious.

DETROIT, June 17 (AP) -- For the second successive day, a last-inning home run gave the Washington Senators a victory over the Detroit Tigers today. The score was 2 to 1 in today's game, which was delayed for more than an hour by rain, and finally was called at the end of the eighth inning because of rain and darkness.

MADRID, June 17. -- Syndicalist labor union demonstrators marched through the Alcala, Madrid's main street, this evening and hurled three bombs at the main entrance of the Aquarium, one of the largest cafes.

Keep a sound body, a sturdy mind and a point of view, Dr. Frederick W. Maroney, Assistant Professor of Physical Education at Teachers College, advised the seventy-three graduates of the Savage School for Physical Education at its thirty-seventh commencement last night in Town Hall, Manhattan. John H. Wendelken, registrar, and John H. W. Barker, a member of the board of trustees, distributed the diplomas.

TRENTON. June 17. -- Colonel Mark O. Kimberling, who was principal keeper of the New Jersey State Prison, was sworn in today at Governor Hoffman's office in the capitol here as Superintendent of State Police. Later tonight, the Governor nominated R. William Lagay, his secretary, to succeed Colonel Kimberling as prison keeper.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the end of the week on June 6 amounted to 314,353,000 barrels, according to data compiled by the Bureau of Mines for Secretary Ickes. Compared with the preceding week, this represented an increase of 333,000 barrels, comprising a rise of 561,000 barrels in stocks of domestic crude oil and a decrease of 228,000 in stocks of foreign crude.

VIENNA, June 17. -- With the lifting or the disintegration of League of Nations' sanctions against Italy imminent, interest centers again upon the European situation, not complicated by African considerations. What can happen to clear it up?

The State Attorney General's office moved yesterday to break up a weird promotion scheme involving a stock-selling spiritualist and an allegedly self-styled engineer who was represented by the medium to be a reincarnation of the man who built the Pyramids.

The Goldman Band, under the direction of Edwin Franko Goldman, inaugurated its nineteenth season of out-door Summer concerts last night on the Mall in Central Park. This opening event of the series, now known as the Daniel Guggenheim Memorial Concerts, was attended by an audience estimated at more than 25,000.
Fight fans from out of town, jovial and generous, began to arrive in New York yesterday to witness the clash between Joe Louis and Max Schmeling at the Yankee Stadium tonight.
RENO, June 17. -- Mrs. Muriel Vanderbilt Phelps received today an uncontested divorce from Henry Delafield Phelps in a private hearing before Judge B.F. Curler. She charged cruelty.

PITTSBURGH, June 17. -- Two hundred union organizers will be in the nation's major steel centers in ten days, according to plans formulated at the first meeting of the Steel Workers Organizing Committee here today.

BERLIN, June 17. -- By further throttling her imports despite the shortage of certain foods and raw materials, and by increasing her exports to overseas countries, including the United States, Germany was able to improve her trade balance last month.

CHICAGO, June 17. -- Orrin S. Dowse, vice president of the Stratton Grain Company and a director of the Chicago Board of Trade, was elected chairman of the Grain Committee on National Affairs at a meeting here today. He succeeds C.D. Sturtevant, president of the Bartlett-Frazier Company.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- If political conventions were organized to pay the same attention to platforms they pay to candidates, one could conclude that not 3 but 1,003 "blind mice" were gathered last week at Cleveland. Sufficient to justify that opinion was the variance between the tone of the orators and the attitude of the delegates toward the Presidential nomination, on the one hand, and the announced Republican party program, on the other.

Setting a terrific pace which netted him a new track record, Duke Nalon of Chicago drove his gold-colored car to victory in the Queens sweepstakes on the card of midget auto races at the Madison Square Garden Bowl in Long Island City last night.
BRUSSELS, June 17 (AP). -- Premier Paul Van Zeeland announced tonight an agreement had been reached giving Belgian strikers satisfaction on four principal points in their demands.

Any fight fan who sits down and tries to add up 1Vfax Schmeling's chance in a bout with Joe Louis may wind up with an answer approaching the absolute zero. Or even a minus quantity. There is no way of matching up the records and figuring the Hammer of Hamburg out in front at the finish.

VIENNA, June 17. -- Archduke Eugene, granduncle of Archduke Otto and World War field marshal of the Austro-Hungarian Armies, in an address at Linz predicted today the Austrian people "soon will have an opportunity to express an opinion on the question of restoration of the monarchy."

Long before national and State campaigns normally get under way in the East, this State will witness intensive fighting to defeat President Roosevelt and to recapture the State administration and the Legislature from the Democrats. The Assembly is already Republican and the Republicans will make a fight to hold it, but the Senate for the last two years has had a Democratic majority.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., June 17. -- Joe Louis, idol of millions and the larger part of the attraction in his fight with Max Schmeling tomorrow night, found his training camp practically deserted today. Gone were the milling throngs that for weeks had obstructed Joe's every move.
About two hours after a fire had been checked in a loft building at 138 Fifth Avenue last night, a section of the roof gave way, and ten firemen fell to the floor below. Three of them were injured.

Fred Jacoby Jr. of North Bergen, N.J., America's 1935 outboard champion, and Bedford (Bud) Davie of Tuxedo Park, colorful Yale junior who has distinguished himself as an amateur motor-boat pilot, sailed yesterday aboard the French liner Normandie for Paris, where on July 4 they will engage in the second annual Spreckels Trophy race on the Seine.

Jack Dempsey, former heavyweight champion, was guest of honor at a dinner given last night in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Astor, in recognition of his services as a trustee of the West Side Hospital, 446 West Forty-third Street, and chairman of its development committee, which has begun a campaign for a $500,000 building fund.

ROCHESTER, June 17. -- Promising results in the treatment of glaucoma, a painful eye disease which constitutes the third most frequent cause of blindness in this country, by the administration of the hormone from the cortex of the adrenal gland were reported today before the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

Reports current in Wall Street yesterday that replies to the New York Stock Exchange's questionnaire regarding the status of margin accounts of member firms were failing to substantiate the contention of the Exchange that the high margins required were restricting trading, were said yesterday by well informed brokers to be erroneous.

William G. Mather, chairman of the Cleveland-Cliffs Iron Company and a director of its former subsidiary, the Corrigan-McKinney Steel Company, received in 1935 a salary of $33,395, while E.B. Greene, president of the Cleveland-Cliffs company, was paid $43,393, it was shown yesterday in annual reports to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

While praising the administration of Joseph B. Eastman as Federal Coordinator of Transportation, Daniel Willard, president of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad, said yesterday that the expiration of this position was welcomed by the railways.

QUEBEC, June 17. -- A denunciation of jargon, or slang, as one of the dangers besetting the English language, was made today by Lord Tweedsmuir, Governor General of Canada, in an address before a joint meeting of the Canadian Clubs of Quebec.

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 17. -- A formidable aggregation representing the New York Stock Exchange today captured the Charles R. Gay Cup in the nineteenth semi-annual tournament of the Wall Street Golf Association at the Upper Montclair Country Club.

Exhibitors of harder hitting and more aggressive offensive work than their rivals, Harvard and Army yesterday rode into the final round of the annual intercollegiate outdoor polo championship tourney as the competition opened at Morris Memorial Field on Governors Island.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., June 17. -- Mrs. Charles E.F. McCann, showing flowers, plants and vegetables grown at Sunken Orchard, her estate at Sandy Hill, this village, won seventeen Blue Ribbons this afternoon in the opening day's judging of the annual rose and sweet pea show of the Oyster Bay Horticultural Society being held in the Parish Hall of Christ Church.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, June 17 (AP). -- Scientists from many countries were in Turkey today to observe the total eclipse of the sun Friday.

As stated at the final report luncheon of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee, the total so far subscribed ($1,363,812) falls short of the minimum sought by only $137,000 -- that is, by less than 10 per cent. But this great community cannot let the campaign end here. While there will be no more "report meetings," the headquarters will be kept open and the workers will continue the appeal.

As the aftermath of the brisk advance in stock price on Tuesday, yesterday's share market had considerable profit-taking to contend with. This selling was absorbed handily until the final hour, when support lagged, causing the list to close irregular.

CHICAGO, June 17. -- Cyrus Hall McCormick, former chairman of the International Harvester Company, anticipated that 60 per cent of his $18,000,000 estate would be taken for taxes when he made a will bequeathing the remainder to his family and fifteen charities.

MILWAUKEE, June 17. -- Discussing the third-party announcement of the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, Dr. Francis E. Townsend said today that "we are not endorsing anybody at this time," but added that "if they come to us with any kind of a satisfactory offer we'll consider it."

Before this day is ended Max Schmeling will be pointing buoyantly toward another chance at the world's heavyweight championship or will be looking forward disconsolately to an early return to his native Germany, through as a fighter.

March 16, according to an unofficial survey conducted among brewers of the United States, is the most satisfactory date for the opening of the bock beer season from both a psychological and business point of view. Brewers of the country who responded to the survey said that sales last season were smaller than in 1935 but attributed the decline to the unseasonable weather rather than to lack of public interest.

LONDON, June 17. -- By receiving appointment as parliamentary private secretary to Sir Samuel Hoare, First Lord of the Admiralty, after only seven months of parliamentary experience, William Waldorf Astor, eldest son and heir of Viscount and Viscountess Astor, has scored an early advancement in his political career.

Versatile Farley is administered another spanking for his efforts. His alleged volubility, extravagance of expression and general officiousness are the butt of your editorial "Wanted: A Silent Chairman."

Dr. Frank Kingdon, president of the University of Newark, will be the principal speaker at the eighth commencement exercises of Brooklyn College tonight at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The largest graduating class in the history of the college, 765 students, will receive bachelor degrees.

Assailing the opposition of the public utilities to the city's entrance into the power field, Mayor La Guardia promised yesterday a reduction in rates of from 20 to 35 per cent to consumers of electricity in New York City if a municipally owned power unit was built.

RYE, N.Y., June 17. -- Thirty-four yachts started tonight in the American Yacht Club's race from here to New London, Conn., the annual event that takes many craft in the Long Island Sound fleet to the River Thames in time to join the gathering for the Yale-Harvard rowing contests.

BUDAPEST, June 17. -- Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, German Economics Minister, arrived here today from Sofia and was received at the airdrome by the German Minister and Hungarian Government representatives. Dr. Schacht will confer with the president of the Hungarian National Bank and other financial and political leaders, and he will be received by Regent Horthy.
BERLIN, June 17. -- The Boerse showed a confident air generally in the trading today, with prices firmer, gains ranging in the main between 1 and 2 points, although the turnover remained small.
MOSCOW, June 17 (AP). -- Soviet radio stations began a five-day period of broadcasting tests today to determine the effect of the eclipse of the sun Friday upon short-wave transmission.

BOSTON, June 17. -- The alleged nation-wide program of soliciting funds for the Democratic Presidential campaign from Federal office holders, disclosed here yester day when thousands of one dollar "Roosevelt nominator" tickets were said to have been distributed to office holders in the Boston Federal Building, will receive the cooperation of Postmaster Edward F. Carroll of Providence.

Former Mayor James J. Walker sailed on the French liner Normandie yesterday after making a few remarks indicating that his lifelong interest in politics had not dimmed and that he might even take a hand in the forthcoming campaign.
LONDON, June 17. -- Great Britain's air force is to be replanned on a war basis, according to a statement tonight by the Air Ministry, which says the move is "essential."

I read with interest your editorial "The Democratic Opportunity." As a visitor to America I was hoping to see in the Republican declaration of policy some constructive economic proposals which would be likely to hasten the return of trade recovery and prosperity. Frankly, I see very little on which to base any serious expectations.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 17. -- Workers should depend upon collective bargaining with their employers rather than upon legislation to gain their ends, Charlton Ogburn, counsel to the American Federation of Labor, advised today in addressing more than 100 representatives of labor organizations at the sixth annual Institute of Labor at Rutgers University here.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- Business during the first five months of 1936 was more active than in the corresponding periods of any of the four preceding years and many types of activities were at the highest levels since early in 1930, the Federal Reserve Board announced in its bulletin for May, made public today.

Florida possesses the excellent art of electing competent Senators, giving them an opportunity to broaden their experience in national affairs and the mysterious ways of the Senate, and enabling them to acquire influence and power. Mr. TRAMMELL, who died only the other day, began his service in 1916.

The Drukman murder case began March 3, 1935, with the finding of the body of Samuel Drukman, a bookkeeper for a trucking company, in the rumble seat of an automobile in a garage at White and Moore Streets, Brooklyn. Drukman had been beaten and strangled.

DETROIT, June 17. -- A woman who went in terror to the police and disclosed the hiding place of the press which the Black Legion used to produce its literature was found bound, gagged, and brutally beaten in her apartment today.
Reports of railroad earnings for May issued yesterday showed mixed results, two major companies showing increases for the month and one showing lower returns. The statements follow:

There are about forty different estimates of the earth's age, and they run all the way from 100,000,000 to 3,000,000,000 years. Both geologists and physicists insist on a long-time scale, the geologists because they want to account for strata obviously older than a paltry 100,000,000 years and the physicists because of the interval required for uranium to change into lead.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 17. -- Twenty-nine veteran golfers, most of whom launched their careers of swinging clubs three decades ago, enjoyed the limelight today over the tricky Old Westbury links where the annual Long Island old timers' championship was held under the auspices of the Long Island Golf Association.

NOROTON, Conn., June 17. -- Mrs. Jonathan Thorne, medalist and defending titleholder, set a sizzling pace into the semi-final round of the Westchester-Fairfield golf championship at the Wee Burn Club today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 17. -- Bernie Rankin, who beat Harvard in 1934 and last year, today pitched the Elis to a 5-to-2 victory over the Crimson before a commencement crowd of 7,000. Allowing only four hits, Rankin not only won the season's series for Yale but caused Harvard to drop into a tie with Dartmouth for first place in the Eastern Intercollegiate League race.

ORANGE, N.J., June 17. -- Only three of the six seeded players remained in the New Jersey Center Junior championship at the conclusion of the second day of play at the Berkeley Tennis Club today. The boys event reached the quarter-finals with the ranks of the favorites intact.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 17. -- Fifteen Americans, ten men and five women, were among the entrants accepted today for the All-England tennis championships as Fred Perry and Miss Dorothy Round were placed at the top of the seeded groups of eight.
The "zero hour" for the army of the bonus spenders is expected today, retail executives predicted last night.

LITTLE ROCK, June 17 (AP). -- Governor Futrell described as "propaganda" today charges of the Southern Tenant Farmers Union that a Negro sharcropper was beaten fatally because of activities in the East Arkansas cotton workers' strike.

OTTAWA, June 17. -- In the most important constitutional decision rendered in Canada in many years the Supreme Court today knocked nearly all the legal underpinning from the "New Deal" legislation enacted last year by the Bennett government.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- The House today agreed to the Senate's plan for providing a $300,000,000 Reconstruction Corporation revolving fund for Public Works Administration projects in the Deficiency Bill. Also included in the measure was $458,631,860 for the social security program next year, $308,000,000 for emergency conservation work and smaller amounts for other government agencies.

For an administration which believes so strongly in the planned life the national convention in Philadelphia next week constitutes a challenge and an opportunity. It is a question of planning a national convention so as to take up five days for transacting an amount of business that could easily be completed in a single day.

For the quarter ended on May 30, the Collins Aikman Corporation and its subsidiaries reported yesterday a net profit of $1,213,525 after depreciation, Federal, State and Canadian income taxes. This was equivalent to $1.96 a share on 562,800 no-par common shares, excluding 2,200 treasury shares, after dividend requirements on the 7 per cent preferred stock.

Disclosures in papers missing for ten days from the offices of David E. Grange, vice president of the International Seamen's Union, result yesterday in the filing of a request for the suspension of Joseph E. Engdoll, Deputy Shipping Commissioner, on the charge that he had asked Mr. Grange to obtain free passes for him and his wife on ships of the Eastern Steamship Lines.

The health of New York City has been improving right along; except for a sharp rise during the wartime influenza epidemic the death rate has declined steadily ever since 1880. But lately the birth rate has dropped twice as fast as the death rate, and immigration has practically ceased.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- Announcement by the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin that creation of a third party was under way was held by "radicals" here today to be badly timed. It also was said that the various groups expected to make up the party were too divergent in their principles to be united effectively in time to become a factor in the November elections.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- Financing the soldiers' bonus sent the public debt to the highest mark on record at $34,331,355,867, according to the Treasury's balance sheet for June 15, made public today. An increase of more than $1,500,000,000 in the government's operating deficit also was shown.

Jean Hersholt, whose last appearance on the Music Hall screen was in the memorable "Country Doctor," returns to that theatre today in "Sins of Man," a Twentieth Century-Fox picture, in which the newcomer, Don Ameche, makes his cinema debut.

The call from retailers for inexpensive dresses has been well maintained in the wholesale markets, which continue more or less marking time on other types of Summer apparel. The bulk of the orders and reorders from retailers have centered on garments up to $4.75.

Secondary stocks, which have been lagging in the present improvement in share prices, are now showing a better tone, brokers reported yesterday. This is regarded as an important contribution to the extension of the upward movement, since the secondary stocks are in most of the restricted accounts, or those that cannot make additional purchases until their equity has increased, under the Federal Reserve Board's margin rule.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 17. -- Amid scenes of color and gayety, Harvard seniors celebrated Class Day of the 300th anniversary year in spectacular fashion before 4,000 alumni and 5,000 other visitors today.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 17. -The citations for honorary degrees at Yale today were as follows:

There is little prospect that public hearings on rapid transit unification Before the Trahsit Commission will begin this Summer, as desired by Mayor La Guardia and his transit advisers. This was definitely indicated yesterday when it became known that the "definitive plan" of unification, soon to be submitted to the commission, will not constitute a complete agreement between the city's negotiators and those for the rapid transit companies and their security-holding groups.
WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP). -- Attorney General Cummings said today that he "may have to send an investigator" into Arkansas again as a result of new developments in the cotton workers' strike.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 17. -- There are, after all, two other races besides the varsity on the Hudson here next Monday, and today interest swung to the freshman rivalry between Syracuse and Washington in the first event on the program.

Spurred by an official report that New York City had more illiterates than any State except Texas, the Works Progress Administration and the Board of Education, in cooperation with representatives of racial groups, churches and settlement houses, began yesterday a four-year drive to reduce illiteracy here.
The deposit committee for 6 per cent bonds of the American Writing Paper Company, Inc., due in 1947, has advised the New York Stock Exchange that it again will accept deposit of bonds.

The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin was silent yesterday about a third-party candidate for the Presidency. He stayed in his hotel most of the day, working on the radio address he will deliver tomorrow night.

Postmaster General Farley was singled out for censure yesterday by the National Civil Service Reform League in an attack on the spoils system, particularly in view of the charges that Federal employes were being mobilized to aid in the Democratic campaign.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP). -- Informed by the Labor Relations Board that no charges of violating the Wagner Labor Act had been made against the Inland Steel Company of Chicago and the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Company of Denver, Secretary Ickes began new negotiations today for purchase of sheet steel piling for the All-American Canal.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- Owen D. Young, chairman of the General Electric Company, was named today by the Federal Reserve Board as a Class C director of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York for the unexpired portion of the term ending on Dec. 31, 1937.

BOSTON, June 17 (AP). -- Twenty-five thousand Bostonians celebrated the anniversary of the Battle of Bunker Hill today at Suffolk Downs by watching Leon Carter's Black Gift gain a stirring head victory over Chance Line in the mile-and-a-furlong handicap named in honor of that Revolutionary battle to pay $5.60 for $2 in the mutuels.

The free press of this country was commemorated last night at the ninetieth City College commencement exercises with the unveiling of a bust of Horace Greeley, famous editor of the Civil War period, which will be placed in the college Hall of Patriots.

Cuban authorities yesterday joined the United States Government in fighting Florida agricultural interests who are attacking the constitutionality of the Reciprocal Trade Agreement Act and the Cuban trade agreement.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

Claims of more than $1,000,000,000 by 550,000 investors in defaulted guaranteed mortgage certificates and guaranteed mortgages against the twenty-seven title and mortgage companies taken over for liquidation by the State in 1933 and 1934 are absolute and not contingent, Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler ruled yesterday in a test case involving the New York Title and Mortgage Company, against which more than 40,000 claims have been filed.

HAVANA, June 17. -- A bill to apply to general expenses in the 1936-1937 budget the revenues from public works taxes to cover payment on public works bond issues now in default was approved by the Senate late tonight.

Operations in the steel industry have increased 1 point this week to 71 per cent of capacity, the highest level in more than six years, according to the weekly summary issued yesterday by the magazine Iron Age. This rate is 10 points above the peak reached when prices were last advanced in June, 1934.

WASHINGTON, June 17. -- In granting permission to the Middle West Corporation to acquire certain securities of the Missouri Public Service Company, the Securities and Exchange Commission found today that this would not be detrimental to the carrying out of the provisions of Section 11 of the Public Utility Act of 1935, and would serve the public interest by tending toward the economical and efficient development of an integrated public utility system.

Stockholders of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation yesterday adopted proposed amendments to the certificate of incorporation eliminating certain powers which have not been exercised, thus bringing the articles of incorporation into conformity with the business practices of the organization.

PHILADELPHIA, June 18. -- Part of the Illinois delegation arrived today for the Democratic convention, to be greeted by a downpour of rain. An advance guard of New Yorkers established State headquarters, proclaiming that despite rumored defections, the State's vote would be cast in a block for President Roosevelt.

The Bronx yesterday again led in plans for apartment houses, three additional six-story structures being estimated to cost a total of $420,000. So far this week plans for twenty-five houses to cost $4,335,000 have been filed, more than double the eleven projects, estimated to cost filed last week.
PARIS, June 18 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:
CHICAGO, June 18 (AP). -- The Chicago Bar Association today expelled four judges on the finding of its board of managers that they engaged too actively in Illinois primary politics.

Never since the beginning of 1932, when, as chairman of the World Trade League, I followed with intense interest the editorials which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES with regard to foreign trade policies, have I found one as fundamental as that contained in your newspaper on June 17.

Salaries of executives of three companies were disclosed yesterday in annual reports to the Securities and Exchange Commission, while the compensation of officers of a fourth concern, Coty, Inc., was filed as confidential under Rule UB-2. The companies reported as follows:

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- The Federal Conservation Service, in its battle to halt the erosion of farm and grazing lands, finds itself confronted with a second problem, the control of flood waters at their source, which has been found a major factor in every effort to halt land erosion and to conserve millions of acres for crop production.

Six members of the Marine Cooks and Stewards Union took steps yesterday to start action in Supreme Court against David E. Grange, president, and five other officials of the union, charging dereliction of duty and demanding an accounting on $144,359 of union funds.

Bank clearings for the week ended on Wednesday continued to show improvement. The total for the twenty-two leading cities of the country, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc., was $6,439,731,000, compared with $5,899,502,000 for the corresponding week last year. The increase, 9.2 per cent, contrasts with a rise of 18.3 per cent in the week previous.
CHICAGO, June 18 (AP). -- Two seeded stars became the first entrants today to reach the semi-finals of the National Clay Court championship at the River Forest Tennis Club.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP). -- Far-reaching legislation intended to protect the independent merchant from price advantages allowed large competitors was passed tonight by Congress and sent to President Roosevelt.

OMAHA, Neb., June 18. -- A resolution to adopt a carrying charge of one-half of 1 per cent a month for accounts not paid within sixty days from the first of the month following purchase will be voted upon on Friday by the National Credit Association in convention here. A carrying charge also is proposed for all types of installment accounts.

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- Here is a digest of the Securities and Exchange Commission report to Congress recommending legislation to raise the standards of the corporate trustee and remove alleged abuse:

WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP). -- New York City school officials told representatives of the radio industry and the Communications Commission today that schools of the metropolis intended to use television for education as soon as it was perfected.

OTTAWA, Ont., June 18. -- The Canadian Government today ranged itself on the side of the Governments of Great Britain and Australia but in opposition to those of South Africa and New Zealand in favoring the immediate cessation of sanctions against Italy.

The necessary funds have been provided to install the granite steps to the north tower portal of the west front of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Bishop William T. Manning announced yesterday. This is the only portal in which the carving and sculpture has been completed.

Always one of the most sparkling of American sport pageants, the Yale-Harvard varsity boat race is to be rowed in this evening's twilight at New London. It will be the fifty-seventh holding since 1876 of the oldest intercollegiate contest in the country. In the light of statistics, the Blue has a good deal the best of it, with thirty-four victories to the Crimson's twenty-two.
-'he dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as fol-i lows. Quotations are in cents:

The Guaranty Trust Company announced yesterday the appointment of A. Nye Van Vleck as vice president and Robert A. Jones as personal trust officer. Mr. Van Vleck was formerly personal trust officer and Mr. Jones was assistant trust officer.

BRUSSELS, June 18. -- Much excitement was caused in Brussels tonight when placards were posted in all parts of the city announcing that the Defense Minister, General Leon Dens, owing to the gravity of the strike situation, had been authorized to exercise the powers of requisition throughout the Province of Brabant.

WILMINGTON, Del., June 18. -- The Rev. Harold S. Laird, pastor of the First-Central Presbyterian Church of this city, was suspended by the New Castle Presbytery today because of his continued affiliation with the outlawed Independent Board of Foreign Missions.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., June 18. -- Salut D'Amour, an old campaigner, was at home in the heavy going and rain which were in evidence at Agawam Park today and took the featured Enfield Purse under a good ride by Jockey J. Mann.

PARIS, Junet 18. -- The Bourse suddenly reacted today against the campaign and spirit of discouragement and opposition to the government's efforts to carry out the program of reforms which the majority of the people of the nation approved at the recent elections.

In a protest which was published recently in THE NEW YORK TIMES on the appointment of a man to the presidency of Mount Holyoke, Professor A. ELIZABETH ADAMS conceded that "a woman's college should have " on its faculty a proportion of able " men." What proportion?

LONDON, June 18 (AP). -- Prospects for an all-American final in the Queens Club tennis tournament loomed today as red-haired Donald Budge of Oakland, Calif., and David Jones, former Columbia University team captain, won berths in the semi-final round.

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- Democratic pencils and erasers will have less hard service at Philadelphia next week than was expected. The contradictions and compromises of the Republican platform assure that. But these tools of composition will be busier than the prospect of a unanimous convention, controlled by a White House incumbent, would suggest.

DURHAM, N.H., June 18. -- Stimulated and inspired by Dr. Kathryn McHale, general director, members of the American Association of University Women from ten States went out tonight from their initial dinner session at the University of New Hampshire determined to push forward their program as a national unit both for greater effectiveness of action and for wider recognition of its worth.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 18. -- Following are the citations of the honorary degrees conferred at Harvard University today:

OTTAWA, June 18 (Canadian Press). -- Deposits with the Bank of Canada by the Dominion Government declined $3,023,383, and by chartered banks rose $10,122,253, in the week ended yesterday, the bank reported today. The statement follows:

A reduction of $910,000,000 in excess member-bank reserves to $2,040,000,000, the lowest figure since April, 1935, was reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve System in its statement for the week ended on Wednesday. The decline was one of several large shifts shown in the statement, largely as a result of the transactions that took place on last Monday, including the Treasury financing, the income tax payments and the cashing of veterans' bonus checks.

Sternly warning them that any attempt at retaliation against any of the State's witnesses would result in their being forced to serve their maximum sentences, Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook imposed long terms in State prison yesterday on the principal figures in the city's $12,000,000 a year vice ring.

CHICAGO, June 18 (AP). -- Johnny Whitehead bested Johnny Marcum in a close pitchers' duel today, hurling three-hit ball as the White Sox made it two out of three over the Boston Red Sox with a 1-to-0 victory.
T.OigDON, June 18. -- George Ber-! nard Shaw, informed of the death[ of Maxim Gorky, said today:

URBANA, Ill., June 18. -- Farmers were urged to develop their own cooperative credit system by Albert S. Goss Land Bank Commissioner of the Farm Credit Administration, in an address delivered today before the American Institute of Cooperation.

EL CAMPO, Texas, June 18. -- South Texas officers came out victorious tonight in a grim game of hide and seek with a lynch mob which hunted in vain for nine Negroes, held for killing a white deputy sheriff during a "bonus celebration."
A request by Park Commissioner Moses for twenty-four new playgrounds to serve "neglected" areas of the city will be considered by the Board of Estimate at its meeting today.

CHICAGO, June 18. -- Science has discarded the age-old art of meat cookery and developed special machines to test most qualities of meats, except flavor, which still relies upon the human sense of taste.
WASHINGTON, June 18. -- The principal provisions of the compromise Tax Bill on which Senate and House conferees agreed today are as follows:
Congratulations on your editorial "Politics and Music." Vivat sequentes!

Mrs. Rachel Fayette died Wednesday night in the Graham Home for Old Ladies, 320 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn. She was 105 years old. Since she became the oldest person in the institution several years ago, Mrs. Fayette had attracted attention throughout the borough by the colorful nature of her birthday parties.

NOROTON, Conn., June 18. -- Mrs. Jonathan Thorne of Innis Arden took one more step toward retaining her Westchester-Fairfield golf championship by defeating her semi-final round opponent, Mrs. Charles Luckey of Mount Kisco, 6 and 5, today.

The franc dropped back to the effective gold-import point again yesterday after having risen above that level for two days. It sank to 6.595-16 cents and closed at 6.58 3/8 cents, the gold point, down 1/4 point from the previous day. Engagements of $2,660,000 gold in Paris were reported to the Federal Reserve Bank, bringing to $315,900,000 the total engaged since April 24.

TRENTON, N.J., Friday, June 19. -- Final adjournment of the 1936 annual session of the Legislature was expected before dawn as a result of a compromise effected at 1 o'clock this morning between warring Republican factions in the Assembly.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., June 18 (AP). -- The Tennessee Valley Authority prepared today to begin its Tennessee River control program, coincident with a move to end litigation against its vast operations.

CHICAGO, June 18. -- Cooler weather and lighter arrivals of hogs here today made for an increased demand, and prices generally advanced 10 cents a hundredweight. The top price of $10.35 was a new high for the last six weeks. Lard hogs, which have been under pressure, were 15 to 20 cents higher due to advances in the lard market.

"Johnny" Weinstein, the peppery-tempered Washington Street produce dealer, hotly denied Detective Charles S. Corbett's story of the $100,000 bribe offer in the Drukman murder case yesterday. Instead, he gave a new version which depicted the detective as actually a grasping bribe-seeker.

DETROIT, June 18 (AP). -- Washington swept its three-game series with Detroit by handing the Tigers their sixth successive defeat today, 12 to 4. A triple-play by the Senators contributed to the victory.

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- Arguments were completed today in the suit of 434 railroad enterprises to obtain in the District of Columbia Supreme Court an injunction against the railroad retirement legislation of 1935. Justice Jennings Bailey indicated that he would render a decision before June 30.

JERUSALEM, June 18. -- The old city of Jaffa today looked like a battlefield. Before 5 o'clock this morning all entrances to the city were blocked with barbed wire and guarded by troops while the government blew up a section to make way for wide roads and modern buildings.

Fifteen lawyers volunteered yesterday to become Special Assistant District Attorneys on the staff of District Attorney William C. Dodge in an investigation of the recently revived ambulance-chasing racket. Their services were accepted by Mr. Dodge on the recommendation of the bar association at the opening of his new Fraudulent Accident Claims Bureau in the rooms of the association in West Forty-fourth Street.
TOPEKA, June 18. -- Governor Landon issued a call today for a special session of the Kansas Legislature to meet on July 7, the day after his return from a short vacation at a ranch at Estes Park.
Charles S. Sargent, a partner in G.M.P. Murphy Co., has been elected a director of the Ludlum Steel Company.

Anticipating the passage of the Robinson-Patman Anti-Price-Discrimination Bill at this session of Congress, food manufacturers and distributors took steps yesterday to establish an "industry policy" with respect to standardized interpretations of the provisions of the measure.

The jinx that interfered with Promoter Mike Jacobs's plans for two previous ring battles of importance overtook the Twentieth Century Sporting Club chief again yesterday as rain forced a postponement of the fifteen-round bout between Joe Louis and Max Schmeling, scheduled for the Yankee Stadium in the interests of the Free Milk Fund for Babies, Inc.

Even with Governor Lehman as standard-bearer in the Democratic fight for the Governorship, this State would be lost to President Roosevelt as candidate for a second term, John D.M. Hamilton, Chairman of the Republican National Committee, declared yesterday in an interview given at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Donald Wills Douglas, designer and builder of airplanes, will receive the Collier Trophy for 1935, it was disclosed yesterday by Collier's Magazine. The presentation will be made next Friday at the White House by President Roosevelt.

For the fourth consecutive week little change took place in The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices. The index stood at 120.7 on Tuesday, against 120.6 the Tuesday previous, 120.4 on June 2, 120.6 on May 26 and 120 on May 19. The most important change was a sharp advance in wheat.

The cornerstone for the new $300,000 Richmond Borough Office and District Health Center at 51-63 Stuyvesant Place, St. George, S.I., was laid yesterday afternoon by Mayor La Guardia. The Mayor said this was one of eight similar buildings already constructed or in the process of construction in the city.

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- President Roosevelt met with the Cabinet, entertained at luncheon John E. Mack, who will nominate him for a second term as President at Philadelphia next week, and talked with other callers.

MOSCOW, Friday, June 19. -- The Soviet spared no effort to observe and report today's eclipse in a manner worthy of Soviet science, and forty astronomical expeditions, twenty-eight Russian and twelve foreign, were spread across the country along the belt of totality from the Caucasus to Khabarovsk in the Siberian maritime provinces.
LONDON, June 18 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:
Rentals in buildings under construction in Manhattan featured apartment leasing yesterday. Reports by brokers and managing agents indicated a demand for suites in the East and West Side areas.

Low-priced stocks were the leaders of yesterday's market. Of the twelve most active issues on the New York Stock Exchange, eight were in a price range below $30 a share, and six were below $20 a share. All were below $40 a share. The low-priced issues participated to only a minor extent in the recent improvement in securities, but some observers feel that they are now making up the ground which they lost.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 18. -- Reaching through Long Island Sound in a fine southerly breeze, W.H. Wheeler Jr.'s Class Q sloop Cotton Blossom II, Roger S. Robinson's new cutter Sirocco and A.E. Van Bibber's yawl Gadget were the winners in their divisions in the American Yacht Club's race from Rye, N.Y., the annual event that brings the advance yachting fleet here for the Yale-Harvard rowing contests.

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation today received bids on $4,935,000 of Great Northern Railway Company secured 4 per cent serial bonds and thirty-one issues of securities of States, counties, municipalities and districts all paying 4 per cent, which it had taken over from the Public Works Administration.

BOSTON, June 18 (AP). -- The Log Cabin Stud's Liberal, an outside choice at 19-1, romped home to a two-length victory in the Newton Handicap, six-furlong feature of the Suffolk Downs program today. Liberal's time of 1:11 equaled the track record set in the 1935 Inaugural by Sergeant Byrne.

POTTSTOWN, Pa., June 18. -- The eighty-fifth commencement exercises of the Hill School will take place Monday in Memorial Hall. Dr. Henry Noble MacCracken, president of Vassar College, will make the main address to the eighty-seven members of the graduating class.

BERLIN, June 18. -- Heinrich Himmler, new executive chief of all German police forces, was formally inducted into office today by Dr. Wilhelm Frick, Minister of the Interior, who characterized the concentration of police powers as another historic deed by Chancellor Adolf Hitler.

GENEVA, June 18. -- The International Labor Organization conference refused today by a vote of 54 to 47 to take a final decision on the textile shorter week convention at this session. This means the matter goes over to next year. The normal procedure requires two years, but the United States' Government and worker delegates had hoped to speed consideration.

The Long Island Railroad must charge its single-fare riders a two-cents-a-mile fare throughout its system, according to decisions handed down yesterday by the Appellate Division in Brooklyn and the Public Service Commission.

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- Complete agreement on a compromise Tax Bill was reached by the Senate and House conferees late today, and leaders considered that the path was clear for adjournment of the Seventy-fourth Congress on Saturday.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Friday, June 19 (AP). -- Dr. Harlow Shapley, director of the Harvard Observatory, said early tday that a new star had been reported to the observatory by three astronomers, each in a different country.

A broad program of shipping development which would not be permitted to sag at intervals at the expense of the nation's position in the maritime world was urged yesterday by Colonel J. Monroe Johnson, Assistant Secretary of Commerce.

Retail package deliveries in the metropolitan and suburban area showed an increase of 18 per cent for the week ended June 13, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. The gain compares with a rise in packages handled of 14 per cent for the preceding week.

CLEVELAND, June 18. -- Pressing on with all the devastating force of a Midwestern twister, the Yankees today finished their business in Cleveland without so much as leaving a blade of grass erect, and then fared forth to Detroit, where they hope to rub more salt in the wounds of an ailing Tiger.
WASHINGTON, June 18. -- A bitter fight in the Senate apparently lies ahead of the conference report on the Tax Bill. There was no specific evidence, however, of any intention to filibuster.
VATICAN CITY, June 18 (AP). -- Six persons received red Cardinal's hats from Pope Pius today.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., June 18. -- A sharp attack upon the Republican platform because of its alleged unfair attacks upon the Hull tariff program was made by Raymond Leslie Buell, president of the Foreign Policy Association, in an address today before the biennial session of the General Council of Congregational and Christian Churches at Mount Holyoke College.

PITTSBURGH, June 18. -- After decreasing for two weeks, business in the Pittsburgh district pushed into new high ground in the recovery period last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. The bureau's index of business adjusted for seasonal change and for trend rose almost to 90 last week, the highest level reached since October, 1930.

SHANGHAI, June 18. -- The chances of a civil war within thirty days are still between 70 and 80 per cent, declared a secret representative of Kwangsi Province leaders, when he was interviewed here today.
LONDON, June 18. -- Following is the text of the speech delivered by Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden in the House of Commons today:

National Park Rangers and men of the First Division Military Police stationed on Bedloe's Island disclosed yesterday how fire ladders were used on Tuesday night to rescue a tourist couple marooned on the Statue of Liberty parapet.

ABRAHAM LINCOLN, telling the whole story of his education in a paragraph, said that the aggregate of all his schooling did not amount to a year -- and in the scattered periods of this total he had five teachers.

FRIEDRICHSHAFEN, Germany, June 18 (AP). -- When the Zeppelin Hindenburg leaves tomorrow night on its third flight to the United States, Dr. Hugo Eckener, veteran dirigible expert, will be in full charge.

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- Internal revenue collections for the first eleven months of the 1936 fiscal year amounted to $3,041,979,758, an increase of $170,449,906 over the corresponding period of the year before, the Treasury announced today.

With its advertising appropriation expanded by 50 per cent, the Norge Division Borg-Wagner Corporation is concentrating 80 per cent of its promotional activity in newspapers, John H. Knapp, vice president in charge of sales, said yesterday. Here to attend a two-day convention of leading Norge distributors of this territory, Mr. Knapp said the company had enjoyed the best sales advances in its history during the last five months.

Prices of bonds in trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange continued to work toward general and moderately higher levels, with the spirited advance in Italian loans a feature of the day. Volume, however, was somewhat off, sales amounting to $11,153,400, compared with $12,081,600 on Wednesday.

A symposium on "Proposed Roads for American Jewry" was conducted at the afternoon session of the third annual conference of the Institute on Contemporary Jewish Affairs, held yesterday at the Town Hall Club, 123 West Forty-third Street, under the auspices of the National Council of Jewish Women. More than 150 delegates, representing council groups in various sections of the country, heard three speakers express widely divergent views on the subject.

Ermelindo Questell, 39 years old, a Puerto Rican, who lived with his wife and three small children at 67 East 105th Street, was held in $10,000 bail in the Felony Court yesterday for a hearing June 25 on a charge that, since October, 1933, he had frequently beaten and tortured a 10-year-old girl ward, who had lived with his family since she was 4.

When Merle Oberon completes "In Love and War," the Goldwyn version of John Balderston's "Covenant With Death," she will go to England to appear opposite Charles Laughton in "I, Claudius" for Alexander Korda. Marlene Dietrich's picture for Korda this year will be "Knight Without Honor."

BOSTON, June 18. -- Old Bob Smith came in off the Bees' coaching lines today and hurled a two-hit, 4-to-0 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals, thereby cutting the Gas House Gang's National League lead to a slim game and a half.
Attorney General John J. Bennett announced yesterday that he would petition the Supreme Court for a rehearing of the New York Minimum Wage Law case.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 18. -- Albert Walter, 28, of New York, who asserted that he had dedicated his life to vengeance against all women, was linked tonight to the two-year-old mystery slaying of a young woman after he had confessed strangling his most recent girl acquaintance.

In a decision denying to the Home Owners Loan Corporation a deficiency judgment against Justine and Joseph Moske of 722 Sixty-seventh Street, Brooklyn, on the ground that the property involved in the action was not yet sold, Justice Charles C. Lockwood said yesterday in Supreme Court, Brooklyn, that the Home Owners Loan Corporation, in prosecuting foreclosure suits, was acting "contrary to the laudable purposes" for which the Home Owners Loan Act was passed.

PHILADELPHIA, June 18. -- Preparations to receive the Democratic National Convention visitors went forward at a fast pace today as delegates arrived in increasing numbers, to find the city already gayly bedecked in flags and banners.

Eighteen cartoonists who get laughs in the current magazines got arrested yesterday afternoon carrying some of their drawings in the street, as a picket line in front of the offices of "College Humor."
WASHINGTON, June 18. -- Seven recommendations for new legislation are made by the Securities and Exchange Commission to better protect investors as follows:

Victor R. Ridder, WPA Administrator for New York City, will give the address to the graduates tonight at the eighty-seventh commencement exercises of De La Salle Institute, to be held in Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street. Fifty-one will receive diplomas.

The Fokine Ballet has been engaged by Fortune Gallo for the second week of his Summer season at the Jones Beach Stadium. A company of seventy-five, with a symphony orchestra furnishing the musical background, will appear in three different programs, Friday, Saturday and Sunday nights, July 3, 4 and 5.

CAMP DOW, Ak-Bulak, U.S.S.R., Friday, June 19. -- The sun was fully visible to the members of the Harvard-Massachusetts Institute of Technology expedition during the total eclipse here at 9:15 this morning [12:15 A.M., New York time].

It is not President ROOSEVELT'S fault if the Democratic National Convention next week is thought of, after the Republican, as a kind of anticlimax. How can the delegates at Philadelphia be stirred into even a semblance of deep interest by a series of foregone conclusions?

ASCOT, England, June 18. -- William Woodward's Omaha went the way of nearly all great American thoroughbreds before him today when Quashed, a tireless little filly owned by Lord Stanley, beat the American-owned son of Gallant Fox by inches in a breath-taking finish for the Ascot Gold Cup, which first was raced for in 1807.

SYRACUSE, June 18. -- Government regulation of the dairy industry has failed and farmers must prepare for a future in which they will manage their own business, Fred H. Sexauer of Auburn, president of the Dairymen's League Cooperative Association, told 2,500 league members here today.

Diplomas will be awarded to thirty-six graduates of Manhattan College's academic department at the eighty-third commencement exercises at Smith Auditorium on the campus, 242d Street and Spuyten Duyvil Parkway, Riverdale, tonight at 8:15 o'clock.

The sale of $1 tickets of the "Roosevelt nominators," which will admit holders to notification rallies to be held throughout the country, was continued yesterday. The charge of Representative Charles A. Halleck, Republican of Indiana, that postmasters in Massachusetts, Indiana and Missouri had been solicited to sell tickets seemingly did not deter the sales.

The orchestral and band units of the Federal Music Project played a total of 1,839 concerts during the season recently ended to a combined audience of 1,094,642 persons, according to an announcement made yesterday by Lee Pattison, city and State director of the project. More than twenty-one units participated in these concert activities, including symphonic, band, dance and chamber units.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., June 18. -- Dorrance Brown, 30 years old, of St. David's, Pa., member of a wealthy family, was in a "very critical" condition today at Paul Kimball Hospital here, where he was taken yesterday with a broken neck suffered when he dived from a boat into a shallow part of Barnegat Bay near Toms River.

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- The Imco Participating Company, Ltd., of London, has filed under the Securities Act of 1933 covering issuance between July 1 and Nov. l of 675,000 participating certificates to be offered to holders of International Match Corporation preference stock outstanding on the following basis: For each two shares of International preference stock delivered the registrant will issue one preference certificate and for odd shares scrip for participating certificates will be issued.

The Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit System reported yesterday for the eleven months ended on May 31, a consolidated net income of $5,080,588 after taxes, depreciation, interest and minority interests, equivalent, after allowing for dividend requirements on 249,468 shares of 6 per cent preferred stock, to $5.04 a share on the 735,664 no-par shares of common stock.

The world of economics and politics may be tense with anxiety, but the world of science marches on more or less serenely. From a dozen countries astronomers flocked to Russia, to scatter themselves along a path a hundred miles wide from the Black Sea to the Pacific and make the most of a total eclipse of the sun which lasted only two minutes and thirty-one seconds.

The necessity for rehabilitation activities in behalf of Jews in Germany and Eastern Europe was stressed at a meeting here yesterday of a group of Jewish leaders from various parts of the United States.
Major Wilfred E. Boughton, at one time in charge of the effort to place WPA workers back in private industry, is now on relief.

LONG BEACH, L.I., June 18. -- Ray Torgerson, 28-year-old Queens Valley business man, who was the victim of little Charley Mayo Jr. recently in the Long Island amateur, proved himself the outstanding hero of the opening day of match play in the thirty-sixth annual metropolitan district amateur championship at Lido today.

Directors of the Waltham Watch Company yesterday declared a dividend of $2.24 a share on the Class A stock. This is the first payment on the A common since $1.41 was paid on Feb. 5, 1931. Accumulated dividend of $33.25 a share on the prior preference stock and a quarterly dividend of $1.75 also were declared.

The Central Trades and Labor Council of Greater New York, representing about 500 labor unions, with a membership of 800,000 workers, voted last night to give its "loyalty and whole-hearted support" for the re-election of President Franklin D. Roosevelt.
HONGKONG, June 18. -- A peculiar situation is reported to have arisen in Kwangtung and Kwangsi Provinces, where the populace is increasingly apprehensive of war with the Central Government.

LONDON, June 18. -- Flushed and nervous in a House of Commons that seethed with excitement, Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden delivered today the deathblow to those sanctions that he more than any other man had brought into being nine months ago.

The August choice of the Literary Guild will be "Green Laurels; The Lives and Achievements of the Great Naturalists," by Donald Culross Peattie. The book will be published on July 15 by Simon Schuster.

PARIS, June 18. -- With the same instinct she has shown in making for herself a leading place in the world of fashion, Gabrielle Chanel, well-known dressmaker, has acted boldly in the face of the advance of French socialism. She has offered her business to her employes rather than make a settlement with them regarding wages and hours of labor which, she says, she cannot, under present business conditions, promise to be able to fulfill.

ROCHESTER, June 18. -- Transformation for the first time of the virus of one specific disease into the virus of another specific disease, hailed as a new land-mark in medical progress, was reported here today before the Summer meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science by Dr. George Packer Berry, Dr. John A. Lichty and Helen M. Dedrick of the Department of Bacteriology, School of Medicine and Dentistry, University of Rochester.

Bankers have been invited to submit bids on next Thursday for a new issue of $250,000 of hospital bonds, dated June 1, 1936, and maturing March 1, 1937 to 1949, of Saratoga County, N.Y. Bidders are requested to specify a rate of interest not exceeding 4 per cent.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 18 (AP). -- Playing through a drizzle, Newark won from the Chiefs at Municipal Stadium tonight, 3 -- 1. Steve Sundra limited Syracuse to four hits, while the Bruins combed George Hockette and Bob Brown for nine.

The North German Lloyd liner Europa will arrive today from Bremen and Channel ports. On board are Robert Martindale, archaeologist; Hans Brunn, who will take part in the Bermuda-Cuxhaven yacht races; Dr. H. Noltenius, Mr. and Mrs. Richard Hellmann, the Rev. Leo A. Hodapp, Mr. and Mrs. Robert P. Barbour, Mr. and Mrs. Roger Mellick, Ben H. Reese, Dr. Henry Howe, Dr. Leo Casagrande and Mr. and Mrs. Roy L. Coniff.

LITTLE ROCK, June 18 (AP). -- A Federal inquiry into reported floggings in the East Arkansas cotton strike was ordered today while one of the alleged victims, a woman social service worker, said she would file charges against her assailants.

John Hay Whitney's Gleeman led from start to finish of the featured Cairngorm Purse at Aqueduct yesterday as heavy rain once more made the course deep and sloppy. The Royal Minstrel colt's ability to negotiate this kind of footing, and known speed, sent him to the post the public choice at 13 to 10 and he became the fourth consecutive winning favorite.

The wool goods markets were fairly active this week, with spot trade more brisk as clothing manufacturers laid in stocks in anticipation of better orders from retailers following the distribution of bonus money, according to the report issued yesterday by the New York Wool Top Exchange Service.

PARIS, June 18. -- The French Cabinet took an important political decision today when it agreed to proceed by decree in application of the law passed in the last Parliament for the dissolution of "combat groups and militia" -- that is to say, the organized forces of the Croix de Feu, Jeunesses Patriotes, Solidarite Francaise and the Francist party.
KENT, Ohio, June 18. -- Fourteen men were wounded today in a riot precipitated by strikebreakers in two vans who crashed the gates of the Black Decker Electric Company.

Austin, Nichols Co., Inc., and susidiaries reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended on April 30 a net profit of $89,704 after depreciation, interest, Federal income taxes and other charges. This was equivalent to $3.11 each on 28,780 shares of no par $5 cumulative prior A stock, to be outstanding after exchange of 259 shares of old preferred stock not yet presented.

Share prices improved moderately yesterday, although some of the edge was taken off by selling pressure in the final hour, and the closing was irregularly higher. Railway stocks again did well, THE NEW YORK TIMES average of twenty-five issues of this group touching a new high point on the movement.

Unless and until the Municipal Assembly adopts legislation for consolidation of county offices the sheriffs and registers of the five counties of the city who now occupy the posts will hold them indefinitely, it was learned yesterday.

Public Service Commissioner Neal Brewster announced yesterday that he would recommend to the full commission that it issue an order for immediate reduction of rates charged by the New York Telephone Company, effective throughout the State.

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- Colonel Frank M. Andrews, in command of the General Headquarters Air Force of the army, with headquarters at Langley Field, Va., was nominated to the Senate today by President Roosevelt for promotion to the temporary rank of major general, and three colonels and two lieutenant colonels were named for promotion to brigadier general in the Air Corps, as follows:

On the eve of a nation-wide broadcast on the reasons for his inability to support either President Roosevelt or Governor Landon, the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin was still without a candidate to lead a third ticket at which he hinted early in the week.

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended June 17, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,485,000,000, an increase of $9,000,000 compared with the preceding week and a decrease of $1,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1935.

MOSCOW, Friday, June 19. -- The total eclipse of the sun became visible over Soviet territory at Tuapse on the eastern coast of the Black Sea at 6:58 A.M., local time, today [11:58 P.M., Thursday, New York time.] The mist cleared just in time to afford a magnificent view for early risers.

TOKYO, Friday, June 19. -- Seventy per cent of the observers now awaiting the eclipse this afternoon along its line of totality in Hokkaido, Northern Japanese island, can expect successful results, according to Dr. Sakuhai Fujiwara of the Central Observatory.

Firmly headed for a busy season, after a long absence from the Broadway scene, is Bela Blau. Already announced to present a musical comedy, he has now acquired the Alfred R. Hays-Leon Alexander dramatization of "Journeyman," Erskine Caldwell's novel of revival-meeting religion in Rocky Comfort, Ga.

Strong condemnation of President Roosevelt's nomination of State Senator Samuel Mandelbaum and John W. Clancy as judges of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York was voiced yesterday by the committee on judiciary of the New York City Bar Association in a telegram to Senator Henry F. Ashurst of Arizona, chairman of the Senate Committee on Judiciary.

Receipts from the city business tax, for which the payment deadline was Monday, total $6,537,444, or $241,956 more than was collected in 1935, Controller Frank J. Taylor reported yesterday. He predicted that payments yet to be received will bring the total increase over last year to approximately $500,000.

A gift to the State of 200 acres of Westbrook, country estate of the late W. Bayard Cutting at Great River, L.I., for use as a public arboretum was announced yesterday by the Long Island State Park Commission. The tract contains a fine collection of evergreens and is noted for its landscaping.

Before another Spring rolls around the country's legions of homeless wild ducks, ousted from millions of acres of marshlands by the inroads of civilization, are to have a chain of duckports in widely separated sections of the land.

KRUKSHETRA, Punjab, India, Friday, June 19 (AP). -- Almost 1,000,000 pilgrims gathered here yesterday on the eve of the solar eclipse to bathe in sacred waters and gain absolution for their sins. By bathing at the time the eclipse occurs, the pilgrims believe absolution becomes much more certain.

Lightning struck furiously at the metropolitan area yesterday morning in the most severe electrical storm this year. Bolts of lightning killed two electrical workers near Newark and a PWA worker in the Bronx. They struck two schools, several church steeples and caused numerous small fires.

A protest against enactment of the Walsh-Healey Government Contracts Bill in its present form was lodged yesterday with members of the Senate and House committees considering the legislation by Arthur Besse, president of the National Association of Wool Manufacturers.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., June 18. -- Neglect of the human element involved in farm problems was charged to Federal, State and university authorities by rural sociologists at today's session of the Institute on Regional Development at the University of North Carolina.

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- Secretary Ickes raised the question today whether it might not be necessary to amend the Constitution to carry out all "desirable" reforms. He conceded that "many things" can be accomplished under the Constitution as it now stands, but voiced doubt that all desirable results can be attained.

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- A comprehensive program of Federal legislation to raise the standards of the corporate trustee and remove abuses which it is alleged have resulted in the exploitation of investors in securities issued under trust indentures was sent to Congress today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

It is the paradox of GORKY'S career that he was a proletarian writer who achieved a world reputation under the Czarist autocracy, but passed into virtual eclipse after Russia set up her proletarian regime. This does not take account of GORKY'S officially fostered reputation inside Soviet Russia in the last half-dozen years.
LONDON, June 18. -- Striking portions of the address of Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin before the House of Commons today follow textually:

While merchants remained hopeful of imminent materialization of a buying spree, tabulations by banks and by the General Post-office began to take definite form yesterday as an indication of an unexpected volume of saving and thrift rather than an orgy of spending as a result of the payment of the war bonus.

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- The investigation of the organization and operations of the Townsend $200-a-month old-age pension movement was ended today by the special House investigating committee and a report will be made later. The House will be asked to authorize the printing of 200,000 copies of the report in addition to 10,000 copies of the stenographic report of the hearings.

Awards to seventy-nine members of the varsity baseball, track, tennis and rifle teams and the freshmen track and baseball squads at New York University have been approved by both the Board of Athletic Control and the Undergraduate Athletic Board, it was announced yesterday by Graduate Manager Albert B. Nixon.

CHICAGO, June 18. -- Colonel Frank Knox, Republican nominee for Vice President, told the Union League Club today that "the people back home" rather than the delegates nominated Governor Landon for the Presidency. The "stop Landon" movement stopped itself behind the scenes, he said, because the nomination of Mr. Landon was welling up from the "grass roots."

Following a steady advance of about $3 a bale in the last two weeks, prices on the Cotton Exchange developed yesterday a less one-sided trend and closed with an advance of 2 to a loss of 6 points after a day of decided irregularity.

EATONTOWN, N.J., June 18. -- The opening social event in the new Mon Paris Room at the Monmouth County Country Club was held tonight in the form of a supper dance by the Shrewsbury Field Hockey Club. It was the hockey club's annual Spring dance and was attended by nearly 300 persons.

A Hamilton Heights deal yesterday involved the three five-story walk-up apartments at 535, 537 and 539 West 144th Street, between Amsterdam Avenue and Broadway, which were bought by Maurice A. Pearson from the Lawyers Trust Company for modernizing. The buyer was represented by Barron, Rice Rockmore, attorneys, the seller being represented by Strauss, Reich Boyer.

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- Wholesale prices advanced fractionally in the week ended on June 13, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 weekly average as 100, rose to 78.7 compared with 78.4 the preceding week, and 79.8 on June 15 a year ago.

WASHINGTON, June 18. -- Breaking a rule of silence, President Roosevelt tonight revealed that he had refused to intercede in behalf of Arthur Gooch, Oklahoma police kidnapper, scheduled to be hanged in the penitentiary at McAlester at 5 o'clock tomorrow morning.

As usual, the Indiana Democratic State Convention was a halcyon and vociferous occasion. Senator MINTON had a candidate for Governor. So had Senator VAN NUYS. That irresistible warrior and statesman, Governor McNUTT, had his own favorite, who, of course, won on the first ballot as predicted by his sponsor.

VIRGINIA BEACH, Va., June 18 (AP). -- Merrel P. Callaway, president of the trust division of the American Bankers Association and vice president of the Guaranty Trust Company of New York, urged bankers of Virginia today to improve their trust departments by giving them good personnel, adequate compensation and cooperation of other departments.
There is no need to go over all that again. It is moved and seconded that the minutes of the previous meeting be accepted as read. All in favor will say "Aye." Motion carried.

Prices in the commodity futures markets were generally lower yesterday. Trading was quiet. In the cash markets corn, oats, rye, rubber and cotton were higher, while wheat, tin, silk and hides declined.

Postmaster General James A. Farley, Democratic National Chairman, replied yesterday to the challenge of John D.M. Hamilton, Republican National Chairman, to name six States which President Roosevelt would surely carry by predicting that the President would carry a greater number of States than the forty-two carried in 1932.
SYRACUSE, June 18. -- A. movement for the appointment of former President Herbert Hoover as chancellor of Syracuse University has been started among alumni and faculty of the institution.

OTTAWA, June 18 (Canadian Press). -- By a vote of 156 to 31 the House of Commons today gave third reading to the bill amending the Bank of Canada Act, this session's most debated measure. The division was the first that found Conservatives ranged solidly against the government.

The "definitive" plan for transit unification, to be presented to the Transit Commission soon as a basis for public hearings before that body, differs radically from the tentative draft submitted to the commission last Winter by Samuel Seabury and City Chamberlain A.A. Berle Jr., it was disclosed yesterday.

POCATELLO, Idaho, June 18. -- The Pocatello Tribune said today Senator Borah, Republican, of Idaho, had written that he was "willing and rather anxious" to seek re-election because of questions involved in the coming campaign.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 18. -- The rowing colony in training for the intercollegiate regatta Monday was startled today when the Syracuse oarsmen voted to withdraw their junior varsity crew from its race. Coach Jim Ten Eyck was not included in the deliberations but when the decision was announced he did not demur. Notice of the withdrawal will be wired to the board of stewards.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 18. -- Pleas for academic freedom, attacks on the control of education "by legislation" and warnings that liberty to teach truth and search for it were in danger in this country were the themes of speakers at the closing exercises of Harvard University's 300th year.

CHICAGO, June 18. -- Erratic price movements dominated the activity in wheat futures on the Board of Trade today. Fluctuations were confined to a 1-cent a bushel range and final quotations showed net losses of 3/8 to 3/4 cent a bushel. The volume of trading was moderate.

Foreclosure sales of housing properties on Riverside Drive and Broadway were conducted by auctioneers yesterday. Seven forced sales were held in the borough, all the parcels being bought in by the plaintiffs to protect their liens.

Charles (Lucky Luciano) Lucania possesses average intelligence but is "a shallow and parasitic individual who is considerably wrapped up in his own feelings," according to an eight-page report made yesterday By Chief Probation Officer Irving W. Halpern of the Court of General Sessions.

ROBERT MOSES, Commissioner of Parks, so delightfully characterized by Professor PHELPS at Yale during this year's commencement exercises as "combining the love of battle with the love of beauty," has served less heroic and esthetic public causes with equal distinction.

A three-run rally in the last half of the eighth inning after St. John's Prep had scored twice in its half, enabled Fordham Prep's baseball team to turn back the Brooklynites, 5 to 4, and retain its Catholic High Schools Athletic Association championship in the tournament final at Fordham Field yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 19. -- A second upward revision of 1936 domestic sugar consumption estimates, with a comparable increase in production quotas, was announced today by the Agricultural Adjustment Administration.
NEW ORLEANS, June 19 (AP). -- Rising from the dust of the drought-ridden Southeast, 12-cent-a-pound cotton came back to Dixie today.

CHICAGO, June 19. -- A wave of speculative buying in the grain markets on the Board of Trade here today advanced wheat 3 1/2 to 4 1/2 cents a bushel, with all deliveries going above the 90-cent level. December contracts led the advance, with July trailing.

WASHINGTON, June 19. -- In a report of a study of the trusteeship of guaranteed mortgage issues in New York City, which accompanied the report made yesterday to Congress by the Securities and Exchange Commission on Trustees under indentures, the commission declared that certain features of this trusteeship plan were "obviously capable of transplantation into other types of trust indentures."

TORRINGTON, Conn., June 19. -- A car driven by Mrs. Alma Gluck Zimbalist, concert and opera singer, killed Minnie Pisante, a 13-year-old schoolgirl today. The child, dismissed from school an hour before for the Summer vacation, was on an errand for her mother when she stepped from behind a parked car into the path of the singer's car.
With refunding operations by industrial corporations resumed, new bond financing this week amounted to $89,255,500, against $204,466,600 last week and $249,851,000 a year ago this week.

WASHINGTON, June 19. -- Senator Vandenberg today attacked the Good Neighbor League, Inc., formed to support President Roosevelt in his election campaign, as "a smoke screen for the Democratic National Committee." The league, recently incorporated as a $100,000 company in Delaware, is headed by Stanley High, former editor of The Christian Herald.

The first essential for a political career is a sense of humor, District Attorney William C. Dodge told the graduating class of the Dwight School at the commencement exercises last night in the school building, 72 Park Avenue.

In a tense atmosphere in a room full of lawyers yesterday afternoon, an attorney for the $700,000,000 Associated Gas and Electric Company assailed United States Circuit Judge Julian W. Mack as personally biased and prejudiced, and demanded that he withdraw as presiding district judge in the utility holding company's bankruptcy litigation.

NOROTON, Conn., June 19. -- To the Connecticut State championship she won two weeks ago, Mrs. Jonathan Thorne today added the Westchester-Fairfield title for the second year in a row. She ended the 36-hole final on the thirteenth green of the afternoon round at the Wee Burn Club, defeating Mrs. Emmet Whalen of Westchester Hills, 6 and 5.
