The special committee on law reform of the New York State Chamber of Commerce telegraphed last night to Senator Henry F. Ashurst of Arizona, chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, a protest against confirmation of State Senator Samuel Mandelbaum and John W. Clancy as judges of the United States District Court.

Captain ANTHONY EDEN was the right man to stand up in the House of Commons and confess that British leadership of the League of Nations had ended in flat failure. He it was who had done more than any other man at Geneva to persuade the League to declare, first of all, that Italy was to be held an aggressor nation violating the Covenant, and then to proceed to apply sanctions under Article XVI.
WASHINGTON, June 19. -- Senators Walsh, George and Byrd made public tonight some tabulations to support their contention that corporate tax increases under the compromise Tax Bill were inequitable.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 19. -- Conde Nast, the publisher, and not the town of North Hempstead, owns the seven-acre strip of shorefront of the Nast estate at Sands Point, Supreme Court Justice Thomas F. Cuff has decided in a ruling that is expected to end a title dispute more than 300 years old.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., June 19. -- Recognition and understanding of regional differentials are essential to the efficient present administration and to future planning for national development, and in the Southeast they are immediate and vital factors in the preservation of its natural resources, according to conclusions unanimously agreed upon today by experts assembled here from all parts of the country.

WASHINGTON, June 19. -- By a standing vote of 165 to 2, under suspension of the rules, the House passed and sent to the White House today what is known as the Strike-Breaker Bill, which would make it a felony to transport in interstate commerce persons to be used to obstruct or interfere with the right of peaceful picketing during labor controversies.

Unless before adjournment Congress enacts the Kerr-Coolidge bill, or at least agrees to House Joint Resolution No. 632, to stay the deportation of 2,860 men women and children, the majority of whom have American-citizen relatives, and who have committed no moral offense, irreparable injury will be done to these individuals and a serious blow struck at our country's reputation for fair play.

After a three months' controvery with customs officials over the fine points of the government definition of art, Rockwell Kent, the painter, learned yesterday that a group of illustrations he had sent to England would be returned to him duty free.

GENEVA, June 19. -- The British Government's decision to abandon sanctions seems to be taken in League of Nations quarters to mean that sanctions are finished, that the League and Great Britain thereby suffer a bad blow and that the real fight in the June 30 Assembly will center not on sanctions but on non-recognition of Italy's African conquest.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 19 (AP). -- The leaders and tailenders of the International League split even at Municipal Stadium tonight. The pace-setting Newark Bears nosed out the Chiefs in the first game, 4 to 3, and succumbed in the second under an 18-hit onslaught by Syracuse, 11 to 4.

RED TOP, Conn., June 19 (AP). -- Charles J. Whiteside, head coach of Harvard's victorious varsity crew, tonight was informed by Athletic Director William J. Bingham that he would not be re-engaged for next season.
PARIS, Saturday, June 20. -- Relief from the embarrassment of the empty Treasury he had inherited was obtained late last night by Finance Minister Vincent Auriol from the Chamber of Deputies.
I would like to know where the Metropolitan Golf Association gets the power to keep a public links golfer from playing with members of a private club in an open tournament.
The Republican candidate for the Presidency announces that his name is Alf M. Landon, not Alfred, and says he would like the newspapers to refer to him by his right name.

Telegraphic transmission and short-wave radio telephone circuits were interrupted, and in some cases put out of commission temporarily, early yesterday morning by earth currents and electrical disturbances variously attributed to the eclipse of the sun, to sun spots and to the "northern lights" or aurora borealis.

In one of the greatest heavyweight battles of modern ring history Max Schmeling, sturdy, stolid German who formerly held the world's heavyweight title, last night provided one of the ring's biggest upsets when he knocked out Joe Louis, Detroit's famed Brown Bomber, in the Yankee Stadium.

WASHINGTON, June 19. -- Representative Marion A. Zioncheck, Democrat of Washington, was ordered today to appear before a District of Columbia Supreme Court lunacy jury next Friday for a hearing to determine whether he is sane.

The Postoffice Department, veterans' organizations, armories, banks and fiscal agencies cooperating in the distribution and conversion of bonus bonds appeared yesterday to be nearing the completion of their task, with still few signs in evidence that the payment of the bonus would create a buying wave of any considerable size.

Dr. Darwin Hecht, 47 years old, of 1,368 President Street, Brooklyn, who is a member of the American Medical Association and the Kings County Medical Society, was sentenced yesterday to an indeterminate penitentiary term up to three years by Judge Donnellan in General Sessions.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 19. -- The most thorough-looking fiasco of recent Harvard-Yale regatta history became instead a huge success this evening as this one-time whaling port was transformed in the space of a few short hours from a deserted town to a gay, lively center for one of sport's most extravagant spectacles.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP). -- Irving T. Bush, elderly president of the Bush Terminal Company of Brooklyn, N.Y., now in receivership, told the Sabath investigating committee today that there had been offered to him $25,000 a year for life to "stop protecting bondholders" and to step out of the way of a proposed reorganization plan.
BOSTON, June 19 (AP). -- The Reds brought their heavy artillery into play today to defeat the Bees, 8 -- 4, in the series opener.

" Father's Day" will be observed in a number of churches tomorrow. Some of the pastors will preach sermons about "Father" and there will be exercises by the children in a few of the Sunday schools paying tribute to their male parent. In Congregational churches prayers will be offered for a blessing upon the biennial meeting of the National Council of the Congregational and Christian Churches in session at South Hadley, Mass.

The Harvard varsity crew defeated Yale by five and a half lengths last night in their seventy-fourth annual race, the oldest American intercollegiate sporting event, as 50,000 lined the banks of the Thames River at New London, Conn.

Of thirty-three trade groups listed in a study of national advertising expenditures in 1935 by 387 companies in newspapers, magazines and chain broadcast, twenty-two favored newspapers, according to the annual survey released yesterday by the Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association.

By this time there can be no question of who is the successor to the late Father DUFFY as leading citizen of New York west of Ninth Avenue between Forty- second Street and Columbus Circle. He is JACK DEMPSEY, head of a campaign committee now engaged in raising a $500,000 building fund for the West Side Hospital on Forty-third Street near Tenth Avenue.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 19. -- Following the visit to Belgrade of Dr. Hjalmar Schacht of Germany, this story has gone the rounds:

The alleged "fraudulent and dishonest" activities of Welker Cochran, former three-cushion billiard champion of the world, cost the brokerage firm of Harris Vose $300,612 in 1930 when Cochran was employed by that concern as a $100-a-week customers' man, it was charged yesterday in Federal court.
The text of Father Coughlin's radio address last night from the studio of WABC, Columbia network, follows:
WASHINGTON, June 19. -- President Roosevelt lunched with Bernard M. Baruch, appointed Richard L. Disney and Miss Marian J. Harron to the Board of Tax Appeals and attended to routine matters.
LONDON, June 19. -- The government's retreat from sanctions was accepted quietly by the British public today except for extreme pro-Leaguers of the Liberal and Labor parties.

GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, June 19. -- Five English fishermen who ran away from Grimsby April 2 with the trawler Girl Pat and dodged arrest on both sides of the Atlantic were under police protection in jail here tonight.

CANTON, China, June 19. -- Regardless of the tenor of telegrams and official announcements from Canton and Nanking indicating submission of Kwangtung Province to Nanking, it is evident that General Chen Chia-tang, head of the Kwangtung Government, has not the least intention of submitting to the Central Government.

Mr. Bones, John Hay Whitney's keen colt which was beaten only a nose for the rich prize of the Belmont stakes, is named as one of half a dozen starters for today's renewal of the $11,000 Dwyer Stakes, feature at Aqueduct. The test was run years ago as the Brooklyn Derby.

The Guaranty Trust Company has been appointed agent by the Standard Oil Export Corporation to redeem the 5 per cent cumulative non-voting guaranteed preferred stock of that company beginning June 30, at $110 a share.

At least four workmen were crushed to death and a dozen others injured at 3:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon in the collapse of the center section of a sixty-family apartment house under construction at 112 East Mosholu Parkway South, the Bronx.

KAMISHARI, Japan, June 19. -- Clouds that appeared shortly before the total eclipse and thickened, though with occasional gaps until totality was over, deprived a British expedition under Professor F.J.M. Stratton of Cambridge of the results they had hoped for.
AK-BULAK, Siberia, June 19. -- Conditions for viewing the total eclipse of the sun were perfect here in Siberia, and our hopes were realized.

PHILADELPHIA, June 19. -- With the assertion that "God is the person that the American voter has got to reckon with in the coming election," the Rev. Dr. Frank N.D. Buchman, founder of the Oxford Group, came to Philadelphia today with nearly 100 group members from several countries to remain until the end of the Democratic National Convention.

Threatened by foreclosure proceedings, the Second Presbyterian Church, also known as the Scotch Presbyterian Church since it was founded in pre-Revolutionary days, filed a petition in Federal court yesterday to reorganize under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act.
JONES BEACH, L.I., June 19. -- Before an audience of 10,000, a cast of 1,000 persons took part in a pageant here tonight marking the season's opening of the Jones Beach Stadium.

Construction work started last month totaled $216,070,700, more than 70 per cent above the May, 1935, total of $126,720,000 but below the $234,631,600 for last April, a survey of the thirty-seven States east of the Rocky Mountains shows.

WASHINGTON, June 19. -- The Empire Properties Corporation of Newark, N.J., formerly the Empire Debenture Corporation, has filed under the Securities Exchange Act of 1933 covering $3,087,477 of collateral trust bonds. It was organized to promulgate a plan of adjustment for bond certificates insured by the Metropolitan Casualty Insurance Company of New York. The exchange will be $1,000 of the new issue for $1,000 of bond certificates.

Italian dollar loans advanced to new high levels for the year on gains of 2 to 5 1/4 points yesterday in bond trading on the New York Stock Exchange. This movement, which began on Thursday, is attributed to action by Great Britain toward abandoning the economic sanctions against Italy.

BALTIMORE, June 19. -- Action which indicated reorganization of the Hugo Stinnes Corporation and Hugo Stinnes Industries, Inc., was begun in Federal court here today when petitions were filed under Section 77b of the Federal Bankruptcy Act. Judge William C. Coleman of the United States District Court signed an order setting June 30 for the hearing.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers.

What's what in the fishing world, as gleaned from the mailbag: Anent the weakfishing in Peconic Bay, Frank Johnson of New Suffolk, operator of anglers' headquarters at that port, writes: "Recently there have been so many conflicting reports on Peconic Bay fishing that it is hard for the angler to know just what the true conditions are.
DUBLIN, June 19. -- President Eamon de Valera took tonight the vital decision of proclaiming the Irish Republican Army illegal under the public Safety Act.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 19. -- Rain or no rain, yachtsmen who have had to endure slippery, drenched decks for six of the last eight days afloat could not and would not be kept from their annual rendezvous on the Thames today.

The selection of the Book-of-the-Month Club for August is Walter Edmunds's "Drums Along the Mohawk," which will be published on Aug. 1 by Little, Brown. The book has had two pre-publication printings, totaling 20,000 copies.

THE week's supply of books has been a fairly large one, and now that Saturday is here, at least three of the items thus far neglected cry out for invention. "With malice toward none and injustice toward all," the conscientious reviewer must murmur as he squeezes several notices into the confines of one day's column.

BERLIN, June 19. -- While courts in Coblenz and other German cities continue to grind out sentences against Catholic priests and friars charged with immorality, Germany's Catholic bishops are issuing pastoral letters which are being read in the churches, defining their attitude toward this new wave of criminal prosecution.

Nearly 1,000 delegates from the United States and Canada will attend the twelfth convention of the World's Sunday School Association in Oslo, Norway, July 6-12. These will include some of the most prominent leaders in the Protestant Church.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week amounts to $22,335,148, representing two States and sixty-seven municipalities. This compares with the revised total of $18,563,898 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date is $23,912,422.

In THE TIMES today there is a letter from Gridley Adams insinuating that Senator Borah has only a "little learning," a "dangerous thing," because he spoke of the Federal Constitution as "guaranteeing" free speech.

Trust officers and chief executives of Wall Street banks were deeply disturbed yesterday by the report of the Securities and Exchange Commission criticizing existing standards of corporate trustee work and recommending remedial legislation.

DETROIT, June 19. -- The excursion steamer Tashmoo, with water cascading through a gaping hole in her side, won a race with death early today while 1,400 passengers danced to the music of a swing band and members or the engine room "black gang" stoked boiler fires while water swirled around them waist deep.

Your recent editorial "Little Americans" was an indictment of the deplorable exhibition of retrogression evidenced in the Republican platform with respect to the party's attitude toward our foreign relations. Every step, however faltering, that has been so painfully and laboriously made toward an enlightened understanding of the part America inevitably must take in world affairs has been ruthlessly abandoned.

MANILA, June 19 (AP). -- Major Gen. Douglas MacArthur, former United States Chief of Staff, gave the young Philippines Commonwealth a defense plan today "to give pause to the most ruthless and powerful."

ISLAND OF CHIOS, Greece, June 19. -- The eclipse was observed under almost perfect morning conditions by a British expedition headed by Dr. R.L. Waterfield. It was the most transparent sky the expedition had seen here from its position 200 feet high one mile north of Kardamyla, overlooking the Aegean Sea, Lesbos and the Turkish coast.

The Senate conferees made a more complete surrender on the Tax Bill than was generally thought possible when the conference began. There is now, however, some reason to believe that the bill as reported will not be passed by that body. The rates of the conference measure are much worse even than those in the Black-La Follette proposal.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 19. -- The members of the Westchester Citizens Government Commission sent to the Board of Supervisors today their resignations, effective immediately, because "it is the unanimous view of the commission that its work has been completed."

WASHINGTON, June 19. -- The Senate Judiciary Committee voted today to recommend the confirmation of John W. Clancy and Samuel Mandelbaum as Federal District judges for New York City. Chairman Ashurst indicated that he would try to get the Senate to act on the nominations tomorrow.
Although the sky was overcast, suitable weather favored the crowd of 45,000 fight fans that gathered at the Yankee Stadium last night to see Joe Louis battle Max Schmeling.

FARMINGDALE, L.I., June 19. -- This quiet agricultural center on the eastern border of Nassau County was the scene of a daring bank messenger hold-up at 10:05 A.M. today. Three robbers escaped with $12,000 in payroll funds that were being delivered from the Farmingdale postoffice to the First National Bank, a block away, on Main Street.
ALBANY, June 19 (AP). -- Changes in the personnel of New York's Legislature already were in the making tonight, assuring new faces when the 1937 session convenes in January.

A conflict with the provisions of the interstate commerce laws pertaining to interlocking directorates has halted negotiations for the reorganization of the $80,000,000 Chicago Eastern Illinois Railway, now in bankruptcy proceedings, it developed yesterday.

CLEVELAND, June 19 (AP). -- George Blaeholder pitched to only one batter and received credit for the Indians' 9-6 triumph over Washington today. The victory snapped the Tribe's three-game losing streak and the Senators' trio of consecutive wins.

WASHINGTON, June 19. -- The long-awaited report by the Securities and Exchange Commission on the "feasibility and advisability" of the complete segregation of the functions of broker and dealer is expected to be transmitted to Congress tomorrow.

TOPEKA, June 19. -- Governor Landon virtually completed the organization of his campaign advisory staff today with the announcement of the selection of Charles P. Taft, son of the former President, and Ralph W. Robey, writer of economics, to be his aides.

Your current correspondents, as well as those who have written you over a period of months, are entirely within the facts as to the substandard service of the new Madison and Lexington Avenue bus lines. Only the normal sheep- like acquiescence of New Yorkers can have kept the expression from coming to a head before.

CHICAGO, June 19. -- Whether the Townsend old-age pension and the share-the-wealth movements will support the Presidential candidacy of Representative Lemke and his Union party ticket this Fall will depend on the outcome of a conference between representatives of those groups and Mr. Lemke.

Riker Operating Co., in 225 W. 4th St., through 5. D. Robilotto Co.; Green Borshop, in 225 W. 28th St.; Joseph Schwartz, in 547 Greenwich St.; Albert Fenn, in 126 W. 23d St.; Lifschitz Boockvar, in 415 W. 28th St.; Harry Selznick, in 142 W. 23d St.; Max Lubowsky, in 227 W. 28th St.; Par-X-Uniform Service Corp. and Waltzer Electric Co., in 245 7th Av.; Dwight, Voorhis Perry, brokers.

WASHINGTON, Saturday, June 20. -- Congress early this morning stood on the verge of adjournment, despite Senate filibustering against three things -- hasty adoption of the conference report on the Tax Bill, ratified last night by the House; adoption of the conference report on the Treasury-Postoffice Supply Bill with its item for ocean mail contracts; and enactment of the Guffey Coal Conservation Bill, already passed by the House.

" I don't think I've ever been happier in my life," Max Schmeling said in his dressing room after his unbelievable triumph over Joe Louis. "It was a great victory for me, because I beat a great fighter."

Note three openings for today: "Border Flight," which enters the Rialto, is a study of the Coast Guard, with John Howard, Grant Withers, Frances Farmer and Roscoe Karns; the Globe presents Charles Bickford in "The Red Wagon," a circus story without Dexter Fellowes, but with Greta Nissen and Raquel Torres; third is an Italian film, "Crooked Love," with Nelly Corradi.

The huge and rain-drenched gathering which turned out for the Princeton track meet at Palmer Stadium last Saturday was just another testimony to the deep-rooted love we Americans bear for manly competition and healthy sportsmanship.

Slow buying response to the moderate offerings characterized proceedings in stocks yesterday as market followers preferred to operate cautiously pending final news on the Federal Tax Bill and on the adjournment of Congress. Then, too, the market was entitled to some easement on technical grounds.

TRENTON, June 19. -- New Jersey's 160th Legislature, buffeted by six months of controversy, not the least of which was the public criticism over the case of Bruno Richard Hauptmann, adjourned sine die at 7:10 A.M. today after an all-night session.

CHICAGO, June 19. -- Lighter receipts of hogs and a better wholesale demand for fresh pork advanced prices for hogs today 10 cents a hundredweight over those of yesterday. The top price of $10.40 was the highest since May 4. The day's average was $9.90, an advance of 5 cents.

WASHINGTON, June 19. -- The Sioux City Gas and Electric Company has filed under the Securities Act of 1933 for $9,000,000 of 4 per cent first-mortgage bonds due in 1966 and $1,500,000 of serial debentures, series A, maturing from July 1, 1937, to July 1, 1946. The debentures maturing from July 1, 1937, to July 1, 1941, will pay 3 per cent interest and those maturing after that date 5 per cent.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 19. -- Astronomers in many parts of the world reported the discovery today of a nova, or new star, which has flared into sudden brilliance far away in interstellar space.

BERLIN, June 19. -- The Boerse started weak today from realizing sales by professional traders, which forced the opening prices slightly below those at the finish yesterday. Despite reports of further improvement in the steel and automotive industries, buying by the public was light and the scattering upturns made in part of the session could not be maintained at the closing.

WASHINGTON, June 19. -- Deciding unexpectedly today to give way to the pressure from certain Senate leaders, House chieftains suddenly called up the Copeland Pure Food and Drug Bill under suspension of the rules, and it was passed after only forty minutes of debate by a standing vote of 151 to 27.

Prominent members of the Catholic hierarchy representing dioceses in this country and England joined in the celebration yesterday of the fiftieth anniversary of the ordination of the Right Rev. Mgr. Joseph H. McMahon, founder and pastor of the Church of Our Lady of Lourdes.

That boisterous Gas House Gang from St. Louis, flying high at the top of the pack and proud of it, opened hostilities against the Giants at the Polo Grounds yesterday, knocked out Hal Schumacher in two rounds and scored enough runs during that period to clinch the victory.

CHICAGO, June 19 (AP). -- A single by Mule Haas with one on in the thirteenth inning broke up a pitching duel between Vernon Kennedy and Bill Dietrich today and gave the White Sox a 5-to-4 victory over the Athletics in the opening game of the series.
Joe Louis weighed 198 pounds and Max Schmeling 192 for the bout at Yankee Stadium last night. Arthur Donovan was the referee and George Le Cron and Charley Lynch were the judges.

CHICAGO, June 19. -- America's premier collegiate athletes, striving for berths on Uncle Sam's Olympic team, smashed two world records and tied another in the preliminaries of the National Collegiate A. A. track and field championships today.

The rising tendency evident for several weeks in some important agricultural commodities was accelerated yesterday when wheat advanced around 4 cents a bushel and cotton moved to the highest level since last November. The financial community was very much interested in the advances in grains and cotton, the important agricultural crops of the nation, as it means increasing purchasing power for millions of persons.
In the last two dissenting opinions of Justice Cardozo recently printed in your columns he consistently refers to the Federal Government as the "central government."

A series of disorders staged by hoodlums occurred in Harlem late last night following the defeat of Joe Louis, Detroit Negro, by Max Schmeling of Germany. In one of them a 50-year-old man, white, was knocked down and kicked by thirty men, Negroes, and was taken to Harlem Hospital.

Ambrose Doskow, in your issue of June 16, charges me with "a glaring historical inaccuracy" in my assertion that the "no-government's land" of legislation which Mr. Roosevelt discovered after the recent minimum wage decision was rendered, is 147 years old. He points out that the constitutional provision involved in that decision was established in 1868 by the passage of the Fourteenth Amendment.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., June 19. -- Changes that were said to be called for in the economic structure of the country were the subject of addresses by business men and pastors at the biennial session of the General Council of Congregational and Christian Churches of the United States at Mount Holyoke College today.

Slot St.; Louis Riggio, in 49 E. 86th St.; John E. Lock-i wood, in 166 E. 96th St.; Culver, Hollyday Co., brokers.

Representative William Lemke has been a stormy petrel in the politics of the Northwest for almost two decades. In the past few years in Washington he has been conspicuous for his support of inflationary measures.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

NEW LONDON, Con., June 19. -- Harvard, twice defeated on the diamond by Yale this week, today turned back the Elis by a 3-0 score before 700 spectators on Mercer Field under threatening skies as a baseball feature scheduled between the morning and evening races of the annual regatta on the Thames.
Sale of a Hoboken industrial plant by a bank featured the New Jersey realty deals reported yesterday. Various housing and business parcels were included in the transactions.

WASHINGTON, June 19. -- Curtailment of governmental regulation of industry, which the Republican platform says would encourage reemployment of the jobless, was condemned as a policy today by the American Federation of Labor in its monthly survey of business.
I wish to comment on the self-sacrificing play made by Al Simmons of the Tigers when he was at bat in the first inning of the game against the Yankees on June 12.

While the soldiers' bonus trade did not measure up to expectations, retail sales in the metropolitan area continued last week to hold to approximately the 10 per cent gain over a year ago reported for the first half of the month by the local Federal Reserve Bank.
LONDON, June 19 (AP). -- Donald Budge of Oakland, Calif., and David Jones, former Columbia University team captain, today qualified for the singles final of the Queens Club tennis tournament.

Trade movements were more active this week, with retail sales for the country as a whole showing an estimated gain of 10 to 15 per cent over the figures for the corresponding period last year, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. Reports received by the agency from leading cities showed increases ranging from 5 to 8 per cent over the volume in the previous week.

Headed by Postmaster General James A. Farley, Democratic leaders departed yesterday for Philadelphia. Chieftains from up-State passed through the city every hour on their way to the national convention.

For the second time this week, rising prices on the Cotton Exchange were led by the July delivery, which advanced a quarter cent to the highest quotation of the season. The July went about 70 points over October, which in turn touched the highest figures of the season.

DURHAM, N.H., June 19. -- The recent decisions of the Supreme Court and the selection of a man as president of Mount Holyoke College were presented tonight to the American Association of University Women by Miss Dorothy Kenyon for consideration as of major importance to the membership.

TWO laborers were cutting the grass on the suburban lawn owned by Herr Franz Frisch and old Onkel Franz, the sand-haired leader of the St. Louis Cardinals, was surveying them with suspicion. He was afraid that they might run wild and snip precious patches out of his prize rose bushes or dwarf cedars. Onkel Franz now has reached the state where he worries about everything.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 19. -- James Roosevelt, son of the President, is to race the schooner Sewanna in the Eastern Yacht Club's ocean contest from here to Marblehead, Mass., which starts from Sarah Ledge, off the mouth of the Thames, tomorrow.

PHILADELPHIA, June 19. -- It was revealed here tonight that Governor Landon, in his telegram to the Cleveland convention, closely followed the money plank ideas of former President Hoover as the latter expressed them in a message to Chester Rowell, head of the California delegation.

The annual convention of the New York State Bankers Association, which will open this morning at Bolton Landing on Lake George, is expected to be the most largely attended of any convention since the depression began. This, officials of the organization said yesterday, is an apparent reflection of the growing improvement in banking and business.

The list of the French liner Champlain, leaving today for Havre, via Plymouth, will include a large group of members of the Garden Club of America, who will visit many of the famous gardens of France. The party is headed by Mrs. Robert H. Fife, president of the Garden Club of America, who will be accompanied by her sister, Mrs. Robert B. English.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP). -- The searing heat of drought burned deeper over the Central United States today, bringing from the Federal crop reporting board a warning that conditions were critical.

Edward Lazansky, presiding justice of the Appellate Division in Brooklyn, signed late yesterday afternoon an order staying the reduction to a two-cent fare for single-trip riders on the Long Island Railroad until arguments before the full bench next Monday morning at 10 o'clock.

The other night Intourist took a group of foreign visitors to show them the sights of Moscow. There were among us people from England, New Zealand, the Scandinavian countries. I was the lonely American.

ROME, June 19. -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden's speech in the British House of Commons announcing that sanctions would be abandoned is considered perfect in Italy except for one detail -- namely, that it insisted upon regarding Italy as the aggressor and contained no reference to what is called here "Geneva's judicial error."
ASCOT, England, June 19. -- Sir Abe Bailey's consistent 5-year-old Cecil today won the Alexandra Stakes, longest race run under Jockey Club rules, as the four-day Ascot meet concluded.

Those Summer visitors who wish to see the much-talked-about "Folies de Femmes" revue at the French Casino ere it gets away had better do so on or before July 11 -- because that is the date on which the management has decided to close up shop and pack the whole kit and caboodle of girls off to its London branch.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., June 19. -- With an array of hunters and saddle horses truly representative of New Jersey's splendid stables competing, the fifth annual Plainfield Horse Show started on its two-day stand in the spacious ring of the Vinebrook Farm today.

Sales of art and literary property held at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., during the season just ended yielded $3,218,283.50, an increase of more than 14 per cent over the preceding season, according to announcement yesterday by the galleries. The seventy-nine public auctions comprised 144 sessions.

How can anybody stay away from Philadelphia next week? Both the esthetic and the moral sensibilities may there have exquisite satisfactions. Tammany, always regular even if insufficiently "placated," will be there in all its glory. More than six hundred braves will represent the famous temple of philanthropy in Union Square.

OTTAWA June 19. -- In five months of Prime Minister Mackenzie King's new trade expansion policy, Canadian exports have risen at the rate of $12,000,000 a month. In the same period, which is also five months, since the Canadian-American trade treaty came into effect, Dominion producers have benefited by an additional $17,000,000 sold in the markets of the United States.

WASHINGTON, June 19. -- A conference which will represent the first effort by the Soil Conservation forces and the engineering professions to ally themselves in an effort to solve the problem of upper watershed control, which is vital in the control of floods and erosion, was approved today by President Roosevelt.

Speaking of G-men in baseball reminds me of an incident that took place at the Polo Grounds in the days of the old wooden stands when the late Captain Eddie Grant, whose monument now stands back of center field in the Polo Grounds, was the central figure in a most extraordinary incident.

Now that June is getting along, the Times Square mortality rate goes higher. Three shows are scheduled to depart from Broadway tonight and one of the WPA's more popular attractions leaves Harlem. In addition, the Theatre Guild has now set the final dates for all three of its attractions, making a gruesome list that reads like this:

TOKYO, June 19. -- The Japanese Government has decided to invoke the Trade Protection Law against Australia. Its action has been taken because Australia has declined to reconsider its new high tariffs against Japanese goods.
PARIS, June 19. -- Official notification of their dissolution was served today on four Rightist militant organizations by the police.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 19. -- William Fox, former movie executive, listened calmly today as charges of fraud and of solicitation of claims to control the election of a trustee were read into the record at the first hearing on his $9,535,261 bankruptcy petition.

Strongly denouncing the "brazen" racket operations of Charles (Lucky Luciano) Lucania and his gang, Mayor La Guardia charged yesterday that these activities "could not have been conducted without the knowledge, if not the connivance, of some of the very people entrusted with the enforcement of the law."

The declaration of his program by Finance Minister Vincent Auriol of France, involving a strong rejection of devaluation and the threat of penalties against hoarders and those who have sent capital abroad, strengthened the franc yesterday in the foreign exchange market here.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 19. -- Five of the eight seeded players, paced by Frank Bowden of New York, ranked No. 1, advanced into the quarter-final round of the New Jersey State men's singles tennis championship tournament today at the Montclair Athletic Club.

WASHINGTON June 19. -- Administration officials moved today to eliminate a focal point of criticism against the Federal work program by deciding that it was no longer necessary for WPA job seekers to go on local relief rolls. At the same time steps were taken to provide against any stampede toward Federal work jobs.

William W. Kleinman, Assistant District Attorney of Kings County, who is accused of taking a $300 bribe in the Drukman murder case, submitted yesterday to a searching cross-examination into the suspected phases of his public and private life.

DES MOINES, Iowa, June 19 (AP). -- The Detroit Athletic Club set a new American record of 3:22.2 in the 300-meter medley relay in the national A.A.U. swimming meet today to climax a succession of noteworthy performances in the first four championship events of the three-day program.

LONDON, June 19. -- The London Stock Exchange was cheerful again today under the lead of British funds, which continued in demand, partly on foreign account. European securities were firm and Brazilians improved further in the foreign department.

WASHINGTON, June 19. -- An incomplete record of nearly 1,000 individuals, corporations and partnerships that in the three years of Federal control of farm production had AAA contracts that brought them a minimum of $10,000 annually, was laid before the Senate today in a bulky report by the Farm Administration in response to Senator Vandenberg's resolution.

WASHINGTON, June 19. -- Representative William Lemke, Republican, of North Dakota, announced today that he would be a candidate for President on the Union party ticket, which he said he had been instrumental in "establishing officially."
WASHINGTON, June 19. -- While a filibuster was under way in the Senate to force House acceptance, the latter tonight refused to accept the Senate's version of the new ship subsidy legislation.
DETROIT, June 19. -- There was still no checking Joe McCarthy's astounding juggernaut as it rolled onto Navin Field today to bring more misery to a hopeful gathering of 13,000.

Victor F. Riader, local WPA Administrator, confirmed yesterday the announcement the day before by Frederick J. H. Kracke, Commissioner of Plant and Structures, that skilled rehet workers were taking private jobs in such numbers that they have slowed down the work of repaving the Queensboro and Williamsburg bridges.

Mayor La Guardia addressed a radio appeal to President Roosevelt yesterday in a broadcast interview at Station WOR, to "put his magic 'must' on the Wagner-Ellenbogen Housing Bill, which I regard as the most important measure before Congress today."
Deals for sites to be improved with apartment houses in Manhattan and the Bronx and a candy factory in Brooklyn were announced yesterday.

LONDON, June 19. -- Great Britain is determined to restore order in Palestine, "even if it means using inevitably harsh measures," Colonial Secretary William G.A. Ormsby-Gore told the House of Commons today at the end of a full-length debate on recent disturbances in the Holy Land.

After authorizing a referendum next Tuesday to settle a boundary dispute between the Bronx and Mount Vernon, the Board of Estimate disposed yesterday of several other pending matters in preparation for its Summer recess period.

MARION, Me., June 19. -- Twelve carefree children from Lubec, happy as they celebrated the last day of school, were drowned in Lake Gardner today when a sudden gust of wind capsized an outboard motor boat in which they were riding.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP). -- Legislation to assure government supervision of bondholders' protective committees and others who have charge of the liquidation of defaulted real estate securities for bondholders was suggested to the House today by a special investigating committee headed by Representative Sabath of Illinois.

PARIS, June 19. -- Following the statement of British policy yesterday by Anthony Eden, Foreign Secretary, France has decided to raise the financial and economic sanctions imposed against Italy by the League of Nations.

LONDON, June 19. -- With a slow field in prospect as the result of rains, England will resume her challenge for the international polo cup against the mercurial-paced defending American quartet tomorrow afternoon (9:30 A.M.E.S.T.) on the turf of the Hurlingham Club.

AKRON, Ohio, June 19. -- From this strike-torn area, again peaceful after an outbreak of industrial warfare in Kent yesterday, a group of rubber union organizers and officials left by airplane today for Gadsden, Ala., to begin a drive for a joint organization campaign in the steel, rubber and textile industries.

The problems of trustees and investors under trust indentures have received much attention as a result of various corporate reorganizations. Current interest in these questions is shown by the fact the special committees of the American Bankers Association and of the Investment Bankers Association have recently been appointed to study them.
PASADENA, Calif., June 19 (AP). -- Dr. Fritz Zwicky, distinguished astrophysicist, said today the newly discovered nova delta cephei may prove light is not the fastest thing in the universe.

Accused of taking a revolver from a patrolman, fracturing his skull with the butt of the weapon, driving away the policeman's automobile, shooting at other policemen and wounding a passerby. James Brown, 21 years old, a seaman, of 25 South Street, was held without bail for hearing Monday by Magistrate O'Dywer in Flatbush Court, Brooklyn, yesterday.

In connection with Don Lash's feat of running two miles in 8:58.3 at Princeton last week to break Paavo Nurmi's outdoor world record of 8:59.6, I would like to describe Nurmi's race to his world indoor record which took place on a cold, dreary night more than eleven years ago in the "old" Madison Square Garden.

PHILADELPHIA, June 19. -- Nomination of President Roosevelt by acclamation by the Democratic National Convention on Friday was predicted today by Postmaster General James A. Farley, chairman of the Democratic National Committee.

PARIS, June 19. -- France will not officially participate in the Olympic Games, but the government will ask Parliament to vote 1,000,000 francs to assist private sporting associations to send their representatives to Berlin.

Georg Bernhard, German exile and editor-in-chief of the Pariser Tageszeitung, gave a farewell address here last night on "A World Jewish Question." He is returning tonight to Paris, where be has made his home since Hitler expatriated him.

Cardinal Hayes announced yesterday the appointments to parishes as assistants or to other parochial duties of the young men he ordained to the priesthood two weeks ago this morning in St. Patrick's Cathedral. The Cardinal at the same time announced the transfer of many assistants from their parent parishes to other churches.

With the double objective of winning the intercollegiate outdoor polo crown and avenging an early season defeat, Harvard's strong quartet will combat Army's dashing riders in the final on Morris Memorial Field, Governors Island, today at 2:30 P.M.

MOSCOW, June 19. -- Today's eclipse of the sun, which reached totality across a seventy-mile-wide belt of the Soviet Union from the Black Sea to the Pacific Ocean, was observed under fairly good weather conditions. Of the five main groups of Soviet and foreign astronomers only one was wholly unsuccessful at Kustanaya, in Western Siberia, where the American Geographical Society and a Soviet group were completely foiled by rain.

Prices of commodity futures were generally higher in average trading yesterday. Sugar and coffee were lower. On the cash markets there were no declines, while all the grains, cotton, lard, princloths, wool tops and tins advanced.

LONDON, June 19. -- The possibility of a match race between Lord Stanley's filly, Quashed, and William Woodward's Omaha, which were separated by inches in that order at the finish of yesterday's running of the Ascot Gold Cup, was the chief topic today among England's turf followers.

LONG BEACH, L.I., June 19. -- Ray Billows, 22-year-old Poughkeepsie printing salesman, performed another one of his golfing miracles today at the Lido Country Club when he pulled a hopelessly lost match out of the fire and gained a place in tomorrow's thirty-six hole final of the Metropolitan amateur championship with George T. Dunlap Jr., former national amateur titleholder.

CHICAGO, June 19. -- A blanket denial of every charge of fraud, evasion of law and fleecing of real estate bondholders was made tonight on behalf of the Chicago Title and Trust Company by Chester Davis, vice president and trust officer, on being informed that the Sabath investigating committee's report had named this company and six others in Chicago.

The Rev. Father Charles E. Coughlin endorsed the Presidential candidacy of Representative William Lemke of North Dakota last night in a nation-wide radio broadcast, the text of which is printed on page 3 in this issue.

PARIS, June 19. -- After two weeks spent in Eastern and Central Europe, I have returned with the conviction that in the midst of a madly arming Europe fears of what in France is called "Main Street diplomacy," which foresees all sorts of strategic and military adventures, are not entirely justified by events.

WASHINGTON, June 19. -- Four separate statements opposing the Compromise Tax Bill were issued here today. One was filed by a Senate minority committee composed of Senators George and Walsh, another by Senator Byrd, and a third by a group of the House Conference Committee.
CHICAGO, June 19. -- Swift Co. and the Cudahy Packing Company today took legal steps to recover processing taxes paid to the Federal Government under the defunct Agricultural Adjustment Act.

Jack Dempsey, who used to be a pretty good heavyweight himself and whose popularity seems to ripen with age, was one of the earliest celebrities to make an appearance at the Stadium last night. Hatless and coatless, the old Manassa Mauler was there for the first preliminary but it wasn't until the end of the second one that he was able to take his seat in the second row.
NEW LONDON, Conn., June 19. -- A winning freshman crew buoyed the spirtis of the Harvard rowing camp today, with a splendid triumph that brought back memories of the 1930 yearling crew.
David E. Grange, president of the Marine Cooks and Stewards Union, announced yesterday that he would fight the court action of six union members who have charged him with dereliction of duty.

WASHINGTON, June 19. -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation announced today that it had awarded to the highest bidders the $4.935,000 issue of Great Northern Railway Company secured 4 per cent serial bonds and twenty-eight of the thirty-one issues of State, municipal, county and district securities on which bids were received yesterday.
ASHTABULA, Ohio, June 20 (AP). -- O.K. Stuart, 61, high wire walker, lay in a serious condition today in Ashtabula General Hospital from injuries received in a fall.

The establishment of a unified system of surface transportation in Manhattan will be completed tomorrow, when the New York City Omnibus Corporation begins bus operation on crosstown routes on Seventy-ninth Street, Ninety-sixth Street and Spring-Delancey Streets.

BISMARCK, N.D., June 20 (AP). -- North Dakota's bitterly fought primary campaign, expected to produce a record turnout of voters Wednesday, took on added importance today from Representative Lemke's entrance into the Presidential race as a third party candidate.

DAVENPORT, Iowa, June 20. -- Rangy Ray Mangrim of Dayton, Ohio, backed up his spectacular 66 with another par-smashing round of 67 today for an amazing thirty-six-hole total of 133 to cling to the lead in the annual Western open golf title battle at the halfway stage.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., June 20. -- State Representative Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. of Beverly was endorsed by the Republican State pre-Primary Convention this afternoon for the nomination for United States Senator, the position which has grandfather held for many years. Mr. Lodge is only 34 years old.

SUMMER theatres may come and Summer theatres may go, but the Westchester Playhouse near Mount Kisco, N.Y., has been going on now for seven seasons (five of them under its present management) -- and that, in a business which depends for its success upon the very careful currying of fickle fancies, is practically forever.

DETROIT, June 20. -- Deeming it high time that something be done toward revivifying a somewhat bewildered metropolis, which still finds it difficult to reconcile the running of its world champions in the second division and its Joe Louis not running at all, but lying on the flat of his back, the Tigers, behind an inspired brand of pitching by Tommy Bridges, turned-back the Yankees today, 5 to 0.

While the rush of veterans to spend their bonus windfall was not particularly marked, retail trade in the metropolitan area nevertheless made a good showing last week. Volume for the week, despite two poor days, ranged around 10 per centh over the comparative 1935 period and indicated a gain of that amount or more for the entire month.

Except for the first few yards, John Hay Whitney's Mr. Bones led all the way in the $11,050 Dwyer Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday to prove that his great race in the Belmont against Granville was not a flash in the pan. The dark brown son of Royal Minstrel, with Johnny Gilbert up, was a 7-to-10 favorite with the 15,000 spectators and finished the mile and a furlong over a fast track in 1:49 4-5.

WHICH way Paris? One look at the clothes assembled on this page shows that at this time the great design center on the Seine is of many minds about style trends. This is most noticeable when it comes to gowns created in the Summer mood. And why not? Since this is the season of informal social affairs, shouldn't styles also be casual?

The construction of 350 commercial ships is essential to the maintenance of the position of the United States as a maritime nation, according to a report prepared by the Department of Commerce. Proper facilities for the transport of a sufficient share of the nation's foreign commerce and auxiliary strength for the navy make such a program necessary, the report says.

THIS is get-away week for open-air symphony and opera presentations in this part of the country. The Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at the Lewisohn Stadium in New York, the San Carlo Opera Company at Jones Beach, the Hippodrome Opera Company at the Metropolitan Lyric Stadium in Brooklyn, the Philadelphia Orchestra in Robin Hood Dell, Fairmount Park, Philadelphia, are among the enterprises that will begin their seasons.

Requests for piece-price settlements by firms in the coat and suit industry, the most faithful barometer of production, indicate an increase in early activity of more than 200 per cent over the corresponding period last year and the year before, Samuel Klein, executive director of the Industrial Council of Coat, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, said yesterday.

Grace Harrington, plump, 9-year-old piano virtuoso from Palisades Park, N.J., received yesterday morning for the third consecutive year the Young Artist certificate of the National Guild of Piano Teachers. This was the highest honor conferred at special exercises at Aeolian Hall, where 102 certificates were presented to children whose performances were outstanding in the third annual New York piano-playing tournament, which was held early in June.

CHICAGO, June 20 (AP). -- Bob Johnson's ninth home run of the season was the deciding factor of a thrilling pitching duel between Harry Kelley and Sugar Cain and gave the Athletics a 2-to-1 victory over the White Sox today. Each pitcher allowed four hits.

A record-breaking fleet of sailing yachts is expected to compete in the annual race from the Stamford Y.C. to The Vineyard and return on Friday, Sept. 4, according to Racing Committee Chairman Frederick L. Reid of the Connecticut organization.
ST. PAUL, Minn., June 20. -- The State Supreme Court ruled today that grain trading, where the purchaser does not intend to accept delivery of grain purchased, is gambling.
CLEVELAND, June 20 (AP). -- Mel Harder pitched the Indians into a third-place tie with the Senators today as Cleveland defeated Washington the second time in two days, 2to 1.

JONES BEACH, L.I., June 20. -- Taking the lead at the start and increasing it with each stroke, Miss Elizabeth Ryan, 13-year-old star from the Women's Swimming Association, captured the national junior A.A.U. 440-yard free-style championship as the junior title events got under way today at Zach's Bay.

MORE attention is given by collectors than formerly to bringing out the charm and usefulness of their antiques through artistic arrangement. From the interior decorator they have received much help in enhancing the worth of individual pieces and making attractive combinations of furnishings.
STAUNTON, Va., June 20 (AP). -- The National Association of Gold Star Mothers of North America was organized today with Mrs. Mathilde Burling of Richmond Hill, N.Y., as president.
PARIS JUNE 18,

Brushing a fleck of chocolate ice cream from the lapel of his dark blue suit, Jimmy Hines sat down on the grass in Central Park yesterday and amused as many of his 25,000 youthful guests as one man could. As guests of himself and his fellow members of the Monongahela Democratic Club, he did his best to see they had all the ice cream, candy, soda pop and other delicacies they wanted.

Howard S. Cullman, vice chairman of the National Committee on Safety at Sea, urged yesterday that charges of the "rank and file" seamen alleging improper relations between union officials, ship lines and government officials be investigated.

The statue of Alexander Hamilton, which, since 1892, has been the imposing guardian of the Hamilton Club entrance in Brooklyn Heights, will be moved to Manhattan within a month, according to Alex B. Gale, president of the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club.

LOS ANGELES, June 20. -- Hundreds of Works Progress Administration administrative workers today received by special messenger sealed envelopes containing tickets for a Democratic rally, which the workers were asked to purchase at $1 each or to sell to their friends.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., June 20. -- An $830,000 fund for advancing the general welfare of Steubenville, Ohio, and Weirton, W.Va., and their environs was created in the will of John C. Williams, president of the Weirton Steel Company, who died June 1.
WASHINGTON, Sunday, June 20. -- A listless Congress this morning roared assent to sine die adjournment and went home.

The sugar trade here was disturbed by news from Washington, received soon after the close of trading on Friday, that a further increase of 203,000 short tons in United States sugar quotas had been ordered by the Department of Agriculture.

CHICAGO, June 20. -- Sweeping over a field studded with prospective Olympic stars, athletes from the University of Southern California ran rampant in the National Collegiate Athletic Association track and field championships at Stagg Field today, in which four world's records were eclipsed in the two days of competition.

The school children from every part of the city who have been studying the far-from-lost art of the folk dance in the Park Department's playgrounds throughout the five boroughs this Spring proved their competitive instinct as well as their talents yesterday before an enthusiastic gallery of their elders at the Chrystie-Forsyth playgrounds on the lower East Side.

DISTRIBUTION of the veterans' bonus had less than the expected effect in raising retail trade volume in the week, but unsettled weather conditions were responsible for some slight slackening through the country. Industrial areas reported continued gains, particularly the steel manufacturing sections.

VISITORS to the New York Botanical Garden last Summer and Fall may have noticed two beds of handsome begonias near the conservatory. Recognizable as semperflorens, they puzzled the uninitiated as to their variety.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., June 20. -- Painter Hall, oldest college building in Vermont and one of the finest examples of Colonial institutional architecture in existence, is to be completely remodeled this Summer, Frank L. Bell of Crown Point, N.Y., stated today for the Middlebury College trustees.

Plainly displeased by the revelation that a patrolman earning $2,810 a year had found it possible to bank $83,500 in eight years, Commissioner Valentine expressed his sentiments yesterday morning as to this disparity by suspending George Heidt of the Elizabeth Street station pending the filing of charges.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 20. -- Four hundred bank officials from forty-two States have enrolled for the 1936 session of the Graduate School of Banking which will open at Rutgers University on Monday under the auspices of the American Institute of Banking.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP). -- Representative Lemke of North Dakota, Union party candidate for President, said tonight that the new party probably would be set up at a convention of all interested groups in Cleveland some time in August.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., June 20. -Dr. Raymond L. Ditmars, Curator of Reptiles at The Bronx Zoo, will be 60 years old on Monday. He has not given the matter much thought, preferring to concentrate on the revised edition of his book "The Reptiles of North America," which goes into another edition in the Autumn, and to complete plans for his forthcoming trip in August or September to Trinidad.

With the spate of new books pouring from the presses every Spring and Fall it is well that a critic of Mrs. Becker's perception and discernment should see fit to mark time and remind readers of those older books which are not necessarily forgotten, but which, under that onerous term "classic," are taken for granted and often overlooked.

"Accident Facts," 1936 edition, published by the National Safety Council, confirms last year's high record of 37,000 motor vehicle fatalities, a slight increase in the death rate on a population basis balancing a slight decrease in the death rate on a gasoline consumption basis. The council does not agree with those automobile manufacturers who argue that highway defects are a prime cause of motor accidents; it places them among the "less important" causes.

THE gardener often must wait a long time after the blossoming period of flowers he admires before he can plant the specimens in his own garden. The enthusiasm he develops when he sees new daffodils, tulips or delphiniums in his neighbors' gardens, at trial grounds or in flower shows cannot be translated immediately into action.

A LADY of letters, penetrating to realities by her woman's intuition, elucidates one who, during her lifetime, had so defied the conventions as to become a lady of legend. To others Lady Hester Stanhope was unique: Miss Haslip reveals -- as Dr. Buchman would put it, she shares -- the subtle yet surging instincts that account for the phenomenon.

THE continuity of these poems -- to use the word in its movie sense -- gives them far more importance than any single one seemed to have when it first appeared in a magazine. A seventeenth-century poet would probably have prefaced them with an argument, and we might make a shot at one, subject to the reviewer's inevitable fumbling in prose with poetry.

WILLIAMS BAY, Wis., June 20 (AP). -- The exploding star in the northeastern sky mystified astronomers tonight by adding iron to the blazing stuff it hurled out into space. The iron appeared in the spectrum bands -- color pictures of the star's light -- observed through telescopes at Yerkes Observatory, as the star grew brighter.

Nothing is more pleasingly symbolic of the new spirit in the Republican party than the choice of two pipe-smokers to lead the ticket. Governor LANDON and Colonel KNOX are briar brethren. According to candid campaign photographs, they unite on the straight-stem pipe, which is not the most profound but the most aggressive type.
LONDON, June 20. -- The detailed description of the second match of the Westchester Cup polo series at the Hurlingham Club today follows:

IN her slightly defensive foreword to this novel, Cora Jarrett stresses the honorable tradition behind excursions into the supernormal, the exorbitant, the bizarre. From Shakespeare onward, she says, the hypothetical has always held a special attraction for writers.

BILL JESSE McDONALD was one of the important members of that famous band of frontier keepers of the peace, the Texas Rangers, of which for twenty years he was captain. His full biography was written some twenty-five years ago by Albert Bigelow Paine.

LIS ANDERSEN is a lucky girl. During her twelfth year this daughter of a sea-fevered father sailed the Atlantic in the Monsoon, a rickety ketch which had seen better days as a French fishing smack, but which was capable of carrying this Danish family on one of those adventures which haunt the dreams of children and adults alike.

LONG BEACH, L.I., June 20. -- The sensational spurt of Ray. Billows, 22-year-old Poughkeepsie printing salesman, was brought to an end today, but it took one of the best golfers in the country to do the job.

ROME, June 20 (AP). -- Marchese Guglielmo Marconi was named a Rear Admiral of the Italian Navy by Premier Mussolini today. The decree was issued by Mussolini's authority as Minister of the Navy. Mussolini also appointed Baron Pompeo Aloisi, Italian delegate to the League of Nations, to the rank of Rear Admiral.
WASHINGTON, June 20. -- In dollars and cents, here is how the new Tax Bill would work out for various sized corporations:

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., June 20. -- Next week-end East Hampton will be in Colonial costume to greet visitors coming for the two-day celebration of Long Island's tercentenary. A replica of an old windmill will be erected on the green at the entrance to the village for use as an information bureau, and descendants of pioneer families who settled East Hampton in 1649 will greet visitors.

ORANGE, N.J., June 20. -- William Umstaedter of Millburn, national boys' doubles champion, continued undefeated this season as he won the New Jersey Center boys' tennis championship at the Berkeley Tennis Club today from Joseph Greenberg of New York, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 3.

THE short reign of Jadwiga, Queen of Poland, at the end of the fourteenth century, was the prelude to her country's golden age. She was a Hungarian princess of French, Italian, Bosnian and Polish origin. At the age of 7 she was married to William, heir to the Austrian throne.

SAN FRAINCISCO, June 20. -- The Board of State Harbor Commissioners has refused to increase port rates at San Francisco as requested by the ports of Los Angeles, Long Beach, Oakland and Stockton, according to word received yesterday from P.W. Meherin.

PITTSBURGH, June 19. -- Following an opera bouffe "revolution" in which for a time it had two separate police organizations, Pittsburgh has settled down to watch what may at last become a real fight on the part of its ordinarily light-hearted and wise-cracking Mayor, William N. McNair, to retain his office.

GENEVA, June 20. -- Argentina has informally warned the secretariat of the League of Nations, it is understood, that she will withdraw from the League if the Assembly fails at its next session to apply the non-recognition principle to Italy's annexation of Ethiopia.
SOFIA, Bulgaria, June 20. -- The visit to the Balkans and Central Europe of Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, German Minister of Economics, concluding this week, was outwardly a triumphal progress.

Stocks moved higher last week but trading was dull. Industrial and trade news was good, so much so that predictions are already being made that the political campaign will not greatly interfere with the recovery movement. The "public" is not back in the market, but signs point to a resumption of interest from this quarter, particularly if the market further shows its ability to retain most of the advantages gained on rallies.
One of the most eventful years in the administration of the city's public schools will be brought to a close on Friday.

PASADENA, Calif., June 20. -- A suggestion that cosmic rays may be faster than light is put forward by Dr. Fritz Zwicky, authority on exploding stars at the California Institute of Technology, in connection with the observations of the exploding star, Nova Cephei.

WASHINGTON, June 20. -- Harry L. Hopkins and his aides in the Works Progress Administration explained today in a question and answer radio broadcast the new Federal work relief program. The officials confirmed published reports that the actual need of applicants for work relief and prevailing wages would be determined locally as the work program continued under the $1,245,000,000 appropriation just approved by Congress.
THEY were carting what was left of Shufflin' Joe Louis to his corner when up came three or four hilarious citizens wagging their fingers in an accusing way and chortling: "Now what have you to say?"

SINCE he leaped to fame and Hollywood by writing "Bury the Dead" a lot of people must have wondered what Irwin Shaw has been up to -- i. e., as a dramatist, not as a football scenario writer. Well, what Mr. Shaw has been up to is something pretty different from "Bury the Dead."

BOSTON, June 20. -- The distribution of bonus checks has already had something of a stimulating effect upon retail sales of merchandise. Sales of automobiles this week reached the highest level in six years. The movement was heavy not only among used cars but new car sales also jumped up sharply.

Stroking in flawless style, William T. Tilden of Philadelphia yesterday defeated Bruce Barnes, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 0, in a singles tennis exhibition match that was the highlight of a show conducted at the Tudor City Tennis Club before a gallery of 1,200 spectators.

Consumer cooperation offers the "only constitutional way which has so far been discovered of solving the most menacing of our business problems," and it is only the "most superficial observers who see in it any menace to existing business," according to a study issued yesterday by the Consumer Distribution Corporation, the central wholesale unit of the League of Cooperative Department Stores planned by E.A. Filene.

WIDELY known as lecturer, author, maker of beautiful pictures, preacher, authority upon and collector of antique furniture, Wallace Nutting has come into such close contact with the American public that, he says, it has long been besieging him for personal information, and he has had so many requests for an autobiography that he has at last decided he can throw upon the public the responsibility for this volume.

LONDON. -- The human race is growing taller, with city dwellers generally bigger than country people, according to a study of human growth over a number of years, details of which are given in The British Medical Journal.

AN all-Beethoven program conducted by Jose Iturbi, will open the Stadium season Wednesday night. The soloist for the opening night will be Albert Spalding, who will be heard in the violin concerto. On Friday, in the absence of Mr. Iturbi, who will go to Philadelphia to open the season of Summer Concerts there, Alexander Smallens will conduct an all-Russian program with Remo Bolognini as violin soloist.

When President Roosevelt, on Jan. 3, delivered his opening message. to Congress, it seemed that the session would be very short. The President stood pat on his New Deal. He demanded no further innovations; proudly he pointed to increasing national income which, he said, by itself was bringing an approach to a balanced budget. Then came this pleasing, paragraph:

ATLANTA, June 20. -- Expansion of virtually all major lines of trade was maintained in the Sixth Federal Reserve District this week. Consumer buying was brisk, as warm, dry weather prevailed in most of the area's large cities. Leading department stores reported volume of sales from 12 to 15 per cent above the same period of last year.

MADRID, June 19. -- Immediately after the February elections, Manuel Azana, then Premier and now President of the Republic, said the victorious Popular Front would not exact political vengeance on the Conservatives, who had been in power for two years. If this promise i had been kept there would undoubt- ! edly have been fewer disorders and less property destruction and bloodshed.
Papyri have been discovered in Palestine for the first time in history, according to word received yesterday by Casper J. Kraemer Jr., Professor of Classics of New York University.

OAKDALE, L.I., June 20. -- Evander Childs High School's brilliant array of athletes from the Bronx today brought to an end the most successful track and field year of its history by romping off with the team laurels in the third annual La Salle Military Academy invitation meet.

TODAY'S garden has become more than a place in which to grow things; it is the outdoor room of the house, where one rests and reads and dines and serves tea, even though the plot may be a mere patch of ground at the rear of a city house, or a small suburban yard.

THE Lewisohn Stadium concerts are verging on their majority. Wednesday night's opening will begin the nineteenth Summer of an enterprise that has weathered the depression without curtailment of the length or scope of its seasons.
LONDON, June 20. -- Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin today vigorously defended his government's decision to drop sanctions, declaring war was the only alternative.

JERUSALEM, June 20. -- "Between the Arabians in Palestine and the Jews migrating into the country a life-and-death struggle is raging, a struggle which will not cease before one of the parties has been completely crushed." These words were uttered by Jamal el Husseini, leader of the Arabian Nationalist party, when he was interviewed on the political situation in Palestine.

HILLEL BERNSTEIN, who not so long ago entertained a large number of people with a rollicking satirical farce called "L'Affaire Jones," has in his second book turned to straight and earnest satire. In fact, Mr. Bernstein has been attacked by an ailment that has killed off more than one humorist: he has been infected with a Cause.

THIRTY-FOUR new laws affecting motor vehicle regulation in New York were signed by Governor Lehman during and following the four and a half months' session of the Legislature which ended May 14. Some of these new laws go into effect on July 1; others on Sept. 1 and still others a year hence.

IN this fine and distinguished book Mr. Williamson tells the story of Atlantic salmon, from the rivers where their lives begin to the sea where they wander full grown, and their return over thousands of miles to complete the cycle and spawn in the rivers where they were born.

In a setting that was a strange contrast between modern American and native Chinese dress and custom, the Chinese Community Committee held its first field day and baby parade yesterday afternoon in the Park Department playground in historic old Columbus Park, Baxter and Mulberry Streets.

Stating that the main lines have continued to be satisfactorily productive, "actually and comparatively,'' Fairfax Harrison, president of the Southern Railway Company, in his report for 1935, says that "the problem has been to control the expenses of what now appears to be a disproportionate mileage of local and branch lines taken into the system a generation ago under conditions which no longer obtain."

RENTS to concessionaires of New York are going up, if the recent auction of ferry-house privileges by the Commissioner of Plant and Structures may be taken as an indication. For several months the Fusion administration has been making a determined effort to cure one of the long-standing headaches of municipal government, the concession problem.

SO satisfactory have been its tests at Oakland with the system of blind landings by the use of a combination of the bent radio beam and the Sperry gyropilot that the United Air Lines will make further detailed study of apparatus, it was disclosed last week, during the peak months of Summer traffic and resume tests on a larger scale in the Autumn.

LONDON, June 20. -- The United States polo team gained another great and glorious victory this afternoon, beating England in the second of the series of three matches for the Westchester Cup at the Hurlingham Club, 8 to 6.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- A supplemental report of transactions in equity securities by officers, directors and principal stockholders of corporations for April was made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission. It showed a continuation of the trend in which sales exceeded purchases.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20. -- Under the disapproving eyes of five loyal old Republican watchdogs of the Union League Club, the delegates to the national convention of New Dealers, alias the Democratic party, began assembling today to go through the motions of adopting a platform and nominating a candidate for the Presidency of the United States.

THE third annual Berkshire Symphonic Festival, at which which the Boston Symphony, under Koussevitzky will be the attraction, will be held Aug. 13, 15 and 16, at Holmwood, the estate of Mrs. Margaret Emerson, between Lenox and Stockbridge, Mass.

AN unusually brilliant high school student, applying for admission to a Midwestern college, asked if he could receive college credit, on the basis of examinations, for extra work done in high school. The register replied promptly that that sort of thing was never done at his college.

Because of substantial increases in production of crude oil and manufacture of gasoline, "there have been superficial indications of late that lower prices may be expected unless the industry cuts down its runs," says The Lamp, official publication of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey.

At 2:00 P.M. New York daylight time, the airship Hindenburg was reported by Mackay Radio at Lat. 53.27 N., Long. 31.10 W., or about over mid-Atlantic. No further reports had been received last evening.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., June 20. -- The first of the June debutante parties on Long Island took place tonight at Round Bush, the home of Mr. and Mrs. Paul G. Pennoyer, where their eldest daughter, Miss Virginia Morgan Pennoyer, was introduced to society at a dinner dance for the younger set and a few of the married friends of her parents.

TOMORROW at noon the sharp crack of a pistol will start some forty-nine yachts on a 635-mile race from Brenton's Reef, off Newport, to the Bermudas. Most of them are American vessels, although there will be German, Swedish, Norwegian and British entrants as well.

TWELVE years ago Secretary Denby invited eighty newspaper editors and publishers to be the guests of the fleet at Culebra, east of Puerto Rico, for the purpose of getting acquainted with the navy, of which those following their profession in the interior of the country knew very little.

Nobody made a speech, but a steam-shovel opened its capacious jaws and dug into the dirt. Thus, without ceremony, work was inaugurated last week on the Flushing site of New York's Fair, which is to open in the Spring of 1939.

ANEW line of 1936-37 broadcast receivers featuring "focused tone" is being introduced on the market by the General Electric Company. When the tuner is not exactly on a station's wave the entire dial is red, but as the set is accurately tuned the dial turns green.

WASHINGTON, June 20. -- Striking at what it considers harmful speculative activities, the Securities and Exchange Commission in a report to Congress announced today that it soon would initate a program to control this situation by segregating functions of brokers and dealers on the floors of the organized Exchanges.

WITH a view to improving agricultural production, Mexico is adopting the methods of the old-fashioned State fair, which played such a lively role in the development of our own Midwest. According to recent announcements from the Ministry of Agriculture, a whole series of State fairs has been planned, to be held annually throughout the Mexican Republic.

BOSTON, June 19. -- The shutdown of an important group of shoe factories in Brockton is the latest illustration of the tendency to leave the State, long manifested by both the cotton textile and the shoe industries.

THE purpose of this book is to teach business executives how to use psychology in dealing with themselves and with others. As a collection of the simplest first steps toward an approach to the study of psychology this work is passing.

DOWN in the colorful Southwest there lies a region about half the size of the State of New York, something of a land of wonders that is only now being discovered by the travel-wise. It occupies the "upper right-hand corner" of Arizona; along the bottom it is edged with a double-track steel highway, which in turn is paralleled by a ribbon of pavement -- the country's oldest transcontinental highway.

PARIS. AS the days grow longer and the weather grows warmer -- the latter development having been hastened this year by a heat wave -- it is interesting to see what productions have managed to survive these seasonal phenomena, both of them so unwholesome for the theatre.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 20. -- Seven hundred members of the Greenwich Country Club and guests attended the first of a series of headliner dinner dances at the clubhouse tonight. Howard E. Spaulding is chairman of the entertainment committee.

THE authors of this small volume are justified in their subtitle. If any tourist, traveler or citizen within the confines of the Cape should want more information about it, or more enthusiasm concerning it, than they have compressed within their two hundred-odd pages, he would lay himself liable to the charge of being an unreasonable person.

TOPEKA, Kan., June 19. -- The Republican campaign plans, as they have been outlined here this week, indicate the intention of the party leaders to do two things. The first is to have Governor Alf M. Landon and his running-mate, Colonel Frank Knox, wage a fairly orthodox type of campaign.

PARIS, June 20 (AP). -- The Riviera strike coincided with the first move by Paris Rightists to eject idle workers occupying their places of employment. The Rightists, numbering twenty, under the leadership of Deputy Raoul Sabatier, smashed into a restaurant, threw seven strikers into the street and occupied the place themselves.
Twelve deaths in the United States and Canada were ascribed to excitement over the Louis-Schmeling fight, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20. -- To meet the possible menace to President Roosevelt's re-election raised by the candidacy of Representative Lemke of North Dakota on a third-party ticket, Democratic leaders were planning tonight to appeal to the elements from which Mr. Lemke may derive support.

YONKERS, N.Y., June 20. -- Bill Bonthron found his winning touch today and, running much like the Bonthron of old, slammed through to his first foot-racing victory in two years. A crowd of 8,000 that jammed into the stands at Glen Park and perched on the encircling hillsides for the Metropolitan A.A.U. senior track and field championships watched Bonny take another gigantic step along the comeback trail.

ELMIRA, N.Y., June 20. -- Under a blazing sun several thousand Elmirans and visitors gathered this afternoon for the initial ceremonies of the seventh annual national glider contest under the auspices of the Soaring Society of America.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 20. -- A junior subscription dance at the Round Hill Club tonight attracted 100 boys and girls between the ages of 13 and 16. There was a program of entertainment and dancing on the terrace, where a supper was served.

Pleasant diversion of a comfortable kind is offered by this romance of two generations, carried on simultaneously. There is a variety of charming settings.
