The author picks up her characters at Farover, a delightfully hospitable old estate in Virginia, which its old mistress, due to her fallen fortunes, now conducts as a retreat for paying guests, most of them old friends.

TO Judge from this swift-moving tale Mr. Graham Greene might be called the English W.R. Burnett without too much straining for a comparison. The story is well contrived and Mr. Greene tries to probe below the surface in his study of a young killer, to avoid both the callousness of some stereotyped crime stories and the sentimentality of others.

The Federal Government must go ahead with its housing program to help the lowest income group because private initiative, unable to get profits from decent housing for one-third of the country's population, has done nothing to improve conditions, Public Works Administrator Harold L. Ickes declared here yesterday.

A NEW chapter has been added to the sensational disclosures immured in the volume by John Carter and Graham Pollard which appeared two Summers ago. Theirs, it will be remembered, was the explosive document with the innocent-seeming title, "An Enquiry into the Nature of Certain Nineteenth Century Pamphlets."

WASHINGTON, June 20. -- In the press of last-minute business, the Senate held a special executive session tonight in which it confirmed the nominations of John W. Clancy and Samuel Mandelbaum to be Federal judges for the Southern District of New York. The appointments were made by President Roosevelt a few days ago to the two new benches which Congress authorized a few weeks ago.

Tuesday night, Sept. 8, has been selected as the date for the first annual Eastern all-star football game between a team of the outstanding college players graduated in 1936 and the New York Giants, Eastern professional champions.

AFTER more than two years of joint efforts, officials and civic leaders in Japan and representatives of Harvard University and of the Boston Museum of Fine Arts have been successful in arranging for a loan exhibition of Japanese art from Japan to be opened at the Boston Museum during the Harvard Tercentenary celebration.

OUT into the surge of blue water from the countless coves and inlets which break our coast line from Virginia to Maine, a motley fleet heads into the rising sun each morning, bound for the off-shore banks and their finny treasure.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

TWO new operas, "Der Friedenstag" and "Daphne," are being composed by Richard Strauss, who has just celebrated his seventy-second birthday (June 11). According to advices from abroad, the text of both of the operas have been supplied by Joseph Gregor, chief librarian of the State Library of Vienna, a historian and essayist who gained recognition with his "History of the Modern Theatre."

LONDON, June 20. -- Red-haired Don Budge of Oakland, Calif., carried off the major share of the honors today in the final rounds of the Queen's Club tennis tournament, boosting his stock as one of Fred Perry's chief challengers in the all-England championships starting Monday at Wimbledon.

The official bulletin about MICHEAL T. GOTTLIEB reads a good deal like an inspired news item in the Moscow Pravda or in Herr HTTLER'S personal Berlin organ. Mr. GOTTLIEB was until the other day captain of the Four Aces, whom it is safe to call the best-known contract bridge team in the country.

DES MOINES, Iowa, June 20. -- America's aquatic stars heightened Uncle Sam's Olympic hopes today when they bettered one world and two American long-course marks in the men's National A.A.U. swimming championships.

BISMARCK, N.D., June 20. -- Citizens gathered in mass meetings for a united front in the drought emergency heard Governor Walter Welford relay the assurance of President Roosevelt today that the State would receive all possible support.

PITTSBURGH, June 19. -- "Giant steel," the five-billion-dollar industry whose far-flung arteries stretch from the iron ore beds in the Middle Northwest to the smoke-darkened communities of Illinois, Ohio, Indiana, Pennsylvania and as far south as Alabama, is having "labor trouble."

SCANNING three weeks' commencement oratory as recorded by the daily press, one has the impression that the main adjuration to youth has been to maintain the equality of opportunity offered by this country against the assaults of dictatorship and fascism.

EVEN if the publishers had not told us that Jennie Rosenholtz herself belongs to one of those isolated Jewish families who went pioneering into the farming country of the Middle West, we should nevertheless have suspected that much of this novel was based upon personal experience.

TORONTO, June 20. -- Payments and declarations of dividends by Canadian mining companies thus far in 1936 have amounted to $40,151,166, compared with $59,107,965 for all of 1935. On the basis of this record and of the steadily improving position of the Canadian mining industry, it is estimated that total dividend payments to shareholders this year will be near $75,000,000, a record-breaking figure.

CHICAGO, June 20. -- Showing a fine burst of speed as the field headed into the stretch, Hollyrood, the speedy thoroughbred from Hal Price Headley's stable, captured the $15,000 added Chicago Derby before 20,000 spectators at Hawthorne today.

ORDINARILY, this would be the slack season in the cinema, the intermediary period when the leftovers from last year's production schedules are being dumped on the sultry Summer market to clear the theatrical calendars for the brighter product that is to come.

THERE is still a hint of gorse and thistle about the Glasgow-born director, Frank Lloyd, even after a quarter-century in this country's motion-picture business. It is strongest when he gets enthusiastic, as he did in discussing his latest assignment, "Maid of Salem," for Paramount, a tragic romance of the witchcraft days.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va. -- With the emerald Alleghanies resplendent in the beauty of early Summer garb, the Greenbrier, nestling in a valley six miles from the wooded crest of this mountain range, offers a beautiful setting for the delegates to the biennial convention of the Chi Omega, social fraternity for women.

Educators in the metropolitan area will leave in two special trains Tuesday and Wednesday evenings for Portland, Ore., to attend the annual convention of the National Education Association which opens next Sunday. Dr. William H. Holmes, Superintendent of Schools in Mount Vernon, is a candidate for the office of president of the association.

I am sorry that Mr. Millholland has brought up once again the old question of who won the war. For any discussion of that question is, of course, futile, though I am sure the author of "The Splinter Fleet" does not seriously intend to have us believe that American sub-chasers won the war, as both his book and his letter infer.

THE Japanese beetle will soon emerge from the soil and will be present in the "beetle" stage of its life-cycle from late in June, through July and up to early August. Many gardeners are vitally interested in the best methods of preventing the injury the creature causes to trees, shrubs, plants and flowers.

SEASICKNESS seems to be a subject which offers much to suffer and little to say. Certainly this "guide to and from" its discomforts wraps its pertinent material generously in padding and repetition. The padding does not take the form merely of puns land other would-be humor but brings in pages of wordy dissertations on traveling which are probably intended to be informative, but are more often simply dull.

IT was the late Otto Kahn who christened "New Faces." Its inventor, champion and confessor, Leonard Sillman, had been rehearsing the first of these fledgling romps -- it was the bleak December of '33 -- for some four months, rehearsing it in walk-up apartments, mice-ridden studios, chilled cellars and the Algonquin lobby when Frank Case wasn't looking.

Mrs. Henrietta Wimpfheimer will observe her 100th birthday today at her home, 470 West End Avenue. Owing to mourning the birthday celebration will be limited to a family gathering, which will include Mrs. Wimpfheimer's four daughters, fifteen grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren.

HEREIN we have certain further adventures of Sheriff Blue Steele and his deputy, Shorty Watts, who were introduced to Western fans by Tom Gunn in a swift and lively tale of the old rough and ready days in Arizona Territory called "The Sheriff of Painted Post."

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP). -- A victory for Senate filibusterers was recorded today with final Congressional approval of legislation to expand the American merchant marine through direct government subsidies.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., June 20. -- The fiftieth anniversary of the ordination of the Rev. Richard O'Donnell, pastor of St. Rose of Lima Church, Aider Brook, was celebrated Monday at the church where more than fifty priests, monsignori and 2,000 members of the diocese of Ogdensburg attended.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 20. -- Miss Norma Taubele of New York stroked her way to an easy victory in the women's Eastern clay court championship at the Montclair Athletic Club today. Miss. Taubele defeated Miss Edith Moore of Montclair in the final, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 3.

THE first exhibition of the 1936-37 season at the Museum of Modern Art will open on Sept. 16. It is to be entitled "New Horizons in American Art" and will be a comprehensive exhibition of the work done under the Federal Art Project of the Works Progress Administration during the year of activity since the organization of the project last August.
MANKIND is preparing for war. Yet the wish for peace is strong. Though militarism is organized as never before, the organization is not all on one side.

CHICAGO, June 20. -- Despite a short period of unseasonably cool weather, retail trade this week was about 10 per cent ahead of a year ago. Hot weather marked the distribution of bonus cheeks and merchants experienced a sharp demand for dry goods, especially Summer wear.

The first broadcast of a high school graduation exercise in the metropolitan area will take place Wednesday night when the commencement program of Samuel J. Tilden High School of Brooklyn will be sent over the Municipal Broadcasting Station, WNYC, it was announced yesterday.

THE Summer season, as it grows in intensity from year to year, takes on a decided character of its own quite different from that of the more formal periods. Apparently its dominant note is a migratory one; dancers, teachers, students, do their best to separate themselves from their customary orbits of activity and either show their own work in other fields or else attempt to find out what is going on in these fields.

WASHINGTON, June 20. -- Business will feel the first heavy impact of bonus cash during the coming week. Although almost $1,800, 000,000 in bonds and small checks was distributed to veterans last week, only comparatively small driblets of the cash found their way immediately into trade channels.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20. -- President Roosevelt is pictured as the personification of one of three great struggles in the history of America by two writers who have contributed to the de luxe Democratic National Convention Book, issued by the national committee on the eve of next week's party gathering.

LONDON. -- Having spent the best part of eighteen years since the World War trying to turn their armaments into ploughshares, the British, finding a restless and rearmed Europe just across their protecting strip of Channel are endeavoring to reverse the process in eighteen months.

PORTLAND, Ore., June 19. -- All signs indicate that Senator Borah of Idaho, his aspirations for the Republican Presidential nomination at an end, will seek re-election to the upper house at Washington, which has been the scene of his activities for thirty years.

At least 17,000 of the city's school children need the physical benefits of a Summer camp, their principals informed the Bureau of Attendance of the Board of Education, in answer to a questionnaire, made public yesterday.

Four experienced young Long Island players, headed by F. Skiddy von Stade Jr., placed Harvard back on the polo pinnacle yesterday by toppling Army, 8 to 7, in the intercollegiate outdoor championship final on Morris Memorial Field, Governors Island.

WASHINGTON, June 20. -- Jouett Shouse, president of the American Liberty League and former chairman of an executive committee of the Democratic National Committee, in an address tonight over a National Broadcasting Company network concluded an attack on the New Deal with the statement that Democrats "left without a party in present circumstances must decide the course they will pursue."

WASHINGTON, June 20. -- The Veterans Administration said today that only 10 per cent of the eligible veterans had failed to apply for their bonus bonds so far, and that early indications were that a large number of those already in receipt of bonds were seeking to convert them into cash.

GOSHEN, N.Y., June 20. -- Rex Mays of Glendale, Calif., won the 100-mile national championship automobile race at Good Time Park today by almost half a lap from Wilbur Shaw of Indianapolis, who finished second, and Doc Mackenzie of Eddington, Pa., who was a close third.

The enlargement of the list of railroads recommended by Joseph B. Eastman for investigation by the Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce was interpreted in Wall Street as meaning that the activities of railroad holding companies would be included in the inquiry.

THERE is a new type of campaign manager in the national political arena. When John Daniel Miller Hamilton burst upon the astonished Republican convention and by deft strategy helped bring about the nomination of Governor Landon for the Presidency, it was obvious that the country had traveled a long way from the days of Mark Hanna.

WASHINGTON, June 20. -- The Senate committee made public today without comment an analysis it has worked out to show the principal sources of revenue of a number of organizations, attempting to establish that these bodies draw their financial support almost exclusively from groups of wealthy individuals, banks and utility companies.

WASHINGTON, Sunday, June 21. -- With the galleries crowded the House met at 10:30 yesterday morning, some of its members manifestly irritated because they realized they would be unable to get through pet private bills in the last-minute rush.

Pledging themselves to "rid Harlem of the corrupt political control of the two major parties," more than 100 delegates, representing practically every social, religious and civic organization of that community, attended the opening session yesterday of a two-day convention of the Independent Political Action party at the Renaissance Casino, Seventh Avenue and 138th Street.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., June 20. -- The fifth annual Plainfield Horse Show came to a successful close in the spacious ring of the Vinebrook Farm today with championship honors being divided between Mrs. R.L. Benson's stable of Princeton and Charles W. Cook's Mill Stream Farm of Spring Lake, each of which carried off two rosettes.

Two more patrolmen were dismissed from the Police Department yesterday by Commissioner Valentine bringing to 114 the total number who have been discharged since he took office in September of 1934. He also announced the demotion of two detectives.

The franc rallied strongly yesterday and the flow of gold from Paris to New York halted. The improvement was looked upon in foreign exchange circles as reflecting the announcement on Friday by the French Finance Minister of plans for penalizing the flight of capital.
ASBURY PARK, N.J. -- With rentals of Summer homes far in advance of the same period last year, resorts of the North Jersey shore are hoping for a record-breaking season.

CLEVELAND, June 20. -- Operations in steel works advanced further this week in response to the continued heavy demand for material for immediate consumption, chiefly tin plate and miscellaneous steels, and also because of an increasing amount of advance speculative buying.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., June 20. -- More than 250 persons attended the ball tonight at the Siwanoy Country Club in connection with the annual Bronxville Riding Club horse show on the grounds of the clubhouse in Tuckahoe.
Additional donations to the campaign of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee were announced yesterday by Laurence M. Marks, chairman, from the headquarters of the organization at 14 Wall Street.

The ocean yacht race to Bermuda, one of the leading blue-water events on this side of the Atlantic, will begin tomorrow off Newport with more entries than ever before. If all those that have been entered start, there will be forty-seven yachts, including nine from Europe.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 20. -- Malcolm W. Greenough's new Paine-designed sloop White Lady led the Eastern Yacht Club's fleet around Race Point on Fishers Island this afternoon as the racers in the ocean contest from here to Marblehead, Mass., above Boston, straightened out on the course that will take them through Block Island and Vineyard Sounds, over Nantucket Shoals and up around Cape Cod.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20. -- Reinforced by Governor Landon's telegram to the Republican convention stressing his interest in the merit system in the civil service, the National League of Women Voters is opening headquarters here for a similar campaign for Democratic endorsement.

HAVANA, June 20. -- In an effort to stem the rising tide of criticism over the dilatory action of the government, President Miguel Mariano Gomez issued today a statement assuring the nation an ample amnesty bill would be enacted shortly; that the Constitutent Assembly would be called promptly, and that the problem of the university would be settled without delay.
LONDON, June 17. -- Next week's theatrical openings, a shorter list than in recent days, reads something like this:

HOYLAKE, England, June 20. -- The qualifying rounds of the British open golf championship will be played at Hoylake and the neighboring Cheshire course at Wallasey Monday and Tuesday, and on the three following days, the wheat having been duly sifted from the chaff, the tournament proper will be staged at Hoylake.

The nomination of Colonel Frank Knox, New Hampshire and Illinois newspaper publisher, as Republican candidate for Vice President was a logical selection. Although not the first choice of the party's Eastern reactionaries, Knox is conservative enough to meet their approval without being unacceptable to the mildly liberal Landon, who heads the G.O.P. ticket.

A GITATION against compulsory military drill in American high schools and colleges is entering a new phase with the initiative campaigns now under way in Oregon and Washington. Petitions proposing that all military courses be placed on a voluntary basis are being circulated in both States by student peace groups and other organizations.
WASHINGTON, June 20. -- The whirl and drive of previous days under the New Deal were missing tonight as the Seventy-fourth Congress pushed its weary way toward the end of the session.

THEIR pasteurization experiment with Paul Muni having proved artistically and box-officially satisfying, Warner Brothers began opening histories and biographies for what is known in the trade as the follow-up. The follow-up is something like the "two" in pugilism's "one-two."

OVER this week-end Scouts of the Bronx and Staten Island are on "camporee" -- a word coined to describe the one-day camping program in which the Boy Scouts demonstrate their efficiency under boy leaders. Each season camporees grow in popularity.

MR. DESVERNINE'S book is an examination of the charge that the Roosevelt policies have as their aim the transformation of the political, economic and social institutions of the United States in ways which are incompatible with American ideals, and that the trend is definitely in the direction of a totalitarian State.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 20. -- Five members of the Princeton University faculty, two of them members of the original group of "preceptors" brought to the campus in 1905 by Woodrow Wilson, are retiring this year after teaching a Princeton an average of more than thirty years.

TRENTON, N.J., June 20. -- Colonel Mark O. Kimberling, who took office this week as superintendent of the New Jersey State Police Department, disclosed today that at the request of Governor Hoffman he had recalled Sergeant Eugene Haussling of the Detective Bureau from Brooklyn to make a detailed report on the case of Paul H. Wendel.

HISTORY is full of surprises, and no one can say with any certainty what lies ahead even in the immediate years to come. Yet even the dull observer is aware that our civilization is on the edge of an abyss, over which a new world war would almost certainly push it.

Manufacturing plants in industrial centers of the East and Midwest are escaping the seasonal Summer slump in activity this year because of the vigor which characterizes the current recovery trend, according to the monthly survey of industrial conditions completed yesterday by the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents.

DETROIT, Tune 20 (AP). -- Prosecutor McCrea asked Governor Davey of Ohio today to make a personal investigation of the Black Legion in that State, asserting that his information indicates that "the State of Ohio is the headquarters of the ranking officers."

The story begins with the disappearance of a London business man on his way to his home in the suburbs. Other and more sinister developments follow, and there is reason to believe that a secret society with headquarters somewhere in the Balkans is seeking revenge for real or fancied wrongs.

IT has been many a year since the Southwest has done as much primping, paining and polishing as it is doing at present. The writer has made a fairly comprehensive trip covering the Southwest from Eastern Texas to the Pacific Coast and from Boulder Dam to the Mexican border and everywhere these Southwestern people are preparing for a banner year.
WASHINGTON, June 20. -- The Seventy-fourth Congress will go down in history as the $20,000,000,000 Congress, of which $9,716,430,863 represents the expenditures voted by the second session.

The Constitution Essay Contest for the best 1,000-word essays on the Constitution of the United States written by students in public or private secondary schools of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut will be opened by THE NEW YORK TIMES in September.

YOUNGSTERS who want to be engineers when they grow up, as well as oldsters who may once have had similar ambitions, find sympathetic and stimulating companionship today in numerous groups devoted to keeping alive the traditional American enthusiasm for railroads.

IN the midst of all the contemporary discussion about monopoly, of the need to combat it, to restrict it, perhaps even to end it, these two studies of American business bigness have considerable timeliness. Each in its own peculiar way contributes something to the discussion, and neither holds much comfort for the anti-monopolists, at least for those units which crusade within the capitalist system.

HOLLYWOOD. MOTION pictures are in their infancy. This useful statement was first uttered twenty years ago, and ever since in discussions of the screen it has been employed as an apology, an explanation or a boast.

IN an effort to crystallize the basic needs of television the Radio Manufacturers Association, through James M. Skinner, chairman of its special television committee, has suggested a five-point plan to the Federal Communications Commission.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20. -- Nine visiting professors will augment the regular teaching staff at this year's Summer school of the University of Pennsylvania, it was announced today by Professor John Dolman, the school's director. He said it had the largest advance registration of students since 1929.
PHILADELPHIA, June 19. -- The presentment this week of a special grand jury has given critics of the Philadelphia magistrates' system definite hope for a thorough overhauling of the minor judiciary.

In the case of People v. the New Deal, President Roosevelt opened for the defense recently in Arkansas. He called upon the shades of Thomas Jefferson, Andrew Jackson and the Arkansas Pioneer to stand with him as steadfast, forward-looking Democrats. This was not an adroit approach to intelligent voters.

AT the bottom of the Colorado River Valley, beneath the waters of the huge lake formed by the construction of Boulder Dam, lies the site of an ancient city -- a remnant of the civilization which existed on the Western plains between twelve and fifteen centuries ago.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., June 20 (AP). -- Hermie Roy, brown gelded son of Brown Bud -- Prodigy, won the featured Westfield Purse at Agawarn Park today, closing with a burst of speed to defeat Eldee.

WASHINGTON, June 20. -- While Congress fought its way toward adjournment today, President Roosevelt signed the Robinson-Patman Chain Store Bill and otherwise devoted a full day to work in his office, instead of remaining in the White House residential quarters, as has been his custom on Saturdays.

The national outdoor women's A.A.U. swimming championships, which are scheduled to start on Thursday and continue through Sunday in the Oriental Pool at Manhattan Beach, will attract the attention of swimming followers all over the country as well as abroad.
BOSTON, June 20. -- Airflame, Alfred G. Vanderbilt's 2-year-old, scored his sixth victory today in seven starts in the Mayflower, $2,500 added feature of the program at Suffolk Downs.

WASHINGTON, June 20. -- Strong language was used to denounce the new Tax Bill in a statement issued here tonight by the National Association of Manufacturers. It said that the bill "converts the ascertainment of tax liability into a continuous conundrum."

LAKE MAHOPAC, N.Y., June 20 (AP). -- Norman Thomas, Socialist nominee for President, expressed doubt tonight that the new "Union party of the United States" will play an important role in the campaign.

WILLIAM SOSKIN, editor of Stackpole Sons, reports that one of the first books on the list of the new publishing house will be a biography of Justice Brandeis, entitled "Brandeis: The Personal History of an American Ideal."

IT would be possible for a careless reader, who does not read book jackets and does not remember authors' names, to leaf through this novel of Vincent Sheean's without connecting it with another book, brilliant in another field and manner, which went under the title of "Personal History." Vincent Sheean the journalist is at the moment forgotten in Vincent Sheean the novelist, and, to some extent, historian.

A series of fifteen original autograph letters and documents relating to the Blennerhassett conspiracy of Aaron Burr and others, which aroused a storm of controversy in the early days of the last century, has been acquired by Gabriel Wells from a southern collector in whose collection the historic papers had remained many years.

The members of Mrs. Hortense Farcourt's household include a brother, a daughter, a son-in-law, a nephew, a grandniece and a grandnephew. Each has a griev ance, and their grievances are fundamentally identical -- the old lady will not permit them to live their own lives.

TOURS of the Great Lakes, with a planned program for eleven days of sightseeing and steamer life, are attracting persons with an urge to see one of the great meeting places of the East and West. The tourists start from Buffalo, after a view of Niagara Falls, cruise Lake Erie to Detroit for a day's visit, and continue through Lake and River St. Clair to Sarnia, Ont.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 20. -- Plagued by light, variable airs most of the afternoon, eighty-three boats sailed today in the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's regatta, sixth in the championship series of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound.

Signing of the Robinson-Patman bill by President Roosevelt is expected this week and from all indications will set into motion a gradual but extensive readjustment of buying and selling practices, the ultimate effects of which as yet can be foreseen only in dim outline.

Two rare pamphlets dealing with one of New York's most bitter political quarrels, the Leisler rebellion in 1691, were acquired recently by the New York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West. These pamphlets, published by the city's first printer, William Bradford, in 1702, describe the prosecution and trial of Colonel Nicholas Bayard for supposed high treason and the treatment accorded him from the time sentence was passed against him until his reprieve.

Jack Talbot of Staten Island, seeded No. 8, was halted by Carlton Rood of Brooklyn, North Carolina freshman, yesterday in the first surprise of the ninth annual Richmond County clay court championship at the Clifton Tennis Club, Arrochar.

NO one has suffered more indignities anywhere, either on the screen or off, than Edgar Kennedy, whose baldness -- of the coral atoll or William Jennings Bryan type -- is one of the most familiar stretches of sheer epidermical aridity in the world today.

WASHINGTON, June 20. -- New York State will receive from the Federal Government for old age pensions in the next year $7,500,000, or one-half of the amount it spends, it was stated today after the Social Security Board had approved New York State's old age assistance plan.
BERLIN, June 20 (AP). -- A demand that a world heavyweight title bout between Max Schmeling and James J. Braddock be held in Germany was made today by the official German news bureau.
BRUSSELS, June 20 (AP). -- Troops occupied strategic points around Belgium's capital tonight despite the settlement of the strike of Antwerp dock workers.
CHICAGO, June 19. -- "Big Bill" Thompson, former Mayor of Chicago, recently announced himself as a candidate for Governor of Illinois.

JOHNSONBURG, N.J., June 20. -- Norman Thomas, Socialist leader, economic and engineering professors of leading American universities and public utility executives are included in the list of speakers to be heard at the Summer session on economics of engineering under sponsorship of the Society for the Promotion of Engineering Education at the Stevens Institute of Technology Engineering Camp here June 28 to July 5.

DOG-LOVERS will surely delight in the story of the great German shepherd dog. Beowulf, who served his master so loyally and so valiantly. The heart of a dog is often a wonderful thing, and Beowulf proved many times that his was a great and a most courageous one.

YOU have it on the word of one who must certainly know, that Continental Europe, whatever else it may or may not be at the present moment, is certainly no bed of cinema roses to the motion-picture industry of either the United States or England.

THE prehistoric adobe ruins of the Southwest, threatened with complete destruction by the elements, are to be preserved for posterity. The National Park Service announces that its scientists, after long research, have developed a weatherproofing compound which they believe will maintain the ruins in their present state for years to come.
LONDON, June 20. -- The following are the chief points in the address of Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin today at Wishaw, Scotland:

JERUSALEM, June 20. -- One of the cruelest acts of terrorism yet perpetrated in the cause of "Arab nationalism" occurred last night when a Jewish baby home in the Bakaa quarter on the Jerusalem-Bethlehem Road was set afire.

IN a recent issue of The American Magazine of Art, under title of "Form Through Representation," Walter Abell arrives at a provocative conclusion which well deserves quotation. He finds that "out of the nineteenth century academic bankruptcy on the one hand, and of the early twentieth century abstractionism on the other, has come to artist and observer alike a double lesson.

DETROIT, Mich., June 19. -- Detroit, in common with the rest of Michigan, has rid itself of the panic it felt when it was first revealed that the Black Legion, with night riders and a policy of vengeance, had arisen in its midst. The Black Legion still is front-page news, but the accounts today tell of the law taking its course.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20. -- A defense of President Roosevelt's New Deal policies against the criticism of business is made by Edward A. Filene, president of William Filene's Sons Company of Boston, in a leading article in the national committee's book of the Democratic National Convention.

Cape Cod stories have a seagoing atmosphere even when, as in "Stormy Weather," the chief characters are small-town grocers. The Eastfleet grocery store was owned by Nymphus and Miltiah Tody, old ex-sailormen. Henry Clay Robinson kept their books and wrote "po'try" on the side.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP). -- Twelve years before the Democratic party came out of a name-switching event, the grandson of Benjamin Franklin set out in Philadelphia to organize the Democratic Society of Pennsylvania.
LONDON, June 20. -- It would not be unfair to describe the new British foreign policy that emerged Thursday as a surrender to one treaty-breaker and friendly overtures to another.

WITH the exception of Dr. Grace Kimball's paper on the effect of magnetism on life it cannot be said that anything startling or new came out of the meeting held last week at Rochester, N.Y., by the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

Mary Fitt has written a quaint and curious story with a fantastic plot and the fidelity to detail of a detective thriller. Its style is simple and yet suggestive of seething mysteries. Its atmosphere is that of a better class Bohemian circle in London, with a dash of Graustarkian romance and of fairy-tale legend.

THE first book of a man who has become a famous author gives one a fixed point from which to gauge the distance he has traveled. This is what makes the publication in America of W. Somerset Maugham's first novel -- "Liza of Lambeth" -(Doubleday, Doran CO., $2.50) a real event for his many aficionados.

Polo, "the most ancient of games with stick and ball," was classified as a science by Elbridge T. Gerry, poloist, in a suit he filed yesterday in Federal Court to recover income taxes levied on the United States Polo Association.

ST. LOUIS, June 20. -- Soldiers' bonus expenditures have speeded general business in the Eighth Federal Reserve District, especially in the retail, automobile and household equipment divisions. With the influx of many millions into spending channels, the picture is distorted as against last year, and comparisons are not worth while in several lines.

ANOTHER harness horse-racing campaign is about to begin. Beginning next Saturday, and continuing all Summer, the trotters, sulkies and drivers will be wheeling for the "Go!" on hundreds of tracks the country over.

ROME, June 19. -- Now that diplomatic grave-diggers are at work on final arrangements for disposal of the corpse of the League of Nations sanctions, Italian resumption of full cooperation with the League and with other powers may be foreseen at an early date.

DURHAM, N.H., June 20. -- Fellowship awards, always a ranking theme with the American Associates of University Women, submerged all other topics at the closing session today of the North Atlantic conference. Financially, reports disclosed, the ten States represented are already abreast of their quota for this year for the $40,000 fund which it is hoped to complete in another twelve months.

THE "History of Parliament," of which I recently gave some account, will not, after all, be the biggest enterprise of the kind, measured by the number of volumes required to constitute the complete work. Whereas it will consist of only forty volumes, the new Domesday Book will run to eighty-seven.

The suggestion that trust business should be divorced from commercial banking, which was raised again last week by the report of the Securities and Exchange Commission on the conduct of corporate trusteeships, published on Friday, has been a matter of concern among bankers for more than three years.
WASHINGTON, June 20. -- Following is the text of the conclusions and recommendations of the SEC on the segregation of broker-dealer functions:

Flashing a five-run drive in the fourth inning in which John Stoppa clouted a home-run with two on, the Columbus Council, K. of C., baseball team defeated the New York Athletic Club, 9 to 3, at the Prospect Park Parade Grounds in Brooklyn yesterday.

WITH its publication appropriately timed to a Presidential election year, this brightly amusing novel pictures the swift elevation from comparative obscurity of an honest Midwesterner to occupancy of the White House. Dan Bates, hearty, upright, well-to-do, is a leading figure of Orient, Iowa, his home place, editor of the local weekly and the town's most popular citizen.

Convinced that foreign markets offer the best sales opportunities available since 1928, American companies are sending more men abroad this Summer than at any time in seven years, export trade association executives reported yesterday. Glowing reports sent back by travelers from many parts of the globe in recent months and the expansion of the reciprocal trade program are primary factors in the increase in export sales activity, it was said.
PARIS, June 20 (AP). -- France hastened tonight to counter Great Britain's plan to change the League of Nations, fearing it might reduce her to a "state of dependency" in Europe.

TOKYO. -- There is a widespread belief that the territorial ambition of Japan is confined to North China and Siberia. It is common knowledge that she requires a safety-valve to insure the internal well-being of her rapidly increasing population. An almost equally common impression is that she looks in only one direction for letting off the pressure.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., June 20. -- The Council of Social Action made its first report at Mount Holyoke today to the General Council of the Congregational and Christian Churches, and the same difference as to the wisdom of creating the Council of Social Action was apparent as when it was formed at Oberlin two years ago.

CHICAGO, June 20. -- Buying of wheat was in big volume today in the Board of Trade, and while there also were tremendous profit-taking sales at times, the market showed a remarkable power of absorption and closed 2 1/8 to 2 7/8 cents a bushel net higher.

George S. Kurke, recently appointed principal of the Robert E. Simon Junior High School, 234 West 109th Street, was honored yesterday at a luncheon given in the Hotel Roosevelt by the staff of the Forsyth Junior High School, 45 Rivington Street, which he will leave as principal in September to take up his new post, succeeding Jacob Theobald, recently appointed Assistant Superintendent.
MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., June 20. -- The showboat Periwinkle, its tiny stage filled with villains and maidens in distress, opened its third Summer season Friday night in East Chester Creek.

A number of rumors concerning administration coercion of business men, either because of the latter's pronounced antipathy to present government policies or their failure to contribute campaign funds, were found in a check-up last week to be either without basis or impossible to confirm.

THE so-called "festival weeks" lie just ahead and one is permitted to hope that they will be a little more eventful than the bygone Spring. Indeed, since my last report, more than three months ago, the happenings that even approached importance could have been counted on the fingers of one hand -- with a digit or two to spare.
I grant to your reviewer Mr. Hanson W. Baldwin the privilege of his profession to judge any work of mine for both form and substance so long as he criticizes with sure ground under his own feet.

The aging Colonel Bill Terry may be handicapped by the pain of his creaking joints, but he still is just about the most potent weapon the Giants have in the way of attack. At least he was yesterday, and it was well for the Stoneham clan that this was so.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP). -- The Works Progress Administration announced today that it would continue to provide relief jobs for needy aliens, but at the same time arranged to cooperate with the Labor Department in barring those illegally in this country.

The extension program of debt readjustment for the Chicago Park District, recently completed, will be followed with the public offering, scheduled for Tuesday, of $32,121,955 of various bonds of the district by a nation-wide banking syndicate to be headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., refunding agents for the district in its refinancing plan.

Along about midsummer when the cruiser owner finds a blowing, blustery Sunday and wants to take his Sabbath voyage in calm, protected waters, he has close at home a chance for unusual enjoyment. Let him spend a day along the Hudson poking into the three public yacht basins maintained by the Palisades Interstate Park.

More than 1,000 children of Greenwich Village held a June walk safety parade yesterday, marching through the Village streets with placards appealing to motorists to drive carefully. Entertainment and refreshments in Hudson Park, Hudson and Leroy Streets, followed the walk.
OTTAWA, June 18. -- The Supreme Court of Canada this week dealt with R.B. Bennett's "New Deal" in much the same summary fashion as its American equivalent did with President Roosevelt's innovations.

THERE can be no doubt that the new school of American poetry is that concerned with social reform. Urban environment and Marxist philosophy are directly affecting the poetic imagination. Just how city living and collective thiking are influencing poetic thought is a little difficult to analyze.

Forty-ninth Street between Broadway and Eighth Avenue was sharply divided into two camps yesterday. The thoroughfare, known far and wide as the boxing capital of the world, was still shaking from the repercussions of the surprise enacted in the ring at the Yankee Stadium on Friday night, when Max Schmeling battered Joe Louis to a knockout defeat.
GAMES, serious or silly, can fill in odd hours of a weekend in the country, and so aid the hostess. There are some new games and some new equipment for old ones.

AMERICAN prestige and American influence are higher in South America today than ever before. In less than three years the pendulum of feeling toward the United States has swung from universal distrust to confidence and friendliness.

SOME things besides nationalism, armaments, taxes, world disorder and the danger of poverty and of war have been growing steadily through these seven lean years. One of them is the thing that, some say, brought hard times because it was already growing much faster than our political thought.

THE rose gardens at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden and the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx are now at their prime, following the recent rains, and are being enjoyed daily by thousands of flower lovers in the metropolitan area and by many visitors from distant points.

IN AVIATION, as in other arts, every now and again something crops up to demonstrate that there is little new under the sun. Last week a new translation of a French patent filed Feb. 18, 1876, and issued on April 8 of that year to Messrs. Penaud and Gauchot, became available. It is for an airplane, with many of the features of the speedy craft of today.

A WORK of this kind is in itself at a tremendous disadvantage when considered from the point of view of the reader who would read for pleasure alone. For here Miss Haight considers ancient fiction, a large part of which is not readily accessible to the average reader.

The Hitler regime in Germany, despite its claims of having broken the Reich's "chains of dependence" on foreign food resources, has far to go before attaining that goal. Especially is this true with regard to oils and fats.

SOME readers might find the title of this book far more suggestive than its contents. Yet it cannot be denied that what Mr. Rowe has to say on the subject of his survey does indirectly set one thinking about the validity of what until recently has been assumed to be the only true relationship between markets and men.

PARIS, June 19. -- Since it came into office three weeks ago, Leon Blum's Popular Front government has been so fully occupied with internal readjustments that it has not been able to give much attention to what is called foreign policy. But that does not mean that it has not got one.

Unseasonable weather retarded retail sales last week and resulted in a curtailment of wholesale orders for Summer merchandise, according to a report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers. Fall purchasing brought a large number of buyers to the market to place orders for advance coat sales, men's clothing, sheets, blankets and other items on which prices are firming.

CHICAGO, June 20. -- A suit for an accounting of special assessment funds collected and disbursed by the city of Chicago on sixty-four improvement projects was filed today in the United States District Court in behalf of the Chase National Bank of New York and Maurice H. Ewer of Montclair, N.J., holders of approximately $700,000 of the special assessment bonds issued by the city.
The New York Society of Architects has written to the Board of Aldermen expressing its opposition to the new building code which was printed in the City l:ecord May 19 last.

George Washington High School's hard-hitting outfit became the city Public School Athletic League baseball ruler for 1936 by defeating Samuel J. Tilden High School, 9 -- 4, in the final-round play-off for the championship at Erasmus Field in Brooklyn yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 20. -- The principal provisions of the compromise Tax Bill as passed by Congress with summaries of the less important sections are as follows:

With sales last week reaching the highest point of this year and coming close to the boom activity prior to enactment of the NRA in 1933, executives in the primary cotton goods market predicted yesterday that volume in the second half of 1936 would be the largest since 1929.

MAJOR EDWARD BOWES and his amateur hour will be sponsored by an automobile manufacturer instead of coffee after the termination of his present engagement in September. The fledglings will then be heard over WABC's hook-up on a day other than Sunday. . . .

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., June 20. -- Miss June Morehead, jumping her big chestnut gelding Montauk, this afternoon captured the hunter championship sweepstakes, one of the title events of the seventh annual fixture of the Bronxville Riding Club given in the show ring on the club's grounds.
DETROIT, June 20 (AP). -- Gloom hung over Detroit's Negro district today, but in the home that Joe Louis built for his mother out of his ring earnings there was double trouble.

ITHACA, June 20. -- Sigma Xi scientific honor society, numbering among its members the leading research workers in the country, today honored two of them with the award of semi-centennial prizes of $1,000 each for research, one in biology and the other in physics.

The collapse Friday afternoon of an apartment house under construction at 112 East Mosholu Parkway South, the Bronx, turned out yesterday to have been a disaster in which sixteen workmen were hurled to their death in a jumble of timbers, bricks and mortar.

Because Mamaroneck Harbor is already so crowded, the Ordenta Y.C. has had to turn away a number of prospective members because there is no more mooring space, according to A.C. Emelin. The commodore for this year on the newly elected slate of officers is Dr. Charles A. Roy.

There is no city in the United States that worries more about rain, sunshine or chills than New York. Equal to this concern over the elements is that of the man who tells city dwellers what their weather will be.

WHILE the town regards the average Frank Capra-Robert Riskin picture as an important event, "Lost Horizon," the pair's current endeavor, is being viewed by its producing studio -- Columbia -- as a historical occasion.

PROFESSOR KEMMERER is this country's best known authority on money. No less than thirteen foreign nations have summoned the American "money doctor" to minister to their currency ailments. But when the dollar was sick Dr. Kemmerer was not called in.

From the standpoint of activity, yesterday's share market was typical of a Summer Saturday. The turnover on the Stock Exchange amounted to 317,000 shares, compared with 375,000 the Saturday before. Following a slow start, the list showed advancing tendencies under the leadership of the steel and automotive groups, and closed irregularly higher on the day. Bonds pointed higher in fairly active dealings.

BOSTON, June 20. -- Olney Chandler, 31, a widower and father of three children, went back into a burning house yesterday to die with his 5-year-old daughter, Ethel, after he had rescued his 2-year-old son, Roger. The son died a few hours later at a hospital.

SYRACUSE, June 20 (AP). -- Dr. Francis E. Townsend, leader of the Townsend old-age, pension plan, made a flying visit to Syracuse today and hinted at the possibility of his group supporting Representative William Lemke's third party candidacy for President.

A young English couple, happily and conventionally married, find themselves faced with the problem of the eternal triangle. In this geometrical situation, the third angle is not a lover, but merely the bride's yearning for romance and glamour.

Five co-eds in their 'teens who spend many of their week-ends wearing overalls, life-jackets, spray goggles and helmets while they drive gyrating outboard hydro-planes at thirty, forty or more miles an hour are among the half a hundred entrants this year in the seventh annual national intercollegiate motor boat championships.

DETROIT, June 20 (AP). -- E.F. Seagram looked on wistfully today as Miss Dolphin, a filly he lost for $4,000 in a claiming race a few weeks ago, ran five and one-half furlongs in 1:05 to equal the Detroit track record and win the $5,000 added Moslem Temple stakes.

Seventy years ago, when the autograph album was less common than it is today, the girls of Maine had an ingenious substitute. "Friendly albums" was a fitting name for their patchwork quilts which bore the signatures of their friends, life-long reminders of happy companionships.

A WITTY modern fantasy with a cushion of classical background, "Panic Among Puritans" shrewdly satirizes modern morals and customs. During a London Summer, Mr. Laver brings the old Olympian gods to England to have a look at the present-day world. Fauns and nymphs return to wood and lake.

The persistent demand for Italian dollar bonds which carried those issues to new high levels for the year on gains ranging from 2 1/8 to 7 3/4 points yesterday was the feature of an otherwise dull and routine trading session in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange.

PUERTO RICO, that little island crowded with people, which came to the United States by conquest in the Spanish War, is crying for its independence much as the Philippines voiced their demand for freedom. Wiser men in the island believe that independence will ruin them, but as liberty is an aspiration which is stimulated and guided only by emotion there is not much opposition.
OMAHA, June 19. -- However the farm States view the nomination of Alfred M. Landon at Cleveland, they have reason to feel flattered.

LONDON. THE British film industry moved forward early this month when Alexander Korda directed the first shots of Charles Laughton's starring vehicle "Rembrandt," thus inaugurating his London Film Productions' new $3,000,000 Denham studios.

Lewis A. Hird, chairman of the executive committee of the National Association of Wool Manufacturers, in a communication sent to the directors yesterday referring to labeling practices in that industry and in the apparel field, made a plea for the honest presentation of fabrics.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 20. -- Business on the Pacific Coast just about held its own during the week just ended. Downtown stores in all cities showed a slight dip in sales volume which might have been more pronounced but for activity in jewelry, sports wear and items, affected by school graduation.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20. -- The third party movement has cast its shadow over the Democratic National Convention in connection with a contest from Minnesota which will come before the national committee Monday. One of two rival delegations is headed by Joseph W. Noonan, chairman of the Democratic Central Committee of Minnesota.

STEPS which are being taken to provide the ground organization for regular air transport on the Gold Coast were outlined recently by Sir Arnold Wienholt Hodson, Governor of the Gold Coast, before his Legislative Council.

Frank Cumiskey of North Bergen, N.J., 23-year-old member of the Swiss Turn Verein of Hudson County, became the National A.A. U. all-around gymnastic champion last night at Mecca Temple and automatically qualified as a member of the American Olympic team.

IN the harbor of Portland Charles Merriam saw one day "a great five-masted schooner majestically riding at anchor" whose arrival the day before had been great news in the morning paper. For she was the Edna Hoyt, the last American five-masted schooner in service on the Atlantic.

The Dodgers displayed a great variety of baseball against the Cubs at Ebbets Field yesterday, some of it very good and some very bad, and even contrived to maintain a 4-4 tie until the ninth inning. Then they retired from competition gracefully before a pinch single by Ken O'Dea and the relief pitching of Charley Root to extend the National League champions' winning streak to fourteen games.

The New York Conservation Department urges persons entering the woods not to pick up stray baby animals that they may come across in their wanderings. Whenever a cub bear, fawn, young raccoon or other wild animal is picked up and taken home for a pet, it generally results fatally to the captive, for the odds are against the animal when removed from its natural environment.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 20 (AP). -- Newark again conquered the Chiefs by the margin of a single run tonight in Municipal Stadium, scoring its third victory of the present series, 5 to 4.

WASHINGTON, June 20. -- The nature and volume of reaction to the collection of contradictory declarations which the Republican party presented at Cleveland last week as its platform for 1936 have revived the hope in a certain sector of the Democratic fold that the Jeffersonians will take the cue next week at Philadelphia to answer with cleverness where cleverness seems to be called for.

CHICAGO, June 20. -- Widespread drought persisting in the great central plains area and other important crop producing regions is rapidly becoming a major market factor. It also threatens to project itself into politics because severe damage to crops would again bring to the front the New Deal's policies which put curbs on production.

BOSTON, June 19. -- The Maine primary last Tuesday produced a stunning surprise. The Republican vote lacked only about 2,000 of matching the record. The State and all New England were amazed by the disclosure of the possibility that the Republican party's organization in the First Congressional District, which includes the city of Portland, might come under the control of the followers of Father Coughlin and Dr. Townsend.
ST. PAUL, June 19. -- Of Minnesota's three political parties, only the Republicans came out of the State primary election last Monday with a unity undisturbed by factionalism.

When the French Senate last week passed the first batch of reform legislation sponsored by the Blum Ministry, the Third Republic was ready to move ahead with the Popular Front program. A forty-hour week, vacations with pay and collective labor contracts, now enacted into law, brought back to work a large portion of the 1,000,000 men and women who by folding their arms had paralyzed French industry and business.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20 (AP). -- The Phillies and Pirates divided a twin bill today, the visitors winning the first game, 6-0, behind the 4-hit pitching of Cy Blanton, while in the second the Phillies bunched three of their five hits off Jim Weaver in the seventh -- to push two runs over the plate and gain a 2-1 triumph.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20. -- David Lawrence, chairman of the Democratic party in Pennsylvania, predicting party victory in November, said in a radio address tonight that in his home city of Pittsburgh "Democratic registration exceeds Republican registration for the first time since the Civil War."

AS the vacation season advances, motorists are reported to be flocking in increasing numbers to the Whiteface Mountain Memorial Highway, which was opened to the public for the first time last July 20. Between that date and Nov. 15, when the highway was closed for the season, 45,561 persons in 15,016 automobiles followed its scenic course up the mountain.

A BOSWELL has been found for our oldest and most notable Americans. The biographer is the Federal Forest Service, and the subjects are the historic trees of our land, now being catalogued with their legends for the benefit of posterity and the tourist.

AS the circus men late in the evening pull down the tents to move on in the night to another town, so the broadcasters during the past week have been trouping with their props of magic from Cleveland to Philadelphia to electrify and spread the Democratic National Convention across the land.

LONDON, June 19. -- King Edward VIII entertains a small party of friends each week-end at Fort Belvedere, his country house near Windsor. Mr. and Mrs. Ormond Lawson-Johnston were among his guests last week-end.

BABYLON, L.I., June 20. -- Added interest was attached to today's invitation regatta of the Babylon Yacht Club when the Star Class fleet of the Great South Bay took advantage of the occasion to conduct the first of a series of three elimination races to select a crew to represent it in the Olympic eliminations and finals at Sayville July 6-12.

THE majority of these essays take us into the back country and the byways of literature rather than into well-mapped and frequently traveled territory; they either discuss remote and relatively neglected figures, or else touch upon minor and little known phases of the life of more familiar characters.

High school students throughout our State began taking regents examinations this week. Few business leaders, few social philosophers, few leaders of thought, and in fact few parents, realize what hurdles these youngsters are expected to leap.

Europe's internal boundaries made an extraordinary impression on me. They are not mere politics lines such as separate our own States; they are real, grim and, in many respects under present-time conditions, insurmountable.

LEADERS of all branches of the radio industry met with the Federal Communications Commission in Washington during the past week to map the course for radio, which is now seen "at the cross roads" as it approaches the ultra-short wave spectrum.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20. -- For the second time within less than a month Daniel H. Barrow Jr. defeated Winthrop Rutherfurd Jr., Princeton's former national champion, the Penn A.C. sculler scoring in the feature event of the eighty-third annual Schuylkill Navy regatta today over the mile and a quarter course in Fairmount Park.

Dr. George B. Pegram, Professor of Physics at Columbia University, has been made acting dean of the Graduate Faculties at the university, according to an announcement yesterday by Frank D. Fackenthal, secretary of the university, listing six appointments to the faculty and five promotions, following action by the board of trustees.

THE charm of the essay once more signally demonstrated in this little book by Karel Capek, which on the back of its title page bears the familiar legend, "Printed in Great Britain." This is but a way of saying that its American publishers expected no great sales of a book by an author whose other books sell at least moderately well.

TOPEKA, June 20. -- An extension of the interpretation of the term "freedom of the press" so that it includes the idea of free access by newspapers to information about governmental affairs was made today by Governor Alf M. Landon in a speech before the Kansas Editorial Association, which is holding its annual meeting here.

Charles R. Gay, president of the New York Stock Exchange, and other Exchange officials declined last night to comment on the broker-dealer segregation report of the Securities and Exchange Commission, the text of which they had not had an opportunity to read in full.

DALLAS, June 20. -- While the season for a slowing down in business has arrived, there has been but little slacking up of the pace in the Eleventh Federal Reserve District, of which Texas is the major part of the area. This condition is due in large measure to activities in connection with celebrations of the Texas Centennial, of which the central and major exposition is in Dallas.

In a recent letter Elisha Flagg took issue with an article on the diverting American ritual known as scalping, in connection with the movie "The Last of the Mohicans." Specifically, Mr. Flagg objected to the writer's statement that the portion of the head removed in the operation was "as large as the palm of a hand or larger if you're one of those people impressed by size."

While the volume of bonus spending by veterans in local department and other stores last week fell under expectations in that no buying spree developed, little disappointment was voiced by retail executives. They expressed the point of view that it is a good thing for trade and the veterans themselves that they showed a spirit of caution and kept their bonds in reserve for a "rainy day."

TRENTON, June 19. -- Whatever basis there may have been for criticism of the Emergency Relief Administration in New Jersey since the State some weeks ago shifted to the municipalities the entire responsibility of caring for the needy, conditions are expected to be corrected when the State Financial Assistance Commission begins functioning on July 1 with a $6,000, 000 equalization fund at its disposal.

BERLIN, June 20. -- All German policemen, now under Heinrich Himmler's central command, will be put in new uniforms which will do away with the conspicuous blue and replace it with the gray green of the former State police created by the National Socialist regime as camouflage for the new army during the period of secret rearmament and incorporated in the army after the conscription proclamation.

More than 700 supervisors and other WPA staff leaders assembled in the exhibition hall of the Port Authority Building yesterday afternoon to discuss details of the new Federal relief program. But the radio amplifying system, which was to have brought them an outline of the program from Washington, became choked with static, so they spent the afternoon in demonstrating their admiration and respect for the retiring administrator, Victor F. Ridder.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES of June 14 appears a letter from Professor Hocking of Harvard University, in which he undertakes to pass "severe judgment" on the petition presented by the Pro-Palestine Federation of America to the British Government. The letter so abounds in inaccuracies that we must ask space to correct the writer's most egregious errors.

TAKEN as a whole, the works devoted to city planning and housing now constitute a library of very considerable magnitude. For the greater part this literature deals with a multitude of "technical" considerations and comes to a focus in pleadings for "a good cause."

AT least three institutions of higher learning today are endeavoring to assist prospective college students to determine their fitness for specific vocations before enrolling in any college. Stevens Institute, Worcester Polytechnic Institute and Lafayette College have introduced Summer programs of ten days to two weeks to enable secondary school students to "size up" their chances of ultimate success in different fields of work, and especially in engineering.

ALASKAN HEAT WAVE: One day last week Seward, Alaska, reported a temperature of 110 degrees in the sun and an official 85 in the shade. Strange as that may sound from Alaska, it isn't record-breaking. The regular temperature range in Summer is from 50 to 85; people go swimming and children go barefoot.

RUMSON, N.J., June 20. -- The annual horse show and gymkhana sponsored by the Shrewsbury Junior Riding Club was held this afternoon on the L. Suffern Tailer estate here. Jane Guptil and Marjorie Hasler were tied for points for the championship.

CHICAGO, June 20 (AP). -- Frankie Parker of Milwaukee, a former title holder and the nation's seventh ranking player, will match strokes. tomorrow with Robert Riggs of Los Angeles for the national clay courts tennis singles championship.

PARIS. DESPITE unsettled conditions and unfavorable weather, the "Saisons de Paris" have launched the Summer more brilliantly than ever. Each day is packed with social, artistic or sporting events, interesting from every standpoint. Their sartorial aspect reveals the typical silhouettes of 1936, as approved by the smartest women in the world.

Concluding senior week at Hunter College, commencement exercises for more than 750 members of the class of June, '36, will be held on Wednesday at 10:30 A.M. in Carnegie Hall. Channing Pollock, author and playwright, will deliver the baccalaureate address.

CANADA will celebrate on July 21 the one hundredth anniversary of the opening of her first railway, the fourteen and one-half-mile Champlain St. Lawrence Railroad, between St. John's and Laprairie in the Province of Quebec (then Lower Canada), connecting Lake Champlain with River St. Lawrence and linking up the two great commercial ports of New York and Montreal.

CRUISING "the unsalted seas," combined with faring by rail and highway, is a vacation resource that is winning bookings as the Great Lakes tourist season approaches. It opens June 29. Lake steamship lines report heavy advance ticket sales made by arrangement with leading railroads in the United States and Canada.
A large number of members of the Indian Harbor Y.C. will attend the annual local racing dinner next Tuesday at the clubhouse at Rocky Neck Point, Greenwich.

CAMP DOW, AK-BULAK, U.S.S.R., June 20. -- This astronomical expedition had a miraculous escape from what threatened to be certain failure an hour before the eclipse. Although dawn was fairly clear yesterday, heavy clouds soon began to gather and the sun was completely obscured until the eclipse was almost beginning. Then the clouds suddenly parted.

A new aspect has recently been given to the old dispute over the question of an elective as against an appointive judiciary. It is needless to repeat the familiar arguments on either side. They never led to a definite conclusion. It was customary to make odious comparisons between the judges of a State like Massachusetts or New Jersey, where they were all appointed, and those of New York, where they were all eventually elected.

ALBANY, June 20 (AP). -- Dr. Frank P. Graves, State Commissioner of Education, said today that "some" of the collegiate centers maintained in several New York State cities might be re-established, if a way could be found to do it.

Dr. Ditmars in his recently published book "The Book of Prehistoric Animals" introduced older boys and girls to the science of paleontology. Now Professor Whitnall renders the same service to younger children, staging a parade of some of the fantastic creatures which have swum, flown or lumbered through the swamps and plains of the world during its making.
NEW ORLEANS, June 20 (AP). -- A slow-moving tropical disturbance in the Gulf of Mexico headed toward the lower Texas coast today, prompting storm warnings from Corpus Christi to the Mexican border.

KANSAS CITY, June 20. -- Distribution of the soldiers' bonus money was hardly a noticeable factor in the trade here this week. In fact, department store sales averaged slightly below those last week although they were 10 per cent over a year ago. Wholesale trade increased 5 per cent over last week and was about 25 per cent larger than a year ago.

Simon Lake's search for a $2,000,000 cargo of gold supposed to have been lost when the British frigate Hussar sank near Hell Gate in the East River in 1780 may have to be called off unless the 70-year-old inventor can raise $394 to pay back wages owed to John Gombar, deck hand and diver's tender.

Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins criticized Germany's racial policy in a decision yesterday permitting a former employe of the Reichsbahn (German State Railroads) to bring suit here for upward of $50,000 damages because he was discharged as a "non-Aryan" and sent to a concentration camp.

BOSTON, June 20 (AP). -- A carload of votes from the Midwest poured in today to give the colorful Jerome (Dizzy) Dean the lead in the fans' choice for National League pitchers in the all-star game here July 7. Today was the last day for balloting and the results will be made public June 27.

STROUDSBURG, Pa. -- The Poconos, Pennsylvania's picturesque playgrounds, have already -- a little in advance of the calendar date -- entered their Summer season with the completion of the sixth annual Laurel Blossom Celebration, which closed today with the annual "dad's dinner," for fathers of the blossom "queens" and "princesses" who in the past week have been guests of the various resorts of the county.

Stars of the Grover Cleveland High School finished first, second and third in the fancy dive, the final event of the program, to enable the Ridgewood squad to win the second annual scholastic meet at the Ravenhall Bathing Park in Coney Island yesterday. The victors scored 17 points.

EACH separate episode of the English tithe war published in THE NEW YORK TIMES between Aug. 3, 1933, and March 15, 1936, was sufficiently startling to make readers rub their eyes and wonder if they had gone backward into the medieval era. Read consecutively the story is positively astounding.

VIENNA, June 19. -- With the demise of sanctions the European situation goes back -- with some modification -- to conditions immediately preceding the formation of the short-lived "united front" at Stresa.

MOSCOW, June 19. -- Publication of the project for a new Constitution has had an enormous effect among the Soviet populace. From the great cities to the smallest villages throughout the country the project is being read, studied and discussed at countless meetings.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20. -- A strike which, city officials feared, would keep all food concessions at the Municipal Auditorium closed during the Democratic National Convention and might spread to several hotels and restaurants was averted tonight.

"People of 37 don't fall in love as young girls do," said Ethel, the heroine of this stormy romance. "No, they don't," replied her level-headed friend, Winifred. "They fall in love much more overwhelmingly and irrevocably." And her observation certainly fits Ethel's case.

DUBLIN, June 20 (AP) -- The Irish Free State called out soldiers in full kit tonight to cement a ban on the Irish Republican Army. The Defense Ministry, moving to stop an intended assembly tomorrow at Bodenstown, twenty miles south of Dublin, ordered troops thrown around the entire town.

THIS is the month when the college senior bares his composite soul to the world. On campuses East and West, along with the diplomas and the roses, have come and gone the inevitable polls to determine his deepest preferences in politics, literature and girls, and his secret hopes of gain and glory.

The renomination of President Roosevelt by acclamation and his re-election by a greater margin than in 1932 were predicted yesterday by Miss Mary W. Dewson, delegate at large, as she left for Philadelphia to attend the Democratic National Convention which opens Tuesday.

Four bandits held up a jewelry concern near one of Brooklyn's busiest corners yesterday and got away with $20,000 in diamonds and jewelry, leaving six persons bound in a back room. According to Abraham Newman, one of the firm partners, the jewelry belonged almost exclusively to customers who had left it for repairs and new settings, and the firm was insured for only $5,000.
The West Side Association of Commerce opposes the proposal for construction of a bridge across the Hudson River at Fifty-seventh Street.

MORE than 2,000 Americans, young in age or spirit, are expected to avail themselves this Summer of facilities provided by American Youth Hostels. There is a chain of thirty-three hostels in Connecticut, Massachusetts, Vermont and New Hampshire, and their circuit composes the so-called New England loop-hike, though it may be made on bicycle.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 20. -- Silver plaques were awarded tonight by the National Headliners Club to nine of its members for outstanding feats in the fields of the newspaper, magazine, newsreel and radio. The awards were announced by Earl J. Johnson, general news manager of the United Press, who was chairman of the selection committee, at a dinner at the Hotel Ambassador here.

ONCE upon a time, in the days when golden cherries could be plucked quite easily, if one had the knack of it, from almost any tree, a group of lighthearted young men had a lighthearted young time in Paris, for several years. Most of them were Americans, but there were a few French, and a scattering of other nationalities.

VIRGINIA BEACH, Va., June 20. -- United States Senator Carter Glass was eulogized today by J.F.T. O'Connor, Controller of the Currency, in an address at the concluding session in the Cavalier Hotel of the forty-third annual convention of the Virginia Bankers Association.

LONDON. THE great popular success of John Gielgud and Peggy Ashcroft in "Romeo and Juliet" has established a fashion at the New Theatre, with a consequence which until a few months ago would have been scouted as incredible by those who believe that one must always play down to the public.
Even though the Democrats have not yet held their convention, the campaign of 1936 began in earnest last week.
THE modern divining-rod business is booming. In the last five years more than 300 inventions for geophysical prospecting have been patented here and in foreign countries.
PHILADELPHIA, June 20. -- Dr. Frank N.D. Buchman, founder of the Oxford Group, suggested today that the Democratic party "let God write its platform."

Entries in dog shows in the United States have kept pace with the amazing increase in the number of thoroughbred dogs registered, according to figures announced yesterday by the American Kennel Club. In addition, there will be from 10 to 15 per cent more shows in 1936 than last year, during which there were 298 recognized exhibitions.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 20. -- Weather again played the important part in the week's business in the Ninth District, though it was reflected in attitude rather than actual sales reactions. A factor, too, was the influx of government money in bonus payments.

LAKE GEORGE, N.Y. -- The season here is opening with a number of conventions and conferences. Some 400 members of the New York State Bankers Association are at the Hotel Sagamore for a meeting continuing through Tuesday.

WASHINGTON. UNCLE SAM'S cotton breeders have started a hunt for fine-fibered cottons. Recent investigations by Dr. R.W. Webb of the Department of Agriculture have exploded the belief that long, individual fibers are the only important factor in the strength of cotton.

OF the two processional crosses carried in the services at Washington Cathedral, one is the gift of the recently fugitive Ethiopian Emperor Haile Selassie, given in appreciation of special prayers offered for him in the cathedral at the time of his coronation six years ago.

WASHINGTON, June 20. -- President Roosevelt today ended the United States' first experience under neutrality legislation by declaring that a state of war no longer exists in fact between Italy and Ethiopia.

In contrast with calls in recent weeks, announcements last week of securities called for payment before maturity dates were principally for small parts of bond issues rather than for all bonds of issue outstanding. These operations, largely municipal, were mostly for July.

Preliminary details of the investigation of the American merchant marine which has been urged during the last two years were completed last week when Secretary of Commerce Roper appointed a committee of four to study the problems of inspection of merchant ships.

NEWARK, N.J., June 20. -- Cynara, trotting mare owned by Lou Schmieder of Elizabeth, and driven by Bert Boylan of this city, won the free-for-all class, feature event of the matinee sponsored by the Road Horse Association of New Jersey at Weequahic Park today.

IN this swift and lively tale the reader is regaled with certain further exploits of Deputy United -- States -- Marshal Jim Sinclair, nicknamed The Whistler, who was introduced auspiciously in E.B. Mann's preceding Western story, "Rustlers' Round-Up."

THE recent slash of railroad fares -- inevitably accompanied by competing reductions on the buses -- was happy news to many. But it made more work for the forty-six staff workers of the Travelers Aid Society of New York, whose task it is to look after arriving strangers who are not wise in the ways of the big city or who find themselves stranded here, for one reason or another.

BOLTON LANDING, N.Y., June 20. -- The withdrawal of $2,000,000, 000 of gold from the Federal Reserve Banks for the establishment of a stabilization fund was advocated by S. Sloan Colt, president of the Bankers Trust Company, New York, in his presidential address here today at the forty-third annual convention of the New York State Bankers Association in the Hotel Sagamore.

In expressing appreciation of the survey of the North of England by Harold Callender may I suggest that his remarks with regard to the drift of industry from the North to the South of England may give rise to some misapprehension?
ST. LOUIS, June 20 (AP). -- Five home runs featured the Browns-Boston game today with St. Louis claiming three of them and defeating the Red Sox, 7 to 5.

The good fortune of his bosom companion at dice -- even in competition with a left-handed player -- was advanced by Assistant District Attorney William W. Kleinman of Kings County yesterday in accounting for certain banking transactions concerning which the State demanded an explanation.

THIS new book of poems by the Laureate of England proves at least that John Masefield is still, for the most part, the poet of homely themes and of simple contacts. The bays have not betrayed him into what he is not; namely, the court's high bard, a maker of adulatory rhymes.

WASHINGTON, June 20. -- An increase in the production of steel ingots in the first half of June featured the survey of domestic business conditions made public today by the Department of Commerce. This increase was attributed to expansion of deliveries against second-quarter contracts in anticipation of price increases.
