THE most important vegetable in the American menu -- the potato -- promises to be scarce and high in price this Summer. The shortage and the increased cost can be laid to two factors -- drought in certain potato-growing areas and floods in other localities.

NORTH and west of the mouth of the Hudson River, on the deeply wooded slopes of what were once the superb hunting grounds of the Iriquois, lies Tuxedo Park. Recently Tuxedo celebrated its fiftieth anniversary, and it is unique among social centers of the United States because, starting as a fishing camp for wealthy sportsmen of the Eighties, it has never let down the barriers of exclusiveness.

Powerful in the running events after a poor start in the field, the St Cecilia School of Brooklyn track forces ran off with the trophy in the thirtieth annual Catholic School Athletic League meet at Wingate Field yesterday. The victors totaled 85 points for a new high.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP). -- Representative Burdick of Maryland alleged in a statement printed in the Congressional Record today that Postmaster General Farley and Governor-elect Richard W. Leche of Louisiana entered into a "sale" whereby differences between the national and State administrations were settled.

While soldiers' bonus spending fell below expectations, the payments stimulated business to some extent in many sections of the country last week, with purchases of automobiles, household goods and apparel being especially heavy. Merchants generally, however, look for a substantial pick-up in buying this week.

INSTALLATION of governors on automobiles to limit their speed is not a cure-all for motor car accidents, in the opinion of Arthur A. Bull, president of the Handy Governor Corporation, manufacturer of speed governors. If governors were required on all cars, automobile makers soon would build cars incapable of being driven beyond the governed speeds and car operation would be back where it was twenty years ago.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20. -- Miss Mary Alice Clay Borie, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. C. Louis Borie 3d of Lower Wakefield, Rydal, and grandniece of Mrs. Adolph Borie of New York, was introduced to society this afternoon at a tea given by her grandparents, Mr. and Mrs. Alfred G. Clay, at their home in Jenkintown.

THE Trumbull family has been a favored one in Connecticut, occupying a position somewhat analogous to that of the Adams family in Massachusetts. It has produced a general, three Governors, a historian, a philologist, an artist and a poet.

IN an effort to dramatize progress in aeronautics in the British Empire, another long-distance air race looms for the early Autumn. I.W. Schlesinger, the South African industrialist, who arrived in Cape Town in the steerage in 1894 and now has a hand in many of the Union's enterprises, including ownership of its largest fruit-farm, with 4,000 employes, has offered prizes aggregating $50,000.

A large flotilla of Long Island yachtsmen will have a part in a unique inspection cruise which has been arranged for Thursday and Friday over a distance of more than a hundred miles. Captain Robert A. Schreiber of Freeport, chairman of the Long Island Chamber of Commerce's committee on ports and waterways, has announced that the inspection voyage will be mainly to advance the survey by army engineers of the Long Island Southern Inland Waterway.

PITTSFIELD, Mass. -- In a red-painted barn on the edge of a remote and wild 340-acre reservation at Lenox the seventh annual meeting of the Pleasant Valley Bird and Wild Flower Sanctuary Association is to be held on Wednesday afternoon.

JDUNCAN SPAETH, scholar and oarsman, has just retired from the Princeton faculty. For him, as for the seniors who received their diplomas last week, commencement marked the beginning of a new era of life. Dr. Spaeth will be inducted next Fall as the first president of the three-year-old, privately endowed, liberal arts University of Kansas City.
The Stage Relief Fund, which aids the unemployed of the theatrical profession, will benefit from a special dinner and entertainment program tonight at the Weylin Bar of the Hotel Weylin.

IN the seventeenth-century wars a brigade of the Spanish army refused to obey their commander's order to attack Bordeaux; although they were in the service of Spain, the soldiers were Irish, and they would not fight against France.

Bequests totaling $50,000, including $11,500 to hospitals in this city and Pittsburgh, were left in the will of Mrs. Bella M. Kaufman, which was filed for probate yesterday in Surrogate's Court. Mrs. Kaufman, who died last Wednesday, was the widow of Solomon Kaufman.

The Queens Democratic Executive Committee at a meeting yesterday at the party's headquarters, Woodside Avenue, Woodside, Queens, decided the long-debated question of Democratic leadership in the county by electing James C. Sheridan.

DID the antique turquoise ring that Mrs. Baldridge wore contain poison, as she often told her friends, or was the stuff in its hidden receptacle merely tooth powder placed there in order to impress her friends with the idea that she intended to commit suicide when life had lost its savor?

GREENWICH, Conn., June 20. -Mrs. J. Stillman Rockefeller is chairman of patronesses for the supper dance to be given at the Indian Harbor Yacht Club on Friday by the Greenwich Auxiliary of the Stony Wold Sanatorium.

THOUGH it was not his American debut, inquiries as to whether there were any records by Nathan Milstein in existence seem to have commenced about the time that this phenomenal young violinist made his appearance with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra under Toscanini.

QUEBEC, June 20 (Canadian Press). -- The plan for reorganization of Price Brothers Co., Ltd., newsprint manufacturers, that was submitted last April by the trustee in bankruptcy of the company is not acceptable, Judge Romeo Langlais ruled yesterday.

PARIS, June 20. -- The Senate received today the bill for an accord with the Bank of France to increase the limit on Treasury bonds by 10,000,000,000 francs. The Senate will vote on the measure Tuesday.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20. -- Pennsylvania, classed by Republicans as the Gibraltar of Republicanism, bids fair to be a pivotal State. Here will be waged along with the campaign in New York the most intense battle in the East. These States, with their large electoral votes, may easily decide the outcome of the election.
BOSTON, June 20 (AP). -- A ninth-inning rally gave the Bees a 7 to 6 victory over Cincinnati today and evened the series.

BERLIN, June 20. -- The upward movement on the Boerse came to a standstill today when the public and the professional traders adopted a policy of watchful waiting during the week-end. The trend was mixed, with gains and losses balancing in a very small turnover.

WASHINGTON, June 20. -- Unless President Roosevelt personally requests him to do so, Vice President Garner will not make any speeches during the political campaign this Summer, his close personal friends revealed here today.

A BIT of trouble broke out last week among the members of the Four Aces, the outstanding tournament champions of the last two years. Seemingly aloof, but actually closely connected with the case, was Ely Culbertson, whose rank as a contract bridge sytem-maker the Four Aces have attempted to challenge since they announced a system of their own and published a book early in 1935.
WARSAW, June 19. -- A great majority of the Germans in Poland have turned Nazi.

A letter from John Barbirolli, British conductor, who will open the New York Philharmonic-Symphony season on Nov. 5, discloses to the orchestra's society his present activities in London for the future.

ACE HARLAN, deputy sheriff, was sent into the Tortillon, wilderness to arrest that notorious outlaw Innocencio Ortuzar. He had no difficulty in finding the laughing, dark-eyed Spaniard, coming upon him, indeed, at the very moment to witness a deed of daring that compelled his admiration.

IT difficult to find justification for bringing out this slight short story in its present form -- the solitary item of a slim little volume. The canine protagonist, Bobbie, recounts the tale himself, etching what seems to be a plaus ible likeness of whatever the inner workings of doggish intelligence resemble.

Why did astronomers of the leading countries travel half way around the earth to photograph last week the aspects of a solar eclipse only two and a half minutes in length? For the paradoxical reason that we see the true sun only when we are completely immersed in the moon's shadow. Add up the rare minutes of the total eclipses that have occurred during the last fifty years.
Can the world succeed in reorganizing itself on a peace basis?
The analysis being compiled by the United States Department of Labor of the buying habits of typical New Yorkers met labor trouble from two directions yesterday.

EIN JOURNALIST ERZAEHLT" is the name Ruppert Recking has chosen for his book subtitled "Adventures in Africa" (Deutsche Verlagsanstalt, Stuttgart). And the stories he tells and his manner of telling them are so utterly fascinating that the reader lives through the political developments of the last years of the nineteenth century as if they were part of the living present.

KENNETH MacGOWAN does not mean to indicate that love is disappearing from the Hollywood scene. But the producer believes that motion picture script writers are showing an increasing tendency to get along without the aid of a love interest element.
The first of ten $1,000,000 outdoor swimming pools which the Park Department is building with WPA funds will be opened Wednesday afternoon in Hamilton Fish Park on the lower East Side.

With manufacturers and distributors in doubt last week over the possibility of the passage by Congress of new food and drug legislation, efforts were pushed to establish standards for a wide variety of products with a view to eliminating the need for the tightening of Federal control.

CANBERRA, Australia, June 20. -- The Australian commission investigating aircraft manufacture, comprising Wing Commander L.J. Wackett and Squadron Leaders Harrison and Murphy, has completed its inquiries in Britain and is now en route to the United States.

The estimate of the Federal Reserve's statisticians that industrial production in this country, "indexed" on the basis of the 1923-25 average as 100, had reached that figure last April, was interesting, in view of its decline to 58 in July of 1932. May and June of the present year will very possibly turn out to have done better than April.

There is many an interesting story behind the swimmers who are expected to stand out in the supercharged competitive atmosphere of the national championships at Oriental Pool, Manhattan Beach, Thursday through Sunday.

BARRED: Before the advent of the Nazi regime the stirring tales of Peter Freuchen, polar explorer, were best sellers in Germany; thereafter they were banned, because their author was a "non-Aryan." A Dane by birth, a man of tremendous physique, with a thick red beard and a booming voice, Freuchen had first gone into the Arctic in 1907 on a quest for adventure.

SHENANDOAH National Park, in the Blue Ridge Mountains region of Virginia, will be dedicated by President Roosevelt and other officials on July 3, it is announced. The ceremonies will take place at Great Meadows, on Skyline Drive. The completed part of this drive, which follows the crest of the mountain range, is thirty-two miles long and runs from Thornton Gap to Swift Run Gap.

WHILE our charming native magnolia or sweetbay is often seen in landscape plantings, it is seldom used in the place of vines to cover arches and arbors. Roses, clematis and wistaria have been for a great many years the standard plants for such service, but to the gardener who wants to break away from the commonplace the sweetbay (Magnolia gauca) offers something delightfully different and quite novel.

ENGROSSING as chess is, the acquisition of rare and ornate sets with which the game is played is deemed not less so. That both players and non-players have found reason for being fascinated with this sort of hobby is demonstrated in a current loan display from a New York collector now on view in the Semitic Museum at Harvard University.

PHILADELPHIA, June 21 (AP). -- Chairman Farley said tonight Governor Lehman of New York probably would make one of the speeches seconding renomination of President Roosevelt, his predecessor as chief executive of the Empire State.

Twenty-five witnesses have been subpoenaed by District Attorney Samuel H. Foley of the Bronx in his inquiry into the collapse on Friday of a part of an apartment building under construction at 112 East Mosholu Parkway South, it was learned yesterday.

A ruddy flare of sunset through a cross-street transforms its drab asphalt to a glowing breadth of cherry satin, with the newly lighted are lamps along either margin like great pearls of fabulously rich adornment.

NEW ORLEANS, June 21. -- Trading in the cotton market here last week improved steadily and at times was fairly active. There was an increase in speculative activity and liquidation of the July position proceeded rapidly. Early in the week there was considerable short covering and, near the close, longs sold, causing some reaction in the new crop positions.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, June 21. -- Treaty revision by peaceful agreement instead of by force will have is most conspicuous test in years at Montreux, Switzerland, tomorrow when Turkey's request to the League of Nations for a change in the Straits Convention will be examined.

TOPEKA, June 21. -- On the eve of the Democratic convention in Philadelphia, friends and advisers of Governor Landon have begun talking, with increasing assurance, of a drift back to the Republican party in the farm belt.

PHILADELPHIA, June 21. -- More than a million persons at rallies in 6,343 communities will listen Saturday evening to the speech of President Roosevelt accepting renomination by the Democratic National Convention, Postmaster General James A. Farley declared in speech over the Mutual, National, Columbia and Intercity broadcasting systems. Mr. Farley spoke from his headquarters in the Bellevue-Stratford Hotel, which has been equipped for broadcasting during the convention.

WASHINGTON, June 21. -- Tired members of the Seventy-fourth Congress started home today, some of them to quit political life and others bent upon repairing political fences in order to assure their return next Winter.

BERLIN, June 20. -- Imports in May amounted to 337,000,000 reichsmark, almost 7 per cent less than in April. The recessions were principally in fruit and vegetables from Italy; fruit from Spain; fish from England; butter, lard and eggs from Denmark; vegetables from the Netherlands, and flax from the I Lettish provinces.

AK-BULAK, U.S.S.R., June 21. --The Harvard-M. I. T. expedition obtained approximately 700 individual photographs of the eclipse of the sun and its spectrum. The development of the plates has been postponed owing to the necessity to make special tests and standardize the material.

OSHKOSH, Wis., June 21 (AP). -Wisconsin's Farmer-Labor-Progressive Federation, 6-months-old coalition of the State's Progressive and Socialist parties, turned thumbs down today on the new Union party and its Presidential candidate, Representative William Lemke, North Dakota Republican.
Writing from Pinewood Camp at Canton, Me., Don Jenks supplies an interesting description of a "canoe and carry" trip into the wilderness of Northwestern Maine.

Rimsky-Korsakoff's opera, "The Czar's Bride," is announced for production at the Lewisohn Stadium this Summer. This second opera chosen by Alexander Smallens for the stadium series will be performed Thursday and Friday nights, July 23 and 24, with Maria Kurenko in the leading feminine role and with the company of the Art of Musical Russia, Inc.

CHICAGO, June 21. -- Demand for hogs from packers and shippers advanced prices here last week to the highest levels in six weeks. The top price paid on Friday was $10.40 a hundredweight for selected lots weighing 160 to 230 pounds. The average price for the week was $9.80, a decrease of 5 cents from the previous week.

Appleton-Century, the American publishers of Maxim Gorky, report that at the time of his death he was working on the fourth and final novel of his "Forty Years -- The Life of Clim Samghin." The first three volumes, "Bystander," "The Magnet,'' "Other Fires," represent what Gorky intended to be his magnum opus.

The last sentence of the letter from "Cleveland Democrat" in your issue of June 10 seems a challenge for a partial reply to: "Will any of those now engaged in writing anti-monopoly editorials tell us how monopoly is to be destroyed?"
The ebb and flow of foreign currency values as this was linked to the vagaries of the French financial and political situation stood out as the most interesting incident of the week's trading.

Lawyers in Legislatures are notorious standpatters, but the report, published this morning, of the executive secretary of the State Judicial Council, shows that they "do move." Sixteen of twenty-four recommendations of the council took shape in more than twice that number of bills and were enacted.
The text of the appeal addressed to the delegates to the National Democratic Convention yesterday by Alfred E. Smith, Bainbridge Colby, James A. Reed, Joseph B. Ely and Daniel F. Cohalan follows:
BUENOS AIRES, June 21. -- Military elements in the provisional government of Bolivia expelled the civilian members of the junta last night and announced that the army alone would rule the country.

PHILADELPHIA, June 21. -- Twice as active socially and more than three times as strong numerically as were the Republican women at Cleveland. Democratic women buzzed about the refreshment table and the receiving line in two ballrooms at a tea in the Bellevue-Stratford Hotel this afternoon.

Offering to the public will be made today of an issue of $5,182,000 of city of New Orleans Public Belt Railroad Bridge revenue 4 per cent bonds, due serially on Oct. 1, 1937 to 1956, inclusive, and 1982 by a banking group headed by Banc-america-Blair Corporation.
GENEVA, June 21. -- League of Nations quarters believe the action Washington takes or fails to take on the issue of non-recognition of the Italian conquest of Ethiopia is likely to be decisive.

With the eyes of nearly 17,000 fans upon him and the irrepressible Cubs battling to take the National League lead away from the Cardinals, Van Lingle Mungo stayed in the spotlight at Ebbets Field yesterday and pitched and batted the Dodgers to a 6-4 victory in the second game after they had dropped the opener, 7 -- 2.

BERLIN, June 20. -- Germany's funded debt at the end of March amounted to 9,829,700,000 reichsmark, against 9,584,000,000 on Dec. 31, 1935. The increase was due substantially to the receipt of the second installment of the 500,000,000 reichsmark loan from the savings banks.

LAKEVILLE, Conn., June 21. -- The sermon to the graduating class at the Hotchkiss School was delivered today by the Rev. Dr. Karl Reiland, rector of St. George's Church of New York and an alumnus of the School.

MONTREUX, Switzerland, June 21, -- Security against Italy in the Mediterranean will be an important issue at the Straits conference of the League of Nations which will open here tomorrow. Italy and Spain will not be represented.

AKRON, June 21. -- Mr. John Citizen, the "man on the sidelines" in the labor disputes that have made this a strike-torn section for three years, is now apprehensive lest the situation get out of hand and the threat of a general strike of all local labor, made last Spring, be renewed in August or September when the rubber factories taper off production.

The Stars and Stripes stand for the same thing as the Supreme Court, stability in the United States, Justice William F. Hagarty of the Appellate Division, Brooklyn, told more than 5,000 persons at Flag Day exercises yesterday afternoon in Prospect Park.

Passenger traffic on the Interborough subway and elevated lines for the eleven months ended May 31, 1936, was 1.41 per cent heavier than for the same period in 1935, according to a report to be filed with Federal Judge Julian W. Mack today by Thomas E. Murray Jr., the company's receiver.

A goal by Major C.E. (Stub) Davis three minutes from the end broke a 6-all tie and gave the Governors Island poloists a 7 -- 6 triumph over the Meadow Brook Ramblers, headed by J.C. (Cocie) Rathborne, in a high-goal contest at Morris Memorial Field, Governors Island, yesterday.

In the letter sent to all the Democratic delegates at Philadelphia today, and signed by ex-Governor SMITH, ex-Governor ELY, ex-Senator REED, ex-Secretary COLBY and Mr. COHALAN, there is no lack of courage or, if you please, audacity. It is magnificent, but is it war? Are the objectives stated by the writers those which they really have in mind? If a work of persuasion were being undertaken, it is manifestly too late.

A letter from President Roosevelt hailing the efforts of the National Resorts and Parks Association was made public by the group yesterday in connection with a statement by its president, former Ambassador James W. Gerard, that the United States is about to enjoy a greater share of world travel than ever before.

PARIS, June 21. -- Several thousand members of the Rightist war veterans' organization, Croix de Feu, today fought the police and Mobile Guards who attempted to prevent them from parading. The veterans had been ordered to demonstrate in a protest against the Leftist government of Premier Leon Blum by their chief, Colonel Francois de la Rocque.

With retailers holding sufficient stocks to cover their present needs, there was a falling off in the demand for Summer merchandise last week in the wholesale apparel markets here. Introduction of new lines of cloth coats for Fall stimulated buying in this department.

SHANGHAI, Monday, June 22. -- A Nanking government spokesman at Shanghai denied a Canton report that Kwangsi generals had received an ultimatum Saturday from Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek. The spokesman said Nanking did not at present plan the formal launching of a punitive expedition to the southwest until after the policy had been determined at the plenary session, July 10.

PHILADELPHIA, June 21. -- Four of five signers of the message to the Democratic National Convention delegates calling upon them to put aside President Roosevelt and nominate "some genuine Democrat'' have personal reasons for desiring the defeat of the President, it was said here today.

Following is the text of the report submitted to the Board of Estimate by Samuel Seabury and City Chamberlain A.A. Berle Jr., summarizing the definitive plan of rapid transit unification to be presented to the Transit Commission today:
JERUSALEM, June 21. -- Sergeant Henry Sills was killed early in today's fighting and Arabs dragged his body into a cave. British troops bombed the cave and the Arabs sought shelter elsewhere.

PHILADELPHIA, June 21. -- Republican observers here, especially some from the Middle West and other, farm States, report a decline in President Roosevelt's strength in the farm sections, including those States of the West that deserted the Republican party in 1932.

SEA GIRT, N.J., June 21. -- Governor Hoffman reviewed Marine Corps Reserve troops from three States today in the first of the Summer's Sunday displays of military pageantry at Camp Hoffman, the New Jersey State encampment reservation.

LONDON, June 19. -- Foreign hoarding of British paper currency is continuing on a substantial scale and is responsible for the policy of the Bank of England in increasing its gold reserves, the objective being to neutralize the effect of British Treasury notes passing into foreign hands.

Removal of the offices of Police Commissioner and District Attorney from politics and appointment of their incumbents for life would be a stride toward raising the standards of law enforcement, the Rev. George Drew Egbert suggested yesterday morning in his sermon in the First Congregational Church of Flushing.

PHILADELPHIA, June 21. -- While the third party shot fired against the New Deal yesterday by Representative Lemke and Father Coughlin was still echoing on the Left, a volley from the Democratic Right was discharged today at the delegates gathering for the Democratic National Convention.

WASHINGTON, June 21. -- A ten-point program, aimed toward the formulation and effectuation of national policies designed to contribute to economic recovery and increased employment, was adopted today by the board of directors of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

During the past few months public protest against the violation of the right of asylum and the return of anti-Nazis to Germany has been steadily mounting. After the Labor Department ordered Otto Richter to surrender on June 12 for deportation this protest became so powerful that Richter was held at Ellis Island.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., June 21. -- A citizens' committee, organized by representatives of Westchester municipalities served by the New York, Westchester and Boston Railway, will meet Thursday night at City Hall here to help save the line from threatened liquidation.

The replacing of material values in a "doomed world" by greater spirituality and trust in God was asked yesterday morning by the Rev. Dr. J. Palmer Muntz of Buffalo, preaching at the First Baptist Church, Broadway and Seventy-ninth Street.

The church has been unable to stop the wave of disillusionment that has overwhelmed the modern age because it has been "saying it with flowers instead of thundering home the truth with ruthless certainty,'' Rev. Dr. Joseph M.M. Gray, Chancellor of American University, Washington, D.C., declared in a sermon yesterday at the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street.

AT 1 o'clock in the morning a storm put out the lights. I was about in the middle of Cora Jarrett's "Strange Houses" (Farrar Rinehart, $2.50). I lighted a candle and read for another hour. That's how much "Strange Houses" appealed to me.

PHILADELPHIA, June 21. -- A pre-convention drive of progressive Democrats for a more specific and less conservative platform than that prepared under the direction of Senator Wagner of New York was under way here today despite the manifest reluctance of President Roosevelt and some of his advisers to change their platform course in the face of a threatened third party movement.
A crowd of 30,333 baseball fans saw a lot of excitement at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

I observe your editorial conclusion that the American farmer's life "is essentially the life of a gambler" and that "he so manages his livelihood as to make this country unsafe for the staid and conservative boys in Wall Street."

A watch by Federal agents and Brooklyn detectives on two ex-convicts with long police records, and a 21-year-old youth, said to be middlemen or distributors for a large counterfeiting ring responsible for flooding the money market recently with counterfeit bills of $5 and $10 denominations, resulted in the arrest of the trio early yesterday in Brooklyn.

MADISON, Me., June 21. -- Taking a rifle belonging to her 14-year-old son, Mrs. Annie Jones, 32, today gagged and bound three of her five children, killed them and then committed suicide. Members of her family and neighbors said she had been despondent because of ill health.

Your editorial "Landon Nominated" gives me the impression that you feel Mr. Landon has to know all there is about the job before he gets it. Let me point out that if a man has two fundamentals, namely honesty and courage, they will go far toward enabling him to do a better job than a man whose word one cannot count on for more than two weeks.
William Ewasko, 49 years old, of 437 East Fifth Street, was shot dead at 2:45 A.M. yesterday in William's Tavern, 18 East Thirteenth Street, by two hold-up men.

ELMIRA, N.Y., June 21. -- Miss Lucretia Buxton, daughter of Jay Buxton, veteran California pilot, and Fred C. Barnes made today what was believed to be a new altitude record for two-seat gliders when they soared to about 2,500 feet on the second day of the annual soaring contest. The flight was witnessed by 3,000 persons gathered on Harris Hill.

DANBURY, Conn., June 21. -- Orkil's Applejack, a 4-year-old chestnut gelding owned by Mr. and Mrs. O.P. Kilbourn of West Simsbury, Conn., and ridden by James Scarborough, was adjudged the champion hunter this afternoon at the fourth annual horse show of the West Terrace Riding Club, held on the Danbury Fair Grounds.

WASHINGTON, June 21. -- In a letter to Governor Alf M. Landon, Republican Presidential nominee, the National Council for Prevention of War today asked his views on six issues bearing upon foreign policies.

In the four and a half months since the Federal Social Security Board received its first appropriation from Congress, it has disbursed $25,000,000 to thirty-six cooperating States to help finance their public assistance programs, Miss Jane M. Hoey, director of the security board's bureau of public assistance, said yesterday in a radio talk over WOR.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 21. -Frank Bowden of New York, the top-seeded favorite, defeated Leonard Hartman, former Columbia University captain, No. 2 in the draw, to annex the New Jersey State men's championship today at the Montclair Athletic Club.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., June 21. -- Franklin M. Haines's schooner Marita was apparently the winner of the Commodore Gerard B. Lambert Trophy for the Eastern Yacht Club's 171-mile New London to Marblehead race tonight. Although five craft were not accounted for, none seemed to have a chance of saving any time allowance on the B Class boat from Fishers Island.

After last Friday night's affair in the Yankee Stadium it is odd that no telegram of congratulations went from Premier MUSSOLINI to JOE JACOBS, manager of MAX SCHMELING. It should have said, in substance and derisively, "Hooray for the experts!"

LONDON, June 21 (AP). -- A slashing downpour of rain today threatened to postpone tomorrow's opening round of the tennis championships at Wimbledon as a powerful array of American stars, banished from the Davis Cup series, prepared to regain some prestige in the world's oldest title tournament.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., June 21. -- With eight committees at work on plans and recommendations, the announced purpose of which is "to bridge the chasm between scholarship and reality, between research and administration," Dr. Howard W. Odum, who called into being here last week the first institute on regional development ever assembled in this country, now is confident that his objective is certain of achievement, if not already in sight.

Evidence that the new Federal relief program would expand its aid to jobless youths was received here yesterday as the Welfare Council made public the preliminary findings of a survey showing that 15 per cent of the city's young persons between the ages of 16 and 25 were on relief.

Two interesting financial and industrial landmarks of the period were passed last week. On Tuesday, the TIMES stock market "averages" rose beyond the previous high mark of the year. They had declined nearly 14 points between April 6 and April 30, and subsequently recovered 14 7/8 points, to a figure not reached since the middle of August, 1931.

John J. Halleran, Public Works Commissioner of Queens, who complained recently to the Appellate Division that condemnation proceedings before Supreme Court Justice Charles C. Lockwood were unfair to taxpayers whose land was at stake, directed an attack yesterday on Corporation Counsel Paul Windels, who had come to the defense of Justice Lockwood.

An additional list of contributions received after the formal closing of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee's campaign to raise $1,500,000 was made public yesterday by Laurence M. Marks, chairman of the committee. Although active solicitation has ceased, the committee is keeping open its offices at 14 Wall Street in the hope that new donations will bring in the $135,000 needed to fill the quota.

YONKERS, June 21. -- The first day of Summer brought the first arrests under this city's celebrated modesty ordinance, and officials were pretty sure that it was an "inspired" test case. Photographers were there too soon, they pointed out.

SAN JUAN, P.R., June 21. -- James R. Bourne, who in the past two and a half years has spent $27,000,000 as relief administrator of Puerto Rico, explains in a statement today why relief is to end June 30 with no provision for an adequate organization to carry on the work.

MOUNTAINSIDE, N.J., June 21. -- Four persons were burned to death, a fifth sustained serious burns and two others were painfully cut in an automobile collision here early this morning. The dead, all of whom were trapped in their car, are:
More than 5,000 persons gathered round the bandstand on the Mall in Central Park yesterday afternoon to see the annual Finnish Folk Festival.

Miss Marie Cottrell, the 16-year-old star of the German-American Athletic Club, was the only double winner in the women's metropolitan A.A.U. track and field championships at Castle Hill Park yesterday, bringing in firsts in the 100-meter dash and the 80-meter hurdles to lead her team to victory with an aggregate of 54 points.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 21 (AP). -Senator Hastings, Delaware Republican, accused the Democratic National Committee tonight of illegally soliciting campaign contributions and said the Roosevelt administration was responsible for a campaign "similar in many respects to the unsavory record of a professional gangster."

John Hay Whitney, who formed Pioneer Pictures a year or so back to make motion pictures in techni-color, merged the venture with Selznick International last week. Mr. Whitney is chairman of the board of directors of the latter company, which David O. Selznick organized after leaving Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer last year.

Postponed from last Wednesday, "The Kick Back," a comedy-drama by Edwin Harvey Blum, gets around to its Broadway premiere tonight at the Ritz. "Backwash" was its first name when it was the child of the WPA Managers Tryout Theatre last month in Brooklyn.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, June 21. -- Largely because of Premier George Tatarescu's encouragement of Nazi and anti-Semitic reactionary bodies in their struggle against his own party -- the Liberal party which disowns him -- there was more of Fascist violence in the capital today.

The German dirigible Hindenburg, in a message to the United States Naval Air Station at Lakehurst, N .J., radioed last midnight that she expected to reach the New Jersey coast about 5 A. M. and to land at Lakehurst some time after 6 A. M.

IN the wake of the Schmeling-Louis battle, any one who cares to pick a winner in advance in the Poughkeepsie regatta today will be allowed free rein and no questions asked. This observer prefers to wait until it is over and then poll the judges at the finish. Caution will be the watchword in this corner for some time to come.

Substantial continuing gains in church membership throughout the United States are indicated in The Christian Herald Annual Report of Church Statistics appearing in the July issue. The figures were prepared by Dr. George Linn Kieffer, president of the American Association of Religious Statisticians and statistician of the National Lutheran Council.
CLEVELAND, June 21 (AP). -- A five-run barrage after two were out in the second inning gave the Indians an 8-3 triumph over the Senators today and swept the three-game series.

CHICAGO, June 21 (AP). -- Robert Riggs, who was graduated this year from Franklin High School in Los Angeles and who has been playing the game only three years, won the national clay courts tennis singles championship today with a smashing, straight-set victory over the odds-on favorite, Frankle Parker of Milwaukee, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 21. -- Swinging at anchor in the harbor tonight were fourty-five yachts receiving a last-minute grooming for the 635-mile race to Bermuda, starting tomorrow, which will have the most international representation of any ocean contest ever held.

LONDON, June 19. -- Trade in May showed no definite improvement in the overseas markets although more favorable than in April and March. An adverse balance of 27,500,000 is causing anxiety in the City, although substantial importation of raw materials foreshadows a more active export trade later in 1936.

The message sent from New York yesterday to the delegates to the Democratic National Convention by Alfred E. Smith and four other prominent Democrats was the culmination of an attack on President Roosevelt and the New Deal that began many months ago.

ROSLYN, L.I., June 21. -- Conserving their offensive powers until the late stages, the Roslyn poloists rallied in impressive fashion to gain a 9-all deadlock with Stephen (Laddie) Sanford's Hurricanes in a high-goal practice match on Schiff Field today.

As I have succeeded in establishing my point that the association of the pound sterling with gold is, in Rene Leon's words, "elastic," "not necessarily rigid," and "tied to gold at a variable price," there is no need to protract this correspondence. Those terms and phrases are just as applicable to the association of sterling with any other commodity as they are to its association with gold.

PARIS, June 20. -- Distinctive features of the Bank of France's statement for June 12 are the same as those in its previous weekly statement. Bills discounted further increased by 1,085,000,000 francs and circulation by 150,000,000.

The Atlantic Beach Club at Atlantic Beach, L.I., will be opened formally for its seventh season with a large dinner dance and dance contest on Friday night. A program of divertissements and sports contests has been arranged for subsequent days of the coming weekend.

Twelve scholarship winners, including two native New Yorkers, were listed yesterday by the Kosciuszko Foundation of 149 East Sixty-seventh Street. The awards provide for the Summer study of history, culture and language in Poland.

SAG HARBOR, L.I., June 21. -- The bones of a man believed to have been George Kenneth Simonson, 27 years old, of Garden City, L.I., were found near here today partly covered by sand on the beach at Noyack.

LONG BEACH, L.I., June 21. -Edward Hirsch, an 18-year-old student at New York Military Academy, who returned to his home at 36 Kentucky Street here last night for his Summer vacation, gave his life today in an effort to save a chum with whom he had been canoeing in Reynolds Channel.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., June 21. -- President Roosevelt and Governor Curley of Massachusetts were flayed in picturesque language today by Dr. George Luther Cady, secretary of the American Missionary Association, speaking at the biennial session of the General Council of Congregational and Christian Churches at Mount Holyoke College.

PITTSBURGH, June 21. -- Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 72 per cent of capacity, a rise of 1 point in a week and equaling the recent high rate. May showed the highest average of any month in years, 70.91 per cent.

CHICAGO, June 21. -- Every day of dry weather over the Corn Belt, specialists in this grain believe, reduces the prospects for a large crop. The start was an unusually good one, but corn cannot grow without water. New buying has appeared in the market, and those who were friendly to the staple increased their holdings and the short interest as been greatly reduced.

The recent marked improvement in the cotton manufacturing industry of this country was further extended last week, according to the New York Cotton Exchange Service. Mill sales of both finished and unfinished goods continued to run above current production.

LONDON, June 21. -- Now that Britain has decided to abandon sanctions the Anglo-Italian atmosphere is clearing rapidly. Patches of blue sky are at last beginning to break through the clouds after the worst storm that has ever blown up between Rome and London.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,106,577,800. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.
LILYPONS, Md., June 21 (AP) -- Miss Lily Pons found her namesake postoffice, surrounded by ponds of bright-hued lilies, more charming than the "wealth of kings" today on her initial visit.

PHILADELPHIA, June 21. -- Maurice P. Davidson, formerly chairman of the New York City Fusion party and chairman of the recently formed State-wide Citizens Committee for Lehman, arrived here tonight for the purpose of stimulating the movement to get Governor Lehman to reconsider his decision not to run for re-election.

DETROIT, June 21. -- With that dexterity for which he has distinguished himself more than once, Marse Joe McCarthy looked to have his annihilating Yankee machine back once more on the open road today.

WASHINGTON, June 21. -- President Roosevelt has opened war against alleged monopolistic practices in the steel industry. It was revealed today that on June 15 he instructed the Department of Justice to take "appropriate action" with regard to "collusive bidding" by principal steel companies on PWA contracts for steel piling.

CANBERRA, Australia, June 21. -- The Cabinet will meet tomorrow to draft a reply to Japan's decision to restrict Australian imports. The reply will indicate Australia is prepared to resume negotiations if the restrictions are not applied.
Vice President John N. Garner and United States Senator Edward Burke of Nebraska will receive honorary Doctor of Law degrees today in Jersey City from John Marshall College of Law.

The Drukman conspiracy trial now under way before Supreme Court Justice Erskine C. Rogers in Brooklyn is expected to reach the jury sometime this week, probably about Wednesday, it was reported yesterday by persons closely in touch with its progress:

PARIS, June 20. -- The Bourse was closed today, but unofficially the foreign exchanges weakened in terms of the franc, which indicates that the statement the Minister of Finance made in the Chamber of Deputies and the bills he submitted to Parliament were considered in financial circles as less disturbing than had been feared.

JONES BEACH, L.I., June 21. -- Churning the azure waters of Zachs Bay with powerful strokes, Mrs. Eleanor Holm Jarrett of the Women's Swimming Association today set a new American mark for the 220-yard back-stroke in regaining the senior metropolitan A.A.U. championship.

FRANKLIN SQUARE, L.I., June 21. -- With an attendance of more than 5,000, the fifty-third folk festival under the auspices of the Plattdeutsche Volksfest Verein of Brooklyn and vicinity opened here today in Plattdeutsche Park. The event will continue tomorrow and conclude next Sunday.

Another loss of traffic compared with a year before was reported yesterday for the Interborough Rapid Transit System for May, when travel declined 1,598,214 passengers, or 1.79 per cent. The subway carried 62,211,630 passengers, a decrease of 1,115,109, or 1.59 per cent, from May, 1935, Thomas E. Murray Jr., receiver, said.
PARIS, June 21. -- After having been closed and "occupied" by their employes on strike for seventeen days, the big department and "five-and-ten" stores of Paris will reopen tomorrow.

MADRID, June 21. -- When the leader of the Catholic party in the Cortes read last week to the assembled Deputies the figures detailing the number of outrages which have occurred in Spain since the new government of the Left took office in February, he intensified the long-existing feeling of uneasiness in the outside world about the course of events here.

It is highly significant that Russia has reached a stage where, after a mass movement to protect the Soviet State, she is now concerning herself with the protection of individuals even against the State, Dr. Robert Russell Wicks, Dean of the Chapel at Princeton University, said yesterday morning in his address before the congregation of Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street.

One of the great essentials in this world of turmoil and tumult, where there is such tension "that the worst in the human race makes itself apparent," is to learn the "ministry of silence," the Rev. Edmund Melville Wylie said yesterday in his sermon at the Park Avenue Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Eighty-fifth Street.

Under azure skies the two-masted schooner Effie M. Morrissey eased into the spangled waters of the Kill van Kull shortly after 10 A.M. yesterday, its sails bulging with a spanking breeze, on another trip to the Arctic with her skipper, Captain Bob Bartlett.

Maintaining that localization of vice work is necessary "if we are going to relieve our city of the ignominy of supporting vice syndicates," the Brooklyn Woman's Court Alliance, in its semi-annual report released yesterday, asks for the reopening of the Brooklyn Women's Court and the continuance of its social clinic plan in connection with the court.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 21. -- The Summer program of the Westchester County Recreation Commission will get under way early next month, it was announced here today.

The Republican campaign in the East will get under way this evening with a dinner at the Hotel Astor in honor of John D.M. Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Committee and director of the campaign which culminated in the Presidential nomination of Governor Alf M. Landon.

The attack of Messrs. Smith, Colby, Ely, Cohalan and Reed on President Roosevelt and the New Deal was measured in editorial comment this morning in terms of possible effect. The standing of the five men was recognized, but opinions varied as to the size of a Democratic revolt and doubt of a convention upset was expressed.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., June 21. -- In complete mastery of her mount at all times, 14-year-old Miss Clare S. Weber of Mount Kisco showed her 6-year-old agile gray gelding High Time splendidly to capture three blue ribbons at the Charity Amateur Horse Show staged at the Lawrence Farms Hunt Club today.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 21. -- Mrs. Marietta Johnson, educator and founder of the Fairhope School in Alabama and the Edgewood School in Greenwich, was the guest of honor at a tea and reception given this afternoon at the All Arts Studio.

Prices of cotton here registered further large gains last week. The price movement has been sharply upward for about four weeks, the advance from the low levels of the third week in May to the high marks of last week being 90 points on the old crop July delivery and 120 to 125 points on the new crop deliveries.

The Italian Line announced yesterday that "bon voyage" parties aboard its vessels must be staged early or not at all. Persons visiting departing friends must go aboard a ship at least an hour before and depart half an hour before the sailing time, according to the new regulations.

NEW HAVEN, June 20. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 82.5, which compares with 82.3 the week before, 81.2 two weeks before, 81.2 three weeks before and 80.5 four weeks before.

JERUSALEM, June 21. -- A British sergeant, Henry Sills, of the Seaforth Highlanders, was killed and three privates of the Royal Scottish Fusiliers were wounded and eleven Arabs lost their lives today in fights between British troops and Arab bands.

WASHINGTON, June 21. -- Last-minute strategy to be employed at the Democratic National Convention in Philadelphia and revisions in the Democratic platform were discussed with President Roosevelt by party leaders at the White House today.

While there are no court records to support the statement that "no Boy "Scout has ever been involved in crim "inal proceedings," it is the "best information," based on statements made by several jurists and prosecutors, that no such instances are recalled. It may be that some boys, out of loyalty to the Scouts, have hidden their affiliation with this greatest organization for boys in the world.

Overcoming a two-goal handicap in the initial period, Fort Hamilton triumphed over the Blind Brook Knights, 13 -- 5, in the first Eastern Polo League game for both teams at the Fort Hamilton Army Reservation yesterday.

A definitive plan for rapid transit unification, calling for the purchase by the city of the properties of the B.M.T., the Interborough and the Manhattan Railway Company at a total net price of $416,583,220, will be submitted to the Transit Commission today by Samuel Seabury and City Chamberlain A.A. Berle Jr., acting as Mayor La Guardia's transit advisers.

Pin-ball games are decidedly games of chance, according to an experiment made by Dr. Clarence C. Clark of the General Science Department of New York University's School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance. Dr. Clark based his conclusion on the result of 97,800 plays made by students under his supervision.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., June 21. -- Dr. James G. McDonald of the editorial staff of THE NEW YORK TIMES and former League of Nations high commissioner for refugees from Germany, and Dr. T.Z. Koo, secretary of the World Student Christian Federation of Shanghai, were the principal speakers at an afternoon program of the session of the Geeral Council of Congregational and Christian Churches in the Municipal Auditorium here.

PHILADELPHIA, June 21. -- Two seceding Presbyterian churches of Southern New Jersey successfully resisted efforts today of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America to declare their pulpits vacant and assume control of the services.

PHILADELPHIA, June 21. -- The missing faces among the early arrivals for the Democratic Convention revealed today that former Governor Alfred E. Smith and Senator Copeland of New York are not the only ones "taking a walk" from the party meeting beginning here on Tuesday.
While thunder rolled and lightning flashed over deserted Fifth Avenue at 5:30 A.M. yesterday a man smashed one of the large plate glass windows in Frederics's jewelry shop at Forty-sixth Street.

DES MOINES, Iowa, June 21. -- Uncle Sam's swimming stars shattered two more men's American records and bettered a women's mark today in concluding the four-day national A.A.U. men's senior outdoor championships.

DAVENPORT, Iowa, June 21. -Husky 24-year-old Ralph Guldahl, from Los Angeles, went over the Davenport Country Club acreage today like a prairie fire to score one of the most spectacular rounds in American golfing history, 33 -- 31 -- 64, to snatch the Western open golf championship from Ray Mangrum of Dayton, Ohio.

PARIS, June 20. -- This week the Bourse still has reflected the general feeling of uneasiness prevailing in this country. Rentes and French securities in general declined further, but the market on Saturday was quieter.

Formal offering will be made today by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc.; Graham, Parsons Co. and Dick Merle-Smith of an issue of $4,935,000 of Great Northern Railway Company secured 4 per cent serial bonds, due semi-annually, on Oct. 1, 1936, to April 1, 1944, inclusive.

VIENNA, June. 21. -- Anti-government demonstrations, mainly by Nazis but also by Socialists, occurred yesterday and today on a big scale. They were in part directed against the government's encouragement of Hapsburg propaganda.

CHICAGO, June 21. -- An unexpected reversal in the world's grain crops, especially those in the United States, took place last week. A week ago pit operators were disheartened. Trade was light and almost entirely local, with most speculators either idle or short. It was said to be impossible to get a first-class idea on the starting of a bull market and more than a fractional advance.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 21 (AP). -- The Syracuse Chiefs lost two games to the Newark Bears here today, the first when Newark rallied for two runs in the last inning and scored a 5 -- 4 victory, and the second when the visitors got five runs in the twelfth to win, 9 -- 7.

No man in his senses would attempt to predict in detail the net social effect of the legislation dumped out by the Seventy-fourth Congress in the last few days of its final session. It would require the combined efforts of our best economists and half a dozen Philadelphia lawyers to predict the effects of the so-called Anti-Chain-Store Act alone.
Public employment offices in this State placed more workers in private jobs last month than in any other month since 1929, Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews announced last night.

BERLIN, June 21. -- While German courts continue to grind out prison sentences against Catholic priests and monks, and while the Bishop of Trier, on instructions from Pope Plus, is investigating the State's immorality charges, the Nazi press has opened a public barrage against Catholic institutions.

WASHINGTON, June 21. -- The close of the second session of the Seventy-fourth Congress showed a wide range of important legislation enacted, even though its work did not begin to compare with the vast legislative program of its initial session.

MANHASSET, L.I., June 21. -- Mrs. Payne Whitney will open her home and the grounds of Greentree, her estate in this community, on Friday afternoon for the fifteenth annual circus and lawn festival in aid of the milk funds of the Social Service Department of the New York Hospital and the Family Welfare Association of Nassau County.

PHILADELPHIA, June 21. -- The idea at this National Convention of the Democratic party seems to be to get on record in as substantial and permanent a fashion as possible for President Franklin D. Roosevelt's renomination and reelection.
NEWPORT, R.I., June 21. -- Mr. and Mrs. Verner Z. Reed Jr. entertained at dinner at Terra Mare tonight.

After expressing his sympathy with the fundamental view of the Rev. Dr. J. Gresham Machen and other Fundamentalists who have left the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America to organize the new Presbyterian Church of America, the Rev. John H. McComb, pastor of the Broadway Presbyterian Church, Broadway and 114th Street, in his sermon yesterday morning, announced his intention of remaining within the older church.

Featured by a tendency of firms to expand their present quarters, office renting in lower Manhattan gives evidence of a definite improvement, according to responses to questionnaires sent to agents of thirty-three of the larger buildings in the downtown area.
ROME, June 21 (AP). -- Great Britain and Italy have reached an agreement in principle on the main points of a Mediterranean military accord, army circles said today.

Under the direction of Charles C. Stech, research specialist, members of the Sales Executive Club of New York will participate in a survey on "Problems of Leadership for Sales Executives." Questionnaires for the study will be received by all club members today.
PHILADELPHIA, June 21. -- Delegates and others here for the Democratic Convention visited historic spots today.
PHILADELPHIA, June 21 (AP). -- The Pirates defeated the Phillies in a battle of home runs today by the score of 7 -- 6 before 5,000 fans.

DUBLIN, June 21. -- The de Valera government successfully utilized the full forces of the State to enforce today its ban against the Irish Republican Army's proposed parade at the grave of the eighteenth-century republican patriot, Theobald Wolfe Tone, at Bodenstown, County Kildare.

CHICAGO, June 21 (AP). -- The Athletics drove Babe Phelps from the box with an eight-run uprising today to defeat the White Sox, 11 -- 5, in the final game of the series, taken by the Mackmen, two games to one.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 21. -Because of the increased activities in night operations and field problems in the training of the New York State National Guard units, beginning tomorrow, for two days Camp Smith will be entirely devoid of troops for the first time during the fifty-four seasons of encampment there.

BERLIN, June 20. -- The stock market here this week-end had a rather weak tendency although it had an encouraging start owing to favorable reports on the trade situation by the Reich Trade Investigation Department.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 21. -- Cornelius Shields's Interclub Aileen, young Bob Bavier's Atlantic Frolic, Stanley Ogilvy's Star Jay and F.S. Steinhardt's Victory Nike were the winners today in the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's regatta, the first special Sunday event the club has run off its regular line two miles northeast of Execution Light on the Sound.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 21. -- For the thirty-eighth time since 1895 the tall, rocky cliffs of the Highlands looked down tonight on the last preparations of eight-oared shells for a regatta of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association.

WILLIAMS BAY, Wis., June 21 (AP). -- A universe made up of stars that explode periodically like a string of firecrackers was pictured tonight by astronomers who watched the "new" star blazing in the northeastern sky.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 21. -- City officials here prepared today to apply to the State courts for a writ of review to test the constitutionality of the Durand Beach Commission Law. hurriedly passed by the Legislature at 6 P.M. last Friday.

Summer arrived yesterday after an early morning thunderstorm and brought a perfect June day of pleasantly warm weather tempered with mild breezes. The beaches and resorts of the metropolitan area drew the largest crowds of the season. Traffic was jammed all day on the highways leading from the city.
HOYLAKE, England, June 21. -Gene Sarazen, back again in pursuit of the British open golf championship, surveyed the long stretches of fairway today and sighed:

PHILADELPHIA, June 21. -- Only a small vanguard of Democratic convention visitors had arrived tonight, but Philadelphia hotels were prepared for an influx beginning early tomorrow morning that may overtax their facilities.
FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, June 21. -- The Saar territory got its first taste of Nazi revolutionary tribunals when sentence was passed yesterday on nineteen workers accused of Communist agitation.

The cornerstone of the new Jewish Memorial Hospital, at Broadway and 196th Stret, was laid yesterday afternoon with exercises in which representatives of the government, city and various war vetterans organizations participated. The hospital, a non-sectarian institution, was organized in 1905 and occupied a building at Dyckman Street and River Road.

Irregular price movements marked commodity futures markets here last week. Coffees and sugar were weaker, while cocoa continued its gains. In the cash markets all the grains, cotton, dairy products, raw sugar, print cloths, lard, cocoa and rubber rose, as tins, silk, wool tops and hides eased.

The mind of man should be the tool of his heart, for unless his heart guides the mind, man will misuse his mental capacities and will utilize science for destructive war and material wealth for base purposes, the Rev. Dr. Robert W. Searle, general secretary of the Greater New York Federation of Churches, declared yesterday morning in his sermon at the West End Collegiate Reformed Church, West End Avenue and Seventy-seventh Street.

ROME, June 21. -- The parade held in Rome today to mark the hundredth anniversary of the organization of the Bersaglieri, Italy's crack corps of infantry, gave Premier Benito Mussolini an occasion to issue another reminder of how grave the consequences might be if League of Nations sanctions are not lifted.

Formation of an independent political party -- to be known as the All-Peoples party -- which will enter a slate of candidates in the coming elections in the Congressional, State Senatorial and Assembly districts of Harlem was unanimously voted yesterday afternoon at the closing session of a two-day convention at the Renaissance Casino, Seventh Avenue and 138th Street.

BOLTON LANDING, N.Y., June 21. -- Statutory regulation of investments handled by trust companies "deserves a more fundamental approach than the last Legislature gave the matter," according to the warning pondered today by members of the New York State Bankers Association, who received it here from their committee on trust functions.

ST. LOUIS, June 21 (AP). -- After being shut out, 3 to 0, in the opener of today's double-header, the Browns came back in the second game and bombarded five Red Sox pitchers to win, 6 to 3, and close the series with Boston.

The 15,000,000 votes that Dr. Francis E. Townsend claims in the old age pension movement, and the several million more claimed by the Rev. Gerald L. K. Smith as inheritor of Senator Huey P. Long's Share-the-Wealth group will be offered to Representative William Lemke, candidate for the Presidency, if he will meet platform demands of the two leaders, it developed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 21. -- In a statement issued today Postmaster General Farley praised postmasters and postal employes generally for their handling of the distribution and payment of the veterans' adjusted service bonds. The statement said:

PHILADELPHIA, June 21. -- It was the consensus among the few party leaders who so far have gathered here for the Democratic National Convention that the Smith-Colby-Reed-Ely-Cohalan message calling upon the convention to reject President Roosevelt as a candidate for renomination and his New Deal program, while addressed to the delegates, was really, so far as the convention itself is concerned, intended for the galleries and beyond that to Democratic voters throughout the country.

PHILADELPHIA, June 21. -- Representative Arthur W. Mitchell, Negro Democrat of Illinois, and a resolution of the Bishops' Council of the African Methodist Episcopal Church, were quoted today by W. Forbes Morgan, secretary of the Democratic National Committee, as showing that the Negroes of the United States had received better treatment from the Roosevelt administration than from Republican administrations.

The National Civil Service Reform League, carrying the scars of many battles for the merit system during the half century of its existence, has every right to speak out as it does today when that system is challenged as it has not been in a generation. Postmaster General FARLEY'S rubber stamp signature on letters urging postmasters to solicit campaign contributions may have been used without his consent.

The lists of pending cases before New York courts have been cut down in some instances to the vanishing point according to a report made public yesterday by Judge Frederick E. Crane, Chief Judge of the Court of Appeals and chairman of the Judicial Council of the State of New York.

LAKE MAHOPAC. N.Y., June 21 (AP). -- Legislation to put the right to declare war directly into the hands of the nation's voters was recommended today at the conference of the League for Industrial Democracy.
A practical test of parking meters in the city is urged in a report by the committee on control of street traffic of the Merchants Association of New York, made public yesterday.
BALTIMORE, June 21. -- Twentyeight young Jesuits from New York State were among forty-one members of the Society of Jesus elevated to the priesthood today at Woodstock College.

After a day of guarding city streets, a Brooklyn policeman was awakened at his home last night by a burglar who entered unceremoniously through a front window and departed quickly by the same route when he learned he was in the home of a policeman.

Elimination of objectionable open-front foodstuff markets on both sides of Broadway from Fifty-ninth to ll6th Street began to take effect yesterday. Patrolmen had informed the storekeepers last week that they would have to move all fruit, vegetable and other stands to the interior of their establishments and keep at least three feet inside the entrances.
Plans of a $45,000 synagogue for Brooklyn and several projected groups of dwellings in Queens were outstanding items listed yesterday, as follows:

In itself the President's letter to the Attorney General, asking the latter to act on the charges of the Federal Trade Commission that four great steel companies have been engaged in collusive bidding, should not be a cause for surprise. When four companies submit identical bids on three PWA contracts for steel piling, one cannot attribute the result to mere coincidence.

WASHINGTON, June 22. -- O.P. Van Sweringen, head of large railroad interests, was ordered today to appear tomorrow before the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee to be questioned on alleged evasiveness pursued by him and his employes in connection with the committee's investigation into railroad reorganizations and financing.

The fifty-seventh commencement concert of the New York College of Music, 114 East Eighty-fifth Street, will take place tonight in Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street. Forty students will be graduated. Miss Grace Spofford, associate director of the school, will speak.

OMAHA, Neb., June 22. -- L.S. Crowder of St. Louis, general manager-treasurer of the National Retail Credit Association since 1934, was reappointed by the new board of directors following the convention that was in session here through Friday of last week. Arthur H. Hert, St. Louis, was reappointed secretary and research director.
PHILADELPHIA, June 22. -- This Democratic National Convention may enter upon a novel venture (one might almost call it an adventure) of drafting a candidate for Governor of New York.
A decision of Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler, announced yesterday, may mean many thousands of dollars to holders of certificates in mortgage issues.

In a letter to The Journal of the American Judicature Society Mr. NEWTON D. BAKER, speaking of judges elected by popular vote, as is the custom in most States, says that this system "practically commits this election "of judges to politicians, whose deter- "mination is not necessarily bad, but "is quite obviously not primarily di- "rected toward a discriminating judg- "ment in the matter of fitness for "judicial service."

American Automatic Restaurants Inc., operating the Servall Restaurants, has leased the entire basement 21,000 square feet, of the Pershing Square Building at 100 East Forty-second Street, opposite Grand Central Terminal. Robert T. Neeley is president of the company, which automatically will dispense food and beverages, including draught beer, in return for coins inserted in slots.

For the third time in three months a police van was carried yesterday to the tenth floor of the Port Authority Building, 111 Eighth Avenue, to bundle off eight men arrested while seeking an interview with Victor F. Ridder, local Works Progress Administrator, or one of his experts on labor relations.

G.C. Beresford does not, as his publishers say, believe in rushing into print. His book, "School Days With Kipling -- The True Inner History of 'Stalky Co.,'" was begun in 1897 and completed last year. Putnams will publish it this Fall. Beresford was the original M'Turk who played so large a part in "Stalky Co.," Kipling's account of his school days.

There were some strange doings last evening at the Ritz, where Summer met up with the drama and eyed askance a brief number called "The Kick Back." A play by Edwin Harvey Blum, it came from Brooklyn and the aegis of the WPA, preceded by the favorable reports of transpontine scouts and basking in the glory of a late June premiere.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., June 22. -- Ernest Desmond De Hagen, 46 years old, wanted by the New York police on a charge of attempted extortion, was arrested here today on information received from Chief Inspector John J. Seery of New York.
WESTFIELD, Mass., June 22. -- Former Governor Ely announced tonight his willingness to take the stump for Governor Landon if called upon to do so.

A building cleaner fell twelve stories to his death on the Broadway side of The Times Building, in Times Square, at 9:30 A.M. yesterday, and another clung for his life to a tipped scaffold while throngs stared up from the streets. A broken scaffold rope caused the accident.

WASHINGTON, June 22. -- The Kable Brothers Company of Mount Morris, Ill., which prints about 170 magazines for various companies, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a statement covering 12,419 shares of common stock of $10 par value and having a proposed maximum offering price of $10 a share.

Sixteen men, two women and five corporations entered pleas of not guilty in Special Sessions yesterday to the "information" filed last week by Assistant District Attorney Eugene B. McAuliffe alleging they conspired to violate the State trade-mark law in the sale of counterfeit automobile parts.
NEWPORT, R.I., June 22. -- The Newport-Bermuda sailing race, which started today, is being followed by several yachts with owners and guests aboard.

PHILADELPHIA, June 22. -- Wandering in some confusion down Broad Street this afternoon was an elderly gentleman who was identified by a TIMES reporter as Godfrey G. Gloom, the well-known pawpaw planter and old-fashioned Jeffersonian from Amity, Ind.

CHICAGO, June 22. -- Prices of hogs generally advanced 10 cents a hundredweight today to a new high price since May 4. Numerous loads of 180 to 225 pound averages sold at the highest level, which was $10.50. The day's average of $10 was likewise the best since May 4, showing an advance of 80 cents from the low average of May 12.

STONY BROOK, L.I., June 22. -- Bettering par by four strokes, Steve O'Donnell and Walter Scheiber, Cedarwood pair, took low honors in the weekly Long Island amateur-pro best-ball tournament conducted at the St. George's Golf and Country Club today.

PHILADELPHIA, June 22. -- Senator Carter Glass of Virginia, despite an announcement he made on his arrival from Washington tonight that he was too fatigued to serve, will become a member of the resolutions committee of the Democratic convention.

A total of $58,550 was realized at an auction last Saturday in Freeport, L.I., for the John J. Randall estate and the Woodcleft Realty Company. Joseph P. Day, the auctioneer, sold more than fifty lots, including an improved business parcel opposite the Freeport station.

John D. M. Hamilton, Republican National Chairman, hailed last night, as high idealism, the appeal to the Democratic National Convention by Alfred E. Smith and four others to reject the candidacy of President Roosevelt.

PHILADELPHIA, June 22 (AP). -- Jimmy Collins's second home run of the battle and his ninth of the season in the eighth inning with Pepper Martin on base broke a 6-6 deadlock and gave the league-leading Cardinals an 8-6 triumph over the Phillies today in the opener of a four-game series.

Mayor La Guardia's chief transit advisers, Samuel Seabury and City Chamberlain A.A. Berle Jr., handed their definitive plan for rapid-transit unification to the Transit Commission yesterday, along with a warning that prompt action by that body was essential if unification was to be achieved.

BERLIN, June 22. -- Prices on the Boerse fell today throughout the list, responding to news of the new Reich loan which had been influencing trading for some days. The turnover, however, was strictly limited, partly because of the hot weather, partly because market preparations already had been made for announcement of the loan.
LAKEVILLE, Conn., June 22. -- Only the sturdy should enter politics, Governor Cross declared in an address to the graduating class of Hotchkiss School at commencement exercises today.

The Phoenix Securities Corporation has acquired a substantial interest in Consolidated Motor Lines, Inc., of Hartford, Conn., and is supplying the concern with cash to carry out a plan of expansion subject to rulings of the Interstate Commerce Commission.

WASHINGTON, June 22. -- Construction work accounted for 78.5 per cent of the money expended throughout the nation in the WPA program to April 15, Harry L. Hopkins, Works Administrator, reported today. Of the $1,459,371,856 spent by WPA to that date, $1,145,866,107 went for construction, Mr. Hopkins declared.

PHILADELPHIA, June 22. -- In a spirit of loyalty to the President and his administration, obviously intensified by the open hostility of radical independents and conservative Democrats, the Democratic National Convention will assemble in its first session tomorrow noon in the Municipal Auditorium.

ELMIRA, N.Y., June 22. -- Using automobile and shock cords to get into air in the absence of the right wind, several glider pilots made satisfactory but not spectacular journeys today at the national soaring contests. Richard C. Dupont of Wilmington, Del., using a new German sail plane, sailed to an altitude of 4,000 feet on thermal currents.

WASHINGTON, June 22. -- The government prepared today to put many millions of dollars into the drought-stricken area of South Dakota, North Dakota and Montana. Official reports show that an exodus of sufferers already has begun and that the drought is as serious, in a more limited area, as that in the entire plains territory in 1934.

Specialists on the Stock Exchange were congratulated yesterday upon what was regarded by brokers as the vindication, upon its practical merits, of the specialist system in the Securities and Exchange Commission's segregation report. Well-informed individuals attributed the specialists' apparent good fortune to their self-discipline.

PHILADELPHIA, June 22. -- A series of declarations topped by the broader social and economic aspirations of the New Deal, and based largely on the legislative record of the administration to date, was reported tonight to have been agreed upon by President Roosevelt and his advisers as the platform to be adopted by the Democratic National Convention which opens here tomorrow.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 22 (AP). -- With the men's field cut in half, women stars will enter the tennis championship lists tomorrow with an all-British match between Miss Dorothy Round and Miss Betty Nuthall holding the spotlight on the center court.

PHILADELPHIA, June 22. -- Some of the ablest feminine minds in the Democratic party concentrated this afternoon on suggestions for planks representing dominant interests of women, to be presented to the committee on resolutions. The first point of agreement was on a strong peace plank, which read:

DALLAS, Texas, June 22. -- With more than 5,000 retail grocers from all parts of the nation present for the opening session of their four-day convention, D.A. Affleck of Salt Lake City, president of the National Retail Grocers Association, announced that all previous attendance records had been broken. The grocers laughed at the near-record temperatures that greeted them, declaring that Texas heat was nothing to worry about.
BISMARCK, N.D., June 22. -- A moisture deficiency of as much as fifty-three inches in North Dakota in the past six years was officially reported today.

WASHINGTON, June 22. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today denied the application of nine corporations for confidential treatment of data filed with it under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, granted applications by twenty-four companies for secrecy of certain information and made public data which one company had first asked be held confidential and later withdrew such request.

OTTAWA, June 22. -- A series of clashes between the House of Commons and the Senate today prolonged the dying hours of the Canadian Parliament whose obsequies had originally been expected last Saturday.
Darley Randall, who has been in the investment department of the Fiduciary Trust Company three years, has been elected an assistant vice president.

PHILADELPHIA, June 22. -- Despite former Governor Smith's demand that the Democratic convention repudiate the New Deal, the Tammany Hall delegation, reaching here late this afternoon, is 100 per cent for the renomination of President Roosevelt.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 22. -- Willie Macfarlane, veteran Old Oaks professional, equaled the Fenway Club course record today with a brilliant 34, 33 -- 67, but even this effort left him and his partner, George Klein, a stroke short of the best-ball total posted by Joe Creavy and David Scope of Mount Vernon in the one-day professional-amateur tournament sponsored by the Metropolitan Golf Association and the Westchester P.G.A.

" No lawyer should feel that his retainer requires him to aid a client to perpetrate an injustice or violate the law," said Presiding Justice Francis Martin of the Appellate Division yesterday in an address to 135 new lawyers in advising them as to their future conduct.
HAVANA, June 22. -- President Miguel M. Gomez late this afternoon sent the proposed 1936-37 budget, amounting to $73,166,971.17, to Congress. Last year's budget totaled $65,125,000.

WASHINGTON, June 22. -- Conferences on proposals by the Securities and Exchange Commission for segregation of the broker-dealer functions on the floors of the national securities Exchanges, except for the specialists, will await study by officials of the Exchanges and others interested, of the various changes proposed to be made in floor practices.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 22. -- The story of how the spirit of Rotary International halted a dangerous race war in a city in India was related at the twenty-seventh annual convention here today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 22. -- More than 200 delegates, representing the governments of twenty countries, engineering concerns, universities, learned societies, and research institutions attended the first International Conference on Soil Mechanics and Promotion Engineering which opened at the Harvard Graduate. School of Engineering here today.

WASHINGTON, June 22. -- Describing John Dillinger as "a beer-drinking plugugly," and "Pretty Boy" Floyd as an "ego-inflated rat," J. Edgar Hoover today asked the Hi-Y Clubs of America to adopt the slogan "Save a Boy From Crime."

IT'S a long way to the football season, but Lou Little had better swing into action immediately. Unless something is done it may be that the Columbia Lions will have to fight their way through the football wars without the first aid of Doc Barrett, the veteran trainer who has been treating and bandaging the wounded Columbia athletes for so many years.

In THE TIMES recently Gridley, Adams wrote: "If the late Huey Long had wanted to stop free speech in his State of Louisiana and could have got his Legislature to pass such a law, the Federal Government could not have had a word to say about it -- the Constitution forbids the Congress to make any law restricting Louisiana's States' rights."
The Long Island Railroad lost, won and then won again yesterday in a day of fast court action in its fight to prevent the establishment of a two-cent-a-mile fare for single trips on the road.

The Presidential candidacy of Representative William Lemke on a "Union party" ticket will be discussed at a conference in Washington today, the Rev. Gerald L.K. Smith announced here today. Participating, he said, would be Dr. F.E. Townsend and a representative of the Rev. Father Charles E. Coughlin, as well as Representative Lemke himself.
POUGHKEEPSIE N.Y., June 22. -- Two great Washington crews today set the stage for the dramatic climax of the varsity victory.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., June 22. -- For its first production of the Summer, the Red Barn Theatre, with an enlarged seating capacity, offered tonight a new play, "Please Do Not Disturb," by Charles O. Locke, under the management of D.A. Doran and Arthur Hanna.
