BERLIN, June 22 (AP). -- The 1936 Olympic Games at Berlin have drawn a record entry of fifty-three participating nations, the German Olympic Committee officially announced tonight after completing its listing of the entries, which closed Saturday.

TIENTSIN, June 22 (AP). - Japanese consular officials said today that "Japan suffered an insult she is unable to ignore" when a Chinese customs cruiser fired on a Japanese vessel off Tangku yesterday.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 22. -- Expressing faith in the future of American banking, Robert V. Fleming, president of the American Bankers Association, urged his colleagues here tonight to adopt a "fair and temperate attitude" in considering legislative proposals relating to their profession.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., June 22. -- Led by Chase Kimball, banker, of Waterbury, Conn., and the Rev. Rockwell Harmon Potter of Hartford, Conn., the delegates of the General Council of Congregational and Christian Churches of the United States, in session at Mount Holyoke, today adopted an amendment to the committee resolution on international relations, reaffirming the general council's former action favoring membership of the United States in the League of Nations and the World Court.
PARIS, June 22. -- Germany has placed a ban on the motion picture "The Country Doctor" starring the Dionne quintuplets, the Paris Tageszeitung reported today.

LONDON, June 22. -- Millions of men will wear bright flowers in their buttonholes tomorrow as a greeting to King Edward on his forty-second birthday. It will be a tribute for which there is no precedent, although Britons have become hardened to tag days of all sorts.

WASHINGTON, June 22. -- The public utility holding companies won a victory in litigation with the government today when the United States Court of Appeals held that the District of Columbia Supreme Court had exceeded its authority in staying further proceedings in suits filed hero by seven companies asking injunctions and attacking the constitutionality of the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935.

PHILADELPHIA, June 22. -- It is now a matter of hours until the Democratic National Convention shall open. Four days have passed since the crowds began to assemble here -- delegates, spectators, alternates, hangers-on, the usual camp following which every great convention attracts.

Details of the Inland Steel Company's plan to acquire, through an exchange of shares, control of the Milcor Steel Company, a Delaware corporation, were disclosed yesterday with the listing on the New York Stock Exchange of 59,000 additional shares of Inland's no-par capital stock.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 22. -- Quite the biggest of the Big Five American stars, all of whom won their first-round matches in men's singles at the All-England tennis championships today, was Bryan M. Grant of Atlanta Ga., who, when all seemed lost, pulled the match against Heiner Henkel of Germany out of the fire and finished by beating Germany's No. 2 player in five sets.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

His own scrupulous honesty and aggressiveness as a former Federal prosecutor, which earned him a number of enemies, now his vengeful accusers, was assigned by Henry G. Singer yesterday as the reason for his present plight as a defendant charged with conspiracy in the Samuel Drukman murder case.
MINEOLA, L.I., June 22. -- More than $25,000 worth of equipment has been lost through "piracy" along the North Shore of Long Island during the last few weeks, it was revealed today.

WASHINGTON, June 22. -- While Senator Harrison acted as virtual White House spokesman to minimize the political threat to the administration in the bolt threatened by Alfred E. Smith and his conservative associates, President Roosevelt held a round of conferences today.

BERLIN, June 22. -- The German Government announced today another domestic loan of 700,000,000 marks, raising the total of middle-term and long-term government securities to 3,300,000,000 marks during the last eighteen months.

Of all the patriotic services of the late Senator from Florida, Duncan U. Fletcher, none was more important than his organization of a nonpartisan bloc in the United States Senate immediately after the failure of the Austrian Credit-Anstalt had ushered in the secend stage of the world depression.

WASHINGTON, June 22. -- For the third consecutive month the monthly figures of payrolls and employment in manufacturing and non-manufacturing industries have shown an upward trend, which Secretary Perkins today called "most unusual," because the statisics for March, April and May usually show seasonal declines.
PHILADELPHIA, June 22. -- Eugene Talmadge, Georgia's anti-New Deal Governor, was ousted tonight as his State's member of the Democratic National Committee.
PHILADELPHIA, June 22. -- The Democratic National Convention, which will open here tomorrow, is "under control," to use a favorite expression of Postmaster General Farley, national chairman.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., June 22. -- The fifth annual "Night of Sports" was presented tonight under the big top next to the Bronxville School by the Leonard S. Morange Post of the American Legion. More than 2,500 attended. Proceeds aid the post's welfare fund.
Professor Casey Stengel yesterday watched his Dodgers return to normalcy and a near-shutout at the hands of Paul Derringer and the Reds, who romped away with the series opener, 7 -- 2.
BOSTON, June 22 (AP). -- The Bees turned back their nemesis, Tex Carleton, for the second time in three years today and defeated the Cubs, 5 -- 1, in the opener of a four-game series.

Columbia Pictures will release fifty-eight feature films and 126 short subjects during the 1936-37 season, according to an announcement made here yesterday coincident with the opening of the company's annual sales convention in Chicago.

The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary arrived yesterday from England and France, the trip being almost four hours longer than her maiden Atlantic crossing. She made the passage of 3,158 miles from Cherbourg Breakwater to the Ambrose Channel Lightship in 4 days 16 hours and 13 minutes at an average speed of 28.14 knots.

This evening it is the Federal Government, through the agency of the WPA, that looks with a nostalgic eye on old line melodrama. And, no sooner seen than done. At 8:45 or thereabouts the curtain of the Palm Garden, neighbor of the Theatre Guild on Fifty-second Street, will rise on a revival of "The Lights o' London," or George R. Simms's play of life in 1881.

An offer of $1,250,000 to stage a world's heavyweight championship bout between James Y. Braddock and Max Schmeling at Cleveland was received yesterday by Mike Jacobs, promoter of the Twentieth Century S.C.

MANCHESTER, N.H., June 22. -- The statement by former Governor Alfred E. Smith and four other Democrats was welcomed today by Colonel Frank Knox, Republican Vice Presidential nominee, as he arrived at his Manchester home for two weeks of rest preparatory to the start of his campaign.

LAKEHURST, N.J., June 22. -- The Hindenburg, world's largest and newest airship, set a new record for the western crossing of the North Atlantic by arriving at the Naval Air Station here at 4:43 A.M. (daylight time) today.
EXETER, N.H. June 22. -- Class day exercises were held here today as the final event before the commencement program tomorrow of Philips Exeter Academy, marking the school's 155th anniversary.

WASHINGTON, June 22. -- The Treasury announced tonight that a total of $281,318,000 had been offered in response to its requests for bids for two series of Treasury bills to be dated June 24 in an aggregate amount of about $100,000,000. Of the amount offered $100,058,000 was accepted.

PHILADELPHIA, June 22. -- The Democrats' century-old two-thirds rule for the nomination of President and Vice President will be abrogated by this convention, Senator Bennett Clark, who will be chairman of the rules committee, said today.
Vice President John N. Garner was among those who received honorary degrees of Doctor of Law yesterday from John Marshall College of Law in Jersey City.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The question of United States recognition of the Italian conquest of Ethiopia will be avoided when Fulvio Suvich, former Under-Secretary for Foreign Affairs, is officially received by President Roosevelt as the Ambassador of Italy in succession to Augusto Rosso, who is being transferred to Moscow.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., June 22. -- The last boats in the Eastern Yacht Club's 171-mile New London to Marblehead race finished early this morning after a rough night of beating across Massachusetts Bay in the teeth of a strong northwester, so that at daybreak all eighteen competitors were accounted for.
ATLANTA, June 22. -- Governor Eugene Talmadge called upon Alfred E. Smith and other "take a walk Democrats" today to join him in his intraparty fight against President Roosevelt and the New Deal.
Nine men in their sixties, some of whom had not seen each other for fifty years, when they were boys at school, met at a dinner last night in a private suite at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Except for special movements in a few selected industrial loans, which were not indicative of the general market tone, trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange was strictly routine in character and devoid of any outstanding features.

BURLINGTON, Vt., June 22. -- "In the lifetime of those who graduate today there has been a repudiation of solemn promises on a scale never before known in the history of the world," Melvin M. Johnson, dean of the Boston University Law School, told the 219 graduates and 1,500 guests at the commencement exercises of the University of Vermont today.

NEWARK, N.J., June 22. -- Selection of the Newark Industrial Commission was turned over by Mayor Ellenstein today to the citizens' committee which aided in advancing the project. At a luncheon at the Down Town Club, the Mayor asked the committee to submit the names of the five members of the commission, and to decide on the terms to be served by each.

BOGOTA, Colombia, June 22. -- General Amadeo Rodriguez and an aide were arrested today after an exchange of shots with a judge and Secret Service men who sought to search the general's house in connection with the investigation of an alleged plot by Conservatives to overthrow the government during the proposed visit of President Alfonso Lopez to neighboring countries.

BOLTON LANDING, N. Y., June 22. -- An assertion that Governor Landon, if elected President, would not be able to balance the Federal budget or scrap regimentation policies of the New Deal was made before the New York State Bankers Association today by Dr. F. Cyril James, Professor of Finance of the Wharton School of Finance of the University of Pennsylvania.

LONDON, June 22. -- The Stock Exchange opened the new account today in a cheerful and confident mood. British Government issues advanced strongly all along the line. Industrials were firm on hopes that abandonment of sanctions would stimulate business activity.

RYE, N.Y., June 22. -- Tennis players from Choate School dominated the scene today as the fourth annual invitation tournament for Eastern private boarding schools got under way at the Manursing Island Club. With a field of 116 boys from twenty-six schools on hand, the first and second round matches brought out some excellent playing and indications again point to Choate having probably the strongest squad in the competition.

Again there is progress to report toward rapid transit unification, however distant that goal may still be. Messrs. SEABURY and BERLE have woven the city's Independent System, left somewhat to one side in earlier endeavors, closely into the new fabric. Their reasons uor so doing are convincing.

MADRID, June 22. -- The Madrid labor unions under pressure have at last agreed upon who will represent them in the mixed tribunals charged with arbitrating the various strikes now in progress. And today the tribunal got to work. It settled no strikes, but it is working.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 22. -- The red blood cells in the human body carry on their surfaces a total amount of electricity sufficient to keep a twenty-five watt lamp burning for five minutes, it was reported today to the American Physical Society, meeting at the University of Rochester.

The twenty-first convention of the Atlantic District of the Lutheran Synod of Missouri, Ohio and Other States opened yesterday afternoon at St. Mark's Lutheran Church, Bushwick Avenue and Jefferson Street, Brooklyn, for four days. More than 300 delegates were registered.

Former Governor Smith came back to New York yesterday following his appeal to the Democratic National Convention to reject Franklin D. Roosevelt as a candidate. He had nothing further to say and he would give no light upon his future course.
The School Art League of New York City awarded eighty-six medals and eleven scholarships to high school students of the city yesterday afternoon in the auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

The orders placed by dry goods wholesalers in the primary markets yesterday indicated that the week would be another active period of buying. All types of finished goods shared in the demand and advance orders comprised a larger portion of the business than at any time this year.

Making her first start since returning from England with the American Curtis Cup team, Miss Charlotte Glutting of Rock Spring yesterday teamed with Miss Louise Iselin of Piping Rock and carded an 83 to set the pace for a field of fifty-six pairs at the half-way mark of the first thirty-six-hole Scotch foursome championship of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association.

LONDON, June 22 (Canadian Press). -- Temporarily halted in its leadership drive last week, Kent scored a convincing seven-wicket two-day victory over Worcestershire in the English County Cricket competition today to retain top place.

WASHINGTON, June 22. -- A recommendation that definite periods of the day be set aside for the radio broadcasting of news was made to the Federal Communications Commission today by Elisha Hanson, general counsel of the American Newspaper Publishers Association.

PHILADELPHIA, June 22. -- Verbal pyrotechnics soared and sputtered in the feminine ranks today and further marred the picture of a Democratic love feast at Philadelphia. Mrs. Emma Guffey Miller, national committeewoman from Pennsylvania, touched off the forensics at the luncheon of the National League of Women Voters in behalf of its proposed plank for the merit system in civil service, by making a vigorous defense of the party against spoils system charges.

GOSPORT, England, June 22 (AP) -- A dazed and rather frightened young Royal Air Force pilot crawled out of the wreckage of his plane on a deck of the giant French liner Normandie today and told Captain Rene Pugnet.

CHICAGO, June 22. -- Frankie Crosetti, brilliant young member of the Yankees' Italo-American set, unfurled two startling and tremendous wild heaves today which had a far-reaching influence upon the opening clash between the McCarthymen and the White Sox.

TOPEKA, June 22. -- Governor Landon will deliver his speech of acceptance of the Republican nomination for the Presidency from the steps of the State House here on Thursday evening, July 23. In making the announcement today, Governor Landon fixed the time of the ceremonies at 8 P. M. (10 P. M. Eastern daylight time).

Mr. and Mrs. Morgan Wing Jr. gave a dinner last night in the Summer Garden of the Ambassador for Miss Katharine Sage Bolton and George Arrel Parson, who will be married next Tuesday in the Church of the Heavenly Rest. Other guests were the Misses Charmion Kineon, Julia Booth, Lorraine Cooper, Jane Holden, Frances Parson, Jean Parker and Andrea Dowd, all of whom will be bridesmaids at the wedding.

The Legislature of 1935 enacted Section 233 of the Real Property Law, which went into effect Sept. l, 1935, for the protection of tenants. It provides that money deposited on a contract for the rental of real property as security for performance of the contract shall belong to the person making such deposit and shall be a trust fund in the possession of the person with whom such deposit or advance shall be made.

The immediate future of the Marx brothers has been settled as definitely as anything can be settled that has to do with the Marx brothers. In addition to "A Day at the Races," which the trio will take on a tryout-tour at a reputed $15,000 a week, Irving Thalberg has scheduled them for an untitled musical by Kalmar and Ruby, and perhaps for another musical bought yesterday from Lew Lipton.

DOVER, N.J., June 22. -- Reginald Twilley, 39-year-old explosive engineer, who served with General Pershing on the Mexican border, committed suicide by shooting himself today in his home at Ledgewood, near here.

Uncertainty tinged with disappointment featured the reaction yesterday of manufacturers and retailers here to the signing of the Robinson-Patman Anti-Discrimination Bill by President Roosevelt at the week-end. There were reports that large-scale orders were being held up and while these could not be confirmed, it was feared in authoritative merchandising quarters that this tendency might be strong in the period directly ahead.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 22. -- "Great rowing" was the comment of Al Ulbrickson, varsity coach of the University of Washington, after seeing his three crews sweep the Hudson.

What does internal evidence say about the authorship of the anti-Roosevelt manifesto signed by AL SMITH et al? It is in parts a roughly written document. For instance, there is the expression "You must take the heavy hand of Government off of business."

An immediate trial before a referee of the suit by the B.F. Goodrich Rubber Company to establish the validity of the vote of its stockholders to mortgage its property for $45,000,000 as security for bonds of that amount was applied for yesterday by the rubber company. The plea will be heard today by Justice Church.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., June 22 (AP). -- Long shots again had their innings today at Agawam Park, although favorites also delivered.

HOYLAKE, England, June 22. -- An electrical storm struck Hoylake and Wallasey today, unleashed one bolt of lightning that stunned three spectators and a caddy and washed out forty cards in the qualifying round of the British open golf championship, including a record breaking 67 by Henry Cotton, 1934 champion.

PHILADELPHIA, June 22. -- This city of brotherly love took on the atmosphere of a circus lot today as the extras for the mob scenes in James A. (Phineas T.) Farley's extravaganza entitled "Renominating a President," or "The Triumph of Strength," began pouring into town for tomorrow's revival of a show which is as well rehearsed as "Abie's Irish Rose" after its 2,000th performance.

PHILADELPHIA, June 22. -- The first discordant note in the Democratic National Convention was struck today when the Minnesota delegation, headed by Joseph N. Moonan, State chairman, and Representative Elmer R. Ryan, refused to accept the decision of the national committee to seat both this delegation and the contesting group, headed by Joseph Wolf, national committeeman, with a divided vote.

CHICAGO, June 22. -- Two youngsters from Yale University, Paul Jamison and Herbert Eshelman, shot the Blue into the lead for the national intercollegiate golf team championship today, as they shared first day scoring honors with Fred Haas Jr. of Louisiana State and Lynford Lardner of Harvard with 75s over the North Shore course.
VAN HORNESVILLE, N.Y., June 22. -- The candidacy of Attorney General Bennett for the Democratic Gubernatorial nomination received a boost today from Owen D. Young.

Two hundred and fifty canvas bags, each containing 250 gold double eagles, with a total face value of $1,250,000 and worth about $2,100,000 in devalued dollars, were seized yesterday by Federal Secret Service agents in a safe-deposit vault at 25 Broad Street and transferred to the United States Assay Office.

With an unusually large budget of fiscal, political and trade news appearing over the week-end, followers of the share market had much to contemplate yesterday. But the point that received probably the closest attention was the enactment of the Revenue Act of 1936 which embodies the untried theory of forcing greater distribution of corporate earnings.

Shipping operators studied the newly enacted Shipping Act yesterday, debating the value of its provisions and attempting to determine its potential effect upon the industry. General agreement prevailed only in the opinion that success of the legislation would depend upon the caliber of the men to be named to the Maritime Authority that will be created to administer it.

LAST week it was Vincent Sheean and the Neapolition revolution of 1799. Today it is the French revolution of 1848, in Sylvia Townsend Warner's "Summer Will Show" (Viking, $2.50). The common topic of social unrest has many points in its favor. It happens to be about the only historical subject that can be offered to a modern audience without apology.

A quiet foreign exchange market yesterday was featured by further improvement in the gold-bloc currencies. The franc continued the rally that started on last Friday when the new Popular Front Government of France announced the measures to be taken in defense of the currnecy against devaluation.
JERUSALEM, June 22 (AP). -- Soldiers and police, searching for fugitives from a Sunday battle, killed five Arab train snipers and blasted a cave to capture two accused slayers today.

Support of the United Palestine Appeal to raise $3,500,000 for the settlement in Palestine of a maximum number of persecuted Jews in Germany, Poland and other countries was urged last night at a dinner to Carl Laemmle, veteran film producer, in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 22. -- Only five years ago William Fox was worth "millions and millions and millions of dollars" in assets, was still at the height of his motion-picture-producing career -- and last month he had to borrow $100.

Judge JOHN BARTON PAYNE will not be forgotten so long as the American Red Cross remembers. He had a distinguished career in the practice of law and in public service, but it was crowned by years of voluntary service as chairman of this greatest agency of mercy, and under five Presidents of the United States.

MONTREUX, Switzerland, June 22. -- The Dardanelles conference opened today with Turkey proposing virtually to abolish the 1923 Straits Convention and being warmly praised by every signatory present except Japan -- discreetly silent thereon -- for having asked consent of the League of Nations for refortifying.

Two "mystery fish" lay in the fish box when the converted trawler Babe eased up to the dock of the Forked River Tuna Club at Forked River, N.J., the other day, marking the end of an exciting trip to the Gulf Stream, 140 miles off shore, for a group of intrepid deep-sea anglers.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., June 22. -- Miss Martha Phyllis Whitney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Whitney of 120 East Eightieth Street, New York, and this village, was" introduced to society tonight at a sUppEr dance given at Home Acres, the Whitney home, by her parents.

MONTREUX, June 22. -- Issues likely to have a profound effect on the future of Europe came up today at the opening of the international conference to discuss Turkey's request that she be allowed to refortify her Straits.
On the Giant bench yesterday before the Terrymen went into battle with the Pirates, Travis Jackson was asked facetiously, "How is the home-run king?"

CHICAGO, June 22. -- Three promises in the farm plank of the Republican platform were held to be "as impossible as jumping to the moon" by Secretary Wallace in a letter today to Burridge D. Butler, publisher of The Prairie Farmer.

PHILADELPHIA, June 22. -- Former Governor Alfred E. Smith and the four Democratic insurgents associated with him as signatories to yesterday's message calling upon the Democratic National Convention to reject President Roosevelt as a candidate for re-election, together with his platform, will receive their answer from Democrats loyal to the administration at a Bryan memorial breakfast to be given Wednesday morning.
The Bronx building crash took its seventeenth victim yesterday when Carrado Vialonga, 54 years old, of 876 Kinsella Street, the Bronx, died in Fordham Hospital.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., June 22. -- The progress made and the difficulties encountered in coordinating, as between white and Negro students and institutions, educational work in the South was reviewed at today's session of the Institute on Regional Development at the University of North Carolina.

Ship lines operating in the New York-South African trade were notified yesterday that a Senatorial investigation of the trade had been ordered during the closing hours of the last session of Congress.
WASHINGTON, June 22. -- By a stipulated agreement before the Board of Tax Appeals it was held today that no income tax deficiency would be assessed against the Western Power Corporation of New York.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

PHILADELPHIA, June 22 (AP). -- Al Ettore stopped LeRoy Haynes's string of seven successive knockouts tonight, outpointing his city heavyweight rival in fifteen rounds before 17,000 fans at the Phillies' ball park. The blond boxer weighed 187 pounds and Haynes 193.

Passenger revenues increased substantially in the first four months of the year, according to reports by 144 Class 1 railroads to the Interstate Commerce Commission. The recent cuts in passenger fares did not take effect until June 2.

WASHINGTON, June 22. -- The Seversky Aircraft Corporation of Farmingdale, L.I., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 840,000 shares of $1-par-value common stock.

OTTAWA, June 22. -- Action of the Canadian Supreme Court last week in declaring unconstitutional the Unemployment Insurance Act and the Natural Products Marketing Act and dividing evenly, three to three, on several Federal labor laws does not finally decide the fate of the "reform program" enacted by the recent conservative administration, led by R.B. Bennett.

Price movements in the commodity futures markets yesterday were mixed. Trading was active. Sugar, wool tops, cocoa, metals and hides declined. While coffee, cottonseed oil, silk and rubber advanced. On the cash markets cotton and rye sold at new high prices and wheat, flour, hides, rubber, silk and tins advanced.

MARION, Mass., June 22. -- More than 100 aspiring youngsters from twenty-three preparatory institutions between Virginia and Massachusetts gathered today for the seventh interscholastic yacht championship, and two-thirds of them sailed four races, sixteen schools being represented in two contests in Buzzards Bay for the Clifford D. Mallory Trophy and ten in a couple of harbor races in small craft for silver bowls.

Michael Woods of 2,022 Benedict Avenue, the Bronx, and David Patterson of 2,191 Eighth Avenue received prison sentences of eighteen months each when they were convicted yesterday by a jury in Federal court of defrauding the government by interfering with the functions of the Works Progress Administration.

Haro1d W. Hastings, Assistant District Attorney, asked the State Department in Washington yesterday to obtain permission from Austria to try Ivan Poderjay, husband of the missing Agnes C. Tufverson Poderjay, corporation lawyer, on a perjury indictment.
PARIS, June 22 (AP). -- Red flags flew over ships in Marseilles Harbor today when sailors struck. Rightists clashed with the police and Leftists here for the third successive day.
CLEVELAND, June 22 (AP). -- George Puccinelli's eighth-inning double scored Lou Finney and gave the Athletics a 4-3 triumph over the Indians in the series opener today.

Passenger revenues increased substantially in the first four months of the year, according to reports by 144 Class 1 railroads to the Interstate Commerce Commission. The recent cuts in passenger fares did not take effect until June 2.

The Democratic National Convention at Philadelphia will be broadcast coast-to-coast by a hook-up of more than 200 transmitters beginning at noon today when music and preliminary previews by commentators go on the air. The "grand opening" is scheduled for 1 o'clock, Eastern daylight time, when Chairman Farley raps for order.

Police lieutenants paraded into Brooklyn Police Headquarters last night to identify Louis Randall, accused of having employed a forged deed 128 times since the first of the year to bail prisoners in Brooklyn station houses.

Play in the annual junior and boys' Long Island center championships got off to a good start on the courts of the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills yesterday, with sixty-four entrants seeing action in the junior division and forty-one competing in the younger group.

Walter Fairchild, attorney for 217 home owners in the Sunnyside Gardens community of Queens, announced yesterday he had been served with notice by attorneys for the incorporators of the City Housing Corporation that the incorporators would ask the Appellate Division to dismiss the home owners' suit for fraud.

LEXINGTON, Ky., June 22 (AP). -- The 2:05 trot, in which Guy Scotland, bred, owned and trained by Will C. Moore, scored an impressive victory, marked the opening of the six-day Spring meet of the Kentucky Trotting Horse Breeders' Association today.

BOSTON, June 22. -- In as thrilling a race as has been run at the Suffolk Downs meeting, Percy M. Pike's Ebony Lady, black daughter of Flying Ebony, scored a brilliant neck victory over Miss Careful today.
Offering is being made today of $32,121,955 Chicago Park District 3 1/2 per cent and 4 per cent bonds by a group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc.

A banking syndicate headed by Dillon, Read Co. submitted yesterday the highest bid for a new issue of $15,000,000 of 3 1/4 per cent first mortgage bonds, due July 1, 1966, of the Potomac Electric Power Company, offering 103,027. Public offering of the bonds is expected to be made on Thursday, following the filing of an amendment to the original registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Following an early reaction, prices on the Cotton Exchange moved upward sharply $1 a bale yesterday to end with net gains of 5 to 9 points. Closing prices were the highest of the season. The setback in the first half hour dropped quotations 10 points before the market developed any resistance.

Walter M. Jeffords's Regal Lily, a 2-year-old daughter of Man o'War and Regal Lady, showed her fleet heels to four other juveniles to capture the Artvis Purse at five furlongs, feature at Aqueduct yesterday. Leading all the way, she won by a length from Joseph E. Widener's Handle Cross, while Miquelon, one of the entry from the Sanford Stud Farms, was third.

An appraisal yesterday of the estate of Mrs. Anna Blaksley Bliss of 525 Fifth Avenue, who died at her Winter home in Santa Barbara, Calif., on Feb. 22, disclosed that she left $13,077,313 gross and $12,386,055 net. Mrs. Bliss was the widow of William H. Bliss, patent attorney.

Charles C. Burlingham's exposition in THE TIMES of June 15 of the conflict of courts and Legislatures in respect to minimum wage laws, and especially the New York Minimum Wage Law for women, illuminates that conflict for readers but is silent in respect to the fundamental question of the constitutionality of minimum wage laws in general. Indeed, Mr. Burlingham seems to imply an unqualified endorsement of them as a valuable contribution to current social legislation.

Four young men accused of crimes punishable by death, which were committed in connection with the robbery on March 20 of the Nanuet National Bank in Rockland County, went on trial yesterday in Federal court on the first indictment returned in this district under the Banking Law of 1933.

Two of the playgrounds planned by Park Commissioner Robert Moses to meet the city's needs were eliminated yesterday when Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins handed down a decision restraining the commissioner from completing the playgrounds in Stuyvesant Park.

DETROIT, June 22 (AP). -- Biography, which was entered with 102 pounds to pace his stablemate, Woodlander, kept on sprinting in the mile and a sixteenth handicap feature at the Fair Grounds today and finished four lengths in front of Arson to equal the track record of 1:44.

Members of the New York Stock and the New York Curb Exchanges pondered yesterday the probable effects upon their businesses of the segregation of broker-dealer functions proposed to Congress on Saturday by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Political circles are buzzing with the question which of the two main parties stands to gain or lose by the placing of the Lemke-O'Brien ticket in the field. It can probably be organized successfully in only a few of the States, and its campaigning through the Summer can hardly be well financed or sustained.

An effort will doubtless be made at Philadelphia to abrogate the two-thirds rule which has governed Democratic nominations for so many years, and present evidence indicates that it will be successful. Several of the State delegations have already caucused on the question and decided to advocate repeal.

LONDON, June 22. -- The British Government made it clear today that its abandonment of sanctions would not mean formal recognition of Italy's conquests in Africa or financial assistance to Italy at present.

Officials and attorneys of the New York Stock and the New York Curb Exchanges awaited yesterday the first move by the Securities and Exchange Commission to put into effect the program of segregation of broker-dealer functions which it presented to Congress before its adjournment on Saturday.

The passage of the Ship Subsidy Bill last week once more brings to the fore the insidious potency of a well-organized and heavily financed lobby. Can it be that the taxpayers are not aware that in supporting ship subsidies they are endorsing America's most lucrative racket, and that they, themselves, are the victims?

PHILADELPHIA, June 22. -- Leaders and delegates, on the ground for the Democratic convention, dismissed today as an empty threat the message of former Governor Smith of New York and his co signers calling on the convention to repudiate President Roosevelt. Postmaster General Farley was terse in his comment.

PARIS, June 22. -- Demonstrators rioted today in protest against the government's dissolving of the organized forces of the Nationalist League. At the Saint Lazare railway station at 2 P.M. and at 6 P.M. there were clashes between youthful partisans of the patriotic leagues and the Popular Front.

CHICAGO, June 22 (AP). -- Paul Gulbord of Dartmouth, seeded No. 4 and considered a strong contender for the individual title, was eliminated from the singles competition as the national intercollegiate tennis championships opened at Northwestern University today.

PHILADELPHIA, June. 22. -- Standing tonight near the Liberty Bell, Governor Earle of Pennsylvania characterized the nation's founders as "bold experimenters in the field of government" and asserted that the country perpetuated "a most important" tradition "when we go forward with new measures and new policies to meet new conditions.''

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., June 22 (AP). -- Gradual mechanization of the army and steady building up of personnel and equipment is the aim of the War Department, General Malin Craig, chief of staff, said in an address today at the national convention of the Reserve Officers Association of the United States.

Concerted efforts to induce Governor LEHMAN to change his decision not to be a candidate in November seem to be gathering strength every day. Some of them are nonpartisan, coming as they do from persons long interested in social reform. They express the belief that another term for the Governor would see their common program brought nearer to achievement.
A campaign to broaden the scope and increase the membership of the Air Defense League will be opened tomorrow night at a dinner at the Hotel Gotham.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., June 22. -- Washington won all three races on the Hudson River today in the thirty-eighth regatta of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association. There can be no higher tribute paid the youngsters from the Pacific Northwest than that simple statement of fact.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 22. -- With a wandering breeze under clouds that seemed in a passive mood of sparkling sunshine, forty-three yachts started this afternoon from the Guardian Lightship off here for St. David's Head, Bermuda.

WASHINGTON, June 22. -- An accumulation of bonus bonds sent through banks for redemption has so snarled the routine of the Treasury Department that it may be weeks before those veterans who thus sought redemption will receive checks in return for the bonds they deposited.

The American Association of Advertising Agencies released yesterday Section A of the fifth volume of Market and Newspaper Statistics. In form similar to preceding volumes, it deals with the fifty-six cities in the United States and Canada with more than 100,000 population for which ABC audit reports were issued for periods ended Sept. 30 and Dec. 31, 1935.
The following is the text of the address by John D.M. Hamilton, Republican National Chairman, delivered last night at the Hotel Astor:

" His Majesty's Government has no "intention at the forthcoming meeting "of the League of proposing or assent- "ing to the recognition of Italy's an- "nexation of Ethiopia." It would be rash to assume that this reply of ANTHONY EDEN to a question in the House of Commons yesterday means that Great Britain has determined to ask for the application to Ethiopia of the so-called Stimson Doctrine of non-recognition as that was applied to Manchukuo.

PHILADELPHIA, June 22. -- Outwardly, today, the New Deal status quo was triumphantly maintained. Mr. Farley, Mr. Michelson and the other militant Democratic mouthpieces fervently asserted that President Roosevelt next November will carry each of the forty-eight States, all our territorial possessions, British Columbia, part of Alberta, Albania and the Windward Isles, with an excellent chance in Australia and Finland.

LONDON, June 23. -- Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin tonight spoke more hopefully than ever before of the prospect for negotiations between France, Germany and Britain in a few weeks to organize security for Europe on a new basis.

John D.M. Hamilton, Republican national chairman, declared yesterday that he would be "tickled to death" if Alfred E. Smith would take the stump to express his views about the current Presidential campaign.

An appraisal of the Democrats as "a powerful host" in the coming campaign, coupled with a warning catalogue of "serious and perhaps dangerous problems of strategy," will appear in the forthcoming issue of Today by Raymond Moley, editor, former member of the Roosevelt "Brain Trust."

Advance orders were delayed in several wholesale markets here yesterday as retailers and manufacturers tried to clear up the uncertainty created in merchandising circles by the Patman Anti-Discrimination Law.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 23. -- Broad-shouldered Alick Gerard Jr., representing Peddle, showed the way to ninety-odd rivals in the thirteenth annual Eastern interscholastic golf championship today by going around the Greenwich Country Club course in 74 strokes, four over par.

PHILADELPHIA, June 23. -- Seymour Weiss, one of Huey P. Long's closest friends, arrived today at the head of Louisiana's delegation of twenty with the declaration that he was ready to "go down the line" for President Roosevelt and the New Deal which the assassinated Senator so bitterly assailed.

Marsden J. Perry, banker, art patron and public utility operator, who owned one of the largest Shakespearean collections in the country, left an estate appraised yesterday at $2,008,148 gross and $1,523,854 net. Mr. Perry died at his home, 755 Park Avenue, on last April 15. His securities were found to be worth $1,959,978, the largest holding being the stock of the Walpole company, a family investment company, valued at $1,959,750.

Senator Hastings in his radio speech Sunday called for a bipartisan investigation of the Democratic campaign funds. He has proofs of corrupt practices! The Democratic money-bags are being filled by illegal subscription methods!

BERLIN, June 23. -- A German official delegation that will confer with United States Treasury officials over the situation created by the American announcement of countervailing duties on imports from Germany sailed from Bremen today on its way to Washington.
PHILADELPHIA, June 23. -- The Rev. Dr. J. Gresham Machen, fundamentalist leader of this city, was formally suspended today as a minister of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 23 (AP). -- Apparently having regained her form after her lapse in the Wightman Cup matches, Miss Helen Jacobs, four times American champion, made short work of Miss M. Cable. Likewise did Miss Dorothy Round play at her peak in disposing of the formidable Miss Betty Nuthall.

The turnover of bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange was slightly larger than on the preceding day and many of the pivotal speculative issues were subjected to selling pressure and yielded ground easily. This trend was apparent particularly among the secondary rail liens.
Veal Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

Here is one Democrat who wrote to Governor Smith yesterday before the statement appeared to tell him that she was ready to accompany him "where'er he walked," and today I am of the same opinion, although I might not be willing to subscribe to all of the tenets of that platform: and I might also wish that the names of some of the signers of that document might be missing.

The first refunding operation by the Niagara Hudson Power System will take place today with the public offering of a new issue of $32,493,000 of 3 1/2 per cent first and refunding mortgage bonds, due on March 1, 1966, of the Niagara Falls Power Company, by a banking syndicate headed by Morgan Stanley Co., Inc.

Front running seeded players continued to hold sway and no serious upsets were in order as competition in the annual junior and boys' Long Island Center singles championships tournament reached the quarterfinals at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills yesterday.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., June 23 (AP). -- The Earle (Ark.) Enterprise said today that whipping "has produced results" in eliminating cotton labor agitation where other methods failed, and that "there is no sharecroppers' strike in Earle."

PHILADELPHIA, June 23. -- By a narrow squeak, Democratic women managed to maintain their strategic advantage today over the Republican sorority by achieving two representatives on the committee to frame the party platform. Only one woman attained such a post at Cleveland.
The Federal Labor Bureau's general index of manufacturing employment in May compares with preceding months and years as follows, with the three-year average of 1923-25 taken as 100:
Max Schmeling, conqueror of Joe Louis and now the No. 1 challenger for the heavyweight title, left New York yesterday to board the Hindenburg at Lakehurst, N.J., bound for Germany.
NANKING, June 23 (AP). -- The American magazine Asia was barred from circulating in China today by the Foreign Office.
PARIS, June 23. -- In its premier declaration of foreign policy the Leftist Cabinet of Leon Blum proposed today:

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., June 23 (AP). -- Governor Lehman renewed today his criticism of the Legislature for failure to pass his social security program, telling the State Conference of Health Officers and Public Health Nurses in a message that, as a result, it would be "difficult, if not impossible," to carry out the State Health Department's plans for "the training of personnel in our larger cities."

Bronx building plans, which during the last two weeks have been filed in extraordinary numbers, yesterday reached a new record high for the period. Plans for twenty-nine new six-story apartment structures, to cost a total of $6,675,000, were submitted to the borough's Building Department.

PHILADELPHIA, June 23. -- Senator Alben W. Barkley in his keynote speech to the Democratic National Convention tonight omitted considerable of the text which had been issued to the press in advance in order to keep within his radio time and deviated from the advance text at some points. Following is a stenographic report of his address, as delivered:

The action of Surrogate Delehanty in refusing probate to the second codicil of the will of Edward W. Browning, real estate operator, was reversed yesterday by the Appellate Division in an opinion in which the court criticized the surrogate for the manner in which he conducted the hearing into the execution of the codicil, which disposed of $300,000.

OTTAWA, June 23. -- Sir Herbert Marler, now Canadian Minister to Japan, has been appointed Minister to the United States by Prime Minister Mackenzie King and will take the Washington post in the Fall. It has been vacant since the resignation of W.D. Herridge in October.

Residents of the Bronx and Mount Vernon went to the polls yesterday to vote in a referendum to decide whether or not to redraw the boundary line that has separated the two communities in such a manner as to cause some houses to be set half in Mount Vernon and half in the Bronx.

The Rutland Railroad, which is controlled jointly by the New York Central and the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroads, will pay $185,000 interest due in July, it was said after a meeting yesterday of Rutland officials and representatives of insurance companies and savings banks which hold the company's bonds.

STAMFORD, Conn., June 23. -- Gutzon Borglum, the sculptor, today offered a reward of $500 for information leading to the arrest and conviction of persons who stole valuable objects and destroyed property valued at several thousand dollars at his Summer home at Turnof River.

DALLAS, Texas, June 23. -- Taxes on gross receipts of retail merchants were criticized here today by Harry Walker of Maryland in an address before the thirty-ninth annual convention of the National Association of Retail Grocers.
MUNICIPAL AUDITORIUM, Philadelphia, June 23. -- The prayer opening the night session of the Democratic Convention tonight given by Francis R. Taylor of the Society of Friends, was as follows:
WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP). -- Representative Marion A. Zioncheck was taken tonight to a private hospital specializing in mental cases at Towson, Md., for an indefinite period of treatment.

Municipal Court Justice Leopold Prince conducted his City Amateur Symphony Orchestra last night in the first of a series of concerts on the Mall in Central Park. Despite the uncertain weather, an audience of 7,500 persons, as well as Mayor La Guardia, the official sponsor of the concerts, enthusiastically applauded the program.

TOPEKA, June 23. -- Governor Landon today began clearing his desk of accumulated State and campaign business in preparation for the vacation trip which he will start tomorrow evening. He and his family, the newspaper reporters and photographers will leave on three special cars, attached to a Union Pacific train, at 6:58 tomorrow night, to arrive in Denver at 7:30 the following morning.

Workmen began yesterday the job of preparing the site in the rear of the Collegiate Church of St. Nicholas for a thirty-four-story office building which will be the eleventh unit in Rockefeller Center.
Commencement exercises for 769 students of Hunter College will be held at 10:30 A.M. today at Carnegie Hall, where Channing Pollock, author and playwright, will deliver the baccalaureate oration.

The graduating class of Public School 95, Ninetieth Avenue and 179th Street, Jamaica, presented a parchment scroll yesterday to Patrolman George J. Doherty of the Jamaica precinct in recognition of his bravery in stopping a runaway horse that endangered the lives of pupils of the school.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 23. -- While America's leading men doubles players were slashing their way to victory today, two of their foremost women compatriots and one lesser star in the singles of the All-England tennis championships were tasting defeat that was as surprising as it was complete.

JERUSALEM, June 23. -- A passenger on a Jewish-owned bus was killed and three others were wounded today by rifle fire of Arabs near the Jewish colony of Rosh Pinah as the Arab anti-Jewish campaign continued.

WASHINGTON, June 23. -- A plea that radio amateurs be permitted to partake in the development of television was made to the Federal Communications Commission today by Philo T. Farnsworth, vice president of Farnsworth Television, Inc.
PHILADELPHIA, June 23. -- The text of the address by Chairman Farley in opening the Democratic National Convention today was as follows:

Fascinating business, this offshore fishing. It's not only the prospect of tying into a finny torpedo that takes men twenty or thirty miles to sea. There is always the chance of encountering some strange and rare inhabitant of the mysterious world beneath the waves.

PORTSMOUTH, Ohio, June 23 (AP). -- Strike battle bullets killed a guard and wounded four other men today in a clash between strikers and company guards at the closed Wheeling Steel Corporation plant in near-by New Boston.

Turkey, apparently, is about to secure the consent of the interested Powers to free itself from the only remaining restriction on its sovereignty. The international conference which opened this week in Montreux welcomed the Turkish proposal for drastic revision of the Straits Convention of 1923, so as to re-establish complete Turkish control over the Straits of the Dardanelles and the Bosporus.

PARIS, June 23. -- The bills by which Premier Leon Blum's Cabinet proposes to revise the statutes of the Bank of France and to repress speculation that might result from the measures taken were distributed in Parliament today.

The Federal Theatre Project of the WPA last evening pointed over its shoulder at the horse-and-buggy drama. Call it a revival of the George R. Sims play, "The Lights o' London," and say that at the palm Garden you can also buy beer.For the Project, having tried everything from a living newspaper to the poetic drama, has now taken a leaf from Hoboken's palmy days and is having a fine time waving it.

CHICAGO, June 23. -- John McKinlay, president of Marshall Field Co. for the last six years, has turned in his resignation to the directors, the company announced tonight. His successor has not been named, but the selection is expected to come before directors at their next meeting on June 29.

The winning streak of the Giants attained the respectable proportions of four straight yesterday as the Terrymen crept within half a game of third place in the National League at the expense of the Pirates.

PHILADELPHIA, June 23. -- William Lemke, Union party candidate for President, was told today by John H. Landberg, attorney for the Farmers Unions in Pensylvania that he would not be able to run under that party name in Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, June 23. -- New York State asked today from the Supreme Court a rehearing on the five-to-four decision of three weeks ago whereby the court held that the New York State Minimum Wage Law was unconstitutional.

By a vote of three to two, the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court reversed yesterday the order of Supreme Court Justice Louis A. Valente disapproving the bid of the Commercial Investment Trust Corporation for 100 per cent of the stock of the National Surety Corporation, found to be the highest bid, and authorizing Louis H. Pink, the State Superintendent of Insurance to sell 70 per cent of the stock to the Bancamerica-Blair Corporation.

NANKING, China, June 23. -- The Chinese Government has received confirmation of a report that Japan has concluded an agreement for a large loan to the rebellious South China Province of Kwangsi, an official said tonight.

The highest weekly registration of buyers during the last two months was reached during the week ended yesterday. This high total was also well above the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES. For the week 834 arrivals were reported, the highest since the week of April 22, when 1,1017 were registered.

HOYLAKE, England, June 23 (AP). -- Henry Cotton, the tall, 29-year-old British pro of a Brussels club and winner of the title in 1934, fired his second record-breaking round in as many days as the field of 286, including seven Americans headed by Gene Sarazen, completed the first eighteen holes of the thirty-six-hole qualifying round today in the British open golf championship.

PHILADELPHIA, June 23. -- Following is the prayer made by the Most Rev. Hugh L. Lamb, Auxiliary Bishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Philadelphia, at the opening of the Democratic National Convention here.

With the support of a majority of stockholders, Irving T. Bush, president and founder of the Bush Terminal Company, and a group of associates were re-elected or elected to the board at the annual meeting yesterday. Opposition manifested for a time quickly disappeared when proxies were called for.

Bidu Sayao, Brazilian soprano, and Vina Bovy, European singer, have been engaged to appear at the Metropolitan Opera House during the international season next Winter, it was learned yesterday. Anna Kaskas, who sang with the company during the Spring season, has also received a contract for the main fourteen-week term.

The New York School of Industrial Art, 257 West Fortieth Street, which was started in 1932 as a Board of Education WPA project, held a fashion show yesterday afternoon. There were about 100 models, students at the school, and most of them wore costumes they had designed and made themselves.
Rabbi Eichler gives the following "Ten Commandments of Patriotism":

Colonial expansion, the aim of Germany and Italy, offers no hope for the solution of economic problems pressing those two "hungry" nations, Baron Stefan Ropp, managing director of the International Poznan Fair in Poland, asserted yesterday as a guest speaker at a luncheon meeting of the Export Managers Club of New York in the Hotel Pennsylvania.
LONDON, June 23. -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden visited Haile Selassie today at the Ethiopian Emperor's express wish, spending three-quarters of an hour with him.

RYE, N.Y., June 23. -- Kent and Groton schools came into the spotlight today to threaten Choate's three-year dynasty in the fourth annual invitation tournament for eastern boarding schools at the Manursing Island Club.

WASHINGTON, June 23. -- James A. Reed, former Senator, who joined with Alfred E. Smith and others in threatening to bolt the Democratic party, was criticized today by David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies' Garment Workers Union, as a foe of unionism and an aggressive opponent of minimum wages created under the NRA codes.
The Authors Club lost yesterday its plea to the Appellate Division for permission to use $250,000, given by Andrew Carnegie for special purposes, to meet the general expenses of the club.

PHILADELPHIA, June 23. -- Cascades and torrents of exultant oratory which approached the proportions of Noah's deluge flowed today and tonight from spokesmen of the Democratic party as its national convention assembled in the cradle of liberty.

MUNICIPAL AUDITORIUM, Philadelphia, June 23. -- With Postmaster General James A. Farley defining the paramount issue of the campaign as continuance of the New Deal, the Democratic National Convention opened today with a blare of bands, the first waves of what will be a flood of oratory, and a thirty-minute demonstration for President Roosevelt at the end of Mr. Farley's speech.

In reporting a reduction in the company's annual net loss, Charles J. Hardy, president of the American Car and Foundry Company, predicted yesterday a resumption of sustained demand for railway equipment.

CHICAGO, June 23. -- Fred Haas Jr., tall, slender youngster from Louisiana State, batted out a notable 71, a stroke better than par for the long, trap-ridden North Shore course today to win the thirty-six-hole qualifying medal in the thirty-eighth annual national intercollegiate golf championship with a 146 total.
Resale of a group of Jersey City flats featured the New Jersey realty conveyances reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 23. -- For the first time since January, the United States merchandise exports in May exceeded its imports, a Department of Commerce survey revealed today. Moreover, May was the fifth consecutive month to show a larger foreign trade than in the corresponding month of 1935.

WASHINGTON, June 23. -- President Roosevelt revealed today the appointment of a three-man commission which will visit eight, and possibly nine, European countries this Summer to study plans for developing cooperatives in the United States in the fields of marketing, housing, credit, electrical distribution, insurance and banking.

Endorsing the campaign of the Children's Welfare Federation to raise more than $1,000,000 to send 110,000 needy children to Summer camps, Mayor La Guardia issued a proclamation yesterday making this week "Send a Child to Camp Week."

At last the Massachusetts Republicans have begun to profit by the lessons of adversity. In the days of easy victory they forgot the racial changes in the population that time was bringing. It would probably be wrong to attribute to prejudice this neglect of a multitude of voters of the most vigorous and fertile strains.

The complaint in the $6,000,000 suit brought by the trustees appointed to reorganize Series Q of the defaulted guaranteed mortgage certificates against the president and directors of the Manhattan Company was dismissed by the Appellate Division yesterday.
LONDON, June 23. -- American subsidized shipping was a subject that the House of Lords viewed with alarm for the whole afternoon today.

The Ship Subsidy Bill passed by Congress and now awaiting the signature of the President provides for the creation of a Maritime Commission. Each of five members will receive a salary of $12,000 per annum. When this bill becomes law, supervision of the entire shipping industry will be centralized in this specialized bureau especially designed to foster and develop the American merchant marine.

PARIS, June 23. -- A foreign policy of active, incessant striving for peace by armaments reduction beginning with nationalization of the arms industry in France, by consolidation of collective security and by a strengthening of existing friendships among the democratic nations of the world was announced by the French Government today.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 23. -- Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius N. Bliss gave a supper dance tonight at their farm in the Wheatley Hills in honor of Miss Elizabeth Harriman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. E. Roland Harriman of 10 East Sixty-eighth Street, New York, and Miss Marne Lloyd-Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wilton Lloyd-Smith of Cold Spring Harbor.

The folk-dances and folk-costumes that now and then enliven and adorn Central Park, which is in its own beauty more attractive than it has been for years, keep us mindful of FRANKLIN K. LANE'S glorious catalogue of the gifts which the migrants from the Old World have brought to the making of America:

CHICAGO, June 23. -- Larger supplies of hogs, receipts of 17,000 head being the largest for a Tuesday in four weeks, proved somewhat in excess of trade demands and prices were lowered 5 to 10 cents a hundredweight to effect sales, although a few brought what appeared to be about steady with Monday.

WASHINGTON, June 23. -- A truce was arranged today between O.P. Van Sweringen and the Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce. The railroad operator signed and handed to Chairman Wheeler a draft of a plan by which his interests would cooperate hereafter with the committee in its investigation of railroad reorganizations.

Veterans who certified their bonus bonds through city postoffices six or seven days ago and have not yet received their checks should get in touch with postoffice authorities, they were advised yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 23. -- American owners of motor cars bought more than 16,000,000,000 gallons of gasoline in 1935 and in doing so paid in taxes to the States more than $619,000,000.

Federal Judge William Bondy granted to the Russell Brothers Towing Company, Inc., an order requiring the International Longshoremen's Association and the Harbor Tow Boatmen's Union, Local 933-3, to show cause why they should not be restrained from interfering with the towing company's coal-carrying business.

WASHINGTON, June 23. -- Endorsement of the Presidential candidacy of Representative William Lemke of North Dakota was temporarily withheld today by Dr. Francis E. Townsend on behalf of his old-age pension movement, and by Rev. Gerald K. Smith, representing the "share-the-wealth" clubs organized by the late Senator Huey P. Long.

MONTREUX, Switzerland, June 23. -- The Dardanelles conference began today in private its serious bargaining on the draft convention Turkey proposes. A main line of friendly cleavage developed that seems likely to characterize the conference.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 23. -- Masterful stroking and effective defensive play carried the Aknusti poloists to an 8-to-5 victory over Stephen (Laddie) Sanford's Hurricanes today in the final of the third Westbury Challenge Cup tourney on Cochran Field at the Meadowbrook Club.

I note in your paper this morning the demand the self-styled Democrats are making on the delegates in the Democratic convention. They seem to think their own narrow views entitle them alone to be called true Democrats. Why, the Republican party was full of them, and still is pretty well loaded with men who have similar reactionary views.

PHILADELPHIA, June 23. -- Platform declarations for production control in agriculture, a foreign policy based on reciprocal trade agreements and the "good neighbor" policy, a balanced budget when feasible and continuation of the managed currency idea were agreed on here today on the eve of the meeting of the resolutions committee of the Democratic National Convention.

The will of Bruno Richard Hauptmann was filed late Monday afternoon in the Surrogate's Court in the Bronx, it became known yesterday. The estate, according to the petition for probate, amounts to less than $1,000, all of which was left to Mrs. Anna Hauptmann.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., June 23. -- An exhibition of miniature paintings by members of the American Society of Miniature Painters has opened in the Marjorie Woodhouse Galleries at Guild Hall, to continue for three weeks.

WEST POINT, June 23. -- With all seeded players except two remaining in the singles matches of the all-Army tennis championships, tomorrow will see the start of the doubles and the second round of the consolation singles. The second round of the championship singles has been completed.

DETROIT, June 23 (AP). -- The Red Sox overcame a four-run deficit today to defeat the Tigers, 7 to 6, and even the series despite the efforts of Al Simmons, who hit two home runs and a single, batting in five runs.

MARION, Mass., June 23. -- Three boys from the St. Paul's School of Concord, N.H., Jock Raymond of East Gloucester, J.D. Westin of Sayville, L.I., and J.A. MacColl of Providence, were the only young sailors in the seventh interscholastic yachting championships to keep their records clear when they won again today and clinched a place in the finals, which probably will begin on Thursday.

Public offering will be made today of $32,000,000 of first mortgage 4 per cent bonds, and $3,700,000 of 4 per cent serial debentures of the Wisconsin Power and Light Company by a banking group headed by Field, Glore Co.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 23. -- Calling for closer cooperation in industry, Sir Charles A. Mander of Wolverhampton, England, past director of Rotary International, expressed the conviction today that there was an inescapable trend to a government control of industry.

PHILADELPHIA, June 23. -- The following telegram has been sent by fifty-two members of the Economists National Committee on Monetary Policy to the chairman of the resolutions committee of the Democratic National Convention and to James A. Farley:

MADRID, June 23. -- Accumulated profits that the Spanish Telephone Company owes the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation of New York, of which the Spanish concern is a subsidiary, are being sent to the United States in the form of olive oil.

Conferences between officials of the Securities and Exchange Commission and of the various Security Exchanges over the problems involved in the segregation of broker-dealer functions on Exchanges are expected in Wall Street to occupy the better part of the remainder of this year.

With the completion of testimony in the Drukman conspiracy trial yesterday afternoon -- on the twenty-second day of the trial -- the defense opened the summing up by both sides, which is expected to last until tomorrow evening, when Supreme Court Justice Erskine C. Rogers will give the cases against the five defendants to the Brooklyn blue-ribbon jury.

Modification of service contracts between the Byllesby Engineering and Management Corporation and certain subsidiaries of the Standard Gas and Electric Company as of Sept. 30, 1935, are noted in the annual reports of such companies to the Securities and Exchange Commission, as released yesterday for inspection at the New York Stock Exchange.

Relief from drought in several States, with showers predicted over a wide area east of the Mississippi River, encouraged profit-taking operations on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and prices eased, losing 12 to 15 points. Though conditions in Texas remained unchanged, highly beneficial rains in other sections brought out cotton and October was set back below 11 1/2 cents a pound.

WASHINGTON, June 23. -- New York Stocks, Inc., of Jersey City, a mutual investment company, filed today under the Securities Act of 1933, covering 2,000,000 shares of convertible special stock to be issued in twenty-one series, the registration statement placing the offering at $24,000,000.

Mindful of more than a year he spent in the Kings County Hospital after a hit-run driver left him in the street four years ago, Jimmy Williams, 14 years old, of 4,124 Second Avenue, Brooklyn, did not want to see his four brothers and sisters with no place to play except the streets.

WASHINGTON, June 23. -- Collections of income taxes from June 1 to 20 amounted to $298,505,823, compared to $242,688,776 the same time last year, or an increase of about 23 per cent, the Internal Revenue Bureau announced today. In the six New York districts the collection amounted to $86,412,211, an increase of $9,570,152, or 11 per cent.

MANHASSET, L.I., June 23. -- A round of 76 by Frank Strafaci, the national public links champion, featured the Long Island Golf Association's one-day tourney today and also brought the Brooklyn golfer the low gross honors.

Religion, which has been "outlawed" from the various governments for the last twenty-five years, is the principal need in our schools today, the Rev. Dr. Edward Lodge Curran, president of the International Catholic Truth Society, declared yesterday. Dr. Curran delivered the commencement address of St. Angela Hall Academy before 1,200 persons at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

Controller Frank J. Taylor has no right to compel film distributors to charge a 2 per cent sales tax on films rented for exhibition outside New York City. The Appellate Division made this ruling yesterday on an application by the United Artists Corporation to review a determination of Mr. Taylor that the company must pay $21,188 as a sales tax on film rentals.

Use of political pressure and resort to the courts were discussed as possible courses of action to stay the imposition of countervailing duties to be assessed by this coun try on a variety of German products after July 11, by 250 business men who attended a protest meeting sponsored by the Board of Trade for German-American Commerce at the Merchants' Association yesterday.
The Marine Parkway Authority will open bids today for the construction of a $6,000,000 toll bridge across Rockaway Inlet between Marine Park, Brooklyn, and Jacob Riis Park on the Rockaway peninsula.

HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., June 23. -- Thirty-five homes of the model industrial-homestead project being built here by the Federal Resettlement Administration have been completed and will be occupied by July 15, it was announced here today.

THE MUNICIPAL AUDITORIUM, PHILADELPHIA, June 23. -- Three thousand delegates and alternates to the Democratic National Convention, in the presence of seven or eight thousand spectators, gave demonstrations of enthusiasm for President Franklin D. Roosevelt tonight with a spirit that indicated confidence in his re-election.

CHICAGO, June 23. -- New high prices for the season in the deferred deliveries of wheat were reached on the Board of Trade and in the Minneapolis market in the forepart of today's session. Quotations here were advanced as much as 2 1/2 cents a bushel before profit taking and local pressure was sufficient to check the bulge.

Nathan Waxberg, 50 years old, a partner of L.D. N. Waxberg, wholesale hardware dealers at 42 Ludlow Street, was convicted yesterday after a two-day trial in Special Sessions as a purveyor of metal slugs used as counterfeits in telephone and restaurant coin boxes and subway turnstiles.
POTTSTOWN, Pa., June 23. -- Dr. Henry Noble MacCracken, president of Vassar College, told members of the graduating class of the Hill school yesterday that "with knowledge comes responsibility."

DENVER, June 23 (AP). -- Miss Marion Miley, defending champion from Lexington, Ky., led favored players safely through the first round of the women's trans-Mississippi golf tournament today. She set a fast pace in crushing Mrs. J.L. Bailey of Emporia, Kan., 7 and 6.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 23. -- The Larchmont Garden Club held its annual flower show here today at the Larchmont Avenue Church house, Mrs. Stephen A. McClellan was chairman.

Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State chairman, was designated yesterday as the official head of the party's campaign in New York State. At the same time major State leaders virtually agreed that the State convention on Sept. 28 and 29 would be held in Albany.
LONDON, June 23 (AP). -- King Edward VIII, bright in scarlet and gold, paused amid British birthday pageantry today to salute his mother.

The Marquess and Marchioness of Milford Haven, second cousins of the King of England; Mr. and Mrs. Bernard M. Baruch, Nicholas Biddle and Mr. and Mrs. S.R. Guggenheim are among the persons sailing today for France and England on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary.

CHICAGO, June 23. -- Another seeded player met defeat in the singles competition and a seeded doubles pair was eliminated as the national intercollegiate tennis championships continued at Northwestern University today.

BOSTON, June 23. -- The Lenox Handicap, six-furlong feature of the program at Suffolk Downs, was called a dead heat today when the Waite camera locked Miss A. Doris's Lady Higloss and Felix Spatola's Wise Prince together at the finish line.

While business failures declined in the week ended June 18 in the manufacturing and wholesale divisions as compared with the figures for the previous week, insolvencies increased in the retail division, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

A banking group headed by the First National Bank of New York obtained yesterday the award of a new issue of $3,000,000 of public works bonds of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts on a bid of 100.49 for 1 1/4s. The bonds will mature on June 15, 1937 to 1941.

The new Republican National Chairman, Mr. JOHN HAMILTON, is going to do something new with his office. He is to be an active campaigner. The speech which he made on Monday night was in itself a novelty. It opened the Republican campaign. Seldom, if ever before, can a national chairman of either party have done that.

PHILADELPHIA, June 23. -- Away back in the earliest years of the Christian era there lived in Rome one of the world's greatest reporters from then to now, and even reckoning in the B.C. period. His name was Juvenal, and he was, in reality, a columnist, only he used tablets instead of tabloids for his writings.

Since January gains in employment have been recorded by the Department of Labor each month, and the report of a further increase in May does not seem surprising. But it is significant for several reasons. As Secretary PERKINS points out this improvement is contra-seasonal.

WASHINGTON, June 23. -- With his usual urbanity, President Roosevelt told newspaper men at his press conference today that he had been too busy to follow developments at Philadelphia, and much too busy to be concerned with the platform which is being framed for submission to the Democratic convention.
WASHINGTON, June 23. -- The Tax Bill over which Congress labored to the breaking point became a law today when President Roosevelt signed it without ceremony or public statement.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 23 (AP). -- An out-of-court settlement for about $150,000 ended tonight one phase of Ann Cooper Hewitt's $500,000 suit against her mother, Mrs. Peter Cooper Hewitt, over the estate left to the 21-year-old girl by her father.
BOSTON, June 23 (AP). -- The Cubs snapped the Bee's winning streak at three straight today, 8 to 6, and remained a game and a half behind the pace-setting Cardinals.
Tenement houses formed the bulk of realty turned over in realty activity reported by brokers yesterday.

Directors of the Lehman Corporation declared yesterday a special dividend of $1 a share, payable on July 10 to stockholders of record of June 30. On June 3 the regular quarterly dividend of 75 cents was voted.

A banking group will offer today by means of a prospectus 225,000 shares of no-par $2.25 cumulative preferred stock, with five-year common stock purchase warrants attached, of the Crown Cork and Seal Company at $45 a share and accrued dividend.

HOYLAKE, England, June 23. -- Qualifying play for the British open golf championship started today at Hoylake and the neighboring Cheshire course at Wallasey, with Gene Sarazen, the first big gun at Hoylake, doing nobly with a 71, but Henry Cotton, British pro, made the round in 68, six under par.
LEXINGTON, Ky., June 23 (AP). -- Dominion Grattan's sensational victory today in the Arrow Point Stake for free-for-all pacers featured the second day of the Spring meeting of the Grand Circuit.

IF your memory goes back fifteen years you will recall that, according to the headline writers, Society Girl Wed Poet early in 1921. The society girl was one Priscilla Pardridge of Chicago; the poet was one Lester Cohen. About five years later, by virtue of a novel entitled "Sweepings," the poet came to be designated Lester Cohen, without the humbling adjective.

PEIPING, June 23 (AP). -- Japanese bayonets cleared the way for Peiping's greatest martial display in about thirty-five years today. A United States Army captain and other foreigners were reported to have been forced from the roads and sidewalks.

PHILADELPHIA, June 23 (AP). -- For the second successive day Dizzy Dean stepped in to save a game for the league-leading Cardinals as Frank Friseh's men scored a 3-2 triumph today over the Phillies in the second game of the series.

The security and commodity markets encountered considerable profit-taking yesterday, as the more or less natural consequence of the recent strong advances. In stocks, the claiming of profits occasioned no very sharply declined weaknesses but did bring about a small decline in the volume of trading.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 23. -- A day of rapid developments in the fight by Mayor Clarence E. F. Hetrick and members of the City Council against the Durand Beach Commission Law found city officials tonight still in control of the beachfront.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP). -- A four-point program of emergency relief, coupled with expert study of land utilization and rural rehabilitation work, was mapped by government officials today to aid drought-stricken North-Central States.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., June 23. -- Mrs. Robert Loughborough gave a tea this afternoon at her home here for her sister, Mrs. John Williams Morgan of New York and Irvington-on-Hudson.

CAPE MAY, N.J., June 23. -- With more than 200 rabbis from all parts of the country in attendance, the forty-seventh annual convention of the Central Conference of American Rabbis of America, opened here tonight. Sessions will continue until Monday.

CHICAGO, June 23. -- Warfare between Ernest Palmer, State Director of Insurance for Illinois, and the big Eastern fire insurance companies, which has been smoldering ever since the Eastern interests succeeded in blocking enactment of Mr. Palmer's proposed insurance code by the State Legislature, broke into the open today with an official order by Mr. Palmer instructing all companies to reduce premium rates 10 per cent on dwellings and apartment buildings throughout the State.

PARIS, June 23 (AP). -- The 6 per cent discount rate of the Bank of France, adopted to halt the rapid drain of gold to other countries, was lowered today to 5 per cent to relieve pressure on business and industrial loans.

" Steps Going Down," by John T. McIntyre of Philadelphia, has been selected as the American contender in the All-Nations Prize Novel Competition in which a prize of about $19,000 is offered. The competition is aranged by the Literary Guild, Farrar Rinehart, Warner Brothers and eleven foreign publishers.

The daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,963,400 barrels, compared to 2,971,400 in the preceding week, a decline of 8,000, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A decline of 20,900 barrels in the daily average output of Oklahoma and a gain of 17,850 in Texas were the important changes.

" The White Angel," Warner Brothers' cinema story of the life of Florence Nightingale, opens this morning at the Strand, with Kay Francis in the leading role. She is supported by Ian Hunter, Donald Woods, Nigel Bruce, Donald Crisp, Billy Mauch, Henry O'Neill, Phoebe Foster. Eily Malyon, Halliwell Hobbes, Montague Love and Lillian Cooper.

PHILADELPHIA, June 23. -- Filled with excitement and anxious to miss nothing, five youthful winners of a public speaking contest in Kansas reached Philadelphia this afternoon by motorcade. Three boys and two girls, whose eloquence in defense of the administration and its policies won them the trip, came direct from Wichita and the finals of their competition there.

PHILADELPHIA, June 23. -- The election of Clark Howell Sr., Atlanta publisher, to succeed Governor Talmadge as Democratic National Committeeman from Georgia is regarded by Georgians at the Democratic Convention as foreshadowing the political eclipse of the man who organized a "grass root" gathering to oppose the Roosevelt policies and has been, perhaps, the most outspoken foe of the President and of the New Deal within the Democratic party.
