THERE was no sign of Pie Traynor in the lobby of the Pirate hostelry, but President Bill Benswanger of the Pittsburgh club and Coach Jewel Ens were willing to let an outsider in on their conversation on baseball.

Prices of commodity futures were generally lower on the markets here yesterday. The volume of trading was fairly heavy. Rubber and metal futures were firm. On the cash markets corn, rye, butter, tins, silk and rubber gained, while wheat, cotton, lard and cocoa declined.

HACKENSACK, N.J., June 23. -- Miss Norma Taubele of New York, No. 1 seeded player, led a group of five other stars and one who was not seeded into the quarter-final round of the women's New Jersey State tennis championship at the Oritani Field Club today.

PHILADELPHIA, June 23. -- Following are the members of the committee on resolutions of the Democratic National Convention, as filed with W. Forbes Morgan, secretary of the national committee, with the exception of the members from South Dakota, Puerto Rico and the Canal Zone:

PARIS, June 23. -- The Bank of France announced today a reduc tion in its discount rate from 6 to 5 per cent, which was made possible by the recent strengthening of the franc in the foreign exchange trading. The rate for advances on securities and the 30-day rate were reduced from 8 to 6 per cent and from 6 to 5 per cent respectively.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., June 23. -- Declaring that the race differential is only one, and a much exaggerated, factor in the social problem of the South, Dr. Will W. Alexander of Atlanta warned the Institute of Regional Development here today that the time had come for whites and Negroes alike to "stop talking about the race question and get together in the solution of their mutual difficulties."

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., June 23. -- Laymen made their bid today, under the leadership of the New York Conference, for larger lay representation in the membership of the General Council of Congregational and Christian Churches of the United States.
PHILADELPHIA, June 23. -- Governor Lehman was unanimously chosen chairman of the New York Democratic delegation at a caucus late this afternoon in the Rose Room of the Hotel Bellevue-Stratford.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 23. -- The most accurate atomic scale yet developed for weighing pure energy, which is matter in its immaterial state, was reported here today before the closing sessions of the American Physical Society at the University of Rochester by Dr. M. Stanley Livingston and Dr. J.G. Hoffman of Cornell University.

The Rev. Dr. Arthur Brunn of Brooklyn was re-elected to serve a third term as president of the Atlantic District of the Evangelical Lutheran Synod of Missouri, Ohio and Other States at the second session yesterday of its convention at St. Mark's Evangelical Lutheran Church, Bushwick Avenue and Jefferson Street, Brooklyn.

NEWARK, N.J., June 23. -- Charging that the Federal Social Security Act was "designed to coerce the State into accepting Federal requirements for governing their internal affairs," a suit filed in Federal court here today seeks to have the taxing provisions of the act declared unconstitutional and to restrain enforcement of the payroll tax under the act.

PHILADELPHIA, June 23. -- The sound of a gavel striking wood reverberated through the arched recesses of the chastely decorated Municipal Auditorium today and the opening session of what has been called a convention of Democrats by some, and a soiree of yesmen by others, was under way.

Punishment of persons caught littering parks by putting them to work immediately on the park cleaning force was proposed yesterday by Marshall Bidwell Dierssen, Chairman of the Manhattan committee of the Park Association of New York City, Inc.

In one of the closest finishes of the meeting thus far, with the camera in use, and the outside horse once more favored, Arthur J. Saekett's Tabitha yesterday won the featured Aquebogue Handicap at Aqueduct. Charles Nurtsinger's never-give-up ride aboard the daughter of Victorian had much to do with the result, for at the sixteenth pole Tabitha appeared soundly beaten.

PHILADELPHIA, June 23. -- There has been one good controversy at the Democratic convention over the recommendations of the women's advisory committee to the platform committee, which has been meeting, with intervals out for food and sleep, for thirty-six hours.

CAMDEN, N.J., June 23. -- A strike call was issued to employes of the RCA Manufacturing Company here today and picket lines were thrown around the plant at 12:15 P.M. by local 103, United Electrical and Radio Workers of America.

The five-story brick house at 20 Washington Square North, built about a century ago by George P. Rogers on what was then the Rogers farm, has been leased by New York University to be used as the administrative center of the Division of General Education, according to an announcement yesterday.

The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company took over the twelve-story Della Robbia apartments at 740 West End Avenue, northern corner of Ninety-sixth Street, on a bid of $500,000 at a foreclosure sale conducted yesterday in 18 Vesey Street by Edwin J. McDonald, auctioneer.

Alfred E. Smith continued silent yesterday as to the reception of his appeal to the Democratic National Convention to reject Franklin D. Roosevelt as nominee again, and refused, along with the other signers of the protest, to disclose his exact plans.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 23. -- The estate of the late Commodore E.C. Benedict at Indian Harbor was the scene of the annual flower show of the Greenwich Hortulus Club, held this afternoon from 3 until 7 o'clock.

CLEVELAND, June 23 (AP). -- The Athletics stopped a ninth-inning rally, begun by Hal Trosky's seventeenth home run of the season, and took the second game of their series with the Indians today, 8 to 6.

PHILADELPHIA, June 23. -- Among the crowd drifting across the University of Pennsylvania campus after the first session of the convention today, a TIMES reporter discovered Godfrey G. Gloom, the old-fashioned Jeffersonian from Indiana.

Alfred E. Smith continued silent yesterday as to the reception of his appeal to the Democratic National Convention to reject Franklin D. Roosevelt as nominee again, and refused, along with the other signers of the protest, to disclose his exact plans.

With messages of endorsement from Governor Lehman and Secretary of Labor Perkins, a "career conference" opened yesterday in the auditorium of James McCreery Co. under the auspices of the Vocational Service for Juniors. The program will continue through tomorrow.

For eighteen years Leopold Friedman, a stoop-shouldered little man, was a postal clerk, a frugal man, who neither drank nor gambled, but went from Station H of the postoffice to his home in Brooklyn on pay days and gave his week's salary of $40 to his wife.

The death of Captain Lindsay M. Bawsel, army flier, and his three children, 5, 3 and 2 years old, was revealed yesterday in a radio message received from the army transport Chateau Thierry and made public at the Brooklyn army base.

Maritime labor leaders who are interested in the proposed organization of a Maritime Federation of the Atlantic along the lines of the body which controls the Pacific Coast ports have visited New York recently to sound out union men on the plan.
PARIS, June 23. -- The text of the government's foreign policy declaration made before Parliament today follows:

The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company took over the twelve-story Della Robbia apartments at 740 West End Avenue, northern corner of Ninety-sixth Street, on a bid of $500,000 at a foreclosure sale conducted yesterday in 18 Vesey Street by Edwin J. McDonald, auctioneer.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 23. -- The estate of the late Commodore E.C. Benedict at Indian Harbor was the scene of the annual flower show of the Greenwich Hortulus Club, held this afternoon from 3 until 7 o'clock.

CLEVELAND, June 23 (AP). -- The Athletics stopped a ninth-inning rally, begun by Hal Trosky's seventeenth home run of the season, and took the second game of their series with the Indians today, 8 to 6.

PHILADELPHIA, June 23. -- Defenders of the historic two-thirds rule for nomination, led by Senator Byrd of Virginia, will demand that if it is abrogated by the Democratic National Convention, the unit rule prevailing in many States also be abolished.

LAKEHURST, N.J., June 23. -- With the rain pouring on her silver envelope increasing its weight by thousands of pounds, the airship Hindenburg sailed tonight for Germany. In her warm, bright cabins were fifty-seven passengers and with the crew there were more than 100 persons aboard when, at 11:24 o'clock, the dirigible backed away from her mooring mast and nosed up toward the low-hanging clouds.

In their present state of apparent helplessness the Dodgers yesterday were hardly a match for the hustling Reds as the visitors sent them down to a 3-0 defeat at Ebbets Field, marking the seventh time this season that they had been blanked.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 23. -- Hatred of "Scarface Al" Capone on the part of his fellow-convicts on Alcatraz Island blazed anew today and the former Chicago gang leader was stabbed in the back. The wound, described as "not serious," was inflicted with a pair of barber shears wielded by James C. Lucas, serving thirty years for bank robbery.

ALBANY, June 23. -- Employment and payrolls in New York State's wholesale stores rose nearly 1 per cent from April to May, said a statement today by Elmer F. Andrews, industrial commissioner. In May, 1935, small decreases were reported.

WASHINGTON, June 23. -- Before high-ranking officers of the Air Corps and officials of the National Geographic Society Major Albert W. Stevens and Captain Orville Anderson jointly received the Mackay Trophy today in recognition of their feat in ascending 72,394 feet into the stratosphere on Nov. 11, 1935.

PHILADELPHIA, June 23. -- The Rev. and Mrs. Harrison B. Wright gave a tea this afternoon at their home, Ithan Derlwyn, in Radnor, for their debutante granddaughter, Miss Sibyl B. Coates, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Osborne Coates of Long Acre, Wayne.

WASHINGTON, June 23. -- The Potomac Electric Power Company has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an amendment to its registration statement covering $15,000,000 of first mortgage bonds 3 1/4 per cent series due in 1966, giving the offering price to the public at 104 and to the underwriters at 103,027, in each instance, plus accrued interest.
The analogy from MAX SCHMELING and JOE LOUIS may yet become a menace to sound thinking. One veteran political reporter in Philadelphia said in yesterday's paper that he thinks LANDON will be elected.

PHILADELPHIA, June 23. -- Mayor S. Davis Wilson of Philadelphia was cast in the role of a weather prophet today at a reception at Franklin Institute, where he played host to Mayors attending the Democratic convention.

CHICAGO, June 23. -- Sprawled out for a count of nine in the sixth round, the Yankees suffered an experience today akin to running into an open door in the dark. They bounced around for a time in bewildered fashion and then expired with the White Sox in full possession of the field by a score of 13 to 4.

THE TIMES reports that the Merchants Association is urging the city to install parking meters on the curbstones of New York. Under the plan you insert a coin for a set period of parking your car. At the end of this period a green flag goes down and you are expected to insert another coin.

BOSTON, June 23 (AP). -- Thomas C. O'Brien of Boston, Vice Presidential nominee of the Union party, said he would leave Boston today for a tour of the country for the purpose of forming State committees to carry on the local work of the party.

PHILADELPHIA, June 23. -- Pressure of administration leaders failed to influence Senator Glass of Virginia to become a member of the resolutions committee and assume an active role in the shaping of the party's platform.

The Guaranty Trust Company has been appointed paying agent of principal and interest for the new $30,000,000 of Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation first mortgage bonds, Series A, 4 1/2 per cent, and also will act as agent here for the exchange of temporary bonds for definitive bonds of this issue.

THE TIMES reports that the Merchants Association is urging the city to install parking meters on the curbstones of New York. Under the plan you insert a coin for a set period of parking your car. At the end of this period a green flag goes down and you are expected to insert another coin.

BOSTON, June 23 (AP). -- Thomas C. O'Brien of Boston, Vice Presidential nominee of the Union party, said he would leave Boston today for a tour of the country for the purpose of forming State committees to carry on the local work of the party.

PHILADELPHIA, June 23. -- Pressure of administration leaders failed to influence Senator Glass of Virginia to become a member of the resolutions committee and assume an active role in the shaping of the party's platform.

Two prominent officials of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association, Miss Rosalie Knapp of Women's National and Mrs. James M. Robbins of Rockland, yesterday triumphed over a formidable array of players in the first Scotch foursome championship of the organization at the Queens Valley Golf Club in Forest Hills.

The International Hydro-Electric System and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the first quarter of 1936 a consolidated net profit of $141,290, compared with $597,536 for the corresponding period of 1935.

The Guaranty Trust Company has been appointed paying agent of principal and interest for the new $30,000,000 of Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation first mortgage bonds, Series A, 4 1/2 per cent, and also will act as agent here for the exchange of temporary bonds for definitive bonds of this issue.

PHILADELPHIA, June 23. -- There is growing belief among the high strategists of the Democratic National Convention that President Roosevelt will have the benefit in his home State of Governor Lehman's candidacy for a third term.

ST. LOUIS, June 23 (AP). -- Although hit equally hard, the Senators leaped through the Browns' defense today and won, 10 to 5, for their seventh victory over the" Hornsbymen in eight games this season.

Justice Hyman Rayfiel of the Court of Special Sessions will retire from the bench today after nearly thirty-six years in the city service. Yesterday, his last day in court, colleagues, court attendants and attorneys bade him farewell at an impromptu ceremony, the speakers emphasizing his sympathy for the "under dog."

Urging that the 3 per cent Federal tax on fur-trimmed cloth coats be included in the price of the merchandise, representatives of the Association of Buying Offices declared yesterday that listing of the tax as a separate item would disturb wholesale and retail prices, create confusion which would aid the sale of competing fur garments and lead to various forms of subterfuge that will place ethical manufacturers at a disadvantage.

Representatives of the 1,500 employes of the city's Emergency Relief Bureau protested yesterday at a public hearing before the Municipal Civil Service Commission against the commission's proposal to put relief employes under civil service.

WASHINGTON, June 24. -- Graduates of the War College were warned today by General Malin Craig, Chief of Staff, to keep their minds alert, to think sanely and soundly and to be willing to take a chance when in command of troops in warfare.

ST. LOUIS, June 24 (AP). -- Buck Newsom was effective even though he issued five walks today and Washington clubbed a 7 to 4 victory over the Browns, who have been able to win only one game from the Senators all season.

PORTSMOUTH, Ohio, June 24 (AP). -- Sheriff Arthur Oakes filed a first-degree murder charge late today against James Sexton, 51, in the slaying of George Meyers, 38, Wheeling Steel Corporation guard, who was shot to death in a battle at the strike-closed plant here yesterday.

As the Democratic convention proceeds to the drafting of a party platform, it faces one issue which outranks all others in political importance. This is the question of the national budget. On that issue the Democratic party is most vulnerable. It can point to its social security program, to its reciprocal trade treaties and to its farm legislation as efforts to redeem its pledges of four years ago.

WASHINGTON, June 24. -- The Chicago Federation of Labor, second largest city organization in the American Federation of Labor, has asked the national federation to withdraw its "ultimatum" against the ten unions comprising the Committee for Industrial Organization and allow the craft-industrial union dispute to go to the next annual convention at Tampa for settlement instead of suspending the unions from affiliation.

LONDON, June 24. -- For the first time in more than a year there is a prospect of genuine Anglo-French cooperation tonight as a result of the simultaneous burial of sanctions on both sides of the Channel and yesterday's new statement of French foreign policy.

THE MUNICIPAL AUDITORIUM, PHILADELPHIA, June 24. -- The prayer of the Rev. Dr. Ivan Murray Rose of the First Baptist Church of Philadelphia, at the night session of the Democratic National Convention, was as follows:
According to standard definitions, the word "bolt" means "to refuse to support the principles or platform of a political party."

PHILADELPHIA, June 24. -- This is a unanimous, almost a totalitarian convention. It is also a convention in suspense. The question puzzling most observers is what it is leading up to. It is argued that a political leader with Mr. Roosevelt's sense of showmanship does not drag out a two-day event for five days unless he is working up to a grand finale.

Dr. Alberto C. Bonaschi, Fusion member of the Board of Education from the Bronx, joined yesterday with a group of students of James Monroe High School in protesting the action of Dr. Henry E. Hein, principal of the Bronx school, in refusing diplomas to two members of the senior class.

THIS is no time to be turning away cash customers with a justified grievance. From the many congratulatory messages (!) received in the wake of the Schmeling-Louis encounter, the following postcard summons is culled:

As a builder of houses and apartments, and as a developer of rural housing for fifty years, I regret to see what appears to be concerted action by the land value speculators to link their activities to the legitimate business of building construction. That would be injurious to real builders.

Mayor La Guardia made an exception to the ban on unnecessary noise yesterday by directing the Police Department Band to "serenade" the seventy-four Bronx residents who voted in a referendum on Tuesday to remain residents of the Bronx instead of becoming residents of Westchester.

William R. Hayward, suspended principal of the Theodore Roosevelt High School, was dismissed from the public school system for the second time by the Board of Education at its meeting last night. All members found the principal guilty, but two voted against dismissal.

THE MUNICIPAL AUDITORIUM, PHILADELPHIA, June 24. -- The Democratic National Convention met early this afternoon for its third session with nothing before it but routine business, mostly appointment of its standing committees and honorary officers and ratification of the election of national committee members by the States, Territories and possessions.

PHILADELPHIA, June 24. -- William Allen White, Kansas editor and one of the group which conducted the campaign for the nomination of Governor Landon for the Presidency, said in his story of the convention written tonight for the North American Newspaper Alliance:

WASHINGTON, June 24. -- Thorough overhauling of the Bureau of Air Commerce with a "view to improving its administrative officials is urged upon the Secretary of Commerce in a preliminary report just made public by the Senate Committee on Commerce.
LEXINGTON, Ky., June 24 (AP). -- S.F. Palin, Indianapolis, carried off the driving honors today, the third session of the light harness meeting.

BERLIN, June 24. -- Max Schmeling, who has already had to leave $40,000 out of his purse from the Louis fight in the United States pending an income tax check-up, is probably scheduled to surrender another $40,000 to the German Government when he arrives home.

" Love on the Dole," the play derived by Ronald Gow and Walter Greenwood from the latter's novel of the same name, will close its New York run at the Longacre on Saturday. After a long run in London it opened on Broadway Feb. 24, with Wendy Hiller -- who has since left the cast -- in the leading role.

PARIS, June 24. -- Striking French sailors in the harbor of Marseilles, who had advertised their stand by floating red flags from the halyards, tonight won their demands. The government announced the ship owners had accepted the seamen's demands and that they would return to work tomorrow night.

CHICAGO, June 24 (AP). -- Harrison E. Spangler, director of the Republican National Committee's Western division, said today that Senator Barkley's keynote speech "reflects an interesting departure" from his 1932 keynote.

The program of the opening concert of the Lewisohn Stadium series did not proceed beyond the first number last night when it was postponed because of rain. Jose Iturbi completed Beethoven's "Leonore" Overture No. 3 as an intermittent drizzle thickened into a steady rainfall.

About 6,000 persons, mostly women, took part in ceremonies yesterday afternoon opening a new sewing project of the Works Progress Administration at the 369th Regiment Armory, Lenox Avenue and 143d Street. The project, the tenth opened under WPA auspices to provide employment for women, is to aid in turning out the 9,000,000 garments which, it was estimated, are needed by those on relief.

Public offering will be made today of an issue of $11,000,000 of ten-year 3 1/4 per cent notes of the Western Massachusetts Companies by an underwriting group headed by the First Boston Corporation, and including White, Weld Co., F.S. Moseley Co., Kidder, Peabody Co., Tifft Brothers and Arthur W. Wood Company.

A banking group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., obtained yesterday the award of a new issue of $5,000,000 of fifty, year 3 1/4 per cent bonds of the city of Philadelphia on a bid of 106,635. The bonds are to he dated July 1, 1936, and mature on July 1, 1986, optional on July 1, 1956.

New York's Fourth of July celebration this year may not be as noisy and spectacular as it was last year, but it will be much safer under the terms of an ordinance signed yesterday by Mayor La Guardia which prohibits the discharge or storage of fireworks without permission from Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott.

Hearings were begun yesterday before the Public Service Commission on the application of the Consolidated Edison Company to merge several of its wholly owned subsidiaries as the first step in a plan to merge all its subsidiaries into one corporation.

Retail trade, both here and elsewhere, during the last ten days has been better than the diminished activity in the apparel and accessory markets would indicate. Comparative volume of both chains and department stores has maintained the gains noted over 1935 during the first half of the month.

HOYLAKE, England, June 24 (AP). -- In addition to Gene Sarazen, the Americans who qualified in the British open championship were Ted Turner, with 146; Willie Goggin, 150; Joe Ezar, 150, and Errie Ball, Mobile, Ala., 154.

If a sprig of the common garden variety of larkspur had strayed into the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, yesterday in somebody's buttonhole it would never have recognized as even its remotest relative the velvety blue and purple skyscraper delphiniums which towered from tall vases against white walls.

For a few fleeting moments yesterday at the Polo Grounds the Giants saw a ray of sunshine through the low-hanging clouds over Coogan's Bluff. They were in third place after stretching their winning streak to five games as Johnny Welch wild-pitched them to victory in the first half of a twin bill with the Pirates.
The Federal Government took steps yesterday to assert its priority over other creditors of William Fox, former motion-picture producer, who filed a petition in bankruptcy last May in Camden, N.J.

This government must decide the problem of making public service "a career service or the foulest racket it has ever faced," according to H. Eliot Kaplan, executive secretary of the National Civil Service Reform League, who addressed the conference for high school and college students held yesterday under the auspices of the Vocational Service for Juniors.

Dr. Herbert Feis, economic adviser of the Department of State in Washington, and Arthur P. Chew, assistant director of the Information Service of the Department of Agriculture, are returning from Europe today on the Washington of the United States Lines after making a survey of conditions.
Years ago "Pro Bono Publico" used to "write to THE TIMES" complaining about the villainous United States postage stamp. His grievance was that the stamp did not stick to its job.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., June 24. -- An exhibition of sculpture, paintings and drawings by Allen Townsend Terrell of New York and Riverhead, L.I., opened in the Guild Hall Galleries today, to continue for two weeks.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., June 24. -- The relative merits of independent "super" research and development organization and one to be created by the more adequately financed and coordinated efforts of colleges and universities and of persons enabled to join them in such work were further explored today by members of the Institute on Regional Development.

The Republican party, through its alliance with the "Hearst-Liberty League Wall Street" forces, has become the "chief enemy" of the Peace, freedom and prosperity of the American people and must be defeated "at all costs" in the coming Presidential election, Earl Browder, general secretary of the Communist party of the United States, asserted yesterday afternoon.

CHICAGO, June 24. -- Fresh reports of damage to the Spring wheat crop in the Northwest had only a temporary effect on prices on the Board of Trade today. An early upturn of around 1 cent a bushel from Tuesday's finish failed to bring in outside buying, and with commission house profit-taking and a forecast indicating somewhat unsettled weather in North Dakota the market quickly settled back.

Bankers' acceptances outstanding declined $13,162,389 in May to $330, 531,460, compared with $374,755,247 at the end of May, 1935, said the survey of the American Acceptance Council, issued yesterday. The survey was the last by the council, which has voted to dissolve.
LONDON, June 24. -- America denied England even a grain of comfort by winning the third and last Westchester Cup polo game at Hurlingham today, 15 to 9, thus sweeping the board clean.

SHANGHAI, Thursday, June 25. -- Reports from several sources today said serious clashes had occurred in Southern Hunan Province between Central Government forces and troops of the "Anti-Japanese Salvation Army" of the South China Provinces of Kwangsi and Kwangtung.

DALLAS, Texas, June 24. -- Formal election of officers of the National Association of Retail Grocers will take place tomorrow, and if the report of the nominating committee is adopted, as it is expected to be, C.E. Smith of Dayton, Ohio, will become president. He now is vice president.
BERLIN, June 24. -- Activity was extremely limited on the Boerse today, with mixed quotations in a timid tendency toward strength.

PHILADELPHIA, June 24. -- After a brief, perfunctory public hearing, at which every major voter interest in the country was represented, the resolutions committee of the Democratic National Convention turned over today to a subcommittee composed of seven New Deal Senators, a State WPA administrator and four others, the task of pasting together the party's platform declarations.

WASHINGTON, June 24. -- Protests against the right of the Securities and Exchange Commission to "invade the privacy of a citizen" were made today to the Supreme Court by four residents of New York who thus far have been defeated by two lower courts in their fight against the commission.

Gulf ports have won a point in their fight to retain the export traffic in unboxed automobiles from the Middle West in a contest with ports on the Atlantic seaboard and the ports of Halifax and St. John, as the result of a decision announced by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

The action of the Board of Taxes and Assessments in fixing an assessment of $1,665,000 for 1935 on the Pierpont Morgan Library in East Thirty-sixth Street after declaring the library tax exempt as an educational institution on Oct. 1, 1934, was attacked in the Supreme Court yesterday by the library as illegal.

There is good news from Paris. The French Cabinet has taken BRIAND as its model in foreign affairs. Not since that great leader was in power has there been a statement of French foreign policy so conciliatory and realistic as that read last Tuesday in the two houses of Parliament by LEON BLUM and his Foreign Minister YVON DELBOS.

RYE, N.Y., June 24. -- Starting their third quest of the doubles honors in the annual invitation tennis tournament for Eastern boarding schools, Henry Daniels and Robert Low of Choate entered the third round today as a result of a bye in the opening round and a second-round victory over the Groton team of Robert Terry and B.H. Tompkins at the Manursing Island Club.

PHILADELPHIA, June 24. -- Mrs. Herman L. Cochran and Mrs. Donald H. Draughon, both of San Juan, Puerto Rico, chosen yesterday as members of the Democratic convention platform committee, are divided on one plank suggested by the woman's committee to the committee on resolutions.
DENVER, June 24 (AP). -- Top favorites won their second-round matches in the women's transmississippi golf championship today, cutting the field to eight for tomorrow's quarter-finals.

Intimations that the New York Stock Exchange might resist efforts of the Securities and Exchange Commission to put into effect its program of segregating the functions of stock brokers and dealers were contained in a letter addressed last night to all members of the Exchange by its president, Charles R. Gay.

The American Bridge Company and the Frederick Snare Corporation were the low bidders yesterday on contracts for the construction of the Marine Parkway lift bridge across Rockaway Inlet between Brooklyn and the peninsula.

The most equitable form of taxation yet devised for mutual investment trusts is embodied in Sections 13 and 48 of the new 1936 Revenue Act just passed by Congress, investment trust managers said yesterday. The law provides that if a mutual investment company passes on to its stockholders the net income received, including net capital gains from the sale of securities, it is relieved from the regular corporation and surplus tax.

Directors of the Consolidated Oil Corporation began yesterday a new dividend policy for the common stock by declaring a regular quarterly dividend of 15 cents a share on these shares, payable on Aug. 15 to stock of record of July 15. In the last few years the company has been paying dividends from time to time on the common stock as the directors believed earnings warranted action.

LOS ANGELES, June 24. -- The statement that meteorite-borne bacteria may link life on this planet with life elsewhere in the universe was made before the fourth annual convention of the Society for Research on Meteorites at the University of California at Los Angeles.

Deploring the modern generation of "wisecrackers" that "prefers cleverness to greatness," Channing Pollock, author and playwright, in a baccalaureate address at Hunter College commencement exercises in Carnegie Hall yesterday pleaded for simplicity and respect for tradition as a means to security.

BOSTON, June 24. -- Arthur McDonnell's Party Spirit, outlucked in his previous outing, earned brackets in the six furlongs of the second round of the Commonwealth Handicap today, defeating Mrs. W.W. Jefford's Indomitable by a neck at Suffolk Downs before 15,000 persons.

A consolidated income statement of the Associated Gas and Electric Company and subsidiaries, excluding affiliates in New England, shows gross operating revenues of $109,634,405 for the year ended on May 31, including all properties for the entire period irrespective of the dates of acquisition.

PHILADELPHIA, June 24. -- With the plane of compromise and the varnish of language, the 1936 platform of the Democratic party was being prepared tonight for public inspection while the national convention, which held two sessions today, listened to Senator Joseph T. Robinson -- who tomorrow will be elected permanent chairman -- deliver in the capacity of a delegate from Arkansas a keynote speech, the second of a series.
A dozen properties -- eleven in Manhattan and one in the Bronx -- went to mortgagees at foreclosure auction sales yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, June 24. -- An assertion that he was "through" with the Democratic National Convention and "sick of the whole damn thing" was voiced angrily tonight by Senator Ellison D. Smith of South Carolina after he had walked out of the political conclave in protest against the presence of Negroes.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 24. -- Professor Jean Piccard's anxious walt for word of his missing experimental stratosphere balloon ended early tonight when a telegram from Huntsville, Ark., revealed that the cellulose bag and its instruments had landed five miles northeast of there at 5 P.M.

PHILADELPHIA, June 24. -Franklin D. Roosevelt was hailed as the political legatee and presentday exponent of the political doctrines of William Jennings Bryan by speakers at a memorial breakfast today when some 400 visitors to the Democratic National Conventeion and other admirers paid tribute to the life and teachings of the "Great Commoner."

The weather obstinately refused to cooperate yesterday, and so the first of the Park Department's new million-dollar swimming pools at East Houston and Pitt Streets was opened on a day that felt more like a prelude to Fall than the beginning of Summer.

The incomparable Shirley Temple comes to the Music Hall today in "Poor Little Rich Girl," produced by Twentieth Century-Fox from a screen play by Sam Hellman, Gladys Lehman and Harry Tugend. The title is the one that used to head the tales written by Eleanor Gates and Ralph Spence.

Morgan Stanley Co., Inc., as sole underwriters, will offer to the public today a new issue of $26,000,000 of first and refunding mortgage 3 3/4 per cent, Series E, bonds, due on April 1 in the year 2003, of the Louisville Nashville Railroad Company.

LONDON, June 24. -- Business continued active today on the London Stock Exchange and the atmosphere was again cheerful in most departments. British Government stocks became steadier, with less selling of the 2 1/2 per cent funding loan than yesterday.

Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson reserved decision yesterday on applications for a total of $1,603,156 for attorneys' and other fees in connection with the completed reorganization of the McCrory Stores Corporation under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act.

Mayor La Guardia climbed aboard a pile-driver late yesterday afternoon and hammered the last piling into the foundation of the new Central Harlem Health Center at 136th Street and Fifth Avenue. More than 1,000 residents of the district, which ranks among the most unfavorable in the city from a public health standpoint, cheered the Mayor as he pulled on yellow gloves and jerked the throttle.
WASHINGTON, June 24. -- Two Democratic Senators returned together from Philadelphia today, but neither is "taking a walk." In fact, one of them went back to the convention tonight.
Reflecting gains in earnings reported generally by the railroads for May, the first eleven companies to report showed an aggregate increase of 41.7 per cent in net operating revenue for the month.
PARIS, June 24. -- Although the French Cabinet yesterday obtained all but a two-to-one majority for its foreign policy declaration there is much and violent criticism in today's opposition press.

Republican State leaders mapped strategy yesterday to get into smooth running order next week the machinery they will use for their drive to carry New York State both for the Landon-Knox ticket and the State slate.

PHILADELPHIA, June 24. -- Nearly 200 women attending a breakfast at the Bellevue-Stratford Hotel this morning rose cheering and clapping as Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, eulogized Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt for her work to promote human welfare.

A drive to raise funds for the American Olympic team was launched yesterday at a meeting of the newly organized New York Olympic Committee at the Bankers Club. W.H. Minton, managing director of the committee, presided at the meeting, which was attended by many leaders in industry, finance, transportation and trade.

WASHINGTON, June 24. -- A hearing has been called for July 7 by the Securities and Exchange Commission in proceedings to determine whether the unlisted trading privilege on the New York Curb Exchange of the common shares of the Bower Roller Bearing Company should be terminated, because the company has withdrawn these securities from listings on the Detroit Stock Exchange, effective tomorrow.

PHILADELPHIA, June 24. -- Godfrey G. Gloom, the Jeffersonian pawpaw planter of Amity, Ind., was encountered this afternoon by a TIMES reporter in the rear of the room where the committee on resolutions was in session, while the rain dripped mournfully down through a leak in the ceiling.

HOYLAKE, England, June 24. -- At the end of the qualifying play in the British open golf championship today Henry Cotton, one of the favorites to win, led with a score of 139. Four shots behind was Gene Sarazen, American favorite, who carded a 73 at Wallasey today.

Scattered liquidation of the July prior to the circulation of notices this morning eased near-month quotations on the Cotton Exchange yesterday, but beyond causing some irregularity in new-crop fluctuations, it had little influence on the market. After opening with a loss of a few points, prices recovered to end with an advance of 4 points on December to a loss of 12 points on July.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 24 (AP). -- David Jones, former Columbia University star and the latest American tempest to strike these parts, passed from the All-England championships today, but left an impression that will be hard to forget.

PHILADELPHIA, June 24. -- From a tumultuous twenty-minute demonstration given Governor Earle of Pennsylvania at the close of his address at Convention Hall last night there developed today among delegates the view that he must be regarded as a definite possibility when Democratic party leaders look over the Presidential timber in 1940.

PARIS, June 24. -- After nearly a month of the strikes and social conflict that ushered in the Blum government, the atmosphere of order and discipline that has characterized the situation is giving way to one of factional strife.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:
CLEVELAND, June 24 (AP). -- Earl Averill hit three home runs today to lead Cleveland to a double victory over the Athletics. The Indians won the first game, 5 to 3, and took the second, 14 to 2.

POLAND SPRINGS, Me., June 24 (AP). -- The National Editorial Association adopted a resolution today stating that it would "aggressively resist any and all attempts to extend government control, Federal or State, over advertising in publications."

ATLANTIC CITY, June 24. -- Dr. Amos O. Squire, consulting physician for Sing Sing Prison and a criminologist since 1914, told the twenty-seventh annual convention of the Rotary International today that "sending a bad boy to prison only makes him worse."

MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 24. -- Stalwart Jess W. Sweetser of Siwanoy, former American and British amateur champion, today captured the top honors in a star-studded field of fifty-five players in the third annual William Rice Hochster memorial invitation thirty-six-hole tournament at the Quaker Ridge Golf Club.

WASHINGTON, June 24. -- An appeal to communities to lighten the burden on "poor old government" by cooperating in handling social problems was made by President Roosevelt today in an impromptu talk before delegates to the annual convention of Kiwanis International, meeting here.

Rackets which victimize business men through misrepresented advertising media were discussed yesterday by H.J. Kenner, general manager of the Better Business Bureau of New York, before the season's final luncheon meeting of the New York Financial Advertisers Association at the Lawyers' Club.
The 1935-36 undergraduate honor roll, of Fordham College, containing 195 names, twenty-one more than last year, was announced yesterday by the Rev. Charles J. Deane, dean of the college.

Prices were firmer in the local commodity futures markets yesterday, although wool tops, hides, rubber and lead eased moderately. On the cash markets corn, rye, oats, butter, tins and cocoa advanced, while cotton, wheat, lard, wool tops, hides, and silk declined.
DETROIT, June 24 (AP). -- The Tigers took the rubber game of their series with the Red Sox, 7 to 6, today, counting the winning run in the eighth on Marv Owen's homer over the scoreboard.

Despite the maintenance of steel production this week at 71 per cent of capacity, the long-term outlook for the industry is far from encouraging, according to The Iron Age summary to be issued today. With the end of the peak of forward buying at second-quarter prices, the Summer prospects are "clouded by ominous uncertainties," the magazine said.

In a suit involving 1,600,000 policy holders of the New York Life Insurance Company and their claims to $15,000,000 in policy dividends, the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court decided yesterday against them and upheld the company in paying dividends to holders of ordinary life insurance policies at a rate higher than that paid to holders of policies combining life and disability provisions.

F.E. Williamson, president of the New York Central Railroad, left this city with other officials of the company yesterday to participate today in the christening of the Mercury, latest steam streamlined train, in Indianapolis. Miss Louise Landman, daughter of L.W. Landman, general passenger traffic manager of the company, will break a bottle of champagne made in Sandusky, Ohio, one of the cities to be served by the train, on the nose of the locomotive.

A slightly easier tone in United States Government loans and highly conflicting price trends among domestic corporation issues characterized dull and featureless trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The marketing of a substantial amount of new bonds apparently diverted trading interest from the listed market, as the turnover dwindled to $8,660,000, compared with $9,188,700 on Tuesday.

LENOX, Mass., June 24. -- Stuyvesant Morris Pell, naturalist and warden of the Pleasant Valley Bird and Wild Flower Sanctuary, read his report at the annual meeting this afternoon in the Red Barn Museum. He identified last year an all-time record of 157 varieties of bird life.

GLEN COVE, L.I., June 24. -- About 350 sub-debutantes and college students, children of members of the Nassau Country Club and their house guests, attended the first of the junior dances tonight. Many dinners in country homes in the North Shore colonies preceded the dance.

WASHINGTON, June 24. -- The $805,000,000 Revenue Act passed in the closing hours of Congress was actually signed by the President on Monday night, although announcement of its approval was made only yesterday.

No one can say of the Minister of Labor in the New Zealand Government that he aims too low. The other day he was speaking down under in Wellington, N.Z., on some labor question. In the course of his remarks he declared that he would not be satisfied "until the workers of New Zealand are living up to the standard of an American millionaire."

WEIRTON, W.Va., June 24 (AP). -- The board of directors of the Weirton Steel Company today elected T.E. Millsop president of the corporation to succeed J.C. Williams, who died early this month. Ernest T. Weir, chairman of the board, said:

The Summer Social Register of 1936, now being distributed to its subscribers, shows that the families of social prominence listed are responding to the economic recovery, in point of increased numbers spending the Summer in the country or at the shore and residing abroad.

PHILADELPHIA, June 24. -- A handful of farm leaders, always a powerful factor at a national political convention, fought a losing battle today for inclusion in the Democratic platform of a detailed list of their demands on the administration.

PHILADELPHIA, June 24. -- A 9,000-mile trip from Boort, Australia, ended here today for Kelvin Rodgers, 3 years old, who was brought to Philadelphia by his mother, Mrs. Marjorie Rodgers, to have a nail removed from his lung.
Money market continued dull, and quotations unchanged for all grades.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 24. -- While Alick Gerard Jr., sole survivor of the record smashing Peddie team of a year ago, was setting the pace in the qualifying round of the thirteenth annual Eastern interscholastic championship today, four representatives of Hill School were establishing a new mark in the team event.

CAMDEN, N.J., June 24. -- Three men were hurt and thirty-two persons arrested in clashes between pickets and strike-breakers at the Victor division factory of the R.C.A. Manufacturing Company here today during the first full day of the organizational strike of Local 103, United Electrical and Radio Workers of America.
Former Governor Smith was understood to have left New York yesterday, but his destination remained unrevealed.

July 4 this year falls on Saturday, and as a consequence of the observance of our Day of Independence all postoffices in the United States will be closed for business after 10 A.M., and will not open again until Monday morning.

On the last day of the session the Senate, without debate and without a record vote, passed a bill which had previously received very little general attention. This bill is the Welsh-Healey Government Contracts Act, and if signed by the President it promises to cause a great deal of trouble in one way or another.

CHICAGO, June 24. -- A more or less orderly parade of favorites, paced, as expected, by Fred Haas Jr. of Louisiana State University, moved over the North Shore Club course today into the quarter-finals of the national intercollegiate title golf tournament.

Today's Federal Reserve report is expected to show a further increase in the volume of money in circulation, following the rise of $111,000,000 reported last week. The cashing of veterans' bonus checks has continued at a substantial rate and a good part of the money is probably still outstanding as cash.
WASHINGTON, June 24. -- Treasury experts undertook to answer informally today questions of newspaper men concerning various phases of the Tax Bill passed in the closing hours of Congress.

FACTUAL books on Scotland Yard are at a disadvantage in the American market. Even the sketchiest fact account of American crime has an inexhaustible ocean of experience to draw upon. In this country about 3,000 persons are murdered every year. In England there were 115 murders in 1938, the last year for which full records seem to be available.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 24. -- The Deputy United States Collector of Internal Revenue at Albany telephoned here this afternoon that he had rescinded an order taxing the proceeds of a testimonial dinner given Saturday night to Henry R. Barrett, local Republican leader, by the Men's Republican Club of White Plains.
CRESTWOOD, N.Y., June 24. -- A deft touch on the greens and good length from the tees helped Mrs. A.U. Rodney to victory in the first women's invitation tournament at the Leewood Golf Club today.
There is much talk about a "definite program." I agree with whoever wrote that it was just as well that Governor Landon did not give an opinion on every conceivable problem of government.

Evincing the same calm disregard for proceedings at the Democratic National Convention as it did for the recent Republican conclave, the stock market moved ahead yesterday as traders thought in terms of second-quarter corporate earnings and dividend possibilities.

President Angell's recent address to the graduates of Yale deserves serious consideration. Our two major political parties which are about to engage in a struggle for supremacy have something tangible to strive for besides personal ambition or party success. President Angell discloses an outstanding human trait common to most men when he states: "It is not the fate of one man or another but the nature and quality of the social order that is involved."

CAPE MAY, N.J., June 24. -- Nationalization of the munitions industry and a host of other peace measures were advocated today by the international peace session of the forty-seventh annual convention of the Central Conference of American Rabbis in Congress Hall here.

ROME, June 24. -- The French Government's foreign policy declaration is viewed in official Italian circles as showing more inclination than might have been expected from a Socialist government to live in harmony with all States, regardless of their political regimes.
NANKING, June 24. -- "The Central Government does not want civil war," said Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek last night in an exclusive interview with THE NEW YORK TIMES.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., June 24. -- Jewels and cash of a total value of more than $420,000 were stolen from two North Shore estates within two miles of each other between noon yesterday and daybreak today by Long Island's mysterious "Summer Phantom."

LOS ANGELES, June 24 (AP). -- The Federal grand jury today indicted a man it identified as a Japanese naval officer and a former petty officer in the United States Navy on charges that they conspired to furnish the Japanese Government with United States Navy information in violation of the Espionage Act.

PHILADELPHIA, June 24. -- The delegates to the Democratic National Convention left to the members of the resolutions committee today worry about ways and means of saving the country from whatever the platform makers decide is the country's gravest peril, and had themselves a right good time, as one of the Texans phrased it.

Charles T. Mattmann, local club champion and holder of the private schools crown, led the field into the semi-final bracket in the junior singles of the annual Long Island Center tennis championship competition yesterday at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills. He eliminated Alter Milberg, James Madison High captain, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 1, in the feature quarter-final clash.

CHICAGO, June 24. -- With Colonel Jacob Ruppert viewing the spectacle and wearing at the same time his best smile, the only one, indeed, that could be seen in the gathering of 7,000, the Yankees today put on a gorgeous show for the edification of their employer.

FALMOUTH, England, June 24. -- Endeavour II, T.O.M. Sopwith's potential America's Cup challenger, sailing in her first race today, finished last, Hugh Paul's Astra winning by ten minutes. H.A. Andrae's Endeavour I was second and W.L. Stephenson's Velsheda third.

PHILADELPHIA, June 24. -- After the stormiest meeting since the convention opened here, the committee on credentials, at a late hour tonight, voted to seat both of the contesting delegations from Minnesota, each delegate to have a half vote.

PHILADELPHIA, June 24. -- Led by Representative Caroline O'Day of New York, advocates of the platform planks sponsored by women's organizations paraded to the platform and the microphones today to make their pleas before the resolutions committee.

CHICAGO, June 24. -- Seeded players found the going rough in the national intercollegiate tennis championships at Northwestern University today, four of them being jolted out of the running for the singles title.

Condemnation of the five-year warranty on electrical refrigerators as "frequently misleading to consumers" was voiced yesterday by department store merchandisers and buyers of appliances, meeting in the Hotel Pennsylvania. The consensus was that a two-year guarantee, covering all replacements, would be more desirable.

The new official angle skeet rules will receive their first test in big-time competition when the stars of this shotgun-shooting sport assemble at Lordship, Conn., tomorrow for the three-day Great Eastern skeet tournament.

WASHINGTON, June 24. -- Public building projects numbering 321, to be financed under the $60,000,000 Emergency Construction Fund, have been approved by Secretary Morgenthau and Postmaster General Farley, it was announced today.

PHILADELPHIA, June 24. -- Unremitting pressure continued to be brought to bear on Governor Lehman of New York in an effort to persuade him to become a candidate for renomination and increase the chances of President Roosevelt to carry his home State.
PHILADELPHIA, June 24. -- The text of the address to the Democratic National Convention by Senator Robinson of Arkansas follows:

The Chesapeake Stakes winner, Gold Seeker, which later succumbed to the filly jinx in the Kentucky Derby, ran with horses of her own sex in the $5,100 Gazelle Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday and triumphed in decisive fashion. At the end of the mile and a sixteenth the daughter of Messenger and Golden Fair was two lengths in front, and returned 5 to 1.

Alfred A. Knopf tells of the author, Aksel Sandemose, that because one of his books became a best seller he changed his language. All Sandemose's early books were written in Danish. The last of them was a novel that he wrote to make money, and when it succeeded in this he decided that something was wrong with the Danes, left Den[mark, settled in Norway, and began to write in the Norwegian.

The first move to bring about an agreement for the promotion of a heavyweight title fight between Champion James J. Braddock and Max Schmeling here in September was made yesterday by Mike Jacobs of the Twentieth Century Sporting Club.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., June 24. -- Members of the Garden Club of Southampton met this morning at Top Notch Farm, the home of Mrs. Ancell H. Ball. Mrs. Adrian H. Larkin, first vice president, presided in the absence of Mrs. Henry E. Coe, who is inspecting gardens in France with members of the Garden Club of America.

WASHINGTON, June 24. -- John D.M. Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Committee, asserted here today that he "never saw a crowd so scared and unwilling to admit it" as the Democrats at Philadelphia. He said that this "fright" was reflected in the speeches of Senator Barkley and Postmaster General Farley at the convention yesterday.

A resolution calling for a "decisive shake-up in Congressional representation in New York to secure a better understanding on the part of legislators of the coat and suit industry's problems, with particular reference to those affecting the consuming public," was adopted yesterday by the "consumers' protection committee" of the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board at a meeting in the Hotel New Yorker.

THE MUNICIPAL AUDITORIUM, PHILADELPHIA, June 24. -- A demonstration for Senator Robinson of Arkansas was the feature of tonight's session of the Democratic National Convention. The demonstration, which took place before Senator Robinson spoke, lasted fifteen minutes and was very enthusiastic.

ALBANY, June 24. -- The broad provisions of the New York Public Welfare Law permit the Department of Social Welfare to accept and administer Federal funds for child welfare services under the Federal Security Act, Attorney General Bennett ruled today.

WASHINGTON, June 24. -- An analysis of registration statements under the Securities Act of 1933, which became effective in May, showed a sharp diminution in bonds and debentures to be used for the retirement of debt and a striking increase of preferred and common stock issues, indicating, the commission said, to a certain extent a revival of public interest in offerings of equity securities.

HAMMONTON N.J., June 24. -- Able-bodied persons on relief who refuse to accept berry-picking jobs will be dropped from the relief rolls, it was announced today by Mayor James A. Ruberton. This policy was decided upon by the Mayor, the six members of the Town Council and Mrs. Margaret Caruso, Overseer of the Poor.
FARGO, N.D., June 24 (AP). -- Governor Walter Welford took an early lead over former Governor William Langer for the Republican Gubernatorial nomination in North Dakota's primary election today.

Two more developments came yesterday in college rowing as aftermaths of the past season which came to its climax, so far as the intercollegiate sport is concerned, with the Poughkeepsie regatta, though the Olympic trials are still to be rowed.
FARGO, N.D., June 24 (AP). -- Governor Walter Welford took an early lead over former Governor William Langer for the Republican Gubernatorial nomination in North Dakota's primary election today.

The United States Smelting, Refining and Mining Company reported yesterday for the five months ended on May 31 a consolidated net income of $2,116,394 after taxes, interest, depreciation, depletion, amortization and other charges. After dividend requirements on the 7 per cent preferred stock the earnings equaled $2.71 each on 528,765 shares of $50-par common stock.

ABOARD GOVERNOR LANDON'S TRAIN, ABILENE, Kan. June 24. -- Governor Landon, heading westward tonight for a vacation in Colorado, gave an example of the type of campaigning that has been effective for him in Kansas, and that the Republican National Committee hopes to be equally effective in the coming national campaign.
Bernard Baruch gave expert advice yesterday on avoiding Wall Street rumors as guide-posts of modern trends. He refused to discuss polities.

The lease of the fifteen-story building at 155 Sixth Avenue, corner of Spring Street, which has sixteen years to run, was purchased yesterday by the Junior Leasing Corporation, John C. Penrose, president. Erected in 1928, the structure fronts 100 feet on the avenue and 125.11 feet on the street.

The proper practice might well be for the party in power to hold its national convention before that of the Opposition. That would seem to be a natural order. The country first hears the Administration orators recite their glorious record and appeal for an extension of their lease of office, and then the spokesmen of the "outs" begin their attack.

An announcement that William W. Hawkins has been selected as chairman of the board of directors of the Scripps-Howard newspapers, replacing Roy W. Howard, who resigned, was issued yesterday. Mr. Hawkins, prior to the appointment, was general manager of the newspaper chain.

WASHINGTON, June 24. -- The Commercial Investment Trust Corporation filed late today a registration statement covering an issue of $35,000,000 of fifteen-year debentures to be used in part to retire outstanding debentures. The statement did not give the interest rate or the maturity date. These and other details will be furnished by amendment.

A vigorous attack on excess commissions in the fire insurance business was proposed yesterday by Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, speaking at a special meeting of the New York Fire Insurance Exchange, 85 John Street.

ITHACA, N.Y., June 24 (AP). -- General progress in various State crops due to recent rains was reported today by the Federal Department of Agriculture Weather Bureau at Cornell University in its weekly report of weather and crop conditions.

Titleholders and leading competitors from virtually every section of the country are included in the record field entered in the four-day program of the national A.A.U. women's outdoor swimming and diving championships, scheduled to start today in the Oriental pool at Manhattan Beach.
Purchases of three business corners and a corner apartment site in Queens, in addition to two Bronx corner apartment sites, were reported yesterday by Frederick Brown, operator.

PHILADELPHIA, June 24. -- Students from thirteen States, attending the Summer School of the League for Industrial Democracy, came from New York today to picket the Democratic convention and denounce President Roosevelt, Senator Robinson and the New Deal for conditions in Arkansas.

The schooner Countess, owned by Jack R. Aron of Great Neck, L.I., and an entrant in the ocean yacht race from Newport to St. David's Head, Bermuda, put in at New London yesterday noon disabled. A back stay on the 55-foot craft gave way in rough weather late Tuesday after about 150 miles of the 635-mile journey had been covered.
The rush to file plans for new buildings continued in four boroughs yesterday when architects submitted specifications for dwellings and flats in Manhattan, the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens.

Summoning in his own behalf this time all the skill and eloquence he used in years past to convict others, Assistant District Attorney William W. Klienman of Brooklyn pleaded yesterday for three and one-half hours before a blue-ribbon jury for his own acquittal in the Drukman conspiracy trial in Brooklyn.

Two decisions by Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler were upheld yesterday by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in test cases under which investors of more than $15,000,000 in guaranteed mortgage certificates must be paid in full before any of the twenty-seven closed title companies may receive anything on the unsold portions of certificate issues or on certificates repurchased from the public.

BERLIN, June 24. -- Authoritative opinion tonight said frankly that the references made by Premier Leon Blum of France to Franco-German relations pointed the way to a new orientation in these relations.

PHILADELPHIA, June 24. -- Students from thirteen States, attending the Summer School of the League for Industrial Democracy, came from New York today to picket the Democratic convention and denounce President Roosevelt, Senator Robinson and the New Deal for conditions in Arkansas.

The schooner Countess, owned by Jack R. Aron of Great Neck, L.I., and an entrant in the ocean yacht race from Newport to St. David's Head, Bermuda, put in at New London yesterday noon disabled. A back stay on the 55-foot craft gave way in rough weather late Tuesday after about 150 miles of the 635-mile journey had been covered.
The rush to file plans for new buildings continued in four boroughs yesterday when architects submitted specifications for dwellings and flats in Manhattan, the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens.

Summoning in his own behalf this time all the skill and eloquence he used in years past to convict others, Assistant District Attorney William W. Klienman of Brooklyn pleaded yesterday for three and one-half hours before a blue-ribbon jury for his own acquittal in the Drukman conspiracy trial in Brooklyn.

Two decisions by Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler were upheld yesterday by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in test cases under which investors of more than $15,000,000 in guaranteed mortgage certificates must be paid in full before any of the twenty-seven closed title companies may receive anything on the unsold portions of certificate issues or on certificates repurchased from the public.
THE MUNICIPAL AUDITORIUM, PHILADELPHIA, June 24. -- The following is the text of the prayer by the Rev. Marshall L. Shepard, pastor of the Mount Olivet Baptist Church:

Tenacity of purpose was the chief characteristic of Arthur W. Cutten, speculator par excellence, who became one of the wealthiest men in the world by his spectacular plunges on the Chicago grain market.

MONTREUX, Switzerland, June 24. -- The historic conflict between Russia and Great Britain was reopened today in the Dardanelles conference that is studying Turkey's request to the League of Nations for control over her straits. Here it is in balder terms than were used by Maxim Litvinoff, Soviet Foreign Commissar, and Earl Stanhope, head of the British delegation:

Sparing their ammunition but using deadly aim when they did let go, the rollicking Reds yesterday completed the sweep of the four-game series by shooting down the dolorous Dodgers in both ends of a double-header and leaving them in a very softened condition to greet Frankie Frisch's Gashouse Gang today.

Finals in the Park Department's city-wide harmonica contest were held on the Mall in Central Park last night. Competing for the championship were the winners in the elimination contests which have been held in all boroughs in the last three months.

RYE, N.Y., June 25. -- Supreme Court Justice William F. Bleakley of Yonkers was endorsed for the Republican nomination for Governor at the annual convention of the Westchester County Republican Committee in Playland Casino here today.

FARGO, N.D., June 25 (AP). -- A trend favorable to former Governor William Langer in late-reporting rural areas kept alive tonight his hope for victory in his 'comeback" contest with Governor Walter Welford.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- More than 16,500 farmers, whose properties are within the demonstration areas in which the United States Soil Conservation Service is perfecting a soil conservation program for the country, are cooperating with the government in the effort to conserve the productivity of millions oil agricultural and grazing acres now menaced by wind and water erosion.

BOSTON, June 25 (AP). -- Weathering a furious rally by his younger rival in a savagely fought ten-round bout, Jack Sharkey, 33-year-old former heavyweight champion, signalized his comeback tonight by whipping Phil Brubaker, 22-year-old Dinuba (Calif.) slugger, before a crowd of 8,000 spectators in Fenway Park.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- While President Roosevelt worked today over the speech with which he will accept renomination by the Democratic National Convention, it was announced that his address would probably not be more than 2,000 words long.

Civic leaders from upper Manhattan, the Bronx and Queens called at the offices of the Triborough Bridge Authority yesterday morning with complaints, grievances and suggestions relating to the Triborough dedication ceremonies on July 11.

PHILADELPHIA, June 25. -- A platform emphatically endorsing and continuing the New Deal to the point of amending the Constitution to make room for it if the Supreme Court persists in the narrow constructions of recent times was submitted to the Democratic National Convention tonight by a unanimous committee on resolutions and unanimously adopted.
LONDON, June 25. -- Emperor Haile Selassie left today for Geneva to plead the cause of his conquered country before the League of Nations Council.

Herman Shumlin yesterday set July 4 as the closing date of "The Children's Hour" at Maxine Elliott's Theatre. And that will be the end of a landmark, as landmarks go around here; for it was Nov. 20, 1934, when Lillian Hellman's tragedy opened, and eighty-five weeks will be the length of its run when it closes.

PHILADELPHIA, June 25. -- The century-old two-thirds rule, born in a tragic day of American history, when Jackson was President, died today in the progressive Roosevelt era. The convention tonight adopted the report of the rules committee, which recommended its abrogation and the substitution of the majority rule for the nomination of President and Vice President.
BERLIN, June 25. -- The Boerse was definitely in the doldrums today and it is expected to remain stagnant the rest of the Summer in accordance with the tradition in the Berlin market.
LONDON, June 25. -- Business on the London Stock Exchange today was smaller in volume than yesterday, and profit-taking lowered prices in some departments. British Government stocks continued firm.
Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that he would move the seat of city government from its present location in City Hall to the old Bartow Mansion, in Pelham Bay Park, for July and August.

LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., June 25. -- Charles Halperin of Brooklyn and Fred Becker of the Bronx were drowned in Lake George today when their canoe was capsized off the northern shore of Big Burnt Island, when caught in the wake of a speeding motor launch. Both bodies were recovered by grappling crews.

Charles Halsey Clark, 72 years old, has retired in the fiftieth year of his service with the real estate firm of Horace S. Ely Co., 76 William Street, it was announced yesterday. He began his career on Jan. 24, 1887, as a junior clerk in the office of Horace S. Ely, then at 22 Pine Street.
THE MUNICIPAL AUDITORIUM, PHILADELPHIA, June 25. -- The sudden appearance of Al Smith banners in a corner of the upper balcony here tonight caused a free-for-all fight which was quelled by police.

PEIPING, June 25. -- The United States and French Embassies today handed notes to the Japanese embassy calling attention to the rough treatment of two American citizens and one French citizen last Tuesday, when the Japanese Embassy guard held a parade to receive the regimental colors from the Emperor.

MARION, Mass., June 25. -- Four races sailed in a fifteen-knot southwester closed the preliminaries today in the interscholastic yacht championship and left for the finals tomorrow St. Paul's, last year's titleholder; Taft, Noble and Greenough, Loomis, Hotchkiss, Belmont Hill, which won in 1934; Rye Country Day and Boston Latin.

SEATTLE, June 25 (AP). -- The Post-Intelligencer says that Representative Byron B. Harlan, Democrat, of Ohio, disclosed today that the Federal Government plans to establish another Alaskan colony to create a gigantic naval air base to be operated by a permanent force of 20,000 men.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., June 25. -- East Hampton's two-day celebration of Long Island's three hundredth anniversary begins tomorrow, to last over the week-end. At 1 and 3:30 o'clock tomorrow afternoon the yacht Montauk will leave Promised Lane, on Gardiner's Bay, with 125 visitors, making "pirate's cruises" around Gardiner's Island, where the Suffolk County historian, Morton Pennypacker, has had a large banner placed at the spot where Captain William Kidd buried treasure in 1699.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- With the Treasury's cash balance on June 23 at $3,182,447,344 Secretary Morgenthau today announced that he would discontinue the weekly borrowing of $50,000,000 in Treasury bills in excess of the amount maturing each week.
THE MUNICIPAL AUDITORIUM, PHILADELPHIA, June 25. -- Senator Joseph T. Robinson, permanent chairman, called the convention to order at two minutes of 9 o'clock.

Willis Sharpe Kilmer, who has had scant success on the turf this season, scored his first double of the year at Aqueduct yesterday when his Sun Asia captured the featured Olympus Handicap, following the victory of his Beausympathy in the fourth race.

PHILADELPHIA, June 25. -- President Roosevelt and Governor Lehman will meet here Saturday, and the question is being asked by a multitude: What will the President of the United States say to the Governor of New York and what will the Governor of New York say in reply?

TRENTON, N.J., June 25. -- Governor Hoffman signed today the Municipal Budget Bill, designed to put all municipalities in the State on a cash basis before 1945; the annual Appropriation Bill, totaling $42,851,106, and the bill giving to the State Financial Assistance Commission $6,000,000 as an equalization fund to help municipalities provide emergency relief during the rest of this year.

Bank clearings in the United States, for the week ended on Wednesday, fell from the preceding week, but continued higher than a year ago. The amount for twenty-two leading cities, as reported to Dun Bradstreet, Inc., was $5,572,681,000, compared with $4,997,943,000 for the corresponding week last year, an increase of 11.5 per cent.

PHILADELPHIA, June 25. -- To obtain greater publicity through the radio, Postmaster General James A. Farley and other members of the Democratic board of strategy decided this afternoon to hold a night session of the Democratic convention tomorrow, so that the renomination of President Roosevelt might be broadcast throughout the nation at about 10 o'clock.

The Robinson-Patman Anti-Price Discrimination Law will lead "to considerable litigation just as soon as the Federal Trade Commission attempts to limit quantity discounts," the National Retail Dry Goods Association declared yesterday in a bulletin analyzing the measure and sent to member stores.

Sharp increases in advertising, particularly in rotogravure sections of Sunday newspapers, trade magazines and spot radio broadcasts were outlined yesterday to 400 dealers, salesmen and other representatives at the regional convention of the Williams Oil-O-Matic Heating Corporation, in the Commodore Hotel.
PARIS, June 25 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 25. -- More than 10,000 delegates to the annual convention of Rotary International carefully side-stepped today any action that would put the organization on record as regards international relations.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 25. -- In an effort to break the monotony of the weekly medal-play tournaments, the officials of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association today staged a best-ball fixture at the Knollwood Country Club, with the result that this novel type of competition, so popular with the men players, will be a regular feature in the future schedules of the organization.

With orders from their retail accounts pouring in faster than had been expected, dry goods jobbers experienced another busy period this week and bought substantial quantities of goods. Many of them, who had purchased what they thought would be sufficient requirements for many weeks early in June, were compelled to return to the market this week for merchandise, as demand from retailers exceeded expectations.

DALLAS, Texas, June 25. -- With election of officers as nominated by the committee on nominations, and selection of Boston as the place for holding its fortieth annual convention next year, the National Association of Retail Grocers closed its convention here this afternoon.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., June 25. -- Twelve golfers, all over 55 years of age, won the annual metropolitan senior team matches for New Jersey at the Englewood Golf Club today, running up a total of 40 points as compared with 35 for the Long Island squad and 33 for Westchester. It was the second successive victory for New Jersey.

PARIS, June 25. -- A proposal to double the pay of the French soldier from 25 to 50 centimes a day (about 3 cents) was made in a Cabinet council this morning by the Minister of National Defense, Edouard Daladier, and the necessary credits will be asked.

MOSCOW, June 25. -- The new Soviet Constitution will be voted by the All-Union Congress of Soviets about the middle of November, but already it is the subject of ardent discussion throughout the Soviet Union.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 25. -- The Women's Auxiliary of the Army and Navy Y.M.C.A. is arranging for a benefit dance for the association to be given in the auditorium at the Naval Training Station on !Aug. 1.

The Transit Commission fixed Sept. 10 yesterday as the date for the first public hearing on the plan of rapid transit unification placed in its hands last Monday by Mayor La Guardia's transit advisers, Samuel Seabury and City Chamberlain A.A. Berle Jr.

A succession of more than a dozen shippers and representatives of business interests took the stand before Interstate Commerce Commission examiners here yesterday to urge the commission to grant the application of Eastern railroads for inauguration of complete free door-to-door pick-up and delivery service of less-than-carload freight.

A banking group headed by the Chase National Bank and including R.H. Moulton Co., the First Boston Corporation and Dean Witter Co., won yesterday the award of a new issue of $5,000,000 of veterans' welfare 2 3/4 per cent bonds of the State of California, in a sale marked by close bidding by several syndicates.
I would appreciate the opportunity to comment on the resolution which was adopted on June 15 at a meeting conducted by employes of the Emergency Relief Bureau. It reads as follows:

Price movements were mixed on the local commodity futures markets yesterday, with sugar, cocoa, rubber and tallow firmer, with others irregularly lower. On the cash markets wheat, corn, oats, cotton and cocoa were strong, while rye, lard, wooltops, tins and silk eased.

So many million words and so many thousand square feet of maps have been printed about the world's sore spots that it is a pleasure to take note of the other thing -- the Edens or oases or lotus lands, or whatever is at the opposite pole from a sore spot.

With simple ceremonies the Rev. Dr. Robert I. Gannon became president yesterday of Fordham University, succeeding the Rev. Dr. Aloysius J. Hogan, whose six-year term in that office has expired and who now becomes dean of the Graduate School at Georgetown University, Washington, D.C.

PHILADELPHIA, June 25. -- Praise of Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt as a smasher of precedents was added today by Fannie Hurst to the eulogy voiced yesterday by Frances Perkins. The novelist, who is one of the striking figures in the convention throng, arrived today and promptly spoke her mind.

CHICAGO, June 25 (AP). -- Ernest Sutter of Tulane, heavy' favorite and top-seeded entrant, continued his impressive march through the singles division of the national intercollegiate tennis championship by disposing of Gardner Mulloy, University of Miami star, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 2, in the quarter-final round today.
Leases of garage properties and sales of one and two family dwellings comprised realty activity in Brooklyn yesterday.

MONTREUX, Switzerland, June 25. -- The Dardanelles conference suspended general discussion today until after the League of Nations sessions, leaving only technical experts on duty. The likelihood that the conference will then reach a convention enjoying unanimous consent, including that of Italy, is lessening daily.

GENEVA, June 25. -- Representatives of the World War neutral powers met here today to exchange views and try to formulate a common policy on Ethiopia for the session of the League of Nations Council opening tomorrow and the session of the Assembly next week.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 25. -- The mysterious alleged disappearance of a Brooklyn fortune once estimated at $3,000,000 and an attack on the male secretary of an aged and crippled woman who left her wealth to him and his family, featured a will contest today in Atlantic County Probate Court.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 25. -- Play started in the second of the twenty-goal polo tournaments at the Meadow Brook Club today and three teams rode through their first-round matches of the Meadow Brook Club Cups.

Members of the New York Stock Exchange expressed approval yesterday of the letter that they had received from Charles R. Gay, president of the Exchange, intimating that the organization would be guided by their wishes in its decision whether to accept or oppose the Securities and Exchange Commission's program for segregating the functions of brokers and dealers.
