WASHINGTON, June 25. -- The average of wholesale prices was unchanged during the week ended June 20, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The bureau's index, based on 1926 as 100, remained at 78.7. A year ago it was 79.3.

OTTAWA, Ont., June 25. -- The Senate having killed the government's bill to establish Dominion provincial loan councils in Canada, Charles Dunning, Finance Minister, announced today that a Dominion Provincial Finance Committee would be set up on a purely voluntary basis to take their place so far as possible.

Leaders in the field of design reviewed the advantages and disadvantages of illustration, fashion and industrial designing at yesterday's closing session of the conference conducted by the Vocational Service for Juniors in the auditorium of James McCreery Co.'s store, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street.

Gleanings from mailbag and notebook: This week-end should see salt-water fishing activity pick up on all fronts -- surf, bay, inshore and offshore. . . . While a number of Summer species still are far from plentiful, there are enough evidences of continuing migratory movements in near-by waters to encourage anglers to try their luck. . . . If good weather prevails, the week-end should be the most productive to date.

A general advance in commodity prices, largely stimulated by drought reports from the Northwest and Southeast, sent the Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices 1.8 points higher to 122.6 on June 23 from 120.8 (revised) the Tuesday before.

Federal Judge Julian W. Mack upheld in its entirety yesterday the employes' pension system of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company, which had been assailed as inequitable and "hopelessly insolvent" by 150 members of the independent Transport Workers Union.

PHILADELPHIA, June 25. -- Through Miss Mary W. Dewson, chairman of the advisory committee of the women's division, and Mrs. Caroline O'Day, their spokesman before the resolutions committee, the feminine section of the Democratic party expressed pleasure tonight over its platform.

HACKENSACK, N.J., June 25. -- Favorites advanced in straight sets to the semi-final round of the women's New Jersey State tennis championships at the Oritani Field Club today but all of them, notably Miss Norma Taubele, top seeded player, were pressed for the first time since this tournament began.

Five pupils in the city's public schools, recognized for their character, scholarship and courage in overcoming physical difficulties, received the M. Samuel Stern Memorial Prizes of $200 each and the Rebecca Elsberg Memorial Prizes of $150 yesterday in the office of Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools.

LEXINGTON, Ky., June 25 (AP). -- Ed Lasater, in winning the Lexington Herald purse for 3-year-old trotters in two straight heats today, repeated a 1935 victory over Vagabond King. The entry of John L. Dodge was third. The winner is the property of his breeder, W. N. Reynolds of Winston-Salem, N.C., and was driven by his trainer and developer, Ben F. White.

ELMIRA, N.Y., June 25. -- Male pilots filled the air today, with soaring conditions satisfactory but aerial currents none too speedy. As a consequence three women contestants remained upon the ground until the wind velocity increased so that they might have some assurance of success in assaulting their own as well as their opponents' records.

CHICAGO, June 25. -- Wheat today made a strong start and a tame finish on the Board of Trade. An early upturn of around 1 1/4 cents a bushel, induced by extremely high temperatures in the United States and Canadian Northwest, with no rainfall, ran into persistent hedging pressure against the movement of the new Winter grain crop in the Southwest.

The Cunard White Star liner Aquitania arrives today from Southampton and Cherbourg. On board are Miss K.M. Swann, W.W.J. Studd, P.S. Powart, Mr. and Mrs. John T. Pratt, G.A. Allen, James Bruce, Mrs. Royal Van Etten, Mrs. Philip Woollcott and John M. Cunliffe.

MADRID, June 25. -- On the theory that a statement of views from the Extreme Left Socialists, who are now exerting pressure on the Casares Quiroga government, and a similar statement from the Right, which is mildly opposing the government and violently opposing the Left, might elucidate for American readers this crucial situation in Spain, this correspondent sought both.

W.O. Briggs, president and chairman of the board of the Briggs Manufacturing Company, received in 1935 a salary of $60,000, while $75,000 was paid to W.P. Brown, vice president, it was disclosed yesterday in the company's annual report to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

PHILADELPHIA, June 25. -- Fair words and tempting from Postmaster General Farley wooed Democratic women today to accelerated organization activity which took no account of the lull in convention proceedings.

In the interim between the dedication of the Hamilton Fish swimming pool on Wednesday and the Thomas Jefferson pool tomorrow the Park Department will open today eleven playgrounds in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens. The occasion will not be marked by any ceremonies.
This day has been on the minds of hundreds of thousands of children in the city for weeks, for school will be over and they will be in a carefree world for the rest of the Summer.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- The United States Embassy in Peiping, China, made representations today to the Japanese Embassy there against indignities by Japanese soldiers against two American citizens when Japanese troops entered Peiping in considerable force last Tuesday.
Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that he would promote City Magistrate Bernard A. Kozicke of Brooklyn to succeed Justice Hyman Rayfiel of the Court of Special Sessions.
BUENOS AIRES, June 24. -- The fortnightly statement of the Central Bank of Argentina for June 15 shows the following changes in paper pesos:

PHILADELPHIA, June 25. -- The plank on foreign policy in the Democratic platform follows, in the main, President Roosevelt's own ideas on the international relations of the United States as they have been re-shaped and modified by the events and experience of the past year.

OTTAWA, June 25 (Canadian Press). -- Deposits with the Bank of Canada by the Dominion Government decreased $9,127,320 and deposits by chartered banks fell $658,418 in the week ended yesterday, compared with the previous week, the bank reported today.

SHANGHAI, Friday, June 26. -- Though the Central Government and the Canton army headquarters denied today the reports of skirmishes in Hunan Province, China appears to be inescapably nearing her most destructive civil war since the revolution began a quarter of a century ago.

The dispute at the James Monroe High School in the Bronx over the action of the principal in withholding the diplomas of two students for failure to "live up" to regulations on "personal character and citizenship" flared anew yesterday at one of the school's two commencement exercises.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 25. -- In utter defiance of the jinx that so often hovers over a tournament medalist, young Alick Gerard Jr. of Southampton, L.I., Peddie graduate, who led the qualifying field with a score of 146, is now safely in the semi-final round of the twenty-fifth annual Eastern interscholastic championship.
PHILADELPHIA, June 25 (AP). -- The Phillies and Cardinals divided a double-header today before 14,000 fans, many of them visitors to the Democratic convention.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- The Democratic National Committee has opened a campaign to encourage 115,073 government officeholders in the District of Columbia to vote in their own States, since no elections are held in the District and its residents have no vote unless they establish voting status in their home States.
Agitation against the Works Progress Administration program in New York City has been almost entirely eliminated, Victor F. Ridder, local WPA administrator, declared yesterday.

Cooperation of the Tenement House Department and the Federal Housing Administration during the last two months has benefited greatly the department and tenement owners, Langdon W. Post, Tenement House Commissioner, reported yesterday.

The share market closed lower yesterday in heavier trading. From the opening it was a tussle for leadership, steel issues on the side of the decline, and motor and oil shares on the side of the advance; the steels won out as many traders found it safer to take profits and await developments, and the market sold off quickly in the final hour so that closing prices were at or near the day's lowest marks.

Sweeping through their semi-final engagements, Charles Mattmann, top favorite, and Joseph Fishbach, ranked fourth, reached the last round in the junior singles of the annual Long Island center championships at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills yesterday.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

PHILADELPHIA, June 25. -- At a lunch counter in the convention-hall lobby this afternoon a TIMES reporter discovered Godfrey G. Gloom, the veteran Jeffersonian from Amity, Ind., thoughtfully consuming a hamburger sandwich.

PHILADELPHIA, June 25 (AP). -- Senator Smith of South Carolina walked out of the Democratic National Convention again tonight when a Negro spoke from the platform and said this time he was gone "to stay gone."

The full initial program and the opening night ceremonies, deferred because of a brief shower on Wednesday, took place last night at the Lewisohn Stadium. An audience of about 12,000 persons heard the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, directed by Jose Iturbi and with Albert Spalding as soloist, play Beethoven's music and listened to the annual introductory address of Adolph Lewisohn, honorary chairman of the Stadium Concerts committee.
PHILADELPHIA, June 25 (AP). -- Both William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, and John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, tonight praised the Democratic platform.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 25 (AP). -- With the defeat of Miss Carolin Babcock, Los Angeles, at the hands of Mrs. Hilda Krahwinkel Sperling before 17,000 spectators in the women's singles of the All-England tennis championships, Uncle Sam's main hope to keep the title vacated by Mrs. Helen Wills Moody was Miss Helen Jacobs, four-time American champion.

Included in a large volume of business space leases reported yesterday were several contracts for entire floors. A leading deal of this type involved 40,000 square feet in 498 Seventh Avenue, where the Susquehanna Silk Mills took the fourth floor.

CICELY HAMXLTON'S "Modern Ireland" (Dutton, $2.75) appears at exactly the right moment. About a month ago the British National Council for Civil Liberties issued its long-awaited report upon the Ulster "dictatorship." Some days later the Irish Free State Senate was formally ushered into the limbo of forgotten things. A week ago today the Free State outlawed the Irish Republican Army.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated., compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:
Builders who recently purchased an upper East Side site expanded their activities yesterday by acquiring a parcel similar in size directly across the street.

Various newspapers have lately been publishing letters attacking ERB employes for their efforts to achieve civil service status and job security. Permit me to point out to the writers of those letters that as a result of many surveys and investigations by private charity organizations the question of unemployment relief has come to he recognized as a permanent evil that must be dealt with in an organized manner with long-term planning.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended June 24, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,478,000,000, a decrease of $7,000,000 compared with the preceding week and an increase of $1,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1935.

Your recent editorial "Difficult Unity" in emphasizing the sectional cleavage which has split the Republican party asunder has recalled for me an ominous observation of the late Edward J. Phelps, Minister to England in the first Cleveland administration, and often humorously described as the only Democrat then living within the borders of Vermont.

James B. Shackelford, veteran explorer and former associate of Dr. Roy Chapman Andrews, curator of the American Museum of Natural History, returned to New York yesterday from an eight months' sailing trip around the world. He brought with him a collection of flint implements discovered near the Pyramids which are estimated to be more than 50,000 years old.

The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company of America and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended on Feb. 29 a net profit of $16,593,252 after depreciation and Federal taxes. This was equivalent to $7.08 a share on 2,086,748 shares of common stock, after providing for dividends on the 7 per cent preferred stock.

Private industry took 5,300 persons off the rolls of the Home Relief Bureau in May, according to the figures released yesterday by Miss Charlotte Carr, executive director of the ERB. The total was a new high for 1936, she said.

A futile attempt of an automobile driver to avoid hitting a girl playing in the street ended last night with the girl critically injured and another girl and her father also seriously hurt as the car swerved onto the sidewalk of Ninety-eighth Street, about 200 feet west of Central Park West.

DETROIT, June 25 (AP). -- Lynwood (Schoolboy) Rowe limited the Athletics to two hits today in an amazing return to form as the Tigers registered a 13-to-1 victory in the series opener. Detroit moved into fourth place with the triumph, displacing Cleveland.
CHICAGO, June 25. -- The Yankees did not exactly annihilate the White Sox today but there was enough long-range firing to bring about another satisfactory result.

RYE, N.Y., June 25. -- As the fourth annual invitation tennis tournament for Eastern boarding schools approached its final stages today at the Manursing Island Club, Kent School loomed prominently in the path of Choate, which is defending its three-year supremacy in this tourney.

DETROIT, June 25 (AP). -- William Lemke, Union party candidate for President, declared tonight after a conference with the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin that his goal was not only to split the vote of either major party, but to attain the Presidency.

According to the actual count of sales made by the Baker Taylor Company, book wholesalers, between May 18 and June 15, Mary Roberts Rinehart's novel, "The Doctor," was the best selling novel, and Dorothea Brande's "Wake Up and Live" the best selling book on the general list.

After a hearing devoted to arguments mostly in opposition to a proposed plan for the reorganization of the Warner-Quinlan Company, makers of petroleum products, under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act, Federal Judge Hulbert adjourned the case yesterday until next Wednesday.

CHICAGO, June 25. -- The market for hogs was slightly weaker in the early trading today, some sales being regarded as 5 to 10 cents a hundredweight lower, but the main trade vas steady. The top price of $10.60 and the day's average of $10 showed no change compared with Wednesday's levels.

General Sherrill's greatest pride from a sporting standpoint was that he was the inventor of the crouching start. When the general was an undergraduate at Yale all footracers used to get off their marks from a standing position. Somehow or other he figured out that he would be able to get more drive by crouching down and getting into motion from that position.

The disappearance early last Monday morning of Captain Lindsay M. Bawsel, army flier, and his three children, 5, 3 and 2 years old, from the army transport, Chateau-Thierry, still remained a mystery yesterday with the arrival of the transport at the Brooklyn Army Base pier at the foot of Fifty-eighth Street, Brooklyn.

PHILADELPHIA, June 25. -- A 100-foot section of grand stand on the parkway collapsed tonight, injuring fifty persons, while one of the largest and most boisterous crowds in Philadelphia's history struggled to see a combined Mummers' revel, military parade and mardi gras given for Democratic National Convention visitors.
The tragic loss of life in last week's Bronx apartment-house collapse focuses attention on building construction throughout the city.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., June 25. -On the undisputed theory that "an increase in happy, wholesome marriages is the only permanent solution of the divorce problem," Ernest R. Groves, pioneer in the educational field of specialization on marriage and the family and founder of this course at the University of North Carolina, predicted today the ultimate inclusion of such instruction in all college curriculums.

Frank F. Walker of Eastman, Dillon Co. was elected president of the Bond Club of New York at its annual meeting yesterday at the Bankers Club. He succeeds Ralph T. Crane, vice president of Brown Harriman Co., Inc., who headed the club for the last year.

Assailing the "reactionary leadership" of the executive council of the American Federation of Labor, Jack Stachel, a member of the central committee of the Communist party of the United States, called upon his party yesterday to pledge full support to the efforts of the federation's Committee for Industrial Organization to bring about the unionization of employes of the steel industry.
Three women who pleaded respectively to robbery, pocket-picking and burglary were sentenced in General Sessions Court yesterday to terms in the State prison for women at Bedford Hills.

KINGSTON, N.Y., June 25. -- A memorial tablet to the late J. Waldo Smith, Engineer of Water Supply for New York City from 1903 to 1933, was unveiled at noon today on a hilltop overlooking Ashokan Reservoir of the New York water supply by a committee of civil engineers.

The plight of thousands of Christian refugees who were forced to leave Germany because of their religion was described last night by Dr. Henry Smith Leiper, secretary of the American Section of the Universal Council and of the American Christian Committee for German Refugees.
BERLIN, June 25 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of June 23 is as follows, in thousands of marks, with changes from preceding week:
LONDON, June 25 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

The Cardinal Hayes Literature Committee made public yesterday a list of ninety-six titles in a Summer list of books approved for Roman Catholic readers. The list, which is divided into twelve sections, contains but twelve works of fiction.

CHICAGO, June 25 (AP). -- The drought, in the Spring Wheat Belt, has virtually cut down whatever hopes America held of returning to an export basis for the grain this year, according to some trade statisticians.

As an average citizen I am sincerely looking for guidance. To my mind the Democratic administration has proved its ability by bringing the country through a most perilous period, has saved it financially, kept people like myself sheltered and free from the pangs of hunger and, I firmly believe, averted a social revolution.

A plot in the Pelham Bay Park section of the East Bronx changed hands when Richard M. Lederer purchased six lots on the west side of Burr Avenue, 186 feet north of Westchester Avenue, from Emily Figola. The lots, which face Pelham Bay Park, will be offered for resale, according to Jacob Emil Leitner, Inc., broker in the transaction.

CHICAGO, June 25. -- Swift Co. are considering plans to sell out all interest in stockyard companies held either by the parent company or through subsidiaries, it was learned today. The stock of these properties has been held in trust since 1921 when the Supreme Court ordered all packing companies to divest themselves of their holdings in stock yards companies.

WIMBLEDON, England, June -- Fred Perry's slashing defeat John Van Ryn, American star, the all-English tennis championships so dominated the talk around the courts today that the exit of Miss Carolin Babcock of the United States in a state bordering on exhaustion after an encounter with Mrs. Hilda Krahwinkel Sperling, Danish player, passed almost unnoticed.
ST. LOUIS, June 25 (AP). -- The Senators defeated the Browns; 12 to 5, today for their third successive victory and ninth in the ten starts this season.

The two-thirds rule has played a major role in the history of the Democratic party ever since its adoption at the party's first national convention in 1832. It has survived many bitter attacks, principally because of the allegiance to it of Southern party members who felt that it gave the "Solid South" a veto power over nominations.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- President Roosevelt made known today his approval of a bill authorizing a maximum strength of 2,320 planes for the army. It was one of sixty bills approved yesterday. Three more were acted upon this morning.

The effects of the bonus payment to veterans continued to dominate the banking and currency position in the week ended on Wednesday, according to the Federal Reserve's report for that period, published yesterday. Chiefly because of net disbursements of $451,000,000 of its previously acquired balances by the Treasury, the excess reserves of member banks rose $400,000,000 to $2,440,000,000.

The main body of pivotal issues in the listed bond market reflected yesterday a lack of support, with the result that lower prices spread over a broad list at the end of the day. United States Government bonds were no exceptions and participated in the decline in the heaviest turnover in those issues this month.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., June 25. -- The younger set at the Homestead arranged for a picnic supper at the Skeet Field last night to celebrate the completion of the new clubhouse. It was held on the upper terrace. Darkies provided native music, songs and dances.

Fiscal agents for external loans of the Polish Government were notified yesterday by a special delegation of that government which arrived here a few days ago that transfers of debt service funds had been suspended temporarily. For the time being, the delegation stated, payments due under the loan agreements will be made in deposits of "blocked" zlotys in the Bank of Poland.

CHICAGO, June 25. -- Stolid Charles Kocsis of Michigan battled through thirty-eight long holes today to conquer John Levinson of Yale and remain in the battle for the national intercollegiate golf crown with the Louisiana State pair, Fred Haas Jr. and Paul Leslie, and young Willie Turnesa of Holy Cross.

A list of fifty-nine works of fiction and non-fiction outlining life in this city was furnished yesterday for applicants to civil service posts here. The list was compiled by Rebecca B. Rankin, librarian of the Municipal Reference Library, at the request of the Municipal Civil Service Commission and was published in The City Record.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 25. -- Yesterday's $400,000 jewel robbery at the W. Robertson Coe estate in Upper Brookville engaged the attention today of J. Edgar Hoover's Department of Justice agents. Two "G-men" visited the North Shore to gather details of the case.

Your editorial, on women professors opens the whole question of the American attitude toward women in the learned world. It seems to be taken for granted that men are needed on the staffs of women's colleges, but the demand for women on the staffs of men's colleges is not precisely overwhelming.

BOSTON, June 25. -- The Massachusetts Racing Commission banned photographic finishes at the Suffolk Downs racetrack today. Hereafter, the commission ruled, placing judges will decide on the order of the finish of races.

PHILADELPHIA, June 25. -- Florida's delegation insists it has the youngest member among the 1,500 delegates at the Democratic National Convention. Miss Edith Herlong, 22 years old, who has been observing the political scene since she joined the Young Democrats as a charter member for Dade County at 18, said she came to Philadelphia "to see how things really work instead of getting the information second hand through university schoolbooks."

HOYLAKE, England, June 25. -- Three favorites to win the British open golf championship -- Gene Sarazen of the United States, Henry Cotton and Alf Padgham -- ended the first round today tied with three others at 73.

CAMDEN, N.J., June 25. -- Ten more persons were arrested today, most of them on disorderly conduct charges, as a strike at the Victor division plant of the R.C.A. Manufacturing Company entered its third day.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- In another step to simplify registration under the Securities Act of 1933, the Securities and Exchange Commission sent today to interested persons for criticism and comment the tentative draft of a new form for companies organized within two years to engage in the exploitation of mineral deposits other than oil or gas.

PALMYRA, N.J., June 25. -- William S.C. Roray, 58 years old, an attorney, HOLC official and receiver of the First National Bank here, and his wife, Mrs. Florence Roray, 55, were found dead of gunshot wounds before noon today in separate bedrooms on the second floor of their home at 430 Leconey Avenue.

TOLEDO, Ohio, June 25 (AP). -- That old master, Walter Hagen, paired with youthful Ky Laffoon of the Chicago Northmoor Club and put on a par-breaking show today in the first round of the Inverness invitation best-ball tourney to tie for the lead.

PHILADELPHIA, June 25. -- The 1936 platform of the Democratic party, pledging a continuance of the social and economic objectives of the New Deal and asking a return to power on those grounds, was completed here late today and adopted unanimously by the convention late in the evening.

Women's coats and suits subject to the 3 per cent levy under the new Federal fur tax law will be sold on a "tax extra" basis, according to a decision reached by the membership of the Industrial Council of the Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc., at a meeting at the Hotel New Yorker last night.

The paper and pulp and electrical manufacturing industries are making "an exceptionally fine record in their voluntary efforts to increase employment and to maintain fair standards of wages and working hours," it was announced yesterday by George A. Sloan, chairman of the Consumers' Goods Industries Committee.

NEWARK, N.J., June 25. -- Paul Florence's single scoring Ab Wright, who opened the tenth inning with a double, gave the Baltimore Orioles a 6-to-5 victory over the Bears in the opener of a three-game series today.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., June 25. -- Miss Audrey Gray and Miss Camilla Morgan were presented to society tonight at a supper dance at Longford, the country home of Mr. and Mrs. Henry G. Gray, with Mr. and Mrs. Charles Morgan as co-hosts.
BOSTON, June 25. -- The Chicago Cubs spoiled the Boston Bees' celebration of the National League's sixtieth birthday today by winning both games of a double-header, 1 to 0 and 8 to 4.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- Quoting from the decision of the United States Supreme Court in the case of J. Edward Jones, counsel for the National Boston Montana Mines Corporation of Montana sought today to obtain from the Securities and Exchange Commission at a long hearing permission to withdraw a registration statement which it had filed under the Securities Act of 1933 soon after the law was enacted.

The Container Corporation of America resumed yesterday common dividends with the declaration of a quarterly dividend of 25 cents, payable on Aug. 15 to stock of record of July 25. The last previous payments were 30 cents quarterly, paid on Jan. 1, 1931, on the Class A common stock, and 15 cents quarterly, paid on April 1, 1929, on the Class B common then outstanding.
ITHACA, N.Y., June 25 (AP). -- James Wray confirmed tonight his dismissal as head rowing coach at Cornell University, the post he has held since 1926.

LAWRENCE, Mass., June 25. -- Two bandits were critically wounded here today in a gun battle which blocked their attempt to rob an armored bank car, and a bank employe, who took active part in the fight, was less seriously hurt. Two other robbers fled before the bullets of Abbot Corkum, the bank aide, and Inspector Timothy O'Brien, guard of the car, which carried $19,000.

WOODBURY, L.I., June 25. -- Mr. and Mrs. Ogden L. Mills gave a dinner tonight at their home to introduce to society Miss Margaret Stevenson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Stevenson of Glen Cove and a niece of Mrs. Mills.

Following is the draft of the Constitution of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, submitted by the Constitution Commission of the Central Executive Committee of the U.S.S.R. and approved by the Presidium of the Central Executive Committee of the U.S.S.R. to be presented for consideration by the All-Union Congress of Soviets, as received from Moscow:

PARIS, June 25. -- In preparation for the League of Nations' meeting at Geneva, Premier Leon Blum and Foreign Minister Yvon Delbos dined this evening with the British Foreign Secretary, Anthony Eden, at the British Embassy here.

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- The privilege of Democratic leaders at the Philadelphia convention to criticize the Supreme Court was defended today by Senator Borah, one of the court's stoutest champions, who said that no governmental institution should be beyond criticism.
NEW ORLEANS, June 25 (AP). -- T. Semmes Walmsley, political foe of Senator Huey P. Long, announced today his resignation as Mayor of New Orleans, effective Tuesday.

LOS ANGELES, June 25 (AP). -- Government prosecutors of a navy "spy plot" moved swiftly tonight toward immediate trial for a discharged navy yeoman accused of selling naval secrets to an agent of Japan.

TRENTON, N.J., June 25. -- John D.M. Hamilton, new chairman of the Republican National Committee, will confer with New Jersey leaders of the party tomorrow night at the home of Henry W. Jeffers, chairman of the State committee, at Plainsboro, but Governor Hoffman is not expected to be present.

Beside the Democratic platform adopted last night at Philadelphia let us put the program shaped two weeks ago at Cleveland, in order to find out what purposes the two parties have in common, what policies they disagree upon and what alternatives they have now offered to the country.
The conspiracy case against the five men accused of plotting to obstruct justice in the Samuel Drukman murder case will be given to the jury in Brooklyn this morning, after four weeks of trial.
GADSDEN, Ala., June 25 (AP). -- A mob stormed an organization office of the United Rubber Workers Union today, beat a number of the occupants and ordered them out of town.

New pictures come to three Broadway screens today: "San Francisco," with Jeanette MacDonald, Clark Gable and Spencer Tracy to the Capitol; "Parole," with Ann Preston and Henry Hunter to the Roxy, and "Bunker Bean," a film counterpart of the Harry Leon Wilson character, with Louise Latimer and Owen Davis Jr., to the Palace.

PHILADELPHIA, June 25. -- The action of Representative John J. O'Connor, as New York member on the rules committee, in voting against the abolition of the two-thirds rule in Democratic conventions surprised the New York delegation today.

A consolidated net income of $9,007,274 was reported yesterday by the American Power and Light Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on May 31, comparing with $5,718,549 reported for the previous year. Annual preferred dividend requirements are $9,653,484.

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 25. -- The Foreign Office dispatched last instructions this afternoon to the Chilean delegate to the League of Nations, Manuel Rivas Vicuna, for tomorrow's meeting at Geneva concerning sanctions against Italy.

With showers at only a few stations in the Southwest where moisture is needed, prices on the Cotton Exchange stiffened yesterday and closed at the top with gains of 9 to 10 points. No cotton was tendered on first July notice day here, although notices for 1,500 bales were issued in New Orleans.

Many find it hard to be patient with the ponderous and slow-moving procedure of national party conventions. They sometimes seem an immense waste of human time and effort. Why could not there be some swifter and more direct means of putting two national parties into the field in fighting trim?

The passenger departments of ship lines in the transatlantic, South American and West Indian trades were operating yesterday at high speed as final arrangements were made for one of the season's most active travel week-ends.

Through a sensational three-run rally in the last inning, topped off with Gus Mancuso's fourth homer of the season, the Giants returned to the victory column at the Polo Grounds yesterday with a 5-to-4 triumph over the Pirates.

The Russian Nobility Association announced here yesterday that it had investigated the recently announced Noblemen's Club and "is not impressed." At the Ritz Carlton Hotel, where the Russians have their offices, Prince Serge Obolensky said he spoke for "our own membership among noble Russians alone, 125 men and women -- with and without titles."
MIAMI, Fla., June 25 (AP). -- The judge who secretly married John D. Crews to Maureen Orcutt, golf star, a year ago, adjudged him in contempt of court today and sentenced him to 120 days in jail.

CAPE MAY, N.J., June 25. -- Exemption of Jews from military service "in accordance with the highest interpretation of Judaism" is sought from the United States Government in a resolution adopted tonight by the Central Conference of American Rabbis at the social justice session of the organization's forty-seventh annual convention here.

THE MUNICIPAL AUDITORIUM, PHILADELPHIA, June 25. -- A series of compromises, directed by Chairman Farley, warded off debate on the floor of the Democratic National Convention today on contests from Minnesota, Puerto Rico and the Canal Zone. Failure of the committee on credentials to report last night prevented permanent organization of the convention and forced Senator Robinson of Arkansas to speak as a delegate instead of as permanent chairman.

John H. Delaney, who has served as chairman of the Board of Transportation as a holdover since his term expired on June 30, 1934, is scheduled for reappointment for a full six-year term, starting July 1, it was reported yesterday.

CAMP TAMIMENT, Pa., June 25. -- Immediate formation of labor parties in States and municipalities as the first step toward establishment of a national labor party was urged before the Tamiment Economic and Social Institute at the opening session of its conference here tonight.

Yesterday's downward movement in stocks was touched off by overnight declines of more than a point in leading steel issues. The general market for a short time withstood the weakness in the steel group, and then declined rather steadily until the close.

With twenty-eight men already qualified for places in the final Olympic tryouts at Randalls Island on July 11 and 12 as a result of performances in the National Collegiate A.A. championships last week-end, the battle for 108 more places in the finals will be begun today on three far-flung fronts as semi-final Olympic track and field tests are staged in Cambridge, Milwaukee and Los Angeles.

Professor E. Adelaide Hahn, Latin and Greek scholar, who has been teaching at Hunter College for twenty years, has been appointed head of the Department of Classics there, it was announced today by Dr. Eugene A. Colligan, president of the college. Professor Hahn has been acting head of the department since the retirement of Dr. Ernst Riess in February.

ESTES PARK, Col., June 25. -- A vacation trip which turned into a miniature campaign tour ended this afternoon with Governor Landon, Republican Presidential nominee, and his family resting comfortably at the McGraw ranch, six miles from here, in the heart of Colorado's Rockies.

LATONIA, Ky., June 24 (AP). -- The second largest daily double in the history of the combination in Kentucky, surpassed only by one at Churchill Downs last Spring, injected a punch into what otherwise was a listless card today at Latonia.

PHILADELPHIA, June 25. -- Dr. Francis E. Townsend came to Philadelphia to look in on the Democratic National Convention, found it "only a lot of smoke and noise," and checked out this morning, saying that his old-age pension movement "may have to nominate a man of our own."

WASHINGTON, June 25. -- A summary issued today by the Securities and Exchange Commission showed that the value of transactions on all registered Securities Exchanges in May, amounting to $1,432,039,743, was 34.6 per cent less than the value of trading in April and 7.6 per cent below the figures for May, 1935.

Disquieting reports of failure by the Bureau of Air Commerce adequately to administer the Federal aids to aviation which are so important a part of the safety of air transportation are now brought to a head by the preliminary report filed by the Senate Committee on Commerce and signed by Senators COPELAND, CLARK and DONAHEY.
THE MUNICIPAL AUDITORIUM, PHILADELPHIA, June 25. -- Following is the text of the platform as adopted by the Democratic National Convention:...

John H. Delaney, who has served as chairman of the Board of Transportation as a holdover since his term expired on June 30, 1934, is scheduled for reappointment for a full six-year term, starting July 1, it was reported yesterday.

CAMP TAMIMENT, Pa., June 25. -- Immediate formation of labor parties in States and municipalities as the first step toward establishment of a national labor party was urged before the Tamiment Economic and Social Institute at the opening session of its conference here tonight.

Yesterday's downward movement in stocks was touched off by overnight declines of more than a point in leading steel issues. The general market for a short time withstood the weakness in the steel group, and then declined rather steadily until the close.

With twenty-eight men already qualified for places in the final Olympic tryouts at Randalls Island on July 11 and 12 as a result of performances in the National Collegiate A.A. championships last week-end, the battle for 108 more places in the finals will be begun today on three far-flung fronts as semi-final Olympic track and field tests are staged in Cambridge, Milwaukee and Los Angeles.
WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP). -- The radio amateur had his hour today before the Federal Communications Commission.

PHILADELPHIA, June 26. -- Vice President Garner set the pace and the style for a large list of Democrats who stepped before the microphones tonight at the Penn Athletic Club to address massed young Democratic clubs from all parts of the nation.

The golden jubilee convention of the New York State Christian Endeavor Union will be held in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., beginning next Friday and continuing through Monday. A feature will be a youth parade next Saturday afternoon. In the procession the New York City Christian Endeavor Union will have an "international group" in national costumes, carrying their national flags. The same evening there will be a dinner.

The governing committee of the New York Stock Exchange adopted yesterday the recommendation of the committee on stock list to list 754,105 shares of no-par capital stock of General Theatres Equipment Corporation, issued, in accordance with the company's reorganization plan.

NEWARK, N.J., June 26. -- The Baltimore Orioles made it two in a row over the league-leading Newark Bears with a 6-4 triumph tonight. Cliff Melton, first ranking pitcher of the league, limited the Bears to seven hits and struck out eight.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for' savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

CHICAGO, June 26. -- The Chicago North Western Railway Company filed today a plan of reorganization under the National Bankruptcy Act in the United States District Court. The plan calls for a wholesale recasting of the railroad's financial structure and a drastic scaling down of its fixed-income-bearing debt which the company has not been able to carry for several years because of the heavy shrinkage in its revenue.

BOSTON, June 26 (AP). -- Houghton Metcalf's Good Flavor, a 47-to-1 shot, lasted gamely to score by a neck over Mrs. H.J. Mohr's Bob's Boys in the mile of the New England Turf Writers' Handicap today at Suffolk Downs. W. Elliott's Miss Careful was third, a half a length back and three in front of the Mulvhill Brothers' Mountainy Man.

PHILADELPHIA, June 26. -- The platform adopted by the Democratic convention last night was attacked today by one national organization and questioned in several particulars by another, but meanwhile the delegates voiced almost unanimous approval of its pledge of continuance of New Deal activities.

WASHINGTON, June 26. -- To meet objections raised to its regulations the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve Board today announced amendments effective on July 1 to facilitate loans between banks and brokers. The changes made, however, do not affect the 55 per cent margin level now in force.
HARTFORD, June 26. -- "Absolutely no such thing," was Governor Cross's comment tonight when asked about reports that he had left the Democratic convention in a pique. He was a delegate-at-large.

PHILADELPHIA, June 26. -- Bobbing up one by one out of the pandemonium like swimmers tossed up from the breakers of color and din, the Roosevelt children staged an exuberant reunion this morning at the height of the demonstration which greeted their father's nomination.

FREE CITY OF DANZIG, June 26 (AP). -- A Nazi declaration of independence amounting to a virtual demand that the League of Nations withdraw its supervision from Danzig will be published here and throughout Germany simultaneously tomorrow.

DUBLIN, June 26. -- There were wild scenes in Dublin tonight when extremist Republicans turned up in force to demonstrate at a government party meeting on College Green addressed by Sean Lemass, Minister of Industry and Commerce.

As the site for two six-story apartment houses the plot 250 by 100 feet on the west side of Barker Avenue, about 500 feet north of Pelham Parkway, has been sold by the Bank of the Manhattan Company to a client of John J. Reynolds, broker. The buildings will be of the garden type and will contain elevators.

THE MUNICIPAL AUDITORIUM, PHILADELPHIA, June 26. -- Mayor Hague of Jersey City, National Committeeman, predicted tonight that President Roosevelt would carry New Jersey by a larger plurality than he did in 1932, when the figure was about 35,000 votes.

After prevailing upon Victor F. Ridder to continue until Aug. 1 as local WPA Administrator, a post Mr. Ridder had intended to leave on July 1, Harry L. Hopkins, Federal WPA Administrator, said here yesterday that he would announce in Washington next week the appointment of Mr. Ridder's successor.

WASHINGTON, June 26. -- The Protective Committee for Secured Gold Debentures, 5 1/2 per cent series due in 1953, of the American Community Power Company was exempted today from the provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935 by the Securities and Exchange Commission as temporarily occupying the capacity of a holding company solely because of the acquisition of securities for purposes of liquidation or distribution.

YELLOW SPRINGS, Ohio, June 26. -- Celebrating its eighty-third year and about to hold its eightieth commencement, Antioch College inaugurated as its president this afternoon Algo Donmyer Henderson. The first president of the college was Horace Mann.
THE MUNICIPAL AUDITORIUM, PHILADELPHIA, June 26. -- The speech of Governor Lehman of New York seconding the nomination of President Roosevelt was as follows:

WASHINGTON. June 26. -- For the first time in many months the Federal Reserve Board's seasonally adjusted index of industrial production for May showed an increase over the 1923-25 average. For May the index registered 101 per cent of the 1923-25 average, compared with 100 per cent in April.

Judge Mortimer W. Byers, in the Federal court in Brooklyn, yesterday granted the final decree in the reorganization proceedings of the James Butler Grocery Company of Long Island City. The order putting the decree into effect will be signed as soon as copies of the decree have been served on all the interested parties.

A Washington Heights deal was reported yesterday by Maurice Wurtzel, operator, who purchased the six-story Shenandoah Apartments at 400 Fort Washington Avenue, southeast corner of West 178th Street. This is an elevator building on a plot 105 by 100 feet.

The renomination of FRANKLIN D. ROOSEVELT has been foreordained for many months. Long before the first delegates arrived at Philadelphia it was certain that no other name would be placed in nomination and no other hand would guide at every point the proceedings of the convention.

Sermons will be preached tomorrow on patriotic and national issues. The patriotic note will be due to the fact that a week from today will be Independence Day. The national note is because today will close the National Democratic Convention in Philadelphia following that of the Republican party in Cleveland.

PEIPING, June 26. -- A Japanese military spokesman declared today that the Japanese Embassy would reply in a day or two to protests of the American and French Embassies against alleged rough treatment of their citizens by Japanese soldiers here.

THE MUNICIPAL AUDITORIUM, PHILADELPHIA, Saturday, June 27. -- With two prolonged demonstrations for Governor Herbert H. Lehman and another for President Roosevelt, the Democratic National Convention, at its session which ended nearly an hour after midnight this morning, attempted by a frank show of its enthusiasm to tie together the personalities of these two leaders for the campaign.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 26. -- Sensational golf on the part of Eddie Driggs Jr., former New York State champion, enabled his team to lead the qualifiers in the Cherry Valley Club's invitation best-ball tournament today.

Miss Helen Louise Helm gave a dinner last night in the Rainbow Room, Rockefeller Center, for Miss Elizabeth Jane Arnold and Frank Arnold L'Hommedieu, whose engagement has been announced. Other guests were the Misses Averett, Elizabeth Helms and Janet Weed; Norman Dix, Walter Krementz, William Dane.

PHILADELPHIA, June 26. -- Jovial Jack Garner, Vice President, arrived here at 7 o'clock tonight to participate with President Roosevelt in the notification ceremonies tomorrow night. Escorted by 175 mounted policemen from the Thirtieth Street station, he was cheered by the crowds, whose attention was attracted by shrieking sirens as he and the reception committee proceeded to his hotel.

A new offering of $50,000,000 debentures of the Consolidated Oil Corporation will be made by an underwriting group probably on Tuesday. These debentures, which bear a 3 1/2 per cent rate and are due on June 1, 1951, it developed yesterday, will be priced around 98. It is understood that Kuhn, Loeb Co. will head the offering syndicate.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 26. -- Eulace Peacock's dream of a double Olympic conquest vanished in the sultry air of Harvard Stadium today as the Negro youth who broke the world's 100-meter dash and broad-jump records in a single afternoon last year failed to qualify for the final Olympic track and field tryouts.

Cardinal Hayes announced yesterday the first of his annual assignment of chaplains for nearly 100 non-sectarian camps in the Archdiocese of New York. The announcement was made through the Rev. Dr. Edward Roberts Moore, director of the Division of Social Action of the Cardinal's Catholic Charities organization.

The drive to "draft" Governor Lehman at the Democratic National Convention is being watched closely by New York State Republican leaders, it was learned yesterday. They are holding up plans to shape their own course pending the outcome of the move.

Herbert Agar, author of the Pulitzer Prize winning "The People's Choice" and co-editor with Allen Tate of "Who Owns America?" has just signed a contract with his publishers, Houghton Mifflin, to write a history of the Democratic party.
CALGARY, June 26. -- King Edward VIII may find himself the owner of rich Southern Alberta oil lands, it became known today with developments in the search for the true crude oil pool in Alberta.

Mervin LeRoy has finally attained his pet ambition, which, incidentally, has been a matter of controversy for some months. Warners have consented to the young director's pleas for his own production unit, and after he completes their film transcription of "Three Men on a Horse" Mr. LeRoy will make "Balboa" independently for release through the Warner distribution channels.

BOSTON, June 26. -- The nation's baseball fans booted twenty of their 1935 major league all-star idols onto the sidelines for this year's fixture here July 7, announcement of the personnel of the two squads revealed tonight.

SHANGHAI, June 26. -- Facing the dire prospect of civil war on an unprecedented scale, likely to break out at almost any moment, the Central Government is also certain to receive soon demands of the utmost severity from Japan, resulting from the firing Upon two Japanese vessels by Chinese customs cutters.

From the roar of the Cave of Winds at Philadelphia the seeker of rest turns gladly to Nature, to the charm of colors, the soft speech of flowers; more specifically, to the New Hampshire Concord. Colonel KNOX'S Manchester Union views the landscape o'er and sings:

TRENTON, N.J., June 26. -- William A. Anderson of Princeton was elected today president of the John A. Roebling's Sons Company, manufacturer of bridge and other cables, to succeed the late Ferdinand W. Roebling Jr. It is the first time that the company has been headed by any one other than a member of the family.

HOYLAKE, England, June 26. -- American stock depreciated slightly in the second round of the British Open Golf championship today, with Gene Sarazen, American favorite, scoring 148, four shots behind the leaders, Bill Cox and Jim Adams, British professionals.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., June 26. -- An exhibition of East Hampton's antiques and historic places, arranged as a part of East Hampton's celebration of Long Island's tercentenary, opened today in Clinton Academy. Samuel C. Hedges, president of the East Hampton Historical Society, aided by Miss Alice Dayton and Mrs. Miriam Shaw and Edward Strong, arranged the exhibition.

Interest due on July 1 on the 8 per cent bonds of the Polish Government and the 7 per cent bonds of the Province of Silesia, and that due on Oct 15 on the 7 per cent bonds of the Polish Government will be paid as usual in dollars, it was made known yesterday at the office of the Polish Embassy.

Delegates from the Communist party will not be permitted to take the floor at the Socialist State Convention here today and tomorrow to present a plea for joint Socialist-Communist nominations for Congressional and some local candidates, the Socialist State Committee decided last night at the party headquarters, 21 East Seventeenth Street.
The directors of the Amerex Holding Corporation declared yesterday a dividend of 50 cents a share, payable on Aug. 1 to stockholders of record of July 15.

CHICAGO, June 26 (AP). -- Charles Kocsis, Michigan's Big Ten champion, turned on another dazzling stretch finish today to conquer Willie Turnesa of Holy Cross in thirty-seven holes and enter the final of the national intercollegiate title golf tournament with Paul Leslie of Louisiana State, who upset his favored team-mate, Fred Haas Jr., 5 and 4.

The Associated Marine Workers, an American Federation of Labor organization, charged yesterday through counsel in Federal court that two other A.F. of L. unions, both of which are engaged in a dispute with Russell Brothers Towing Co., Inc., had been guilty of "chiseling in" on its territory.

UNION CITY, N.J., June 26. -- Despondent because he had failed in his year's school work and would not be promoted, a 15-year-old boy attempted suicide by swallowing poison here today in his classroom in the Lincoln School.

A brisk rally in railway shares in the final hour saved yesterday's stock market from being reported as commonplace. During the first four hours of the trading day prices fluctuated narrowly; steel issues moved lower but the pressure was by no means as insistent as on Thursday.

WASHINGTON, June 26. -- The income of American farmers for May was put at $572,000,000, including cash and Federal payments, in a bulletin issued today by the Department of Agriculture's Bureau of Economics. The amount was declared to be the highest for that month since 1930.

Echoes of the controversy in the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America, which resulted in a group breaking away and forming the Presbyterian Church of America, were heard yesterday afternoon at the annual meeting of the Presbyterian League of Faith in the Broadway Presbyterian Parish House, 601 West 114th Street.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., June 26. -- A par-shattering inward nine score of 35, which gave him a 74, enabled Tommy Goodwin of Winged Foot, a former New York State amateur champion, to capture the medal in the qualifying round of the annual invitation tournament at the Briar Hills Golf and Country Club today.

Officials of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, the Merchants Association of New York City, the New York Board of Trade and the Manufacturers Association of Connecticut joined yesterday with individual shippers in supporting before the Interstate Commerce Commission the application of Eastern railroads for establishment of complete free door-to-door pick-up and delivery of less-than-carload freight.

MANCHESTER, N.H., June 26 (AP). -- Colonel Frank Knox of Chicago, addressing a rally in his honor as Republican Vice Presidential nominee, pledged himself tonight to support six points of government policy for which he said New England long has stood.
Statewide reductions in certain rates, tolls and charges of the New York Telephone Company designed to save subscribers $4,152,000 annually were ordered yesterday by the Public Service Commission.

The American Institute of Steel Construction is planning ceremonies later in the year for the unveiling of plaques on the three bridges chosen by that organization as the most beautiful spans erected in the past year.
LONDON, June 26. -- The news of the suspension of service on the Polish debt resulted in a heavy fall in Polish bonds here today.

LYNCH, Neb., June 26 (AP). -- Fresh evidence hinting that pre-Columbian American civilization extended back possibly as much as forty centuries was discovered today by a University of Nebraska archaeological expedition exploring the site of an ancient city.

PHILADELPHIA, June 26. -- A large number of contracts for textile and garment supplies for the Army Civilian Conservation Corps, on which bids were opened early this week, today were awarded at the Quartermaster Depot as follows:

Alexander K. Goldman's criticism of the attitude of the Upper Harlem Taxpayers Association toward that provision of the Multiple Dwelling Law which requires fire-retarding in the old-law tenements shows a lack of understanding of the problems presented by that phase of the law.
Eight liners sailing today for Europe will carry 6,500 passengers in all classes.

CHICAGO, June 26. -- Swift Co. and John Dewitt, a local investment banker, who formerly maintained a brokerage business in New York City, today confirmed reports that negotiations are under way for the sale of the company's stockyards holdings to Mr. Dewitt, but they denied that the deal had been closed.

With July coming over the horizon and the weather much too warm for any trail blazing, activity in the nocturnal haunts these evenings finds itself generally confined to the lifting of tall, cool drinks and an occasional replacement of entertainers.
The Continental Bank and Trust Company has been appointed registrar for the convertible $3 preferred stock of no-par value of the Consolidated Aircraft Corporation.

PHILADELPHIA, June 26. -- The new party under the old name has been born. Its new rules take the veto power from the old South, its new platform gives all reserve power to the President. It is, in essence and politically, the creature of Hamilton; its Jeffersonian ideal is to establish approximate economic equality even if it must deny to the average man much political liberty.

SOUTI-IA_MPT01, L. I., June 26.7 Mrs. Arthur Y3. Claflin gave a dinner and bridge tonight at her home in the Shinnecock Hills for Mrs. T. Charles FarreIly, who has joined her and Mr. Claflin for a visit.

WASHINGTON, June 26. -- The Narragansett Electric Company, Providence, R.I., has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering $34,000,000 of Series A, 3 1/2 per cent bonds, due on July 1, 1966, and to be used for refinancing purposes. The price to the public, names of the underwriters and the underwriting discounts or commissions are to be furnished later.

Three large rallies, headed by a Madison Square Garden gathering, will be conducted tonight by Democratic organizations of the city to assemble crowds to listen to broadcasts from Philadelphia of President Roosevelt's acceptance speech.

MILWAUKEE, June 26. -- Glen Morris of the Denver Athletic Club captured the lead in the American decathlon trials by making the best mark among sixteen entries in the high jump at the Central Olympic track and field semi-final trials in the Marquette Stadium tonight.
WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) . -- John Hamilton, the Republican national chairman, told reporters today that he would like to know how many "mental walkouts" had occurred at the Democratic convention.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP). -- AAA officials said today that the administration definitely planned to offer farmers optional crop insurance in connection with soil conservation benefit payments despite failure of the Democratic national platform to recommend it.

MANHASSET, L.I., June 26. -- More than 3,000 persons, including many children, attended the fifteenth annual circus and lawn fete this afternoon at Greentree, the estate of Mrs. Payne Whitney, for the benefit of the Milk Fund of the New York Hospital Social Service Department and the Family Welfare Association of Nassau County. Special traffic officers guarded the gates of Northern Boulevard and handled the cars that streamed into the grounds.
What several London papers have termed "a grave picture of Britain's danger from the air" was drawn by Professor F.A. Lindemann of Oxford in a London lecture the other day.

THE MUNICIPAL AUDITORIUM, PHILADELPHIA, June 26. -- Campaignomania, an occupational disease common to politicians at recurrent intervals, notably in Presidential years, broke out on the floor of the Democratic convention today and spread rapidly until a large proportion of the visitors in the balconies was infected.

If the stock market gave any definite response yesterday to the publication of the Democratic party's platform, brokers were unable to discern it. It might be said that the market came as close to ignoring the platform completely as was possible in the circumstances.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., June 26. -- Dwight F. Rockwell of the Oakland Golf Club won the Metropolitan Senior Golf Championship at the Englewood Golf Club today when he shot a 78 to add to his first round of 76. The total of 154 for the 36-hole event was seven strokes better than that recorded in any year since this event was inaugurated in 1928.

Curt Davis was up to his old Philadelphia tricks at the Polo Grounds yesterday. The rangy right-hander from Azuza, Calif., who used to cause the Giants no end of embarrassment when he played under the banner of Jimmy Wilson, made his first appearance in Harlem as a member of the Chicago Cubs, and promptly proceeded to wield the old influence.

Retail trade continued notably active in the metropolitan area during the week despite the cool weather, which had a slight effect in holding down expansion of Summer apparel sales. Retailers here estimated a gain of 10 to 12 per cent in dollar volume over the corresponding period a year ago.

The United States Polo Association announced yesterday the revival of what formerly was one of its popular tournaments. This is the national intercircuit championship, for 12-goal teams, which will be held this Summer at the Hunting Valley Polo Club in Cleveland, as one of the sports features for the Great Lakes Exposition.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 26 (AP). -- Guido C.V. Di Madrone, a member of the Italian Senate, said today that "judging by the rate at which civilization is rushing to its doom," no time should be lost in devising a substitute for the League of Nations.

The placing of a $500,000 wager by a foreigner at odds of 5 to 6 that President Roosevelt would not be re-elected was reported yesterday by Dow, Jones Co. A syndicate of eight Americans was reported to have put up the $600,000 necessary to cover the bet.
The Consolidated Edison Company of New York paid $311,400 last year to fourteen trustees and directors, according to its annual report filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

While THE TIMES did not go to extremes in predicting the outcome of the Schmeling-Louis fight, James P. Dawson, in one of his stories, picked a knockout by Louis, and John Kieran, in his column, went even further than Dawson.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., June 26. -- The rapidly rising birth rate in regions unsuited to an increase in population was emphasized today in an address by Dr. W.F. Ogburn of the University of Chicago before the Institute on Regional Developments.

PHILADELPHIA, June 26. -- An authoritative account tonight of the secret deliberations of the Democratic platform committee disclosed that the constitutional plank was a compromise and that a flat declaration for a constitutional amendment was almost inserted.
A protest against Mayor La Guardia's plan to set up a City Hall in the Bronx for the Summer was made yesterday by a delegation of 200 unemployed at a City Hall demonstration.

CAMDEN, N.J., June 26. -- Twelve persons were injured and twenty-four were arrested late this afternoon when workers emerging in a body from the Victor division plant of the R.C.A. Manufacturing Company were attacked by strikers and sympathizers.

Resisting the usual seasonal influences, both production and distribution in the major lines showed no recession of consequence this week from the previous week's levels, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. Retail sales, which were maintained chiefly by regular purchasing, began to show more of the stimulus of bonus-money spending, the agency states.

A complaint of disorderly conduct against Cleo Long of 25 West Forty-sixth Street was dismissed in West Side Court yesterday after she had signed a promise on the back of the summons promising to discontinue the bread line for pigeons she has been conducting three times a day in Forty-sixth Street between Fifth and Sixth Avenues.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP). -- The Interstate Commerce Commission ordered today seven Class I railroads operating from the Port of New York to revise warehousing and handling practices, which it said violated the Interstate Commerce Act.

CLEVELAND, June 26 (AP). -- Joe Vosmik broke up a free-hitting game in the tenth inning today, smashing a home run over the wall in right center field to give the Indians an 8-to-7 victory over the Red Sox.

CHICAGO, June 26 (AP). -- Heat of 100 degrees overspread wide reaches of the Western plains today, facilitating new inroads by the June drought, now termed by Federal relief authorities "apparently worse than that of 1934."

RYE, N.Y., June 26. -- For the second time within three weeks golfing members of the Retail Dry Goods Association and the New York Publishers Association today tried to surpass Leroy Clark Palmer's efforts on the links, but their attempts proved considerably inferior to those flashed by the vice president of Oppenheim, Collins Co.

CHICAGO, June 26. -- Four gunmen today held up two New York jewelry dealers and a private detective guarding them, slugged one of the dealers, kidnapped both and escaped with gems valued at $100,000 after leading a police squad on a wild six-mile chase through the heart of the city.

LOS ANGELES, June 28 (AP). -- With most of the 5,000 fans howling in derision, the opening program of the Far Western Olympic track and field tryouts was sharply curtailed tonight because stars whose entries were expected failed to show up.

President Roosevelt's selection of a research committee to study the consumers' cooperative movement in Europe will be hailed by many who have been intrigued by the successful cooperatives of Sweden and Denmark. The recent book "Sweden, the Middle Way," by Marquis Childs has done much to create interest in the Scandinavian system.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 26. -- Persistency was rewarded today when trim Alick Gerard Jr., recently graduated from Peddie, gained the Eastern interscholastic golf championship by defeating 17-year-old Tommy Pierce of Clark, 3 and 2, in the eighteen-hole final at the Greenwich Country Club.

The second concert of the series at the Lewisohn Stadium, which was devoted entirely to Russian orchestra, compositions, was given last night before an audience of 4,500 persons. In the absence of Joss Iturbi, who had gone to Philadelphia to conduct at the Robin Hood Dell, Alexander Smallens assumed the responsibilities of batonist.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 26. -- Exaggerated, ignorant, and intolerant national pride in all nations is the leading cause of war, according to Dr. Chengting T. Wang of Shanghai, veteran Cabinet member, Prime Minister in several Chinese administrations and a district governor of Rotary International.

BERLIN, June 26. -- The Boerse continued quiet today. Heavy industrial shares were advanced by the favorable Rheinstahl dividend report, Rheinstahl itself gaining 5 points and Vereinigtestahl 1 1/2. Potash stocks also were firm on a small turnover.

If the result of the Schmeling-Louis fight does nothing more than to restore the sanity of the experts generally it will have accomplished what every true sport lover has been hoping for these many years. Never within the memory of boxing fans did newspaper writers go so completely berserk over a heavyweight championship prospect as in the case of Joe Louis.

IN the merry month of May the esteemed Karl Johann Grimm, painter, woodworker, musician and manager of the Chicago Cubs, was around these parts wearing a dark suit and a melancholy expression. It's different now. He is around again with a light suit and a light heart. If things continue to improve, he probably will have his banjo with him on his next trip.

Howard S. Cullman, vice president of the National Committee on Safety at Sea, rejected yesterday the proposal of Paul Scharrenberg, legislative representative of the International Seamen's Union, that he support opponents of the newly enacted Load-Line Bill which is in the hands of President Roosevelt awaiting signature.

Business of wholesale firms in this district last month was 1 per cent under the May, 1935, total, the decrease in more than a year, according to trade figures issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

PARIS, June 26. -- No sooner had it been announced that the sailors' strike in the harbor of Marseilles had been settled than workers in the St. Nazaire navy yards, following the sailors' example, raised the red flag over the shipbuilding plants today.

CAPE MAY, N.J., June 26. -- "Religious objection to the policy of any State which strikes at the very practice of religion, specifically the treatment of Catholics in our sister republic of Mexico," was expressed here tonight by the Central Conference of American Rabbis at its annual convention, when it approved a recommendation submitted by the committee on resolutions.

WATERTOWN, Conn., June 26. -- Victories by Woodfellow, the Wynfromere Farm's noted timber-topper which has been an outstanding winner this season, and Double Entry, owned by the Moreland Stables of Durham, Conn., in the two major hunter classes staged today featured the opening session of the tenth annual Watertown Horse Show.

RED BANK, N.J., June 26. -- Mrs. Maude L. Fish, 60 years old, and her 2-year-old granddaughter, Ann Lovett, were burned to death early today at Little Silver, near here, when their home was destroyed by fire. Three other members of the family escaped.

Father Knickerbocker, the reprobate, seems to be sliding back again into his old noisy habits. At first Mayor LA GUARDIA'S campaign made a considerable dint in the din. Lately the public's response has been comparatively feeble. Radios are in full blast again in some localities and many taxicab drivers are forgetting the pledges they made.

Othmar Schmidt, 62 years old, of 1,848 Patterson Avenue, the Bronx, was sentenced by Judge Donnellan in General Sessions yesterday to a penitentiary term up to three years on his plea of guilty to the theft of $6 from the Municipal Court in West Fifty-fourth Street in August, 1932.

J. Crawford Stevens, president, and Reginald P. Ray, vice president, of the defunct Westchester Title and Trust Company, were found guilty at 12:20 A.M. today on all counts of a twenty-count mail fraud indictment by a Federal court jury which had deliberated for more than eight hours.

WASHINGTON, June 26. -- President Roosevelt hinted today of early settlement of the question as to how long Postmaster General Farley would remain in the dual position of Cabinet member and chairman of the Democratic National Committee.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week amounts to only $6,948,427 by forty-three municipalities, the smallest volume for a week this year. This week's revised total was $25,735,148 and the weekly average for the year to date stands at $23,982,527.

In one respect both of the national conventions this year have been timid and disappointing. They have seemed to be under a sort of panic fear regarding anything that might be called international. On that subject scarcely a whisper was permitted in either platform.

TRENTON, N.J., June 26. -- Nearly 300 Republican men and women gathered at the dairy farm of their State chairman, Henry W. Jeffers, at Plainsboro tonight to meet John D.M. Hamilton, the party's new national chairman, and hear him deliver an inspirational campaign talk in the interests of Governor Alf M. Landon's candidacy for President.
GENEVA, June 26. -- Geneva gave Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia a cordial welcome today.

BROOI{VILLE, L. I., June 26.-Mr. and Mrs. John C. Hughes Jr. of 63 East Seventy-fourth Street, New York, gave a dinner dance tonight at Green Court, the country place of Mr. and Mrs. J. Norman de 1%. Whitehouse, which they ae occupying for the season, to introduce to society Mrs. Hughes's daughter, Miss Jamie Porter.

Black bass fishing starts in New York, Connecticut and Pennsylvania next Wednesday. In New Jersey the ban went off two weeks ago. In other States throughout the East and in Canada angling for the bronzebacks will be in full swing during the coming week.

Mayor La Guardia, it was learned yesterday, on Tuesday removed from office John J. Pizzi, a city marshal, who has been sought by authorities for almost a month since he vanished after having been questioned by Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts, with regard to misappropriation of $989.33 in garnishees he was alleged to have collected.

The Rev. Dr. J.L. Dodds of Saharanpur, North India, has accepted election as a secretary of the Presbyterian Board of Foreign Missions, with headquarters at 156 Fifth Avenue, this city. A cablegram was received there from him yesterday announcing his acceptance.

The full text of Soviet Russia's new Constitution as it will come up for approval next Fall appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday. A detailed summary of the new charter from our Moscow correspondent appeared some time ago.

As the Lord's Day Alliance of the United States a quarter-century ago led the movement which eventuated in the closing of first and second class post-offices on Sunday, permit us to reply to the letter of Joseph Lewis.

Joseph Fishbach and Marvin Kantrowitz, the first two players on the city P.S.A.L. championship DeWitt Clinton High School net squad, won the Long Island Center junior doubles title at Forest Hills yesterday, defeating Charles Mattmann and Art Nielsen Jr. of the West Side Tennis Club, 6 -- 2, 3 -- 6, 5 -- 7, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 1.

Since sports experts are admitting that they have made some mistakes in their estimates of Joe Louis, I am wondering if they will give the real colored athlete the break he deserves. I refer to Jesse Owens.

Commodity futures generally were lower on the local markets yesterday. Hides, tallow and cottonseed oil were slightly higher. On the cash markets cotton sold at a new high price and declines appeared in all the grains, lard, butter, eggs, rubber and tins. The latter sold at new low levels.

The Brooklyn blue ribbon jury which listened for four weeks to testimony in the Drukman conspiracy trial had not yet agreed, at 3:30 A.M. today, on verdicts for the five defendants charged with plotting to obstruct justice in the Samuel Drukman murder case.

WILLIAM CHURCH OSBORN, who among his many outstanding public activities continues to serve as president of the Children's Aid Society, in his foreword to the eighty-third annual report makes this significant observation:
Champions retained their titles in two routine victories in the second day of the women's National A.A.U. swimming championships at the Oriental Pool, Manhattan Beach, yesterday.

CAMP TAMIMENT, Pa., June 26. -- Adoption by the Democratic convention of a platform plank pledging the party to seek, if necessary, a constitutional amendment to enable social and economic legislation was hailed as a victory for labor at today's session of the Tamiment Economic and Social Institute.

The Lafayette Theatre has become one of the brightest spots in Harlem. Perhaps more than that, for also it is bright on the books of the WPA's Federal Theatre Project. Its bills have all been of value -- some more than others, of course, but none simply run off for the sake of filling an empty stage on Seventh Avenue.

THE MUNICIPAL AUDITORIUM, PHILADELPHIA, Saturday, June 27. -- After more than eight hours of eulogistic oratory and demonstrations, which kept the Democratic National Convention in session from 1 P.M. yesterday until 12:55 o'clock this morning, Franklin Delano Roosevelt was nominated for re-election by acclamation.

A postponed plaint by the pessimistic Frankle Frisch, leader of the Cardinals, that "the Dodgers are always tough for us," seemed scarcely justified after his Gashouse Gang had finished with the hapless Flatbush athletes at Ebbets Field yesterday.

THE MUNICIPAL AUDITORIUM, PHILADELPHIA, June 26. -- Declaring that the opposition to the New Deal came from the same great financial interests that brought on the depression, John E. Mack of Poughkeepsie put before the Democratic National Convention today the name of Franklin Delano Roosevelt, his personal friend, as a candidate for renomination as President.

The Standard Oil Company of California has entered into agreement with the Texas Corporation for marketing the Standard's crude oil produced east of the Suez Canal and the petroleum products from the refinery now being built on the Island of Bahrein in the Persian Gulf, said a joint announcement made yesterday by K.R. Kingsbury, president of Standard of California, and Captain T. Rieber, chairman of the Texas Corporation.
I have just listened to Senator Robinson's convention speech in defense of the New Deal and "economic liberty." "O Liberty," he cried, "what crimes are committed in thy name!"

HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 26. -- The race committee boat of the Royal Bermuda Yacht Club, out today to check the finish of the race from Newport, sighted a schooner believed to be one of the contestants, but later sent word in from off St. David's Head that the vessel apparently was the Chauve Souris, owned by J.H. Winfield of Halifax, N.S., which was not in the race.

PHILADELPHIA, June 26. -- The $200,000 certified check with which Philadelphians, Democrats and Republicans alike, enticed the Democratic National Convention to their city is paying dividends in cash and good-will.

I am a retired soldier, 66 years old, and I am interested in prizefights only for scientific reasons. If writers had consulted any reliable astrologer in regard to the Sehmeling-Louis fight it would not have turned out to be such a surprise to them.

HACKENSACK, N.J., June 26. -- Top seeded players in the New Jersey State tennis championships for women advanced to the final round on the courts of the Oritani Field Club today when Miss Norma Taubele of New York, seeded No. 1, defeated Miss Elizabeth Blackman of Detroit, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 4, and Miss Eunice Dean of San Antonio won from Miss Germaine of New York, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4.

PHILADELPHIA, June 26. -- Five militant Fundamentalist clergymen who helped organize the new Presbyterian Church of America were "deposed" today by the Philadelphia Presbytery of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America, after a debate lasting more than an hour. Some members of the Presbytery urged moderation and suggested that "a year's grace" be allowed the men, but proponents of "firm action" eventually won.

MADRID, June 26. -- The Cabinet Council today approved a credit of 1,000,000 pesetas for the government program to abolish all public instruction by religious orders in Spain and for the substitution of lay teachers.

ESTES PARK, Col., June 26. -- Governor Landon began the first full day of his vacation this morning by getting up at 6 o'clock, donning his wading boots and other fishing togs and getting in a bit of serious fishing in the trout stream which flows near the McGraw ranch-house.

Mrs. Marie McDowell, widow of Edward G. McDowell Jr., artist who died at Summit, N.J., Feb. 18, 1926, leaving her $5,000 and giving the Art Students' League $250,000 to establish traveling art scholarships, filed suit in the Supreme Court yesterday against the league for an accounting of the fund.
Various housing and business properties were included in the Queens realty deals reported yesterday.

Eighty oil paintings by eighty WPA artists will be placed on public exhibition today at the WPA Federal Art Project Gallery, 7 East Thirty-eighth Street, where the show will continue daily from 10 A.M. to 7 P.M. through July 24.

The Loblaw Groceterias Company, Ltd., of Canada reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended on May 31 a profit of $1,084,354 after depreciation and other charges, but before Dominion income taxes. This compared with a profit of $1,030,876, before taxes, in the preceding year.

New bond financing this week totaled $178,559,955, of which four important refunding loans of public utility companies accounted for $94,193,000. The aggregate last week was $89,255,500 and a year ago $71,153,000.
