Just two plays are vanishing from Times Square this evening: "End of Summer," which is abandoning the Guild, and "Love on the Dole," departing the Longacre. Neither is permanently closed, or so they say, for both are to tour in the Fall. "End of Summer" is the work of S.N. Behrman, and "Love on the Dole" is an English importation, derived by Walter Greenwood and Ronald Gow from the former's novel.

Permanent peace throughout the world can be established only by an international unification of all workers, regardless of political, racial or national beliefs, behind the peace policy of the Soviet Union in an attempt to prevent the outbreak of a new world war instigated by the "ruthless war preparations" of the Fascist-controlled nations, Robert Minor, Communist candidate for Governor of New York, declared yesterday.

THE MUNICIPAL AUDITORIUM, PHILADELPHIA, June 26. -- In one of the most impressive addresses of his public career, Governor Lehman of New York appeared before the Democratic National Convention tonight amid a great ovation to second the nomination of President Roosevelt on behalf of the President's and his own home State.
AMMAN, Trans-Jordan, June 26 (AP). -- Fierce desert warfare threatened tonight as 100,000 Bedouins urged a march across the River Jordan to the aid of their blood brothers, the Arabs of Palestine.

The handicap champion, Discovery, will assail a new height this afternoon when he goes to the post in the forty-eighth Brooklyn Handicap at Aqueduct. The horse, which already has won with more weight than Man 'o War ever carried, will try to take this historic test under 136 pounds, a pound more than was carried by the mighty Exterminator when he won in 1922.

CHICAGO, June 26. -- Light and generally inconsequential showers in parts of the United States and Canadian Northwest and increased hedging pressure from the Winter wheat areas sent wheat prices off 1 3/4 to 2 3/8 cents a bushel on the Board of Trade today, with the finish about at the bottom.
LONDON, June 26. -- Great Britain's intensive air rearmament was demonstrated today when new aircraft recently added to the Royal Air Force were exhibited privately at Hendon airdrome.

RYE, N. Y., June 26. -- Choate School turned back the threat of Kent in the fourth annual invitation tennis tournament for Eastern boarding schools today at the Manursing Island Club and all that remains for the Wallingford outfit to retain its title is to compete in the finals tomorrow.

MARION, Mass., June 26. -- Bill Touret, a Nantucketer who sails an Interclub at the local club, piloted the Loomis School of Windsor, Conn., to the interscholastic yacht championship today and parked the Clifford D. Mallory trophy, a silver boat, along the Connecticut River for the next year.

ELMIRA, N.Y., June 26. -- Six outstanding flights were made today by pilots in the annual national soaring contest, and while no records were broken, the air was almost filled with ships darting here and there in the high wind. It was by far the best day of the contest and hundreds flocked to Harris Hill to share in the excitement.

PASADENA, Calif., June 26. -- A method of preventing many of the 11,200 annual deaths from electric shock in the nation was explained before the convention here of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers by Dr. W.R. Kouwenhoven, dean of the Johns Hopkins University Engineering School.

MADRID, June 26. -- Francisco de Luis, editor of the Debate, mouthpiece of the Catholic parties of the Right and Center, spent a year in New York studying journalism before he assumed his present post in which both Jose Maria Gil Robles and Jose Calvo Sotelo, now leaders of the Right, preceded him.

PASADENA, Calif., June 26. -- A method of preventing many of the 11,200 annual deaths from electric shock in the nation was explained before the convention here of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers by Dr. W.R. Kouwenhoven, dean of the Johns Hopkins University Engineering School.

MADRID, June 26. -- Francisco de Luis, editor of the Debate, mouthpiece of the Catholic parties of the Right and Center, spent a year in New York studying journalism before he assumed his present post in which both Jose Maria Gil Robles and Jose Calvo Sotelo, now leaders of the Right, preceded him.

PHILADELPHIA, June 26 (AP). -- The Reds pounded Bucky Walter and Hal Kelleher for eight runs in the sixth and seventh innings today and defeated the Phillies 11 -- 6 in the first of a four-game series.

BECAUSE of a passionate interest in scientific classification, I am devoting this today's column to various types of anti-New Deal books. Despite the jokes based upon the literary fecundity of the New Dealers, it is the Republicans who lead the political book parade these days; for one pro-Roosevelt tract on the market there are a half-dozen of the opposite persuasion.
PARIS, June 26. -- Although the amount of business done on the Bourse today was small, prices remained firm and rose in some cases. Rentes recovered between 25 and 55 centimes.

WASHINGTON, June 26. -- President Roosevelt signed today legislation setting at 3.2 per cent by weight or 4 per cent by volume the amount of alcohol a State may permit in beverages sold within its borders and still receive Federal protection as a "dry" State under the Twenty-first Amendment.

For all his belief in centralization on the administrative side, Mayor LA GUARDIA likes to show by his actions that the government of the city as a whole belongs to the citizens of all the boroughs. Two years ago he moved his office to the Bronx County Building for a few days.

WASHINGTON, June 26. -- On grounds similar in part to those expounded by the United States Supreme Court majority on May 6, 1935, in invalidating the 1934 Railroad Retirement Act, Justice Jennings Bailey in the District of Columbia Supreme Court today declared unconstitutional the 1935 Railroad Pension Law and its companion tax measure, providing the levying and collection of taxes to finance railway men's pensions.

An editorial of The Knickerbocker Press, in referring to the opening speeches made at the Democratic National Convention, states: "These orators [Mr. Farley and Senator Barkley] * * * must artfully dodge the record of the administration * * * must exert skillful footwork to find enough solid ground on which to stand."

CHICAGO, June 26. -- The price of hogs advanced 10 to 20 cents a hundredweight today to a new high since late in April. The top of $10.75 was 15 cents above yesterday's, while the day's average was up a like amount at $10.15, and an advance of around $1 from the low point in May.

LONDON, June 26. -- Developments in the foreign political situation tended today to lessen business on the London Stock Exchange. One of the weakest features in the foreign bond department was the Polish 7 per cent issue, which fell 15 1/2 points to 50, owing to fears regarding service on the loan following a temporary suspension on loans issued in New York.
BERLIN, June 26. -- A decree was adopted at today's Cabinet session that nullifies the gold clause in all German bonds and like obligations that provide for payment in foreign currencies.
BERLIN, June 26. -- Max Schmeling, who was ignored and in disgrace for signing to fight a Negro when he left for his winning bout with Joe Louis, returned today a national hero.

PHILADELPHIA, June 26 (AP). -- A resolution protesting against the presence of Negroes on the program of the Democratic National Convention was adopted unanimously today by the South Carolina delegation.

PHILADELPHIA, June 26. -- During the demonstration provoked this afternoon by the mention of President Roosevelt's name, a TIMES reporter was surprised to see Godfrey G. Gloom, the old-time Hoosier Jeffersonian, whooping it up in the aisle along with the rest of the crowd.

GLEN COVE, L. I., June 26.4 More than 1,S00 persons filled the Cove Theatre tonight to see the first performance of "The Glen Cove Capers of 1936," a benefit revue given for the Glen Cove Community Chest. A large committee was headed by Mrs. Arthur Gibb of Old Orchard, in the Red Spring colony.

PHILADELPHIA, June 26. -- Determined to pack Franklin Field for a record-breaking Roosevelt demonstration tomorrow evening, party leaders have distributed about 200,000 tickets, 66 per cent more than the capacity of the field in both seating and standing room.

The reaction early this week of about $2 a bale for July contracts appeared to have strengthened technical conditions on the Cotton Exchange, and both new and old crop deliveries rose sharply yesterday into new high territory. July led the advance, rising more than $1.50 a bale at one time as covering operations pushed quotations to 12 1/2 cents a pound.
Many so-called "experts" are going about vainly trying to find a satisfactory explanation for the Joe Louis debacle.

July led the advance, rising more than $1.50 a bale at one time as covering operations pushed quotations to 12 1/2 cents a pound.

A group of Queens civic workers went to work yesterday on a civic project. About twenty-five men, women and children armed with pickaxes, shovels and rakes started last night to fill in holes in the surface of the street intersection at Cross Island Boulevard and 113th Avenue, St. Albans, Queens.

RYE, N.Y., June 26. -- More than 300 persons attended the dance held here tonight at the Manursing Island Club by the alumni of the Canterbury School of New Milford, Conn. The proceeds will be used for the rebuilding fund of the school, which was destroyed by fire.
WASHINGTON, June 26. -- The opinion of Justice Jennings Bailey in District of Columbia Supreme Court, voiding the Railroad Retirement Act of 1935, follows:

Six young men and boys, ranging in age from 11 to 33 years, from Great Britain and one from France arrived here yesterday on the Aquitania to compete at Detroit next Monday in the national model aircraft championships. The British team was accompanied by B.K. Johnson, chairman of the Society of Model Aeronautical Engineers; J.C. Smith, its secretary, and Harry York, representing British newspapers.

The first twenty-four railroads to report earnings for May showed an increase of 25.4 per cent in aggregate net operating income for the month, compared with May, 1935. The following table shows the totals for May in 1936, 1935 and 1934, with the percentage gain of May, 1936, over the preceding three years:

PITTSFIELD, June 27. -- Henry J. Schiebel Jr. of Roosevelt Field and two of three passengers in a Stinson monoplane en route to Montreal were injured this afternoon in a forced landing on the Pittsfield Polo Club Field at Holmesdale, the Holmes Road estate of Donald M. Weston.
CHICAGO, June 27. -- D. Leigh Colvin, the Prohibition party's candidate for President, declared today that he would attack Governor Landon as well as President Roosevelt in his Fall campaign.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., June 27. -- After shattering par to rout his first round opponent, Everett Lander of Elmsford, 6 and 5, Tommy Goodwin of Winged Foot was extended in a quarter-final round match in the third annual invitation tournament of the Briar Hills Golf and Country Club today.
CHICAGO, June 27 (AP) -- The Senators and White Sox broke even in a double-header today when the Senators won the first game, 2 to 1, and lost the nightcap, 7 to 3.

Some controversy seems to have arisen between eminent individuals of the Democratic persuasion. Some are not in entire accord with the practices of the present administration and, in their protest to the convention at Philadelphia, they referred to Thomas Jefferson, the great apostle of American democracy.

MORE than 3,000 elected representatives of farm, labor, unemployed, church and student youth organizations will be on hand for the opening session of the Third American Youth Congress in Cleveland on July 3. They will speak for 1,500,000 organized young people in all parts of the nation.

If democracy is to be saved from Communist or Fascist dictatorship, according to Henry A. Wallace, Secretary of Agriculture, free competition must be abandoned in this country in favor of "cooperatives of consumers, of producers and ultimately of industries."

FOUR new exhibitions have added to the art attractions of New York for the early Summer. All ar group shows -- three of paintings and one of sculpture -- and all are of work by Americans. Giants of the last half of last century to young artists of today are included.

The League of Nations finds itself at the cross-roads. With the Council now in session, the Assembly will meet Tuesday to face, in particular, the difficult situation caused by Italy's conquest of Ethiopia and, in general, the thorny issue raised by suggestions for revision of the covenant.

IN a plea to the Federal Communications Commission for extension of American short-wave broadcasting, Oswald Schuette, president of the Short Wave Institute of America, called attention to the fact that an industry has grown and thrived on an extremely narrow strip of the "ether."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 27. -- What the well-dressed Harvard man wore 100 years ago -- a fancy, colored calico "toga" trimmed with lace -- was revealed today when the only known remaining example of the strange garb was placed on display as part of the tercentenary exhibit.

The consolidated net profit of the Beatrice Creamery Company and subsidiaries for the three months ended on May 31 amounted to $90,644 after interest, depreciation, Federal taxes and other charges. This was equivalent to 90 cents each on 100,000 shares of $100-par 7 per cent preferred stock and compared with a net loss of $207,270 in the corresponding period of 1935.

To those readers who when a mystery story is brought to their attention, ask how many murders there are in it, the answer in this case is "plenty." The precise number escapes us for the moment; suffice it to say that of all the characters who appear in the first few chapters, only a few survive to the end of the story.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 27. -- Indefinite disbarment was ordered today of David J. McCoy, member of the New Haven County Bar Association for twenty-three years, Corporation Counsel for the city of New Haven and chairman of the Democratic Town Committee.

The Empire City race meeting of twenty-two days, with the largest added money value in the history of the association, will get under way Friday and run until July 28. Then will follow the month-long session at Saratoga before the swing is made through the metropolitan circuits once more in the Fall.

This collection of stories deals with prominent characters in Jewish history from Johannan Ben Zakkai in the days of the Emperor Vespasian down to Isaac Meyer Wise and Theodor Herzl. The lives included offer fine examples of heroism and unselfish devotion and in one or two of the accounts -- that of the Rothschild family of Frankfort, for example, and of Sabbatai Zevi, the famous "Turkish Messiah," there is an inherent dramatic quality.
For some time I have been following with interest the letters in THE TIMES about who discovered America -- Brendan, Ericsson or Columbus. Here are a few facts for Ericsson which no one has mentioned.

With the appointment of a special committee this week by the merchandising division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, retailers will seek through conferences with electrical refrigerator manufacturers to reduce the scope of the guarantee on these appliances and to widen, if possible, the mark-up which department stores obtain on these goods.

CLEVELAND, June 27. -- Drought conditions in this district have become acute and damage to crops will be severe unless relief arrives soon. Scattered showers in midJune temporarily aided some sections, but general rains are needed. Hay is short, oats are poor and much corn failed to germinate.

MILWAUKEE, June 27. -- Glenn Morris, the 24-year-old Denver automobile salesman who competed in his first decathlon last April, broke the world record for the event today in qualifying for the United States Olympic team.
HAVERHILL, Mass., June 27 (AP). -- A young Boston law student today confessed that five years ago he killed a wealthy widow with a hammer. Later he repudiated the confession.

VIENNA, June 3, 1936. AFTER his enormous success with "Otello" a year ago it was a foregone conclusion that Victor de Sabata would become an annual visitor in Vienna. People began to envision a sort of new golden age of Italian opera under his incandescent baton.
WASHINGTON, June 27. -- Divergent trends in various production fields were reported today by the Department of Commerce in its weekly business survey.
HOYLAKE, England, June 27 (AP). -- Alf Padgham broke into the professional's shop shortly after daylight to get his golf clubs before going out to win the British open championship today.

DR. ODUM, for many years has been the guiding force of that group of social students who have labored at Chapel Hill, and whose work has borne fruit in the rich harvest of books on the South issuing from the University of North Carolina Press.

EFFECTIVELY and picturesquely stormy years they were indeed, as every one knows whose newspaper memories go hack to the early years of this century, when Carter Harrison as Mayor of Chicago for term after term was filling that city with storm and stress -- and newspapers with headlines -- in his contests with the powers of the underworld.

HOBOKEN, N.J., June 27. -- Sweeping through his first two matches with the loss of only four games, Dave Geller, top seeded player, had reached the third round at the conclusion of play today as the annual Castle Point tennis championship opened at the Hoboken Tennis Club.

THE murder of Benjamin Broadall, merchant-banker, comes to light when Mr. Tolefree is called in to make discreet inquiries as to why Mr. Broadall is absent from his home and from his office. Mr. Tolefree quickly discovers that Mr. Broadall is not absent from his office except in spirit; his body is still there in a locked room.

Philip Van Gelder, national secretary of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, announced in New York last night that labor negotiations with the United Shipyards, Inc., 11 Broadway, had resulted yesterday in an agreement for a 5 per cent wage increase for workers in the company's yards here.

NEW ORLEANS, June 27 (AP). -- Police filed manslaughter charges today against James S. Percy, 27-year-old assistant football coach at Loyola University, after investigating the death of Sommers Carpenter, 21, during the disturbance at a wedding reception here last night.

The increased traffic which has been made available to railroads and truck and ship lines by the general improvement of industry has intensified rivalry among ports and among the competing forms of transportation. Developments in recent weeks have reflected the more active efforts of port cities and the competing transport groups to win their share of the available traffic.
WESTBURY, L.I., June 27 -- Stephen Sanford's Hurricanes rode into the final round of the Meadow Brook Club Cups today with a victory over Jock Whitney's Greentree poloists, 8 to 5, on Belmont Field.

The New York press pays little attention to the struggle of Arab versus Jew in Palestine. In its brief notices it refers to the Arabs as "rebels" and "terrorists." Yet this is the struggle of a nation against invaders foisted upon it by an alien power. It should appeal to the sense of justice and fair-play of Americans.

MR. JOHN HENRY EVANS is a Mormon savant, Profeasor of Church History and English at Latter-day Saints University, biographer of "Joseph Smith: An American Prophet," learned in the history of the Rocky Mountain West.

BROOKS ATKINSON can get away with it. He sneaks off to Prink Hill, wherever that might be, harkens to the house wren, loses his Pekingese -Mr. A. is the last person we should have suspected of harboring a Pekingese -- and writes his annual "No Sunday Article."

DEPARTURE of Major Bowes and his amateur troupe from the Sunday night air in September is expected to result in quite a change in broadcasting during that "witching hour" which opens at 8 o'clock. For more than a year the Major has completely dominated that sixty minutes.

BERLIN, June 27. -- The secret National Socialist tribunal known as the People's Court sentenced 22year-old Guenther Hoffmann, a Czech, today to eight years in prison for gathering information for the foreign press. The State's Attorney charged Hoffmann attempted to obtain for a Czech news service details of German military bases and aviation fields along the Czech frontier.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP). -- The old home of John C. Calhoun in South Carolina has become the center of a government-financed project to restore to its former glory one of the most historical plantation areas of the South.

MAPLEWOOD, N.J., June 27. -- Two teams were tied for the lead at the half-way point today in the fourth annual John F. Roche Memorial golf tournament at the Maplewood Country Club. They were the duos of Martin Issler of Rock Spring and Edwin B. Hoertz of the home club and Robert Lester of Baltusrol and G.R. Richner, also of Maplewood.

Announcements last week of bonds called for redemption before maturity were about half the number of the preceding week. Most of them were for small lots of municipal bonds and for payment in July. Among the calls, however, were several large public utility and industrial refundings for later months.
STROUDSURG, Pa. -- The Summer vacation season in the Poconos is in full swing, having opened with the annual laurel-blossom fete throughout the resort area.

TO many gardeners it is high tide in the floral year when the madonna lilies are in bloom. Though they may be blossoming in borders well filled with delphinium, double baby's breath, the white phlox Miss Lingard, purple harebells and pink astilbes, they are the first flowers to be seen in any group and the ones longest remembered.
PORTLAND, Ore., June 27 (AP). -- A move for classroom freedom in the discussion of controversial political subjects was the center of attention of the nation's school teachers tonight.

WHITE MOUNTAINS, N.H. -The great White Mountain playground is in readiness for its army of Summer visitors and there have been many arrivals already this month. The mountain clubs are active in trail building and maintenance and the free camp grounds of the Forestry Department in the White Mountains National Forest have been newly equipped with shelters and conveniences.

WASHINGTON, June 27. -- When President Roosevelt delivered his speech in Philadelphia tonight accepting renomination by the Democratic party for the Presidency, he took a definite step, known in advance to only a few of his friends, toward establishing that he would wage a campaign based on fundamental issues rather than personalities.

On the morning of July 2, 1932, a tri-motored airplane, carrying Governor Roosevelt of New York, took off for Chicago from the airport at Albany. The night before at the Chicago Stadium, delegates at the Democratic convention, deaf to the booing of supporters of "Al" Smith, had overwhelmingly nominated Mr. Roosevelt for President of the United States.

PHILADELPHIA, June 27. -- Godfrey G. Gloom, the aged Jeffersonian from Amity, Ind., died this evening as a result of injuries sustained when he was crossing a street in West Philadelphia on his way to Franklin Field.

FOR nearly twenty years the relationship between Franklin D. Roosevelt and Alfred E. Smith has been a pivotal factor in the Democratic party. In friendship and in enmity they have brought color and excitement to the party's counsels. Now, with another campaign under way, a new chapter in the dramatic story is being written.

In a match that required more than two hours for a decision, Joseph Fishbach, De Witt Clinton High School captain, vanquished Charles T. Mattmann of Trinity School, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 4, 1 -- 6, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4, in the final round of the Long Island Center junior tournament at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills yesterday.

THE first series of the Composers' Forum-Laboratory -- which has devoted itself to contemporary American music -- was brought to a close last Wednesday night at the Federal Music Project headquarters, 110 West Forty-eighth Street.

GLEN COVE, L.I., June 27. -More than 700 tonight attended the country ball at the Nassau Country Club after the final performance of the "Glen Cove Capers of 1936," a benefit revue given at the Cove Theatre for the community chest fund.

LONDON, June 24. -- Denis Johnston, the Irish author of "The Moon in the Yellow River," will shortly have two plays running in London simultaneously. The Gate Theatre of Dublin, which is now the tenant of the Westminster, is staging his "A Bride for the Unicorn" next Friday, while the following Monday Ronald Adam is doing his "Storm Song" at the Embassy, with Sir Esme Percy.

UTICA, N.Y., June 27 (AP). -- Harold B. Johnson, publisher of The Watertown (N.Y.) Times, declared today that the Democratic platform would leave President Roosevelt "an 'out' possible for everything" if he should be re-elected.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 25. -- A children's crusade against the tax on candy and ice cream, encouraged by the confectionery and ice cream trade and even taken into the churches and Sunday schools, seems to worry a number of State legislators, and the possibility arises that when the August special session of the General Assembly is called by Governor A.B. Chandler, the levies will be repealed. They are scheduled to go into effect July 1.

Retail trade and basic industrial conditions continued favorable in the metropolitan area last week. Consumer purchasing continued to expand, with estimates indicating that sales volume of leading department stores here exceeded those of the comparative week last year by 10 to 12 per cent.

The eighty pictures in the exhibition opened yesterday by the Easel Painting Project, a division of the WPA Federal Art Project, reveal how deeply the artists have been influenced in their art work by the depression.
PHILADELPHIA, June 27. -- In an atmosphere of general satisfaction at its unprecedented solvency, the Democratic National Committee met this afternoon and organized for the coming campaign.

As an outgrowth of its experience in making loans under the Federal Housing Administration program, the Manufacturers Trust Company has formed an industrial credit division to make advances to manufacturers against deferred-payment notes covering sales made by them to users of various types of equipment, machinery and other products on which loans have been insured under Title I of the National Housing Act.
ST. LOUIS, June 27. -- The luckless Browns, bossed by the wily Rogers Hornsby, made a noble bid today win a ball game along scientific lines. But the Yankees would have none of it.

PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT, Henry Ford, Rockwell Kent, MacKinlay Kantor and others are assembled in one of the most brilliant gatherings yet staged by The Colophon. They are all represented in the current issue, Number 4 of the New Series, which marks the end of an important chapter in the history of this famous book collector's quarterly.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., June 27. -Mr. and Mrs. Dwight F. Davis Jr. gave a dinner tonight at their home for Mrs. William T. Wetmore and Philip Tiffany. Other guests were Mr. and Mrs. Paul Morton Smith, Miss Virginia Thaw, William de Rham, W. Butler Duncan and William Otis Gay.

ONE arrives in Paris, digs up art gossip, pokes down the rue de Seine, shoulders the overimpressive doors leading to La Bootie and Faubourg St.-Honore Galleries, questions the dealers' weary transports -- all to the same end.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 27. -- With 650 members of the 101st Cavalry Regiment of Brooklyn and Manhattan leaving Pine Camp at Great Bend, N.Y., today for home, the movement of 5,300 National Guardsmen, involved in two training camp changes over the weekend, got under way.

PHILADELPHIA, June 27. -- Ernie Riedel, America's many-time national and international single blades canoe champion, from the Pendleton Canoe Club of New York, starred in the opening events of the final Olympic trials on the Schuylkill River today. All races were held over the 10,000-meter course.

Beginning in September, a series of new courses will be offered at City College in preparation for certification as a teacher of Hygiene and Physical Education in the State of New York. The new curriculum, which will lead to a degree in physical education, will be under the joint jurisdiction of the Department of Hygiene, headed by Professor Frederick A. Woll, and the School of Education, under Dean Paul Klapper.

PHILADELPHIA, June 27. -- As the second of the two least memorable major party conventions in history adjourns, and before observations made at Cleveland and Philadelphia become blurred by distance, it may be worth while to set them down in the form of notes.

Suit may be instituted against the Chicago Board of Education to force the prorating of any further disbursements to the holders of the board's tax-anticipation warrants issued against the 1929 tax levy, it was indicated in a letter sent yesterday to holders of those warrants by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc.

Senator Barkley, Democratic keynoter at the Philadelphia convention, sailed yesterday on the liner Aquitania, on his way to the Inter-Parliamentary Union sessions to be held in Budapest on Julyt. He heads the American delegation.

MANY educators are coming to believe that if boys and girls in our schools and colleges today turn mainly to the reading of trash in their hours of ease, it may mean a distinct deterioration of literary output in the next quarter-century.

EDUCATORS from some forty countries will gather in Geneva next month to exchange information on common problems and to receive ideas from compilations made by the International Bureau of Education. The conference will be the third held in as many years under the auspices of the bureau, which has a number of Ministers of Education among its members.

KING EDWARD has produced so many surprises during these first few months of his reign that by this time the question arises whether some new form of kingship is not beginning. His father made an unparalleled success of his own particular methods of kingship, but there are no fixed standards of right and wrong in these matters.

ON Big Meadow, high up in the Blue Ridge Mountains of Virginia, with its spectacular vistas of the broad Shenandoah Valley, President Roosevelt will take part next Friday in the dedication of the Shenandoah National Park.

WASHINGTON, June 27. -- Aubrey Williams, Acting works Progress Administrator, made public today detailed answers to a list of demands made on June 11 by a delegation representing the Workers Alliance of Greater New York, an organization of WPA workers.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 27. -The New Rochelle Yacht Club here held its annual regatta dinner dance tonight. More than 200 members and their guests attended the event.

WE are witnessing a revival of interest in Sainte-Beuve, the great critic of the nineteenth century, who raised the art of appreciating literary values and of analyzing the writers' characters so high that his "Causeries" and "Portraits" have the power of original creative productions.

BIRDS IN THE WILDERNESS" is the story of an avocation that is also a vocation. Dr. George M. Sutton, curator of the Museum of Ornithology at Cornell University, is one of those rarely fortunate people who are able to combine the two.

THIS unique book has grown out of a series of articles by Mme. Pastorelli that appeared several years ago in the Paris magazine Revivre, and aroused so wide a response and so much keen interest that the author was persuaded, against her wish, to unite with them other and more personal writings concerning illness, pain and suffering and publish the whole in book form.

PARIS, June 27. -- Colonel Francois de la Rocque on Monday will convert his Croix de Feu veterans' organization, or as much of it as is prepared to follow him, into the "French Social party." This move has been decided upon to avoid the consequences of dissolution of the Croix de Feu group.

EASTERN CANADA is looking forward this season to one of its greatest invasions by vacationists from the United States. The movement across the international line got off to an unusually early start this year. By late May, motor and fishing parties had begun visiting the Laurentians, the Saguenay country and Gaspe's heights overlooking the Gulf of St. Lawrence, and now the tide is at its height.

If the 130,000,000 people dwelling south of the St. Lawrence and the Great Lakes know little about the dominion spreading northward to the Arctic, they know still less about that other dominion in the Pacific.

Alfredo Salmaggi and his New York Hippodrome Opera Company will give three opera performances at the Atlantic City Auditorium on July 3, 4 and 5. For Friday evening, July 3, "Aida" is the production; on Saturday night, a double bill, "Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci," is scheduled, and for Sunday evening "Carmen." Giuseppe Bamboschek will conduct the operas.

Senator ROBINSON, as permanent Chairman of the National Democratic Convention, must have had one novel and agreeable sensation. It was when he was called upon to put a motion to shut off debate. Think of a United States Senator, as presiding officer, being able to do that!

Skippers of the Brooklyn Power Squadron and their shipmates are riding at anchor this morning in Broad Channel off Jamaica Bay, between Big Egg Marsh and Long Bar, for one of their periodical fleet rendezvous. They left their yacht clubs and home ports yesterday, had a dinner, dance and revue last night at the Grassy Point Hotel and this morning will cruise in formation to a near-by beach for another assembly.

DEERFIELD, Mass., June 27 (AP). -- The Eastern Archery Association's three-day tournament ended tonight with the Philadelphia Archery Club team victor and with five new records established by J.F. Waterman of Belmont, Texas.

WHILE the NRA and its codes have been declared unconstitutional few observers would dare to pretend that the fundamental problems of social and economic planning and regulation are definitely out of the American picture.

FOR more than twenty years "Boy Scouts of Birch-Bark Island" has been a favorite with young readers. This volume contains further experiences of the three leading characters of the earlier book, who are now adventuring among Eskimos and whalers of the Far North; the story, however, is complete in itself.

IT was in the Spring of 1918 that Sir Edward Elgar retired to a cottage in Sussex to escape the grim atmosphere that pervaded England during the third year of war. The nature of what had engaged him up to that time is reflected in the titles of the works immediately preceding his self-imposed solitude: the Belgian Flag and the Spirit of England.

THIS is another of the monographs so attractively designed by Merle Armitage and printed by the Will A. Kistler Company under the supervision of Lynton R. Kistler. The subject this time is a young Californian of real talent, Millard Sheets, whose work is becoming well known and has been much admired here in the East as well.

NEWARK, N.J., June 27. -- Cynara, trotting mare owned by Louis Schmieder of Elizabeth, and Colorado Scott, 3-year-old pacer, the property of J. Bruce Hay of South Orange, won the feature events of the Road Horse Association of New Jersey's weekly matinee at Weequahic Park today.

THIS year's Institute of Public Affairs at the University of Virginia will open next Sunday its tenth anniversary session. Since the first institute assembled in August of 1927 the university founded by Thomas Jefferson has been annually for two weeks the scene of an assembly unique in this country, if not in the world.

FIFTY years is merely a chapter in the history of most communities, but to Vancouver, Canada's third largest city, it represents a lifetime. Vancouver, accordingly, is preparing for a sixty-day golden jubilee, to start on July 1, with naval, military and aviation displays, and an exchange of radio broadcasts with London.

RUMSON, N.J., June 27. -- Showing like the great little dog that she is, Champion Solus Joy, smooth fox terrier owned by E. Coe Kerr of Mill Neck, L.I., and handled in the ring by Percy Roberts, this afternoon was chosen by Theodore Offerman of New York City as the best dog among the 709 benched in the annual all-breed fixture of the Monmouth County Kennel Club on the Harding estate.
THE athletic programs of many small colleges throughout the country will be facing readjustment, curtailment and in some cases abandonment because of lack of funds.

BAR HARBOR, Me. -- With the reopening of the Bar Harbor Club tomorrow night the Summer season is fully launched. All the larger hotel began their season on Saturday with the exception of the Malvern, which opens next Tuesday.

ONLY in sections affected by drought did retail trade fail last week to run up sizable gains over a year ago. The increases ranged as high as 25 per cent. Veterans' bonus payments, apparently, did not account for a major part of these gains or else the effect of this stimulant is too indirect to be traced to that source.
New York University has added sixty-seven new members to its faculty and promoted sixty-six others, it was announced yesterday.

THE Fourth of July, aside from being Independence Day and an excuse for sending off firecrackers, rings up the curtain on new millinery outbursts. It always seems a bit incongruous that with the big holiday that signifies the beginning of most people's Summer holidays early Autumn hats should make their appearance, but so it is.

We are rearming to end the drift to war, and British rearmament will prove for ourselves and the world the best possible treatment for the morbid and pathological state of the world that now encourages this dangerous talk about the inevitability of war.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., June 27. -One man was killed and seven other persons -- including two small children -- were injured this afternoon in the collision of two trucks and two automobiles on Route 29 in Green Brook Township, near here.

PINE ORCHARD, Conn., June 27. -- The formal opening of the Pine Orchard Yacht and Country Club tonight attracted more than 150 persons. A gala dance was held under the auspices of the entertainment committee consisting of Harold H. Sherburne of New Haven, chairman, the Misses Sally Youns of Scarsdale, Polly Bradley of New Haven, Katherine Baldwin of Mount Carmel and Malcolm Farrel of New Haven and Oliver Stonington of New York.

THE American Express Company announces that it has arranged a series of motor tours over the newly constructed roads of the Soviet Union this Summer. Those who wish to make the trip may enter or leave Russia over three international highways.

Charles S. Lobingier, in THE TIMES, recently quoted Elson's History of the United States that an ordinance for the government of the Southwestern Territory was framed by Jefferson in 1784 and rejected by Congress.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 27. -- Two persons were killed, sixteen seriously injured and more than fifty slightly hurt in a clash today between Montenegrin peasants and the gendarmerie near Cettinje, capital of the former Kingdom of Montenegro, which now is a part of Yugoslavia.

AS the season here is drawing to a close, "The Great God Brown" has put in a belated and far too brief appearance at the Vasa, and simultaneously a visiting troupe of Danish players has presented "Ah, Wilderness!" already known to this city through the Swedish production a few months ago.
GREENWICH, Conn., June 27. -The first of the series of Summer junior dances for debutantes, sub-debutantes and newly married couples was held at the Greenwich Country Club tonight.

The New Jersey Legislature has passed a bill prohibiting the netting of striped bass at all times and increasing the minimum-size limit from ten to twelve inches. Enactment of the measure has been hailed with enthusiasm by surf anglers who have watched with growing concern the steady depletion in the supply of this prized game fish.
Plans for a "clearance sale" on July 15 of eighteen city-owned properties, mostly vacant plots in Manhattan, were announced yesterday by the Board of Transportation.

PARIS, June 27. -- French workers took over a munitions plant with the consent of its owners today amid sporadic political and strike disorders and signs of dissension from one faction of the reigning Popular Front, the Radical Socialists.
THE June races reveal a piquant assemblage of varied materials and types of costume. Furs rub shoulders with organdie; velvet hobnobs with linen.

Trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange was wholly routine in character, and enlivened only by a moderate rebound in Polish Government loans following Friday's sharp break in those issues. Speculative interest in domestic corporation loans was at a minimum and total transactions dwindled to $3,947,600, compared with $4,236,200 on Saturday the week before.

WASHINGTON, June 27. -- Agreed settlement of more than half the suits brought against the Federal Government by the air mail lines whose contracts were canceled by Postmaster General Farley in February, 1934, was announced by the Postoffice Department.

OCEAN CITY, N.J. -- Ocean City will stage three events of outstanding interest in the next ten days. The National Marbles Tournament starts tomorrow, with the finals on Thursday. Next Saturday there will be a Fourth of July program featuring a military parade and fireworks.

The million children and youth who are this week beginning their school vacations are the real millionaires in that most of them have millions of minutes of life ahead of them -- a prospect for which men and women who have spent the greater part of their time-fortune would be glad to give in exchange much of substance that they have.

It is a drastic cure for our farm problem that Dr. ALONZO E. TAYLOR recommends. He advocates nothing less than permanent abandonment of 1,000,000 American farms embracing 250,000,000 acres of land out of the present total of 1,055,000,000 acres. He calls it "squeezing the slums out of agriculture."
BERLIN, June 27. -Prices on the Boerss were firm today, although the wek-end activity was limited.

COVENT GARDEN closes its doors to opera at the end of the week, and unless the projected visit of the Dresden company materializes, the only music to be heard in our major opera house for eleven months will be dance music.

PORTLAND, Ore., June 27. -- All Representatives and Senators running for re-election this Fall will have to satisfy the nation's teachers as to their attitude on Federal aid to education, according to plans being laid by leaders of the National Education Association, assembling here for the association's annual convention which starts tomorrow.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 26. -- California enthusiasm for Utopian panaceas seems to have exhausted itself in the 1934 campaign, when Upton Sinclair polled 879,000 votes for Governor, and a diligent search has failed to discover any enthusiasm or strength for the Coughlin-Lemke third-party movement.
MOSCOW, June 27 (AP). -- A big family project which taxes divorces and grants State aid to families with numerous children became law tonight on approval by the Soviet Central Executive Committee.

Born in 1890 to comfortably well-off New England parents, taken at the age of 10 for nine years' pleasant traveling over Europe with his mother, endowed with more than ordinary intelligence, Mark Parow seemed to be headed for a happy life.

DETROIT, June 27. -- Whopper, giant 4-year-old colt, raced in a neck ahead of Stand Pat to win the second running of the $5,000 added Ponchartrain Handicap today and give another stake to Hal Price Headley, whose Hollyrood won the $25,000 Detroit Derby.

HOYLAKE, England, June 27. -- Alfred Padgham, a British favorite, today won the British open golf championship with a total score of 287, one stroke ahead of Jim Adams, 25-year-old Scottish professional, whose tying putt refused to drop.

IS the historic, one-roomed school house destined to oblivion? Within twenty years public school enrollment has increased 34 per cent, but one-room buildings have decreased 30 per cent. It is estimated that in 1915 the total number was 195,500.

BELLPORT, L.I., June 27. -- E.V. Ketcham Jr. of Babylon held his lead in the elimination races being conducted by the International Star class fleet of Great South Bay to select a crew to represent it in the forthcoming Star Olympic eliminations and finals at Sayville, July 6-12.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 27. -- A special Summer program on applied physics, featuring conferences on spectroscopy and color, and their applications, will open at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology on July 20, bringing to Cambridge a distinguished group of leading authorities in this fast-growing field of research.

ROME. -- The prospective lifting of the League sanctions against Italy is regarded here as offering the possibility of a reduction in new taxes which the government found it necessary to levy during the Italo-Ethiopian War.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 27. -- James N. MacLean, chairman of the Citizens Committee for a City College, has announced that the Nassau Collegiate Center, a local free junior college, will be reopened next September for at least one more scholastic year.

ONE can confidently recommend this collection to those who wish to sample the popular story in its most unsullied form. Here it is, complete and water-tight, as tricky and glib as ingeniously preposterous as any of its admirers could demand.

THE age-old call of the sea is still heard by young men and boys of the hinterland. New Yorkers accept their harbor and its traffic as a matter of course, but the visitor from out of town still longs to smell salt water and to watch the big liners of which he has read so often.

TORONTO, June 27 (Canadian Press). -- Provision for the issue and distribution of securities of the Great Lakes Paper Company, Ltd., incorporated in Ontario on April 3, last, as consideration for purchase of the property and other assets of the company of the same name that had a newsprint mill at Fort William, was made today by an order of Justice J.A. McEvoy.

Storm clouds darkened the Polo Grounds yesterday as the Giants renewed hostilities with the Cubs. Rain pattered down on the field, making the going heavy and uncertain, the ball slippery and treacherous. Despite the conditions and a steady parade of Chicago replacements, the Terrymen carried on valiantly to trounce the invaders and pull into a tie with Pittsburgh for third place in the league standing.

TIRED of frills and furbelows? Try tailor-made chic for a change. On a hot Summer night it's as snappy as an Arctic breeze. Boyish lines that enhance feminine charms are the smoothest things for gay July evenings.

I am moved to protest against the infelicitous language used by Professor Menzel of Harvard University, when he mentions that astrology is a racket in which a gullible public is preyed on by unscrupulous individuals; the language being used in his article, "Science Again Turns to the Sun," in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine.
In the French Senate last Tuesday Premier Leon Blum announced his government's foreign policy; among other things he said:

IT is now some time since a really good novel has come to us out of Sweden, so that one need not be swept off one's feet by the publisher's announcement that this is "the outstanding Swedish novel of recent years." It is not, in fact, a book to treat in superlatives at all.

IT was late afternoon in Autumn when the visitors stopped their car by the hotel on the village green. About them the Autumn glory flamed on all the mountains, and as they entered the lobby they were glad of the pleasant heat from the big stove in the center of the room.

AS I write a column of smoke rises within a mile of my windows, behind a block of new, neat, cubist-cut pink, gray, white, green and purple houses erected on the northern outskirts of Madrid for comfortable but simple bourgeois folk. I know what that smoke means.

THE hobby of building dish gardens -- a craft of pebbles, sand, small stones, earth, moss and tiny plants -- offers an absorbing occupation for the house-bound person who loves the outdoors and for the person who in Winter would reconstruct some pastoral scene remembered from Summer.

PITTSFIELD, Mass. -- Elaborate plans are being made for the observance of Independence Day at Berkshire clubs. At the Lenox Club, oldest of the Berkshire Summer resort organizations, the sixty-second annual Fourth of July luncheon will be held for members land guests.

THE landlubber who goes to sea these days takes for granted hotel service on shipboard, particularly in the matter of cuisine. His appetite, sharpened by salt air, will surely be keen, and when he sits down to dinner he ranges through a bill of fare as comprehensive as he would find at any swanky hotel on shore.

LITCHFIELD, Conn. -- From its historic third of July night bonfire, with which Litchfield opens its season to the costume ball on Labor Day, which marks its close, this old town will offer many attractions for the Summer colonists.

THE MUNICIPAL AUDITORIUM, PHILADELPHIA, June 27. -- The following is the prayer offered by the Rev. Frank W. Ruth, pastor of the Reformed Church, Wernersville, Pa., at the final session of the Democratic National Convention today:

THE news that two new lyric sopranos, Bidu Sayao and Vina Bovy, had been engaged for the Metropolitan Opera's next Winter season came to light last week. The story behind this intelligence would seem to be the management's efforts to find artists who will be capable of replacing Lucrezia Bori, retired.
RECENTLY announced plans to organize a plant phenologic survey of the United States have aroused interest in a branch of human knowledge hitherto strikingly neglected in this country.

Can an important peace treaty be revised by legal means? That was the significant question to which Turkey sought an answer last week at Montreux when she formally asked the signatories of the Lausanne treaty of 1923 for permission to refortify the Straits of the Dardanelles and Bosporus and to assume greater control over their navigation.

CHICAGO, June 27 (AP). -- Fifty-six pairs entered the qualifying round of the American Whist League's tournament today, competing for the All-America contract pair trophy. Finals in the opening event were to be played off tomorrow night and Monday.

Columbia University has acquired a collection of intimate records of some of its famous alumni of the nineteenth century, which disclose glimpses of diplomacy, fashions and education of that period, it was announced yesterday by Milton Halsey Thomas, curator of Columbia.
CLEVELAND, June 27 (AP). -- Making a lively splash of color on the shore of Lake Erie, the Great Lakes Exposition opened its gates today in the name of Ontario, Erie, Huron, Michigan and Superior.

HANKOW, June 27. -- The imminence of civil war in China was stressed last night by General Yang Yun-tai, chairman of the Hupeh provincial government. His capital city, Wuchang, southward of Hankow is certain to be one of the main objectives of the Southern forces when their northward march is resumed.

MUST the brass band remain the Cinderella among instrumental ensembles? Or, on the contrary, are its inherent merits such that, properly fostered, they can raise the band's status until it rivals that of the symphony orchestra?

THIS journal of a shiftless fellow, dedicated to the careful study of an almost unbelievably good man, presents in itself a piquant contrast. Adrian Willis was "a middle-aged poet of faded fame" with bad drinking habits, worse financial ones, and no principles.

Miss Margaret M. Grandfield, the Brooklyn history teacher who prepared the winning syllabus in the Constitution Contest for city junior high schools, will save her $400 NEW YORK TIMES award for a year's study in Europe as part of the preparation she plans for a doctor's degree.

MODEL aircraft enthusiasts will turn their eyes toward Detroit this week-end where the 1936 National Championship model airplane meet begins tomorrow. Flying models will include stick and cabin types and the closed craft will be powered both by rubber band motors and by tiny gasoline engines.

POLAND SPRING, Me. -- Poland Spring, between the White Mountains and the Maine coastal resorts, is holding its usual appeal for visitors. The Poland Spring House is having its sixty-first season, and the Mansion House, under the same management, is having its 141st.

THE various guilds, which have been strangely out of the news of late, are showing activity, albeit some of it is of a negative nature. After the Screen Writers Guild was found guilty of a tactical error in seeking an issue rather than patiently awaiting the arrival of one, all of the militant organizations withdrew from the spotlight.

TELEVISION on the wings of radio jumps out of its laboratory nest tomorrow from the lofty peak of the Empire State Building. Where it will fly even the experts confess they do not know, but they expect to know much more about it six months from now, after they have had an opportunity to watch the antics of the images.

LONDON. IN the year 1550 Sir Colin Campbell, Laird of Glenorchy in the Highlands of Scotland, consulted a witch. Fresh from a foray which had expelled the MacGregors from their fastness at the head of Loch Tay, he wished to build a castle to which he could retire in the intervals of harrying the neighboring clans.

HOUSTON, Texas, June 27 (AP). -- A baby hurricane which was born and blew itself out in a single day struck the South Texas coast today. No loss of life was reported. There was considerable damage to frame buildings, small boats and crops.

JONES BEACH, L.I., June 27. -- An innovation in the presentation of grand opera for the Summer was launched here tonight. On a gigantic stage constructed on piles over the waters of Zach's Bay, Bizet's "Carmen" was offered to the complete enjoyment of a capacity audience of 10,000 persons seated in the Jones Beach Stadium on the shore of the bay.

EN ROUTE WITH PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT TO HYDE PARK, N.Y., June 27. -- After being cheered at Franklin Field by the greatest crowd that ever assembled to greet him, President Roosevelt left Philadelphia late tonight for the Summer White House at Hyde Park to plan the opening steps in his campaign for re-election.

LOS ANGELES, June 27. -- Outstanding performances by flying Frank Wykoff, Jimmy LuValle, Ben Eastman and Mack Robinson featured the finals of the Far Western tryouts for the American Olympic track and field team today.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. is Children's Week in Atlantic City, and the magic carpet has been spread for some 3,000 youngsters here from all sections of the world.

As a result of an improvement in the net incomes of many public utility companies this year, the managements of numerous systems are engaged in preliminary surveys of ways and means to eliminate the considerable accumulations of arrears on the preferred stocks of operating and holding companies.
LONDON, June 26. -- Now that sanctions are virtually out of the way, one hears less talk than formerly about that "reform" of the League which was to have been a sequel to the Ethiopian story.

LONDON, June 27. -- World-famous educators, assembled here today to celebrate the centenary of the University of London, acclaimed a living and ever-growing memorial to the intellectual heroes of the nineteenth century.

WE aren't a fan magazine ourselves and don't mean to become one if we can help it, but we cannot restrain the observation that George O'Brien and Marguerite Churchill look to us suspiciously like the Ideally Mated Pair those softhearted publications love to rave about.

LONDON, June 26. -- Lieut. Col. Raymond E. Lee, military attache of the United States Embassy in London, attended the ceremony of trooping the colors on the occasion of the forty-second birthday of King Edward VIII.

THE leading chauffeurs of Hollywood, it seems, are not the dark gentlemen or the ex-generals who chariot Mae West, Garbo or Marlene Dietrich from place to place. First place goes to the lean, unsung heroes who drive the studio luncheon cars from the kitchen out to location -- miles off in the cactus or rock where the pictures are being made.

Hush! Hush! This is all Secret Service stuff, and you are not to know for many a page what it is all about. It may be a plot to blow up the Houses of Parliament, or to deprive free-born Englishmen of their afternoon tea. Even Gunston Cotton himself knows nothing except that another Secret Service man named Maison has disappeared.

SAG HARBOR, N.Y., June 27. -A yachtsmen's vision, promising, practical and alluring, of a new and important link in the Long Island-to-Florida inside waterway was unfolded during a unique two-day cruise which ended last night at Montauk.

ALICE GRANT ROSMAN'S growing popularity in this country is warranted by the fashion in which she sustains the level of her own best performance. Comparatively few writers of this kind of light and dexterous romance can be counted upon so confidently to produce an entertaining
PHILADELPHIA, June 27. -- The text of President Roosevelt's speech of acceptance was as follows:
Inevitably, of course, many writers will be tempted to try their hand at biographies of Lawrence for young people. This volume is less successful than "Lawrence.

FOR years a heated controversy has been waged over the question of whether or not President Lincoln in 1861 saved from execution William Scott, a private in the Third Vermont Regiment, who had been tried by court-martial and sentenced to be shot for sleeping on his post as sentinel.

CAN organized crime, such as that revealed in the Drukman case and the loan-shark and vice prosecutions in New York City, be broken up? Can the relationship between politicians and crime be smashed, except temporarily?

STAMFORD, Conn., June 27. -- A surprise intended for his host had an unpleasant aftermath today when Barclay Warburton Jr., 38, member of a well-known Philadelphia family, was injured as he shot off a fireworks rocket about 1 A.M., to announce his arrival at the Summer home of Harold W. Ross, editor of The New Yorker.

ZIMMER, a student of Planck's, has written a very compact volume of semi-popular exposition devoted principally to quantum theory in its evolution by revolution. The theory itself seems to have gone forward by jumps like the electrons it talks about.

EXPECTATION of the Whitsun holiday called a halt to playgoing in the middle of last week, but not until "Boy Meets Girl" had made its bow in London and a new piece by Walter Hackett, "The Fugitive" had provided a contrast of entertaining nonsense in the English manner.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses requested the Board of Estimate yesterday to authorize a $7,000,000 appropriation for the construction of the final section of the West Side improvement, from St. Clair Place to a connection with the Henry Hudson Parkway at Dyckman Street.

Like a character out of a story by Kipling, Mrs. Violet McTurk, who came to New York on Wednesday for the first time in her life, lives in the jungles of British Guiana, alone except for a few native Indians who work for her.

THE American Bridge League has announced the schedule of events for its annual Summer tournament at Asbury Park, N.J., the week of Aug. 3. Pair tournaments for men and for women will be held concurrently, beginning Monday night, Aug. 3, and continuing Tuesday night and Wednesday afternoon.

INDEPENDENCE DAY in the United States is hardly the day it used to be. Uncle Sam in his ripe age inclines more and more to observe the birthday of his freedom in a sedate, adult-minded way, indulging liberally in the orderly pleasures of life, golfing, touring, bathing, watching baseball, and feasting in the greenwood, but avoiding sudden excitement, repressing elation, and resisting the impulse to fire off shotguns at the unoffending zenith.
PHILADELPHIA, June 27 (AP). -- The Democratic National Convention has created a new order of wandering men -- the lost hat legion.

GENEVA, June 26. -- The special Assembly convened at Argentina's request to decide League policy toward sanctions and Italy's annexation of Ethiopia meets this week in a bewilderingly complicated situation. It involves not merely the League's future but the whole diplomatic set-up from the Old World's trembling balance to the New World's coming conference at Buenos Aires.

IT may be said without fear of contradiction that people divide sharply into two groups: those whose love of animals is so great that it can lead to the most extravagant claims for their intelligence and to the most lavish expression of affection; and those whose indifference may drop to coldness, even though not so frequently as to former centuries, to actual cruelty.

LAKESIDE, Ohio, June 27 (AP). -- The commission on new patriotism of the Christian Youth Conference of North America recommended in its report to the conference today that youth evaluate by Christian standards the issues of the national political campaign.

The sharp decline in the demand for Federal Reserve loans by business men indicates a definite improvement in industrial conditions, W.H. Pouch, president of the Concrete Steel Company and chairman of the industrial advisory committee on loans in this district, said here yesterday.

The first half of the year comes to a close with the major lines of business moving vigorously ahead and the outlook promising for the balance of 1936. Retailers are already making heavy commitments for all types of merchandise in the wholesale markets in anticipation of one of the most active Fall seasons in the last six years.
BURLINGTON, Vt. -- Resorts along the Vermont shore of Lake Champlain are all open for the season and have been filling up rapidly during the past week.

Arrested in the afternoon on a charge of operating a policy bank, a man who described himself as Charles H. Miller, 43 years old, a Puerto Rican, of 2,053 Eight Avenue, was held in $5,000 bail by Magistrate Oliver in Night Court last night, for hearing in West Side, Court tomorrow.

NEW YORK STATE'S great 5,000,000-acre playground in the Adirondacks, with its hundreds of lakes, mountain trails and limpid fishing streams, is launched on a season which resort managers of the area are confident will be one of the best in its history.
BERLIN, June 27. -- Max Schmeling lunched today with Chancellor Hitler in the Reich Chancellery. The mother and wife of the heavyweight boxer also were guests of the Fuehrer.
ROME, June 26. -- Events moved fast in Europe while the Italia Army in Ethiopia awaited eagerly orders that would have meant a far greater war than that against Emperor Haile Selassie.

In its latest vacation pamphlet the Conservation Department advertises New York as "The State That Has Everything." That is a large claim to make, and it need not be taken too literally. The State has no glaciers, or geysers, or active volcanoes, although it has at least one extinct volcano, several natural wonders matching Old Faithful, and some of the best Winter sports in the world.

MR. THOMAS DODDS, chairman of the board of directors of the new Atlantic Film Productions, Limited, is the very model of an English solicitor-at-law. It wouldn't surprise us at all if some day Mr. Dodds were to be conscripted by his own casting director to play such a role in an Atlantic production.

CAPE MAY, N.J., June 27. -- Preaching the annual sermon before the Central Conference of American Rabbis at the closing session today, Rabbi William F. Rosenblum of Temple Israel, 210 West Ninety-first Street, New York City, called for a reorganization of reform Judaism as well as a restatement of its creed.

ASBURY PARK, N.J. -- Social activities in this resort area have begun with the opening of the larger hotels along the North Jersey shore, from Bay Head to Atlantic Highlands. Among the outstanding events of the opening week will be the Style Show next Friday afternoon in the Spring Lake Community House.

THIS second edition of the admirable Oxford Bridges adds "October and Other Poems" (1920), "New Verse" (1921) and three new pieces. (It does not yet include the 1,500 lines of "The Testament of Beauty.") The "Shorter Poems" retain their fragrance and delicate bloom.

The return of a great champion to her former eminence, the continued dominance by another brilliant champion and the crowning of two new stars marked the third day of the women's national A.A.U. swimming and diving championships at Manhattan Beach yesterday.

STRATFORD, Conn., June 27. -- Giving a remarkable demonstration of accurate marksmanship under pressure, stocky Frank R. KeLly equaled the world 410-gauge record in capturing the feature event of the eighth annual Great Eastern skeet championships held during intermittent showers over the Remington Gun Club's famous Lordship Shooting Grounds today.

TWO bronzed men and a dog, once pure white, arrived in New York early on the morning of July 26, 1903, in an open touring car caked with every variety of mud between the two oceans. They were the first transcontinental tourists.

THE American Association for the Advancement of Science continued its session at Rochester last week. To this commentator the most noteworthy utterance was that of Dr. and Mrs. Carol G. Montgomery of the Bartol Research Foundation of the Franklin Institute.

PHILADELPHIA, June 27. -- Although scattered groups of convention visitors having satisfied their curiousity or been influenced by depleted finances started for their homes earlier, the great exodus from Philadelphia was timed to start at the close of tonight's notification ceremony and continue without cessation through most of tomorrow.

DALLAS, June 27. -- Texas retail trade is feeling the effects of additional buying by thousands of visitors from outside the State who have come to see the Texas Centennial Exposition here. Dallas merchants report increases amounting to 25 to 35 per cent over the volume for the corresponding week of last year.
An airplane crash in which four persons were believed killed, and the forced landing of two other planes, marred the fifth annual flying yesterday of the Roosevelt Field-Montreal good-will flight.
DENVER, June 27 (AP). -- A mile high before they leave the ground, six balloonists will cast off and soar into the darkness here next Friday night, seeking the national championship.

WITH air-mail poundage for the past year nearly double that of the record year of 1934, the early operation of a trans-Canada air-mail service seems imminent. The latest information from Ottawa is to the effect that a decision is now pending as to whether the service will be publicly or privately operated.

CHICAGO, June 27. -- Representative Lemke of North Dakoto, Union party candidate for President, stated here today that his organization did not represent a merger of dissatisfied groups, but a combination of distinct lines of endeavor. Its purpose, he said, was to restore representative government.
DANZIG, June 27 (AP), -- Germany plans further steps soon to return this free area to the Reich, foreign observers predicted tonight following a Nazi independence declaration.

HEAVY travel across the Atlantic to Europe has long been news. Today, the ocean traveler heading west is taking the headlines. Several factors have contributed to this interest in things American -- favorable exchange, lower steamship rates and a growing curiosity about the United States.

With world cotton consumption continuing at a high level, the South faces the prospect of another year of relative prosperity, threatened only by the contingency of an international catastrophe that might choke export outlets. Cotton spinners and traders are now concentrating attention on the new crop, seeking to appraise its probable volume and to determine the influence of the agricultural conservation program upon plantings.

Share prices moved narrowly in quiet trading during yesterday's two-hour session. The closing was irregular. The trend was slightly lower in the first hour and higher in the second. Transactions on the Stock Exchange aggregated 366,000 shares, compared with 317,000 the Saturday before.

An attempt to "reach" the blue-ribbon jury that heard jury-tampering evidence in the Drukman conspiracy case for the last four weeks was disclosed yesterday afternoon when the jurors, unable to agree on verdicts in the cases of Assistant District Attorney William W. Kleinman and Detective Giuseppe F.L. Dardis, were discharged after more than twenty-seven hours' deliberation.

HOT SPRINGS, Va. -- A large holiday crowd is expected at the Homestead over Independence Day week-end, and a comprehensive program of sports events has been arranged. The most important of these, the annual Independence Day tennis tournament, will commence on the En-Tout-Cas courts next Thursday.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., June 27. -At tonight's weekly dinner dance at the Devon Yacht Club Mr. and Mrs. John Laurence Hutton and Dr. and Mrs. Louis Faugeres Bishop Jr. gave a dinner for about forty guests in honor of Mr. and Mrs. Sturtevant Erdmann.

DIFFICULT to understand, is it not, why the very name of Winslow Homer should make you thrill to what you believe is Americanism? I am not at all sure that I know what Americanism really is. But so the case stands: Americanism really is, and, in art, Winslow Homer is its great exemplar.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I. -- Independence Day, which marks the formal beginning of social activities in Southampton, promises to be unusually gay this season. Many members of the Summer colony already are planning for the entertainment of house parties, a traditional feature of the first important holiday of the Summer, and several large community projects are under way.

James Catania, 37-year-old nephew of Ciro Terranova, was arrested at 2 o'clock Friday afternoon and appeared in the line-up at police headquarters yesterday on a vagrancy charge. In Bronx magistrate's court later, Magistrate Overton Harris held him in $500 bail for a hearing tomorrow on an additional charge of improper automobile registration and adjourned the vagrancy hearing until the same time, setting bail at $100.

WASHINGTON, June 27. -- The great national conventions have passed into history, and while they have answered, to their own satisfaction, many important questions, they have left unanswered what is perhaps the most important question of all:

WASHINGTON, June 27. -- Due to a sharp decrease in the value of non-residential structures for which permits were issued, the aggregate value of building permits during May was below the April level, Secretary Perkins announced today. The drop in the total value came despite an increase in the value of permits for new residential buildings, and for additions, alterations and repairs to existing structures.

THE A.C.A. Gallery's first annual competitive exhibition (current until July 4) is sponsored by the American Artists Congress. This was held in order to give young artists an opportunity to show their work. A jury chose the Japanese artist Sakari Suzuki from this exhibition for a one-man show at the gallery next season.

The broad scope and continuing impact of the inventive genius of Thomas Alva Edison on the complexities of modern life are graphically portrayed in the Edison Industries Exhibition which opened yesterday morning at the New York Museum of Science and Industry in Rockefeller Center.
NEWARK, N.J., June 27. -- Nolen Richardson's single with the bases loaded and one out in the ninth inning enabled the Newark Bears to defeat the Baltimore Orioles, 4 to 3, today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 27. -- The ever amazing Bill Bonthron, as unpredictable in his march along the comeback trail as he was at the height of his career two years ago, provided the sensation of the semifinal Olympic track and field try-outs in the misty rain at Harvard Stadium today when he administered to the great Gene Venzke a stunning defeat in the 1,500-meter run.

TOLEDO, Ohio, June 27 (AP). -- The $4,600 Inverness invitation four-ball golf tourney became a three-team race today as sixteen of the country's leading professionals tore the course apart with 83 birdies, upset the leaders and jumbled the standings.

By a curious turn of fate the University of London commemorates its 100th anniversary and the University of Heidelberg its 550th in this same week. A few years ago the coincidence would hardly have called for extended comment. Today it is otherwise. Both institutions have reason to rejoice in a glorious past.

TRENTON, N.J., June 27. -- M. William Murphy, WPA director of Mercer and Burlington Counties, denied today that force or pressure was used in the sale of Roosevelt nominator cards at $1 each to persons employed on Federal relief projects under his supervision.
HOLLYWOOD, June 27 (AP) -- Myrna Loy, movie star, was married to Arthur Hornblow Jr. today in Ensenada, Lower California, they have informed friends here.

IN ever-widening scope, flying is entering into the making of maps and surveys. New instruments both for making aerial pictures themselves and for combining the results in both flat and contour maps are rapidly being developed.
JAMESTOVN, N.D., June 27 (AP). -- The worst drought in the history of Stutsman County has transformed once fertile prairies into a dismal landscape.

BOY PASSES EXAM: That last inexorable hurdle before the schoolboy's vacation -- June exams -- plays no favorites, not even a King. Last Tuesday royal professors announced that Peter II of Yugoslavia had passed "with great distinction" the entrance examinations for the third class of Belgrade College.
PHILADELPHIA, June 27. -- The address by Governor Allred of Texas nominating Vice President Garner for another four-year term was a follows:

The government won round three in its legal encounter with liquor-purchasing tourists yesterday, and in effect terminated the bout with a new customs regulation abrogating the $100 tax-free exemption as applied to spiritous beverages brought in by returning travelers.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 27. -- All eight seeded players in the men's division of the All-England tennis singles championship have won through to fill all the places in the quarter-final round, and that is something that never has happened since seeding was introduced here a decade ago.

CHICAGO, June 29. -- Hot weather here this week caused a sharp rise in retail sales. The average increase along State Street was between 15 and 20 per cent, with some stores running much higher. Summer wearing apparel and household goods moved in good volume. Retailers attributed very little of the business gain to bonus payments.

THE Executive Mansion in Topeka is not an imposing structure. It combines the faults and virtues of the architecture of the Eighties in such a manner that the passerby, his glance attracted perhaps by the fairly spacious lawn, might look at it and murmur, "looks like a roomy old place," and then pass on without another thought of it.

That American dog show judges are acquiring a wider knowledge of the many breeds benched at our exhibitions and are less often influenced by tradition, precedent and reputation is evident from the best-in-show awards made in recent months in widely separated parts of the United States.

MR. MATTHEWS returns to his task of showing that the consumer is an unfortunate guinea pig upon whom organized business experiments, the objectives of such laboratory work being the getting of greater profits by ever more ingenuity in gypping the purchaser.
PORTSMOUTH, Ohio, June 27 (AP). -- Violent outbreaks at the strike-closed Wheeling Steel Corporation plant prompted today a grand jury investigation.

The jury before Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson which shortly after midnight yesterday convicted three former officers of the Westchester Title and Trust Company for mail fraud announced yesterday afternoon it was unable to agree on a verdict with reference to the fourth defendant, Frederick P. Condit, and the trial was terminated.

Discussions among bankers and in Federal Reserve circles for many months about the problem created by the piling up of a huge volume of excess reserves have taken a new turn recently with the suggestions advanced by S. Sloan Colt, president of the Bankers Trust Company, and Murray Shields, economist of the Irving Trust Company, for Treasury action to sterilize gold imports.

That chamber of chill, the House of Lords, was warmed up a bit the other day. The debate was on Lord CRAWFORD'S motion disapproving the reading of speeches. He complimented the House on the "high level" of its debates, but added maliciously that the level would be higher if peers would cease to deliver written essays and would "not confine their interest to their own essays."

IT was Mr. Blanchard's commendable purpose in preparing this book to set forth and explain the foundational structure of the government of this country in so simple and interesting a style that any one would find it easy to read and to understand.

HEIDELBERG, Germany, June 27. -- Old Heidelberg, minus its swaggering "corps" members and most of its dueling scars, began its 550th birthday festivities tonight under the flags of thirty-two nations.

ALL the progress that women have made in the business world has not stilled discussion over their right to be and stay there. A woman lawyer advises university women that they must fight to keep their jobs, and reminds them of what has happened to their German and Italian sisters.

Like many others in private life, I wonder what is wrong with our present set-up that it should produce so much confusion and divergence of ideas as to what is best for our country, After much consideration and consultation with many I have come to the conclusion that what we need most is constructive leadership.

Following action by the Board of Higher Education nine members of the teaching staff of Hunter College have been elevated to higher rank, it has been announced by Dr. Eugene A. Colligan, president of Hunter College. The promotions will take effect in September.

THE MUNICIPAL AUDITORIUM, PHILADELPHIA, June 27. -- On motion of Postmaster General Farley the Democratic National Convention adopted today a resolution in memory of Louis McHenry Howe, secretary and intimate friend of President Roosevelt.

LONDON, June 27 (Canadian Press). -- Amar Singh, Indian professional with Colne, a Lancashire club, and the touring Indian team, made England's batsmen look weak in the first cricket test match between the two countries, started today.

BEES and birds of England hummed and twittered over flowery meadows and trimmed hedges on one of those August afternoons that give Summer the scene and fragrance of its truest meaning. A large man played with a shaggy collie, and when he bent over the dog it was not easy to distinguish the iron-gray shocks of either.
LONDON, June 27 (AP). -- Chancellor of the Exchequer Neville Chamberlain declared tonight the empire was "devoting itself night and day" to the task of defensive rearmament.

This is a story of a battle of wits between a private detective and a crooked political boss and racketeer in a city on the West Coast.
