Other weapons besides wits are used, however, quite frequently enough to provide the excitement that readers crave, for the boss is completely ruthless in his methods and has some very tough citizens on his payroll.

THIS work is a survey of the literature on prenatal and postnatal activity from 1920 to 1934. The author has shown considerable scholarship in interpreting leading ideas found in this mass of data and has fortunately avoided arranging the facts in compendium form.
JERUSALEM, June 27. -- One thing certain -- life in Palestine today is a real Tophet. The atmosphere is tense, fear reigns everywhere and human life is without value.

UTICA, June 27. -- Six persons were killed shortly before noon today at the Cherry Valley Turnpike in Sangerfield, about twenty miles south of here, when their automobile was struck by a Delaware, Lackawanna Western passenger train.
HUNTINGTON, L.I., June 27. -Miss Barbara Field, daughter of Mrs. E. Marshall Field of Brookville and of Marshall Field, was introduced to society tonight at two parties. About 1,100 guests attended.

CHICAGO, June 27 (AP). -- Charles (Chuck) Kocsis, steel-nerved young shotmaker, from Detroit, drilled-in a twenty-two-foot putt on the thirty-first green at the North Shore Club today to overwhelm young Paul Leslie of Louisiana State, 6 and 5, and bring the national intercollegiate golf crown to Michigan and the Big Ten for the second time in thirty-eight years.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y. -- While Summer sojourners at other resorts these days are looking forward to conventional observances of the Fourth, many of Lake Placid's visitors are checking over their ice skates and skating togs for next Saturday -- featured by the opening of Lake Placid's midsummer indoor ice season -- marks the first Independence Day celebration in the Adirondacks ever to include ice skating.

WITH the current emphasis on the importance of design in garden making, gardeners -- especially amateurs -- are coming more and more to realize the basic importance of shrubs. The shrubs indeed are to the garden what the foundation is to the house -- the beginning from which one builds.
LAKELAND, Fla., June 26. -- There is a general feeling among Floridans that the cross-State ship canal is a lost cause that will stand as a conspicuous reflection upon the New Deal.

WASHINGTON, June 27. -- An appeal for Senator Borah's active support and participation in the Landon campaign was understood to have been made in an hour's conference today between the Senator and Roy A. Roberts, managing editor of The Kansas City Star and one of the leading figures in the Landon camp.

During the last sixteen months the saga of Samuel Drukman, murdered Brooklyn garage employe, who in life was a nonentity but became a cause celebre in death, has been heard by three grand juries and two trial juries. Nor is the end yet in sight.

FRANKLIN FIELD, PHILADELPHIA, June 27. -- This great playing field was turned into an enormous convention hall without a roof tonight when, for the second time in his career, Frank Delano Roosevelt appeared before the delegates who had nominated him for the Presidency to thank them for the honor they had bestowed upon him.

WITH vacation time at hand, the studios are braced for the onslaught. From the little theatres of the crossroads and the cities, from the drama appreciation classes of the universities, and from the class plays of thousands of high schools and colleges, by plane, train, bus and hitch-hiking will come the season's young hopefuls of the screen, all bent on uplift and all determined to run Garbo, Hepburn, Colman and Cooper to the tall timber.

The Democratic platform, despite its progressive features, offers no real guarantee of social and economic security to the workers of the nation, Earl Browder, general secretary of the Communist party of the United States, declared yesterday afternoon in an address before the ninth national convention of the Communist party at the Manhattan Opera House, 311 West Thirty-fourth Street.

LAKE GEORGE, N.Y. -- Five entries have been received for the Gold Cup race to be held in Bolton Bay on July 25, according to Dr. Edwin B. Jenks, chairman of the regatta committee. George Reis of Bolton Landing and Pasadena, Calif., will defend the title with his El Lagarto, the only boat to have won the race three times.

SYRACUSE, June 27. -- Dr. Charles W. Flint will retire as chancellor of Syracuse University July 31. Dr. William P. Graham, as vice chancellor, will be in charge until a successor to Dr. Flint has been selected.

PORTLAND, Ore., June 26. -- New Deal adherents in the Pacific Northwest are considerably more alarmed over the Lemke candidacy than they have been over the bombardments from the right by Alfred E. Smith and other conservative critics.

Members of the Board of Education and the board's former president, Dr. George J. Ryan, were among the more than 150 persons who paid tribute yesterday to Miss Clara E. Bell, an educator for nearly fifty-three years, at a luncheon held in her honor at the Ambassador Hotel.

BERLIN, June 27 -- The progressive aggravation of the relations between the Catholic Church of Germany and the Third Reich appears to be heading for a situation that may culminate in abrogation of the concordat concluded by the Holy See and the Reich on July 20, 1933.

MADRID, June 27 -- In reviewing Spain's political difficulties, it becomes apparent that they are due mostly to economic ills. Improve the condition of the Spanish masses and Spain's political problems would soon disappear.

Highly critical of provisions of the new Federal Tax Law which affect their interests, importers yesterday charged that Congress, by passing the revenue measure, has resorted to tactics which in business would be called "the acme of dishonesty."

PHILADELPHIA, June 27 (AP). -- The Reds won their sixth straight game today, their longest victory run of the season, by defeating the Phillies, 10 -- 9, with a home-run attack in which four round-trip clouts were hammered out of the park.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP). -- A special war plans committee of the Army General Staff has begun a study to determine whether modern warfare conditions necessitate reorganization of the size of combat divisions.

HEIDELBERG, June 27. -- The celebration of the 550th anniversary of the founding of Germany's oldest university began here tonight with a National Socialist military ceremony. As the flags of thirty-two nations, whose universities have sent delegates to the celebration, were hoisted atop thirty-two masts on the old town's public square a company of black-coated Hitler guardsmen presented arms.

LEESBURG, Va., June 27. -- Our Way, Ray S. Shoemaker's splendid 3-year-old bay gelding by Tom Tiger -- Keosey, was named champion at the Loudoun Hunt Horse Show, held today at Belmont, the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick J. Hurley.

THE twenty-fifth-year class has just completed a stock-taking operation. On scores of college and university campuses during the past month the young gentlemen (and of course numerous ladies) who graduated in 1911 into a world of philosophical and moral certainties and alluring economic grooves have been facing a future in which a good deal of this standard equipment of their youth appears to be missing.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 27. -- Continuing as the favorite team, Eddie Driggs Jr., former New York State champion, and his partner, Henry Hoch of Montclair, gained the semi-final round of the Cherry Valley Club's invitation best-ball tournament today by scoring a pair of victories.
SALT LAKE CITY, June 27 (AP). -- Fellow convicts went to the aid of Delbert Green today in his fight to escape a Utah firing squad after conviction for three murders and the death sentence.

WHEN the clerks of the polls finished tabulating the balloting for the big baseball party to be held in Boston they discovered that the voters had violated the election laws here and there. That's an old custom in this country, one that sprouted with the annual November marking of the old-fashioned long pink ballot with column after column of names.

A readable description of present day South Africa with some account of its history and development. The early voyages of Diaz and Vasco da Gama; the Kimberley diamond mines; the great wild animal sanctuary where zebra, giraffe and lion calmly watch the approach of the traveler's automobile, the contrast between Dutch and English in the early days of colonization; native life and customs, provide ample variety and interest.

THE research man -- or woman, for there is a female of the species -- plies one of the most enthralling trades in motion pictures. He is the G-man of the movies, who goes about his job quietly, out of the public view. He is forever asking people exasperating questions and it may be safely said that he always gets the information he is seeking.

BROUGHT about by the necessity to find a theatre for its all-year-round ensemble, its own house in the city's central part still being under reconstruction when the full season broke, the State Playhouse annexed the Kunstler Theatre, near Kurfurstendamm, and, for the first time since its existence, invaded Berlin's most fashionable and alive section, the West.

NEWPORT. -- The Fourth of July has long been considered the date of the real opening of the Newport season. The large number of Summer colonists already in the city expect one of the gayest Fourths they have had in recent years.

CHICAGO, June 27. -- The Summer racing season at Hawthorne closed today with St. Bernard, owned by E.D. Shaffer, Chicago sportsman, winning the $5,000 added Illinois Owners' Handicap before 15,000 spectators.

DETROIT, June 27 (AP). -- The Tigers landed on Dusty Rhodes for six runs in the seventh inning today to defeat the Athletics, 8 to 4, in the second game of the series and tie the Senators and Indians for third place.

PROFESSOR TASASU SAIKI, director of the Imperial Government Institute for Nutrition in Tokyo, broadcasts recipes for concentrated food, and he is paving the way for a peaceful revolution in Japan, the revolution of nutrition.

SYDNEY, Australia -- Red and yellow sand dust, blowing in from arid Central Australia, threatens desolation to the rich mining town of Broken Hill, New South Wales. The dust has been encroaching on Broken Hill for several years and rows of abandoned homes, many of them partly buried by sand, testify to its relentless march.

PHILADELPHIA, June 27. -- A very considerable proportion of the delegates to the convention did not stay for the climax, and on the platform during the closing session this morning misgivings were freely expressed by the political impresarios as to the net effect of holding a party conclave exclusively for the radio audience instead of for the delegates who have to organize and carry on the campaign.
The New York State Socialist party, holding a two-day convention at the Hotel Delano, nominated Dr. Harry W. Laidler for Governor by acclamation yesterday.
MADRID, June 27 (AP). -- Fascists, cheered by the first break in the Leftist united front, renewed their activities tonight against the regime of Premier Santiago Casares Quiroga.

JAMAICA. JAMAICA is known for the richness of her flora, now in fresh bloom after the recent rainy season. Some of the oddest trees in the world grow in her forests and are constantly a source of surprise to visitors.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 27. -- Mrs. Mary Dougherty left here today to hitch-hike to Philadelphia, where, at the Democratic convention, she hopes to finds some powerful person to whom she can tell her troubles. She carried an extra pair of shoes under her arm and wore an extra daub of rouge on each cheek, because, to her, her trip was "fraught with importance."

The Dodgers' losing streak was suspended at five games yesterday when a sudden shower, coming just after the gates were opened to a small group of fans, caused cancellation of their second meeting with the Cardinals. The game probably will be played off as part of a double-header during the Gashouse Gang's next Eastern invasion.

About 10,000 persons, most of them Democrats, heard an amplified radio broadcast of President Roosevelt's speech accepting the party's nomination for President at a rally in Madison Square Garden last night. In Queens more than 3,000 heard the speech at a rally at the Madison Square Garden Bowl.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 27. -- Contracts for the purchase of the steamers Diana, Margaret, Melville and Stuart Dollar have been signed by the Hawaiian-American Steamship Company, according to word received yesterday from Thomas G. Plant, vice president.

WIMRLEDON, England, June 27 (AP) -- Britons know now why Bryan Grant is the giant-killer of the tennis courts. The Atlanta atom, who stands barely over five feet when he takes a deep breath and pulls himself up to his full height, shelled Vivian McGrath of Australia to cover in the fourth round of the All-England championship today.

RYE, N.Y., June 27. -- An excellent doubles team of Emmet Steele and George MacCall from the Scarborough School defeated Choate's star combination of Henry Daniels and Robert Low in the final of the fourth annual invitation tennis tournament for Eastern boarding schools today at the Manursing Island Club.

HENRY THOREAU was anomaly -- an improvident visionary in a land of tight-fisted practical New Englanders; and what innate qualities molded him into this pattern are still a question of dispute. James Russell Lowell in his essay, on Thoreau -- an essay delightfully adorned with the felicities of his mellow scholarship -- thought the reasons for his withdrawal from the world were inherent in his disposition.

RICHMOND, June 27. -- Rains fell throughout most of the Fifth Federal Reserve District during the week, and thus the ten-week drought was broken and farmers who had been discouraged, were cheered because crops that threatened to become dead losses improved considerably.

The Lycee Francais de New-York, a school offering "an education simultaneously in two civilizations," has just completed its first year successfully and demonstrated "the wisdom of the experiment," according to Dr. Stephen Duggan, one of its patrons.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., June 27. -- A program which covers nearly every Controversial-subject of the day has been prepared for the Institute off Public Affairs, to open at the University of Virginia July 5. The program was arranged by Dr. Charles G. Maphis, founder and director of the institute, and Dean Armistead M. Dobie, assistant director.

Many out-of-town buyers arrived in the wholesale market here last week, but mail requisitions were light on Summer merchandise because of ample retail stocks, according to a report prepared especially for THE TIMES by the McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buyers.

Robert P. Baruch has been racing yachts on Long Island Sound for several years, formerly owning a Fishers Island class sloop. He also competed in the Bermuda race from New London, Conn., two years ago in the schooner Zingara and was one of the last to finish.

HEIDELBERG is draped with Nazi flags. From the leading universities of the world 1,300 of the academic elite -400 from foreign countries alone -have been invited to the old town beneath the famous Schloss on the hill to honor this week one of the world's greatest institutions of learning.

GENEVA, June 27. -- Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia, according to a credible source here, is contemplating informing the League of Nations that he desires safe conduct to return to help the government established in Gore, Western Ethiopia, and to continue the war against the aggressor.

WASHINGTON, June 27. -- The National Youth Administration will expand its activities in the fiscal year 1937 with larger funds, Aubrey W. Williams, executive director, announced today as the program entered its second year. There will be available the next fiscal year $71,250,000, allotted out of the $1,425,000,000 Deficiency Bill.

ESTES PARK., Col., June 27. -- Governor Landon has devoted several hours of his vacation, he revealed today, to drafting his message to the special session of the Kansas Legislature, in which he will make an unequivocal recommendation for a constitutional amendment to qualify Kansas for participation in all phases of the Federal social security program.

CHICAGO, June 27. -- Movement of Winter wheat in the West and Southwest is expanding so rapidly that hedging against the grain more than dominated the action of the market on the Board of Trade today. An early advance of around 1 cent, laid to dry weather in the Northwest and strength in Liverpool, was quickly lost from persistent selling by houses with Southwestern connections, and final not losses were 3/8 to 1/2 cent.

The Mercury, the New York Central Railroad's steamlined steam train, which arrived in the Mott Haven yard Friday after an exhibition run from Indianapolis, will be exhibited in the Grand Central Station from 9 A.M. to 10 P.M. today and from 7 A.M. to 7:30 P.M. tomorrow.

NORTH DAKOTA will forget drought, despair and depression next week-end to again recall, in a three-day celebration on July 3, 4 and 5, the golden pages of history that have been turned in the seventy-five years since President James Buchanan set his hand to the act creating Dakota Territory, a vast land of plain and mountain, later to be divided into the States of North and South Dakota.

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 27. -- The newspaper La Nacion, the government's mouthpiece, denied today that there was any truth in statement persistently made by the opposition press that Chile's proposal partly to resume payments on its foreign-debt obligations under the plan embodied in Law 5,580 had completely failed.

Of all the competitors in the national swimming and diving championships at the Oriental Pool this week-end, the writer, for the second year in succession, found her interest most closely drawn to the little diving wonder from Miami. Last year it was inevitable that 11-year-old Mary Hoerger, winning her first national championship, should be the center of attention.

The cleverest thing about this Hollywood story is its original narrative scheme. The book begins with a publicity turn rapping out on his typewriter the first announcement of an excessively super movie: "Richard Halycutt, Vice President in Charge of Production of Premier Pictures, today announced --"

Heavy buying of both furniture and rugs is assured at home furnishings trade openings scheduled here and in Chicago July 6, executives said yesterday. Rug manufacturers, in particular, are certain of an active season and predicted yesterday that advance orders for merchandise will reach the highest volume figures since 1929.

MADRID, June 27. -- Spain is nationally eager to attract foreign tourists, and has established an excellent tourist information bureau here, with branches in other countries to facilitate their coming. She is also tentatively trying, on a small scale, a system of supplying cheap tourist pesetas, adopted by some other countries, but they are obtainable at present only in London.

MOSCOW, June 27. -- Alexander P. Serebrovsky, president of the Soviet Gold Trust, announced today at a special meeting here of the leaders of heavy industry that the trust had just accomplished a half year's program four days ahead of time, with an increase of 25 per cent in production and 39 per cent in labor productivity, as compared with last year.

THE MUNICIPAL AUDITORIUM, PHILADELPHIA, June 27. -- The Democratic party wound up its convention with a sweeping gesture of gallantry today, naming eight women as vice chairmen of its national committee.
If the Democratic platform adopted last week at Philadelphia were to be briefly described it might be said that the Democrats have changed their strategy more than their philosophy since 1932.
Two news items in your recent issues are grave symptoms of a serious malady which threatens the social order.
ST. PAUL, Minn., June 26. -- At least half of the politicians and candidates for office in the Central Northwest have been thrown into confusion and embarrassment by the Lemke-Coughlin movement.

What effect will the new Union party, headed by Representative William Lemke of North Dakota as Presidential candidate, have upon the election next November? That question has been asked by the politically minded everywhere since the announcement of the new party eight days ago.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 27. -- In a gray day of light, fitful breezes, Van S. Merle-Smith's international twelve-meter Seven Seas, W.R. Manny's handicap twelve Night Wind, Sam Pirie's thirty-footer Oriole, Mrs. Van Wyck W. Loomis's interclub Nixie and H.G. Hanan's fifty-footer Spartan sailed to victory in the regatta held by the New Rochelle Yacht Club this afternoon.

DUBLIN, June 26 -- The de Valera government has won out in its first big trial of strength with the Irish Republican Army, which it has proclaimed illegal. Acting with firmness, the President used every force at his disposal to enforce, successfully, the ban on the extremists' proposed parade last Sunday at the grave of the eighteenth-century Republican patriot, Theobald Wolfe Tone, at Bodenstown, Kildare.

AN Ohio country school where there are no "report cards" and no pupils "left back" is to have a $5,000 grant from the Keith Fund of New York next year to help it work out an ideal program for rural children.

The plan of reorganization filed with the Federal court in Chicago by the Chicago North Western Railway and one that the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific proposed to file in that court are considered in Wall Street to exemplify the present gap between the views of bondholders and of managements on the rights of security holders in railway bankruptcies or receiverships.
MELBOURNE, Australia, June 26. -- In the last twenty years, the trade between Japan and Australia has increased more than tenfold.

THE "one-man" delphinium show open today until 6 P.M. and continuing through Wednesday is one of the most interesting flower displays ever staged in the metropolitan district. The blooms shown represent the results of twenty-six years of cross-breeding and selection by Edward Steichen, artist and photographer, who is president of the American Delphinium Society, in his ten-acre "delphinium laboratory."
It is a singular fact that many persons believe nervous diseases are more prevalent in the foreign-born population of large American cities.
CHICAGO, June 27. -- One hundred-degree heat returned to sections of the drought belt today after scattered showers.

PHILADELPHIA, June 27. -- Vice President Garner did not attend the convention session today at which he was renominated. In his room at the Bellevue-Stratford he listened in on the speech placing him in nomination and the seconding speeches.

Clarence Chamberlin, veteran airplane pilot, discussed yesterday further plans for his proposed stratosphere flight to Europe. He arrived in New York after his marriage Friday in Maine to a former school teacher of that State who is also the holder of a student's pilot license.

BAYHEAD, N.J., June 27. -- Despite the handicap of miserable weather conditions, sixty yachts turned out in nine classes for the opening of the thirty-sixth annual championship season of the Barnegat Bay Yacht Racing Association today.

Mayor La Guardia will be the principal speaker tomorrow evening in Carnegie Hall at the annual commencement of the New York Training School for Officers of the Salvation Army at which seventy-five will be graduated.

PHILADELPHIA, June 27. -- The most blatant, highly mechanized, elaborately specified and blueprinted, vociferous, vertiginous, vocal and voluble week of political exhibitionism this country ever saw has now come to a clamorous end.

Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's Discovery needs new worlds to conquer, for he easily flipped aside the most formidable challenger for his crown of handicap champion when he won the Brooklyn Handicap for the third time yesterday at Aqueduct.

ALBANY, June 27 (AP). -- The government's "emergency two-year colleges" will reopen in September in fifteen up-State communities, but several others will not reopen because of a lack of students, the WPA announced today.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP). -- For almost fifteen years, through the period of "normalcy" with President Harding, "prosperity" with President Coolidge, the beginning of the "depression" with President Hoover and the "New Deal" with President Roosevelt, the phrase "That man McCarl" has been one of the most suggestive on the Washington scene.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 27. -- Retail trade in the Ninth District rose sharply in the urban districts this week. Department stores reported gains of 8 per cent over a week ago, while smaller shops showed sharper increases. Warm weather brought the rise.

With gains for the first half of the year surpassing expectations, advertising volume for the coming six months will register even sharper increases and bring the total close to that of the early days of the depression, advertisers and agency executives predicted here yesterday.

LAKE HOPATCONG, N.J. -- The Lake Hopatcong Yacht Club will hold its first dance of the season on July 4, topping it off with a display of fireworks. The first yacht race of the season is being sailed today.

Price trends were mixed on local commodity futures markets last week, with copper, cocoa, rubber, silk and tallow stronger, while other metals, hides, sugar, coffee and wool tops eased. On the cash markets wheat, rye, oats, cotton, butter, silk and rubber gained and cocoa made a new high, while corn, lard, eggs and tins declined, the last named to new lows.

THE MUNICIPAL AUDITORIUM, PHILADELPHIA, June 27. -- With the galleries nearly empty of spectators and not more than half the delegates present, the Democratic National Convention renominated Vice President Garner of Texas, by acclamation at an unenthusiastic final session in this auditorium.

CHERCHEZ la femme," said Mr. Arthur Mayer in his best Harvard French. Broadway's fighting exponent of male rights in the cinema was standing in front of his modernistic Rialto Theatre with a copy of Freud in one hand and Variety in the other.

NEE ALNEENG, Ariz., June 27 (AP). -- A veteran white trader, trusted as a brother in secret councils of the Navajos, joined today in the renewal of the ancient Indian ceremony of supplication for rain.

RECENT rains and cooler weather have helped to keep the foliage of the Spring-blooming bulbs -- daffodils, tulips and all the hosts of smaller things which contribute to the gay vernal pageantry -- growing to a later date than usual. This augurs well for next Spring's blooms, for with this type of plant the growth made after flowering in one season determines to a large extent what the performance will be in another season.

THIS book, which furnishes an interesting footnote to Texas history, comes as a part of the centennial celebration straight from the pen of a Texas author and the presses of a Texas publishing house that describes itself as "publishers in and of the Southwest."

FOR a long time the townsfolk of Victoria, capital of the British Seychelles Islands in the Indian Ocean, have been terrified by a mysterious and elusive band of nocturnal robbers. Now the police have discovered that the thieves were none other than the convicts of Victoria Prison.

BOSTON, June 27 (AP). -- Nearly 25,000 persons at Suffolk Downs today saw Donald Christmas's Accolade, an 8-1 shot, smash home to a neck victory in the Puritan Handicap, mile and a sixteenth feature. Accolade turned in a time of 1:44 3-5.
HACKENSACK, N.J., June 27. -- The winning streak of Miss Norma Taubele on the tennis courts came to an end today.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 27. -- Thirteen of the yachts in the 635-mile race from Newport had arrived here tonight, and the winner of the long thrash, into which was injected a Gulf Stream gale that lasted ten hours, was Robert P. Baruch's new sloop Kirawan, which is only 53 feet long on her deck.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., June 27. -- Dr. Howard W. Odum, head of the Department of Sociology in the University of North Carolina and founder and director of its Institute for Social Research, returned today after a brief absence to find himself charged with the responsibility and duty of carrying out a plan he had suggested for consideration by the Institute on Regional Development which assembled here at his invitation last week.

AT a cost of only a few dollars above ordinary living expenses, the nation's capital offers the Summer visitor a well-rounded vacation. The superintendent of National Capital Parks has just prepared a sample fourteen-day vacation schedule in detail to show how wide a variety of activities the vacationist can find.
IF "Ocean Racing," by Alfred F. Loomis, were merely a collection of records to be kept to gather dust in the library of this yacht club or that, the book,

PARIS, June 26 -- For the first month of its existence the Left Popular Front majority in the Chamber of Deputies has stood behind Premier Leon Blum and his colleagues in the government. There is as yet no sign of any break despite the severe strain that has been put on some of its member parties by the strike epidemic in France and the measures that have been taken to satisfy the strikers.

WASHINGTON, June 27. -- Drought once again is gripping the plains country, driving home to millions west of the Mississippi, and particularly to those who inhabit the Dakotas and Montana, the fact that science is still helpless to control the elements.

IF YOU do not get your emotional thrills from this novel, it is hardly for lack of effort on the part of Polan Banks. The plot is highly spiced, complex, unusual -- to put it mildly; the hero is a wealthy, well-born New Yorker who owns a historic mansion on the Hudson called January Heights.

Principally via a four-run drive in the eighth inning, the Police Department stole victory from the grasp of their rivals, the Fire Department, in their annual baseball game staged before more than 25,000 spectators at the Yankee Stadium yesterday.
PARIS, June 25. -- An afternoon tea party in the Longchamp pesage, between the races, is one of this season's innovations. Rose or mauve linen tailleurs, made with velvet collars, were notable.

GARDENERS who have admired some beautiful bearded iris in a neighbor's yard, or at a flower show, my act now if they wish to make sure of having similar flowers blooming in their own gardens next year. The iris planting season is at hand, and best results will be had if the plants are obtained and set out at an early date.

COMMENT on the broadcasting of a prizefight goes 'round and 'round in radio circles for many days after the final gong. The listeners then have their innings; some of them are highly complimentary and others quite critical.

The League of Nations stands today at a turning point, in the opinion of Arthur Sweetser of Boston, the only American among the directors of the League's Permanent Secretariat. It is facing both its most critical and its most interesting period.

The steamer Lorentz W. Hansen will arrive in New York some time late today and after loading at several piers will sail again tomorrow for Labrador with the annual supplies for the International Grenfell Association's welfare headquarters at St. Anthony's.

INCIDENTAL pieces of luggage that hold the things one wants on a Fourth of July week-end trip or a jaunt by automobile are important items in most baggage collections. There is one light-weight, fabric-covered case, measuring about a foot square and five inches deep, in which one can carry indispensable lotions and creams, as well as other immediate necessaries.

MILWAUKEE, June 26. -- The newly formed Union party is causing no waves of enthusiasm in Wisconsin, but may become quite a factor in reducing President Roosevelt's heavy vote in this La Follette-controlled State. The La Follette brothers are considered friendly to Roosevelt.

Few people who listened on the radio to recent "convention proceedings," or who read the next morning's newspaper account, can have escaped a sense of incongruity. Delegates were assembled, at Cleveland and Philadelphia, to declare the principles and select the candidate of the political party which might conduct, in the next four years, the affairs of a great Government.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that he had signed a resolution of the Municipal Civil Service Commission which, if approved by the State Civil Service Commission, would put some 4,000 now exempt employes of the Department of Hospitals under civil service next Jan. 1.
ELMIRA, N.Y., June 27. -- Ground entertainment held the attention of visitors at the national soaring contest as gliders and planes lay about Harris Hill becalmed.

Thirty persons, including several children, were injured yesterday afternoon when the ferryboat Syracuse went out of control and crashed into a slip at the West Shore Railroad terminal in Weehawken, N.J.

PARIS, June 27. -- Private bankers from eighteen countries attended the first meeting of its kind under the auspices of the International Chamber of Foreign Commerce and heard speakers strongly urge the nation to favor an international stabilization agreement.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -The Chamber of Commerce of the United States said today that Congress, in the rush for adjournment, passed legislation "vitally affecting business without mature consideration of the consequences."

MR. KOMROFF'S tale of the Corsican's Hundred Days is a lively scenario. As a novel it is interesting but undistinguished. He is to be admired for the temerity to compete at times with Houssaye as a historian and Thackeray in the Duchess of Richmond's ballroom.

Thousands of motorists are filing applications in the National Safe Driver Contest being conducted by the American Automobile Association with the support of the C.I.T. Safety Foundation, it was reported yesterday. To be eligible for the contest an applicant must have driven 50,000 miles in the last ten years without an accident or conviction for any violation of traffic regulations.

SINCLAIR LEWIS has recently been visiting Waterbury, Conn., as the guest of his friend and Yale classmate, E. Robert Stevenson, editor of The Waterbury Republican and The Waterbury American. When interviewed by Jerry Harrington, THE NEW YORK TIMES Waterbury correspondent, Mr. Sinclair declined to discuss the nature of his next novel, but he made no secret of the fact that he was spending hours on end going through the Waterbury brass factories.
TORONTO, Ont., June 27. -- Ontario's production of gold in May fell more than $100,000 below the value for April. The figure was $6,511,801, compared with $6,646,735 in April and $6,714,506 in March.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 27. -- A list of 115 officers of twenty-three Princeton University undergraduate organizations for the year 1936-37 was made public today by Professor Christian Gauss, dean of the college.

AN apple a day keeps the doctor away," and then again maybe it doesn't. I am not, however, entering upon a joust with doctors or with apples, but with another catch line equally as susceptible of criticism in my opinion.

Led by the French franc and other gold-bloc currencies the foreign exchanges rallied strongly against the dollar yesterday, driving the United States currency unit to a discount for the first time in fourteen weeks.

ATLANTA, June 26. -- The kaleidoscopic whirl of events during the past ten days has seen the exile of Eugene Talmadge from his never more than precarious foot-hold in the National Democratic organization, and the Fourth of July will reveal the plans of the Georgia Governor to retain his grip in State politics.

TWO schools of thought have developed relative to the introduction of radio-sight to the public. One contends television for its debut must be full-grown and the first home-receivers will cost as much as an automobile. The other group believes that television need not be a "bearded baby," and that the machines may be built for about $250.

WASHINGTON, June 27. -- Additional cotton held under the 1936 loan will be released for immediate domestic consumption and export at a minimum of 12 1/4 cents a pound on the twelve-cent loan and 11 1/4 cents on the eleven-cent loan, the Commodity Credit Corporation announced today.

CAPE TOWN, Union of South Africa. -- The Union's unsatisfactory trade balance with the United States was debated recently in the House of Assembly, the Union Parliament, and the government was severely taken to task for allowing South African trade to be dominated by the Stars and Stripes.

CHICAGO, June 27. -- Ernest Sutter, Tulane ace, marched into the final round of the national intercollegiate tennis championships at Northwestern University today with a victory over Ramsay Potts of North Carolina, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 2.

The speed with which skilled relief workers are being reabsorbed into private industry was reflected in a report, made public yesterday, of the number of skilled workers transferred from the Emergency Relief Bureau to the Works Progress Administration last month.

The Citizens Family Welfare Committee drew nearer to its goal of $1,500,000 yesterday when Laurence M. Marks, chairman, announced receipt of additional gifts of $20,184 from employes of the Consolidated Edison system.

Under the Robinson-Patman Anti-Price Discrimination Act, the problem of the manufacturer of most nationally distributed goods has now probably become one of justifying why certain types of quantity orders are not given lower prices than those which have prevailed in the past, according to an analysis of the act from the standpoint of national distributor, issued yesterday by the Institute o Distribution, 570 Seventh Avenue.

THE annual appearance of striped bass, kingfish, bluefish and other species along the Atlantic Seaboard attracts thousands of surf anglers who are aware of the wonderful sport to be had by casting into the breakers.
PHILADELPHIA, June 27 (AP). -- New Jersey Democrats announced today as the National Convention ended they would start immediately an intensive campaign to carry the State in November.

RICHMOND, Va., June 27. -- College outboard racing made an invasion of Dixie this week-end for the first time since it was inaugurated seven years ago at Colgate and on the first of three days of competition no fewer than six intercollegiate marks were hoisted to new highs.

BOSTON, June 26. -- Now that the Republican pre-primary convention is over, the Massachusetts electorate knows the choices to be made next November. For Governor they must choose between John W. Haigis, veteran Republican legislator, and Charles F. Hurley, youthful State Treasurer, endorsed two weeks ago by the Democratic convention.
DOVER, Del., June 27 (AP). -- Senator Hastings, Republican, of Delaware, said today he found nothing to commend in the new Democratic platform.
TOKYO, June 27. -- The police chiefs from all the districts in Japan have been in conference with the central authorities in Tokyo Thursday and yesterday.

TO the list of Summer dance activities already announced must now be added a post-scrip of particular interest. This has to do with the formation of a little ballet company which is planning to tour the Summer theatres under the name of the Ballet Caravan.

Mexico, D.F. WITH elaborate ceremonies participated in by government representatives of Mexico and the United States, the new Mexican Highway will be formally opened next Wednesday, and the army of American motorists who for years have waited for the occasion will at last be able, without difficulty, to invade the republic to the South.

IT was the good ship Stortebeker, ketch-rigged, fifty-four feet in length, fifteen feet in beam, with a draft of seven feet and twenty-one tons net register, and Philip Rigg sailed her, with the aid of a crew of three men, from Athens, Greece, to Miami, Fla., the passage requiring six months.

TRENTON, N.J., June 27. -- George Stoddard, 39 years old, of Newark, a convict, was fatally shot by Leo Kennedy, a tower guard, while Stoddard was attempting to escape over the wall of the New Jersey State prison here this afternoon.

CAMP TAMIMENT, Pa., June 27. -- Two bills, designed to accomplish the purposes of the New York Minimum Wage Law, invalidated by the Supreme Court, are being considered by the Federal Government, Henry Epstein, Solicitor General of New York, disclosed today in an address before the Tamiment Economic Social Institute.

OUTSTANDING events of the second week of Stadium Concerts will include the appearance of Harold Bauer tomorrow night as soloist in the Schumann piano concerto; an all Wagner program Tuesday; the first American performance of "Impresiones Portenas" by the Argentine composer Jose Andre.

EIGHTEEN and a half years have passed since the Soviet Revolution; and in the U.S.S.R. boys and girls "come of age," that is to say, have voting rights as citizens, on their eighteenth birthday. This means much in terms of human values. It means that there has grown up a new generation of Russian youth, which has nothing in its consciousness save the revolution.

CAPE MAY, N. J. -- With the hydrangeas blooming in Cape May, indications are that the annual flower festival will be a brilliant affair. A meeting of city officials and the flower committee will be held next week to set a definite date for the event.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 27. -- An introductory course of public lectures on astronomy by Dr. Harlow Shapley, in which the director of Harvard Observatory will explain problems of the cosmos in terms understandable to the layman, will be a feature of the special astronomical work of the Harvard Summer School session from July 6 to Aug. 15.

FRANKLIN FIELD, PHILADELPHIA, June 27. -- Probably the most impressive setting for a notification ceremony in the history of the United States was that witnessed here tonight when President Roosevelt and Vice President Garner were notified by the officials and delegates of the recently adjourned Democratic National Convention that they had been called to carry the party's standard again in the campaign of 1936.

PEIPING, June 27. -- Acute tension prevails throughout Tsingtao today following three hours of rioting last night in which a Japanese mob of more than 1,000 persons attempted to attack the Custom House.

THERE is a mentality in all of us that is enriched by the small talk of great people. Major Chapman-Huston is a thought-reader who elicits a supply of such gossip to meet the demand. This volume is a reaping of the latest harvest.

LYNCH, Neb., June 27. -- Archaeologists who this week unearthed the site of a large Indian city probably 4,000 years old and, beneath that, another village site, undoubtedly much older, hope to link Nebraska chronology with European to get a better estimate of the antiquity of the discoveries.

Although yesterday's unsettled weather threatened to interfere with last night's concert at the Lewisohn Stadium, the skies cleared before the crowds arrived, and the only storm was the one Jose Iturbi, the conductor, evoked in its proper place in the Beethoven "Pastoral" symphony.

Although the bulk of the political news of the week emanated from the convention floor in Philadelphia, there was much activity in other camps. On the right, the Republicans launched their campaign with a drive in New York State, while their candidate from Kansas went on holiday.

OMAHA, Neb., June 26. -- In the Corn Belt there is virtually unanimous agreement on three points: (1) That the Lemke ticket cannot hope to carry any of these Middle Western farm States; (2) that it serves to confuse somewhat the issues of the coming campaign; (3) that it is likely to prove damaging to President Roosevelt.

The new Thomas Jefferson Park swimming pool at First Avenue and 112th Street was dedicated yesterday by Mayor La Guardia "to the children and people of Harlem," among them certain "pedochiosi," who, the Mayor said, had tried to prevent construction of the natatorium.

THE Vienna Radio performed a real artistic service recently by twice broadcasting Schumann's "Genoveva." This is an opera which one hardly ever encounters in the course of a musical lifetime. Operatic managers dream of producing it as little as they do the works of Spohr and even less than things like Weber's "Euryanthe" or the operas of Heinrich Marschner.

Mayor La Guardia's determination to build up a group of career men in the city service was carried a step further yesterday when he invited sixteen high school pupils, eight boys and eight girls, some of them this year's graduates, to accept city posts for July and August and study the workings of the city government.

Poetic justice designated Senator BENNETT CHAMP CLARK of Missouri to bring in a unanimous report abolishing the two-thirds rule in Democratic National Conventions. The most conspicuous victim of that rule was his father, the late CHAMP CLARK.
WE should, of course, have seen the reflected glory at once when the mighty figure of the darkly gleaming Angel Gabriel stepped across the threshold, but his opening remarks sort of threw us off.

The first two Regional Contests in the Teachers' Syllabus and Article Contests on the Constitution of the United States being conducted by THE NEW YORK TIMES were completed last week with the final judging in the City Junior Regional Contests.

Herbert Bayard Swope, a leader in the movement to induce Governor Lehman to accept renomination, issued a statement early today in reply to a newspaper story that the New York State delegation to the Democratic National Convention was not whole-heartedly behind the movement.
GENEVA, June 27 (AP). -- Nazi Germany and Nazi problems in Danzig stirred the anxiety of League of Nations powers today.

WATERTOWN, Conn., June 27. -- Question Mark, an imposing looking 8-year-old chestnut gelding owned by Miss Fredericka Fry of Greenwich and shown by Arthur McCashin, accounted for an important and somewhat unexpected victory today at the second session of the tenth annual Watertown horse show when he triumphed in the Corinthian Class for Hunters.

After the coroner of Paddington, London, had read to the inquest jury the following letter addressed by Costas Savva Haii Kvriacou, a baker, to his parents and brother and sister in Cyprus, they delivered a verdict that Costas had committed suicide while of unsound mind.

NEWARK, N.J., June 27. -- Police Captain P. Joseph Quinn of the Second precinct and twelve plainclothes men under his command were transferred to other duties today as the result of a raid yesterday afternoon on an alleged horse race betting establishment at 371 Lake Street.

PHILADELPHIA, June 27. -- The New York delegation, assembling for the last time at today's session, went on record unanimously in demanding that Governor Lehman consent to head the State ticket again this Fall.

WASHINGTON, June 27. -- A program involving millions and the coordination of several Federal agencies was started today by Secretary Wallace to bring some measure of relief in what was described as one of the worst drought crises in the history of the country.
PHILADELPHIA, June 27. -- Following is the prepared text of the speech of Vice President Garner in acceptance of renomination:

SO-CALLED independent car manufacturers are rapidly heading back toward prosperous times. Some of the outstanding performances of the year, in both sales and production, have been achieved outside the ranks of the Big Three, General Motors, Ford and Chrysler.

THEY called themselves "Shameless Shirkers," Zephine Humphrey and Christopher, her artist husband, as they began to think about doing something else that Winter, because there were so many things they ought to stay at home for.

BY this morning Norman Bel Geddes has almost certainly bought a play called "Iron Men," by Francis Gallagher. "Construction Job" was its original title, and perhaps that says all you need to know about it at the moment: Locale, New York; treatment, serious.

SORRY: At Gosport, England, last Monday, a young pilot of the Royal Air Force flew his plane low over the liner Normandie's smoking funnel and was sucked down by a hot air current. His plane crashed on the deck, doing little damage. The pilot crawled out unharmed and told Captain Rene Pugnet: "I am terribly sorry about this."

The report of the SEC proposing a limited segregation of the functions of brokers and dealers raises the important question of the extent to which segregation can legally and constitutionally be required.

ALTHOUGH it may be admitted that a small dose of dictatorship is wholesome for a democratic community now and then, if only to make it self-conscious of its inalienable attributes, it is not precisely true that Gambetta administered that dose to France for four months in 1870-1871.

THIS Summer, more than usual, the Boy Scouts will be busy exchanging visits with fellow Scouts throughout the world. The United States will be host to groups from Poland, Norway and the Canal Zone. Abroad, in Estonia, Finland, Austria, Rumania, Norway and England, national Jamborees will be held, at which delegations from other lands will be present.

About all there is to report on the share market on the week is that the list closed irregular in slightly more active trading. The announcement of the Democratic platform was of little influence, marketwise, just as the Republican convention a fortnight earlier was hardly a market factor.
CLEVELAND, June 27 (AP). -- The Indians pounded four Boston pitchers for a total of twenty-one hits to defeat the Red Sox, 14 to 5, today.
After Friday's sharp advance, trading on the Cotton Exchange quieted yesterday, but final quotations were the highest close of the season and were up 4 to 6 points on the day.

A survey covering the views of some 250,000 consumers, reached by questionnaire or direct questioning, shows the belief that fur coats will cut heavily into Fall cloth coat sales to be groundless, according to Miss Ada Kay Price, fashion director of Kirby, Block Co., who made the survey.

THE practical side of modern decorative art is being stressed in the architecture and interior arrangement of many new metropolitan apartment homes. Bizarre shapes and ornamentation, created in a striving for originality, are disappearing, and the modern designer and decorator are today building on the principles of good design, just as applicable in a skyscraper penthouse as they were in a Colonial mansion.
DISREGARDING Summer vacations, school work goes on uninterruptedly the year round in forty universities, as more than 100,000 students continue to toil through 6,000 correspondence courses.

OMAHA, June 25. -- Mounting apprehension of severe grasshopper damage reached a climax with a flight of migratory pests across Nebraska and Western Iowa. The insects were identified as akin to the Rocky Mountain locusts, a scourge in the Corn Belt sixty years ago.

Fourteen men were named members of the American Olympic field handball team yesterday following the final trials at the Castle Hill Athletic Field, in which a team of Blues routed a Red combination, 14 -- 4.

WATERTOWN, Conn., June 28. -- Once again that sterling thoroughbred timber topper, Woodfellow, owned by Miss Helen Bedford's Wynfromere Farm of Green Farms, Conn., and shown by Miss Bedford, was adjudged the hunter champion as the three-day stand of the tenth annual Watertown Horse Show was concluded today on the grounds of the Watertown Riding and Country Club.
Harry Kronenberg, 24-year-old clerk of 2,149 Sixty-sixth Street, Brooklyn, died in the Israel Zion Hospital, Brooklyn, shortly after noon yesterday of a head injury received in a ball game Saturday.

City and State officials will attend the formal ground-breaking and flag-raising ceremonies for the 1939 World's Fair on the 1,050-acre site at Flushing Meadows today. The program, to be widely broadcast, will begin at 12:30 P.M., with music by the sixty-five-piece Department of Sanitation Band.

CHICAGO, June 28. -- Prices of hogs advanced last Week to the highest level since April 27, the top being $10.75 a hundredweight, which was $1.15 above the low level of May. Reduced marketing with a better general demand was the basis for the unusual price appreciation.

NEWARK, N.J., June 28. -- As the climax of an all-night party, John Chicorska, 28 years old, of 423 Springfield Avenue, Newark, early today shot his estranged wife four times and then put a bullet through his heart in Branch Brook Park here.

CHICAGO, June 28. -- With dry weather over the greater part of the leading corn-producing States there is a feeling in the trade that unless general and timely rains appear soon the corn crop will be much smaller than earlier expectations.
Without fanfare or ceremonies, television images will be broadcast across the New York area today in the official opening of the $1,000,000 field tests instituted by the Radio Corporation of America.

STRATFORD, Conn., June 28. -Frank R. Kelly, who in the short span of two and one-half years has become recognized as one of the country's outstanding marksmen, continued to hold the spotlight at the Great Eastern skeet-shooting championships, which came to an end today at the Lordship traps.

Three passengers in a light sedan escaped without serious injury at 2 P.M. yesterday when their machine landed upside down on a rocky ledge thirty feet below Riverside Drive, south of the Dyckman Street ferry, after a triple collision on the Drive.

Samuel J. Battle, the first Negro to become a member of the New York City police force, celebrated two anniversaries yesterday. The first was that of his marriage, which took place June 28, 1905, the other was that of his joining the police force, June 28, 1911.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., June 28. -- Mrs. Thomas H. Barber gave a luncheon today at Claverack House, her place here, for the Rev. Dr. Theodore Sedgwick, former rector of St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Church in Rome, who conducted the services at St. Andrew's Dune Church this morning.

Members of local lodges of the Loyal Orange Institution of America paraded yesterday from Mecca Temple at 133 West Fifty-fifth Street to Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street, for the annual church service of the organization.
The opening paragraph of the Democratic National Platform is magnificent -- but it is not true.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 28. -Checking a father-and-son team in the final, W. Neal Fulkerson Jr., former Long Island amateur champion, and F.G. Brown won the Cherry Valley Club's invitation golf tourney today.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange last week reached the highest levels of the season. It was the fifth consecutive week in which prices made net advances, the gains ranging from 14 to 18 points.

Mary Pickford and Jesse L. Lasky, two of Hollywood's pioneers, have decided to dissolve their company, Pickford-Lasky Productions, Inc., upon completion of "The World Is Mine," now in production with Nino Martini at the United Artists studio.
CHICAGO, June 28 (AP). -- They dealt some big surprises in the qualifying round of the all-American bridge championships of the American Whist League today.

The mind over the weekend has been running much to Indians. In part it would be the Summer vacation pages in the paper, with their trails of all kinds -- woods trails and mountain trails and water trails.

ELMIRA, N.Y., June 28. -Twenty-three gliders, all the craft entered in the national soaring contest here, were in the air at one time today, and a new contest altitude record of 5,760 feet for two-seater gliders was set by Gilbert Slatter of Los Angeles and John D. Batterson of Pasadena, Calif. In a two-hour-and-21-minute flight they took the "transporter" to Tioga Point, Pa., twenty-five miles away.

Is the world turning upside down? Radical Soviet Russia ordains in Article 12 of her new Constitution that "he who shall not work shall not eat," while backward United States proclaims through the New Deal platform that he who shall not work shall enjoy happiness nevertheless because it is the duty of the government to promote the happiness of its citizens whether they work or not.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., June 28. -- More than 1,000 delegates at the opening of the annual convention of the Independent Order B'rith Abraham voted this afternoon to conduct the golden jubilee of the order in connection with the fiftieth convention in New York City next year.

In these days of confusion, when leaders raise contradictory voices, people should learn to be tolerant toward all the major issues before them, the Rev. Dr. Randolph Ray said yesterday in his sermon at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration (Little Church Around the Corner), 1 East Twenty-ninth Street.

From the viewpoint of "first-page news," last week's Philadelphia convention held the stage. If there had been any doubt beforehand regarding the convention's action, markets might have been affected by it. But everything happened according to expectation.

CONCORD, N.H., June 28. -Former Senator George H. Moses announced tonight that he will be a candidate in the Sept. 15 Republican primary for a nomination to return to the Senate, from which he was retired four years ago.
BOSTON, June 28 (AP). -- The season's largest crowd at National League Park, 18,133, saw the Bees outplay the Pirates, 6 to 4, in the nightcap today, after being crushed, 11 to 2, in the opener.

A record-breaking 300-meter medley relay race in which Mrs. Eleanor Holm Jarrett again starred to put the Women's Swimming Association team in first place, and the 880-yard free style championship which went to Mrs. Lenore Kight Wingard without dispute, were the two events which brought the four-day program of the women's national swimming and diving championships at Manhattan Beach to a satisfactory close yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 28. -- There will be no change in the "security wage" paid to WPA workers under the extended program to begin July 1, Aubrey Williams, Acting WPA Administrator, announced today.

LONDON, June 27. -- The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood at 70.2 on June 24, compared with 69.9 two weeks before, 69.8 a month before and with 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931.

An important item of Great Britain's royal memorabilia, a Lord Chancellor's Purse, the repository for the Great Seal of the realm, has been presented to the Association of the Bar of the City of New York by a member, Barnett L. Hollander, whose law practice is in London.

CHICAGO, June 28. -- Dry weather has cut down the oats crop to small proportions, a situation that has spurred covering by shorts, and new speculative and processor buying. Reports from Illinois and Iowa indicate that farmers can get more from the government by plowing up their oats crop than can be obtained in the regular market way, indicating that yields will be below early expectations.

An increase of $300,000 in the budget of the Health Department for 1937 to permit extension of the medical and nursing service in the elementary and junior high schools was urged upon Mayor La Guardia in a letter sent yesterday by William B. Nichols, president, and Frank E. Karelsen Jr., chairman of the executive committee for the Public Education Association.

LONDON, June 27. -- The note circulation of the Bank of England, now at a new peak of 434,789,000, or 38,000,000 above that of a year ago, is expected to reach 450,000,000 by August. The bank's gold purchases in June have exceeded 10,000,000, and if the total stocks were written up to sterling quotations an enormous scope for credit expansion would result.

ITHACA, N.Y., June 28. -- A new mechanism in living cells which reveals a spinning process of the thread-like things -- chromosomes -that govern hereditary traits was announced today at Cornell University.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 28. -- Miss Julia A. Berwind, who had Mr. and Mrs. Parmely Herrick among her week-end guests, gave a luncheon at the Elms today. Mrs. M.M. Van Beuren was a luncheon hostess at Gray Craig. Mrs. Alfred N. Wheeler gave a luncheon at the Baldwin cottage, and the first luncheon of the season was given at the Gooseberry Island Fishing Club.

BOSTON, June 28. -- Advertising's fight of twenty-five years against, dishonesty and fraud and its innumerable contributions to the social and economic welfare of the American people were hailed this afternoon at a meeting held in historic Faneuil Hall as a preliminary to the opening session tomorrow of the annual convention of the Advertising Federation of America.

Helpless to defend themselves, the Giants went down twice before the Cubs at the Polo Grounds yesterday to the undisguised dismay of some 33,000 fans. They were merely the other team on the field, and not much of a team at that, as the clan of Charlie Grimm used them as a take-off spring for a vault back into first place for the first time since May 8.

PHILADELPHIA, June 28. -- For the second straight day Ernie Riedel of the Pendleton Canoe Club, New York, excelled in the final Olympic tryouts on the Schuylkill River today, winning two of the four events over the 1,000-meter or short course.

FARGO, N.D., June 28 (AP). -Governor Walter Welford apparently defeated William Langer by 507 votes for the Republican Gubernatorial nomination in North Dakota in the most bitterly fought contest for that office in State history, complete unofficial returns showed today.
MOSCOW, June 28. -- The Arch of Triumph, built by Alexander I to celebrate Napoleon's retreat from Moscow, is to be razed to make way for traffic.

LONDON, June 26. -- Germany's trade push is stirring up anxious attention in Britain as the Reich's new policy is showing increasing returns, and its continued success, it is held, depends on the capture of markets now the almost exclusive field of British exporters.

A slight thunderstorm that broke suddenly at 11 A.M., in a day that had dawned bright and clear, interrupted travel to the beaches and other resorts yesterday and held back crowds until after 3 P.M., when the skies cleared.

BERLIN, June 28. -- The money market is under the influence of the flotation of the 700,000,000 reichsmark loan by the government to consolidate some of the short-term obligations taken up for the financing of work schemes. Still, the market has been fluid for several weeks, and the success of Dr. Hjalmar Schacht's visit to Jugoslavia, Greece, Bulgaria and Hungary has provided a further impetus.

WASHINGTON, June 28. -- President Roosevelt plans to make a final decision as to whether the much-debated Passamaquoddy tidal power project shall be continued or permanently shelved when he makes his scheduled mid-July visit to his Summer home on Campobello Island, near Eastport, Me., where construction work has centered, an authoritative source revealed here today.

FREEPORT, L.I., June 28. -Thirteen persons went into the waters of Jones Inlet near here today when an explosion and fire wrecked the boat from which they were fishing. Two of them were blown out of the craft by the force of the blast and the others jumped to escape the fire, one nearly being drowned.
CHICAGO, June 28. -- Fears of higher food prices rose with the heat waves on the Western plains today as drought burned deeper into fertile fields.

Two men, said by witnesses to have been stunting near Fitzmaurice Airport at Massapequa, L. I., were killed about 4:30 P.M. yesterday when their Arrow sport model biplane, with a sixty horsepower motor, crashed north of the field.

Retail buyers in the wholesale markets here last week were particularly interested in the offerings of apparel and accessories for early Fall. Retailers took advantage of special groups of Summer merchandise to fill in their stocks, which have been sharply reduced in many instances as a result of active consumer demand recently.
PORT WASHINGTON. L.I., June 28. -- A 16-year-old girl and a youth, 17, were rescued in Long Island Sound this afternoon after clinging to an overturned boat for more than an hour.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., June 28. -- An unerring putter today enabled Donald Hotaling, a former Dartmouth star, unexpectedly to conquer Tommy Goodwin of Winged Foot, 3 and 2, in the final-round eighteen-hole match of the third annual invitation tournament at the Briar Hills Golf and Country Club.

BURLINGTON, Iowa, June 28. --Larruping President Roosevelt, Governor Landon, and more especially Secretary Wallace, Representative Lemke of North Dakota today promised 5,000 perspiring Southeastern Iowans a "new day," not a "new deal with stacked cards," if he should be elected President.

KANSAS CITY, June 28. -- Earl W. Browder, named in New York today as Communist party candidate for President, first attracted attention in this section when he was arrested in Olathe, Kan., in June, 1917, after expressing opposition to the selective army draft.

Facing the unionization drive started among its 500,000 employes by organizing groups headed by John L. Lewis, the steel industry issued a statement yesterday through the American Iron and Steel Institute announcing that it would use all its resources to oppose the closed shop.
One hundred and twenty-two social agencies joined yesterday in warning out-of-town girls to stay away from this city unless they had funds to support themselves for one year.

Columbia University announced yesterday appointment of exchange fellows to and from Italian universities and also named a research fellow in Jewish history, an exchange student to China and two graduate residence scholars.

Earl Browder, general secretary of the Communist party of the United States, and James W. Ford, Negro leader from Harlem, were nominated by acclamation yesterday afternoon as the party's candidates for President and Vice President, respectively, at the final session of the ninth national Communist convention held at Madison Square Garden.
The following tables give the high and low prices for 1936, as well as last price, for all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange that were not traded in last week:...

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 28. -President Roosevelt's renomination was received here as a matter of course. His re-election is anticipated and will gladden the Pan-Americanists, who have found him a master and welder of inter-American relations, smashing the barriers of mistrust and building good-will under his "good neighbor" policy.

Picketing of one American Federation of Labor union by another will be added to Union Square's cycle of labor experience his morning, if instructions issued last night by A.N. Weinberg, manager of the Paper Box Makers Union, Local 18,239, are carried out.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 28. -The week-end movement of 5,300 New York State National Guard members was marred today when three infantrymen of Company G of Oneonta, a unit of the Tenth Infantry of Albany, were injured when the motor truck in which they were riding struck a pole while on the return trip to the home armory after two weeks of training at Camp Smith.

CHICAGO, June 28 (AP). -- Ernest Sutter, 19-year-old Tulane University junior, won the national intercollegiate tennis championship at Northwestern University today with a smashing straight set victory over Vernon John of Southern California, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4.

PARIS, June 28. -- The return of the Bank of France of June 19 shows, for the first time, changes in its form as a result of the agreement of June 18 with the Blum government and approved by the Chamber of Deputies. It is well known that the bank had made disguised loans to the Treasury by discounting government bonds which were included without distinction, in bills discounted, among bankers' bills.

Maurice L. Farrell, chairman of the public relations committee of the New York Stock Exchange, announced yesterday that, at the invitation of the Institute of Public Affairs of the University of Virginia, the Exchange would sponsor a round-table discussion of financial affairs at the institute from July 6 to 11, inclusive.
LONDON, June 28. -- At the start of another Presidential election in the United States one can detect already a change in Britain's attitude toward American politics and foreign policy.

RYE, N.Y., June 28. -- Henry Daniels defeated Robert Low today at the Manursing Island Club in the all-Choate final of the invitation tennis tournament for eastern boarding schools. After losing the first set, Daniels regained the stellar form he had displayed in previous matches to win by 3 -- 6, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 2.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., June 28. -The Poughkeepsie (N.Y.) Garden Club paid a week-end visit to the Mount Everett State reservation at Mount Washington, Southern Berkshire, for the mountain laurel display. Mrs. Edmund J. Drummond had as luncheon guests at the Gateway House near the reservation entrance, Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Scoville, Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Firuski, and Mrs. Joseph Parsons of New York and Mr. and Mrs. Thomas E. Ripley of Santa Barbara, Calif.

TAMIMENT, Pa., June 28. -Speaking before the Tamiment Economic and Social Institute at its closing session here today, Senator Rush D. Holt of West Virginia, Democrat, assailed what he characterized as the dictatorship of the leaders in his party, attacked the WPA administration in his State as a corrupt political machine and accused the Roosevelt administration of failure to cope with the unemployment problem in a constructive manner.
BALTIMORE, June 28. -- Representative Marion A. Zioncheck escaped this morning from the Shepherd and Enoch Pratt Hospital at Towson.

Responding to the new fiscal program of the government, French francs last week soared to the highest in more than three months, carrying with it the other gold moneys which established new highs for the movement.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 28. -Harry Maxwell, old-time skipper in many classes, today added another triumph to his long string when he sailed his Twelve-Meter Handicap yacht Iris to first place in the special regatta conducted by the Larchmont Yacht Club.

Attorney General Cummings, Senator Wagner and Max D. Steuer are among the contributors to the second issue of District Attorney Dodge's personally conducted magazine, "The Human Side of the People's Case," which is published today.

Count de Chevasnerie, French explorer and hunter in Africa; Lady Thelma Furness and her son; Mr. de Camas, French Minister to Santo Domingo; Ortis Linares, First Secretary of the Bolivian Legation in Paris; Mrs. Linares, Princess Aymon de Faucigny, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Ryan and Loukas Roufos, former Greek Minister, are among the prominent persons arriving today on the French liner Normandie from Europe.

Professor Dora Davis Farrington, who has been teaching at Hunter College more than thirty years, will retire this month, it was learned yesterday. She is an Associate Professor in the Department of English.

The New York Conservation Department announces that in the past eight months it has acquired ninety miles of water which will be made available for public fishing. The program of acquisition was made possible by a legislative appropriation of $100,000.

In its bid for both sprint championships at Berlin six weeks hence the United States is very much in the same position as a pitcher who steps on the mound to face the first batter and finds that he has two strikes on him without even having tossed the ball.

LONDON, June 26. -- The first half of 1936 in British finance and trade has been satisfactory, both short and long-term credit being cheaper. An important feature was the internal stability of the pound, measured by wholesale prices which were reasonably stable throughout, while comparative stability also characterized the sterling bloc, and the pound was equally stable against gold currencies.

SINCE he completed "Stars Fell on Alabama" more than two years ago, Carl Carmer has been roaming New York State drumming up folklore and tall stories, hunting out "characters," discovering odd leftovers of the past in histories and the memories of old people. He has talked with Indians, lumberjacks, lunch counter men. A lady, 92 years old, told him of a handkiss she remembered from the early days of the Oneida Community.

NEW HAVEN, June 27. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 82.6, which compares with 82.5 the week before, 82.3 two weeks before, 81.2 three weeks before and 81.2 four weeks before.

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 28. -Lieutenant Dolph E. Muehleisen, Air Corps officer from Marchfield, Calif., not only captured the all-Army tennis singles championship today but, paired with Lieutenant Stanley K. Robinson. Air Corps officer from Bolling Field, Va., won the doubles title.

WASHINGTON, June 28. -- A gain of $16,491,929,000, or 19.72 per cent, in the aggregate gross income of corporations in 1934, as compared with 1933, was disclosed today in a preliminary report on 1934 income statistics issued by Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau.
Your recent editorial "Speechmaking Chairmen" is quite in error and, incidentally, unfair in its references to Mark Hanna, Republican National Chairman in 1896 and 1900.
CLEVELAND, June 28 (AP). -- The Indians bombarded three Boston pitchers today to score their third straight victory over the Red Sox, 11 -- 3, before 20,000 fans.

An independent protective committee for holders of the 6 1/2 per cent notes of the McCallum Hosiery Company, due in 1941, has been formed following the filing of a petition for reorganization under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act by the Propper-McCallum Hosiery Company, Inc., which assumed payment of the notes when it succeeded to the business of the former company in 1930.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 28. -In a group of resolutions deploring the wave of anti-Semitism in Europe, adopted by delegates to the twenty-eighth annual convention of the Federation of Polish Jews in America here today, authorities of the Polish Government were charged with having "ignominiously surrendered to the forces of anarchy and mob violence."
NANKING, China, June 28 (AP). -China plans to earmark an amount equivalent to $375,000,000 for military equipment and education in its budget estimates for the fiscal year beginning July 1.
OLD FORGE, N.Y., June 28 (AP). -- Charles Jeannette, 99-year-old Civil War veteran, ate a long planned wedding supper tonight without the bride he planned to wed today.

A reversal of the government's policy toward the electric power industry in several vital respects would release a "constructive force of tremendous magnitude in the struggle to restore prosperity," the Guaranty Trust Company says in its report of a study of the position of the utilities and their relation to recovery published in The Guaranty Survey.
VATICAN CITY, June 28. -- Pope Plus visited the tombs of his predecessors in the grottos under St. Peter's tonight and meditated on the place he has chosen for himself.

" True Christians should be not afraid to die, but afraid to kill," said the Rev. Dr. Robert W. Searle, general secretary of the Greater New York Federation of Churches, in his sermon, "The Christian Look," yesterday morning at the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street.

For the fourth straight week potato prices were conspicuously high on the city's consumers' food guide issued yesterday by the Department of Public Markets, Weights and Measures. A definite trend downward was noticed, however, and next Sunday's list was expected to show further reductions.

As the result of an apartment vacancy survey started last February the New York City Housing Authority has assisted more than 400 families in finding better apartments in four boroughs, Langdon W. Post, the chairman, announced yesterday.

MEXICO, D.F., June 28. -- The scene of one of the greatest sociological changes that has swept any land in recent years, Mexico today is apprehensively staggering into another Summer of turbulent dissension.

Sol Newman, an insurance broker, with offices on the tenth floor of the Williamsburg Bank Building, Hanson and Ashland Places, Brooklyn, was marooned for five hours yesterday on an eighth-floor balcony of the building.

Rain prevented yesterday's scheduled double-header at Ebbets Field, but neither the weather, Dizzy Dean nor the league rules could prevent those unpredictable Dodgers from scoring one upset triumph over the Cardinals, a feat they accomplished by the score of 5 to 1.

WASHINGTON, June 28. -- Despite the expiration of the Emergency Transportation Act, the railroads of the country intend to continue the study of methods of coordinating facilities and services of the roads, according to an announcement today by J.J. Pelley, president of the Association of American Railroads.

Arriving home to encounter for the first time abrogation of the $100 tax-free liquor exemption by a ruling announced Saturday, 915 Southern cruise passengers disrupted customs examinations yesterday as they argued and haggled indignantly about the new import tax.

Governor Harold G. Hoffman of New Jersey called last night upon the "hundreds of daily newspapers" that subscribe to the finer ethics of journalism to band together to regulate the profession and to protect themselves against the few newspapers which fail to conform to the prevailing code of morality and ethics.

MOSCOW, June 28. -- Surprise and indignation were caused here by a threatening challenge to the Soviet Union, issued a week ago in Harbin by Kozo Makiyama, president of the Japanese delegation, on the way to the Interparliamentary Union meeting in Budapest July 4.

Having suffered during three Summers the effect of sleep-preventing noises from blatant loud-speakers, or ribald laughter and shouts of exhilarated parties, I welcomed gratefully the efforts of the League for Less Noise and the Mayor's campaign for quiet nights, with the hope that at last there would be relief from these health-destroying nuisances.

NEWARK, N.J., June 28. -- Newark's lead in the International League was further reduced today when Albany defeated the Bears, 4 -- 1. The first game of the scheduled double-header was postponed on account of rain.

WASHINGTON, June 28. -- An increase of 90 per cent in the combined farm cash income from cotton, wheat, tobacco, corn and hogs was made between 1932 and 1935, the period during which the AAA program was in operation, according to the annual report of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration, made public today.

BERLIN, June 28. -- All last week the Stock Exchange was quiet and dull, but there were no recessions. The French Government's declaration was only a slight impulse, as France expressed readiness to consider Chancellor Hitler's peace proposals, but the situation failed to stimulate business.

Life is empty for those who crowd it with unmeaning activity so that they may escape facing reality, the Rev Edmund M. Wylie, pastor, said in a sermon yesterday at the Park Avenue Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Eighty-fifth Street.

The late Rev. Dr. Albert E. Ribourg's unceasing endeavors in the prudent leadership of his flock and the aid extended by him to other congregations were stressed in two memorial services yesterday morning. The Rev. Dr. Gustav A. Carstensen, rector emeritus of the Holyrood Church, preached at St. Andrew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and 127th Street, of which Dr. Ribourg had been rector for sixteen years before his death last Tuesday.
