WASHINGTON, June 28. -- The Seventy-fourth Congress actually appropriated $20,589,466,748 in setting its all-time spending record, Representative Taber. Republican, of New York, asserted today. His figures, the highest yet published, held that $10,459,756,227 was appropriated by the Seventy-fourth Congress for the fiscal year 1936 and $10,129,710,521 for the fiscal year 1937.

Robert Burke of Youngstown, Ohio, president-elect of the junior class at Columbia College, and a popular athlete, has been advised "in the best interests of all" not to register at the college next Fall, it was learned last night.

TOLEDO, June 28 (AP). -- Walter Hagen, master showman of them all, and young Ky Laffoon of Chicago won the Inverness four-ball team play golf tourney today, staving off a last-minute drive by Ray Mangrum, lanky lad from Dayton, Ohio, and Craig Wood of Deal, N.J.

SHANGHAI, June 28. -- In a conservatively worded detailed report submitted to the Chinese Government, Sir Frederick Maze, Briton, who is Inspector General of Chinese Maritime Customs, refutes Japanese charges that two Japanese vessels were wantonly fired upon without provocation.

MOSCOW, June 28. -- The law prohibiting abortion in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, which was published today, is a subject of interested discussion all over Moscow. After having listened to dozens of opinions in different circles of society, an observer must reach the opinion that the law is not wholly welcome at the present time.

THE National League is celebrating its sixtieth anniversary (1876-1936) by having banner days in member cities and Secretary Edward Aloysius McGonigle Brannick of the Giants already has his banner up at the Polo Grounds, though the day they celebrate in New York, Aug. 13, is yet far off. It's a long banner, draped from the roof of the grand stand and sprayed with the names of Giant players from antediluvian days to modern times.

HYDE PARK, N. Y., June 28. -President Roosevelt and Governor Lehman spent more than three hours together this morning. Neither, however, gave any indication afterward whether the Governor would reconsider his announced intention to retire from public life when his present term expires or respond to the pressure that is being brought on him to run again for Governor in the interest of a Democratic victory in both the nation and State.

RICHMOND, Va., June 28. -- Graying old veterans of many a race in speed boats in day gone by and a quartet of attractive girls whose make-up was spoiled by smudges of oil and grease stole the show today on the second afternoon of the seventh annual outboard regatta intended mainly for college men and schoolboys.
CHICAGO, June 28 (AP). -- After coming from behind twice to beat the White Sox in the first game of a double-header, 12 -- 9, today, the Senators lost a four-hit game, 4 -- 1, in the nightcap.

WASHINGTON, June 28. -- About 4,000,000 customers paid $923,000,000, or 53.3 per cent, of the total revenue from sales of energy by the electric utility companies of the United States in 1933, according to a report sent to Congress by the Federal Power Commission on "rates for electric service to commercial and industrial customers," which was made public today.

The eighteenth annual report of the Church Pension Fund, issued yesterday, discloses that $1,200,000 is being paid each year to more than 2,200 beneficiaries. The average pension of approximately $1,000 to Episcopal clergymen, their widows or other dependents, is only slightly less than the ultimate goal of individual payments under the Federal Social Security Act which does not protect the welfare of clergymen, the report points out.

PORTLAND, Ore., June 28. -- Ten thousand class-room teachers and school officials are pouring into Portland today for the seventy-fourth annual convention of the National Education Association imbued with a new unanimity and determination to fight for their rights to academic freedom.

PHILADELPHIA, June 28. --Empty information booths on the street corners, miles of flag-dotted thoroughfares and processions of train-bound taxicabs filled with suitcases and sleepy-eyed fares, furnished the chief outward evidence today that Philadelphia had been host to the Democratic National Convention.

In recognition of outstanding records as school citizens, 272 members of the graduating classes of city high schools were selected yesterday as winners of the semi-annual awards of the Cooperation-in-Government movement.

MAPLEWOOD, N.J., June 28. -Eddie Held, former Canadian amateur golf champion, paired today with C.E. Landers to win the fourth annual Maplewood invitation tournament. Held's 68, a record-tying round, enabled the pair to post a second round best-ball score of 67.

Assistant District Attorney William W. Kleinman of Kings County and Detective Giuseppe F.F. Dardis will have to stand trial again on charges of consiracy to obstruct justice in the investigation of the Drukman murder case, it was learned yesterday.

A book by Carl N. Taylor, who was robbed and murdered in his cabin near Albuquerque, N.M., while gathering data for a series of articles on the religious rites of the Penitentes last Winter, will be published by Scribner, July 10. The title is "Odyssey of the Islands," and it is an account of adventures in little-explored parts of the Philippines.

Decrying the false statements of success accepted by the majority of people, the Rev. Raymond L. Forman declared graduates from schools and colleges are "easy victims to commencement harangues about the false goals of life" in his sermon yesterday morning at St. Paul's Methodist Episcopal Church, West End Avenue at Eighty-sixth Street.

JOHNSONBURG, N.J., June 28. -- A "planned economy of abundance" in which the engineer must take a part will have to be organized before the world can have "true abundance" or a secure peace, it was said here today by Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President.

Primitive Christianity struck a note of instinctive joy and happiness, and we must recapture that spirit if we are to end our present-day bewilderment, Dr. Robert E. Speer, senior secretary of the Board of Foreign Missions of the Presbyterian Church, said in his sermon yesterday morning at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, northeast corner of Seventy-third Street.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 28. -- The tennis world, all eyes on Wimbledon's historic courts, will learn tomorrow whether Bryan M. Grant's giant-killing steadiness can carry the "Atlanta Atom" of the net past the deadly accuracy of Fred Perry.
PITTSBURGH, June 28. -- Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 72 per cent of capacity, unchanged from the preceding week.

The first Sunday concert of the series at the Lewisohn Stadium attracted an attendance of 3,900 last night. For this event Jose Iturbi conducted the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in a program featuring the Second symphony of Sibelius, which was heard for the first time in these surroundings.

GENEVA, June 28. -- The Assembly of the League of Nations that will meet here in a special session Tuesday at the call of Argentina to decide how the world can provide a new and comprehensive system of security against aggression has three objectives before it.

WASHINGTON, June 28. -- Plans for complete reorganization of the Farmers National Grain Corporation, established in 1929 during the Hoover administration, under which local farmers' cooperatives and members of such organizations will buy $3,000,000 of new capital stock in the corporation, were announced today by the Farm Credit Administration.

Chief City Magistrate Jacob Gould Schurman Jr. launched a drive yesterday against the employment of professional bondsmen by rings of racketeers interested in vice or gambling for bailing out their underlings who might be arrested, as was the practice of Charles (Lucky Luciano) Lucania and his accomplices.
PARIS, June 28. -- The first attempt at combined retaliation against the strike movement in France upset the Riviera Summer tourist season when a lockout was declared today in 750 Riviera hotels.

NEW ORLEANS, June 28. -- There was a fair volume of trading in the cotton market here last week, with increasing evidences of a freer market and a readier disposition to speculate. A good volume of trade buying and price-fixing by the mills likewise was noted.
DETROIT, June 28 (AP). -- Elden Auker pitched Detroit to a 10-to-4 triumph over the Athletics today, giving the Tigers their fourth straight victory and a sweep of the series.

The beauty of Christianity, which appeals to the highly esthetic taste of the Japanese, and the social service being performed by native and American Christians, are combining to make Christianity a great influence in Japan, the Rev. Dr. Elmer Ellsworth Helms, former pastor of the First Methodist Church of Los Angeles, declared in his sermon yesterday morning at the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 28. -Dr. Thomas Herbert Norton, chess player, pedestrian, genealogist and one of this country's leading chemists, will mark his eighty-fifth birthday Tuesday at the home of his son, Robert Ames Norton, 19 Blackthorn Lane, this city.

MADRID, June 28. -- Labor Minister Juan Lluhi has warned employers' and contractors' associations that he is determined to end the strike of 40,000 building trades workers in Madrid this week. If the employers "persist in sulking" and absent themselves any longer from the labor arbitration court, the Minister said, he will settle the strike by Thursday and then force the employers to comply with the government's terms.

ST. LOUIS, June 28. -- With the thermometer bobbing well over the 100 mark, the Yankees' closing dash through the West was reduced to half-speed today, as they found it utterly beyond them to gain more than an even break in a blistering double-header with the Browns.

Since the word "boondoggle" was injected into our language as a substitute for such colloquialisms as "stalling," "laying down on the job," , the major part of the fire of this invective has been directed at workers on WPA projects. The lasting benefits that have been conferred upon the nation by WPA projects are entirely ignored by hack politicians.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 28. -Fourteen more yachts in the 635mile race from Newport had reached here at dusk tonight, making twenty-seven having finished the long grind, which included ten hours of a Gulf Stream gale. With the six that turned and made ports along the seaboard accounted for, that left eleven of the forty-four that started still at sea.

United action by all labor organizations on broad social and economic questions affecting the workers' rights was approved yesterday by the New York State Socialist Party at its convention in the Hotel Delano.

Miss Gladys Obremski, 22 years old, of 209-64 Forty-fifth Drive, Bayside, Queens, was drowned in Little Neck Bay, about 100 feet off the foot of Twenty-sixth Avenue, Bayside, last night after being accidentally thrown overboard from a speedboat. Her escort, Luke Albanese of 38-11 Bell Boulevard, Bayside, had a narrow escape from drowning in attempting to rescue her.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, June 28. -- Asserting he holds the key to quick independence for Puerto Rico but not revealing that key, Senator Luis Munoz Marin, for months Liberal party representative at Washington urging freedom for the island, today reasserted his determination to oppose his party's participation in the November elections.

Mr. ROOSEVELT may be forgiven for having put a reminiscential fighting quality into the first part of his speech of acceptance on Saturday night. It was natural for him to recur to the struggles and even battles which he had gone through during the last three years at Washington.

With indications of a definite trend toward resale price maintenance legislation in various States, the American Retail Federation is calling the attention of retailers to the necessity of keeping fully informed on the operation of the laws already in effect in thirteen States.

PHILADELPHIA, June 28. -- Delegates to the Democratic National Convention left Philadelphia today with most of them confident that President Roosevelt will be re-elected, despite the admitted defection of conservative Democrats and the attack of Representative Lemke, third party candidate, on the Left.

PARIS, June 28. -- From the very start of the week the tendency of the Bourse was reversed from the preceding week's adverse trend, and the recovery in rentes continued. The reaction for the better was less rapid in the foreign-exchange market, but it became accentuated at the end of the week.

HEIDELBERG, June 28. -- The second day of Heidelberg University's celebration of the 550th anniversary of its foundation has gone by without any one catching sight of an academic robe. Both ceremonies on the day's program had a military and political character.

One hundred and twenty athletes have automatically qualified for 138 places in the final Olympic track and field tryouts at Randalls Island on July 11 and 12, William J. Bingham of Harvard, chairman of the Olympic track committee, announced yesterday following the completion of the semi-final trials on Saturday.

BALTIMORE, June 28. -- The Safe Deposit and Trust Company of Baltimore, as depository for the underlying bondholders of the Seaboard Air Line Railway, has notified holders of certificates of deposit that payment of six months' interest will be made on or before July 7 on the deposited bonds to registered owners as of the close of business on July 1, 1936.
The relatively high rate of spinning activity in England is one of the brightest phases of the world cotton-spinning industry, according to the New York Cotton Exchange Service.

Further study of the proposed tunnel between the Battery and Hamilton Avenue, Brooklyn, before the project is undertaken is recommended by a committee of the Merchants Association in a communication to the New York City Tunnel Authority.
Since the term "priming the pump" has been used politically so often of late, how about applying it literally in regard to the new Tax Bill?

Judge Charles S. Colden in Queens County Court denied yesterday a motion to set aside the first degree murder conviction of John Collins and requested that the District Attorney investigate threats against the State's principal witness, Joseph J. Klem.

An issue of $1,750,000 of ten-year serial debentures of L.C. Smith Corona Typewriters, Inc., will be offered today through an underwriting group comprising F.S. Moseley Co., Riter Co. and Hemphill, Noyes Co. The debentures, carrying interest rates of 2 to 41/2 per cent, will mature at the rate of $175,000 annually from July 1, 1937, to July 1, 1946.

PHILADELPHIA, June 29. -- The marriage of Mrs. Sylvia Scott Korff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Bryant Scott of Chestnut Hill, to Dr. Alexander Goetz of Pasadena, Calif., son of Mrs. Hermann Krezzer of Goettingen, Germany, and of the late Dr. Carl Goetz, took place today at noon.

Mail reorders from retailers on Summer merchandise to fill immediate needs showed a pick-up yesterday, reflecting better weather conditions and active retail trade in many sections last week, Much of the demand, however, was for clearance merchandise, supplies of which in the dress, accessory and beach-wear fields are not large.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., June 29. -- President Roosevelt received assurance today from Democratic leaders that he has an excellent chance to carry Illinois, and at least a fighting chance to capture Michigan, despite the fact that it is the home State of the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, who has thrown his support to the third-party movement.

FARMINGDALE, L.I., June 29. -- Frank Sarro, 16-year-old Lawrence High School golf captain, annexed the Long Island caddie championship in the thirteenth annual caddie and caddie masters' tournament at the Bethpage State Park links today.

With Governor Lehman still refraining from comment on repeated urgings that he become a candidate again, Maurice P. Davidson, State chairman of the State-Wide Citizens' Committee for Lehman, announced yesterday the organization of groups in forty-one counties and the formation of a special committee to draft a formal appeal to the Governor to run for re-election.
HYDE PARK, N.Y., June 29. -- President Roosevelt has directed the navy and Coast Guard to render every possible assistance in searching for Sir Hubert Wilkins.

ESTES PARK, Col., June 29. -- Governor and Mrs. Landon and Peggy Anne Landon and the dozen newspaper men and photographers who accompanied the Republican Presidential nominee on his vacation trip here were guests this evening at an old-fashioned beefsteak fry, held at Bear Lake, eight miles from this village.

Members of Mayor La Guardia's Committee on Conditions in Harlem, which conducted an investigation based on public hearings after the riot in the section on March 19, 1935, disclosed last night that they would meet with the Mayor at 4 o'clock this afternoon to discuss publication of the committee's final report.

ALBANY, June 29. -- Eighty-nine banks and bond houses throughout the State won today awards of tax-anticipation notes amounting to $75,000,000. The awards ranged from $2,100,000 to $300,000 each. They were made by Morris S. Tremaine, State Controller.
HAVANA, June 29. -- A commission to draw up legislation for the establishment of a widespread social security program was created tonight by a bill that was approved by the Senate.

NANKING, June 28. -- Japan has blundered upon the most effective weapon yet to force the central government of China into line with Japan's continental policy through the extensive smuggling that is being carried on in North China in the province of Fukien adjacent to the island of Formosa and to a lesser degree in Canton in South China.

MARGARET MITCHELL'S "Gone With the Wind" (Macmillan, $3) is an outsized novel of Civil War and Reconstruction days in Georgia. It is, in an probability, the biggest book of the year: 1,037 pages. I found it -- well, it is best to delay the verdict for a few paragraphs. Only the most unnatural of reviewers will give away his secret at the outset.

WILMINGTON, N.C., June 29 (AP). -- A Columbus County grand jury began attempts today to pierce the reticence of reprisal-fearing victims of a band of night-riding women-floggers while Solicitor J.J. Burney announced a "war to the death" against the secret group.

The commodity futures markets here in general were firm and dull yesterday, with the exception of silk and hides, which were depressed in active trading. On the cash markets, cotton, hides and silk eased while gains were made by all the grains, butter, pork, rubber and tin.

The proposal of the Securities and Exchange Commission, that the functions of "broker" and "dealer" be legally segregated, does not raise a new question. In the commission's report last week the plan was not urged for immediate Congressional legislation; indeed, the commission expressed belief that its own powers under the act of 1934 would of themselves be sufficient to introduce the suggested requirement, but that there was no immediate occasion for such action.

LONDON, June 29. -- The stock markets here were cheerful today, but the volume of business was small. British Government issues were steady, with little change in prices. Polish 7 per cent bonds recovered smartly on a reassuring statement about suspension of debt service, but otherwise foreign bonds were featureless.
MOSCOW, June 29. -- The beginning of Summer holidays and the end of the scholastic year was made today the occasion of a big press and public ballyhoo about children.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 29 (AP) -- Tales of wagon-spoke beatings and use of the lash by drunken guards came today from a grand jury investigation of the State Reform School for Boys.

There were important absentees at both the major party conventions this month, but more publicity was given to the Democrats who were not at Philadelphia than to the Republicans who were not at Cleveland. Governor Landon's missing wings will be heard from later.

CHICAGO, June 29. -- Whereaway, recent acquisition of the Anthony Pelleteri Stable of New Orleans, swept to victory in the Inaugural Handicap at Arlington Park today as Chicago biggest racing meet got under way. It was Whereaway by three-quarters of a length in the seven-furlong Journey, with Pharosay second and The Fighter third.

A score of detectives searched the West Side last night for suspects and witnesses in the murder of George K. O'Connor, 38 years old, an electrical engineer and honor man of Carnegie Institute of Technology, class of '22, whose home was at 1,020 Austin Street, Evanston, Ill.

An appropriation of $27,829,000 to meet home relief costs in this city during July, August and September was voted yesterday by the Board of Estimate. While the board was meeting in special session, Victor F. Ridder, local Works Progress Administrator, received an allocation of $27,793,000 from the Federal Government to finance work relief here during a five and one-half week period.

Two hundred guests participated in the testimonial dinner at the Town Hall Club last night to Samuel Reshevsky of New York, the new champion of the National Chess Federation here. Many civic notables were on hand.

LOS ANGELES, June 29 (AP). -- Rattlesnakes that the State charges Robert S. James used in slaying his seventh wife struck repeatedly at their glass cage in Superior court today while an expert testified concerning their deadliness.
LONDON, June 29. -- Direct advertising and sponsored programs in British radio broadcasting will be strictly forbidden for at least ten years more, the government announced today.

Nearly ten years have elapsed since we heard of the first hopeful experiments in television. And still there is no commercial television. Yesterday a momentous step was taken toward fulfilling the early promises. Over a hundred receivers have been distributed in the metropolitan area to "see" what is happening in a station at the top of the Empire State Building.

With the exception of three seeded juniors who failed to put in an appearance and were defaulted, all of the favorites in the junior and boys' divisions of the Greater New York tennis championships advanced without the loss of a set as play got under way at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 29. -- Apprehension of damage to the new corn crop from the widespread drought resulted today in that grain becoming the market leader in the Board of Trade, with the December, which represents this year's harvest, soaring 2 cents a bushel to the highest level of the season and finishing at the top.
Gaines Gwathmey, a member of the New York Stock Exchange, has become general partner in Elder Co., and will be the floor member of the firm.
The report by F. Raymond Daniell of the "Alarm of Professor Cerebellum," published June 27, is worthy of most serious consideration.

Bids will be considered today by officials of the city of Quincy, Mass., for a new issue of $300,000 of short-term notes. The notes will be dated July 1, 1936, and become payable on Nov. 25, 1936, and March 26, 1937.

Rockefeller Center's Horticultural Hall, where many of the pampered aristocrats of flowerdom make their debuts, opened its arms to the floral-proletariat yesterday for its own Center Flower Show, the pride of the tenants and employes of Rockefeller Center, Inc.

Property owners from South Ozone Park, Queens, yesterday morning told Supreme Court Justice Charles C. Lockwood, at a hearing in Brooklyn, that improvement of Van Wyck Boulevard under the existing assessments of the entire cost against their holdings would "inevitably" lead to wholesale foreclosures and scores of ruined homes.

CHICAGO, June 29. -- Lawson Little Jr. of San Francisco, who in 1934 and 1935 won both the amateur golf championships of the United States and Great Britain, today was presented with the 1935 James E. Sullivan Memorial Trophy awarded annually to America's outstanding athlete.

ALBANY, June 29. -- Governor Lehman, back at his desk today, continued noncommittal on whether he would yield to appeals to run again. He refused to comment on his conference with President Roosevelt.

DETROIT, June 29 (AP). -- Through a drizzling rain, Genteel Lady ran a mile and seventy yards in 1:42 today to win the Ford City Handicap and equal the track record. F.A.F. Griffith's bay mare beat Chastity by a length and a half. Zsar was third, a length further back.

ELMIRA, N.Y., June 29. -- Taking off in the face of a strong wind today Emerson Mehlhose of Wyandotte, Mich., flew his glider to Orson, Wayne County, Pa., a distance of seventy-seven miles, the longest trip of this year's soaring contest.
NEWPORT, R.I., June 29. -- John Jacob Astor and his wife, the former Miss Ellen Tuck French, will entertain in celebration of their second wedding anniversary tomorrow at their home, Chetwode.

WASHINGTON, June 29. -- Breckinridge Long has resigned as Ambassador to Italy on account of ill health and, it is understood, will be succeeded by a Washington official highly qualified for the duties of the post.

Members of the Hollis-St. Albans Civic Association, who on Friday evening started to repair their own streets, were surprised yesterday morning to discover about fifty men, a steamroller and several trucks from the Queens Highway Bureau at work in the vicinity of Cross Island Boulevard and 113th Avenue, St. Albans.

WASHINGTON, June 29. -- Secretary Wallace will make a personal inspection of the drought-stricken areas of the Western States, it was made known today. Coincidentally, a special committee appointed by him to draft plans for relief of drought sufferers met today, and will have a preliminary report ready to lay before President Roosevelt tomorrow after his return from Hyde Park.

Mrs. Durant is the daughter of Mrs. Joseph E. Davies, the former Mrs. Marjorie Post Close Hutton, and a granddaughter of the late C.W. Post. Her marriage to Mr. Durant took place on Jan. 19, 1927, in St. Thomas Church in this city. Mr. Durant is a well-known sportsman. He was graduated from Yale in 1924.

ST. LOUIS, June 29. -- Scouting the idea that any "sudden or cataclysmic change" will follow the November election, whether the country goes Democratic or Republican, Kenneth Collins, vice president of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., predicted today that, it present business trends continued, "industry will show very large profits this year."

Seventeen YIanhattan properties were bought in by plaintiffs at :6reclosure auction sales yesterday. The properties included a fifteen-story apartment house in West End Avenue and an eleven-story loft building in West Twenty-fourth Street. Details of the sales were as follows:

President Roosevelt is expected to attend the opening of the Triborough Bridge here on July 11, it became known yesterday. No announcement of the speakers for the dedication ceremonies has been made yet, but if the President is present he will deliver, the principal address.

The first of an anticipated total of 80,000 persons went to schools, settlement houses and community centers in all parts of the city yesterday to register for the Summer session of the Adult Education Project, jointly operated by the Board of Education and the WPA.
CROTON-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., June 29. -- The Summer camps of the Westchester County Recreation Commission opened today for their tenth season, with emphasis on pioneer life.

RICHMOND, Va., June 29 (AP). -- Mrs. Katherine Scales Elliman of New York testified at a hearing today on her claim for $13,800 on a war risk insurance policy on her former husband, Edward H. Moon, that she interpreted a letter received several days after the young Richmond broker disappeared from a steamer in 1922 to mean that he had committed suicide.

Your editorial "Reversing a Price Policy" interprets the President's request for action against the alleged collusive bidding on PWA steel contracts as a complete reversal of the price-fixing policies under the NRA.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., June 30. -- Annoyed by the sounds of midnight merrymakers, John Piorkovski, who lives across the street from a resort known as Fred's Restaurant, 255 South Regent Street, shot and killed one of two men who shook the picket fence in front of his home.

Narrow and mixed price movements ruled in extremely dull bond trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The market was almost at a standstill at times during the day. The turnover was only $6,620,700, this being the smallest volume for a five-hour period since Feb. 11, 1935, when sales amounted to $6,151,800.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, June 29. -- The question of whether the new Straits convention to be concluded will still provide for a Straits commission is being freely discussed here.
GREENWICH, Conn., June 29. -- It is fortunate for Charley Clare that the Connecticut State Golf Association recently increased its championship flight to sixty-four, just double the old quota.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., June 29. -- A traffic cop and an unattached professional combined to carry off the honors in the Westchester County Golf Association's pro-amateur tournament today at the Briar Hills Golf and Country Club.

Dr. Maude Royden, noted evangelist and sister of Sir Thomas Royden, former chairman of the Cunard Line; Lady Ashfield, Princess Aimee Galitzine, Archdeacon A.J.B. Dewdney; Howard K. Travers, United States Consul at Southampton; Dennis O'Dea, actor; Miss Bertha Belmore, actress; Senator F. Soukop, president of the Czech Senate; Harry K. Barr, and Mr. and Mrs. Le Roy Harding are among the prominent persons arriving today on the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria.

ANDRE TARI EU paid tribute to French-American amity on Sunday, and did it in the paradoxical manner of the late G.K. CHESTERTON. Almost he argued that the two democracies have been such good friends because they have so little in common.

Public offering will be made today of $50,000,000 of Consolidated Oil Corporation fifteen-year convertible 31/2 per cent sinking fund debentures, dated June 1, 1936, and due on June 1, 1951, by a banking group headed by Kuhn, Loeb Co. and including the First Boston Corporation, Brown Harriman Co., Inc., Kidder, Peabody Co., J. W. Seligman Co., White, Weld Co., Blyth Co., Inc., the Lee Higginson Corporation and associates.

RICHMOND, Va., June 29. -- College and school hydroplane drivers prolonged their regatta on the James River at The Country Club of Virginia for a third day in an effort, although in vain, to boost world's record speed marks.
NEWARK, N.J., June 29. -- Trailing, 5 to 1, coming up in the eighth, Newark staged a six-run rally to beat Albany, 7 to 5, thereby evening the current series.

WASHINGTON, June 29. -- Stanley S. Wohl, State director of Securities of North Carolina, in a statement here today described the recent report by the Securities and Exchange Commission on feasibility and advisability of segregation of the broker-and-dealer functions on Stock Exchanges as an "eminently fair study of the problems" and a "sound economic public document.''

Final arrangements were completed yesterday for the sailing of the American Olympic team on the S.S. Manhattan of the United States Lines two weeks from tomorrow, Secretary Frederick W. Rubien announced yesterday. The entire team, nearly 400 strong, will assemble in the Hotel Lincoln at noon July 13 and receive instructions from President Avery Brundage.

Ten minutes after County Judge Brancato in Brooklyn had dismissed the "torture" charges against a police lieutenant and two detectives yesterday, Police Commissioner Valentine issued an order restoring the policemen to duty.

Two former officers of the Westchester Title and Trust Company, which failed three years ago, leaving 17,000 "investors" holding $81,000,000 worth of its so-called guaranteed mortgages and mortgage certificates, received prison sentences yesterday in Federal court for the part they played in a mail fraud conspiracy.

The American Student Union announced yesterday through James Wechsler, director of publications, that it intended to organize a nation-wide protest against the "dismissal" from Columbia College of Robert Burke of Youngstown, Ohio, president-elect of the junior class, athlete and a leader in the American Student Union chapter at the college.

Howard S. Cullman, vice chairman of the National Committee on Safety at Sea, yesterday released for publication a letter which he has forwarded to Malcolm Kerlin, administrative assistant to Secretary of Commerce Roper, charging Mr. Kerlin with having obstructed the progress of the government's efforts to improve conditions of safety at sea and in aviation.

The national office of the Propeller Club of the United States yesterday submitted to its branch clubs a list of men whom it considers worthy of appointment to the new Maritime Authority and urged its members to recommend them to President Roosevelt.

LONDON, June 29. -- The honorary degree of Doctor of Law was conferred on Benjamin N. Cardozo, Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court, at the University of London's centenary celebration today. Professor Albert Einstein, also absent, received the honorary degree of Doctor of Science.

GENEVA, June 29. -- Preceding tomorrow's special session of the League of Nations Assembly, this day has been one of intense activity in the matter of preparatory conferences -- activity at times almost feverish. Conflicting interests on all sides have been trying to determine what course to pursue.
LONDON, June 29. -- British aircraft manufacturers displayed the latest types of their machines at Hatfield Airdrome today to 3,000 potential buyers representing fifty countries.

VIENNA, June 29 (AP). -- The tide of Austrian monarchist sentiment and propaganda reached new heights tonight following an open declaration of loyalty to Archduke Otto by Major Emil Fey, former Vice Chancellor and ousted head of the Vienna Heimwehr.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., June 29 (AP). -- The Rev. J.J. McLaughlin, 31, of New York, died without regaining consciousness this morning in Callicoon Hospital from injuries suffered last night when the sedan in which he was riding with Father Giles Lawler of Singac, N.J., was in collision with another car near Cochecton.

Late of the Lafayette Theatre in Harlem, the WPA's much acclaimed all-Negro production of "Macbeth" will come into the Adelphi Theatre next Tuesday night. Its engagement in Fifty-fourth Street is announced as "limited," with a tour to follow. . . . "Lights o' London," revived at the Palm Garden Tuesday evening, will retire from there after this Saturday.

Concluding arguments in the city's action to collect $170 from Raymond G. Pollard, Assistant Publio Works Commissioner in Queens, were read into the record of Justice John T. Sullivan's court yesterday by counsel for both sides.

CAMDEN, N.J., June 29. -- The strike here of workers at the plant of the R.C.A. Manufacturing Company was a step nearer settlement tonight after company officials had agreed in a memorandum sent to union officials that they would consent to a poll being taken by the National Industrial Relations Board.

There appeared to be no unanimmity in the stock market yesterday. A few stocks in certain groups, such as Chrysler, made remarkable gains, while other sections of the list, notably the steels, weakened; in still others, advances and declines were about a stand-off.

HEIDELBERG, Germany, June 29. -- The main event of the third day's ceremonies honoring the 550th anniversary of the foundation of the University of Heidelberg was an address by Dr. Bernhard Rust, Minister of Science, Education and People's Education.

More trouble ensued for the customs officials in this port when three popular steamships arrived yesterday from the West Indies and the Bahamas with 830 passengers who had bought 650 cases of assorted liquors which they expected to bring in duty free under the exemption of $100 a person.

A government suit in equity to recover $2,842,616 from nine member banks of the New York Clearing House to complete the payment of depositors in the closed Harriman National Bank was dismissed here yesterday in the State Supreme Court by Justice Bernard L. Shientag.
DAYTON, Ohio, June 29 (AP). -- "Flying heels" for airplanes in the stratosphere were announced today at the Materiel Division of the Army Air Corps at Wright Field.

PORTLAND, Ore., June 29. -- Attacks upon the freedom of teaching in schools are essentially assaults upon the democratic form of government, a dozen different branches of the National Education Association held today. Educators of all degrees, from the United States Commissioner of Education to college professors, classroom teachers and school superintendents, impressed this statement upon their thousands of teacher-hearers gathered from all parts of the country for the annual convention of the association.

CHICAGO, June 29 (AP). -- Efforts of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to collect $10,000,000 from stockholders of the Central Republic Bank and Trust Company were opposed by twelve of Chicago's leading law firms in a joint brief filed today in Federal court.

The Westchester Liquor Dealers Association won a victory yesterday in its fight against Westchester residents who buy their liquor -- at cheaper prices -- in Connecticut and take it to Westchester for leisurely consumption at home.

The announcement by the American Iron and Steel Institute yesterday morning that the unionization drive in the steel industry might lead to strikes was received calmly by Wall Street. For one thing, the decline of the steel stocks last week appeared to have discounted the news.

WASHINGTON, June 29. -- John R. McCarl, Controller General for fifteen years, received the press today on the eve of his retirement and, commenting caustically on "loosely and extravagantly set up" emergency agencies, which he characterized as "tax-consuming in the extreme," expressed hope that a systematic reorganization of government might soon be effected.

CHICAGO, June 29. -- Ernest Palmer, Illinois State Director of Insurance, today served notice on big Eastern fire insurance corporations operating in Illinois either to telegraph assent tomorrow to his order calling for a 10 per cent reduction of premium rates on dwellings and apartments and contents and the removal of alleged discrimination against property owners in Southern Illinois, effective on Sept. 1, or he denied renewal of their licenses on Wednesday.

CINCINNATI, June 29. -- The scarlet-knickered Cincinnati Reds combined four hits with three Chicago errors tonight to defeat the champion Cubs, 4 to 3, and run their National League winning streak to seven games. The setback forced the Cubs into a first-place tie with the idle Cardinals.

Mrs. William Russell Burwell gave a luncheon yesterday in the Weylin for Demetrios Sicilianos, Greek Minister to the United States; Nicholas Lelly, counselor of the Greek Legation in Washington, and Miss Katherine Halle.

CLEVELAND, June 29 (AP). -- Dominion Grattan, cyclonic bay pacer owned by Paul Bowser of Boston, carried far too much fire for six rivals in the $1,000 2:13 pacing stake as the Grand Circuit launched its sixty-third season at the North Randall track today.
WASHINGTON, June 29. -- Representative Marion A. Zioncheck returned today to write another bizarre chapter in his eccentric Capital history.

William Lemke, the Presidential candidate of the new Union party, claims he will carry all of the New England States and some of the Middle and Western States, not to mention a lot of other States. Coming after the claims of the genial Mr. Farley that the Democratic candidate will carry every State in the Union, Mr. Lemke's pretensions are very interesting.

For almost two decades the world's quarter and half-mile records stood at 0:47.4 and 1:52.2, respectively. Those were the classic figures of middle distance running, but the way the Americans have been moving in the last year or two those once "unbreakable records" look like slow-footed feats at best.
A rattlesnake caused a polite flurry at the Empire Boulevard police station in Brooklyn yesterday and stirred a 17-year-old future medical student to vehement protests of injustice.

On a wind-swept ash plateau overlooking the Flushing Meadows, city and State officials and officers of the World's Fair Corporation formally and with due ceremony began work yesterday on the New York World's Fair of 1939.

BERLIN, June 29. -- The Boerse continued today in the usual Summer doldrums. Heavy industrials showed some strength in a dull market, Rheinstahl gaining 1 point. Chemicals were quiet. Machines were mixed and almost inactive, Berlin Karlsruhe gaining 3/4 point and Muag 1/2.
CHICAGO, June 29 (AP). -- Twenty-eight crack contract bridge pairs, survivors of a field of fifty-six, met today in the final sessions of the American Whist League's all-American pair trophy play.

Samuel Prager, 55 years old, proprietor of the Liberty Pharmacy at 111-19 Liberty Avenue, Richmond Hill, Queens, was found murdered at about 12:30 A.M. today in the basement of his store. He had been wounded three times in the head and the pockets of his clothing had been ripped out.

Television's New York debut yesterday in the start of a $1,000,000 field test undertaken by the Radio Corporation of America was favored with an ideal day in which the images might smile through space without being blurred by static.

The second soloist of the still youthful Lewisohn Stadium season was Harold Bauer, who appeared last night as guest artist in the Schumann Piano Concerto. Jose Iturbi was the conductor. The remainder of the program embraced Mozart's Symphony in D (K. 385), known as the "Haffner"; Liszt's "Les Preludes" and Borodin's "Polovetsian Dances" from "Prince Igor."

The Public Service Commission in an announcement yesterday ordered the Long Island Railroad to begin charging single-fare riders a two-cent fare in Nassau and Suffolk Counties beginning tomorrow. The commission denied the railroad's application for a rehearing.

Praising the Salvation Army as an army of peace and social justice, Mayor La Guardia delivered the principal address last night at the annual commencement of the New York Training School for Officers.

WASHINGTON, June 29. -- Public hearings in [he general inquiry the Securities and Exchange Commission is making of investment trusts and investment companies will begin on July 27. It will deal first with some of the predecessor companies of the Equity Corporation, covering substantially the period from their inception to the date when the Equity Corporation, or affiliated interests, assumed control.
CLEVELAND, June 29 (AP). -- Stockholders of the Wheeling Lake Erie Railroad approved today a recapitalization program proposed by Jesse Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

Premier GODBOUT of Quebec presented to the Lieutenant Governor of the Province yesterday the members of his Cabinet. Of the ten, four besides himself held office in the Taschereau Government which resigned June 11. So Mr. GODBOUT undertakes reform within the party.

WASHINGTON, June 29. -- Labor replies today to the statement of the American Iron and Steel Institute's opposition to the union organization drive in the steel industry declared that the issue boiled down to an attempt by the industry to protect company unions.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., June 29. -- Mr. and Mrs. Norman H. Davis have as guests at Ironoque, Stockbridge, the Dowager Marchioness of Reading and Mrs. Howe of London, for whom they entertained at dinner tonight. Lady Reading is the widow of the one-time Viceroy of India and British Ambassador at Washington.

LONDON, June 29. -- Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin's government was attacked as "a danger to our country and the peace and security of the world" tonight, but it won a vote of support in a House of Commons debate.

THE esteemed and plump secretary-treasurer of the A.A.U., Mr. Dan Ferris, ordered a corned beef on rye and a cup of coffee and then ignored both as he orated on the coming national track and field championships in the Palmer Stadium at Princeton. It is annually his favorite meet and he said, in effect, that this time it would be magnificent, astounding, colossal!

As the French liner Normandie, arriving from Europe, was moving into her slip at the foot of West Forty-eighth Street about 2:30 P.M. yesterday, the southwest wind and current swung her port bow into the superstructure of Pier 86, striking it a glancing blow.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 29. -- All forty-three yachts accepted as entries by the Cruising Club of America for the race here from Newport were accounted for this afternoon. Thirty-five had finished and the rest had turned back into United States ports.
GENEVA, June 29. -- Italy, seeking to calm fears of Great Britain and France, promised the League of Nations tonight she would not create a huge Ethiopian army.

Nearly 400 persons crowded the hall of the Board of Education last night to hear thirty-eight speakers, representing school and civic organizations and other groups, present to the board requests for appropriations for the 1937 budget. Colonel Walter Jeffreys Carlin, chairman of the committee on finance and budget, presided.

WASHINGTON, June 29. -- President Roosevelt, in a letter to Secretary Morgenthau made public today, directed that the benefit of lower United States tariff duties flowing from reciprocal trade agreements be withdrawn from Australia on Aug. 1 because of discrimination against United States commerce in Australia's new import licensing system.

TIENTSIN, China, June 29. -- The assignment of the Japanese destroyer Kiku to patrol duty in Po Gulf, coupled with a threat to detain the Chinese customs cutter Yukwang, gave a more serious turn today to the Japanese dispute over the recent firing upon two Japanese smuggling vessels.

With Gardnar Mulloy, University of Miami star, holding down the honored position at the top of the singles draw of sixty-two players, the fourteenth annual Eastern intercollegiate tennis singles and doubles championships got off to a flying start yesterday on the grass courts of the Richmond County Country Club, Dongan Hills, S.I.

JOHNSONBURG, N.J., June 29. -- A "disastrous rise of the price level" with the probability of "serious inflation" was forecast by Ray B. Westerfield, Professor of Political Economy at Yale University, in an address before the Economics Conference of Engineers at the Stevens Institute camp tonight.

BOSTON, June 29. -- Some 1,200 advertising men and women were urged today to spread upon the record the magnificent achievement of American industry and to interpret to the people what business has done for their well-being.

WASHINGTON, June 29. -- A new non-stop distance record for amphibian planes was made today by Major General Frank M. Andrews, commander of the air force of the army, and Major General Frank R. McCoy, commander of the Second Corps Area, with headquarters in New York, in a flight from San Juan, Puerto Rico, to Langley Field, Va.

The first symphonic composition selected by the Federal audition board in its search for material for the series of WPA "New Talent" concerts will receive a world premiere next Sunday evening. The work is "Granada," by L. Leslie Loth. It will be presented at a free symphony concert in Forest Park, Queens, by the Brooklyn Symphony Orchestra, Franco Autori conducting.

Shipments of sugar from Cuba to the United States from Jan. 1 to June 13, together with sugar here or afloat on Jan. 1 that were part of the 1936 quota, aggregate 76.8 per cent of the 2,039,349 tons permitted under the Jones-Costigan Act, the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange estimated yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 29 (AP). -- A night club master of ceremonies who the police said gave "shaky" answers to questions under the "lie detector" was held for investigation tonight in connection with the slaying of Mrs. Florence Thompson Castle, 24, a night club hostess.

INDIANAPOLIS, June 29 (AP). -- Charles P. Howard, president of the International Typographical Union and secretary of the Committee for Industrial Organization, sponsored by John L. Lewis, declared tonight a fund of $500,000 has been provided for support of a campaign for organization of steel workers.
PARIS, June 29 (AP). -- Communists called today for speedy dissolution of Colonel Francois de la Rocque's new Rightist party, formed for "conquest and power" in France.

The annual Summer exodus of boy and girl campers, en route to mountain and lake regions and the surrounding countryside generally, gathered momentum yesterday and is expected to reach its peak tonight and tomorrow night.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 29. -- A variety of recent New York hits and one new play are among the presentations of Westchester Summer theatres for the week commencing tonight.
CHICAGO, June 29 (AP). -- Representative William Lemke said today that Presidents of the United States "put on too much dog."
WIMBLEDON, England, June 29 (AP). -- Today's matches in the All-England championships attracted 30,000 spectators, who jammed the stands and swarmed through the grounds.

A judgment for $540,504 in damages and interest from 1927 was entered yesterday in Federal court against Archie M. Andrews, former chairman of the Hupp Motor Corporation, and in favor of the T.W. Warner Company.

Via United Artists comes the word that Charles Chaplin will make two pictures during the approaching production season. The first, which he will direct, will star Paulette Goddard, the elfin young woman, featured in his "Modern Times." Chaplin directed "A Woman of Paris" in 1923, as a starring vehicle for Edna Purviance, who teamed with him in his comedy heyday.

Louis Strube's Rust, one of the most consistent performers among the fillies in this section and a good second to High Fleet in her last start, easily accounted for the Beldame Handicap for fillies and mares at a mile, feature at Aqueduct yesterday, and pleased a large crowd that made her a 3-to-5 favorite in a field of three.

WASHINGTON, June 29. -- James A. Farley has sent his resignation as Postmaster General to President Roosevelt, This step was taken so that he could devote more time to the chairmanship of the Democratic National Committee and to President Roosevelt's campaign for re-election.

ALBANY, June 29. -- Governor Lehman, on his return today, found hundreds of letters and telegrams awaiting him, lauding his speech seconding President Roosevelt's nomination, and urging him to reconsider his decision to retire from public life at the end of the year.

After planting an undercover man in the Tombs, and later checking up on a convict who was directing a "perfect crime" from his cell in Sing Sing, detectives of the Wall Street squad arrested two men and a woman yesterday, and announced that they had balked a plot to sell counterfeit bonds to New York brokers.

WASHINGTON, June 29. -- The government's fiscal year 1936 will end tomorrow with a public debt of nearly $34,000,000,000, an increase of about $13,013,544,489 since the Roosevelt administration came into power on March 4, 1933, according to figures obtained at the Treasury today.

NEWARK, N.J., June 29. -- Telephone service of 600 lines in Harrison, N.J., was interrupted and numerous toll calls between New York, Newark and other North Jersey points were delayed today when a fire in a manhole at Broad and Bridge Streets burned out six cables of the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company shortly after noon.

BOSTON, Mass., June 29. -- Reports of substantial gains in newspaper and periodical advertising were backed up today by statements from manufacturers of presses, type, printing ink, papers and other supplies, exhibiting in the Hotel Statler, during the convention of the Advertising Federation of America.
Exports and imports from and into the United States by classified groups during May, as announced by the Department of Commerce, compare as follows with those of the corresponding period in 1935:

An announcement that cotton in the 12-cent loan would again be made available to consumers injected an unsettling element into trading on the Cotton Exchange yesterday. Liquidation caused a reaction of 15 points or more, but resistance was met on comparatively limited recessions so that a 10-point recovery left the list 6 to 11 points lower than on Saturday.

For thirteen rounds Tony Marino, 115 1/2, Pittsburgh, was a defeated fighter last night, but with two damaging blows he scored a knockout over Baltasar Sangchili, 117 1/2, European bantamweight titleholder, in the fourteenth of a scheduled fifteen-rounder before 5,000 spectators at Dyckman Oval.

CHICAGO, June 29. -- Prices of hogs generally advanced 10 cents a hundredweight today, at times going as high as 15 to 20 cents above last week's close. They were the highest since late in April. The practical top was up 15 cents at $10.90 a hundredweight, although small lots sold at $11.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP). -- The United States Government already has notified Britain that it was willing to acceed to the British proposal for an increase in the destroyer strength of navies provided London assumed responsibility for the increase. Formal notice that Britain must assume this responsibility was dispatched to the British Government early this month.

Hernand Behn, president of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, who died in France on Oct. 7, 1933, left an estate appraised yesterday at $592,559 gross and $278,516 net. The bulk of the estate was in securities worth $480,598, including 4,278 shares of Behn Bros.
ALBANY, June 29. -- Motor Vehicle Commissioner Charles A. Harnett today asked persons taking tests for drivers' licenses to report promptly any examiner who seeks to exact money.

LONDON, June 29. -- King Edward will go speeding through the waters of the Solent on board the fastest vessel of the British Navy tomorrow when he visits the naval base at Portsmouth for the first time since his accession to the throne.

A hundred years ago lacking only a few months the first white child was born west of the Rocky Mountains -- the daughter of the missionaries to the Indians, MARCUS WHITMAN and his wife, who one hundred years ago his week reached the dividing line between the Atlantic and Pacific Slopes and there celebrated Independence Day.
Mayor La Guardia's choice of a Summer City Hall in Pelham Bay Park, the Bronx, won praise yesterday from Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx, one of the Mayor's most persistent critics.

BOSTON, June 29 (AP). -- Albert G. Tarn's Rushaway gained a spectacular nose victory in the Middlesex County Handicap, main event at Suffolk Downs today spinning the mile in 1:39 1-5. A crowd of 12,000 roared a mighty ovation as the gelded son of Haste battled it out the entire route with Weston Adams's Gallant Gay, the lead changing three times.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- A Commerce Department order enjoining the Gulf conference of steamship companies from maintaining a special contract-rate system of shipments to the Pacific Coast was affirmed today by the United States District Court on the ground that it tended to create a monopoly.

ROME, June 29. -- The first indication that pacification of Ethiopia is proceeding apace and that events are developing there according to the Italian plan was given today when it was announced the Gavinana Division, one of the first sent to East Africa early last year, would return home very soon.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 29. -- In winning the twenty-first annual championship tournament of the Father and Son Golf Association today at the Garden City Golf Club Charles Presbrey and his son, Charles S. Presbrey, of Blind Brook, set a new record for the event with a net score of 65.

The proposal of Eastern railroads for complete free pick-up and delivery service on less-than-carload freight received the endorsement in principle of the Port of New York Authority yesterday, as trucking companies began to present their evidence in opposition to the plan.

The foreign exchanges yesterday retraced a part of the sharp gains they scored against the dollar at the end of last week, but the gold-bloc currencies remained at or above par. The franc lost 1/2 point net to 6.63 1/4 cents, the guilder dropped 8 points to 68.12 cents and the Swiss franc was down 2 points to 32.75 cents.

I knew it! The moment Landon was nominated, I knew that almost the next step would be trout-fishing. This is obviously a peculiarly Republican form of winning sympathy or acclaim, or whatever it is that trout fishers are looking for.

Employes of the leading steel companies are being asked by the corporations to hold firmly to their employe representation plans and to oppose any attempt of the Amalgamated Association of Iron, Steel and Tin Workers to drive a wedge between the employes and the managements of the corporations.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., June 29. -- With the aid of seven birdies, the team of Charles Mayo Jr. of Lido and Jim Barnes of Crescent posted a best-ball score of 35, 32 -- 67 to lead a near-record field of sixty-one twosomes in the weekly Long Island amateur-pro one-day tournament at the Hempstead Golf Club today.

Among the many recent "finds" in Greece are two that were got from wells, where they were thrust no doubt in time of panic. One is a piece of marble, bearing a decree in praise of an Athenian citizen and legislator named TELESCOPOS (that is, "fariseeing "), son of A_RISTOKRATES (an aristocrat).

The Treasury closes its books today on the fiscal year 1935-36 with the largest peacetime deficit in the history of the United States. The reasons for this deficit are worth considering, in view of the attention which national finance has received and will continue to receive throughout the campaign.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., June 29. -- Dave O'Connell, assistant pro at Essex Fells, teamed with 17-year-old George F. Lewis today at Rock Spring to win the first annual New Jersey P.G.A. pro-junior tournament. They had a best-ball score of 66.

Describing conditions in Brooklyn as "rotten," Hiram C. Todd, special prosecutor in the Drukman conspiracy case, yesterday began planning for the retrial of the Assistant District Attorney and the police detective Whose cases resulted in a disagreement by the Brooklyn blue ribbon jury on Saturday.

NEW ROCHELE, N.Y., June 29. -- Expensive beach clubs have in recent years gone far in bringing conveniences to their members without disturbing their sun baths on the sand -- food, cool drinks, messenger service and no end of other aids to comfort -- but it remained for the New Rochelle Public Library to give reality to its new slogan "Read while you tan."
LONDON, June 29. -- By command of King Edward VIII Yeomen of the Guard, who have hitherto compulsorily worn beards, may shave them off if they wish.

CHANGSHA, Hunan Province, China, July 29. -- Interviewed today, General Ho Chien, chairman of the Hunan Provincial Government, expressed the belief that there would be no civil war in China until after the plenary session of the Kuomintang (National People's party) in Nanking on July 10.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., June 29. -- Governor Lehman, in addressing the convention of the Independent Order B'rith Abraham here today, declared that there is a popular misconception of the extent to which government can go in its humanitarian activities.

Many dinner parties will be given in connection with the carnival jamboree in aid of the Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association to be given Friday night on the Locust Valley estate of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Dow Gibson.

BALTIMORE, June 29 (AP). -- A.E. Duncan, chairman of the board of the Commercial Credit Corporation, reported today a net income for the first five months of 1936 which was about 50 per cent larger than for the same period of 1935.

WASHINGTON, June 29. -- Northwest Publications, Inc., St. Paul, Minn., a subsidiary of Ridder Brothers, Inc., which controls The Journal of Commerce in New York, has filed a registration, statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering $4,200,000 of 41/2 per cent sinking fund debenture bonds, due on July 1, 1948.

BALTIMORE, June 29 (AP). -- Secretary Ickes said tonight that the New Deal conception of democracy would help the Negro "because he pre-eminently belongs to the class that the new democracy is designed especially to aid."
Several apartment house properties were included in the urban realty turnover reported yesterday.

Mass psychology, aided no little by the strong sun, temporarily came to the fore yesterday afternoon at the second annual June walk of the Grover Cleveland-Osceola Democratic Club in Central Park's East Meadows, opposite 100th Street, and spoiled what had previously been a successful community gathering of 5,000 under-privileged children and their parents of the Fifteenth Assembly District.

PITTSBURGH, June 29. -- Earl F. Reed, attorney, who has been a key figure in the steel operators' battle against New Deal legislation, predicted tonight labor's unionization drive may lead to a general strike of American labor unions.
DETROIT, June 29 (AP). -- Dayton Dean pleaded guilty today to the Black Legion murder which brought to light the existence of the terrorist organization.

BRIELLE, N.J., June 29. -- Big, tackle-smashing tuna, thick-bodied, deep-swimming fighters of incredible strength, were hitting trolled lures yesterday on famous Barnegat Ridge, twenty-six miles southeast of this port. Today a score or more of fishermen who sailed from this place are nursing sore muscles and bruised and blistered hands.
ST. PAUL, June 29 (AP). -- Wind and rain swept through parts of the Middle West late today, relieving drought conditions in some sections, but causing new damage to property.

WASHINGTON, June 29. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on June 24 shows a decline for the week of $139,000,000 in total loans and investments and increases of $132,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, $38,000,000 in time deposits, $99,000,000 in deposit balances standing to the credit of domestic banks, and $345,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks.
Daniel I. Reiter proposes that Congress pass a law "that would prohibit a citizen from voting if he accepts relief."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 29. -- For the third time in five years the Westchester and Fairfield women's team defeated Connecticut today to regain possession of the Westchester-Fairfield-Connecticut Trophy. The score of the match, played on the Yale golf course, was 8 1/2 -- 6 1/2.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., June 29. -- For the second year in succession Miss Rosalie Knapp and her mother, Mrs. E.S. Knapp, of the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club took low gross honors in the twelfth annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association mother and daughter tournament held today over the Siwanoy Country Club links.
MADISON, June 29. -- Machinery to administer Wisconsin's Employment Insurance Act, first of its kind in the nation, is being rushed to completion, to begin functioning on Wednesday, July 1.

SPOKANE, Wash., June 29 (AP). -- Caustic remarks about President Roosevelt caused the first real domestic split between C.C. Dill and his wife, the former Senator testified at the trial of his divorce suit here today.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

LONDON, June 29. -- The Labor party provoked a hubbub of discussion in Parliament today over last week's speech by War Secretary Alfred Duff Cooper appealing for close understanding between Great Britain and France.

LONDON, June 29 (AP). -- Japan formally refused today to adhere to the 1936 London treaty, signed by Great Britain, the United States and France, and it was learned the British would shortly invoke the escalator clause of the 1930 treaty to save excess destroyers.
LONDON, June 29 (Canadian Press). -Kent vaulted into leadership of the English county cricket competition today with a sparkling eight-wicket victory over Essex at Tunbridge Wells.

ST. LOUIS, June 29. -- Breckinridge Long, former St. Louisan and present Ambassador to Italy, plans to resign his ambassadorship by not later than Wednesday, according to Frank A. Thompson. St. Louis attorney, who was with Mr. Long during an operation and part of his convalescence at the Mayo Clinic, Rochester, Minn., early in June.

NEWARK, N.J., June 29. -- For the third time in three years one of the highest rituals of the Roman Catholic Church was conducted within the unfinished walls of Sacred Heart Cathedral, on the heights of Branch Brook Park here today when Mgr. Frank J. Monaghan, president of Seton Hall College, was elevated to the Episcopate.

WESTPORT, Conn., June 29. -- To make the Summer official at his Country Playhouse, Lawrence Langner tonight turned once again, as he did last year, to the bright and matchless devices of Restoration comedy. His hospitable doors swung wide to admit William Congreve's "Love for Love" -- not precisely as that elegant comedy was written, for with it have come scenes and snatches of the same author's "The Way of the World."

HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 30. -- With the race from Newport finished, some of the yachts which took part in the storm-ridden passage were getting ready today for the start of another and longer thrash -- the transatlantic race to Cuxhaven, Germany.
Editorial comment in New York State on Governor Lehman's announcement that he would run for a third term follows:

BERLIN, June 30. -- The Boerse as usual was in the doldrums today, and it appears that it will be there for the rest of the Summer. Most heavy industrials showed little activity, but Vcrelnigtcstahl gained ; point. Potashes were stagnant. A Iaehinery shares weakened throughout without suffering any serious losses, but Berlin I,i point.

The National City Bank of New York yesterday announced that it would retire on Aug. 1 its $50,000,000 of preferred stock which is held principally by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation. The decision, which came as a surprise to the financial community, follows closely upon the action of the Chase National Bank in retiring a similar amount of its preferred stock last month.

Police Commissioner Valentine and former Governor Alfred E. Smith are among eleven members announced yesterday by the C.I.T. Safety Foundation as its national advisory board in its $250,000 movement to remove traffic accidents.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP). -- The National Labor Relations Board said today it would study the Fruehauf Trailer case decision along with similar opinions of other courts before determining whether it would appeal to the Supreme Court. The board has ninety days in which to serve notice of appeal.

Net income of the International Shoe Company for the six months ended on May 31 amounted to $3,489,057 after expenses, depreciation, provision for income taxes and other charges. After dividend requirements on the preferred stock, the income is equivalent to $1.04 each on 3,350,000 shares of common stock outstanding.

Complete free pick-up and delivery service for less-than-carload freight by Eastern railroads would throw thousands of truck drivers out of work, disrupt the trucking industry, bring rate wars that would harm both truckers and railroads and disrupt the railroad class rate structure, witnesses declared yesterday at the Interstate Commerce Commission hearings on the proposed tariffs for the service.

The Bank of China, a quasi-governmental institution to which the Chinese Government has delegated the special functions of handling foreign exchange transactions and financing China's foreign trade, will open today a New York agency at 40 Wall Street.

Detectives began tracing yesterday the elaborate scheme by which Walter A. Rathbourne, prisoner in Sing Sing, engineered the processing and sale of counterfeit stock certificates and bonds through a nation-wide organization. They found samples of his written orders in the automobile of one of his alleged accomplices.

The steady drizzle last night compelled Jose Iturbi and the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra to give their concert in the Great Hall of City College instead of the Lewisohn Stadium, but that did not detract from the enjoyment of the evening.

Most commodity futures were easier in less active trading on the local markets yesterday. Rubber was strong and silk and some of the metals were firm. On the cash markets, tins advanced and rubber sold at a new high price, while the grains, cotton, wool tops and cocoa lost ground.

BALTIMORE, June 30. -- New and extremely exacting tests will be made tomorrow at Pimlico on the photo finish device used there and at Havre de Grace last Spring and more recently at Suffolk Downs. At the latter course, officials last week were ordered by the Massachusetts State Racing Commission to discontinue use of the machine.

The principal characteristic of business conditions in the United States in the first half of 1936 has been the high degree of stability at the best levels since 1930. The gains of 1935 appeared to have been well consolidated, and only a sturdy revival of the building trades now seems to stand in the way of a return to conditions of 1925 to 1927.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 30. -- Miss Helen Jacobs, keeping her head when all around her seemed to be losing theirs, survived a crisis on the center court today when her dainty Chilean opponent, Miss Anita Lizana, had her on the run in the third set of their match in the quarter-finals of the women's tennis championship and seemed within an ace of rushing her off the court altogether.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 30. -- Two hundred and sixty-six athletic awards were granted at Princeton University the past Spring, according to an announcement made today by Asa S. Bushnell, graduate manager of athletics.

CHICAGO, June 30 (AP). -- Mrs. George Jeremiah of New York and Mrs. William Brownlee of Chicago were announced tonight as winners of the national contract whist championship. The games were played during the afternoon.

Two ships of the United States Lines will sail for Europe today within five hours of each other, carrying a total of 1,555 passengers. The Washington will sail at noon for Cobh, Plymouth, Havre and Hamburg with 965 passengers and the California will sail at 5 P.M. for Southampton and Havre with 590.

The Fourth of July in 1935 was the safest "Fourth" that this city has known in any recent year. There were fewer lives lost and fewer fires as the result of "fireworks accidents" -- but two lives in all. It is hoped, however, that even this record may be improved this year.

Salaries of the principal executives of the United States Steel Corporation, the General Electric Company and more than a dozen other important corporations in 1935 were disclosed yesterday in annual reports to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

A comparatively new participant in tournament in this district, Miss Katharine Sylvester of Green Meadow, set the scoring pace in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association one-day event at the Pomonok Country Club in Flushing yesterday.

Showing a sharp decline from the average for the first twenty-six weeks of this year, retail failures in the week ended June 25 totaled ninety-one, compared with 123 in the previous week, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

The office of Controller General of the United States is one of the most important posts in Washington. For fifteen years JOHN R. McCARL has filled it with distinction. He now takes leave of it because the law makes the Controller ineligible to reappointment.

With former Governor Alfred E. Smith playing an active role, the American Liberty League through its executive committee at a meeting yesterday formally sounded the keynote of its campaign plans to oppose President Roosevelt for re-election.

Abandonment of sixteen high school annex buildings and their removal to more suitable sites and of seventeen portable or temporary structures housing elementary school children is recommended in a report submitted yesterday to Mayor La Guardia by the Joint Committee on Education, an organization representing civic and nonpolitical bodies.

Two young lawyers, a physician who is a brother of one of them, and a part-time furrier pleaded guilty before Justices Salomon, Kernochan and McKiniry in Special Sessions yesterday to ambulance chasing charges.

The influx of gold into the United States that started at the end of April was accelerated in June by heavier shipments of the metal from France. These consignments, besides others from several countries, raised imports of the metal to $214,591,400, the largest for any month since last October.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., June 30. -- Mrs. Pauline V. Rogers, widow of Colonel Henry H. Rogers, the oil man, testified in Surrogate's Court here today that Adrian H. Larkin, her husband's personal attorney, had not told her about her rights under the New York State Inheritance Law.

The $5,000,000,000 steel industry adopted advertising yesterday as a weapon in its fight against the unionization of its 500,000 employes on a closed-shop basis by the Committee for Industrial Organization, headed by John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers of America.
LONDON, June 30. -- Unsatisfactory reports on Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin's health came today from Chequers, where he is taking a complete rest.

Mrs. Clarence Day is collecting the letters of the late Clarence Day for a volume which Alfred A. Knopf plans to publish next year. She has asked those who have kept letters from Mr. Day to send them to her in care of Alfred Knopf, 730 Fifth Avenue.

Fresh-water anglers take a new lease on life today when the legal barriers fall on that democratic denizen of our lakes and streams -- the black bass. The season opens throughout New York State, with the exception of Lake George, and in the neighboring States of Connecticut and Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, June 30. -- President Roosevelt praised in the most enthusiastic terms today Governor Lehman's announcement that he had reconsidered his former decision not to run for re-election as Governor of New York.

TOKYO, Wednesday, July 1. -- A fresh move for foreign recognition of Manchukuo is made by a statement Chang Yen-chin, the Foreign Minister of Manuchukuo, will issue today foreshadowing gradual withdrawal of extraterritoriality privileges and inviting foreign governments to negotiate for their partial continuance.

TOLEDO, Ohio, June 30 (AP). -- Mrs. Edwin T. Meredith of Des Moines, Iowa, was elected unanimously today as chairman of the Independent Coalition of American Women at the national convention here. The name of the organization also was determined.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., June 30. -- The Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation was accused today of being the first independent steel company to discharge workmen at the Atiquippa plant for aiding the drive to unionize the industry. The charge was made by Clinton S. Golden, a follower of John L. Lewis, United Mine Workers president, in the unionization drive.

Edward B. Hall, president of Harris, Hall Co. of Chicago, has been nominated by the governors of the Investment Bankers Association of America to be president of the association for the year, 1936-37, it was announced yesterday through the association's office in Chicago by Orrin G. Wood of Estabrook Co., Boston, president of the association.

BOSTON, June 30. -- Several former neighbors bobbed up at National League Field today and slapped our Giants down into the second division for the first time in five years, and the second time in the regime of Colonel Bill Terry.

Vincent M. Leibell, appointee of President Roosevelt, took the oath of office yesterday as a Federal Judge of the Southern District of New York. John W. Clancy and Samuel Mandelbaum, appointees to the same office, were present at the induction in the new Federal Building.

ALBANY, June 30 (AP). -- Assistant District Attorney James J. McGuiness Jr. placed State losses from fraudulent motor fuel tax refunds today at "close to $100,000" with the arraignment of a third person on indictments returned by an Albany County grand jury.

Running another fast race at Aqueduct, similar to his earlier score at this track, Mrs. Marian Cassidy's Bill Farnsworth yesterday captured the Dalesman Handicap, while E.R. Bradley's Bootmaker was first in the Starbottle Handicap, joint features.

Winning every round but one, which was even, Eddie McGeever, 140, West Side, gained a six-round decision over Danny Koplick, 145 1/2, Brooklyn, in the feature bout at the New York Coliseum in the Bronx last night. A crowd of 3,000 watched the battle.

VATICAN CITY, June 30. -- Pope Pius left by automobile at 6:30 this evening, accompanied only by a few of the most intimate members of his personal household, for his Summer residence at Castel Gandolfo, about fifteen miles south of Rome. He is expected to remain there until October.

The share market yesterday was in many respects like that of the day before. Buying remained selective in character; Chrysler and a few other stocks again climbed to new highs for the year, the steels and certain other groups continued fractionally lower, but the market's undertone was steady.

TODAY, July 1, is the dead-center of the year, or as near dead-center as one can conveniently get: 183 days gone by, 183 days to come. It is also the time for semi-annual interest payments, as well as the beginning of the Federal fiscal year. A very important Wednesday, and quite obviously the proper one on which to reconsider the books of the last few months and to glance ahead at those to come.

PARIS, June 30. -- In ceremonies today France honored John D. Rockefeller Jr., through whose generosity the palace and gardens of Versailles, the Reims Cathedral and Fontainebleau have been restored at a cost of about 60,000,000 francs.

LONDON, June 30 (Canadian Press). -- England today defeated India by nine wickets in the first test cricket match of the year between the two countries before 2,000 at Lord's. England compiled innings of 134 and 108 runs for one wicket, while the visitors' scores were 147 and 93.

A publio offering of 85,000 shares of the common stock of the Quaker State Oil Refining Corporation will be made today by A. G. Backer Co. at ,$16 a share. The offering includes 25,000 shares to be issued by the corporation, the proceeds from the sale of which are to be used in part payment for the cost of plant improvements, while 60,000 shares are being supplied by present shareholders.

Being an organization that doesn't need the backing provided by the films, the Theatre Guild goes on buying plays for itself. It announces this morning that, by arrangement with Charles L. Wagner, it has acquired "Prelude to Exile," by William McNally.

WASHINGTON, June 30. -- John Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Committee, left today for Columbus, Ohio, where he will speak at a meeting of Republican workers tomorrow night. The offices of the Republican National Committee in the Barr Building were closed today and most of the officials departed for Chicago, where the general headquarters will be established for the campaign.
