The foreign exchanges again slipped irregularly lower in terms of the dollar yesterday as the buoyant effects of the short-covering that had taken place late last week continued to wear off. The franc dropped to 6.62 7/8 cents and closed at 6.63 cents, off 1/4 point.

The clarifying amendment to the Constitution suggested in the Democratic platform would bring a concentration of economic power in the Federal Government that would be the first step toward a political dictatorship, Ogden L. Mills, former Secretary of the Treasury, declared last night.

WASHINGTON, June 30. -- The drought situation in the Northwest, Middle West and South was discussed today at a White House conference attended by Secretary Wallace, Chester C. Davis, member of the Federal Reserve Board and former Administrator of the AAA, and Aubrey Williams, Assistant WPA Administrator.
WASHINGTON, June 30. -- President Roosevelt indicated today that he would probably pay a long-deferred call on Lord Tweedsmuir, Governor General of Canada, late in July or early in August.

The New York Hospital, 525 East Sixty-eighth Street, spent $856,726.09 last year for free and below-cost care of the needy of the city, according to the 164th annual report made public yesterday by the Society of the New York Hospital. The figure represented an increase of $91,429.09 over the previous year.

WASHINGTON, June 30. -- Ten American Federation of Labor unions, comprising 1,000,000 members or one-third of the membership of the federation, have been cited to appear before the executive council here next Tuesday to answer charges that they are seeking to set up a rival or dual organization.

PITTSBURGH, June 30. -- Pepper Martin's single in the ninth with a man on second gave the Cardinals a 4-3 victory in the nightcap of a dual bill with the Pirates today. The Cards had regained the National League lead in the opening game by halting the Bucs, 2 -- 1.

Harold L. Kunstler, who resigned as a Municipal Court justice in June, 1934, when a referee who heard charges against him was about to recommend his removal, was disbarred as a lawyer by the Appellate Division yesterday. The action was based mainly on the same charges brought for his removal from the bench.

Miss Cynthia Lenox Banks made her debut last night at a supper dance given jointly by her mother, Mrs. Fisher Kuser, and Mr. and Mrs. Theodore W. Herbst, at Fair-court, the home of the latter in Bernardsville, N.J. A profusion of flowers from the estate, once the home of Mrs. Herbst's parents, the late Colonel and Mrs. Anthony R. Kuser, decorated the house and the grounds were illuminated with electric lights and lanterns.

The frank and manly statement issued yesterday by Governor LEHMAN at Albany shows that he has felt compelled to subordinate personal desires to a public demand. When he announced on May 20 that he would not be a candidate for re-election in November, no one doubted his sincerity.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, June 30. -- Selection and installation of officers ended the national convention of the Independent Order of B'rith Abraham here today.

WOODBURY, N.J., June 30. -- Three militant Fundamentalist ministers were deposed by the West Jersey Presbytery of the Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A. at a three-and-one-half hour meeting here this afternoon.
Jimmy Williams, the 14-year-old Brooklyn boy who wrote to Mayor La Guardia asking that his home at 242 Forty-Second Street be returned to his family had a disappointing visit to City Hall yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 30 (AP). -- Postmaster General Farley, commenting on the decision of Governor Lehman of New York to seek a third term, predicted today that both Mr. Lehman and President Roosevelt would "carry New York State by greater majorities this year than they did in 1932."

BOSTON, June 30. -- J. Pierpont Morgan has been ill for several weeks at the home of his sister-in-law, Mrs. S.V.R. Crosby of West Manchester, it was disclosed tonight when the financier departed by train from Beverly Farms for New York. A physician and a nurse accompanied him.

The city was defeated yesterday in its attempt to collect $170 from Raymond G. Pollard, Deputy Public Works Commissioner of Queens, for using a city automobile on two trips to Georgia. Municipal Court Justice John J. Sullivan ruled that the "city is not engaged in any auto rental business."
HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, June 30. -- A record total of 121 entries, including a strong American contingent, will open competition tomorrow in the Royal Henley Regatta.

CHICAGO, June 30. -- Wheat markets were on the down grade today on the Board of Trade. Local operators who had bought yesterday went out of their holdings, while hedging pressure from the Southwest, showers in Western Canada and weakness in Liverpool were the bearish influences and more than offset the continued drought comments from the United States Northwest.

American admiralty law was defended as fair and the alleged need of thorough revision discounted in a report published yesterday by a majority of the admiralty committee of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York.
HONGKONG, June 30 (AP). -- Troops of the Canton (Southern) Chinese Government were reported entirely withdrawn behind their own frontiers in Kwangtung and Kwangsi Provinces today.

Pointing out that the requirements of the nation's welfare agencies continue to be "very great," Gerard Swope, president of the General Electric Company, asked all Americans yesterday to meet generously the demands of human need, "the most compelling issue in the country."

Contributions totaling $128,680 were reported by Peter Grimm, general chairman of the 1936 Boy Scout maintenance fund campaign, at a luncheon meeting held yesterday at the Columbia University Club, 4 West Forty-third Street. The city-wide drive for a $225,000 objective to maintain the Scout program on its present basis was opened in May by the Boy Scout Foundation, of which President Roosevelt is the honorary president and Barron Collier the acting president.

WASHINGTON, June 30. -- With the Railroad Retirement Board certifying some pension payments to railway vorkers to the Treasury tomorrow, the way will be opened for determining to what extent such pensions may be paid out of the $47,000,000 appropriated by the government.
June this year more than lived up to its reputation as the month of marriages, all records for total licenses issued being broken in the city clerk's offices in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens.

Nullification of the Constitution by "legislative attrition" or its amendment by means other than those provided in the Constitution itself are "traitorous," Bainbridge Colby, former Secretary of State, declared last night at a dinner at the Hotel Plaza.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP). -- Appointment of a successor to Controller General McCarl was deferred today by President Roosevelt for at least two weeks. The term of office expires at midnight tonight.

CHICAGO, June 30. -- The best hogs sold steady to 10 cents a hundredweight higher with the practical top up 5 cents at $10.95, although small lots again sold at $11. The day's average was up 5 cents from yesterday's level at $10.30 with the spread between that figure and the top quotation of 65 cents the widest since last October.
ONE of the elder statesmen of the newspaper profession handed over a clipping with the dry remark:
The 1939 World's Fair announced yesterday the appointments of Thomas J. Watson, president of the International Business Machines Corporation, and Major Gen. Dennis E. Nolan, retired, to its staff.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

William Z. Foster, three times a candidate for President on the Communist ticket, charges in an article in today's Daily Worker that the statement made by the American Iron and Steel Institute "is a declaration of war not only against the steel workers and the Committee for Industrial Organization but against the whole labor movement."

Progress in correcting social conditions in Harlem was the subject of a report made by Mayor La Guardia in City Hall yesterday to seven members of the committee appointed to study those conditions after the Harlem rioting of March, 1935.
SHANGHAI, Wednesday, July 1. -- China's domestic and foreign complications continue to become more serious.
LONDON, June 30. -- Prices were irregular today on the Stock Exchange, with business continuing quiet. British Government stocks were comparatively idle, owing to the half-year scarcity of money.

Traffic was interrupted for about a half hour soon after 1 P.M. yesterday when a northbound Sixth Avenue bus crashed into an elevated railway pillar at the southeast corner of Sixth Avenue and Forty-fifth Street. Four persons were treated for minor injuries.

In an effort to bring about more equitable conditions with respect to labor in the fur garment manufacturing industry here, members of the American Fur Manufacturers Association, at a meeting in the Governor Clinton Hotel last night, decided to push a drive for an agreement with the International Fur Workers Union.

When Mayor La Guardia drives up to Pelham Bay Park tomorrow to set up his "Summer City Hall" there, he may glance out the window as his car passes along Boston Road at 168th Street. If he looks quickly in the right direction he will be assured that he is then five miles from his destination.

CINCINNATI, June 30 (AP). -- The Sixth United States Circuit Court of Appeals held today that Congress had no authority to regulate or control the relations between an employer engaged in manufacture and his employes unless those relations directly affected interstate commerce.

Between showers yesterday George B. Dunn, University of Pennsylvania senior, and Barclay A. Kingman of Williams, the only seeded players to take the court in the fourteenth annual Eastern intercollegiate tournament, met divergent fates.

BOSTON, June 30 (AP). -- Percy M. Pike's Ebony Lady scored a length victory in the mile Mayfair Purse before 14,000 at Suffolk Downs today. The daughter of Flying Ebony was timed in 1:38 3-5 as she finished ahead of Col. Greene, which had two lengths on the Corsicana Stable's Wacoche.
GENEVA, June 30. -- Following is a summary of the address before the League of Nations Assembly today by Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia, with the principal parts giver textually:

Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins denied yesterday the application by Count Ludwig Salm for the removal of his former wife, Millicent Rogers Balcom, as one of the guardians of their son Peter, one of the chief heirs of the estate of his maternal grandfather, Colonel Henry H. Rogers.

While New York City considered the advisability of arresting jaywalkers in a campaign to reduce traffic accidents, New Jersey moved toward the same goal of safety yesterday by starting a system of compulsory inspection for all motor vehicles in the State.

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 30. -- The nation is gradually becoming aware of the necessity of providing for reasonable encouragement to capital to make new investments in productive facilities, Eugene C. Grace, president of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, said today at the formal opening of the company's new $20,000,000 strip and sheet mill at Lackawanna.

Miss Vera Stretz, acquitted last April of the murder of Dr. Fritz Gebhardt, appeared at Police Headquarters with a companion yesterday to have her photograph and fingerprints removed from police records.

ROME, June 30. -- The mere fact that Emperor Hails Selassie of Ethiopia should have been allowed to participate in the League of Nations Assembly proceedings and to deliver a speech, even more than what he said, has created in Italy what circles very close to the government term "a most disastrous impression."

The number of visiting buyers reported in the market during the week ended yesterday was less than in the preceding week. However, the total was above the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES. For the past week 702 arrivals were registered, as against 834 in the previous week and 536 in the same period last year.

If it is the intention of the Yankees to spread-eagle the field by July 4, even their severest critics will now admit that they are succeeding. Yesterday in the presence of 54,000 persons at the Stadium, the largest week-day turnout of the campaign, they came from behind twice to annex two games from the Red Sox, 10 -- 5 and 6 -- 3.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 30 (AP). -- The story of a flogging so severe that a reform school inmate "prayed to die" came to the grand jury from a former dormitory matron today at the conclusion of an investigation into conditions at the institution.

A survey of earnings of salesmen for wholesale liquor houses covering payments made them by their employers from March 1 to yesterday has been ordered by the liquor board of trade of the New York Institute of Wine and Spirit Distributors, Inc., John J. Connolly, executive secretary of the National Institute of Wine and Spirit Distributors, Inc., announced yesterday.

ST. PAUL, June 30. -- Clothed with authority to "start things going at once," PWA administrators of the five States most severely hit by the drought issued instructions tonight designed to put thousands of needy farmers at work on a variety of public projects.

ELMIRA, N.Y., June 30. -- Calibration of barographs today robbed Emerson Mehlhose of Wyandotte, Mich., of a new gilder altitude record which he thought he had earned yesterday. His barograph revealed that his altimeter was far off in recording an altitude of 6,500 feet on his flight yesterday to Orson, Pa.

BOSTON, June 30. -- Addressing the sales-promotion division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association held today in conjunction with the thirty-second annual convention of the Advertising Federation of America, Louis Kirstein, vice president of William Filene's Sons Company of this city, declared that the social security and labor legislation of the Roosevelt Administration would "release tremendous buying power."

LONDON, June 30. -- The British position in the Eastern Mediterranean will be strengthened decisively soon by the conclusion of a treaty of "perpetual alliance" between Great Britain and Egypt on the basis of mutual friendship and mutual help in case of trouble.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,969,150 barrels, compared to 2,963,400 in the preceding week, a gain of 5,750, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A decrease of 11,000 barrels in the daily average output of California and a gain of 8,950 in Oklahoma were the important changes.

Governor Lehman announced yesterday in Albany that he would become a candidate for re-election and, amid declarations of jubilation from President Roosevelt, Democratic hopes for carrying State and nation went soaring.

Asserting that the problems of government become "almost insuperable" when the Supreme Court "either mistakes or lags behind in understanding the economic and social trends of the times," Henry A. Wallace, Secretary of Agriculture, expresses his belief that the Constitution should be interpreted more broadly and more in accordance with what he describes as the purposes of its framers.

OSLO, Norway, June 30 (AP). -- The Norwegian liner Stavangerfjord reported to Oslo today receipt of a message from the Wyatt Earp, exploration motor ship of Sir Hubert Wilkins, which has been unreported for twelve days.

District Judge Robert P. Patterson, the youngest Federal judge in this district, dismissed yesterday as "frivolous" the charges of personal bias and prejudice leveled against Judge Julian W. Mack of the Circuit Court of Appeals, the oldest jurist, by the Associated Gas and Electric Company.

The National Youth Administration closed a year of experimentation here yesterday, with Mark A. McCloskey, regional director, confident that the Federal program was succeeding in its effort to restore "self-confidence and hope" to youthful victims of the depression.

Today's lone newcomer is "I Stand Condemned," at the Rivoli, which previously had been an-announced by London Films as Moscow Nights." Its roster of players is headed by Harry Baur, who appeared as the police inspector in the Gallic "Crime et Chatiment."

HAVERSTRAW, N.Y., June 30. -- A 20-year-old youth, member of a well-to-do family here, who has "peculiar" feelings, becomes "annoyed" and is "beset" with a desire to set fires near the time of the full moon, was said to have confessed today that he was responsible for nearly all of the mysterious blazes which have destroyed fourteen buildings in Haverstraw in the last year.

The annual rush to juvenile Summer camps, which usually dominates the railroad stations at this period, is just a swirl in the general flood of vacation travel this year. Groups of children, bound for vacation camps, made little stir in the hurly-burly of movement in the railroad stations.

GLEN COVE, L.I., June 30. -- Robert Riggs of Los Angeles, national clay court and junior champion, was leading Watson Washburn, 10 -- 3, 3 -- 2, today when rain interrupted the opening round of play in the invitation turf court tennis tournament at the Nassau Country Club.

WASHINGTON, June 30. -- As the Treasury warrants to continue employment of 2,300,000 needy during the next three months were counter-signed by the retiring Controller General, J.R. McCarl, WPA officials explained that State and local administrators had been authorized to select projects to be carried out from the funds left over from the present program.

Mayor La Guardia opened possible careers in city service yesterday for sixteen high school pupils selected from the general school population to take an intensive course in practical city government this Summer.

VIENNA, June 30. -- Under circumstances surrounded by considerable mystery, Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg at last officially admitted tonight that he had refused personal invitations from Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden of Britain and Foreign Minister Yvon Delbos to go to Geneva.

PHILADELPHIA, June 30 (AP). -- Sixteen-year-old Miss Hope Knowles of Philadelphia kept step with veterans today in the third round of the women's Middle States tennis championships at the Philadelphia Cricket Club.

The following table gives the amount of the dealings in the stocks from which the averages are computed, as well as the total dealings in the rails and industrials, and the combined trading in both classes of issues and the number of the latter appearing in the daily and weekly transactions: ...

PROVIDENCE, June 30 (AP). -- Final Olympic trials for women track and field stars will be held here Saturday regardless of the financial troubles of the Providence Tercentenary Committee, which is sponsoring the tryouts, A.A.U. officials said today.

The court ham dismissed the Government suit against the nine New York clearing house banks which refused, after the failure of the Harriman National Bank in 1933, to pay their pro rata share in making good the deposits of that defaulted institution. In July of 1932 the Controller of Currency considered the closing of that bank; it was probably then insolvent.

WASHINGTON, June 30. -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation has authorized a loan of $1,236,000 to American Air Lines, Inc., of Chicago, the loan to be secured by equipment trust certificates similar to those used in the purchase of railroad equipment.

Public offering will be made today of an issue of $19,250,000 of General American Transportation Corporation 3 per cent serial notes by Kuhn, Loeb Co., at prices to yield from 1 to 3.25 per cent, according to maturity. The notes will be dated July 1, 1936, and will mature serially in installments of $1,750,000 each on July 1, 1937, and Jan. 1 and July 1 in each year thereafter from 1938 to 1942. inclusive.
Joseph Curran, leader of the "rank and file" group of seamen on the Atlantic Coast yesterday asked President Roosevelt to undertake a thorough investigation of conditions on American merchant ships.

BOSTON, June 30 (AP). -- The Massachusetts Department of the Veterans of Foreign Wars decided tonight to test the right of a District Court judge to order a war veteran to use his bonus money to pay a debt.
BALTIMORE, June 30 (AP). -- Amateur baseball aces began assembling today from the far corners of the nation in a movement to make the great American sport a part of the Olympic Games.

The condition of William A. Thompson Jr., 19-year-old resident of Sayville, L. I., who has been kept alive for the last two days by blood transfusions given by his friends in Broad Street Hospital, this city, was reported yesterday as still critical.

Ten days ago Attillio Agnoli collected his war bonus of more than $1,500 and brought to a temporary end at least three years of poverty. He immediately moved from the Bowery lodging house, where the transient bureau of the EBB had maintained him, to the comparative luxury of the Mills Hotel, 161 West Thirty-sixth Street.

Organized crime will dominate the city unless the present investigation into rackets conducted by Thomas E. Dewey as special prosecutor is continued and, if possible, intensified, the extraordinary grand jury which has been cooperating with him said yesterday in a communication to Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook.

With the sentencing of the three convicted Drukman conspirators to a year in jail yesterday the seven-month inquiry reached a point where important political developments are expected to result within a short period.

A further revision of the Bankers' Agreement to reduce the interest rate on $28,150,000 of revenue notes now outstanding from 3 to 2 per cent has been negotiated by Controller Frank J. Taylor, it was announced yesterday.

ALBANY, June 30. -- Mrs. Herbert H. Lehman put behind her today whatever personal disappointment the Governor's decision to run again might have held for her and said that she realized in Philadelphia that his change of mind was inevitable.
PARIS, June 30. -- Disturbances, in some cases of an anti-Semitic character, are reported from the Algerian Provinces of Oran, Alger and Constantine.

HARTSDALE, N.Y., June 30. -- Miss Sylvia Worth, seeded No. 1 in the seventh annual district tournament for girls at the county tennis club, continued her outstanding playing today by turning back Miss Ann Cohen of Bedford, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 1, in a third-round match.

GENEVA, June 30. -- At the opening session of the League of Nations Assembly today Emperor Haile Selassie made his crucial plea for Ethiopia and his appeal to the conscience of the League and the world, and Italian Fascisti here gave it point.

The Long Island Railroad announced yesterday that it would continue to charge a three-cents-a-mile rate to single-trip riders in Nassau and Suffolk, despite the Public Service Commission's ruling that the two-cent fare must become effective today.

PARIS, June 30. -- Tempers ran high and the noise at times was deafening when the Chamber of Deputies "discussed" today the action of the leftist government in dissolving the patriotic leagues. The discussion was a series of accusations and countercharges interrupted by booing and desk banging while Edouard Herriot, recovered in health and back in the presidential chair, tried to keep order.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., June 30. -- Mrs. Arthur B. Claflin gave a luncheon, followed by bridge, today at her home in the Shinnecock Hills for Mrs. T. Charles Farrelly, who is passing the week with her and Mr. Claflin.

CINCINNATI, June 30. -- A deal whereby the blast furnaces and coke ovens of the Hamilton Coke and Iron Company near Hamilton will be acquired by the American Rolling Mill Company of Middletown, Ohio, was made known today. It involves about $4,000,000.
A program issued at the Mayor's office cleared up late yesterday afternoon the mystery about who will speak at the ceremonies opening the Triborough Bridge on July 11.

PHILADELPHIA, June 30 (AP). -- Oarsmen from the Atlantic to the Pacific are entered in the combined Olympic tryouts, national and peoples' day regattas on the Schuylkill River Friday and Saturday. Eighty-three crews entered for the Schuylkill races.

SYRACUSE, June 30 (AP). -- Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State Chairman, declared today that Governor Lehman's announcement of his candidacy for a third term "has not left him in a favorable light before the people of the State."

Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Directors of the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway declared yesterday a dividend of $2 on the common stock. This is the first payment on the stock since $2 was disbursed on Sept. 3, 1935. The company said that the dividend would be paid out of accumulated surplus.

A "declaration of highway dependence" which motorists are urged to follow for the Fourth of July holidays was issued yesterday by J.R. Crossley, vice president of the Automobile Club of New York. The declaration says in part:
WASHINGTON, June 30. -- The few Senators remaining in Washington expressed unanimous approval of Governor Lehman's candidacy for re-election.

Only three maternity deaths were reported in the city last week, the Department of Health announced yesterday. This figure equaled the low record established last year in the week ending Sept. 14. A year ago six deaths were reported.
CHICAGO, June 30. -- William E. Dodd, Ambassador to Germany, disclosed an unpublished conversation with Woodrow Wilson in a lecture today at the University ot Chicago.

WASHINGTON, June 30. -- Charges that the $10,338,938,839 appropriated during the recent session of Congress represents a single year's expenditures were disputed today by Chairman Buchanan of the House Appropriations Committee. The sum set aside for the fiscal year 1937, he said, should properly be $6,817,156,740, exclusive of relief money.

BALTIMORE, Md., June 30. -- Reorganization of the two Stinnes companies, Maryland corporations, the assets of which are largely properties in Germany, was agreed to today by Judge William O. Coleman of the United States court, who announced that he would continue, at least temporarily, the present officers in the management.

ST. LOUIS, June 30 (AP). -- The triumphant return of the almost forgotten art of hand weaving has brought smiles and dollars to women on relief here, where revival of pioneer household arts and crafts is a project.

The Divineform Brassiere Company, Inc., of 28 West Twenty-third Street was the victim of a payroll hold-up yesterday because, according to police, it had failed to take advantage of protection offered by the West Twentieth Street station.

Upset victories by Robert Braithwaite, unseeded captain of the Woodbridge (N.J.) High team, over Robert Proctor, rated second, and Clinton Hendrickson, ranked fifth, and the elimination of the other favored players, Lyman Crossman and Alter Milberg, in the junior division of the Greater New York tennis championships, marked the second day's play at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club yesterday.

The city of Utica, N.Y., will consider bids on July 8 for a new issue of $1,000,000 of tax-anticipation certificates of indebtedness. The certificates will be dated July 10, 1936, and will become payable on Dec. 10, 1936.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 30. -- With an unexpected show of team work, Roslyn moved through to the final of the Meadow Brook Club cups with a victory over the East Williston team, 11 to 4, in the last of the semi-finals, played today on Cochran Field.

NEWARK, N.J., June 30. -- Social security is no concern of the Federal Government, and to apply a uniform law throughout the country on such a matter would destroy government as it now exists, Merritt Lane, counsel to the receivers of the Newark Milk Company, declared today before Federal Judge Guy L. Fake.

The Chase National Bank, fiscal agent, has invited tenders of Government of the Argentina Nation external 5 1/2 per cent bonds due on Aug. 1, 1962, at a price below par, in an amount sufficient to exhaust $184,692, which will be available in the sinking fund by Aug. 1.
Professor Franz Boas, one of the world's most eminent anthropologists, retired yesterday from active service at Columbia University after forty-one years of service as lecturer and professor.

CHAPPAQUA, N.Y., June 30. -- The winners of the Westchester Golf Association's 1934 father-and-son championship, Thomas M. Barnard and his son, Clinton, today regained the diadem in the eleventh annual fixture over their home links, the Whippoorwill Golf Club.

HEIDELBERG, Germany, June 30. -- There is no place in German universities for truth for truth's sake, Dr. Ernest Kreick, Professor of Philosophy at Heidelberg, declared today "in the name of German science" during an address on objectivity in sciences delivered before the rectors and leading professors of all German universities and representatives of thirty-one foreign institutions of higher learning.

PARIS, June 20 (AP). -- The Iranian Prince Farid of Sadri-Azam advertised today in the Paris edition of The New York Herald Tribune that he would "inform the civilized world" of his divorce from the former Mrs. Sebastian S. Kresge by writing a book.

What is reflected by the betting odds on elections now quoted in Wall Street? Moves on the political surface, undoubtedly, and not the deeper research which will come in October. An example of the superficial controls of these "odds" was given yesterday when they rose in favor of the President's re-election on the news from Albany that Governor Lehman will run again this Autumn, after all.

CHICAGO, June 30. -- Representative Marion A. Zioncheck passed through this city tonight en route from Washington, D.C., to his home in Seattle, Wash., and was the center of a brief whirl of excitement.

The United States Government lost yesterday an application to the Appellate Division for title to $1,149,600 that has accumulated the last eleven years while the State Supreme Court has been liquidating the First Russian Insurance Company.

PORTLAND, Ore., June 30. -- In a whirl of red tape and parliamentary rulings which left many of the nation's educators as dazed as a first class in fractions, the long-heralded fight over "democratizing" the control of the National Education Association ended today in a victory for the status quo.

Those little white moths that emerge in the city these days when twilight comes and seem to get by screens and closed doors in homes and offices were identified yesterday by Dr. C.C. Hamilton of the State Agricultural Experiment Station in New Brunswick, N.J., as snow-white linden moths.

Bonds called for redemption in June before maturity made the smallest total in three months but a larger amount than a year ago. The total was $304,088,000, compared with $371,061,000 for May and $206,296,000 in June, 1935.

CAMDEN, N.J., June 30. -- Although strikers and management at the Victor division plant of the RCA Manufacturing Company here have tentatively agreed to let the National Labor Relations Board conduct an employe election to determine the majority representation and name an agent for collective bargaining, no agreement had been reached tonight on the terms of the poll.

The balance between peace and war in China remains precarious. In the south, large forces of Nanking troops exchange raids with forces from the Provinces of Kwangtung and Kwangsi. In the northeast and Inner Mongolia, Japanese military preparations and demonstrations grow more ominous.

One hundred and ninety-three athletes and sport managers at Columbia will receive insignia for their participation in intercollegiate competition this past Spring, it was announced yesterday by Graduate Manager Reynolds Benson. The insignia recipients were members of the varsity and freshman squads in rowing, track, baseball and tennis, with two additional awards being made to wrestlers.

With curtailed home relief payments to veterans who received bonuses scheduled to go into effect today, it became known that the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration had liberalized its ban on State payments to veterans to such an extent that many would not suffer at all and others would be affected only slightly.

WASHINGTON, June 30. -- The farmer in New York State "has suffered greatly through the operation of the reciprocal tariff and the regulations of the Treasury Department," Representative Taber, Republican, of New York, asserted in a statement today.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 30 (AP). -- Jack Crawford and Adrian Quist, who were defeated in the singles quarter-finals yesterday, lost the All-England doubles title today when they bowed to the French players.
WASHINGTON, June 30. -- William Phillips, Under-Secretary of State, has been chosen as Ambassador to Italy, to succeed Breckinridge Long, who has resigned because of ill health.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange last month was slightly more active than in the preceding month. Sales for June, as compiled by THE NEW YORK TIMES, totaled 21,428,377 shares, compared with 20,614,690 in May and 22,339,512 in the corresponding month of 1935.

WASHINGTON, June 30. -- President Roosevelt cleared his desk today of all business left behind by Congress when he passed upon about forty bills, approving among them two highly important measures, the Ship Subsidy Bill and the Government Contracts Bill.

Dr. C. T. Wang, former Premier and Minister of Foreign Affairs of China, told members of the China Society of America yesterday that the martial spirit was spreading rapidly in his country and that the Chinese people at last were beginning to realize that to survive they must employ the same means others were using "who are trying to destroy us."
WASHINGTON, June 30. -- The Interstate Commerce Commission approved today without any amendments the Wheeling Lake Erie's plan for reconstruction of its capital-stock structure.

Demand for credit showed no appreciable increase last month and interest rates for both call and time loans remained at quotations unchanged since May 11, when a general increase of one-quarter of 1 per cent was made for all accommodations.

The Consolidated Gas, Electric Light and Power Company of Baltimore reported yesterday that its net income for the twelve months ended on May 31, after all deductions, amounted to $6,439,576, equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $4.55 each on 1,167,397 no-par common shares, compared with $6,014,476, or $4.16 a common share, in the preceding twelve months.

LONDON, June 30. -- Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, warned civil servants from his place in the House of Commons today that any who sought to indulge in a "stay-in" strike -- as had been threatened by an organization claiming more than 3,000 members in three defense departments -- would be liable to instant dismissal.

While waiting for a decision from Madison Square Garden on his proposal for an arrangement for promoting a championship fight between James J. Braddock and Max Schmeling, Mike Jacobs of the Twentieth Century Sporting Club announced yesterday that in the event the negotiations failed he was prepared to stage a return battle between Joe Louis and Schmeling in one of the local ball parks in September.

If a body meets a body driving home to Rye, N.Y., from Greenwich, Conn., with liquor purchased in the latter place, then the driving body has a good chance to be arrested if the body of the first part happens to be a policeman.

TRENTON, June 30. -- Republican State Chairman Henry W. Jeffers Sr. of Plainsboro announced tonight he would be chairman of a special campaign committee he was authorized to appoint by party leaders for the Landon-Knox ticket in New Jersey.

With moisture at more than thirty stations in Texas and private reports that rain was falling at various points west of the Mississippi River, selling of a line estimated to be between 35,000 and 40,000 bales broke prices on the Cotton Exchange $1 a bale yesterday.

PORTSMOUTH, England, June 30. -- King Edward VIII, after riding today in one of the navy's new "mosquito" torpedo boats as it sliced through the chopping waters of Portsmouth harbor, completed his first inspection as monarch by giving the order, "Splice the main-brace," which was wigwagged to all ships.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotatlons for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

The new Randalls Island Stadium, scene of the final Olympic track and field tryouts on July 11 and 12, will be opened for practice purposes on Monday, Frederick W. Rubien, secretary of the American Olympic Committee, announced yesterday.
THE TIMES special dispatch from Washington contained the following paragraph on the decision of Justice Bailey in regard to the Railroad Retirement Act and the accompanying Tax Act of 1935:

Apropos the editorial "Noisy Again" conditions are quite as bad now as they were before the ordinance against unnecessary noise was adopted, and we notice it more because of the lull we enjoyed when the agitation against noise was first inaugurated.

WASHINGTON, June 30. -The I Associated Gas and Electric Corn-I party, one of the great public utility I holding companies which is contestI ing the constitutLonality of the PubConthued on rage Fory lie Utility Act of 1935, has been permitted by the Securities and Exchange commission to withdraw sLxty-six applications for exemption from provisions of the act made on behalf of subsidiary companies.

During the twenty-four hours ending at midnight tonight seven ships will have sailed for Europe carrying 9,031 passengers, the largest number of the Summer eastbound season. The list was headed by the North German Lloyd liner Bremen, leaving for Channel ports at 12:30 A.M. with 2,200 passengers.

BOSTON, June 30. -- The Newspaper Advertising Executives Association, meeting today at the Hotel Statler, in conjunction with the Advertising Federation Convention, endorsed the "united front" movement for a five-year $1,500,000 campaign to promote newspapers and at the same time sharply criticized two executives of newspaper representatives' association for approving the recent adjustment of rate differentials by The St. Louis Post Dispatch.

A program calling for distribution by the United Artists Corporation of thirty-four feature-length motion pictures and eighteen short subjects during the 1936-37 season was announced here yesterday to coincide with a similar announcement by George J. Schaefer, vice president in charge of sales, at the corporation's sales convention at the Ambassador Hotel in Hollywood.

PHILADELPHIA, June 30. -- The Quartermaster Depot today made a number of contract awards for textile and garment supplies for the Army and Civilian Conservation Corps, bids on which were opened recently. The successful bidders follow:

The tenth exhibition at the Temporary Galleries of the Municipal Art Committee, 62 West Fifty-third Street, opened with a preview yesterday afternoon and will continue until July 19. It is made up, as usual, of work by four groups of painters and occupies all the exhibition rooms on four floors.

ESTES PARK, Col., June 30. -- Governor Landon continued today to receive favorable reports on sentiment in the West from callers dropping in to pay their respects. A Congressman from Oregon, and several Colorado newspaper editors headed the list of visitors.

A background of facts on which he and judges of higher courts are expected to rule on the constitutionality of the holding company provisions of the Public Utility Act of 1935 was received yesterday by Federal Judge Julian W. Mack when counsel for the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Electric Bond and Share System, and other interested parties flied stipulations with the court.

Reflecting the continued improvement in business, the total of dividends declared last month was the best for a June since 1931. The total was $294,880,158 for 1,345 corporations, compared with $412,340,784 for 866 companies in the prece ding month and with $255,346,504 for 1,250 companies in June, 1935.

WASHINGTON, June 30. -- The sum of $36,697,500 was made available today to New York City for continuing some present WPA projects and starting others already approved, as $350,000,000 of the new $1,425,000,000 work relief fund was released for immediate use by the signing of a Treasury warrant.

Major Gen. James G. Harbord, chairman of the board of the Radio Corporation of America, was honored yesterday at a luncheon at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria by the Catholic Writers Guild of America in recognition of his book, "The American Army in France," which was published recently by Little, Brown Co.

Abraham Wilson, who was attorney for William J. Flynn, former Bronx Commissioner of Public Works during the Seabury investigation in 1932, was suspended from practice for three months yesterday by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court.

Four of the thirty persons questioned by the police in connection with the murder of George K. O'Connor, Illinois electrical engineer, whose body was found before dawn Monday in the hallway at 469 West Forty-second Street, are to be held as material witnesses, authorities announced last night.

Harry de Berkeley Parsons, consulting engineer and yachting authority who died Jan. 26, 1935, left an estate appraised yesterday at $1,387,531 gross and $1,178,476 net which included securities worth $1,002,356 and real estate valued at $247,180.

Joseph Faia, 44 years old, described by the police as a "troublesome character," who was widely known in the Cherry Hill section of the East Side, was found shot dead at 3:30 o'clock yesterday morning in front of a tenement house at 60 Henry Street.

SOUTHAMPTON, England, June 30. -- Walter Wanger, film producer, arrived in Southampton tonight to sail on the Queen Mary after a brief visit in Europe with the single object of discussing with Premier Mussolini the production of films in Italy.
That racing is thriving here from the standpoints of attendance and revenue is reflected in figures released yesterday by the New York State Racing Commission, headed by Herbert Bayard Swope.

HAVANA, June 30. -- Countess Covadonga, the former Edelmira Sampedro, will begin suit in the Cuban courts in a few days to obtain a divorce from her husband, the former Prince of the Asturias, eldest son of former King Alfonso of Spain, she said this afternoon. The grounds will be incompatibility.
ALBANY, June 30. -- A one-cent reduction in the gasoline tax from 4 to 3 cents becomes effective tonight at midnight, under the bill passed at the last Legislature and signed by Governor Lehman.

Any American who ever has seen Jack Lovelock run a mile is quite ready to admit that the medical student from New Zealand stands out at the head of the parade. He has beaten Glenn Cunningham, Gene Venzke and Bill Bonthron and, on this side of the Atlantic at least, looks like the epitome of invincibility.

To that laughing Iowa philosopher, The Logan Observer, we are indebted for the expressive word "going-to-doer." It is applied, perhaps unjustly, to a local Representative in Congress. It cannot be so restricted. It applies to much the larger part of the population. In Hamlet the type is fixed on the highest intellectual plane.

Harry de Berkeley Parsons, consulting engineer and yachting authority who died Jan. 26, 1935, left an estate appraised yesterday at $1,387,531 gross and $1,178,476 net which included securities worth $1,002,356 and real estate valued at $247,180.

Joseph Faia, 44 years old, described by the police as a "troublesome character," who was widely known in the Cherry Hill section of the East Side, was found shot dead at 3:30 o'clock yesterday morning in front of a tenement house at 60 Henry Street.

SOUTHAMPTON, England, June 30. -- Walter Wanger, film producer, arrived in Southampton tonight to sail on the Queen Mary after a brief visit in Europe with the single object of discussing with Premier Mussolini the production of films in Italy.

Any American who ever has seen Jack Lovelock run a mile is quite ready to admit that the medical student from New Zealand stands out at the head of the parade. He has beaten Glenn Cunningham, Gene Venzke and Bill Bonthron and, on this side of the Atlantic at least, looks like the epitome of invincibility.

To that laughing Iowa philosopher, The Logan Observer, we are indebted for the expressive word "going-to-doer." It is applied, perhaps unjustly, to a local Representative in Congress. It cannot be so restricted. It applies to much the larger part of the population. In Hamlet the type is fixed on the highest intellectual plane.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 1. -- Risking everything on assault and losing little that really mattered after the first hurricane set, Fred Perry of England swept Donald Budge, the last American in the competition, out of the All-England tennis singles championship today in a four-set match that contained some of the best close-range rallies seen on the famous center court in years.
Estate purchases and a business property deal featured the Westchester activity reported yesterday.

The June 30 bank statements normally share honors with those of the year's end for the large size of the figures reported. At this season the expansion of deposits and total assets is particularly noticeable, for comparisons are being made with reporting dates in March which caught the banks at a time when their deposits had been drawn down.
CHICAGO, July 1. -- Through the WPA the Federal Government rushed aid today to drought-stricken sections of five Northwestern States and watched closely weather conditions in four more.
With hundreds of millions of bonds being floated, some at rates as low as 3 per cent, it might be well for bondholders to look into the trust indentures under which the bonds are issued.

With the official announcement by Greece that she will spend the $13,500,000 blocked to her credit in the Reichsbank to buy one huge order of German arms, the technique of forced sale of war equipment to small countries evolved by Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, German Economics Minister, counts its first major success.

OCEAN CITY, N.J., July 1. -- Two Pennsylvania boys emerged the victors today in the Eastern and Northern division championships of the national marbles tournament being played at the Ringer Stadium here.

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- An application for the merger of the Union Gas and Electric Company with the Cincinnati Gas and Electric Company, both subsidiaries of the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation, owner of all the common shares of each, has been approved by the Federal Power Commission.

The program presented by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Jose Iturbi, at the Lewisohn Stadium last night contained as a novelty the set of three pieces entitled "Impresiones Portenas" by the Argentine composer, Jose Andre.

Nine athletes were selected yesterday by the Committee on Fair Play in Sports to represent the United States in the People's Olympics, which are to be staged in Barcelona, Spain, July 19-26. George Gordon Battle and Dr. Henry Smith Leiper are co-chairmen of the committee.
SAN ANTONIO, July 1. -- Crushing houses and wrecking a freight train, a South Texas flood caused a mounting death toll listed at twenty-one tonight. At least fourteen persons were missing.

Mrs. Maryon Cooper Hewitt, who has been in the psychopathic ward of the Jersey City Medical Center since Feb. 20 under charges of attempted suicide and being a fugitive from justice in California, was finally arraigned yesterday in First Criminal Court, Jersey City.

CHICAGO, July 1. -- Senator William E. Borah, stopping here between trains today on his way to Idaho, declared that in the farming regions the reciprocal trade agreements will be an important issue in the election. The Republican farm plank adopted at the Cleveland convention, he asserted, "states the true doctrine."
TORONTO, July 1. -- Canadians celebrated Dominion Day today, marking the sixty-ninth anniversary of confederation.
HONGKONG, July 1. -- Reports leaking out of Canton describe a virtual military dictatorship there approaching a reign of terror.

The United States Polo Association yesterday announced receipt of a cabled report from Robert E. Strawbridge Jr., chairman of the association, who is still in London, of the formal challenge on the part of the Argentines for the cup won in Buenos Aires by America in 1932 and of his acceptance for this country.

NEWARK, N.J., July 1. -- The tail-end Syracuse team trounced Newark by 8 to 4 in the opening game of their series today. As a result of the setback and two Rochester victories at the expense of Montreal, the Bears' margin at the top was cut to a single point.

Starting an ambitious program of boxing tournaments for members of boys' clubs under its jurisdiction, the Police Athletic League conducted a fistic show before about 15,000 spectators, two-thirds of whom were boys and girls, last night at Dyckman Oval, Tenth Avenue and Academy Street. Other tournaments will be held in the various boroughs during the Summer.

TOKYO, July 1 -- The Supreme Court Martial rejected the appeal of Lieut Col. Saburo Aizawa, condemned to die for the assassination of Lieut. Gen. Tetsuzan Nagata, Director General of Military Affairs, last Summer, and confirmed the death penalty.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., July 1. -- Mrs. Pauline V. Rogers, widow of Colonel Henry H. Rogers, recalled in testimony here today that she once expressed an opinion to Mrs. Millicent Rogers Balcom, the oil man's daughter, that he was "incompetent" and that his will, now the center of litigation, was not "really" his.

The Foreign Bondholders Protective Council, Inc., has requested all holders of the bonds of the Republic of Poland, the Land Mortgage Bank of Warsaw, the Province of Silesia and the city of Warsaw to record their names and addresses with it in order that it may be able to keep in touch with as many holders of Polish bonds as possible and advise them of developments.

BOSTON, July 1. -- Raymond Moley, former adviser to President Roosevelt, declared today that a rising tide of "moderation" in public opinion toward business was apparent and that the word "conservative'' is returning to "the realm of respectability."

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- The Bureau of Air Commerce of the Commerce Department will take over the three airways traffic control stations now being operated at Newark, Chicago and Cleveland by the airlines in cooperation with the bureau and expand them into a national airways traffic control system, it was announced today.

Directors of the Transamerica Corporation, meeting yesterday in San Francisco, increased the regular annual dividend on capital stock by 10 cents a share to 40 cents by declaring a semi-annual payment of 20 cents a share. They also declared an additional special dividend of 5 cents a share for the half year ended on June 30.

Charles R. Gay, president of the New York Stock Exchange, sent yesterday to the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System in Washington a summary of the returns from the Exchange's questionnaire to member firms on the status of margin accounts showing conclusively, in the opinion of brokers, that the board's 55 per cent margin requirements are unduly restricting stock trading.

CHICAGO, July 1 (AP). -- The Tigers gave the White Sox one of the worst beatings of the season today when they hammered three pitchers for twenty-five hits to win, 21 to 6. The triumph put the Tigers in second place, one percentage point ahead of the Red Sox and Senators.

What may be described as a "first edition" of James Boswell's "Journal of a Tour of the Hebrides with Dr. Samuel Johnson" will be published next November by the Viking Press, 163 years after it was written. The original manuscript, recently discovered in Ireland, is proof that the book has been known for the past century and a half only in greatly abbreviated form.

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- A picture of rising national income, increasing government revenues, declining Federal expenditures and steadily improving business was painted tonight by Secretary Morgenthau in a nation-wide radio address.

Dark prophecies of unemployment in the trucking business if the proposed complete free pick-up and delivery of less-than-carload freight by Eastern railroads is put into effect were repeated yesterday by truckers who testified at the Interstate Commerce Commission hearing on the plan at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Although twenty-three o the leading oil companies in the United States distributed 80.2 per cent of their aggregate net income in the ten years, 1926 through 1935, a compilation by Carl H. Pforzheimer Co. shows that they distributed in cash dividends last year only 47.6 per cent of their earnings.

TRENTON, July 1. -- State Motor Vehicle Commissioner Arthur W. Magee said today he did not expect the first of the semi-annual inspections of automobiles would be made until the latter part of September or early part of October. Motorists will be notified two or three weeks in advance of the time they are to present their cars for inspection, he explained.

CHAPPAQUA, N.Y., July 1. -- A slender Georgetown sophomore, Charles Pettijohn Jr. of the Westchester Country Club, today captured the medal in the qualifying round of the sixteenth annual Westchester Golf Association junior championship and advanced to the semi-finals along with other favorites.

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- James M. Landis was re-elected chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission today for his second term, which will end on June 30, 1937. He was named for his first term on Sept. 23, 1935, immediately after the resignation of Former Chairman Joseph P. Kennedy.

GLENS FALLS, N. Y., July 1. -- The reorganization plan of the Imperial Paper and Color Corporation, unanimously adopted by stockholders on May 1, was perfected today at a reorganization meeting in the offices of the corporation in Queensbury.

GLEN COVE, L.I., July 1. -- George Phillip Black, who retired from the field of steel and railroad investment about three decades ago, was found fatally shot on the floor of the laundry of his fifteen-room house here at 7:30 A.M. today.

CHICAGO, July 1. -- Prices of hogs were barely steady at the start here today, but there was a lack of the aggressive buying which had been in evidence for several days, and later the best grades declined 10 to 15 cents a hundredweight, while packing sows were 10 to 25 cents lower.
Trying to make an orderly survey of events in which athletes have to skim over hurdles is an extremely foolhardy undertaking. One nicked barrier spells the difference between victory and defeat.

The compensation of more than a dozen executives receiving in 1935 salaries ranging from $50,000 to $100,000 was disclosed yesterday in annual reports of corporations to the Securities and Exchange Commission. Among the largest were $100,360 for Percy S. Straus, president of R.H. Macy Co.; $95,696 for A.R. Graustein, former president of the International Paper Company, and $74,682 for P.A.S. Franklin, president of the International Mercantile Marine Company.

GLEN COVE, L.I., July 1. -- J.P. Morgan, 68-year-old financier, stricken with a heart attack about two weeks ago while visiting relatives in West Manchester, Mass., was resting comfortably tonight at Matinecock Point, his home on East Island.

BERLIN, July 1. -- The Boerse was slightly more active today, but still remained in the state of Summer doldrums. Heavy industrial stocks showed scattered strength, Vereinigtestahl gaining 1/2 point and Reinstahl 1 1/2. The machinery group was mixed, but Miag rose 2 points.

There was little change in the fundamental characteristics of the bond market in yesterday's trading. Sales on the New York Stock Exchange amounted to $8,244,200, compared to $7,699,900 on Tuesday. With the exception of a further brisk rally in Polish Government loans and a fairly broad demand for public utility issues in the corporate section, trading largely was routine, with prices moving within narrow limits.
PARIS, July 1 (AP). -- The Army Committee of the Senate decided tonight upon a detailed study by French military experts of potential defense positions along the Swiss border.

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau gave a report to the country on government financing during the 1935-36 fiscal year, in the following address, which was broadcast over a nation-wide radio network:
The Zeppelin Hindenburg reached New York at 2:25 o'clock this morning after her speediest trip to date across the Atlantic, during which she followed a new route that took her over Canada.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 1. -A battered old plug, its white wooden body bearing the scars of countless battles with mettlesome black bass, plunked into the lily pads hugging the eastern bank of Gypsy Lake in Putnam County.

The finals of the Park Department's second annual one-act play contest for children were held yesterday afternoon in Central Park. The children performed on a portable stage lent by the Federal Theatre Project, which was set up before the bandstand on the Mall.

Mayor La Guardia formally opened the new Felony Court in Brooklyn yesterday morning by telling an audience of 400 persons of the city's fight against organized crime, of how well Commissioner Valentine was running the Police Department and of the city's challenge to politicians and racketeers.

Steel-ingot production has increased fractionally this week to 71 1/2 per cent of capacity, according to the weekly summary issued yesterday by The Iron Age. The increase was ascribed to the fact that Independence Day will mean a cessation of production, and the producers have been trying to make up for this loss by heavier schedules earlier in the week.

For a short time yesterday the Dodgers emerged from the National League cellar, caught a glimpse of a bit of sunlight and then fell to the bottom again as the Phillies took the second game of a twin bill at Ebbets Field to gain an even split for their long afternoon's work.

Twenty-nine Norwegian Boy Scouts, wearing the colorful blue and gray uniforms of their troops, arrived yesterday on the Norwegian- American liner Bergensfjord for a 3,793-mile tour of the United States and Canada. The tour, arranged by the International League of Norsemen, will be made by bus.

" Mr. Shaddy," the new J.C. Nugent comedy, which has been tried out this Summer at Skowhegan and elsewhere, will show up next week at the Theatre of the Four Seasons in Roslyn, L.I. . . . Next Tuesday evening has been set for the seasonal opening of the Casino Theatre at Newport, R.I., the first attraction being "When Ladies Meet," with Doris Dalton.

Soaring wheat prices and a strong market for cotton failed yesterday to impart much general strength to securities. Several individual issues in various groups in the industrial stock list made sizable gains on the day, while the showing made by many other issues was disappointing.

The majority report of the admiralty committee of the Bar Association of the City of New York, which was published yesterday, was criticized last night by James W. Ryan, a member of the committee, as an effort to place responsibility for the condition of merchant ships upon the government rather than upon the owners.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, July 1. -- The brilliant opening of the famous Royal Henley Regatta today, with a record program of forty-one races, was a day of triumph for all three American crews competing for the Thames Challenge Cup, which again is likely to go to the United States.

The Canadian International Paper Company reported yesterday for 1935 a net loss of $3,759,427 after all charges, including interest on junior bonds, all owned by the International Paper Company; depreciation and depletion. The loss in 1934 was $3,984,823.
Apartment buildings in such widely scattered sections as Yorkville and the Dyckman Street area changed hands in deals reported by brokers yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, July 1 (AP). -- The Senators easily disposed of the Athletics in both ends of a double-header today, remaining in the thick of the fight for the runner-up position to the Yankees. The scores were 13 to 5 and 14 to 4.

Andrew W. Mellon, former United States Secretary of the Treasury; Viscount and Viscountess Knollys, Julia, Lady Rickett and Sir Charles and Lady Mander will be among the prominent persons sailing tonight for Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria. Others departing on the ship will include:
LONDON, July 1. -- Oswald Pirow, the South African Defense Minister, left for home today as if entirely satisfied with his discussions with British Ministers and defense experts.

Elated at the decision of Governor Lehman to head the State ticket in the New York elections, Democratic chieftains pushed forward yesterday with their plan to name Robert H. Jackson for Lieutenant Governor in the hope of consolidating support for State and national slates in the western part of the State.

Over the radio last night Secretary MORGENTHAU announced that the national debt stood at a little less than $34,000,000,000 when the Treasury closed its books at the end of the fiscal year. That is an increase of almost precisely $13,000,000,000 since the Roosevelt Administration entered office.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 1. -- Mrs. James B. Duke gave her first large dinner party of the season at Rough Point this evening. More than twenty guests were present.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., July 1. -George F. Lewis Jr. of the Essex Fells Country Club today won the qualifying medal in the eighteenth annual New Jersey State junior golf championship when he scored a 73 over the Rock Spring club course.
Changes in partners in several member firms, effective yesterday, were announced by the New York Stock Exchange.

By way of indicating that the Yankees, although thundering miles ahead of the rest of the field, have really uncorked only a part of what the sagacious Marse Joe McCarthy seems to have bottled up for the second half of the season's grind, burly Charles Ruffing stepped out on the mound at the Stadium yesterday and to the wonderment of a gathering of 10,240 spectators, pitched a shut-out.

The cost of the "Frankenthaler plan" for the reorganization and administration of defaulted certificated guaranteed mortgages was made known yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler when he handed down a decision on the claims by attorneys and others for services in aiding the court to devise the plan for the reorganization of the largest series, that of F-1 of the New York Title and Mortgage Company.

CHICAGO, July 1 (AP). -- Helen Hayes, stage and screen actress, testified today in defense of a $100,000 alienation of affections suit that she could not remember details of screen magazine interviews that purported to reveal her romance with her playwright husband, Charles MacArthur.

" WATERLOO" (Coward-McCann, $2.50), the new novel by Manuel Komroff, author of "Coronet," appears to be the work of a contented and happy author. The novel reads as though it had been dictated by a highly intelligent man who was sure that his readers would find pleasure and interest in whatever he had to say about Napoleon, if he also said enough about love, and about children in war.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 1. -- Mrs. Allan C. Bakewell gave a dinner tonight for Mrs. L. Pomeroy Deans of Bedford Hills, N.Y., who is visiting her. Among the other guests were Mrs. Newell W. Tilton, Mrs. John Farr Jr., Miss Justine Van Rensselaer Townsend and Mrs. Franklin S. Richardson.

Retail package deliveries in the metropolitan and suburban areas increased 20 per cent for the week ended June 27, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. The gain is one of the largest in recent months and compares with an increase of 16 per cent for the preceding week.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- President Roosevelt closed the record of the Seventy-fourth Congress today by vetoing the last four bills remaining for his consideration. His record for the last session of Congress was announced by the White House as 881 bills approved and eighty-five vetoed.

CHICAGO, July 1. -- The Board of Education of the Methodist Episcopal Church, meeting here, has ousted the Rev. Dr. Blaine E. Kirkpatrick and the Rev. Owen M. Geer as secretaries in charge of the church's youth program.

TIENTSIN, July 1. -- More than 600 soldiers of the Third Battalion of General Sung Cheh-yuan's 217th Regiment, which was involved in the detention of a Japanese officer last week, have been hurriedly withdrawn from their Fengtai barracks and replaced by other forces of the Twenty-ninth Army.

PORTLAND, Ore., July 1. -- In an almost unprecedented move here today, school men and women of the United States, at the annual convention of the National Education Association, acting on the advice of their own special investigating committees, voted censure of four local school boards in as many States for "unwarranted" dismissals of individual teachers.

One of the largest contracts for the purchase of an Upper Harlem block of real estate in recent years was announced yesterday when operators acquired eleven apartment houses facing St. Nicholas Park. Having a total assessed valuation of $930,000, the buildings occupy the entire square block bounded by St. Nicholas Terrace, Convent Avenue, 128th and 129th Streets, with the exception of two structures not involved in the purchase.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 1. -- Mr. and Mrs. R.M. Sherriff, Mrs. W.S. Fitzpatrick, Mrs. Thomas M. Gayley, Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Detwiller, Mr. and Mrs. A.E. Spalthoff, Mr. and Mrs. Charles N. Rambeau, Walter Stunzi, Edward Reeve and Harry Horner are among those making reservations for the holiday week-end at the Hedges.

ROME, July 1. -- All Italy is up in arms tonight in defense of the Fascist newspaper men whose violent protest against the speech of Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia disturbed yesterday's meeting of the League of Nations Assembly.

MADRID, July 1. -- Labor Minister Juan Lluhi announced today that the clothing-trade strike had been settled and that he expected to make good his promise to end the walkout of woodworkers and building-trade workers by tomorrow night.

The Pennsylvania Station and Grand Central terminal were crowded yesterday as thousands of vacationists left the city for the mountain and lake regions of upper New York State and New England and other sections of the countryside.

At a session of hot arguments, in the course of which he announced that he would not be "bulldozed," Federal Judge Hulbert acted yesterday on a special master's report that the management of the Warner-Quinlan Company, distributor of petroleum products, should not continue its operation, and appointed two trustees.

CAMDEN, N.J., July 1. -- Renewing hostilities late this afternoon after a few days of comparative peace, more than 5,000 men and women, representing strikers and workers at the Victor division plant of the R.C.A. Manufacturing Company here, engaged in a battle which spread across the Delaware River to Philadelphia.

Herbert Hoover may, in the heat of the campaign, grow enthusiastic over the qualifications of Governor Landon to be President. His immediate attitude is one of hope rather than confidence. Alfred E. Smith does not consider Franklin D. Roosevelt a "genuine Democrat."

The promotion of three sergeants to the rank of lieutenant, the promotion of twelve patrolmen to the rank of sergeant arid the transfer of Inspector Anthony L. Howe, head of the motor cycle division, from police headquarters in Manhattan to the Fourth Traffic District in Long Island City were announced yesterday by Police Commissioner Valentine.

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- The Navy Department favors installation of 16-inch guns on any new capital ships that may be constructed, it was indicated today by Admiral William H. Standley, Chief of Operations.

Four $1,000 prizes have been awarded in the Limited Editions Club book illustration competition. The winners are John Austen of London for his wood engravings to illustrate Aristophanes' "The Frogs"; Richard Floethe of New York for his linoleum blocks in color to illustrate "Pinocchio"; Fritz Kredel of Offenbach-am-Main, Germany, for his line and wash drawings to illustrate "The Autobiography of Benvenuto Cellini"; Mariette Lydis of Paris for her lithographs to illustrate "The Beggars' Opera."

GENEVA, July 1. -- Throughout today the League of Nations Assembly listened to speeches in varying keys and voicing different conclusions. Thousands of words were added to the record without appreciable advance toward the decision that sooner or later must be reached as to the League's future. On this point voices are still dissonant.

LONDON, July 1. -- The ancient University of Oxford paid tribute today to its lusty young neighbor, the University of London, which is celebrating its centenary this week in the presence of scholars from all parts of the world.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., July 1. -- About seventy-five Reserve officers from New York City, headed by Colonel Julius Ochs Adler, commanding the 306th Infantry, Seventy-seventh Division (Reserves), arrived here today for fourteen days of active duty with the army.

CHICAGO, July 1. -- Reports of drought and damage from the southern sections of the three Canadian Prairie Provinces sent prices of grain soaring today. Wheat at the extreme showed 4 5/8 cents a bushel above yesterday's finish in Minneapolis, while all deliveries of corn and oats on the Board of Trade here sold at the highest prices of the season.

LONDON, July 1. -- Permanent officials of the Foreign Office were dragged today into the controversy that continues to rage over War Secretary Alfred Duff Cooper's unusually friendly speech to a French audience in Paris last week.

Approval of an interest cut from 3 per cent to 2 per cent on $28,150,000 of city revenue notes covered by the city's agreement with its bankers was voted yesterday by the Board of Estimate in a special meeting at City Hall.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., July 1. -- W.L. Balthis of Gastonia and associates have bought and will begin to operate on next Monday the Number 1 and 2 plants of the United Spinners and those of the Peerless Corporation and Insulating Yarns, Inc., at Lowell, N.J.

NUEVO LAREDO, Mexico, July 1. -- Vice President Garner and General Eduardo Hay, Mexican Minister of Foreign Affairs, met and exchanged formal greetings at the center of the international bridge today, thus signalizing the opening to traffic of the great $17,000,000 highway linking the Texas border with Mexico, D.F.

Federal Judge Murray Hulbert dismissed a Jury yesterday after it had failed to agree on a verdict in a suit for $200,000 brought by Harris Vose, a stock brokerage house, against the Indemnity Insurance Company of North America and the United States Fidelity and Guaranty Company.

While most of the players were having trouble on the fast greens and in the sand traps, Mrs. Sylva Annenberg toured the Pomonok Country Club course in Flushing yesterday in 83 strokes for low gross in the Women's Long Island Golf Association's one-day handicap tournament.

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- The Supreme Court received today its first case affecting the constitutionality of the Wagner Labor Relations Act with the filing of a brief by the Bradley Lumber Company of Arkansas asking a review of lower court decisions. The act was assailed as violating the due process provisions of the Constitution.

More than 254,000 employes out of a total of 275,000 in thirty major steel plants throughout the country have voted by secret ballot in favor of collective bargaining through existing employe representation plans, thus evidencing their opposition to any "outside" unions, according to a compilation made public yesterday from the office of the American Iron and Steel Institute.

The consolidated income statement of the Engineers Public Service Company and its subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on May 31, issued yesterday, showed a net income of $2,330,674 after deducting expenses, depreciation, taxes and other charges, including dividend requirements on the preferred stocks of subsidiaries.

Appointment of L.G. Kurtz, former general superintendent of the Buick Motor Company, as deputy commissioner in his department was announced yesterday by Sanitation Commissioner William F. Carey. Mr. Kurtz, one of the nation's leading automotive construction engineers, will be responsible for the rehabilitation of the 3,000 pieces of mechanical apparatus the department owns.
The recreation-mindedness of Americans has increased twofold and facilities for leisure-time pursuits have more than doubled during the last decade, according to the National Recreation Association.

HARTSDALE, N.Y., July 1. -- As the outstanding girl players of Westchester and near-by Connecticut approached the final today at the County Tennis Club in the seventh annual district tournament, Miss Sylvia Worth of Bronxville still loomed as the championship threat.
ESTES PARK, Col., July 1. -- Governor Alf M. Landon, fish creel over shoulder, twice crossed the Continental Divide today and took part in a friendly snowball battle.

Ten men arrested late Tuesday night by Secret Service agents on charges of counterfeiting United States and Canadian liquor stamps were held in bail by Garrett W. Cotter, United States Commissioner, yesterday, pending action by the grand jury.

Sir Charles Morgan-Webb, British economist, speaking at a luncheon given for him yesterday at the Bankers Club by the Economic Forum, said Great Britain never would return to the gold standard in any form, but that the pound ultimately would be stabilized on a wholesale price index.
Children under 16 unaccompanied by adults may now attend motion picture theatres, under the terms of a local law signed yesterday in City Hall by Mayor La Guardia.

The first of the July 1 index numbers of average commodity prices, published by Dun's Review, reckons an increase of 3 1/2 per cent during June. The Review states that this is the largest gain of any month since September, 1935. The July 1 index number is three-quarters of 1 per cent under the highest of 1936, reached on March 1; it is only a trifling fraction above the average of Jan. 1.

SHAMOKIN, Pa., July 1. -- In the presence of more than 5,000 spectators a rescue crew of experienced anthracite miners dug steadily tonight in an attempt to penetrate a forty-foot wall of rock and coal to reach Enoch Kulshinskie Jr., 35 years old, who was imprisoned this morning in his North Mountain "bootleg" coal mine by a fall of top rock.

Following the sale of 15,000 to 20,000 bales on the Cotton Exchange early yesterday, the market developed resistance, turned upward and ended with net gains of 17 to 20 points. It was estimated that a line of between 50,000 and 60,000 bales was distributed in the last hour on Tuesday and first hour yesterday but final quotations were higher than when the liquidation started.

The current debate at Geneva reflects the confusion in international relations. HAILE SELASSIE'S uncompromising and courageous indictment of Italy and of the nations responsible for the failure of sanctions, Captain EDEN'S apologetic reply, LEON BLUM'S warning to Germany and assurances to France's allies, the statement by the seven "neutral" smaller Powers -- these are clear indications of the deep cleavages of national interests and aims.

Only four of the eight seeded players reached the quarter-final round of the Eastern intercollegiate tennis championship at the Richmond County Country Club in Dongan Hills, S.I., yesterday and those four had plenty of difficulty in so doing.

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- Assertions that the American Iron and Steel Institute, by shouting "general strike," is seeking to provoke walkouts and attempting to turn public opinion against the industrial unions' drive for unionization of the steel industry were made today by Philip Murray, chairman of the Steel Workers Organizing Committee.
Johnson S. Johnston, who has been with Lapham, Fahy Co. six years, has been appointed treasurer of the Electric Steam Sterilizing Corporation.

Complaints received at the District Attorney's office that a group of small merchants in the midtown district were selling wearing apparel of inferior quality on misrepresentations they were "cancellations" of Fifth Avenue stores led to the arrest of one of the alleged offenders yesterday.

TONAWANDA, N.Y., July 1. -- While aerial bombs boomed a salute and rockets studded the skies with crystals of scarlet and green, Governor Lehman rode through gayly decorated streets tonight to open the Town of Tonawanda centennial celebration with an address in which he envisaged a greater Niagara frontier.
LONDON, July 1. -- The stock markets were cheerful today at the start of the new half year, but British Government issues declined on unfavorable revenue figures.

Engineering construction contracts in the United States during the first half of this year totaled $1,121,375,000, against $657,271,000 in the 1935 half-year, The Engineering News Record reported yesterday.
WIMBLEDON, England, July 1. -- The final of the men's singles on Friday will be a repetition of the 1935 championship round, which saw Fred Perry vanquish Baron von Cramm, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4.

Houses formed the bulk of new building projects filed for in Manhattan, the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens yesterday. Most of the latest operations call for dwellings and tenement houses, the owners getting their plans on record in anticipation of stricter requirements under the pending new construction code.

The country is working below its productive capacity, and people still have wants unsatisfied, and if the recovery is kept moving with all the elements in balance and without interference, it can go on indefinitely. This is the conclusion reached by the National City Bank in its July survey of business and finance, in which it summarizes the recent progress made in important fields.

NATURAL BRIDGE, Va., July 1 (AP). -- Death came swiftly to five of thirty-four persons aboard a huge bus which crashed into a bank and overturned early today a few yards from the 215-foot gorge spanned by the famous Natural Bridge. Seven others were injured seriously enough to require hospital treatment.

ELMIRA, N.Y., July 1. -- While Miss Lucretia Buxton's two-seater glider from California soared over Harris Hill today, piloted by Jay Buxton on one trip and Albert Slatter on the second flight, a steady two-way conversation was carried on between the craft and the hill station 3,000 feet below.

Joseph A. Solovei, widely known Brooklyn lawyer, former political protege of the late Mayor John F. Hylan and an attorney for the killers of Samuel Drukman, was declared unfit to be a lawyer in a communication sent by the Drukman special grand jury to the Appellate Division in Brooklyn yesterday.

Large gains in deposits and in total assets, lifting the figures in many cases to the highest ever reported, were shown in the statements of condition as of June 30, published yesterday by local and out-of-town banks and trust companies.

Though Peter Lorre's Hollywood career got off to a bad start in "Mad Love" and "Crime and Punishment," Paramount is confident things will take a turn for the better if the killer of the German film, "M," consents to appear in "Gun For Hire," which Dore Schary now is busy whipping into screen form.
