Police Commissioner VALENTINE wants authority to arrest pedestrians who cross streets against the lights or in the middle of the block. He would concentrate on a limited number of danger spots -Times Square, Grand Central zone and downtown.
BOSTON, July 1 (AP). -- Mrs. W.A. Bridges's Goldey F. scored a smashing victory today in the Betsy Ross Handicap, five-furlong sprint feature for juveniles, before 15,000 fans at Suffolk Downs.

DANZIG, July 1. -- The Polish Minister of Commerce, General Roman Goerecki, visited Danzig today before returning to Warsaw from the annual celebration at the neighboring Polish Port of Gdynia of Poland's resumption of direct access to the sea.

PHILADELPHIA, July 1. -- Mr. and Mrs. Percy M. Chandler of New York introduced their daughter, Miss Marie Louise Chandler, to Philadelphia society at a garden party at Brandywine Lodge, their Summer estate in Pocopson, Pa.

Bernard Jacoby, Evander Childs High School captain, and husky Vincent Eichler of Utica were extended to their utmost before reaching the title bracket of the junior singles division of the Greater New York tennis championships yesterday on the courts of the Jackson Heights Tennis Club in Queens.
PITTSBURGH, July 1 (AP). -- Three Cardinal hurlers failed to halt a fifteen hit Pirate attack today and the Bucs scored a 9-4 triumph over St. Louis in the third game of their series.

A tired porcupine was put carefully to bed without supper at the shelter of the Queens Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals last night, while a bewildered attendant wondered what else besides peaches a hungry "porc" would eat.

Count Alfonso Covadonga, eldest son of former King Alfonso of Spain, announced yesterday that he would sue to annul his marriage to the former Edelmira Sampedro of Cuba. His announcement followed publication here of a report from Havana that the Countess Covadonga planned to begin a suit for divorce in the Cuban courts within a few days on the ground of incompatability.

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- The world wheat surplus was estimated today by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics at 388,000,000 bushels -- the smallest in nine years. This surplus July 1 in Argentina, Australia, Canada and the United States, the principal exporting nations, compared with 532,000,000 bushels a year ago, 741 000,000 in 1934 and 789,000,000 -- an all-time peak -- in the Summer of 1933.
The wail of boatswains' pipes skirled over the decks of the gunboat Erie yesterday as the new 2,000-ton ship, first of her type, was commissioned at the navy yard in Brooklyn.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 1. -- In view of the business uncertainties that still exist, it may be "some time before a significant change occurs in present low interest rates," Dr. Harold G. Moulton president of the Brookings Institution, Washington, D.C., told 400 bank officials here tonight at the Graduate School of Banking, conducted under the Joint auspices of Rutgers University and the American Bankers Association.

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- The Works Progress Administration approved today an expenditure of $1,155,588 from new work relief funds to complete a taxation survey being carried out by the unemployed which is expected to serve as the basis for estimating future revenues, proposing tax legislation and amending existing legislation.
PARIS, July 1. -- After twenty-one days of conflict Gabrielle Chanel has won her fight against the strike leaders in her establishment.

A score of swimmers and divers who will compete in the final tryouts for the American Olympic team ten days hence met yesterday in the outdoor swimming pool of the Panama Pacific liner California for a foretaste of the training they will get while the liner Manhattan is at sea en route to Germany.

Not long ago it was editorially suggested by THE TIMES that a medal should be struck by Barnard College in honor of GEORGE A. PLIMPTON after the pattern of the old English coin called the "angel-noble" showing him standing as St. Michael triumphant over a dragon, for he had overcome one of the most menacing of modern dragons, a continuing college deficit.

Two national nominating conventions that should have met in September instead of June have shown how wasteful Americans are of time and money and emotion in trying to secure the type of government they want. Two months before the conventions were spent in costly preparation and five months will now be spent in costly journeys, meetings, reports and discussions.

CHICAGO, July 1. -- Secretary Wallace, who came here today to talk over a corn-hog program with farmers, told a class in contemporary thought at Northwestern University in Evanston that "weather changes" might be under way to convert the United States into an arid land.

Two hundred Negro delegates attending the 115th annual State convention of African Methodist Episcopal Zion Church, at the mother African Methodist Episcopal Zion Church, 140 West 137th Street, were welcomed to New York City last night by Mayor F.H. La Guardia, who described his administration's efforts to better conditions in Harlem.

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- Federal drought relief plans moved forward on several fronts today as the Weather Bureau announced that "the present urgent need for rain is more widespread than was the case in either 1930 or 1934 at this season of the year."

I listened to President Roosevelt's speech of acceptance. I was not a part of an excited throng. I was alone in my room, without a light, save for the two red eyes of my radio. Calm, serious and striving earnestly to analyze the President's message. A cold sensation of fear stole into my heart.

The commodity futures markets here were generally lower yesterday in quiet trading. Most of the declines were small, however, and some commodities, including rubber, cottonseed oil, cocoa and copper, were slightly stronger. In the cash markets, wheat, corn, rye, oats, lard and cotton were higher, while silk, tin and hides were lower.

ST. LOUIS, July 1 (AP). -- Battling for almost five and a half hours today, the Browns won the first game from the Indians, 16 -- 12, and tied the nightcap, which was called at the end of the ninth because of darkness with the score 5 -- 5.

TOLEDO, Ohio, July 1 (AP). -- The Independent Coalition of American Women, organized at a conference here to support anti-New Deal candidates in the national election this Fall, adopted a statement of principles today, supporting the candidacies of Governor London and Colonel Frank Knox, the Republican nominees for President and Vice President.

Anxiety over the non-appearance of the little schooner Dewless since she set sail from Newport a week ago Monday with the racing fleet for Bermuda as eased yesterday when it was believed that she had been sighted by the Furness Bermuda liner Queen of Bermuda.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 1. -- John D. M. Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Committee, charged in a speech here tonight that the Democratic party platform was "nothing but oratorical evasion'' and that the delegates to the Democratic convention acted "as mere rubber stamps."

Representatives of civic and patriotic organizations joined yesterday in forming the National Statue of Liberty Fiftieth Anniversary Committee to cooperate with the National Park Service in commemorating the dedication of the statue on Bedloe's Island by President Grover Cleveland on Oct. 28, 1886.

THE report at noon yesterday was that Joe Cronin, manager of the rich Red Sox, was not in his room. In the wake of the double drubbing of the Fenway Millionaires by the Yankees on the previous afternoon, this looked suspicious. Considering the severe shocks he had received, somebody should have been keeping watch on the fellow.

A study of classified advertising in newspapers throughout the country, just completed by Printer's Ink, "shows unmistakably that the United States is fast working itself out of the depression, with a shortage in labor that is almost nationwide."

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia today affirmed a decision of the District Supreme Court dismissing a suit of the Haskins Brothers Company of Omaha, soap manufacturers, and other soap firms "similarly situated" to enjoin the Secretary of the Treasury from turning over to the new Philippine Government the $26,000,000 fund which has accrued from the domestic processing taxes on coconut oil.

GLEN COVE, L.I., July 1. -- In a long day of arduous competition, Manuel Alonso of the Spanish Davis Cup team, J. Gilbert Hall and Leonard Hartman were eliminated from the invitation turf court tennis tournament of the Nassau Country Club today.

Already quadrennial campaign fever begins to inflict its victims with that too well-known lassitude and other symptoms. American arches are weakening with standing at the parting of the ways. Our institutions totter. The ark of the Constitution trembles. Greed and Humanity are training for a ferocious wrestling-match in which fouls are of custom.

Shipments of all types of hosiery in May totaled 9,379,143 dozen pairs, an increase of approximately 3 per cent over the figures for the corresponding period last year, according to a report issued yesterday by the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 1. -The Connecticut State golfers went back to the old schedule of two rounds daily today, with the result that competition in their thirty-seventh annual championship reached the quarter-final stage.

Two new cameras, one a motion picture machine, will be used at the Empire City race meeting which will get under way tomorrow, according to an announcement yesterday from the New York State Racing Commission.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 1. -- Defending academic freedom for Harvard University teachers, a committee set up by the Harvard overseers in a report made public tonight advocated a liberal point of view in the university discussions of current economic problems.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 1. -- Miss Mary Aspinwall Tappan and her niece, Mrs. Gorham Brooks of Boston, have leased historic Tanglewood at Lenox to Mr. and Mrs. E.R. Boots of Short Hills, N.J. The place derived its name from "The Tanglewood Tales," written in 1852 by Nathaniel Hawthorne in a little red cottage on the place that burned in 1890.

CLEVELAND, July 1 (AP). -- Twilight Song, sturdy bay filly owned by the Brooklyn harness horse fancier, William H. Strang Jr., and driven by the Indianapolis veteran, Sep Palin, recorded a straight-heat victory today in the $1,650 Rainy Day Sweepstakes for 2-year-old trotters at the North Randall track.

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- The War Department made a start today toward the solution of one of the most serious problems of national defense now confronting it -- the establishment of permanent air bases at strategic points capable of handling the concentration, within twenty-four hours, of the General Headquarters air force of 1,000 airplanes.

Frederick I. Daniels, chairman of the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration, took the city government to task yesterday for creating an "erroneous public impression" that the city was paying its full share of home relief to bonus recipients while the State was withdrawing its 40 per cent contribution.

Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, leader of the Democratic party in New Jersey and Eastern vice chairman of the Democratic National Committee, was named defendant yesterday in a suit for $60,000 instituted by Theodore M. Brandle, deposed labor leader and former friend and political associate of the Mayor.

Lieutenant Edward J. Moran, after forty years and ten months service on the police force, retired Tuesday midnight on a pension. Moran who lives with his wife and one of their three grown daughters at 481 Fort Washington Avenue, turned over his shield at a tour of desk duty in the Oak Street station.

ST. PAUL, July 1 (AP). -- A threatened breach in the National Farmers Holiday Association ranks was averted tonight when its national convention avoided any reference to the Union or Farmer-Labor parties in adopting resolutions.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., July 1. -With an attendance larger than had been expected because of its large market here in May, the Grand Rapids Furniture Exposition got under way today to continue to July 18, the longest period for any single market in its seventy-five years.

Jaffrey Harris, former conductor of the National Opera Company of England and founder of the Westchester Philharmonic Orchestra, will appear as guest conductor of the Naumburg Orchestra in its second concert on the Mall in Central Park on Saturday night.

Price reductions ranging from 25 cents to $2.25 a dozen were put into effect on Fall lines yesterday by two makers of branded hosiery, Julius Kayser Co. and the Gotham Silk Hosiery Company. The reductions caught the market by surprise and are expected to prevent producers of unbranded merchandise from making contemplated advances in their quotations.

Maurice (Moose) Peters, contract rider for William du Pont Jr.'s Foxcatcher Farms, yesterday at Aqueduct scored his first triple of the metropolitan season, beginning his sweep of the last part of the card with his employer's Fairy Hill in the Great American Stakes.

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- The government in effect today "called" its loans on last year's corn which are still outstanding among farmers, the Commodity Credit Corporation having made it known that the loans expiring on July 1 for the most part would not be extended.
Mayor La Guardia expects to arrive at his Summer City Hall in Pelham Bay Park about 2 o'clock this afternoon, after attending two official functions in Manhattan this morning.

Police Commissioner Valentine suspended from duty yesterday Patrolman Edward Shelubov and announced that he would have to stand departmental trial on charges of conduct unbecoming an officer, violation of departmental regulations and making a false official statement to the commissioner.

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- A uniform system of accounts prescribed for public utility companies and licensees subject to provisions of the Federal Power Act was made public today by the Federal Power Commission. The new system is to take effect on Jan. 1, thus giving the utilities six months to adjust their accounting.

The New York World's Fair of 1939 will have its own telephone exchange named "World's Fair 9-" if tentative arrangements with the New York Telephone Company go through, Grover A. Whalen, president of the World's Fair Corporation, announced yesterday at a meeting of the board of directors.

An investigation by the District Attorney's office into reports of racketeering by "runners" and other employes of lawyers who loiter in the vicinity of the Criminal Court Building was indicated yesterday when a law clerk was arraigned before Magistrate Brough in the Tombs Court.

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- The commercial and political capitals of New York State were on opposite sides today in one of the hardest fought railroad rate battles recently before the Interstate Commerce Commission, with Albany demanding drastic changes in the existing structure and New York City demanding "preservation of the status quo."

" This generation of Americans has a rendezvous with destiny." And so at the moment has the President and possibly also Governor Landon of Kansas. But the strange thing is that this rendezvous seems to have been made for the New Deal, not by it; made perhaps or Governor Landon and not by him.
MOSCOW, July 1 (AP). -- The Soviet government ordered tonight issuance of consolidated internal loan bonds totaling 19,000,000,000 rubles, which will absorb seven outstanding industrial loans.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 1 (AP). -- Charles P. Howard, International Typographical Union president, said today that he would not appear before the American Federation of Labor Executive Council in Washington July 10 to explain his union's attitude toward the setting up of a dual labor organization.

Copies of a memorandum left at the White House on Tuesday by a delegation of foreign traders interested in obtaining postponement of the order imposing countervailing duties on a number of German products were made available here yesterday by the Board of Trade for German-American Commerce.

The Sheffield Farms Company, Inc., has leased as a site for its projected new building the large vacant plot on the east side of Eleventh Avenue between Fifty-sixth and Fifty-seventh Streets for a term aggregating sixty-three years from the Fifty-seventh Street and Eleventh Avenue Corporation.
NICE, France, July 1. -- Alexander Berkman, long an anarchist associate of Emma Goldman in the United States, committed suicide here last Sunday, it became known tonight.

The city of Minneapolis, Minn., has issued a call for bids for a new issue of $876,000 of relief, public improvement, park, library and school bonds, award of which will be made on July 20. Further details of the financing will be announced later.

Manufacturers of food products will act individually, for the present at least, in conducting their business affairs under the provisions of the Robinson-Patman Anti-Price Discrimination Act, it was indicated yesterday at a special meeting of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

PARIS, July 1. -- When I arrived in America in the Spring of 1927 I found the country still ringing with the memory of the sufferings and victories of the great war. The names of Foch, Joffre, Petain, Gouraud and Clemenceau had become legendary and almost on the same level as those of Lafayette, Rochambeau and De Grasse.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

BOSTON, July 1. -- Colonel Bill Terry limped off National League Field today, wondering where it will all end and how. His Giants, for whom he had forecast such a promising season in the Spring, had just lost their fourth straight ball game, their second in a row to the Bees.

BERLIN, July 1. -- The German press brings to an end in tomorrow's editions its long silence on the real issue involved in the attempt to apply sanctions to Italy as an aggressor and breaks out in unconcealed jubilation.

SHANGHAI, Thursday, July 2. -- The institution of the most severe censorship by Canton lends credence to Japanese reports that Kwangsi Province armies have occupied the important city of Paoching in Southwestern Hunan, the Central Government forces withdrawing northwestward toward Hsinhua.

DES MOINES, July 1 (AP). -- Henry A. Wallace, Secretary of Agriculture criticized the Republican farm plank as contradictory and praised the Democratic plank as "clear and explicit" in a letter made public here today.

Madison Square Garden and Mike Jacobs of the Twentieth Century Sporting Club were still deadlocked yesterday over the proposal to stage a heavyweight championship fight between James J. Braddock and Max Schmeling.

PITTSBURGH, July 2 (AP). -- Dizzy Dean and the Cardinals defeated the third-place Pirates today, 4 -- 2. Dean held the Corsairs to seven hits in scoring his fourteenth victory of the season. The triumph gave the Cardinals three out of four in the series.

Cardinal Hayes yesterday promoted the Very Rev. Thomas J. Deegan, who has been president for the last ten years of Cathedral College, Madison Avenue and Fifty-first Street, to the pastorate of St. Augustine's Church, Larchmont, N.Y. The Rev. Hamilton P. Shea was advanced from the office of vice president of the college to the presidency.
NEWARK, N.J., July 2. -- The Newark Bears evened their series with the tail-end Syracuse Chiefs tonight when Kemp Wicker outlasted the veteran Fred Fussell in a pitching duel, 3 to 2.

Still excited over what he called "two swell games," Stewart B. Iglehart, No. 3 of the United States polo team which defeated England in London last month for the Westchester Cup, returned aboard the Ile de France of the French Line yesterday.

LAKEHURST, N.J., July 2. -- Through storm, fog and ice formation and over a longer route than usual, the giant airship Hindenburg arrived at the Naval Air Station here today with a new record for the westward crossing of the North Atlantic.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., July 2. -- Regular army and Reserve officers charged with the training at this year's Citizens Military Training Camp were up to their ears in work tonight. More than 900 candidates who left New York City early this morning By special train did not arrive until just before nightfall.

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- Sharp gains in the prices of farm products and foods caused a rise in the general level of wholesale prices in the week ended on June 27, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 weekly average, rose to 79.4 from 78.7 for the previous week and 78.9 on June 29, 1935.

Many reservations have been made for the "Jamboree" to be held tonight at Land's End, the Summer place of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Dow Gibson in Locust Valley, L.I., for the benefit of the Lenox Hill Settlement House. After dinner, games, a swimming exhibition, an amateur hour and a display of fireworks are among the events arranged by the committee.

Vincent Eichler, strapping 17-year-old Utica lad, gave a brilliant exhibition in capturing the junior singles laurels in the Greater New York tennis championships yesterday on the Jackson Heights Tennis Club courts in Queens.

GOSTA GUSTAV-JANSON, of whom not many Americans had heard before the advance publicity on "The Old Man's Coming" (Knopf, $2.75) began to appear, is 34 years old and scion of a literary Swedish family. "The Old Man's Coming," first of his novels to appear in this country and a best-seller in Sweden last year, is compelling evidence of his breadth of view and talents.

The strange case of Miss Mary Brophy, teacher-clerk in the city school system, who had served since 1914 without benefit of credentials, according to officials, provided a mystery yesterday at the Board of Education.
Housing and business properties in Hartsdale were included in the Westchester turnover reported yesterday.

CHICAGO, July 2. -- Wheat prices in leading United States markets soared 5 cents a bushel today, the limit permitted for one day under Exchange regulations, as the result of a somewhat belated recognition of the damage from heat and drought which has occurred in the Dakotas, Minnesota and Montana, and which now threatens what has heretofore been regarded as a promising outlook in the Canadian Northwest.
CHICAGO, July 2 (AP). -- A widespread damper on the crop-consuming drought was forecast by the Weather Bureau today as various authorities estimated its cost to date at $250,000,000.

CHICAGO, July 2 (AP). -- The Tigers, behind the seven-hit pitching of Schoolboy Rowe, beat the faltering White Sox, 7 -- 1, today to sweep the abbreviated two-game series. It was Rowe's seventh victory of the season.

PHILADELPHIA, July 2. -- College and club oarsmen from all parts of the country will compete in the Olympic trials in connection with the two-day national and People's Day regattas, which open on the Schuylkill River tomorrow. All the visiting crews went over the 2,000-meter course today.
WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP). -- The navy's high command shook its officers' roster "from truck to keelson" today by promoting more than 1,000 gold-striped men.

To Chairman HAMILTON, addressing his party's State convention in Ohio, the Democratic platform is but "oratorical evasion" adopted by a lot of "rubber stamps." Considering the confused and contradictory doctrines of the Republican document, perhaps its best defense is attack, and Mr. HAMILTON is proceeding according to sound military rules.
HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, July 2. -- English crews went down like so many nine-pins before the American invasion on the second day of the Henley Regatta today.

RICHMOND, Va., July 2. -- Directors of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation were elected here today when stockholders got together after nearly three months of disagreement. The directors are Harley L. Clarke, Morris E. Feiwell, Harry M. Hope, Archibald L. Jackson, Ronald R. Monroe, Henry A. Stix and Philip B. Shaw.

NYACK, N.Y., July 2. -- The American Legion of Rockland County declared at its meeting here this morning that Federal funds were being used to promote Communism at Camp Jane Addams, recreation center run for unemployed girls by the National Youth Administration on Lake Tiorata in Bear Mountain Park near here.

A redistribution within the Federal Reserve System of the holdings of United States Government securities of the twelve Federal Reserve Banks so as to concentrate all such investments in a special "system account" and to reallocate on the basis of earnings requirements the participation in this account of individual Reserve Banks was disclosed yesterday in connection with the weekly report of the Federal Reserve System.

" The Princess Intervenes," a new play by Roland Bottomley, will be the initial offering next week at the Bay Shore (L.I.) Memorial Community Building, under the direction of Clyde Armstrong. . . . The Auditorium Theatre at Concord, N.H., will be operated as a Summer show-shop this season, beginning on July 13 with Cornelia Otis Skinner in "Candida." . . .

The appointment of men off high caliber to the Maritime Authority created by the new Federal Merchant Marine Act, was urged upon President Roosevelt yesterday by the Merchants Association and the Propeller Club of the Port of New York.

Legislation outlawing suits for alienation of affections is unconstitutional, the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, in Brooklyn, ruled yesterday. The 1935 Legislature lacked the authority to enact such legislation without providing some adequate substitute, the court decided by a vote of 3 to 2.

Doris Humphrey and Charles Weidman, with the assistance of their excellent concert group, last night gave the first of the Summer season's dance performances at the Lewisohn Stadium, and a first-rate performance it proved to be. Indeed, not in several years has the Stadium offered a dance program of equal merit either in the high standard of its compositions or in the expertness and charm of its presentation.

ITHACA, July 2. -- A new weight for the hydrogen atom, the most accurate so far obtained, was announced here today at a symposium on nuclear physics a Cornell University, the most comprehensive of its kind to be held so far in the United States, by Professor Kenneth T. Bainbridge, one of the world's leading "atom-weighers," of Harvard University.

NORFOLK, Va., July 2 (AP). -- Alarmed over the failure to obtain any information concerning the schooner Dewless, which started in the Newport-to-Bermuda race last week, Norfolk Coast Guard headquarters today dispatched the cutter Modoc to search for her.

LONDON, July 2. -- The stock market here continued cheerful today in fairly active trading. British Government issues were firm and there were many bright spots among the industrials. Buildings, iron and steel shares and aviations rose further on renewed speculative demand.

SHAMOKIN, Pa., July 2. -- Enoch Kulshinskie Jr., rescued this morning from a "bootleg" coal mine in which he had been imprisoned for twenty-two hours by a fall of rock, died in the Shamokin Hospital tonight of a broken back and internal injuries.

Realty Associates, Inc., last month closed more contracts than it had since 1927, James Graham, vice president of the company, reported yesterday. The more than forty transactions arranged last month included apartment houses, vacant land, stores and dwellings in Brooklyn and other communities on Long Island.

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended July 1, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,473,000,000, a decrease of $5,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $2,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1935.

The Conversion Office for German foreign debts announced yesterday offers of exchange to the holders of drawn or matured bonds of three additional issues, as follows: Ruhr Chemical Corporation 6 per cent series A bonds, due in 1948; German Atlantic Cable Company first mortgage 7s, due 1945, and Free State of Anhalt 7 per cent bonds, external loan of 1936.

Clement H. Congdon, editor and publisher of The Philadelphia Sunday Transcript; two brokers, one of whom was formerly a member of the New York Stock Exchange, and two attorneys were among nineteen persons indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury for an alleged $5,000,000 mail fraud conspiracy.

The unrelieved drought in the Grain Belt extended its influence yesterday to the stock market. As wheat prices rocketed in Chicago the 5 cents a bushel permissible in a single day, the shares of farm-implement companies dropped sharply and those of mail-order houses declined.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, July 2. -- President Pehr Evind Svinhufvud pardoned the American, Arvid Verner Jacobson, who, in August, 1934, was sentenced by the Supreme Court to six years at hard labor for complicity in Mrs. Mary Louise Martin's espionage activities.

PITTSBURGH, July 2. -- Tendencies considerably mixed were revealed in the business reports of last week for the Pittsburgh district, according to the Bureau of Business Research of the University of Pittsburgh. There were some actual gains, a number of declines that were less than seasonal and some declines that were distinctly more than seasonal.

The Appellate Division reversed yesterday an order of a lower court and granted a temporary injunction restraining the Board of Education and the Board of Estimate from permitting further performance of a contract awarded to the Children's Bus Service, Inc., covering school transportation throughout the city.

A Fourth of July celebration under cloudy skies and showers was forecast yesterday by the Weather Bureau. Rail, bus and air terminals were jammed with advance travelers arriving and departing from the city for the week-end holiday.

HAVANA, July 2. -- The action of the Gomez administration in discharging some 3,000 government employes on June 30, a majority of whom were military reservists, today brought forth an order from Colonel Fulgencio Batista, chief of staff of the Cuban Army, to the heads of all regiments of the island to accord dismissed employes "every attention, which they merit by reason of their valiant and efficient conduct."
CINCINNATI, July 2, (AP). -- The Cubs stopped Cincinnati's winning streak at seven straight today by taking an 8-6 thirteen-inning game.

PORTLAND, Ore., July 2. -- Teachers of the nation had in effect the blessing of the American Legion today, as by overwhelming vote at the convention of the National Education Association they adopted resolutions condemning curbs on freedom of teaching, including loyalty oath bills and the "red rider" to the District of Columbia Appropriation Bill.

CHICAGO, July 2. -- President Roosevelt, Postmaster General Farley and the Democratic party's platform were assailed tonight by John D.M. Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Committee, in an address in which he predicted the election of the Landon-Knox ticket in November, and with it "a victory for America."

CHICAGO, July 2. -- The statement that the administration's foreign trade policy is opening the way to foreign economic, and "perhaps political," colonization was made by George N. Peek, former AAA head and adviser to President Roosevelt on international commerce, in an address before the Agricultural Club today.

Conflicting price trends characterized slightly more active trading in the bond market yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. United States Government obligations, as a group, were moderately higher on a heavier turnover, the guaranteed Federal Farm Mortgage and Home Owners Loan issues scoring the widest gains.

The American Olympic track and field committee yesterday named 152 additional qualifiers for the final Olympic track and field tryouts following a mail vote of the committee conducted by Chairman William J. Bingham.
PARIS, July 2 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

PLYMOUTH, England, July 2. -- T.O.M. Sopwith's new yacht Endeavour II, prospective challenger for the America's Cup, and W.L. Stephenson's Velsheda both were dismasted in a race off here today. They were caught in the teeth of a gale in the English Channel.

OCEAN CITY, N.J., July 2. -- Leonard Tyner, 13-year-old Negro orphan from Chicago, won the national marbles tournament here today after two of the four semifinalists had withdrawn in protest of alleged race prejudice. He is now "marbles champion of the United States."

Interstate action for a uniform gasoline tax or an agreement to prevent gasoline smuggling was advocated yesterday by Assemblyman John A. Byrnes, chairman of the New York Joint Legislative Committee on Interstate Cooperation, in making public the report of his committee.
The July Fourth week-end usually finds both fresh and salt-water anglers busy on all fronts.

A banking group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., won yesterday the award of three issues of bonds of Nassau County, L.I., aggregating $3,000,000 on a bid of 100.215 for 2 3/4s. The bonds, dated July 15, 1936, and maturing on July 115, 1938 to 1953, are to be issued for road, emergency relief and refunding purposes.
LONDON, July 2 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

The New York Interscholastic team defeated New Jersey, 44 to 30, yesterday in an interstate team swimming contest at Manhattan Beach, the 200-meter relay team of the winners setting a new world interscholastic record for the distance.

NORWALK, Conn., July 2. -- Mrs. Jonathan Thorne, former women's metropolitan golf champion, ended in a tie with her clubmate, Mrs. Russell Holman of Innis Arden, in the race for first honors in the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association tourney today.

She is the Governor's Lady, and she obviously has her share of the good sportsmanship in the Herbert Lehman family. Her husband having bowed to the command of people and party, Mrs. LEHMAN ruefully observes she doesn't know whether to be happy or unhappy about it, but that it was inevitable.

After hearing the Robinson-Patman Anti-Price Discrimination Act praised as a constructive piece of legislation and also attacked by attorneys yesterday, members of the drug, chemical and allied trades section of the New York Board of Trade decided to appeal to the Federal Trade Commission for aid in interpreting questionable provisions of the new law.

Withdrawal by the General Foods Corporation of its advertising allowances to distributors is among the first direct effects of the Robinson-Patman Anti-Price Discrimination Act. Although not officially announced, it is understood that the withdrawal covers sales promotion allowances to the corporate chains, wholesalers, voluntary chains and the independents. Other food companies were reported yesterday as having similar action in view, with the week featured by meetings with attorneys on the questions involved.

A West Bronx deal in the University Heights section was reported by Grudin Sawitch, brokers, who sold the six-story elevator building housing sixty-five families at 1,746 Andrews Avenue for the Danbern Realty Corporation to B. Jakubowitz.

John Hay Whitney, member of the Jockey Club and the Racing Commission, who captured the Dwyer Stakes with Mr. Bones, scored a double yesterday on the final afternoon of the sport at Aqueduct when his juveniles Flying Scot and Royal Feast were winners.

Only one Easterner, George B. Dunn, University of Pennsylvania junior and holder of the Delaware State title, made his way into the semi-final round of the Eastern intercollegiate tennis championship at the Richmond County Country Club at Dongan Hills yesterday.

TOKYO, Friday, July 3. -- Lieut. Col. Saburo Aizawa fell before the bullets of a firing squad today, the first Japanese officer to be executed in the twenty-eight years since the military code was promulgated.

BRUSSELS, July 2. -- The Belgian strikes, hitherto confined to Walloonia, were-spreading through the Flemish half of Belgium today. Without warning, last night Antwerp trams returned to their depots and service was suspended today.

Nineteen directors of the Borg-Warner Corporation received in 1935 total compensation of $534,946, it was disclosed yesterday in the annual report of the company to the Securities and Exchange Commission. H.E. Blood, vice president of the company, received $106,900; G.W. Borg, chairman of the board, $102,300, and C.S. Davis, president, $94,126, the report showed.

WESTPORT, Conn., July 2. -- Miss Helen Bedford, M.F.H., showing her well-known Wynfromere Farm entry, swept through the hunter division of the annual horse show of the Fairfield County Hunt Club, which opened this morning and will continue through Saturday.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

CHICAGO, July 2. -- The best grades of hogs were in demand today and prices were steady to 10 cents a hundredweight higher than yesterday, although the top was $10.95 on each day. Packing sows, however, after selling slightly higher early, weakened in the later trading and some sales showed a decline of 10 cents.

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- The question of ways and means to make as concise as possible the selling prospectus filed with registration statements by issuers using Form A-2 under the Securities Act of 1933 was discussed today in an opinion by Harold H. Neff, director of the Division of Forms and Regulations of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

In New York State the owner or builder is allowed to file plans. He is not required to have his plans approved by a registered engineer. Neither is he required to assure the public against damage nor catastrophe during the erection. Only an engineer with thorough training is competent to design and supervise the construction of structures and their attending foundation, each of which is a separate and distinct problem.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

PARIS, July 2. -- By a vote of 282 to 193 the Chamber of Deputies this afternoon, after a stormy discussion, refused to validate the election as a deputy for Corsica of Jean Chiappe, former prefect of Paris police, whose dismissal by Premier Edouard Daladier in February, 1934, was one of the contributory factors in the rioting which took place over the Stavinsky scandal.

ST. LOUIS, July 2 (AP). -- Johnny Allen held the Browns to five hits and Hal Trosky drove his twentieth home run of the season as the Indians won the second game of a double-header today, 4 -- 2. Cleveland took the first, 14 to 6.

Following publication yesterday of the New York Stock Exchange's analysis of the status of customers' margin accounts with member firms, reports were circulated again in Wall Street that the Federal Reserve Board would ease its margin requirement of 55 per cent.

Under the new soil conservation program, Eastern farmers, if so minded, will receive sizable bonuses for allowing parts of their acreage to remain in fertilized grass crops, whereas under AAA, crop benefits in this section were few and far between.
The charge that New Jersey "is experimenting with slow starvation" for recipients of unemployment relief was made in a report made public yesterday by the American Association of Social Workers.

LOS ANGELES, July 2. -- The manner in which a Japanese agent assertedly acquired secret information about the American Navy was described in Federal Court today at the trial of Harry Thomas Thompson on charges of being a paid agent for a Japanese spy.

Filing of plans for six-story apartment houses continued in volume yesterday as architects hastened to have their projects recorded before adoption of the new Building Code. Yesterday's plans included a $500,000 multi-family structure for Flushing, Queens.

Up to this year any one who wanted to could hold a public fireworks affair on July Fourth, and a couple of dozen bid for favor in all parts of this city. This year there will be only two, possibly only one, because last year a child's arm was blown off at Patterson Park and the city had to pay $6,000 damages.

John W. Clancy, who was appointed judge of the United States Court for the Southern District of New York by President Roosevelt, took his oath of office yesterday in a court room of the new Federal Building at induction ceremonies presided over by Senior Judge John C. Knox.

Three new arrivals are due today. "The Harvester," screen version of Gene Stratton-Porter's novel, with a cast including Alice Brady, Frank Craven, Russell Hardie and Ann Rutherford, will come to the Roxy. The Rialto will offer "Forgotten Faces," with Herbert Marshall and Gertrude Michael, the story having been filmed twice before under the title "Heliotrope."

ST. PAUL, July 2 (AP). -- Five Farmers Holiday Association State presidents today disregarded the group's national convention, which closed here yesterday, and named their own set of officers empowered to call a national convention "within sixty days."
BERLIN, July 2 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of June 30 is as follows, in thousands of marks, with changes from the preceding week: ...

IT will be Junior Class Day for the sprinters, hurdlers and field workers down at Princeton today except for one important event, the 10,000-meter run, Mr. Dan Ferris, the stylish-stout secretary-treasurer of the A.A.U., said he wouldn't miss that race under any consideration. He wants to see just how far a fellow named Don Lash can go.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., July 2. -- Bobby Jacobson, defending champion, was eliminated today in the second round of the New Jersey State junior golf championship, bowing to Wilson Flohr, 17-year-old Canoe Brook Country Club star, in their meeting on the Bock Spring links. Jacobson, representing the Hollywood Golf Club, won the title the last two years. Flohr's winning margin was 4 and 2.
WASHINGTON, July 2. -- Albert J. Zager of Baltimore asked the Supreme Court today to declare part of the National Prohibition Act still in effect, despite the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment.

This year the question that seems to be most in discussion at the meeting of the National Education Association is as to the seeking of Federal aid for public education, which has been almost exclusively a State function. Such aid has been granted as relief during the last two or three years.
Dwelling deals furnished the bulk of the New Jersey realty activity reported yesterday.

In a move consolidating its scattered units in the metropolitan area, the International Harvester Company has leased the three-story building under construction on the easterly block front on Eleventh Avenue from Forty-first to Forty-second Streets, it was announced yesterday.

ELIZABETH, N.J., July 2. -- John Crempa, Scotch Plains farmer whose wife was killed during the family's six-year conflict with the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey, and his son, John Jr., 17, were found guilty today by Vice Chancellor Henry Kays here of contempt of court.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP). -- R. Granville Curry, counsel for the Port of Albany, N.Y., told the Interstate Commerce Commission today that the port could handle all traffic that might come to it through the institution of proposed "port rates."

SAN FRANCISCO, July 2 (AP). -Found sane by a jury, Albert Walter Jr. was sentenced today to be hanged at San Quentin prison Sept. 4 for the silk-stocking strangling of Miss Blanche Cousins of Idaho Falls, whom he attacked.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 2. -- Estimating at 22,000,000 bags the 1936-37 coffee crop, plus 4,000,000 to 5,000,000 bags left over from last year's crop, the National Coffee Department has established a quota of thirty per cent to be destroyed. It is paying growers five milreis a bag for coffee destroyed.

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- Philip Morris Co., Ltd., of New York, today filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 103,866 shares of $10 par value common capital stock to be offered, through transferrable warrants, to stockholders of record of July 28 at $50 a share in the ratio of one new share for each four shares held.

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- The nation now has more than 46,000,000 gainfully employed persons, compared with 48,000,000 noted by the decennial census in 1930, according to Secretary Perkins, who said today that the increase in employment, excluding agriculture and Federal emergency employment, since the low point of the depression in March, 1933, appeared to be 5,370,000.

Freight carloadings in the current quarter of the year are expected to be about 10.7 per cent more than the actual loadings in the third quarter of 1935, according to estimates compiled by the thirteen Shippers' Regional Advisory Boards and announced yesterday.

However it may be glossed over by assurances from the Attorney General to Mr. FARLEY of "justification" for the cancellation of air mail contracts which disrupted the air transport industry of the United States in 1934, the Postoffice Department's announcement that it had compromised suits brought by four important contractors as a result of that cancellation will be recognized the country over for what it is: an admission that the Government's position was untenable.

With practically every potential member of the American Olympic team competing, the forty-eighth annual national A.A.U. track and field championships will get under way on the lightning fast Palmer Stadium cinderpath at Princeton, N.J., today. The junior title meet will open the show and, as is always the case, will uncover a wealth of new talent.

Mrs. Alfred W. Erickson, who purchased the five-story English basement town house at 15 East Sixty-seventh Street, between Fifth and Madison Avenues, last April, has resold the property at a profit to a client of Frances Tilghman, Inc.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 2 (AP). -- Almost without exception, the 14,000 spectators who watched Miss Helen Jacobs carefully chop her to her triumph today, were way hoping she would at last achieve her ambition, a Wimbledon championship, when she meets Mrs. Hilda Krahwinkel Sperling Saturday.

Additional testimony in support of the proposal of Eastern railroads to establish complete free pick-up and delivery of less-than-carload freight brought to an end yesterday the New York hearings of the Interstate Commerce Commission on the plan.

A struggle on an escalator between the second and third floors of Ohrbach's department store at 48 East Fourteenth Street, in Union Square, followed a hold-up in the store crowded with women shoppers at 1 P.M. yesterday. A suspect was seized and $185 which he was said to have taken from a cashier was recovered.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 2 (AP). -G. Newt Choate, superintendent of the State Reform School, whose administration a Davidson County grand jury described as "most inhumane," quit today without the formality of submitting a resignation.

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- An application of the Washington Water Power Company for a license for the construction of a dam, reservoir, power plant and appurtenant works at Kettle Falls, on the Columbia River in Ferry and Stevens Counties in the State of Washington, was denied in an order dated July 1, the Federal Power Commission announced today.

A bit sheepish but "mighty proud" that a home town boy and a fellow-Mayor now rules over "the world's swellest police force," William A. Sullivan, Mayor of Globe, Ariz., and the Sheriff of his county, yesterday revealed the details of how a pickpocket took his pocketbook as he was about to take his pretty 18-year-old daughter on her first trip to Coney Island.

Although bank clearings for the week ended on Wednesday showed a decline of 11.6 per cent from the corresponding week a year ago, they showed an increase over the total of the previous week. The total for the twenty-two leading cities throughout the nation, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc., was $6,021,760,000, which compared with $5,572,681,000 the week before and $6,810,432,000 for same week in 1935.

A word from a lifelong Democrat concerning reflections being cast by the public press and others on the motives of a former Governor of New York State who, incidentally, before the New Deal, put his State foremost in the Union in the passage of social security and humanitarian legislation:

WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP). -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today exemptions to holding-company provisions of the Public Utility Act of 1935 which ordered separation of financial institutions and utility holding companies or their subsidiaries.

The problem of payment of relief money to veterans who have received the soldiers' bonus continued to agitate city officials yesterday, with Mayor La Guardia assailing the position allegedly taken by the State Temporary Relief Administration.

Virtually nothing of a comforting nature to the Dodgers transpired at Ebbets Field yesterday. Cavorting before Brooklyn's smallest crowd this year, the Flatbush forces, instead of evacuating the National League cellar, made just four singles and absorbed their ninth shutout setback of the campaign.
WARM SPRINGS, Ga., July 2. -- Franklin D. Roosevelt, Georgia farmer, stands to lose "a lot of money" this year because of the drought, the worst in this section in years.

ESTES PARK, Col., July 2. -- Governor Alf M. Landon was represented today as being opposed to farm benefit payments as a permanent part of the nation's farm policy, and as feeling that some other method of dealing with the problem must be worked out.

As the first step in a proposed shakeup of his much-criticized staff of assistants, District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan of Brooklyn is awaiting today the resignation of William W. Kleinman, the alleged conspirator in the Drukman murder plot, concerning whose guilt the blue ribbon jury was unable to agree last week.

Because, by his admission in court, he "lost his head," Harold W. Spindell, 38 years old, of 254 West Thirty-first Street, former third deputy commissioner in the Tenement House Department, received a suspended sentence on a street littering charge in Yorkville Court yesterday.
WESTBURY, L.I., July 2. -- Draws for the Hempstead Cups and the Wheatley Cups, 12 and 9 goal tournaments, respectively, of the Meadow Brook Club, were announced today.

NEWMARKET, England, July 2. -- Loaded down under the backbreaking top weight of 138 pounds, William Woodward's Omaha lost his last bid for a major victory on the English turf today when he dropped a narrow decision to the Aga Khan's Taj Akbar in the Princess of Wales Stake.

On the eve of opening nine more outdoor swimming pools, built and financed by the government as WPA projects, the City of New York yesterday was prevented by litigation in Federal court from acquiring machines for spreading chlorine gas, a disinfecting agent, through the water.
CLEVELAND, July 2 (AP). -- Rosalind, queen of the 2-year-old trotters last year, captured the three miles of the $4,060 Matron Stake on the Grand Circuit card at North Randall today.

Objections were voiced yesterday to a proposed plan for the reorganization of the Consolidated Textile Corporation under Section 77B of the Bankruptcy Act at a hearing before Peter B. Olney Jr., official referee.

The Citizens Budget Commission yesterday made public a series of memoranda urging changes in several fiscal phases of the proposed draft of the new city charter which have been submitted to the Charter Revision Commission.

OTTAWA, July 2 (Canadian Press). -Deposits of the Dominion Government with the Bank of Canada on June 30 were $679,128 less than the week before, according to the weekly statement today issued by the bank. Deposits of chartered banks were down $1,041,249.

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- The Louisville Nashville Railroad Company received today permission of the Interstate Commerce Commission to procure the authentication and delivery of $30,000,000 of first and refunding mortgage 3 3/4 per cent gold bonds, series E, most of which is to be used, with funds in the treasury, for the redemption of two bond issues.

Leaving a note saying that he was a descendant of a noble French family, Thomas W. Eastland, 43 years old, a lawyer, committed suicide yesterday morning by inhaling gas in his furnished room at 173 St. Marks Avenue, near Cariton Avenue, Brooklyn, according to the police, who found the body at 10 A.M.
BOSTON, July 2. -- The Giants saved something from the wreck of this disastrous visit with the Bees today before a ladies' day crowd of 7,000.

Yesterday's statement of the the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings and the reserve note circulation to be at the highest point of the year to date, while total bills discounted were at the lowest. The ratio of reserve at the New York bank was also at the highest point of the year.

John Brantley of Savannah gave a luncheon yesterday in the Summer garden of the Ambassador for United States Senator and Mrs. Walter F. George of Vienna, Ga., who are at that hotel. Other guests were Mr. and Mrs. Henry Law, Mr. and Mrs. John Calvin Thorne, Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Smith of Atlanta, William G. Vereen of Moultrie and Arthur Lucas of Atlanta.

Three of the young lawyers whom the Bar Association last week caused District Attorney Dodge to appoint as special prosecutors in the revived investigation of racketeering by lawyers and others in accident claims brought about the arrest yesterday of the first lawyer under inquiry, Henry Steinberg, 31 years old.

CHAPPAQUA, N.Y., July 2. -- Complete mastery of his short game over the undulating fairways and greens of the tricky Whippoorwill Golf Club today enabled Charles C. Pettijohn Jr. of the Westchester Country Club to capture the sixteenth annual Westchester Golf Association junior championship.

Clinton L. Bardo, bankruptcy trustee for the New York, Westchester and Boston Railroad, told the Transit Commission yesterday that he must, under the terms of his appointment, make the line pay its way or cause it to be "liquidated.''

GENEVA, July 2. -- Into the pleasant League of Nations arena of complacent oratory and verbal deviousness just after the Assembly closed this evening the Ethiopian delegation dropped a documentary bombshell that created a far greater stir than did the Emperor's moving appeal the opening day.

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- After conferences with farmers and agricultural leaders in the drought States, Secretary Wallace wired instructions to Washington today from Duluth, Minn., to set in motion a program of purchase and processing of cattle forced off ranges in the Northwest by severe drought conditions.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 2. -- Mr. and Mrs. John Jacob Astor are planning a trip through the West and to the West Coast. They will be accompanied by Mrs. Astor's sister, Miss Virginia French. They are to leave by special car on July 22 and will be away for three weeks, returning to Newport for tennis week.

Taking the testimony of eleven bricklayers who had worked on the building at 112 East Mosholu Parkway South, the Bronx, in the collapse of which eighteen workmen were killed June 19, the June Bronx grand jury yesterday neared completion of its investigation of the accident.

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- Under a storm of protests that its act constituted censorship of the air, the Federal Communications Commission has changed from July 1 to Aug. 1 the effective date of an order that all radio stations must have its written permission before rebroadcasting foreign radio programs.

CHANGSHA, Hunan Province, China, July 2. -- The Central Government has now concentrated 600,000 troops within striking distance on the borders of the hostile South China Provinces of Kwangsi and Kwangtung.

The efforts of 14-year-old Jimmy Williams to find a suitable home for his family brought their first tangible result yesterday when he received a letter from James N. MacLean, general chairman of the Municipal Committee for the Relief of Home Owners, stating that the committee had found new living quarters for him.

The Engineers Public Service Company resumed yesterday dividends on its various preferred stocks, the directors declaring distributions of $4 a share on the $5 convertible preferred stock, of $4.40 a share on the $5.50 cumulative preferred stock and of $4.80 a share on the $6 cumulative preferred stock, all payable on Aug. 1 to stock of record on July 15.

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- President Roosevelt held his first serious conference relating to his coming campaign for re-election today on the eve of his Fourth of July weekend speaking trip. For three hours he discussed various details of the party organization, campaign budget and other political matters with party leaders at his office in the White House.

Private enterprise and the critics of "boondoggling" were scored yesterday by Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, and Mayor La Guardia at the formal delivery of First Houses by the WPA to the New York City Housing Authority.

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- At least one additional New York City low-cost housing and slum clearance project will be carried out under the new PWA program on a 45 per cent grant basis, with New York City furnishing the remaining 55 per cent of the cost, Secretary Ickes said today.

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- Members of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System withheld comment today as to their reaction in regard to the summary prepared by the New York Stock Exchange of the data contained in questionnaires which the Exchange sent to member firms to determine the status of margin accounts.
WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP). -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt finished her fourth year of press conferences today and prepared to close the busy White House for another Summer's remodeling.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 2. -- Perfectly trained and showing impeccable match play temperament in such minor crises as arose, Miss Helen Jacobs, American champion, overwhelmed Miss Jadwiga Jedrzejowska, the sturdily built Polish girl, in straight sets on the center court today.

Unfilled orders in the wool fabric industry are unofficially estimated at about 38,000,000 linear yards, or the equivalent of twelve weeks' production at the present rate of operations, according to a report issued yesterday by the New York Wool Top Exchange Service.

As a means of "belatedly according honor, gratitude and admiration to a noble race which held in perfect trust the New World, which they loved but did not selfishly hold," the residents of Ridgefield Lakes Club and the owners of adjacent historic territory in Fairfield County, Conn., have started a movement for a national holiday in tribute to the American Indian.

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- The government spent about a dollar for every 46 cents it collected between July 1, 1935, and June 30, 1936, and ended the fiscal year with a deficit of $4,763,841,642, the greatest in peace-time history, the Treasury announced today.

Summer furniture lines had an especially good season this year, beating figures of 1935 for both dollar and unit volume by wide margins. The large percentage of better price merchandise ordered by retailers was one of the outstanding features of the season, manufacturers said.

The Brooklyn grand jury that indicted Ellis H. Parker Sr., Burlington County (N.J.) detective, in the Paul H. Wendel kidnapping case, took occasion yesterday to "deplore" the indifference, not to say "interference," of the New Jersey authorities in the affair.

Holding court in the living room of his Summer home in White Plains, Associate Justice Benjamin N. Cardozo of the United States Supreme Court refused yesterday to grant a stay of involuntary bankruptcy proceedings to the Associated Gas and Electric Company pending its application for a review of an adverse decision in a good-faith issue.

PHILADELPHIA, July 2 (AP). -- The Senators kept in the thick of the fight for second place in the American League today, defeating the Athletics, 4 -- 3, behind Earl Whitehill's strong pitching in the pinches.

MONROVIA, Liberia, July 2. -- Without having had even the briefest glimpse of "the angry gods" who were reported to have swallowed him, Dr. Robert Morey, anthropologist of the Rockefeller Institute, rested here today and will return soon to the United States.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 2. -- Even years seem to jinx husky Charley Clare, Racebrook star. He has won the Connecticut State golf crown three times in the last six years and all his victories have come in the odd ones.

With leading wheat futures markets here and in Canada reaching the limit within which they are permitted to fluctuate within a day's trading, and with offering prices after the cessation of trading at the maximum for a day, it appeared that there were people who were afraid there would not be enough wheat, including the carryover, to supply world requirements until the next crop was harvested.

BOSTON, July 2 (AP). -- The Corsicana Stable's Wacoche annexed the Advertising Federation of America Handicap by a length over Mrs. E.E. Russel's Sun Apollo, to pay $6.20 for $2 in the mutuels, before a gathering of 15,000 today at Suffolk Downs.

GLEN COVE, L.I., July 2. -- Gregory Mangin, the national indoor champion; Robert Riggs of Los Angeles, the clay court titleholder, and Wayne Sabin, with whom he shares the clay court doubles crown, reached the semi-final round of the Nassau County Club invitation tennis tournament today.

Twelve members of the Police Department, including several who have been cited for bravery or otherwise commended, face departmental trials on charges of having paid sums ranging from $500 to $1,000 to a fixer in unsuccessful attempts to buy promotions to the rank of sergeant, it was disclosed yesterday.
Earnings of the Manhattan Shirt Company in the six months ended on May 30 were double those of the corresponding period last year, it was announced yesterday.
VATICAN CITY, July 2. -- The following is the official translation of the Latin text of a papal encyclical on motion pictures issued here today:

A generally strong tone was evidenced in the local commodity futures markets yesterday, with coffee, cocoa and cottonseed oil showing sizable gains. On the cash markets new high prices were made by wheat, corn, rye, oats, cotton, rubber and cocoa, and flour, butter and eggs also advanced.

The appointment of a new American Ambassador to Italy on the same day the Italian journalists at Geneva staged their childish demonstration against the Emperor HAILE SELASSIE serves to focus attention on the difficult and delicate role our diplomatic representatives are called upon to play in the abnormal tensions of the contemporary world.

VATICAN CITY, July 2. -- In an encyclical letter issued today Pope Pius makes an impassioned appeal for a ban on all motion pictures that are indecent or morally unsound, so as to oblige producers to improve the moral standard of films released to the public.

" Oh, plainsman on the dizzy heights, beware the breathless air that bites!" The correspondents' faces blanch: "Beware the awful avalanche!" He looks as genial as he can, the glacier goes Republican. Flower of the States and child of the sun, you yearned for mountains, at last you've one.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., July 2 (AP). -- Governor Sholtz today appointed William L. Hill of Gainesville, Fla., as temporary successor to the late Senator Duncan U. Fletcher.

Showing optimism about carrying Eastern States for Governor Landon, Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr., Eastern campaign director, announced yesterday the plans for organization here and pledged a hot battle to win the Eastern electoral votes for the Kansas Governor.

Higher prices for cattle, hogs and their products more than offset declines in the grains, and The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices advanced to 122.7 on Tuesday from 122.5 (revised) on the preceding Tuesday.

Catholic leaders in New York yesterday were silent on the encyclical of Pope Pius that not only endorsed the Catholic action against indecent motion pictures as carried out in this country through the Legion of Decency, but also recommended its application on a world-wide scale.

Mayor La Guardia and his official family received a warm welcome from Bronx residents yesterday afternoon when he moved the headquarters of city government to the century-old Bartow mansion in Pelham Bay Park.

Ten paddlers were selected to represent the United States in the Olympic canoeing competition at Berlin, Aug. 7 and 8, by the American Olympic canoeing committee at its final session last night at the Paramount Hotel.

For the second time in three years drought has gripped the Western States. Over a wide area between the Rockies and the Appalachians rainfall during the past two months has been even less than in 1934, when the United States suffered from the worst drought ever recorded in its history.

Barney Balaban of Chicago, president of the Balaban Katz Corporation, theatre-chain subsidiary of Paramount Pictures, Inc., was elected president of the latter company yesterday, succeeding John E. Otterson.

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- None of the unions comprising the Committee for Industrial Organization, cited to answer a charge of seeking to build a rival federation, will appear before the executive council of the American Federation of Labor next week, it was indicated today after a meeting of the C.I.O.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., July 2. -- The trial of the suit involving the will of Colonel Henry H. Rogers, wealthy oil man, ended here today in a maze of contradictory testimony in the Suffolk County Surrogate's Court.

Joseph Curran, a seaman, formerly of the crew of the Panama Pacific liner California, brought suit yesterday for $200,000 in the Supreme Court against the International Mercantile Marine Company, charging that he had been libeled by statements issued by the company to its agents and published as advertisements in New York newspapers.

LONDON, July 2. -- Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin disappointed his political enemies and confounded prophets when he returned to London today after three days of rest at Chequers, despite predictions that he was physically unfit to continue to head the government.

Large gains in deposits and total assets continued to be reported by local banks and trust companies yesterday as additional statements of condition as of June 30 were made public. Although as yet no calls for statements have been issued by the Controller of the Currency and the State Superintendent of Banks, local and out-of-town institutions have come forward with more than usual promptness to report.

The Italian Superpower Corporation (Delaware) reported yesterday for the first quarter of 1936 a net loss of $166,322 after income taxes, loss on foreign exchange, debenture interest and other charges. For the year ended on March 31 the net loss was $907,068, including $80,283 profit on debentures retired and deducting $1,360,944 loss on sales of securities.

Performing like a master magician who keeps his audience in suspense right up to the very last moment before he converts the egg into a grand piano, Marse Joe McCarthy dug deep in his bag of tricks yesterday to prove once more the astounding versatility of his very astonishing Yankee ball club.

CHICAGO, July 2 (AP). -- Before Charles MacArthur wrote plays that made him famous, he spent one phase of his life "lying on the beach" at Los Angeles "getting healthy" while his first wife worked to pay the bills, she testified today in her $100,000 alienation of affections suit against the actress, Helen Hayes.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 2. -Mr. and Mrs. Lucien Hamilton Tyng are planning the building of a new home along Colonial lines of architecture on the site of Middunes, their beach house on the ocean at Flying Point. Construction on their new residence will start early next week.

PLATTSBURG BARRACKS, N.Y., July 3. -- The provisional citizen's military training camp regiment completed its first day in camp here today, and a drenching rain added to the trials of the youthful candidates, many of whom are unaccustomed to roughing it in the open air.

HEIDELBERG, Germany, July 3. -- The formal announcement to the world in Heidelberg early this week that German science must be National Socialist science and not a search for "truth for truth's sake" is producing practical results already.

The John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company has sold to an investor the 104-family Benjamin Franklin house in Broadpark Way, White plains. The structure, said to be the largest apartment unit in White Plains, was sold for cash above a $450,000 first mortgage for ten years, at 4 to 4 1/2 per cent, held by the insurance firm.
PRAGUE, July 3. -- The most definite and important pronouncement made for some time on the Hapsburg restoration question appears in the Prager Presse, the Czechoslovak Foreign Office's newspaper.

At the dedication yesterday of Shenandoah National Park, President ROOSEVELT spoke with justifiable pride of the work done by the Civilian Conservation Corps. It was a sound instinct which prompted him, early in his Administration, to propose the creation of that agency and thereby to find a practicable way, as he said yesterday, "of putting "idle people to the task of ending the "waste of our land."
NEWARK, N.J., July 3. -- Newark completed its home stay tonight with a 5-to-3 victory over Syracuse before 5,000.
Architects yesterday continued the heavy filing of plans that has marked building activity in this city for the past week. Most of the projects call for tenements and one and two-family dwellings.
MADRID, July 3 (AP). -- Hatred between Rightists and Leftists flared anew in this capital tonight, leaving a total of five dead and eight wounded in the day's outbreaks.

WASHINGTON, July 3. -- A stipulation has been entered into with the Federal Trade Commission by the Bergdorf Goodman Company, Inc., 754 Fifth Avenue, New York, a member of the Uptown Creators Guild, to discontinue trade practices alleged to have a tendency to and effect of establishing a boycott in the millinery business and otherwise to restrain interstate trade in millinery.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

Receiving this correspondent one day early this week in the Presidential Palace at Havana, Dr. Miguel Mariano Gomez, newly elected President of Cuba, pledged himself to maintain a constitutional system of government, with full civil guarantees for all.
Uncle Sam decided yesterday to stop being a kind relative to 101 naturalized citizens, most of whom have returned to the "old country" after they apparently had earned a comparative fortune here.

Congoleum-Nairn, Inc., which obtained a temporary order from the United States Court of Appeals against publication by the Securities and Exchange Commission of the salaries of its executives, disclosed in its annual report to the SEC yesterday only that the aggregate compensation of twelve directors was $167,095.

The inspection of merchant ships by the Bureau of Marine Inspection and Navigation, which heretofore has been done in routine fashion with regular calls by inspectors attached to the local office of the bureau, has been broadened in recent weeks by the use of "surprise" visits.

Herbert Graf of Vienna has been engaged by the Metropolitan Opera as one of its stage directors for next season, according to a cable received from him yesterday by his American agent and confirmed last night in a message to THE NEW YORK TIMES from Edward Ziegler, assistant general manager of the Metropolitan, who is in Winchendon, Mass.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 3. -- Outstanding among the Westchester Fourth of July celebrations tomorrow will be ceremonies at Hastingson-Hudson in observance of the 135th anniversary of the birth of Admiral Farragut.

Improved subway and elevated service on Interborough lines in the Bronx during non-rush hours were ordered yesterday by the Transit Commission, to become effective Sept. 14. The order was issued after public hearings on complaints filed with the commission by civic organizations and individuals.

CHICAGO, July 3 (AP). -- The White Sox defeated the Indians, 6 -- 5, today to pull the Red Sox back into the American League first division. With Boston idle, the defeat for the tribe gave the Red Sox a tie for fourth place.

WASHINGTON, July 3. -- Calls for the condition of all national, State member and other banks insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation as of June 30 were issued today. About 14,158 banks were involved.

I care not a whit about vague theories and generalities. They have never helped feed, clothe or house my family. What I do respect are concrete facts. It appears to me that every argument advanced against the policies of Mr. Roosevelt is of a general nature.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 3. -- Don Lash of Indiana, America's running robot of the Paavo Nurmi pattern, became the first track man to make the Olympic team today when the Hoosier won the final 10,000-meter tryout and left a block of shattered records to attest the conclusiveness of his triumph.

MOSCOW, July 3 (AP). -- The Soviet Government presented tonight an official demand to Japan to call a halt to poaching by Japanese fishing vessels in Soviet waters off the Kamchatka peninsula in Far Eastern Siberia.

In a message to employes of the United States Steel Corporation, William A. Irvin, president, said yesterday that the plan of employe representation adopted in the company's plants three years ago was the "fairest method of collective bargaining that the employes and the management have been able to devise."

Lumber production was higher last week and the adjusted index, which is a component of THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity, advanced to 83.1 from 82.8 in the previous week. It stood at 54.6 for the week ended June 29, 1935.

Stocks closed generally higher yesterday in trading that again slightly exceeded 1,000,000 shares on the Stock Exchange. The motor and utility issues assumed leadership; the steel stocks recovered part of their recent losses, and the farm-equipment and mail-order issues, part of the setbacks of the day before.

BERLIN, July 3. -- Prices on the Boerse were firm today without much activity in the market. Interest centered on little-known specialties. Heavy industrials showed some strength; Harpener, after falling yesterday, regained 2 1/4 points. Machines were firm, Berliner Maschinen gaining 1 1/2 points.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 3. -- A transfer tax appraisal filed here with Surrogate Leone D. Howell today shows that a gross estate of $1,335,050.40 was left by Ray A. Graham, automobile executive when he died at Chatham, Ont., on Aug. 13, 1932. Deductions of $1,245,781.18 were allowed, leaving a net estate of $89,269.22.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., July 3. -- More than 2,000 persons attended the Independence Day jamboree tonight at Land's End, the country place of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Dow Gibson at Fox Point, for the benefit of the Lenox Hill Settlement House in New York.

JONES BEACH, L.I., July 3. -- The stage on Zach's Bay here tonight was the background for a colorful procession of dances by the Fokine Ballet, an ensemble of seventy-five dancers. An enthusiastic audience of 6,000 persons watched the performance from the Jones Beach Stadium on the shore.
A harbor for transatlantic liners at the doorstep of the World's Fair site in the Flushing Meadows, Queens, is being planned by the Fair corporation, it was announced yesterday.
Although the official calls were not issued until yesterday, most local banking institutions already have published their reports as of June 30. Additional statements issued yesterday follow:

HOT SPRINGS, Va., July 3. -- The Tobacco Association's opening market dates were announced at this morning's meeting as follows: Georgia, Aug. 4; South Carolina belt, Aug. 13; Eastern North Carolina belt, Sept. 1; middle belt, Sept. 22; old belt, Oct. 5.

A gambling house at 134 West Sixty-fifth Street, said to net its Japanese owners $5,000 weekly, was raided last night for the second time in two days by police under Inspector Louis Rosenfeld, and twenty-nine men were arrested. The four-story brownstone building, near Broadway, is near a populous Filipino district.

I'm really sorry for the poor experts because of their incorrect guesses on the outcome of the Schmeling-Louis battle. They were subjected to mob psychology and went along on the wave. Experts, so called, should be above the motley throng, but sometimes they are carried along with it.

BIG MEADOWS, SHENANDOAH NATIONAL PARK, Va., July 3. -- Standing on this plateau atop the Blue Ridge Mountain chain, President Roosevelt today dedicated the newest of the national parks as an example "of our great program of husbandry -- the joint husbandry of our human resources and our national resources."

Despite the decline in retail distribution in the districts affected by the drought, the general trend of business was upward this week, with some divisions making the best showing in more than a month, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

For the first five months of this year the 140 Class I railroads in the United States had a net operating income of $187,931,355, compared with $160,673,752 in the corresponding period last year, according to the Bureau of Railway Economics of the Association of American Railroads.

NICE, France, July 3. -- Emma Goldman, Anarchist writer, asked this correspondent today to deny reports published in the United States that she was present in the room when Alexander Berkman, long her associate in the United States, shot and killed himself Sunday.

On the ground that Abraham Aronstein, a lawyer, who was admitted to the bar in 1911, offered false testimony in explanation of a charge that he received $250 from client to settle a suit and then converted the money to his own use, the Appellate Division disbarred him yesterday.
It's always open season on fishing yarns, so George P. Buckley of Montpelier jumps off the deep end with one about a greedy great northern pike of Lake Dunmore in Vermont.

Mayor La Guardia put in his first real day yesterday at the Summer City Hall in Pelham Bay Park, but in view of the holiday week-end he called a halt early in the afternoon and left in his automobile for his Summer home in Westport, not to return until Monday.

WASHINGTON, July 3. -- A national speed limit of forty-five miles an hour for buses and trucks operating as common or contract carriers in interstate commerce was proposed in a set of safety regulations for these vehicles issued today for "comments and criticism" by the Bureau of Motor Carriers of the Interstate Commerce Commission.
JERUSALEM, July 3 (AP). -- All Arabic newspapers in Palestine were under suspension today by the government.

The Devoe Raynolds Company, Inc., and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the six months ended on May 31 a profit of $239,458 after expenses, depreciation and other charges but before Federal income and excess profits taxes, an increase of $37,872 over the profit in the first six months of 1935, amounting to $201,585.

Mussolini and Italy have, so far, triumphantly defeated Great Britain, France and the League of Nations.
