This is because of America's policy of selfish isolation and her supplying Italy with petroleum with which to conquer Ethiopia, and because of the duplicity and folly of Mr. Laval and the French Government in their impossible policy of trying to run with the hare and hunt with the hounds.

Application by the Callahan Zinc-Lead Company to the New York Stock Exchange to list 747,518 additional shares of $1-par common stock, announced yesterday, was made with the expectation that new capital and management will be contributed to the company by Frank Eichelberger, who resigned this week as vice president and general manager of the Sunshine Mining Company.

A Harlem Hospital ambulance will two doctors, a driver and a patient, overturned at 9:10 o'clock last night at Thirty-eighth Street and Madison Avenue, after being in collision with one automobile and caroming off another.

The annual report of the American and Foreign Power Company for 1935, issued yesterday, showed an income of $3,591,350 before exchange adjustments. For 1934 the income was $2,133,465 after all expenses, reserves, underlying dividends and minority interest, taxes and charges.
HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, July 3. -- Three American schoolboy eights competing for the Thames Challenge Cup again rowed to victory in the Henley regatta today, entering the semi-finals.

WASHINGTON, July 3. -- Eugene L. Vidal, director of the Bureau of Air Commerce of the Department of Commerce, is criticized in a report drafted for the Senate Air Safety Committee by Colonel Harold E. Hartney, chief investigator.

The efforts of 14-year-old Jimmy Williams to find a suitable home for his family and pets received a temporary setback yesterday. But Jimmy was consoled by James N. MacLean, chairman of the Municipal Committee for the Relief of Home Owners, who said he would continue to search for suitable quarters for the family.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:
WIMBLEDON, England, July 3 (AP). -- Baron Gottfried von Cramm could offer only feeble opposition today as Fred Perry won his third straight All-England championship.
ATLANTIC CITY, July 3. -- Industrial production organizations have become too powerful for individualism to survive, it was said here today by Stanley Reed, United States Solicitor General.

Without going so far as to call all persons who feed pigeons in the city streets "morons," I for one heartily agree with Magistrate Burke that pigeons in the heart of the city are a pest, and neither need nor deserve encouragement.

WASHINGTON, July 3. -- Destitute farmers in the drought-stricken areas of the Dakotas, Wyoming, Montana and other States in which the situation has attained grave proportions will be paid by the government for carrying forward work, under the direction of the Soil Conservation Service, to lessen the disastrous effects of future droughts such as that of 1934 and the present one.
WIMBLEDON, England, July 3 -- Something was wrong with Baron Gottfried von Cramm today, but what?

SEATTLE, Wash., July 3 (AP). --Representative Marion A. Zioncheck came home in solemn mood today, announced "the show's over" and intimated he might leave the field of eighteen aspirants to his job to themselves -- while he runs for Governor.

Commodity futures continued firm in active pre-holiday trading on the local markets yesterday, with hides a weak exception. On the cash markets, rubber sold at a new high price, and gains appeared in printcloths, butter, eggs, Santos coffee, tins and silk, while declines were made in cotton, rye, oats, lard, antimony and cocoa.

Martha Vichnes, 15-year-old Brooklyn schoolgirl who took $400 of her father's bonus money ten days ago so that she could see Hollywood, ended her trek in a freight elevator of the Grand Central station at 8:40 yesterday morning. Within the next two hours Joseph Vichnes learned the manner in which his "nest egg" had been dissipated.

All business in financial centers throughout the United States will be suspended today in observance of Independence Day. The banks as well as the markets generally will be closed. A few brokerage houses will have skeleton staffs on hand for transactions in connection with Canadian and European commodity markets, which will function as usual.

United States Government long-term bonds responded to a broad demand yesterday with gains ranging from 1-32 to 5-32 point. On a turnover of $1,350,600, good buying was evident both in the direct and guaranteed obligations, although there was little in the way of outside influences to direct the movement in those securities.

This evening will take a heavy toll of Broadway's few remaining attractions, no less than five scurrying away after their final curtains to regions remote and otherwise. Two of those departing are Theatre Guild "hits," two are WPA productions and the fifth is the second oldest attraction on the local boards. They are:

WESTPORT, Conn., July 3. -- Honey Blossom, bay mare of fifteen hands, owned and shown by Gerard S. Smith of Brooklyn, today captured the first championship event of the thirteenth annual horse show of the Fairfield County Hunt Club, scoring among the polo mounts.
QUEBEC, Que., July 3. -- President Roosevelt will visit the Governor General here July 31, it was announced today.

MOSCOW, July 3. -- The Turkish project for a new Dardanelles treaty has caused surprise and irritation here, although the Soviet supported the Turkish demand for refortification of the Straits when it was first voiced.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., July 3. -- A parade in which all ten towns in the county will be represented will mark the official opening here tomorrow of Suffolk County's celebration of the Long Island Tercentenary. Herbert F. Austin of Patchogue is chairman of the parade committee.

May I register a protest about the shabby treatment of Joe Louis by the press recently? I didn't see the fight, not even in motion pictures, but it seems rather difficult to believe that Schmeling could have made such a victim of Joe as the writer described.

Retail trade in the metropolitan area continued notably brisk during the week. Department stores were estimated as showing increases ranging around 15 per cent for the week over the comparative 1935 period. Volume on Wednesday was particularly heavy, as many shoppers completed their pre-holiday purchasing.

DENVER, July 3 (AP). -- The national balloon race got under way here late tonight under ideal weather conditions which followed a brief wind flurry that ripped a hole in the Detroit entry, eliminating it and cutting the field to five balloons.

The government's first prosecution here of defendants accused of violating a section of the National Banking Law which permits imposition of the death penalty upon those convicted resulted yesterday in the sentencing of four youths to terms of from ten to fifteen years each in prison.
Sale of a tall loft building in the Pennsylvania Station section featured real estate trading in Manhattan yesterday.

LONDON, July 3 (Canadian Press). -- Nottinghamshire regained its position at the head of the English County cricket table today when the County triumphed over Hampshire by an innings and 47 runs. Occupant of the No. 2 position for a week, Kent slid down to the third rung with a first-innings decision over Sussex.
CHICAGO, July 3 (AP). -- Hopes for drooping crops revived in many seared areas of the drought belt tonight with a Weather Bureau prediction of more and wider scattered showers.

CLEVELAND, July 3 (AP). -- Vic Fleming, prominent handler of pacers from Syracuse, N. Y., recorded today the first double of the inaugural Grand Circuit meeting when he captured the $1,350 Matron 3-year-old pace with Erla and the $1,000 Randall 2:18 pace with Dillon Hall.

Mr. BALDWIN once attributed to himself "a certain obstinacy" inherited from his Quaker forefathers on the paternal side. His Conservative ill-wishers may feel that he is showing it by his refusal to resign on account of his health. The poor man sadly needs a rest. Why won't he be nursed and coddled?

The injunction granted by Supreme Court Justice Cotillo restraining the State Commissioner of Agriculture and Markets from putting into effect a regulation directing retailers to charge one cent a quart more for milk sold in paper containers than for that dispensed in bottles was reversed by the Appellate Division yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, July 3 (AP). -- Roxie Lawson, Tiger hurler, had four shaky innings today but he pulled through, aided by heavy hitting by his mates, and the Browns were subdued, 9 to 5, for Detroit's seventh straight triumph.

ITHACA, July 3. -- Discovery within the hearts of atoms of three distinct types of cosmic forces, different from electricity, magnetism, gravitation or any other force known in nature, and much more powerful than any of them, was reported here today before the symposium on nuclear physics at Cornell University by Professor H.A. Bethe, Cornell physicist.

GENEVA, July 3. -- Sweden's white-haired woman delegate, Miss Kirstin Hesselgren, first representative of her sex to address the League of Nations Assembly as a delegate, voiced today what she called the anguish of the women of all nations over the menace of war.
GLEN COVE, L.I., July 3. -- The semi-final pairings in the invitation tennis tournament of the Nassau Country Club were completed today when Frank Bowden took his allotted bracket.
BIG MEADOWS, Va., July 3. -Following is the text of the address delivered today by President Roosevelt at the dedication of Shenandoah National Park:
PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 3. -- The "night before" ball at the Pittsfield Country Club tonight brought out 200 members and guests. More than a hundred were at a "Dutch treat" dinner at the club.

The South and East successfully staved off the Western threat for the Eastern intercollegiate tennis singles championship, as Gardnar Mulloy of Miami and George Dunn of Pennsylvania won through to the final round on the grass courts of the Richmond County Country Club at Dongan Hills, S.I., yesterday.
CHICAGO, July 3. -- Discovery, handicap champion of the American turf, goes gunning for his second successive triumph in the $10,000 added Stars and Stripes Handicap at Arlington Park tomorrow.

Lieut. Col. Brehon Burke Somervell, United States Army engineer in charge of the Florida ship canal, will succeed Victor F. Ridder as local WPA administrator on Aug. 1, it was announced here yesterday by Harry L. Hopkins, Federal WPA Administrator.

Newspaper advertising, particularly in the metropolitan area, is credited with increasing the resort business in this State, New Jersey and New England, to such proportions that this Summer is expected to be the biggest since 1929. Newspaper advertising has expanded considerably this year, with some of the hotels that had done little or no advertising in former years finding it both necessary and beneficial, reports yesterday indicated.

PARIS, July 3 (AP). -- The Chamber of Deputies turned its attention today to French agricultural legislation at home while the police halted slashes between farm hands and their employers in the vineyard district near Laon. One person was injured in the fighting.
CHICAGO, July 3. -- Helen Hayes, star of stage and screen, emerged a victorious heroine tonight in a real-life drama that cast her as defendant in her first court role off the stage.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 3. -The dinner dance at the Devon Yacht Club tonight, celebrating the twenty-fifth anniversary of the club's founding, was a gala affair.

PHILADELPHIA, July 3. -- With a bullet wound in the head, Colonel Thomas F. Meehan, president of the chemical manufacturing concern of James Good, Inc., and wartime chief of staff of the Seventy-eighth Division, was found dead today on his estate near Norristown.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals $12,807,971, to be represented by fifty municipalities. This compares with the revised total of only $8,448,427 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $23,407,190.

The Colony Club and other opponents of the erection of a theatre at the northeast corner of Madison Avenue and Sixty-second Street were accused yesterday by Supreme Court Justice John F. Carew of resting their objections "entirely, absolutely and solely on a dog-in-the-manger, selfish spirit."

A Pyrrhic victory for the stars is reported from the Warner studios, to which Ann Dvorak has just returned after winning her contract case -- the trial of which has kept her from the studio since the early part of the year. Miss Dvorak has been restored to the salary list and will be cast in "The Green Light," with Errol Flynn and Anita Louise.

With the nation's principal systems of transportation taxed with record loads of traffic, the 160th anniversary of Independence Day will be celebrated today throughout the United States, in her Territories, dependencies, in military stations and consulates around the world.

LAKEHURST, N.J., July 3. -With lightning flashing on the horizon, the Zeppelin Hindenburg rose into the air here tonight from the Naval Air Station at 10:44 P.M. at the order "up ship" from Captain Ernst Lehmann on her bridge.

A chase under Broadway along the I.R.T. subway tracks, during which detectives fired several shots at three fugitives and finally captured one after the latter's pistol had jammed, was disclosed yesterday when the prisoner appeared in the police line-up.

CHICAGO, July 3 (AP). -- Three rivals of long standing won places on the United State's three-meter springboard Olympic diving team and competition in the water polo advanced to the semi-finals inOlympic trials at Burnham Park lagoon today.

WALPOLE, Mass., July 3. -- Representatives of many Eastern colleges attended the funeral at his home here today of George A. Plimpton, head of Ginn Co., publishers, and a well-known book collector, who died here on Wednesday at the age of 80.

Union services for the Park Slope Protestant Churches will start tomorrow morning at the Park Slope Congregational Church, Eighth Avenue and Second Street, Brooklyn. The preacher will be the Rev. J. Elmer Frazee of Mount Vernon, formerly assistant at Plymouth Church of the Pilgrims, Brooklyn. The topic of discourses at Roman Catholic churches will be "Christ the Redeemer."

The Gregorian calendar has conspired with the night club and resort bonifaces to make the weekend a memorable affair, the former by locating the Fourth of July where it is and the latter by providing entertainment commensurate with the honor due the day.

The charge has been made and undoubtedly will be made throughout the campaign that the Roosevelt administration has been guilty of disregard of the Constitution, by passing numerous laws which have been found by the Supreme Court to be in violation of the Constitution.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., July 3. -Twelve old Yale buildings, taxed by the city of New Haven at $108,275, will be torn down this Summer in the interest of economy, although it was stated at the office of the university tonight that the object of their removal was not primarily to remove them from the tax list.

The chance of State Senator George R. Fearon of Syracuse getting the Republican nomination has been increased by Governor Lehman's decision to run for re-election on the Democratic ticket, local Republican leaders said yesterday.

Total market value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange rose $913,665,765 last month, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange. Average price a share of all listed stocks on July 1 was $38, compared with $37.35 at the beginning of June.

CHICAGO, July 3. -- Federal Judge William H. Holly today approved a compromise settlement between creditors of the Rosenbaum Grain Corporation and members of the Rosenbaum family, under which the latter will relinquish their stock holdings in the company and withdraw from the reorganization proceedings.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 3. -- The end of the trail for all but one crew rests here on the quiet surface of Princeton's Carnegie Lake. Early tomorrow evening and late on Sunday afternoon the nine men will be to carry the hopes of the United States into the eight-oared rowing event at the Olympic Games in Berlin will be selected.

WASHINGTON, July 3. -- Exports increased to every major geographical division in May, and imports increased from all but South America and Oceania, the Department of Commerce announced today. Total exports for the month were valued at $200,666,000, compared with $165,459,000 in May, 1935, and imports were $191,110,000 and $170,533,000, respectively.

WASHINGTON, July 3. -- Sales of equity securities by officers, directors and principal stockholders of corporations continued the predominant feature of reports made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission for May, and supplemental reports for some of the earlier months, although there were considerable acquisitions in the securities of a few companies.

CHICAGO, July 3 (AP). -- An offer to assist police efforts to solve the killing of Mrs. Florence Thompson Castle, 24, tavern hostess, came today in a letter from her brother, Fred F. Wicks of 49 Van Wangenen Street, Jersey City.
An attack on President Roosevelt and the Democratic platform is made by The Brooklyn Tablet, weekly newspaper published by the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn, in its issue today.

CHICAGO, July 3. -- Hogs weighing 275 pounds and under advanced 10 to 15 cents a hundredweight here today to a new high level since Feb. 28, sales being made up to $11.10, or 15 cents above the top on Thursday. Heavy kinds were slow sale, with prices steady to as much as 25 cents lower, while packing sows were off 10 to 25 cents.

Dr. HJALMAR SCHACHT is adding to his already formidable reputation as financier, economist and liquidator of foreign creditors. The article by GEORGE WELLER in last Thursday's NEW YORK TIMES about Dr. SCHACHT'S sales triumph in Greece illustrates also his use of his masterly technique in other Balkan States.

ESTES PARK, Colorado, July 3. -- Governor Alf M. Landon smilingly described himself today as "a horse-and-buggy Governor." He did so fully aware that he was setting a note for his campaign with the remark, a note that will fit in with the type of appeal the Republican party organization expects him to make to the electorate this Fall.
WASHINGTON, July 3. -- One hundred years ago tomorrow President Andrew Jackson wrote his signature to an act of Congress creating the United States Patent Office.

Dr. Joseph Lazarus has rented eleven rooms in 875 Park Avenue for his offices and nine rooms in 1,185 Park Avenue for his residence, F. Ann Kutner, the broker, reported yesterday. Marshall S. Brown, Dean of Faculties of New York University, leased ten rooms and four baths in 755 Park Avenue through Douglas L. Elliman Co.
Investment buying of multi-family buildings formed the bulk of activity in the Bronx yesterday.

CHICAGO, July 3. -- Passing boom-time levels, deposits in banks in this city are now above the $3,000,000,000 mark for the first time in history, according to statements of the banks' condition given out today in answer to the calls by the Controller of the Currency and the State Auditor.

The gold-bloc currencies improved slightly yesterday, although dealings in the foreign exchange market were quiet under the influence of the approaching holiday. The franc rose 1/4 point to 6.63 1/8 cents, at which price it showed a net loss of 5/8 point in the week.
CAMDEN, N.J., July 3. -- Jail sentences were given to six more persons today in connection with disorders growing out of the strike at the R.C.A. Manufacturing Company's plant here.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

The Bankers Trust Company has sold to an investor the sixty-family Macroy apartment house at 404-10 State Street, Brooklyn, assessed at $140,000. The buyer paid cash above a $110,000 purchase-money mortgage. The plot is 75 by 90 feet. R.M. Dinsmore Co. were the brokers.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, July 3 (AP). -- A powerful triumvirate has entered the lists against Mrs. Magda Lupescu, whom critics characterize as King Carol's "uncrowned queen."

Veterans' bonus checks amounting to $932,200,000 had been debited against the Treasury's bank account with the Federal Reserve System up to Thursday night, indicating that veterans had cashed more than half of the $1,673,000,000 of bonds and checks to which they are entitled under the Adjusted Compensation Payment Act.
PARIS, July 3. -- Disorders in Algeria subsided today. Since the arrival here of Governor General Le Beau, who came by airplane, the Paris authorities have become reassured over the situation.

GENEVA, July 3. -- The League of Nations Assembly experienced another day of long speeches today, and again the speeches contributed very little toward deciding the important questions involved in the Italian conquest of Ethiopia. Meanwhile, representatives of the great powers, who will eventually steer the Assembly's action, were trying to settle these questions in private negotiations.

A boy later identified as Thomas Crowley Jr., 10 years old, of 38-05 Hunters Point Avenue, Long Island City, was killed about 8 o'clock last night, when he was struck by an automobile while riding his bicycle at Greenpoint Avenue and Thirty-ninth Place, Long Island City.

RYE, N.Y., July 3. -- One hundred and six craft, the top number of the season and a record for a weekday contest other than during Larchmont Race Week, were out today for the American Yacht Club regatta, the first of the three championships over the week-end holiday.

Expansion leases by various firms in Rockefeller Center were reported yesterday as follows: American Petroleum Institute, Davis Co., Gro-Flex Corporation, Marsh Products, Monsanto Chemical Company and Sperry Gyroscope Company, in RCA Building; Pierre Amouroux, Inc., in La Maison Francaise; Kay Kamen, Ltd., in RKO Building; Wildrick Miller, Inc., in International Building and Nicholas de Pasquale and Mario Lauro, in Palazzo d'Italia.

The details of the manner in which the Legion of Decency to fight for clean motion pictures was organized in the United States and the method of its operation will be made available to the hierarchy of the Roman Catholic Church throughout the world for similar drives in other countries, it was indicated here yesterday.

VIENNA, July 3 (AP). -- Advices from Bucharest indicated the opponents of Mrs. Magda Lupescu were uniting to make common cause against the woman who is accused of exerting too much influence in King Carol's court.
CHICAGO, July 3 (AP). -- A strange game of "hide and seek" tonight confronted police seeking the woman wanted for questioning in the hotel-room slaying of Miss Audrey Vallette, 31 years old.

Relatively few changes were made in the list of securities considered legal for investment by savings banks in New York State as of July 1, and announced yesterday by William R. White, Superintendent of Banks. In the corporate section the most important eliminations were of the bonds of some public utility companies, the earnings of which did not meet the requirements of the State Banking Department.
LONDON, July 3. -- For the first time in history Britain's dominions are to have a special part in crowning a British King.

WASHINGTON, July 3. -- Awards of engineering contracts totaling over $9,206,000 were announced by the War Department today. They included one of $2,799,458.30 to the Columbia Construction Company of Bonnerville, Ore., for reconstruction of the south jetty in Grays Harbor, Washington, and one of $1,058,980 to Wilbanks Pierce, Inc., of New Orleans, for construction of a North Shore levee at Lake Okeechobee, Fla. Others follow:

LOS ANGELES, July 3. -- Harry Thomas Thompson, a former navy yeoman, was convicted speedily today of selling, confidential information about the United States fleet to a Japanese secret agent, a case unprecedented in Navy and War Department history.

GENEVA, July 3. -- Tragedy in concrete form intruded itself into this gathering of the League of Nations today. It concerned directly neither the Ethiopian issue nor the League's future, but it did indicate the despair of a large section of the world's population over the failure of League bodies to act positively on any question.

One hundred and sixty years after the publication of Mr. JEFFERSON'S well-known literary effort it is still being widely read -- for one day in the year, anyhow. But how do things stand with the author himself?

WASHINGTON, July 3. -- A fairly even division of sentiment on the question of suspending the unions affiliated with the Committee for Industrial Organization, headed by John L. Lewis, was reported today among the members of the executive council of the American Federation of Labor.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, July 3. -- Bermuda's Legislative Council, the upper house of the Colonial Parliament, defeated by a vote of 4 to 3 today a motion for the second reading of the investment companies' bill, designed to enable foreign-owned investment companies to incorporate here.

With more improvements, new cameras, a dead heat, a bright sun, a fast track and a big crowd, the Empire City race meeting got under way at Yonkers yesterday with enough excitement to last most observers over the week-end. But more thrills will be supplied today when the Empire City Handicap and the Demoiselle Stakes are decided as the twin features.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 3. -- Diversion of Federal money now used for "increased militarization of youth" to the relief of unemployed youth was demanded tonight by William W. Hinckley at a mass meeting here which opened the third annual American Youth Congress.

In a succession of quick raids, following months of surveillance and investigation, police and Federal agents from the local division of the Postoffice Department arrested last night ten prisoners, two of them women, and confiscated a vanload of mailing lists, mailing paraphernalia and more than 1,000,000 genuine sweepstakes tickets.
WEST ORANGE, N.J., July 3. -- George F. Lewis Jr. of Essex Fells was virtually thrust into the New Jersey State junior golf championship today by Wilson Flohr of Canoe Brook.

HAMBURG, Germany, July 3. -Max Schmeling, who met his trainer, Max Machon, on his arrival in Cuxhaven yesterday, announced today that he is not interested in any kind of return match with Joe Louis and will refuse all bids for such a bout.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 3. -- Hanging on doggedly, even when it looked as if his chances were hopeless, Richard D. (Dick) Chapman today overcame a three-hole deficit in the last nine to defeat C.S. (Sherry) Munson, 1 up, in the thirty-six hole final of the thirty-seventh annual Connecticut State amateur championship.
I am one of the many millions of American boxing fans who picked Joe Louis to knock out Max Schmeling. I missed my guess -- so did the millions -- so did the experts.

SINCE today we celebrate our national freedom, it is appropriate that this morning's column should be devoted to a new book on freedom, Hilaire Belloc's "The Restoration of Property" (Sheed Ward, $1.50). As it happens, I agree with hardly a single one of Mr. Belloc's points, and I very much doubt that they have anything to do with freedom at all.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

While 5,286 copies of Vincent Sheean's "Sanfelice" were being sold last week, orders for 2,390 copies of his "Personal History," published more than a year ago, came to his publishers, Doubleday, Doran. Mr. Sheean has gone to the west of Ireland to fish in currachs in the Atlantic by night.

CHICAGO, July 3. -- John D.M. Hamilton, Republican National Chairman, said today that the "surge to the Republican party" was growing so rapidly that he believed "President Roosevelt in November is going to take the same kind of licking Smith did in 1928 and Hoover did in 1932."

DETROIT, July 3. -- In today's issue of Social Justice, published by the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, he hotly attacked the Democratic platform. An editor's note stated that Father Coughlin's inspection of the platform "shatters this brittle structure of glass promises into a thousand slivers of worthless political debris."
PEIPING, July 3 (AP). -- A storm of Japanese disapproval today greeted a British consular court's decision denying implication of two British soldiers in the slaying of a Japanese soldier.

TRENTON, July 3. -- S.S. Kenworthy, executive secretary of the New Jersey League of Municipalities, said today criticism of the New Jersey relief situation by the American Association of Social Workers was exaggerated.

WASHINGTON, July 3. -- The Indianapolis Water Company, Indianapolis, Ind., filed a registration statement today under the Securities Act of 1933 covering $13,875,000 of first mortgage bonds, 3 1/2 per cent series, due on July 1, 1966. The proceeds, according to the applicant, would be used principally to redeem all of the company's outstanding funded debt.
BOSTON, July 3 (AP). -- Donald Christmas's Accolade shattered the Suffolk Downs track record for the mile and seventy yards to capture the Quincy Handicap, feature race today.

The twelve patrolmen accused of having paid $500 to $1,000 apiece to a professed "fixer" five years ago for promotion to the rank of sergeant were victims of a "vicious system," Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday. None of the men obtained the promotion.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 3. -- Everything is in readiness for the celebration of the Fourth of July in the Summer colony. There will be numerous entertainments and dinners. Early in the day the annual meeting and bake of the Newport Clambake Club is expected to draw a large gathering.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, July 3. -- Following a series of interviews today by leading politicians with King Boris and an animated Cabinet council, it has become fairly certain that a government of reconstruction will be carried through tomorrow.

BOSTON, July 3 (AP). -- Frank D. Comerford, chairman of the New England Power Association, said today a preliminary report for the five months ended May 31 showed increases in both gross and net earnings, despite rate reductions and flood damage.

Many of the largest corporations of the country are drawing from WPA rolls skilled and technical workers with whom they are completely satisfied, it was asserted by Victor F. Ridder, local WPA administrator, in an address broadcast last night over WINS.
Well, well, well!
TOKYO, July 3. -- The Cabinet today commenced examination of plans for the administrative renovation and reform pledged when it was appointed amid emotions evoked by the February revolt.

Seeking a way in which his country may further her development along the lines of American practice, L. Kanarkaris Roufos, former Foreign Minister of Greece, has just arrived in New York. He will visit members of the State Department at Washington, he said yesterday, and talk with bankers and industrialists during his stay in the United States.

Two conceptions which are really the same conception and which, though not new, are newly felt, characterize America on the one hundred and sixtieth anniversary of the birth of the Republic. Under the claptrap and static and canned speeches of both political conventions one note was clear.

Bank exchanges at the principal clearing houses of the country in June totaled $28,509,245,874, an increase of 15.8 per cent over the preceding month and of 17.1 per cent over June, 1935. For a June it was the largest turnover since 1931.

Disregarding practical Brooklyn politics, District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan moved swiftly yesterday to meet charges against him by announcing a plan to appoint a new, non-political staff of assistants.

After yielding about 10 points in the early trading yesterday as a result of additional generous gains in various parts of the Cotton Belt, prices on the Cotton Exchange turned upward and ended with net gains of 1 to 5 points in new crop positions and a loss of 2 points on the July.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 3. -- Smoke and flame at an 8,000 foot altitude forced down Miss Jacqueline Cochran, formerly of New York, one of America's leading fliers, as she headed late today for Columbus, Ohio, in a costly airplane, in which Howard Hughes, movie director, set several records recently.

LONDON, July 3. -- Britain's vast expenditure on rearmament is bound to create a budget deficit by next year, Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, warned the House of Commons today during a debate in which last April's budget passed its third reading.

New bond financing this week amounted to $80,996,000, of which industrial borrowing accounted for $71,500,000. This compares with $178,559,955 in new bonds put onto the market last week and with $125,151,000 a year ago this week.

A charge of simple assault was made yesterday against four detectives who arrested Benjamin Philip Kaplan for creating a disturbance at the graduation exercises in James Monroe High School in the Bronx on June 25. The complaint was drawn up before Magistrate Alfred Lindau in Bronx magistrate's court after a witness said he had seen the detectives beat Kaplan while taking him from the school auditorium.

PHILADELPHIA, July 3. -- University of Washington oarsmen are still winning crew races. In the national championship and Olympic tryouts for four-oared crews with coxswain, the Huskies rowed to victory in the qualifying trials over the Schuylkill River course today.

WASHINGTON, July 3. -- What may be the first of a series of surveys by business men of foreign market possibilities for American products was announced here today by S.C. Lamport, president of the Lamport Manufacturing Supply Company of New York.

WASHINGTON, July 3. -- What may be the first of a series of surveys by business men of foreign market possibilities for American products was announced here today by S.C. Lamport, president of the Lamport Manufacturing Supply Company of New York.

There is an exhibit at the Newark Museum which seems to disagree with the article in THE TIMES about white moths and tent caterpillars. According to this exhibit, the white moths now in flight about our streets are not the moths of the so-called tent caterpillar but are the adults of the measuring worm of the family Geometridae.

In reference to the letter from A.B. Laid on "Amateur Golf Control," which appeared in THE TIMES of June 20, I would like to state that he is correct when he says that no public links golfer is permitted to play in any tournament conducted by the Metropolitan Golf Association.

CITIES as well as individuals, museums as well as exhibitions have definite personalities -- something which differentiates them and which gives them each a peculiar and often a highly specialized character. Cleveland as a city harks back to its forbears.

On July 4 President Andrew Jackson signed the Act of 1836, a piece of patent legislation of unprecedented character. So this is the hundredth year of the present patent system, under which 2,045,000 patents for inventions have been granted.

MOTOR vehicle operators and the petroleum industry received fairer treatment during the 1936 legislative sessions that have adjourned since the first of the year than they have in any other recent year, according to Baird H. Markham, director of the American Petroleum Industries Committee.

DIPLOMAT as well as sailor, the new commander-in-chief of the United States Fleet who recently hoisted his four-starred flag on the battleship Pennsylvania brings to his new job an experience as varied as it is vivid.

PHILADELPHIA, July 4. -- Among social events in celebration of the Fourth in this locality were the supper party given tonight by Mr. and Mrs. Charlton Yarnall at their Summer home, Crum Creek Farm, Devon; a tennis tournament sponsored by Mr. and Mrs. William Jackson Clothier at their place, Valley Hill Farm, in Valley Forge, and a swimming party which Mr. and Mrs. Humbert Borton Powell gave at Willowdale Farm, their place in Devon.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 4. -- Never behind at any stage and with burly Earle A.S. Hopping in the stellar role, the Roslyn quartet vanquished Stephen (Laddie) Sanford's Hurricanes, 9 to 6, today in the final of the Meadow Brook Club cups handicap tourney for 20-goal teams.

WASHINGTON, July 4. -- In that strange trading post known as the Chicago wheat pit, excited traders on Thursday saw the price of this basic commodity rise the permitted limit of 5 cents a bushel and pass the $1 mark. Liverpool, sensitive world wheat barometer, saw prices rise 4 cents on the same day as black reports flashed in from the United States and Canada.

PHILADELPHIA, July 3. -- The charge this week that Philadelphia's Board of Education had "pooh poohed" allegations of Communist teachings in the public schools followed by about two months a decision to have Dr. Edwin C. Broome, Superintendent of Schools, investigate the extent of "Red" propaganda here.
BALTIMORE, July 4 (AP). -- Newark blanked the Orioles, 3 to 0, today in the second game of a double-header after losing the first, 6 to 5. A crowd of 7,500 saw the twin bill.
SANTIAGO, Chile, July 4. -- Dissolution of the Republican militia was ordered today by its commander, General Julio Schwarzenburg.

IT was a Victorian world, its young women still of the mid-Victorian type though the seeds of a new age were already sprouting, when Marion Talbot, a young Boston woman in her first thirties, went to Chicago to be dean of women in the new university that was just getting on its feet.

The resignation of Dr. Louis I. Harris, former New York City Health Commissioner, from the National Board of Motion Picture Review was revealed yesterday. In his letter Dr. Harris declared that the board was futile and was hampered because the industry paid for its activities.

BOSTON, July 4. -- Forty thousand spectators saw the Greentree Stable's Memory Book win the $15,000 added Yankee Stakes at Suffolk Downs today, smashing the track record for the mile and three-sixteenths by two and three-fifth seconds.

GREAT BRITAIN has decided to continue its ban on direct advertising on the air and will completely exclude sponsored programs for at least another ten years, according to Postmaster General G.C. Tryon.

THE Triborough Bridge, described as the greatest single highway construction job in the history of the city, will be formally opened next Saturday by President Roosevelt and a group of civic leaders headed by Mayor La Guardia.

THROUGHOUT the Eastern United States, reports from plant disease experts and commercial arborists indicate that the fungus disease known as "maple wilt," affecting maples and other trees and shrubs, is on the increase.

Though some weeks will pass before the Presidential campaign begins in earnest, it is already evident that the American public will hear much of the question of "free enterprise." On that issue the Republicans put great emphasis at Cleveland, borrowing from WILLIAM JENNINGS BRYAN language in which to write a strong denunciation of monopolies and trusts.

DROUGHT, in miniature form, is probably the worst enemy of any plant in a clay pot. But recent experiments have shown that it can be licked, and licked thoroughly, by using a moist pad under the pot. Moss, used in this way, has given excellent results.

With six months of substantial sales gains behind them, the furniture and rug industries tomorrow will open campaigns for Fall business convinced that they can make an even better showing in the last half of the year. Rug mills will offer new merchandise tomorrow at the regular trade opening here.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 4. -- Miss Anne Wright of East Hampton won the championship cup for the greatest number of points scored in the gymkhana held this afternoon at the Southampton Riding and Hunt Club. Miss Wright also won a leg on the silver challenge cup, donated by Allan Howard.

WASHINGTON, July 4. -- Students of American history derived considerable amusement today through the revelation that the panel in the magnificent bronze doors of the $11,500,000 Supreme Court Building depicts Chief Justice Marshall handing to Justice Story the famous Marbury vs. Madison opinion, rendered more than eight years before Mr. Story became a member of the court.

HOW would Old Bill Williams, hunter, trapper, guide, mountain man, squaw man. "Old Solitaire," dressed in greasy, ragged buckskin, his face dirty and hairy and a shaggy mane of red hair hanging over his shoulders, have felt about it if he could have known that long after his death books would be written about him, controversies rage over him, a mountain and a river be named for him?

With preliminary purchase budgets in frequent instances showing increases ranging up to 15 per cent over last year, thousands of buyers representing stores all over the country will arrive in the local merchandise markets on their early Fall buying trips beginning tomorrow.

Mayor La Guardia and Park Commissioner Robert Moses will speak at the exercises marking the dedication and opening to the public of the new Tompkinsville swimming pool at Pier 6 and Arietta Street, Staten Island, Tuesday night at 8:30 o'clock.

The automotive industry ended the first half of 1936 with an estimated output of 2,570,000 cars and trucks, or 15 per cent more than the 2,329,521 units turned out in the same period of 1935, according to Automotive Industries.

BABYLON, L.I., July 4. -- A feature of the annual Fourth of July invitation regatta of the Babylon Yacht Club which opened today and will continue tomorrow was the appearance of the Star Class boat Three Star Too of the Eastern San Francisco Bay Star fleet.

Until the Act of July 4, 1836, was signed by President JACKSON nowhere was there an institution like the United States Patent Office. For the first time in history patents were granted by qualified examiners only to original inventors -- in theory.

Cooperation with organized labor in the formation of a State Labor party but opposition to the endorsement of President Roosevelt, Governor Lehman or any other old party candidates, was the prevailing sentiment at the first State convention of the Social Democratic Federation which began a two-day session in the Labor Temple, Eighty-fourth Street and Third Avenue, yesterday.

Except as amended by the Revenue Act of 1936, which was signed by President Roosevelt on June 22, the excise taxes upon capital stock and so-called excess profits of corporations as imposed by the Revenue Act of 1935, continue in full force and effect.

NEWPORT, R.I. -- The yachting colony is looking forward to some informal brushes this week between the Rainbow and the Yankee, both of which are moored in Brenton's Cove. Their owners, Harold S. Vanderbilt and Gerald B. Lambert, are living near by on their yachts, Vara and Atlantic.

STROUDSBURG, Pa. -- The Summer season in the Pocono Mountains has got into full swing, with all of the resort houses filled to capacity over the holiday weekend and many of them booked completely for the entire season. More than 3,000 children who flocked into the county during the past week fill more than a score of boys' and girls' camps.
FILER, Idaho, July 4 (AP). -- Senator Borah, observing that both major parties have said in their platforms they will "destroy monopoly in the United States," asserted today:

PHILADELPHIA, July 4. -- Numerous patriots among the 15,000 fans who crowded into the bandbox Baker Bowl today sent firecrackers popping merrily about the ears of the distracted Dodgers, who by contrast displayed no explosive qualities whatever in subsiding before the Phillies in both ends of the double-header.

The past academic year was the most successful since 1931-32 for Hunter College undergraduates seeking part-time employment, according to Mrs. Harriet L. Loewenstein, director of the college's bureau of occupations.

WASHINGTON, July 4. -- Among the flood of bills passed in the final week of Congress was one awarding a medal to Lincoln Ellsworth for his work in the Antarctic. The bill includes the first official recognition of the vast area claimed there for the United States.

All good people in Mrs. Hill's wholesome stories have a full share of trials and tribulations. But once they decide to put their trust in the Lord, they come through in fine style. And the wicked, though they may flourish like the green bay tree for a time, eventually get their come-uppance.

NOVELTY will not be an essential element in the programs arranged for the seventy-seventh annual Worcester Festival, to be held Oct. 5-10 in Worcester, Mass. Excepting the first three parts of Ernest Bloch's "Sacred Service" and William Grant Still's "Afro-American" symphony, the offerings will be almost entirely made up of works well-known through frequent performance.

The fifteen largest banks in this city, including J.P. Morgan Co., reported an aggregate increase of $665,051,000 in deposits in the last quarter year, or 6.1 per cent, and an aggregate gain of $689,807,000 in total assets, or 5.5 per cent, according to their statements of condition on June 30, published last week.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 4. -- The largest number of scholarships allotted in a single academic year by the New Jersey College for Women has just been awarded for 1936-37. Names of 280 scholarship winners were announced today by Miss Fredericka Belknap, director of the personnel bureau and secretary of the scholarship committee.

Praise of President Roosevelt by Attorney General Homer S. Cummings and Senator Robert F. Wagner and covert criticism of the New Deal by Senator Royal S. Copeland featured the Independence Day celebration of the Society of Tammany or Columbian Order yesterday.
PATCHOGUE, L.I., July 4. -- Under a Summer sky swept clear of clouds by a cooling southwest breeze, the opening of the Long Island Tercentenary celebration in Suffolk County took place here today.

JOHANNESBURG, Union of South Africa. -- A serious problem is facing this city and other Reef towns as the result of the accelerated influx of destitute families from the floral areas. Social workers are perturbed at the apparent impossibility of stopping this great trek of poverty-stricken and industrially unskilled people, who have no possible hope of survival at a decent standard of living in the urban areas.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 4. -- President Roosevelt, in an Independence Day address delivered on the lawn of Monticello, called for a renewed development of the spirit of youth which enabled Thomas Jefferson 160 years ago, at 33 years of age, to write the Declaration of Independence.

NEWARK, N.J., July 4. -- A record-breaking mile in 2:09 by Mr. Watt, fleet 2-year-old trotter from the Newbrook Stables, featured the holiday matinee of the Road Horse Association of New Jersey at Weequahic Park today.

WHATEVER the outcome of this year's Presidential campaign it will probably not shake the poise of a certain lady who is one of Franklin D. Roosevelt's most ardent admirers, and who has herself made no small contribution to history during the past three years.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., July 4. -- Attacking what he called the "vampire bureaucracy" in Washington, Senator Vandenberg opened the Republican campaign in Michigan today with an appeal to "traditional Democrats" to join with Republicans in fighting a common enemy, the "Roosevelt party."

LESTER COHEN, born and brought up in Chicago, is the author of "Sweepings," a novel which was a best seller. He spent some time in Hollywood learning how to make motion pictures, but this gave him little knowledge "of the millions of people of this earth, living in the many countries, languishing or flourishing in the different cultures, civilizations, economic systerns."

In this story of the lop-eared, little blue horse, known to cattlemen as the best horse from the Rio Grande to the Canadian border, is condensed a panorama of life in the old cow country as it was really lived. Artlessly written, with less regard for grammar and consistency of plot, than for color and accuracy, the narrative is, nevertheless, bound to capture the imagination of man and boy.

The Coast Guard cutter that conveys customs and immigration officials to Quarantine to board incoming passenger ships will leave the Battery tomorrow at 5:45 A.M. to meet the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary, which is scheduled to dock at Pier 90, North River, at 7:30 A.M.

JUDGING from the size of the Summer's exodus to Europe, bon voyage presents must be a major concern to stay-at-home friends of travelers. Those who are obliged to send gifts to voyager after voyager may let the entire job, like a contract, to a shop in town that puts up simple and tastefully decorated bon voyage packages stocked according to the individual taste of the recipient.

GILBERT'S gentle observation that every child is born "either a little liberal or a little conservative" sounds the keynote of our bipartisan system. No matter what names the standard bearers adopt, it is always the same two fundamental principles that are in conflict.

AWAY back in early April, when snow water still raced through swollen brooks, the trout fisherman tossed his waders into the car and set out for his first week-end in the Catskills. But the trout fisherman has had his day, and now it is the metropolitan angler's turn.

ABOARD GOVERNOR LANDON'S TRAIN, LIMON, Col., July 4. -- Governor Landon was headed eastward tonight to his home State of Kansas, prepared to resume again the dual role of Governor and Presidential nominee, after a ten-day vacation in the heart of Colorado's Rockies.
GENEVA, July 4. -- Danzig's dynamite was flung provocatively on the table of the League of Nations Council tonight within an hour after the Assembly had bowed before Italy's conquest of Ethiopia.

HOT SPRINGS, Va. -- Programs have just been issued for the Warm Springs Valley Flower Show, which will be held in the Valley High School auditorium on Wednesday, July 29. For many years past, the annual show has been held in the Warm Springs Presbyterian Church, but larger quarters are now required.

SINCE during the past year, the Constitution has been resurrected from the civics textbooks and the World Almanac to become as frequent a topic of conversation as the weather, the appearance of these two books is particularly well timed.

NEW YORK CITY'S season for high-pressure education is here again, with more than 33,000 students enrolled for Summer work on half a dozen campuses. Last year Columbia University, New York University and the College of the City of New York, in that order, had the largest Summer registrations in the country.

ROME, July 3. -- With the occupation of Addis Ababa on May 5 the Italo-Ethiopian campaign came officially to an end after seven months of hostilities, and any fighting that has taken place since then partakes more of the character of police operations than real war.

THREE HUNDRED AND FOUR years of family history in exactly 304 printed pages. This must surely be both the coincidence and the stint of the week, in fiction anyway. It sounds breathtaking, but isn't. First, there is nothing breathtaking about the material, and, second, Miss Watson manages, by the grace of newsreel technique, to march her time and not gallop it.

CHICAGO, July 4. -- The details of the "refinancing" of the Farmers National Grain Corporation, which came to light this week, revealed that the Federal Government has wiped off the slate loans of $14,000,000. In addition to this, the government is advancing new credits to the corporation of some $7,500,000.

CONVINCED that more progress could be made in understanding the function of the pituitary gland if there were more of it to analyze, Dr. E.M.K. Geiling of the University of Chicago's pharmacological department has decided to turn to the whale.

LENOX, Mass., July 4. -- About 100 persons attended the Lenox Club luncheon today. Mr. and Mrs. David T. Dana had sixteen guests at their table, Mr. and Mrs. Henry Hollister Pease fourteen, Mr. and Mrs. James Dwight Francis twelve and Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Horton Lippincott ten.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 4. -- Miss Helen Stephens, the Fulton (Mo.) farm girl who is rapidly becoming a second Babe Didrikson in women's track and field circles, continued her habit of winning three events in the national championships on Brown University Field today.

A NEW attempt to reduce the number of adult illiterates in New York City will be launched this week by the Board of Education in cooperation with the Federal relief authorities, who have assigned an adequate supply of teachers and home visitors to the task.

LONDON, July 3. -- Hostesses have had a busy time fitting in their engagements during the most crowded week of the season. There have been many private and charity dances, polo at Hurlingham, tennis finals at Wimbledon and open-air performances of Shakespearean plays in Regent's Park.
CHICAGO, July 4 (AP). -- The White Sox beat Cleveland in both ends of a double-header this afternoon, 9 -- 2 and 8 -- 4, to win their third straight from the Indians in two days.
BATON ROUGE, La., July 4. -- Louisiana lobbyists considered the possibility today of having to work in green skull caps and gaudy plaid trousers and hoped the Legislature was only fooling.
RYE, N.Y., July 4. -- Many of the country, yacht and beach clubs in Westchester County featured dinner dances tonight in celebration of Independence Day.

THE American contender in the All-Nations Prize Novel Competition is "Steps Going Down," by John T. McIntyre, which will receive a $4,000 prize as the American winner in the event that it does not receive the international prize, in which case the prize will be much greater.

THE motion-picture industry, having benefited by many electrical devices developed for broadcasting, will have an opportunity to more than repay the debt to radio when television comes, according to The Radio Times, official program organ of the British Broadcasting Corporation.
